label: "Unorganized Territory,"
description: former designation for most of the area formerly in Mattamuskeet Township, central Hyde County. Owned by the federal government and used as a fish and wildlife reservation. Residents vote and list taxes in Lake Landing Township.

label: 30 Mile Post
description: marked corner on the North Carolina-Georgia state line, SE Clay County 30 mi. W of Ellicott Rock, which see. Survey completed to the corner in 1819. There the state line turns due S for 1,983 ft. to Montgomery Corner, which see.

label: Añadales Chase
description: an otherwise unidentified designation appearing on the Smith map, 1624, shown between what is now Tar and Roanoke Rivers, NW of the head of Pungo River, probably in what is now N Pitt and Martin Counties.

label: Aaron
description: See Hood Swamp.

label: Aaron Branch
description: rises in N Mitchell County and flows SE into Bean Creek.

label: Aaron Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NW into Taylor Creek.

label: Aaron Duff
description: See Iron Duff.

label: Aaron Swamp
description: rises in W Robeson County and flows S into Ashpole Swamp.

label: Aarons Corner
description: community in N Stokes County. Named for a church.

label: Aarons Creek
description: rises in NW Granville County and flows NE into Virginia, where it enters Dan River.

label: Abbot Top
description: mountain in central Cherokee County between Hiwassee River and West Prong Grape Creek.

label: Abbots Island
description: See Croatoan Island.

label: Abbott's Creek
description: rises in N Wake County and flows NE into Neuse River.

label: Abbotts Creek
description: rises in NE Davidson County and flows SW into Yadkin River. Appears as Abbots Creek on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Abbotts Creek Township
description: SE Forsyth County.

label: Abbotts Township
description: SW Bladen County.

label: Abbottsburg
description: town in SW Bladen County. Inc. 1903. Alt. approx. 99. Named for Joseph C. Abbott (1825-81), president of the Cape Fear Building Company there.

label: Abbs Creek
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows S into Caney Fork.

label: Abe Creek
description: rises in S Macon County and flows SE into West Fork Overflow Creek.

label: Abel Bay
description: SW Hyde County in the mouth of Pungo River.

label: Abel's Creek
description: rises in North River Pocosin in S Camden County and flows E into North River.

label: Abells
description: community in NE Johnston County served by post office, 1880-1900.

label: Aberdeen
description: town in S Moore County. Inc. 1893. Known originally as Blue's Crossing after settler Malcolm Blue. Renamed in 1887 by resident John Graham, who had formerly lived in Aberdeen, Miss., which in turn was named for the seaport in Scotland. Economy caters to golf and tourist industry and area military bases. Produces carpets, hosiery, textiles, furniture, and canned foods. Alt. 339.

label: Aberdeen Creek
description: rises in S Moore County and flows SW into Lumber River. Known as Devil's Gut Creek or Devils Creek until early in the twentieth century.

label: Aberly
description: community in E Onslow County.

label: Abernethy
description: community in W Iredell County.

label: Abernethy Creek
description: rises in SW Gaston County and flows NE and SE in an arc into Crowders Creek.

label: Abes Mountain
description: SW Cleveland County near Broad River. Alt. 950.

label: Abi
description: community in central Stanly County served by post office, 1894-1907.

label: Abier Creek
description: rises in SE Burke County and flows N into Henry Fork.

label: Abigails Islands
description: appear on the Smith map, 1624, as the cluster of islands in Pamlico Sound off S Hyde County between Rose Bay and Swanquarter Bay. Now Bell, Great, Judith, Marsh, and Swanquarter Islands, which see.

label: Abingdon Creek
description: rises in SW Caldwell County and flows SE into Lower Creek. Sometimes called Greasy Creek. Originally Aventon Creek for Aventon Sherrill, early settler.

label: Abner
description: community in N Montgomery County formerly known as Saunder's Hill and served by post office, 1859-98. Took Abner name in 1898. Post office by the name operated until 1953. By tradition named for local principal.

label: Abraham Bay
description: small bay in the mouth of Turn-again Bay in N Carteret County.

label: Abraham's Plains
description: former district in NE Granville County. It had 62 heads of families in 1790 at the time of the first census. Took its name from the home, built 1766, of Col. Samuel Smith, who had fought in the battle at Abraham's Plains at Quebec, Canada.

label: Abrams Branch
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows NE into French Broad River.

label: Abshers
description: community in N Wilkes County between Harris Creek and Middle Prong Roaring River.

label: Academy Crossroads
description: See Nahunta.

label: Acconeechy
description: See Hillsborough.

label: Ace Enloe Ridge
description: NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur of Hughes Ridge.

label: Acme
description: town in NE Columbus County on Livingston Creek. Known originally as Livingston for the creek. Inc. 1905 as Cronly and named for local landowner; name changed to Acme in 1911 for Acme Manufacturing Company, producer of fertilizer. Produces fertilizer and paper. Alt. 37.

label: Acorn
description: community on Jones Pond E Gates County. Sometimes also known as Acorn Hill.

label: Acorn Hill
description: See Acorn.

label: Acre
description: community in N central Beaufort County. Long Acre appears on the Collet map, 1770, as a ridge in the Dismal Swamp of NE Beaufort and S Washington Counties. It supported a post road from Plymouth to Bath. It is called Long Acre on various maps until Kerr, 1882, where it is marked "Long Acre Ridge." Long Acre community grew up at the S end of the ridge, and a post office there from 1883 to 1907 was called Acresville. By 1917 it was called Acre from the railroad name, and the ridge was no longer recorded on maps. Alt. 32.

label: Acresville
description: See Acre.

label: Acton
description: community between Enka and Sulphur Springs, central Buncombe County.

label: Ad Tate Knob
description: on Utah Mountain in central Haywood County.

label: Adair
description: community in N Gates County.

label: Adake
description: community in W Caldwell County on Wilsons Creek.

label: Adam's Store
description: community in NW Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1852-55.

label: Adams
description: community in central Watauga County.

label: Adams Branch
description: rises in N Cleveland County and flows SE into Knob Creek.

label: Adams Creek
description: rises in E Swain County and flows S between Cooper Creek and Owl Branch into Oconaluftee River.

label: Adams Crossroads
description: community in W Wake County between Brier Creek and Sycamore Creek.

label: Adams Hollow
description: in NW Swain County extends S on a tributary of Ekaneetlee Creek to Grill Cove.

label: Adams Mountain
description: W Caldwell County. Alt. 1,500.

label: Adams Point
description: point of land in E Beaufort County on Pamlico River near the mouth of Pungo River. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Adams Run
description: community in E Henderson County on Big Hungry Creek.

label: Adams Store
description: See Adamsville.

label: Adamsville
description: former community in central Wayne County on the E edge of Goldsboro. At one time known as Adams Store. Now within the corporate limits of Goldsboro.

label: Adcock Creek
description: rises in S Granville County E of Stem and flows E into Tar River. Named for Adcock family.

label: Addie
description: community in N Jackson County, on Scotts Creek. Located about 3 mi. NE of town of Sylva. Alt. 2,249.

label: Addor
description: town in S Moore County. Inc. 1881 as Keyser; named for an officer of the Raleigh and Augusta Airline Railroad. During World War I, the name became unpopular because of the similarity to "Kaiser." Name changed in October 1918 to Addor in honor of Felix Addor, local resident, who had been killed on the troopship SS Leviathan in March. Long inactive in municipal affairs. Served by post office, 1877-1918.

label: Adelaide
description: community in S Rockingham County served by post office, 1883-1905.

label: Adkin Branch
description: rises in N Lenoir County and flows SE through the city of Kinston into Neuse River. Named for Robert Atkins, who had land grants there in 1729.

label: Adkins
description: community in N Yancey County.

label: Adkins Branch
description: rises in N Buncombe County and flows NW into Madison County, where it enters Ivy River.

label: Adkins Falls
description: rapids in Cape Fear River in central Harnett County E of the town of Lillington and near the confluence of Buies Creek with the river. Mentioned as early as 1819 in a survey of the rivers of North Carolina.

label: Adlai
description: community in SE Union County served by post office, 1896-1900.

label: Adley
description: community in S Wilkes County on the S side of Yadkin River. Home of Capt. John Brown, in which the Wilkes County government was organized in March 1778, is across the river. The W. Kerr Scott Dam is there.

label: Adoniram
description: community in N Granville County served by post office, 1889-1906.

label: Advalorem Branch
description: rises in N Swain County between Jumpup Ridge and Bald Ridge and flows SE into Forney Creek.

label: Advance
description: town in E Davie County. Known as Shady Grove as early as 1816. When a post office was est. in 1877, a new name was required because there was already a Shady Grove post office in the state. Named because local citizens expected progress with the addition of a post office to the community. Inc. 1893. Alt. 810.

label: Affinity
description: See Marietta.

label: Afton
description: community in SW Warren County between Lees Branch and the head of Richneck Creek. Post office est. 1874 but discontinued in 1919.

label: Afton Run
description: stream, rises in N Cabarrus County and flows S into Coddle Creek. Also appears in early documents as Ashton Run and Astin's Run.

label: Agate
description: community in NW Hertford County served by post office, 1892-1906.

label: Aggie Run
description: is formed in NW Beaufort County by the junction of Old Ford Swamp and Snoad Branch. It flows S into Tranters Creek.

label: Agiqua
description: See French Broad River.

label: Agnela
description: community in SW Hertford County.

label: Aho
description: community in S Watauga County near the heads of Stony Branch, Moore Branch, and Buffalo Creek. It is said that a group of men gathered to select a name for the community but, being unable to agree on a name, decided that the next word spoken by any one of them would be accepted. After a long silence, B. B. Dougherty arose, stretched, and said "Aho!"

label: Ahoskie
description: town in S Hertford County. Post office as early as 1828 named Ahosky Ridge. Inc. 1893. Name of Indian origin, spelled Ahostsky and Ahostskey as early as 1719. Produces apparel, lumber, and wooden containers. Alt. 59.

label: Ahoskie Creek
description: rises in SE Northampton County and flows NE into Hertford County, where it enters Ahoskie Swamp.

label: Ahoskie Swamp
description: rises in S Hertford County and flows SE and NE into Bear Swamp. Appears as Ahotskey Swamp on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Ahoskie Township
description: S Hertford County.

label: Ahosky Ridge
description: See Ahoskie.

label: Ahostsky, Ahostskey, Ahotskey
description: See Ahoskie.

label: Ai
description: community in SE Person County served by post office, 1887-1907.

label: Aiken Branch
description: rises in NW Swain County and flows SE into Lake Cheoah.

label: Aiken Mill Creek
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows N into French Broad River.

label: Aiken Mountain
description: S Transylvania County between Aiken Creek and Carson Creek.

label: Air Bellows Gap
description: on the Alleghany-Wilkes county line. An early road across the Blue Ridge Mountains passed through the gap. Alt. 3,744.

label: Airbellows
description: former community in S Alleghany County, now an entrance to the Blue Ridge Parkway. Alt. 3,800.

label: Airlie
description: community in E New Hanover County on the N side of Bradleys Creek.

label: Akwetiyi
description: a spot on Tuckasegee River in NW Jackson County, about 1 mi. NW of town of Dillsboro, and between mouth of Dicks Creek and mouth of Laurel Branch. According to Indian tradition there was a dangerous water monster in the river. The meaning of the name is lost.

label: Alamance
description: community in W Alamance County. A post office est. there as early as 1828; cotton mill built in 1837 by E. M. Holt. Alt. 454. Post office name for many years was Allemance.

label: Alamance Battleground State Historic Site
description: W central Alamance County. Markers and a museum on the 40-acre site tell the story of the battle on May 16, 1771, in which the North Carolina militia under Gov. William Tryon defeated the Regulators.

label: Alamance Church
description: community in SE Guilford County. Second Ulster Scots Presbyterian Church in Guilford County, founded in the second half of eighteenth century.

label: Alamance County
description: was formed in 1849 from Orange County. Located in the central part of the state, it is bounded by Orange, Chatham, Randolph, Guilford, and Caswell Counties. Named for Great Alamance Creek, which see, or the Battle of Alamance, May 16, 1771. The name appears as Aramancy River in the writings of William Byrd, 1728. Area: 434 sq. mi. County seat: Graham, with an elevation of 656 ft. Townships, now numbered 1 to 13, were formerly Patterson, Coble, Boon Station, Morton, Faucette, Graham, Albright, Newlin, Thompson, Melville, Pleasant Grove, Burlington, and Haw River. Produces auto parts, tobacco, poultry, dairy and beef cattle, pecans, textiles, electronics, paper boxes, apparel, crushed stone, pyrophyllite, and bricks.

label: Alamance Creek
description: See Great Alamance Creek.

label: Alarka
description: community in S Swain County on Yalaka Creek, from which it takes its name.

label: Alarka Creek
description: See also Yalaka Creek.

label: Albans
description: community in NE Union County.

label: Albemarle
description: city and county seat in N central Stanly County. Alt. 505. Post office opened there as Smith's Store in 1826; name changed to Albemarle, 1841. Inc. 1857. Named for George Monck (1608-79), Duke of Albemarle, one of the original Lords Proprietors of Carolina in 1663.

label: Albemarle Beach
description: NW Washington County on Albemarle Sound, W of the town of Mackeys. Formerly known as Reas Beach.

label: Albemarle City Lake
description: central Stanly County on Long Creek. Formed in 1915. Covers 75 acres; max. depth 40 ft. Fishing, swimming, boating.

label: Albemarle County
description: was est. in 1664 in the NE portion of the Lords Proprietors’ new province of Carolina covering a poorly defined 1,600 sq. mi. The first governor of the county was appointed in October 1664, and it soon also had a legislature and courts. By 1668 it was divided into Chowan, Currituck, Pasquotank, and Perquimans precincts. The county ceased to exist as a unit of government in Carolina in 1689, when Governor Seth Sothel departed. The next governor had his commission for "that part of our province of Carolina that lyes north and east of Cape feare," which was basically the whole of modern North Carolina.

label: Albemarle River
description: See Albemarle Sound.

label: Albemarle Section
description: See Albemarle, The.

label: Albemarle Sound
description: NE North Carolina, separated from the Atlantic Ocean by a part of the Outer Banks. Approx. 52 mi. long and 5 to 14 mi. wide. Max. depth 25 ft. Sea level; freshwater not affected by tide. Waters from the Chowan and Roanoke Rivers enter the sound on the w; it drains into Roanoke, Croatan, and Pamlico Sounds. Explored by Ralph Lane, 1586; known as Sea of Rawnocke (Roanoke Sea) in 1609. Appears as Roanoke Sound on the Comberford map, 1657. Known briefly in 1663 as Carolina River and appears as Albemarle River on the Locke map, 1671, and the Blome map, 1672. The John Barnwell map of about 1722 was one of the first to use the name Albemarle Sound. First permanent settlements in North Carolina were made along its N shore. Named after 1663 for George Monck, Duke of Albemarle, one of the Lords Proprietors of Carolina. See also Weapemeoc.

label: Albemarle Township
description: See North Albemarle Township; South Albemarle Township.

label: Albemarle, The
description: or the Albemarle Section a term applied to NE North Carolina. It was the location of the first county, Albemarle County, which see.

label: Albert Mountain
description: S Macon County between Bearpen Gap and head of Hurricane Creek. Alt. 5,207.

label: Albertson
description: community in NE Duplin County. Earlier known as Holt's Store for Marion Holt. Post office est. there as early as 1828.

label: Albertson Township
description: NE Duplin County.

label: Alberty
description: See Fairview.

label: Albright Township
description: NW Chatham County.

label: Albrittons
description: community in W Lenoir County.

label: Alco
description: community in E Montgomery County served by post office, 1889-1915.

label: Alder Branch
description: community in S Camden County. Alt. 10. Probably named for the alder bush, which grows in profusion in the vicinity. The branch, called Cross Branch in colonial days, connects a swamp that drains into Pasquotank River to another swamp that drains into North River.

label: Alderman
description: community in S Cumberland County served by post office, 1885-1907.

label: Aldridge Creek
description: rises in SW Person County and flows SE into South Flat River.

label: Ale
description: community in SW Stokes County served by post office, 1898-1903.

label: Alert
description: community in N Franklin County. Alt. 300. Settled about 1900. Name chosen by first postmaster, Thomas D. Farrow.

label: Alex's Creek
description: See Grants Creek.

label: Alex's Cross Roads
description: See Alexis.

label: Alexander
description: town in N Buncombe County on French Broad River. Settled about 1828; inc. 1905, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Named for James Mitchell Alexander, who built and operated a stagecoach tavern there. Alt. 1,791.

label: Alexander Branch
description: rises in N Buncombe County near Lovelace Gap and flows NW into Paint Fork.

label: Alexander County
description: was formed in 1847 from Iredell, Caldwell, and Wilkes Counties. Located in the W central section of the state, it is bounded by Iredell, Catawba, Caldwell, and Wilkes Counties. It was named for William Julius Alexander (1797-1857), member of the General Assembly from Mecklenburg County and Speaker of the House of Commons. Area: 259 sq. mi. County seat: Taylorsville, with an elevation of 1,247 ft. Townships are Ellendale, Gwaltneys, Little River, Millers, Sharpes, Sugar Loaf, Taylorsville, and Wittenburg. Produces cattle, poultry, barley, apples, corn, bearings, textiles, furniture, and paper boxes.

label: Alexander Knob
description: See Jess Knob.

label: Alexander Mills
description: town in S Rutherford County. Inc. 1925. Named for textile mill est. by J. F. Alexander.

label: Alexander's Store
description: community in E Mecklenburg County also known as Lawyers and Hornet's Nest. Named for postmaster Guy Alexander.

label: Alexandriana
description: See Croft.

label: Alexis
description: town in N Gaston County. Inc. 1899, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Formerly known as Alex's Cross Roads for a man named Alexander who owned land there.

label: Alfordston
description: town authorized to be laid off and inc. 1793 on land of Thomas Matthews. Site approx. 1 mi. S of Carthage, central Moore County. The town was never laid off.

label: Alfordsville
description: community in W Robeson County. A post office operated there from 1800 to 1922.

label: Alfordsville Township
description: SW Robeson County.

label: Alfred
description: community in SE Beaufort County. Settled about 1910 and named for Fred R. Alfred, large landowner. Alt. 25.

label: Alfred Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NW into Taylor Creek.

label: Algood
description: community in S Yadkin County served by post office, 1886-1904.

label: Alkalithia Springs
description: See All Healing Springs.

label: All Healing Springs
description: See Crumpler.

label: Allan Branch
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows E into Nolichucky River.

label: Allan Creek
description: rises in N Madison County and flows SE into Little Laurel Creek.

label: Allanstand
description: community in N Madison County on Martin Creek. In the days when stock was driven to market, a drover's station or stand was operated there by a man named Allen. Since 1897 site of Allanstand Cottage Industries, handicraft shop est. by Frances Goodrich.

label: Allbone Branch
description: rises in W Clay County and flows SW into Hiwassee River.

label: Alleghany County
description: was formed in 1859 from Ashe County. In the NW part of the state, it is bounded by the state of Virginia and by Surry, Wilkes, and Ashe Counties. The name is a corruption of the Delaware Indian name for the Allegheny and Ohio Rivers and is said to have meant "a fine stream." Area: 230 sq. mi. County seat: Sparta, with an elevation of 2,939 ft. Townships are Cherry Lane, Cranberry, Gap Civil, Glade Creek, Piney Creek, Prathers Creek, and Whitehead. Produces corn, barley, apples, hay, pipes, turkeys, Christmas trees, Irish potatoes, dairy products, livestock, textiles, apparel, and crushed stone. There are manganese and granite deposits in the county.

label: Alleghany Township
description: S Davidson County.

label: Allegheny
description: community N Madison County on Shelton Laurel Creek.

label: Allegheny Mountains
description: See Appalachian Mountains.

label: Allemance
description: See Alamance.

label: Allen
description: community in NE Mecklenburg County.

label: Allen Branch
description: rises in N Macon County and flows W into Burningtown Creek.

label: Allen Creek
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows NE into Richland Creek. Named for Allen family, pioneer settlers in Haywood County, approx. 1812.

label: Allen Creek
description: rises in S Catawba County and flows NW into Maiden Creek.

label: Allen Gap
description: N Cherokee County near the head-waters of Allen Branch.

label: Allen Mountain
description: NE Buncombe County.

label: Allen's Creek
description: See Lilliput Creek.

label: Allen's Crossroads
description: community in S Granville County W of Hester Station.

label: Allen's Fall
description: See Ramseur.

label: Allendale Township
description: SE Hoke County.

label: Allens Branch
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows SE into Scott Creek.

label: Allens Creek
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows NW into Pigeon River. Named for Allen family, pioneer settlers in Haywood County, approx. 1812.

label: Allens Level
description: community in S Person County.

label: Allensville
description: community in E Person County. Formerly known as Trilby.

label: Allensville Township
description: E central Person County.

label: Allenton
description: former town in SE Stanly County on Pee Dee River. Laid off in 1-acre lots on an 85-acre tract on the lands of William and James Allen and John Davison in 1799. A post office operated there from 1813 to 1831; Allenton ferry operated there into the twentieth century. Site now under waters of Lake Tillery.

label: Allents Cove Branch
description: rises in E Transylvania County and flows N into Crab Creek.

label: Alliance
description: community in N Pamlico County, in the center of an area that produces potatoes and tobacco. Settled in the 1890s and named for the Farmers’ Alliance movement. Former railroad station there was known as West Alliance.

label: Alliby Creek
description: See Ellerbee Creek.

label: Alligator
description: farming and grazing community in NE Tyrrell County on the Big Savanna near Alligator Creek.

label: Alligator Bay
description: in S Onslow County at the E end of Stump Sound.

label: Alligator Creek
description: a tidal stream on Eagles Island in E Brunswick County. It flows S into the Cape Fear River.

label: Alligator Dismal Swamp
description: See Great Alegator Dismal Swamp.

label: Alligator Lake
description: a natural lake in N Hyde County, 3½ mi. in diameter, almost a perfect circle. Not shown on the Collet map, 1770, or the Mouzon map, 1775; a map in The Political Magazine (November 1780) shows an enlarged area at the head of Alligator River. Not until 1812, on a map published in Boston, is the lake clearly shown. Within a few years it was being labeled Alligator Lake on maps. The lake now is filled by swamp drainage; its two outlets are the New Lake Fork of Alligator River and a drainage ditch leading into Pungo River. Alligator Lake, known locally as New Lake, covers approx. 6,000 acres and is 6 to 7 ft. at its deepest.

label: Alligator Pond
description: built beside McClendon's Creek 2 mi. S of Carthage, Moore County. 1 acre.

label: Alligator River
description: rises in central Hyde County and flows E and N to the Hyde-Tyrrell county line, SE to the Dare-Tyrrell county line, and N into Albemarle Sound. In part, the Intracoastal Waterway follows the Alligator River. Appears as Layn Flu[ve] on the Smith map, 1624, undoubtedly named for Ralph Lane, governor of the first Roanoke colony. Appears as Alligator River on the Ogilby map, 1671.

label: Alligator River Bridge
description: See East Lake Landing; Sandy Point.

label: Alligator Swamp
description: rises in NW Brunswick County and flows N into Juniper Creek.

label: Alligator Township
description: NE Tyrrell County.

label: Alligoods
description: community in central Beaufort County. Alt. 37.

label: Allison
description: community in W central Caswell County. A post office operated there from 1886 to 1909.

label: Allison Creek
description: rises in S Macon County and flows NE into Cartoogechaye Creek.

label: Allman Branch
description: rises in S Madison County and flows NW into French Broad River.

label: Allman Branch
description: rises in N Buncombe County and flows NW into Madison County, where it enters French Broad River.

label: Allmon Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SE into Morris Creek.

label: Allmon Creek
description: rises in N Cherokee County in the Snowbird Mountains and flows S into Hyatt Creek.

label: Allreds
description: community in NE Montgomery County served by post office, 1880-1953. Took its name from Allred family, operators of gristmill on Little River.

label: Alma
description: See Daystrom.

label: Almond
description: community in W Swain County on Little Tennessee River. Inc. 1905, but no longer active in municipal affairs. Named for Bud Almond, donor of original town site. Alt. 1,613.

label: Almond Township
description: W Stanly County.

label: Alora
description: community in E Buncombe County served by post office, 1900-1906.

label: Alpha
description: community in N Rowan County served by post office, 1894-1904.

label: Alpine
description: community in S Sampson County served by post office, 1894-1915.

label: Alspaugh
description: community in central Forsyth County.

label: Alston
description: community in central Warren County. Post office est. there in 1903 but discontinued in 1918.

label: Altamahaw
description: community in W Alamance County on Haw River. Founded about 1860 with the establishment of a cotton gin there. Later the site of several textile mills. The community of Ossipee lies directly s. Name of Indian origin, meaning unknown.

label: Altamont
description: community in S Avery County. Name means high mountain. Thomas Wolfe adopted name for his fictitious Asheville in Look Homeward, Angel (1929).

label: Altamont Township
description: S Avery County.

label: Altan
description: community in S central Union County. Served by post office from 1890 to 1904.

label: Altapass
description: community in SE Mitchell County on Little Rose Creek. Alt. 2,623.

label: Alto
description: See Lasker.

label: Alum Knob
description: between Caney Fork and Tuckasegee River in central Jackson County.

label: Alum Ridge
description: NW Madison County parallel to Pounding Mill Branch.

label: Alum Spring
description: mineral waters in W Onslow County near Southwest Creek.

label: Aman's Store
description: See Verona.

label: Amantha
description: community on Cover Creek in W Watauga County. Settled 1870. First known as McBrides Mill for Hiram McBride, first postmaster; post office by that name, 1869-87. Name later changed to honor Amantha Combs, local resident; post office by that name, 1887-1937.

label: Amboy
description: community in N Chowan County served by post office, 1880-1904.

label: Amelia
description: community in NW Alleghany County.

label: Ames Turnout
description: See Wingate.

label: Amherst
description: See Roberson Store.

label: Amity Hill
description: community in S Iredell County.

label: Ammon
description: community in NW Bladen County.

label: Ammon Bottom
description: E Cherokee County between Elliott Branch and Piper Branch.

label: Ammon Knob
description: on the Cherokee-Clay county line in the Valley River Mountains.

label: Ammons Branch
description: rises in SE Macon County and flows SE into Chattooga River.

label: Ammons Knob
description: S Macon County between the head of Hayes Mill Creek and Nickajack Creek. Alt. 3,916.

label: Amorita
description: community in N Alleghany County served by post office, 1899-1906.

label: Amos Creek
description: rises in NE Madison County and flows SW into Spillcorn Creek.

label: Amos Mill Pond
description: See Weldons Millpond.

label: Amos Plott Balsam
description: See Waterrock Knob.

label: Amour
description: See Armour.

label: Amy
description: community in N central Ashe County.

label: Anderson
description: community in S central Caswell County, known earlier as Anderson's Store. A post office was operated there during the approx. period 1820 to 1905.

label: Anderson Branch
description: rises in S Graham County and flows NE into Tulula Creek.

label: Anderson Branch
description: rises in W Clay County and flows NW into Hiwassee River.

label: Anderson Cove
description: valley through which Shelton Branch flows in N Buncombe County.

label: Anderson Cove Branch
description: rises in W Madison County and flows NW into Puncheon Camp Branch.

label: Anderson Creek
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows NE into Burnett Creek.

label: Anderson Creek Township
description: S Harnett County.

label: Anderson Mountain
description: E Haywood County between the headwaters of Stamey Cove Branch and Sally Haines Branch.

label: Anderson Swamp Creek
description: rises in central Vance County and flows N into Kerr Lake.

label: Anderson Township
description: S central Caswell County.

label: Anderson's Mountain
description: NE Lincoln County. Also known as Little Mountain.

label: Anderson's Store
description: See Anderson.

label: Andersons Crossroads
description: community in N Halifax County.

label: Andreas Branch
description: rises in N central Swain County and flows W into Noland Creek.

label: Andrews
description: town in NE Cherokee County. Inc. 1905. First known as Valley Town, a name still applied to an adjacent community. Renamed for Alexander Boyd Andrews (1841-1915), leader in the development of the Western North Carolina Railroad. Alt. 1,825. Produces textiles and apparel.

label: Andrews Bald
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park between Forney Creek and Salola Branch. Alt. 5,860.

label: Andrews Geyser
description: SW McDowell County, in Horseshoe Bend of the Southern Railway, was constructed in the 1880s, restored in 1911 and 1975, as a tribute to Col. Alexander Boyd Andrews, builder of the Western North Carolina Railroad into Asheville. Water from a higher mountain lake about 2 mi. away is piped to the site. Natural pressure forces the water upward in a 100-ft. jet from the center of a stone fountain. Formerly passenger trains stopped there for 20 minutes to enable those interested to visit the site.

label: Andy
description: community in N Polk County on the head of Bullin Creek.

label: Andy Branch
description: rises in NW Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains and flows about 2 mi. SE to join Woody Branch, which then joins Conrad Creek in forming Little Cataloochee Creek. Named for Andy Bennett, a former homeowner in the area.

label: Andy Gap
description: S Macon County between Cedar Cliff Mountain and Mulberry Gap.

label: Angel Mountain
description: SW Macon County between Bryson Branch and Moore Creek.

label: Angelico Gap
description: SW Cherokee County at the SW end of Angelico Mountain.

label: Angelico Mountain
description: SW Cherokee County extending NE from Angelico Gap to Bowmans Gap. See also Rocky Face.

label: Angeline
description: community in N Henderson County between McDowell Creek and North Fork.

label: Angier
description: town in N Harnett County. Inc. 1901. Named for Col. John C. Angier, one of the town's founders. Produces apparel. Alt. 301.

label: Angle
description: community in SE Wayne County served by post office, 1888-1902.

label: Anglin Branch
description: rises in W Yancey County and flows SE into Jacks Creek. Named for Manon Anglin, an early settler.

label: Anglin Knob
description: central Yancey County near the head of Bailey Branch.

label: Anglins Mill
description: community in NW Rockingham County. Named for Anglin family, members of which operated gristmill on Mayo River in mid-eighteenth century.

label: Angola
description: See Maple Hill.

label: Angola Bay
description: pocosin in S Duplin and N Pender Counties. Angola Bay Game Preserve there is maintained by the N.C. Wildlife Resources Commission; bear, deer, and other wildlife abound. See also Holly Shelter Bay.

label: Angola Creek
description: rises in Angola Bay in NE Pender County and flows S into Holly Shelter Creek.

label: Ann Mountain
description: on a branch of Cabin Creek in S Henderson County.

label: Anna
description: community in central Alleghany County served by post office, 1890-1921.

label: Annandale
description: community in SE Pender County. Alt. 44.

label: Annie Mountain
description: E Henderson County S of Bradley Mountain. Alt. 2,731.

label: Anson County
description: was formed in 1750 from Bladen County. In the S central section of the state, it is bounded by the state of South Carolina and by Union, Stanly, and Richmond Counties. It was named for George Anson, Lord Anson (1697-1762), a British admiral who, for a number of years, was assigned to protect the commerce of the Carolina coast from pirates. Area: 536 sq. mi. County seat: Wadesboro, with an elevation of 423 ft. Townships are Ansonville, Burnsville, Gulledge, Lanesboro, Lilesville, Morven, Wadesboro, and White Store. Produces lumber, bricks, soybeans, oats, corn, milo, cotton, broilers, turkeys, hosiery, textiles, and wooden boxes. Sand, gravel, and crushed stone are also produced, and there are deposits of granite, sandstone, and shale for brick.

label: Ansonville
description: town in N central Anson County. Alt. 324. Settled 1844, named in 1857 for the county. Inc. 1885. Carolina Female College, 1850-67, est. by local planters and later operated by the Methodist Church, was there.

label: Ansonville Township
description: N central Anson County.

label: Anthony Bolick Branch
description: rises in NW Caldwell County on NW slopes of Rocky Knob and flows W into Johns River.

label: Anthony Branch
description: See Auntery Branch.

label: Anthony Creek
description: rises in central Catawba County and flows SW into Clark Creek.

label: Anthony Mountain
description: S central Avery County.

label: Anthony's Creek
description: rises in NW Caldwell County and SE Avery County and flows SE into Johns River.

label: Antioch
description: community in S Hoke County on Raft Swamp.

label: Antioch Township
description: E Wilkes County.

label: Antler
description: community in central Moore County served by post office, 1891-1907.

label: Antone
description: See Concord.

label: Apalachia Lake
description: NW Cherokee County on Hiwassee River at the Tennessee state line. Formed by Tennessee Valley Authority dam completed in 1943. Covers 1,123 acres, max. depth 120 ft., approx. 10 mi. long. Spelling with single p contrary to accepted manner.

label: Apex
description: town in W Wake County on the head of Beaver Creek. Inc. 1873. Named because it was supposed to be the highest point on the railroad between Richmond, Va., and Jacksonville, Fla. When first settled, the area was an important producer of turpentine and rosin. The town now produces apparel, plywood, and chemicals.

label: Appalachian Creek
description: rises in NW Rutherford County and flows NE into Broad River.

label: Appalachian Mountains
description: include all of the E mountains of the United States from Alabama to northern Maine. The name was given by Spaniards under Hernando De Soto in 1539 for the Apalachee Indians, whose name meant "people on the other side" (presumably of a river). In North Carolina the Blue Ridge, Black Mountains, and Great Smoky Mountains are part of the Appalachian Mountains. At one time, both Appalachian and Allegheny were names applied to the range from Georgia to New York, but a study by Arnold Guyot, "On the Appalachian Mountain System," published in 1861, firmly established the present name. See also Mountain Region.

label: Appalachian Trail
description: a marked footpath extending approx. 2,050 mi. from Maine to Georgia. In North Carolina approx. 70 of the 200 mi. within the state cross the crest of the Great Smoky Mountains. The highest point on the trail is Clingmans Dome, with an alt. of 6,642 ft. Proposed in 1921 and completed in 1937, it has been described as the longest marked footpath in the world.

label: Appie
description: community in N Greene County. Named about 1907 for Mrs. Appie (Apelia?) Bynum, local resident.

label: Apple Grove
description: community in NW Ashe County. Alt. 3,137.

label: Appletree
description: community in NW Greene County served by post office, 1886-98. Later known as Lindell, which see.

label: Appletree Branch
description: rises in NW Macon County and flows SW into Queens Creek.

label: Appletree Swamp
description: rises in NE Wayne County and flows SE into Nahunta Swamp in Greene County. The name appears in local records prior to 1750.

label: Applewhite
description: community in E Columbus County served by post office, 1892-1907.

label: Aquadale
description: community in S Stanly County. Inc. 1943; charter repealed 1945. Named by local resident: aqua (water) and dale (valley). Many springs in the area.

label: Aquascog River.
description: See Whipping Creek.

label: Aquascogoc
description: appears on the White map, 1585, as an Indian village near the head of Pungo River estuary, not far from either modern Scranton in Hyde County or Belhaven in Beaufort County.

label: Aquone
description: community in W Macon County on Nantahala River. Alt. 2,950. Settled on the site of Fort Scott, one of the stockades where Cherokee Indians were housed before being removed to Oklahoma, 1838. Name believed to be a corruption of egwanul'ti (by the river).

label: Arabi
description: community in N Robeson County served by post office, July-November 1900.

label: Arabia
description: nickname applied about 1860 to the desolate Outer Banks of North Carolina.

label: Aramancy River
description: See Great Alamance Creek.

label: Aramuskeet
description: described in 1758 as a part of Hyde County: "That Part of the County is a Peninsula, or rather an Island for three Parts of the Year, and can be entered by foot Passengers only in the Height of Summer, and that with great Difficulty for several Miles together. It was formerly an Indian Settlement, and there are at present about 12 Families of Indians, who live dispersed among the Whites, and dress and live like them, but they have still one whom they call the King among them." See also Aromuskek Marshes; Lake Mattamuskeet.

label: Arapahoe
description: town in S Pamlico County, inc. 1920. Post office est. 1886. Said to have been named for a local racehorse.

label: Ararat
description: community in E Surry County on Ararat River. Named for the river. Alt. 898.

label: Ararat River
description: rises in Virginia and flows S across Surry County into Yadkin River. Appears on the Collet map, 1770. Named for the biblical Mount Ararat.

label: Arba
description: community in S Greene County. Named for the biblical name Kirjatharba (Joshua 14:15).

label: Arbuckle
description: community in E Yancey County between North Toe and South Toe Rivers near their junction. A former post office, Dobag [Doe Bag], served the area.

label: Arcadia
description: community in N Davidson County.

label: Arcadia Township
description: NW Davidson County.

label: Arch Hill
description: a mountain in N Macon County between Tellico Creek and Bird Branch.

label: Arch Ridge
description: SE Clay County, extends S in arc from Vineyard Mountain to Shooting Creek.

label: Archdale
description: town in SE Cleveland County. Alt. 943. Settled in the eighteenth century and named for Quaker John Archdale, governor of Carolina, 1694-96.

label: Archdale County
description: was formed before 1696 "on Pampticoe River without the Bounds of the County of Albemarle." It was named for John Archdale (1642?-1717), governor of Carolina, 1694-96. The precinct of Pampticoe was a part of Archdale County in 1696, at which time it became the County of Bath. The name of Archdale County was changed to Craven, which see, about 1712.

label: Archdale Precinct
description: was formed from Bath County on December 3, 1705, and named in honor of John Archdale (1642?-1717), governor of Carolina, 1694-96. The name was changed about 1712 to Craven County, which see.

label: Archer Lodge
description: community in N Johnston County.

label: Archie's Point
description: point of land extending from Bogue Banks into Bogue Sound, SW Carteret County. Named for Archibald Smith. Sometimes also called Point of Woods.

label: Archies Creek
description: rises in NE Surry County and flows E into Stokes County, where it enters Dan River.

label: Archies Knob
description: NW Stokes County near Dan River.

label: Arcola
description: community in SE Warren County E of Fishing Creek. Post office est. there in 1849, but discontinued in 1954.

label: Arcot
description: community in central Sampson County served by post office, 1894-1902.

label: Arden
description: town in S Buncombe County. Settled about 1840. Inc. 1883, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Known first as Shufordsville. Renamed for the Forest of Arden in Shakespeare's play As You Like It Alt. 2,225.

label: Ardreys
description: community in S Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1898-1902.

label: Ardulusa
description: community on Rockfish Creek in S Cumberland County.

label: Arenuse Creek
description: consists of two branches, both rising in central Camden County and flowing generally SW into Pasquotank River. The branches come together in such a fashion that they seem to form an arrow nose. The fact was noted by the Indians, and the white settlers merely translated their word for "arrow nose" when they gave the creek its present name. The present name appears in records as early as 1694. To distinguish between the two branches, local inhabitants sometimes refer to First Milldam (nearest the county seat) and Second Milldam since water mills existed on each.

label: Argo
description: former town in N Nash County on Short Swamp Branch. Inc. 1889. Nearby Argo Gold Mine worked from about 1850 until about 1920. Both town and mine are now abandoned.

label: Argura
description: community in E central Jackson County on Gladie Creek. Alt. 3,291.

label: Argyle
description: former community on Little Rockfish Creek in NE Hoke County. Site now within the Fort Bragg Military Reservation. Named for Argyll, Scotland.

label: Arington Branch
description: rises in N Madison County and flows SW into West Fork [Bull Creek].

label: Arlington
description: See Coinjock.

label: Arlington Branch
description: rises in S Swain County and flows NW into Tuckasegee River.

label: Arm, The
description: an extension of Big Bald Mountain on the line dividing Unicoi County, Tenn., from Madison and Yancey Counties, N.C.

label: Armour
description: community in NE Columbus County. Named Amour (French, "love") for the Love family in the area, but through the years the spelling was changed.

label: Armstrong
description: former community in NW McDowell County on Threemile Creek. With the establishment of Little Switzerland, which see, 2 mi. nw, the community began to decline.

label: Armstrong Branch
description: rises in S Lincoln County and flows NE into Dellinger Branch.

label: Armstrong Creek
description: rises in NW McDowell County and flows E into North Fork [Catawba River].

label: Arnold
description: community in W Davidson County near the headwaters of Swearing Creek.

label: Arnold Branch
description: rises in E Macon County and flows SW into Cullasaja River.

label: Arnold Knob
description: SE Mitchell County between North Toe River and Rose Creek.

label: Arnt
description: formerly a small community and site of Arnt Ferry over the Catawba River, NE Catawba County. Site now covered by waters of Lookout Shoals Lake.

label: Aromuskek Marshes
description: appear on the Ogilby map, 1671, in the E section of present Hyde County between Lake Mattamuskeet and Pamlico Sound. See also Aramuskeet.

label: Arp Gap
description: W Cherokee County between Bowman Gap and Wolfpen Gap. Alt. approx. 2,750.

label: Arrowhead Branch
description: rises in W Macon County and flows SW into Nantahala Lake.

label: Arrowwood Creek
description: rises in W Macon County and flows SE into Wayah Creek.

label: Arrwood Mill
description: community in E Cherokee County on Slow Creek.

label: Art Stewart Ridge
description: W Graham County N of Wright Creek and parallel to it. Named for an early settler who came from Georgia.

label: Artesia
description: community in central Columbus County.

label: Arthur
description: See Bellarthur.

label: Arthur Township
description: W central Pitt County, formerly known as Beaver Dam Township.

label: Arthurs Creek
description: rises in NW Northampton County and flows S into Roanoke River.

label: Arturs Knob
description: E Mitchell County between Snow Creek and Bear Creek. Alt. 3,695. Named for Arthur ("Artur") McFalls (died 1839), who fought as a Tory at the Battle of Kings Mountain in 1780 but afterward joined the Americans. He lived alone for many years on the mountain. Sometimes erroneously called Otters Knob.

label: Arundells Island
description: See Croatamung.

label: Asa
description: community in central Greene County served by post office, March-September 1900.

label: Asa Cove
description: S Macon County between Messer Ridge and Betty Creek.

label: Asahel Creek
description: rises in NE Davidson County and flows SE into Abbotts Creek.

label: Asbury
description: community in W Wake County on the head of Richland Creek. Settled 1900. Named by its founder, Calvin Bridgers, for Asbury, England. Alt. 484.

label: Asbury Mountain
description: NE Alexander County. Alt. 1,820. Probably named for local Asbury family, which settled near the head of Snow Creek. Locally known as Big Mountain.

label: Asey Hole
description: deep section of White Oak River in E Onslow County near the mouth of Freemans Creek. Named for an old man, Asa Moore, who fell into the river there.

label: Asgini Ridge
description: NW Swain County extending as a short spur SE from the Great Smoky Mountain ridge centering near lat. 35°32'50" N., long. 83°46'20" W.

label: Ash
description: community in W Brunswick County.

label: Ash Bearpen Knob
description: SW Watauga County on the head of Moodys Mill Creek.

label: Ash Branch
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows NE into Tuckasegee River.

label: Ash Cove
description: NE Cherokee County in the Snowbird Mountains.

label: Ash Cove Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SW into Gipp Creek.

label: Ash Flat Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows N into Allison Creek.

label: Ash Hill
description: community in E Surry County served by post office, 1881-1907.

label: Ash Knob
description: central Clay County between Downing and Licklog Creeks.

label: Ashby Harbor
description: a bay on the W shore of Roanoke Island, E Dare County, in the waters of Croatan Sound. Site of landing by troops of Union general Ambrose Burnside, February 7, 1862.

label: Ashe County
description: was formed in 1799 from Wilkes County. In the NW corner of the state, it is bounded by the states of Tennessee and Virginia and by Alleghany, Wilkes, and Watauga Counties. It was named for Samuel Ashe (1725-1813), Revolutionary patriot, superior court judge, and governor of the state (1795-98). Area: 427 sq. mi. County seat: Jefferson, with an elevation of 2,900 ft. Townships are Chestnut Hill, Clifton, Creston, Elk, Grassy Creek, Helton, Horse Creek, Hurricane, Jefferson, Laurel, North Fork, Obids, Oldfields, Peak Creek, Pine Swamp, Piney Creek, Pond Mountain, Walnut Hill, and West Jefferson. Produces corn, tobacco, Christmas trees, rubber products, wood products, hay, dairy livestock, chemicals, textiles, hosiery, furniture, and electronics. Home to a cheese plant in West Jefferson. Copper and mica are mineral products, and the county has a potential for the production of stone, iron ore, and gem stones.

label: Ashe Creek
description: rises in E Pender County in Holly Shelter Bay and flows W into Northeast Cape Fear River. Appears as Ashes Mill on the Price map, 1808, and as Ashe's Mill Creek on the MacRae map, 1833. Exeter, which see, was nearby.

label: Ashe Gap
description: on the Mitchell County, N.C.-Carter County, Tenn., line.

label: Ashe's Island
description: S Onslow County in Stump Sound on the S side of Spicers Bay, a tidal-marsh and coastal-beach island approx. 1¼ mi. long. Named for John Baptista Ashe (1748-1802).

label: Ashe's Mill Creek
description: See Ashe Creek; Exeter.

label: Asheboro
description: town and county seat, central Randolph County. Inc. 1796. Named for Samuel Ashe (1725-1813), governor of North Carolina, 1795-98. Produces hosiery, apparel, textiles, blankets, batteries, furniture, toys, and shoes. Alt. 879.

label: Asheboro South
description: unincorporated outskirts of Asheboro, central Randolph County.

label: Asheboro Township
description: central Randolph County.

label: Asheboro West
description: unincorporated outskirts of Asheboro, central Randolph County. A portion of the area was taken into the town of Asheboro late in 1960 after the census had been taken.

label: Ashes Creek
description: See Upper Broad Creek.

label: Asheville
description: city and county seat, central Buncombe County on French Broad River. Settled about 1792; inc. 1797. First called Morristown, probably for William Morrison, who cast the deciding vote as one of the commissioners to select a site for the courthouse in 1792. Named Asheville for Samuel Ashe, governor of North Carolina (1795-98). As the city grew, its boundaries were extended to take in a number of adjacent areas, including Kenilworth, Biltmore, Montford, Ramoth (or Woolsey), Sunset Park, Victoria, and West Asheville. Historically a tourist and health resort, the city experienced a renaissance as bohemian mecca in late twentieth century. Alt. 2,216. University of North Carolina at Asheville N of downtown. Industry: publishing, software, apparel electronics, furniture, handicrafts, metalwork.

label: Asheville Township
description: central Buncombe County.

label: Ashford
description: community in N McDowell County on North Fork [Catawba River]. Alt. 1,762.

label: Ashland
description: community in SW Caswell County. A post office operated there from 1878 to 1915.

label: Ashley
description: community in NW Ashe County served by post office, 1888-1905.

label: Ashley Branch
description: rises in S Buncombe County and flows NE into French Broad River.

label: Ashley Heights
description: community in W Hoke County. Alt. 438.

label: Ashmont
description: community in W Hoke County.

label: Ashpole
description: See Fairmont.

label: Ashpole Swamp
description: rises in W Robeson County and flows SE and SW into South Carolina.

label: Ashpole Swamp
description: S Robeson County between Ashpole Swamp (stream) and Lumber River.

label: Ashton
description: community in S Pender County. Named for a member of the Ashe family who was a railroad official.

label: Ashton Run
description: See Afton Run.

label: Ashturn Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows N into Junaluska Creek.

label: Ashwood
description: S Bladen County, was the home of William Bartram, uncle of the naturalist of the same name. The naturalist lived there 1761-65 and 1770-72. It was called Ashwood by John Baptista Ashe, a previous owner, as early as 1731. It was on the right bank of Cape Fear River, approx. 5 mi. NE of Council. Only a cellar excavation and some chimney brick remain to mark the site.

label: Ashworth
description: community in NE Rockingham County served by post office, 1901-22. Was near Chandler's Mill on Wolf Island Creek.

label: Ashworth Creek
description: rises in SE Buncombe County near Henderson County line and flows NW into Cane Creek.

label: Askew
description: See Union.

label: Askew Ridge
description: S Avery County.

label: Askewville
description: town in central Bertie County. Settled in 1890s, named for local family. Alt. 64. Inc. 1951.

label: Askins
description: community in NE Craven County. Named for Alec Askins, on whose land a former post office was built. Alt. 18. See also Ernul.

label: Askins Creek
description: a cove on the Pamlico County side of S Hatteras Island, S Dare County, below the community of Avon.

label: Aspen
description: community in E Warren County. Post office est. there in 1908 but discontinued in 1915.

label: Aspen Grove
description: See Wittys Crossroads.

label: Assembly
description: See General Assembly.

label: Assembly Lake
description: SE Buncombe County at Ridge-crest, Baptist assembly grounds, on a tributary of Swannanoa River.

label: Astin's Run
description: See Afton Run.

label: Atfa
description: community in W Johnston County served by post office, 1893-1903.

label: Athens
description: community in NE Robeson County served by post office, 1880-1903.

label: Atherton
description: See Jackson.

label: Athlone
description: See Bowlens Creek.

label: Atkin River
description: See Yadkin River.

label: Atkins Bank
description: See Kinston.

label: Atkinson
description: town in W Pender County. Laid out on the lands of W. H. Lewis in 1883 (the year after a station had been est. there on the railroad) and known as Lewis. Inc. 1909 as Atkinson, named for an engineer whose work sped the completion of the railroad. Alt. 65.

label: Atkinson Pond
description: approx. 1 mi. long, on Moccasin Creek in SE Johnston County.

label: Atlantic
description: town in NE Carteret County, inc. 1905, but not now active in municipal affairs. Alt. 15. Settled about 1740; called Hunting Quarters until 1890. Post office est. 1880.

label: Atlantic Beach
description: town on the E end of Bogue Banks on the Atlantic Ocean. Inc. 1937.

label: Atlantic Ocean
description: forms the E boundary of North Carolina. The state has a shoreline of 328 mi.

label: Atlantic Township
description: on Core Sound in E Carteret County. Formerly known as Hunting Quarters Township.

label: Atlee
description: community in E Rockingham County served by post office, 1889-1903.

label: Atoah Creek
description: rises in S Graham County and flows NE into Long Creek.

label: Atoah Gap
description: in S Graham County between Eller Cove and the headwaters of Atoah Creek.

label: Attakulla
description: See Mount Mitchell.

label: Atwell Township
description: SW Rowan County.

label: Atwood
description: community in S Forsyth County.

label: Auberry
description: community in W Clay County on Hiwassee River.

label: Auburn
description: community in E Wake County. Alt. 340.

label: Augerhole Branch
description: rises in W Swain County and flows SW into Fontana Lake.

label: Aughburn
description: See Ogburn.

label: Augusta
description: community in SE Davie County served by post office, 1890-1902.

label: Aulander
description: town in NW Bertie County. In existence before the Civil War as Harmon's Crossroads. Inc. as Aulander in 1885. Alt. 73. The intended name was Orlando, but a phonetic spelling was used to distinguish it from Orlando, Fla. Another story is that a local sawmill operator, Andrew J. Dunning, had the town named for himself, i.e. "Ole Ander."

label: Auman's Hill
description: See Asbury.

label: Aumans Crossroads
description: community in S Randolph County.

label: Auntery Branch
description: also known as Anthony Branch, rises in SE Graham County and flows SW into Tulula Creek. Named for Jack Anthony.

label: Aurelian Springs
description: community in W Halifax County. Named aurelian (golden) because the water from the seven springs there was believed to be a cure-all. A popular recreation area of the late nineteenth century.

label: Aurora
description: town in SE Beaufort County. Alt. 25. Inc. 1880. Named for a former county newspaper, Aurora Borealis Originally a settlement of free African Americans called Betty Town existed there.

label: Ausbon
description: community in W Washington County. Alt. 41. Named for C. V. M. Ausbon, clerk of Superior Court, 1906-42.

label: Austin
description: community in NE Wilkes County near the headwaters of Little Elkin River.

label: Austin Creek
description: rises in E Wake County and flows SW into Smiths Creek. Shown on 1870 map as Millstone Creek.

label: Austin Mountain
description: W Yancey County near the head of Dryspring Branch.

label: Austins Mill
description: community in N Scotland County.

label: Auston Branch
description: rises in S Madison County and flows S into Morrow Branch.

label: Autreys Creek Township
description: See Otter Creek Township.

label: Autro
description: community in W Cleveland County served by post office, 1883-1904.

label: Autryville
description: town in W Sampson County. Settled about 1888; inc. 1891. Named for James L. Autry, who erected stores and est. a trading center there. Alt. 108.

label: Avalon
description: former community in W Rockingham County. Built about 1899 as a mill village on the Mayo River. On June 11, 1911, the mill was destroyed by fire, and soon afterward the 60 or so houses in Avalon, a Moravian church, a school, and a company store were moved on horse-drawn rollers to Mayodan, about 2 mi. sw.

label: Avalon Beach
description: area of extensive real estate development N of Wright Memorial in E Dare County. Once known as Moore's Shore.

label: Aventon
description: community in N Nash County on the head of Crooked Swamp. Named for the Avent family, which settled there about 1738; descendants still live on the original grant. A post office, Aventsville, opened there prior to 1828; Aventon post office operated from 1903 to 1911. Alt. 175.

label: Aventon Creek
description: See Abingdon Creek.

label: Avents Creek
description: rises in N Harnett County and flows SW into Cape Fear River.

label: Aventsville
description: See Aventon.

label: Averasboro
description: formerly a town on the Cape Fear River in SE Harnett County. Provided for by legislative act in 1791, to be laid off on land owned by Alexander Avera and called Averasburg. Site of a gristmill about 1740 and soon afterward of other public buildings. Site of Confederate attack on Sherman's army, March 15, 1865. Town began to decline soon after Civil War and by 1888 was practically abandoned. Site, 1 mi. S of Erwin, is marked by grove of large oak and beech trees and sets of historic houses and historical markers.

label: Averasboro Township
description: SE Harnett County.

label: Avery County
description: was formed in 1911 from Mitchell, Watauga, and Caldwell Counties. In the NW section of the state, it is bounded by the state of Tennessee and by Watauga, Caldwell, Burke, McDowell, and Mitchell Counties. It was named for Colonel Waightstill Avery (1741-1821), Revolutionary soldier and attorney general of North Carolina. Area: 247 sq. mi. County seat: Newland, with an elevation of 3,589. Townships are Altamont, Banner Elk, Beech Mountain, Cranberry, Linville, Roaring Gap, Toe River, Wilson's Creek. Produces corn, dairy and beef cattle, Christmas trees, mica, hay, cabinets, textiles, kaolin, iron, sand and gravel. There are also deposits of olivine and asbestos in the county.

label: Avery Creek
description: rises in S Buncombe County and flows E into French Broad River.

label: Avery Creek
description: rises in N Transylvania County and flows SE into Davidson River.

label: Avery Creek Township
description: SW Buncombe County.

label: Averys Bald
description: See Big Yellow Mountain.

label: Avilla
description: community in W Alexander County on Middle Little River. Served by post office from 1888 to 1906.

label: Avoca
description: community in E Bertie County on the site of Avoca Plantation, part of the eighteenth-century Nathanael Duckenfield estate. Name comes from the phrase "sweet vale of Avoca" in Thomas Moore's poem "The Meeting of the Waters." See also Black Walnut Point.

label: Avon
description: community on Hatteras Island, SE Dare County. Post office est. in 1873 as Kinnakeet. Post office renamed Avon in 1883. Alt. 3.

label: Avondale
description: community in SE Rutherford County on Second Broad River between the communities of Caroleen on the N and Henrietta on the s.

label: Axe Ridge
description: in S Graham County, extends N from Panther Cove to Little Snowbird Creek.

label: Axtell
description: community in W Warren County between Long Branch and Phoebes Creek. Alt. 400. Settled during the Revolutionary War and first named Old Shatter, a corruption of Chateau. Shatter Muster Ground, used during the Civil War, was located there. The post office that was located there from 1885 until 1889 was named Shatter. Name changed to Axtell in 1890 for noted race horse.

label: Aycock
description: community in N Wayne County and S Wilson County between Great Swamp and Aycock Swamp.

label: Aycock Creek
description: rises in S Granville County and flows NE into Tar River.

label: Aycock Crossing
description: community in SW Wilson County.

label: Aycock Millpond
description: in N Wayne County on Great Swamp. Adjacent to Sasser Millpond, named for the original owners. Max. depth 12 ft.; area covered, 30 acres. Fishing and boating open to the public.

label: Aycock Swamp
description: rises in N Wayne County and flows NE into Wilson County, where it enters Turners Swamp.

label: Aycocks Pond
description: SW Warren County on Lees Branch.

label: Ayden
description: town in S Pitt County. Inc. 1891. Name changed to Harriston in 1895 but changed back to Ayden in 1899. Alt. 64. Produces canned foods.

label: Ayden Branch
description: rises in N Swain County and flows S into Beech Flats Prong.

label: Ayden Township
description: SW Pitt County.

label: Aydlett
description: community on the W shore of Currituck Sound in central Currituck County. Probably named for first postmaster around 1909.

label: Ayersville
description: community in NE Stokes County served by post office, 1833-1915. Named for first postmaster, James Ayers.

label: Ayles Creek
description: rises in E Yancey County and flows NE into Little Crabtree Creek.

label: Ayr
description: former community in W Rutherford County near Lake Lure. Site of a pre-Civil War tannery that made saddles for the Confederate army during the war. A Scotsman, Francis Reynolds, operated the tannery and named the community for his native town. Post office est. there 1880, closed 1911.

label: Azalea
description: community in central Buncombe County, E of Asheville. Known as Gudger's Ford until renamed for the flowering shrub. Alt. 2,052.

label: Babbit's Pond
description: See Parrish's Pond.

label: Bacchus
description: community in E Yancey County.

label: Bachelor
description: community in SE Craven County on Clubfoot Creek.

label: Bachelor Creek
description: rises in Great Dover Swamp in NE Jones County, flows NE into central Craven County, and then turns to flow SE for approx. 3 mi. along the W border of Hog Island before entering Neuse River approx. 3½ mi. NW of town of New Bern. Approx. 14 mi. long. Appears as Batchellors Creek on the Moseley map, 1733. Formerly called Batchelder Creek. Named for Edward Batchelor.

label: Bachelor's Delight Swamp
description: rises in N Onslow County and flows SW into New River. Mentioned in local records as early as 1744.

label: Back Bay
description: a bay formed by the encircling islands of Hog Island in NE Carteret County.

label: Back Creek
description: rises in W Alamance County and flows SE into Great Alamance Creek.

label: Back Creek Mountain
description: central Randolph County W of Asheboro. One of the principal mountains of the Uwharrie range.

label: Back Creek Township
description: W central Randolph County.

label: Back Lake
description: a small lake on the mainland of Dare County E of the community of Lake Worth on Stumpy Point Bay.

label: Back Landing
description: in NW Tyrrell County on Scuppernong River. See also Newport.

label: Back Landing Creek
description: rises in the highlands of Indian Island, SE Camden County, and flows SE into North River.

label: Back Marsh
description: rises in N Duplin County and flows SW into Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: Back of Beyond
description: name given to far western counties by Horace Kephart in Our Southern Highlanders (1913). Derived from longtime inaccessibility of region.

label: Back Sound
description: between Shackleford Banks and Harkers Island in SE Carteret County.

label: Back Swamp
description: rises in NW Nash County and flows SE into Big Peachtree Creek.

label: Back Swamp Township
description: central Robeson County.

label: Backcountry
description: term used during the early settlement and colonial period for the vast interior of North Carolina, located away from the coastline and including both the modern-day Piedmont and Mountain regions.

label: Bad Branch
description: rises in E Macon County and flows SW into Big Creek.

label: Bad Creek
description: rises in SW Jackson County and flows SE into South Carolina, where it enters Chattooga River.

label: Bad Fork
description: rises in NW Henderson County and flows S into Wash Creek.

label: Bad Knob
description: in N Mitchell County between Aaron Branch and Big Ridge.

label: Badin
description: community in NE Stanly County on Badin Lake. Alt. 400. Est. 1913 by Adrien Badin, French industrialist who operated aluminum-reduction plant there. Plant opened as Aluminium Francais in 1915, later operated by Aluminum Company of America, closed 2002.

label: Badin Lake
description: on Yadkin River in Montgomery and Stanly Counties. Covers 5,973 acres; max. depth 40 ft. Completed 1917 by Carolina Aluminum Company to generate hydroelectricity and for recreation. Also referred to as Narrows Reservoir.

label: Bagdad
description: community in N Davidson County served by post office, 1893-1902.

label: Bagley
description: community in NE Johnston County. Named for local family.

label: Bagley Academy Branch
description: rises in NE Warren County and flows N into Little Stonehouse Creek.

label: Bahama
description: (ba-HAY-ma), community in N Durham County. Settled about 1880. Originally called Balltown until renamed. Bahama coined from the first two letters of the names of three prominent families-Ball, Harris, and Mangum. For a time in the nineteenth century, the post office name was Hunkadora. Alt. 507.

label: Bailey
description: community in W Davie County served by post office, 1890-1902.

label: Bailey Branch
description: rises in W central Yancey County on SE slopes of Roland Knob and flows S into Cane River.

label: Bailey Branch
description: rises in E Madison County and flows S into Gabriels Creek.

label: Bailey Cove
description: N central Yancey County near the head of Star Branch.

label: Bailey Creek
description: rises in SE Beaufort County and flows E into South Creek.

label: Bailey Hill
description: N Yancey County, extends NW from Locust Rough Mountain to Jacks Creek. Early settlers named Bailey are buried there and the site is reserved for a burying ground.

label: Bailey Meadows
description: in E Mitchell County between Sparks Ridge and Beaver Creek.

label: Bailey Mountain
description: E Yancey County between Browns Creek and South Toe River.

label: Bailey Ridge
description: S Madison County, extends NE from Bull Creek to Gabriels Creek.

label: Bailey Township
description: SE Nash County.

label: Bailey's Camp
description: community in NW Caldwell County.

label: Bailey's Fork
description: rises in S central Burke County and flows N into Silver Creek.

label: Baileys
description: See Bailey.

label: Bain
description: community in E Davidson County near the headwaters of Beaverdam Creek.

label: Baines Mountain
description: in S Swain County between Little Yalaka Creek and De Hart Branch.

label: Baird's Forge
description: See Granite Falls.

label: Bairds Creek
description: rises in W central Watauga County and flows SW into Watauga River.

label: Baker
description: See Drexel.

label: Baker Creek
description: rises in W central Yancey County and flows N into Cane River. Named for Sidney Baker, an early settler.

label: Baker Gap
description: on the Watauga County, N.C. Johnson County, Tenn., line in the Stone Mountains.

label: Baker Island
description: a sandy island approx. 2 mi. long in the Roanoke River, NW Northampton County. Called Eaton Island on the Price map, 1808, and Lashleys Island on the MacRae map, 1833.

label: Baker Mill
description: See Wheeler Creek.

label: Baker Mountain
description: W Catawba County. Alt. 1,812.

label: Baker Swamp
description: rises in E Cumberland County and flows SW into Reese Creek.

label: Bakers
description: community in W central Union County.

label: Bakers Branch
description: rises in N Madison County and flows NE into Spillcorn Creek.

label: Bakers Creek
description: rises in N Catawba County and flows S into Lyle Creek.

label: Bakers Crossroads
description: community in S Franklin County.

label: Bakers Lake
description: a natural lake in NW Bladen County, approx. 1½ mi. long. Formerly known as Wilkinson's Lake.

label: Bakers Ridge
description: W Alleghany County.

label: Bakers Swamp
description: rises in N Washington County and flows NE into Kendricks Creek.

label: Bakersville
description: town and county seat, in central Mitchell County on Cane Creek. Alt. 2,457. Settled prior to 1857 and named for David Baker, who settled on a grant that he had at the site in 1797. During the latter part of the Civil War and until 1868 known as Davis, apparently in honor of Confederate president Jefferson Davis. Inc. 1868.

label: Bakersville Township
description: central Mitchell County.

label: Bal-Gra
description: home of Thomas Pollock, president of the Council and acting governor, 1712-14 and 1722. Located in E Bertie County on the N side of Salmon Creek at its junction with Chowan River and Albemarle Sound. The brick house, named for the Pollock home in Renfrow County, Scotland, is no longer standing. Near site of Edenhouse, which see.

label: Balconce Branch
description: rises in W Lee County and flows NW into Little Pocket Creek.

label: Bald Beach
description: island on Atlantic Ocean in SW Brunswick County.

label: Bald Branch
description: rises in SW Madison County and flows N into Spring Creek.

label: Bald Cove
description: on the head of Cove Creek in E Haywood County.

label: Bald Creek
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows SW into Crabtree Creek.

label: Bald Creek
description: rises in N Cherokee County and flows SW into Davis Creek.

label: Bald Fork
description: rises near Bald Knob in NW Buncombe County and flows SW into Sandymush Creek.

label: Bald Gap
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park between Canadian Top and Bald Top near lat. 35°39' N., long. 83°06'22" W.

label: Bald Ground Mountain
description: NW Burke County. Alt. 4,100.

label: Bald Head
description: See Smith Island.

label: Bald Hill
description: See Intelligence.

label: Bald Knob
description: central Surry County.

label: Bald Knob
description: N Buncombe County NW of Cherry Log Gap.

label: Bald Knob Creek
description: rises in N Cleveland County and flows SE into Little Knob Creek.

label: Bald Knob Mountain
description: W Alexander County. Alt. 1,887.

label: Bald Knob Ridge
description: S Yancey County between Left Prong South Toe River and Right Prong South Toe River.

label: Bald Mountain
description: on Grassy Ridge near the Avery-Mitchell county line. Known also as Grassy Ridge Bald.

label: Bald Mountain Creek
description: rises in central Avery County and flows NE into Banner Elk Creek.

label: Bald Mountain Falls
description: in Yadkin River opposite Bald Mountain in S Davidson County. Mentioned as early as 1819 in a survey of the rivers of North Carolina.

label: Bald Mountain Township
description: NE Watauga County.

label: Bald Mountains
description: in Haywood, Madison, and Yancey Counties, N.C., and Cocke, Greene, and Unicoi Counties, Tenn., forming the common boundary line of North Carolina and Tennessee from the Pigeon River, near lat. 36°04'20" N., long. 82°24'30" W., to the Nolichucky River, near lat. 35°46'15" N., long. 83°04'50" W. On 25 of 40 miscellaneous maps, 1795-1930, the section of the mountains between Pigeon River and the French Broad River bears no name; and the names on 15 maps vary between Iron, Great Iron, Smoky, and Great Smoky. There is also some usage of Max Patch.

label: Bald of Humpback Mountain
description: S Mitchell County at the head of Rose Creek.

label: Bald Point
description: peninsula extending from S Hatteras Island, S Dare County, into Pamlico Sound.

label: Bald Ridge
description: central Avery County.

label: Bald Rock
description: mountain on the Jackson-Transylvania county line at the head of Tucker Creek. Alt. 4,150. Part of Tennessee Ridge, which see.

label: Bald Rock Mountain
description: S Jackson County, bordered on SW by Fairfield Lake and on N and W by Trays Island Creek. Alt. 4,232.

label: Bald Spot Mountain
description: See Gregory Bald.

label: Bald Spring Branch
description: rises in N Clay County and flows SW into Fires Creek.

label: Bald Top
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park between Little Davidson Branch and Coggins Branch near lat. 35°39' N., long. 83°06'30" W. Alt. 3,960.

label: Bald Top Mountain
description: N Henderson County between Clear Creek and Kyles Creek. Named by William Mills, first known white settler of the county.

label: Bald, The
description: a peak in NW Watauga County in the Stone Mountains.

label: Baldhead Creek
description: a tidal waterway extending from just inside the outer coast of Smith Island in Brunswick County in a NW direction into the Cape Fear River. Also known as Lighthouse Creek.

label: Baldwin
description: community in SW Ashe County. Named for family of early settlers. Alt. 3,100.

label: Baldwin Cove
description: on Burningtown Creek in central Macon County.

label: Baldwin Gap
description: N Henderson County between Rich Mountain and Hightop.

label: Baldwin Swamp
description: rises in central Pitt County and flows SE into Moyes Run.

label: Baldwin Township
description: NE Chatham County.

label: Bales Creek
description: rises in SW Anson County and flows E into Deadfall Creek.

label: Balfour
description: community in central Henderson County now part of Hendersonville on its N side. Alt. 2,125. Railroad name was Smyth. Named for Capt. William Balfour Troy, who operated a rock quarry there in 1880 and was agent for the newly opened railroad.

label: Balfours
description: community in central Randolph County adjacent to Asheboro on the n, formerly known as North Asheboro. Named for an abandoned community of the same name in W central Randolph County, SW of Asheboro, which was the home of Col. Andrew Balfour, Revolutionary patriot. Spero, formerly a community in its own right, is now considered to be a part of Balfours.

label: Ball
description: community in NW Ashe County. Formerly a post office.

label: Ball Creek
description: rises in S Macon County and flows NE into Coweeta Creek.

label: Ball Gap
description: S Buncombe County, NW of Ball Mountain.

label: Ball Island
description: small tidal-marsh island in the Bay River estuary, E Pamlico County. Used as a target for practice bombing by Marines.

label: Ball Mountain
description: S Buncombe County.

label: Ball Pocosin
description: E Lenoir County between Vine Swamp and Southwest Creek.

label: Ball's Point
description: point of land extending from W Carteret County into White Oak River.

label: Ballard
description: community in N Martin County, named for the plantation of John Bryant located near there in 1734. The first court in Martin County met in the community on the land of John Griffin, 1774.

label: Ballard Cove
description: N Buncombe County S of Horse Gap.

label: Ballard Creek
description: rises in N Lincoln County and flows SE into Anderson Creek.

label: Ballard Creek
description: rises in E Buncombe County and flows SE into Cane Creek.

label: Ballard Crossroads
description: community in SW Gates County.

label: Ballard Gap
description: Swannanoa Mountains, S Buncombe County E of Face Rock peak.

label: Ballards Crossroads
description: community in W Pitt County.

label: Ballast Bank
description: the point of land in the mouth of South Fork Creek at Scuppernong River, W Tyrrell County.

label: Ballast Pit
description: stony area about 1 mi. square, E central Anson County. Worked commercially for construction material.

label: Ballast Point
description: peninsula from E Roanoke Island extending into Roanoke Sound S of Shallowbag Bay, E Dare County.

label: Ballentine's Mills
description: community in S Wake County.

label: Ballou Hill
description: community near Balsam on Jones Creek in NE Jackson County.

label: Balls Creek
description: rises in E Catawba County and flows E into Catawba River.

label: Balls Creek Camp Ground
description: E Catawba County. Est. 1853, and trustees inc. 1861. Methodist. Camp meetings held there annually during the last week in August.

label: Balls Mountain
description: S Orange County at the head of Mountain Creek.

label: Balltown
description: See Bahama.

label: Balm
description: community in NE Avery County.

label: Balsam
description: town in NE Jackson County. Inc. in 1951, but not active in municipal affairs. Named for Balsam Mountains. Has highest standard-gauge railroad E of Rocky Mountains. Alt. 3,315.

label: Balsam Branch
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows SE into Raven Fork.

label: Balsam Cone
description: mountain in S Yancey County between the head of Timber Creek and the head of Middle Creek. Alt. 6,611.

label: Balsam Corner
