description: mountain on the Haywood-Swain county line. In Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°40'17" N., long. 83°10'55" W., near a sharp bend in the county line, hence the name. Alt. 6,020.

label: Balsam Corner Creek
description: rises in NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows SW into Straight Fork Raven Creek.

label: Balsam Gap
description: on the Buncombe-Yancey county line W of Walker Knob, near the S end of Bear Wallow Stand Ridge. The Blue Ridge Parkway passes through the gap. Alt. 5,320.

label: Balsam Grove
description: community in W Transylvania County on North Fork French Broad River.

label: Balsam High Top
description: mountain on the Haywood-Swain county line between Beech Gap and Laurel Gap in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Alt. 5,688.

label: Balsam Mountain
description: on the Haywood-Swain-Jackson county line, centering near lat. 35°35' N., long. 83°12' W. Tricorner Knob, which see, is at its junction with the main divide of the Great Smoky Mountains. Also known as Chiltoskie Ridge in Swain County. See also Richland Balsam.

label: Balsam Ridge
description: NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur extending SW from Hughes Ridge.

label: Baltic
description: community in W Duplin County. Alt. 146.

label: Baltimore
description: community in E Davie County. Alt. 828. Site of a community store from the 1880s.

label: Bamboo
description: community in S Watauga County on Sawpit Branch.

label: Bandana
description: community in W Mitchell County on Toe River. Alt. 2,331. Name said to have been given after a railroad brakeman left a bandana tied to a laurel bush to mark the location of a station.

label: Bandy
description: community in E Catawba County. Named for pioneer Bandy family.

label: Bandy Cove Mountain
description: NW Burke County. Alt. 2,747.

label: Bandy Township
description: SE Catawba County. Named for George Bandy, Virginian, who settled in Lincoln County, 1783.

label: Bangor
description: community in NW Wake County served by post office, 1888-1904.

label: Banjo Branch
description: rises in central Avery County and flows S into North Toe River.

label: Banjo Fork
description: rises in E Beaufort County and flows NW into Pungo Creek.

label: Bank Mountain
description: N Henderson County between Garren Mountain and Kyles Creek.

label: Bank Point
description: extends from SE Pasquotank County into Pasquotank River on the S shore of Little Flatty Creek.

label: Banks
description: community in S Wake County.

label: Banks Branch
description: rises in W Hertford County and flows NE into Meherrin River.

label: Banks Channel
description: a channel through a mass of tidal-marsh islands in the extreme W end of Bogue Sound in SW Carteret County.

label: Banks Creek
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows NW into Price Creek.

label: Banner Branch
description: rises in N Stokes County and flows SW into Snow Creek.

label: Banner Elk
description: town in NE Avery County on Elk River at the mouth of Shawneehaw Creek. Alt. 3,710. Inc. 1891 as Shawneehaw; reincorporated 1911 as Banner Elk. First settlers said to have arrived at the site about 1825. Named for the Banner family, early settlers on the Elk River. Lees-McRae College is there.

label: Banner Elk Creek
description: rises in E Avery County and flows N into Elk River.

label: Banner Elk Township
description: NE Avery County.

label: Banner Township
description: S Johnston County.

label: Banner's Store
description: See East Bend.

label: Bannerman's
description: or Bannerman's Bridge, community in E Pender County on Northeast Cape Fear River. Est. prior to the Revolution, but now largely abandoned.

label: Bannertown
description: community in NE Surry County.

label: Banton Creek
description: rises in NE Washington County and flows NE into Bull Bay; a portion of it forms the boundary with Tyrrell County. Sometimes erroneously called Bunton Creek.

label: Baptist Church Township
description: former township in central Cabarrus County. Now township no. 11. In 1945 a part of the township was annexed to Concord, coextensive with Concord township.

label: Bar Banks
description: See Bear Banks.

label: Barbacue Creek
description: See Barbecue Swamp.

label: Barbecue Swamp
description: rises in NE Bertie County and flows NE into Hertford County, where it enters Chinkapin Creek.

label: Barbecue Township
description: SW Harnett County.

label: Barber
description: community in W Rowan County. Two lines of the railroad cross there, hence sometimes called Barber's Junction. Named either for W. P. Barber, from whom the railroad purchased land for the station, or for R. L. Barber, first postmaster. Alt. 752.

label: Barber Creek
description: rises in central Pitt County and flows SE into Tar River.

label: Barber Junction
description: See Barber.

label: Barclaysville
description: community in NE Harnett County. Once the center of the Barclay-Barbee naval stores industry.

label: Barco
description: community in central Currituck County. Named for first postmaster. See also Coinjock.

label: Barden Pond
description: W Duplin County on a tributary of Rockfish Creek.

label: Bardins Bay
description: a sand-filled bay in W Cleveland County.

label: Bare Banks
description: See Bear Banks.

label: Barefoot's Mill Pond
description: See Contentnea Lake.

label: Bareford Swamp
description: rises in W Bladen County and flows SW through Hesters Pond into Crawley Swamp.

label: Barfields
description: See Tuscarora Beach.

label: Bargaw Creek
description: See Burgaw Creek.

label: Barham
description: community in NE Wake County.

label: Barium Springs
description: community and former health resort in S Iredell County. Known by the Indians as Poison Springs; developed in the 1880s as Linsters Springs. Post office name changed from Poison Springs to Barium Springs in 1889. Named for springs that contain barium salts and other minerals. Presbyterian Orphans Home est. there, 1891.

label: Barker Butt
description: E Swain County on Hickory Mountain.

label: Barker Creek
description: rises in NW Graham County and flows NE into Cheoah River.

label: Barker Heights
description: community in central Henderson County on S side of Hendersonville. Home to regional airport.

label: Barker Road Gap
description: on the Cherokee-Graham county line.

label: Barker-Ten Mile
description: community in NE Robeson County. Named for Barker Methodist Church and Ten Mile Baptist Church. A prosperous farming center.

label: Barkers Bridge
description: See Stella.

label: Barkers Creek
description: is formed by junction of West Fork and Middle Fork in W Jackson County and flows NE into Tuckasegee River.

label: Barkers Creek Township
description: NW Jackson County.

label: Barkers Ferry
description: on Catawba River at Mecklenburg-Lincoln county boundary. Now under waters of Lake Norman.

label: Barkerside
description: community in central Pitt County.

label: Barkley
description: community in W Lincoln County served by post office, 1889-1906.

label: Barlowes
description: community in SE Pender County on Bishop Creek. A former post office there was known as Sloop Point, which see.

label: Barn Branch
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows N into Jonathans Creek.

label: Barnard
description: community in central Madison County on French Broad River at the mouth of Brush Creek. Alt. 1,534. Barnard's Station post office est. as early as 1830. Named for Job Barnard, who settled there by 1794.

label: Barnards Creek
description: rises in central New Hanover County and flows W into Cape Fear River.

label: Barnardsville
description: town in N Buncombe County near the junction of North Fork Ivy Creek and Dillingham Creek. Inc. 1959. A post office operated there beginning in 1875. Alt. 2,250. Produces wearing apparel.

label: Barnes Branch
description: rises in N Haywood County and flows SE into Big Creek.

label: Barnes Creek
description: rises in central Cleveland County and flows NW and SW in an arc into First Broad River.

label: Barnes Crossroads
description: community in N Johnston County.

label: Barnes Store
description: community in W Wilson County. Named for Elias G. Barnes. A post office, 1877-1907.

label: Barnesville
description: community in S Robeson County. Alt. 125. Settled 1898. Named for R. R. Barnes, who gave land for the right-of-way for a rail-road, now abandoned. Served by post office, 1879-1943.

label: Barnett Branch
description: rises in central Cherokee County and flows SW into Slow Creek.

label: Barnett Creek
description: rises in E Clay County and flows NE into Buck Creek.

label: Barnett Knob
description: on the Jackson-Swain county line near the head of Pigeon Creek.

label: Barnett Mountain
description: central Madison County between Brush and Walnut Creeks.

label: Barnetts Pond
description: See Loch Lily.

label: Barney Slue
description: in the waters of Pamlico Sound, N of Hatteras Inlet, S Dare County.

label: Barns Creek
description: See Bartrams Creek.

label: Barnwell Mountain
description: on the Buncombe-Henderson county line.

label: Barr Banks
description: See Bear Banks.

label: Barr Creek
description: rises in SW Iredell County and flows S into Davidson Creek.

label: Barren Head
description: See Smith Island.

label: Barren Inlet
description: See Mason Inlet.

label: Barrett
description: community in NE Alleghany County.

label: Barrett Branch
description: rises in SE Clay County and flows NW into Right Fork [Eagle Creek], which is also sometimes known as Dave Barrett Creek.

label: Barrett Cove
description: N Buncombe County between Chestnut Knob and Reems Creek.

label: Barrett Mountain
description: SW Alexander County. Alt. 1,950. Named for Jonathan Barrett, pioneer settler who laid out road from Fort Dobbs to Quaker Meadows.

label: Barriers Mill
description: community on Dutch Buffalo Creek in E Cabarrus County.

label: Barringer Township
description: SE Iredell County. Named for a Civil War muster ground.

label: Barris Creek
description: rises in central Beaufort County and flows E into Pamlico River.

label: Barrows Mill Pond
description: W Northampton County on Gumberry Swamp. Approx. 1 mi. long. Appears as Jones Mill on the Collet map, 1770; known as Wheeler's Mill by 1833 and more recently by its present name. Boyhood home of Willie and Allen Jones, Revolutionary leaders, was there.

label: Barry Bay
description: a small bay in NE Carteret County, W of Core Sound and S of Cedar Island and Thorofare Bay, into which it empties.

label: Barshavia Creek
description: See Bechewa Creek.

label: Bart Branch
description: rises in W Transylvania County on Brushy Mountain and flows SW into Shoal Creek.

label: Bartlett
description: See Bluebutton.

label: Bartlett Creek
description: rises in NW McDowell County and flows SE into O'Dear Creek.

label: Bartlett Mountain
description: central Buncombe County SE of Swan Mountain.

label: Bartleys Island
description: narrow sandy strip approx. 2¾ mi. long beside French Broad River, W Madison County.

label: Barton Creek Township
description: NW Wake County.

label: Bartonsville
description: community in NE Hertford County. Named for local Barton family before the Civil War.

label: Bartrams Creek
description: rises in SW Carteret County and flows S into Bogue Sound. Also known as Barns Creek. Probably named for William Bartram.

label: Bartrams Lake
description: See White Lake.

label: Basal Creek
description: rises in SW Wake County and flows SE and then NE through Mills Pond and into Sunset Lake, where it joins Middle Creek.

label: Basin Creek
description: rises in S Alleghany County and flows S through Doughton Park in N Wilkes County to join Lovelace Creek in forming Middle Prong Roaring River.

label: Basin, The
description: a body of water at the S tip of New Hanover County. The Cape Fear River on the W is separated from The Basin by a dam; New Inlet on the Atlantic Ocean side permits access from Onslow Bay. The Brunswick-New Hanover county line divides The Basin near its center.

label: Basnight
description: community in W central Washington County midway between towns of Roper and Plymouth. Locally called Macedonia.

label: Basnights Ditch
description: rises in S Tyrrell County and flows NE into The Frying Pan.

label: Bason
description: community in central Rockingham County served by post office, 1885-1904.

label: Bass
description: See Keener.

label: Bass Ferry
description: See West Point.

label: Bass Lake
description: S Watauga County on String-fellow Branch in Moses H. Cone Memorial Park, which see. Formerly known as Cone Lake, it was formed before 1908. Covers 22 acres, with a max. depth of 30 ft. On the Blue Ridge Parkway.

label: Bass Mountain
description: peak in the Cane Creek Mountains, S Alamance County.

label: Bass's Crossroads
description: See Momeyer.

label: Bat Cave
description: community in NE Henderson County on Broad River. Alt. 1,250. Named for a nearby cave inhabited by bats and rare animals. The cave is preserved as a natural area. Fans of 1960s Batman television series coveted postmark.

label: Bat Fork
description: rises in SE Henderson County and flows NW into Mud Creek.

label: Batchelder Creek
description: See Bachelor Creek.

label: Batchellors Creek
description: See Bachelor Creek.

label: Batchelor Bay
description: formed at the mouth of the Roanoke and Cashie Rivers, E Bertie County, at the head of Albemarle Sound. Confederate ironclad Albemarle crossed bay to meet seven Union ships 15 mi. e, May 7, 1864.

label: Bateman Branch
description: rises in NW Macon County and flows SW into Whiteoak Creek.

label: Bates
description: community in SE Beaufort County served by post office, 1900-1904.

label: Bates Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows SE into Little Tennessee River.

label: Bates Creek
description: rises in central Cherokee County between Bates and Fain Mountains and flows SW into Hiwassee River.

label: Bates Gap
description: S Macon County between Fulcher Branch and Hickory Knoll Creek.

label: Bates Mountain
description: central Cherokee County, extends from Hiwassee River to Blackwell Mountain.

label: Bates Ridge
description: S Macon County between Bristle Ridge and Hickory Knoll Creek.

label: Batey Branch
description: rises in NW Macon County and flows S into Cold Springs Creek.

label: Bath
description: town in central Beaufort County at junction of Bath and Back Creeks. Alt. 9. Settled 1690. Inc. 1705. The oldest town in North Carolina, it was the county seat from 1696 to 1785, when it was changed to Washington. Probably named for Bath County in which it was originally located. Bath is now a State Historic Site and a number of restored buildings are open to the public. St. Thomas Church there, the oldest church in North Carolina, was built in 1734. The colonial assembly met there in 1744 and 1752.

label: Bath County
description: formed in 1696 from the territory S of Albemarle Sound, was named in honor in John Granville, Earl of Bath, one of the Lords Proprietors. On December 3, 1705, the territory was divided into Archdale, Pamptecough, and Wickham precincts. Bath County was not abolished with the creation of the precincts but continued to be referred to in records as late as 1724. As the precincts increased in importance, eventually becoming counties themselves, the parent county lost its identity.

label: Bath Creek
description: rises in central Beaufort County and flows S into Pamlico River.

label: Bath Township
description: E central Beaufort County.

label: Bathsheba Creek
description: See Bechewa Creek.

label: Baton
description: community in S Caldwell County.

label: Bats Grave
description: See Batts Island.

label: Batson Creek
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows N into Carson Creek.

label: Battery Bolles
description: See Fort Fisher.

label: Battery Island
description: a tidal-marsh island in the Cape Fear River opposite Southport, SE Brunswick County.

label: Battis Point
description: See Wades Point.

label: Battle Branch
description: rises in central Davidson County and flows SW into Abbotts Creek.

label: Battle Cove
description: E Swain County between Falls Branch and Fishtrap Branch.

label: Battle Creek
description: See Johnsons Mill Creek.

label: Battle Ground
description: former community in central Guilford County, now within the limits of the city of Greensboro. Served by post office, 1858-1923. Site of Battle of Guilford Courthouse, March 15, 1781.

label: Battle Royal
description: community 10 mi. W of Wilmington in Brunswick County. Site of tar manufactory, 1884.

label: Battle Run Brook
description: rises in E Catawba County and flows SE into North Fork Mountain Creek.

label: Battleboro
description: town in NE Nash and SW Edgecombe Counties. Inc. 1872. Had its origin about 1840 as a railroad depot in a rich agricultural area. The station was named for James and Joseph Battle, stockholders in the Wilmington and Raleigh Railroad. Produces lumber. Annexed by Rocky Mount, 2002. Alt. 131.

label: Battles Falls
description: in Cape Fear River in N Harnett County along a rock outcrop between the confluence of Camels Creek and Fish Creek with the river. The N end of the rapids, near Camels Creek, is called Battles Upper Falls; the S end, near Fish Creek, is called Battles Lower Falls. Mentioned as early as 1819 in a survey of the major rivers of North Carolina.

label: Batts Crossroads
description: community in NE Wilson County. Named for John Batts before the middle of the nineteenth century.

label: Batts Grave
description: See Batts Island.

label: Batts House
description: the home of Nathaniell Batts, first-known permanent white settler in North Carolina, was built as early as 1655 and stood between Roanoke River and Salmon Creek, E Bertie County, facing Albemarle Sound.

label: Batts Island
description: former island in Albemarle Sound near the mouth of the Yeopim River, SW Perquimans County. Named for Nathaniell Batts, who acquired property in the area, September 24, 1660. It is mentioned in local records as early as 1694. In 1749 it was 40 acres in area and had houses and orchards on it; by 1756 it had been reduced to 27 acres. Early in the twentieth century it was a campsite for fishermen, but later it was reduced to a mud flat with a few dead trees. A hurricane in the 1950s completely destroyed the island. Appears as Heriots Island, probably for Thomas Hariot (1560-1621), on the Smith map, 1624; as Hariots Island on the Comberford map, 1657: and as Bats Grave on the Moseley map, 1733, and the Collet map, 1770.

label: Baucoms
description: community in N central Union County on the head of Watson Creek.

label: Baughn Mountain
description: W Rockingham County E of the Mayo River and N of the Dan River near the junction of the two. Originally known as East Mayo Mountain; renamed for Henry Baughn, who settled there in 1814. By 1897 known as Cedar Point Mountain. Alt. 995.

label: Baum Creek
description: rises in SW Roanoke Island, Dare County, and flows SW into Oyster Creek.

label: Baum Point
description: extends from N Roanoke Island into Roanoke Sound, Dare County.

label: Bawdy Creek
description: rises in E Johnston County and flows SE into Neuse River.

label: Bawdy Swamp
description: rises in central Johnston County and flows SE into Bawdy Creek.

label: Baxter
description: community in E Henderson County on Tumblebug Creek. Post office operated there, 1881-1914.

label: Baxter Branch
description: rises in N Madison County and flows SE into White Rock Branch.

label: Baxter Creek
description: rises in S Davie County and flows SE approx. 2 mi. into Bear Creek.

label: Bay
description: See Bull's Bay.

label: Bay Branch
description: rises in SW Beaufort County and flows E into Chocowinity Creek.

label: Bay City
description: community in Bay City Pocosin, N Pamlico County. Est. in the early twentieth century as a farming community by out-of-state developers. Now produces grain.

label: Bay City Pocosin
description: muck-filled area approx. 12 mi. wide in N Pamlico and S Beaufort Counties.

label: Bay Creek
description: a tidal creek on Smith Island in Brunswick County that extends from its junction with Cape Creek first SE and then NE to flow into Buzzard Bay.

label: Bay Creek, The
description: See Turnagain Creek.

label: Bay River
description: rises in N Pamlico County and flows NE for approx. 16 mi. into the Neuse River. Named for the bay tree, which flourishes in the vicinity. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Bay River Point
description: peninsula off E Pamlico County extending into Bay River estuary.

label: Bay Shore Park
description: town in S Carteret County on Bogue Sound. Inc. 1959.

label: Bay Swamp
description: E Pender County, drains NW into Holly Shelter Bay.

label: Bay, The
description: See Turnagain Bay.

label: Bayboro
description: town and county seat, central Pamlico County on Bay River. Named for the river, which see. Became the county seat in 1876, succeeding Vandemere. Inc. 1881. Alt. 8.5.

label: Baybush Swamp
description: a fine sandy loam swamp in N Craven County.

label: Bayleaf
description: community in N central Wake County.

label: Bayley
description: See Shawboro.

label: Baymarsh Thorofare
description: waterway between Sheep Island and Portsmouth Island, E Carteret County.

label: Baymeade
description: community in NE New Hanover County.

label: Baynes
description: community in S Caswell County.

label: Bays
description: See Carolina Bays.

label: Baysden Mill Pond
description: in SW Onslow County on Cypress Creek. Covers approx. 10 acres; max. depth 10 ft.

label: Bayside
description: See Bayview.

label: Bayview
description: community in S Onslow County served by post office, 1895-1902.

label: Beach Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SE into Right Fork Webb Creek.

label: Beach Creek
description: rises in S Clay County and flows SW into Brasstown Creek.

label: Beach Springs
description: community in W Perquimans County.

label: Beach Top
description: S Clay County near the headwaters of Beach Creek and Long Branch.

label: Beacon Height
description: mountain in E Avery County.

label: Beacon Island
description: in Pamlico Sound, NE Carteret County, is situated between Wallace Channel and Blair Channel leading through Ocracoke Inlet. Approx. 1,200 ft. long. Name derived from two large beacons on the island formerly used by pilots guiding ships through the channels. Jonathan Price wrote in 1795 that a "fort" was built on the S end of the island in 1794-95 pursuant to an act of Congress. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Beacon Island Road
description: See Wallace Channel.

label: Beacon Island Shoal
description: in Pamlico Sound in NE Carteret County, obstructing passage through Ocracoke Inlet. Located between Beacon Island and Wallace Channel. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Beal's Knob
description: N Clay County near the Cherokee County line. Alt. 5,000-5,100.

label: Beals Mill Pond
description: E Northampton County on a tributary of Potecasi Creek.

label: Beam Mill
description: community in E Cleveland County on Magness Creek. Alt. 1,001.

label: Beaman Run
description: the S part of Howell Swamp, in N Greene County; it flows SW into Contentnea Creek. Named for the Beaman family, which settled in the vicinity about the time of the Revolution.

label: Beamans Crossroads
description: community in N Sampson County between Old Mill Swamp and Marsh Swamp.

label: Bean Creek
description: is formed in N Mitchell County by the junction of Right Fork Bean Creek and Left Fork Bean Creek. It flows SE into Big Rock Creek.

label: Bean Shoals
description: a succession of rocks and loose stones in Yadkin River on Surry-Yadkin county line, approx. 1 mi. S of the confluence of Ararat River. The shoals measure 2 mi. in length. The communities of Shoals (Surry County) and Bean Shoals (Yadkin County) are nearby. Mentioned as early as 1819 in a survey of the rivers of North Carolina.

label: Beantown Creek
description: rises in central Haywood County and flows SE and NE into Jonathans Creek.

label: Bear Banks
description: coastal beach in SE Onslow County on the Atlantic Ocean between Bogue and Bear inlets. Mentioned in local records as early as 1713; also spelled Bare, Bar, and Barr. Known also as Bear Beach and Heady's Beach for Daniel Heady and four generations of his descendants who owned the area. The Banks are approx. 3½ mi. long.

label: Bear Bay
description: See Allenton.

label: Bear Beach
description: See Bear Banks.

label: Bear Branch
description: rises in S Lee County and flows E into Crane Creek.

label: Bear Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NW into Junaluska Creek.

label: Bear Cove
description: in W Macon County at the head of Wayah Creek.

label: Bear Creek
description: See Warrior Creek.

label: Bear Creek
description: rises in E Onslow County and flows SE into Brown's Sound. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733. Known earlier as Deep Creek.

label: Bear Creek
description: rises in SW Chatham County and flows SE and NE into Rocky River.

label: Bear Creek
description: rises in E Ashe County and flows NW into South Fork New River.

label: Bear Creek Lake
description: central Jackson County on Tuckasegee River. Formed in 1954 as a reservoir for Nantahala Power and Light Company. Covers 476 acres, with a max. depth of 195 ft. Shoreline is 13.5 mi. Used for generating hydroelectric power. Named for Bear Creek, which feeds it. Also receives the waters of Sols, Flat, and Robinson Creeks. Known for bass and trout fishing. Alt. 2,560.

label: Bear Creek Township
description: SW Chatham County.

label: Bear Gap
description: S Clay County on Chunky Gal Mountain.

label: Bear Grass Creek
description: rises in central Craven County and flows S into Trent River S of New Bern.

label: Bear Inlet
description: SE Onslow County, through which Brown's Sound drains into the Atlantic Ocean. Mentioned in local records as early as 1713 and appears on the Moseley map, 1733. Following the Spanish alarm of 1747, Bear Inlet Fort was constructed there.

label: Bear Island
description: not now identifiable, appears on the Moseley map, 1733, in Bogue Sound, S Carteret County W of Dog Island.

label: Bear Knob
description: on the Cherokee-Graham county line.

label: Bear Knob
description: SW Macon County between Little Indian Creek and Nantahala River.

label: Bear Marsh Branch
description: rises in NW Duplin County and flows SW into Merritt Mill Pond and Goshen Swamp.

label: Bear Mountain
description: S Jackson County between Doubletop Mountain and Glassy Rock Creek. Alt. 4,650.

label: Bear Pen Branch
description: rises in N Madison County and flows SW into Little Laurel Creek.

label: Bear Pen Gap
description: N Clay County between Tuni Creek and the Cherokee County line.

label: Bear Pen Islands Swamp
description: N central Brunswick County. A part of Green Swamp.

label: Bear Pen Ridge
description: SE Clay County.

label: Bear Pocosin
description: NE Sampson County S of Youngs Swamp and E of Six Runs Creek.

label: Bear Point
description: extends into Pamlico Sound from E Hyde County.

label: Bear Point
description: SE Tyrrell County, extends from the mainland into Alligator River.

label: Bear Poplar
description: community in W Rowan County. Known first as Rocky Mount; present name adopted in 1878, when a post office was est. Name came from the nearby location of a poplar tree in which Capt. Thomas Cowan, Revolutionary hero, treed a bear in the late eighteenth century.

label: Bear Ridge
description: between Cashie Branch and Licklog Creek in N Jackson County.

label: Bear Rock Branch
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows SE into South Toe River.

label: Bear Swamp
description: rises in W Halifax County and flows SW into Little Fishing Creek.

label: Bear Swamp
description: E Chowan and W Perquimans Counties. Covered about 1/8 of Chowan County before being drained to provide farmland.

label: Bear Swamp Creek
description: rises in N Franklin County and flows SW into Tar River.

label: Bear Wallow Branch
description: rises in NE Madison County and flows SW into Foster Creek.

label: Bear Wallow Gap
description: NE Haywood County on the head of Wesley Creek.

label: Bear Wallow Knob
description: S Yancey County between Hurricane Gap and Ogle Gap. Alt. 5,085.

label: Bear Wallow Ridge
description: S Yancey County between Middle Fork and Grassy Knob Branch.

label: Bear Wallow Stand Ridge
description: S Yancey County between Raven Fork and Blue Sea Creek.

label: Bearcamp Creek
description: rises in SW Transylvania County and flows SE into South Carolina and into Toxaway River.

label: Beard
description: community in NE Cumberland County.

label: Beard Cove
description: central Buncombe County, between Beard Mountain and Gooch Peak in the Elk Mountains.

label: Beard Creek
description: rises in S Pamlico County and flows S into Neuse River. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733. Local tradition attempts to associate the origin of the name with Blackbeard, the early eighteenth-century pirate.

label: Beard Mountain
description: central Buncombe County in the Elk Mountains.

label: Beards Creek
description: community in S Pamlico County on Beard Creek, which see, and Neuse River, where a recreational area has been developed. Settled prior to 1750; a post office operated there from 1878 to 1914 as Bairds Creek.

label: Bearford Bay
description: a marshy bay in SW Duplin County.

label: Beargarden Pocosin
description: central Greene County. Named because it was a favorite haunt of bears and numerous flowering plants grow there. Yellow jasmine and honeysuckle were so fragrant that they could be smelled a mile or so away downwind.

label: Beargrass
description: town in S Martin County on a tributary of Beargrass Swamp. Settled about 1828. Inc. 1909, but inactive in municipal affairs until 1961, when the General Assembly appointed new officers. Alt. 65.

label: Beargrass Swamp
description: rises in S Martin County and flows W into Turkey Swamp.

label: Beargrass Township
description: S central Martin County.

label: Bearhead Creek
description: rises in E Onslow County and flows NW into Wallace Creek.

label: Bearmeat Branch
description: rises in SE Swain County and flows SW into Yalaka Creek.

label: Bearpaw
description: community in W Cherokee County at the mouth of Bearpaw Creek.

label: Bearpaw Creek
description: rises in W Cherokee County and flows SW and SE into Hiwassee River.

label: Bearpen Branch
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows W into Allen Creek.

label: Bearpen Creek
description: rises in N Madison County and flows S into Chimney Creek.

label: Bearpen Creek
description: rises in S Macon County and flows W into Nantahala River.

label: Bearpen Gap
description: on the Clay-Macon county line.

label: Bearpen Gap
description: N central Avery County.

label: Bearpen Knob
description: NE Buncombe County between Beartree and Bearpen Gaps.

label: Bearpen Mountain
description: SE Macon County between Little Bearpen Mountain and Saltrock Branch.

label: Bearpen Mountain
description: on the Jackson-Transylvania county line between Sassafras Mountain and Horsepasture River. Alt. 4,025.

label: Bearpen Ridge
description: S Haywood County between Daniels Cove and Correll Branch.

label: Bearpen Rock
description: a mountain in W Avery County.

label: Bearpond
description: community in S Vance County, named for a local tradition of a celebrated bear hunt there. In 1785 a practical joke was played on Zeke Brown to put an end to his tall tales of bear killing. A mock bear hunt was arranged at the present site of Bearpond in which a local citizen, Jake Sims, dressed in bearskins and gave Brown such a scare he left the county for "Orrapeake." The community is now known locally as Buena Vista, after the plantation of Dr. Robert Christian Pritchard (b. 1812) in nearby S Warren County.

label: Bearskin
description: community in W central Sampson County near Bearskin Swamp.

label: Bearskin Creek
description: rises in W Union County and flows E through the city of Monroe into Richardson Creek.

label: Bearskin Swamp
description: rises in W central Sampson County and flows SW into Little Coharie Creek.

label: Beartown Mountain
description: on the Mitchell County, N.C.-Carter County, Tenn., line. Alt. 5,481.

label: Beartown Ridge
description: NE Mitchell County between Beartown Mountain and Big Rock Creek.

label: Beartrail Ridge Gap
description: on the Haywood-Jackson county line.

label: Beartrap Knob
description: S Haywood County between Raven Hollow and Possum Hollow.

label: Beartrap Ridge
description: S Haywood County between Big Beartrap Branch and Raven Hollow.

label: Beartree Creek
description: rises in E Chatham County and flows SE into New Hope Creek.

label: Beartree Gap
description: NE Buncombe County between Snowball Mountain and Bearpen Knob.

label: Bearwallow
description: community in NE Henderson County. Named by William Mills, pioneer settler, because of a nearby, much-frequented bear wallow.

label: Bearwallow Bald
description: peak in N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Welch Ridge. Alt. 4,954.

label: Bearwallow Branch
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows NE into Carter Creek.

label: Bearwallow Brook
description: rises in N Transylvania County and flows SE into South Fork Mills River.

label: Bearwallow Creek
description: rises in E Jackson County and flows SW into Piney Mountain Creek.

label: Bearwallow Gap
description: NW Mitchell County on Bearwallow Creek.

label: Bearwallow Gap
description: SE Buncombe County SE of Bearwallow Mountain.

label: Bearwallow Mountain
description: on the Buncombe-Henderson county line. Alt. 4,249.

label: Bearwallow Ridge
description: N Jackson County between Cherry Orchard Branch and Rough Branch.

label: Bearwell Pocosin
description: SE Lenoir County between Joshua Creek and Trent River. Probably a corruption of the family name Burwell. Thomas Burwell was living in the vicinity about 1750.

label: Beasley
description: community in N Washington County. Known locally as Holly Neck.

label: Beasley Bay
description: in Currituck Sound between Jarvis Channel and Currituck Banks in E Currituck County.

label: Beasley Branch
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows SE into Cherryfield Creek.

label: Beasley Creek
description: rises in W Transylvania County and flows S into West Fork French Broad River.

label: Beasley Creek
description: rises in NE Macon County and flows SW into Cowee Creek.

label: Beasley Gap
description: S Macon County between Mulberry Creek and Commissioner Creek.

label: Beasleys Creek
description: rises on the Pender-Onslow county line and flows SE into Stump Sound in S Onslow County. Appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Beasleys Mill Pond
description: on Millers Creek in W Duplin County.

label: Beason Creek
description: rises in SE Cleveland County and flows SE into Buffalo Creek.

label: Beatie's Ford
description: See Beattie's Ford.

label: Beaton Branch
description: rises in S Buncombe County and flows N into Bent Creek.

label: Beattie's Ford
description: across the Catawba River, Lincoln-Mecklenburg Counties near the Iredell County line. Named for John Beatty, who owned land in the area as early as 1749. A post office named Beatie's Ford existed in the vicinity from 1806 to 1838. A part of the British army, in pursuit of Gen. Nathanael Greene, crossed the river there on February 1, 1781. The site is now under the waters of Lake Norman.

label: Beatty Branch
description: rises in central McDowell County and flows SE into Paxton Creek.

label: Beattys Mill Pond
description: in E Bladen County on Lake Creek.

label: Beaty Spring Knob
description: S Haywood County on the head of Inman Branch.

label: Beaucatcher Mountain
description: central Buncombe County in E Asheville. Alt. approx. 3,200. About 1850 James W. Patton erected a summer house or arbor there, and it became quite popular with courting couples, hence the name. Highway construction in 1979 opened a cut in the mountain alongside 1929 tunnel despite public opposition.

label: Beaufort
description: town and county seat in S central Carteret County. Laid out in 1713 and settled soon afterward. Inc. 1723. Named for Henry Somerset (1684-1714), Duke of Beaufort, one of the Lords Proprietors of Carolina. Built on the site of an Indian village, Wareiock, said to have meant "Fish Town" or "Fishing Village"; the town was first called Fishtown. Home of North Carolina Maritime Museum. Alt. 9.

label: Beaufort County (BOE-furt)
description: was first called Pamptecough Precinct when it was formed in 1705 from Bath County; the name was changed to Beaufort about 1712 to honor Henry Somerset, Duke of Beaufort (1684-1714), who in 1709 became one of the Lords Proprietors. Located in the E part of the state, it is bounded by Craven, Hyde, Martin, Pitt, Pamlico, and Washington Counties. Area: 957 sq. mi. County seat: Washington, with an elevation of 11 ft. Townships are Bath, Long Acre, Chocowinity, Pantego, Richland, and Washington. Produces tobacco, corn, hogs, cattle, boats, air filters, soybeans, Irish potatoes, peanuts, wheat, oats, sorghum, cotton, canned seafood, lumber, and phosphate.

label: Beaufort Inlet
description: S central Carteret County, from the Atlantic Ocean into Bogue Sound, between Bogue Banks on the W and Shackleford Banks on the e. Appears as Topsail Inlet on the De Graffenried map (French text), 1711, and was later known as Old Topsail Inlet.

label: Beaufort Township
description: on Taylors Creek and Beaufort Inlet in central Carteret County. For a time called township no. 4.

label: Beaumont
description: community in S Chatham County served by post office, 1851-1914.

label: Beautancus
description: community in N Duplin County near Bear Marsh Branch.

label: Beauty Spot
description: mountain on the Mitchell County, N.C. Unicoi County, Tenn., line. Alt. 4,254.

label: Beauty Spot Gap
description: on the Mitchell County, N.C.-Unicoi County, Tenn., line.

label: Beaux
description: community in N Wilkes County near Mulberry Creek.

label: Beaver Branch
description: rises in NE Wayne County and flows SE into Nahunta Swamp in W Greene County. The name dates from colonial times.

label: Beaver Creek
description: rises in NW Jones and E Lenoir Counties and flows E into Trent River.

label: Beaver Creek
description: rises in NE Cabarrus County and flows S into Dutch Buffalo Creek about 2 mi. N of town of Mount Pleasant.

label: Beaver Creek Pond
description: See Beaver Lake.

label: Beaver Creek Township
description: N Jones County.

label: Beaver Dam Branch
description: rises in E Brunswick County and flows E into Cape Fear River.

label: Beaver Dam Branch of Hunting Creek
description: rises N of Calahaln in W Davie County and flows S into Hunting Creek.

label: Beaver Dam Brook
description: rises in S Catawba County and flows SW into South Fork Catawba River.

label: Beaver Dam Creek
description: rises in SE Brunswick County and flows S into Cape Fear River.

label: Beaver Dam Lake
description: basin on Falls Lake along the Granville-Wake county line fed by Robertson, Beaverdam, Smith, and Little Beaverdam Creeks.

label: Beaver Dam Swamp
description: rises in E central Brunswick County and flows S into Town Creek.

label: Beaver Dam Township
description: SE Cumberland County.

label: Beaver Gap
description: S Cherokee County N of Sheep Knob.

label: Beaver Island Creek
description: rises in E Stokes County and flows E into Rockingham County, where it turns S to flow into Dan River.

label: Beaver Island Township
description: E Stokes County.

label: Beaver Lake
description: in the city of Asheville near its N limits, central Buncombe County. On Beaverdam Creek. Constructed as part of real-estate development.

label: Beaver Store
description: community in E Wayne County between Exum Mill Branch and The Slough.

label: Beaverdam
description: community in SW Buncombe County on Beaverdam Creek NE of Long Mountain.

label: Beaverdam Bald
description: on the Cherokee County, N.C. Monroe County, Tenn., line in the Unicoi Mountains. Alt. 4,280.

label: Beaverdam Bay
description: a section of Green Swamp, central Brunswick County.

label: Beaverdam Bay
description: NE Bladen County.

label: Beaverdam Branch
description: rises in NE Franklin County and flows NE into Sandy Creek.

label: Beaverdam Brook
description: rises in Magnolia in W Duplin County and flows NE into Maxwell Creek.

label: Beaverdam Creek
description: rises in W Rowan County and flows NE into Withrow Creek.

label: Beaverdam Creek
description: rises in NW Gaston County and flows NE into South Fork Catawba River.

label: Beaverdam Creek
description: rises in SE Bladen County and flows NE into Waymans Creek in Columbus County.

label: Beaverdam Gap
description: NW Henderson County on the NW end of Trace Ridge. Alt. 3,500.

label: Beaverdam Gap
description: SW Buncombe County in New-found Mountain.

label: Beaverdam Pocosin
description: NW Bertie County.

label: Beaverdam Ridge
description: W Watauga County extends NW from Watauga River, W of Cove Creek and SE of Ward Hollow.

label: Beaverdam Run
description: rises in S Greene County and flows SE in an arc into Contentnea Creek.

label: Beaverdam Swamp
description: rises in N Sampson County and flows SW into Great Coharie Creek.

label: Beaverdam Swamp
description: rises in NW Bertie County and flows E into Loosing Swamp, which becomes Stony Creek.

label: Beaverdam Swamp Canal
description: rises in S Harnett County and flows S into Cape Fear River.

label: Beaverdam Township
description: N Watauga County.

label: Beaverdam Township
description: N Cherokee County.

label: Beaverpond Creek
description: rises in NW Northampton County and flows NE into Virginia, where it turns SE to flow back into Northampton County. It again turns NE to flow back into Virginia, where it enters Fontaine Creek. It appears on the map of the North Carolina-Virginia line prepared by William Byrd in 1728.

label: Bechewa Creek
description: rises in W Forsyth County and flows SW into Yadkin River. Appears as Bathsheba Creek on Collet map, 1770, and as Barshavia Creek on MacRae map, 1833.

label: Beck
description: community in N Wake County served by post office, 1882-1903.

label: Beck Mountain
description: a granite formation in SW Chatham County.

label: Beck Springs
description: See Bennett.

label: Beckham Millpond
description: See South Lake.

label: Beckon Mill
description: See South Lake.

label: Becks Bald
description: peak on Hughes Ridge, N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Alt. 5,022.

label: Becks Branch
description: rises in NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows S into Oconaluftee River.

label: Beckwith
description: community in E Beaufort County.

label: Beddingfield Creek
description: rises in E Wake County and flows SE into Johnston County, where it turns N and flows into Neuse River.

label: Bedford County
description: A bill was introduced in the Assembly on November 23, 1768, to create Bedford County and Trinity Parish from parts of Rowan and Orange Counties, but the bill was rejected on December 1. The Bethabara Diary (Records of the Moravians, 1, 381) for December 18, however, reports that a county by the name was est. "last year" in "Lord Granville's part of the Province." Another bill to erect a Bedford County and St. John Parish from the upper part of Tyrrell County and the lower part of Halifax County was considered on November 6, 1769, but it was not passed. The name probably was intended to honor John Russell, Duke of Bedford (1710-71), Lord President of the Council, 1763-65.

label: Bee Branch
description: rises in central Madison County between Red Hill Knob and Lisenbee Ridge and flows SW into Ammons Branch.

label: Bee Branch
description: rises in N Buncombe County near Rattlesnake Ridge and flows SW into Reems Creek.

label: Bee Cove Knob
description: N Graham County on the NE end of Bee Cove Lead.

label: Bee Cove Lead
description: extends NE from Yellow Creek to Bee Cove Knob in N Graham County.

label: Bee Creek
description: rises in central Graham County and flows NW into Yellow Creek.

label: Bee Gap
description: at SW end of Sassafras Ridge in SW Graham County.

label: Bee Gum Branch
description: rises in N central Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows SW into Forney Creek.

label: Bee Island Bay
description: swamp in W central Brunswick County. A part of Green Swamp.

label: Bee Knob
description: at the head of West Buffalo Creek in W Graham County.

label: Bee Log
description: community in N Yancey County on Bald Mountain Creek. Named when a fallen tree in the vicinity was discovered to contain bees and honey.

label: Bee Mountain
description: SW Caldwell County between the headwaters of Husbands and Abingdon Creeks.

label: Bee Ridge
description: central Buncombe County NE of Busbee Reservoir.

label: Bee Rock Creek
description: rises in NW McDowell County and flows E into Armstrong Creek.

label: Bee Stump Branch
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows N into South Toe River.

label: Bee Tree Branch
description: rises in N Wilkes County and flows S into Mulberry Creek.

label: Bee Tree Canal
description: W Tyrrell County, flows NE from Lake Phelps to a tributary of Scuppernong River. Dug by slave labor to drain swamplands for cultivation.

label: Bee Tree Creek
description: rises in S Jackson County and flows S into Cedar Creek.

label: Bee Tree Fork
description: rises in NW Transylvania County and flows SE into North Fork French Broad River.

label: Bee Tree Mountain
description: See Craggy Knob.

label: Bee Tree Ridge
description: N Watauga County; extends sw, W of Laurel Branch.

label: Beebranch Mountain
description: central Yancey County near the head of Bee Branch.

label: Beech
description: community in N Buncombe County near the junction of Maney Branch and Reems Creek. Alt. 2,413. Named for large grove of beech trees in the vicinity. Served by post office, 1885-1919.

label: Beech Bottom
description: community in W Avery County.

label: Beech Branch
description: rises in E Nash County and flows SE into W Edgecombe County and SE into Tar River.

label: Beech Cove Branch
description: rises in W Macon County and flows W into Nantahala River.

label: Beech Creek
description: rises in W Haywood County near lat. 35°39'30" N., long. 83°11'30" W., on E slope of Balsam High Top, and flows SE to join Falling Creek in forming Palmer Creek.

label: Beech Creek
description: rises in SE Clay County and flows SW into Towns County, Ga., where it enters Tallulah River.

label: Beech Flats Prong
description: rises in N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park at Luftee Gap and flows SE to join Kephart Prong in forming Oconaluftee River.

label: Beech Gap
description: SE Clay County between Scaly Ridge and Fairfield Ridge.

label: Beech Glen
description: community in E Madison County on Little Ivy Creek. Alt. 2,105.

label: Beech Knob
description: on the Haywood-Transylvania county line. Alt. 5,160-5,180.

label: Beech Mountain
description: on the Avery-Watauga county line. Peak in Avery County. Alt. 5,506.

label: Beech Mountain Township
description: N Avery County.

label: Beech Nursery Creek
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows NW into Cane River.

label: Beech Nursery Gap
description: S Yancey County between Beech Nursery Creek and Big Pine Mountain.

label: Beech Ridge
description: NW Haywood County between Seven Mile Ridge and the head of Big Creek.

label: Beech Spring Gap
description: S Haywood County between Shining Rock and Dog Loser Knob.

label: Beech Swamp
description: rises in central Halifax County and flows SE into Fishing Creek. Appears as Rogers Creek on the Moseley map, 1733, and as Beech Creek on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Beechertown
description: community in NW Macon County on Nantahala River. A large hydroelectric power development is there.

label: Beechflat Creek
description: rises in E Jackson County and flows SW into Mull Creek.

label: Beechgrove
description: community in NW Washington County.

label: Beechnut Gap
description: on the Swain County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park.

label: Beechville
description: community in NE Beaufort County.

label: Beef Market Top
description: NE Jackson County on Grassy Ridge. Alt. 5,040. Said to have been named (1) because deserters from the Confederate army, hiding in the area, stole and slaughtered cattle there; or (2) because a young man killed cattle there that belonged to the father of his sweetheart when he was forbidden by her father to see her again.

label: Beer Rice Gap
description: on the Madison County, N.C.-Unicoi County, Tenn., line.

label: Beetree Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NW into Valley River.

label: Beetree Creek
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows SW into Swannanoa River. An early settlement W of the Blue Ridge Mountains was est. there in 1785.

label: Beetree Reservoir
description: on Beetree Creek, NE Buncombe County. Alt. 2,669. The 55-acre lake is part of the water system of the city of Asheville.

label: Beetree Ridge
description: extends SE from Candler Knob to Big Creek in NW Henderson County.

label: Begonia
description: community in S Gaston County served by post office, 1880-1905.

label: Belcross
description: community in central Camden County named for Bell family. Post office est. 1882.

label: Belew Creek
description: community in NE Forsyth County. A post office est. 1870. Originally est. as Belews Creek Mill.

label: Belews Creek
description: rises in NE Forsyth, NE Guilford, and SW Rockingham Counties and flows NE across the SE edge of Stokes County and into the Dan River on the Stokes-Rockingham county line. The creek rises independently of East and West Belews Creeks, both of which flow into it. Belews Creek appears on Collet map, 1770.

label: Belews Creek Township
description: NE Forsyth County.

label: Belews Lake
description: on Belews Creek, Rockingham County, was constructed 1970-73 by Duke Power Company. The 3,863-acre lake serves as cooling lake for power plant.

label: Belfast
description: community in E Davidson County served by post office, 1892-1907.

label: Belford
description: community in NW Nash County near the Franklin County line. Named by David Sills, who settled there in 1798, for his home in N England. A post office operated there, 1804-55.

label: Belgrade
description: See Bonarva.

label: Belgrade
description: community in NE Onslow County. Thousands of tons of limestone marl, used in building road foundations and in concrete, are shipped from there annually.

label: Belhaven
description: town in E Beaufort County on Pungo River and Pantego Creek. Alt. 4. Settled about 1890; inc. 1899. Name a combination of the words "belle" and "haven," meaning beautiful harbor. See also Aquascogoc.

label: Bell
description: community in central Buncombe County served by post office, 1883-1902. Named for first postmaster, George H. Bell.

label: Bell Bay
description: in the mainland of SW Hyde County on Pamlico Sound immediately W of Rose Bay. Known as Jasper's Creek in the eighteenth century. The courthouse for Hyde County was located on Jasper's Creek in 1791-92.

label: Bell Branch
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows SE into Beetree Creek.

label: Bell Collar Cove
description: on Shining Creek in S Haywood County.

label: Bell Coney Mountain
description: on the E end of Lizzy Mountain in central Jackson County. Alt. 4,349.

label: Bell Cove
description: site of early settlement on the E end of Bogue Banks, S Carteret County. Name is taken from the fact that a bell in the local church was rung for services. Storms drove out early settlers until settlement of Salter Path, which see.

label: Bell Creek
description: rises in N Cherokee County and flows SE into Garreck Creek.

label: Bell Creek
description: rises in SW Anson County and flows S into Deadfall Creek.

label: Bell Island
description: a peninsula extending from the E mainland of Currituck County into Coinjock Bay and Currituck Sound. Formerly separated from the mainland and called Willowbies Island on the Ogilby map, 1671, in honor of Peregrine Bertie, Lord Willoughby de Eresby (1555-1601), thought to have been a subscriber to the Roanoke voyage of 1585. On the Collet map, 1770, and subsequent maps until MacRae, 1833, the name Betts Island is used. It is now 1½ mi. long and ½ mi. wide. See also Bell's Island.

label: Bell Knob
description: on the Clay-Macon county line.

label: Bell Mountain
description: W Henderson County between Little Willow Creek and South Fork.

label: Bell Point
description: peninsula off N Pamlico County extending into Bay River.

label: Bell River
description: is formed in S Alexander County where Glade Creek enters Lower Little River. It flows S approx. 1½ mi. into Catawba River. Local usage applies the name to Lower Little River S from a point about midway between the mouths of Muddy Fork and Spring Creeks, where N.C. Highway 90 crosses Lower Little River.

label: Bell Swamp
description: community in E central Brunswick County.

label: Bell Swamp Creek
description: rises in E central Brunswick County and flows E into Rices Creek.

label: Bell View
description: community in S Cherokee County.

label: Bell's
description: community in NW Pitt County.

label: Bell's Ferry
description: See Grifton.

label: Bell's Island
description: a real-estate development, E Currituck County on Bell Island, which see. The 1967 General Assembly passed an act under which, by a vote of the residents, Bell's Island may be inc. as a town by resolution of the county commissioners.

label: Bellair
description: community in central Craven County.

label: Bellamy
description: crossroads community in E Robeson County. Alt. 108. Settled about 1910. Named for John D. Bellamy (1854-1932), counsel for the Seaboard Air Line Railroad. Bellamy station, now abandoned, was 2 mi. s.

label: Bellamys Lake
description: about ¾ mi. long, on Rocky Swamp near its confluence with Fishing Creek, SW Halifax County.

label: Bellarthur
description: town in W Pitt County. Settled about 1907. Inc. 1907 as Arthur; named for L. C. Arthur, local landowner and farmer. Name changed to Bellarthur, 1933. Alt. 79.

label: Bellcollar Gap
description: on the Graham-Swain county line between Little Bald and Cheoah Bald.

label: Bellemont
description: community in W central Alamance County, est. as a mill village prior to 1900.

label: Bellevedere Pond
description: N Wayne County in a tributary of Nahunta Swamp.

label: Bellfont
description: See Russellborough.

label: Bellows Bay
description: at the N end of Currituck Sound and mouth of North Landing River; extends into the S tip of MacKay Island in NE Currituck County.

label: Bells Branch
description: rises in central Hertford County and flows SE and NE into Potecasi Creek.

label: Bells Corners
description: See Newport.

label: Bells Creek
description: rises in N Richmond County and flows SE into Rocky Fork Creek.

label: Bells Cross Roads
description: community in SW Iredell County. A post office named Fallstown operated there from 1811 to 1866.

label: Bells Ferry
description: appears on the Moseley map, 1733, across Lockwoods Folly River on the Brunswick, N.C.-Charleston, S.C., road in New Hanover Precinct of Clarendon County. The site is in what is now S central Brunswick County.

label: Bells Island
description: a marshy island in Core Sound about 1 mi. E of Marshallberg in SE Carteret County. Formerly known as Great Marsh.

label: Bells Point
description: the S end of Bells Island, on the W side of Core Sound about 1 mi. E of Marshallberg in S Carteret County. Formerly known as Bell Point, Bell's Point, and Great Marsh Point.

label: Belltown
description: community in central Granville County.

label: Bellview
description: community in N Moore County.

label: Bellvue Mountain
description: central Avery County.

label: Belmont
description: city in E Gaston County. Site of cotton mills in late nineteenth century. Named Garibaldi in the 1870s for the man who built the railroad water tank there. Inc. as Belmont, 1895. Named for August Belmont (1853-1924), New York banker and financier. Roman Catholic St. Mary's College opened there in 1878, chartered 1886; renamed Belmont Abbey College, 1913. Sacred Heart Junior College operated there, 1892-1987. Produces textiles and hosiery. Alt. 685.

label: Belmont Mountai
description: N Henderson County between Clear Creek and Featherston Creek.

label: Belmont-South Rosemary
description: community on the W outskirts of Roanoke Rapids, N Halifax County.

label: Belo
description: community in central Surry County served by post office, 1886-1905.

label: Belva
description: community in N Madison County on Shelton Laurel Creek. Alt. 1,689.

label: Belvidere
description: community in W Perquimans County on the Perquimans River. Settled by Quakers early in the eighteenth century. The Moseley map, 1733, shows "G. Newby's Ferry" at about the site; appears as Newbes Bridge on the Collet map, 1770. A post office, Newby's Bridge, est. there, 1827; changed to Belvidere, 1861.

label: Belvidere Township
description: N Perquimans County.

label: Belville
description: highly developed plantation of 8,000 acres, of which 1,700 were cleared, in Currituck and Pasquotank Counties. Flourished 1757-77. Located on North River, with wharf and shipyard. Owned wholly or in large part by Thomas Macknight. Numerous buildings were scattered throughout the area connected by roads. Canals drained much of the land.

label: Belvoir Township
description: NW Pitt County.

label: Belwood
description: community in NE Cleveland County. Alt. 990. Served by post office, 1882-1954.

label: Bems Creek
description: rises in W Halifax County and flows SE into Little Fishing Creek.

label: Ben Bolen Creek
description: rises in SW Ashe County and flows W into Three Top Creek.

label: Ben Cove Branch
description: rises in E Jackson County and flows SE into Sols Creek.

label: Ben Creek
description: rises in N Macon County and flows NW into Cold Spring Creek.

label: Ben Johnson Lake
description: on Eno River, central Orange County. Formed 1955. Covers 15 acres; max. depth 12 ft. Source of water for town of Hillsborough. Known as Hillsboro Lake prior to February 1956.

label: Benaja
description: community in S Rockingham County served by post office, 1870-1917 and 1921-33. Alt. 687. Store, depot, watering station there served the railroad. Named for the creek.

label: Benaja Creek
description: rises in NE Guilford County and flows NE into Rockingham County, where it enters Haw River. Original name was Benajar. Believed to have been named for the tropical ben tree, plus ajar in the sense of "out of place."

label: Bench Mountain
description: E Macon County between Caler Fork and Mica City Creek.

label: Benge
description: community in S Ashe County near Benge Gap on the Wilkes County line.

label: Benge Gap
description: on the Ashe-Wilkes county line.

label: Bengle Creek
description: See Wolfpen Creek.

label: Benham
description: community in NE Wilkes County between Little Elkin River and Elkin River.

label: Benn Knob
description: mountain on Burke-Cleveland county line. Part of South Mountains. Alt. 2,894.

label: Bennehan
description: community in S Granville County. Named for Bennehan Cameron, planter and University of North Carolina trustee.

label: Bennett
description: community in SE Anson County. Alt. 251.

label: Bennett Branch
description: rises in N Transylvania County near Bennett Gap and flows SE into Cherry Cove Branch.

label: Bennett Branch
description: rises in SE Haywood County and flows NW into East Fork Pigeon River.

label: Bennett Gap
description: N Transylvania County between Looking Glass Creek and Avery Creek. Alt. 3,516.

label: Bennett Knob
description: N Transylvania County on Seniard Ridge S of Big Bear Pen Branch.

label: Bennetts Creek
description: is formed by the junction of Duke, Harrell, and Raynor Swamps in central Gates County. It flows SW and SE into Chowan River. Named for Richard Bennett, governor of Virginia, 1652-55. Appears on the Ogilby map, 1671.

label: Bennetts Creek Landing
description: See Gatesville.

label: Bennetts Millpond
description: on Rockyhock Creek in central Chowan County. Formed about 1856. 2 mi. long and ⅓ mi. wide, centering near lat. 36°09'10" N., long. 76°39'40" W. Covers approx. 50 acres. Max. depth 6 to 8 ft. Probably named for William Bennett (d. 1785), an early owner of the site.

label: Bennies Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows NE into Turtle Pond Creek.

label: Benny Cove
description: extends NW from Benny Ridge to Vengeance Creek in NE Cherokee County.

label: Benny Ridge
description: mountain in Valley River Mountains between Kimsey Cove and Horse Ridge, NE Cherokee County.

label: Bens Creek
description: rises in E Warren County and flows SE into Little Fishing Creek. Mentioned in local records as early as 1764.

label: Bens Ridge
description: SW Buncombe County W of Ripshin Mountain.

label: Bensalem
description: community in W Moore County on the head of Dry Creek. A Presbyterian church was organized there in 1813. Former names were Caledonia (post office, 1828-78) and Bigoak (post office, 1878-1906).

label: Bensalem Township
description: W Moore County.

label: Bensborough
description: See Falkland.

label: Benson
description: town in SW Johnston County. Inc. 1887 and named for M. C. Benson, pioneer settler and landowner. Alt. 245. Produces lumber and apparel.

label: Benson Creek
description: rises in N Surry County and flows SE into Stewart Creek.

label: Bent Creek
description: is formed in N Yancey County by the junction of Left Prong Bent Creek and Right Prong Bent Creek. It flows SE approx. ⅒ mi. into Cane River.

label: Bent Creek
description: rises near Bent Creek Gap, S Buncombe County, and flows NE into French Broad River.

label: Bent Creek Experimental Forest
description: S Buncombe County, a part of Pisgah National Forest.

label: Bent Creek Gap
description: S Buncombe County, near the headwaters of Bent Creek. Alt. 3,270.

label: Bent Fork Gap
description: at the head of Bad Fork in NW Henderson County.

label: Bent Knee Knob
description: on the head of Stevens Creek, N Haywood County, near lat. 35°38'05" N., long. 83°02'30" W., in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Alt. 4,000.

label: Bent Knob
description: central Mitchell County between Ellis Mountain and Toe River.

label: Bent Mountain
description: SW Buncombe County W of Piney Mountain.

label: Bent Ridge
description: S Mitchell County in a bend of North Toe River.

label: Bentley
description: community in S central Alexander County.

label: Benton Branch
description: rises in E Lenoir County and flows NE into Dailys Creek. Probably named for Francis Benton, who was living in the vicinity as early as 1760.

label: Benton Crossroads
description: See Fairview.

label: Benton Heights
description: town in central Union County. Inc. 1913. Merged with city of Monroe in 1945. Alt. 595.

label: Bentonville
description: community in S Johnston County.

label: Bentonville Battlefield
description: State Historic Site, S Johnston County. Scene of Civil War battle, March 19-22, 1865, in which Confederates under Gen. Joseph E. Johnston encountered Federals under Gen. William T. Sherman. Bloodiest battle ever fought on North Carolina soil.

label: Bentonville Township
description: SE Johnston County.

label: Benvenue
description: community in E Nash County between Horn Beam Swamp and Compass Creek. Took its name from the plantation of Benjamin Hickman Bunn, which was named about 1890 for Ben Venue, a small mountain in Perthshire, Scotland.

label: Berea
description: community in W Granville County. Alt. 475. Settled prior to 1870.

label: Bergaw Creek
description: See Burgaw Creek.

label: Berkeley County
description: est. prior to 1691 by the Lords Proprietors of Carolina in what is now E South Carolina. Named for John Berkeley (ca. 1607-78), Baron Berkeley of Stratton, one of the original eight Lords Proprietors.

label: Berkeley Parish
description: Church of England, Perquimans County, was est. in 1701, coextensive with the county. In 1767 it was composed of 900 white taxable "inhabitants in midling Circumstances."

label: Berkeley Precinct
description: See Perquimans County.

label: Berlin
description: See Bina.

label: Bermuda Island
description: in the waters of Kitty Hawk Bay, N Dare County.

label: Bernal Branch
description: rises in W Johnston County and flows SE into Hannah Creek.

label: Bernice
description: community in NE Ashe County.

label: Berry
description: community in central Rockingham County served by post office, 1880-1903.

label: Berry Creek
description: rises in E Macon County and flows NW into Corbin Creek.

label: Berry Gap
description: on the Jackson-Macon county line.

label: Berry Mill
description: community in E Macon County on Watauga Creek.

label: Berry Mountain
description: S Madison County between Dan Payne Mountain and Doctor Mountain.

label: Berry Mountains
description: two adjacent mountains in SE Gaston County on South Fork Catawba River.

label: Berryhill Township
description: former township in SW Mecklenburg County. Now township no. 2.

label: Berrys Gap
description: SW Buncombe County between Long and Young Pisgah Mountains.

label: Berryville
description: See Hickory.

label: Bert Creek
description: rises in SE Graham County and flows SW by Bert Creek Lead into Tulula Creek. Named for Bert Wiggins.

label: Bert Creek Lead
description: SE Graham County between Franks Creek and Bert Creek.

label: Bertha
description: community on W shore of Currituck Sound in central Currituck County.

label: Bertie
description: former town in SE Bertie County. Inc. 1939 and merged with the town of Windsor in 1959. Known earlier as Rosemont.

label: Bertie County (BURR-tee)
description: was formed in 1722 from Chowan County. Located in the NE section of the state, it is bounded by Albemarle Sound, Chowan River, and Washington, Martin, Halifax, Northampton, and Hertford Counties. Area: 721 sq. mi. Named for James Bertie (1673-1735), who held a proprietary share of North Carolina. His brother Henry (1675-1735) appears as a Proprietor in 1728, and it has often been said that the county was named for both men. County seat: Windsor, with an alt. of 10 ft. Townships are Colerain, Indian Woods, Merry Hill, Mitchells, Roxobel, Snake Bite, Whites, Windsor, and Woodville. Site of the home of Nathaniell Batts, first known permanent white settler in North Carolina, which was built by 1655. Produces tobacco, corn, soybeans, peanuts, cotton, hogs, sweet potatoes, poultry, seafood, and lumber. See also Society Parish.

label: Berwick
description: community in W central Bladen County.

label: Bessemer City
description: town in W Gaston County. Inc. 1893. Named for Sir Henry Bessemer (1813-98), discoverer of process for making steel from cast iron. Iron ore had been found in the vicinity, and there were hopes that steel mills might be est. there. Produces textiles, machinery, and chemicals. Alt. 912.

label: Bessie
description: community on the head of Flat Creek in SW Jackson County.

label: Best
description: community in E Wayne County. Named for Henry Best, who had a grant of land there in 1743. Alt. 126.

label: Beston
description: community in SE Wayne County served by post office, 1882-1910.

label: Beta
description: community in N Jackson County on Scott Creek. Alt. 2,145.

label: Bethabara
description: See Old Town.

label: Bethania
description: town in W Forsyth County on Muddy Creek. Settled 1759, inc. 1839, but no longer active in municipal affairs. Named by the Moravians, whose second or "new town" it was, for the biblical town of Bethany. Refugees during the French and Indian War found protection within the Bethania stockade, and many of them remained to build homes there. Alt. 789.

label: Bethania Township
description: NW Forsyth County.

label: Bethany
description: community in N Davidson County. Settled in late eighteenth century by Germans and called Fredericktown. Later known as Possumtown. In 1861 a new church was built and named Bethany, a name soon applied to the community.

label: Bethany Township
description: central Iredell County.

label: Bethel
description: community in NW Watauga County on Rube Creek.

label: Bethel
description: community in S Alexander County.

label: Bethel Church Township
description: a former township in S Cabarrus County. Now township no. 10.

label: Bethel Creek
description: rises in SW Perquimans County and flows SE into Yeopim River.

label: Bethel Hill
description: community in N Person County.

label: Bethel Township
description: W central Bladen County.

label: Bethesda
description: community in SE Durham County.

label: Bethlehem
description: community in S Hertford County.

label: Betsey Gap
description: on Madison-Haywood county line. Alt. 5,895.

label: Betsy Branch
description: rises in central Jackson County and flows NW into Trout Creek.

label: Betsy Ridge
description: N McDowell County, extends S from Woods Mountain.

label: Bett Brook
description: rises in S Catawba County and flows SE into Clark Creek.

label: Bettie
description: community in E Carteret County on E side of North River.

label: Bettie McGee's Creek
description: rises in W Randolph County and flows SW into Uwharrie River. Said to have been named for the second wife (also known as Martha McGee) of William Bell, first sheriff of the county. Cornwallis and troops camped nearby at mill operated by William McGee. Monument at Guilford Courthouse National Military Park in her honor.

label: Bettis Branch
description: rises in N Cherokee County and flows S and SW into Valley River.

label: Betts Branch
description: rises in central Swain County and flows SW into Deep Creek.

label: Betts Island
description: See Bell Island.

label: Betty Branch
description: rises in NW Henderson County and flows SE into Boylston Creek.

label: Betty Branch
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows NE into Savannah Creek.

label: Betty Creek
description: rises in S Macon County and flows SE into Rabun County, Ga., where it joins Darnell Creek in forming Little Tennessee River.

label: Betty Creek Gap
description: at the head of Betty Creek in S Macon County.

label: Betty Gap
description: W Jackson County near the head of Betty Branch. Alt. 3,000.

label: Betty Noland Cliff
description: between Norton Branch and the head of Ammons Branch in SE Macon County.

label: Betty Town
description: See Aurora.

label: Beulah
description: community in SW Hyde County.

label: Beulah Township
description: NE Johnston County.

label: Beulaville
description: town in E Duplin County. Alt. 95. Inc. 1915. Produces apparel.

label: Bev Jones Crossroads
description: community in S Wake County S of Swift Creek.

label: Bevins Branch
description: rises in SE Cherokee County and flows SE and NE into Brendle Branch.

label: Bewes Ordinary
description: appears on the Collet map, 1770, apparently in what is now W Guilford County S of the community of Colfax, E of Deep River, and near Sandy Ridge Church.

label: Biddie Toe Creek
description: rises in W Nash County and flows NE into Tar River.

label: Biddleville
description: community in central Mecklenburg County. Historically black, the area took its name from Biddle University, predecessor institution of Johnson C. Smith University. Served by post office, 1892-1908.

label: Big
description: community in SW Warren County.

label: Big Abrams Gap
description: mountain gap on the Swain County, N.C.-Blount County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park.

label: Big Alamance Creek
description: rises in SE Guilford County and flows NE to join Little Alamance Creek in forming Great Alamance Creek, which see.

label: Big Andy Ridge
description: NE Buncombe County between Little Andy Creek and Walker Branch. See also Point Misery.

label: Big Arm Creek
description: rises in N Johnston County and flows SW into Marks Creek.

label: Big Bald
description: on the Avery-Mitchell county line. Sometimes called Penland Yellow or Big Yellow.

label: Big Bald Branch
description: rises in W Haywood County and flows NW into Caldwell Fork.

label: Big Bald Mountain
description: on the Ashe-Watauga county line E of Long Hope Creek.

label: Big Bay
description: central Columbus County filled with fine sandy loam.

label: Big Bay
description: E central Bladen County.

label: Big Beach
description: a section of outer beach in SW Brunswick County between Holden Beach and Shallotte Inlet.

label: Big Bear Creek
description: rises in NW Stanly County and flows SE into Long Creek.

label: Big Bear Pen Branch
description: rises in N Transylvania County and flows E into Looking Glass Creek.

label: Big Beartrail Ridge
description: S Haywood County, between Right Hand Prong and Little Beartrap Branch.

label: Big Beartrap Branch
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows E into Middle Fork.

label: Big Bearwallow Creek
description: rises in central Transylvania County and flows S into North Fork French Broad River.

label: Big Beaverdam Creek
description: rises in SE Sampson County and flows E into Duplin County, where it enters Rockfish Creek.

label: Big Bend
description: a turn in Pigeon River in N Haywood County near the mouths of Groundhog Creek and Skiffley Creek.

label: Big Black Pine Ridge
description: W Watauga County, extends NW to the Avery-Watauga county line N of Grassy Gap Branch.

label: Big Branch
description: rises in E Wake County and flows N into Walnut Creek.

label: Big Branch
description: rises in N Macon County and flows NW into Cold Spring Creek.

label: Big Branch
description: rises in NE Brunswick County and flows E into Cape Fear River.

label: Big Branch
description: rises in W Avery County and flows SW into Roaring Creek.

label: Big Buckeye Cove
description: SE Haywood County on the head of East Fork Pigeon River.

label: Big Buffalo Creek
description: rises in central Lee County and flows NW into Deep River.

label: Big Bugaboo Creek
description: rises in NE Wilkes County and flows S into Yadkin River.

label: Big Butt
description: on the Madison County, N.C.-Greene County, Tenn., line. Alt. 4,836.

label: Big Butt
description: S Macon County between Mooney Gap and Bearpen Gap.

label: Big Butt Creek
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows NW into Straight Creek.

label: Big Butt Knob
description: on the Buncombe-Yancey county line between Flat Spring Knob and Little Butt Knob.

label: Big Butt Mountain
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. On Mount Sterling Ridge near lat. 35°40'20" N., long. 83°10'10" W.

label: Big Butte
description: mountain on the Buncombe-Yancey county line SW of Flat Springs Gap. Alt. 6,001. Formerly known as Wilson Knob Mountain; also called Yeates Knob.

label: Big Butte Mountain
description: W Avery County.

label: Big Cataloochee Mountain
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. A Balsam Mountain peak, alt. 6,122, near lat. 35°40'25" N., long. 83°10'27" W. Known briefly in the 1890s as Nibb's Knob after a member of the U.S. Geological Survey party attempted to name the peak for himself.

label: Big Chestnut Bald
description: mountain on the Swain County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Alt. 4,970.

label: Big Chinquapin Branch
description: See Chinquapin Branch.

label: Big Colington Island
description: See Colington Island.

label: Big Colly Bay
description: NE Bladen County, approx. 5½ mi. long. Colly Creek rises there. Probably named for the obsolete adjective "colly," meaning grimy or coal-black.

label: Big Cove
description: NE Buncombe County S of Chestnut Cove Ridge.

label: Big Cove
description: SW Buncombe County near the headwaters of Webb Branch.

label: Big Cove Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SW into Dan Holland Creek.

label: Big Crabtree Creek
description: rises in SE Yancey County and flows N on the Mitchell-Yancey county line into North Toe River.

label: Big Craggy
description: See Craggy Dome.

label: Big Creek
description: rises in N Madison County and flows S into Shelton Laurel Creek.

label: Big Creek
description: rises in E Cumberland County and flows NE and SE into South River on the Cumberland-Sampson county line.

label: Big Creek Township
description: NW Stokes County.

label: Big Cypress Swamp
description: rises in S Columbus County and flows S to join Monie Swamp in forming Seven Creeks.

label: Big Dam Branch
description: rises in N Cherokee County in the Snowbird Mountains and flows SW into Hyatt Creek.

label: Big Deserter Island
description: a land formation in S Duplin County surrounded by marsh.

label: Big Dismal
description: a pocosin at the head of Big Swamp, a stream in W Sampson County.

label: Big Dog Mountain
description: in SE Macon County between Cullasaja River and Kettle Rock.

label: Big East Fork
description: a cove on Dry Branch in E Haywood County.

label: Big Elk Creek
description: rises in NE Watauga County and flows SE into South Fork New River at town of Todd.

label: Big Elk Mountain
description: S central Avery County.

label: Big Fall Creek
description: See Honeycutt Creek.

label: Big Falls
description: on Stony Creek in central Alamance County near the confluence with Haw River. A post office existed in the vicinity as early as 1882. See also Hopedale.

label: Big Fat Gap
description: NW Graham County at the head of Bear Creek.

label: Big Flats
description: mountain peak in SE Buncombe County W of Patton Gap in Swannanoa Mountains.

label: Big Flats Branch
description: rises in N Swain County and flows SW into Bone Valley Creek.

label: Big Flatty Creek
description: rises in S Pasquotank County and flows SE into Albemarle Sound. Shown on the Hack map, 1684, as Flatt Creek; on the Moseley map, 1733; and the Collet map, 1770, as Flatty Creek.

label: Big Fork Knob
description: peak on Big Fork Ridge, NE Buncombe County.

label: Big Fork Ridge
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, extending NE from Cataloochee Balsam; a Balsam Mountain summit between Rough Fork and Caldwell Fork. Center near lat. 35°35'40" N., long. 83°07'30" W.

label: Big Garland Gap
description: N Graham County between Sawyer Creek and Stecoah Creek at the SW end of Hogback Mountain.

label: Big Gooseberry Ridge
description: E Jackson County between Frady Creek and Chastine Creek.

label: Big Governors Creek
description: rises in E Moore County and flows NW into Deep River on the Moore-Lee county line. Called Millstone Creek in a 1748 grant to Governor Gabriel Johnston. Named for Johnston, who owned 7,000 acres N of the creek. Appears as Governors Creek on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Big Grassy Creek
description: rises in E central Avery County and flows SW into Linville River.

label: Big Green Mountain
description: SE Jackson County between Little Green Mountain and Panthertown Creek. Alt. 4,100.

label: Big Grill Ridge
description: NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, extending SE from Devils Tater Patch.

label: Big Harris Creek
description: rises in central Cleveland County and flows SE into First Broad River.

label: Big Haw Mountain
description: central Avery County.
