label: Big Head Branch
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows SE into Straight Fork.

label: Big Hogback Creek
description: rises in SE Jackson County and flows SW into Horsepasture River.

label: Big Horse Creek
description: rises in SW Grayson County, Va. and flows SE into N central Ashe County, where it enters North Fork New River.

label: Big Hungry Creek
description: rises in E Henderson County and flows SW into Green River.

label: Big Hungry Mountain
description: E Henderson County at the head of Big Hungry Creek. Alt. 3,006.

label: Big Indian Creek
description: rises in SW Macon County and flows N into Nantahala River.

label: Big Island
description: in Green Swamp, central Brunswick County.

label: Big Ivy Creek
description: See North Fork Ivy Creek.

label: Big Junction
description: a mountain on the Graham County, N.C.-Monroe County, Tenn., line.

label: Big Juniper Creek
description: rises in W Moore County and flows NE into McLendons Creek.

label: Big Kennedy Creek
description: rises in S Yadkin County and flows S into Iredell County. It enters Flat Rock Creek NE of Houstonville.

label: Big Kinnakeet Coast Guard Station
description: SE Hatteras Island in Dare County. First est. as lifesaving station in 1878-79. Lifesaving Service and Revenue Cutter Service joined to form U.S. Coast Guard in 1915. Now decommissioned.

label: Big Kitchens Knob
description: SE Clay County at the NW end of Big Kitchens Ridge.

label: Big Kitchens Ridge
description: SE Clay County between Sassafras Branch and Holden Cove.

label: Big Knob
description: on the N end of Big Ridge in S Jackson County.

label: Big Knob
description: on Snowbird Creek in SW Graham County.

label: Big Lake, The
description: formed by a large rock dam on Long Creek, W Surry County. Covers approx. 30 acres; max. depth 35 ft.

label: Big Laurel
description: peak in SE Clay County on the NW end of Little Kitchens Ridge.

label: Big Laurel Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows NW into Kilby Creek.

label: Big Laurel Creek
description: rises in W Macon County and flows NW into Whiteoak Creek.

label: Big Laurel Creek
description: rises in NW Ashe County and flows SE into North Fork New River.

label: Big Laurel Gap
description: on the McDowell-Yancey county line near the head of Neals Creek. Alt. approx. 3,700.

label: Big Laurel Mountain
description: on the McDowell-Yancey county line.

label: Big Laurel Township
description: former township in N central Madison County; now township no. 10.

label: Big Lick
description: community in SW Stanly County. Inc. 1879; charter repealed 1919. Named because salt in the ground attracted deer and buffalo. See also Oakboro.

label: Big Lick Creek
description: rises in E central Durham County and flows NE into Neuse River.

label: Big Lick Township
description: S central Stanly County.

label: Big Lost Cove Creek
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows N into South Toe River.

label: Big Marsh Swamp
description: rises in Hoke County and flows SE into Robeson County, where it joins Gallberry Swamp in forming Big Swamp.

label: Big Meadow Creek
description: rises in W Stanly County and flows W into SE Cabarrus County, where it enters Rocky River.

label: Big Meadows
description: loamy section between Balls Mountain and Blackwood Mountain on the head of Old Field Creek in S Orange County.

label: Big Milksick Knob
description: on the Clay-Macon county line.

label: Big Mooney Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows SW into Kilby Creek.

label: Big Mountain
description: See Asbury Mountain.

label: Big Mountain Branch
description: rises in W Transylvania County and flows SW into North Fork French Broad River.

label: Big Mountain Creek
description: rises in S Montgomery County and flows SW into Richmond County, where it enters Pee Dee River.

label: Big Mountain Gap
description: central Transylvania County in Big Mountain Ridge, Pisgah National Forest. Alt. approx. 3,060.

label: Big Mountain Ridge
description: central Transylvania County, extends about 2 mi. in a north-south direction. Bounded on the N by Three Forks Mountain. The ridge is a part of Pisgah National Forest.

label: Big Oak Gap
description: W Macon County on Fire Gap Ridge.

label: Big Peachtree Bald
description: in the Valley River Mountains on the Cherokee-Clay county line.

label: Big Peachtree Creek
description: rises in E Franklin County and flows SE into Nash County, where it joins Little Peachtree Creek in forming Stony Creek.

label: Big Pine
description: community on Big Pine Creek in S Madison County. Alt. 2,500. Post office, Big Pine Creek, est. prior to 1882.

label: Big Pine Creek
description: rises in NE Alleghany County and flows W into Brush Creek.

label: Big Pine Creek Township
description: former township in SW Madison County; now township no. 12.

label: Big Pine Fishing Gut
description: a water-filled ditch adjoining the Neuse River in E Durham County.

label: Big Pine Mountain
description: S Yancey County between Beech Nursery Creek and Big Poplar Creek.

label: Big Pine Ridg
description: S Clay County between Rocking Chair Branch and Pounding Creek.

label: Big Piney Branc
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows SE into Flat Creek.

label: Big Piney Ridg
description: NE Buncombe County between Big Piney Branch and Little Piney Branch.

label: Big Pisgah
description: See Mount Pisgah.

label: Big Pisgah Mountai
description: W Transylvania County between Panthertail Mountain and West Fork French Broad River.

label: Big Pocosin
description: sand and swamp area covering approx. 150 sq. mi. in SW Beaufort and NE Craven Counties. Includes Reedy and Blount Pocosins in its N and NW edges. Drained by many tributaries into Neuse River at the SW end and into Pamlico River at the NE end.

label: Big Pond Branch
description: rises in central Columbus County and flows SW into Beaverdam Swamp.

label: Big Poplar Cree
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows NE into Sugar Camp Creek.

label: Big Porpoise Ba
description: in Pamlico Sound on the E side of Goose Creek Island, NE Pamlico County.

label: Big Raft Swamp
description: rises in S Hoke County and flows SE into Robeson County, where it enters Lumber River.

label: Big Rattlesnake Branch
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows S into Swannanoa River.

label: Big Ridge
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. A short spur of Big Fork Ridge extending SE near lat. 35°34'50" N., long. 83°08' W.

label: Big Ridge Mine
description: on the head of Deep Gap Creek, S Haywood County. An old source of feldspar and mica operated most recently during World War II.

label: Big Roan Ridge
description: W Avery County.

label: Big Rock Creek
description: rises in N Mitchell County and flows SW into Toe River.

label: Big Rocky Branch
description: rises in N Madison County and flows SE into White Rock Branch.

label: Big Rocky Creek
description: See Patterson Creek.

label: Big Rough Knob
description: E central Avery County.

label: Big Sandy Creek
description: rises in NE Wilkes County and flows SW into East Prong Roaring River.

label: Big Savanna
description: N Tyrrell County, is a slough extending NE in an arc N of Mills Ridge from near the community of Levels to Alligator Creek.

label: Big Savannah
description: central and NW Pender County. Originally covered over 2,000 acres, lying between 50 and 60 ft. above sea level. A flat, treeless area, surrounded by pine woods. Water table generally at or close to the surface. Much of the Big Savannah has been drained and cultivated. Once noted for the large variety of wildflowers that grew among the grasses. Also known as Burgaw Savannah.

label: Big Scaly
description: peak in SE Clay County at the NE end of Scaly Ridge. Alt. 5,070.

label: Big Shoal Branch
description: rises in SW Macon County and flows E into Big Indian Creek.

label: Big Shoeheel Creek
description: rises in N Scotland County and flows S through W Robeson County into South Carolina, where it enters Little Pee Dee River. See also Maxton.

label: Big Snowball Mountain
description: See Snowball Mountain.

label: Big Spring
description: community in N Jackson County served by post office, 1852-1903.

label: Big Spring Branch
description: rises in W Haywood County and flows SE into Jonathans Creek.

label: Big Spring Creek
description: rises in E Mitchell County and flows S into Hawk Creek.

label: Big Spring Gap
description: E Mitchell County at the head of Big Spring Creek.

label: Big Stamp
description: a peak in the Valley River Mountains on the Cherokee-Clay county line.

label: Big Stamp Knob
description: on the Cherokee-Clay county line.

label: Big Stonehouse Creek
description: See Stonehouse Creek.

label: Big Swag
description: peak of Round Mountain Ridge in NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Alt. 3,685.

label: Big Swag Branch
description: rises in central Jackson County and flows N into Bear Creek.

label: Big Swag Gap
description: See Beech Gap.

label: Big Swamp
description: rises in NW Brunswick County and flows SW into Juniper Creek for a distance of several mi.; it forms a part of the boundary between Brunswick and Columbus Counties.

label: Big Tom
description: peak in Mount Mitchell State Park, S Yancey County. One of two peaks known as Black Brothers until 1947, when renamed in honor of Thomas "Big Tom" David Wilson (1825-1909), bear hunter and guide who found the body of Elisha Mitchell on July 7, 1857, after he had fallen to his death on Mount Mitchell. Known earlier as Hairy Bear Mountain.

label: Big Tomahawk Creek
description: rises in S Sampson County and flows S to join Little Tomahawk Creek in forming Tomahawk Creek.

label: Big Warrior Mountain
description: S Polk County, W of town of Tryon. Named for Big Wayah (wolf), chief of the Cherokee Indians. Alt. 2,466.

label: Big White Oak Creek
description: rises in W Wake County and flows S and SW into Chatham County, where it enters New Hope River.

label: Big White Pocosin
description: sandy pocosin in SE Cumberland County.

label: Big Witch Creek
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows SW into Wrights Creek.

label: Big Witch Gap
description: on the Jackson-Swain county line near the head of Moody Branch.

label: Big Yellow
description: See Big Bald.

label: Big Yellow Bald Mountain
description: W Avery County.

label: Big Yellow Mountain
description: at the junction of Avery and Mitchell Counties, N.C., and Carter County, Tenn. Alt. approx. 5,600. Known also as Bright Yellow Mountain and Averys Bald. See also Rose Ridge.

label: Biggerstaff Branch
description: rises in SE Mitchell County and flows SW into Beaver Creek.

label: Bigoak
description: See Bensalem.

label: Bigspring Gap
description: S Macon County at the head of Pinnacle Branch.

label: Bilboa
description: community in S Durham County near the head of Northeast Creek. Named for the Bilbo family, which lived in the vicinity in the early nineteenth century before moving to Mississippi. Alt. 401.

label: Bilesville
description: See New London.

label: Bill Allen Branch
description: rises in E central Yancey County and flows N into Little Crabtree Creek. Named for Bill Allen, an early settler who raised a large family there.

label: Bill Branch
description: rises in central Catawba County and flows SW into Clark Creek.

label: Bill Cole Mountain
description: N Buncombe County between Bradley and Gentry Gaps. Alt. 3,284. See also Morgan Ridge.

label: Bill Cove
description: E Haywood County between Poplar Cove and James Branch.

label: Bill Davenport Branch
description: rises in SE Mitchell County and flows S into North Toe River.

label: Bill Holt Mountains
description: a short range in the Cane Creek Mountains, S Alamance County.

label: Bill Moore Creek
description: rises in S Buncombe County near Stradley Mountain and flows N into Hominy Creek. Enka Lake is on Bill Moore Creek.

label: Bill Wray Gap
description: S central Yancey County at the SW end of Callaway Mountain.

label: Billet's Bridge
description: See Shiloh.

label: Billie Top
description: a peak on Holland Mountain on the Buncombe-Haywood county line between Newfound Gap and Grassy Top.

label: Bills Branch
description: rises in W Haywood County and flows SW into Evans Creek.

label: Bills Creek
description: rises in NW Rutherford County and flows E into Cove Creek. Named for Rev. William (Billy) Logan, whose brick house still stands nearby.

label: Bills Knob
description: N Haywood County on the E end of Cedar Cliff.

label: Bills Mountain
description: E Henderson County near Henderson Creek.

label: Billy Branch
description: rises in N Transylvania County and flows SW into South Fork Mills River.

label: Billy Cabin Ridge
description: in SE Macon County between Big Creek and Cullasaja River.

label: Billy Cove
description: valley in SE Buncombe County NW of Billy Cove and Billy Cove Knob.

label: Billy Cove Gap
description: S Buncombe County between Billy Cove Knob and Hickory Top.

label: Billy Cove Knob
description: S Buncombe County, SW of Billy Cove Gap.

label: Billy Top
description: N Haywood County on the head of Laurel Branch.

label: Billy's Branch
description: rises in central Carteret County and flows W into Black Creek.

label: Billy's Creek
description: flows between tidal-marsh islands in the mouth of White Oak River in E Onslow County. Named for Billy (William) Russell.

label: Billys Creek
description: rises in N Franklin County and flows NE into Tar River.

label: Biltmore
description: former town in central Buncombe County. Inc. 1893 but since 1929 within the corporate limits of Asheville. Named for the Biltmore Estate, which see. Alt. 1,994. Known as Best as early as 1880, when a post office existed there; named for William J. Best, one of the owners of the Western North Carolina Railroad. Post office operated briefly as Bilton, 1890. See also South Biltmore.

label: Biltmore Estate
description: central Buncombe County on the S outskirts of Asheville. Built for George W. Vanderbilt (1863-1914); the name combines the last part of his family name with more, an old English word for rolling, upland country. The house, in the style of a French chateau, was formally opened in 1895 after 5 years of construction. Handsomely furnished, surrounded by formal gardens, and including adjoining forests, farms, winery, and dairy lands, the estate has been open to the public since 1930.

label: Biltmore Forest
description: a part of the Biltmore Estate in S Buncombe County, approx. 11,000 acres along the Swannanoa and French Broad Rivers. Alt. approx. 2,000-2,300. Est. 1890 on land largely cut over; planting continued until about 1911. Gifford Pinchot, the first trained American forester, planned and directed the work. In 1898 Carl A. Schenck founded the Biltmore School of Forestry there, the first such school in the United States. See also Carl Alwin Schenck Forest.

label: Bina
description: community in N central Ashe County. First known as Berlin but name changed during World War I.

label: Bingham Branch
description: rises in E Alamance County in the N outskirts of Mebane and flows NW into Mill Creek.

label: Bingham Heights
description: community in central Buncombe County NE of Emma. Site of Bingham School, 1891-1928, and residence of teacher Robert Bingham.

label: Bingham Township
description: SW Orange County.

label: Birch
description: community in SW Cherokee County on Beech Creek.

label: Birch Branch
description: See Birch Creek.

label: Birch Cove
description: the valley through which Chairmaker Branch flows in central Clay County.

label: Birch Creek
description: rises in central Pender County and flows SW into Rileys Creek. Now often referred to locally as Birch Branch.

label: Birch Fork Creek
description: rises in NE Rockingham County and flows E into Wolf Island Creek. Originally known as Birchfield Fork Creek.

label: Birch Knob
description: central Clay County at the SE end of Birch Cove.

label: Birch Spring Gap
description: NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Twenty-mile Ridge.

label: Birchfield Branch
description: rises in NW Swain County and flows SE into Fontana Lake.

label: Birchfield Creek
description: rises in W Avery County and flows SE into North Toe River.

label: Birchfield Fork Creek
description: See Birch Fork Creek.

label: Bird Branch
description: rises in N Macon County and flows N into Little Tennessee River.

label: Bird Creek
description: rises in SE Buncombe County and flows NE into McDowell County, where it enters Crooked Creek.

label: Bird Creek
description: rises in W Mitchell County and flows SE into Pigeonroost Creek.

label: Bird Island
description: on the Atlantic Ocean, SW Brunswick County. The W tip of the island is in South Carolina.

label: Bird Islands
description: approx. a dozen small islands on Clam Shoal, in the waters of Pamlico Sound, S Dare County, off the S part of Hatteras Island.

label: Bird Rock Falls
description: W Transylvania County on North Fork French Broad River just below where it is formed by junction of Indian Creek and Shoal Creek. Alt. approx. 2,720.

label: Birdstand Mountain
description: S Haywood County between Little East Fork Pigeon River and West Fork Pigeon River.

label: Birdtown
description: community in E Swain County on Oconaluftee River. Probably named for the Bird Clan, In-a-cheese-quah, one of the original seven clans of the Cherokee Indians. Bird Town is one of the five townships of the Cherokees' Qualla Boundary, which see. Alt. 1,900. See also Oconaluftee River.

label: Birta
description: community in S Pender County served by post office, 1894-1905.

label: Biscoe
description: town in E Montgomery County. Alt. 609. Inc. 1901. Known as Filo until 1895, when it was renamed for Maj. Henry Biscoe, lumber commission merchant. Produces textiles.

label: Biscoe Township
description: E Montgomery County.

label: Bishop
description: community in NE Brunswick County.

label: Bishop Creek
description: rises in SE Pender County and flows S into Topsail Sound.

label: Bishops Cross
description: a community in E Beaufort County. Alt. 12. Perhaps named for the interesting figure, somewhat like a bishop's staff, formed by former railroad intersection and two highways that crossed it.

label: Bismarck
description: community in W Johnston County served by post office, 1886-1903.

label: Bissett Mill Pond
description: S Nash County on Beaverdam Creek. About ¾ mi. long.

label: Biven
description: community in S Brunswick County served by post office, 1898-1904.

label: Bixby
description: community in E Davie County. The first train on that portion of the track ran in 1891. From 1881 to at least 1889, the community was known as Chaplin's Stand. Named by a railroad conductor after he observed a large stock of Bixby Shoe Polish in the community store. Alt. 835.

label: Bizzell Millpond
description: E Wayne County on Walnut Creek. Site of the Dobbs County courthouse, jail, and stocks from sometime after 1758 until 1779. After the formation of Wayne County in 1779, the county court met variously on Little River. The old courthouse, jail, and stocks were sold to Col. William McKinne. The McKinne heirs sold the property to Elijah Bizzell of Duplin County, who moved there and erected a mill in 1839.

label: Black Ankle
description: a strip of deep fertile soil across the S portion of Robeson County. Named for the fact that a plowman's ankles would be black after plowing in the soil.

label: Black Ankle
description: derisive name for an area in S central Randolph County and NE Montgomery County. Named because bootleggers operating there during Prohibition would start fires over a large area when they were operating a still so that officers of the law could not find the still. They were said to have "black ankles" from walking through the ashes of old fires to start new ones. Name also said to derive from fact that gold miners in the area stood in muck.

label: Black Bald
description: S Macon County at the head of Dry Branch. Alt. approx. 5,100.

label: Black Balsam Knob
description: S Haywood County between the headwaters of Yellowstone Prong and Flat Laurel Creek.

label: Black Branch
description: rises in E Clay County and flows SW into Buck Creek.

label: Black Brothers
description: former name of two peaks approx. 1 mi. N of Mount Mitchell, S Yancey County. Renamed Mount Craig and Big Tom, which see, in 1947.

label: Black Camp Gap
description: on the Haywood-Swain county line near the head of Bunches Creek in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Balsam Mountain. A log-house camp was built there for the use of cattle rangers and hunters. A forest fire partially burned the camp, burning off the bark and charring the logs of the cabins. Later campers lodging there got themselves black from contact with the burnt logs, hence the name Black Camp. Alt. 4,492.

label: Black Creek
description: town in S Wilson County named for nearby stream. Alt. 120. Est. 1840 as a station and post office on the Wilmington and Weldon Railroad. Inc. 1870.

label: Black Creek
description: rises in E Carteret County and flows S into Newport River. Sometimes called Black River.

label: Black Creek Swamp
description: appears on the Collet map, 1770, as a fork of East Mingo Branch, which see, lying completely in modern Harnett County between Black River and East Mingo Branch. The particular fork is no longer named on maps.

label: Black Creek Township
description: S Wilson County.

label: Black Dome
description: See Mount Mitchell.

label: Black Fields
description: an area of black, poorly drained soil in E Washington County, covering an area of approx. 6 sq. mi., W of the community of Scuppernong. Mentioned as early as 1868 in local records.

label: Black Fox Ridge
description: S central Burke County.

label: Black Gap
description: on the Clay-Macon county line. Alt. 3,841.

label: Black Gut Creek
description: rises in NW Northampton County and flows S into Roanoke River.

label: Black Jack Branch
description: rises in E Union County and flows E into W Anson County and into Brown Creek.

label: Black Jack Mountain
description: W Randolph County just W of Caraway Mountain in a close group with Slick Rock, Vineyard, and Prickly Pear Mountains.

label: Black Jack Township
description: W central Richmond County.

label: Black Knob
description: SE Buncombe County SW of High Windy peak. Alt. 4,240.

label: Black Lake
description: a natural lake in E central Bladen County with a max. depth of 71 ft. and covering 1,418 acres. Fishing, boating, and swimming. Part of state park system.

label: Black Mine
description: former gold mine in W Union County near the town of Indian Trail.

label: Black Mingle Pocosin
description: N Gates County.

label: Black Mingo
description: See East Mingo Branch.

label: Black Mountain
description: at the head of Black Mountain Branch in S Macon County. Alt. 3,735.

label: Black Mountain
description: N central Alleghany County. Formerly known as Carson Mountain.

label: Black Mountain Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows NE into South Fork [Skeenah Creek].

label: Black Mountain Gap
description: about ¼ mi. NW of Bald Knob, between the Black Mountain on the N and the Blue Ridge on the S on the Buncombe-Yancey county line. Lat. 35°43' N., long. 82°16'45" W. Known originally as Beech Gap, later as Swannanoa Gap, and finally since 1949 by its present name. Alt. approx. 5,200.

label: Black Mountain Natural Area
description: in Pisgah National Forest, Yancey County. Covers 1,405 acres, the watershed of Middle Creek, a tributary of the South Toe River on the E slope of Mount Mitchell. The area was set aside from all commercial use on October 22, 1932, and reserved for scientific study.

label: Black Mountain Township
description: E central Buncombe County.

label: Black Mountains
description: range extending from the Buncombe-Yancey county line NE to the head of Bowlens Creek in S central Yancey County. Among the peaks are Mount Mitchell, Clingmans Dome, Potato Knob, and Mount Craig. Named for the dark green foliage of Fraser fir, which covers the top and sides. Known by the Cherokee Indians as See-noh-ya (dark; night). See also Appalachian Mountains.

label: Black Pine Ridge
description: N Madison County between Dry Creek and Mill Creek.

label: Black Ridge
description: S Yancey County between Lower Creek and Camp Creek.

label: Black River
description: rises in N Harnett County and flows SE across the county into E Cumberland County, where, at the Cumberland-Sampson county line, it joins East Mingo Branch in forming South River.

label: Black River Chapel
description: See Delta.

label: Black River Township
description: NE Cumberland County.

label: Black Rock
description: community and fishery in E Bertie County. Site of Black Rock plantation, home of Thomas Pollock Jr.

label: Black Rock
description: a peak in SE Jackson County between Rye Mountain and Little Green Mountain. Alt. 4,500.

label: Black Swamp
description: rises in W Bladen County and flows W into Big Swamp in Robeson County. Bryants Pond is on Black Swamp.

label: Black Swamp Creek
description: rises in SE Jones County and flows S into White Oak River.

label: Black Wall Street
description: Parrish Street in Durham, center of African American entrepreneurship, ca. 1905. Black-owned businesses such as Mechanics and Farmers Bank and North Carolina Mutual Life Insurance Co. originated there. Booker T. Washington and W. E. B. DuBois chronicled the area's growth.

label: Black Walnut Point
description: E Bertie County on Chowan River between Avoca and Scotch Hall plantations.

label: Blackburn
description: community in SW Catawba County. Alt. 1,000.

label: Blackburn Knob
description: S Watauga County between Middle Fork [South Fork New River] and Matney Branch.

label: Blackjack
description: community in E Pitt County. Served by post office, 1882-1907. Spelled as Blackjack after 1895.

label: Blackjack Mountain
description: W Henderson County at the head of Little Mud Creek.

label: Blackman Crossroads
description: community in S Johnston County.

label: Blackman's Landing
description: See Coniott Landing.

label: Blackman's Mills
description: community in N Sampson County served by post office, 1858-1914.

label: Blacknel
description: community in N Lee County. Named for Tom Blacknal, a free black. Primarily an African American community centered around a church.

label: Blackrock Branch
description: rises in SE Macon County and flows SW into Big Creek.

label: Blackrock Creek
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows NW into Soco Creek.

label: Blackrock Gap
description: S Macon County between Dryman Fork and Ball Creek.

label: Blackrock Knob
description: E Swain County in Yalaka Mountains near the head of Piney Wood Creek. Alt. 4,364.

label: Blackrock Mountain
description: on the Jackson-Macon county line between Granite City formations and Wildcat Gap.

label: Blackrock Ridge
description: N Jackson County, extends N from Scott Creek to Soco Creek.

label: Blacksnake Branch
description: rises in N Transylvania County and flows SE into Turkey Creek.

label: Blackstock Branch
description: rises in N Buncombe County and flows NW into Madison County, where it enters Ivy River.

label: Blackstock Knob
description: on the Buncombe-Yancey county line between Balsam and Rainbow Gaps. Alt. 6,325. Probably named for a surveyor, Nehemiah Blackstock, who worked in the vicinity in 1845.

label: Blackstone
description: community in NE Caldwell County. Named for Sir William Blackstone (1723-80), English jurist, by Col. George N. Folk, who conducted a law school there after the Civil War.

label: Blackwalnut Swamp
description: rises in E Bertie County and flows E into Chowan River.

label: Blackwater River
description: rises in Virginia and flows SW into North Carolina, where it joins the Nottoway River a short distance S of the Virginia line on the Hertford-Gates county line to form the Chowan River. The name appears on the Comberford map, 1657.

label: Blackwater Run
description: rises in S Rowan County and flows S into N Cabarrus County, where it enters Dutch Buffalo Creek. The last Indians in Cabarrus County lived along the stream.

label: Blackwell
description: community in NW Caswell County. A post office operated there, 1830-1909. A tobacco factory also formerly existed there.

label: Blackwell Gap
description: central Cherokee County near the middle of Bates Mountain.

label: Blackwell Mountain
description: a peak on Bates Mountain, central Cherokee County.

label: Blackwell Ridge
description: SW Macon County between Long Branch and Curtis Creek.

label: Blackwood
description: community in S Orange County. Alt. 487.

label: Blackwood Creek
description: rises in central Gaston County near the SW limits of West Gastonia and flows S into Crowders Creek.

label: Blackwood Mountain
description: S Orange County between Mountain Creek and Old Field Creek.

label: Bladen County
description: was formed in 1734 from New Hanover County. Located in the SE section of the state, it is bounded by Sampson, Pender, Columbus, Robeson, and Cumberland Counties. It was named for Martin Bladen (1680-1746), English soldier and politician who was commissioner of trade and plantations, 1717-46. Area: 891 sq. mi. County seat: Elizabethtown, elevation 121 ft. Townships are Abbotts, Bethel, Bladenboro, Brown Marsh, Carvers Creek, Central, Colly, Cypress Creek, Elizabethtown, French's Creek, Hollow, Lake Creek, Turnbull, White Oak, and Whites Creek. Produces turkeys, chickens, tobacco, corn, soybeans, oats, peanuts, grapes, blueberries, hogs, dairy livestock, wood products, and sand for concrete.

label: Bladen Lakes State Forest
description: Bladen County, covers 35,875 acres, of which 1,000 acres around Jones, Singletary and Salters Lakes are reserved for park purposes and in which no cutting is done. Named for the lakes included in the area. Objectives: to build up the growing stock of timber on overcut and previously badly burned areas; to utilize all the resources of the area, including game, forestry demonstration, and recreation. Acquired by the state of North Carolina from the federal government in 1939.

label: Bladenboro
description: town in SW Bladen County. Inc. 1903. Alt. 111. Named for the county. Produces textiles. See also West Bladenboro.

label: Bladenboro Township
description: SW Bladen County.

label: Blades
description: community in E Craven County on Clubfoot Creek.

label: Blaine
description: community in NW Montgomery County. Known as Post Oak prior to 1884, when it was renamed in honor of James G. Blaine (1830-93), Republican nominee for president. Served by post office, 1884-1934.

label: Blaine Branch
description: rises in central Macon County and flows NE into Cartoogechaye Creek.

label: Blaine Knob
description: S Macon County between Jones Creek and North Fork [Skeenah Creek].

label: Blair Channel
description: in Carteret and Hyde Counties, a navigable lane in Ocracoke Inlet running N and S between Wallace Channel and Teaches Hole. Appears on the Price survey of Ocracoke Inlet, 1795, as Ship Channel.

label: Blair Creek
description: rises in S Clay County and flows NE into Hiwassee River.

label: Blair Fork
description: rises in central Caldwell County and flows S and SW into Lower Creek.

label: Blake
description: community in central Sampson County served by post office, 1898-1905.

label: Blake Mountain
description: S Buncombe County N of Skyland.

label: Blakeley County
description: On November 28, 1817, the General Assembly attempted to create a county by the name from a portion of Rowan County. It was intended to honor War of 1812 naval hero Johnston Blakely.

label: Blakeleyville
description: town authorized to be est. and laid off on the lands of Andrew Polk on Little Creek in NW Anson County in 1817. Probably named for Capt. Johnston Blakely, North Carolina naval hero who lost his life at sea in the War of 1812. There is no evidence that the town was est., nor is it known whether there was any connection with the nearby community of Blakely in Montgomery County.

label: Blakely
description: former community in W Montgomery County on Pee Dee River at the mouth of Island Creek. A post office as late as 1822, but abandoned shortly afterward as a result of the depression of 1819. See also Blakeleyville.

label: Blakely's Depot
description: See Garysburg.

label: Blakley
description: community in NW Forsyth County served by post office, 1894-1903.

label: Blalock
description: community in W McDowell County served by post office, 1898-1906.

label: Blanch
description: community in N Caswell County on Dan River. Named for Blanche Moore, niece of D. G. Watkins, who owned the land on which the community developed beginning about 1875. Alt. 750.

label: Blanchards
description: community in S Wake County.

label: Bland
description: community in SE Sampson County served by post office, 1887-1904.

label: Bland Branch
description: rises in S Duplin County and flows SE into Allan Creek.

label: Bland Crossroads
description: community in W Lenoir County.

label: Blankenship Creek
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows NW into Price Creek.

label: Blanket Bottom Creek
description: See Blanket Creek.

label: Blanket Creek
description: rises in SW Forsyth County and flows SW into Yadkin River. Appears as Linviles Creek on the Collet map, 1770; called Blanket Bottom Creek in Moravian records, 1778; and appears as Clements Creek on the MacRae map, 1833.

label: Blanton Branch
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows N into Ochre Creek.

label: Blantyre
description: community in E Transylvania County near the mouth of Gash Creek. Named by C. H. Boswell, railway construction engineer, for his birthplace near Glasgow, Scotland.

label: Blazed Creek
description: rises in NE Macon County and flows SW into Beasley Creek.

label: Blazed Gap
description: on the Macon-Swain county line.

label: Bledsoe Creek
description: rises near Fender Mountain in W Alleghany County and flows SE into Little River.

label: Blennerhassett Island
description: S Madison County in the French Broad River opposite Marshall. The sandy island, approx. ¼ mi. long, probably was named for the island in the Ohio River below Parkersburg, W.Va., where Harman Blennerhassett and Aaron Burr plotted in 1805-1806 to seize an empire in the West.

label: Blevin Branch
description: rises in N Buncombe County and flows SE and W into Panther Branch.

label: Blevine Knob
description: W Yancey County between Edney Branch and Cane River.

label: Blevins
description: community in N Ashe County served by post office, 1889-1906.

label: Blevins Branch
description: rises in N Mitchell County and flows W into Big Rock Creek.

label: Blevins Creek
description: community in central Avery County.

label: Blevins Crossroads
description: community in NE Alleghany County.

label: Blevins Ridge
description: N central Avery County.

label: Blewett Falls Lake
description: on the Pee Dee River in Anson and Richmond Counties. Rocking-ham Power Co. began development of falls for hydro electric power, 1907-1908; Carolina Power and Light Co. (now Progress Energy) took over, 1926. A dam 1,470 ft. long impounds a lake 9.4 mi. long covering 2,500 acres. Named for William Bluit or Blewett (1719-1810), native of England, who owned land there in 1758. Falls, now under the lake, dropped 8 or 9 ft. over a distance of about 1,000 ft.

label: Blewing Creek
description: See Blue Creek.

label: Bliss
description: community in E Surry County served by post office, 1880-1902.

label: Bloat Springs Landing
description: on Cape Fear River in central Bladen County.

label: Block House Creek
description: rises in South Carolina and flows NE into Polk County, where it enters Pacolet River.

label: Blockade Branch
description: rises in W Macon County and flows NE into Choga Creek.

label: Blockade Shoal
description: lies off the NW shore of Roanoke Island, E Dare County, in the waters of Croatan Sound.

label: Blockers
description: See Stedman.

label: Blockersville
description: See Stedman.

label: Blockhouse Mountain
description: NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Jenkins Trail Ridge near lat. 35°33' N., long. 83°42'35" W. Alt. 5,425.

label: Blockhouse Ridge
description: NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a spur of Jenkins Trail Ridge extending SE from Blockhouse Mountain near lat. 35°32'40" N., long. 83°41'15" W.

label: Blood Camp Ridge
description: central Avery County.

label: Blood Creek
description: rises in SW Wilkes County and flows N into W. Kerr Scott Reservoir.

label: Bloodrun Creek
description: rises in W Chatham County and flows SW into Brush Creek. Local tradition says that a "hot skirmish" occurred between small bands of Whigs and Tories during the Revolutionary War. Each side, not wishing to reveal its losses, buried its dead secretly. One of the sites selected as a burying ground was near the small stream, and it was given its present name to commemorate the shedding of blood in battle.

label: Bloody Bluff
description: S Sampson County overlooking Black River.

label: Bloody Fork
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows NW into Cane River.

label: Bloody Rock
description: near Cullasaja, E Macon County. A blood-colored liquid oozing from the granite rock is said by legend to mark the site where a young man of the community was murdered by a jealous rival for the affections of a local lass.

label: Bloomery Swamp
description: is formed by the junction of Millstone and Juniper Creeks in NW Wilson County. It flows SE into Contentnea Creek. Known prior to 1782 as Great Swamp.

label: Bloomingdale
description: community in S Robeson County.

label: Bloomington
description: community in W Stanly County. Probably named for an early operator of a cotton gin.

label: Blossie Creek
description: waterway off Roanoke Bay separating Off Island from Bodie Island, E Dare County.

label: Blossom Swamp
description: rises in S Pender County and flows NE into Trumpeters Swamp. Probably named for Samuel Blossom, a Portuguese emigrant who operated a ferry across the Northeast Cape Fear River in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.

label: Blossomtown
description: community in central Macon County on a tributary of Cartoogechaye Creek.

label: Blount Pocosin
description: the N section of Big Pocosin in SW Beaufort County.

label: Blounts Creek
description: community in S Beaufort County approx. 2 mi. from the source of the stream for which it is named. Post office est. there about 1894.

label: Blounts Ford
description: See Grifton.

label: Blountsville
description: former town in NW Martin County on the Roanoke River. Est. 1785 on the lands of Whitmel Hill (1743-97) near Hamilton, but probably never developed. A post office, Clark's Store, existed there from 1819 to 1842.

label: Blowing Rock
description: town in S Watauga and N Caldwell Counties near the head of Yadkin River. First settled in 1870; inc. 1889. Named for a peculiar rock formation rising above the Johns River valley that creates a current of air that returns to the sender light articles thrown over the void. Known as Ohlanto by the Indians and the subject of many legends. In 1927 the communities of Green Park, which see, and Mayview Park were annexed. Fort Rollins, used in the Civil War, was located there. Alt. 3,586.

label: Blowing Rock Township
description: S Watauga County.

label: Blowing Spring
description: W Swain County near Nantahala Gorge; its waters fall into Nantahala River.

label: Blue Banks, The
description: high marl bank along Contentnea Creek below Edwards Bridge, Greene-Pitt county line. The name comes from the distinctive color of the formation. The banks are on both sides of the creek but are more prominent on the Pitt County side.

label: Blue Branch
description: rises in N Buncombe County and flows W into French Broad River.

label: Blue Creek
description: rises in E Caldwell County and flows NE into Kings Creek.

label: Blue Gap
description: SW Buncombe County E of Thompson Knob.

label: Blue Mud Creek
description: is formed in N Warren County by the junction of Terrapin and Malones Creeks; it flows N into Smith Creek.

label: Blue Ridge
description: community in E Henderson County. Alt. 2,270.

label: Blue Ridge Cove Creek
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows N into South Toe River.

label: Blue Ridge Gap
description: S Transylvania County in Blue Ridge Mountains near the head of Toxaway Creek.

label: Blue Ridge Island
description: a sandy elevation in the middle of Angola Bay in S Duplin and N Pender Counties.

label: Blue Ridge Mountains
description: is the name applied to the E portion of the Appalachian Mountains, which see, extending from a few mi. N of Harpers Ferry, W.Va., to N Georgia. The average elevation is from 2,000 to 4,000 ft. The highest peaks of the Blue Ridge are in the Black Mountains of North Carolina, which see. The name comes from the hazy blue appearance of the mountains. The Cherokee Indians knew the section of the mountains as Sa-kohna-gas (blue).

label: Blue Ridge Parkway
description: W Haywood County, Great Smoky Mountains National Park, extends SE from Cataloochee Balsam; a Balsam Mountain peak between Straight Creek and Caldwell Fork, center near lat. 35°34'30" N., long. 83°08'40" W.

label: Blue Ridge Pinnacle
description: See Pinnacle.

label: Blue Ridge Township
description: SE Watauga County.

label: Blue Rock Branch
description: rises in E Yancey County and flows W into South Toe River.

label: Blue Rock Knob
description: SE Buncombe County NE of Little Pisgah Mountain.

label: Blue Sea Creek
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows NW into Beech Nursery Creek.

label: Blue Sea Falls
description: on Blue Sea Creek, S Yancey County in Pisgah National Forest.

label: Blue Springs Township
description: SW Hoke County. A part of Robeson County until 1911.

label: Blue Valley
description: joined valleys of East Fork Overflow Creek and West Fork Overflow Creek in SE Macon County.

label: Blue Wing
description: community in NW Granville County served by post office, 1841-1905.

label: Blue Wing Creek
description: rises in E Person County and flows NE into Hyco Creek in Virginia. Mentioned in 1728 by William Byrd. The bluewing was a small duck regarded as a delicacy.

label: Blue's Crossing
description: See Aberdeen.

label: Blue's Mountain
description: an elevation in N Hoke County on the Fort Bragg Military Reservation. Named for the Blue family, former owners.

label: Bluebutton
description: community in S central Camden County, named for the plantation of Stephen Richardson located there in 1722; in turn named for the small periwinkle (Vinca minor) commonly called bluebutton and native to the area. The community was the gathering point, in 1840, for families in the area beginning on their W migration. From 1908 to 1929, the post office name of Bluebutton was Bartlett, for a local family.

label: Bluefield
description: community in S central Bladen County. Named for John Blue.

label: Bluerock Knob
description: E Yancey County near the head of George Fork. Alt. 4,859.

label: Blues Pond
description: W Scotland County on Joes Creek. Covers 30 acres. Formed prior to 1909 and known earlier as Gibsons Millpond.

label: Bluewing
description: community in NW Granville County.

label: Bluewing Mine
description: copper mine on branch of Aarons Creek in NW Granville County. First operated 1898-1900; opened again for a short time during World War I.

label: Bluff
description: community in W Madison County on Meadow Fork. Alt. 2,150.

label: Bluff Branch
description: rises in N Clay County and flows SW into Tusquitee Creek.

label: Bluff Mountain
description: W Madison County near the head of Hickory Ridge Branch. Alt. 4,640.

label: Bluff Mountain
description: SW Ashe County. Alt. 5,073.

label: Bluff Park
description: See Doughton Park.

label: Bluff Point
description: S Chowan County approx. 8½ mi. SE of Edenton, extends into Albemarle Sound. Mentioned in local records from the early eighteenth century; appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Bluff Shoal
description: formed by the merging waters of the Albemarle and Pamlico Sounds, extends from Bluff Point on the S mainland of Hyde County to Royal Shoal on the Carteret-Hyde county line. The name appears as early as the Mouzon map, 1775.

label: Bluffs, The
description: rough, rocky mountain peaks in SW Alleghany County E of the Blue Ridge Parkway near Doughton Park, which see.

label: Bly Gap
description: S Clay County. The Appalachian Trail passes through the gap just N of the Georgia line.

label: Blythe Branch
description: rises in E Transylvania County and flows SW into Lydia Creek.

label: Blythe Mill Creek
description: rises in NW Henderson County and flows SE into French Broad River.

label: Blythe Mountain
description: W Henderson County on Little Willow Creek.

label: Board Camp Creek
description: rises in N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park below Broad Camp Gap and flows W into Forney Creek.

label: Board Camp Gap
description: N Swain County on Forney Ridge in Great Smoky Mountains National Park.

label: Board Cove Branch
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows N into Bunches Creek.

label: Board Gap
description: on Drymans Branch in S Macon County.

label: Boardman
description: town in NW Columbus County on Lumber River. Inc. 1891 as Hub; name changed in 1899 to honor prominent American Baptist clergyman George Dana Board-man (1828-1903). Long inactive in municipal affairs.

label: Boardtree Creek
description: rises in S Macon County and flows SE into Poplar Cove Creek.

label: Boat Island
description: E Onslow County just inside Bogue Inlet. Named because early fishermen pulled boats up there.

label: Boathouse Creek
description: rises in W Carteret County and flows SW into White Oak River.

label: Boatman Branch
description: rises in N Franklin County and flows SE into Sandy Creek.

label: Bob Branch
description: rises in W central Clay County and flows S parallel to and E of Graveyard Ridge into Hiwassee River.

label: Bob Creek
description: rises in NE Pender County and flows S into Angola Creek.

label: Bob Whites Corner
description: community in S Pasquotank County.

label: Bob's Cove
description: site of early settlement on E end of Bogue Banks, S Carteret County. Storms drove out early settlers until settlement of Salter Path, which see.

label: Bob's Knob
description: S Burke County. Alt. 2,000.

label: Bob's Ridge
description: E Haywood County between Big East Fork and Big Cove.

label: Bobbitt
description: community in SE Vance County near Lynch Creek.

label: Bobs Creek
description: rises in E Yancey County and flows NW into South Toe River.

label: Boby Cove
description: between Laurel Mountain and Big Creek in NW Henderson County.

label: Boddies Mill Pond
description: W Nash County on Stony Creek. Covers more than 100 acres; max. depth 15 ft. Owned by Braswell Milling Company and furnishes power for corn mill.

label: Bodie Island
description: (pronounced "body"), one of the Outer Banks, E Dare County. N boundary was formerly New Inlet, now the area around Kitty Hawk. Bounded on the S by Oregon Inlet. Mentioned by John Lawson in 1700. Appears on the Moll map, 1729. Cow Island and Duggs Island, also shown on the Moll map, are now joined with and a part of Bodie Island. See also Etacrewac.

label: Boger City
description: community in central Lincoln County. Named for Robert Boger, who est. a textile mill there. Previously known as Goodsons Store and Goodsonville.

label: Boggan
description: community in central Anson County. Alt. 306. Probably named for Patrick Boggan, pioneer settler. See Wadesboro.

label: Bogue
description: community in W Carteret County. Site of auxiliary air base for Cherry Point Marine Corps Air Station.

label: Bogue Banks
description: barrier beach in S Carteret County forming one of the Outer Banks. It is 25 mi. long and from ½ to 2 mi. wide. Fort Macon is at the E end; the towns of Atlantic Beach, Salter Path, and Emerald Isle are on Bogue Banks. The name appears on the Moseley map, 1733. Josiah Bogue settled in the vicinity in the early eighteenth century. Named for him or for the family.

label: Bogue Inlet
description: an inlet from the Atlantic Ocean into Bogue Sound between Dudley's Island, E Onslow County, and Bogue Banks, SW Carteret County. White Oak River enters the Atlantic Ocean through the inlet. Shown on the De Graffenried map (French text), 1711.

label: Bogue Sound
description: extends from the SW end of Carteret County along its S edge to the SE section of the county at Beaufort and Morehead City. The sound drains into the Atlantic Ocean through Beaufort Inlet, which see.

label: Bogue Swamp
description: rises in N central Columbus County and flows SE into Waccamaw River.

label: Bogue Township
description: central Columbus County.

label: Boiling Springs
description: community in N Cherokee County on Hanging Dog Creek.

label: Boiling Springs Lake
description: town in SE Brunswick County. Inc. 1961.

label: Boiling Springs Township
description: former township in SW Cleveland County, now township no. 2.

label: Bold Branch
description: rises in N Henderson County and flows SE into Clear Creek.

label: Bold Run Branch
description: rises in S Franklin County and flows SW into Wake County, where it enters New Light Creek.

label: Bolden Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NW into Junaluska Creek.

label: Bolick Branch
description: See Anthony Bolick Branch.

label: Bolin Creek
description: rises in SE Orange County on the S slope of Bald Mountain and flows SE, on N side of the town of Chapel Hill, to join Booker Creek in forming Little Creek. Appears as Bollings Creek on a map of Chapel Hill made in 1792 by John Daniel. The Bolling family settled in Orange County in the eighteenth century.

label: Bolin Knob
description: mountain at junction of Burke-McDowell-Rutherford county line. Alt. approx. 2,200. Named for a family living in the area by the late eighteenth century.

label: Bolivia
description: town in E central Brunswick County. Settled in the late nineteenth century and inc. in 1911. Alt. 40. County seat located nearby in 1978.

label: Bollens Run
description: rises in S Granville County and flows S into Tar River.

label: Bollers Knob
description: central Henderson County at the head of Findley Creek.

label: Bolling
description: community in N Halifax County a short distance W of Roanoke Rapids.

label: Bolling Creek
description: See Bolin Creek.

label: Bolton
description: town in NW Columbus County. Settled 1889. Inc. 1915. Named for Bolton Lumber Company. Alt. 66.

label: Bolton Township
description: E Columbus County.

label: Bombay
description: community in SW Randolph County served by post office, 1889-1917.

label: Bona
description: community in SW Chatham County.

label: Bonaparte Landing
description: SW Brunswick County on the Intracoastal Waterway.

label: Bonarva
description: plantation of the Pettigrew family in SE Washington County and W Tyrrell County. Of the various plantation houses of the Pettigrew family, two were on Bonarva. Belgrade, in Washington County, was built about 1796 and is still standing; it was named for the earlier Pettigrew house on Harveys Neck in Perquimans County. Magnolia was built in Tyrrell County, the site of the greater portion of the Pettigrew lands. Scotch Hall was the Pettigrew home in Bertie County. Belgrade is now a part of Pettigrew State Park, which see.

label: Bonarva Canal
description: W Tyrrell County, flows from Lake Phelps NE into Old Canal. Known also as Magnolia Canal. Dug during antebellum era with slave labor to drain swamplands for cultivation.

label: Bond Creek
description: rises in SE Beaufort County and flows N into the mouth of South Creek at Pamlico River.

label: Bonds Ferry
description: See Pamlico River.

label: Bone Camp Branch
description: rises in S Madison County and flows SW into Bull Creek.

label: Bone Valley
description: NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Named after an early settler found the bleached bones of his long-lost cows there.

label: Bone Valley Creek
description: is formed in NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park by the junction of Roaring Creek and Defeat Branch. It flows S into Hazel Creek.

label: Bones Creek
description: rises in NW Cumberland County and flows SE and S into Little Rockfish Creek.

label: Boney Mill Pond
description: on Paget Branch in S Duplin County.

label: Bonlee
description: community in SW Chatham County. Est. 1894 and first known as Dunlap's Mill; in 1898 renamed Causey for Joshua Causey, local resident. Renamed Bonlee in 1910, supposedly for a brand of cloth. Inc. 1913; charter repealed 1936. Alt. 526.

label: Bonner Bay
description: waterway in E Pamlico County between the mouth of Spring Creek and Bay River.

label: Bonner Bridge
description: See Oregon Inlet.

label: Bonnerton
description: community in SE Beaufort County.

label: Bonnets Points
description: appears on the Moseley map, 1733, from what is now SE Brunswick County extending into Cape Fear River between Elizabeth River and Dutchmans Creek.

label: Bonnie Doone
description: community in central Cumberland County NW of Fayetteville near limits of the Fort Bragg Military Reservation. Inc. 1941; charter repealed 1953.

label: Bonsal
description: community in SW Wake County on the head of Tom Jack Creek. Settled 1900. Inc. 1907; charter repealed 1917. Named for the railroad engineer who drove the first train through the area. Alt. 305.

label: Bonus
description: community in N Jones County served by post office, 1888-1903.

label: Boogertown
description: community in S Gaston County at the N end of Jackson Knob, about 3 mi. S of Gastonia.

label: Booker Creek
description: rises in SE Orange County and flows through Eastwood Lake to join Bolin Creek just E of town of Chapel Hill to form Little Creek.

label: Boomer
description: community in S Wilkes County on Warrior Creek, by which name it was known until renamed for "Boomer" Matheson, local postmaster.

label: Boomer Branch
description: rises in N Swain County and flows SE into Proctor Creek.

label: Boomer Inn Branch
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows E into Right Hand Prong [Pigeon River].

label: Boomer Township
description: SW Wilkes County.

label: Boon Hill Township
description: SE Johnston County. See also Princeton.

label: Boon Station
description: community in W central Alamance County.

label: Boon Station Township
description: former township in W central Alamance County, now township no. 3.

label: Boon's Mill Pond
description: W Northampton County on Gumberry Swamp. Covers 100 acres; max. depth 20 ft. Confederates repulsed Union march there on July 28, 1863.

label: Boone
description: town and county seat, central Watauga County. Inc. 1871. Named for Daniel Boone (1734-1820) who, according to tradition, camped there while on a hunting trip. Home of Appalachian State University. The outdoor drama Horn in the West, by Kermit Hunter, has been produced there each summer since 1952. Produces electronics components, apparel, canned foods, wood products, and shoes. Alt. 3,266.

label: Boone Branch
description: rises in N Clay County and flows SE into Tuni Creek.

label: Boone Camp Branch
description: rises in E Watauga County and flows SE into Elk Creek.

label: Boone Cove Gap
description: on the Madison County, N.C.-Unicoi County, Tenn., line.

label: Boone Creek
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows NE into Flannery Fork [South Fork River].

label: Boone Fork
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows NE and N into Watauga River.

label: Boone Ridge
description: W Yancey County between Wolf Branch and Shepherd Branch.

label: Boone Township
description: W Davidson County, named for Daniel Boone, who is said to have lived in a cabin along the banks of the Yadkin River in the area.

label: Boone's Cave
description: on a high bluff overlooking the Yadkin River in W Davidson County is traditionally said to have been occupied by Daniel Boone. It is near Horseshoe Neck, which see, and a park is maintained near the cave by the county.

label: Boone's Fork
description: stream, rises in NW Caldwell County and flows W into Mulberry Creek. Named for Jesse Boone, pre-Revolutionary settler and nephew of Daniel Boone.

label: Boones Crossroads
description: community in SW Northampton County.

label: Boones Gap
description: SW Wilkes County near the headwaters of Warrior Creek. Named for the explorer Daniel Boone.

label: Boonford
description: community in E Yancey County on North Toe River. Named for Daniel Boone, who is said to have forded the river there.

label: Boons Ferry
description: appears on the Collet map, 1770, as being on the Meherrin River between NE Northampton County and NW Hertford County. By 1802 it had ceased operation, and by 1833 Boone Bridge existed at the site. A bridge still crosses the river there.

label: Boons Fork
description: community in central Northampton County.

label: Boonville
description: town in N Yadkin County. Inc. 1895. Named for Daniel Boone (1734-1820), who is said to have camped at the site. Produces textiles and processed grain.

label: Boonville Township
description: NW Yadkin County.

label: Bordensville
description: See Mill Creek.

label: Border
description: community in W Orange County served by post office, 1880-1905.

label: Border Creek
description: rises in E Lincoln County and flows SE into Catawba River.

label: Boring Creek
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows NW into East Fork French Broad River.

label: Boring Mill Branch
description: rises in S Buncombe County and flows SE into French Broad River.

label: Borough, The
description: SW Pender County on Black River near the mouth of Moore's Creek, a shipping point for goods sent by water. Dates from prior to the Revolution. Apparently, site was authorized to be laid off in 1798 for the town of Parkersborough on the land of Hardy Parker. It is not known whether the town was actually established. The remains of an old wharf may still be seen a short distance from the bank of the river. A fishing camp is now operated at the site, and three old roads through the woods converge at the wharf site.

label: Bosley
description: See Wardville.

label: Bost Creek
description: rises in SE Cabarrus County and flows SE into Rocky River.

label: Bostic
description: town in central Rutherford County between Second Broad River and Puzzle Creek. Alt. 923. Inc. 1893. Named for George T. Bostic, first mayor.

label: Bostick's Mills
description: community in N Richmond County served by post office, 1830-1905.

label: Bosts Mills
description: community in SE Cabarrus County on Rocky River, former site of gristmill and sawmill.

label: Boswell
description: community in central Buncombe County W of Asheville near Deaver View.

label: Boteler Peak
description: NE Vineyard Mountain, E Clay County. Alt. 4,500.

label: Bottom
description: community in N Surry County on Beaver dam Creek.

label: Bottomless Pools
description: in Pool Creek, SW Rutherford County at Lake Lure. Formed by whirlpool action of the rushing water in weaker sections of the huge granite rock over which it flows. Three pools now exist, and a fourth apparently is being formed. In 1947 a geologist who studied them reported that the pools may vary in age from 100,000 to a million years.

label: Boulding Creek
description: rises in central Granville County and flows SE into Tar River.

label: Boushell
description: community in E central Wake County.

label: Bowan's Crossing
description: See Icard.

label: Bowans Gap
description: SW Cherokee County at the NE end of Angelico Mountain.

label: Bowden Mountain
description: E Davidson County between the headwaters of Flat Swamp Creek and Fourmile Branch.

label: Bowden Pond
description: on the head of Bear Swamp in W Duplin County.

label: Bowdens
description: community in NW Duplin County. Alt. 167. Settled prior to 1872, inc. 1911, but no longer active in municipal affairs. Named for Capt. James Bowden, who owned land in the vicinity. Railroad name is Bowden.

label: Bowditch
description: community in E Yancey County on Ayles Creek.

label: Boween River
description: rises in S Cleveland County and flows SW into South Carolina, where it enters Broad River.

label: Bowen Point
description: a point of land on the W side of the mouth of Shallotte River. The channel of the Intracoastal Waterway cuts through the point.

label: Bower
description: community in SW Forsyth County served by post office, 1894-1904.

label: Bower's Store
description: See Sparta.

label: Bowers Creek
description: rises in S Swain County and flows NW into Yalaka Creek.

label: Bowers Gap
description: on the Avery-Watauga county line SE of Shawneehaw Creek.

label: Bowies Falls
description: See Buies Falls.

label: Bowlens Creek
description: community in central Yancey County. Formerly known as Athlone.

label: Bowlens Creek
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows NW into Cane River.

label: Bowlens Pyramid
description: peak in S central Yancey County between Jumpoff Gap and the head of George Fork. Alt. 4,908. The northernmost peak in the Black Mountains.

label: Bowles
description: community in central Wilkes County served by post office, 1888-1902.

label: Bowling Green Creek
description: rises in NW Mitchell County and flows SE into Hollow Poplar Creek.

label: Bowman Bluff
description: an elevation in W Henderson County overlooking French Broad River. Named because it was an Indian lookout site.

label: Bowman Gap
description: SW Cherokee County between Angelico Mountain and Pack Mountain. Alt. approx. 3,215.

label: Bowmans Bluff
description: community in W Henderson County near the mouth of Willow Creek. Settled about 1875-80.

label: Bowmore
description: community in S Hoke County.

label: Box Creek
description: rises in N central Rutherford County at Camel Knob and flows S into Second Broad River.

label: Box, P[ort]
description: See P[ort] Box.

label: Boyd
description: community in SW Rockingham County served by post office, 1884-1905. Mill run by J. Wright Moore was nearby.

label: Boyd Branch
description: rises near Little Hickory Top in S Buncombe County and flows SE into Bent Creek.

label: Boyd Creek
description: rises in central Alamance County and flows S into Haw River.

label: Boyd Mountain
description: NW Buncombe County between Cherry and Wade Gaps.

label: Boyd Township
description: NE Transylvania County.

label: Boyd's Ferry
description: See Grimesland.

label: Boyden
description: community in SE Surry County on Yadkin River. Alt. 771.

label: Boyds Crossroads
description: community in E Pitt County.

label: Boyette
description: town in SW Wilson County. Inc. 1887 as Silverboro; name changed 1897 to honor first mayor, Nathan Boyette. Long inactive in municipal affairs.

label: Boyles' Store
description: See Dalton.

label: Boylin
description: community in W Anson County served by post office, 1900-1903.

label: Boylston
description: community in NW Henderson County. Site of numerous unsuccessful attempts to mine gold. Named for Revolutionary War soldier.

label: Boylston Creek
description: rises in NE Transylvania County and flows NE into Henderson County, where it enters French Broad River.

label: Boza Creek
description: rises in NW Rockingham County and flows SW into Mayo River.

label: Bracebridge Hall
description: home of Elias Carr, governor 1893-97, stands 5 mi. SE of Pinetops, S Edgecombe County.

label: Brachcoast Swamp
description: pocosin in E Cumberland County drained by Reese Creek. One of the Carolina Bays, which see.

label: Brack Branch
description: rises in S Madison County and flows SE into Big Pine Creek.

label: Bracken Mountain
description: a ridge approx. 1½ mi. long in W Transylvania County S of and parallel to the headwaters of Tucker Creek. Named for a large coarse fern growing there.

label: Brackens Creek
description: rises in two forks in central Transylvania County; one flows NE and the other SE to join. The creek then flows E into Nicholson Creek.

label: Brackett Township
description: SE McDowell County.

label: Brackettown
description: See Demming.

label: Bracketts Creek
description: rises in S Rutherford County and flows SE into Floyds Creek.

label: Braden Mountain
description: E Cherokee County, extends from the headwaters of Lamb Branch on the S to Slow Creek on the n, due W of Indian Grave Gap.

label: Bradey Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SE into Valley River.

label: Bradford Mountain
description: S Caldwell County. Alt. 1,313. Named for Bennet Bradford, eighteenth-century settler who is buried on its slopes.

label: Bradley Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows SE into Norton Branch.

label: Bradley Butt
description: E Macon County between Fall Branch and Mica City Creek.

label: Bradley Creek
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows SW into East Fork French Broad River.

label: Bradley Creek
description: rises in N Macon County and flows SW into Little Tennessee River.

label: Bradley Fork
description: is formed in NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park by the junction of Chasm Prong and Gulf Prong. It flows SE into Oconaluftee River.

label: Bradley Gap
description: N Buncombe County between Bruce Knob and Bill Cole Mountain.

label: Bradley Mountain
description: E Henderson County between Little Hungry River and Hungry River. Alt. 2,731.

label: Bradley's Store
description: See Kipling.

label: Bradshaw
description: community in SW Orange County served by post office, 1880-1905.

label: Bradshaw Branch
description: rises in S Lincoln County and flows SW into Leepers Creek.

label: Bradshaw Township
description: NW Mitchell County.

label: Bradshaws Millpond
description: S Sampson County, drains SW into Black River.

label: Bragg
description: community in N Scotland County served by post office, 1888-1912.

label: Bragg Crossroads
description: community in S Granville County.

label: Bragtown
description: former community in central Durham County N of the city of Durham, now within the limits of the latter. Also spelled Braggtown.

label: Branchs Store
description: community in N Duplin County.

label: Branchville
description: See Manson.

label: Brand Swamp
description: rises in N Wilson County and flows SE into Cattail Swamp. Named for Benjamin Brand.

label: Brandle Branch
description: rises in SE Cherokee County and flows SE into Little Brasstown Creek.

label: Brandon
description: community in N Ashe County. Alt. approx. 2,850.

label: Brandy Creek
description: rises in W Franklin County and flows NE into Cedar Creek.

label: Brandy Gap
description: in NW Mitchell County at the head of Right Fork [Pigeonroost Creek].

label: Brank Cove
description: the valley through which Brank Cove Branch flows in N Buncombe County, W of Thurz Mountain.

label: Brank Cove Branch
description: rises near Brittain Mountain in N Buncombe County and flows NW into Flat Creek.

label: Brank Mountain
description: N Buncombe County between Pink Fox Cove and Little Middle Mountain.

label: Branning
description: community in N Bertie County served by post office, 1895-1906.

label: Branon
description: community in S central Yadkin County near South Deep Creek.

label: Branson Creek
description: rises in central Onslow County and flows E into New River.

label: Brant Island
description: a tidal marsh island approx. Â½ mi. long in Pamlico Sound, NE Pamlico County off Goose Creek Island.

label: Brantley Island
description: a neck of land in SW Brunswick County between Saucepan Creek and the Intracoastal Waterway.

label: Brassfield
description: community in S Durham County. Named for a local family. Formerly known as Flemington; name changed prior to 1865.

label: Brassfield Township
description: SE Granville County.

label: Brasstown
description: community in SW Clay County on Ledford Branch. Alt. 1,650. Reputedly named because of confusion of two Cherokee words of similar sound but different meaning-itse'yi (a place made green with vegetation) and untsai'yi (brass). The John C. Campbell Folk School, on a 175-acre farm, is there.

label: Brasstown Creek
description: rises in S Clay County and flows NW to the Cherokee-Clay county line, which it forms for a short distance before flowing into Hiwassee River.

label: Brasstown Gap
description: S Clay County on the headwaters of Beach Creek.

label: Brasstown Knob
description: N Jackson County on Coward Mountain.

label: Brasstown Township
description: SE Clay County.

label: Braswell
description: community in NW Columbus County.

label: Braswells Crossroads
description: community in S Halifax County.

label: Brave Mountain
description: on the N end of Buck Mountain in W Haywood County.

label: Bray
description: See Riddle.

label: Brazel Creek
description: rises in S Wake County and flows NE into Sunset Lake.

label: Breakneck Ridge
description: E central Avery County.

label: Breedlove Branch
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows S into Bulldie Creek.

label: Breeze
description: community in W Orange County served by post office, 1892-1905.

label: Brendletown
description: community in E Macon County on Coon Creek.

label: Brett Bay
description: in the waters of Core Sound, NE Carteret County. Formerly known as Britts Bay.

label: Brevard
description: town and county seat, central Transylvania County. Est. as county seat 1861 or 1862; inc. 1889. Named for Ephriam Brevard (1744-81), teacher, secretary of the convention that drew up the Mecklenburg Resolves of May 31, 1775, and Revolutionary surgeon. Home of Brevard College, founded 1853 as Rutherford College, which see; merged in 1934 with Weaver College and took its present name. Summer music camp, begun in 1936, is there. Noted tourist area. Produces chemicals, textiles, and leather products. Alt. 2,230.

label: Brevard Station
description: See Stanley.

label: Brevard Township
description: central Transylvania County.

label: Brewer Branch
description: rises in W Swain County and flows S into Tuckasegee River.

label: Brewers
description: community in N Wilkes County near Double Creek. Alt. 1,450.

label: Briar Branch
description: rises in SE Buncombe County and flows NE into Wolfpit Branch.

label: Briar Creek
description: rises in SE Durham County and flows S into Wake County and into Stirrup Iron Creek.

label: Briar Patch Branch
description: rises in N Madison County and flows SW into Culvin Creek.

label: Briarpatch Ridge
description: S Mitchell County between Middle Fork Grassy Creek and East Fork Grassy Creek.

label: Briary Creek
description: rises in SW Henderson County and flows SW into Transylvania County, where it enters Reasonover Creek.

label: Briary Knob
description: E Haywood County on the head of Pisgah Creek.

label: Brice Creek
description: rises in S Craven County and flows NW into Trent River. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Brice Creek Pocosin
description: SW Craven County.

label: Brick Church
description: community in SE Guilford County. First German Calvinist (German Reformed) church in Guilford County.

label: Brick Kiln Branch
description: rises in NE Onslow County and flows SE into White Oak River.

label: Brick Mill
description: See Hunsucker.

label: Brickhaven
description: community in Chatham County. Center of brick manufacturing.

label: Brickhouse
description: See Savages Crossroads.

label: Brickhouse Point
description: E Pasquotank County extends into the Pasquotank River S of Davis Bay.

label: Brickle Inn
description: See Union.

label: Brickle's Ferry
description: See Brittle's Ferry.

label: Bricks
description: community in N Edgecombe County. Named for Joseph Keasbey Brick, in whose honor an agricultural, industrial, and normal school for blacks was est. there by Mrs. Julia Elma Brewster Brick in 1895. School closed, 1933.

label: Brickton
description: community in N Henderson County. Took its name from former large brick-manufacturing plant.

label: Bridal Veil Falls
description: SE Macon County on Cullasaja River. Water falls 120 ft. See also Cullasaja River.

label: Bridge Branch
description: rises in N Macon County and flows SE into Burningtown Creek.

label: Bridge Creek
description: rises in central Craven County and flows S into Trent River.

label: Bridge Falls
description: SE Haywood County on West Fork of Pigeon River. In a series of falls, water drops between 300 and 400 ft. Named because a bridge crosses the river at the top of the falls.

label: Bridgeport
description: community in central Stanly County served by post office, 1883-1916.

label: Bridgers Creek
description: rises in S Northampton County and flows W into Roanoke River. Appears as Bridges Creek on the Moseley map, 1733. Pulhams Ferry, according to the Collet map, 1770, was operated across the Roanoke River at the mouth of Bridgers Creek. By 1808 and as late as 1833, the ferry was known as Pollock's Ferry, and in 1862 it was known as Devereux's Ferry.

label: Bridgersville
description: town in E Wilson County. Inc. 1925, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Named for John F. Bridgers. Post office operated there, 1889-95.

label: Bridges Camp Gap
description: on the Haywood-Transylvania county line.

label: Bridges Creek
description: See Bridgers Creek.

label: Bridgeton
description: town in central Craven County. Settled about 1900. Inc. 1907. Named for the bridge across the Neuse River that connected it with New Bern. Alt. 8.

label: Bridgewater
description: community in W Burke County on the Catawba River. Originally the name of the plantation of John Rutherford, who named it for Francis Egerton (1736-1803), Earl of Bridgewater, inland navigation expert and canal builder.

label: Bridgewater Reservoir
description: See Lake James.

label: Bridle Creek
description: rises in W Warren County and flows E into Fishing Creek. A bridge across the creek is mentioned in local records as early as 1765.

label: Bridle Ridge
description: extends SE from Yancey County into NW McDowell County between Bee Rock and Cow Creeks.

label: Brief
description: community in N Union County between Red Creek and Duck Creek.

label: Brier Creek
description: rises in NW Cleveland County and flows SW and S into Rutherford County, where it enters First Broad River.

label: Brier Knob
description: on Swain County, N.C.-Blount County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°34'15" N., long. 83°40'48" W. Alt. 5,225.

label: Brier Lick Gap
description: on Swain County, N.C.-Blount County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°32'00" N., long. 83°49'42" W.

label: Brier Ridge
description: N Jackson County between Licklog Creek and Dark Cabin Creek.

label: Briertown Mountain
description: SW Swain County, extends NE beside Nantahala Gorge.

label: Briery Bay
description: a loam-filled bay in S Columbus County.

label: Briery Hall Point
description: a point of land in central Dare County near the NW end of South Lake and its junction with Alligator River.

label: Briery Run
description: rises in N Lenoir County and flows E into Stonyton Creek.

label: Briery Swamp
description: rises in N Pitt County and flows SE into Tranters Creek.

label: Briggs Hollow
description: valley in central Avery County.

label: Briggsville
description: community in SE Madison County served by post office, 1887-1907.

label: Bright
description: community in N Polk County on Lake Adger, Green River.

label: Bright Yellow Mountain
description: See Big Yellow Mountain.

label: Brights Creek
description: rises in NW Polk County and flows SE into Green River.

label: Brights Mill Creek
description: See Mill Creek.

label: Brightwater Branch
description: rises in W Henderson County near Jumpoff Mountain and flows N into Shaw Creek.

label: Brigman Hollow
description: N Madison County on a branch of Rocky Branch.

label: Brim
description: community in NE Surry County near Archies Creek.

label: Brindletown
description: community in SW Burke County. In the heart of the former gold-mining area of the county. A post office operated there, 1829-1907. A former township by the name was abolished in 1885 and merged with Silver Creek Township.

label: Bringles
description: community in SW Davidson County served by post office, 1879-1905.

label: Brinkland
description: community in S Bladen County served by post office, 1874-1903.

label: Brinkleyville
description: community in W Halifax County. Named for Joseph Brinkley, who settled there in 1767. A post office as early as 1822.

label: Brinkleyville Township
description: SW Halifax County.

label: Brinkly
description: See Delco.

label: Bristle Ridge
description: S Macon County between Bates Ridge and Little Tennessee River.

label: Bristol
description: community in N Ashe County. Post office in late nineteenth century.

label: Bristol Branch
description: rises in N Clay County and flows S into Tusquitee Creek.

label: Bristol's Mill Creek
description: rises in N central Burke County and flows S into Lower Creek at Chesterfield. Formerly known as White's Mill Creek, Bullinger's Mill Creek, and Kincaid's Mill Creek.

label: Bristow
description: community in NW Mecklenburg County.

label: Brittain
description: See Westminster.

label: Brittain Cove
description: SE Buncombe County.

label: Brittain Mountain
description: N Buncombe County SW of Watershed Ridge.

label: Brittain Store
description: community in central Burke County.

label: Britten Creek
description: rises in NW Polk County and flows SE approx. 5½ mi. into Green River. Sometimes known as Bullin Creek.

label: Brittle Ordinary
description: See Union.

label: Brittle's Ferry
description: appears on the Collet map, 1770, just above Winton on Chowan River, E Hertford County. Name probably a corruption of the prominent Hertford County name of Brickle.

label: Britton Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows S and SW into Valley River. Panther Den Falls, which see, are on Britton Creek N of Andrews.

label: Britton Mountain
description: S Buncombe County. Alt. 2,530.

label: Brittons Creek
description: rises in NW Bertie County and flows W and S into Roanoke River.

label: Brittons Crossroads
description: See Roxobel.

label: Britts Bay
description: See Brett Bay.

label: Britts Store
description: community in N Hertford County.

label: Britts Township
description: SE Robeson County.

label: Broad
description: community in W Rutherford County.

label: Broad Branch
description: rises in N Mitchell County and flows W into Big Fork Creek.

label: Broad Creek
description: rises in W Carteret County and flows SE into Bogue Sound. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Broad Creek
description: fed by several canals from the Dismal Swamp in N Beaufort County, flows S and E into Pantego Creek.

label: Broad Creek Point
description: peninsula on the E shore of Roanoke Island, E Dare County, extending SE into Roanoke Sound and Broad Creek.

label: Broad Inlet
description: appears on the Moseley map, 1733, in the beach barrier of E New Hanover County between the present Masonboro and Moore Inlet.

label: Broad River
