description: rises in SE Buncombe County and flows SE across NE Henderson County into W Rutherford County; SE to the Polk-Rutherford county line, where it is joined by Green River; SE and NE into Cleveland County; and SE into South Carolina, where it joins Saluda River at Columbia to form the Congaree River. Sometimes known locally as Rocky Broad River and Main Broad River. Known by the Indians as Ess-ee-daw Lake Lure is on Broad River. Appears on the Collet map, 1770. See also Hickory Nut Gorge.

label: Broad River Township
description: SE Buncombe County. Formerly in McDowell County but annexed to Buncombe County by legislative act in 1925.

label: Broad Run
description: rises in E Pitt County and flows SE into Tar River.

label: Broad Shoals
description: community in S Alexander County served by post office, 1881-1904.

label: Broad Swamp
description: W Beaufort County, is the lower course of Hall Swamp. It flows S into Pamlico River.

label: Broadbay Township
description: S Forsyth County. Named for Broadbay, Mass. (now Waldoboro, Maine), the former home of the first settlers of Friedland, a community in the township. See also Friedland.

label: Broadneck Swamp
description: SE Bertie County. Named for its location in a neck of the Roanoke River. See also Town Swamp.

label: Broadway
description: town in E Lee County. Inc. 1907. Settled in the 1870s and named for a broad, level opening in the vast pine forest that covered the area.

label: Broadway Gap
description: S Macon County between Little Scaly Mountain and Fork Mountain.

label: Brock
description: community in N Graham County on Sawyer Creek.

label: Brock Knob
description: on French Broad River in W Henderson County.

label: Brodie
description: former community in S Warren County on Shocco Creek. A post office was est. there in 1879; apparently the community died out after the post office was discontinued in 1913.

label: Brogden
description: community in S Wayne County.

label: Brogden Township
description: S Wayne County. Named for the family of Curtis Hooks Brogden (1816-1901), governor of North Carolina and a native of the county.

label: Broke Yoke Gap
description: on Graham-Swain county line between Tyre Knob and Peachtree Gap.

label: Brokeleg Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows S into Gipp Creek.

label: Bromine-Arsenic Springs
description: See Crumpler.

label: Brompton
description: central Bladen County on Cape Fear River, 4 mi. N of Elizabethtown. Started as a home by Governor Gabriel Johnston (1699-1752) but not completed. Evidence remains of unfinished building.

label: Brook Branch
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows SE into Greens Creek.

label: Brook Cove
description: community in SE Stokes County.

label: Brookford
description: town in W Catawba County, on Henry Fork at site of former Hanging Rock Bridge. Inc. 1907. Alt. 1,000. Named for parts of the name of joint owners of a local mill, Hol brook and Shu ford

label: Brookland
description: community in central Person County served by post office, 1899-1901.

label: Brookride
description: community in NE Watauga County.

label: Brooks Branch
description: rises near Potato Knob in SW Buncombe County and flows SE into New-found Creek.

label: Brooks Cove
description: SW Buncombe County near the headwaters of Little Pole Creek.

label: Brooks Creek
description: rises in E Hertford County and flows SE into Wiccacon River.

label: Brooks Crossroads
description: community in W Yadkin County. Alt. 1,072.

label: Brooks Gap
description: central Graham County on Santeetlah Lake.

label: Brooks Gap
description: on the Buncombe-Haywood county line near the headwaters of South Hominy Creek.

label: Brooks Knob
description: on the Surry-Wilkes county line.

label: Brooks Point
description: off the N shore of Hatteras Island, opposite Cape Hatteras and extending into the waters of Pamlico Sound, S Dare County.

label: Brooksdale
description: community in central Person County. Named for the Brooks family, local landowners and merchants.

label: Brookston
description: community in E Vance County. Post office est. in 1882.

label: Broom Straw Mountain
description: E Madison County between Paint Fork and Crooked Creek.

label: Broomfield Swamp Creek
description: rises in SE Beaufort County and flows E into South Creek.

label: Browders Branch
description: rises in N Columbus County and flows SW into West Prong Creek.

label: Brower Township
description: SE Randolph County.

label: Brower's Mill
description: (or Mills), former community and post office on Fork Creek in SE Randolph County. A post office operated there from 1828, when Alfred Brower was postmaster, until 1910. The name appears on a map of 1919 but apparently is not found after that date.

label: Brown
description: community in S Randolph County served by post office, 1879-1914. Known as Brown's Store until 1895.

label: Brown Branch
description: rises in SW Beaufort County and flows SW into Chocowinity Creek.

label: Brown Cove
description: E Haywood County between Medford Cove and Sorrells Cove.

label: Brown Creek
description: rises in W Transylvania County and flows SE into Parker Creek.

label: Brown Creek
description: rises in N Carteret County and flows N into Neuse River.

label: Brown Fork Gap
description: at the E end of Cheoah Mountains in E central Graham County at the head of Sawyer Creek.

label: Brown Gap
description: at the head of Henson Branch in SE Macon County.

label: Brown Marsh Station
description: See Clarkton.

label: Brown Marsh Swamp
description: rises in SW Bladen County and flows SE into Columbus County, where its name is changed to Red Hill Swamp. Appears as Brown Meadow on the Moseley map, 1733. See also Brown Meadow.

label: Brown Marsh Township
description: S central Bladen County.

label: Brown Meadow
description: appears on the Collet map, 1770, in what is now Columbus County, NW of the headwaters of White Marsh. See also Brown Marsh Swamp.

label: Brown Mountain
description: on the Burke-Caldwell county line approx. 1Â½ mi. W of Wilson Creek. Alt. 2,725. Noted for mysterious lights, known since 1833 in many popular legends. Many explanations have been offered for the lights, among them burning marsh gas, foxfire, and light refraction by the atmosphere of train, automobile, or city lights.

label: Brown Mountain Beach
description: a recreational beach in Wilson Creek in W Caldwell County.

label: Brown Ridge
description: N Avery County.

label: Brown Summit
description: See Browns Summit.

label: Brown's Creek
description: See Browns Swamp.

label: Brown's Crossroads
description: community in NW Randolph County. The former county seat of Johnstonville, which see, was there.

label: Brown's Island
description: S Carteret County, approx. 1½ mi. long, N of the E end of Harkers Island and separated from it by Westmouth Bay and Eastmouth Bay.

label: Brown's Sound
description: S Onslow County. Largely tidal marsh, it lies between Brown's Island and Onslow Beach and the mainland and extends from Bear Inlet to New River Inlet. It empties into the Atlantic Ocean through Bear Inlet, Browns Inlet, and New River Inlet. Now within the limits of Camp Lejeune.

label: Brown's Store
description: See Brown.

label: Browning Branch
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows NW into Richland Creek.

label: Browning Peak
description: See Black Mountain (Jackson-Haywood county line).

label: Browns Creek
description: rises in E Yancey County and flows E into South Toe River.

label: Browns Creek
description: rises in central Bladen County and flows E into the Cape Fear River. Appears as Earthquake Branch on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Browns Ford
description: in Yadkin River, SW Wilkes County. Named for Capt. John Brown, Revolutionary War soldier, who lived nearby and in whose home the first county government was organized in 1778. A bridge was built there after 1900, later replaced by a modern highway bridge.

label: Browns Inlet
description: SE Onslow County between the N end of Onslow Beach and Bear Inlet. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Browns Knob
description: SW Buncombe County between Billy Cove and Sheep Rock. Alt. 3,760.

label: Browns Landing
description: U.S. Lock Number 2 on Cape Fear River in central Bladen County.

label: Browns Mill Creek
description: ises in S Transylvania County and flows NE into French Broad River.

label: Browns Mountain
description: SW Wilkes County between Yadkin River and Long Fork of Beaver Creek. Named for James Brown, eighteenth-century resident who lived at its foot. Alt. 2,075. Joins Jerry Mountain in NE Caldwell County.

label: Browns Siding
description: See Vaughan.

label: Browns Summit
description: community in N Guilford County. Alt. 805. Land there acquired by Jesse Brown, 1858. Named for him in 1863 when Richmond and Danville Railroad was built; the Brown farm was the highest point on the line. Also called Brown Summit.

label: Browns Swamp
description: rises in SE Onslow County and flows SW into Turpentine Creek. Appears in local records as Brown's Creek as early as 1744.

label: Browns Swamp
description: rises in E Cumberland County and flows SE into Big Creek.

label: Browns Turnout
description: See Vaughan.

label: Brownsville
description: community in NE Granville County on Grassy Creek. A post office as early as 1822.

label: Browntown
description: former town in NE Davidson County. Inc. 1843 at the junction of the Fayetteville-to-Salem and the Greensboro-to-Salisbury roads. A center of trade and furniture making until one of the roads was changed in 1859. The coming of the railroad brought a decline to the town and, after the Civil War, it was abandoned. Many of the people moved to what became High Point.

label: Bruce
description: community in W Pitt County. Cottendale, the plantation of the Cotten family (Sallie Southall Cotten, Bruce Cotten, and others) is nearby.

label: Bruce Knob
description: N Buncombe County between Wolfpen Gap and Middle Mountain.

label: Bruce Ridge
description: E Clay County between Glade Branch and Cold Spring Branch.

label: Bruce Township
description: NW Guilford County, named for Charles Bruce, early settler, Revolutionary War soldier, and founder of Bruce's Crossroad, now Summerfield.

label: Bruce's Crossroads
description: See Summerfield.

label: Brumleys Creek
description: rises in NE Caldwell County and flows SE into Lower Creek approx. 3 mi. W of Lenoir.

label: Brummett Creek
description: rises in W Mitchell County and flows SW into Toe River.

label: Brundana
description: community in W Mitchell County.

label: Brunswick
description: former town in SE Brunswick County on Cape Fear River, now a State Historic Site. A museum contains artifacts, and many building sites have been excavated. Settled about 1725 and est. 1745. Named for King George I, Duke of Brunswick and Lunenberg. First abandoned about 1776, but two or three families moved back after the Revolution. By 1830 the town was totally in ruins. During the Civil War, Fort St. Philip (named for St. Philips Church there but also known as Fort Anderson) was constructed over part of the site. Brunswick was the county seat, 1764-79. Several colonial governors resided there. Modern archaeological work has revealed foundations of 23 of 60 colonial-era structures identified at the site.

label: Brunswick County
description: was formed in 1764 from New Hanover and Bladen Counties. In the SE section of the state, it is bounded by the Atlantic Ocean; South Carolina; Columbus, Pender, and New Hanover Counties; and the Cape Fear River. Named for the town of Brunswick, which see. Area: 907 sq. mi. County seat in rural setting near Bolivia. Townships are Lockwood Folly, Northwest, Shallotte, Smithville, Town Creek, and Waccamaw. Produces corn, soybeans, oats, hogs, beef cattle, fishmeal, lumber, fertilizer, hay, tobacco, strawberries, and processed seafood.

label: Brunswick River
description: NE Brunswick County, extends S from Cape Fear River along the W side of Eagles Island and empties into Cape Fear River. Approx. 5 mi. long. The waterway undoubtedly is the Hilton's River discovered by William Hilton in 1663 and described by him in an account published the next year.

label: Brush Creek
description: is formed in E Alleghany County by the waters of Laurel Branch, Little Pine, and Little Glade Creeks. It flows N into Little River.

label: Brush Creek Township
description: E Yancey County.

label: Brush Fence Ridge
description: on the Buncombe-Yancey county line between Point Misery and Balsam Gap.

label: Brush Fork
description: rises in SW Ashe County and flows NE into North Fork New River.

label: Brush Fork Creek
description: rises in central Anson County and flows S into Reedy Fork Creek.

label: Brush Mountain
description: W Randolph County.

label: Brushcreek
description: community in W Chatham County on Little Brush Creek.

label: Brushy Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows NE into Wayah Creek.

label: Brushy Creek
description: rises in S Avery County and flows SW into North Toe River.

label: Brushy Face
description: mountain in SE Macon County between Horseshoe Mountain and Sassafras Knob.

label: Brushy Fork
description: rises in central Watauga County and flows NW into Cove Creek.

label: Brushy Fork Branch
description: rises in E central Forsyth County and flows S and SW into Salem Creek near the E limits of Winston-Salem.

label: Brushy Fork Creek
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows NE into Greens Creek.

label: Brushy Fork Mountain
description: W Jackson County between Savannah Creek and Brushy Fork.

label: Brushy Fork Township
description: W central Watauga County.

label: Brushy Gap
description: NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Shiltoskie Ridge.

label: Brushy Head Mountain
description: NE Cherokee County between Graybeard Creek and Valley River.

label: Brushy Knob
description: NE Buncombe County near the headwaters of Walker Branch.

label: Brushy Mountain
description: See Gilreath.

label: Brushy Mountain
description: N Haywood County between Mount Sterling Creek and Dogwood Flats Creek. Alt. approx. 5,600.

label: Brushy Mountain Township
description: S Wilkes County.

label: Brushy Mountains
description: a low range extending across S Wilkes County, N Alexander County, and into E Caldwell County. Sometimes also described as crossing Yadkin and Surry Counties, with isolated Pilot Mountain included as the E peak. Pore's Knob in Wilkes County, the highest peak, is 2,680 ft.; Hibriten Mountain in Caldwell County is 2,265 ft. Shown on the 1755 ed. of the Fry-Jefferson map.

label: Brushy Ridge
description: NE Buncombe County between Sugar Fork and Laurel Branch.

label: Brushy Ridge
description: SE Polk County on the South Carolina line.

label: Brushy Ridge Branch
description: rises in W Transylvania County and flows SW into Cathey's Creek.

label: Bryan
description: community in E Pitt County.

label: Bryan Creek
description: rises in central Pitt County and flows SE into Tar River.

label: Bryan Township
description: W Surry County.

label: Bryan's Settlement
description: area in Yadkin River valley of NE Davie County. In 1748 Morgan Bryan moved there with his large family. Their holdings totaled over 5,000 acres.

label: Bryant Branch
description: rises in N Davie County near Pino and flows SE approx. 4 mi. into Dutchmans Creek. Named for the Bryant family, which settled in the area prior to 1752.

label: Bryant Mountain
description: central Watauga County N of Howard Creek.

label: Bryant Swamp
description: rises in Big Bay in SW Bladen County and flows W into Robeson County, where it enters Big Swamp.

label: Bryantown
description: community in S Northampton County.

label: Bryants Pond
description: NW Bladen County on Reedy Meadow Creek and Black Swamp. Formed by a dam built about 1860 to create a millpond. Fishing, swimming, and boating.

label: Bryson Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SW into Valley River.

label: Bryson Branch
description: rises in central Swain County and flows SE through Bryson City into Tuckasegee River.

label: Bryson City
description: town and county seat in central Swain County on Tuckasegee River. Alt. 1,736. Inc. 1887 as Charleston. Name changed to Bryson City in 1889 by act of General Assembly; named in honor of Capt. Thaddeus Dillard Bryson (1829-90), one of the founders of the town.

label: Bryson Cove
description: on a tributary of Cowee Creek in N Macon County.

label: Bryson Creek
description: rises in E Transylvania County and flows SE into W Henderson County, where it enters French Broad River.

label: Bryson Knob
description: E Macon County between Mashburn Branch and Cullasaja River.

label: Bryson Lead
description: NW Cherokee County, parallel to Shular Creek and NW of Chestnut Orchard Ridge, Nin Ridge, and Groundhog Ridge.

label: Bryson Mountain
description: N Henderson County between Sitton Creek and Foster Creek.

label: Bubble Branch
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows SE into West Fork Tuckasegee River.

label: Bubbling Springs Branch
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows N into West Fork Pigeon River.

label: Buby Gap
description: on the Jackson-Macon county line.

label: Buchanan
description: community in N Granville County served by post office, 1856-1906.

label: Buchanan Branch
description: rises in SW Clay County and flows SW into Brasstown Creek.

label: Buchanan Falls
description: on Pee Dee River on the Anson-Richmond county line about 1½ mi. N of the South Carolina line.

label: Buchanan Ferry
description: See Diggs Ferry.

label: Buchanan Hollow
description: E Mitchell County between Mine Hill and Sandy Branch.

label: Buchanan's Pond
description: NW Scotland County on a tributary of Gum Swamp Creek. Formed in 1950 and named for owner, D. M. Buchanan. Covers 23 acres; max. depth 12 ft. Fishing, swimming, boating.

label: Buck
description: community in S Wilkes County near Millers Creek.

label: Buck Branch
description: rises in central Wilson County and flows approx. 3 mi. S into Toisnot Swamp, which see. Known as Buckhorn Branch as early as 1754.

label: Buck Cove
description: E Haywood County on the head of Thickety Creek.

label: Buck Cove Mountain
description: E Haywood County between Buck Cove and Rice Cove.

label: Buck Creek
description: rises in N central Carteret County and flows W into South River.

label: Buck Creek
description: See McLendons Creek.

label: Buck Creek Falls
description: See Buck Creek.

label: Buck Creek Gap
description: on the McDowell-Yancey county line between Horse Trail Gap and Hazelnut Gap. Alt. approx. 3,200.

label: Buck Forest
description: mountain, E Transylvania County between Laurel and Tom Creeks.

label: Buck Gap
description: on the Buncombe-McDowell county line S of Sourwood Gap.

label: Buck Gap
description: on the Swain County, N.C.-Blount County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°32'03" N., long. 83°49'20" W.

label: Buck Hill
description: mountain peak in SW Avery County.

label: Buck Hill Gap
description: W Avery County.

label: Buck Hollow Mountain
description: NE Rutherford County at the head of Duncans Creek.

label: Buck Island
description: is a raised area of land surrounded by swamp in Mon Swamp in SE Tyrrell County.

label: Buck Knob
description: W Cherokee County between Shular Creek and Caney Branch.

label: Buck Knob
description: SW Macon County at the head of Allison Creek.

label: Buck Marsh
description: rises in SE Wayne County and flows SE into Duplin County, where it enters Buck Run.

label: Buck Mountain
description: W Lee County. Several very rocky hills, one of which is quite steep, in an area of 3 or 4 acres.

label: Buck Mountain
description: SW Transylvania County, extends SE between the headwaters of Thompson River and Whitewater River.

label: Buck Quarter Creek
description: rises in NE Orange County and flows S into Eno River. It is mentioned in land grants as early as 1750. Sometimes called Buck Water Creek.

label: Buck Ridge
description: E Mitchell County between Gouges Creek and Jackson Branch.

label: Buck Ridge
description: NE Yancey County between Green Mountain and Brush Creek.

label: Buck Ridge,
description: N Haywood County on Chestnut Branch.

label: Buck Run
description: rises in NE Duplin County and flows SW into Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: Buck Shoal
description: on French Broad River in N Henderson County. Named because deer formerly fed on moss growing there. Bill Nye (1850-96), American humorist, lived there from about 1880 until his death.

label: Buck Shoals
description: community in SW Yadkin County on North Hunting Creek. Named for the herds of deer that once gathered in the shoals of the creek.

label: Buck Shoals Township
description: SW Yadkin County.

label: Buck Spring
description: NE Warren County between Hub-quarter Creek and Stonehouse Creek. Formerly the plantation of Nathaniel Macon (1758-1837), member of Congress (1791-1828) and speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives; he is buried there. House burned by vandals, 1977, and reconstructed. Post office operated there from 1901 to 1905. Site owned and maintained by Warren County.

label: Buck Spring Gap
description: on the Haywood-Transylvania county line on Pisgah Ridge just S of Little Pisgah Mountain at the head of Pisgah Creek. Alt. 4,980.

label: Buck Swamp
description: rises in S Wayne County and flows NW into Thoroughfare Swamp.

label: Buck Swamp Township
description: NW Wayne County.

label: Buck Water Creek
description: See Buck Quarter Creek.

label: Buck Water Mountain
description: E Macon County between Little Buck Creek and Katie Creek.

label: Buckeye Branch
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows SE into Raven Fork.

label: Buckeye Cove
description: E Haywood County on the head of Cove Creek.

label: Buckeye Cove
description: NW Haywood County on the head of Big Creek.

label: Buckeye Cove Creek
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows NW into North Fork Ivy Creek.

label: Buckeye Creek
description: rises in S Macon County and flows SW into Tessentee Creek.

label: Buckeye Gap
description: central Watauga County S of Norris Branch.

label: Buckeye Knob
description: N Watauga County between the forks of Fork Ridge.

label: Buckeye Mountain
description: a peak in the Swannanoa Mountains, S Buncombe County between Cedar Cliff and Face Rock.

label: Buckeye Ridge
description: W Madison County between Max Patch Mountain and Roaring Fork Mountain.

label: Buckeye Spring
description: on the Avery-Watauga county line. Source of Buckeye Creek.

label: Buckhead Creek
description: rises in central Cumberland County and flows S into Little Rockfish Creek.

label: Buckhead Swamp
description: rises in SE Bladen County and flows S into Columbus County, where it enters Slap Swamp.

label: Buckhill Branch
description: rises in W Duplin County and flows SW into Buster Hall Branch.

label: Buckhorn
description: community in W Orange County.

label: Buckhorn
description: See Como.

label: Buckhorn Bald
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Forney Ridge. Alt. 4,829.

label: Buckhorn Branch
description: See Buck Branch.

label: Buckhorn Creek
description: rises in SW Gates County and flows SE into Chowan River.

label: Buckhorn Creek
description: rises in SW Wake County and flows SW into SE Chatham County, where it enters Buckhorn Lake on the Cape Fear River.

label: Buckhorn Crossroads
description: community in W Wilson County S of Contentnea Creek and W of Buckhorn Branch.

label: Buckhorn Falls
description: in Cape Fear River at the junction of Chatham, Harnett, and Lee Counties. Mentioned as early as 1819 in a survey of the major rivers of North Carolina. Since 1908 the site of a power-generating plant operated by what is now Progress Energy. Navigation locks built there as early as 1805; iron ore mined nearby during the Civil War.

label: Buckhorn Gap
description: N Transylvania County between the head of Avery Creek and Rich Mountain.

label: Buckhorn Iron Furnace
description: See Cokesbury.

label: Buckhorn Knob
description: N Caldwell County. Named by Bryson Coffey about 1870 for a big pair of antlers that he found there. Alt. approx. 1,500.

label: Buckhorn Lake
description: SE Chatham and NE Lee Counties on Cape Fear River. Formed by a dam constructed in 1907, the lake covers 400 acres, with a max. depth of 21 ft. Used to generate hydroelectric power.

label: Buckhorn Mountain
description: S Macon County between Buckhorn Gap and Cullasaja River.

label: Buckhorn Ridge
description: E Swain County between First Hurricane Branch and Second Hurricane Branch.

label: Buckhorn Swamp
description: rises in NE Robeson County and flows SE into Gallberry Swamp.

label: Buckhorn Township
description: SW Wake County.

label: Buckingham Mountain
description: SW Alamance County.

label: Buckland
description: community in N central Gates County. Alt. 32. Settled prior to 1711.

label: Buckland Mill Branch
description: rises in N Gates County, flows sw, and joins Hacklan Branch in forming Cole Creek. Formerly known as Knotty Pine Creek.

label: Buckle Creek
description: rises in SW Bladen County and flows SE into Pender County, where it enters Lyon Creek.

label: Buckle Swamp
description: rises in SE Bladen County and flows SE into Pender County, where it enters Lyon Creek.

label: Buckleberry Pocosin
description: SE Bertie County.

label: Bucklesberry Pocosin
description: NW Lenoir County. Mentioned in local records as early as 1780. Camp Blackjack (named for the black oak, commonly called blackjack oak), a Civil War training camp on the railroad near La Grange, was in the vicinity.

label: Buckner
description: See Colon.

label: Buckner Branch
description: rises in S central Swain County and flows NE into Tuckasegee River 1½ mi. W of Bryson City.

label: Buckner's Knob
description: See Craggy Pinnacle.

label: Bucks Corner
description: community in W Carteret County N of Pettiver's Creek.

label: Bucks Knob
description: E Madison County near the head of East Fork [Bull Creek].

label: Bucks Peak
description: SE Alleghany County and NE Wilkes County. Also appears on maps as Buck Mountain and state highway maps as Beech Mountain.

label: Buckskin Branch
description: rises in central Duplin County and flows SE into Grove Creek.

label: Buckwheat Knob
description: N Transylvania County on the head of Avery Creek.

label: Bud
description: community in N Ashe County served by post office, 1894-1906.

label: Bud Lowe Gap
description: S Wilkes County near the head of Rocky Creek.

label: Bud Ridge
description: S Buncombe County E of Billy Cove.

label: Buddy Gap
description: S Macon County between Coweeta Creek and Little Tennessee River.

label: Budget Falls
description: in Yadkin River in SE Surry County, W of the junction of Ararat River. Mentioned as early as 1819 in a survey of the rivers of North Carolina.

label: Buena Vista
description: SW Warren County near the Franklin County line, was formerly the home, office, and tavern of Dr. Robert Christian Pritchard. See also Bearpond.

label: Buff Creek
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows S into Scott Creek.

label: Buffalo
description: community in NE Stokes County near the head of Buffalo Creek.

label: Buffalo Branch
description: rises in W Warren County and flows S into Shocco Creek. Mentioned in local records as early as 1764.

label: Buffalo City
description: community on the mainland, W Dare County. Settled 1888. Named for Buffalo City Mills, former sawmill there. Alt. 10.

label: Buffalo Cove
description: community in N Caldwell County. Named for the cove in which many buffalo were killed. Settled late eighteenth century.

label: Buffalo Creek
description: rises in central Franklin County and flows SW into Tar River.

label: Buffalo Creek
description: rises in E Stokes County and flows into Rockingham County and into Mayo River.

label: Buffalo Creek
description: See Warrensville.

label: Buffalo Ford
description: community in SE Randolph County served by post office, 1850-1904. Known as Buffaloford after 1894.

label: Buffalo Island
description: swampy land formation on Potecasi Creek in central Hertford County.

label: Buffalo Island Creek
description: rises in N Rockingham County and flows SE into Dan River.

label: Buffalo Knob
description: a stony elevation on the Cleveland-Lincoln county line.

label: Buffalo Lake
description: W Harnett County on the headwaters of Reedys Swamp. Approx. ½ mi. long. Alt. 293.

label: Buffalo Race Path
description: See Bute County.

label: Buffalo Shoals Creek
description: rises in W Iredell County and flows S into Catawba River.

label: Buffaloford
description: See Buffalo Ford.

label: Buffeys Branch
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows SW into East Fork French Broad River.

label: Buford
description: See Canton.

label: Buford Township
description: S central Union County.

label: Bug Hill
description: community in SE Columbus County.

label: Bug Hill Township
description: SE Columbus County.

label: Buggs Island Lake
description: See Kerr Lake.

label: Buie
description: community in N Robeson County. Inc. 1909. Charter repealed 1947, though previously long inactive in municipal affairs. Railroad name was Buies.

label: Buies
description: See Buie.

label: Buies Creek
description: community in E central Harnett County. Settled in the latter part of the nineteenth century. Inc. 1903; charter repealed 1967. Campbell University is there. Alt. 210.

label: Buies Falls
description: rapids in Cape Fear River in central Harnett County at the junction of Buies Creek with the river. Called Bowies Falls by Hamilton Fulton in his 1819 survey of the rivers of North Carolina.

label: Buies Pond
description: N Robeson County on a branch of Richland Swamp. Covers approx. 150 acres, with a max. depth of 10 to 12 ft.

label: Buladean
description: community in N Mitchell County on Big Rock Creek. Known first as Magnetic City for its location near large deposits of magnetic iron ore. Present name said to have been for Beulah Dean, daughter of the first postmaster.

label: Bull Bay
description: NW Tyrrell County and NE Washington County, formed by the Scuppernong River estuary in Albemarle Sound. Surface area approx, 10,000 acres; max. depth 14 ft.

label: Bull Branch
description: See Millers Creek.

label: Bull Cove
description: SW Macon County on a tributary of Big Indian Creek.

label: Bull Creek
description: rises in N Buncombe County near Bull Mountain and flows S into Swannanoa River. The last buffalo seen in the county was killed by one of the first white settlers in the vicinity, Joseph Rice.

label: Bull Creek
description: rises in NE Washington County and flows NE into Bull Bay.

label: Bull Creek Gap
description: N Madison County between Big Laurel Creek and the head of West Fork [Bull Creek].

label: Bull Creek Township
description: former township in S central Madison County, now township no. 3.

label: Bull Gap
description: N Buncombe County at the W end of Bull Mountain. Alt. 3,177.

label: Bull Head Township
description: NW Greene County.

label: Bull Hill
description: community in SW Northampton County.

label: Bull Hill Mill Pond
description: SW Northampton County on Wheeler Creek. Covers approx. 400 acres; max. depth 12 ft. Partly a natural lake but enlarged by a dam on the creek. Originally known as Lake Witheranna.

label: Bull Mountain
description: S Watauga County S of Sims Creek and E of Laurel Creek.

label: Bull Pocosin
description: N Sampson County bounded on the S by Goshen Swamp, on the W by Ward Swamp and Craddock Swamp, and on the N by Kill Swamp.

label: Bull Point
description: NE Washington County, extends into Bull Bay from the N shore of Bull Creek estuary.

label: Bull Ruffin Mountain
description: SE Watauga County. Alt. approx. 4,100.

label: Bull Run Creek
description: rises in E central Surry County and flows SE into Ararat River.

label: Bull Tail Branch
description: rises in NE Pender County and flows S to join Bullhead Branch in forming Bull Branch.

label: Bull's Bay
description: community in NW Tyrrell County. Called Bay when a post office was there. It is on Bull Bay.

label: Bulla
description: community in central Randolph County served by post office, 1882-1903.

label: Bulldie Creek
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows SE into Raven Fork.

label: Bulldie Ridge
description: NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a spur extending NE from Katalsta Ridge.

label: Bullfrog Creek
description: rises in central Currituck County in Great Swamp and flows S into North River.

label: Bullhead
description: community in W Greene County S of Nahunta Swamp near the Wayne County line. Settled as early as 1769. During the Revolution, as British soldiers approached, a ferocious bull was turned loose to frighten them. The soldiers, however, killed the bull, cut off his head, and placed it on a fence post.

label: Bullhead Branch
description: rises in NE Pender County and flows S to join Bull Tail Branch in forming Bull Branch.

label: Bullhead Creek
description: rises in S Alleghany County and flows S into Wilkes County, where it enters East Prong Roaring River.

label: Bullhead Gap
description: NE Buncombe County between Craggy Dome and Bullhead Mountain.

label: Bullhead Mountain
description: NE Buncombe County in the Great Craggy Mountains. Named for its resemblance to a bull's head. Alt. 5,958.

label: Bullhead Ridge
description: NE Buncombe County between Waterfall and Peach Orchard Creeks.

label: Bullhole, The
description: section of the shoals on the South Yadkin River bordering Davie and Rowan Counties. Lumbering along the river included use of oxen and mule teams to assist work at sawmills. Heavy rains and a swollen river led to loss of a bull ox, swept into a whirlpool. Area now part of park at Cooleemee Falls.

label: Bullin Creek
description: See Britten Creek.

label: Bullinger Mountain
description: E Caldwell County. Alt. 1,595. Probably named for Henry Bullinger, eighteenth-century settler.

label: Bullinger's Mill Creek
description: See Bristol's Mill Creek.

label: Bullock
description: community in NE Granville County. Settled about 1750. Alt. 429.

label: Bullpen Cove
description: SE Haywood County on East Fork Pigeon River.

label: Bullscrape Gap
description: central Avery County. Alt. 3,882. A salt lick there once attracted cattle; bulls scraped the ground with hooves, pawing before charging one another in combat. See also Montezuma.

label: Bulltail Swamp
description: rises in SE Sampson County and flows SE into Duplin County, where it enters Doctors Creek.

label: Bumgardner Branch
description: rises in N Swain County and flows SW into Deep Creek.

label: Bumgardner Ridge
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a spur extending SW from Sunkota Ridge.

label: Bumgarner Branch
description: rises in N Jackson County approx. 2 mi. SE of Sylva and flows SW 1½ mi. into Mill Creek.

label: Bumgarner Gap
description: N Wilkes County between North Fork Reddies River and Burke Mountain. Named for Daniel Bumgarner, early nineteenth-century resident.

label: Bumgartner Mountain
description: peak in South Mountains on Burke-Rutherford county line.

label: Bumplanding Creek
description: rises in SW Currituck County and flows W into North River.

label: Buna Ridge
description: E Madison County parallel to Holland Branch.

label: Bunch
description: community in SW Randolph County served by post office, 1888-1901.

label: Bunches Bald
description: on the Jackson-Swain county line near the head of Madcap Branch.

label: Bunches Creek
description: rises in NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows s, w, and NW into Raven Fork.

label: Buncombe County
description: was formed in 1791 from Burke and Rutherford Counties. Located in the W section of the state, it is bounded by McDowell, Henderson, Haywood, Madison, and Yancey Counties. Named for Col. Edward Buncombe (1742-78), a Revolutionary War soldier. Area: 770 sq. mi. County seat: Asheville, with an elevation of 2,216 ft. Townships are Asheville, Avery Creek, Black Mountain, Broad River, Fairview, Flat Creek, French Broad, Ivy, Leicester, Limestone, Lower Hominy, Reems Creek, Sandy Mush, Swannanoa, and Upper Hominy. Produces tobacco, corn, cattle, printed products, engines, cutlery, wine, apparel, electronics, textiles, nursery products, lumber, and crushed stone. Rep. Felix Walker (1753-1828), in "speaking for Buncombe," gave rise to term "bunk."

label: Buncombe Hall
description: the home of Col. Edward Buncombe of the Continental Line, who was captured at Germantown and died a prisoner in 1778. Stood 1 mi. W of Roper, NW Washington County.

label: Buncombe Horse Range Ridge
description: S Yancey County between South Fork Upper Creek and Right Prong South Toe River.

label: Bundle Mountain
description: N Montgomery County between Buck Mountain and Morris Mountain.

label: Bunn
description: town in S Franklin County. Alt. 295. Settled about 1909; inc. 1913. Named for Green Bunn, local resident.

label: Bunnlevel
description: community in S Harnett County. Est. in 1904 or 1905 around railroad depot. Originally called Bunn's Level after a local resident's flat plot of land. Inc. 1921 as Bunlevel, but recently inactive in municipal affairs. Authorized by General Assembly in 1961 to est. municipal government if approved by vote, but the proposition was defeated.

label: Bunton Creek
description: See Banton Creek.

label: Bunton Island
description: lies off the SW shore of Roanoke Island, E Dare County, in the waters of Croatan Sound.

label: Bunyan
description: community in W Beaufort County. Alt. 14. A post office operated there from 1880 to 1902.

label: Burch
description: community in S Surry County. Alt. 881. A former post office named Rusk operated there, 1851-1951.

label: Burcham
description: community in E Wilkes County served by post office, 1882-1901.

label: Burd Gap
description: SW Macon County at the head of Anderson Branch.

label: Burden
description: community in NW Bertie County.

label: Burden Branch
description: rises in W Wayne County and flows SW into Moccasin Swamp.

label: Burden Creek
description: rises in S Durham County and flows SW into Northeast Creek.

label: Burdett
description: community in NE Mecklenburg County. Served by post office, 1880-1903.

label: Burgaw
description: town and county seat, central Pender County. When the county was formed in 1875, it was directed that the place chosen as a county seat should be named Cowan, but an act of 1877 directed that it should be named Stanford. Burgaw was chosen, however, and an act of the General Assembly of 1879 changed the name Stanford to Burgaw and inc. the town. Burgaw appears on maps as early as 1861. See Burgaw Creek for early uses of the name. Alt. 49.

label: Burgaw Creek
description: rises in central Pender County NE of the town of Burgaw and flows SE into Northeast Cape Fear River. Appears on the Collet map, 1770, as Bargaw Creek and on the Mouzon map, 1775, as Bergaw Creek. Burgaw Plantation in the vicinity appears in records of 1764.

label: Burgaw Savannah
description: See Big Savannah.

label: Burgaw Township
description: central Pender County.

label: Burger Mountain
description: W Cherokee County between Shoal Creek and Apalachia Lake.

label: Burgess
description: community in N side of Harveys Neck in S Perquimans County.

label: Burgin Cove
description: SE Buncombe County between Black Mountain and Ridgecrest.

label: Burgin Cove Branch
description: rises in SE Yancey County and flows NW into Three Forks Creek.

label: Burgoin Gap
description: E Macon County between Rough Knob and Moses Branch.

label: Burke County
description: was formed in 1777 from Rowan County. Located in the W central section of the state, it is bounded by Catawba, Cleveland, Rutherford, McDowell, Avery, and Caldwell Counties. It was named for Thomas Burke (1744-83), member of the Continental Congress and governor of North Carolina. Area: 517 sq. mi. County seat: Morganton, with an elevation of 1,182 ft. Townships are Drexel, Icard, Jonas Ridge, Linville, Lovelady, Lower Creek, Lower Fork, Morganton, Quaker Meadow, Silver Creek, Smoky Creek, Upper Creek, and Upper Fork. Produces corn, soybeans, hay, oats, wheat, poultry, medical supplies, baked goods, textiles, furniture, sand, gravel, and mica.

label: Burke Mountain
description: N Wilkes County extending N between North Fork Reddies River and Mulberry Creek. Probably named for James Burke (died 1776), pioneer settler.

label: Burkemont
description: community in S Burke County near the headwaters of Bailey's Fork.

label: Burkes Creek
description: rises in S Caswell County and flows NE into Pinson Creek.

label: Burkeville
description: community in S Forsyth County served by post office, 1898-1902.

label: Burl Branch
description: rises in E Cherokee County and flows S and SE into Peachtree Creek.

label: Burl Mountain
description: W Henderson County between French Broad River and Johnsons Mill Creek.

label: Burl Mountain
description: N central Transylvania County between King Creek and Southern Mountain.

label: Burleson Bald
description: SW Avery County.

label: Burleson Branch
description: rises in central Yancey County and flows N into Cane River.

label: Burlington
description: city in central Alamance County. About 1851 the North Carolina Railroad built its repair shops there and the name Company Shops was applied to the community until 1887, when a list of names suggested by local citizens was referred to a committee for decision. Burlington is said to have been suggested by Katherine Scales, daughter of Governor Alfred M. Scales. Inc. 1893. Railroad shops moved to Spencer in 1896. A Civil War training camp was est. at Company Shops. Alt. 658. Produces textiles, hosiery, electronics, and paper boxes.

label: Burlington Crossroads
description: community in S Hoke County.

label: Burlington Township
description: former township in central Alamance County, now township no. 12.

label: Burnett Bear Pen Ridge
description: S Yancey County near the head of Big Lost Cove Creek.

label: Burnett Cove
description: E Haywood County on Burnett Creek.

label: Burnett Creek
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows NW into East Fork Pigeon River.

label: Burnett Reservoir
description: NE Buncombe County on North Fork [Swannanoa River] W of Walkertown. A part of the Asheville water system.

label: Burnett Siding
description: community in S Haywood County on West Fork Pigeon River.

label: Burney
description: community in NW Bladen County.

label: Burney Mountain
description: on the Buncombe-Henderson county line.

label: Burningtown
description: community in central Macon County on Burningtown Creek.

label: Burningtown Bald
description: N Macon County between Copper Bald and Burningtown Gap. Alt. 5,115.

label: Burningtown Creek
description: rises in W Macon County and flows NE and NW into Little Tennessee River.

label: Burningtown Falls
description: in Downes Branch in central Macon County.

label: Burningtown Gap
description: N Macon County at the head of Burningtown Creek. Alt. approx. 3,700.

label: Burningtown Township
description: N central Macon County.

label: Burns Creek
description: rises in W Henderson County and flows SE into French Broad River.

label: Burns Gap
description: SW Cherokee County near the headwaters of Shoal Creek.

label: Burns Mountain
description: central Mitchell County between Bandana Hollow and Snow Creek. Appears as Burns Mountain on maps but is known locally as Burnt Mountain.

label: Burnsville
description: town and county seat, central Yancey County. Alt. 2,817. Est. 1833 at the creation of the county. Named for Otway Burns (1775-1850), privateer of the War of 1812 and later member of the General Assembly. Although he was an easterner, he supported the political ambitions of the westerners around the time Yancey County was created. Burnsville was chartered in 1857 but repealed in 1921; rechartered 1922. Produces hosiery, carpets, textiles, and minerals.

label: Burnsville Township
description: central Yancey County.

label: Burnt Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NW into Valley River.

label: Burnt Cabin Gap
description: in SE Jackson County between Panthertown Creek and Little Hogback Mountain.

label: Burnt Chimney
description: See Forest City.

label: Burnt Coat Branch
description: rises in NE Duplin County and flows SW into Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: Burnt Coat Swamp
description: rises in W central Halifax County and flows SW into Beech Swamp. Appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Burnt Hill
description: See Burnthill.

label: Burnt Mill Creek
description: rises in Bear Swamp, SE Chowan County, and flows SE on the Chowan-Perquimans county line into Yeopim River. The Collet map, 1770, shows Mingo Mill on the headwaters of Yeopim River; the present name appears in local records as early as 1800.

label: Burnt Mills
description: community in N central Camden County. Tradition says watermills were destroyed by fire in the vicinity, hence the name. Last mill there discontinued about 1910, but water still flows down the mill race.

label: Burnt Mountain
description: See Burns Mountain.

label: Burnt Ordinary
description: formerly an inn on the post road in what is now N central Warren County, about ¾ mi. NE of the present town of Macon. Appears on the Collet map, 1770. The correct name for the inn is thought to have been Burnet Ordinary.

label: Burnt Pocosin
description: N Sampson County between Little Coharie Creek and Sevenmile Swamp.

label: Burnt Ridge
description: E Yancey County between the head of Browns Creek and the head of Shuford Creek.

label: Burnt Rock Ridge
description: follows the course of Sassafras Creek in SW Graham County.

label: Burnt Shanty Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows S into Valley River.

label: Burnt Shop
description: See Melville.

label: Burnt Spruce Ridge
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur extending SE from Noland Ridge near lat. 35°32'30" N., long. 83°26'20" W.

label: Burnt Stocking Branch
description: central Robeson County.

label: Burnt Swamp
description: rises in W Robeson County and flows SE into Richland Swamp.

label: Burnt Tavern
description: See Clarksville.

label: Burnt Timber Branch
description: rises in E central Avery County and flows S into Wilson Creek.

label: Burntcabin Creek
description: rises in E Clay County and flows S into Shooting Creek.

label: Burnthill
description: community in E Ashe County served by post office, 1899-1914.

label: Burntshirt Mountain
description: NE Henderson County.

label: Burr Mountain
description: N Buncombe County between Dillingham Creek and North Fork Ivy Creek.

label: Burris Creek
description: rises in W Surry County and flows E and NE into Fisher River.

label: Burrtown
description: See Erwinsville.

label: Bursted Rock Creek
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows NW into East Fork French Broad River.

label: Burt
description: community in SW Wake County.

label: Burthen Channel
description: flows through a mass of tidal marsh islands in the extreme W end of Bogue Sound in SW Carteret County. Probably originally known as Borden Channel for William Borden, who owned the neighboring section of Bogue Banks and a plantation on the mainland. The local pronunciation of Borden is Burden, and from Burden the name Burthen derived.

label: Burton
description: community in E Durham County. Alt. 300.

label: Burton Creek
description: rises in E Pamlico County and flows S into Broad Creek.

label: Busbee
description: community in S Buncombe County. Named for the nearby mountain.

label: Busbee Mountain
description: S Buncombe County near the headwaters of Robinson Creek. Named for one Busby, hunter, whose cabin was on its slopes.

label: Bush Arbor
description: community in S Caswell County.

label: Bush Creek
description: rises in N Randolph County and flows SW into Deep River.

label: Bush Hill
description: See Archdale.

label: Bushnell
description: former town in W Swain County on Tuckasegee River. Inc. 1913. Site now under the waters of Fontana Lake.

label: Bushy Fork
description: rises in SW Person County and flows NE into South Flat River.

label: Bushy Fork
description: community in SW Person County.

label: Bushy Fork Township
description: SW Person County.

label: Bushy Ridge
description: W Jackson County between Hog Cove Branch and Sassafras Branch.

label: Busick
description: community in SE Yancey County on Three Forks Creek. Post office serving the community in the late nineteenth century was named Three Forks.

label: Bussels Creek
description: rises in S Wilkes County and flows NE into Hunting Creek.

label: Buster Hall Branch
description: rises in W Duplin County and flows S into Stewarts Creek.

label: Butcher
description: See Stony Knoll.

label: Bute County
description: was formed from Granville County in 1764; named in honor of John Stuart (1713-92), Earl of Bute, who until his resignation in 1763 had been First Lord of the Treasury. The county was divided in 1779 to form Franklin and Warren Counties. The courthouse was ordered to be built on Jethro Sumner's land at a place called Buffalo Race Path; the site is in Warren County approx. 6 mi. SE of Warrenton. See also St. John's Parish, Granville County.

label: Butler
description: See Oakland.

label: Butler Creek
description: rises in W Surry County and flows SE into North Fork Mitchell River.

label: Butler Gap
description: E Yancey County near the head of Long Branch.

label: Butler Island
description: NE Tyrrell County in the mouth of Alligator Creek.

label: Butler Knob
description: peak in the South Mountains, S Burke County. Alt. 2,062.

label: Butler Mountain
description: SE Henderson County.

label: Butler's Mills
description: community in central Montgomery County served by post office, 1827-47.

label: Butlers
description: community in central Bertie County.

label: Butlers Crossroads
description: community in S central Sampson County.

label: Butner
description: community in SW Granville County. State hospital, training school, and factories are there. Camp Butner, which see, activated 1942, closed 1946, named for Maj. Gen. Henry Wolfe Butner (1875-1937), was there. Produces textiles, hosiery. See also Hampton; Knap of Reeds.

label: Butt Mountain
description: W Henderson County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a spur extending SE from Big Butt Mountain on Mount Sterling Ridge, near lat. 35°39'20" N., long. 83°09'10" W.

label: Butte Mountain
description: E Madison County between Holland Branch and Middle Fork.

label: Butter Gap
description: W Transylvania County between Stone Mountain and Cedar Rock Creek.

label: Buttermilk Creek
description: rises in S Caswell County and flows SE into Alamance County, where it enters Haw River.

label: Buttermilk Mountain
description: on Bradley Creek in NW Henderson County.

label: Butters
description: community in W Bladen County. Butters Lumber Company was located there. Alt. 111.

label: Butterwood Creek
description: rises in NW Halifax County and flows SW into Bear Swamp.

label: Butterwood Township
description: W central Halifax County.

label: Button Bay
description: a loam-filled bay in N Columbus County.

label: Button Branch
description: rises in NW Columbus County and flows SW into Dunn Swamp.

label: Buxton
description: plantation house in S Warren County S of the community of Inez; home of John Buxton Williams, a local planter. The house, built in 1850, is still standing.

label: Buxton Woods Coastal Reserve
description: See Hatteras Woods.

label: Buzzard Bay
description: on the sound side of N Bodie Island in E Dare County; opposite the town of Kill Devil Hills and on S coast of Colington Island. See also Colington Island.

label: Buzzard Branch
description: rises in N Franklin County and flows NE into Sandy Creek.

label: Buzzard Knob
description: S Buncombe County NW of Hickory Top.

label: Buzzard Knob
description: SW Macon County at the SW end of Horse Ridge.

label: Buzzard Point
description: a large neck of marsh land on the Roanoke River, SE Halifax County.

label: Buzzard Rock
description: peak on Sevenmile Ridge, E Yancey County near the head of Murphy Branch.

label: Buzzard Roost
description: peak in N Haywood County W of Pigeon River near Big Bend.

label: Buzzard Roost Ridge
description: N Macon County parallel to Mason Branch.

label: Buzzardroost Mountain
description: central Swain County between Middle Peachtree Creek and Canebrake Branch.

label: Buzzards' Rocks
description: near Shulls Mill, S Watauga County.

label: Buzzardtown
description: See Darlington.

label: Byarsville
description: community in S Cleveland County served by post office, 1875-1903.

label: Byers Branch
description: rises in central Clay County and flows SW into Shooting Creek.

label: Byers Creek
description: rises in SW Iredell County and flows S into Davidson Creek.

label: Byers Mountain
description: N Henderson County on Byers Creek.

label: Bynum
description: community in N Chatham County on Haw River. Named for the Bynum family, which est. a cotton mill there. Alt. 322.

label: Bynum Mill Creek
description: rises in S Edgecombe County and flows NE into Town Creek.

label: Bynum's Bluff
description: NE Burke County, promontory alongside Linville Gorge.

label: Byrd
description: community in NE Wilkes County served by post office, 1882-1912.

label: Byrd Pond
description: S Harnett County on Stewarts Creek. Approx. ½ mi. long.

label: Byrds Branch
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows SE into Jacks Creek.

label: Byrds Creek
description: rises in S Person County and flows NE into South Flat River.

label: Byrdsville
description: community in NE Columbus County.

label: Ca-Vel
description: community in central Person County. Post office est. 1948. Formerly known as Bakers. Produces textiles.

label: Cabarrus
description: community in S Cabarrus County.

label: Cabarrus County
description: was formed in 1792 from Mecklenburg County. Located in the S central section of the state, it is bounded by Stanly, Union, Mecklenburg, Iredell, and Rowan Counties. It was named for Stephen Cabarrus (1754-1808), member of the General Assembly and speaker of the House of Commons. Area: 360 sq. mi. County seat: Concord, with an elevation of 704 ft. Townships are nos. 1-12, formerly Rocky River, Poplar Tent, Odell School, Kannapolis, Mount Gilead, Watts Cross Roads, Earnhardts, Mount Pleasant, Smiths, Bethel Church, Baptist Church, and Concord. Reed Gold Mine in the county was the site of the first discovery of gold in North Carolina, 1799. Produces wheat, barley, corn, cigarettes, plastics, cattle, oats, corn, cotton, poultry, dairy products, textiles, and apparel.

label: Cabbage Branch
description: rises in N central Anson County and flows S into Brown Creek.

label: Cabbage Inlet
description: appears on the Moseley map, 1733, in the barrier beach of E New Hanover County between what is now Masonboro Sound and Myrtle Sound. It was still open in 1775 but closed by 1808.

label: Cabe Branch
description: rises in S Swain County and flows NW into Little Tennessee River.

label: Cabin
description: community in E Duplin County on Cabin Creek.

label: Cabin Branch
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows SW into Bradley Fork.

label: Cabin Branch
description: rises in NW Anson County and flows SE into Brown Creek.

label: Cabin Cove
description: SE Buncombe County, E of Garren Mountain.

label: Cabin Creek
description: rises in S Henderson County and flows SE into Green River.

label: Cabin Creek
description: rises in SE Davidson County and flows SW into Yadkin River.

label: Cabin Ridge Plantation
description: the home of Col. Thomas Lee of Lees Mills (now Roper, which see), used as the first courthouse for Washington County; county court met there from 1800 until sometime in 1801.

label: Cabin Swamp
description: community in central Tyrrell County near Second Creek.

label: Cable Creek
description: rises in central Randolph County and flows SW and NW into Back Creek.

label: Cable Gap
description: NE Graham County at the head of Panther Creek.

label: Cables Cove Creek
description: rises in N central Graham County and flows N into Fontana Lake.

label: Cabo de Trafalgar
description: See Cape Fear.

label: Cabot
description: community in S Cleveland County served by post office, 1898-1902.

label: Cackalacky
description: modern variant homonym of Carolina that gained use in popular culture after World War II. Origin variously attributed to tsalaki, Cherokee word for native people, and to cocklaleechie, a traditional Scottish soup.

label: Cadon Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows SW into Tessentee Creek.

label: Cadon Gap
description: S Macon County at the head of Whiterock Branch.

label: Cadwell Creek
description: rises in Virginia and flows SW into N Stokes County. Turning slightly to the NW, it flows back into Virginia.

label: Caesar Austin Branch
description: rises in central Clay County and flows SE into Tusquitee Creek. Named for an early black settler who lived on the branch.

label: Caesar Swamp
description: rises in W Sampson County and flows SE into Little Coharie Creek.

label: Caesar's Branch
description: rises in N Franklin County and flows NE into Little Shocco Creek.

label: Caffey Gap
description: S Watauga County on the head of Laurel Creek.

label: Caffey's Inlet
description: former inlet N of present town of Duck, E Dare County. In 1788 George Caffee bought a tract in the area but lost much of it when a small inlet cut through his property. Also known as Providence Inlet.

label: Caffey's Inlet Station
description: was built by the U.S. Lifesaving Service in 1874 at Caffey's Inlet. Destroyed by fire, its replacement, built 1899, later served U.S. Coast Guard. Later housed restaurant.

label: Cagle Branch
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows SE into Savannah Creek.

label: Cagles Mill
description: community in NE Montgomery County served by post office, 1876-1921.

label: Cahaba
description: community in SW Bertie County.

label: Cahoogue Creek
description: rises in SE Craven County approx. 3 mi. NW of North Harlowe and flows approx. 3½ mi. NW into Hancock Creek.

label: Cahoon Point
description: extends from E Onslow County into White Oak River. Named for John Cahoon, early settler.

label: Caintuck Township
description: See Canetuck Township.

label: Cairo
description: community in SE Anson County. Served by post office, 1878-1904. Center of rich farming land. Named for Cairo, Egypt, also a center of rich farming land.

label: Cajahs Mountain
description: S Caldwell County. Alt. 1,342. Said to have been named for a man named Micajah who was hanged there.

label: Cal Cove
description: S Graham County between Willie Knob and Little Snowbird Creek.

label: Calabash
description: community in SW Brunswick County. Settled prior to 1880. Original name was Pea Landing. Changed to Calabash in 1880 for the gourds that hung outside wells in the vicinity. Noted for its seafood restaurants.

label: Calabash Creek
description: rises in SW Brunswick County and flows W into South Carolina, where it enters Little River.

label: Calahaln
description: community in W Davie County. Probably named for William Callahan (or his descendants), who was in the area as early as 1778. Post office est. there 1858.

label: Calahaln Mountain
description: W Davie County. Signs of excavations made on the mountain are said to be the result of Indians digging for gold.

label: Calahaln Township
description: W Davie County.

label: Caldwell
description: community in N Mecklenburg County between towns of Cornelius and Huntersville. Named for Joseph Caldwell (1773-1835), first president of the University of North Carolina.

label: Caldwell Branch
description: rises in SW Madison County and flows W into Spring Creek.

label: Caldwell County
description: was formed in 1841 from Burke and Wilkes Counties. Located in the W central section of the state, it is bounded by Alexander, Catawba, Burke, Avery, Watauga, and Wilkes Counties. It was named for Joseph Caldwell (1773-1835), first president of the University of North Carolina. Area: 480 sq. mi. County seat: Lenoir, with an elevation of 1,182 ft. Townships are Globe, Judson, Johns River, King's Creek, Lenoir, Little River, Lovelady, Lower Creek, Mulberry, North Catawba, Patterson, Wilson Creek, and Yadkin Valley. Produces poultry, dairy products, hogs, furniture, apparel, textiles, hosiery, and gravel. Center of trucking industry.

label: Caldwell Creek
description: rises in SE Mecklenburg County and flows N into Cabarrus County and Reedy Creek. Named for family of David Caldwell (d. about 1780).

label: Caldwell Fork
description: rises in W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows NE to join Palmer Creek in forming Cataloochee Creek.

label: Caldwell Institute
description: community in W Orange County served by post office, 1877-1904.

label: Caldwell Township
description: SE Catawba County. Named in 1868 for Caldwell family, members of which were large landowners.

label: Caleb Branch
description: rises in W Carteret County and flows W into Hadnot Creek.

label: Caleb's Creek
description: rises in E Onslow County and flows NE into White Oak River.

label: Caledonia
description: state prison farm since 1892 on the Roanoke River, E Halifax County. It consists of 3,700 acres. Named before 1713 for an early plantation that took its name from the Latin term for northern Scotland. Dikes were built along the river to control flooding. The plantation was later owned by Samuel Johnston of Edenton. Numerous Indian relics have been found there.

label: Caledonia Creek
description: rises in SW Pender County and flows S into Black River.

label: Caler Cove
description: at the head of Caler Cove Branch in N Macon County.

label: Caler Cove Branch
description: rises in N Macon County and flows S into Little Tennessee River.

label: Caler Fork
description: rises in E Macon County and flows SW into Cowee Creek.

label: Caler Knob
description: on Macon-Swain county line near the head of Gibby Branch.

label: Cales Creek
description: rises in NW Carteret County and flows SW into White Oak River.

label: Calf Branch
description: rises on Fort Bragg Military Reservation in N Hoke County and flows SW into Rockfish Creek.

label: Calf Creek
description: rises in SW Beaufort County and flows N into Pamlico River.

label: Calfpen Gap
description: NE Graham County.

label: Calhoun
description: community in E Transylvania County between Little River and McCall Branch.

label: Calhoun Branch
description: rises in W Cherokee County and flows S into Hiwassee River.

label: Calhoun Island
description: formerly a 15-acre island in Little Tennessee River in NE Graham County. Now under the waters of Fontana Lake.

label: Calico
description: community in S Pitt County. Named for the fact that a local store, owned by Henry Venters and his father, sold more calico cloth than any other store in Pitt County. The store also housed the local post office.

label: Calico Bay
description: a loam-filled bay in SW Duplin County.

label: Calico Creek
description: rises in central Carteret County and flows E and SE into the mouth of Newport River. An English ship, loaded with calico, is said to have wrecked near Beaufort in a storm. Afterward, pieces of calico were found draped over bushes growing along the creek.

label: California
description: community in central Hertford County on the head of Mill Branch.

label: California Branch
description: rises in N Cabarrus County and flows N into Rowan County, where it enters South Second Creek.

label: California Creek
description: rises in E Madison County and flows S to join Paint Fork in forming Little Ivy Creek.

label: California Gap
description: S Macon County between Gold Mine Branch and California Ridge.

label: California Knob
description: central Surry County.

label: California Ridge
description: S Macon County between California Gap and Henderson Mountain.

label: California Township
description: See Falkland Township.

label: Call
description: community in S Wilkes County on Mill Creek. Named for a local family.

label: Call Millpond
description: S Wilkes County on Fishing Creek. Covers two acres; max. depth 12 ft. A grain mill and a sawmill operate there.

label: Callaghan Creek
description: rises in central Dare County on the mainland and flows E into Croatan Sound.

label: Callahan
description: See Calahaln.

label: Callahan Branch
description: rises in E Madison County and flows NE into Laurel Creek.

label: Callaway Mountain
description: central Yancey County parallel to Cane River.

label: Callisons
description: community in central Pamlico County.

label: Caltolina
description: former lumbering community in E Person and W Granville Counties. A 1,300-acre tract belonging to the John Pomfret Webb family and later to the Calton family, from which the name was developed. The tract was divided into 15 farms about 1919.

label: Calvander
description: community in SE Orange County. Formed from the name of Calvin Andrews, who operated Andrews's Academy there. The post office was first known as Faucette. Andrews's wife was Elizabeth Faucette.

label: Calvert
description: community in S Transylvania County between Calloway Creek and French Broad River.

label: Calvin
description: See Carbon City.

label: Calypso
description: town in NW Duplin County. Settled about 1890, inc. 1913. Alt. 167. Named for the sea nymph in Homer's Odyssey Produces lumber.

label: Calypso Community Pond
description: on the head of Dicks Branch in NW Duplin County.

label: Cam Branch
description: rises in N Duplin County and flows E into Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: Cambridge
description: See Ostwalt.

label: Camden
description: unincorporated county seat in W central Camden County. Known as Plank Bridge as early as 1740; inc. as Jonesborough, 1792. As early as 1840, the name "Camden" was being used. From the end of the Revolution until about 1830, the community was a port of entry for customs collection. Alt. 10.

label: Camden County
description: was formed in 1777 from Pasquotank County. Located in the NE section of the state, it is bounded by the state of Virginia, Albemarle Sound, and Pasquotank, Gates, and Currituck Counties. It was named for Sir Charles Pratt, Earl of Camden (1716-94), English jurist and political leader who opposed taxation of the American colonies and believed the Stamp Act to be unconstitutional. Area: 308 sq. mi. County seat: Camden, with an elevation of 10 ft. Townships are Court House, Shiloh, and South Mills. Produces corn, soybeans, Irish potatoes, wheat, steel products, concrete products, seafood, and hogs.

label: Camden Point
description: the SE tip of Camden County that extends into the Albemarle Sound. See also Poquoson Point.

label: Camel Field
description: cove in N Buncombe County between North Knob and Reems Creek.

label: Camel Hump Knob
description: a peak in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on the line between Haywood County, N.C., and Cocke County, Tenn., near lat. 35°43'33" N., long. 83°13' W. Alt. 5,200-5,250.

label: Camel Knob
description: N Rutherford County N of Camp Creek. Alt. 2,124.

label: Camels Creek
description: rises in W Harnett County and flows NE into Cape Fear River. Named for "Surveyor John" Campbell, who settled along its banks about 1770.

label: Camera
description: See Willard.

label: Camerer Ridge
description: on the Haywood County, N.C.-Cocke County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Extends NE from Low Gap to Mount Camerer, then E approx. 2½ mi. to the valley of Pigeon River. Named in honor of A. B. Camerer, formerly of the U.S. Department of Interior, who was active in promoting the park.

label: Cameron
description: town in E Moore County. Inc. 1876 and named for a civil engineer who surveyed the Raleigh and Augusta Airline Railroad. Alt. 304.

label: Camerons Hill
description: See Johnsonville.

label: Camp Alamance
description: Civil War training camp near Company Shops, now Burlington, central Alamance County.

label: Camp Ashe
description: a Civil War training camp in New Hanover County, described in contemporary records as being "12 miles from Wilmington."

label: Camp Bay
description: a bay in central Columbus County filled with fine sand.

label: Camp Beauregard
description: Civil War training camp in W Warren County near the community of Ridgeway.

label: Camp Blackjack
description: See Bucklesberry Pocosin.

label: Camp Branch
description: rises in N central Wilkes County and flows NE into Roaring River.

label: Camp Branch
description: rises in W Avery County and flows S into Horse Creek.

label: Camp Branch Falls
description: 360-ft. waterfalls on the Nantahala River, Clay-Macon county line.

label: Camp Butner
description: former army post in Durham, Granville, and Person Counties. Est. 1942; closed 1946. Infantry training center, convalescent hospital, and reassignment center. Housed Axis prisoners of war. Named for Maj. Gen. Henry Wolfe Butner (1875-1937), native of Surry County. See also Butner.

label: Camp Call
description: community in central Cleveland County on Little Harris Creek.

label: Camp Campbell
description: a Civil War training camp near Kinston in E Lenoir County.

label: Camp Canal
description: Civil War training camp in Carteret County, probably at or near Morehead City.

label: Camp Chronicle
description: a World War I training camp located on the W side of present S. Linwood Street, Gastonia, central Gaston County. Operated in connection with an artillery range at the foot of Crowders Mountain. Named for Maj. William Chronicle, killed at the Battle of Kings Mountain, 1780.

label: Camp Clingman
description: former Confederate camp in Asheville (French Broad Avenue near Philip Street), central Buncombe County. Named for Thomas L. Clingman, U.S. senator and brigadier general in the Confederate army.

label: Camp Crabtree
description: Civil War training camp located approx. 3 mi. N of Raleigh on "Crabtree," the plantation of Kimbrough Jones Sr.

label: Camp Creek
description: rises in SW Surry County and flows SE and NE into Mitchell River.

label: Camp Creek
description: rises in SE corner of Burke County and flows NE into Jacob Fork.

label: Camp Creek
description: rises in N Burke County and flows NW into Avery County, where it enters Linville River. Named for three brothers—Everette, Howard, and Arthur Camp—of Chicago, who were railroad builders in the vicinity.

label: Camp Creek Bald
description: on Madison County, N.C.-Greene County, Tenn., line. Alt. 4,844.

label: Camp Creek Mountain
description: S central Avery County.

label: Camp Creek Township
description: N central Rutherford County.

label: Camp Davis
description: a Civil War training camp near Wilmington, W New Hanover County.

label: Camp Fisher
description: Civil War training camp near High Point, SW Guilford County.

label: Camp Gap
description: NW Macon County at the head of Camp Branch.

label: Camp Glenn
description: National Guard camp, 1907-13, in Morehead City on site of Carolina City, which see. Also site of first U.S. Coast Guard air station, 1920-21.

label: Camp Greene
description: World War I training camp, 6,000 acres in area. Est. July 1917 and located in SW Charlotte; named for Gen. Nathanael Greene.

label: Camp Grier Lake
description: W McDowell County on a tributary of Mill Creek; 1/5 mi. long, about 1 mi. NW of Old Fort. A summer camp is operated there by the Presbyterian Church. Formerly known as Lake Refuge.

label: Camp Hebron
description: S Watauga County on Boone Fork, operated for girls.

label: Camp Hill
description: a Civil War training camp described as being near Garysburg in Northampton County. It was also referred to as a "camp of instruction."

label: Camp Jeter
description: former Confederate camp in Asheville (Cherry Street-Flint Street section), central Buncombe County.

label: Camp Johnston
description: a Civil War training camp in the vicinity of Kinston, named for Gen. Joseph E. Johnston.

label: Camp Knob
description: N Cleveland County between Cove and Cox Creeks.

label: Camp Lamb
description: a Civil War training camp near Wilmington, W New Hanover County.

label: Camp Lejeune
description: Marine base in S Onslow County on both sides of New River, adjacent to Jacksonville. Construction began in 1942. Known first as New River Marine Base; later named for Maj. Gen. John A. Lejeune (1867-1942), World War I Marine commandant. The base covers 173 sq. mi., of which 26,000 acres are underwater. Onslow Beach, a part of the base, is used for amphibious assault training.

label: Camp Mackall
description: World War II training camp, the second-largest Airborne training center in the nation. Site in E Richmond and NW Scotland Counties. See also Hoffman.

label: Camp Macon
description: See Macon.

label: Camp Mangum
description: Civil War training camp in central Wake County about 3 mi. W of Raleigh on site of present state fairgrounds.

label: Camp Mason
description: Civil War training camp near Graham, central Alamance County.

label: Camp Mountain
description: E Jackson County between Tanasee Creek and the Transylvania County line.

label: Camp Patton
description: Civil War training camp in Asheville (East Chestnut Street E of Charlotte Street), central Buncombe County. Probably named for Capt. Thomas W. Patton, who served with distinction in the Confederate army. The camp was probably on land that he owned, as his home was nearby.

label: Camp Point
description: at the NW tip of the largest island in the Hog Island group, NE Carteret County. Earlier known as Whale Camp Point and was the site of an early settlement.

label: Camp Polk
description: World War I tank camp of 1,600 acres located in Raleigh and named for William Polk, Revolutionary War colonel. Camp had two sections: administrative, housing, and assembly grounds on Hillsborough Street and tank training grounds on Blue Ridge Road.

label: Camp Ridge
description: mountain in W Avery County.

label: Camp Springs
description: community in SW Caswell County. Believed to have been named because Cornwallis's troops camped there during the American Revolution.

label: Camp Swamp
description: rises in S Columbus County and flows SE into Horry County, S.C., where it enters Buck Creek.

label: Camp Tuscarora
description: Boy Scout camp and lake in S Wayne County S of Sleepy Creek.

label: Camp Two Branch
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows NW into Middle Prong.

label: Camp Vance
description: a Civil War training camp near Sulphur Springs, central Buncombe County. Named for Col. Robert B. Vance of the 29th N.C. Regiment, which trained there.

label: Camp Whiting
description: a Civil War training camp at Wilmington, W New Hanover County.

label: Camp Wilson
description: See Vaughan's Springs.

label: Camp Wyatt
description: a Civil War training camp in S New Hanover County about 2 mi. N of Fort Fisher. Named for Henry Lawson Wyatt, first North Carolina soldier killed in action in the Civil War, at Bethel Church, June 10, 1861.

label: Campania
description: an estate of 19,000 acres in Currituck, Pasquotank, and Perquimans Counties owned by Thomas Macknight. Being developed at the time of the Revolutionary War.

label: Campbell
description: community in N Stokes County near the head of Little Creek.

label: Campbell Creek
description: rises in S Graham County and flows NE into Tulula Creek.

label: Campbell Creek
description: rises in SE Beaufort County and flows E to join Upper Spring Creek in forming Goose Creek.

label: Campbell Gap
description: central Macon County between Iotla Branch and Iotla Creek.

label: Campbell Island
description: E Brunswick County on the Cape Fear River. Once known as Crane Island. Named for William Campbell (1745-81), a general in the Revolution.

label: Campbell's Creek
description: community in SE Beaufort County in the center of an Irish potato-growing area. Phosphate deposits exist in the vicinity.

label: Campbell's Crossroads
description: See Semora.

label: Campbell's Mill on Waterhole Swamp
description: See Pembroke.

label: Campbells Creek
description: rises in E Mecklenburg County and flows S into McAlpine Creek.

label: Campbells Falls
description: rapids in Cape Fear River in SE Harnett County near the confluence of Juniper Creek with the river. Mentioned as early as 1819 in a survey of the rivers of North Carolina.

label: Campbellton
description: See Fayetteville.

label: Campground Gap
description: on the Buncombe-Yancey county line between Campground Knob and Rocky Knob.

label: Campground Knob
description: on Buncombe-Yancey county line between Sugartree Gap and Campground Gap.

label: Campground, The
description: SW Gates County approx. 3 mi. NW of Gatesville, the site of religious camp meetings from the 1820s until the early 1900s. Popular with the people from Hertford, Bertie, and Chowan Counties. An artesian well at the site supplied water.

label: Camping Creek
description: rises in SW Franklin County and flows NE into Cedar Creek.

label: Camping Fork
description: rises in N Mitchell County and flows SW into Right Fork Bean Creek.

label: Camping Island Creek
description: rises in central Stokes County and flows NE between Hanging Rock and Flat Shoal Mountain into Dan River.

label: Camprock Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows SE into Shope Fork.

label: Camps Store
description: See Gaston.

label: Cana
description: community in N Davie County. Made a post office in 1875 and named for James H. Cain, first postmaster.

label: Canada Township
description: SE Jackson County.

label: Canadian Hole
description: deep trough just offshore in Pamlico Sound, N of Buxton, E Dare County. Frequented by windsurfers, many of them Canadian. Term also used by N.C. Department of Transportation to describe section of highway 12 subject to frequent washouts.

label: Canadian Top
description: peak in W Haywood County, Great Smoky Mountains National Park, near lat. 35°38'55" N., long. 83°06'13" W.

label: Canady Creek
description: rises in N Guilford County and flows NW into Rockingham County. Name is a variation of Thomas Kennedy, pioneer settler.

label: Canal A
description: in central Washington County, drains NE from East Dismal Swamp into Main Canal.

label: Canal B
description: in central Washington County, drains NE from East Dismal Swamp into Main Canal.

label: Canal Gut
description: rises in SW Bertie County and flows S into Roanoke River.

label: Canal Swamp
description: rises in E Northampton County and flows SE into Hertford County, where it enters Potecasi Creek.

label: Canby
description: community in S Montgomery County on Thickety Creek. Served by post office, 1900-1932. Named by Chesley Greene for Fort Canby, Wash., where he served during the Spanish-American War.

label: Candills
description: community in W Johnston County served by post office, 1891-1903.

label: Candle Branch
description: rises in W Forsyth County and flows SW into Yadkin River.

label: Candler
description: community in SW Buncombe County at the junction of South Hominy and Hominy Creeks. Alt. 2,108. Named for George Candler, an early settler.

label: Candler Knob
