description: on Buncombe-Henderson county line, SW of Cutthroat Gap. Alt. 4,548.

label: Candon
description: community in W Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1833-75. Also operated as Clear Creek post office.

label: Candor
description: town in E Montgomery County. Alt. 729. Inc. 1891. Named by three local merchants who envisioned a "town of frankness and sincerity." Post office est. as Cabin Creek in 1873; name changed in 1885. Also once called Lamond's Old Field.

label: Candy Creek
description: rises in NE Guilford County and flows N into Rockingham County, where it enters Haw River. Known as Kenady's Branch and as Kanady Creek prior to 1800, named for an early settler.

label: Cane
description: community in S Alamance County.

label: Cane Bottom
description: community in N Yancey County on Nolichucky River.

label: Cane Brake Creek
description: rises in S Rutherford County and flows S into Broad River.

label: Cane Branch
description: rises in E Yancey County and flows N into Little Crabtree Creek.

label: Cane Creek
description: rises in W Orange County and flows SW into Haw River.

label: Cane Creek
description: rises in S Cherokee County and flows NE into Nottely River.

label: Cane Creek Gap
description: SE Buncombe County near the headwaters of Cane Creek.

label: Cane Creek Mountains
description: S Alamance County. Among the named peaks are Huronian Mountain and Stafford Hill. Alt. approx. 1,033.

label: Cane Creek Township
description: E Mitchell County.

label: Cane Island
description: sandy island approx. ¼ mi. long in French Broad River, W Madison County.

label: Cane Mountain
description: between Foster Creek and McDowell Creek in NW Henderson County.

label: Cane Mountain
description: extends from Cane River in N Yancey County NE to the junction of Toe and Cane Rivers.

label: Cane River
description: community in W central Yancey County.

label: Cane River Gap
description: on Buncombe-Yancey county line SE of Ivy Gap. Also known as Little Cane River Gap.

label: Cane River Township
description: NW Yancey County.

label: Canebrake Branch
description: rises in W central Swain County and flows S into Tuckasegee River.

label: Canedy Gap
description: W Cherokee County at the SE end of Chestnut Gap Mountain.

label: Canedy Mountain
description: W Cherokee County S of Canedy Gap between Shoal and Bearpaw Creeks.

label: Canetuck
description: community in SW Pender County on Buckle Creek.

label: Canetuck Township
description: SW Pender County, formerly Caintuck Township.

label: Caney Bottom Creek
description: rises in N Transylvania County and flows SE into Cove Creek.

label: Caney Branch
description: rises in W Cherokee County and flows SE and SW into Hiwasee River.

label: Caney Fork
description: stream formed in NE Jackson County by the junction of Piney Mountain Creek and Rough Butt Creek; flows SW into Tuckasegee River.

label: Caney Fork Bald
description: on Haywood-Jackson county line NW of Lone Bald. Alt. 5,926.

label: Caney Fork Branch
description: rises in S Madison County and flows NW into Robert Branch.

label: Caney Fork Township
description: E central Jackson County.

label: Caney Lead
description: extends NE from Hangover Lead to Cheoah River in NW Graham County.

label: Canie Creek
description: rises in central Buncombe County and flows SE into Hominy Creek.

label: Cannon
description: community in W Henderson County. Settled soon after the Revolutionary War.

label: Cannon Branch
description: rises in N Avery County and flows E into Buckeye Creek.

label: Cannon Creek
description: rises in E Transylvania County and flows SE into Buckhorn Creek.

label: Cannon Gap
description: N Avery County near the head of Cannon Creek.

label: Cannon Lake
description: is fed by several small streams in SW Rowan County. Covers 100 acres. Used as a source of water by former Cannon Mills and the town of Kannapolis.

label: Cannon Swamp
description: rises in central Pitt County and flows SE into Moyes Run.

label: Cannon's Ferry
description: community on the Chowan River in NW Chowan County.

label: Cannons Crossroads
description: community in central Pitt County.

label: Canoe Creek
description: rises in W Burke County and flows SE into Catawba River in central Burke County.

label: Cansadie Top
description: central Haywood County between Shook Gap and Jolly Gap.

label: Canterbury Creek
description: See Southwest Creek.

label: Canto
description: community in NW Buncombe County near the Madison County line.

label: Canton
description: town in E Haywood County. Inc. 1889 as Buford. Name changed to Pigeon River in 1891 and to Canton in 1893. Named for Canton, Ohio, source of the steel used in the bridge being built across Pigeon River. Produces paper. Alt. 2,609.

label: Cantrell Creek
description: rises in N Transylvania County and flows SE into South Fork Mills River.

label: Cantrell Mountain
description: W Henderson County between North Fork and South Fork.

label: Cantrell Top
description: NW Cherokee County.

label: Cape
description: community in SE Randolph County served by post office, 1886-1904.

label: Cape Amidas
description: See Cape Hatteras.

label: Cape Carteret
description: town in SW Carteret County on Bogue Sound. Inc. 1959.

label: Cape Creek
description: a tidal creek on Smith Island in SE Brunswick County rising about 1 mi. N of Cape Fear just inside the outer beach and extending NW to the main outlet on the W shore of Smith Island.

label: Cape Fair
description: See Cape Fear.

label: Cape Fear
description: the southernmost tip of Smith (Bald Head) Island, S Brunswick County, at the mouth of Cape Fear River in the Atlantic Ocean. Discovered by Verrazzano in 1524. Appears as Promontorium tremendum on the De Bry map, 1590, and as Cape of Feare on the Molyneuxmap, 1592. The name apparently originated in 1585 when the Tiger, en route to Roanoke Island, was nearly wrecked "on a breache called the Cape of Feare." John White had a similar experience and mentioned the name again in 1587. Spanish maps of the same period mark the point as Cabo de Trafalgar. At a later time, when it was desirable to attract colonists to the Carolina region, the name Cape Fair was substituted but not permanently accepted.

label: Cape Fear River
description: is formed by the junction of Deep and Haw Rivers on the Chatham-Lee county line. It flows SE along the Chatham-Lee county line and through Harnett County, S through Cumberland County, SE through Bladen County, and along the Columbus-Pender, Brunswick-Pender, and Brunswick-New Hanover county lines into the Atlantic Ocean. It had a succession of names after it was first discovered by Europeans. Spanish explorers in 1526 named it Rio Jordan; a Barbadian colony in 1664 named it Charles River; and between 1664 and 1667, when Clarendon County existed in the area, it was known as Clarendon River. It appears as Clarendon River on the Ogilby map, 1671; as "C. Fear R. or Clarendon R." on the Gascoyne map, 1682; as Cape Fear River on the Barnwell map, 1722; as Clarendon River on the Moll map, 1729; and as Cape Fear River on the Moseley map, 1733, and thereafter on others.

label: Cape Fear Section
description: a term applied to SE North Carolina along the Cape Fear River. Appears as Pine Plains on the Ogilby map, 1671.

label: Cape Fear Township
description: former township in E Lee County, now township no. 3.

label: Cape Feare
description: See Cape Lookout.

label: Cape Hatteras
description: the easternmost point in North Carolina, is at the S tip of Hatteras Island, SE Dare County. Diamond Shoals, extending into the Atlantic Ocean SE from the Cape, reach to the Gulf Stream at the notorious "Graveyard of the Atlantic." Called Cape St. John on the Velasco map, 1611; Cape Amidas on the Smith map, 1624; and its present name on the Ogilby map, 1671. The word "Hatteras" apparently is an English rendition of the Algonquian Indian expression of "there is less vegetation." Archaeological evidence indicates that the sixteenth-century Indian village of Croatoan may have been located there. See also various entries under Hatteras; Diamond Shoals.

label: Cape Hatteras National Seashore
description: est. 1953, consists of the S part of Bodie Island and most of Ocracoke and Hatteras Islands, except the settled areas. First U.S. national seashore, it was authorized by Congress in 1937. Campsites provided. On the Outer Banks of SE Dare and Hyde Counties.

label: Cape Hatteras Woods
description: See Hatteras Woods.

label: Cape Kenrick
description: in the sixteenth and early seventeenth centuries extended into the Atlantic Ocean from Hatteras Island in E Dare County between the present communities of Rodanthe and Salvo. Appears on the Velasco map, 1611. It disappeared later in the seventeenth century, either through erosion or in a storm. Wimble Shoals, which see, are now at the site. Kenrick is believed to have been derived from the Algonquian Indian word for "sinking-down-sand."

label: Cape Lookout
description: the southernmost tip of Core Banks in SE Carteret County. A lighthouse, coast guard station, and a few summer cottages are there. The De Bry map, 1590, marks the point as "Promontorium tremendum." On the Velasco map, 1611, it is Cape Feare. On the Ogilby map, 1671, it appears as Cape Lookout.

label: Cape Lookout National Seashore
description: was authorized to be est. by U.S. Congress in 1966 on Core Banks, Portsmouth Island, and Shackleford Banks on the Outer Banks of E Carteret County. Area contains approx. 16,400 acres.

label: Cape Lookout Shoals
description: in the Atlantic Ocean off Cape Lookout, which see, SE Carteret County.

label: Cape of Feare
description: See Cape Fear.

label: Cape Point
description: the extreme tip of land at Cape Hatteras, extends into the Atlantic Ocean, SE Dare County.

label: Cape St. John
description: See Cape Hatteras.

label: Cape, The
description: See Buxton.

label: Capell Mills
description: community in N Richmond County served by post office, 1869-1905.

label: Capella
description: community in W Stokes County between Quaker Gap and East Prong Yadkin River.

label: Capelsie
description: community in S Montgomery County on Little River. Named for A. W. Capel and M. Elsie Shamburger, owners of a cotton mill est. there about 1870. Served by post office, 1902-16.

label: Capernium
description: community in SW Forsyth County.

label: Capps Hill
description: community in N Mecklenburg County on the head of Stuarts Creek.

label: Caraleigh
description: former community in central Wake County now within the city of Raleigh.

label: Caraway
description: community in central Randolph County served by post office, 1845-1932.

label: Caraway Creek
description: rises in NW Randolph County and flows S into Uwharrie River near town of Farmer. Appears on the Collet map, 1770. Traditionally an Indian name, probably a survival of Keyauwee, the name of an Indian tribe that inhabited the area when white men first entered it. See also Keeauwee.

label: Caraway Mountain
description: W Randolph County between Black Creek and Caraway Creek, which see. Appears on the Collet map, 1770, as a name applied to all of the small mountains between the Uwharrie and Deep Rivers.

label: Carbon City
description: community in W central Burke County. Formerly known as Calvin but renamed following the construction of the Great Lakes Carbon Company plant at the site.

label: Carbonton
description: community in S Chatham County on Deep River at the junction of the Chatham-Lee-Moore county lines. Named by Mrs. Peter Evans, daughter of Gov. John Motley Morehead, for the element carbon, a constituent of coal, abundant in the vicinity. Alt. 260.

label: Cardenas
description: community in S Wake County.

label: Careening Point
description: extended into North River estuary of Carteret County from the mainland on Moseley map, 1733. The name has fallen into disuse, though the point still exists.

label: Carl
description: community in E central Montgomery County served by post office, 1893-1909.

label: Carl Alwin Schenck Forest
description: central Wake County, approx. 3 mi. W of North Carolina State University. Covers 245 acres. Est. 1936 and afterward named in honor of Schenck (1865-1955) who, in 1898, founded the first forestry school in the United States at Biltmore Forest, which see. The school was closed in 1912. The Schenck Forest, owned and operated by the Department of Forestry and Environmental Resources, N.C. State University, is used for demonstration, research, and forest genetics. Schenck's ashes are scattered in the forest.

label: Carlile Island
description: See Colington Island.

label: Carlisle
description: community in NW Davidson County served by post office, 1886-1905.

label: Carlos
description: community in N Cumberland County.

label: Carlton
description: community in W Granville County.

label: Carmel
description: community in W Montgomery County served by post office, 1884-1915.

label: Carmen
description: community in N Madison County on Shelton Laurel Creek.

label: Carolana
description: a province proposed to be est. in America and named in the charter of King Charles I to Sir Robert Heath, October 30, 1629. The province was to extend from 31° to 36° N. lat. along the Atlantic Ocean and presumably W to the Pacific Ocean. No settlements were made, and the charter was considered vacated in 1663 when Carolina was granted to eight Lords Proprietors by King Charles II. See also County of Norfolk.

label: Carolarns Islands
description: presumably the Outer Banks, which see, named in the charter of King Charles I to Sir Robert Heath, October 30, 1629.

label: Caroleen
description: community in SE Rutherford County on Second Broad River. Alt. 805. Named in honor of Caroline, wife of Simpson B. Tanner Sr., industrialist. The Post Office Department ruled that Caroline was too similar to Carolina to be acceptable, so Caroleen was selected instead. The communities of Avondale and Henrietta lie directly s.

label: Carolina
description: was named by King Charles II of England in his own honor in the charter that he granted in 1663 to eight Lords Proprietors. It was applied to the region between Florida and the Virginia colony extending from the Atlantic to the Pacific Ocean. See also Carolana.

label: Carolina Bays
description: oval-shaped lakes, swamps, pocosins, savannahs, and peat beds in SE North Carolina, E South Carolina, and NE Georgia. Several explanations have been advanced as to the origin of the Carolina Bays, but the most generally accepted one is that they were formed thousands of years ago by a shower of meteorites. White Lake, Jones Lake, Singletary Lake, and Lake Waccamaw are Carolina Bays. There also are numerous others, many of which no longer contain water.

label: Carolina Beach
description: town in SE New Hanover County on the Atlantic Ocean. Alt. 5. Settled about 1885; inc. 1925. Sugar Loaf, a former community at or near the site, was the scene of an engagement between Confederate and Union forces after the capitulation of Fort Fisher, January 15, 1865.

label: Carolina Beach Inlet
description: SE New Hanover County, an artificially created inlet from the Atlantic Ocean through the barrier bar about 2Â½ mi. N of the town of Carolina Beach. A dredged channel extends from the inlet to the Intra-coastal Waterway.

label: Carolina City
description: was laid out in 1855 in S central Carteret County by Carolina City Land Company to be terminal point of Atlantic and North Carolina Railroad. Opening of Morehead City on adjacent land to the E and the coming of the Civil War brought about its demise. Union army camped at the site for 3 years and afterward the State Guard trained there. See Camp Glenn.

label: Carolina Island
description: See Conine Island.

label: Carolina Power Lake
description: NW Person and NE Caswell Counties on Hyco River. Formed in 1964 by the construction of Hyco Dam by Carolina Power and Light Company to condense turbine exhaust steam at its electricity-generating plant there. The lake is approx. 10 mi. long and covers 3,750 acres. It is also used for public recreation. Sometimes referred to as Roxboro Lake and Hyco Lake.

label: Carolina River
description: See Albemarle Sound.

label: Carolina Shoal Beach
description: extreme S tip of the mainland of New Hanover County between the Atlantic Ocean and the Cape Fear River.

label: Carolina Township
description: NE Pitt County.

label: Caroon Point
description: a point extending from mainland of N Dare County, near Mashoes, into Albemarle Sound.

label: Carpenter
description: community in W Wake County settled 1865. Named for William Carpenter, early settler. Alt. 325.

label: Carpenter Branch
description: rises in W Haywood County and flows S into Jonathans Creek.

label: Carpenter Knob
description: in N Cleveland County between Poundingmill and Knob Creeks. Alt. 1,619.

label: Carpenters Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows N into Allison Creek.

label: Carpenters Knob
description: W Lincoln County. Alt. 1,500.

label: Carr
description: community in NW Orange County.

label: Carr Township
description: E Durham County.

label: Carr's Mount
description: community in central Anson County on N outskirts of Wadesboro. Alt. 445. Site of a silk mill in the early twentieth century. Other mills operated there from early nineteenth century; early fairgrounds and racetrack were there.

label: Carraway Creek
description: rises in S central Wayne County and flows NW approx. 5 mi. into Neuse River. First known as Michael's Creek for the owner of surrounding land, Michael Rosher. Land sold to John Carraway in 1743 and the name of the creek changed.

label: Carrboro
description: town in SE Orange County immediately W of Chapel Hill. Alt. 500. Settled 1898. Inc. 1911 as Venable; named for Francis P. Venable (1856-1934), president of the University of North Carolina. Changed to Carrboro, 1913, for Julian S. Carr (1845-1924), who est. a textile mill there.

label: Carrell Knob
description: on the Cherokee-Clay county line in the Valley River Mountains.

label: Carrikers
description: community in S Cabarrus County named for local family.

label: Carringer Gap
description: N Graham County between Yellow Creek and Cochran Creek.

label: Carrol Gap
description: near the SE base of Carroll Mountain, W Clay County between the headwaters of Sweetwater and Qualls Creeks near lat. 35°02'45" N., long. 83°51'20" W.

label: Carrol Knob
description: S Macon County between Jones Creek and the head of North Fork Coweeta Creek.

label: Carroll
description: community in W Duplin County served by post office, 1899-1902. Named for Charles Carroll, postmaster.

label: Carroll Branch
description: rises in W Clay County on the E slope of Carroll Knob and flows S into Carroll Lake near lat. 35°03'45" N., long. 83°54'53" W., in Nantahala National Forest.

label: Carroll Gap
description: E Watauga County on the head of Long Branch.

label: Carroll Knob
description: on the Cherokee-Clay county line at the SW end of Valley River Mountains, Nantahala National Forest. Alt. 2,540.

label: Carroll Lake
description: a spring-fed lake in W Clay County, N of Hiwassee River, formed about 1920. Covers 30 acres; max. depth 20 ft. Privately owned. Named for John C. Carroll, first owner.

label: Carroll Mountain
description: W Clay County, S of Hiwassee River and N of Qualls Creek. See also Jim Carroll Top.

label: Carroll's Creek
description: rises in N Burke County and flows S into Johns River.

label: Carrolls Branch
description: rises in SE Moore County and flows E into Mill Creek.

label: Carrot Island
description: a marshy island about 1.5 mi. long SE of Beaufort in S Carteret County and separated from the mainland by Taylor Creek. Long refuge for wild horses. Formerly Cart Island.

label: Carrs Creek
description: rises in S Lee County and flows S into Little River.

label: Carrs Township
description: NE Greene County. Named for the Carr family, prominent in the area from a time prior to 1804.

label: Carson
description: community in central Catawba County. Alt. 1,000.

label: Carson Cove
description: on a tributary of Iotla Creek in central Macon County.

label: Carson Creek
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows NW into French Broad River.

label: Carson Mountain
description: N Buncombe County N of Wildcat Knob.

label: Carson Mountain
description: N Rutherford County, extends NE between Cane Creek and Lookadoo Mountain.

label: Carson's Creek
description: community in SE Transylvania County near the South Carolina line.

label: Cart Island
description: See Carrot Island.

label: Carter
description: community in S Gates County.

label: Carter Branch
description: rises in N Macon County and flows SW into Little Tennessee River.

label: Carter Cove
description: the valley through which Beaverdam Creek flows in SW Buncombe County.

label: Carter Cove Creek
description: rises in the Elk Mountains, central Buncombe County, and flows SW into Beaverdam Creek.

label: Carter Creek
description: rises in the Great Craggy Mountains, NE Buncombe County, and flows generally NW to join Mineral Creek in forming Stony Creek.

label: Carter Gap
description: on the Clay-Macon county line.

label: Carter Mill Ridge
description: N Madison County between Big Creek and Mill Creek.

label: Carter Mountain
description: N Buncombe County near the Madison County line.

label: Carter Pond
description: S Wayne County in Yellow Swamp.

label: Carter Top
description: on the N end of Rich Mountain in NW Jackson County.

label: Carteret
description: town est. 1723 to be laid out on the NE side of Roanoke Island, then Bertie, later Tyrrell, and now E Dare County. An act of 1715, without naming the town, attempted to encourage its establishment. A few lots may have been sold by 1733, when it was referred to as "Roanoak Town," but it never developed as planned.

label: Carteret County
description: was formed in 1722 from Craven County. Located in the E section of the state, it is bounded by the Atlantic Ocean, by Onslow, Jones, and Craven Counties, and by Neuse River and Pamlico Sound. Bogue and Core Sounds separate the Outer Banks from the mainland of the county. It was named for John Carteret (1690-1763), later second Earl Granville, one of the Lords Proprietors. Area: 1,063 sq. mi. (532, land; 531, water). County seat: Beaufort, with an elevation of 9 ft. Townships are Beaufort, Cedar Island, Davis, Harkers Island, Merrimon, Harlowe, Marshallberg, Morehead, Newport, Portsmouth, Smyrna, Straits, and White Oak. Produces corn, soybeans, Irish potatoes, Irish potatoes, hogs, apparel, boxes, boats, and seafood.

label: Carteret Precinct
description: Albemarle County, formed by 1681, composed of present Currituck, Pasquotank, and Camden Counties.

label: Carteret Township
description: former township of NE Carteret County. Previously a part of Straits Township, now largely Merrimon Township.

label: Carters Creek
description: rises in NE Davie County near Hillsdale and flows 3 mi. SE into Yadkin River. Formerly known as Linville Creek.

label: Carters Falls
description: SW Surry County on the Yadkin River near Elkin.

label: Carters Mills
description: community in N Moore County on Bear Creek. Named for S. M. Carter, in whose house the post office was first opened. A mill there was est. about 1790 by Nicholas Nall, who also had a tavern there on the old Salem-Fayetteville road.

label: Carters Mountain
description: extends NW in N Wilkes County between North Prong Roaring River and Middle Prong Roaring River.

label: Carters Ridge
description: S Mitchell County between Grassy Creek and North Toe River.

label: Cartersville
description: community in S Duplin County.

label: Carthage
description: town and county seat, central Moore County. Authorized to be laid off and inc. 1796. Name changed to Fagansville in 1806 for Richardson Fagin, sheriff of Moore County, 1785-87, and on whose land the town was located; changed back to Carthage, 1818. Produces textiles. Alt. 575.

label: Carthage Township
description: central Moore County.

label: Cartledge Creek
description: rises in central Richmond County on W edge of town of Ellerbe and flows SW into Pee Dee River. Named for Edmund Cartledge, who owned land in the vicinity prior to 1758.

label: Cartoogechaye Creek
description: rises in S Macon County and flows NE into Little Tennessee River. The name is believed to be the Cherokee Indian word for "corn fields."

label: Cartoogechaye Township
description: W Macon County.

label: Cartwheel Branch
description: rises in E Onslow County and flows NE into Holland Mill Creek.

label: Carver Creek
description: rises in NW Clay County and flows SW into Hiwassee River.

label: Carver Gap
description: NW Clay County in Tusquitee Mountains.

label: Carver Knob
description: S Madison County between Morrow Branch and Worley Cove.

label: Carver Mountain
description: between Cope Creek and Blanton Branch in N central Jackson County. Alt. 3,600.

label: Carvers
description: community in SE Bladen County.

label: Carvers Branch
description: rises in S Mitchell County and flows SW into East Fork Crabtree Creek.

label: Carvers Creek
description: community in N Cumberland County.

label: Carvers Creek Township
description: N central Cumberland County.

label: Carvers Falls
description: on Carver Creek, central Cumberland County, approx. 7 mi. NE of Fayetteville at the junction of the forks of Carver Creek near its mouth in the Cape Fear River.

label: Carvers Gap
description: on the Mitchell County, N.C.-Carter County, Tenn., line.

label: Carvers Gap Creek
description: rises in E Mitchell County and flows SE into Fall Creek.

label: Cary
description: town in W Wake County, settled about 1863 as the site of Frank Page's lumber operations and known as Page's Turnout or Page's Tavern. Later, when the railroad was built, it became Page's Siding. Inc. 1871 as Carey; named for Senator Samuel Fenton Carey (1814-1900) of Ohio, a Prohibition leader. The spelling became Cary as early as 1899.

label: Cary Branch
description: rises in SW Wake County and flows SW into Buckhorn Creek.

label: Cary Creek
description: rises in W Wake County and flows SW into Chatham County, where it enters Whiteoak Creek.

label: Cary Flat Branch
description: rises in E central Avery County and flows S into Wilson Creek.

label: Cary Township
description: W central Wake County.

label: Casar
description: town in N Cleveland County. Settled about 1870 and inc. 1903, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Alt. 1,145. Intended to be named for Julius Caesar but an error was made in the spelling.

label: Casar Township
description: former township in NW Cleveland County, now township no. 11.

label: Cascade
description: community in NW Guilford County served by post office, 1892-1903.

label: Cascade Branch
description: rises in N Madison County and flows SE into Spring Creek.

label: Cascade Creek
description: rises in S Virginia and flows SE into Rockingham County, where it enters Dan River. Named by William Byrd, surveyor of region in 1728, for small rapids near boundary.

label: Cascade Falls
description: on Cascade Creek, W central Stokes County in Hanging Rock State Park. From a high rock precipice, water falls about 200 ft. in an "Upper Cascade" and then falls another 60 ft. in a "Lower Cascade." The falls are S of Tories Den.

label: Cascade Lake
description: in E Transylvania County in Little River. Covers 150 acres and has max. depth of 75 ft. Used for hydroelectric power and recreation.

label: Cascoponung River
description: See Scuppernong River.

label: Case Camp Ridge
description: N Transylvania County, extends E in an arc from Pisgah Ridge to Case Ridge Gap.

label: Case Cove
description: the valley through which Wise Branch flows in SW Buncombe County.

label: Case Ridge Gap
description: in N Transylvania County at the E end of Case Camp Ridge.

label: Cases
description: community in W Rockingham County served by post office, 1882-1905.

label: Casey Bay
description: on Pamlico Sound side of Portsmouth Island W of community of Portsmouth, E Carteret County.

label: Casey Branch
description: rises in SW Polk County and flows NE into Cove Creek.

label: Casey Island
description: in Pamlico Sound off Portsmouth Island, E Carteret County.

label: Cash Corner No. 2
description: community in S Pamlico County SE of Arapahoe. Named because a store at the crossroads there sold goods cheaper for cash than on credit. See also Hollyville.

label: Cash Creek
description: rises in W Henderson County and flows SE into French Broad River.

label: Cashie Branch
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows NW into Scott Creek.

label: Cashie Neck
description: swampy region of SE Bertie County between the Roanoke and Cashie Rivers opposite Plymouth.

label: Cashie River
description: (ca-SHY) rises in NW Bertie County and flows SE into Batchelor Bay and Albemarle Sound. One of the few rivers in the state to have its complete course in one county, Cashie was originally named Kesiah, the present name being a gradual corruption. See also Connaritsa.

label: Cashiers (CA-shers)
description: town in S Jackson County beside Cashiers Lake. Inc. 1927. Post office est. 1851 as Cashiers Valley; named changed to Cashiers in 1881. The origin of the name is uncertain, but there are many stories, some concerning a horse named Cash that grazed there. Other stories concern a hermit named Cashiers who lived there.

label: Cashiers Lake
description: an artificial lake in S Jackson County formed in 1922 on Chattooga River. Covers 30 acres, with a max. depth of 50 feet. Used for fishing, boating, and power generation. Named for nearby town of Cashiers.

label: Cashiers Township
description: S Jackson County.

label: Cashiers Valley
description: See Cashiers.

label: Cashoke Creek
description: rises in SE Bertie County and flows SE into Cashie River.

label: Cason Old Field
description: community in S central Anson County. Named for local family.

label: Castalia
description: town in NW Nash County. Settled about 1850. Named about 1853 by David S. Richardson, local schoolmaster and native of Cornish, N.H., for Castalian Springs (of Greek mythology) located near Mount Parnassus. Alt. 319.

label: Castalia Township
description: NW Nash County.

label: Castle Creek
description: rises in N Person County and flows N into Hyco River.

label: Castle Dobbs
description: See Russellborough.

label: Castle Hayne
description: community in N New Hanover County. Est. by 1861 and known as Spring Garden for a number of years. Appears as such on the Colton map, 1861, and on other maps through the 1870s. By 1882 (Kerr map) it was called Castle Hayne. Named for Capt. Roger Haynes, who built a "castle" nearby prior to the Revolutionary War. Originally Castle Haynes but shortened to Castle Hayne by the railroad and later adopted by the post office. A 6,000-acre agricultural colony est. there by Hugh MacRae in the early twentieth century included a number of Dutch families. Produces commercial flowers and bulbs, vegetables, and chemicals. Alt. 20.

label: Castle of Thundertontrenck
description: See Lenox Castle.

label: Castle Tryon
description: See Russellborough.

label: Castle, The
description: an island of approx. 1/10 acre in the Pamlico River, W Beaufort County, about 350 yards offshore from the town of Washington. Site of shipbuilding activity in nineteenth century.

label: Castletons Creek
description: See Raccoon Creek.

label: Castoria
description: community in N central Greene County. A noted pre-Civil War plantation house of the name still exists there and gave its name to the community. Probably named for Castor, one of the Greek mythological Dioscuri twins.

label: Casville
description: community in W Caswell County. Known as Dove's Crossroads until about 1962.

label: Caswell
description: community in N Jones County. Alt. 46.

label: Caswell Beach
description: the S beach front on Oak Island, SE Brunswick County.

label: Caswell Branch
description: rises in SW Warren County and flows S into Shocco Creek.

label: Caswell County
description: was formed in 1777 from Orange County. In the N central section of the state, it is bounded by the state of Virginia and by Person, Orange, Alamance, and Rockingham Counties. It was named for Richard Caswell (1729-89), member of the First Continental Congress, major general in the Revolutionary War, and first governor of the state of North Carolina. Area: 435 sq. mi. County seat: Yanceyville, with an elevation of 619 ft. Townships are Anderson, Dan River, Hightowers, Leasburg, Locust Hill, Milton, Pelham, Stony Creek, and Yanceyville. Produces wheat, oats, corn, tobacco, livestock, hogs, textiles, meat, clothing, lumber, crushed stone, and sand.

label: Caswell Court House
description: See Yanceyville.

label: Caswell District
description: one of the districts into which Caswell County was divided at the time of the 1790 census. It contained 201 heads of families.

label: Caswell Township
description: W Pender County.

label: Caswells Branch
description: See Poorhouse Run.

label: Caswells Landing
description: See Hookerton.

label: Cat Creek
description: rises in E Macon County and flows NW into Rabbit Creek.

label: Cat Gap
description: central Transylvania County near the head of King Creek.

label: Cat Island
description: a small island in SW Carteret County in Bogue Sound.

label: Cat Pen Branch
description: rises in W Madison County and flows S into Roaring Fork.

label: Cat Pen Gap
description: N Transylvania County between Cat Gap and Horse Cove.

label: Cat Point
description: central Onslow County in Farnell Bay.

label: Cat Ridge
description: NE Transylvania County N of McCall Mountain.

label: Cat Square
description: crossroads community in NW Lincoln County. Named after unwanted cats and kittens were left there on several occasions.

label: Cat Tail Creek
description: rises in N Johnston County and flows SE into Little River.

label: Cataloochee
description: community on Cataloochee Creek in W Haywood County. Now almost entirely in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Alt. 2,620. Population formerly around 250. Cataloochee is a corruption of the Indian word gad-a-lu-sti, a descriptive exclamation that means "standing in a row." It is what the Indians saw from Cove Creek Gap—timber standing up on the distant mountains near the head of the watershed.

label: Cataloochee Balsam
description: mountain on the Haywood-Swain county line between Horse Creek Gap and Pauls Gap. Alt. 5,940.

label: Cataloochee Creek
description: is formed in W Haywood County by the junction of Caldwell Fork and Palmer Creek. It flows SE and E into Waterville Lake on Pigeon River.

label: Cataloochee Divide
description: W Haywood County, Great Smoky Mountains National Park, extending NE from Whim Knob. It forms the E boundary of the park for more than 10 mi. It also marks the Cataloochee Creek and Johnson Creek drainage line.

label: Cataloochee Township
description: NE Haywood County.

label: Catawba
description: town in E Catawba County on the Catawba River. Inc. 1893. Alt. 834. Post office first est. as Chestnut Grove in nearby Iredell County, but the name was changed to Catawba Station when it was moved to E Catawba County in 1859. Became Catawba in 1877.

label: Catawba County
description: was formed in 1842 from Lincoln County. Located in the W central section of the state, it is bounded by Iredell, Lincoln, Burke, Caldwell, and Alexander Counties. It was named for the Catawba Indians, who once inhabited the region. Area: 412 sq. mi. County seat: Newton, with an elevation of 996 ft. Townships are Bandy, Caldwell, Catawba, Clines, Hickory, Jacobs Fork, Mountain Creek, and Newton. Produces wheat, oats, barley, hay, poultry, corn, cattle, hogs, hosiery, furniture, fiber-optic cable, textiles, electronics, fabricated metals, lumber, paper boxes, crushed stone, and brick.

label: Catawba Creek
description: rises in central Gaston County within the limits of Gastonia and flows SE into South Carolina, where it enters the Catawba River near the state line.

label: Catawba Falls
description: on the headwaters of Catawba River in SW McDowell County near Ridgecrest. Water falls in a continuous spray down five levels of rock. Sometimes called Rocky Glen for one of the upper falls where water plunges over a ledge 200 ft. high.

label: Catawba Ferry
description: operated on Catawba River at Lincoln-Mecklenburg county line in NW Mecklenburg County.

label: Catawba Lake
description: See Lake Wylie.

label: Catawba Land
description: See Piedmont.

label: Catawba River
description: rises in the Blue Ridge Mountains in SW McDowell County near the Buncombe-McDowell county line. It flows NE through McDowell and E through Burke County; forms successively the Caldwell-Catawba, Alexander-Catawba, Iredell-Catawba, Iredell-Lincoln, Mecklenburg-Lincoln, and Mecklenburg-Gaston county lines. It enters South Carolina W of Charlotte and flows S to join Big Wateree Creek in Wateree Pond to form the Wateree River about 20 mi. above Camden. From its headwaters to the South Carolina line, it flows approx. 150 mi. Catawba was an Indian word that may have meant "people of the river banks" or "people of the river [Catawba] with broken banks." For some of the named fords across the river, see also Beattie's, Cowan's, Island, Sherrills, Tools, and Tuckasege.

label: Catawba Springs
description: community in N Catawba County. Former resort, popular in late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries. Est. as Elliott Springs on June 10, 1859, and became White Sulphur Springs on August 1, 1860. The Sparkling Catawba Springs Company was inc. in 1869 to erect buildings and open and maintain the mineral springs. Became Sparkling Catawba Springs in 1877.

label: Catawba Springs Township
description: E Lincoln County.

label: Catawba Station
description: See Catawba.

label: Catawba Township
description: E Catawba County. Name changed in 1879 from Hamilton Township.

label: Catawba Vale
description: See Old Fort.

label: Catechna
description: See Snow Hill.

label: Cateechee Branch
description: rises in E central Transylvania County and flows SE into French Broad River.

label: Caterpillar Creek
description: rises in SE Alamance County and flows SE into Orange County, where it enters Cane Creek.

label: Cates Creek
description: rises in central Orange County and flows NE into Eno River.

label: Catfield Point
description: S Onslow County in Stones Bay.

label: Catfish
description: community in W Catawba County served by post office, 1886-1903.

label: Catfish Lake
description: a natural lake in Croatan National Forest, E Jones and SW Craven Counties. Covers 950 acres, with a max. depth of 4 to 5 ft. It is in the Lakes Pocosin, which see.

label: Catfish Point
description: E Tyrrell County, extends from the mainland into Alligator River.

label: Catharine Creek
description: rises in E Hertford County and flows N into Chowan River. Undoubtedly a corruption of Cautaking, Catokinge, or Cataking, an Indian village of the sixteenth century located in the area. The Indian name probably meant "at the land that pushes" or "bulges out," as if into the river.

label: Catharine Lake
description: a natural lake in NW Onslow County. Covers approx. 45 acres, with a max. depth of 15 ft. Alt. 17. A community by the name existed as early as 1861, but the lake itself apparently is not shown on early maps. Local tradition says that it was named by John Avirette for his fiancée, Catharine Cole. Another source relates that it was named for the Cothran family in the vicinity.

label: Catherine Creek
description: is formed on the Gates-Chowan county line by the junction of Trotman and Warwick Creeks and flows SW into Chowan River. Appears on the Collet map, 1770, as Catharines Creek.

label: Cathey
description: community in E Jackson County served by post office, 1883-1901.

label: Cathey Cove
description: S Haywood County on a tributary of Little East Fork Pigeon River.

label: Cathey Creek
description: rises in NW Mecklenburg County and flows W into Davidson Creek.

label: Cathey Gap
description: E Haywood County between Rocky Knob and Pressly Mountain.

label: Cathey Ridge
description: S Haywood County between Cathey Cove and Hemlock Branch.

label: Cathey's
description: community in W Rowan County. Named for George Cathey, who had a grant of land there in 1750.

label: Cathey's Creek
description: See Kerr Creek; Sloans Creek.

label: Cathey's Fort
description: See Woodlawn.

label: Catheys Creek
description: rises in W Transylvania County and flows SE into French Broad River.

label: Catheys Creek Falls
description: is located on Catheys Creek in central Transylvania County between King Mountain and Kagle Mountain. Falls are 40 ft. high. Alt. approx. 2,520.

label: Catheys Creek Township
description: central Transylvania County.

label: Caton
description: See Zorah.

label: Catskill Creek
description: See Catskin Creek.

label: Catskin Creek
description: rises in S Pender County and flows SW into Merricks Creek. Formerly Catskill Creek until corrupted by local usage into present name.

label: Catstair Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NW into Ashturn Branch.

label: Catstairs, The
description: a very rough and steep trail followed by wildcats from one mountain to another near the head of West Fork Overflow Creek in S Macon County. See also Winding Stairs for another use of the name.

label: Cattail Bay
description: a loam-filled bay in central Columbus County.

label: Cattail Branch
description: rises in N Wilson County near Cliftonsville and flows S approx. 1 mi. into Toisnot Swamp.

label: Cattail Creek
description: rises in central Granville County and flows SW into Tar River.

label: Cattail Peak
description: S Yancey County between Balsam Cone and Potato Hill in the Black Mountains. Alt. 6,583.

label: Cattail Swamp
description: rises in N central Wilson County and flows E into Town Creek.

label: Causey
description: See Bonlee.

label: Cavanaugh Ditch
description: a drain in S Duplin County to carry the waters of Kenan Pocosin into Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: Caves, The
description: natural subterranean caves in NW Rutherford County between Broad River and Buffalo Creek in Rumbling Bald Mountain, which see.

label: Cawcaw Bay
description: shallow mucky area about 5 mi. long and about 2 mi. wide near SW edge of Green Swamp, SW Brunswick County.

label: Cawcaw Swamp
description: rises in Cawcaw Bay, SW Brunswick County, and flows SW into Waccamaw River.

label: Cecil
description: community in S Haywood County served by post office, 1898-1914.

label: Cecil Township
description: S Haywood County.

label: Cecils Harbor
description: appears on the Smith map, 1624, applied to the three bays in S Hyde County now called Rose Bay, Swanquarter Bay, and Juniper Bay. Perhaps named for William Cecil, Lord Burleigh (1520-98), or Robert Cecil, first Earl of Salisbury (1563?-1612).

label: Cedar
description: community in NW Bladen County served by post office, 1882-1903.

label: Cedar Bay
description: is formed by waters of Neuse River and the N tip of Carteret County.

label: Cedar Bay Point
description: a point on the S shore of the Neuse River about 4 mi. upstream from its mouth and N of the entrance to Cedar Bay in NE Carteret County.

label: Cedar Branch
description: rises in central Columbus County and flows E into Soules Swamp.

label: Cedar Branch
description: rises in SE Wilson County and flows S approx. 3½ mi. into Black Creek.

label: Cedar Cliff
description: peak in the Great Craggy Mountains, NE Buncombe County, between Eagle Rock Cove and Wolf Branch. Alt. 4,400.

label: Cedar Cliff Knob
description: NE Buncombe County W of Sheepwallow Knob.

label: Cedar Cliff Lake
description: central Jackson County on Tuckasegee River, 14 mi. S of Sylva. Covers 121 acres; max. depth 150 ft. Dam constructed 1952; used to generate hydroelectric power for Nantahala Power and Light Company. Named for Cedar Cliff Mountain at the upper end of the lake. Alt. 2,330.

label: Cedar Cliff Mountain
description: S Macon County between Andy Gap and Buddy Gap. Alt. 4,824.

label: Cedar Cliff Ridge
description: N Macon County at the head of Shepherd Creek.

label: Cedar Cliffs
description: at the S end of Cullowhee Mountain in W Jackson County.

label: Cedar Cove
description: W Graham County between Cedar Top and Santeetlah Creek.

label: Cedar Creek
description: community in S Cumberland County on the stream of the same name. Appears as Terebinthe on the Kerr map, 1882.

label: Cedar Creek
description: rises in SE Buncombe County and flows SE into Rutherford County, where it enters Cove Creek.

label: Cedar Creek
description: rises in E Anson County and flows N into Pee Dee River.

label: Cedar Creek Township
description: E central Cumberland County.

label: Cedar Falls
description: community in central Randolph County on Deep River. Inc. 1899; charter repealed 1901. Once known as Everett's Mill for Col. Benjamin Everett. The first cotton mill in the county, Sapona Cotton Mill, was built there in 1836. Produced underwear for Confederate troops.

label: Cedar Fork
description: rises in NE Wake County and flows E into Little River at Mitchells Millpond. Also known as Cedar Prong of Little River.

label: Cedar Fork Township
description: W Wake County.

label: Cedar Forks
description: community in W Northampton County.

label: Cedar Grove
description: community in NW Orange County. A post office was est. there in 1826.

label: Cedar Grove Township
description: NW Orange County.

label: Cedar Hammock
description: an island in Bogue Sound, SW Carteret County.

label: Cedar Hill
description: community in N Anson County.

label: Cedar Inlet
description: an inlet approx. in the middle of Core Banks in E Carteret County on Outer Banks.

label: Cedar Island
description: a small island in Bogue Sound, S Carteret County.

label: Cedar Island
description: a two-acre uninhabited tidal-marsh island in Cedar Island Bay on the W side of Church Island, central Currituck County.

label: Cedar Island Bay
description: approx. 4 mi. long and 1½ mi. wide, NE Carteret County. Bounded by Cedar Island, Back Bay, and Core Sound.

label: Cedar Island Point
description: NE Carteret County; easternmost point of Cedar Island on S side of entrance from Core Sound into Cedar Island Bay.

label: Cedar Knob
description: W Madison County between Granger Mountain and Friezeland Creek.

label: Cedar Lodge
description: community in E Davidson County. Named for the home of John W. Thomas, founder of Thomasville, who lived there, 1825-52. A nineteenth-century post office serving the community was Fair Grove, a name by which the community is also sometimes known.

label: Cedar Mountain
description: SW Polk County. Alt. 2,200.

label: Cedar Mountain
description: a peak in the South Mountains, S Burke County. Alt. 2,160.

label: Cedar Point
description: point of land in SW Carteret County extending into the mouth of White Oak River and Bogue Sound. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Cedar Point Mountain
description: W Rockingham County near Mayo River. See Baughn Mountain.

label: Cedar Prong of Little River
description: See Cedar Fork.

label: Cedar Rock
description: community in E Franklin County.

label: Cedar Rock
description: E Transylvania County between Buck Forest and Little River.

label: Cedar Rock Creek
description: rises in W Transylvania County near Cedar Rock Mountain and flows N into Davidson River.

label: Cedar Rock Mountain
description: W Randolph County.

label: Cedar Rock Township
description: former township in E Franklin County, now township no. 8.

label: Cedar Run
description: See Vashti.

label: Cedar Run Creek
description: rises in NE Alexander County and flows S into South Yadkin River. Considered the head stream of South Yadkin River.

label: Cedar Swamp Creek
description: rises in central Carteret County and flows NE into Newport River.

label: Cedar Top
description: mountain in W Graham County between Hooper Mill Creek and Hooper Cove. Alt. approx. 4,000.

label: Cedar Valley
description: community in S Caldwell County on Upper Little River.

label: Cedar Valley Creek
description: rises in central Jackson County and flows SW into Tuckasegee River. Formerly known as Niggerskull Creek; name changed in 2006 by U.S. Board on Geographic Names.

label: Cedar Valley Knob
description: in central Jackson County between Cedar Valley Creek and Gladie Creek. Alt. 3,500. Formerly known as Nigger-skull Mountain; name changed in 2006 by U.S. Board on Geographic Names.

label: Cefare
description: community in NW Wilson County between Turkey Creek and Marsh Swamp. Named for Cefare Bissett. A post office existed there, 1899-1904.

label: Ceffo
description: community in NW Person County. Served by post office, 1881-1907.

label: Celia Creek
description: rises in SW Caldwell County and flows SE into Husbands Creek. Originally named Sealeys Creek for George Sealey, eighteenth-century settler.

label: Celo
description: community in E Yancey County on Browns Creek. Alt. 2,735. Named for nearby Celo Knob.

label: Celo Knob
description: E Yancey County near the head of Browns Creek. Alt. 6,326.

label: Celo Ridge
description: E Yancey County between Ayles and Browns creeks. Named for the Indian word seeloo (corn).

label: Cemetery Branch
description: rises in central Wake County within the limits of Raleigh and flows N into Pigeon House Branch.

label: Center
description: community in W Yadkin County E of Cranberry Creek.

label: Center Grove
description: community in central Granville County.

label: Center Grove Township
description: N central Guilford County.

label: Center of North Carolina
description: See Geographic Center.

label: Center Township
description: central Chatham County.

label: Centerville
description: See Kelly.

label: Centerville
description: community in NE Franklin County. Alt. 300. Settled about 1882. Named because of its central position between Warrenton, Louisburg, and Littleton.

label: Central Falls
description: community on Deep River, central Randolph County. Long the site of one or more textile mills. Named for minor falls on the river, now obliterated by dams constructed for water power.

label: Central Township
description: central Bladen County.

label: Centre
description: community in S Guilford County. Named for Centre Friends Meeting, begun in 1757.

label: Centre Hill
description: town in E Chowan County. Inc. 1935, but no longer active in municipal affairs. A post office est. there in 1886 was first known as Centre Hill but was renamed for James N. Tyner (1826-1904), a former postmaster general. Tyner is still the post office name.

label: Cerro Gordo
description: town in W Columbus County. Inc. 1874 and named for the Mexican battleground where Gen. Winfield Scott, in 1847, was victorious. In Spanish the name means "big hill." Alt. 95.

label: Cerro Gordo Township
description: W Columbus County.

label: Chacandepeco
description: See Chancandepeco Inlet.

label: Chadbourn
description: town in N Columbus County. Inc. 1883. Named for a family of lumber merchants. Produces lumber and textiles. Alt. 105.

label: Chadbourn Township
description: W central Columbus County.

label: Chadwick
description: former mill community in W Mecklenburg County.

label: Chadwick Acres
description: in S Onslow County on Chadwick Bay. Inc. 1961, but now inactive in municipal affairs. Planned as a resort development. Covers 308 acres.

label: Chadwick Bay
description: SE Carteret County, the mouth of Chadwick Creek. Named for Samuel Chadwick, eighteenth-century whaler who lived in the vicinity.

label: Chadwick Creek
description: rises in S Carteret County and flows S into Chadwick Bay. Appears as Larler Creek on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Chafin
description: community in W Harnett County served by post office, 1890-1908.

label: Chainshot Island
description: NE Carteret County in Core Sound, midway between Hog Island and Harbor Island. Named for a kind of shot consisting of two balls or half balls united by a short chain, formerly used in naval warfare to cut a ship's rigging or to sweep its decks. Named as early as the Moseley map, 1733. See also Hunting Quarter Sound.

label: Chairmaker Branch
description: rises in central Clay County and flows NW into Tusquitee Creek.

label: Chairman
description: community in NE Brunswick County.

label: Chalk Creek
description: rises in N Rutherford County and flows SW into Cove Creek.

label: Chalk Level
description: community in N Harnett County served by post office, 1855-1908.

label: Chalk Mountain
description: S Mitchell County between Brushy Creek and North Toe River. Alt. 3,558.

label: Chalybeate (ka-lib-e-ate)
description: community in N Harnett County. Settled 1760. Named for nearby springs containing salts of iron. Former health resort. Alt. 175.

label: Chambers
description: community in SW Burke County.

label: Chambers Branch
description: rises in E Haywood County on Chambers Mountain and flows S into Pigeon River.

label: Chambers Cove
description: S Haywood County on a tributary of West Prong Pigeon River.

label: Chambers Creek
description: rises in N Swain County and flows SW into Fontana Lake.

label: Chambers Creek Gap
description: N Swain County on Welch Ridge near the head of Bear Creek. Named for John Chambers, an early settler.

label: Chambers Mountain
description: E Haywood County, extends NE from the head of Long Branch to the head of Rogers Cove Creek.

label: Chambersburg Township
description: SE Iredell County. Named for local Chambers family.

label: Champion
description: community in SW Wilkes County near South Prong Lewis Fork Creek.

label: Chancandepeco Inlet
description: from the Atlantic Ocean into Pamlico Sound through Hatteras Island N of Cape Hatteras, SE Dare County. Opened prior to 1585 and closed prior to 1657. Appears as Chacandepeco on the Velasco map, 1611. The name is possibly a Spanish spelling for an Algonquian Indian word meaning "it dips and disappears as shallows."

label: Chance
description: community in W Sampson County served by post office, 1889-1904.

label: Chandler
description: community in NE Montgomery County served by post office, 1875-1927. Known as Chandler's Grove until 1894.

label: Chandler Creek
description: rises in E Madison County and flows SE into California Creek.

label: Chandler Knob
description: N Madison County near the head of Revere Creek.

label: Chandler's Grove
description: See Chandler.

label: Chaney Creek
description: rises in central Onslow County and flows SW into New River.

label: Chapanoke
description: community in E Perquimans County. Named for an Indian village, Chepanoc, the site of which probably is on Wade Point, Pasquotank County. The name apparently was an Indian word for "land of the dead." Alt. 15.

label: Chapel Branch
description: rises in W Beaufort County and flows N into Bear Creek.

label: Chapel Creek
description: rises SE of the town of Chapel Hill, SE Orange County, and flows SE into Morgan Creek.

label: Chapel Hill
description: town in SE Orange County, seat of the University of North Carolina, which opened January 16, 1795. A committee to lay out the town was authorized by the trustees of the university on December 8, 1792, and lots were first sold on October 12, 1793. Appears on the Samuel Lewis map published in Carey's atlas in 1795. Inc. 1819. Named for the Church of England New Hope Chapel, which once stood at the crossroads on the wooded hill. Alt. 501.

label: Chapel Hill Township
description: SE Orange County.

label: Chapel Swamp
description: NW Tyrrell County on the W side of Scuppernong River. Named for St. Paul's Church, which stood in the vicinity in the eighteenth century.

label: Chaplin's Stand
description: See Bixby.

label: Chapman
description: community in N Alexander County.

label: Chapmans Creek
description: rises in central Surry County and flows SE into Fisher River.

label: Chappel Creek
description: appears on the Moseley map, 1733, rising in E Beaufort Precinct and flowing E into Machapungo River. The water course probably is either modern Jordan or Satterthwaite Creek.

label: Chappel Swamp
description: N Washington County on the head of Whites Creek, drains NW into Kendricks Creek.

label: Chappels Creek
description: rises in S Person County and flows S into North Flat River.

label: Charity
description: community in S Duplin County.

label: Charles
description: community in N central Iredell County.

label: Charles Creek
description: See Muddy Creek.

label: Charles Creek
description: rises in NE Mitchell County and flows SW into Little Rock Creek.

label: Charles River
description: See Cape Fear River.

label: Charles Town
description: center of a colony from Charlestowne, Mass., est. in 1662 under the leadership of William Hilton, on Town Creek, E Brunswick County. Abandoned in 1663. In 1664 a colony from Barbados under the leadership of Sir John Yeamans occupied the site, but they abandoned it in 1665. New Town on the Ogilby map, 1671, apparently was intended to designate the settlement. See also Clarendon County.

label: Charleston
description: community in SE Halifax County.

label: Charleston Township
description: E Swain County. Enlarged between 1934 and 1940 with the establishment of Great Smoky Mountains National Park to include the E part of Forneys Creek Township and all of Oconalufty Township.

label: Charley Bald
description: a peak at the N end of Charley Ridge on Rich Mountain in E Jackson County. Alt. 5,530.

label: Charley Branch
description: rises in W Madison County and flows SE into Spring Creek.

label: Charley Creek
description: rises in E Jackson County and flows S into Wolf Creek.

label: Charley Knob
description: on the S end of Charley Ridge in E Jackson County.

label: Charley Ridge
description: E Jackson County between Gage Creek and Charley Creek.

label: Charlie Creek
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows S into Little Creek.

label: Charlie Ridge
description: N Buncombe County W of Brittain Mountain.

label: Charlies Bunion Mountain
description: on Swain County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Alt. 5,375. So named because Charles Connor remarked to George Masa that the peak looked "like a bunion on Old Smoky's foot."

label: Charlies Island
description: a land formation in S Duplin County that is surrounded by swamp.

label: Charlies Ridge
description: on the Avery-Mitchell county line between Wolf Ridge and Spear Tops.

label: Charlone Creek
description: See Shelton Creek.

label: Charlotte
description: city and county seat, central Mecklenburg County. Settled about 1750; est. 1768. Named for Queen Charlotte Sophia of Mecklenburg-Strelitz (1744-1818), wife of George III. Appears as Charlottesburgh on the Collet map, 1770. Home of University of North Carolina at Charlotte, Queens University of Charlotte, Johnson C. Smith University, and Central Piedmont Community College. Center for banking services. Produces fabricated metals, textiles, dairy and bakery products, industrial machinery, canned foods, paper products, hosiery, processed meat, primary metals, aircraft parts, apparel, furniture, electronic components, boxes, and chemicals. Alt. 795.

label: Charlotte Branch
description: rises in W Madison County and flows NE into Spring Branch.

label: Charlotte Cove
description: N Cherokee County between Moss Branch and Little Dam Branch.

label: Charlotte Crossing
description: See Claremont.

label: Charlotte Township
description: former township in central Mecklenburg County, now township no. 1.

label: Charlottesburgh
description: See Charlotte.

label: Charm
description: community in central Robeson County served by post office, 1888-1903.

label: Chasm Prong
description: rises in N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows E to join Gulf Prong in forming Bradley Fork.

label: Chasteen Creek
description: rises in NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows SW into Bradley Fork.

label: Chasteen Mountain
description: SW Clay County between Trout Cove Branch and Greasy Creek.

label: Chastine Creek
description: rises in E Jackson County and flows S into Caney Fork.

label: Chatham
description: See Pittsboro.

label: Chatham County
description: was formed in 1771 from Orange County. Located in the central section of the state, it is bounded by Wake, Harnett, Lee, Moore, Randolph, Alamance, Orange, and Durham Counties. It was named for William Pitt, Earl of Chatham (1708-78), who vigorously opposed the harsh measures taken in England with regard to the American colonies in 1774-75 and who advocated cessation of hostilities in 1777. Area: 707 sq. mi. County seat: Pittsboro, with an elevation of 409 ft. Townships are Albright, Baldwin, Bear Creek, Cape Fear, Center, Gulf, Hadley, Haw River, Hickory Mountain, Matthew, New Hope, Oakland, and William. Produces wheat, oats, livestock, poultry, hay, corn, furniture, plywood, bricks, mobile homes, nursery products, textiles, hosiery, crushed stone, and clay for brick.

label: Chattoka
description: a Tuscarora Indian village appearing on the Lawson map, 1709, and the Moll map, 1729, between the Neuse and Trent Rivers, central Craven County. The name meant "where the fish are taken out." When the Tuscarora Indians moved to New York, they took the name with them and it has survived as Chautauqua.

label: Chattooga Ridge
description: S Jackson County, extends SE in an arc from Little Terrapin Mountain to Heddie Mountain. The name is a variation of the Cherokee word chatawga (chicken).

label: Chattooga River
description: rises in SW Jackson County and flows S to the Jackson-Macon county line, which it forms for a short distance before flowing into South Carolina, where it enters Savannah River.

label: Chatuge Lake
description: SE Clay County on Hiwassee River. Created 1942 by a dam in the river at the mouth of Shooting Creek. Lake about 10 mi. long, covers over 8,000 acres; max. depth 144 ft. Forms a holding reservoir in the Tennessee Valley Authority system. Used for power, boating, swimming, and fishing.

label: Chawanoac
description: an Indian village near the junction of the present Chowan-Gates-Hertford county lines on the Chowan River. Appears on the White map, 1585. See also Chowan.

label: Cheathamville
description: See Manson.

label: Cheaves
description: community in SE Franklin County served by post office, 1898-1903.

label: Cheaves Mill
description: formerly a homestead and mill in SW Vance County located approx. a mile upstream from the mouth of Tabb Creek, below the junction of Long Creek. Appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Cheecods Creek
description: See Chicod Creek.

label: Cheek Creek
description: rises in SE Montgomery County and flows SW into Richmond County, where it enters Little River.

label: Cheek Creek Township
description: S central Montgomery County.

label: Cheek Mountain
description: grass-covered peak in the Peach Bottom Mountain range, W central Alleghany County.

label: Cheeks
description: community in SE Randolph County on Deep River.

label: Cheeks Crossroads
description: community in W Orange County.

label: Cheeks Township
description: W central Orange County.

label: Cheeohwa
description: See Cheoah.

label: Cheeweo
description: a Tuscarora Indian village, appears on the Moseley map, 1733, on the Roanoke River. Site probably near the present town of Williamston in N central Martin County.

label: Chemway
description: community in W Mecklenburg County.

label: Cheney Bay
description: S Carteret County, lying between Turner Creek and North River Thorofare.

label: Cheoah
description: community in E central Graham County on Sweetwater Creek. Alt. 2,300. Named for the Indian word tsiyahi or cheeohwa, meaning "otter."

label: Cheoah Bald
description: on the Graham-Swain county line between Bellcollar Gap and Sassafras Gap. Alt. 5,062.

label: Cheoah Branch
description: rises in NW Swain County and flows SW into Fontana Lake.

label: Cheoah Mountains
description: extend across central Graham County E in an arc from the headwaters of Gladdens Creek to the headwaters of Sawyer Creek.

label: Cheoah River
description: is formed in central Graham County by the junction of Sweetwater and Tulula Creeks. It flows NW into Little Tennessee River at Cheoah Dam. Santeetlah Lake is on Cheoah River.

label: Cheoah Township
description: S Graham County. See also Qualla Boundary.

label: Cheoah Valley
description: See Robbinsville.

label: Chepanuu
description: two Indian villages of the Weapemeoc tribe shown on the De Bry map, 1590, in what is now SW Pasquotank County on the Little River estuary.

label: Cheraw
description: community in central Caldwell County, named for the Cheraw (or Saura) Indians that formerly roamed the area.

label: Cherokee
description: town in E Swain County on Oconaluftee River that is the governmental and spiritual center of the Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians. Alt. 1,955. The name probably is from the Muskogee Indian word tciloki, meaning "people of a different speech." The outdoor drama Unto These Hills, written by Kermit Hunter, has been produced there each summer since 1950; the Museum of the Cherokee Indian and the Oconaluftee Indian Village Living History Museum are also there.

label: Cherokee County
description: was formed in 1839 from Macon County. Located in the W section of the state, it is bounded by the states of Georgia and Tennessee and by Graham, Swain, Macon, and Clay Counties. It was named for the Cherokee Indians, some of whom still live in the region. Area: 467 sq. mi. County seat: Murphy, with an elevation of 1,535 ft. Townships are Beaverdam, Hot House, Murphy, Notla, Shoal Creek, and Valley Town. Produces corn, poultry, dairy products, livestock, hogs, hay, textiles, apparel, tools, lumber, marble, talc, and crushed stone.

label: Cherokee Creek
description: rises in SE Rutherford County and flows N into Second Broad River.

label: Cherokee Gap
description: on Jackson-Swain county line near Oconaluftee River.

label: Cherokee Indian Reservation
description: See Qualla Boundary.

label: Cherry
description: town in E Washington County on Scuppernong River. Inc. 1907. A post office from 1898 until 1908.

label: Cherry Branch
description: rises in NW Macon County and flows NW into Otter Creek.

label: Cherry Cove
description: S Haywood County on the head of Cherry Cove Creek.

label: Cherry Cove Branch
description: rises in S Clay County and flows NW into Hothouse Branch.

label: Cherry Cove Creek
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows NE into Allen Creek.

label: Cherry Creek
description: rises in central Henderson County and flows W into Mud Creek.

label: Cherry Flats
description: E Haywood County on the head of Cove Creek.

label: Cherry Gap
description: on the Mitchell County, N.C.-Unicoi County, Tenn., line.

label: Cherry Gap
description: on the Haywood-Transylvania county line on Pisgah Ridge S of Bennett Gap.

label: Cherry Gap Branch
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows W into Cullowhee Creek.

label: Cherry Glade
description: community in NW Pasquotank County.

label: Cherry Grove
description: community in SW Caswell County.

label: Cherry Hill
description: plantation in S Warren County near the community of Inez, the home of George W. Alston. The house built in 1852 is still standing.

label: Cherry Knob
description: NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on the W side of Jenkins Trail Ridge and at the NE end of Big Fork Ridge. Alt. 4,420.

label: Cherry Knob
description: on Cullowhee Mountain in W Jackson County.

label: Cherry Lane
description: community in SE Alleghany County, settled about 1838 and named for cherry tree-bordered lane leading to home of Frank Bryan. Alt. 2,810.

label: Cherry Lane Township
description: SE Alleghany County.

label: Cherry Log Gap
description: N Buncombe County between Bald Knob and Little Snowball Mountain.

label: Cherry Log Ridge
description: S Yancey County between Left Prong South Toe River and Hemphill Creek.

label: Cherry Mountain
description: mountain range in E Rutherford County. Called Flint Hill prior to the Civil War, when flint for rifles was obtained there. Acquired the name Cherry Mountain after the war when Amos Owens, Confederate veteran, made corn liquor and "cherry bounce" from cherry trees growing there. See also Sweezy Mountain.

label: Cherry Orchard Branch
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows NW into Hornbuckle Creek.

label: Cherry Point
description: a point of land extending into the Neuse River near the mouth of Hancock Creek in SE Craven County.

label: Cherry Point Marine Air Station
description: SE Craven County on Neuse River. Begun in July 1941; opened March 1942. On 12,000 acres, it is the largest Marine air station in the world. The Overhaul and Repair Department of the U.S. Marine Air Corps there is the largest industrial defense plant in the state. A small community, Cherry Point, existed there prior to the est. of the station. The town of Havelock is adjacent.

label: Cherry Pond
description: a marsh in central Duplin County.

label: Cherry Ridge Landing
description: S Tyrrell County on Alligator River approx. 2 mi. E of its confluence with Northwest Fork [Alligator River]. The Indian village Tramaskecooc, which see, was at or near the site.

label: Cherry Run
description: rises in W Beaufort County and flows SW into Tranters Creek.

label: Cherryfield
description: community in S Transylvania County between Morgan Mill Creek and Cherryfield Creek. Alt. 2,180.

label: Cherryfield Creek
description: rises in W Transylvania County on S slopes of Three Forks Mountain and flows SE into French Broad River.

label: Cherryville
description: town in NW Gaston County. Post office est. there in 1854 as White Pine. Named changed to Cherryville in 1865; inc. 1872. Named for a row of cherry trees planted along an old rail fence parallel to the post road. Produces textiles. Alt. 971.

label: Cherryville Township
description: NW Gaston County.

label: Chesnut Ridge
description: See Wilson's Store.

label: Chesquau Branch
description: rises in W Swain County and flows S into Fontana Lake.

label: Chesson
description: community in N central Washington County.

label: Chester Branch
description: rises in S Jackson County and flows S into Fowler Creek.

label: Chesterfield
description: community in N central Burke County. Formerly known as Hoodsville.

label: Chesters Creek
description: rises in W Carteret County and flows SE into White Oak River.

label: Chestnut
description: community in W Catawba County served by post office, 1887-1904.

label: Chestnut Bald,
description: on the Haywood-Transylvania county line between Devils Court House and Silvermine Bald. Alt. 6,040.

label: Chestnut Branch
description: rises in N Clay County and flows NE into Tuni Creek.

label: Chestnut Branch
description: rises in N Haywood County near lat. 35Â°45'15" N., long. 83Â°09'45" W., and flows E into Big Creek.

label: Chestnut Cove
description: S Buncombe County SW of Truck-wheel Mountain.

label: Chestnut Cove Branch
description: rises in NE Buncombe County near Middle Mountain and flows W through Chestnut Cove into North Fork [Swannanoa River].

label: Chestnut Cove Creek
description: rises in E Swain County and flows NE into Connelly Creek.

label: Chestnut Cove Knob
description: on the Jackson-Macon county line.

label: Chestnut Cove Ridge
description: NE Buncombe County between Chestnut Cove and Big Cove.

label: Chestnut Creek
description: rises near Candler Knob on the Buncombe-Henderson county line and flows N into Stony Fork.

label: Chestnut Crossroads
description: See Macon.

label: Chestnut Flat
description: a relatively level area in N Buncombe County near Coles Cove.

label: Chestnut Flat Cove
description: S Haywood County on Little East Fork Pigeon River.

label: Chestnut Flat Ridge
description: central Haywood County parallel to Laurel Branch.

label: Chestnut Flats
description: a relatively level area in SE Buncombe County NE of Blue Rock Knob.

label: Chestnut Gap
description: on Buncombe-Madison county line between Little Sandy Mush Bald and North Fork Gap.

label: Chestnut Gap
description: in W Macon County at the head of Pierce Creek.

label: Chestnut Gap Mountain
description: W Cherokee County extending SE from Shoal Creek to Canedy Gap.

label: Chestnut Grove
description: community in SW Stokes County.

label: Chestnut Hill
description: community in NE Ashe County.

label: Chestnut Hill Township
description: NE Ashe County.

label: Chestnut Knob
description: N central Transylvania County near the head of Shutin Branch. Alt. approx. 3,860.

label: Chestnut Knob
description: N Buncombe County between Brank Mountain and Windy Gap.

label: Chestnut Log Branch
description: rises in central Cherokee County and flows S into Pace Branch.

label: Chestnut Log Gap
description: N Graham County between Tuskeegee Creek and Sawyer Creek.

label: Chestnut Log Spring Gap
description: on the Madison County, N.C.-Greene County, Tenn., line.

label: Chestnut Mountain
description: N Wilkes County between Mulberry Creek and Herald Mountain.

label: Chestnut Mountain
description: central Jackson County between Shoal Creek and Little Trout Creek.

label: Chestnut Mountain
description: at the junction of Avery-Burke-Caldwell county lines. Alt. 3,173.

label: Chestnut Oak Flats
description: level valley in W Avery County.

label: Chestnut Oak Ridge
description: W Avery County.

label: Chestnut Orchard Branch
description: rises in W Macon County and flows N into Choga Creek.

label: Chestnut Orchard Ridge
description: NW Cherokee County extending SE from Bryson Lead to Turkey Pen Hollow and Copper Creek.

label: Chestnut Ridge
description: E Jackson County between Rough Fork Creek and Piney Mountain Creek.

label: Chestnut Ridge
description: N central Avery County.

label: Chestnut Ridge Creek
description: rises in E Jackson County and flows SW into Piney Mountain Creek.

label: Chestnut Stamp Knob
description: N Clay County at the NE end of Evans Ridge.

label: Chestnut Top
description: on Buncombe-Henderson county line. Alt. 3,069.

label: Chestnutwood Ridge
description: W Avery County.

label: Chetola Lake
description: S Watauga County on Middle Fork [South Fork New River] N of town of Blowing Rock. Formed by a dam constructed in 1920; also fed by Stringfellow Branch. Covers 15 acres, with a max. depth of 20 ft.

label: Chicamacomico
description: the name given to three communities on N part of Outer Banks, E Dare County, S of Pea Island: formerly North Rodanthe, South Rodanthe, and Clarks, now known as Rodanthe, Waves, and Salvo.

label: Chicamacomico Banks
description: the name commonly given to Pea Island in E Dare County. The name appears on John Lawson's map, 1709, as Chickinnaccomac. A portion of the word is believed to be derived from an Algonquian word for "sinking-down sand."

label: Chicamacomico Coast Guard Station
description: in the community of Rodanthe on N Hatteras Island in E Dare County. Est. in 1874 as Lifesaving Station. Lifesaving Service and Revenue Cutter Service joined to form U.S. Coast Guard in 1915. Decommissioned, 1954.

label: Chickasaw Knobs
description: N Henderson County near Clear Creek. Alt. 2,686.

label: Chickehauk
description: See Kitty Hawk.

label: Chickinacommock
description: See New Inlet.

label: Chickinnaccomac
description: See Chicamacomico Banks.

label: Chickorack River
description: See South Creek.

label: Chicod
description: See Simpson.

label: Chicod Creek
description: rises in W Beaufort County and flows NW into Pitt County, where it enters Tar River. Appears as Cheecods Creek on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Chicod Township
description: SE Pitt County.

label: Chicora
description: a name applied to the Carolina coastal area, probably from the Cape Fear River to the Savannah River, explored by the Spaniard Louis Vázques de Ayllón in 1526.

label: Chiking Indian Fort
description: was referred to in grants made in 1730 for land in what is now Greene County. It was located 3 to 4 mi. downstream from Hookerton, SE Greene County, on the N side of Contentnea Creek, approx. ¾ mi. above the mouth of Polecat Branch.

label: Childsburgh
description: See Hillsborough.

label: Chiloe
description: community in central Moore County served by post office, 1891-1907.

label: Chiltoes Mountain
description: on Haywood-Swain county line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Located at NE end of Balsam Mountain near lat. 35°35'56" N., long. 83°11'09" W. Alt. 5,888.

label: Chiltoskie Ridge
description: See Balsam Mountain.

label: Chimney Creek
description: rises in N Madison County and flows E into Big Creek.

label: Chimney End Ridge
description: E Mitchell County between Reuben Creek and Powers Branch.

label: Chimney Knob
description: S Macon County between Carpenters Branch and Jones Creek.

label: Chimney Mountain
description: NW Burke County. Alt. 3,657. Known by the Cherokee Indians as Connatara.

label: Chimney Rock
description: a resort community in W Rutherford County S of Broad River. Named for nearby granite monolith rising 225 ft. from the shoulder of Chimney Rock Mountain and overlooking Hickory Nut Gorge (see Hickory Nut Gap) and Lake Lure. Alt. 1,050. A post office by the name existed there as early as 1843. Long owned by the Morse family, monolith and surrounding area were acquired for a state park in 2007.

label: Chimney Rock Mountain
description: W Rutherford County.

label: Chimney Rock Township
description: W Rutherford County.

label: Chimney Top
description: peak on Piney Mountain, W central Polk County. Ostin Creek rises there. Alt. 1,500.

label: Chimneytop Mountain
description: in S Jackson County 1 mi. E of Hampton Lake and S of Rocky Mountain. Alt. 4,618. Known by the Cherokee Indians as Kayoo-lanta (a chimney).

label: China Creek
description: rises in S Watauga County about 1 mi. W of town of Blowing Rock and flows S into Thunderhole Creek in N Caldwell County.

label: China Grove
description: town in S Rowan County. Post office est. there in 1823; name changed to Luthersville in 1846, but in 1849 it was changed back to China Grove. Named for chinaberry trees growing there. Inc. 1889. Alt. 867.

label: China Grove Township
description: S Rowan County.

label: China Hill
description: community in SW Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1829-40.

label: Chinkapin Creek
description: rises in NE Bertie County and flows NE into Hertford County, where it turns N to enter Wiccacon River. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Chinquapin
description: community in SE Duplin County, 1 mi. E of Northeast Cape Fear River. Name is an Algonquian Indian word for a kind of small chestnut. Produces tobacco, corn, and poultry. Birthplace of Caleb Bradham, inventor of Pepsi-Cola.

label: Chinquapin Branch
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows SW into Pisgah Creek.

label: Chinquapin Creek
description: rises in W Stokes County and flows SW into Surry County, where it enters Toms Creek.

label: Chinquapin Cross Roads
description: See Courtney.

label: Chinquapin Mountain
description: central Transylvania County between Gladys Branch and Country Club Lake.

label: Chinquapin Mountain
description: S Macon County between East Fork Overflow Creek and Little Scaly Mountain.

label: Chinquapin Ridge
description: high ground in Pantego Swamp, E Beaufort County.

label: Chinquapin Township
description: W Jones County.

label: Chip
