description: community in NE Craven County.

label: Chisholm's Store
description: See Pekin.

label: Chiska Creek
description: rises in W central Bertie County and flows E into Cashie River. Hills Mill on the creek is shown on the Collet map, 1770, but not on later maps.

label: Chisman
description: community in SE Stokes County.

label: Chockeyotte
description: town in N Halifax County. Inc. 1901.

label: Chockoyotte Creek
description: rises in N Halifax County and flows SE into Roanoke River. Name believed to be a Tuscarora Indian word. A stone aqueduct, part of the pre-Civil War Roanoke Navigation Canal, remains over the creek. It appears as Chocolate Creek on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Chocolate Creek
description: rises in SE Guilford County and flows NE into Stinking Quarter Creek.

label: Chocolate Drop Mountain
description: See Foster Mountain.

label: Chocowinity
description: town in W Beaufort County. Known as Godleys Crossroads until renamed for nearby creek. Inc. 1917; charter repealed 1947; reincorporated 1959. Railroad station name was Marsden, adopted in 1917 for Marsden J. Perry, a railroad official. Alt. 35.

label: Chocowinity Bay
description: formed by the mouth of Chocowinity Creek in Pamlico River, W Beaufort County.

label: Chocowinity Creek
description: rises in SW Beaufort County and flows N into Chocowinity Bay and Pamlico River. Called Worsley Creek on the Collet map, 1770; by 1808 (Price's map) it was called by its present name, though MacRae's map in 1833 called it Chocowinity Swamp. The name is said to be Indian in origin and to mean "fish from many waters."

label: Chocowinity Swamp
description: See Chocowinity Creek.

label: Chocowinity Township
description: SW Beaufort County.

label: Choffington
description: traditional site of the first courthouse of Cumberland County, located at the mouth of Little River near the present site of Linden in the N part of the county. The courthouse was there from 1755 until it was moved to Campbellton in 1765. The name may be derived from the old English word "chuff," meaning a rustic or rude, coarse fellow, and may have been applied by people of English descent to the recently arrived Scots.

label: Choga Creek
description: rises in W Macon County and flows NE into Nantahala Lake.

label: Choggy Butte Mountain
description: in E Jackson County on the head of Mull Creek.

label: Chokeberry Branch
description: rises in N Swain County and flows W into Forney Creek.

label: Choowatic Creek
description: rises in SE Bertie County and flows E into Roquist Creek.

label: Choratuck Inlet
description: See Currituck Inlet.

label: Chowan
description: an Indian town, shown on the Moseley map, 1733, as lying in the S central part of present Gates County between Bennetts Creek and Trotman Creek.

label: Chowan Beach
description: on Chowan River S of the mouth of Meherrin River on the E border of Hertford County. First named Mount Gallant for John Gallant, who operated a ferry there about 1720. Known as Mount Zion in the latter half of the eighteenth century.

label: Chowan County
description: was formed by 1668 as Shaftesbury Precinct of Albemarle County. Renamed Chowan Precinct about 1681. Located in the NE section of the state, it is bounded by Albemarle Sound, Chowan River, and Bertie, Hertford, Gates, and Perquimans Counties. It was named for the Chowan River. Area: 234 sq. mi. County seat: Edenton, with an elevation of 16 ft. Townships are nos. 1-4, formerly Edenton, Middle, Upper, and Yeopim. Produces corn, soybeans, peanuts, cotton, hogs, textiles, tires, boats, sweet potatoes, sorghum, cantaloupes, lumber, and processed seafood.

label: Chowan River
description: is formed on the Hertford-Gates county line a short distance S of the Virginia state line by the junction of the Nottoway and Blackwater Rivers. It flows SE on the Hertford-Gates and Bertie-Chowan county lines into Albemarle Sound. Named for the Chowanoc tribe of Indians who lived in the area. The word is a variant of the Algonquian sorwán (south). It may have derived from sowánohke (south country). The river was referred to by the Roanoke explorers, 1584-85, but given no specific name except as the location of the tribe. Appears as Choan River on the Comberford map, 1657.

label: Chowanoke
description: See Croatoan Island.

label: Chrissawn Knob
description: SE Yancey County on South Toe River near the mouth of Rock Creek.

label: Christ Branch
description: See Banjo Branch.

label: Christ-Church Parish
description: See Craven Parish.

label: Christian Creek
description: rises in SE Buncombe County and flows NW into Swannanoa River.

label: Christie Ford
description: See Murphy.

label: Chronicle
description: community in SE Catawba County. Est. 1857. Named for Maj. William Chronicle, killed at Battle of Kings Mountain. Alt. 1,048.

label: Chublake
description: community in central Person County served by post office, 1884-1905.

label: Chuckle
description: community in N Wilkes County near East Prong Roaring River.

label: Chum Creek
description: rises in NE Rutherford County and flows S into Duncans Creek.

label: Chunky Gal Mountain
description: SE Clay County, extending SE from Riley Knob to Big Laurel. Alt. 4,986. Named by slim Indian maidens who delighted in the capture (by her father) of a heavyset Indian lass who had run away to marry a young brave against her family's wishes.

label: Chunky Pipe Creek
description: rises in central Durham County and flows E into Little Lick Creek.

label: Chunn Cove
description: central Buncombe County near the headwaters of Ross Creek.

label: Chunn Cove Creek
description: See Ross Creek.

label: Church Branch
description: rises in central Clay County and flows S between Matlock Creek and Moores Branch into Tusquitee Creek.

label: Church Island
description: a peninsula in E Currituck County extending into Currituck Sound. Coinjock Bay lies between its W shore and the mainland of the county. It is 5 mi. long, 1 mi. wide. Shown as Emperors Island on the Comberford map, 1657; as White Island on the Ogilby map, 1671; and as Church Island on the Moseley map, 1733. The W portion of the peninsula is known as Piney Island.

label: Churchill
description: community in NE Warren County. Post office est. there in 1884 but discontinued in 1905.

label: Churchland
description: community in W Davidson County.

label: Churchville
description: community in SW Montgomery County served by post office, 1830-36.

label: Cid
description: community in E Davidson County. Est. 1885. Named either for Sidney Muffley, superintendent of silver mine nearby; or for Cid, Scotland, by miners who came from there.

label: Cilley
description: See German's Hill.

label: Cindy Branch
description: rises in central Cherokee County and flows SE into Morgan Creek.

label: Cindy Edwards Branch
description: rises in SW Beaufort County and flows W into Chocowinity Creek.

label: Cipo River
description: See Pamlico River.

label: Cisco
description: community in central Chowan County served by post office, 1891-1907.

label: Cisco Cove
description: central Buncombe County S of Cisco Mountain.

label: Cisco Mountain
description: central Buncombe County between Piney Mountain and Randall Gap.

label: Citron
description: community in SW Alleghany County. Known as City until some time after 1918.

label: Citte Weeks Branch
description: stream about 3 mi. long, rises in W Carteret County and flows W into White Oak River. Also known as Godfrey Branch.

label: Cittys Store
description: community in SE Rockingham County.

label: City
description: See Citron.

label: Clabber Branch
description: rises in SW Clay County and flows SE into Pinelog Creek.

label: Clam Shoal
description: in the waters of Pamlico Sound, S Dare County, off the S part of Hatteras Island. Bird Islands are on Clam Shoal.

label: Clanpit Cove
description: on Burningtown Creek in central Macon County.

label: Clara
description: community in SW Stokes County served by post office, 1888-1904.

label: Claremont
description: town in NE Catawba County. The earliest name was Charlotte Crossing; later Setzer's Depot. Changed to Claremont in 1892. Inc. 1893. Alt. 969. Named for Clare Sigmon, daughter of Jones Sigmon, an early settler. Produced furniture.

label: Clarendon
description: community in E Brunswick County.

label: Clarendon County
description: one of 3 counties (Albemarle and Craven being the other two) set up in 1664 by the Lords Proprietors of Carolina. It embraced the territory around the mouth of Cape Fear River (then known as Charles River). Named for Edward Hyde (1609-74), Earl of Clarendon, one of the Lords Proprietors. See also Charles Town, a settlement that existed in the colony, 1662-65.

label: Clarendon River
description: See Cape Fear River.

label: Clargeons Creek
description: See Yeopim Creek.

label: Clarissa
description: community in E Mitchell County on Cane Creek.

label: Clark
description: community in W Haywood County.

label: Clark Branch
description: rises in N central Buncombe County and flows NW into Flat Creek.

label: Clark Creek
description: rises in N Catawba County and flows SE and SW through Catawba County into Lincoln County, where it enters South Fork Catawba River.

label: Clark Gap
description: between Cunningham Mountain and Couch Mountain in N Henderson County.

label: Clark Point
description: point of land extending into Goose Creek, SE Beaufort County.

label: Clarke Creek
description: rises in NE Mecklenburg County and flows SE into W Cabarrus County, where it enters Rocky River. Named for a family of early settlers, one of whom was scalped by Indians.

label: Clarks
description: community in central Craven County. Alt. 31.

label: Clarks Bay
description: a small bay in the waters of Pamlico Sound off N Hatteras Island, E Dare County S of Salvo.

label: Clarks Branch
description: rises in a small pond in S central Brunswick County and flows S into Lockwoods Folly River.

label: Clarks Creek
description: is formed in N Mecklenburg County by the junction of North Prong and South Prong. It flows E into Cabarrus County, where it enters Rocky River.

label: Clarks Island
description: a small tidal-marsh island off the SE tip of Eagles Island in the Cape Fear River, NE Brunswick County.

label: Clarks Little River
description: See Upper Little River.

label: Clarks Mills
description: community in SE Montgomery County served by post office, 1885-1902.

label: Clarks Mountain
description: E central Anson County. Alt. approx. 525.

label: Clarks Store
description: See Blountsville.

label: Clarksberry
description: community in NW Rockingham County served by post office, 1857-66. Named for local Methodist church.

label: Clarksville
description: community in NW Davie County. John Pinchback operated Burnt Tavern or Pinchback's Tavern nearby after 1797. Before the Civil War, the stagecoach from Salem to Statesville stopped there for the night. Hinton Rowan Helper (1829-1909), author of The Impending Crisis (1857), was born nearby on a farm on Bear Creek. A post office operated there from 1855 until 1869.

label: Clarksville Township
description: NW Davie County.

label: Clarkton
description: town in S Bladen County. Alt. 93. Inc. 1901. Known earlier as Brown Marsh Station and Dalton. Renamed after 1863 for John Hector Clark (1821-98).

label: Clarrissa
description: community in S Mitchell County served by post office, 1887-1952.

label: Clawhammer Cove
description: N Transylvania County, extends S from Clawhammer Mountain to Avery Creek.

label: Clawhammer Creek
description: rises in N Transylvania County and flows E into South Fork Mills River.

label: Clawhammer Mountain
description: in N Transylvania County between Clawhammer Cove and Clawhammer Creek.

label: Clay
description: community in E Granville County.

label: Clay County
description: was formed in 1861 from Cherokee County. In the W section of the state, it is bounded by the state of Georgia and by Cherokee and Macon Counties. It was named for Kentucky senator Henry Clay (1777-1852). Area: 219 sq. mi. County seat: Hayesville, with an elevation of 1,893 ft. Townships are Brasstown, Hayesville, Hiwassee, Shooting Creek, Sweetwater, and Tusquittee. Produces corn, cable, cattle, hay, poultry, lumber, and apparel.

label: Clay Fork
description: community in SE Cumberland County served by post office, 1875-1906.

label: Clay Knob
description: See Nigger Head.

label: Claybrook
description: community in NW Rockingham County served by post office, 1890-95.

label: Claypole Branch
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows NE into Middle Fork French Broad River.

label: Clayroot
description: community in SE Pitt County.

label: Clayroot Swamp
description: rises in SE Pitt County and flows SW and SE into Swift Creek. For a part of its course, it forms the boundary between Craven and Pitt Counties.

label: Clayton
description: town in NW Johnston County. Inc. 1869. Known previously as Stallings Station. Named for a local school, Clayton Academy, or for Senator John M. Clayton (1796-1856) of Delaware, coauthor of the Clayton-Bulwer Treaty of 1850 with Great Britain. Alt. 345. Produces textiles and apparel.

label: Clayton Bay
description: swamp NW Brunswick County. A part of Green Swamp.

label: Clayton Branch
description: rises in SE Cherokee County and flows NW into Little Brasstown Creek.

label: Clayton Creek
description: rises in S Buncombe County and flows NE into French Broad River.

label: Clayton Hall
description: See Rocky Point.

label: Clayton Township
description: NW Johnston County.

label: Clear Branch
description: rises in NW Macon County and flows S into Queens Creek.

label: Clear Branch
description: rises in N central Avery County and flows NE into Elk River.

label: Clear Creek
description: rises in W McDowell County and flows SE into Catawba River.

label: Clear Creek
description: rises in S Avery County near Doe Hill Mountain and flows SW into North Toe River.

label: Clear Creek Ridge
description: S Yancey County, extends NE from South Toe River to East Branch.

label: Clear Creek Township
description: NE Henderson County.

label: Clear Pond
description: natural lake in SE Brunswick County. Max. depth 12 ft.; 2 acres in area.

label: Clear Run
description: community in S Sampson County on Black River.

label: Clear Run Swamp
description: rises in SE Sampson County and flows SW into Black River.

label: Clear View
description: community in E New Hanover County.

label: Cleaveland County
description: See Cleveland County.

label: Clegg
description: community in S Durham County.

label: Cleghorn Creek
description: rises in W central Rutherford County and flows SW into Broad River. The name occurs in deeds as early as 1764; perhaps named for John Cleghorn, pioneer settler.

label: Cleghorn Mountain
description: N Rutherford County at the head of Catheys Creek.

label: Clement
description: community in W Sampson County near Jones Swamp.

label: Clement Grove
description: park setting in Mocksville, Davie County. Site of annual Masonic picnic, benefit for Oxford orphanage since 1883. Land once belonged to Herbert Clement.

label: Clements Creek
description: See Blanket Creek.

label: Clemmons
description: town in SW Forsyth County. Known as Clemmonstown as early as 1816; inc. 1824 as Clemmonsville but later known simply as Clemmons. Alt. 792. Named for Peter Clemmons, who moved there from Delaware in 1777. Clemmons was the author of Poor Peter's Call to His Children, printed in Salisbury in 1812.

label: Clemmonsville Township
description: SW Forsyth County.

label: Clems Beech Ridge
description: E Jackson County between Oak Ridge Creek and Chestnut Ridge Creek.

label: Clems Branch
description: flows through SW Mecklenburg County and into South Carolina.

label: Cleone
description: community in W Union County served by post office, 1886-1905.

label: Cleveland
description: town in W Rowan County. Inc. 1883 as Third Creek; name changed in 1887 to honor Grover Cleveland (1837-1908), president of the United States. Alt. 788.

label: Cleveland County
description: was formed in 1841 from Rutherford and Lincoln Counties. Cleaveland was originally used, but the present spelling was adopted in 1887. In the SW section of the state, it is bounded by the state of South Carolina and by Rutherford, Burke, Lincoln, and Gaston Counties. It was named for Col. Benjamin Cleveland (1738-1806), noted partisan leader of the W frontier and one of the heroes of the Battle of Kings Mountain. Area: 466 sq. mi. County seat: Shelby, with an elevation of 85 ft. Townships, now numbered 1 to 11, were formerly River, Boiling Springs, Rippys, Kings Mountain, Warlick, Shelby, Sandy Run, Polkville, Double Shoals, Knob Creek, and Casar. Produces wheat, oats, corn, dairy products, hogs, livestock, poultry, soybeans, nursery products, squash, honey, glass products, textiles, bakery products, limestone, and mica.

label: Cleveland Mills
description: inc. 1877 as a town between Lawndale and Casar in N central Cleveland County. No longer in existence.

label: Cleveland Township
description: W Johnston County.

label: Cleveland Township
description: NW Rowan County.

label: Clifdale
description: community in W Cumberland County. Formerly known as Clifton. Alt. 237.

label: Cliff Branch
description: rises in N Swain County and flows NE into Oconaluftee River.

label: Cliffield Mountain
description: on the Polk-Henderson county line.

label: Clifford
description: community in E Rutherford County served by post office, 1891-1901.

label: Cliffs
description: See Rhodhiss.

label: Cliffs of the Neuse State Park
description: SE Wayne County. Est. 1945 on 355 acres given to the state by the Weil family of Goldsboro and others. Cliffs 90 ft. above the Neuse River are an unusual geological feature in E North Carolina. Galax, laurel, and other mountain plants grow there. It is a scenic and recreational park with a nature museum, trails, etc. Swimming and fishing.

label: Cliffside
description: community in SE Rutherford County on Second Broad River. Founded by Raleigh B. Haynes, who est. a textile mill there. High Shoals, former community in the vicinity, was a post office as early as 1828.

label: Cliffside Lake
description: at the junction of South Skitty Branch and Skitty Creek in SE Macon County.

label: Clifton
description: See Clifdale.

label: Clifton
description: community in central Ashe County. Alt. approx. 2,900.

label: Clifton Township
description: NW Ashe County.

label: Cliftons Pond
description: on Crooked Creek in SW Franklin County. Formed about 1890. Covers approx. 55 acres. Max. depth 16 ft. Named for owners.

label: Cliftonville
description: community in N Wilson County near the head of Cattail Branch. Named for Clifton Parker. Post office, 1895-1902.

label: Climax
description: community in SE Guilford County. Alt. 824. Est. 1853. Named for its location on high ground.

label: Clinchcross
description: community in E McDowell County. Probably named for the nearby Clinchfield Railroad.

label: Cline Creek
description: rises in central Catawba County and flows SW into Clark Creek.

label: Cline Mine
description: former copper and gold mine near the community of Watts Crossroads, NE Cabarrus County approx. 8 mi. NE of Concord. Last worked about 1901-1902; later explored by the U.S. Bureau of Mines and by the Tennessee Copper Company.

label: Clines Township
description: N Catawba County.

label: Clingman
description: community in E Wilkes County near West Swan Creek. Named for Senator Thomas L. Clingman (1812-97). Known also as Frog Level.

label: Clingman Mine Branch
description: rises in N Avery County and flows E into Buckeye Creek on the Avery-Watauga county line.

label: Clingmans Creek
description: rises in N Swain County near Clingmans Dome and flows SE into Noland Creek.

label: Clingmans Dome
description: mountain on the Swain County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Named approx. 1860 by Harvard professor Arnold Guyot for Thomas L. Clingman (1812-97), member of the party that first measured it in 1858. Clingman was a soldier, mountain climber, geologist, congressman, and senator from North Carolina. Alt. 6,642, the highest point in the park. A 45-ft. observation tower has been built at the peak. Known to the Indians as Ku-wa-hi, meaning "mulberry place." Early settlers called it Smoky Dome.

label: Clinton
description: former town in SE Davie County (then Rowan) at the junction of South Yadkin and North Yadkin Rivers. Inc. 1818 by Yadkin Navigation Co. About 100 lots were sold before a panic in 1819 stopped work at the site. A post office existed there in 1822, but the town was abandoned soon afterward.

label: Clinton Township
description: former township in central Sampson County, now divided into North Clinton and South Clinton Townships.

label: Clio
description: community in E central Iredell County. Site of Clio's Nursery, a classical school est. in 1778 by Rev. James Hall (1744-1826). His attempt to make the sciences a part of academic training was the first in North Carolina.

label: Clontz Branch
description: rises in W Haywood County and flows NW into Caldwell Fork.

label: Closs
description: community in E Lenoir County. A post office from 1888 to 1905.

label: Clotho
description: community in NE Transylvania County served by post office, 1887-1906.

label: Cloudland
description: community in NE Mitchell County on NE Roan Mountain.

label: Clover Branch
description: rises in NW Madison County and flows N into French Broad River.

label: Clover Garden
description: former community in SW Orange County near Haw River. A post office was est. there as early as 1822. Clover Garden Methodist Church is there.

label: Clover Orchard
description: community in S Alamance County served by post office, 1849-1906.

label: Cloverdale
description: community in N Henderson County.

label: Club Gap
description: N Transylvania County at the SW end of Rich Mountain.

label: Club Lake
description: SE Macon County on Monger Creek.

label: Clubfoot Canal
description: about 2½ mi. long extending from the head of Clubfoot Creek to the head of Harlowe Creek, N Carteret County and N Craven County, affording a waterway from the Neuse River to Newport River. Planned 1797; completed about 1828.

label: Clubfoot Creek
description: rises near the Carteret-Craven county line and flows N into Neuse River. A canal connects the stream with Harlowe Creek in central Carteret County, affording a waterway from the Neuse River to Newport River. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733. The Indian name for the stream was Irisquoque.

label: Clum
description: community in SW Chowan County served by post office, 1897-1902.

label: Clun Seat
description: 10,000-acre estate in SE Warren County between Great Fishing and Shocco Creeks. Granted to Edward Moseley in 1728, and after his death in 1749, sold by his sons to Joseph Montfort. Mentioned in local records as late as 1765. Probably named for the Clun River or the town of Clun in England.

label: Cluster
description: community in S Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1893-1903. Successor to Maxwell's Store, which see.

label: Clyde
description: town in central Haywood County. Inc. 1889. Named for a member of a firm of railroad construction engineers. Known previously as Lower Pigeon. Alt. 2,539.

label: Clyde Township
description: central Haywood County.

label: Coahoma
description: community in NE Lenoir County served by post office, 1888-1902.

label: Coakley
description: town in E Edgecombe County. Inc. 1903, but not now active in municipal affairs.

label: Coalglen
description: community in S Chatham County on Deep River. Known earlier as Farmville. Site of former Carolina Coal Mine, from which the name is derived.

label: Coalville
description: community in NE Cherokee County in Nantahala National Forest.

label: Coastal Plain
description: E North Carolina, extends inland from the Atlantic Ocean 100 to 150 mi. to the fall line of the rivers. The W limit extends from Northampton and Halifax Counties on the N in a SW direction through Anson County on the S. In altitude the area ranges from sea level to approx. 500 ft. Generally the soil is sand and black loam. See also Tidewater Area.

label: Coats
description: town in E Harnett County. Inc. 1905 and named for Elder Tom Coats. Previously known as Troyville for a Fayetteville lawyer. Alt. 314.

label: Cobb Bluff
description: S central Cherokee County on the Nottely River at the mouth of Moccasin Creek.

label: Cobb Creek
description: rises in NW Yadkin County and flows NE into Martin Creek.

label: Cobb Point
description: E Pasquotank County, extends into the Pasquotank River between Forbes Bay and Davis Bay.

label: Cobb Town
description: community in NW Rockingham County named for Pleasant Cobb, local blacksmith.

label: Cobb's Shop
description: community in W Caswell County.

label: Cobbs Creek
description: rises in E Caswell County and flows NE into Person County, where it enters North Hyco Creek.

label: Cobbs Crossroads
description: community in N Wilson County near Town Creek.

label: Cobin Branch
description: rises in the Cane Creek Mountains, S Alamance County, and flows NW into Rock Creek.

label: Coble Township
description: former township in SW Alamance County, now township no. 2.

label: Coburn
description: community in SW Buncombe County.

label: Coburn Knob
description: N central Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near the head of Lands Creek. Alt. 4,370.

label: Coburn's
description: community in NW Union County.

label: Cochran Branch
description: rises in S Swain County and flows NE into Tuckasegee River.

label: Cochran Creek
description: rises in central Graham County and flows W into Cheoah River.

label: Cochrane Cove
description: on Burningtown Creek in central Macon County.

label: Cochrum
description: community in W Yadkin County served by post office, 1891-1905.

label: Cockerne Ferry
description: See Colerain.

label: Cockey Swamp
description: rises in NE Nash County and flows SE into SW Edgecombe County, where it enters Town Creek.

label: Cockey Township
description: former township in SW Edgecombe County, now township no. 13.

label: Cockle Point
description: peninsula extending from E Pamlico County into Neuse River.

label: Cockrells Crossroads
description: community in central Nash County.

label: Cod Camp Creek
description: rises in SW Cumberland County and flows SE on the Cumberland-Robeson county line before entering Robeson County, where it flows into Gallberry Swamp.

label: Coddle Creek
description: rises along the Rowan-Iredell county line and flows S through Cabarrus County into Rocky River. Appears on the Collet map, 1770, as Codle Creek.

label: Coddle Creek Township
description: SE Iredell County.

label: Cody
description: community in S Surry County served by post office, 1888-1914.

label: Cody Branch
description: rises in central Graham County and flows NW into Yellow Creek.

label: Cody Creek
description: rises in W central Surry County and flows SE into Fisher River.

label: Cody Gap
description: central Graham County at the head of Cody Branch.

label: Coefield Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NE into McClellan Creek.

label: Coefield Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NW into Radder Creek.

label: Coenjock
description: See Coinjock.

label: Coffee Branch
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows N into Garden Creek.

label: Coffee Creek
description: a tidal creek in N central Carteret County that flows into South River.

label: Coffee Ridge
description: N Haywood County parallel to Laurel Creek.

label: Coffer
description: community in N Moore County served by post office, 1892-1905.

label: Coffey Cove
description: central Cherokee County between Mason Branch and Rhea Branch.

label: Coffey Creek
description: rises in W Mecklenburg County and flows S into Sugar Creek.

label: Cofield
description: community in E Hertford County.

label: Cogdell
description: community in S Wayne County served by post office, 1888-1903.

label: Coggins Bend
description: N Macon County in Little Tennessee River.

label: Coggins Branch
description: rises in W Haywood County, Great Smoky Mountains National Park, near lat. 35°39'08" N., long. 83°06'12" W., and flows NE into Little Cataloochee Creek.

label: Coggins Mine
description: community in N Montgomery County named for local gold mine operated on Coggins farm.

label: Coglin Creek
description: rises in S Onslow County and flows W into New River.

label: Cognac (cog-nack)
description: community in E Richmond County. Settled about 1890 and first known as Eighty-Nine Mile Siding for its distance from Raleigh. Renamed for the town in France or the brandy produced there. Alt. 400.

label: Coharie River
description: is formed in S Sampson County by the junction of Little Coharie and Great Coharie Creeks and flows SE for approx. 6 mi. to join Six Runs Creek in forming Black River.

label: Cohary Swamp
description: See Great Coharie Creek.

label: Cohooque
description: community in SE Craven County served by post office, 1880-1914.

label: Coinjock
description: community in S central Currituck County. Inc. 1893 as Arlington but dissolved by court order, March 1894, because of technical inaccuracy in description of the boundary. As early as 1830, a post office there was called Coenjock, the same name used by Bishop Thomas Coke in writing of a visit there in 1785. On Intracoastal Waterway. Originally located where Barco is today; moved S when Albemarle and Chesapeake Canal was built. Other early spellings were Cornjack and Cowenjock. Alt. 5.

label: Coinjock Bay
description: in the waters of Currituck Sound, central Currituck County, between Church Island and the mainland.

label: Cokes
description: community in E Granville County.

label: Cokesbury
description: community in N Harnett County. Early center of Methodism in Cape Fear area. Named for Thomas Coke (1747-1814) and Francis Asbury (1745-1816), Methodist bishops. Nearby, Buckhorn Iron Furnace operated during Civil War and until 1873.

label: Cokey Swamp
description: rises in SE Nash County and flows SE into W Edgecombe County, where it enters Town Creek. An Indian village, Tiancok, which see, appears on the site on the Comberford map, 1657. Tyancoka Creek appears on the Collet map, 1770, at the location, and the spelling Tincoco and Tiancoco are used on other maps. See also Redmans Old Field.

label: Cokey Township
description: See Edgecombe County.

label: Colbert Creek
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows SE into South Toe River.

label: Colbert Ridge
description: S Yancey County between Locust Creek and Colbert Creek.

label: Cold Branch
description: rises in W Graham County and flows SE into Santeetlah Creek.

label: Cold Branch
description: rises in central Clay County and flows NW into Tusquitee Creek.

label: Cold Camp Creek
description: rises on the Cumberland-Robeson county line and flows SE into Gallberry Swamp.

label: Cold Creek
description: rises in E Jackson County and flows SW into Tanasee Creek.

label: Cold Knob
description: on Buncombe-Henderson county line between Bent Creek Gap and Pine Mountain.

label: Cold Mountain
description: S Haywood County, is parallel to Little East Fork Pigeon River. Alt. 6,030. According to Cherokee legend, some children played on a large rock at the foot of the mountain, and their footprints are said to be there still. Their name for the mountain was Da-tsula-gun-yi, meaning "where they made tracks." Eponymous novel by Charles Frazier in 1997 and later film led tourists to seek out site.

label: Cold Mountain Branch
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows NE into East Fork French Broad River.

label: Cold Spring
description: community is NW Burke County.

label: Cold Spring Branch
description: rises in N Clay County and flows SE into Long Branch.

label: Cold Spring Creek
description: rises in N Burke County and flows S into Carroll's Creek.

label: Cold Spring Gap
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near the head of Bear Creek. Called in Cherokee Aha-lu-na (ambushed) or U-ni-ha-lu-na (where they watched). Cherokees are said to have ambushed a large party of invading Iroquois, slaying all but one. His ears were cut off, as was the custom, and he was sent home to take the news to his people.

label: Cold Spring Knob
description: on the Swain County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park at the junction of Miry Ridge and the main divide of the Great Smoky Mountains. Alt. 5,240. Named for spring of cold water near the summit.

label: Cold Spring Knob
description: S Haywood County on Lickstone Ridge. Alt. 5,960.

label: Cold Springs Creek
description: rises in N Haywood County and flows SW into Pigeon River.

label: Cold Water Creek
description: See Coldass Creek.

label: Coldass Creek
description: rises in NW Caldwell County and flows E into Johns River. Both it and Pinchgut Creek were named by two men hunting in the area. They followed a stream until it came to a fork. There they separated, each following one of the forks; they agreed to meet later and name each stream according to their feelings toward it. One man carried the food and the other the sleeping equipment. They became lost but finally met the next day, when they named the creeks. Sometimes shown as Cold Water Creek on modern maps.

label: Coldside Mountain
description: in S Jackson County between Heddie Mountain and Terrapin Mountain.

label: Coldspring Branch
description: rises in E Cherokee County and flows NW into Peachtree Creek.

label: Coldspring Gap
description: on Cherokee-Graham county line in E end of Unicoi Mountains.

label: Coldspring Mountain
description: on the Madison County, N.C.-Greene County, Tenn., line.

label: Coldwater Creek
description: rises in S Rowan County and flows S into Cabarrus County, where it enters Rocky River. Appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Cole Cove
description: S Buncombe County between Pine Mountain and Fannie Ridge.

label: Cole Creek
description: is formed by junction of Hacklan Branch and Buckland Mill Branch in W Gates County. Flows S through Lilleys Millpond and empties into Sarem Creek. Formerly known as Sarem Creek.

label: Cole Gap
description: SE Macon County W of Houston Branch and approx. 3 mi. N of town of Highlands.

label: Cole Gap Mountain
description: W central Stokes County between Indian and Neatman Creeks.

label: Cole Mountain
description: E Macon County at the head of Houston Branch.

label: Cole Mountain Gap
description: at the head of Skitty Creek in E Macon County. Alt. 4,100.

label: Coleman
description: community in S McDowell County near Old Fort; former station on Western North Carolina Railroad.

label: Coleman Branch
description: rises in W Johnston County and flows SW into Black Creek.

label: Coleman Creek
description: rises in S Clay County and flows E into Hyatt Mill Creek.

label: Coleman Gap
description: SE Cherokee County at the headwaters of John Mason Branch.

label: Colerain
description: town in NE Bertie County. Settled by 1700; inc. 1794. Named by its founder, John Campbell, for his hometown of Coleraine, County Londonderry, Ireland. The post office, est. in 1818, dropped the final letter of the name in the mid-nineteenth century. Cockerne Ferry across the Chowan River N of the site of Colerain appears on the Collet map, 1770, but it apparently ceased operation by 1808.

label: Colerain Township
description: NE Bertie County.

label: Coleridge
description: community in E Randolph County on Deep River. Originally known as Foust's Mill. A cotton mill est. there in 1883. Named for James A. Cole, local storekeeper.

label: Coleridge Township
description: E central Randolph County.

label: Colers Ordinary
description: See Ridgeway.

label: Coles Cove
description: the valley through which Coles Creek flows in N Buncombe County.

label: Coles Creek
description: rises in N Buncombe County near Watershed Ridge and flows NW into Flat Creek.

label: Colesville
description: See Coleville.

label: Coleville
description: community in N Stokes County near Cadwell Creek. Post office there in the late nineteenth century was Colesville.

label: Coley Gap
description: W Madison County between Puncheon Camp Branch and Divide Mountain.

label: Coleys Branch
description: rises in N Gaston County and flows NE into South Fork Catawba River.

label: Coleys Crossroads
description: See Vicksboro.

label: Colfax
description: community in W Guilford County. Alt. 972. Named for Schuyler Colfax (1823-85), vice president of the United States (1869-73).

label: Colfax Township
description: E Rutherford County. Named for Vice President Schuyler Colfax (1823-85).

label: Colington
description: scattered fishing community on Colington Island, NE Dare County.

label: Colington Creek
description: a waterway between Kitty Hawk Bay and Buzzard Bay; E of Colington Island and separating it from N Bodie Island, E Dare County.

label: Colington Island
description: in Roanoke Sound, NE Dare County. About 2 mi. from N to S and from E to w, it is separated from Bodie Island by Colington Creek. Consists of two islands, Little Colington and Big Colington. Named for Sir John Colleton (1608-66), one of the Lords Proprietors, to whom it was granted in 1663. Settled by the winter of 1664-65. Earlier known as Carlile Island in honor of Christopher Carleill, stepson of Sir Francis Walsingham, who accompanied Sir Francis Drake on his 1586 Florida-Virginia expedition as Drake's lieutenant general. Appears as Carlile Island on the Ogilby map, 1671, and as Colleton Island on both the Blome map, 1672, and the Moseley map, 1733. The Collet map, 1770, and the Mouzon map, 1775, have Collintons Island.

label: Colington Island Shoal
description: lies off the NW tip of Roanoke Island, Dare County, in the waters of Albemarle and Croatan Sounds.

label: Colkins Neck
description: a sandy area about 2 mi. long and 1 mi. wide, almost surrounded by tidal marsh, SW Brunswick County along the South Carolina line.

label: Colleton County
description: was est. prior to 1691 by the Lords Proprietors of Carolina in what is now SE South Carolina. Named for Landgrave James Colleton, who resided in the area.

label: Colleton Island
description: See Colington Island.

label: Collett Camp Branch
description: rises in N Clay County and flows SW into Long Branch.

label: Collett Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NW into Tatham Creek.

label: Collett Ridge
description: NE Cherokee County in the Valley River Mountains.

label: Collettsville
description: town in W Caldwell County on Johns River. Inc. 1897, but no longer active in municipal affairs. Named for James H. Collet, on whose land the town was laid out. Settled as early as 1837, when post office was est.

label: Collie Swamp
description: rises in W Martin County and flows S into Tranters Creek. Appears as Huskanaw Swamp on the Price map, 1808, and the MacRae map, 1833.

label: Collins Canal
description: See Somerset Canal.

label: Collins Creek
description: rises in S Orange County and flows SW into Chatham County, where it enters Haw River.

label: Collins Crossroad
description: See Dixie.

label: Collins Crossroads
description: See Hollemans Crossroads.

label: Collins Gap
description: on the Swain County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Alt. 5,720.

label: Collins Mountain
description: W central Swain County on the NW end of Jackson Line Mountain.

label: Collinstown
description: community in N Stokes County N of Dan River. Name likely derived from that of early settlers Roger Collins and his kin. Also known as Stateline.

label: Collinsville
description: community in S Polk County on Hughes Creek. Settled about 1875. Named for Thomas G. Collins, local planter.

label: Collinwood
description: former community in W Swain County on Little Tennessee River; the site is now under the waters of Fontana Lake.

label: Colly
description: community in NE Bladen County.

label: Colly Creek
description: rises in Big Colly Bay in NE Bladen County and flows SE into Pender County, where it enters Black River.

label: Colly Swamp
description: an arm of Big Colly Bay in NE Bladen County.

label: Colly Township
description: E central Bladen County.

label: Colmans Gap
description: central Haywood County on the head of Big Branch.

label: Colon
description: community in N Lee County. Coal from Egypt mine formerly delivered to the Seaboard Railroad there; later the center of a large gas-fired brick industry. Post office est. in 1891 as Buckner; changed to Colon in 1892.

label: Colonial Assembly
description: See General Assembly.

label: Colson's Mill
description: See Coulson Ordinary.

label: Colt Creek
description: rises in SE Henderson County and flows NE into Polk County, where it enters Pacolet River.

label: Columbia
description: town and county seat in N Tyrrell County on Scuppernong River. Alt. 10. Originated as a trading post, Shallop's Landing; inc. 1793 as Elizabeth Town. Name changed to Columbia in 1801. Became county seat in 1802. Name is poetic appellation for the United States. Produces lumber.

label: Columbia Township
description: NE Pender County.

label: Columbus
description: town and county seat, S Polk County on the head of Whiteoak Creek. Inc. 1857. Named for Dr. Columbus Mills, state legislator who was instrumental in the formation of the county. Alt. 1,145.

label: Columbus County
description: was formed in 1808 from Brunswick and Bladen Counties. Located in the SE section of the state, it is bounded by the state of South Carolina and by Robeson, Bladen, Pender, and Brunswick Counties. It was named for Christopher Columbus. Area: 954 sq. mi. County seat: Whiteville, with an elevation of 59 ft. Townships are Bogue, Bolton, Bug Hill, Cerro Gordo, Chadbourn, Fair Bluff, Lees, Ransom, South Williams, Tatums, Waccamaw, Welch Creek, Western Prong, Whiteville, and Williams. Produces tobacco, corn, soybeans, oats, peanuts, pecans, cotton, cucumbers, cotton, poultry, livestock, hogs, fish, sweet potatoes, wood products, tires, air filters, chemicals, packaging, watermelons, fertilizer, paper, lumber, textiles, and catfish.

label: Columbus Township
description: S central Polk County.

label: Colvard Creek
description: rises in N Cherokee County on Hanging Dog Mountain and flows SE into Valley River.

label: Colvin Creek
description: rises in NE Madison County and flows SW into Spillcorn Creek.

label: Colvins Creek
description: rises in W Pender County and flows SE into Black River.

label: Combs Knob
description: N Wilkes County between Big Sandy Creek and Little Sandy Creek. Named for George Combs, a Revolutionary soldier who lived nearby.

label: Comet
description: community in N central Ashe County.

label: Comfort
description: community in S Jones County. A post office existed there as early as 1828.

label: Commissary Branch
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows NW into Little River.

label: Commissary Hill
description: S Yancey County approx. 9/10 mi. SE of Mount Mitchell. Alt. 5,780. Named for a commissary located there by the Carolina Spruce Lumber Company during lumbering operations in the early 1900s.

label: Commissary Ridge
description: S Yancey County between Mount Mitchell and Commissary Hill.

label: Commissioner Gap
description: S Macon County between Rich Knob and Commissioners Creek.

label: Commissioners Creek
description: rises in S Macon County and flows SE into Little Tennessee River. Likely named in honor of the commissioners who surveyed the North Carolina-Georgia state line in 1819.

label: Como
description: town in N Hertford County. First known as Buckhorn. Post office est. in 1883 was named Como for Lake Como in Italy. Inc. 1967.

label: Company Mills
description: community in NE Guilford County served by post office, 1873-1903.

label: Company Shops
description: See Burlington.

label: Compass Bald Mountain
description: NE Clay County at the head of Compass Creek. Alt. 3,296.

label: Compass Creek
description: rises in N Clay County between Julie Ridge and Deadline Ridge and flows S into Tusquitee Creek. Received its name when Robert Henry, a surveyor and Revolutionary War veteran, dropped his compass in the stream as he was crossing it.

label: Complex
description: community in SE Davidson County.

label: Conaby Creek
description: rises in W Washington County S of the town of Plymouth and flows NE into Roanoke River. It appears as Conalis Creek on the Collet map, 1770, and as Conaly Creek on maps as recent as the 1932 soil survey map. Shown as Coneby Creek on the MacRae map, 1833, and referred to as Conoby Creek in Doc. No. 259, House of Representatives, 63d Congress, 1st Session, 1913.

label: Conalis Creek
description: See Conaby Creek.

label: Conaly Creek
description: See Conaby Creek.

label: Concave
description: community in SW Scotland County.

label: Concord
description: city and county seat, central Cabarrus County. Inc. 1798; alt. 704. Named for the harmonious settlement of a dispute over the site for the town. Home of Barber-Scotia College. Produces textiles, hosiery, and poultry products.

label: Concord Lake
description: N Cabarrus County on the E edge of Kannapolis. Formed in 1926 by a dam on Patterson Branch. Covers 85 acres, with a max. depth of 25 ft. Owned by the city of Concord and used for fishing and as a municipal water source.

label: Concord Mountain
description: S Buncombe County SW of Fairview Gap.

label: Concord North
description: unincorporated outskirts of the city of Concord, central Cabarrus County.

label: Concord Township
description: former township in central Cabarrus County, now township no. 12. In 1945 parts of townships nos. 4, 5, and 11 (Cooks Cross Roads, Mount Gilead, and Baptist Church) were added to the township.

label: Cone Lake
description: See Bass Lake.

label: Cone Memorial Park
description: See Moses H. Cone Memorial Park.

label: Coneat
description: See Coniott Landing.

label: Coneby Creek
description: See Conaby Creek.

label: Coneghta
description: See Conetoe.

label: Conetoe (cuh-NEAT-uh)
description: town in SE Edgecombe County, inc. 1887. Known earlier as Warren's Station. Named for nearby Conetoe Creek. Produces tobacco, cotton, and peanuts. Alt. 49.

label: Conetoe Creek
description: rises in E Edgecombe County and flows s, where it forms a part of the Edgecombe-Pitt county line. It then flows S and SW into Tar River in Pitt County. The Collet map, 1770, shows Great Coneghta Pocosin as a swampy area on the W side of present-day Conetoe Creek in Edgecombe County. The name appears in county records as early as 1745.

label: Coney Creek
description: rises in SE Caswell County near Ridgeville and flows N into North Hyco Creek. Coney is an old word for rabbit.

label: Coneyhoe Creek
description: See Conoho Creek.

label: Confederate Memorial Forest
description: in Pisgah National Forest along the Haywood-Transylvania county line on the West Fork Pigeon River and the Blue Ridge Parkway. Dedicated July 12, 1942. Sponsored by the N.C. United Daughters of the Confederacy, the forest contains 125 acres planted with 125,000 red spruce and balsam trees.

label: Cong Branch
description: rises in W Sampson County and flows S into Little Coharie Creek.

label: Congleton
description: community in NE Pitt County at the head of Great Branch. Inc. 1885 as Keelsville, with members of both the Congleton and Keel families appointed temporary officers. The name, however, was not adopted, nor was a municipal government continued.

label: Congo
description: community in W Wilkes County between Lewis Fork Creek and Fishdam Creek.

label: Conine Bend
description: in the Roanoke River, S Bertie County, at the W mouth of Conine Creek.

label: Conine Creek
description: S Bertie County, is a canal connecting two bends in the Roanoke River and creating Conine Island.

label: Conine Island
description: S Bertie County, formed in a bend of the Roanoke River by Conine Creek, which cuts across a neck formed by the river. Appears as Caroline Island on the Collet map, 1770. See also Purchace Islands.

label: Coniott Creek
description: rises in SW Bertie County and flows SE into Roanoke River. The name is a Tuscarora Indian word meaning "making cloth."

label: Coniott Landing
description: on the Roanoke River in SE Bertie County at the mouth of Coniott Creek. Possibly the site of the extinct town Wimberly, which was est. in 1752. Joseph Wimberly petitioned to operate a ferry across the Roanoke River at "Coneat," and the town was built on his land. Site has also been known as Blackman's Landing; Blackman and Wimberly families were owners of large tracts of land in the county.

label: Conley Branch
description: rises in W Macon County and flows SW into Jarrett Creek.

label: Conley Ridge
description: S Macon County between Wheatfield Branch and Stillhouse Branch.

label: Connaritsa
description: community in NW Bertie County. The name Conneritsat appears in local records as early as 1729 with reference to the location of a bridge across Cashie River.

label: Connaritsa Pocosin
description: NW Bertie County.

label: Connaritsa Swamp
description: rises in NW Bertie County in Connaritsa Pocosin and flows SE into Cashie River.

label: Connatara
description: See Chimney Mountain.

label: Connelly Creek
description: rises in SE Swain County and flows NW into Tuckasegee River.

label: Connelly Mountain
description: E Swain County, between Chestnut Cove Creek and Improvement Creek.

label: Connelly Springs
description: town in E central Burke County on Island Creek approx. 2 mi. E of Valdese. Settled before the Civil War and named Happy Home. Later, the Connelly family developed a resort there around mineral springs. Named for Mrs. William L. Connelly. Inc. 1920. Alt. 1,195.

label: Conner Mill Branch
description: rises in central Haywood County and flows N into Pigeon River.

label: Connestee Falls
description: in S Transylvania County in Carson Creek. Said to have been named for Indian Princess Connestee.

label: Connor
description: community in W Wilson County near Turkey Creek. Post office, 1890-1904.

label: Conoby Creek
description: See Conaby Creek.

label: Conoconary Creek
description: See Conoconnara Swamp.

label: Conoconnara Swamp
description: rises in central Halifax County and flows NE into Roanoke River. It appears as Conoconary Creek on the Collet map, 1770. Conoconnara, the 2,500-acre plantation of Thomas Pollock Sr., was located there in 1721. Before the American Revolution, a Church of England chapel stood near the banks of the stream.

label: Conoconnara Township
description: E Halifax County.

label: Conoho
description: See Oak City.

label: Conoho Bend
description: in the Roanoke River at the mouth of Conoho Creek in N Martin County.

label: Conoho Creek
description: rises in NW Martin County and flows SE into Roanoke River. Appears as Coneyhoe Creek on the Collet map, 1770. The headwaters of Conoho Creek are called Fort Branch on the Collet map.

label: Conover
description: town in central Catawba County. Settled 1871. Inc. 1877. Alt. 1,060. Named by Mrs. John Seitz, local resident, for Canova, the Italian sculptor whose statue of George Washington was destroyed by the fire that leveled the capitol in Raleigh in 1831. Produces furniture, lumber, and textiles.

label: Conoway Knob
description: on the McDowell-Rutherford county line. Alt. 2,144.

label: Conrad Branch
description: rises in NW Haywood County on the N side of Cooks Knob and flows NE approx. 1½ mi to join Woody Branch in forming Little Cataloochee Creek.

label: Conrad Hill
description: former site of a gold mine, central Davidson County near Holly Grove community.

label: Conrad Hill Township
description: E central Davidson County.

label: Conrads
description: community in E Yadkin County served by post office, 1880-1905.

label: Contara
description: See Whitewater Falls.

label: Contaroga
description: See Whitewater Falls.

label: Contentnea
description: town in central Greene County on Contentnea Creek. Inc. 1877, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Name derived from the Iroquoian/Tuscarora phrase meaning "fish passing by." Similarly named village of Cotechney (thief; rogue) is 4 mi. upstream.

label: Contentnea Creek
description: is formed in W Wilson County by the junction of Moccasin and Turkey Creeks. It flows SE into Greene County across the county and onto the Lenoir-Pitt county line, which it follows into Neuse River. Contentnea is from the Iroquoian/Tuscarora phrase meaning "fish passing by." Formerly known as Great Contentnea Creek, it is referred to in the De Graffenried account of the founding of New Bern, 1709-10. Appears as Great Cotecktney Creek on the Collet map, 1770. Cotechney was an Indian village on the creek banks in present Greene County. Other eighteenth-century references to the stream use the name Quotankney Creek. See also Moccasin River.

label: Contentnea Lake
description: central Wilson County on Contentnea Creek. Formed 1773. Covers 450 acres; max. depth 15 ft. First known as Cobb's Mill Pond (1773); later as Hadley's Mill Pond (named for Thomas Hadley), Barefoot's Mill Pond (1863), Wiggins Pond (1886), and David Daniel's Pond (1897). Acquired by Wilson Power and Light Co., 1904.

label: Contentnea Neck Township
description: NE Lenoir County.

label: Contentnea Township
description: See Winterville Township.

label: Conway
description: town in E Northampton County. Settled about 1835 and known first as Martin's Crossroads; later, by the early 1880s, as Kirby; and finally as Conway to honor the wife of an officer of the railroad. Inc. 1913. Alt. 105.

label: Conway Creek
description: See Little Fishing Creek.

label: Conwell
description: community in SE Northampton County on the E limits of Rich Square.

label: Coohooca
description: See Cohoogue.

label: Cook
description: community in SW Catawba County served by post office, 1895-1905.

label: Cook Branch
description: rises in N Madison County and flows S into Big Laurel Creek.

label: Cook Creek
description: rises in central Cherokee County near Beaverdam Gap and flows SE into Hanging Dog Creek. See also Kilby Cove.

label: Cook Gap
description: S Watauga County between the head of Laurel Branch and the head of Flannery Creek. Alt. 3,349.

label: Cook Mountain
description: NW Buncombe County between Sugar Creek and North Turkey Creek S of Earlies Gap.

label: Cooks Creek
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, rises near lat. 35°40'30" N., long. 83°09'38" W., and flows SE into Pretty Hollow Creek.

label: Cooks Cross Roads Township
description: former township in NW Cabarrus County, now township no. 4. Formerly also known as Kannapolis Township.

label: Cooks Crossing
description: community in N Cabarrus County.

label: Cooks Knob
description: W Haywood County, Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°39'28" N., long. 83°08'42" W., on Indian Ridge between Short Bung (ridge) and Davidson Branch.

label: Cooks Wall Mountain
description: W Stokes County at the head of Indian Creek.

label: Cooktown
description: community in N Mitchell County on Holison Creek.

label: Cool Run
description: community in SW Brunswick County.

label: Cool Spring
description: See Scuppernong.

label: Cool Spring
description: community in E central Iredell County. Began with a store and hotel in the 1850s. An academy there in the 1870s became a high school at the turn of the century.

label: Cool Spring Branch
description: rises in SE Union County and flows N into Lanes Creek.

label: Cool Spring Precinct
description: See Scuppernong Township.

label: Cool Spring Township
description: E central Iredell County.

label: Cool Springs Township
description: SE Rutherford County.

label: Cooleemee
description: town in S Davie County on the South Yadkin River. Inc. 1985. Site of former Fisher's Ford. Cotton mill est. there and named for Cooleemee Plantation, which see. Post office est. 1900. Produced textiles. Alt. 840.

label: Cooleemee Plantation
description: E Davie County overlooking the Yadkin River. Land purchased by the Hairston family in 1817; plantation house, with four wings in the form of a cross from a central hall, begun in 1850, completed in 1854. Still owned by the Hairston family. Origin of the name unknown, but legend says that Revolutionary War major Peter Hairston had fought the Creek Indians in Florida; he returned home with a young Indian captive who could remember only one word of his native tongue, the word Cooleemee, believed to mean "place where the white oak grows."

label: Coolers Knob Mountain
description: W Randolph County between Cedar Rock Mountain and Brush Mountain.

label: Cooley Creek
description: rises in central Franklin County and flows NE into Neal Gut.

label: Coollyconch Mountain
description: a sandy loam elevation in NW Cumberland County on the Fort Bragg Military Reservation.

label: Coombs Fork
description: community in W Jones County.

label: Coon Creek
description: rises in E Granville County and flows S into Fishing Creek.

label: Coon Hollow
description: S Haywood County on a tributary of Middle Prong.

label: Coon Mountain
description: N central Alexander County. Alt. 1,520.

label: Coontree Branch
description: rises in N Transylvania County near Coontree Mountain and flows S into Davidson River.

label: Coontree Mountain
description: N Transylvania County on the head of Coontree Branch.

label: Cooper
description: community in NE Cherokee County.

label: Cooper
description: community in NE Cumberland County on South River.

label: Cooper Branch
description: rises in W Mitchell County and flows S into Toe River.

label: Cooper Creek
description: rises in N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows SW into Tuckasegee River.

label: Cooper Gap
description: N Yancey County between Peterson Ridge and the head of Sampson Branch.

label: Cooper Gap Township
description: N Polk County.

label: Cooper Knob
description: at the SW end of Franks Creek Lead in S Graham County.

label: Cooper Mountain
description: W central Swain County, a spur running SW from Jackson Line Mountain.

label: Cooper Store
description: former community in SW Mecklenburg County.

label: Coopers Branch
description: rises in N central Avery County and flows NW into Cranberry Creek.

label: Coopers Township
description: S central Nash County.

label: Coopertown
description: community in S Nash County between Little Sapony Creek and Sapony Creek. Known also as Deans Community.

label: Coor Millpond
description: W Wayne County on Beaverdam Swamp. A mill there was owned by Ollin Coor, sheriff of Wayne County in 1848.

label: Coot Cove
description: W Swain County between the forks of Pilkey Creek.

label: Copal Grove
description: community in N Stanly County served by post office, 1875-1905.

label: Cope Branch
description: rises in NW Swain County and flows S into Haw Gap Branch.

label: Cope Creek
description: rises in N central Jackson County on the SW slope of Carver Mountain and flows W approx. 4 mi. into Scott Creek on the E limits of Sylva.

label: Cope Knob
description: on the Jackson-Macon county line.

label: Cope Mountain
description: N Jackson County between Soapstone Creek and Scott Creek.

label: Copeland
description: community in S Surry County near the head of East Double Creek.

label: Copeland Creek
description: rises in W Ashe County and flows SE into North Fork New River.

label: Coppedge Crossroads
description: community in E Franklin County.

label: Copper Bald
description: N Macon County at the head of Big Branch. Alt. 5,249.

label: Copper Creek
description: rises in N Cherokee County between Groundhog Ridge and Copper Ridge and flows SE into Beaverdam Creek.

label: Copper Gap
description: on the Swain County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park between Eagle Rock and Mount Sequoyah.

label: Copper Knob
description: N Macon County between Rhinehardt Creek and Younce Creek.

label: Copper Mine Branch
description: rises in Forest City, S central Rutherford County, and flows SE into Broad River.

label: Copper Mine Creek
description: rises in N Lee County and flows SE into Hughes Creek. Named for a copper mine operated near its head. Many broken Indian arrowheads have been found on a knoll near its junction with Hughes Creek; since no perfect arrowheads have been found, it has been suggested that they were made at the site.

label: Copper Mines
description: former community in NW Alleghany County. Copper mines operated there during the Civil War.

label: Copper Neck
description: W Chowan County S of the mouth of Rockyhock Creek. The name is a corruption of Cowpen Neck, the name of a plantation owned in 1747 by Charles West.

label: Copper Ridge
description: NW Cherokee County, extends NE from Nin Ridge.

label: Copper Swamp
description: rises in E Martin County and flows W into Gardners Creek.

label: Copperas Bald
description: mountain in W Avery County.

label: Copperas Mountain
description: NE Buncombe County at the NW end of Big Fork Ridge.

label: Copperas Rock
description: peak in N Transylvania County on Mills River.

label: Coppermine Creek
description: rises in E Jackson County and flows SE into Mull Creek.

label: Coquina Beach
description: part of Cape Hatteras National Seashore on S Bodie Island, E Dare County across from Bodie Island Lighthouse. Remains of shipwreck Laura A Barnes, grounded 1921, rest there.

label: Cora
description: community in S Caldwell County. Named for daughter of Albert G. Corpening. Alt. 1,224.

label: Corani River
description: See New River.

label: Coranine River
description: See Newport River.

label: Coranine Sound
description: See Core Sound.

label: Corapeake
description: community in NE Gates County, settled late seventeenth or early eighteenth centuries. Known as Orapeake until a post office was est. and the Post Office Department made a mistake in the spelling. Alt. 44. See also Bearpond.

label: Corapeake Swamp
description: rises in N Gates County and flows SE into Hamburg Ditch in the Dismal Swamp. Appears as Orapeak Creek on the Moseley map, 1733. The lower course of the stream is called Elm Swamp on the Moseley map but Loosen Swamp on the Collet map, 1770. Later maps, until as recently as 1929, use the name Orapeake Swamp.

label: Corbett
description: community in SE Caswell County. Named about 1880 for J. C. and Calvin Corbett, who operated a store there. Alt. 800.

label: Corbetts Ferry
description: See Ivanhoe.

label: Corbin Creek
description: rises in E Macon County and flows SW into Cat Creek.

label: Corbin Knob
description: on the Jackson-Macon county line. Alt. 4,445.

label: Corbin Mountain
description: on the Henderson County, N.C.-Greenville County, S.C., line.

label: Corbinton
description: See Hillsborough.

label: Cordova
description: community in SW Richmond County on the Pee Dee River. A post office, Steeles Mill, existed there as early as 1828 and became the name of the railroad station. Cordova post office est. 1899. Produces textiles.

label: Corduroy Swamp
description: rises in N Northampton County and flows E and NE to join Rogers Swamp in forming Kirbys Creek.

label: Core Banks
description: outer barrier beach extending from Cape Lookout to Swash Inlet along the SE side of Core Sound, E Carteret County. Named for Core Indians. Velasco map, 1611, shows the name Endesoakes at the NE end of Core Banks; the Smith map, 1624, shows the name Salvage Island. Including Portsmouth Island, the Core Banks are approx. 44 mi. long. See also Cape Lookout National Seashore Recreational Area.

label: Core Beach
description: a portion of Core Banks, which see, in E Carteret County between Core Sound and the Atlantic Ocean. It lies just S of Portsmouth Island.

label: Core Creek
description: originally rose in central Carteret County and flowed S into Newport River. Dredging and the cutting of a canal now make Core Creek a connecting link between the waters of Neuse and Newport Rivers.

label: Core Point
description: S side of Pamlico River central Beaufort County. Named for Coree Indians.

label: Core Sound
description: a body of water between the mainland and the Outer Banks extending from Cape Lookout to Pamlico Sound in E Carteret County. Named for the Coranine or Coree Indians who lived in the area. The name Corenines appears on the Comberford map, 1657. The Moll map, 1729, shows Coranine Sound; and the Moseley map, 1773, has Core Sound.

label: Corine
description: community in SW Duplin County served by post office, 1894-1903. Named for postmaster Luther Powell's daughter, Corina.

label: Corinth
description: community in SW Catawba County.

label: Corn Crib Point
description: SE Carteret County, extends into Jarrett Bay SE of the community of Davis.

label: Cornatzer
description: community in central Davie County. Named for local family. Alt. 777.

label: Corncake Inlet
description: SE Brunswick County from Onslow Bay in the Atlantic Ocean into Buzzard Bay and Cape Fear River N of Smith Island.

label: Corncob Island
description: W Bogue Sound, SW Carteret County.

label: Corncob Mountain
description: extends NE between Seniard Creek and Sitton Creek in NW Henderson County.

label: Corndack Creek
description: rises in E Moore County and flows S into Little River. Originally known as Cuidreach Creek, it was named for the Cuidreach McDonald family. Early English mapmakers could only translate its Gaelic pronunciation as Corndack.

label: Cornelia
description: community in NE Cumberland County served by post office, 1888-1904.

label: Cornelius
description: town in N Mecklenburg County. Est. 1893 as Liverpool. Inc. 1905 and renamed Cornelius in honor of Joe B. Cornelius, principal stockholder in a local mill. Produces textiles. Alt. 833.

label: Cornelius Creek
description: rises in S Iredell County and flows SW into Catawba River.

label: Corner Knob
description: on the Jackson-Macon county line.

label: Corner Rock Creek
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows W to join Walker Branch in forming Dillingham Creek.

label: Cornet Branch
description: rises in SE Macon County and flows SE into Clear Creek.

label: Cornet Knob
description: SE Macon County between Tom Branch and Cornet Branch.

label: Cornett Branch
description: rises in NW Watauga County and flows SE into Rube Creek.

label: Cornjack
description: See Coinjock.

label: Cornwall
description: community in N Granville County served by post office, 1892-1908.

label: Cornwell Branch
description: rises in E Cherokee County and flows SE into Snead Branch.

label: Corolla
description: community on Currituck Banks, E Currituck County. Known as Currituck Beach until 1895, when a post office was est. there and named Corolla. Whalehead Club built there in the 1920s, later used as a summer school for boys and now open to visitors as part of park. A lighthouse there, the last major one constructed on the Outer Banks, was first lighted on December 1, 1875.

label: Correll Branch
description: rises in W Haywood County, Great Smoky Mountains National Park, near lat. 35°42'05" N., long. 83°07'06" W., and flows SE into Little Cataloochee Creek. The stream has also been known as North Prong.

label: Corundum
description: community in E Clay County on Barnett Branch.

label: Corundum Hill
description: E Macon County between Lickskillet Branch and Crows Branch. Named for the mineral found there.

label: Corys Store
description: community in S Martin County on Smithwick Creek.

label: Cosby Knob
description: on the Haywood County, N.C.-Cocke County, Tenn., line, Great Smoky Mountains National Park, on the Great Smoky Mountains divide near lat. 35°43'47" N., long. 83°11'12" W. Alt. 5,145.

label: Cosma
description: community in SW Wake County.

label: Cossart
description: term used by Moravians to describe land in what is now Watauga and Wilkes Counties. Appears on the 1757 Bellin map. Title to the tract was taken by Henry Cossart (1714-63), agent who facilitated purchase of Wachovia.

label: Costin
description: community in W Pender County on Moores Creek, formerly called Costins Store.

label: Costins Store
description: See Costin.

label: Costner
description: community in S Gaston County served by post office, 1891-1902.

label: Cotan
description: See Seco.

label: Cottage Point
description: E Pasquotank County, extends into the Pasquotank River within limits of Elizabeth City.

label: Cotten's Cross Roads
description: See Roxobel.

label: Cottendale
description: See Bruce.

label: Cotton Creek
description: rises in E Montgomery County and flows E into Moore County, where it enters Cabin Creek.

label: Cotton Grove
description: community in S central Davidson County.

label: Cotton Grove Township
description: W central Davidson County.

label: Cotton Hammock
description: E Carteret County between community of Stacy and Piney Point.

label: Cotton Patch
description: former community on Pigeon River in N Haywood County. A number of years ago, a resident planted a small patch of cotton there, and his wife used it to weave cloth. The patch is now grown over and the place abandoned, but the name persists.

label: Cotton Patch Bay
description: an arm of Big Colly Bay in NE Bladen County.

label: Cotton's Crossing
description: See Tuscarora Beach.

label: Cottonville
description: community in S Stanly County. Named prior to the Civil War because of the quantity of cotton grown in the vicinity.

label: Cottonwood
description: community in S Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1890-1900.

label: Cottrell Hill
description: community in E Caldwell County on Zacks Fork. Named for William Cottrell, who settled there shortly before the Civil War.

label: Couch Mountain
description: N Henderson County between Clark Gap and Rich Mountain.

label: Couches Creek
description: rises in NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows SE into Oconaluftee River.

label: Coulson Ordinary
description: appears on the Collet map, 1770, on the Pee Dee River in what is now SE Stanly County E of the town of Norwood. At Colson's Mill nearby, Col. William Lee Davidson's Whig militia defeated Col. Samuel Bryan's Tories in July 1780.

label: Council
description: town in S Bladen County. Alt. 64. Inc. 1905. Named for industrialist K. Clyde Council (1886?-1951). Also called Council Station because of depot on railroad.

label: Council Gap
description: W central Watauga County near the head of Bairds Creek.

label: Council Mill Pond
description: S Bladen County 14 mi. SE of county seat; an artificial pond on Friar Swamp owned by Clyde Council estate. Fishing. Not open to the public.

label: Council Station
description: See Council.

label: Counterfeit Branch
description: rises in N Haywood County and flows SW into Pigeon River.

label: Country Line
description: community in N Granville County.

label: Country Line Creek
description: rises in SE Rockingham County and flows NE across Caswell County into Virginia, where it enters Dan River NE of Milton. Mentioned in local records as early as 1754. Named for the eighteenth-century custom of calling the North Carolina-Virginia line the "country line."

label: County Line
description: community in W Davie County served by post office, 1828-1906.

label: County Line Gap
description: on the Caldwell-Wilkes county line.

label: County Line Ridge
description: on the Caldwell-Wilkes county line.

label: County of Norfolk
description: was created in 1636 by authorities in Virginia to give Henry Frederick Howard, Lord Maltravers, a specific area for his proposed settlement. Maltravers in 1632 acquired the Heath grant (see Carolana). The new county extended from about the site of present Suffolk, Va., to New Bern, N.C. It was into the area that the earliest settlers of what is now North Carolina began to move from Virginia. The County of Norfolk was soon divided into Upper Norfolk and Lower Norfolk Counties, with the latter containing the region that later became a part of North Carolina.

label: Court House Bald
description: SE Clay County on the SE end of Ravenrock Ridge.

label: Court House Bay
description: S Onslow County in New River. The county's first courthouse was on the banks of New River there, 1734-35.

label: Court House Creek
description: rises in NW Transylvania County and flows SE into North Fork French Broad River.

label: Court House Falls
description: NW Transylvania County in Court House Creek.

label: Courthouse Knob
description: N peak of Richland Mountains in N Buncombe County near lat. 35°41' N., long. 82°27'30" W.

label: Courthouse Township
description: central Camden County.

label: Courtney
description: community in S Yadkin County. Formerly known as Chinquapin Cross Roads. Named for Courtney Baptist Church, organized there in 1832. A late nineteenth-century post office serving the community was named Cross Roads Church.

label: Cove
description: community in E Haywood County on Cove Creek.

label: Cove Branch
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows NE into East Fork French Broad River.

label: Cove City
description: town in W Craven County. Alt. 48. Settled 1859; inc. 1907. Known earlier as Cove Creek.

label: Cove Creek
description: community in central Haywood County on Jonathans Creek. Post office from late nineteenth century until mid-twentieth century.

label: Cove Creek
description: rises in central Haywood County and flows NE into Jonathans Creek.

label: Cove Creek Gap
description: central Haywood County, Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°37'52" N., long. 83°02'50" W., at the head of Winding Stair Branch. Alt. 4,071.

label: Cove Creek Ridge
description: central Watauga County, forms a semicircle just SW of Buckeye Knob.

label: Cove Creek Township
description: W central Watauga County.

label: Cove Field Branch
description: rises in SW Haywood County and flows NE into Allen Creek.

label: Cove Field Ridge
description: SW Haywood County parallel to Cove Field Branch.

label: Cove Gap
description: on the Alexander-Wilkes county line S of Pores Knob.

label: Covefield Branch
description: rises in SE Macon County and flows SE into Clear Creek.

label: Covington
description: community in NW Richmond County. A post office was est. there as early as 1830.

label: Covington Mountain
description: NW Cleveland County on Brier Creek. Alt. 2,038.

label: Cow Bog Branch
description: rises in central Columbus County and flows SE into Waccamaw River.

label: Cow Branch
description: rises in NW Columbus County and flows SW into Porter Swamp.

label: Cow Branch
description: rises in N Burke County and flows N into Avery County, where it enters Linville River.

label: Cow Camp Branch
description: rises in central Avery County and flows N into North Toe River.

label: Cow Camp Creek
description: rises in central Avery County and flows N into Kentucky Creek.

label: Cow Camp Gap
description: near head of Cow Camp Creek in central Avery County.

label: Cow Creek
description: rises in the highlands of Garrenton's Island in E Camden County and flows E into North River.

label: Cow Gallus Creek
description: rises in E Pamlico County and flows E into Long Creek.

label: Cow Hole Branch
description: rises in N Duplin County and flows S into Goshen Swamp.

label: Cow Island
description: higher ground surrounded by swamp, S Duplin County.

label: Cow Pond Branch
description: rises in NW Craven County and flows S into Neuse River.

label: Cow Swamp
description: rises in S Pitt County and flows NE into Chicod Creek.

label: Cowan
description: See Burgaw.

label: Cowan Cove
description: the valley through which the upper course of Smith Mill Creek flows in central Buncombe County.

label: Cowan Knob
description: on the W end of Lizzy Mountain in central Jackson County.

label: Cowan's Ford
description: over Catawba River at the Lincoln-Mecklenburg county line, now under the waters of Lake Norman. Cornwallis, pursuing Gen. Nathanael Greene, crossed the Catawba there after a sharp fight on February 1, 1781, in which Gen. William Lee Davidson was slain.

label: Coward Bald
description: peak at NE end of Coward Mountain in E Jackson County. Alt. 5,200.

label: Coward Creek
description: a small tidal stream flowing E through the swampy part of Oak Island into Molasses Creek in SE Brunswick County.

label: Coward Lake
description: formed in 1950 in central Jackson County on Norton Creek. Covers 1 acre and has max. depth of 10 ft. Used for fishing. Not open to the public.

label: Coward Mountain
description: extends from Moses Creek in central Jackson County NE to Coward Bald.

label: Cowarts
description: community in central Jackson County on Caney Fork.

label: Cowee
description: chief town of the Middle Cherokees, destroyed by the Rutherford Expedition, 1776. The mound on which the council house stood is a short distance NW of Franklin in central Macon County. The name is believed to have meant "place of the Deer Clan." Also spelled Keowee.

label: Cowee Bald
description: on the Jackson-Macon county line. Alt. 5,085.

label: Cowee Creek
description: rises in N Macon County and flows SW into Little Tennessee River.

label: Cowee Gap
description: on the Jackson-Macon county line.

label: Cowee Mountains
description: a range of mountains in SE Swain, E Macon, and W Jackson Counties. The Jackson-Macon county line follows the peak of the ridge.

label: Cowee Township
description: NE Macon County.

label: Cowee Tunnel
description: See Dillsboro.

label: Coweeta
description: community in SW Macon County between the Nantahala Mountains and Little Tennessee River near Otto. Alt. 2,875. U.S. Forest Service hydrologic laboratory is located there. Older residents and old records use the spelling Coweta. Federal officials adopted the spelling Coweeta, and it now appears on maps and in official records.

label: Coweeta Creek
description: rises in S Macon County and flows NE into Little Tennessee River.

label: Coweeta Gap
description: S Macon County between Carrol Knob and Black Mountain.

label: Cowell's Bridge
description: See Sligo.

label: Cowenjock
description: See Coinjock.

label: Coweta
description: See Coweeta.

label: Cowford Swamp
description: rises in SW Robeson County and flows NE into Ashpole Swamp.

label: Cowhead Creek
description: rises in SE Onslow County and flows SW into Frenchs Creek.

label: Cowhorn Swamp
description: rises in N Onslow County and flows SW into New River.

label: Cowl Cove
description: on a tributary of Clear Branch in SW Macon County.

label: Cowlick Branch
description: rises in W Edgecombe County and flows NW into Tar River.

label: Cowmire Branch
description: rises in central Cherokee County and flows S into Colvard Creek.

label: Cowpen Island
description: a point of land extending from Core Banks into Core Sound in SE Carteret County.

label: Cowpen Neck
description: See Copper Neck.

label: Cowpen Top
description: peak on Whiteoak Mountain in N Haywood County.

label: Cowper's Hill
description: See Maxton.

label: Cowrock Mountain
description: S Jackson County between Logan Creek and Long Branch. Alt. 4,240.

label: Cowstamp Mountain
description: E Swain County between Long Creek and Hickorynut Branch.

label: Cox Branch
description: rises in E Transylvania County and flows SW into Cascade Lake.

label: Cox Creek
description: rises in N Henderson County and flows SE into Clear Creek.

label: Cox Creek
