description: rises in NW McDowell County and flows S into Armstrong Creek.

label: Cox Creek Gap
description: N Yancey County between the head of North Cox Creek and South Cox Creek.

label: Cox Knob
description: E Yancey County between the forks of Long Branch and Crabtree Creek.

label: Cox Mill
description: See Mill Grove.

label: Cox Millpond
description: on the Johnston-Wayne county line on Mill Branch, just before its confluence with Mill Creek. Named for an early Quaker family of Wayne County.

label: Cox Point
description: extends from E Onslow County into White Oak River.

label: Cox Store
description: community in E Polk County between Whiteoak Creek and Green River. Alt. 868.

label: Cox's Falls
description: formerly rapids in Neuse River in SW Wayne County but now submerged by Goldsboro Cooling Pond. Mentioned as early as 1819 in a survey of the rivers of North Carolina.

label: Cox's Knob
description: E Caldwell County. Alt. 2,430. Probably named for Matthew Cox, eighteenth-century settler.

label: Cox's Mill
description: former mill on Deep River, E central Randolph County. Was headquarters of David Fanning, noted leader of N.C. Tories, 1781-82. Appears on the Collet map, 1770. See also Coxsborough; Mill Creek.

label: Coxcomb Mountain
description: on the Buncombe-Yancey county line between Rocky Knob and Ogle Meadows. Alt. 5,443.

label: Coxe Branch
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows SE into Little Creek.

label: Coxe's Store
description: See Newton Grove.

label: Coxsborough
description: town authorized to be laid off in 1797 at or near Cox's Mill, E central Randolph County at the junction of Mill Creek and Deep River. Warehouses for inspection of agricultural products were to be est. there in connection with navigation up and down Deep River. Apparently the town was never set. See also Cox's Mill.

label: Coxville
description: community in S Pitt County.

label: Cozad Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SE into Morris Creek.

label: Cozad Gap
description: NE Cherokee County in the Snowbird Mountains.

label: Cozart
description: community in SW Granville County served by post office, 1889-1905. Alt. 332.

label: Crab Creek
description: rises in W Henderson County and flows W into E Transylvania County and NW into Little River approx. 2 mi. N of Cascade Lake.

label: Crab Creek Township
description: W Henderson County.

label: Crab Island
description: in swampy area of S Currituck County between Sligo and Shawboro. Used by local Confederates under Capt. Caleb Grandy. Target of Union troops under Gen. Edward Wild, 1863.

label: Crab Orchard Fields
description: an open section in E Haywood County between Crabtree Bald and Gudger Knob.

label: Crab Orchard Township
description: former township in E central Mecklenburg County, now township no. 7.

label: Crab Point
description: a point of the mainland in central Carteret County extending into waters of Newport River.

label: Crab Point Bay
description: in Newport River, Carteret County, near mouth of Calico Creek N of Morehead City.

label: Crab Point Thorofare
description: a channel running between Newport Marshes and the mainland in central Carteret County.

label: Craborchard Creek
description: rises in SW Watauga County near Avery county line and flows E into Dutch Creek. Also known as Orchard Creek.

label: Crabtree
description: community in E Haywood County. Alt. 2,659. Settled about 1809. Named for the creek.

label: Crabtree Bald
description: E Haywood County at SW end of Crab Orchard Fields. Alt. 5,320-5,360.

label: Crabtree Creek
description: rises in W Wake County and flows NE and SE into Neuse River E of Raleigh. Appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Crabtree Creek State Park
description: See William B. Umstead State Park.

label: Crabtree Falls
description: on Long Branch in SW Mitchell County near Big Crabtree Creek.

label: Crabtree Gap
description: E Haywood County on the head of Rogers Cove Creek.

label: Crabtree Mountain
description: SW Mitchell County at the head of Roaring Branch. Alt. 3,960.

label: Crabtree Township
description: E Yancey County.

label: Craddock Swamp
description: rises in N Sampson County and flows SW into Ward Swamp.

label: Craggy
description: community in central Buncombe County on the W bank of French Broad River S of Elk Mountain. Alt. 1,944.

label: Craggy Dome
description: peak in Great Graggy Mountains, NE Buncombe County. Formerly known as Big Craggy. Alt. 6,080-6,100.

label: Craggy Gardens
description: a 675-acre area in NE Buncombe County N of Craggy Knob. Noted for its native purple rhododendron, which blooms in mid-June.

label: Craggy Knob
description: peak in Great Craggy Mountains, NE Buncombe County. Sometimes shown on old maps as Bee Tree Mountain or High Top of Bee Tree. Alt. 5,600-5,700.

label: Craggy Pinnacle
description: peak in the Great Craggy Mountains, NE Buncombe County. Appears in early records and on old maps as Buckner's Knob. Alt. 5,900-6,000.

label: Cragnola Gap
description: at the head of Cabin Creek in S Henderson County.

label: Craig
description: community in S McDowell County served by post office, 1896-1912.

label: Craig Mountain
description: S Macon County near the heads of Mulberry Creek and Waterloo Branch.

label: Craig's Creek
description: rises in W Caldwell County and flows E into Wilson's Creek.

label: Craigrownie
description: community in SE Montgomery County. Settled by Scots. Area noted for production of naval stores.

label: Craigs Point
description: extends into the E side of Sulliers Bay in SE Onslow County.

label: Crains Creek
description: name applied to the lower course of Dunhams Creek, which see, E Moore County. It flows SE into Little River. Named for the Crain family, which settled along its banks before 1750.

label: Cramerton
description: town in SE Gaston County on South Fork Catawba River. Est. 1906 when a mill was constructed by J. H. Mayes. Known as Mayesworth until purchased by Cramerton Mills, Inc., founded by Stuart W. Cramer (1868-1940). Inc. 1967. Produces textiles. Alt. 633.

label: Cranberry
description: community in N central Avery County. Alt. 3,202. A post office est. there in 1850 as Cranberry Forge; discontinued for a brief period following the Civil War. Name changed to Cranberry after 1882. Named for cranberries that grew abundantly nearby. Cranberry Iron Mine, which see, was there.

label: Cranberry Creek
description: rises in W Yadkin County and flows SE into South Deep Creek.

label: Cranberry Gap
description: central Avery County between Minneapolis and Cranberry. Alt. 3,500.

label: Cranberry Iron Mine
description: surface iron mines in N central Avery County. Believed to have been worked by Cherokee Indians. Discovered by white settlers in 1781; worked from 1826, most actively from 1865 to 1930. Supplied iron to the Confederacy. See also Cranberry.

label: Cranberry Island
description: high ground in N Tyrrell County surrounded by peat lands N of community of Levels.

label: Cranberry Knob
description: NW Burke County. Alt. 4,223.

label: Cranberry Ridge
description: N Jackson County between Cranberry Creek and Hornbuckle Creek.

label: Cranberry Township
description: W Avery County.

label: Crane Branch
description: rises in central Madison County and flows N into Revere Creek.

label: Crane Creek
description: rises in S Rowan County and flows NE into High Rock Lake (Yadkin River). Mentioned in local records as early as 1728. Appears on the Collet map, 1770, as Cane Creek, but as Crane Creek on the Price map, 1808. Crane Creek has three tributaries, all called Crane Creek; one of them, near Salisbury, is sometimes called Town Creek.

label: Crane Creek
description: See Crains Creek. The stream in Lee and Moore Counties has been variously spelled Crane, Crane's, and Crains.

label: Crane Island
description: See Campbell Island.

label: Crane Ponds
description: a cluster of half a dozen small natural lakes in NW Onslow County. Apparently first named on Bache's U.S. Coast Survey map, 1865.

label: Crane(y) Island
description: See Harkers Island.

label: Cranes Island
description: See Eagles Island.

label: Cransford Cove
description: W Macon County at the head of Wayah Creek.

label: Craters Mill
description: community in S Forsyth County.

label: Craven
description: community in SE Rowan County served by post office, 1882-1915.

label: Craven County
description: one of three counties (Albemarle and Clarendon being the other two) set up in 1664 by the Lords Proprietors of Carolina. Its territory embraced what later became South Carolina. The Ashley River settlement, Charles Town (Charleston), was est. in 1670.

label: Craven Gap
description: central Buncombe County between Rice Knob and Peach Knob in the Elk Mountains.

label: Craven Parish
description: Church of England, Craven County, est. 1715, coextensive with the county. By 1741 it was called Christ-Church Parish. In 1767 there were 1,378 white taxables in the parish. Christ Church Parish of the Episcopal Church, however, still functions in New Bern.

label: Crawford
description: See Currituck; Danbury.

label: Crawford Branch
description: rises in central Macon County and flows SE and NE into Little Tennessee River.

label: Crawford Creek
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows NE into East Fork Pigeon River.

label: Crawford Creek Gap
description: S Haywood County on the head of Crawford Creek.

label: Crawford Gap
description: N Haywood County on the NE end of Hurricane Mountain.

label: Crawford Mountain
description: SW Orange County on Cane Creek.

label: Crawford Township
description: W central Currituck County. See also Currituck.

label: Crawley Creek
description: rises in N Rutherford County and flows SE into Camp Creek.

label: Crawley Swamp
description: rises in W Bladen County and flows W into Robeson County, where it enters Big Swamp.

label: Creasman Branch
description: rises in S Buncombe County and flows E into Wesley Creek.

label: Creed's Hill
description: See Frisco.

label: Creedmoor
description: town in SW Granville County. Founded about 1840 by Thomas Lyon. Inc. 1895 as Creedmore; reincorporated 1905 as Creedmoor. Appears as Creedmoor in an 1887 atlas. Said to have been called "Need More" in the earliest days of the community but, with its growth, a more dignified name was desired. Until 1960 "mule capital of North Carolina" because of market for farm animals. Produces apparel.

label: Creedmoor Lake
description: SE Granville County on Ledge Creek. Formed in 1939 as a source of water for the town of Creedmoor and for recreation. Covers 100 acres. Also called Lake Rogers. Max. depth 30 ft.

label: Creeds Hill Coast Guard Station
description: formerly on S Hatteras Island, SE Dare County. First formed as a lifesaving station in 1878-79, it became a Coast Guard Station in 1915 but has since been deactivated.

label: Creek
description: community in S Warren County on Fishing Creek. Settled prior to 1800. Post office located there, 1883-1930.

label: Creek Mills
description: community in NE Forsyth County.

label: Creeksville
description: community in central Northampton County on Potecasi Creek.

label: Creeping Swamp
description: rises in SW Beaufort County and flows SW into Clayroot Swamp. For a part of its course, it forms the Beaufort-Pitt and Craven-Pitt county lines.

label: Cremo
description: community in N central Bertie County.

label: Crenshaw's Branch
description: rises in central Wake County and flows NE into Neuse River.

label: Crescent
description: community in S Rowan County.

label: Cressville
description: See Creswell.

label: Crestmont
description: former community in NW Haywood County on Big Creek near lat. 35°45' N., long 83°06'37" W. A sawmill community, the site is now in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Inc. 1913, but the charter was repealed in the same year.

label: Creston
description: community in W central Ashe County. Alt. approx. 2,850. Post office est. 1830 as North Fork; changed to Creston, 1882. Named for its location near the crest of the mountains.

label: Creston Township
description: SW Ashe County.

label: Creswell
description: town in E Washington County N of Scuppernong River. Alt. 6. Known as Cool Spring as early as 1826, when a post office by the name was est. there. The name was used locally as late as 1895. When William Atkinson became postmaster in 1874, the post office name was changed to Cressville in honor of John A. J. Creswell, U.S. postmaster general. Inc. 1874 as Cressville; named changed to Creswell in 1885.

label: Cribs Creek
description: rises in NW Anson County and flows N into Rocky River.

label: Cricket
description: community in central Wilkes County. Est. 1888 and named by the Post Office Department.

label: Cricket Hill
description: a man-made island in W Bogue Sound, S Carteret County.

label: Cricket Swamp
description: rises in E central Bertie County and flows S into Eastmont Swamp. Probably named for John Crickett, who owned land in the area as early as 1729.

label: Crims Crossroads
description: See Grimes Crossroads.

label: Crimsie
description: community in N Lincoln County served by post office, 1894-1903.

label: Crinkley
description: community in central Warren County served by post office, 1896-1903.

label: Crisp
description: community in S Edgecombe County.

label: Crisp Creek
description: rises in W Martin County and flows SW into SW Edgecombe County. It then flows SE and forms a portion of the Edgecombe-Pitt county line before entering Conetoe Creek.

label: Crit
description: community in SE Clay County served by post office, 1898-1906.

label: Croaker Channel
description: W Carteret County in White Oak River. Named for a species of fish. Formerly one of two channels used to reach Swansboro in the days of sailing vessels. Boats moving up Bogue Sound used Croaker Channel, while those approaching from the Atlantic Ocean used Ship (or West) Channel. Croaker Channel is now almost completely filled with sand.

label: Croatamung
description: an island shown on the White map, 1585, in what is now a part of Currituck Banks in E Currituck County. Smith, 1624, calls it Arundells Island; Comberford, 1657, makes it Lucks Island. As the latter, is the N boundary of the Carolina territory granted to the Lords Proprietors in 1663. See also Lucks Island.

label: Croatan
description: community in E Craven County. Settled about 1800. Alt. 28.

label: Croatan National Forest
description: in parts of Carteret, Craven, and Jones Counties. Est. 1933. Covers 294,610 acres. Includes the Croatan Cooperative Wildlife Management Area. Headquarters are in New Bern.

label: Croatan Sound
description: connects Albemarle and Pamlico Sounds between Roanoke Island and the mainland of Dare County. Appears as The Narrows on the Moseley map, 1733. Virginia Dare Memorial Bridge, opened 2002 and 5 mi. in length, spans the sound to connect Roanoke Island to Manns Harbor.

label: Croatan Township
description: central Dare County on the mainland.

label: Croatoan Island
description: a name applied by John White on his map of 1585 to the S portion of Hatteras Island (Dare County) and a portion of Ocracoke Island (Hyde County). Hatteras Inlet, now dividing this portion of the Outer Banks into two islands, was opened in 1846. Ralph Lane, governor of the first Roanoke colony, named the island "My Lord Admirals Iland" in honor of Lord Howard of Effingham, created Lord High Admiral in 1585. By 1657 Comberford showed the island as "Chowanoke." Smith, in 1624, had called it Abbots Island. The name Croatoan was derived from the Indian village that was on the present Cape Hatteras (Kro-otÃ¤n [talk town], indicating the chief's residence.) See also Portsmouth Island.

label: Croft
description: community in N Mecklenburg County. A post office there, Alexandriana, was est. in the home of Joseph McKnitt Alexander in 1804 and continued until 1886. By 1896 the name Croft was in use. Long served by only filling station in N Mecklenburg County.

label: Cromartie
description: community in central Robeson County served by post office, 1892-1917.

label: Cromarties Bridge
description: See Hickory Grove Crossroads.

label: Cromartys Ferry
description: See Hickory Grove Crossroads.

label: Cromwell Canal
description: a stream, rises in S Edgecombe County and flows SW into Tar River.

label: Cronly
description: See Acme.

label: Crooked Branch
description: rises in S Richmond County and flows S into South Carolina, where it enters Lightwood Knot Creek.

label: Crooked Creek
description: is formed in N Union County by the junction of North Fork Crooked Creek and South Fork Crooked Creek. It flows NE into Rocky River.

label: Crooked Creek
description: See Fork Creek.

label: Crooked Creek Township
description: SW McDowell County.

label: Crooked Fork
description: rises in NW Granville County and flows SE in an arc into Aarons Creek.

label: Crooked Run
description: rises in W Vance County and flows NE into Kerr Lake.

label: Crooked Run Creek
description: rises in S Stokes County and flows SW into N Forsyth County, where it flows back NW into Stokes County again and into Little Yadkin River.

label: Crooked Swamp
description: rises in N Nash County and flows SE then NE into Fishing Creek.

label: Cross Branch
description: rises in S Columbus County and flows SW into Horry County, S.C., where it enters Buck Creek.

label: Cross Branch
description: See Alder Branch.

label: Cross Canal
description: See Hamburg Ditch.

label: Cross Creek
description: colonial trading center in central Cumberland County on Cape Fear River begun about 1760. Appears as Crosscreek on both the Collet map, 1770, and the Mouzon map, 1775. Consolidated with Campbellton, approx. 1¼ mi. away, in 1778. In 1783 the name was changed to Fayetteville, which see.

label: Cross Creek Township
description: central Cumberland County. Coextensive with the city of Fayetteville.

label: Cross Hill
description: former community near Carthage, central Moore County. There, at Alexander Morrison's home, Tories gathered before going to the Battle of Moores Creek Bridge, February 27, 1776.

label: Cross Knob
description: N Buncombe County between Chestnut Ridge and Rattlesnake Ridge.

label: Cross Landing
description: community in W Tyrrell County E of Scuppernong River.

label: Cross Millpond
description: See Hunters Millpond.

label: Cross Mountain
description: on the Buncombe-McDowell county line. Alt. approx. 3,600.

label: Cross Roads
description: See Maysville.

label: Cross Roads Church
description: See Courtney.

label: Cross Roads Township
description: S central Martin County.

label: Cross Rock
description: community in S Madison County served by post office, 1856-1929.

label: Cross Swamp
description: rises in E Columbus County and flows SE into Waccamaw River.

label: Crossing Knob
description: W Watauga County W of a bend in Watauga River.

label: Crossnore
description: town in S Avery County. Alt. 3,546. Inc. 1925. Settled about 1838 and named for George Crossnore, keeper of general store. Crossnore School, founded in 1913 by Dr. Mary Martin Sloop, since has trained mountain children and promoted crafts.

label: Crossroads Township
description: central Wilson County.

label: Crossville
description: community in E Gates County served by post office, 1870-84.

label: Crossway
description: community in S Scotland County on Lytch's Pond.

label: Crouse
description: town in S Lincoln County. Settled about 1840. Inc. 1907. Named for W. L. Crouse, a physician who built the first house in the community.

label: Crow Branch
description: rises in SE Orange County about 2 mi. N of town of Chapel Hill and flows E into Booker Creek.

label: Crow Creek
description: rises in SW Randolph County and flows SE into Montgomery County, where it enters Uwharrie River.

label: Crow Hill
description: point of land W of Straits, E Carteret County, extending into North River.

label: Crow Island
description: appears on the Collet map, 1770; it existed as late as 1833. In Currituck Sound, NE Currituck County, it was SE of Knotts Island and barred the sound side of New Currituck Inlet until the inlet closed. After 1833 Crow Island began disintegrating, so that by 1861 it was only a mass of tidal-marsh islands.

label: Crowder Mountain Township
description: SW Gaston County.

label: Crowders
description: community in S Gaston County. Nineteenth-century post office there was known as Crowder's Creek. Alt. 775.

label: Crowders Creek
description: rises in SW Gaston County and flows NE and SE into South Carolina, where it enters Catawba River.

label: Crowders Mountain
description: SW Gaston County. Named for Ulrich Crowder, an early settler who soon moved away. Some action against Tories took place there during the Revolution. Alt. 1,624. See also All Healing Springs.

label: Crowells
description: community in central Halifax County between Tillery and Enfield. Named for two brothers, Edward and Joseph Crowell, who settled there about 1730.

label: Crowells Springs
description: community in E Stanly County on Mountain Creek.

label: Crown Stream
description: community in S Pender County. An abandoned railroad station nearby was named Richards.

label: Crozier Branch
description: rises in SE Mecklenburg County and flows E into Cabarrus County, where it enters Ready Creek.

label: Crumpler
description: community in NE Ashe County on North Fork New River. Named for Maj. Thomas Newton Crumpler, who died of wounds received in the Civil War. Thompson's Bromine-Arsenic Springs nearby discovered in 1885; hotel and cottages built in 1887. This and nearby All Healing Springs made the region a popular resort in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.

label: Cruse
description: community in E Haywood County on East Fork Pigeon River. Est. 1885 and named by first postmaster, who had just read Robinson Crusoe Alt. 2,900.

label: Cruso
description: community in central Haywood County served by post office, 1892-1942.

label: Crusoe Island
description: See River View Community.

label: Crutchfield
description: community in SW Surry County on Yadkin River. Alt. 872.

label: Crutchfields Falls
description: rapids in Yadkin River, W Surry County near the mouth of Fishers River, S of the community of Crutchfield. The rapids comprise a fall of 4 ft. over a distance of approx. ¼ mi. Mentioned as early as 1819 in a survey of the rivers of the state.

label: Crystal
description: community in SE Guilford County served by post office, 1880-1903.

label: Crystal Coast
description: modern term used to promote tourism on Bogue Banks and surrounding area, Carteret County.

label: Crystal Lake
description: E Moore County on Shaddock's Creek at the community of Lakeview. Formed in 1855 when Duncan Blue constructed a dam there; enlarged about 1908. Covers approx. 100 acres. Used for fishing, swimming, and boating.

label: Cub Branch
description: rises in E Jackson County and flows SE into Charley Creek.

label: Cub Creek
description: rises in NE Davie County and flows SW into Cedar Creek.

label: Cub Creek
description: rises in S Wilkes County and flows N into Yadkin River.

label: Cub Island Creek
description: See Cub Creek.

label: Cuba
description: former community in N Rutherford County on Gilkey Creek. Post office from 1850 until 1906. Site of a cotton gin, mill, store, and other buildings; market for cherry bark and herbs.

label: Cuccoowink Creek
description: See Dawson Creek.

label: Cucklemaker Swamp
description: rises in N central Bertie County and flows S into Hoggard Mill Creek.

label: Cucklers Creek
description: See Cuckolds Creek.

label: Cuckolds Creek
description: rises in E Beaufort County and flows W into Pantego Creek. Perhaps because of the meaning of the word cuckold, the name Cucklers has been applied to the creek.

label: Cucumber Creek
description: See Rock Hole Creek.

label: Cudda Bum
description: a creek, rises in NE Davidson County and flows S into Abbotts Creek. Named for Cuddahy Crouch, who lived nearby. "Bum" was his favorite expression and, when Cuddahy Creek was dammed for a mill, he began to speak of it as "a bum creek." From Cuddahy's Bum Creek the name Cudda Bum evolved.

label: Cuidreach Creek
description: See Corndack Creek.

label: Culberson
description: town in SW Cherokee County on South Fork Rapier Mill Creek. Inc. 1911. Named for Henry Culberson, who donated the site for the town and the post office. Alt. 1,618.

label: Culbert Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NW into Junaluska Creek.

label: Culbert Ridge
description: N Yancey County between Hensley Branch and Bald Mountain Creek.

label: Culbreth
description: community in central Granville County served by post office, 1892-1907.

label: Cullasaja
description: community in E Macon County on Cullasaja River. Once known as Sugar Town. The Cherokee word Kul-say-gee meant "sugar" or "sweet."

label: Cullasaja Branch
description: rises in S Swain County and flows NE into Yalaka Creek.

label: Cullasaja Falls
description: See Cullasaja River.

label: Cullasaja River
description: rises in SE Macon County and flows NW into Little Tennessee River. Bridal Veil, Dry, and Lower Cullasaja Falls, which see, are on the river. Moses Ashley Curtis, writing from Franklin on September 2, 1829, said that the "Falls of Sugar Town Creek" are "very imposing—nearly as high as Linville."

label: Culler
description: See Pinnacle.

label: Cullie Creek
description: rises in N central Carteret County and flows NW into Cedar Creek. It is a very short stream.

label: Cullowhee
description: community in W central Jackson County on Tuckasegee River. Originally named Kullaughee Valley, an Indian word meaning "place of the lilies." Name changed to Painter, for the first postmaster, when a post office was est. there in 1883 (closed 1908). Renamed Cullowhee about 1900. Home of Western Carolina University, founded in 1889. Alt. 2,066.

label: Cullowhee Creek
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows N into Tuckasegee River.

label: Cullowhee Gap
description: on the Jackson-Macon county line.

label: Cullowhee Mountain
description: W Jackson County, extends N from Hunter Jim Creek to Webster Creek. Alt. 4,411.

label: Cullowhee Township
description: W central Jackson County.

label: Cumberland
description: town in W Cumberland County. Settled 1850. Known as Beaver Creek for the stream on which it is located until 1889, when it was inc. Long inactive in municipal affairs. Alt. 125.

label: Cumberland County
description: was formed in 1754 from Bladen County. Located in the SE section of the state, it is bounded by Sampson, Bladen, Robeson, Hoke, Harnett, and Moore Counties. It was named for William Augustus, Duke of Cumberland (1721-65), second son of George II, who was commander of English troops at the Battle of Culloden in 1746 in which Scottish Highlanders were defeated. His extreme severity earned him the nickname of "The Butcher." It is ironic that the county named for him should have been settled by Scottish Highlanders. Area: 662 sq. mi. County seat: Fayetteville, with an elevation of 107 ft. Townships are Beaver Dam, Black River, Carvers Creek, Cedar Creek, Cross Creek, Eastover, Grays Creek, Manchester, Pearces Mill, Rockfish, and Seventy-First. Produces tobacco, corn, soybeans, wheat, oats, cotton, poultry, bakery products, textiles, dairy products, machinery, and lumber. See also Fayette County; Choffington.

label: Cumberland Gap
description: central Cherokee County near the junction of Rose and Dockery Creeks.

label: Cumberland Knob
description: NW Surry County. Alt. 2,885. Construction on the Blue Ridge Parkway began there September 11, 1935. Cumberland Knob Recreation Area with picnic grounds and hiking trails is there. Said to have been named by Dr. Thomas Walker, a Virginia explorer, for his patron, the Duke of Cumberland, in the 1750s.

label: Cummins Creek
description: rises in NE Onslow County and flows SE into Grants Creek.

label: Cumnock
description: community in NW Lee County. The Egypt coal mine is there; it operated at intervals from 1855 until 1928 and supplied coal for Confederate blockade runners. The community was named Egypt because large crops of corn produced in the area brought in buyers from the outside as in the biblical story of Joseph. Post office name changed to Cumnock in 1895 for an official of the mine. Alt. 259.

label: Cundiff Creek
description: rises in S Surry County and flows SE into Yadkin River.

label: Cunningham
description: community in NW Person County. Named for John W. Cunningham, local landowner and planter. Post office, Cunningham's Store, operated there from 1816 to 1908.

label: Cunningham Creek
description: rises in S Macon County and flows NE into Shope Fork.

label: Cunningham Field
description: U.S. Marine Corps Air Station, 1941, named for aviator A. A. Cunningham. Renamed Cherry Point, which see, 1942.

label: Cunningham Mill
description: See Monroeton.

label: Cunningham Mountain
description: N Henderson County between Fletcher Branch and Clark Gap.

label: Cunningham Township
description: NW Person County.

label: Curfew
description: community in SW McDowell County. Site of store, post office, and one-room schoolhouse.

label: Curl
description: community in central Montgomery County.

label: Curl Tail Creek
description: rises in NW Stanly County and flows NE in an arc into Riles Creek. Named for its meandering course. Known in 1903 as Fraley Branch.

label: Currie
description: community in SW Pender County. Alt. 33. Settled about 1888. Named for John H. Currie, a director of the Cape Fear & Yadkin Valley Railroad. Battle of Moores Creek Bridge, February 27, 1776, the first battle of the Revolution in North Carolina, was fought nearby. Moores Creek National Military Park, a 30-acre tract with numerous historical monuments and a museum, is at the site.

label: Curries Branch
description: rises in N Columbus County and flows S into West Prong Creek.

label: Curriesville
description: community in S Moore County est. as railroad stop in 1920s.

label: Currituck
description: community and county seat, central Currituck County. Mentioned in local records as early as 1755. In 1822 a commission was appointed to purchase 20 acres around the courthouse, if local citizens voted approval, to lay out a town to be named Crawford. The proposal was defeated. Alt. 8.

label: Currituck Banks
description: or North Banks of Currituck, in E Currituck County, one of the Outer Banks, extends S from Virginia to Bodie Island in E Dare County. All or a part of Currituck Banks is shown as Lucks Island on the Comberford map, 1657. See also Lucks Island; Croatamung; Point Bacon; Goade Island.

label: Currituck Beach
description: See Corolla.

label: Currituck County
description: was formed by 1681 as a precinct within Albemarle County. Located in the NE section of the state, it is bounded by the Atlantic Ocean, Albemarle Sound, Camden County, and the state of Virginia. The name is traditionally said to be derived from Coratank, an Indian word for wild geese. Area: 469 sq. mi. County seat: Currituck, with an elevation of 8 ft. Townships are Crawford, Fruitville, Moyock, and Poplar Branch. Produces Irish potatoes, sweet potatoes, corn, soybeans, hogs, cattle, peanuts, steel products, concrete products, seafood, and lumber. See also Farmington.

label: Currituck Creek
description: rises in SE Hertford County and flows SE into Bertie County, where it enters Chowan River.

label: Currituck Inlet
description: through what is now Currituck Banks, E Currituck County, shown on the Comberford map, 1657, as Choratuck Inlet. Closed by a storm in 1828. See also Denniss Island.

label: Currituck Narrows
description: See Poplar Branch.

label: Currituck Parish
description: Church of England, Currituck County, coextensive with the county, est. 1715. In 1767 the parish had 400 white taxables.

label: Currituck Point
description: extends from the SW mainland of Hyde County into the mouth of Pungo River.

label: Currituck Sound
description: the body of water between Currituck Banks on the E and the mainland of Currituck County on the W and from Knotts Island on the N to Powells Point on the s. Approx. 30 mi. long; max. width, 4 mi. It appears on the Moseley map, 1733. In 1930 Wright Memorial Bridge, 3 mi. long wooden span, was built across the sound from Point Harbor to N of Kitty Hawk. See also Titepano.

label: Currituck Township
description: W Hyde County.

label: Curtis
description: community in central Alamance County served by post office, 1855-1905.

label: Curtis Cove
description: S Haywood County. A tributary of West Fork Pigeon River flows through the cove.

label: Curtis Creek
description: rises in W McDowell County and flows SE into Catawba River.

label: Curtis's Mills
description: See Curtis.

label: Curtiss Knob
description: S Macon County at the head of Piney Knob Creek.

label: Cuscopang River
description: See Scuppernong River.

label: Cushing Branch
description: rises in N Henderson County and flows NW into Cane Creek. Also known as Cushion Creek.

label: Cushion Creek
description: See Cushing Branch.

label: Cut Laurel Gap
description: in Stone Mountains, W Ashe County on the Tennessee state line. Named because early settlers encountered such a thick "rhododendron hell" there that they had to cut a tunnel through it for a mile or more. Alt. 3,746.

label: Cut-off Ridge
description: N Jackson County, extends N from Scott Creek.

label: Cutawhiskie Swamp
description: rises in SE Northampton County and flows NE into Hertford County, where it enters Livermans Mill Pond on Potecasi Creek. Named for an Indian village mentioned in local records (with various spellings) as early as 1718.

label: Cutoff Island
description: E Dare County, in the waters of Roanoke Sound off the SW tip of Bodie Island.

label: Cutshall Branch
description: rises in N Madison County and flows W into Shelton Laurel Creek.

label: Cutshalltown
description: community in N Madison County on a tributary of Shelton Laurel Creek.

label: Cutthroat Gap
description: on the Buncombe-Henderson county line between Candler Knob and Stony Bald. Alt. approx. 4,200.

label: Cuwhiffle Swamp
description: rises in SE Sampson County near Delway and flows NW into Six Runs Creek. The name may be derived through faulty pronunciation of the Gaelic Culmhutar (pronounced "kul-vú-tar"), meaning "smuggler" or "mutineer." See also Quewhiffle.

label: Cwareunoc
description: an Indian village shown on the De Bry map, 1590, as being on Bogue Sound, S Carteret County.

label: Cycle
description: community in W Yadkin County on Dobbins Creek. Known first as Pea Ridge. Post office est. 1904 and named Cycle from the fact that the patrons it served lived in a circle from the post office. Post office name gradually replaced the older name.

label: Cynthia Branch
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows W into Cane River.

label: Cypress Branch
description: rises in central Columbus County and flows NE into White Marsh.

label: Cypress Creek
description: rises in N Onslow County and flows N into Jones County, where it enters Trent River. Appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Cypress Creek
description: See Goodwin Creek.

label: Cypress Creek Bay
description: a mucky, loam-filled bay in central Columbus County.

label: Cypress Creek Township
description: S Jones County.

label: Cypress Landing
description: community in E Pender County.

label: Cypress Point
description: a point of land extending from the mainland of W Dare County S of Mill Tail Creek into Alligator River.

label: Cypress Run
description: rises in SE Beaufort County and flows E into South Creek.

label: Cypress Swamp
description: See Goodwin Creek.

label: Cyprett's Bridge
description: former bridge over New Hope Creek in NE Chatham County on the road from New Bern by Raleigh to Pittsboro. Also spelled Ceputt's, Cipritz, Cyprits, Cypretz. It was selected in 1793 from seven suggested sites within 15 mi. of which the University of North Carolina was to be located. Later called Prince's Bridge, which see.

label: Cyrus
description: community in W Onslow County on Harris Creek.

label: Da-loh-no-geh
description: See Yellow Mountain.

label: Da-tsu-la-gun-yi
description: See Cold Mountain.

label: Dabbs
description: community in S central Caswell County.

label: Dabney
description: community in W Vance County. Named for local store operator.

label: Dabney Township
description: W Vance County.

label: Dads Top
description: mountain peak N of Twelve O'clock Top on the Buncombe-Haywood county line.

label: Dailys Creek
description: rises in W Lenoir County and flows NE into Neuse River. Probably named for John Dailey, who settled there about 1800.

label: Dairy Branch
description: flows SW thorough Mecklenburg County into Little Sugar Creek.

label: Dale
description: community in SE Surry County served by post office, 1894-1904.

label: Dalila
description: community in central Sampson County served by post office, 1892-1904.

label: Dalkeith
description: plantation house in SE Warren County near Arcola. Built in 1824 by Jack Burgess; still used as a dwelling.

label: Dallas
description: town in central Gaston County. Authorized to be laid out as county seat by act creating the county, 1846. It remained the county seat until 1909, when Gastonia was selected by popular vote. Inc. 1863. Named for George M. Dallas (1792-1864), vice president of the United States at the time the county was created. The area received postal service as early as 1817 from Hoylesville post office, named for Andrew Hoyle, first postmaster, and located 3 mi. E of site of Dallas. Post office service began in Dallas in 1846.

label: Dallas Township
description: N central Gaston County.

label: Dalton
description: community in SW Stokes County. Alt. 785. A post office there in 1874 was known as Boyles’ Store.

label: Dalton Branch
description: rises in NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows SE into Moore Springs Branch.

label: Dalton Creek
description: rises in E Macon County and flows NE into Caler Fork.

label: Dalton Gap
description: on the Swain County, N.C.-Blount County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park between Sheep Wallow Knob and Parsons Bald. Alt. 2,955.

label: Dalton Ridge
description: NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park extending NW from the head of Judy Branch to Sheep Wallow Knob.

label: Dam Creek
description: rises in S Pasquotank County and flows E into Big Flatty Creek.

label: Damons Mountain
description: SW Cherokee County, extends from Cole Gap NE to Dickey Branch.

label: Dan Gap
description: S Macon County between Henderson Mountain and Little Fishhawk Mountain.

label: Dan Holland Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SE into Valley River.

label: Dan Payne Mountain
description: S Madison County at the head of Caney Fork Branch.

label: Dan River
description: rises in S Patrick County, Va., and flows SE into Stokes County. It flows SE and NE into Rockingham County and back into Virginia. It dips back into North Carolina on the Caswell-Rockingham county line and into N Caswell County, then flows NE in Virginia into Kerr Lake, which see, on Roanoke River. Mentioned by William Byrd in 1728. Probably an Indian name.

label: Dan River Township
description: N central Caswell County.

label: Dan Sisk Gap
description: S Burke County in South Mountains.

label: Dan Weeks Point
description: a point of land extending into White Oak River, SW Carteret County.

label: Dan's School
description: community in central Forsyth County.

label: Dana
description: community in E Henderson County. A post office was est. there in 1892 expressly to serve the Hadley Hotel; named for Dana Hadley, son of the owner of the hotel. Apple growing and packing center.

label: Danamora
description: community in N Guilford County served by post office, 1892-1903.

label: Danbury
description: town and county seat, central Stokes County on the Dan River. Replaced Germantown as the county seat in 1849 when the county was divided to form Forsyth County. Inc. 1957. Called simply "county town of Stokes" from about 1849 until 1851, when it was given the name Crawford in honor of the wife of John Hill, longtime clerk of court and member of Congress. Changed to Danbury in 1852 for name of plantation of Gov. Alexander Martin (1738-1807) near the mouth of Jacobs Creek on the Dan River in Rockingham County. Martin was governor when Stokes County was created. Alt. 825. See also Intelligence.

label: Danbury Creek
description: rises in SW Stokes County and flows W into Little Yadkin River.

label: Danbury Township
description: central Stokes County.

label: Dandy
description: community in NW Ashe County. Alt. 3,455.

label: Danes Creek
description: rises in N Macon County and flows SE into Younce Creek.

label: Daniel Boone Wildlife Management Area
description: part of Pisgah National Forest in NW Burke County.

label: Daniel Boone's Cave
description: See Boone's Cave.

label: Daniel Ridge
description: in NW Transylvania County between Shuck Ridge Creek and Daniel Ridge Creek.

label: Daniel Ridge Creek
description: rises in NW Transylvania County and flows SE into Right Fork Davidson River.

label: Daniel Swash
description: waterway through a group of unnamed tidal-marsh islands in Pamlico Sound just off Portsmouth Island, E Carteret County.

label: Daniel Town
description: community in S Rutherford County. Named for Leonard N. Daniel, who operated a store there, owned adjacent land, and built several houses.

label: Daniels Cove
description: S Haywood County on Shining Creek.

label: Daniels Creek
description: rises in W Harnett County and flows NE into Cape Fear River. The name is a corruption of Donnelys; named for Arthur Donnely, who settled on its banks in 1750. Earlier known as McPhersons Creek.

label: Daniels Gap
description: on the Ashe-Wilkes county line.

label: Daniels Marshes
description: See Roanoke Marshes.

label: Daniels-Rhyne
description: textile community in central Lincoln County SW of Lincolnton. Originally two separate communities. Daniels named for Daniel Warlick, pioneer settler; Rhyne named for founder of local mill.

label: Danover
description: community in NE Surry County.

label: Dans Creek
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows SW into Straight Fork.

label: Dans Knob
description: E Madison County between Beetree Creek and East Fork [Bull Creek].

label: Danson's Manor
description: See Shiloh.

label: Danton
description: town authorized to be est. in 1803 on the lands of Thomas Rivers on the N side of Dan River, Stokes County. Apparently the town never developed.

label: Danville
description: See Startown.

label: Darb Branch
description: rises in N Transylvania County and flows NE into Bradley Creek.

label: Darby
description: community in W Wilkes County on Elk Creek. Named for Darby Hendrix, eighteenth-century pioneer landowner.

label: Dardens
description: community in NE Martin County. A post office known as Davis’ Store served the area from 1827 to 1833. Named Dardens for local family, one of whom, Col. James G. Darden, was a personal friend of Warren G. Harding from as early as 1917 and later, as an oil man, was involved in the Teapot Dome affair. Alt. 46.

label: Dare County
description: was formed in 1870 from Currituck, Tyrrell, and Hyde Counties. Located in the NE section of the state, it is bounded by the Atlantic Ocean; Pamlico, Croatan, and Albemarle Sounds; and Hyde and Tyrrell Counties. It was named for Virginia Dare, born August 18, 1587, on Roanoke Island in the county; she was the first child of English parents to be born in America. Area: 1,246 sq. mi. (388, land; 858, water). County seat: Manteo, with an elevation of 12 ft. Townships are Atlantic, Croatan, East Lake, Hatteras, Kennekeet, and Nags Head. Produces boats, concrete products, cabinets, scuppernongs, figs, poultry, processed seafood, corn, soybeans, and lumber.

label: Darfer
description: community in S Cleveland County served by post office, 1894-1903.

label: Darham Creek
description: See Durham Creek.

label: Dark Branch
description: rises in central Duplin County and flows SE into Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: Dark Corner
description: reputed bootlegger haven in SW Henderson County. Now part of Greenville, S.C., watershed.

label: Dark Cove
description: extends NW from Big Butte Mountain to West Cove in E Haywood County.

label: Dark Mountain
description: N Montgomery County near Barnes Creek.

label: Dark Prong
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows E into East Fork Pigeon River.

label: Dark Ridge
description: community in N Avery County.

label: Dark Ridge Creek
description: rises in NE Jackson County and flows NW into Scott Creek.

label: Dark Ridge Creek
description: rises in N Avery County and flows W into Tennessee, where it enters Elk River.

label: Darkridge Gap
description: mountain gap in N Avery County.

label: Darlington
description: community in N Rutherford County served by post office, 1887-1904.

label: Darnell
description: community in NW Wilkes County on a tributary of North Fork Reddies River. Named for Abdiel Darnell, who settled in the vicinity shortly after 1800.

label: Dasemunkepeuc
description: See Manns Harbor.

label: Dashoga Ridge
description: NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Its center is near lat. 35°40'40" N., long. 83°14'55" W.

label: Dave Barrett Creek
description: See Right Fork [Eagle Creek].

label: Dave Bellew Top
description: peak in SW Cherokee County between Wolf Creek and Hot House Creek.

label: Dave Rock
description: in W Transylvania County E of Bart Branch.

label: Davenport
description: community in S Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1888-1903.

label: Davenport Branch
description: rises in S Clay County and flows SE into Hiwassee River.

label: Davenport Forks
description: community in NE Washington County S of Deep Creek.

label: Davenport Gap
description: a wind gap in Great Smoky Mountains where the North Carolina-Tennessee boundary crosses the NE boundary of Great Smoky Mountains National Park, Haywood County, N.C., and Cocke County, Tenn., near lat. 35°46'30" N., long. 83°6'30" W. Named in honor of Col. William Davenport, who in 1821 marked a stone on the "north side of Cataloochee Turnpike Road" as the starting point of his survey of the Tennessee-North Carolina state line.

label: Davenport Mountain
description: W Henderson County between Johnsons Mill Creek and Shaw Creek.

label: Davers Island
description: See Harkers Island.

label: David Daniel Pond
description: See Contentnea Lake.

label: Davids Creek
description: rises in E Stanly County and flows SE into Cedar Creek.

label: Davids Point
description: an arm of N Hatteras Island extending into Pamlico Sound, E Dare County. Lies E of Great Island and S of the community of Waves.

label: Davidson
description: town in N Mecklenburg County. Inc. 1879 as Davidson College; name changed, 1891. Davidson College founded there, 1837, named for Gen. William Lee Davidson (1746-81), Revolutionary War hero killed at the Battle of Cowan's Ford. Alt. 826.

label: Davidson Branch
description: rises in W Haywood County and flows S into Palmer Creek.

label: Davidson College
description: See Davidson.

label: Davidson County
description: was formed in 1822 from Rowan County. Located in the central section of the state, it is bounded by Randolph, Montgomery, Rowan, Davie, Forsyth, and Guilford Counties. It was named for Gen. William Lee Davidson (1746-81), who was killed at the Battle of Cowans Ford on the Catawba River during the Revolutionary War. Area: 560 sq. mi. County seat: Lexington, with an elevation of 810 ft. Townships are Abbotts Creek, Alleghany, Arcadia, Boone, Conrad Hill, Cotton Grove, Emmons, Hampton, Healing Springs, Jackson Hill, Lexington, Midway, Reedy Creek, Silver Hill, Thomasville, Tyro, and Yadkin College. Produces wheat, oats, corn, tobacco, poultry, livestock, glass products, vinyl siding, box springs, voting machines, furniture, apparel, lumber, concrete pipe, batteries, lumber, slate, flagstone, and shale for brick.

label: Davidson Creek
description: rises in S Iredell County and flows SW into Mecklenburg County, where it enters Catawba River. Probably named for George Davidson, who owned 500 acres on the creek in 1778.

label: Davidson Gap
description: SE of Robinson Rough on the Buncombe-Madison county line.

label: Davidson River
description: rises in W Transylvania County and flows SE into French Broad River.

label: Davidson Township
description: SW Iredell County. Named for a local family.

label: Davidson's Fort
description: See Old Fort.

label: Davidsonville
description: community in S Cherokee County on Moccasin Creek.

label: Davie
description: community in central Henderson County. Alt. 2,214.

label: Davie Academy
description: See Kappa.

label: Davie Branch
description: rises in NW Henderson County and flows NE into North Fork.

label: Davie County
description: was formed in 1836 from Rowan County. Located in the central section of the state, it is bounded by Davidson, Rowan, Iredell, Yadkin, and Forsyth Counties. It was named for William Richardson Davie (1756-1820), Revolutionary War soldier, member of the Federal Convention of 1787, governor of North Carolina, minister to France, and one of the founders of the University of North Carolina. Area: 264 sq. mi. County seat: Mocksville, with an elevation of 866 ft. Townships are Calahaln, Clarksville, Farmington, Fulton, Jerusalem, Mocksville, and Shady Grove. Produces corn, wheat, barley, oats, dairy products, livestock, hogs, apparel, furniture, chemicals, garage doors, and textiles.

label: Davie Crossroads
description: community in S Davie County at the crossing of U.S. Highway 601 and N.C. Highway 801. Est. 1911-15 when a garage and store opened there. Locally now called Greasy Corner for lube work performed by mechanics at the junction. Alt. approx. 740.

label: Davie Mountain
description: NW Henderson County near Davie Branch.

label: Davis
description: community on Core Sound in E Carteret County on Davis Shore.

label: Davis Bald
description: on the Macon-Swain county line near the head of Little Laurel Creek. Alt. approx. 4,500.

label: Davis Bay
description: E Pasquotank County between Cobb Point and Brickhouse Point on the Pasquotank River.

label: Davis Branch
description: rises in S central Swain County and flows SW into Yalaka Creek.

label: Davis Cove Branch
description: rises in W Madison County and flows E into Spring Creek.

label: Davis Creek
description: rises in SE Brunswick County and flows SW into tidal marshes that drain into the Atlantic Ocean through Lockwoods Folly Inlet.

label: Davis Ford
description: former ford over Rocky River, Anson-Stanly county line at the mouth of Richardson Creek. John Davis owned a plantation in the vicinity. Richard Lane Ordinary is located at approx. site on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Davis Gap
description: mountain gap in S central Swain County on the head of Davis Branch.

label: Davis Island
description: in Core Sound at the S end of Davis Shore, E Carteret County. Named for William Davis, who settled there in 1715.

label: Davis Landing
description: on Pungo River, E Beaufort County.

label: Davis Mill Pond
description: on Trotters Creek, W Lenoir County. Formed about 1850. Covers 60 acres; max. depth 12 ft.

label: Davis Shore
description: E shore of a peninsula in E Carteret County extending into Core Sound.

label: Davis Slough
description: E Dare County in the waters of Pamlico Sound SW of Oregon Inlet.

label: Davis Township
description: on Core Sound in E Carteret County.

label: Davis White Sulphur Springs
description: former resort in E Alexander County. Flourished from about 1883 until early twentieth century. Known also as Sulphur Springs. Davis family operated gristmill there before and after the site was popular as a summer resort.

label: Davis’ Store
description: See Dardens.

label: Davistown
description: former community in S Edgecombe County. Now only a railroad crossing.

label: Dawson
description: community in S Halifax County. A post office as early as 1830.

label: Dawson Creek
description: rises in S Pamlico County and flows SE into Neuse River. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733. Named for Richard Dawson, who purchased land there in 1706. Prior to 1706 the creek was known as Cuccoowink Creek. See also Janeiro.

label: Dawson's Landing
description: community in NW Bladen County served by post office, 1873-1903. Formerly Harrison Creek.

label: Day Book
description: community in NE Yancey County on Jacks Creek. Alt. 2,350. Post office est. about 1815 and named for a book in which names were recorded of settlers moving west. Another version of the traditional origin of the name is that it came from a time book kept for employees of a local lumber company.

label: Day's Gap
description: See Hugh Day's Gap.

label: Daylo
description: community in NW Wilkes County on Middle Fork Reddies River. Est. 1924 by E. N. Vannoy, a merchant, and named for a brand of flashlights that he sold.

label: Days Creek
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows NW into East Fork [South Fork New River].

label: Days Crossroads
description: community in N Halifax County.

label: Daystrom
description: community in W Robeson County. Alt. 179. Known first as Alma for the Alma Lumber Company, which operated there. Name changed about 1950 when Daystrom Laminates, a furniture manufacturer, began operations there.

label: Dayton
description: community in SE Durham County served by post office, 1881-1905.

label: De Armond Bald
description: mountain in NW Swain County on Jenkins Trail Ridge in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Alt. 5,100.

label: De Armond Ridge
description: NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains, a short spur extending SW from De Armond Bald on Jenkins Trail Ridge.

label: De Hart Bald
description: in S Swain County on the head of Licklog Creek.

label: De Hart Branch
description: rises in S Swain County and flows SW into Yalaka Creek.

label: De Hart Creek
description: rises in S Swain County and flows SW into Little Tennessee River.

label: De Lozier Gap
description: N Swain County on Welch Ridge near the head of West Fork [Chambers Creek].

label: Dead Backwater
description: a sluggish body of water that flows only at high tide between Bird Island and the mainland of Colkins Neck, extending from inside Mad Inlet to Bonaparte Creek in SW Brunswick County.

label: Deaden Top
description: peak in central Cherokee County between Hiwassee River and West Prong Grape Creek.

label: Deadfall Creek
description: rises in SW Anson County and flows NE and S into South Carolina, where it enters Thompson Creek.

label: Deadline Ridge
description: central Clay County, extends N from Tusquitee Creek to Chestnut Branch.

label: Deals
description: See Wash Woods.

label: Deals Branch
description: rises in NW Swain County and flows S into Lake Cheoah.

label: Deals Creek
description: rises in N Rowan County and flows NE into Yadkin River.

label: Deals Gap
description: mountain gap on the Swain County, N.C.-Blount County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Alt. 1,957.

label: Dealsville
description: community in W Alexander County. Alt. 1,150. Named for local family that operated a store and leather tannery.

label: Dean
description: community in E Macon County on Lake Emory.

label: Dean Island
description: a sandy island approx. ½ mi. long in Little Tennessee River in N Macon County.

label: Deans Community
description: See Coopertown.

label: Deaver View
description: community in central Buncombe County.

label: Deaver View Mountain
description: central Buncombe County. Alt. 3,130.

label: Deavers
description: former community in central Transylvania County near the confluence of Davidson and French Broad Rivers. Later known as Puella and today as Pisgah Forest.

label: Deavers Mill Pond
description: on Poley Swamp in N Duplin County. Alt. 106.

label: DeBerry's Mill Pond
description: NE Northampton County on Kirbys Creek. Covers approx. 100 acres; max. depth 10 ft.

label: Debruhls
description: See Rhems.

label: Debs Knob
description: S Wilkes County near the head of East Prong Cub Creek. Probably named for Deborah Riddle, a nineteenth-century resident of the area.

label: Deck Hill
description: peak in S Watauga County between Flannery Fork [South Fork New River] and Payne Branch.

label: Deep Bay
description: a bay on the SE shore of South Lake, central Dare County.

label: Deep Bottom
description: stream, rises in W Washington County and flows NW into Welch Creek. Mentioned in local records as early as 1868.

label: Deep Bottom Branch
description: rises in N Jones County and flows S into Beaver Creek.

label: Deep Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SE into Valley River.

label: Deep Cove
description: a channel separating Judith Island and Swanquarter Island in Pamlico Sound, S Hyde County.

label: Deep Creek
description: is formed in S Yadkin County by the junction of North Deep Creek and South Deep Creek. It flows SE into Yadkin River. Appears as Fifth Creek on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Deep Creek
description: rises in W Graham County and flows NE into Cheoah River.

label: Deep Creek
description: rises in N central Alamance County and flows SW into Stony Creek.

label: Deep Creek Gap
description: mountain gap N Swain County on Fork Ridge in Great Smoky Mountains National Park.

label: Deep Creek Township
description: former township NE Edgecombe County. Now township no. 4.

label: Deep Cut
description: See Eufola.

label: Deep Ford Creek
description: rises in W Transylvania County and flows E and NE into Toxaway River.

label: Deep Gap
description: E Swain County between Deep Gap Branch and Connelly Mountain.

label: Deep Gap
description: S Jackson County on the head of Frolic town Creek.

label: Deep Gap
description: mountain gap in Firescald Mountain, W Avery County.

label: Deep Gap
description: mountain gap in Bullhead Mountain, SE Alleghany County.

label: Deep Gap Branch
description: rises in E Swain County and flows NE into Chestnut Cove Creek.

label: Deep Gap Cove
description: S Haywood County on a tributary of Little East Fork Pigeon River.

label: Deep Gap Creek
description: rises in E Watauga County near Laxon and flows NE into SE Ashe County, where it enters South Fork New River. Once known as Gap Creek.

label: Deep Gap Mountain
description: E Graham County extends NE from Dry Creek.

label: Deep Gully
description: rises on Craven-Jones county line and flows SE into Trent River.

label: Deep Gully Creek
description: rises in N Onslow County and flows SW into Mill Creek.

label: Deep Hole Point
description: See Marshallberg.

label: Deep Inlet
description: appears on the Price map, 1808, in E New Hanover County just N of the present Masonboro Inlet. Deep Inlet closed after 1838 but before 1861.

label: Deep Point
description: point of land extending into Alligator River, E of junction of Intracoastal Waterway and Alligator River, N Hyde County.

label: Deep River
description: is formed in SW Guilford County at High Point Lake by the junction of East Fork Deep River and West Fork Deep River. It flows SE through Randolph County, continues across the NE edge of Moore County, and forms a part of the Chatham-Lee county line. It joins Haw River in SE Chatham County to form Cape Fear River. The junction of Haw and Deep Rivers, site of the town of Haywood, which see, was one of six sites suggested in 1788 for the location of the state capital.

label: Deep River Township
description: former township in N Lee County. Now township no. 4.

label: Deep Run
description: a stream fed by several canals in E Beaufort County, flows W into Broad Creek.

label: Deep Run Swamp
description: rises in E Martin County and flows NW into Gardners Creek.

label: Deep Swamp Branch
description: rises in SE Hertford County and flows NE into Chowan River.

label: Deep Water Point
description: appears on the Moseley map, 1733, in what is now Brunswick County between Elizabeth River and Walden Creek, E of the present town of Southport. Appeared as late as 1851-53 on navigation charts. See also Walkersburg.

label: Deeplow Gap
description: N Swain County on the E slope of Thomas Ridge in Great Smoky Mountains National Park.

label: Deer Branch
description: rises in NE Franklin County and flows E into Sandy Creek.

label: Deer Creek
description: a creek in Core Sound near Core Banks in E Carteret County.

label: Deer Creek Gap
description: on the Haywood County, N.C.-Cocke County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°43'04" N., long. 83°15' W.

label: Deer Gap
description: S Macon County between High Knob and Rich Knob.

label: Deer Island
description: SE Onslow County W of Swansboro in the mouth of Hawkins Slough. Formerly 3 acres but now considerably reduced. The name is now applied to the nearby peninsula between Swansboro and The Hammock.

label: Deer Lick Branch
description: rises in S Mitchell County and flows N into East Fork Crabtree Creek.

label: Deer Mountain
description: S Yancey County between Winter Star Ridge and the head of Locust Creek. Alt. 6,212.

label: Deer Park Mountain
description: W Madison County between Ferry Branch and Spring Creek.

label: Deer Pond Branch
description: rises in N Granville County and flows NE into Spewmarrow Creek.

label: Deer Ridge
description: N Yancey County parallel to Deer Creek.

label: Deerfield
description: community in S Watauga County near East Fork [South Fork New River].

label: Deerlick Gap
description: on the McDowell-Mitchell county line.

label: Deerlick Knob
description: in E Macon County between Corbin Creek and the head of Laurel Creek.

label: Deerlick Ridge
description: extends E from West Buffalo Creek to Snowbird Creek in S Graham County.

label: Deerplay Gap
description: on the Avery-Mitchell county line.

label: Deerstand Creek
description: rises in NW McDowell County on the S slope of Woods Mountain and flows S into Slim Creek.

label: Deets
description: community in W Jackson County served by post office, 1900-1913.

label: Defeat Branch
description: rises in N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows SW to join Roaring Creek in forming Bone Valley Creek. Named after an early hunter there had his shoes burned in the campfire while he slept during a snowstorm.

label: Defeat Knob
description: on the Cherokee-Clay county line in the Valley River Mountains.

label: Dehart
description: community in N Wilkes County near North Prong Roaring River.

label: Del Mar Beach
description: SE Pender County on the Atlantic Ocean side of Topsail Island.

label: Delco
description: town in NE Columbus County. The site was first known as Brinkly when it was a stop on the Wilmington, Columbia, and Augusta Rail Road. Inc. 1913 as New Berlin when Hugh MacRae of Wilmington attempted to attract German colonists to work surrounding farmlands. In 1918, during World War I, the name was changed to Pershing in honor of Gen. John J. Pershing. After about six months, for an unknown reason, it became necessary to change the name. Delco was chosen because the Delco Light Plant Company had just installed a lighting system in the local high school. Alt. 50.

label: Delight
description: See Lattimore.

label: Delightful Plains
description: is shown on the Moseley map, 1733, as extending from the present Big Bay of Bladen County SE and parallel with the present Brown Marsh Swamp.

label: Delk
description: community in W Forsyth County served by post office, 1889-1907.

label: Dellaplane
description: community in S Wilkes County between Brier Creek and Fishing Creek. Col. John Bryan (1753-1842) settled there about 1803.

label: Dellinger Branch
description: rises in S Lincoln County and flows SE into Leepers Creek.

label: Dellinger Hollow
description: in E Mitchell County between Long Ridge and the Avery-Mitchell county line.

label: Dellingers
description: See Concord.

label: Dellview
description: town in NW Gaston County. Inc. 1925 by three Dellinger brothers who operated a large chicken farm at the site. They wanted better protection from stray dogs than was provided by the county. By incorporating their farm as a town, they could enact and enforce a town ordinance against stray dogs. About 1930 fire destroyed the chicken business, and by 1967 only a single member of the family was living in the "town."

label: Dellwood
description: community in central Haywood County on Jonathans Creek. Alt. 2,771.

label: Delmar
description: community in central Halifax County between Halifax and Enfield.

label: Delmont
description: community in S Henderson County on Little Mud Creek.

label: Deloach Branch
description: rises in central Edgecombe County and flows SW into Cokey Swamp.

label: DeLoatche's Mill Pond
description: central Northampton County on Potecasi Creek.

label: Delos
description: community in SW Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1892-98.

label: Delphi
description: community in N Alleghany County served by post office, 1880-94.

label: Delta
description: community in S Sampson County served by post office, 1880-1917. Formerly known as Black River Chapel.

label: Delway
description: community in SE Sampson County on the head of Cuwhiffle Swamp.

label: Demia
description: community in S Buncombe County served by post office, 1888-1902.

label: Demming
description: community in SE McDowell County served by post office, 1892-1914. Founded in antebellum period during gold rush and named for mining company officer. Now known as Brackettown.

label: Democrat
description: community in N Buncombe County near the junction of Sugar and Ivy Creeks. Alt. 2,119.

label: Dendron
description: community in S McDowell County near Old Fort. Named by Western North Carolina Railroad.

label: Denim
description: former community in central Guilford County, now within the limits of the city of Greensboro. Est. 1895 and named for the cloth made by the local mill.

label: Denis Creek
description: a tidal creek rising in the N part of Oak Island in SE Brunswick County and flowing E into Elizabeth River.

label: Denmark
description: community in central Buncombe County served by post office, 1890-1902.

label: Denneysville
description: See New Castle.

label: Dennis
description: community in N Forsyth County. Formerly known as Salem Chapel.

label: Dennis Creek
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows SE into Caldwell County.

label: Dennis Crossroads
description: community in W Wake County between Jim Branch and Buckhorn Creek.

label: Dennis Mountain
description: W Montgomery County between Walker Mountain and Dutchmans Creek.

label: Denniss Island
description: formerly an island in present Currituck Banks, E Currituck County. It was separated from Currituck Banks by Currituck Inlet on the N and Musketo Inlet on the s, both of which are now closed. Shown on Comberford map, 1657. See also Currituck Inlet; Musketo Inlet.

label: Denny
description: community in W Wilkes County on Elk Creek. Named in the early twentieth century for John A. Denny, a local citizen.

label: Dennys Store
description: community in E Person County.

label: Denson Creek
description: rises in N Montgomery County and flows SE into Little River.

label: Denton
description: town in SE Davidson County. Inc. 1907. Known as Finch's Crossroads prior to 1875. Post office est. 1878 and name changed to Denton at the recommendation of Samuel Moses Peacock, who had been reading about the town of the same name in Texas and who became the first postmaster.

label: Denton Gap
description: on the Graham County, N.C.-Monroe County, Tenn., line.

label: Dentons
description: community in S Graham County on Little Snowbird Creek.

label: Denver
description: town in NE Lincoln County. Inc. 1877. Settled about 1770 and known as Dry Pond for an adjacent swampy area; in 1873 it was renamed by D. Matt Thompson, school principal, for the capital of Colorado, then being considered for admission to the Union.

label: Deppe
description: community in NE Onslow County. Named for Nelson R. Deppe of Pennsylvania, who est. a lumber mill at the site.

label: Derby
description: community in NE Richmond County.

label: Derham Creek
description: See Durham Creek.

label: Derita
description: community in central Mecklenburg County. Named for Derita Lewis, a friend of Amos L. Rumple, first postmaster when post office was est. in 1882. Alt. 812.

label: DeRossett Creek
description: rises in Angola Bay, N Pender County, and flows SW into Northeast Cape Fear River. Named for the DeRossett family, early settlers.

label: Derr
description: community in E Lincoln County served by post office, 1883-1904.

label: Derreberry Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NW into Puett Creek.

label: Derreberry Gap
description: NE Cherokee County in the Valley River Mountains.

label: Desert, The
description: a pocosin in N Robeson County between Big Raft Swamp and Big Marsh Swamp. Oval shaped and presumed to be one of the Carolina Bays, which see. Covers 1,200 acres; water depth varies from 6 in. to 4 ft. Game abounds there, especially deer.

label: Deserta Arenosa
description: See Sandhills.

label: Deserta Montana
description: See Sandhills.

label: Deserter Island
description: a land formation in S Duplin County surrounded by swamp.

label: Desolation Branch
description: rises in NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows SW into Roaring Creek. It was named after some early hunters were thoroughly soaked in a cold rain there.

label: Dester
description: community in S Union County.

label: Deuces Quarter
description: See Jews Quarter Island.

label: Devenport
description: See River Neck.

label: Devereux's Ferry
description: See Bridgers Creek.

label: Devil Den Ridge
description: N Macon County between Matlock Creek and Wests Branch.

label: Devil Knob
description: E Madison County on Laurel Creek.

label: Devil's Courthouse
description: overhang of Whiteside Mountain, which see, Jackson County.

label: Devil's Cradle Creek
description: rises in N Franklin County and flows SE into Flatrock Creek.

label: Devil's Den
description: See Pilot Mountain.

label: Devil's Kitchin
description: pocosin in N Pender County adjacent to Stag Park tract.

label: Devil's Tramping Ground
description: W Chatham County 10 mi. S of Siler City, a circular path about 40 ft. in diameter that old-timers say has "always" been there. Legend says the Devil appears there at night to walk in a circle while he plots against the good and thinks up new forms of evil. No vegetation will grow in the path.

label: Devils Court House
description: SW Jackson County, is a N ridge or extension of Whiteside Mountain, which see.

label: Devils Court House Ridge
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur extending S from Mount Buckley.

label: Devils Courthouse
description: a mountain of jagged black rock in NW Transylvania County near the Haywood County line. Located S of the Blue Ridge Parkway, from which a spectacular overlook affords a fine view of the mountain. Named for its sinister appearance. Alt. 5,740.

label: Devils Creek
description: rises in NW Yancey County and flows NE into Nolichucky River.

label: Devils Creek Gap
description: NW Yancey County near the head of Devils Creek.

label: Devils Den
description: ridge in S Yancey County extending S between Little Mountain Creek and Long Arm Ridge.

label: Devils Elbow
description: a sharp bend in the Cashie River, SE Bertie County. Appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Devils Elbow Landing
description: on Pungo River, E Beaufort County.

label: Devils Fork
description: rises in E Henderson County and flows W into Mud Creek.

label: Devils Fork Gap
description: on the Madison County, N.C.-Unicoi County, Tenn., line.

label: Devils Garden
description: on the Alexander-Wilkes county line. Alt. 3,428. A rough, rocky area in which rattlesnakes and copperheads are commonly found.

label: Devils Gut
description: stream in NE Martin County connecting a bend in the Roanoke River. Mentioned in local records as early as 1729 and shown on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Devils Head
description: W Rutherford County near Chimney Rock, a natural rock formation suggestive of the devil's head.

label: Devils Nest
description: peak in N Mitchell County on Big Ridge.

label: Devils Prong
description: rises in SW Macon County and flows N into Kimsey Creek.

label: Devils Race Patch
description: peak in NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Jenkins Trail Ridge. Alt. approx. 5,160.

label: Devils Shoals Ford
description: former ford across the Catawba River, S Caldwell and NE Burke County. Site now under the waters of Lake Hickory.

label: Devils Tater Patch
description: peak on the Swain County, N.C.-Blount County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Alt. 4,752.

label: Devotion
description: community in SW Surry County on Mitchell River, served by post office, 1888-1954.

label: Dew's Mill
description: See Silver Lake.

label: Dewberrie
description: community in NW Warren County. Post office there from 1900 until 1905.

label: Deweese
description: community in NW Cabarrus County.

label: Deweese Creek
description: rises in W Macon County and flows NE into Burningtown Creek.

label: Deweese Township
description: former township in NW Cabarrus County. Now township no. 3. Formerly also known as Odell School Township, which see.

label: Dewey
description: community in SW Randolph County served by post office, 1898-1911.

label: Dewey Pier
description: landing in N Tyrrell County on Albemarle Sound W of Ship Point.

label: Dewitt
description: former community in E Henderson County on Henderson Creek.

label: Dews Creek
description: rises in E central Brunswick County and flows N into Town Creek.

label: Dews Island
description: See Jews Quarter Island.

label: Dexter
description: community in E Granville County served by post office, 1889-1907.

label: Dial
description: community in W Cumberland County served by post office, 1882-1903.

label: Dial Creek
description: rises in N Durham County and flows S into Flat River.

label: Diamond City
description: former community near the E end of Shackleford Banks, S Carteret County. Named for the diamond-shaped design painted on the Cape Lookout Lighthouse. Site of whaling operations in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. Several storms in the early twentieth century caused the residents to begin moving to Harkers Island, Morehead City, Beaufort, and elsewhere.

label: Diamond Creek
description: rises in W Transylvania County and flows SE into North Fork French Broad River.

label: Diamond Grove
description: community in N Northampton County. A post office operated there, 1827-36.

label: Diamond Hill
description: community and former post office, 1837-1905, NW Anson County. So called simply as a "fancy name."

label: Diamond Shoals
description: a series of three shoals extending SE from Cape Hatteras, which see, into the Atlantic Ocean off SE Dare County. Hatteras Shoals is nearest to the cape, Inner Diamond Shoal is in the middle, and Outer Diamond Shoal extends farthest into the Atlantic. The channel between Hatteras Shoals and Inner Diamond Shoal is Hatteras Slough; Diamond Slough is the channel between the two Diamond Shoals. There, warm Gulf Stream waters collide with cold arctic waters from the n, causing a constant turbulence in the Atlantic. Area known as the "Graveyard of the Atlantic." Appears as Sholes of Hatteras on the Moll map, 1729.

label: Diamond Slough
description: See Diamond Shoals.

label: Diamond Valley
description: in W Macon County between Chestnut Gap and Dicks Creek.

label: Dick Branch
description: rises in N Buncombe County and flows SW into Flat Creek.

label: Dick Cove
description: central Cherokee County at the headwaters of Dick Branch.

label: Dick Green Branch
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows N into Middle Fork [South Fork New River]. Named for a farmer in the area.

label: Dickens
description: community in E Franklin County. Alt. 250. Settled about 1892. Named for T. H. Dickens, first postmaster.

label: Dickens Creek
description: rises in W Granville County and flows SW into Knap of Reeds Creek.

label: Dickerson
description: community in E Granville County. Named for A. J. Dickerson, who gave land for the railroad right-of-way and depot.

label: Dickey Branch
description: rises in SW Cherokee County and flows SE into Nottely River.

label: Dickey Mountain
description: SW Cherokee County, extends NE from Rapier Mill Creek to Dickey Branch.

label: Dickey Top
description: peak on Dickey Mountain, SW Cherokee County.

label: Dickinson
description: community in central Harnett County served by post office, 1888-1903.

label: Dickinson Clearwater Branch
description: rises in NE Brunswick County and flows E into the Cape Fear River.

label: Dickinson's Branch
description: rises in S Wilson County and flows E into Contentnea Creek.

label: Dicks
description: See Randleman.

label: Dicks Branch
description: rises in N Haywood County and flows NE into Pigeon River.

label: Dicks Creek
description: is formed in N Jackson County by the junction of West Fork and East Fork and flows SW into Tuckasegee River.

label: Dicks Gap
description: S Yancey County between South Toe River and Three Forks Creek.

label: Dicks Knob
description: S Madison County at the head of Little Pine Creek.

label: Dicks Mountain
description: a peak in the Peach Bottom Mountain range, W central Alleghany County.

label: Dickson Creek
description: rises in central Jackson County and flows NW into West Fork Tuckasegee River.

label: Die Bend
description: a bend in the Nottely River in SW Cherokee County downstream from the mouth of Walker Mill Creek.

label: Diggs
description: community in SW Richmond County.

label: Diggs Ferry
description: over the Pee Dee River about 2 mi. N of the South Carolina line. Formerly known as the Buchanan Ferry.

label: Dill Knob
description: SE Buncombe County. Alt. approx. 3,790.

label: Dillard
description: community in E Stokes County.

label: Dillard Creek
description: rises in NE Chowan County and flows SW into Chowan River. The U.S. Geographic Board in 1933 announced that the stream should henceforth be known as Indian Creek, but the ruling seems to have been ignored locally. Appears as Indian Town Creek on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Dillard Top
description: peak on the Cherokee-Graham county line in the Unicoi Mountains.

label: Diller Branch
description: rises in S Cleveland County and flows NE into Broad River.

label: Dillingham
description: community in NE Buncombe County on Dillingham Creek.

label: Dillingham Creek
description: is formed in NE Buncombe County by the junction of Corner Rock Creek and Walker Branch. It flows NW and joins North Fork Ivy Creek in forming Ivy Creek.

label: Dillon Ridge
description: extends NE and supports a school and a few houses in the middle of swamplands in N Tyrrell County. Alt. 14. Site of commercial timber operations.

label: Dills Branch
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows S into Scotts Creek. Named for Allen B. Dills.

label: Dills Creek
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows SE into Fisher Creek.

label: Dills Gap
description: W Jackson County between Black Mountain and Tuckasegee River.

label: Dills Knob
