description: E Macon County between Buzzard Knob and Cullasaja River.

label: Dillsboro
description: town in N Jackson County on the Tuckasegee River. Inc. 1889 and named for William A. Dills, founder of the town and member of the General Assembly, 1889-91. Post office first est. there in 1852 as Cowee in the home of Dills, whose wife was postmistress. Known as Webster Station from 1882 until 1889.

label: Dillsboro Township
description: NW Jackson County.

label: Dimmette
description: community in E Wilkes County near the headwaters of Little Elkin River.

label: Dimond City
description: See Dymond City.

label: Dimsdale
description: community in N Polk County between Bullin Creek and Walnut Creek.

label: Dina Branch
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows NE into North Fork.

label: Dinah Landing
description: on Upper Goose Creek, central Beaufort County.

label: Dingle Creek
description: rises in S Buncombe County and flows W into French Broad River.

label: Dinkin Branch
description: rises in N Cherokee County and flows SW into Owl Creek.

label: Dipping Vat Creek
description: rises in E Pamlico County and flows SE into Long Creek.

label: Dirty Britches Creek
description: See Shit-Britches Creek.

label: Dirty John Creek
description: rises in W Macon County and flows SW into Jarrett Creek.

label: Dish Knob
description: NE McDowell County near the Burke County line. Alt. 1,800.

label: Dismal
description: community in W Sampson County served by post office, 1869-1904.

label: Dismal Bay
description: sand-filled bay in S Sampson County N of Keiths Bay. See also Carolina Bays.

label: Dismal Branch
description: rises in Little Dismal Swamp, SW Johnston County, and flows SW into Mingo Swamp.

label: Dismal Cove
description: SW Macon County at the head of Pat Stable Branch.

label: Dismal Creek
description: rises in W Henderson County and flows NW into Crab Creek.

label: Dismal Mountain
description: E Jackson County, extends NE from Tuckasegee River to Neddie Creek.

label: Dismal Swamp
description: marsh, lake, and cypress-filled area approx. 30 mi. long and 10 mi. wide, largely in SE Virginia but partially in Gates, Pasquotank, Camden, and Currituck Counties. Appears on the Dudley map, 1647, as "Terra Bassa" (low land) and on the Comberford map, 1657, as "a swampy wilderness." Present name might have been known as early as 1715, when the term "dismal swamp" was applied to the Pasquotank County area by John Talbot in a letter to John Urmston, a missionary to the colony for the Society for the Propagation of the Gospel. Shown on the Moseley map, 1733, as Great Dismal Swamp (the name it is sometimes called today) and as Dismal Swamp on the Mitchell map, 1755. George Washington initiated surveys in 1763 for a canal. The Intracoastal Waterway now passes through the swamp. Also called The Desert in North Carolina.

label: Dismal Swamp Canal
description: connects the waters of Elizabeth River in Virginia with those of the Pasquotank River. It flows from the state line through NW Camden County. The Intracoastal Waterway is routed through the canal, and there are locks on the W borders of South Mills.

label: Dismal Township
description: NW Sampson County.

label: District of Washington
description: in the W territory of North Carolina that is now Tennessee; it developed from the Watauga Settlement, which see, and was recognized by North Carolina in 1776. Delegates attended the Provincial Congress at Halifax in November 1776. The district was the second place in America to be named for George Washington. In 1777 Washington County was formed from the district, and Jonesboro became the county seat. The district was a part of the area ceded by North Carolina in 1789 to the federal government. See also Franklin.

label: Ditch Branch
description: rises in S Wake County and flows S into W Johnston County, where it enters Middle Creek.

label: Ditch Creek
description: NE Pamlico County, connects Jones Bay with the Bay River estuary.

label: Ditch, The
description: waterway from Pamlico River to Goose Creek, E Beaufort County. It separates Reeds Hammock from the mainland.

label: Divide Mountain
description: W Madison County between Rector Branch and Rocky Branch.

label: Dividing Ridge
description: S Avery County.

label: Dividing Ridge
description: in NE Henderson County between Burntshirt Mountain and the Buncombe-Henderson county line.

label: Dix Creek
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows N into East Fork Pigeon River.

label: Dix Creek Gap
description: SW Buncombe County between Suther Knob and Hayes Top.

label: Dixie
description: community in W Mecklenburg County. Formerly Collins Crossroad, named for a store at the location. Known as Equality, 1836-46. Named changed to Dixie about 1883, when a community band was formed, the favorite tune locally being "Dixie." Served by post office, 1885-1920.

label: Dixon
description: community in S Onslow County.

label: Dixon Branch
description: rises in SE Cleveland County and flows SW into South Carolina, where it enters Kings Creek.

label: Dixon Creek
description: a short stream in N central Carteret County flowing N into South River.

label: Dixon Gap
description: N Cleveland County. Alt. 943.

label: Dixon Mine
description: former gold mine in S Yadkin County between Courtney and the head of Roby Creek.

label: Dixon Mountain
description: W Madison County between Little Creek and Meadow Fork.

label: Dixon Point
description: S Onslow County, extends into Stump Sound from the mainland.

label: Dixons Store
description: community in NE Person County.

label: Dobag
description: See Arbuckle; Doe Bag Creek.

label: Dobbersville
description: community in SW Wayne County near the Sampson County line.

label: Dobbin Creek
description: rises in NW Yadkin County and flows S into North Hunting Creek.

label: Dobbins Mill Pond
description: central Yadkin County on North Deep Creek, covers approx. 25 acres. Max. depth 30 ft. Formed 1936 by Nelson Dobbins. Used for fishing, boating, irrigation, waterskiing.

label: Dobbs County
description: formed from Johnston County in 1758, was named in honor of Arthur Dobbs (1689-1765), governor of North Carolina, 1754-65. Wayne County was formed from Dobbs in 1779, portions of it were added to other counties, and the remainder was divided into Glasgow and Lenoir Counties in 1791. Walnut Creek was the county seat until 1779, and Kingston (Kinston) from 1779 to 1791. See also Bizzell Millpond; St. Patrick's Parish.

label: Dobbs Parish
description: Rowan County, was est. in 1755 to consist of the Wachovia, which see, section of the county settled by the Unitas Fratrum (United Brethren), or Moravians. The area included in Dobbs Parish is now largely in Forsyth County. See also St. Luke's Parish.

label: Dobson
description: town and county seat, central Surry County. Est. 1851 as county seat after the county had been divided. Inc. 1891. Named either (1) for William Dobson, local justice of the peace in 1776, or (2) for William P. Dobson, member of the General Assembly in 1814. Alt. 1,265.

label: Dobson Branch
description: rises in E Mitchell County and flows NW into Sugartree Branch.

label: Dobson Hill
description: community in S Graham County on Snowbird Creek.

label: Dobson Knob
description: E McDowell County.

label: Dobson Mount
description: mountain in central Macon County between Patton Mountain and the head of McKee Branch. Alt. approx. 3,500.

label: Dobson Mountain
description: S Jackson County between Little Hogback Creek and Long Branch.

label: Dobson Ridge
description: between the forks of Wrights Creek and Big Witch Creek in N Jackson County.

label: Dobson Township
description: central Surry County.

label: Dobson's Crossroads
description: See Kernersville.

label: Doby Creek
description: rises in N Mecklenburg County and flows NE into Mallard Creek.

label: Doc Stewart Ridge
description: extends NE from Little Huckleberry Knob to Santeetlah Creek in W Graham County. Named for an early settler.

label: Dock Branch
description: rises in N Buncombe County near the Madison County line and flows SE into Whittemore Creek.

label: Dockery
description: community in N Wilkes County near Middle Prong Roaring River.

label: Dockery Creek
description: rises in central Cherokee County and flows SE into Hanging Dog Creek.

label: Dockerys Store
description: community in W Richmond County. A post office existed there as early as 1828.

label: Doctor Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows S into Valley River.

label: Doctor Mountain
description: S Madison County at the head of Bear Creek.

label: Doctors Creek
description: rises in SE Sampson County and flows E along the Duplin-Pender county line into Rockfish Creek.

label: Dodgen Creek
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows NE into Cullowhee Creek.

label: Dodgen Ridge
description: E Jackson County between Gladie Creek and Sols Creek.

label: Dodgetown
description: community in E Stokes County.

label: Dodging Hill
description: E Henderson County between Bat Fork and Green River.

label: Dodson Crossroads
description: community in S Orange County.

label: Dodson Store
description: See Gilreath.

label: Dodsons Creek
description: formerly a stream in N Vance County; its entire course now lies under the waters of Kerr Lake.

label: Doe Bag Creek
description: rises in E Yancey County and flows NE into Toe River. Sometimes spelled Dobag.

label: Doe Branch
description: rises in E Jackson County and flows NE into Tuckasegee River.

label: Doe Branch
description: rises in W Madison County and flows NE into French Broad River.

label: Doe Creek
description: rises in N central Carteret County and flows W into South River.

label: Doe Hill Mountain
description: S Avery County. Alt. 4,217.

label: Doe Knob
description: peak on Swain County, N.C.-Blount County, Tenn., line, in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Alt. 4,520.

label: Doehead
description: community in W Edgecombe County served by post office, 1888-1902.

label: Dog Branch
description: rises in central Alleghany County and flows SE into Little River.

label: Dog Cove
description: E Swain County on the head of Wesser Creek between Middle Ridge and Odear Cove.

label: Dog Creek
description: rises in W Henderson County and flows SW into Boylston Creek.

label: Dog Creek
description: rises in E Ashe County and flows SE into South Fork New River.

label: Dog Island
description: formerly a single island in Bogue Sound near Bogue Banks, S Carteret County. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733. Now three small islands.

label: Dog Loser Knob
description: S Haywood County between Beech Spring Gap and Old Butt Knob.

label: Dog Mountain
description: SE Macon County at the S end of Chestnut Ridge. Alt. approx. 4,000.

label: Dog Ridge Mountain
description: N Madison County in a bend of Big Laurel Creek.

label: Dogback Mountain
description: part of Linville Mountain, lies on Burke-McDowell county line.

label: Doggett Gap
description: S Madison County at the head of Friezeland Creek.

label: Doggett Knob
description: S Madison County at the head of Walnut Cove Branch.

label: Dogs’ Ears
description: rock formation near Shulls Mill, S Watauga County.

label: Dogville Crossroads
description: See Hassell.

label: Dogwood
description: community in N Burke County served by post office, 1888-1907.

label: Dogwood Branch
description: rises in S Virginia and flows SE into Northampton County, where it enters Pea Hill Creek.

label: Dogwood Flats
description: community in N Haywood County on Dogwood Flats Creek.

label: Dogwood Flats Creek
description: rises in N Haywood County and flows NE into Mount Sterling Creek.

label: Dogwood Gap
description: W Madison County at the head of Georgia Branch.

label: Dogwood Ridge
description: high ground in S Washington County in East Dismal Swamp. Length from W to E extremity approx. 2½ mi. Soloman Sawyer's plantation, known by the name, was located there as early as 1742.

label: Dogwood Stump Mountain
description: in S Burke County between Jacob Fork and Whiteoak Creek. Alt. 2,546.

label: Dolly Gut
description: gully cut by stream in central Craven County. Stream rises in central Craven County and flows NE into Neuse River just S of Greens Thorofare.

label: Dome
description: community in SE Buncombe County near the junction of Flat Creek and Broad River.

label: Donahues Creek
description: rises in N Caldwell County and flows S into Yadkin River. Named for Henry Donahue, who died in 1775 and is buried nearby.

label: Donaldson Branch
description: rises in SE Cherokee County and flows SE into Brasstown Creek.

label: Donaldson Creek
description: rises in E Person County and flows NW into Maho Creek.

label: Donegal County
description: was a proposed county in SE North Carolina. In 1749 a bill was introduced in the House of the General Assembly to separate the "upper part of New Hanover County" to form Donegal County, but the bill was not passed. The parish would have been called St. Colomb. It would have been named for Donegal County, Northern Ireland.

label: Donnelys Creek
description: See Daniels Creek.

label: Donnoha
description: community in NW Forsyth County on Yadkin River. An Indian village was at or near the place that is named for Donnahee, an Indian chief. The name was applied in 1889 or 1890 by Dr. Samuel Martin of Winston, a descendant of the chief, who accompanied the surveying party that laid out the road from Winston to Wilkesboro and which passes through Donnoha. Richmond, former seat of Surry County, 1774-89, which was destroyed in 1830 by a tornado, was nearby. Alt. 757.

label: Donoho Creek
description: rises in S Bladen County and flows E into Cape Fear River. Named for David Donoho, who had a grant of land there in 1727.

label: Doolie
description: community in SW Iredell County. Takes its name from a local Baptist church.

label: Doolittle Mill Pond
description: N Northampton County on Paddys Delight Creek. Covers approx. 75 acres. Max. depth 10 ft.

label: Doomas Creek
description: See Dumas Creek.

label: Dora
description: community in W Lincoln County.

label: Dora Mills
description: See Midstate Mill.

label: Dora's Island
description: SE Onslow County in the mouth of Queens Creek.

label: Dorithea Creek
description: See Muddy Creek.

label: Dorsey
description: former community in W Swain County on Tuckasegee River. Site now under the waters of Fontana Lake.

label: Dort
description: community in NW Gates County served by post office, 1879-1910.

label: Dortches
description: community in E Nash County near the head of Horn Beam Swamp. Settled about 1890. Named for local family. Alt. 120.

label: Dosier
description: community in W Forsyth County.

label: Doster
description: community in S central Union County.

label: Dothan
description: community in S Columbus County.

label: Dotmond
description: community in NE Caswell County.

label: Dotson Branch
description: rises in central Haywood County and flows NE into Pigeon River.

label: Double Branch
description: rises in W Forsyth County and flows S into Panther Creek.

label: Double Creek
description: rises in W Person County and flows NW into South Hyco Creek.

label: Double Gap
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Cataloochee Divide near lat. 35°34'17" N., long. 83°06' W.

label: Double Gap Branch
description: rises in W Haywood County and flows NW into Caldwell Fork.

label: Double Gap Ridge
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur of Cataloochee Divide extending NW near lat. 35°34'45" N., long. 83°06'12" W.

label: Double Head
description: a mountain on the Buncombe-Henderson county line. Also known as Double Knob. Alt. 3,399.

label: Double Knob
description: on the head of Slatten Creek in central Jackson County.

label: Double Knob Mountain
description: in S Jackson County on the head of Packs Creek. Alt. 4,412.

label: Double Knobs
description: mountain peak in N central Avery County.

label: Double Shoals
description: community in central Cleveland County between Big Harris Creek and First Broad River. Settled in the nineteenth century and named for two shoals in the nearby river. Alt. 995.

label: Double Shoals Township
description: former township in E central Cleveland County, now township no. 9.

label: Double Spring Gap
description: S Haywood County on Lickstone Ridge. Alt. 4,000.

label: Double Springs
description: community in N McDowell County near Yancey County line and Blue Ridge Parkway.

label: Double Springs Gap
description: S Transylvania County on the head of Morgan Mill Creek.

label: Double Top
description: mountain on the Buncombe-Henderson county line N of Dads Top.

label: Double Top Mountain
description: central Jackson County between Johns Creek and Cedar Valley Creek. Alt. 5,481.

label: Doublehead Creek
description: rises in W Avery County and flows SE into North Toe River.

label: Doublehead Gap
description: W Avery County.

label: Doubleside Gap
description: E Haywood County between Long Branch and West Cove.

label: Doubletop Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows NW into Hickory Knoll Creek.

label: Doubletop Creek
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows NE into Dark Ridge Creek.

label: Doubletop Fields
description: grassy pastureland in S Macon County between Buckeye Creek and Hickory Knoll Creek. An early settler cleared land atop the mountain on which he settled as well as on the next mountain, hence the name.

label: Doubletop Mountain
description: on the Haywood-Buncombe county line.

label: Doughton
description: community in NE Wilkes County on Elkin River.

label: Doughton
description: community in central Pender County served by post office, 1893-1903.

label: Doughton Mountain
description: peak in the Peach Bottom Mountain range, N central Alleghany County. Alt. 3,650.

label: Doughton Park
description: S Alleghany and N Wilkes Counties, a Blue Ridge Parkway recreation area on Basin Creek. Covers approx. 7,000 acres. Est. about 1935 as Bluff Park; renamed to honor Congressman Robert L. Doughton (1863-1954), who worked for the establishment of the parkway. A high, rolling, bluegrass area terminates there in precipitous bluffs, and stands of rhododendron bloom in May and June. Wild Cat Rock is nearby. See also The Bluffs.

label: Douglas
description: community in central Rockingham County served by post office, 1869-1903. Named for Senator Stephen A. Douglas, whose two sons inherited a large farm in the area on Dan River.

label: Douglas Ordinary
description: See St. Johns.

label: Dove's Crossroads
description: See Casville.

label: Dover
description: town in NW Craven County. Settled 1879, but the place name dates from as early as 1749, when Francis Stringer owned a plantation there called Dover, probably named for the city in England. Inc. 1901. Alt. 63.

label: Dover Branch
description: rises in SE Yancey County and flows NE into Crabtree Creek.

label: Dover Crossroads
description: See Gum Swamp.

label: Dover Knob
description: S Macon County between Penson Knob and Norton Branch.

label: Dover Ridge
description: SE Yancey County between Dover Branch and Crabtree Creek.

label: Dovers Branch
description: rises in SE Yancey County and flows NW into Three Forks Creek.

label: Dowd
description: community in central Stanly County served by post office, 1883-1907.

label: Dowdle Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows SE into Little Tennessee River.

label: Dowdle Knob
description: S Macon County between Little Tennessee River and Porter Cove.

label: Dowellton
description: central Yadkin County approx. 1½ mi. W of the present courthouse in the vicinity of modern Harmony Grove Church; was the site of the first court held for the new county in 1851.

label: Dowgap
description: community in W Surry County.

label: Downes Branch
description: rises in central Macon County and flows N into Burningtown Creek.

label: Downing Creek
description: rises in central Clay County and flows SE through Holden Cove into Hiwassee River.

label: Downingville
description: community in NW Bladen County served by post office, 1857-1913.

label: Downs Mountain
description: S Macon County between Mulberry Creek and Norton Branch.

label: Downsville
description: community in E Caldwell County. Named for Downs family, two members of which were postmasters there following the Civil War.

label: Dowry Island
description: about ¼ mi. long in Chowan River on the Gates-Hertford county line.

label: Dowtins Creek
description: See Duncans Creek.

label: Draco
description: community in E Caldwell County on the headwaters of Middle Little River. Served by post office, 1888-1915.

label: Drain, The
description: See Barden Inlet.

label: Drakes Crossroads
description: community in central Northampton County.

label: Dram Tree Point
description: extends from Eagles Island, W New Hanover County, into Cape Fear River. Named for an old moss-covered cypress tree that stood there; it is said that outgoing mariners, in passing the point, had a drink to the success of their voyage. To those inward bound, it was a welcome signal that port was near.

label: Draper
description: former town in N Rockingham County on Dan River. Mill village est. 1905 by Frank Mebane. Arthur J. Draper instrumental in planning village's layout. Inc. 1949; merged with Leaksville and Spray in 1967 to form Eden, which see.

label: Draughn
description: community in N Edgecombe County.

label: Dresden
description: community in central Ashe County. Alt. approx. 2,800.

label: Drew
description: community in W central Bertie County. Est. about 1900 and named for a local family.

label: Drewry
description: community in E Vance County. Alt. 453. Settled in 1860 and named by G. W. Morrow, president of the Clarksville Railroad, for his father, Drewry Morrow.

label: Drexel
description: town in central Burke County. Inc. 1913. Alt. 1,192. Named for the Drexel family of Philadelphia. Originally known as Baker. A large furniture-manufacturing plant is located there.

label: Drexel Township
description: E central Burke County.

label: Drift Branch
description: rises in W Haywood County and flows SE into Richland Creek.

label: Drift Falls
description: in SW Transylvania County in Horsepasture River just upstream from High Falls.

label: Drip Off Creek
description: rises in NW Iredell County and flows S into Rocky Creek.

label: Drivers Store
description: community in E Wilson County near Whiteoak Swamp.

label: Driving Creek
description: rises in W Nash County and flows SW into Turkey Creek.

label: Drowned Bay
description: mucky swamp, SW Brunswick County.

label: Drowning Creek
description: rises on the Montgomery-Moore county line and flows SE across Moore County. At the Moore-Richmond county line, it joins Naked Creek in forming Lumber River.

label: Drowning Creek Mountains
description: extend from NE Burke County into NW Catawba County.

label: Drug Store
description: community in W Johnston County.

label: Druid
description: community in N Madison County.

label: Druid Hills
description: community in central Henderson County on N side of Hendersonville. Alt. 1,788.

label: Drum Creek
description: rises in the S part of Goose Creek Island, NE Pamlico County, and flows S into Jones Bay.

label: Drum Hill
description: community in N Gates County. Alt. 79. Settled about 1890.

label: Drum Inlet
description: between Portsmouth Island on the NE and Core Banks on the SW in E Carteret County. Water from Pamlico and Core Sounds drains into the Atlantic Ocean through the inlet. Also known as Whalebone Inlet. Named for a species of fish. An inlet in the area appears on the De Graffenried map (French text), 1711, as Drum Passage. Another Drum Inlet appears on the Moseley map, 1733, now commonly referred to as Old Drum Inlet. The inlet shown on the Moseley map closed in the late eighteenth century.

label: Drum Passage
description: See Drum Inlet.

label: Drum Point
description: point on mainland of NE Carteret County extending into mouth of Nelson Bay.

label: Drummersville
description: community in N Duplin County.

label: Drummond's Point
description: SE tip of Chowan County extending into the mouth of Yeopim River. Named before 1700 for William Drummond (d. 1677), first governor of Albemarle under the Lords Proprietors. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733. Site of one of the largest early seine fisheries on Albemarle Sound.

label: Drums Crossroads
description: See Drumsville.

label: Drumsville
description: community in SE Catawba County, formerly Drums Crossroads. Alt. 946.

label: Dry Branch
description: rises in N Macon County and flows SW into Cold Spring Creek.

label: Dry Branch
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows SE into Right Fork [Swannanoa River].

label: Dry Creek
description: rises in N Harnett County and flows S into Cape Fear River.

label: Dry Creek
description: rises in W Alamance County and flows E into Haw River.

label: Dry Falls
description: waterfall in Cullasaja River, SE Macon County NW of Highlands. Water drops approx. 75 ft. from a protruding ledge, making it possible to walk behind it without getting wet, hence the name. See also Cullasaja River.

label: Dry Ford
description: N Union County in Rocky River.

label: Dry Fork
description: rises in W Lee County and flows NE into Pocket Creek.

label: Dry Fork Branch
description: rises in S Lee County and flows SW into Moore County, where it joins Crains Creek in forming Whiteoak Creek.

label: Dry Gap Ridge
description: N Haywood County parallel to Skiffley Creek.

label: Dry Hill
description: community in E Henderson County W of Dana. Named for fact that a local well ran dry.

label: Dry Lake
description: NE Surry County. Formed in 1937 by the construction of a dam across a dry hollow into which a small unnamed stream was diverted. Covers approx. 8 acres; max. depth 15 ft. Municipal water supply for Mount Airy.

label: Dry Mountain
description: peak on Newfound Mountain on the Buncombe-Haywood county line S of Haywood Gap.

label: Dry Pocosin
description: a muck-filled pocosin in E Duplin County.

label: Dry Pond
description: See Denver.

label: Dry Pond Gap
description: S Watauga County between the heads of Storey Creek, Buffalo Creek, and Joe Creek.

label: Dry Pond Ridge
description: W Madison County between Mountain Island Branch and Raccoon Branch.

label: Dry Sand Shoal
description: See Vera Cruz Shoal.

label: Dry Sluice Gap
description: mountain gap on the Swain County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Alt. 5,375.

label: Dry Wells Township
description: SW Nash County. Created 1903 by act of General Assembly.

label: Dryman Fork
description: rises in S Macon County and flows NE into Coweeta Creek.

label: Dryman Mountain
description: central Buncombe County NW of Asheville.

label: Drymans Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows W into Middle Creek.

label: Drys Mill
description: community in NE Cabarrus County.

label: Drysborough
description: former town in central Craven County. Inc. 1806 and referred to in the session laws until as late as 1847. The site is now within the limits of New Bern and is the part of town that lies N of Queen Street.

label: Dryspring Branch
description: rises in W Yancey County and flows NW into Banks Creek.

label: Drywells
description: community in S Nash County served by post office, 1891-1904.

label: Duart
description: community in NW Bladen County.

label: Dublin
description: See Royal.

label: Dublin Creek
description: rises in W Carteret County and flows SW into White Oak River.

label: Duck
description: community near the S end of the North Banks in NE Dare County. Inc. 2002. Situated next to Currituck Sound. Named for wild ducks in the area. Alt. 10.

label: Duck Branch
description: rises in SE Mitchell County and flows S into Rose Creek.

label: Duck Creek
description: rises in S Iredell County E of Barium Springs and flows NE into Third Creek.

label: Duck Creek
description: community in SE Onslow County on Mirey Branch.

label: Duck Island
description: in Roanoke Sound at the S end of Bodie Island in E Dare County.

label: Duck Mountain
description: S Macon County between Saltrock Gap and Middle Creek.

label: Duck Pond Swamp
description: pocosin in E central Cumberland County drained by Reese Creek. One of the Carolina Bays, which see.

label: Duckenfield Estate
description: See Avoca.

label: Ducker Creek
description: rises near Ducker Mountain in S Buncombe County and flows SW into French Broad River.

label: Ducker Mountain
description: S Buncombe County.

label: Duckett Top
description: W Madison County between Meadow Fork and Spring Creek.

label: Duckettsville
description: See Roper.

label: Duckmill Branch
description: rises in N Madison County and flows SE into Shelton Laurel Creek.

label: Dude Branch
description: rises in W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°41'45" N., long. 83°07'08" W., and flows SE into Correll Branch.

label: Dudley
description: town in S Wayne County. Settled in 1837. Inc. 1897; charter repealed 1899; reincorporated 1903. Named for Edward B. Dudley, governor of North Carolina (1836-41) and president of Wilmington and Raleigh Railroad. Alt. 185.

label: Dudley Shoals
description: community on Upper Little River in SE Caldwell County.

label: Dudley's Island
description: E Onslow County in the mouth of White Oak River at Bogue Inlet.

label: Duel Hill
description: See Marshall.

label: Duffey
description: community in W Robeson County served by post office, 1892-94.

label: Duffs Creek
description: rises in SW Duplin County and flows S into Rockfish Creek.

label: Dugar Mountain
description: SE Watauga County between Mast Knob and Little Dugger Mountain. Alt. 3,700.

label: Duges Island
description: E Carteret County in Core Sound near Core Banks.

label: Dugger Creek
description: rises in SE Watauga County and flows SE into Wilkes County, where it enters Elk Creek at Darby. Appears in eighteenth-century records as Julius Duggar's Rock House Creek.

label: Duggs Island
description: See Bodie Island.

label: Duharts Creek
description: rises in central Gaston County and flows SE into South Fork Catawba River.

label: Duke
description: See Erwin.

label: Duke Forest
description: W Durham and E Orange Counties, consists of a total of 7,020 acres in 5 main units. Est. 1931, it is owned by Duke University and used for demonstration, an experimental forest, and an outdoor laboratory for students in forestry. There are recreational areas and provisions for picnickers, hikers, and horseback riders.

label: Duke Hall
description: See Halls.

label: Duke Power Park
description: state park in S Iredell County on Lake Norman. Contains 1,328 acres, with 6 mi. of shoreline. Boating, camping, and recreational facilities.

label: Duke Swamp
description: rises in N Gates County and flows S to join Raynor Swamp and Harrell Swamp in forming Bennetts Creek.

label: Duke Township
description: SE Harnett County. Named for the former community, Duke, now Erwin.

label: Dukes
description: community in NW Nash County. Named for Rev. G. W. Duke, local resident.

label: Dukes Crossroads
description: See Epsom.

label: Dukeville
description: community in E Rowan County on High Rock Lake. Named by A. W. Hicks, editor of the Spencer News, for James B. Duke.

label: Dukie Halls Crossing
description: See Halls.

label: Dula Knob
description: S Mitchell County between Middle Fork Grassy Creek and East Fork Grassy Creek.

label: Dula Springs
description: community in N Buncombe County on Little Flat Creek E of Weaverville.

label: Dula Town
description: an African American community in S central Caldwell County. Named for Alfred Dula, who gave 400 acres of land to his freed slaves. At the close of the Civil War, he also gave a horse, wagon, and cow to each former slave family.

label: Dulin's Grove
description: community in W Mecklenburg County named for local family.

label: Dulins
description: community in NE Davie County served by post office, 1877-1905.

label: Dumas Creek
description: rises in N Montgomery County and flows SE into Denson Creek. Named for Dumas family, early settlers. Appears on recent maps as Doomas Creek.

label: Dumplin Creek
description: short stream in N central Carteret County, flows W into Adams Creek.

label: Dunbars Landing
description: in NW Tyrrell County on the N side of Scuppernong River.

label: Duncan
description: community in N Harnett County. Alt. 430.

label: Duncan Creek
description: rises in E Transylvania County and flows SW into Little River.

label: Duncan Mountain
description: SE Transylvania County S of Duncan Creek.

label: Duncans Creek
description: rises in central Warren County and flows E into Walkers Creek. At one time called Dowtins Creek.

label: Duncans Creek
description: community in NE Rutherford County. Post office est. there 1829.

label: Duncans Creek Township
description: NE Rutherford County.

label: Dundarrach
description: town in S Hoke County. Inc. 1911.

label: Dunfields Creek
description: rises in N central Cumberland County and flows SW into Cape Fear River.

label: Dunhams Creek
description: rises in E central Moore County and flows se. A short distance above the mouth of Herds Creek, it becomes Crains Creek, which see. Named for Joseph Dunham, who settled along its banks in 1760.

label: Dunlap's Mill
description: See Bonlee.

label: Dunmoor Branch
description: rises in E central Bertie County and flows N into Cricket Swamp.

label: Dunn
description: town in SE Harnett County. First known as Tearshirt and later as Lucknow. Renamed Dunn in 1886 for Bennett R. Dunn, construction engineer of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad. Inc. 1887. Produces apparel, canned foods, lumber, and candy. Alt. 214.

label: Dunn Creek
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows NW into French Broad River.

label: Dunn Mountain
description: S Rowan County S of Crane Creek and NE of the town of Granite Quarry. Alt. approx. 1,000. Named for John Dunn, early attorney and clerk of Rowan County court.

label: Dunn Swamp
description: rises in NW Columbus County and flows NW into Porter Swamp.

label: Dunn Township
description: former township in SE Franklin County, now township no. 1.

label: Dunns Creek
description: rises near Brushy Mountain in W Transylvania County and flows NE into Catheys Creek.

label: Dunns Rock
description: peak in NE Transylvania County S of French Broad River.

label: Dunns Rock Township
description: SE Transylvania County.

label: Dunnsville
description: See Neuse Crossroads.

label: Dunsmore
description: community in SW Buncombe County on Stony Fork.

label: Dunsmore Cove
description: valley of Dunsmore Cove Branch, SE Buncombe County near Ridgecrest.

label: Dunsmore Cove Branch
description: rises near the McDowell County line in SE Buncombe County and flows NW into Swannanoa River.

label: Dunsmore Mountain
description: SW Buncombe County. Alt. 2,700.

label: Duplin County (DOO-plin)
description: was formed in 1750 from New Hanover County. Located in the E section of the state, it is bounded by Jones, Onslow, Pender, Sampson, Wayne, and Lenoir Counties. It was named for Thomas Hay (1710-87), Lord Duplin, member of the Board of Trade and Plantations. Area: 823 sq mi. County seat: Kenansville, with an elevation of 127 ft. Townships are Albertson, Cypress Creek, Faison, Glisson, Island Creek, Kenansville, Limestone, Magnolia, Rockfish, Rose Hill, Smith, Warsaw, and Wolfescrape. Produces hogs, turkeys, cotton, cattle, bell peppers, sweet potatoes, hay, wheat, oats, nursery products, cabbage, collards, strawberries, cucumbers, lumber, poultry, textiles, and wine.

label: Duplin Court House
description: See Kenansville.

label: Duplin Roads
description: See Wallace.

label: Dupree Crossroads
description: community in NW Pitt County.

label: Durant Island
description: N Dare County in Albemarle Sound; about 5 m. long from E to W and 3 mi. N to S at the widest. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Durant Point
description: peninsula extending from the S part of Hatteras Island, S Dare County, into Pamlico Sound N of Sandy Bay.

label: Durants Neck
description: community on Durants Neck peninsula, E Perquimans County. Formerly known as New Hope; a post office by the name was est. by 1820.

label: Durants Point
description: See Durants Neck.

label: Durbro
description: community in S Cleveland County served by post office, 1880-1902.

label: Durgantown
description: See Vanceboro.

label: Durgy Mine
description: former gold and copper mine in E Person County. Operated in late nineteenth century and until about 1920. At its peak operation, approx. 500 persons were employed in the mine.

label: Durham
description: city and county seat, central Durham County. A post office est. there in 1851 was named Durhamsville; changed to Durham in 1855. Named for Dr. Bartlett Snipes Durham (1822-58), donor of land for the railroad station. Inc. 1866. Formerly center of tobacco manufacturing. Home of Duke University and N.C. Central University. Produces drugs, bricks, grain products, dairy products, apparel, textiles, hosiery, commercial printing, furniture, corrugated boxes, and industrial machinery. Alt. 406. See also Prattsburg.

label: Durham Branch
description: rises in central Swain County and flows SE into Deep Creek.

label: Durham County
description: was formed in 1881 from Orange and Wake Counties. Located in the central section of the state, it is bounded by Wake, Chatham, Orange, Person, and Granville Counties. It was named for the town of Durham, which see. Area: 300 sq mi. The county seat is Durham, with an elevation of 406 ft. Townships are Carr, Durham, Lebanon, Mangum, Oak Grove, and Triangle. Produces tobacco products, pharmaceuticals, software, computers, electronics, plastics, cattle, nursery products, bricks, textiles, machinery, and commercial printing.

label: Durham Creek
description: rises in NW Pamlico County and flows N into Beaufort County, where it enters Pamlico River. Named for Richard Durham, who acquired land near its mouth in 1706. Appears in local records as early as 1715 as Dereham's Creek, and by 1770 it was being called Derham and Darham Creek. Appears on the MacRae map, 1833, as Derham Creek. The garrison that gave Garrison Point, which see, its name was located on Durham's land.

label: Durham Township
description: central Durham County.

label: Durham's Creek
description: community in central Beaufort County served by post office, 1839-1902.

label: Dusty Hill
description: community in central Northampton County.

label: Dutch Buffalo Creek
description: rises near Organ Church in SE Rowan County and flows SE through Cabarrus County into Rocky River. Named for the "Pennsylvania Dutch" (German, Deutsch) who settled there. See also Irish Buffalo Creek.

label: Dutch Cove
description: E Haywood County on the head of Dutch Cove Creek.

label: Dutch Cove Creek
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows NW into Hominy Creek.

label: Dutch Creek
description: rises in SW Watauga County on N slope of Hanging Rock and flows NE into Watauga River.

label: Dutch Creek Falls
description: SW Watauga County on Dutch Creek approx. ½ mi. upstream from the mouth of Pigeonroost Creek. Falls are 85 ft. high and make a perpendicular descent over moss- and lichen-covered rock. Also known as Marianna Falls.

label: Dutch District
description: See Dutchville Township.

label: Dutch Second Creek
description: See South Second Creek.

label: Dutchman Creek
description: rises in S central Wake County and flows NE into Swift Creek.

label: Dutchman Mountain
description: peak in W Randolph County.

label: Dutchman Ridge
description: mountain peak on the Buncombe-McDowell county line.

label: Dutchmans Creek
description: approx. 30 mi. long, rises in S Yadkin County and flows S into NE Iredell County and then SE across Davie County into Yadkin River near the Horseshoe. Appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Dutchville Township
description: SW Granville County. A nineteenth-century post office in the SW part of the county was called Dutchville, and in 1790 there was a Dutch District that had 76 heads of families reported in the census for that year.

label: Dwight
description: community in W Perquimans County served by post office, 1892-1904.

label: Dyeleaf Creek
description: rises on the S side of Spring Mountain in NE Buncombe County and flows W through Laughter Cove into Cane Creek. Named for Sweet Leaf or Horse-sugar (Symplocos tinctoria), the leaves and bark of which yield a yellow dye.

label: Dyeleaf Mountain
description: SE Buncombe County between Cane and Garren Creeks.

label: Dyer Knob
description: W Watauga County N of Rush Branch and E of Beaverdam Creek. Alt. approx. 3,300.

label: Dykers Creek
description: rises in W Davidson County and flows W into Yadkin River.

label: Dymond City
description: former community in SE Martin County in Great Swamp. A post office by the name existed in 1882. Appears as Dimond City on the Kerr map, 1882, located near the head of Deep Run Swamp.

label: Dysartsville
description: community in SE McDowell County. Alt. 1,262. Named for the Dysart family, early settlers. John Dysart, local militiaman, was a veteran of the Battle of Kings Mountain.

label: Dysartville Township
description: SE McDowell County.

label: Eads Gap
description: SE Buncombe County between Chestnut Flats and Garren Mountain.

label: Eagle
description: community in W Iredell County served by post office, 1848-1907.

label: Eagle Branch
description: See Spread Eagle Branch.

label: Eagle Cliff
description: NE Mitchell County between Fork Mountain and Roan Mountain.

label: Eagle Creek
description: is formed in SE Clay County by the junction of Left Fork and Right Fork and flows NW into Shooting Creek. Known also as Eagle Fork Creek.

label: Eagle Falls
description: a low falls on Dan River, W central Rockingham County. Land adjacent was granted to Charles Galloway in 1745, and early county courts were held on his property. Eagle Falls plantation there, occupied by the Galloway family for many years and later passed to descendants named Carter. The house is now used for farm storage. See also Jackson.

label: Eagle Fork Creek
description: See Eagle Creek.

label: Eagle Gap
description: W Cherokee County between Fowler Bend and Hiwassee Dam.

label: Eagle Knob
description: in central Graham County between Sweetwater Creek and Mountain Creek.

label: Eagle Mills
description: community in NE Iredell County. Mill operated by the Eagle family there burned by Stoneman's raiders, 1865, later rebuilt. A grain mill is now operated on Hunting Creek at the site.

label: Eagle Mills Township
description: NE Iredell County.

label: Eagle Rock
description: mountain on Swain County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line between Pecks Corner and Copper Gap. Alt. 5,950-6,000.

label: Eagle Rock Cove
description: valley of Eagle Rock Creek, NE Buncombe County.

label: Eagle Rock Creek
description: rises in Great Craggy Mountains, NE Buncombe County, and flows SW into Beetree Reservoir.

label: Eagle Springs
description: community in W Moore County. Settled about 1890. Site of a mineral spring, it probably was named for the Eagle family, which settled in the vicinity in the eighteenth century. Alt. 668.

label: Eagle Swamp
description: rises in N Lenoir County and flows SE into Contentnea Creek.

label: Eaglenest Branch
description: rises in E Transylvania County near Black Knob and flows NE into Little River.

label: Eaglenest Creek
description: rises in W Haywood County and flows SE into Richland Creek.

label: Eaglenest Mountain
description: W Haywood County on the head of Eaglenest Creek.

label: Eaglenest Ridge
description: W Haywood County, extends E from Rattlesnake Knob to Eaglenest Mountain.

label: Eagles Island
description: a group of swampy islands in W New Hanover County between Cape Fear and Brunswick Rivers opposite Wilmington. Named for Joseph and Richard Eagle, eighteenth-century settlers in the vicinity. See also Dram Tree Point. Appears as Cranes Island on the Ogilby map, 1671.

label: Eagleton Point
description: point of land extending NW from Colington Island into the waters of Kitty Hawk Bay, N Dare County. Also known as North Point and Eggleston Point.

label: Eagletown
description: community in SE Northampton County; an early Quaker settlement. Served by post office, 1887-1907.

label: Eakers Corner
description: community on Stoney Run in W Cleveland County.

label: Earl
description: town in S Cleveland County. Inc. 1889, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Named for Abel Earl, local landowner. Alt. 925. Produced manufactured fibers.

label: Earl Mountain
description: NE Rutherford County between the head of Duncans Creek and South Creek.

label: Earleys
description: community in S Hertford County. Alt. 65.

label: Earlies Gap
description: NW Buncombe County between Cook and Robinson Mountains.

label: Earnhardts Township
description: former township in NE Cabarrus County. Now township no. 7. In 1945 a part of the township was annexed to Concord, coextensive with Concord Township. In 1940 the township was listed as Reed Misenheimers.

label: Earpsboro
description: community in N Johnston County near Little River.

label: Earthquake Branch
description: See Browns Creek.

label: Eason Crossroads
description: community in central Gates County.

label: Eason Millpond
description: W Pitt County on Kitten Creek.

label: Easonburg
description: community in SE Nash County, on N side of Tar River.

label: East Arcadia
description: community in SE Bladen County. Known originally as Marlville for local marl beds. Served by post office, 1900-1919. Formerly known as Marlsville.

label: East Bay
description: in N Piney Island E of Rattan Bay, NE Carteret County. Approx. ¾ mi. long and ½ mi. wide.

label: East Belews Creek
description: rises in E Forsyth County and flows N into Belews Creek.

label: East Bend
description: town in NE Yadkin County between Logan Creek and Yadkin River. Known as Banner's Store for a local merchant, Martin Banner, until the name was changed about 1849 for a nearby E bend in the Yadkin River. Inc. 1887.

label: East Bend Township
description: NE Yadkin County.

label: East Bluff Bay
description: S Hyde County in Pamlico Sound E of Bluff Point.

label: East Branch
description: rises in SE Yancey County and flows N into Little Whiteoak Creek.

label: East Branch Chicod Creek
description: formed in W Beaufort County by the junction of Juniper and Harding Swamps. Flows NW into Pitt County, where it enters Chicod Creek.

label: East Buffalo Creek
description: rises in central Graham County and flows SW into Santeetlah Lake.

label: East Buies Creek
description: rises in NE Harnett County and flows SW into Buies Creek. It appears as Hugh McCrarey's Creek on early maps of the region and later as Hugh's Creek.

label: East Creek
description: rises in central Currituck County and flows SW into North River.

label: East Dismal Swamp
description: a 20,000-acre area of peat and muck swamp extending NE from N Beaufort County across S and E Washington County into W Tyrrell County. See also Dogwood Ridge; New Lands.

label: East Double Creek
description: rises in S Surry County and flows S to join West Double Creek in forming Double Creek.

label: East Fayetteville
description: unincorporated outskirts of city of Fayetteville, central Cumberland County 1½ mi. E of Market House.

label: East Flat Rock
description: former town in central Henderson County. Alt. 2,214. Inc. 1926; charter repealed by local action, 1948, and by act of the General Assembly, 1949. Est. as a commercial adjunct to the residential community of Flat Rock, which see.

label: East Fork
description: community in S Transylvania County.

label: East Fork Chattooga River
description: rises in S Jackson County and flows S into South Carolina, where it enters Chattooga River.

label: East Fork Crabtree Creek
description: rises in S Mitchell County and flows NW into Crabtree Creek.

label: East Fork Creek
description: rises in E Beaufort County and flows S into Pamlico River.

label: East Fork Deep River
description: rises in W Guilford County and flows SE into High Point Lake, where it joins West Fork Deep River in forming Deep River.

label: East Fork French Broad River
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows SW and NW into French Broad River.

label: East Fork Gap
description: E Haywood County on the head of Garden Creek.

label: East Fork Grassy Creek
description: rises in S Mitchell County and flows NW to join Middle Fork Grassy Creek in forming Grassy Creek.

label: East Fork Lake
description: in central Jackson County on Tuckasegee River. Formed in 1955 to be a reservoir for Nantahala Power and Light Company. Combines with Wolf Creek Lake, which see, to generate hydroelectric power. Covers 40 acres, with max. depth of 120 ft. Shoreline is 3.2 mi. Named for East Fork of Tuckasegee River, an old name for the Tuckasegee River.

label: East Fork Overflow Creek
description: rises in SE Macon County and flows SW to join West Fork Overflow Creek in forming Overflow Creek.

label: East Fork Pigeon River
description: rises in SW Haywood County near the Transylvania County line and flows N to join West Fork Pigeon River in forming Pigeon River. Known by the Cherokee Indians as Junietta.

label: East Fork Shut-in Creek
description: rises in W Madison County and flows NW to join West Fork Shut-in Creek in forming Shut-in Creek.

label: East Fork Township
description: S Haywood County.

label: East Fork Twelvemile Creek
description: rises in W Union County and flows SW to join West Fork in forming Twelvemile Creek.

label: East Fork [Barkers Creek]
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows N to join West Fork in forming Barkers Creek.

label: East Fork [Bull Creek]
description: rises in E Madison County and flows SW to join West Fork in forming Bull Creek.

label: East Fork [Campbell Creek]
description: rises in W Haywood County and flows N into Campbell Creek.

label: East Fork [Cove Creek]
description: rises in W Watauga County and flows S into Cove Creek.

label: East Fork [Dicks Creek]
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows SW to join West Fork in forming Dicks Creek.

label: East Fork [Goose Creek]
description: rises in N Pamlico County and flows SW into Goose Creek.

label: East Fork [Jenkins Creek]
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows SW to join West Fork in forming Jenkins Creek.

label: East Fork [Kirkland Creek]
description: rises in S Swain County and flows NW to join West Fork [Kirkland Creek] in forming Kirkland Creek.

label: East Fork [Moses Creek]
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows SW to join West Fork in forming Moses Creek.

label: East Fork [Savannah Creek]
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows NW into Savannah Creek.

label: East Fork [South Fork New River]
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows NW to join Middle Fork and Flannery Fork in forming South Fork New River approx. 2 mi. SE of town of Boone.

label: East Fork [South River]
description: a short stream at the headwaters of South River in N central Carteret County.

label: East Franklin
description: community in central Macon County.

label: East Fruitland
description: See Pores Knob.

label: East Gastonia
description: unincorporated outskirts of city of Gastonia, central Gaston County.

label: East Howellsville Township
description: E Robeson County.

label: East Kings Mountain
description: former town in W Gaston County on the Cleveland County line. Inc. 1907. By popular vote, it was transferred to Cleveland County in 1915. Became a part of Kings Mountain, which see, in 1923.

label: East Lake
description: lake on the mainland of N Dare County, empties into the mouth of Alligator River.

label: East Lake
description: community on the mainland of NW Dare County on South Lake. Settled about 1790. Alt. 10.

label: East Lake Landing
description: NW Dare County on Alligator River. State-operated free ferry from the landing to Sandy Point in NE Tyrrell County was replaced by the Lindsay C. Warren Bridge, 2.83 mi. long and opened in May 1962; named for Lindsay C. Warren (1889-1976), former U.S. congressman and comptroller general.

label: East Lake Township
description: NW Dare County mainland.

label: East Laport
description: community in N Jackson County on Tuckasegee River. Developed at the site of an eighteenth-century French trading post that the French considered to be an east gate or door (la porte) to the Cherokee country. Alt. 2,186.

label: East Laurinburg
description: town in S Scotland County. Inc. 1903 as Scotland Village; name changed, 1909.

label: East Lumberton
description: former town in E central Robeson County. Inc. 1901. Charter repealed 1953. Now a part of Lumberton. Was a mill-owned village until 1950, when houses were sold to individuals.

label: East Mayo Mountain
description: See Baughn Mountain.

label: East Mingo Branch
description: rises in SW Johnston County and flows S to join Black River in forming South River on the Cumberland-Sampson county line. For a part of its course, it forms the boundary between Johnston and Harnett Counties and between Harnett and Sampson Counties. Sometimes known as Mingo Swamp. Appears as Black Mingo on the Collet map, 1770. Mingo was an Indian word for a treacherous person. It was also frequently used as a slave name, appearing as such as early as 1680 in Albemarle County. See also Black Creek Swamp.

label: East Monbo
description: now covered by waters of Lake Norman but formerly a community on the Catawba River in W Iredell County. A cotton mill was est. there in the late nineteenth century and named Mont Beau (beautiful mountain) by its owners. The natives soon corrupted the name to Monbo and, since it was on the E side of the river, it became East Monbo (there being another mill on the W side of the river in Catawba County). East Monbo was long a popular picnic and swimming site.

label: East Nelson Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SE into Valley River.

label: East Prong
description: rises in central Burke County and flows W into Sandy Run Creek.

label: East Prong Cub Creek
description: rises in S Wilkes County and flows NW into Cub Creek at the E outskirts of Wilkesboro. Originally known as Little Cub Creek.

label: East Prong Deep River
description: rises in W Guilford County and flows SE into Deep River.

label: East Prong Little Yadkin River
description: rises in W Stokes County and flows SW to join West Prong Little Yadkin River in forming Little Yadkin River.

label: East Prong Moon Creek
description: rises in W Caswell County and flows NE into Moon Creek.

label: East Prong Roaring River
description: rises in NE Wilkes County and flows SE into Roaring River.

label: East Prong [Hickory Fork]
description: rises in N Madison County and flows SW into Hickory Fork.

label: East Ridge
description: E Watauga County, extends SE between Mary Simmons Ridge and Clear Branch.

label: East Rockingham
description: unincorporated outskirts of town of Rockingham, W Richmond County.

label: East Sanford Township
description: former township in central Lee County. Now township no. 5.

label: East Spencer
description: town in E Rowan County. Originated as Southern City (along the route of the Southern Railway), a real-estate development by John S. Henderson and others. Inc. 1901. The town of Spencer is to the sw. "Spring Hill," plantation of Maxwell Chambers, was there.

label: East Swan Creek
description: rises in W Yadkin County and flows NW into Wilkes County, where it joins West Swan Creek in forming Swan Creek.

label: East Wilmington
description: unincorporated outskirts of the city of Wilmington, W New Hanover County.

label: East Woodford
description: community in SE Mecklenburg County.

label: Eastatoe Creek
description: rises in NE Pickens County, S.C., in the Blue Ridge Mountains and flows N into S Transylvania County, N.C., and NE into Middle Fork French Broad River.

label: Eastatoe Gap
description: S Transylvania County between Shoal Creek and Eastatoe Creek. Alt. 2,686.

label: Eastatoe Township
description: S central Transylvania County.

label: Eastbrook
description: community in NE Brunswick County.

label: Eastern Channel
description: a tidal waterway in SW Brunswick County extending E from Tibbs Inlet inside Hales Beach for about 3 mi.

label: Eastern Channel
description: a tidal waterway in S Brunswick County extending W from Montgomery Slough to Lockwoods Folly Inlet.

label: Eastfield
description: community in NE Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1880-1902.

label: Eastham Creek
description: rises near the center of Goose Creek Island, NE Pamlico County, and flows NW into Goose Creek.

label: Eastland
description: community in W Caswell County. A post office operated there, 1887-1905.

label: Eastman Creek
description: rises in N Carteret County and flows W into South River.

label: Eastmost River
description: is formed in SE Bertie County by the junction of Middle River and a branch of Roanoke River near its mouth. It flows NE into Batchelor Bay.

label: Eastmost Swamp
description: rises in E central Bertie County and flows S into Salmon Creek.

label: Eastmouth Bay
description: in the waters of Core Sound between the two large islands comprising Harkers Island in SE Carteret County.

label: Eastover Township
description: E central Cumberland County.

label: Eastview
description: community in SW Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1903.

label: Eastwood
description: community in S Moore County. Named for J. B. Eastwood, lumberman who est. a store there about 1912.

label: Eastwood Lake
description: S Orange County in NE Chapel Hill. Formed in 1937 by a dam on Booker Creek. Approx. ¾ mi. long, covering 58 acres, with a max. depth of about 20 ft. Now the center of a residential area.

label: Easy Hill
description: community in NE Brunswick County.

label: Easy Ridge
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur extending NE from Noland Divide.

label: Easy Ridge Gap
description: S Swain County at the head of First Hurricane Branch.

label: Easy Street
description: historically black community in N Sampson County. Said to have been named for the fact that it was easy to purchase illegal liquor there.

label: Eatman
description: community in S Nash County served by post office, 1890-1906.

label: Eaton Island
description: See Baker Island.

label: Eatons Ferry
description: in NE Warren County on Roanoke River, was privately owned and operated as early as 1770 and appeared on the Price map, 1808. It was purchased by the state in 1935 and operated until January 1962, when a bridge over Lake Gaston was opened.

label: Eaves Creek
description: rises in N Franklin County and flows SE into Lynch Creek.

label: Ebenezer
description: community in central Cherokee County at the junction of Dockery and Hanging Dog Creek.

label: Eby Creek
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows SW into Little River.

label: Echo
description: crossroads community in SW Robeson County.

label: Echota Mission
description: N Jackson County, maintained by Holston Conference of Methodist Church for Cherokee Indians about 1840-85. School est. 1850. Missionary's house still stands.

label: Ecola
description: former community in W Swain County; site now under the waters of Fontana Lake.

label: Ecusta
description: See Pisgah Forest.

label: Ed Top
description: peak in N Haywood County on the head of Laurel Branch.

label: Edam
description: community in NW Wilson County.

label: Eden
description: town in N Rockingham County on Dan and Smith Rivers. Formed in 1967 by the merger of Leaksville, Draper, and Spray, which see. Named for William Byrd's estate, "Land of Eden," which see.

label: Edenhouse
description: community in E Bertie County on the Chowan River. Site of Eden House, home of Governor Charles Eden, 1714-22, and Governor Gabriel Johnston, 1732-52.

label: Edenhouse Point
description: point of land extending into Chowan River, E Bertie County. Location of an early seine fishery.

label: Edens Pond
description: See Watsons Pond.

label: Edenton
description: town and county seat, S Chowan County on Albemarle Sound. Settled by 1710 and known by the Indians as the Town on Matecomack Creek. Town authorized to be laid off in 1712 and the first lot sold in 1714. Known as the Town on Queen Anne's Creek from 1715 until 1723, when it was inc. as Edenton in honor of Charles Eden (1673-1722), governor, who had just died. Edenton was the capital of the colony from 1722 until 1743, and a building was provided for the Assembly by 1733 (and perhaps as early as 1725), though the Assembly met there 1722-36 and 1740-43. The Edenton Tea Party on October 25, 1774, is the earliest known instance of political activity by American women. Alt. 16. Processes peanuts and seafood; produces textiles, veneer, seed, fertilizer, and lumber. See also St. Paul's Parish.

label: Edenton Bay
description: S Chowan County in Albemarle Sound. Formed by the mouth of Pembroke Creek. Covers approx. 4,000 acres.

label: Edenton District
description: at the time of the 1790 census, was composed of Bertie, Camden, Chowan, Currituck, Gates, Hertford, Pasquotank, Perquimans, and Tyrrell Counties and the town of Edenton.

label: Edenton Township
description: former township in S Chowan County, now township no. 1. For voting purposes, the township is divided into East Edenton and West Edenton.

label: Edgar
description: community in N Randolph County.

label: Edge
description: community in N Bladen County served by post office, 1886-1908.

label: Edgecombe
description: community in SE Pender County.

label: Edgecombe County
description: was formed in 1741 from Bertie County. Located in the E section of the state, it is bounded by Martin, Pitt, Wilson, Nash, and Halifax Counties. It was named for Richard Edgecumbe (1680-1758), afterward first Baron Edgecumbe, a member of Parliament, lord of the treasury, and holder of other political offices. Area: 511 sq. mi. County seat: Tarboro, with an elevation of 71 ft. Townships, now numbered 1 to 14, were formerly Tarboro, Lower Conetoe, Upper Conetoe, Deep Creek, Lower Fishing Creek, Upper Fishing Creek, Swift Creek, Sparta, Otter Creek, Lower Town Creek, Walnut Creek, Rocky Mount, Cokey, and Upper Town Creek. Produces tobacco, corn, soybeans, peanuts, cotton, sweet potatoes, cucumbers, hogs, livestock, textiles, baked goods, lumber, plastics, paper products, machinery, fabricated metals, and furniture.

label: Edgecombe, Parish of
description: Church of England, Edgecombe County, later Halifax, est. 1741 with the creation of Edgecombe County. Coextensive with the county. In 1756 the parish was divided, creating St. Mary's Parish in the s; the Parish of Edgecombe remained in the n. With the creation of Halifax County in 1758, the Parish of Edgecombe became coextensive with the new county. St. Mary's Parish was coextensive with Edgecombe County. Edgecombe Parish in 1767 had 1,500 white taxables.

label: Edgemont
description: community in W Caldwell County.

label: Edgewater
description: community in S central Carteret County NW of Morehead City. Alt. 19 ft. Formerly named Morehead Bluffs.

label: Edgewood
description: community in E Robeson County served by post office, 1883-95.

label: Edinburg
description: former town in SW Montgomery County. Inc. 1807 at the store of, and on the land of, John Billingsly. A post office was there as early as 1828 and as recently as 1882. Site now abandoned. Also spelled Edinborough and Edenboro, 1827-94. Named for the city in Scotland by local residents of Scottish descent. Site of former Edinborough Academy.

label: Edith
description: community in SE Catawba County. Alt. 1,050.

label: Edith Lake
description: S Henderson County on Green River. Approx. 1½ mi. long.

label: Edmiston
description: See Sunnyside.

label: Edmonds
description: community in NE Alleghany County and Virginia.

label: Edney Branch
description: rises in W Yancey County and flows S into Cane River.

label: Edneyville
description: community in E Henderson County. Named for Rev. Samuel Edney, Methodist minister who served as postmaster and magistrate. A post office there since 1842. Former high school now a regional training center for law enforcement. Alt. 2,247.

label: Edneyville Township
description: NE Henderson County.

label: Edonia
description: community in S Cumberland County served by post office, 1883-1907.

label: Edward
description: town in SE Beaufort County. Alt. 25. Inc. 1889 as Edwards’ Mill, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Named for Josephus Edwards, who built a mill on nearby Durham Creek about 1868.

label: Edward Cove
description: S Haywood County on a tributary of Bird Creek.

label: Edward Jones Creek
description: See Little Turnbull Creek.

label: Edwards Branch
description: rises in N Macon County and flows SE into Daves Creek.

label: Edwards Branch
description: rises in N Mitchell County and flows S into Little Rock Creek.

label: Edwards Bridge
description: community in E Greene County on Contentnea Creek. Bridge built over the creek as early as the 1850s.

label: Edwards Creek
description: rises in SE Macon County and flows SE into Big Creek.

label: Edwards Crossroads
description: community in N Alleghany County. Alt. approx. 2,800.

label: Edwards Mountain
description: peak in the Peach Bottom Mountain range, central Alleghany County. Alt. approx. 3,400.

label: Edwards Pocosin
description: S Northampton County between Lily Pond Creek and Quarter Swamp.

label: Edwards Township
description: E Wilkes County.

label: Edwards’ Mill
description: See Edward.

label: Edwardsville
description: community in W Surry County served by post office, 1871-1905.

label: Effie
description: community in S Jackson County served by post office, 1888-1902.

label: Efird's Mills
description: community in central Stanly County served by post office, 1848-1916.

label: Efland
description: community in W Orange County. Alt. 658.

label: Egg Shoal
description: in the waters of Pamlico Sound, S Dare County off the S part of Hatteras Island.

label: Eggleston Point
description: See Eagleton Point.

label: Eggtown
description: community in NW Anson County.

label: Egypt
description: See Cumnock.

label: Egypt Land
description: a name applied to the S portion of Vance County because of its reputation at one time as a land of slaves and corn.

label: Egypt Township
description: N Yancey County.

label: Eight-Foot Ditch
description: canal in NW Pasquotank County that drains NE into Shepherd Ditch.

label: Eighty-Nine Mile Siding
description: See Cognac.

label: Ekaneetlee Creek
description: rises in NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows SE into Eagle Creek.

label: Ekaneetlee Gap
description: on the Swain County, N.C.-Blount County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Alt. 3,852.

label: El-see-toss
description: See Mount Pisgah.

label: Ela
description: community in E Swain County on Tuckasegee River. Name is a Cherokee word meaning "earth." Alt. 1,830.

label: Ela Lake
description: on Oconaluftee River in E Swain County. Covers 20 acres; max. depth 15 ft. Formed in 1925. Owned by the Aluminum Company of America and used to generate electric power. Formerly known as Onitalooga Lake.

label: Elah
description: or community in NE Brunswick about 2 mi. SW of Leland. Settled prior to 1882. Inc. 1903 as Myrtle to meet the requirement that whiskey stills could be operated only in incorporated towns. Charter repealed 1905. Took name Elah from local Elah Baptist Church.

label: Elams
description: community in NE Warren County between Walker Creek and Lizard Creek. Settled in 1880 and named for James Elam, local resident. Alt. 400.

label: Elbaville
description: community in E Davie County. Name derived from the first syllables of names of two local families, Ellis and Bailey. Post office est. 1870. Alt. approx. 808.

label: Elberon
description: community in S Warren County between Lees Branch and Buffalo Branch. Post office est. in 1897 but discontinued in 1954.

label: Elberta
description: community in W Moore County. A peach-growing center named for the Elberta peach. Alt. approx. 661.

label: Elbethel
description: community in SE Cleveland County. Named for El Bethel Methodist Church.

label: Elbow
description: community in central Columbus County served by post office, 1894-1910.

label: Elbow Branch
description: rises in N Swain County and flows NW into Hazel Creek.

label: Elbow Creek
description: rises in NW Cherokee County and flows S into Shuler Creek.

label: Elbow Landing
description: on Pungo River, E Beaufort County.

label: Elbow Ridge
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur extending W from Welch Ridge between Elbow Branch and Hazel Creek.

label: Elder Branch
description: rises in central Duplin County and flows SE into Maxwell Creek.

label: Eldora Township
description: E central Surry County.

label: Eldorado
description: community in NW Montgomery County served by post office, 1875-1953. Earlier known as Tan Yard. Formerly a center of gold mines of varying productivity. Named for a legendary South American king who owned much gold. A post office in the late nineteenth century. Now a residential community.

label: Eldorado Township
description: NW Montgomery County.

label: Eleanors Crossroads
description: community in central Gates County.

label: Elease
description: community in S Cumberland County.

label: Eleazer
description: community in SW Randolph County on Uwharrie River. Served by post office, 1883-1933.

label: Elerbe
description: community in SW Granville County.

label: Elevation Township
description: SW Johnston County. Named for the fact that it is in a hilly section of the county.

label: Elf
description: community in S Clay County on Chatuge Lake.

label: Elgin
description: plantation house in central Warren County. Built in 1832 and named by a Scottish immigrant, Peter Mitchel, for his native city, Elgin, county seat of Elginshire (or Moray County). The house is still used as a dwelling.

label: Eli
description: community in S Rowan County served by post office, 1892-1902.

label: Eli Whitney
description: community in SE Alamance County. Named for inventor of cotton gin. Public quilting bee held there since 1931.

label: Elise
description: See Robbins.

label: Elisha
description: community in S Pasquotank County.

label: Elisha Creek
description: approx. 5 mi. long, rises in central Davie County and flows SE into Dutchmans Creek. Appears in local records, 1815, as "Lisha, formerly called Licking Creek."

label: Elizabeth City
description: city and county seat, E Pasquotank County on Pasquotank River. Settled in 1790; inc. as Redding in 1793. In 1794 named changed from "Reading" to Elizabeth-town; became Elizabeth City in 1801. Probably named for Elizabeth Tooley, wife of Adam Tooley, on whose land the town was est. Elizabeth City State University and College of the Albemarle are there. Produces textiles, ships, lumber, hosiery, apparel, paper boxes, and industrial machinery. Alt. 12.

label: Elizabeth City Township
description: E central Pasquotank County.

label: Elizabeth River
description: rises in SE Brunswick County and flows E into the Cape Fear River.

label: Elizabeth Town
description: See Columbia.

label: Elizabethtown
description: town and county seat, central Bladen County. Alt. 121. Est. 1773, chartered 1843, and inc. 1895. Named either for Queen Elizabeth I of England or for the sweetheart of Isaac Jones, on whose land the town was laid out. In the Battle of Elizabethtown, August 27, 1781, Whigs broke Tory power in Bladen County by driving them into Tory Hole, a deep ravine along the banks of Cape Fear River in the middle of the town.

label: Elizabethtown Township
description: in central Bladen County.

label: Elk Branch
description: rises in E Mitchell County and flows S into Cane Creek.

label: Elk Creek
description: rises in W Alleghany County and flows N into New River.

label: Elk Fork
description: rises in SW Yancey County and flows NE into Little Creek.

label: Elk Hollow Branch
description: rises in W Avery County and flows E into Roaring Creek.

label: Elk Hollow Ridge
description: W Avery County.

label: Elk Knob
description: N Watauga County near the head of Hoskin Fork.

label: Elk Lodge Mountain
description: S central Transylvania County between Allison Creek and Lamb Creek.

label: Elk Marsh
description: See Marsh Swamp.

label: Elk Mountain
description: community in central Buncombe County W of Woodfin. Alt. 1,950.

label: Elk Mountains
description: central Buncombe County NE of Asheville, extend from Peach Knob to Roaring Gap. Alt. 3,149-3,190.

label: Elk Park
description: town in NW Avery County. Inc. 1885. First county court held there while the courthouse at Newland was under construction. Named for elk that once roamed the region. Alt. 3,182.

label: Elk Ridge
description: extends S from Bluff Mountain in SW Ashe County.

label: Elk River
description: rises in NE Avery County near Banner Elk and flows W into Tennessee, where it enters Watauga River. For most of its course, it flows in a deep gorge.

label: Elk River Falls
description: in Elk River, NW Avery County, a drop of about 85 ft.; for the next 4 mi. downstream, there is a fall of about 100 ft. per mile.

label: Elk Shoal
description: community in W Yancey County on Cane River. A nineteenth-century post office serving the community was named Wampler.

label: Elk Shoal Creek
description: rises in W Yancey County and flows E into Cane River.

label: Elk Shoals
description: former community in E Alexander County near headwaters of Elk Shoals Creek. Post office est. there in 1852 was discontinued in 1901 with postal service transferred to Stony Point. Named for shoals in creek at which elk crossed.

label: Elk Shoals Creek
description: rises in SE Alexander County and flows S and SW into Catawba River. The name occurs in local records as early as 1760, and the stream is shown on Collet map, 1770.

label: Elk Spur
description: N Wilkes County near Little Sandy Creek.

label: Elk Township
description: SE Watauga County.

label: Elk Wallow Creek
description: rises in W Yancey County and flows SE into Bald Creek.

label: Elk Wallow Gap
description: central Buncombe County in Elk Mountains.

label: Elk Wallow Knob
description: on the Madison-Yancey county line near the head of Elk Wallow Creek. Alt. approx. 4,600.

label: Elk X Roads
description: See Todd.

label: Elkin
description: town in SW Surry County on Yadkin River near the mouth of Elkin River. Alt. 947. Inc. 1889. Named for the river. Immediately S, separated by Yadkin River, is the town of Jonesville in Yadkin County. Produced woolen goods.

label: Elkin River
description: rises in NE Wilkes County and flows SE across the SW corner of Surry County and into Yadkin River on the Surry-Yadkin county line near the town of Elkin. Appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Elkin Township
description: SW Surry County.

label: Elkinsville
description: See Elkton.

label: Elkland
description: See Todd.

label: Elko
description: community in N Stokes County served by post office, 1882-1904.

label: Elks Crossroads
description: See Todd.

label: Elkton
description: community in S Bladen County. Alt. 90.

label: Elkton Swamp
description: rises in S Bladen County and flows S into Brown Marsh Swamp.

label: Elkville
description: community in SW Wilkes County on Yadkin River. Alt. 1,200.

label: Elkwallow Knob
description: NW Mitchell County between Leatherman Fork and Bearwallow Creek.

label: Elkwood
description: See Weaverville.

label: Ell Branch
description: rises in S Jackson County and flows SE into Robinson Creek.

label: Ellenboro
description: town in E Rutherford County. Alt. 1,046. Founded 1886; inc. 1889. Said to have been named for Ellen Robinson, daughter of the president (or engineer) of the Carolina Central Railroad. Robinson gave a bell to the school there with his daughter's name engraved inside. May have been named by Burwell Blanton Byers, owner of much local property, for himself and his wife, Ellen—Ellenburwell, which later became Ellenboro.

label: Ellenburwell
description: See Ellenboro.

label: Ellendale
description: community in W Alexander County. Formerly known as Ellendale Chalybeate Springs, a summer resort. Named for Ellen Reid, daughter of the owner of the spring.

label: Ellendale Township
description: W Alexander County.

label: Eller
description: community in N Davidson County. Alt. 902. Named for one Eller, who settled in the vicinity about 1753. Also known locally as Midway because of its position between Lexington and Winston-Salem.

label: Eller Branch
description: rises in N Buncombe County and flows NW into Madison County, where it enters Ivy River.

label: Eller Cove
description: S Graham County between Horse Range Ridge and Atoah Gap.

label: Eller Cove
description: N Buncombe County between Little Davis and Lydie Mountains.

label: Ellerbe
description: town in N central Richmond County. Scottish settlers in the eighteenth century had a fair at the site each May and November, and it came to be known as The Fair Grounds. After W. T. Ellerbe developed a popular watering place at nearby Ellerbe Springs, the present name began to be applied. Inc. 1911. Produced hosiery.

label: Ellerbee Creek
description: rises in W Durham County about 2 mi. W of Durham and flows E and NE about 11 mi. into Neuse River. Known earlier as Alliby Creek and Elliby Creek.

label: Elliby Creek
description: See Ellerbee Creek.

label: Ellicott Mountain
description: S Jackson County near the head of East Fork Chattooga River. Alt. 3,800. Named for Andrew Ellicott (1745-1820), who surveyed the North Carolina-Georgia state line in 1813.

label: Ellicott Rock
description: on the E side of Chattooga River in SW Jackson County at the North Carolina-South Carolina-Georgia state line. A granite boulder indicating the junction was marked in 1813 by and named for Andrew Ellicott (1754-1820), surveyor.

label: Ellijay
description: community in E Macon County on Ellijay Creek. Alt 2,200. Name is from a Cherokee word meaning "verdant earth."

label: Ellijay Creek
description: rises in E Macon County and flows SW into Cullasaja River.

label: Ellijay Township
description: E central Macon County.

label: Ellington Branch
description: rises in NW Warren County and flows NE into Smiths Creek.

label: Elliott
description: community in E Sampson County. Alt. 137. A post office was opened there in 1886 but closed in 1940. Named for Dr. Elliott Lee of Clinton. An early stop on the railroad there was known as Summit. The community is at the site of "Mt. Pleasant," the plantation of James Faison.

label: Elliott Branch
description: rises in E Cherokee County and flows S into Peachtree Creek.

label: Elliott Cove
description: N Swain County between Sunkota Ridge and Deep Creek.

label: Elliott Springs
description: See Catawba Springs.

label: Ellis
description: community in N Bladen County served by post office, 1885-1907.

label: Ellis Creek
description: rises in S Davidson County and flows W into Yadkin River.

label: Ellis Cross Roads
description: community in NE Rowan County. Settled about 1885.

label: Ellis Lake
