description: a natural lake in Croatan National Forest, S Craven and N Carteret Counties. Covers 1,500 acres; max. depth 4 to 5 ft. Named for the Ellis family, which lived on its shores.

label: Ellis Mountain
description: central Mitchell County between Rebel Creek and Toe River.

label: Ellis Store
description: community in SE Bertie County.

label: Ellisboro
description: community in SW Rockingham County. Est. 1889 with extension of Cape Fear and Yadkin Valley Railroad. Named for Ellis Roberts, relative of developer. Failed to develop and was abandoned in 1936. Alt. 829.

label: Ellison Branch
description: rises in SE Buncombe County and flows S into Cane Creek.

label: Ellison Creek
description: rises in SW Forsyth County and flows SW into Yadkin River.

label: Elm City
description: town in N Wilson County. Alt. 131. Inc. 1873 as Toisnot, and post office est. there, succeeding nearby post office at Joyner's, which see. Named changed to Elm City, 1891; back to Toisnot, 1895; and again to Elm City, 1913.

label: Elm Swamp
description: See Corapeake Swamp.

label: Elmer
description: community in W Yancey County served by post office, 1881-1907.

label: Elmira Crossroads
description: community in SE Pitt County.

label: Elmore
description: community in S central Scotland County formerly called Elmores Crossroads.

label: Elmore Branch
description: rises in E Macon County and flows S into Rabbit Creek.

label: Elmores Crossroads
description: See Elmore.

label: Elmwood
description: community in SE Bertie County on Salmon Creek. Named for an early plantation at the site. Was early waiting place for the ferry across the creek to Edenton and beyond.

label: Elon
description: town in W Alamance County. Inc. 1893. Formerly known as Mill Point for a freight depot for shipping mill products manufactured nearby. Elon College, a four-year coeducational institution, opened there in 1890. Upon the school's name change to Elon University in 2001, the town formerly known as Elon College became Elon. Its name comes from the Hebrew word for oak and was selected because of the large oak trees in the area. Alt. 716.

label: Elrod
description: community in W Robeson County.

label: Elrod Branch
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows NW into Middle Fork [South Fork New River].

label: Elroy Store
description: community in E Wayne County near the head of Walnut Creek.

label: Elsworth Creek
description: rises in E Davie County and flows SW into Dutchmans Creek.

label: Elwell Ferry
description: across Cape Fear River in SE Bladen County.

label: Emaline Gap
description: S Macon County between Everett Mountain and Brush Creek.

label: Emandell
description: community in SW Washington County W of Van Swamp. Since the 1950s the name has not generally appeared on maps of the county.

label: Emanuel
description: community in E Caldwell County served by post office, 1880-1902.

label: Embro
description: community in central Warren County N of Reedy Creek. A post office est. there in 1889 was discontinued in 1921.

label: Emerald Isle
description: town on Bogue Banks, SE Carteret County. Inc. 1957. A resort town located on the Atlantic Ocean.

label: Emerson
description: community in S Bladen County. Alt. 104. Railroad name was Portersville.

label: Emerson Branch
description: rises in NW tip of Cabarrus County, where it forms a part of the headwaters of Coddle Creek.

label: Emit
description: community in N Johnston County on Little River. See also Flower Hill.

label: Emma
description: community in central Buncombe County W of Asheville. Alt. 2,075.

label: Emma Branch
description: rises in central Buncombe County near Dryman Mountain and flows SE through the community of Emma into Smith Mill Creek.

label: Emmons Mine
description: former gold mine in E Davidson County about 5 mi. N of Denton. In 1855 a large gold nugget ("123 penny-weights") was picked up in the vicinity.

label: Emmons Township
description: E central Davidson County.

label: Emory
description: community in central Warren County.

label: Emperor Landing
description: SW Chowan County in the mouth of Chowan River. Probably named for Emperor Moseley, early landowner.

label: Emperors Island
description: See Church Island.

label: Empire
description: community in E Randolph County served by post office, 1882-1906.

label: Encas
description: community in E Wilson County.

label: Endesokes
description: See Core Banks.

label: Endicott
description: community in central Montgomery County served by post office, 1886-1911.

label: Endicott Branch
description: rises in NW Surry County and flows SE into Fisher River.

label: Endor Iron Works
description: on Deep River N of Sanford in Lee County, large smelting furnace provided iron to Confederacy, 1862-65. Operated irregularly thereafter.

label: Endy
description: community in W Stanly County. Named for Arch Eudy who, in 1903, applied for the establishment of a post office there. The Post Office Department misread his name and assigned the name Endy instead of the requested Eudy.

label: Endy Township
description: central Stanly County.

label: Energy
description: See Siler City.

label: Enfield
description: town in S Halifax County. The county seat of Edgecombe County was there from 1745 until the formation of Halifax in 1759; the first Halifax court met there, but Halifax (town) was afterward the county seat. Inc. 1861. Named probably for the town of Enfield, Middlesex, England. Known originally as Huckleberry Swamp. Alt. 111.

label: Enfield Township
description: S Halifax County.

label: Engagement Hill
description: a sand hill between the ocean and sound in Nags Head, E Dare County, now covered by houses. A favorite spot for visits by young couples in former days.

label: Engelhard
description: community in E Hyde County on Far Creek. Alt. 2. Inc. 1874; charter revoked 1967. Named for Joseph A. Engelhard (1832-79), publisher of the Wilmington Daily Journal, 1861-70. Known earlier as Far Creek.

label: Engine Gap
description: NE Mitchell County near the Tennessee state line.

label: English
description: community in E Madison County at the head of Puncheon Fork Creek. Named for an early settler.

label: English Branch
description: rises near Chalk Mountain in S Mitchell County and flows SE into North Toe River. Named for Isaac English, an early settler.

label: English Knob
description: E Mitchell County between Beaver Creek and Gouges Creek.

label: English Town
description: community in N Pender County.

label: Enka
description: community in central Buncombe County. Alt. 2,060. Home of the American Enka Corporation, est. 1929. The name is from the letters N and K taken from the firm's official name: Nederlandsche Kunstzyde Fabricken. Produces textiles and chemicals.

label: Enka Lake
description: central Buncombe County on Bill Moore Creek. Covers 40 acres; max. depth 40 ft. Owned by American Enka Corp. as a source of water for rayon manufacturing. Formed 1928.

label: Enloe Creek
description: rises in NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows SE into Raven Fork Creek.

label: Enloe Ridge
description: NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur extending E from Hughes Ridge.

label: Ennetts Point
description: W Carteret County, extending into Bogue Sound W of the mouth of Deer Creek. Named for the Ennett family.

label: Ennice
description: community in E Alleghany County. Named for Ennice Higgins, daughter of the first postmaster, 1883.

label: Enno
description: See Holleman's Crossroads.

label: Eno River
description: rises in N Orange County and flows SE across the county into W Durham County, where it flows E and joins Flat River in forming the Neuse River. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733. The name probably is from the Tuscarora Indian word e-eno (a great way; far off).

label: Eno Township
description: E central Orange County.

label: Enoch Canal
description: E Washington County, extends NE from Lake Phelps to Mall Creek.

label: Enoch Mill Creek
description: rises in S Sampson County and flows SE into Black River.

label: Enochville
description: town in SW Rowan County. Inc. 1877. Named for St. Enoch's Evangelical Lutheran Church. Long inactive in municipal affairs. Served by post office, 1877-1902.

label: Enola
description: community in S Burke County. Name is "alone" spelled backwards.

label: Enon
description: community in E Yadkin County between Logan Creek and Yadkin River.

label: Enon Mountain
description: in E Transylvania County W of Lydia Creek.

label: Enos Plotts Balsam Mountain
description: W Haywood County about 5 mi. W of Waynesville. Alt. 6,097. Known by the Cherokee Indians as Sunneehaw. See also Plott Balsam.

label: Ens Creek
description: See South Fork.

label: Enterprise
description: community in N Davidson County. Name chosen to suggest the nature of the inhabitants.

label: Entwistle
description: community in central Richmond County.

label: Eoka
description: community in central Columbus County served by post office, 1884-1902.

label: Ephesus
description: community in S Davie County. Named in 1890 when a post office was est. there in Miles A. Foster's store.

label: Ephraim Branch
description: rises in N Haywood County and flows SW into Groundhog Creek.

label: Ephraim Hensley Mountain
description: N Madison County between Rick Branch and Big Creek.

label: Ephraim Place
description: mountain on the Mitchell County, N.C.-Unicoi County, Tenn., line.

label: Epping Forest
description: an eighteenth-century community and census district in SW Vance County. The community was located near the present town of Kittrell. In 1790 the district had 65 heads of families.

label: Epps Springs
description: community in central Swain County on Tuckasegee River. Alt. 1,662.

label: Epsom
description: community in E Vance County and N Franklin County. Known as Dukes Crossroads in 1881. When a post office was est. there in 1887, the name Duke was rejected because there was another post office by that name. According to tradition, the present name was suggested by Dr. Bennett P. Alston, who noticed a stock of Epsom salts in the local store.

label: Epworth
description: community in N Edgecombe County served by post office, 1893-1907.

label: Equality
description: community in SW Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1836-46. Later known as Dixie, which see.

label: Erastus
description: community in W Jackson County on Little Piney Creek.

label: Erect
description: community in SE Randolph County. Name suggested to Post Office Department in 1873 by C. M. Tysor, local merchant, to compliment the posture of his neighbor, Tom Bray.

label: Erie Mills
description: community in SW Montgomery County served by post office, 1879-1905.

label: Erlanger
description: former community in central Davidson County. Est. 1914 and named for founder of local mill. Alt. 806. Now within the limits of Lexington.

label: Ernul
description: community in NE Craven County. Alt. 25. Settled about 1888. Named for James and Freeman Ernul, residents. Post office est. 1919 as successor to one at Askins.

label: Ervinsville
description: See Erwinsville.

label: Ervintown
description: community in NW Onslow County on the W limits of Richlands. Named for the numerous Ervins living there.

label: Erwin
description: town in SE Harnett County. Est. about 1902 with the construction there of Erwin Cotton Mills. First known as Duke for the Duke family of Durham. Name changed to Erwin about 1925 for William Allen Erwin (1856-1932), operator of the local mill. Inc. 1967. Produces textiles. Alt. 195.

label: Erwinsville
description: also known as Ervinsville, a former town in SW Cleveland County (then Rutherford County). Inc. 1808; previously inc. as Burrtown in 1800. Located near the mouth of First Broad River and the South Carolina line E of Ellis Ferry. In 1800 the General Assembly authorized 50 acres there to be laid out and sold in lots. Post office est. 1813, active until 1882. Town site later abandoned.

label: Eskota
description: community in S Yancey County on Cane River. Alt. 3,101.

label: Eskridge Cove
description: the valley through which Eskridge Cove Branch flows in SE Buncombe County.

label: Eskridge Cove Branch
description: rises in SE Buncombe County near Lookoff Gap and flows NW into Swannanoa River.

label: Esmeralda
description: community in NW Rutherford County on Broad River.

label: Ess-ee-daw
description: See Broad River.

label: Essex
description: town in SW Halifax County. Inc. 1891, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Prior to 1860 it was the center of a settlement of free blacks.

label: Essex Island
description: See Etacrewac.

label: Estatoe
description: See Rosman.

label: Estatoe Path
description: S Transylvania County, trading route between settlements of Cherokee Indians and their town of Estatoe, now in South Carolina.

label: Estatoe River
description: See Toe River.

label: Estelle
description: community in NE Caswell County. A post office operated there during the approx. period 1880-1905.

label: Estes Branch
description: rises in N Swain County and flows SW into Indian Creek.

label: Etacrewac
description: appears on the White maps, 1585 and 1590, as an island that today would be bounded on the N by the community of Duck on the North Banks and on the S by a point on Bodie Island opposite Broad Creek Point on Roanoke Island, E Dare County. The name appears to have been Algonquian for "evergreen-ground." See also Bodie Island; North Banks. The Smith map, 1624, appears to apply the name Essex Island there.

label: Ether
description: community in NE Montgomery County. Known as Freeman's Cross Roads prior to the establishment of a post office there in 1888, when it was named by Dr. F. E. Asbury, local physician.

label: Etheridge Creek
description: rises in SE Halifax County and flows SE on the Halifax-Edgecombe county line into Etheridge Swamp.

label: Etheridge Swamp
description: receives the waters of Etheridge Creek on the Halifax-Edgecombe county line and flows SE into Conoho Creek in Martin County.

label: Etheridge's Branch
description: rises in NW Wilson County and flows S and SE into Contentnea Creek.

label: Ethram Boney Bay
description: a large sandy loam marsh in S Duplin County.

label: Etna
description: community in N Macon County on Lakey Creek.

label: Etowah
description: community in W Henderson County. Alt. 2,101. The name comes from the Cherokee word I'tawa or Et-toh-wah, an unidentified kind of tree.

label: Eubanks
description: community in S Orange County.

label: Euchulla Cove
description: W Swain County between Wiggins Creek and Nantahala River.

label: Eufola
description: community in W Iredell County on Southern Railway. Alt. 788. Prior to 1903 known as Deep Cut; the railroad station was Plotts. May have been named for the Eufaula or Yufala Indian tribe in Georgia.

label: Eupeptic Springs
description: community and former resort (1860s-1870s), NW Iredell County. Known as Powder Springs prior to development as a resort by Dr. John Ford, who renamed it Eupeptic (good digestion).

label: Euphronia
description: community in N Moore County served by post office, 1877-1905.

label: Eure
description: town in W Gates County. Alt. 22. Inc. 1915, but no longer active in municipal affairs.

label: Eureka
description: town in NE Wayne County near the head of Watery Branch. Inc. 1879 as Saul's Cross Roads; name changed 1901.

label: Eurins Creek
description: rises in E central Stokes County and flows SE into Rockingham County, where it enters Dan River. Perhaps a variant of the older forms Hewins, Hewings, and Hughens.

label: Eury Lake
description: central Montgomery County on Little River, approx. 8 mi. S of Troy. Constructed about 1914 by S. J. and W. G. Smitherman and J. C. Hurley to provide electric power. Covers 80 acres, with a shoreline of approx. 3 mi. Later owned by Carolina Power and Light Company but sold in 1962 to the Montgomery County Hunt Club, Inc. Known as Hurley Lake until 1916, when the present name came into use.

label: Euto
description: See New Salem.

label: Eva
description: community in SW Perquimans County served by post office, 1887-1905.

label: Evan's Store Crossroads
description: See Winnabow.

label: Evans
description: community in SW Chatham County.

label: Evans Branch
description: rises in central Clay County and flows SW into Johnson Mill Creek.

label: Evans Creek
description: rises in S Macon County and flows NW into Tessentee Creek.

label: Evans Gap
description: W Swain County between Greasy Branch and Flat Branch.

label: Evans Knob
description: W Swain County between Fishtrap Branch and Tuckasegee River. Alt. 2,481.

label: Evans Mountain
description: W Henderson County at the head of South Fork.

label: Evans Ridge
description: N Clay County, extends NE from Shearer Creek to Chestnut Stamp Knob.

label: Evansdale
description: community in S Wilson County. Post office, 1908-10. Named for one Evans, who operated a sawmill at the site.

label: Evansville
description: community in E Bertie County served by post office, 1893-1905.

label: Everett Creek
description: rises in S Onslow County and flows E and N into New River.

label: Everett Mountain
description: S Macon County between Buck Creek and Emaline Gap.

label: Everett's Crossroad
description: community in central Beaufort County.

label: Everetts
description: town in W Martin County. Settled about 1877. Inc. 1891 as Everitts; reincorporated 1893 as Everetts. Named for local family; S. F. and J. A. Everetts were commissioners of the town when inc. Alt. 66.

label: Everetts Creek
description: rises in S New Hanover County and flows E into Myrtle Sound.

label: Everetts Mill
description: See Cedar Falls.

label: Everetts Mill Pond
description: in SW Richmond County on Marks Creek, approx. 1 mi. long.

label: Evergreen
description: town in NW Columbus County. Settled 1870; inc. 1907. Named for surrounding pine forest. Alt. 104.

label: Evergreen Island
description: Pamlico Sound just off the central section of Portsmouth Island, E Carteret County.

label: Evergreen Slough
description: inlet into E end of Portsmouth Island on Pamlico Sound side, E Carteret County.

label: Everitts
description: See Everetts.

label: Everittsville
description: former community near Dudley in S Wayne County. Prior to the Civil War, a group of plantation owners built homes together there and went out daily to tend their nearby plantations. There were schools and churches and in 1851 a post office, but no stores or other businesses. Named for Joseph Everitt, early settler. Only a cemetery remains to mark the site.

label: Ewart
description: community in N Mitchell County on Big Rock Creek.

label: Ewing
description: community in W Wake County.

label: Exact
description: community in E Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1898-1903.

label: Excelsior
description: See Rutherford College.

label: Exeter
description: former town in E Pender County on the E side of Northeast Cape Fear River on a high sandy bluff between Sand Hill Cove and Jumping Run. Flourished from about 1740 to 1790. Est. 1754 as New Exeter for Exeter, England, but it seems generally to have been known as Exeter. Appears on the Collet map, 1770, as Exeter. Began to decline as South Washington, which see, grew in importance after 1790 but appears on the Purcell map, 1792. Rutherfords Mill (later Ashe's Mill) was located nearby in the nineteenth century. In 1781, during the Revolution, British major Sir James Henry Craig constructed field fortifications there, which are still visible. Headquarters of the Holly Shelter State Game Management Area now occupy the site.

label: Exter
description: community in central Bertie County served by post office, 1886-1905.

label: Exum
description: community in NW Brunswick County.

label: Exum Mill Branch
description: rises in E Wayne County and flows E and NE into The Slough. Named for early settlers who had a mill on the stream in the late eighteenth century.

label: Exum Store
description: community in NE Wayne County between Turner Swamp and Ivy Swamp.

label: Exway
description: crossroads community in N Richmond County on the Montgomery County line. The name X-Way was recommended to the Post Office Department when a post office was about to be est. in 1898. The name was accepted, but the spelling was altered.

label: Eye
description: community in NW Ashe County served by post office, 1889-1906.

label: Ezra
description: community in central Johnston County served by post office, 1881-1903.

label: Ezzell Mill Pond
description: See McLamb Mill Pond.

label: Face Rock
description: peak at the W end of Bearwallow Mountain on the Buncombe-Henderson county line.

label: Factor Branch
description: rises in central Haywood County and flows NE into Lake Junaluska. Named for a "factory" that once stood nearby. The structure was a large warehouse where plants and herbs were collected, graded, dried, and packed for shipment.

label: Factory Branch
description: See Factor Branch.

label: Fagansville
description: See Carthage.

label: Faggart Mine
description: See Nash Mine.

label: Faggarts
description: community in central Cabarrus County.

label: Faggarts Township
description: See Watts Cross Roads Township.

label: Faggs Creek
description: rises in N Stokes County and flows S into Dan River.

label: Fain Cove
description: E Cherokee County, through which a short tributary of Slow Creek flows.

label: Fain Mountain
description: central Cherokee County, extends NE from Laurel Creek.

label: Fair Bluff
description: town in W Columbus County on a bluff overlooking Lumber River. Authorized to be laid off on the lands of John Wooton at Fair Bluff in 1807 and to be known as Wootonton. The new name apparently was not adopted, as Fair Bluff appears on the Price map, 1808, and on the MacRae map, 1833. Reincorporated in 1873 as Fair Bluff. Alt. 69.

label: Fair Bluff Township
description: W Columbus County.

label: Fair Grounds, The
description: See Ellerbe.

label: Fair Grove
description: community in NW Randolph County.

label: Fair Mountain
description: S Watauga County on the head of Laurel Creek.

label: Fairfax
description: community in NW Swain County on Lake Cheoah.

label: Fairfield
description: town on the N shore of Lake Mattamuskeet in central Hyde County. Alt. 3. Inc. 1885. Said to have been named for "fair fields" of crops grown on adjacent reclaimed swampland.

label: Fairfield Falls
description: S Jackson County on Trays Island Creek near N edge of Fairfield Lake. Alt. approx. 3,200.

label: Fairfield Lake
description: S Jackson County on Trays Island Creek formed in 1910. Covers 100 acres; max. depth 40 ft. Used for fishing, swimming, and boating and as a power source. Not open to the public. See also Fairfield Falls.

label: Fairfield Ridge
description: SE Clay County between Scaly Ridge and Bear Pen Ridge.

label: Fairfield Township
description: N central Hyde County.

label: Fairly
description: community in central Scotland County.

label: Fairmont
description: town in S Robeson County. Known first as Ashpole for nearby Ashpole Swamp. Inc. 1899 as Union City; name changed to Ashpole, 1901, and to Fairmont, 1907.

label: Fairmont Township
description: S Robeson County.

label: Fairntosh
description: community in N Durham County. Named for the plantation of Duncan Cameron (1777-1853); house built in 1802 still stands. Former post office nearby was named Stagville. Alt. 284.

label: Fairplains
description: community in central Wilkes County near Long Branch.

label: Fairport
description: community in E Granville County.

label: Fairview
description: community in SE Buncombe County.

label: Fairview Gap
description: S Buncombe County NE of Concord Mountain.

label: Fairview Township
description: SE Buncombe County.

label: Faison
description: town in NW Duplin County. Est. as Faison's Depot about 1833 on the land of Henry Faison. Inc. as Faison's Depot in 1872 through the efforts of Elias Faison, landowner and stockholder in the Wilmington and Raleigh Railroad. Received postal service from nearby Wrightsville as early as 1822. Fruit and vegetable market; produces pickles. Alt. 166.

label: Faison Township
description: NW Duplin County.

label: Faisons Old Tavern
description: community in central Northampton County between Corduroy and Wildcat Swamps. Named for a tavern operated there by the Faison family. The community of Odamsville, which had a post office as early as 1830, is traditionally said to have been the predecessor of Faisons Old Tavern.

label: Faith
description: town in S Rowan County. Inc. 1903. Named for a granite quarry opened by J. T. Wyatt, who lacked experience in quarrying but went ahead with his work "on faith."

label: Falcon
description: town in NE Cumberland County on Mingo Swamp. Alt. 125. Known as Starling's Bridge from as early as 1863 until 1893, when a post office was est. Inc. 1913. When a name was being sought for the post office, it is said that J. A. Culbreth glanced at a box of Falcon pens on the shelf of a country store and said, "Name it Falcon."

label: Falkland
description: town in W Pitt County. Post office est. in 1813 as Bensborough, changed to Falkland in 1838. Inc. 1887. Said to have been named for Falkland, Scotland, long the home of Scottish kings; or may have been named for the Falkland Islands, which the British had long claimed but only finally occupied a few years before Bensborough was changed to Falkland. Alt. 76.

label: Falkland Township
description: NW Pitt County. Formerly named California Township.

label: Fall Branch
description: rises in E Cherokee County and flows SE and SW into Hiwassee River.

label: Fall Branch
description: rises in central Avery County at Bellvue Mountain and flows SW into North Toe River.

label: Fall Creek
description: rises in E Mitchell County and flows S into Little Rock Creek.

label: Fall Creek
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows SW into Crabtree Creek.

label: Fall Creek Township
description: NE Yadkin County.

label: Fall Line
description: the dividing line between Coastal Plain and Piedmont North Carolina where the soft sedimentary soils of the Coastal Plain meet the hard rocks of the Piedmont. It often is marked in streams by falls and rapids. The fall line runs W of Wilson and E of Sanford in an irregular progression N and s.

label: Fall Ridge
description: S Watauga County, extends S in Watauga Township and causes a bend in Boone Fork.

label: Fallcliff
description: community in W Jackson County on Cullowhee Creek.

label: Falling Branch
description: rises in N Franklin County and flows SW into Tooles Creek.

label: Falling Creek
description: rises in NE Sampson County and flows NE into W Wayne County, where it enters Beaverdam Creek. See also Thoroughfare Swamp.

label: Falling Creek
description: rises in NW Catawba County and flows NE into Catawba River.

label: Falling Creek Township
description: central Lenoir County.

label: Falling Hollow
description: SW Watauga County on the head of Watauga River.

label: Falling Rock Creek
description: rises in W Haywood County, Great Smoky Mountains National Park, near lat. 35°36'56" N., long. 83°10'40" W. Flows NE to join Beech Creek in forming Palmer Creek. Named when an overhanging rock cliff on a stream where hunters, fishermen, and others camped fell after being heated by a big campfire. One person was killed and others were injured.

label: Falling Run
description: See Deep Creek.

label: Falling Water Branch
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows W into Cane River.

label: Falls
description: community in N Wake County on Neuse River. See also Falls of the Neuse.

label: Falls Branch
description: rises in E Macon County and flows S into North Prong Ellijay Creek.

label: Falls Branch
description: rises in SE Swain County and flows N into Yalaka Creek.

label: Falls Creek
description: rises in N Cumberland County and flows NE into Carver Creek. Named for the falls just downstream from its junction with Carver Creek.

label: Falls Lake
description: was built by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers by damming the Neuse River at the community of Falls in Wake County. Provides water supply, recreation, and flood control. Main body of 20 sq. mi. Lake is in Durham and Wake Counties.

label: Falls of Gouges Creek
description: E Mitchell County.

label: Falls of Gunpowder
description: See Granite Falls.

label: Falls of the Neuse
description: rapids in Neuse River, N Wake County near the community of Falls. Name appears on the Price map, 1808.

label: Fallston
description: town in NE Cleveland County. Settled 1885. Inc. 1893, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Alt. 950. Named for John Z. Falls, sheriff of the county when the town was inc. Served by post office, 1886-1940.

label: Fallstown
description: See Bells Cross Roads.

label: Fallstown Township
description: SW Iredell County.

label: False Gap
description: on the Swain County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park between The Sawteeth and Laurel Top.

label: Fancy
description: community in S Cleveland County served by post office, 1883-1902.

label: Fancy Hill
description: See Loray.

label: Fandon
description: community in Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1892-95.

label: Fannie
description: community in central Haywood County served by post office, 1892-1902.

label: Fannie Ridge
description: extends NE from the Henderson county line into S Buncombe County between Cole Cove and Reed Cove.

label: Far Creek
description: See Engelhard.

label: Faraby Island
description: a narrow sandy loam island about 1 mi. long in the mouth of North Landing River, NE Currituck County. Sometimes called Ferebee's Island.

label: Farley Branch
description: rises in N Graham County and flows E into Little Tennessee River.

label: Farley Cove
description: follows the SE course of a small stream flowing into Santeetlah Lake in W central Graham County.

label: Farlow Gap
description: NW Transylvania County between Klesee Creek and Shuck Ridge Creek. Alt. 4,559.

label: Farmer
description: town in W Randolph County. Inc. 1897, but long inactive in municipal affairs. In center of a rich farming community.

label: Farmer Branch
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows NW into Richland Creek.

label: Farmer Top
description: central Cherokee County S of Hiwassee River and NW of Murphy.

label: Farmer's Branch
description: rises in W central Wilson County and flows S into Toisnot Swamp. Named prior to 1770 for Isaac Farmer Sr.

label: Farmers Creek
description: rises in N Yadkin County and flows N into Yadkin River.

label: Farmers Store
description: community in NW Ashe County.

label: Farmers Turnout
description: See Maco.

label: Farmington
description: community in N Davie County. As early as 1805, former residents of Currituck County began to move into the area. Two hurricanes in 1830 and another one in 1839 caused extensive crop damage in the Currituck County area; the population of the county dropped from 7,655 in 1830 to 6,703 in 1840. The community was known as Little Currituck until 1837, when a post office was est. and named Farmington for the fertile farming land there. Alt. 758.

label: Farmington Township
description: NE Davie County.

label: Farmville
description: See Coalglen.

label: Farmville Township
description: W Pitt County.

label: Farnell Bay
description: central Onslow County, is formed by an indentation of the E bank of New River SE of Hadnot Point.

label: Farnell Point
description: central Onslow County on the mouth of Wallace Creek.

label: Farner Branch
description: rises in N Cherokee County and flows W into Cook Creek.

label: Faro
description: community in NE Wayne County near the head of Beaver Branch.

label: Farrar
description: former town in central Edgecombe County on the SW limits of Tarboro and now wholly within Tarboro. The name West Tarboro was changed to Hilma in 1893, when it was inc. Name changed from Hilma to Farrar, 1899, probably for O. C. Farrar, who purchased land in Tarboro for a cotton mill. Charter repealed 1909.

label: Farrars Island
description: in the Cape Fear River at the junction of the Chatham, Harnett, and Lee county lines NW of Buckhorn Falls. Approx. 1½ mi. long. Mentioned as early as 1819 in a survey of the rivers of the state.

label: Farrington
description: community in NE Chatham County. Named for local Fearrington family at the time of the construction of the Durham and Southern Railroad.

label: Fate Puett Cove
description: E Cherokee County on the headwaters of Burl Branch SE of Indian Grave Gap.

label: Faucett Township
description: central Halifax County.

label: Faucette
description: See Calvander.

label: Faucette Township
description: former township in N central Alamance County. Now township no. 5.

label: Faucetts Store
description: community in NW Halifax County.

label: Faulk
description: community in SE Union County.

label: Faulkner Creek
description: rises in NE Surry County and flows SW into Ararat River. Probably named for William Faulkner, an eighteenth-century resident of the county.

label: Faust
description: community in E Madison County on Big Laurel Creek.

label: Fawn Branch
description: rises near Burl Mountain in N central Transylvania County and flows SE into King Creek.

label: Fawn Mountain
description: E Yancey County between Blue Rock Branch and a bend in South Toe River.

label: Fax Creek
description: rises in N Graham County and flows NE into Little Tennessee River.

label: Fayette County
description: was formed in July 1784 when an act of the General Assembly divided Cumberland County into Fayette and Moore Counties. It was intended to honor Marquis de Lafayette (1757-1834), who visited the United States that year. Fayette County retained the courthouse in Fayetteville. In October of the same year, the act was amended to retain the name Cumberland for the county.

label: Fayette District
description: at the time of the 1790 census, was composed of Anson, Cumberland, Moore, Richmond, Robeson, and Sampson Counties and the town of Fayetteville.

label: Fayetteville
description: city and county seat, central Cumberland County at the head of navigation on the Cape Fear River. The first settlement at the site was about 1730. Est. 1762 as Campbellton, named for Farquhard Campbell. In 1778 Campbellton, and the adjacent trading center of Cross Creek, which see, were consolidated as Lower and Upper Campbellton, respectively. Name changed to Fayetteville in 1783 in honor of Marquis de Lafayette (1757-1834), who assisted Americans during the Revolutionary War. The legislature met there 1786, 1788-90, 1793-94. Location of Fayetteville State University and Methodist University. Produces textiles, dairy products, bakery products, machinery, lumber, and soft drinks. Alt. 107. Fort Bragg, which see, is nearby.

label: Featherston Creek
description: rises in N Henderson County and flows SW into Mud Creek.

label: Fed Cove
description: on a tributary of Caler Fork in E Macon County.

label: Fed Gap
description: E Macon County between Fed Cove and Mason Mountain.

label: Federal Point
description: projects from the S tip of New Hanover County between Cape Fear River and the Atlantic Ocean.

label: Federal Point Township
description: S New Hanover County.

label: Feds Branch
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows S into Cane River.

label: Fee Branch
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows SE into Rock Creek.

label: Feeding Ridge
description: N Mitchell County between Cook Branch and Gouges Creek.

label: Feezor
description: community in S Davidson County. Named for local family.

label: Felts
description: community in SE Wilkes County. Named for local family.

label: Fender Mountain
description: peak in the Peach Bottom Mountain range, W Alleghany County. Alt. approx. 3,600.

label: Fenix
description: community in W Cumberland County.

label: Fennimore
description: community in E Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1892-1903. Formerly known as Garrison.

label: Fentress
description: See Pleasant Garden.

label: Fentress Township
description: S central Guilford County. Named for Frederick Fentriss.

label: Ferebee's Island
description: See Faraby Island.

label: Ferguson
description: community in W Wilkes County on Yadkin River. Named for Capt. Lindsay C. Ferguson, a nineteenth-century resident.

label: Ferguson Hill
description: central Yancey County between Pine Swamp Branch, Cane River, and Bowlens Creek.

label: Ferguson Peak
description: on the Buncombe-Henderson county line SE of Hickory Nut Gap.

label: Fern Knob
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Suli Ridge between Jonas Creek and Huggins Creek. Alt. 3,780.

label: Fern Mountain
description: N Jackson County on the NE end of Black Mountain. Alt. 5,200.

label: Ferndale
description: community in E Rockingham County served by post office, 1888-1903.

label: Fernside
description: community in central New Hanover County. Est. 1908 and named for Fernside Fertilizer plant. Alt. 15.

label: Ferrell's Springs Branch
description: rises in NE Wake County and flows SE into Upper Barton's Creek.

label: Ferrells Creek
description: rises in S Orange County and flows S into Chatham County, where it enters Haw River.

label: Ferrells Township
description: SW Nash County.

label: Ferrin Knob
description: on the Buncombe-Henderson county line between Beaverdam and Long Gap.

label: Ferry
description: community in S Rutherford County formerly known as Ferry Store.

label: Ferry Branch
description: rises in W Madison County and flows NE into French Broad River.

label: Fetner
description: community in W Wake County.

label: Few
description: community in S Durham County. Formerly known as Oyama, the name taken from that of a Japanese city; a railroad station opened there about 1904. The name was changed after the attack on Pearl Harbor, December 7, 1941, to honor William P. Few (1867-1940), first president of Duke University.

label: Fiars Creek
description: See Fires Creek.

label: Fiddler Creek
description: rises in S Forsyth County and flows SW into South Fork. Named for Fidler or Fiedler family living in the vicinity by 1777. Appears as James Creek on Collet map, 1770.

label: Fiddlers Run
description: rises in central Burke County and flows N into Sandy Run Creek.

label: Fidelity
description: community in E Jackson County served by post office, 1888-1901.

label: Fie Creek
description: rises in W Haywood County and flows S into Jonathans Creek.

label: Fie Top Mountain
description: W Haywood County. Alt. 5,060. A ski run, Cataloochee, which see, is now operated there.

label: Field Branch
description: rises in W Hoke County on Fort Bragg Military Reservation and flows E into Rockfish Creek. Earlier known as Old Field Branch. Leslies Mill Pond, now drained, was formerly on the creek.

label: Fields
description: community in NW Lenoir County. Alt. 111. Named for a local family.

label: Fieldsboro
description: See Walstonburg.

label: Fifth Creek
description: See Deep Creek.

label: Fig
description: community in W central Ashe County. Alt. approx. 2,880.

label: Figure Eight Island
description: E New Hanover and Pender Counties between Middle Sound and the Atlantic Ocean and extending from Mason Inlet on the S to Rich Inlet on the n. In 1965 work was begun to develop the island into a private gated resort community. A 260-foot causeway and a bridge over the Intracoastal Waterway connect it with the mainland.

label: Fillie Gap
description: NE Buncombe County E of McKinney Gap.

label: Filmore
description: community in W Wilson County.

label: Filo
description: See Biscoe.

label: Finch
description: community in S Nash County served by post office, 1890-1903.

label: Finch Cove
description: E Haywood County on Rush Fork.

label: Finch's Mill Pond
description: W Wilson County on Bloomery Swamp. Formed 1875 and named for owner. Covers 30 acres; max. depth. 10 ft. Fishing, boating. Finch Mill post office, 1898-1901.

label: Fincher Mountain
description: central Haywood County on the head of McElroy Branch.

label: Fincher's Branch
description: rises in NE Orange County and flows S into Buck Quarter Creek. It was named for Jonathan Fincher, who acquired land in the vicinity in 1755.

label: Finchs Crossroads
description: See Denton.

label: Findley Creek
description: rises in central Henderson County and flows NE and S into Perry Creek.

label: Findleysville
description: community in Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1810-34.

label: Fines Creek
description: community in N Haywood County on the creek of the same name. Settled about 1850.

label: Fines Creek Gap
description: NE Haywood County on the head of Fines Creek. Alt. 3,948.

label: Fines Creek Township
description: NE Haywood County.

label: Finger
description: community in W Stanly County.

label: Finger Counties
description: five counties in the NE corner of the state—Chowan, Perquimans, Pasquotank, Camden, and Currituck—whose collective geographical mass resembles digits on a hand.

label: Finley
description: community on the upper waters of the Yadkin River in N Caldwell County. Named for Finley P. Curtis, who was active in securing a post office for the community.

label: Fire Gap Ridge
description: W Macon County between Roaring Fork Creek and Jarrett Creek.

label: Fire Scald Knob
description: SE Alleghany County about 3 mi. SE of Bullhead Mountain.

label: Fire Scald Ridge
description: S Haywood County between West Hollow and West Fork Pigeon River.

label: Fires Creek
description: rises in N Clay County and flows SW into Hiwassee River. Appears as Fiars Creek in the 1861 law establishing the county.

label: Firescald Branch
description: rises in W Yancey County and flows SE into Big Creek.

label: Firescald Creek
description: rises in N McDowell County on the SW slope of Betsy Ridge and flows SW into Slim Creek.

label: Firescald Mountain
description: W Yancey County between Simms Fork and Elk Wallow Creek. Alt. 4,840.

label: Firescald Ridge
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a spur of Welch Ridge extending SE between Jonas Creek and Little Jonas Creek.

label: First Broad River
description: rises in E Rutherford County and flows SE into Cleveland County. There it flows SE and SW into Broad River. Appears on the Collet map, 1770, as Sandy River.

label: First Gum Swamp
description: See Gum Swamp.

label: First Hurricane Branch
description: rises in S Swain County and flows SW into Yalaka Creek.

label: First Potts Creek
description: rises in W Davidson County and flows SE into High Rock Lake on Yadkin River. Appears on the Collet map, 1770, as Potts Creek.

label: Fish Creek
description: rises in W Harnett County and flows NE into Cape Fear River.

label: Fish Dam
description: community in E Durham County served by post office, 1881-1902. Spelled Fishdam after 1895.

label: Fish Hawk Point
description: NE Carteret County extending into Rumley Bay.

label: Fish Ridge
description: N Haywood County, extends S beside Morgan Creek.

label: Fish Trap Creek
description: See Fishdam Creek.

label: Fishcreek
description: See Mamers.

label: Fishdam
description: See Fish Dam.

label: Fishdam Creek
description: rises in W Wilkes County and flows SE into Yadkin River. Known as Fish Trap Creek until the 1960s, when the spillway of one of the flood-control dams in connection with the W. Kerr Scott Dam emptied into it and the name was changed.

label: Fisher
description: community in SW Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1891-92. Earlier known as Kelleyville, which see.

label: Fisher Creek
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows S into Scott Creek.

label: Fisher Lake
description: on a tributary of Watkins Creek in S Macon County.

label: Fisher Peak
description: mountain on the Surry County, N.C.-Carroll County, Va., line. Alt. 3,609.

label: Fisher River
description: rises in Virginia and flows S into Surry County and SE across the county into Yadkin River. Appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Fisher Swamp
description: rises in NE Craven County and flows SW into Little Swift Creek.

label: Fisher's Ford
description: See Cooleemee.

label: Fisherman Bay
description: E Pamlico County in the Bay River estuary.

label: Fisherman Islands
description: two small tidal-marsh islands, E Pamlico County in the Bay River estuary SE of Bay Point.

label: Fishermare Branch
description: rises in N Cherokee County on Fishermare Ridge and flows S into Hyatt Creek.

label: Fishermare Ridge
description: N Cherokee County in the Snowbird Mountains.

label: Fisherville
description: community in S Forsyth County.

label: Fishhawk Mountain
description: S Macon County between Little Fishhawk Mountain and Wolf Rock. Alt. 4,684.

label: Fishing Branch
description: rises in N Person County and flows NW into Marlowe Creek.

label: Fishing Creek
description: rises in S Wilkes County in the Brushy Mountains and flows NE into Yadkin River.

label: Fishing Creek District
description: See Fishing Creek Township.

label: Fishing Creek Township
description: E central Granville County. Fishing Creek District had 59 heads of families in 1790.

label: Fishing Creek Township
description: former township in central Wilkes County, now a part of Wilkesboro Township.

label: Fishprong Branch
description: rises in E Clay County and flows SE into Barnett Creek.

label: Fishton
description: community in W Polk County on Green River.

label: Fishtown
description: See Beaufort.

label: Fishtrap Branch
description: rises in E Swain County and flows NE into Tuckasegee River.

label: Fitch
description: community in S Caswell County, formerly known as Fitch's Store. A post office was operated there, 1876-1926.

label: Fitches Knob
description: SE Wilkes County. Alt. 1,850.

label: Fites Creek
description: rises in E Gaston County and flows SE into Catawba River.

label: Fitts
description: community in N central Warren County. Post office est. in 1895 but discontinued in 1905. Named for the first postmaster, Edward F. Fitts.

label: Fitzgerald
description: community in N Rockingham County served by post office, 1900-1906. Named for Thomas B. Fitzgerald, textile executive and local farmer.

label: Five Comb Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SE and SW into Valley River.

label: Five Forks
description: community in N Yadkin County.

label: Five Mile Branch
description: See Fifth Creek.

label: Five Mile Creek
description: rises in E Robeson County and flows SW into Saddletree Swamp.

label: Five Points
description: community in W Hoke County.

label: Fivemile Branch
description: rises in central Columbus County and flows SE then N into Cedar Branch.

label: Flag Branch
description: rises in SE Union County and flows NE into Rays Fork.

label: Flaggtown
description: community in NW Montgomery County served by post office from 1879 until 1895, when name was changed to Pontop. Area now home to Uwharrie Point Lake and golf course community.

label: Flake
description: community in W Iredell County served by post office, 1900-1905.

label: Flannery Fork [South Fork New River]
description: rises in Moses H. Cone Memorial Park approx. 2 mi. NW of town of Blowing Rock, S Watauga County. It flows W into Trout Lake and then NE to join East Fork and Middle Fork in forming South Fork New River approx. 2 mi. SE of town of Boone.

label: Flat Branch
description: rises in NW Gates County and flows SE through Jones Swamp into Hacklan Branch.

label: Flat Branch
description: See Sweetwater Creek.

label: Flat Branch Gap
description: on the Jackson-Macon county line.

label: Flat Creek
description: rises in NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows SE into Bunches Creek.

label: Flat Creek
description: community in N Buncombe County. Alt. 2,161.

label: Flat Creek Bald
description: NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on the N end of Overlook Ridge. Alt. 5,240.

label: Flat Creek Falls
description: SE Buncombe County on Flat Creek.

label: Flat Creek Township
description: N central Buncombe County.

label: Flat Fork Creek
description: rises in central Anson County and flows N into Brown Creek.

label: Flat Gap
description: on the Jackson-Haywood county line.

label: Flat Knob
description: N Macon County at the head of Rhinehart Creek.

label: Flat Land Branch
description: rises in E central Avery County and flows S into Wilson Creek.

label: Flat Laurel Creek
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows NW into West Fork Pigeon River.

label: Flat Laurel Gap
description: on the Haywood-Transylvania county line between Big Bald and Little Bald Mountain.

label: Flat Mountain
description: SE Macon County between Cullasaja River and Big Creek.

label: Flat River
description: community in NE Durham County served by post office, 1881-1903.

label: Flat River Township
description: S central Person County.

label: Flat Rock
description: mountain in E central Avery County.

label: Flat Rock
description: community in NE Vance County named for large, flat rock in old stage road.

label: Flat Rock Branch
description: rises in N Nash County and flows NE into Swift Creek.

label: Flat Rock Creek
description: rises in SW Wilkes County and flows SE through the corner of Yadkin County and into Iredell County, where it enters Hunting Creek. Sometimes known locally as North Hunting Creek.

label: Flat Shoal Creek
description: rises in S central Stokes County and flows NE into Dan River.

label: Flat Shoal Mountain
description: central Stokes County parallel to Flat Shoal Creek.

label: Flat Shoals
description: community in S central Stokes County.

label: Flat Springs
description: SW Yancey County at the head of Indian Fork.

label: Flat Springs Creek
description: rises in Tennessee and flows E into N Avery County, where it enters Beech Creek.

label: Flat Springs Gap
description: on the Buncombe-Yancey county line between Flat Springs Knob and Big Butt.

label: Flat Springs Knob
description: on the Buncombe-Yancey county line NE of Flat Springs Gap at lat. 35°47'30" N., long. 82°20'30" W. Alt. 5,700-5,800. Sometimes also known as Flattop.

label: Flat Swamp
description: rises in SW Onslow County and flows NW into Pender County, where it enters Shaking Creek.

label: Flat Swamp Creek
description: See Flat Creek.

label: Flat Swamp Mountain
description: a long mountain in S Davidson and E Rowan Counties through which the Yadkin River cut a channel. Geologists indicate that the mountain is the remnant of ancient lava flow.

label: Flat Top
description: mountain knob in central Caldwell County.

label: Flat Top Mountain
description: SE Buncombe County between Trantham Creek and Flat Branch.

label: Flatrock Creek
description: rises in N Franklin County and flows SE into Sandy Creek.

label: Flats
description: a tourist resort and community in SE Macon County near the head of Middle Creek. It is on an elevation that extends SE from Middle Creek in Macon County into Rabun County, Ga.

label: Flats Township
description: S central Macon County.

label: Flatt Creek
description: See Big Flatty Creek.

label: Flatt's Creek
description: See Salmon Creek.

label: Flattop
description: peak in N Yancey County N of Big Creek. Alt. approx. 4,807.

label: Flattop
description: See Flat Springs Knob.

label: Flattop Branch
description: rises in S Watauga County at the SW end of Flattop Mountain and flows SE into Middle Fork [South Fork New River].

label: Flattop Cliffs
description: See Flattop Mountain.

label: Flattop Creek
description: rises in E central Avery County and flows N into Banner Elk Creek.

label: Flattop Mountain
description: See Flat Mountain.

label: Flattop Mountain Branch
description: rises in NW Yancey County and flows W into Tennessee, where it enters Spivey Creek.

label: Flatty Creek
description: See Big Flatty Creek.

label: Flatwood Gap
description: NW Macon County. Alt. 1,475.

label: Flatwoods, The
description: level land at the head of Shoal Creek in SW Henderson County. Settlers moved from nearby mountains into The Flatwoods in late nineteenth century.

label: Flax Creek
description: rises in SW Cherokee County and flows SE into Persimmon Creek.

label: Flay
description: community in W Lincoln County.

label: Flea Branch
description: rises in E Madison County and flows S into Laurel Creek.

label: Flea Mountain
description: central Cherokee County between Dockery and Cook Creeks.

label: Fleaback Mountain
description: S Clay County between Needmore Branch and Hothouse Branch. Alt. 3,165.

label: Fleetwood
description: community in S Ashe County.

label: Fleetwood Point
description: extends from mainland of NE Dare County into Croatan Sound.

label: Fleming's Creek
description: See Raymond's Creek.

label: Flemington
description: See Lake Waccamaw (town).

label: Flemming
description: community in SE Catawba County served by post office, 1875-1907.

label: Fletcher
description: community in N Henderson County. Alt. 2,112. Named for Dr. George W. Fletcher, popular country doctor and surgeon during the Civil War. Est. about 1883 after the railroad was completed. With the development of Fletcher, Shufordsville, approx. 2 mi. n, declined, and the post office there was transferred to Fletcher and the name changed. Produced textiles.

label: Fletcher Branch
description: rises in N Henderson County and flows NW into Cane Creek.

label: Fletcher Creek
description: rises in NW Henderson County and flows se, where it joins Big Creek in forming North Fork.

label: Fletcher Knob
description: W Caldwell County. Named for Reuben Fletcher, Revolutionary soldier.

label: Flint
description: community in W Wake County.

label: Flint Gap
description: NE Graham County between Meetinghouse Mountain and Little Tennessee River.

label: Flint Hill
description: See Scottville.

label: Flint Hill Creek
description: rises in E Rutherford County and flows NE into Cleveland County, where it enters Hinton Creek.

label: Flint Knob
description: SE Buncombe County between Miner and Sam Gaps.

label: Flint Level Branch
description: rises in W Madison County and flows SW into French Broad River.

label: Flint Rock Gap
description: N Macon County near the head of Sugar Cove Creek.

label: Flint Spring Branch
description: rises in N Clay County and flows SE into Fires Creek.

label: Flinty
description: See Newdale.

label: Flinty Gap
description: on the McDowell-Yancey county line between Green Knob and Big Craggy.

label: Flora
description: community in SW Randolph County served by post office, 1883-1914.

label: Floral College
description: community in NW Robeson County. Alt. 193. Named for a woman's college that operated there, 1841-78. One of the earliest colleges for women in the South, it was named for the wildflowers growing in profusion in the area.

label: Florence
description: community in E Pamlico County on Bald Creek. Known earlier as Spring Creek; named for Florence, wife of Stanley Martin, first postmaster.

label: Florian
description: community in central Anson County served by post office, 1893-1904.

label: Flounder Slue Rock
description: two small islands in Pamlico Sound, NE Carteret County N of Portsmouth Island. In 1795 the islands were called Flounder Rocks.

label: Flower Cove
description: S Swain County on the head of Marr Branch.

label: Flower Gap
description: S Haywood County between Nigger Spring and Dina Branch.

label: Flower Hill
description: community in SE Randolph County served by post office, 1877-1907.

label: Flower Knob
description: S Haywood County on the head of Little East Fork Pigeon River.

label: Flowers Gap
description: at the head of Coon Creek in E Macon County.

label: Flowers Swamp
description: rises in E Robeson County and flows SW into Lumber River.

label: Flows Store
description: community in S Cabarrus County named for Daniel W. Flowe, who opened a store there in 1881. Flowe's store, closed about 1925, still stands.

label: Flox
description: community in N Onslow County served by post office, 1891-1907. Formerly Purgatory, served by post office beginning in 1884.

label: Floyd
description: community in SE Cumberland County served by post office, 1889-1907.

label: Floyds Creek
description: rises in S Rutherford County and flows S into Broad River.

label: Fly
description: community in central Montgomery County served by post office, 1889-97.

label: Flynn
description: community in S Moore County served by post office, 1891-1901.

label: Flynn Ridge
description: S Yancey County between Setrock Creek and Whiteside Branch.

label: Fodderstack Mountain
description: See Terrapin Mountain.

label: Folk Hill
description: community in central Rockingham County named for Douglas Foucht, local sawmill owner and farmer, whose home stood on large hill. By 1920s name became Folk Hill.

label: Folkstone
description: community in SW Onslow County. Alt. 69. Believed to have been named by a retired sea captain for his native town in England. Served by post office, 1902-54.

label: Folly Creek
description: rises in W Henderson County and flows NW into Little Willow Creek.

label: Folly Fork
description: community in NE Gates County. Folly post office est. prior to 1828. Frequently in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, the word folly was used in the sense of the French folie (delight; favorite abode) and it formed a part of the name of English estates.

label: Folly Swamp
description: rises in NE Gates County and flows E into Dismal Swamp.

label: Fonta Flora
description: See Flora.

label: Fontana
description: former community in NW Swain County, est. 1902 by employees of Montvale Lumber Co. The site is now covered by the waters of Fontana Lake, which see. Said to have been named by Mrs. George Leidy Wood, wife of an official of the lumber company, because it was "a short word, musical, easy to spell," and it reminded her of "the waterfalls that looked like fountains, leaping from ledge to ledge" in the nearby forest.

label: Fontana Lake
description: N Graham and W and central Swain Counties on Little Tennessee River and its tributaries. Forms the S boundary of the Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Dam begun in 1941, completed in 1945, forms the lake, largest of the Tennessee Valley Authority system. Max. depth 480 ft. The lake, 30 mi. long, has a shoreline of 248 mi. and covers 10,530 acres at full lake. Provides flood control, electric power, and recreation facilities. The dam there is the highest in E America. Alt. 1,710. See also Fontana and Fontana Village.

label: Fontana Village
description: resort community in N Graham County in Welch Cove near Fontana Lake. Alt. 1,800. Built in 1941 as a construction village for the employees of Fontana Dam. After the dam was completed, it was leased to a private corporation for development as a resort. See also Welch Cove.

label: Fontcal
description: See Wagram.

label: Fontena
description: formerly the plantation of the Baker family, located between Little Fishing Creek and Reedy Creek near the community of Grove Hill, S Warren County. The plantation house, no longer standing, was built in 1790 by Judge Blake Baker, attorney general of North Carolina in 1794. In 1816 the library at Fontena was described as the finest in the state.

label: Fonville
description: community in S Harnett County.

label: Footsville
description: community in S Yadkin County near South Deep Creek. Known first as Footville.

label: Forbes
description: community in W Mitchell County on Toe River. Alt. 2,185.

label: Forbes Bay
description: E Pasquotank County between Cottage Point and Cobb Point on the Pasquotank River.

label: Forbes Millpond
description: central Pitt County on Greens Mill Run.

label: Forbush
description: community in central Yadkin County on Logan Creek.

label: Forbush Creek
description: rises in N Yadkin County and flows SE into Logan Creek.

label: Forbush Township
description: SE Yadkin County.

label: Ford Creek
description: rises in SE Granville County and flows NE into W Franklin County, where it enters Tar River.

label: Forest
description: community in central Craven County.

label: Forest City
description: town in S central Rutherford County. Alt. 869. Inc. 1877 as Burnt Chimney; name changed to Forest City in 1887 in honor of Forest Davis, lumber merchant.

label: Forest Grove
description: community in N Watauga County on Forest Grove Creek.

label: Forest Grove Creek
description: rises in N Watauga County and flows SW into Beaverdam Creek.

label: Forest Hill
description: former town in central Cabarrus County. Inc. 1887 but now a part of the city of Concord. Began as a mill settlement in the 1850s and named McDonalds Mill. Later known as Odell Mill and Locke Mills; now the site of Randolph Mill.

label: Forestville
description: community in NE Wake County S of the town of Wake Forest. Inc. 1879; charter repealed 1915.

label: Forge
description: community in E Surry County served by post office, 1888-1903.

label: Forge Knob
description: on the Swain County, N.C.-Blount County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park between Rich Gap and Buck Gap.

label: Forge Mountain
description: NW Henderson County between South Fork Mills River and Boylston Creek in Pisgah National Forest. Alt. 3,280. Granted to Philip Sitton about 1806 as a "forge bounty" where he manufactured iron for many years. Adjoining it was the Gillespie gun works, where long guns were fashioned from Sitton's iron.

label: Fork
description: town in SE Davie County. Inc. 1895 as Fork Church, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Developed around Fork Baptist Church, organized 1793. Alt. 824.

label: Fork Branch
description: rises in N Watauga County on Fork Ridge and flows SW into Little Beaverdam Creek.

label: Fork Church
description: See Fork.

label: Fork Creek
description: rises in S Randolph County and flows SE into Deep River. Appears as Crooked Creek on the Collet map, 1770; as Pork Creek (likely a typographical error) on the Price map, 1808; and as Fork Creek on the MacRae map, 1833.

label: Fork Legged Mountain
description: E Madison County at the head of California Creek.

label: Fork Mountain
description: NW Haywood County N of Conrad Branch in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Alt. approx. 4,000.

label: Fork Mountain
description: S Swain County between Yalaka Creek and Bowers Creek.

label: Fork Mountain Branch
description: rises in central Avery County and flows S into North Toe River.

label: Fork Mountain Township
description: central Mitchell County.

label: Fork Point
description: a peninsula in W Beaufort County between Chocowinity Bay and Pamlico River.

label: Fork Point
description: point of land at the mouth of Bond Creek in SE Beaufort County at Pamlico River.

label: Fork Point Island
description: in Chocowinity Bay, W Beaufort County. Approx. 1/10 mi. long.

label: Fork Ridge
description: between North Fork and Plott Balsams in N Jackson County.

label: Fork Ridge
description: NW Watauga County, begins near head of Little Beaverdam Creek at State Line Gap and extends s, branching SW and SE to form an inverted Y. Highest point is about 4,300 ft.

label: Fork Ridge
description: S Yancey County between Middle Fork Rock Creek and North Fork Rock Creek.

label: Fork River Bald
description: on the Haywood-Transylvania county line at the NW end of Fork River Ridge.

label: Fork River Ridge
description: NW Transylvania County, extends SE from Fork River Bald between Daniel Ridge Creek and Right Fork Davidson River.

label: Fork Swamp
description: rises in central Pitt County and flows S into East Branch.

label: Fork Township
description: W Wayne County. Named for location in fork of Neuse and Little Rivers. Designation has remained unchanged since first listed in 1838.

label: Forkade
description: community in NE Moore County served by post office, 1886-1905.

label: Forked Mountain
description: on the Henderson-Transylvania county line.

label: Forked Ridge
description: W Watauga County, extends NW between Grassy Gap and Beech Creek.

label: Forked Tree Mountain
description: NE Buncombe County between Burleson Branch and North Fork Ivy Creek.

label: Forks of Ivy
description: community on the Buncombe-Madison county line on Ivy Creek. Named for the fact that it is near the junction of Ivy and Little Ivy Creeks. Alt. 1,978.

label: Forks of Pigeon
description: See Canton. Post office operated by the name, 1841-1901.

label: Forks of Tar River
description: See Washington.

label: Former Camp Branch
description: rises in N Madison County and flows S into Big Laurel Creek.

label: Forney
description: former community in W Swain County on Tuckasegee River at the mouth of Forney Creek. Alt. 1,537. The site is now under the waters of Fontana Lake.

label: Forney Creek
description: rises in E Lincoln County and flows SE into Killian Creek. Named for Jacob Forney, pioneer settler of about 1750.

label: Forney Creek
description: rises in N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows SW and S into Tuckasegee River.

label: Forney Ridge
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a lofty spur extending SW from Clingmans Dome between Forney Creek and Noland Creek.

label: Forneys Creek Township
description: NW Swain County.

label: Forrester Ridge
description: NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, extends SE from Blockhouse Mountain to the confluence of Haw Gap Branch and Hazel Creek.

label: Forshee
description: community in S Rockingham County between Troublesome Creek and Little Troublesome Creek. Served by post office, 1900-1917. Named for Annie Forshee, relative of postmaster.

label: Forsyth County
description: was formed in 1849 from Stokes County. In the central part of the state, it is bounded by Guilford, Davidson, Davie, Yadkin, and Stokes Counties. It was named for Col. Benjamin Forsyth (ca. 1760-1814), a native of Stokes County who was killed on the Canadian frontier in the War of 1812. Area: 424 sq. mi. County seat: Winston-Salem, with an elevation of 858 ft. Townships are Abbotts Creek, Belews Creek, Bethania, Broadbay, Clemmonsville, Kernersville, Lewisville, Middle Fork, Old Richmond, Old Town, Salem Chapel, South Forks, Vienna, and Winston. Produces tobacco, wheat, oats, soybeans, blueberries, grapes, corn, poultry, dairy products, livestock, hogs, cigarettes and other tobacco products, hosiery, textiles, bakery products, machinery, fabricated metals, banking services, corrugated boxes, apparel, lumber, and crushed stone. See also Dobbs Parish; Wachovia.

label: Forsyth Creek
description: rises in E central McDowell County and flows SE into Lake James on the Catawba River.

label: Fort Anderson
description: See Brunswick.

label: Fort Barnwell
description: community in NW Craven County. Alt. 40. Settled about 1800. Named for Fort Barnwell, constructed by Col. John Barnwell of South Carolina in a campaign against the Tuscarora Indians in April 1712. Remains of the fort are on a bluff overlooking the Neuse River 2 mi. NE of the community.

label: Fort Bartow
description: Civil War fort on Roanoke Island, Dare County.

label: Fort Benjamin
description: Civil War fort on the Newport River, E Carteret County opposite town of Newport.

label: Fort Bragg
description: NW Cumberland, E Hoke and Moore, and S Harnett Counties. Est. 1918 as Camp Bragg, a U.S. Field Artillery training center; name changed to Fort Bragg in 1922. Named for Gen. Braxton Bragg (1817-76), Confederate commander. Alt. 110. Area, 200 sq. mi. Now headquarters for airborne troops and special operations. Reached a peak of 104,000 men just prior to the North African invasion in World War II. Pope Air Force Base, which see, is adjacent.

label: Fort Branch
description: See Conoho Creek.

label: Fort Butler
description: S Cherokee County, military installation where Gen. Winfield Scott, in command of U.S. forces, gathered Cherokee Indians before moving them west in 1838.

label: Fort Butler Mountain
description: S Cherokee County S of Right Prong Martin Creek and W of Martin Creek. Named for the fort near the present town of Murphy, which see, where Gen. Winfield Scott, in command of U.S. forces, gathered the Cherokee Indians before moving them west in 1838.

label: Fort Caswell
description: on the SE tip of Oak Island in SE Brunswick County. Begun by United States in 1826; seized by North Carolina troops in 1861 and abandoned by Confederates in 1865. Used also in Spanish-American War and both world wars. Well-preserved remains now in Baptist summer camp area.

label: Fort Clark
description: Civil War fort on Cape Hatteras 1 mi. up the beach from Hatteras Inlet. It was laid out by William B. Thompson and construction started about July 1861.

label: Fort Creek
description: rises in NE Caldwell County E of Fort Defiance and flows N into Yadkin River.

label: Fort Creek
description: rises in W Granville County and flows NE into Tar River. Shown on modern maps as Ford Creek.

label: Fort Defiance
description: NE Caldwell County. Home of William Lenoir, leader in Revolutionary War and public affairs; built 1788-92 and stands on site of frontier Fort Defiance.

label: Fort Dobbs
description: See Fort Macon.

label: Fort Fisher
description: State Historic Site and former Confederate fort at the S tip of New Hanover County. Construction began in April 1861 under direction of Capt. Charles P. Bolles, who was soon transferred. The first section of the fort was named Battery Bolles. Upon completion, the fort—constructed of sand, palmetto logs, and railroad iron—was named for Capt. Charles F. Fisher (1816-61), who had been killed at the Battle of First Manassas while commanding North Carolina troops. Fort Fisher controlled the Cape Fear River and kept the port of Wilmington open. The fort was bombarded from the sea on December 23-25, 1864, and January 12-13, 1865. It fell on January 15. During World War II, the site was used in connection with coastal defense. Restoration and development as a State Historic Site began in 1960.

label: Fort Fisher Junction
description: community in S New Hanover County. Prior to 1957, when the name was changed by the county commissioners, the community was known as Monkey Junction because the proprietor of a store there once owned a great many monkeys.

label: Fort Hamby
description: a name applied to a log house fortified in 1865 at the end of the Civil War by deserters from the Union Army. Named for a woman, apparently of evil repute, who formerly owned the house. Located in SW Wilkes County near the mouth of Lewis Fork Creek in Yadkin River, it provided refuge for a band of armed men who robbed and murdered the residents of several counties. A group of local citizens, including a number of former Confederate soldiers, attacked the "fort," set it on fire, and captured a number of the men. Some were shot during the attack and others were tried and sentenced to prison.

label: Fort Hampton
description: See Fort Macon.

label: Fort Hembree
description: See Hayesville.

label: Fort Hill
description: former Confederate batteries on the Pamlico River, E central Beaufort County, which enabled Gen. D. H. Hill's forces to besiege Washington, N.C., in the spring of 1863.

label: Fort Hill
description: a Civil War fort "near Hill's Point" in Buncombe County. The exact location cannot now be determined.

label: Fort Island
description: a large sandy area in Big Pocosin in SW Gates County about 1 mi. N of Chowan River. Named for George Fort.

label: Fort Johnston
description: was located at the present town of Southport, SE Brunswick County. Built 1748-64 and named for Gov. Gabriel Johnston (1699-1752); burned by Whigs, 1775. Rebuilt by U.S. government, 1794-1809. Seized by Confederate forces in 1861 and used in the Civil War. Only the officers’ quarters remain.

label: Fort Lamb
description: small battery below Fort Anderson on Price Creek in SE Brunswick County. Named for Col. William Lamb (1835-1909) of Fort Fisher.

label: Fort Landing
description: NE Tyrrell County at the mouth of Alligator Creek. Believed to be the oldest settlement in Tyrrell County, but date unknown. Said to have been named for an old fort that stood near the Alligator Creek landing. The Price map, 1808, shows Warington at the approx. location. Appears as Port Landing on the MacRae map, 1833, but as Fort Landing on subsequent maps.

label: Fort Lane
description: a Civil War fort, was located 3 mi. SE of New Bern in Craven County.

label: Fort Macon
description: built 1826-34 on the E end of Bogue Banks, S Carteret County, to protect Beaufort Inlet. Replaced the earlier Fort Hampton and Fort Dobbs. Now a state park, est. 1924 on 390 acres. Historical museum maintained inside the brick fort; swimming, fishing, hiking, nature study. Site of Civil War battle.

label: Fort Macon Village
description: part of the Cherry Point Housing Area in SE Craven County. See also Cherry Point.

label: Fort McFadden
description: See Mountain Creek.

label: Fort McGaughey
description: See Westminster.

label: Fort Raleigh
description: NE shore of Roanoke Island, E Dare County. The remains of the earthen fort, constructed in 1585 by Ralph Lane's colony, were reconstructed in 1950 by the National Park Service after extensive archaeological study. Appears on the Collet map, 1770. The Fort Raleigh National Historic Site and the Waterside Theatre—at which Paul Green's symphonic drama, The Lost Colony, has been presented in the summer since 1937—are there. An Elizabethan Garden maintained by the Garden Club of North Carolina and a museum are also nearby.

label: Fort Rollins
description: See Blowing Rock.

label: Fort Run
description: stream, rises in W Greene County and flows NE into Contentnea Creek. Named because an early eighteenth-century Tuscarora Indian fort was located nearby. John Lawson was killed near the head of the stream in 1711.

label: Fort San Juan
description: W Burke County, camp used by Spanish expeditionary force by Juan Pardo. Explorers built fort upon site of Indian village known as Joara or Xuala in January 1567; it was destroyed by Indians, 1568. Archaeological work at what is known as Berry site each summer.

label: Fort Shaw
description: former fort on the beach of Oak Island in SE Brunswick County. Used to protect Confederate blockade-runners moving in close to shore.

label: Fort St. Philip
description: See Brunswick.

label: Fort Thompson
description: Civil War fort, site 5 mi. SE of New Bern on Neuse River in Craven County.

label: Fort Totten
description: one of the forts built around New Bern by Union forces after they took the town in March 1862. Located in S central Craven County.

label: Fortin Island
description: the westernmost of a small group of islands in Core Sound about 3 mi. SE of community of Davis, SE Carteret County.

label: Fortiscue Creek
description: rises in SW Hyde County near Beulah and flows NW into Pungo River.

label: Foscoe
description: community in SW Watauga County on Watauga River. Alt. 2,969.

label: Foster
description: community in SE Person County served by post office, 1892-1910.

label: Foster Cove
description: N Graham County between Carringer Gap and Bee Creek.

label: Foster Creek
description: rises in NE Madison County and flows SW into Big Laurel Creek.

label: Foster Creek Township
description: former township in N central Madison County, now township no. 16.

label: Foster Knob
description: S Macon County between Ash Flat Branch and Rockyface Mountain.

label: Foster Mill Creek
description: rises in NW Henderson County and flows SE into Mills River.

label: Foster Mountain
description: central Polk County N of Columbus. Also called Chocolate Drop Mountain. Alt. 1,500.

label: Foster Ridge
description: S Macon County parallel to Ash Flat Branch.

label: Foster's Mill Creek
description: See Sweeten Creek.

label: Foundry Branch
description: rises in central Granville County and flows SE into Fishing Creek. Named for Hobgood's Foundry, which operated in Oxford during the Civil War.

label: Fountain
description: town in W Pitt County. Settled about 1900 and first known as Reba for the sister of Henry Clark Bridgers, founder of the East Carolina Railway. When a post office was est., the name had to be changed, as another Reba already existed in the state. Inc. 1903; named for Robert Almon Fountain (1878-1962), local merchant.

label: Fountain Fork
description: community in E Edgecombe County.

label: Fountain Hill
description: community in N Lenoir County on Contentnea Creek. Named for a local family, the first member of which, Francis Fountain, settled in the vicinity prior to 1769.

label: Fountain Park
description: community on Hickory Nut Creek in NE Henderson County.

label: Fountain Township
description: W Pitt County.

label: Fountainshead
description: town inc. 1818 and authorized to be laid out on the Pee Dee River in Anson County on the lands of John and James Permenter, 11 mi. E of Wadesboro. No evidence exists that the town was est. See also Permetter Creek.

label: Four Corners
description: community in NW Davie County. In 1924-25 a gasoline station and a grocery store were built at the rural crossroad, which was given the name by the owners.

label: Four Diamond Ridge
description: mountain in NE Avery County.

label: Four Forks
description: community in central Pasquotank County.

label: Four Oaks
description: town in W Johnston County. Settled about 1885; inc. 1889. Named for four oaks growing from the stump of a tree that had been cut down in an opossum hunt in the yard of K. L. Barbour, first to build a house there. Alt. 208.

label: Fourmile Branch
description: rises in central Davidson County and flows S into Flat Swamp Creek.

label: Fourmile Creek
description: rises in SE Mecklenburg County and flows SW into McAlpine Creek.

label: Fourth Creek
description: rises in W Iredell County and flows E into Rowan County, where Third and Fourth Creeks join before entering South Yadkin River. It is the fourth creek in a series of creeks crossed by early settlers from Salisbury. The name appears on the Collet map, 1770. A settlement on the creek about 1750 later became the city of Statesville, which grew up around Fourth Creek (Presbyterian) Church.

label: Fourway
description: community in S Greene County. Community took the name of a filling station built there in the late 1920s or early 1930s.

label: Foust's Creek
description: See Moulder Branch.

label: Foust's Mill
description: See Coleridge.

label: Fowler Bend
description: formerly a sharp bend in Hiwasee River in W central Cherokee County, now a peninsula extending into Hiwassee Lake.

label: Fowler Cove
description: in N Swain County on the head of North Fork [Chambers Creek].

label: Fowler Creek
description: rises in SW Jackson County between Terrapin Mountain and Coldside Mountain and flows S 4 mi. into Chattooga River at the county line.

label: Fowlers Mill Creek
description: rises in E Wake County and flows E into Little River.

label: Fox Branch
description: rises in NW Swain County and flows SE into Lake Cheoah.

label: Fox Cabin Gap
description: on the Madison County, N.C.-Greene County, Tenn., line.

label: Fox Creek
description: rises in E Madison County and flows S into Laurel Creek.

label: Fox Creek
description: rises in W Yancey County and flows SE into Bald Creek.

label: Fox Gap
description: NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Twentymile Ridge between the head of Fox Branch and Hamilton Hollow.

label: Fox Grape Branch
