description: rises in NE Brunswick County and flows W into Columbus County, where it enters Dams Creek.

label: Fox Island Falls
description: See Foxes Island.

label: Fox Knob
description: NW Yadkin County at the NE end of the Brushy Mountains. Alt. 1,590. Also known as Star Peak.

label: Fox Mountain
description: central Polk County NE of Columbus. Alt. 1,500.

label: Fox's Mountain
description: NW Iredell County. Named for Fox family, owners in twentieth century. Formerly known as Shumaker Mountain for early settlers. In the mid-twentieth century, "an authentic Western town" called Love Valley was constructed on the S side of the mountain.

label: Foxes Island
description: central Harnett County in Cape Fear River NW of Lillington. Mentioned in Fulton's survey of North Carolina rivers in 1819 and appears on the MacRae map, 1833. A series of low falls or rapids there, known as Fox Island Falls, drop between 5 and 10 ft. over a distance of about a quarter of a mile.

label: Foxtown Mountain
description: W Madison County between Baltimore Branch and Spring Creek.

label: Foxville
description: community in W Buncombe County served by post office, 1880-96.

label: Foys Creek
description: rises in S Pender County and flows S into Topsail Sound.

label: Fradey Mountain
description: S Buncombe County between Ducker and Blake Mountains.

label: Frady Creek
description: rises in E Jackson County and flows SE into Chastine Creek.

label: Fraley Branch
description: See Curl Tail Creek.

label: Francis Cove
description: in S Haywood County on the head of Raccoon Creek.

label: Francisco
description: community in N Stokes County between Big Creek and Dan River.

label: Francktown
description: See Franktown.

label: Frank
description: community in W Avery County. Said to have been named prior to 1901 for a post office official.

label: Frank Mountain
description: S Henderson County near the South Carolina state line. Formerly known as Gau Mountain.

label: Franklin
description: a state organized in December 1784 in what had been the western territory of North Carolina. The area had been ceded by the state to the federal government briefly, but the act of cession was repealed. During the period, residents of the area organized the State of Franklin, and it was not until 1789 that North Carolina was able to reestablish jurisdiction over the area, the State of Franklin having collapsed the previous year. The area was again (and finally) ceded in 1789, and the state of Tennessee, admitted to the Union in 1796, was formed from it. See also Watauga Settlement; District of Washington.

label: Franklin
description: community in N Rowan County est. about 1828 as Franklinville, named for Benjamin Franklin. Named changed to Franklin in 1884.

label: Franklin Branch
description: rises in W Caldwell County and flows S into Johns River near the town of Collettsville.

label: Franklin County
description: was formed in 1779 from Bute County, which see, when that county was divided to form Franklin and Warren Counties. Located in the NE section of the state, it is bounded by Nash, Wake, Granville, Vance, and Warren Counties. It was named for Benjamin Franklin (1706-90). Area: 494 sq. mi. County seat: Louisburg, with an elevation of 280 ft. Townships, now numbered 1 to 10, were formerly Dunn, Harris, Youngsville, Franklinton, Hayesville, Sandy Creek, Gold Mine, Cedar Rock, Cypress Creek, and Louisburg. Produces corn, wheat, oats, tobacco, Irish potatoes, hogs, livestock, marble, aluminum products, pharmaceuticals, electronics, lumber, and fabricated metals.

label: Franklin Gap
description: SW Cherokee County S of Franklin Mountain.

label: Franklin Mountain
description: SW Cherokee County between Hothouse Branch and Wolf Creek.

label: Franklin Spring
description: former resort in NW Person County. Flourished in the early twentieth century. Mineral water bottled and sold.

label: Franklin Township
description: S Sampson County.

label: Franklin Township
description: NW Surry County.

label: Franklinsville
description: See Franklinville.

label: Franklinsville Township
description: E central Randolph County.

label: Franklinton
description: town in W Franklin County. Alt. 432. Est. in 1839 as Franklin Depot on land of Shemuel Kearney. Name changed to Franklinton in 1842, when it was inc. Produced textiles.

label: Franklinton Township
description: former township in W Franklin County, now township no. 4.

label: Franklinville
description: See Franklin.

label: Franks Creek
description: rises in E Graham County and flows SW between Franks Creek Lead and Bert Creek Lead into Tulula Creek.

label: Franks Creek Lead
description: follows the course of Franks Creek in E Graham County.

label: Franks Ferry
description: See Mill Creek.

label: Franktown
description: community in NW Onslow County between Jenkins Swamp and Juniper Swamp. Formerly called Francktown for the Franck family, which owned much land in the area.

label: Frankum Branch
description: rises in S Cherokee County on Poor House Mountain and flows SE into Ricks Branch.

label: Frankum's Creek
description: rises in NW Caldwell County and flows S into Mulberry Creek.

label: Fray Creek
description: See Fryes Creek.

label: Frazier Creek
description: rises in E central Forsyth County and flows SW into Brush Fork Branch E of Winston-Salem.

label: Fraziers
description: See Progress.

label: Fraziers Creek
description: on the W end of Bogue Banks, SW Carteret County, flows W into Bogue Inlet.

label: Fraziers Crossroads
description: community in S Hertford County.

label: Frederick
description: community in W Wilson County. Post office, 1894-95.

label: Fredericktown
description: See Bethany.

label: Freedom Hill
description: See Princeville.

label: Freeland
description: community in NW Brunswick County.

label: Freeman
description: community in NE Columbus County. Believed to have been named for free blacks living in the area before the Civil War.

label: Freeman Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows S into Beaver Creek.

label: Freeman Creek
description: rises in S Henderson County and flows SE into Edith Lake.

label: Freeman Knob
description: N Cherokee County in the Unicoi Mountains.

label: Freeman's Channel
description: in the tidal marshes of Brown's Sound in S Onslow County.

label: Freeman's Cross Roads
description: See Ether.

label: Freeman's Mills
description: community in S Guilford County served by post office, 1870-1904.

label: Freemans Creek
description: rises in E Onslow County and flows NE into White Oak River.

label: Freemans Township
description: See Youngsville Township.

label: Freemason Creek
description: rises in S Caldwell and flows S into Catawba River.

label: Fremont
description: town in N Wayne County. Inc. 1867 as Nahunta; name changed, 1869. Settled prior to 1830 and known as Narhantes and Torhunta. Named Fremont in honor of Col. S. L. Fremont, chief engineer of Wilmington and Weldon Railroad. Birthplace of Gov. Charles B. Aycock (1859-1912), 1 mi. s, has been restored as a State Historic Site. Alt. 152.

label: French Branch
description: rises in central Jones County and flows N into Trent River.

label: French Broad River
description: is formed in S Transylvania County near Rosman by the junction of North Fork and West Fork. It flows NE in Transylvania and into Henderson County, where it turns NW to flow through Buncombe and Madison Counties into Tennessee. From the state line, it flows W 102 mi. to join Holston River near Knoxville to form Tennessee River. One of the Cherokee names was Tah-keeos-tee (racing waters). Others, frequently for only a part of the river, were Poe-li-co, Agiqua, and Zillicoah. Known by the English at first as Broad River and appears as such on the De Brahm manuscript map of Indian Nations in the Southern Department, 1766. By 1776 the present name was in use. Named because much of the territory that it drained W of the Blue Ridge was held by the French in the eighteenth century.

label: French Broad Township
description: NW Buncombe County.

label: Frenchmans Creek
description: See Frenchs Creek.

label: Frenchs Creek
description: rises in SE Onslow County and flows NW into New River opposite Rhodes Point. Appears as Frenchmans Creek in local records as early as 1744. Took its name from the fact that Alexander Nicola, a Frenchman, settled near its mouth.

label: Frenchs Creek Township
description: SE Bladen County.

label: Fresh Pond Hill
description: a sand hill near Wash Woods 4 mi. S of the Virginia state line on Currituck Banks, NE Currituck County.

label: Freydeck
description: term used by Moravians to describe "area across the Blue Mountains on New River," likely the present Watauga-Wilkes County area. By the account in Bishop Augustus Spangenberg's diary (1752), "it is very lonesome, not one man lives there." From the German freideck, meaning blank slate. Appears on the Bellin map, 1757.

label: Friar Swamp
description: rises in N Columbus County and flows SW into Lake Waccamaw.

label: Friars Cove
description: SE Buncombe County between High Hickory Ridge and Eskridge Cove.

label: Friday Shoals
description: in South Fork Catawba River, N Gaston County near Hardin. Named for Capt. Nicholas Friday, who settled there about 1760. The court for newly established Lincoln County met at his house in 1783 and 1784.

label: Friedberg
description: community in N Davidson County served by post office, first in 1860 and later from 1893 to 1903.

label: Friedland
description: community in S Forsyth County. Settled 1770 by Moravian families from Broadbay, Mass., now Waldoboro, Maine. Name, in German, means "land of peace."

label: Friendship
description: community in W Duplin County.

label: Friendship
description: community in NE Yadkin County near Yadkin River.

label: Friendship Township
description: W central Guilford County.

label: Fries Creek
description: rises in NW Forsyth County and flows SW into Yadkin River.

label: Friezeland
description: community in S Madison County served by post office, 1886-1905.

label: Friezeland Creek
description: rises in S Madison County and flows NW into Spring Creek.

label: Frisbee Branch
description: rises in S Swain County and flows SW into De Hart Branch.

label: Frisco
description: community on Hatteras Island SW of Buxton, SE Dare County. Known first as Trent, but post office est. in 1898 was named Frisco, perhaps to avoid confusion with Trenton, Jones County. In 1795 three sand hills known as Stowe's Hills were described there. Later the name Creed's Hill was applied to a single large sand hill S of Frisco.

label: Frog Creek
description: rises in N Rutherford County and flows S into Camp Creek.

label: Frog Level
description: See Oakland.

label: Frog Level Swamp
description: SW Bertie County.

label: Frog Mountain
description: on Lower Trail Ridge in SW Macon County.

label: Frog Pond
description: community in E Cherokee County N of Peachtree.

label: Frogsboro
description: community in E Caswell County.

label: Frogtown
description: community in N Moore County.

label: Frohock Mill
description: See Grants Creek; Macay's Mill.

label: Frohock Sawmill
description: appears on the Collet map, 1770, as being near the mouth of Hunting Creek in present W Davie County. Undoubtedly owned by John Frohock (d. 1772), colonial official.

label: Frolictown Creek
description: rises in SE Jackson County and flows NE into Panthertown Creek.

label: Frost Mill Creek
description: rises in N Davie County and flows E into Dutchmans Creek. Formerly known as Sweet Creek, and as such appears in numerous early local records.

label: Frost's Iron Works
description: former community in SW Stokes County. A post office from 1829 to 1836; iron foundry flourished there about 1850-60.

label: Frosty Knob
description: mountain in W central Buncombe County. Alt. 4,576.

label: Frozea Creek
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows sw, then SE into Toxaway Creek.

label: Frozen Knob
description: in S Transylvania County E of Frozen Creek.

label: Frozen Lake
description: S Transylvania County on Frozen Creek.

label: Frozenhead Ridge
description: W Watauga County, extends SE from the head of East Fork [Cove Creek] to Cove Creek, S of George Gap Branch.

label: Fruit Ridge
description: community in central Columbus County between Whiteville and Chadbourn.

label: Fruitland
description: See Pores Knob.

label: Fruitville Township
description: NE Currituck County.

label: Fry
description: former community in W Swain County on Nantahala River. Site now under the waters of Fontana Lake.

label: Fry Mountain
description: in E Swain County at the NE end of Buckhorn Ridge.

label: Fryes Creek
description: rises in N Davidson County and flows NW into Muddy Creek. Appears on the Collet map, 1770, as Fray Creek.

label: Frying Pan Creek
description: a bay on the N side of Pamlico River, E Beaufort County.

label: Frying Pan Landing
description: E Tyrrell County on The Frying Pan.

label: Frying Pan Shoals
description: in the Atlantic Ocean immediately off Cape Fear, the S tip of New Hanover County. Appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Frying Pan, The
description: E Tyrrell County, is a large body of water roughly shaped like a frying pan. It flows SE into Alligator River. Appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Fryingpan Bend
description: in Roanoke River in N Martin County.

label: Fryingpan Gap
description: on the Haywood-Transylvania county line. Said to be so named because a frying pan was left there at a common camping ground for the use of all comers.

label: Fryingpan Mountain
description: in Haywood and Transylvania Counties. Part of Pisgah Ridge, N of Beech Knob in Pisgah National Forest.

label: Fuda Creek
description: rises in SE Mecklenburg County and flows NE into Cabarrus County, where it enters Back Creek. Said locally to be named for a Scottish word, sometimes spelled "foody," meaning "slightly crazy."

label: Fulbright Cove
description: central Haywood County 1 mi. N of Lake Junaluska.

label: Fulcher Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows W into Little Tennessee River.

label: Fulcher Landing
description: S Onslow County on New River, now the principal landing at the community of Sneads Ferry, which see.

label: Fulcher Mountain
description: N Surry County between Fisher River and Buck Mountain.

label: Fulchers Creek
description: a stream about 1 mi. long flowing SE into Core Sound about midway between Nelson Bay and Brett Bay, E Carteret County.

label: Fulchertown
description: community in S Macon County on Fulcher Branch.

label: Fulford
description: community in SW Brunswick County.

label: Fulford Point
description: peninsula extending off the NW side of Goose Creek Island into Goose Creek estuary, NE Pamlico County.

label: Fulk Creek
description: rises in SE Stokes County and flows SE into Dan River.

label: Fullard Creek
description: rises in S Onslow County and flows SE into Chadwick Bay. Named for Thomas Fulwood or Fullwood, an early settler. Mentioned in local records as early as 1748.

label: Fuller's Creek
description: rises in SW Caswell County and flows N into Moon Creek.

label: Fullwood
description: or See Matthews.

label: Fulmore
description: community in central Robeson County served by post office, 1880-1902.

label: Fulp
description: community in N Forsyth County and S Stokes County.

label: Fulp Creek
description: rises in NE Forsyth County and flows N into Redbank Creek.

label: Fulton
description: a small community in E Davie County on the Yadkin River. Inc. 1819, but active only a short time in municipal affairs, if at all. Site laid off in town lots when attempts were made to improve navigation on the Yadkin River. Post office est. 1822. Probably named for Hamilton Fulton (d. 1834), state engineer, who was employed in connection with many internal-improvement projects. A native of England, Fulton arrived in North Carolina in July 1819.

label: Fulton Township
description: SE Davie County.

label: Funnel Top
description: a peak in W central Graham County between Santeetlah Gap and Santeetlah Lake. Alt. approx. 3,200.

label: Funneltop Mountain
description: in N Transylvania County between Billy Branch and Shooting Ridge.

label: Funston
description: community in E central Brunswick County.

label: Fuquay Springs
description: See Fuquay-Varina.

label: Fuquay-Varina
description: town in SW Wake County N of Harnett County line. Settled prior to 1860. Inc. 1909 as Fuquay Springs, taking its name from David and Stephen Fuquay, early settlers. In 1963 merged with nearby town of Varina, which see, and assumed its present name. Produces tobacco, electronics equipment, apparel, and dairy products. Alt. 350.

label: Fur Creek
description: See Far Creek.

label: Furches
description: community on the Alleghany-Ashe county line.

label: Furniss Mine
description: adjoins the Phoenix Mine property in E Cabarrus County about 8 mi. SE of city of Concord. Former gold mine (late 1800s). Extensive underground exploration in 1954-56 for tungsten.

label: Furr City
description: See Oakboro.

label: Furr Township
description: SW Stanly County.

label: Furrs
description: community in SE Cabarrus County.

label: Futches Creek
description: rises in NE New Hanover County and flows SE into Topsail Sound.

label: G. Newby's Ferry
description: See Belvidere.

label: Gabby Branch
description: rises in N Cherokee County and flows SW into Colvard Creek.

label: Gabes Branch
description: rises in S Nash County and flows NE into Henry Branch. Mentioned in local records as early as 1779.

label: Gabes Mountain Branch
description: rises in E central Avery County and flows S into Wilson Creek.

label: Gabourel's Bluff
description: was a name applied to an area on the W side of Cape Fear River in present NE Brunswick County. At one time, it was the property of Joshua Gabourel, attorney and a justice of the peace in New Hanover County in 1736. Known as Partridge's Bluff prior to 1735.

label: Gabriels Creek
description: rises in E Madison County and flows SW into Ivy River.

label: Gadd Creek
description: rises in W Polk County and flows S into Green River.

label: Gaddis Branch
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows N into Jonathans Creek.

label: Gaddy Township
description: S Robeson County.

label: Gaddy's Goose Pond
description: N central Anson County near Ansonville. Est. 1934 by Lockhart Gaddy when 9 geese were offered winter protection and food. Thousands of geese now winter there.

label: Gaddysville
description: community in SW Robeson County.

label: Gage
description: community in N Rutherford County served by post office, 1898-1908.

label: Gage Bald
description: on Rich Mountain in E Jackson County on the head of Gage Creek. Alt. 5,800.

label: Gage Creek
description: rises in E Jackson County and flows SE into Wolf Creek.

label: Gailors Hammock
description: See Gaylords Island.

label: Gaither
description: community in S McDowell County served by post office, 1891-95.

label: Galamore Branch
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows S into Raven Fork.

label: Galatia
description: community in N Northampton County.

label: Galbreath Creek
description: rises in E Swain County and flows S into Tuckasegee River.

label: Gale
description: community in central Ashe County served by post office, 1898-1921.

label: Gale Creek
description: rises in NW Pamlico County and flows SE into Bay River. A part of the Intracoastal Waterway.

label: Gales Creek
description: rises in W Carteret County and flows S into Bogue Sound. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733. Probably named for Christopher Gale (1680-1734).

label: Gallagans
description: community in N Madison County.

label: Gallant Point
description: a point of land in S Carteret County extending into the mouth of Newport River. Separated from Beaufort by Town Creek.

label: Gallants Channel
description: in the mouth of Newport River, central Carteret County. Named for John Galland, an early settler, but in pronunciation the d became a t Frontage property of North Carolina Maritime Museum.

label: Gallatin
description: See Graham.

label: Gallberry Swamp
description: rises on the Cumberland-Robeson county line and flows SE to join Big Marsh Swamp in forming Big Swamp.

label: Galloway
description: community in S Transylvania County on Toxaway Creek.

label: Galloway Creek
description: See West Prong [Glady Fork].

label: Galloway Crossroads
description: community in E Pitt County.

label: Galloway Mountain
description: S Clay County between Shooting Creek and the Georgia state line.

label: Gallows Branch, The
description: rises in Salisbury, E Rowan County, and flows W into Grant Creek. Named for the fact that the early site of public hangings for Rowan County was nearby.

label: Gambrick Branch
description: rises in NW Burke County and flows E into Linville River.

label: Gamewell
description: community in SW Caldwell County. Alt. 1,078. Named for Gamewell Tuttle, a Methodist circuit rider who was in the area about 1840.

label: Gander Mountain
description: See Mount Bolus.

label: Ganders Fork
description: community in E Duplin County.

label: Gannaway
description: community in SW Caswell County. A post office operated there during the approx. period 1890-1905.

label: Gant Inlet
description: See Gunt Inlet.

label: Gants
description: community in SW Rockingham County served by post office, 1888-92.

label: Gap
description: community in W Stokes County at the head of East Prong Little Yadkin River.

label: Gap Bay
description: boggy area on the Pender-Sampson county line SE of Newtons Crossroads. See also Carolina Bays.

label: Gap Civil Township
description: N central Alleghany County. Training camps were located there during the early months of the Civil War. See also Sparta.

label: Gap Creek
description: See Deep Gap Creek.

label: Gap Point
description: SE Hyde County, extends into Pamlico Sound from the SE end of Ocracoke Island.

label: Gapway Swamp
description: rises in SW Columbus County and flows NW into South Carolina, where it enters Lumber River.

label: Gar Creek
description: rises in NW Mecklenburg County and flows SW into Catawba River.

label: Gar Gut
description: rises in E Beaufort County and flows S into Pamlico River.

label: Garbacon Creek
description: rises in N Carteret County and flows N into Neuse River.

label: Garden City
description: See Pleasant Gardens.

label: Garden Creek
description: rises in N Wilkes County in Doughton Park and flows E into East Prong Roaring River.

label: Garden Farm
description: See Garden Creek.

label: Garden Hill
description: former community in S Guilford County S of Sedgefield near Groometown. Site of Gardiner Hill Gold Mine. Both the community and the mine were deserted after the 1849 gold rush in California.

label: Garden Township
description: E Wilson County. Named for Jack Gardner, prominent local merchant in the mid-nineteenth century.

label: Gardner's Branc
description: rises in E Wilson County and flows N into Town Creek.

label: Gardners Creek
description: rises in E Martin County and flows NE into Devils Gut.

label: Gardnerville
description: community in S Pitt County.

label: Garfield
description: community in SE Rowan County served by post office, 1880-1913.

label: Gargales Creek
description: See Muddy Creek.

label: Garland
description: town in SW Sampson County. Settled about 1888; inc. 1907. Named for Augustus Hill Garland (1832-99), attorney general of the United States, 1885-89. Known earlier as Sloan's Crossing. Alt. 137.

label: Garland Creek
description: rises in SW Cherokee County and flows SE into Rapier Mill Creek.

label: Garland Gap
description: central Mitchell County on Pumpkin Patch Mountain.

label: Garlington's Island
description: a spur of high land containing approx. 250 acres extending from the center of Camden County through North River Pocosin to a point on Crooked Creek 2 mi. from North River. Named because it was the site of the home of Capt. James S. Garlington, commander of two companies raised for service in the War of 1812. Also known as Garrenton's Island.

label: Garner
description: town in S Wake County. Settled about 1800. Inc. 1883 as Garner's Station, named for founder, H. C. Garner. Charter repealed 1891; reincorporated in 1905 as Garner.

label: Garner Branch
description: rises in E Davidson County a short distance N of Denton and flows S into Yadkin River.

label: Garner Cove
description: S Haywood County on the head of Raccoon Creek.

label: Garner's Ford
description: community in NE Rutherford County served by post office, 1828-1933.

label: Garner's Station
description: See Garner.

label: Garners Store
description: community on the Randolph-Moore county line.

label: Garnett
description: community in W Rutherford County served by post office, 1884-96.

label: Garr Island
description: in the waters of Pamlico Sound off the N tip of Pea Island, E Dare County.

label: Garreck Creek
description: rises in N Cherokee County and flows SE and SW into Beaverdam Creek.

label: Garren Branch
description: See Gerren Branch.

label: Garren Creek
description: rises in SE Buncombe County and flows NW into Cane Creek.

label: Garren Mountain
description: N Henderson County between Bank Mountain and Sand Flat Mountain.

label: Garrenton's Island
description: See Garlington's Island.

label: Garrett Creek
description: rises in central Haywood County and flows NW into Jonathans Creek. Named for W. G. B. Garrett (ca. 1845-1925), who owned land and had a ranger's cabin there.

label: Garretts Gap
description: W Haywood County, Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°32'55" N., long. 83°08'25" W. on Cataloochee Divide.

label: Garringer Branch
description: rises in SE Cherokee County and flows SE into Little Brasstown Creek.

label: Garrison
description: See Fennimore.

label: Garrison Branch
description: rises in W Macon County and flows SW into Nantahala Lake.

label: Garrison Point
description: point of land on the S side of Pamlico River, central Beaufort County near the mouth of Durham Creek. A fort or garrison was erected there in 1711 during the Tuscarora War. See also Durham Creek.

label: Garysburg
description: town in W Northampton County. Inc. 1891. Known as Garys in 1833 but changed to Garysburg after the post office there received the name in 1838. Alt. 145. Peebles Tavern and Blakely's Depot were nearby communities in the early nineteenth century, but they were supplanted by Garysburg. Strategically important during Civil War as convergence of two railroads. Site of Camp Beauregard, which see.

label: Gash Creek
description: rises in E Transylvania County and flows SE into French Broad River.

label: Gashes Creek
description: rises in central Buncombe County and flows NW into Swannanoa River.

label: Gasters Creek
description: rises in S Lee County and flows SE into Little River.

label: Gaston
description: town in NW Northampton County on Roanoke River. Inc. 1949, at which time the name was changed from Camp's Store. Named for the township and for the old town of Gaston, the site of which is about 5 mi. w.

label: Gaston County
description: was formed in 1846 from Lincoln County. Located in the SW section of the state, it is bounded by the state of South Carolina and by Cleveland, Lincoln, and Mecklenburg Counties. It was named for William Gaston (1778-1844), a member of Congress and a judge of the Supreme Court of North Carolina. Area: 363 sq. mi. County seat: Gastonia, with an elevation of 825 ft. Townships are Cherryville, Crowell Mountain, Dallas, Gastonia, River Bend, and South Point. Produces corn, wheat, oats, hay, soybeans, air filters, trucking, nursery products, poultry, hogs, livestock, textiles, hosiery, machinery, corrugated boxes, chemicals, motor-vehicle parts, crushed stone, mica, and sand.

label: Gaston Township
description: NW Northampton County.

label: Gastonia
description: city and county seat, central Gaston County. Inc. 1877 and named for the county in which it was located. Replaced Dallas as the county seat, 1909. Produces textiles, hosiery, machinery, corrugated boxes, electronic components, apparel, and motor-vehicle parts. Gaston College, est. 1964, is there. Alt. 825.

label: Gastonia Township
description: S central Gaston County.

label: Gates
description: community in N Gates County. Alt. 73.

label: Gates County
description: was formed in 1779 from Chowan, Hertford, and Perquimans Counties. Located in the NE section of the state, it is bounded by Camden, Pasquotank, Perquimans, Chowan, and Hertford Counties and the state of Virginia. It was named for Gen. Horatio Gates (1728?-1806), commander of Revolutionary forces that defeated Burgoyne at Saratoga, October 1777. Area: 349 sq. mi. County seat: Gatesville, with an elevation of 40 ft. Townships are Gatesville, Hall, Haslett, Holly Grove, Hunters Mill, Mintonsville, and Reynoldson. The area was explored in 1622 by John Pory, who came down from Jamestown, Va. Produces peanuts, corn, soybeans, cotton, hogs, wood products, and lumber.

label: Gates Courthouse
description: See Gatesville.

label: Gatesville
description: town and county seat in central Gates County. Alt. 40. Inc. 1830. Known originally as Bennetts Creek Landing and as Gates Courthouse from 1779 until 1830.

label: Gatesville Township
description: central Gates County.

label: Gatewood
description: community in NW Caswell County, named for J. M. Gatewood, local resident. A post office operated there, 1884-1907.

label: Gath
description: See White Cross.

label: Gatlington
description: community in NW Gates County on Chowan River. Beach there is a popular picnic area, and boat races are held on the river. Prior to the Civil War, known as Lumberton and center for the manufacture of barrel staves and sawed lumber to be shipped down the river.

label: Gau Mountain
description: See Frank Mountain.

label: Gay
description: community in W Jackson County on Savannah Creek.

label: Gaylord
description: community in E Beaufort County.

label: Gaylords Hammock
description: See Gaylords Island.

label: Gaylords Island
description: high ground in Pantego Swamp, E Beaufort County. Known as Gaylords Hammock (also spelled Gailors Hammock) as early as 1754.

label: Gaylors Branch
description: rises in W Transylvania County between Indian Creek and Shoal Creek and flows S about 1 mi. to empty into Indian Creek just above its junction with Shoal Creek.

label: Gela
description: community in N Granville County. Alt. 483.

label: Gem
description: community in NW Buncombe County served by post office, 1886-1929.

label: Gem Creek
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows SE into Little Pine Creek.

label: General Assembly
description: has met in the following places, which see. Bath, Edenton, Fayetteville, Halifax, Halls Creek, Hillsborough, Little River, New Bern, Perquimans County, Raleigh, Smithfield, Tarboro, Wake Court House (Raleigh), and Wilmington. It may also have met at other places, but many records of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries have not survived.

label: Geneva
description: community in S Rockingham County served by post office, 1888-1902.

label: Genlee
description: community in S Durham County. Formerly known as Togo, the name of a Japanese city given the community when a railroad station opened there about 1904. The name was changed after the attack on Pearl Harbor, December 7, 1941, to honor Gen. Robert E. Lee. Produces bricks.

label: Genoa
description: community in S central Wayne County. Named for Genoa, Italy, the birthplace of Christopher Columbus.

label: Gentry
description: community in SW Rockingham County served by post office, 1886-1903. Named for first postmaster.

label: Gentry Branch
description: rises in N Buncombe County and flows NW into Adkins Branch.

label: Gentry Gap
description: N Buncombe County between Bill Cole and Lankford Mountains.

label: Gentrys Store
description: community in N Person County.

label: Geographic Center
description: of North Carolina has been determined by the Geological Survey, U.S. Department of the Interior, to be in Chatham County, 10 mi. NW of Sanford. See also Gulf.

label: George
description: community in E Northampton County, approx. 1 mi. SW of Woodland. Named for a local citizen, George Harrison Parker. Former post office was George; railroad station was Woodland Station.

label: George Branch
description: rises in W central Watauga County and flows SW into Brushy Fork.

label: George City
description: proposed provincial capital in what is now NE Lenoir County near Kinston. Authorized to be laid out in 1758 at Tower Hill, which see, but its establishment was not approved by officials in London. The name was intended to honor King George II.

label: George Creek
description: rises in S Cherokee County and flows NE into Martin Creek.

label: George Fork
description: rises in E Yancey County and flows N into Little Crabtree Creek.

label: George Gap
description: W Watauga County on the head of George Gap Branch.

label: George Gap Branch
description: rises in W Watauga County and flows SE into Cove Creek.

label: George Ira Creek
description: rises in W Haywood County and flows NE into Woody Creek.

label: George Martin Branch
description: rises in E Cherokee County and flows NW into Valley River.

label: George Orr Mountain
description: E Transylvania County, extends NE from the head of Boylston Creek to Bryson Creek. Named for first clerk of court in Transylvania County.

label: George Town
description: planned and begun in 1786 by George Hazard between Bear Creek and Queens Creek in SE Onslow County. It did not prosper and soon was abandoned.

label: Georges Branch
description: rises in N Swain County and flows SW into Indian Creek.

label: Georgetown
description: historically African American community in NE Davidson County between forks of Spurgeon and Abbotts Creeks.

label: Georgetown
description: community in E Lenoir County near Kinston. Takes its name from George City, which see.

label: Georgeville
description: community in SE Cabarrus County at junction of Dutch Buffalo Creek and Rocky River. Named for George Shinn; formerly known as Shinnville. See also Reed Gold Mine.

label: Georgia Branch
description: rises in W Madison County and flows E into Spring Creek.

label: German's Hill
description: a ridge in NE Caldwell County on which was formerly located a small community (post office name Cilley). Named for Wellborn German, who lived there until 1848.

label: Germanton
description: community in S Stokes and N Forsyth Counties. Alt. 662. Est. 1790; charter repealed 1895. County seat of Stokes County from the creation of the county until 1849, when it was divided to form Forsyth County.

label: Germantown
description: town in SW Hyde County. Inc. 1791. Named for German Bernard, on whose land the town was laid off. County seat from about 1792 to 1820.

label: Germany Cove
description: in central Haywood County on a tributary of Hemphill Creek.

label: Gerren Branch
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows SE into Glady Fork. Also spelled Garren Branch.

label: Gerren Creek
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows NE into East Fork French Broad River.

label: Gerton
description: community in NE Henderson County.

label: Gethsemane
description: community in N Edgecombe County.

label: Ghents Creek
description: rises in N Person County and flows NE into Hyco River.

label: Ghio
description: community in SE Richmond County. Named in the 1860s for a German engineer employed by the railroad.

label: Ghock Fork
description: rises in E Richmond County and flows NW into Hitchcock Creek.

label: Ghormley Mountain
description: extends NE from Thompson Branch to Quinn Creek in W Cherokee County.

label: Ghoul's Fork
description: rises in central Carteret County and flows SW into Black Creek.

label: Gibbs
description: community in W Burke County served by post office, 1883-1930.

label: Gibbs Branch
description: rises in NW Jackson County and flows W into Oconaluftee River.

label: Gibbs Creek
description: rises in E Granville County and flows SE into Tar River.

label: Gibbs Creek
description: See Far Creek.

label: Gibbs Lake
description: marsh in SE Duplin County.

label: Gibbs Mountain
description: E Yancey County on the head of Shuford Creek. Alt. 6,224. Named for Rev. Billy Gibbs, a circuit rider.

label: Gibbs Point
description: extends into Pamlico Sound from the E mainland of Hyde County.

label: Gibbs Woods
description: community near Gibbs Point in NE Currituck County. See also Gibbs Point.

label: Gibbton
description: community in central Pamlico County on Trent River.

label: Gibby Branch
description: rises in S Swain County and flows NW into Brush Creek.

label: Gibby Branch
description: rises in S central Swain County and flows SE into Bucknor Branch.

label: Gibraltar
description: former community in central Union County between Richardson's and Crooked Creeks. Appears on the Shaffer map, 1886. Later known as Polk Mountain, but no longer recognized as a community.

label: Gibson
description: town in W Scotland County. Post office est. there 1846 and named for Noah Gibson, storekeeper and first postmaster. Inc. 1899. Alt. 255.

label: Gibson Branch
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows SW into Wesley Creek.

label: Gibson Cove
description: S Swain County E of Wesser Creek.

label: Gibson Cove Branch
description: rises in central Macon County and flows SE into Cartoogechaye Creek.

label: Gibson Knob
description: central Macon County between Gibson Ridge and Mint Branch.

label: Gibson Millpond
description: See Blues Pond.

label: Gibson Pond
description: E central Richmond County on Ghock Fork.

label: Gibson Ridge
description: SE Swain County, extends N from Peaks Bald between Jones Creek and Little Laurel Creek.

label: Gibson's Mill
description: community in central Richmond County served by post office, 1878-1907.

label: Gibsonville
description: town in E Guilford and W Alamance Counties. Alt. 728. Est. 1855 and inc. 1871. Named for Joseph Gibson (1785-1857), local land and slave owner who was active in contracting and grading for the North Carolina Railroad. A station est. about 1 mi. N of his home was named for him and became the town.

label: Giddensville
description: community in NE Sampson County on the W edge of Bear Pocosin.

label: Gideon
description: community in E Stokes County served by post office, 1898-1916.

label: Gideon Swamp
description: rises in N Nash County and flows SE into Sandy Creek.

label: Giesky Creek
description: rises in S Clay County and flows NW into Shooting Creek.

label: Gift
description: community in S Johnston County served by post office, 1887-1903.

label: Gilbert
description: community in N Moore County served by post office, 1887-1906.

label: Gilbert Town
description: former county seat of Rutherford County, 1781-85. Site, now abandoned, is a short distance N of Rutherfordton in the center of the county on Hollands Creek. Named for William Gilbert, owner of the land. Campsite for both sides prior to Battle of Kings Mountain, October 1780.

label: Gilberts Creek
description: rises in S Stanly County and flows S into Rocky River.

label: Gilead
description: community in SW Beaufort County.

label: Gilead Ridge
description: mountain ridge in South Mountains that form Burke-Cleveland county line.

label: Giles Creek
description: rises in SE Rockingham County and flows SW into Haw River.

label: Giles’ Mills
description: community in NW Sampson County served by post office, 1874-1906.

label: Gilkey
description: community in N Rutherford County. Formerly known as Millwood until renamed for a local family.

label: Gilkey Creek
description: rises in N Rutherford County and flows SE into Mill Creek.

label: Gilkey Township
description: central Rutherford County.

label: Gill
description: community in S Vance County; named for a local family.

label: Gill Branch
description: rises in N Buncombe County near Weaverville and flows SW into Reems Creek.

label: Gill Mountain
description: S Wilkes County extending NE from Morris Knob to Owen Knob.

label: Gillam Gap
description: on the Ashe-Wilkes county line.

label: Gillburg
description: community in S Vance County on the head of Gills Little Mill Creek.

label: Gillespie Gap
description: on the McDowell-Mitchell county line. Alt. 2,800. Troops en route to the Battle of Kings Mountain passed through the gap on September 29, 1780. The North Carolina Mineral Museum is located on the Blue Ridge Parkway on the Mitchell County side of the gap.

label: Gillett
description: former community in S Onslow County E of Stones Bay. Abandoned 1941 with the establishment of Camp Lejeune Marine Corps Air Station.

label: Gilletts Creek
description: rises in SE Onslow County and flows SE into Brown's Sound. Also known locally as Old Woman's Swamp from the fact that an elderly woman was drowned there many years ago. Now within the Camp Lejeune Marine Corps Air Station. Mentioned in local records as early as 1744.

label: Gilliam Branch
description: rises in N Vance County and flows NW into Island Creek Reservoir.

label: Gilliam County
description: was name proposed in 1872-73 legislature for new county to be created out of Granville, Warren, and Franklin Counties. Name selected to honor Judge Robert Gilliam of Oxford. Bill failed to pass, but in 1881 Vance County was formed with similar boundaries.

label: Gillikin Creek
description: rises in E Carteret County and flows W into North Leopard Creek.

label: Gilliland's Creek
description: rises in central McDowell County in the Old Fort area and flows into Crooked Creek.

label: Gillis Station
description: See Parkton.

label: Gills Knob
description: N Caldwell County. Alt. 2,000. Probably named for Gilbert Cottrell, eighteenth-century settler in the vicinity.

label: Gills Little Mill Creek
description: rises in S Vance County and flows S into N Franklin County, where it enters Lynch Creek.

label: Gilmer Township
description: central Guilford County.

label: Gilmore Swamp
description: rises in NE Sampson County and flows SE into Six Runs Creek.

label: Gilreath
description: community in S Wilkes County on North Rocky Creek. Formerly known as Brushy Mountain and as Dodson Store. Old Gilreath, another community, is located approx. 3 mi. nw.

label: Gin
description: community in N Cumberland County.

label: Gin Branch
description: rises in central Nash County and flows S into Sapony Creek.

label: Gingerberry
description: high ground in Murphy Bay, E Bladen County.

label: Gingercake Creek
description: rises in NW Burke County and flows SE, E, and NE into Steels Creek.

label: Gingercake Mountain
description: NW tip of Burke County on Jonas Ridge. Alt. 4,120. A summer residential community, Gingercake Acres, is there.

label: Gipps Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SW into Valley River.

label: Gladden Ridge
description: W Madison County parallel to Raccoon Branch.

label: Gladdens Creek
description: rises in central Graham County and flows W into Cheoah River.

label: Glade Branch
description: rises in E Clay County and flows NE into Buck Creek.

label: Glade Creek
description: rises in S central Alleghany County and flows N into Little River.

label: Glade Creek
description: community in E Alleghany County.

label: Glade Creek Township
description: NE Alleghany County.

label: Glade Gap
description: E Clay County near Glade Branch.

label: Glade Mountain
description: at the head of Glade Creek in SE Macon County.

label: Glade Top
description: on the Buncombe-Haywood county line.

label: Glade Valley
description: community in SE Alleghany County. Glade Valley High School there operated under direction of Presbyterian Church.

label: Glade, The
description: loamy marsh in SE Duplin County.

label: Glades Creek
description: rises in S McDowell County and flows N into Catawba River.

label: Gladie Creek
description: rises in E Jackson County and flows SW into Tuckasegee River.

label: Gladis
description: community in E Mecklenburg County.

label: Gladstone
description: See Misenheimer.

label: Glady
description: community in SW Buncombe County on South Hominy Creek.

label: Glady Branch
description: rises in W Swain County and flows S into Tuckasegee River.

label: Glady Creek
description: rises in S Rockingham County and flows SE into Troublesome Creek, a tributary of Haw River. Named for glade, or swampy area, at head of creek.

label: Glady Fork
description: is formed in S Transylvania County by the confluence of West Prong and South Prong. It flows N into East Fork French Broad River.

label: Glady Fork Gap
description: on the Buncombe-Henderson county line.

label: Gladys Branch
description: rises in central Transylvania County and flows SW into Spanish Oak Branch.

label: Gladys Fork Gap
description: at the head of Fletcher Creek in NW Henderson County.

label: Glasgow County
description: formed in 1791 from Dobbs County, was named in honor of James Glasgow, secretary of state of North Carolina, 1777-98. The name was changed to Greene, which see, in 1799 when Glasgow was convicted of land fraud. Glasgow died in Tennessee in 1820.

label: Glass
description: community in N Cabarrus County. Named for Peter Glass, an early German settler.

label: Glass Rock Knob
description: on the McDowell-Yancey county line.

label: Glassmine Branch
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows SW into North Fork [Swannanoa River].

label: Glassmine Gap
description: on Little Bald Mountain, SW Macon County.

label: Glassmine Mountain
description: W Transylvania County between Lamance and Beasley Creeks. Named for the fact that isinglass (mica) was mined in the vicinity.

label: Glassmine Ridge
description: NE Buncombe County between Sugarhouse Cove and Corner Rock Creek.

label: Glassy Rock
description: mountain in SE Henderson County overlooking Flat Rock community. According to legend, renegades hid there during the Civil War, and money and other valuables that they concealed in the caves there were later found. Trail from Connemara, the Carl Sandburg house, leads to the overlook.

label: Glassy Rock Creek
description: rises in S Jackson County and flows S into Webb Lake.

label: Glassy Rock Mountain
description: on the SE end of Glassy Rock Ridge, S Jackson County. Alt. approx. 4,500.

label: Glassy Rock Ridge
description: S Jackson County between Rattlesnake Knob and Glassy Rock Mountain.

label: Glen Alpine
description: town in SW Burke County. Inc. 1883. Alt. 1,206. First known as Turkey Tail because of an old tree root that resembled a turkey's tail. Later called Sigmonsburg for a local storekeeper, and finally given its present name when the railroad was built.

label: Glen Ayre
description: community in E Mitchell County on Little Green Creek. A late nineteenth-century post office there was known as Little Rock Creek.

label: Glen Brook
description: community in NE Montgomery County served by post office, 1880-1906.

label: Glen Burnie Falls
description: on New Years Creek, W edge of town of Blowing Rock in S Watauga County. Height 75 ft. Part of Blowing Rock recreation area since 1906.

label: Glen Cove
description: the valley through which Glen Cove Branch flows in SE Buncombe County.

label: Glen Cove Branch
description: rises in SE Buncombe County and flows NW into Swannanoa River.

label: Glen Falls
description: on East Fork Overflow Creek in SE Macon County. Water drops about 75 ft.

label: Glen Inglis
description: community in central Buncombe County served by post office, 1890-1909.

label: Glen Mary Falls
description: in New Years Creek, W edge of town of Blowing Rock in S Watauga County. Height 100 ft. Part of Blowing Rock recreation area since 1906.

label: Glen Raven
description: community in W Alamance County. Alt. 701. Named by John Q. Gant (1847-1930), who est. first mill at the site. He first chose Glendale, but the name was rejected because it was already a post office name in the state. He kept the "Glen," however, and added Raven because of his fondness for hunting crows.

label: Glenburnie Gardens
description: residential area about 3 mi. N of New Bern, central Craven County.

label: Glencannon Falls
description: E central Transylvania County in Williamson Creek.

label: Glencoe
description: community in central Alamance County. Formerly site of textile mills.

label: Glendale
description: community in N Alamance County served by post office, 1884-1901.

label: Glendale Springs
description: community in SE Ashe County. Alt. 2,850.

label: Glendon
description: community in NE Moore County. Named for E. F. Glenn, owner of the site. A pyrophyllite open-cut mine and processing plant operated there. Alt. 301.

label: Glenfield
description: community in S Greene County. Tyndal's College, located nearby, was est. about 1913, abandoned about 1929. Founded by James Tyndal and son, John, prominent Baptists. The community was settled prior to 1890.

label: Glenhaven
description: community in central Beaufort County on the N bank of Pamlico River.

label: Glenmore
description: community in S Johnston County served by post office, 1879-1902.

label: Glenn
description: See University.

label: Glenn Bald
description: mountain peak in S Buncombe County between Lance Mountain and Shut-in Ridge. Alt. 2,703.

label: Glenn Gap
description: on the Monroe County, Tenn.-Graham County, N.C., line.

label: Glenn Mountain
description: in S Person County near Flat River.

label: Glenola
description: community in N Randolph County. Alt. approx. 793.

label: Glenville
description: town in S Jackson County between Thorpe Reservoir and Glassy Rock Ridge. Inc. 1891. Alt. approx. 3,560.

label: Glenville Lake
description: See Lake Thorpe.

label: Glenwood
description: community in S McDowell County. Inc. 1909; ceased to be active in municipal affairs in 1927; charter repealed 1945. A post office there was known as Nealsville.

label: Glenwood Township
description: SE McDowell County.

label: Gliden
description: community in N Chowan County. Alt. 38.

label: Glisson Township
description: N central Duplin County.

label: Globe
description: community in NW Caldwell County. Alt. 1,325. Settled about 1775 and named because the area cleared by the settlers was practically round. Globe Academy operated there from 1882 until it was washed away in the flood of 1916.

label: Globe Mountains
description: a range of mountains extending across NW Caldwell County on the E side of Johns River. Alt. from 1,500 to 3,283.

label: Globe Township
description: NW Caldwell County.

label: Gloucester
description: community in E Carteret County. Alt. 10. Settled about 1800 and named for the city in Massachusetts.

label: Gloucester District
description: one of the districts into which Caswell County was divided at the time of the 1790 census. It contained 211 heads of families.

label: Gloucester Gap
description: a low gap at the heads of Shoal Creek and Long Branch NW of Rich Mountain, N Henderson County.

label: Gloucester Township
description: NW Transylvania County.

label: Glover
description: community in S Nash County served by post office, 1890-1909.

label: Glover Creek
description: rises in NE Carteret County and flows S into Styron Bay between Sealevel and Atlantic.

label: Glovers Crossroads
description: community in NE Bertie County.

label: Gnat Ridge
description: in SE Macon County between Henson Branch and Brooks Creek.

label: Gneiss
description: community in E Macon County on Cullasaja River. Alt. 2,115. Named for gneiss, a laminated or foliated metamorphic rock found in the vicinity.

label: Goade Island
description: a name applied on the Smith map, 1624, to the S extremity of Currituck Banks, E Currituck County.

label: Goat Bald
description: W Macon County between Bearpen Creek and Wine Spring Creek.

label: Goat Island
description: E Pasquotank County N of Elizabeth City in the Pasquotank River.

label: Goat Knob
description: on the Jackson-Macon county line.

label: Goat Neck
description: community in NE Tyrrell County NE of Fort Landing.

label: Goat Rock
description: E Haywood County on Glade Mountain. Alt. approx. 4,450.

label: Goatrock Ridge
description: central Haywood County, extends E from Jonathans Creek to Snakeden Top.

label: Gobble Creek
description: rises in W Davidson County and flows NW into Yadkin River.

label: Godfrey
description: community in N Richmond County.

label: Godfrey Branch
description: See Citte Weeks Branch.

label: Godfrey Creek
description: rises in S Pender County and flows W into Harrisons Creek.

label: Godley Store
description: community in SE Beaufort County.

label: Godleys Crossroads
description: See Chocowinity.

label: Godsey
description: community in SW Wake County served by post office, 1900-1904.

label: Godwin
description: town in NE Cumberland County. Settled 1877. Inc. 1905. Named for Isaac W. Godwin, who gave the railroad right-of-way. Alt. 156.

label: Godwin's Branch
description: rises in E Wilson County and flows SE into Whiteoak Swamp.

label: Godwins
description: community in S Johnston County.

label: Goff
description: community in NE Chatham County served by post office, 1881-1915.

label: Goff's Swamp
description: See Goss Swamp.

label: Goins Creek
description: rises in Virginia and flows S into Surry County, where it enters Stewart Creek.

label: Gold
description: former community in NW Burke County on Canoe Creek.

label: Gold Branch
description: rises in S Cherokee County and flows SW into Nottely River.

label: Gold Hill
description: community in central Rutherford County.

label: Gold Hill Township
description: SE Rowan County.

label: Gold Mine Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows E into Cullasaja River.

label: Gold Mine Township
description: former township in NE Franklin County, now township no. 7.

label: Gold Park Lake
description: on an unnamed stream in S central Wayne County. Formed by an artificial dam in 1940; max. depth 10 ft.; area 20 acres. Swimming facilities; open to public. First named Woodland Lake; name changed in 1954 to present name based on name of county seat, Goldsboro.

label: Gold Pit Creek
description: rises in W Macon County and flows NW into Cold Spring Creek.

label: Gold Point
description: town in W Martin County on Collie Swamp. Settled about 1871. Inc. 1899 as Gold-point, but long inactive in municipal affairs; reincorporated 1957 as Gold Point. Originally called Long Town. Alt. 74.

label: Gold Rock
description: community in NE Nash County on Swift Creek. Inc. 1875 as Whitaker's Mills, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Henry W. Whitaker was appointed first mayor. Present name selected 1886 by R. R. Gay, postmaster, when a post office was est. there and it was necessary to avoid confusion with nearby Whitakers. Alt. 110.

label: Gold Valley Crossroads
description: community in W Nash County.

label: Golden
description: See Golden Valley.

label: Golden Creek
description: rises in S central Avery County and flows SE into Linville River.

label: Golden Ridge
description: N Madison County between Rocky Branch and Hurricane Creek.

label: Golden Valley
description: community in NE Rutherford County on the head of First Broad River. A post office, Golden, est. there as early as 1835. Large tracts of timber exist in the area; although worked by a lumber company many years ago, there are said to be stands of virgin timber remaining in the far reaches because it was too difficult to get it out.

label: Golden Valley Township
description: NE Rutherford County.

label: Goldengrove
description: See Kenansville.

label: Goldknob
description: community in SE Rowan County served by post office, 1892-1904.

label: Goldmine Branch
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows W into Middle Fork [South Fork New River].

label: Goldsboro
description: city and county seat, central Wayne County E of Neuse River, where it is joined by Little River. Inc. 1847; became county seat in 1850, succeeding town of Waynesborough, which see. Named for Maj. Matthew Tilghman Goldsborough, native of Maryland, assistant engineer for Wilmington and Weldon Railroad. Includes former community of Adamsville, which see. Produces textiles, electronic components, primary metals, leather products, bakery products, tobacco, furniture, lumber, cottonseed oil, machinery, dairy products, and processed grain. Alt. 111. Seymour Johnson Air Force Base, est. 1942, is there.

label: Goldsboro Cooling Pond
description: in W central Wayne County about 5 mi. W of county seat. Impounded in 1961 to cover 575 acres, with max. depth of 15 ft. and a shoreline of 4.6 mi. Used to provide supplementary cooling for the Goldsboro Steam Electric Generating Plant and named for same. Lies in a looping meander of Neuse River (though its water level is as much as 22 ft. above that of the river), and its water covers the site of an old Quaker meetinghouse. The upper meander loop forms an area known as Quaker Neck; the lower meander loop was known as The Roundabout in the 1830s.

label: Goldsboro Township
description: central Wayne County.

label: Goldspring Gap
description: S Macon County between Wolfpen Gap and Pickens Nose.

label: Goldston
description: town in S Chatham County. Settled about 1885; inc. 1907. Named for Joseph Goldston, on whose land the town developed. Alt. 424.

label: Goldview Knob
description: central Buncombe County SW of Beard Mountain.

label: Gooch Gap
description: on the McDowell-Mitchell county line.

label: Gooch Peak
description: central Buncombe County in the W part of the Elk Mountains.

label: Good Spring
description: community in W Surry County served by post office, 1878-1916.

label: Good Spring Branch
description: rises in W Haywood County and flows SE into Pretty Hollow Creek.

label: Goode Creek
description: rises in SE Rutherford County and flows S into Broad River.

label: Goodings Creek
description: See Goodwin Creek.

label: Goodluck
description: community in N Henderson County on Hooper Creek.

label: Goodman
description: community in NW Anson County. Named for local family; J. C. Goodman, Civil War veteran, est. a tannery there soon after the war.

label: Goodman Branch
description: rises in N Union County and flows SE into Richardson Creek.

label: Goodman Swamp
description: rises in S Nansemond County, Va., and flows S into Gates County, where it enters Duke Swamp.

label: Goodmans Island
description: in SE Bertie County between the mouth of Cashie River and Eastmost River. Irregularly shaped, it measures approx. 1¼ mi. in width and length from its most distant points. See also Purchace Islands.

label: Goodson's Store
description: See Boger City.

label: Goodsonville
description: See Boger City.

label: Goodwill
description: community in NE Forsyth County served by post office, 1884-1903.

label: Goodwin Creek
description: rises in W Perquimans County and flows E into Perquimans River. Named for Caleb Goodwin, who operated a mill on the creek about 1820. Appears as Cypress Swamp on the Moseley map, 1733, and generally known as Cypress Creek until renamed for the miller. Appears as Goodings Creek on the 1905 soil-survey map.

label: Goodwin Forest
description: central Moore County, a tract of 1,122 acres owned by James L. Goodwin from 1930 until his death in 1967, when it was given to North Carolina State University for use in education, research, and recreation. Net proceeds are used for scholarships. Pine and hardwoods grow in the forest.

label: Goodwin Hills
description: community on N Cedar Island in NE Carteret County.

label: Goodwin Mill Pond
description: approx. 1½ mi. long, on Goodwin Creek, W Perquimans County.

label: Goose Bay
description: off the SE end of the largest island in the Hog Island group, NE Carteret County.

label: Goose Bay Point
description: at the S tip of the largest island in the Hog Island group, NE Carteret County.

label: Goose Branch
description: rises in E Nash County and flows SE into Tar River.

label: Goose Creek
description: rises in W Carteret County and flows 3 mi. S into Bogue Sound. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Goose Creek
description: rises in E Tyrrell County and flows E into Alligator River. Appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Goose Creek Island
description: the NE neck of Pamlico County cut off from the mainland by the Intracoastal Waterway. Near the end of the nineteenth century, Goose Creek Island post office served the area. The North Carolina Wildlife Resources Commission maintains the Goose Creek Wildlife Management Area of 5,865 acres W of the Intracoastal Waterway in Beaufort and Pamlico Counties. See also Greens Land.

label: Goose Creek State Park
description: Beaufort County. Opened to the public, September 1974. The park covers 1,327 acres and fronts Pamlico River. Features six hiking trails.

label: Goose Creek Township
description: N Union County.

label: Goose Island
description: in Core Sound near Core Banks in E Carteret County.

label: Goose Neck Creek
description: rises in N Granville County and flows E into Kerr Lake. Name derived from irregular course of creek. Also known as Johnson Creek.

label: Goose Nest
description: See Oak City.

label: Goose Nest Township
description: NW Martin County. See also Oak City.

label: Goose Pond
description: community in NE Bertie County. Named for the goose pond on a local plantation owned by the Holley family.

label: Goosecastle Point
description: neck of land extending from N end of Church Island into Currituck Sound in central Currituck County.

label: Gordens Island
description: See Wococon Island.

label: Gordons Mountain
description: SW Anson County near the head of Lick Creek. Alt. 400-500 ft.

label: Gordonton
description: community in E Davidson County. Earlier known as Gordontown.

label: Gordonton
description: community in SW Person County. A post office as early as 1830.

label: Gordontown
description: town authorized to be est. in 1824 on the lands of James Gordon on Cribs Creek, NW Anson County, but there is no evidence that the town was laid out.

label: Gorge, The
description: See Linville Gorge.

label: Gorman
description: community in E Durham County.

label: Gorvas Island
description: an island of uncertain identity shown on the Moll map, 1729, within the bounds of present Currituck County.

label: Goshen
description: former community in SW Wilkes County on Yadkin River. The site is now a part of the W. Kerr Scott Reservoir.

label: Goshen Branch
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows NE into Storey Branch.

label: Goshen District
description: See Goshen.

label: Goshen Hill
description: S Watauga County between Raccoon Branch and Goshen Branch.

label: Goshen Swamp
description: rises in NE Sampson County and flows SE into Duplin County, where it continues SE until it enters Northeast Cape Fear River. Appears on the Collet map, 1770. Holley's Mill is also shown on the Collet map as being near the headwaters of the stream.

label: Goss Swamp
description: rises in SE Wilson County and flows SW into Toisnot Swamp. Known earlier as Goff's Swamp.

label: Gouches Branch
description: rises in SW Buncombe County near Bert Mountain and flows NE into New-found Creek.

label: Gouge Branch
description: rises N of Gouge Mountain in SE Mitchell County and flows NW into Toe River.

label: Gouge Knob
description: central Mitchell County at the head of Rebel Creek.

label: Gouge Mountain
description: SE Mitchell County.

label: Gouges Creek
description: rises in N Mitchell County and flows S into Little Rock Creek.

label: Gould
description: community in S Gaston County served by post office, 1888-1902.

label: Goulds
description: community in SW Wilkes County on Yadkin River at the mouth of Stony Fork Creek. Named for Andy Gould, who operated a mill on Stony Fork Creek.

label: Goulds Fork
description: rises in SW Anson County and flows N into Brown Creek.

label: Gourdvine Creek
description: rises in E Union County and flows NW into Richardson's Creek.

label: Gover
description: See Gibbs Point.

label: Governors Creek
description: See Big Governors Creek; Crawley Creek.

label: Governors Island
description: loamy section in E Swain County on Tuckasegee River extending SE from the mouth of Galbreath Creek to the mouth of Johnson Branch.

label: Gow-ta-no
description: See Neuse River.

label: Gowans Cove
description: NW Cherokee County, through which an unnamed stream flows into Shuler Creek.

label: Grable Branch
description: rises in central Macon County and flows N into Owenby Branch.

label: Grabtown
description: community in SW Bertie County.

label: Grabur Heights
description: community in central Alamance County.

label: Grace
description: community in central Buncombe County served by post office, 1889-1902.

label: Grade
description: community in NW Alexander County. Alt. approx. 975.

label: Gradins Station
description: community in SW Granville County.

label: Grady
description: community in W Robeson County served by post office, 1890-1904.

label: Grady Township
description: SW Pender County.

label: Gradys
description: community in SE Wayne County near Buck Marsh.

label: Gragg
description: community in NE Avery County. Probably named for John Gragg, Revolutionary War soldier (buried at Montezuma) or for Gragg Prong, which see, probably also named for him.

label: Gragg Prong
description: stream, rises in E central Avery County and flows S into Lost Cove Creek.

label: Graggs Fork
description: rises in NW Caldwell County and flows S into Anthonys Creek.

label: Graham
description: city and county seat, central Alamance County. Laid out in 1849 with the formation of the country to serve as county seat. Inc. 1851. Named for William A. Graham, governor, 1845-49. In the act providing for the town, it was first named Gallatin, then Montgomery, Berry, and finally Graham, as chosen by North Carolina representative Giles Mebane, who introduced the bill to create Alamance County. Alt. 656. Produces textiles, hosiery, and primary metals.

label: Graham Branch
description: rises in N Granville County and flows NW into Little Grass Creek.

label: Graham County
description: was formed in 1872 from Cherokee County. Located in the W section of the state, it is bounded by the state of Tennessee and by Cherokee and Swain Counties. It was named for William A. Graham (1804-75), U.S. senator, governor of North Carolina, secretary of the navy, and Confederate senator. Area: 299 sq. mi. County seat: Robbinsville, with an elevation of 2,150 ft. Townships are Cheoah, Stecoah, and Yellow Creek. Produces hay, cattle, poultry, livestock, furniture, fish, and lumber.

label: Graham Creek
description: rises in central Transylvania County and flows NE into Nicholson Creek.

label: Graham Mountain
description: on the Buncombe-Henderson county line.

label: Graham Top
description: central Cherokee County near the headwaters of Cook Creek.

label: Graham Township
description: former township in central Alamance County. Now township no. 6.

label: Graham's Ferry
description: crossed the Catawba River in NW Mecklenburg County at Lincoln County line.

label: Graingers
description: town in NE Lenoir County. Alt. 74. Inc. 1925. Named for Jesse Grainger, on whose plantation it developed after a railroad station was est. there.

label: Grampian Hills
description: a range of hills about 3 mi. long in S Orange County running SW and ne. Named for the Grampian Hills, natural boundary between Scottish Highlands and Scottish Lowlands in Scotland.

label: Granburys Crossroads
description: See Roxobel.

label: Grand View
description: community in E Watauga County S of Laxon Creek.

label: Grandfather
description: community in SW Watauga County on Watauga River.

label: Grandfather Mountain
description: at junction of Avery, Caldwell, and Watauga Counties. Alt. 5,964. Tourist attraction formerly owned by Morton family and sold to state in 2008. "Mile High Swinging Bridge" connects two peaks. Annual "Singing on the Mountain" and "Gathering of the Scottish Clans" are held. Named for the fact that, when viewed from a distance, the outline of the mountain against the sky suggests the profile of an old man. Highest point in the Blue Ridge. Called Tanawha by the Cherokee Indians, meaning "a fabulous hawk or eagle."

label: Grandin
description: former town in NE Caldwell County. Inc. 1913 on the lands of the Grandin Lumber Co. Long inactive in municipal affairs and now abandoned.

label: Grandmother Creek
description: rises in E central Avery County near Grandmother Gap and flows SW into Linville River.

label: Grandmother Gap
description: E Avery County.

label: Grandmother Mountain
description: E Avery County. Alt. 4,696.

label: Grandmother Ridge
description: E central Avery County.

label: Grandview
description: community in central Cherokee County at the junction of Davis and Hanging Dog Creeks.

label: Grandy
description: community in S Currituck County on the E side of North River. Post office est. 1898; closed 1932. Named for Caleb Grandy, first postmaster.

label: Grange
description: See Little River.

label: Granger Branch
description: rises in SW Madison County and flows NW into Spring Creek.

label: Granger Mountain
description: W Madison County between Foxtown Mountain and Spring Creek.

label: Granite City
description: a formation of granite cliffs S of Devils Court House area between Blackrock Mountain and Chattooga River on the Jackson-Macon county line.

label: Granite Falls
description: town in SE Caldwell County. Inc. 1863. Takes its name from a waterfall of the same name, which see, a short distance NE of the town. A former post office serving the community was Baird's Forge; renamed Lovelady in 1824 and Granite Falls in 1887. Produced textiles and pianos. Alt. 1,213.

label: Granite Quarry
description: town in S Rowan County. Inc. 1901 as Woodside; name changed in 1905 for local quarries. Post office est. as Woodside, 1891; name changed to Granite Quarry, 1902.

label: Granny Branch
description: rises in N central Wayne County and flows NE into The Slough.

label: Granny Cove Branch
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows SE through Granny Cove into North Fork [Swannanoa River].

label: Granny Green Mountain
description: S Macon County between Lowery Creek and Allison Creek.

label: Granny Mountain
description: W Haywood County between Johnson Gap and Jonathans Creek.

label: Granny Squirrel Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NE into Valley River.

label: Granston Lake
description: See White Lake.

label: Grant Branch
description: rises in central Northampton County and flows SE into Urahaw Swamp.

label: Grant Knob
description: N Macon County between Mouse Mountain and Devil Den Ridge.

label: Grant Township
description: E central Randolph County.

label: Grantham
description: community in SW Wayne County between Beaverdam Creek and Neuse River. Formerly called Grantham's Store.

label: Grantham Township
description: SW Wayne County. Named for Grantham family, eighteenth-century settlers of the area.

label: Grantham's Store
description: See Grantham.

label: Granthams
description: community in E Craven County.

label: Grants
description: See Grantsboro.

label: Grants Creek
description: rises in S Rowan County and flows NE into Yadkin River. Named because the earliest known grants of land in the area were along the stream. Frohock Mill on Grants Creek appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Grantsboro
description: community in W Pamlico County. Named for an early settler. Alt. 20. Railroad name is Grants.

label: Grantville
description: community in E Madison County.

label: Granville County
description: was formed in 1746 from Edgecombe County. Located in the NE section of the state, it is bounded by Vance, Franklin, Wake, Durham, and Person Counties and by the state of Virginia. It was named for John Carteret, Earl Granville (1690-1763), owner of the Granville District, which see, in which the new county was located. Area: 543 sq. mi. County seat: Oxford, with an elevation of 476 ft. Townships are Brassfield, Dutchville, Fishing Creek, Oak Hill, Oxford, Salem, Sassafras Fork, Tally Ho, and Walnut Grove. Produces tobacco, corn, oats, wheat, hay, sweet potatoes, poultry, livestock, hogs, dairy products, cosmetics, wood products, machinery, lumber, and apparel.

label: Granville District
description: was the portion of North Carolina allotted to John Carteret, Earl Granville (1690-1763), one of the Lords Proprietors, who refused to sell his interest in North Carolina to the Crown in 1729. The upper half of present-day North Carolina was included in the district, which extended from the Virginia boundary to 35°34', a strip 60 mi. wide. The southern line was run from the coast to Bath in 1744, to Haw River in 1746, and to Rocky River in 1766. The district was lost to the Granville estate at the time of the American Revolution.

label: Granville Parish
description: Church of England, Granville County, est. in 1758 in the W part of the county, when St. John's Parish (est. 1746 with the formation of the county and coextensive with it) was divided. After St. John's Parish in the E became Bute County in 1764, Granville Parish was coextensive with Granville County. In 1767 there were 1,022 white taxables in the parish. See also St. John's Parish.

label: Grape Branch
description: rises in SE Nash County and flows NE into Tar River.

label: Grape Cove
description: S Swain County between Mica Knob and Marr Branch.

label: Grape Creek
description: community in central Cherokee County near the mouth of Hanging Dog Creek.

label: Grapevine Bay
description: SE Tyrrell County in Alligator River.

label: Grapevine Landing
description: SE Tyrrell County on Grapevine Bay.

label: Grapevine Ridge
description: E Madison County between West Fork [Bull Creek] and Beetree Creek.

label: Grapevine Township
description: former township in central Madison County, now township no. 14.

label: Graphite
description: See Graphiteville.

label: Graphiteville
description: community in W McDowell County. Alt. 2,037. Named for nearby graphite mine. Also known as Graphite.

label: Grass Branch
description: rises in N central Ashe County and flows S into Windfall Creek.

label: Grass Land Ridge
description: S Madison County between South Fork [Big Pine Creek] and Little Pine Creek. Alt. 3,884.

label: Grassland
description: community in S Avery County.

label: Grassy Bald
description: mountain on the Haywood-Jackson county line. Alt. 5,613.

label: Grassy Branch
description: rises in central Buncombe County and flows S into Swannanoa River.

label: Grassy Branch
description: rises in W central Swain County and flows SW into Yalaka Creek.

label: Grassy Camp Creek
description: rises in SW Jackson County and flows NE into Norton Creek.

label: Grassy Cove Gap
description: S Haywood County between Grassy Cove Ridge and Little Buckeye Cove.

label: Grassy Cove Ridge
description: S Haywood County, extends E from Grassy Cove Top to Grassy Cove Gap.

label: Grassy Cove Top
description: S Haywood County on the S end of Shining Rock Ledge.

label: Grassy Creek
description: rises in S Mitchell County and flows N into North Toe River.

label: Grassy Creek
description: community in N Granville County. A church there was est. in 1755.

label: Grassy Creek Township
description: S Mitchell County.

label: Grassy Gap
description: on the Buncombe-Haywood county line on Newfound Mountain.

label: Grassy Gap
description: SW Swain County between Silvermine Gap and Briertown Mountain.

label: Grassy Gap Branch
description: rises in W Watauga County and flows NW into Buckeye Creek on the Avery-Watauga county line.

label: Grassy Islands
description: several islands in Pee Dee River N of Blewett Falls Lake on the Anson-Richmond county line. Shown on the Price map, 1808, and the MacRae map, 1833.

label: Grassy Knob
description: S Buncombe County.

label: Grassy Knob
description: W Haywood County on Eaglenest Ridge.

label: Grassy Knob
description: W Yancey County between Price and Banks Creeks.

label: Grassy Knob Branch
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows SE into Upper Creek.

label: Grassy Knob Ridge
description: S Yancey County between Lower Creek and Grassy Knob Branch.

label: Grassy Knobs
description: S Macon County between Rattlesnake Ridge and Middle Creek.

label: Grassy Lot Gap
description: N Transylvania County between Thompson Creek and Bradley Creek. Alt. 3,358.

label: Grassy Mountain
description: on the McDowell-Rutherford county line.

label: Grassy Point
description: E Beaufort County on Pungo River.

label: Grassy Ridge
description: on the Avery-Mitchell county line.

label: Grassy Ridge Bald
description: See Bald Mountain.

label: Grassy Ridge Branch
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows NW into Middle Prong.

label: Grassy Top
description: peak on Holland Mountain on Haywood-Buncombe county line.

label: Gravel Creek
description: rises in S Buncombe County and flows SE into Cane Creek.

label: Gravel Hill
description: community in E Bladen County served by post office, 1875-1911. Spelled Gravelhill after 1894.

label: Gravel Knob
description: on the Madison County, N.C.-Greene County, Tenn., line.

label: Gravel Spring
description: community in N Chatham County served by post office, 1879-1904.

label: Gravelhill
description: See Gravel Hill.

label: Gravelly Hill
description: See Hickory Grove Crossroads.

label: Graves Ferry
description: appears on the Moseley map, 1733, over the Neuse River near the mouth of Bachelor Creek, S Craven County. The road from Bath to Wilmington crossed there. A 1901 map shows Nelsons Old Ferry at the site.

label: Graveyard Cove
description: in White Oak River, W Carteret County, a short distance N of the community of Stella. Named for nearby cemetery.

label: Graveyard Creek
description: rises in S Mitchell County and flows NE into Grassy Creek.

label: Graveyard Mountain
description: N McDowell County between North Fork [Catawba River] and Woodlawn. Alt. approx. 2,250.

label: Graveyard Ridge
description: S Haywood County between Yellowstone Prong and Dark Prong. A flat area there has numerous mounds resembling graves. They have been dug into but no human remains found. A hurricane or windstorm likely uprooted trees and, through the years, the old root stumps and trees rotted out, leaving only the dirt mounds. There is a slight depression beside each mound, which is the hole from which the stumps came.

label: Gray Camp Branch
description: rises in NW Haywood County and flows SE into Big Creek.

label: Gray Gap
description: S Macon County between The Pinnacle and Tessentee Creek.

label: Gray Swamp
description: S Pasquotank County between Little Flatty Creek and Big Flatty Creek.

label: Gray Wolf Creek
description: rises in N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows SW into Forney Creek.

label: Gray's Point
description: central Onslow County in S Farnell Bay.

label: Graybeal
description: community in W Ashe County. Alt. approx. 3,000.

label: Graybeard Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows W into Vengeance Creek S of Brushy Head Mountain.

label: Graybeard Mountain
description: on the Buncombe-McDowell county line. Alt. 5, 360-5,400.

label: Grays Branch
description: rises in N Columbus County and flows SW into Pinelog Swamp.

label: Grays Chapel
description: community in NE Randolph County. Named for a local family. A post office est. there as early as 1882.

label: Grays Creek
