description: rises in S Cumberland County and flows SE in an arc into Cape Fear River.

label: Grays Creek
description: community in S central Cumberland County approx. 6 mi. S of city of Fayetteville.

label: Grays Creek Township
description: SW Cumberland County.

label: Grays Landing
description: See Windsor.

label: Grays Mill
description: appears on the Collet map, 1770, near the mouth of Sawyers Creek, W Camden County.

label: Grays Mountain
description: S Randolph County between Needhams Mountain and Pond Mountain.

label: Grayson
description: community in NW Ashe County.

label: Greasy Branch
description: rises in W central Swain County and flows SW into Little Tennessee River.

label: Greasy Corner
description: See Davie Crossroads.

label: Greasy Cove
description: NW Buncombe County SE of Rogers Gap.

label: Greasy Cove Prong
description: rises in SE Haywood County and flows E into East Fork Pigeon River.

label: Greasy Creek
description: See Abingdon Creek.

label: Greasy Mountain
description: SW Wilkes County between Long Fork of Beaver Creek and Beaver Creek.

label: Great Alamance Creek
description: is formed by the junction of Little Alamance and Big Alamance Creeks in E Guilford County and flows E across Alamance County, where it enters Haw River. Appears as Aramancy River on the Moseley map, 1733. Called Aramanchy River by William Byrd, 1728.

label: Great Alegator Dismal Swamp
description: appears on the Collet map, 1770, as the large swampy area in much of present Tyrrell, Dare, and N Hyde Counties.

label: Great Branch
description: rises in NE Pitt County and flows SE into Meadow Branch.

label: Great Coharie Creek
description: rises in N Sampson County and flows S to join Little Coharie Creek in forming Coharie River. Appears as Cohary Swamp on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Great Coneghta Pocosin
description: See Conetoe Creek.

label: Great Contentnea Creek
description: See Contentnea Creek.

label: Great Coteckney Creek
description: See Contentnea Creek.

label: Great Craggy Mountains
description: range in NE Buncombe County extending S from Balsam Gap to the Swannanoa River. Alt. 3,332. Known by the Cherokee Indians as Sunnatee (morning).

label: Great Creek
description: rises in North River Pocosin in S Camden County and flows E into North River.

label: Great Creek
description: See Deep Creek; Smith Creek.

label: Great Dismal Swamp
description: See Dismal Swamp.

label: Great Ditch
description: waterway between two of the E islands in the Hog Island group, NE Carteret County.

label: Great Dover Swamp
description: is located in NE Jones County and SW Craven County; drains SW into Trent River and its tributaries. Mill Branch, Moseley Creek, Bachelor Creek, Grape Creek, Rollover Creek, and Cove Creek rise in Great Dover Swamp.

label: Great Elliby
description: See Upper Bartons Creek.

label: Great Falls
description: See Roanoke Rapids.

label: Great Falls, The
description: See High Falls.

label: Great Fishing Creek
description: See Fishing Creek.

label: Great Hammock Swash
description: lies between Core Beach and Core Banks (on the sound side) in E Carteret County.

label: Great Hogback
description: mountain on Jackson-Transylvania county line. Alt. 4,785.

label: Great Iron Mountain
description: See Bald Mountain; Great Smoky Mountains.

label: Great Island
description: NE Tyrrell County in the mouth of Alligator Creek.

label: Great Island Bay
description: in Core Sound against the Core Banks, E Carteret County.

label: Great Lake
description: a natural lake in Croatan National Forest, S Craven County. Covers approx. 2,600 acres; max. depth 4 to 5 ft. One of several lakes in Lakes Pocosin.

label: Great Lick Creek
description: See Lick Creek.

label: Great Marsh
description: See Bells Island.

label: Great Marsh Point
description: See Bells Point.

label: Great Mountain
description: NE Henderson County.

label: Great Neck Landing
description: E Onslow County on Queens Creek; more recently known as Reed's Landing.

label: Great Pee Dee River
description: See Pee Dee River.

label: Great Pisgah
description: See Mount Pisgah.

label: Great Pond
description: in the NW part of Hog Island on the S side of Pamlico Sound, NE Carteret County.

label: Great Sandy Run Pocosin
description: W Onslow County between Shelter Swamp and Sandy Run Swamp.

label: Great Shell Rock
description: See North Rock.

label: Great Smoky Mountains
description: are a part of the Appalachian Mountains, which see, and lie along the North Carolina-Tennessee state line. Clingmans Dome, at 6,642 ft., is the highest peak. The first written reference to the name Smoky is probably that found in the act of cession, passed in 1789 by the General Assembly of North Carolina, which, in describing the boundary of North Carolina and what is now Tennessee, stated: "thence along the highest ridge of the said mountain to the place where it is called Great Iron or Smoky Mountain." See also Bald Mountains.

label: Great Smoky Mountains National Park
description: lies in portions of Haywood and Swain Counties, N.C., and Blount, Cocke, and Sevier Counties, Tenn. Establishment authorized by Congress in 1926 was the culmination of activity for the purpose beginning in the 1880s. Administered by the National Park Service since 1931. Contains approx. 461,000 acres. Has campgrounds, museums, restorations, nature trails, and other features of interest, including a variety of wild animals, birds, and plants. Clingmans Dome, alt. 6,642, the highest point in the park, has an observation tower.

label: Great Swamp
description: rises in N Tyrrell County and flows N into Albemarle Sound.

label: Great Swamp
description: See Bloomery Swamp; Starkeys Creek.

label: Great Swamp Branch
description: See Hall Swamp.

label: Great Swamp Township
description: NW Wayne County.

label: Great Trading Path
description: See Trading Path.

label: Great White Marsh
description: See White Marsh.

label: Green Banks Landing
description: on Cape Fear River, NE Brunswick County.

label: Green Cove
description: community on Green Cove Creek in E Mitchell County.

label: Green Cove Creek
description: rises in E Mitchell County and flows NW into Cane Creek.

label: Green Creek
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows N into West Fork Pigeon River.

label: Green Creek
description: rises in NE Rockingham County and flows N into Wolf Island Creek.

label: Green Gap
description: E Haywood County between Cove Creek and Fines Creek.

label: Green Hill
description: community in W Rutherford County between Maple and Mountain Creeks.

label: Green Hill
description: an eighteenth-century community in W Washington County on Conaby Creek E of the town of Plymouth. The community declined as Plymouth, on the Roanoke River, grew in importance as a port town.

label: Green Hill Place
description: home of Maj. Green Hill (1741-1826), central Franklin County 1 mi. E of Louisburg. Site of the first annual conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, 1785.

label: Green Hill Township
description: W Rutherford County.

label: Green Island
description: in the waters of Pamlico Sound off the N tip of Pea Island, E Dare County.

label: Green Knob
description: on the McDowell-Yancey county line between Deep Gap and Flinty Gap. Alt. 5,070.

label: Green Level
description: community in W Wake County on head of Whiteoak Creek, est. before 1865.

label: Green Mountain
description: a peak of Linville Mountain on the Burke-McDowell county line.

label: Green Mountain
description: community in N Yancey County on Toe River. Alt. 4,990.

label: Green Mountain Branch
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows SW into Boone Fork.

label: Green Mountain Gap
description: N central Yancey County between Phillips Knob and Three Quarters Creek.

label: Green Mountain Knob
description: S Watauga County S of Martin Knob.

label: Green Mountain Township
description: NE Yancey County.

label: Green Oak Creek
description: rises in E Pender County and flows SW into Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: Green Park
description: former community in N Caldwell County, now within the limits of Blowing Rock, which see. Named for the Green family, descendants of Richard Green, who settled there in the late eighteenth century.

label: Green Point
description: NE Carteret County on W side of central Cedar Island extending into West Bay.

label: Green Pond
description: See Highs Crossroads.

label: Green Ridge
description: S Haywood County between Tom Creek and Green Creek.

label: Green River
description: community in E Polk County between Mill Creek and Whiteoak Creek.

label: Green River Gap
description: on the Henderson-Polk county line. Alt. 2,700. Green River rises nearby.

label: Green River Township
description: S Henderson County.

label: Green Swamp
description: NW Brunswick and E Columbus Counties, an area of approx. 140 sq. mi. of peat and muck timberland. In 1795 the state of North Carolina granted 170,120 acres there to Benjamin Rowell, William Collins, and Stephen Williams. See also River View Community.

label: Green Swamp
description: N Pender County between Angola Bay and Northeast Cape Fear River, drains SW into Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: Green Top
description: mountain peak in SW Buncombe County between Rich Knob and Yellow Gap.

label: Green Valley
description: community in W Ashe County.

label: Green's Ferry
description: See Spring Bank.

label: Green's Grove
description: See Washburns Store.

label: Greenback
description: community in N central Warren County. Post office est. 1884, discontinued 1907.

label: Greenbrier Knob
description: See Mount Davis.

label: Greene Channel
description: in the SW end of Topsail Sound, S Pender County.

label: Greene County
description: was formed in 1799 when the name of Glasgow County, which see, was changed to Greene. Located in the E section of the state, it is bounded by Pitt, Lenoir, Wayne, and Wilson Counties. It was named for Gen. Nathanael Greene (1742-86), Revolutionary War leader whose action at the Battle of Guilford Courthouse led to the American victory at Yorktown. Area: 269 sq. mi. County seat: Snow Hill, with an elevation of 74 ft. Townships are Bull Head, Carrs, Hookerton, Jason, Olds, Ormonds, Shine, Snow Hill, and Speights Bridge. Produces tobacco, corn, cotton, poultry, hogs, turkeys, sweet potatoes, sorghum, oats, lumber, fiberglass products, transformers, and textiles. See also St. Patrick's Parish.

label: Greene County
description: now in Tennessee, was created in 1783 and named in honor of Gen. Nathanael Greene (1742-86). Greeneville became the county seat. It was a part of the territory ceded by North Carolina in 1789 to the federal government.

label: Greene Ridge
description: N Madison County between Big Creek and Dry Creek.

label: Greene Township
description: SE Guilford County. Named for Gen. Nathanael Greene.

label: Greenesville
description: See Greenville.

label: Greenevers
description: town in S Duplin County. Inc. 1969.

label: Greenevills Rode
description: See Port Grenvil.

label: Greenfield Lake
description: a natural lake now within the limits of city of Wilmington, W New Hanover County. Covers 125 acres; max. depth 12 ft. Mentioned by name in the will of Dr. Samuel Green, original owner, about 1760. A municipal park and garden surround the lake.

label: Greenfield Ridge
description: N Buncombe County between Eller Cove and Rattlesnake Ridge.

label: Greenland Creek
description: rises in SE Jackson County and flows NW to join Panthertown Creek in forming Tuckasegee River.

label: Greenleaf
description: community in central Wayne County served by post office, 1886-1912.

label: Greenlee
description: community in S central McDowell County on Catawba River. Settled before the Revolution.

label: Greens Branch
description: rises in N Columbus County and flows SE into West Prong Creek.

label: Greens Creek
description: community in W Jackson County on Savannah Creek. Alt. 2,120.

label: Greens Creek Township
description: SE Polk County.

label: Greens Fork
description: community in central Gates County.

label: Greens Gap
description: on the Jackson-Macon county line.

label: Greens Land
description: is the name applied on the Ogilby map, 1671, to that part of present-day Pamlico County that lies between the Pamlico and Bay Rivers.

label: Greens Mill Run
description: rises in central Pitt County and flows NE into Tar River. Approx. 6½ mi. long. Perhaps the same stream as Rock Creek on the Moseley map, 1733, and the Collet map, 1770.

label: Greens Millpond
description: W central Gates County on Cole Creek. Covers approx. 30 acres; max. depth 8 ft. Formerly known as Lilleys Millpond.

label: Greens Point
description: a projection of N Hatteras Island into Pamlico Sound, E Dare County beside the community of Rodanthe.

label: Greens Store
description: community in SE Rutherford County.

label: Greens Thorofare
description: channel of water separated from the main body of Neuse River and bypassing a curve in the river in N Craven County. Name appears in local records as early as 1819. Land in the area was included in a 1707 grant to Furnifold Green, killed by the Tuscarora Indians in 1714.

label: Greensboro
description: city and county seat, central Guilford County. Alt. 838. Est. 1808 and inc. 1810. Named for Gen. Nathanael Greene (1742-86), American leader at Battle of Guilford Courthouse, 1781. Produces textiles, fabricated metals, food products, tobacco products, chemicals, drugs, aircraft parts, and electronics. The University of North Carolina at Greensboro, Bennett College, Greensboro College, Guilford College, and North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University are located there.

label: Greenstreet Mountain
description: N Wilkes County parallel to East Prong Roaring River. Named for a local family.

label: Greenville
description: city and county seat, central Pitt County on Tar River. Est. 1771 as Martins-borough, named for Josiah Martin (1737-86), last royal governor of North Carolina, serving from 1771 to 1775. Name changed in 1786 to Greensville in honor of Nathanael Greene (1742-86), Revolutionary War general. With the passage of time, the name came to be spelled as it is today. East Carolina University, est. 1908, is located there. Produces tobacco, lumber, textiles, batteries, bakery products, and boats. Alt. 64.

label: Greenville Sound
description: E New Hanover County between Middle Sound on the N and Masonboro Sound on the s.

label: Greenville Township
description: central Pitt County.

label: Greenwood Township
description: E Moore County.

label: Greer Branch
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows E into Middle Fork [South Fork New River].

label: Greer Creek
description: See South Fork.

label: Greer Knob
description: NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Twentymile Ridge between Greer Branch and Proctor Sang Branch. Alt. 4,463.

label: Gregg Branch
description: rises in central Buncombe County near Jack Gap and flows SE into Beetree Creek.

label: Gregory
description: community in W Currituck County. Alt. 9.

label: Gregory Bald
description: peak on the Swain County, N.C.-Blount County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park between Parsons Bald and Rich Gap. Alt. 4,948. Known earlier as Bald Spot Mountain.

label: Gregory Branch
description: rises in NW Haywood County and flows SE into Big Creek.

label: Gregory Crossroads
description: community in NW Onslow County near New River.

label: Gregory's Mill
description: community in E Granville County served by post office, 1848-1951.

label: Gresham's Lake
description: in central Wake County on Perry Creek NE of city of Raleigh. Formed in 1939 to cover 100 acres, with a max. depth of 30 ft. Named for owner, S. T. Gresham. Used for boating and fishing.

label: Gretna Green
description: community in W Halifax County.

label: Grey Eagle
description: See Black Mountain.

label: Greystone
description: community in E Vance County. Alt. 493. Settled by 1835 and named for gray granite once mined there in large quantities. Quarrying done by hand until 1885.

label: Grice Branch
description: rises in SE Buncombe County and flows SW into Broad River.

label: Gridiron
description: community in central Halifax County served by post office, 1900-1902.

label: Grier Bald
description: See Big Bald.

label: Griffins Crossroads
description: community in E Chatham County.

label: Griffins Township
description: NW Nash County.

label: Griffinsville
description: See Marshville.

label: Griffith
description: community in S Mecklenburg County.

label: Griffith Branch
description: rises in W Mitchell County and flows S into Brummett Creek.

label: Griffith's Mill Pond
description: See Worrells Mill Pond.

label: Griffton
description: See Grifton.

label: Grifton
description: town in S Pitt and N Lenoir Counties. Known as Peter's Ferry as early as 1756, when Presbyterian minister Hugh McAden stopped there; in 1764 it was called Blount's Ford; and in the mid-nineteenth century, it was called Bell's Ferry for the ferry operated by Warren Bell. Inc. in 1883 as Bell's Ferry. Name changed to Griffton in 1889 to honor C. M. A. Griffin, local merchant. Griffton soon came to be spelled Grifton. Produces apparel. Alt. 28.

label: Grifton Township
description: S Pitt County. Created after 1950.

label: Griggs Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SW between Fork Ridge and Old Mattie Ridge into Welch Mill Creek.

label: Grill Cove
description: NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Ekaneetlee Creek.

label: Grimes Crossroads
description: community in NE Forsyth County. Also known as Crims Crossroads.

label: Grimes Millpond
description: E Pitt County, drains into Chicod Creek.

label: Grimesland
description: town in E Pitt County. The first settlement there in the eighteenth century was known as Boyd's Ferry, a name that it retained until after 1880. (Boyd's Ferry across the Tar River, ½ mi. NE of the town, continued to operate until after 1909.) For a short while it was called Mount Calvert, and in 1885 the post office was named Nelsonville. In 1887 the name was changed to Grimesland in honor of J. Bryan Grimes (1828-80), Confederate general. Inc. 1893. Alt. 36.

label: Grimesland Township
description: E Pitt County. Created after 1950.

label: Grimshawes
description: community on the head of the Chattooga River in S Jackson County. Named for the first postmaster, Thomas Grimshawe Sr. Touted as site of "world's smallest post office."

label: Grimsley
description: community in N Ashe County served by post office, 1886-1911.

label: Grindle Creek
description: rises in N Pitt County and flows SE into Tar River. Probably named for the fish amiatus calva, commonly known as grindle.

label: Grindle Pocosin
description: N Pitt County.

label: Grindool
description: See Whitehurst.

label: Grindstone Branch
description: rises in central Anson County and flows N into Goulds Fork.

label: Grindstone Knob
description: E Macon County between Ellijay Creek and Walnut Creek.

label: Grindstone Ridge
description: NW Henderson County near Bradley Creek.

label: Grinnel Hill
description: community in N Tyrrell County near town of Columbia.

label: Grinnel Slough
description: stream and swamp in S Pitt County between Contentnea and Swift Creeks and bordered on the S by Neuse River. The stream flows NW into Contentnea Creek.

label: Grinnell Creek
description: swampy low grounds of SE Bertie County between Broad Creek and Middle River.

label: Grissett Swamp
description: rises in SW Columbus County and flows SE into Monie Swamp.

label: Grissettown
description: community in SW Brunswick County.

label: Grissom
description: community in SE Granville County served by post office, 1877-1914. Formerly called Slab Town.

label: Grist Mountain
description: E Davidson County between Flat Swamp Creek and Lick Creek.

label: Grists
description: community in W Columbus County.

label: Grit
description: community in NW Pender County served by post office, 1893-1905.

label: Grog Creek
description: rises in S Rutherford County and flows W into Broad River.

label: Grogan Creek
description: rises in N Transylvania County and flows NE into Davidson River.

label: Grogansville
description: town in NW Rockingham County est. on property of tobacco grower John P. Grogan. Inc. 1889 but never functioned as a municipality.

label: Groometown
description: community in S Guilford County. Named for local family.

label: Gross Mine
description: former gold mine in S Yadkin County on Harmon Creek.

label: Grotto
description: community in N Moore County served by post office, 1893-1905.

label: Groundhog Branch
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows SE into Yadkin Creek.

label: Groundhog Creek
description: rises in N Haywood County and flows SW into Pigeon River.

label: Groundhog Ridge
description: NW Cherokee County in the Unicoi Mountains.

label: Groundnut Creek
description: rises in NW Lenoir County and flows SE into Moseley Creek. Named for the groundnut, or peanut. Groundnut Swamp appears in local records as early as 1750-60.

label: Grove Creek
description: rises in central Duplin County and flows E into Northeast Cape Fear River. Appears on the Collet map, 1770, as Grove Swamp.

label: Grove Hill
description: community in S Warren County E of Buffalo Creek and S of Reedy Creek. Settled prior to 1800; post office est. 1828 but discontinued in 1954. In 1840 the post office name was temporarily changed to Owens Store. See also Fontena.

label: Grove Swamp
description: See Grove Creek.

label: Grove Township
description: E Harnett County. Named for Congressman William Barry Grove (1764-1818) of Fayetteville.

label: Grovemont
description: See Kenansville.

label: Grover
description: town in S Cleveland County. Inc. 1885. Alt. 877. Named for Grover Cleveland (1837-1908), president of the United States, 1885-89 and 1893-97. Produces textiles.

label: Grovestone
description: community in SE Buncombe County between Swannanoa and Black Mountain.

label: Gudger
description: See Newfoundland.

label: Gudger Knob
description: E Haywood County on the NE end of Crab Orchard Fields.

label: Gudger's Ford
description: See Azalea.

label: Gudger's Mills
description: community in NW Buncombe County served by post office, 1888-1906.

label: Guerilla Island
description: N Camden County. Used by local Confederates led by Capt. William Sanderlin. Target of Union troops under Gen. Edward Wild, 1863.

label: Guerrant Springs
description: See Oregon Hill.

label: Guffy Branch
description: rises in S Wake County and flows S into Ditch Branch.

label: Guide
description: community in S Columbus County.

label: Guilders Creek
description: rises in N central Yancey County on N slopes of Rocky Knob and Phillips Knob and flows NW into Jacks Creek.

label: Guilford
description: community in W central Guilford County. Named for the county.

label: Guilford College
description: town in W central Guilford County. Quaker settlement founded 1750 and known as New Garden. Boarding school opened 1837; renamed Guilford College in 1888, at which time the community name also was changed. Chartered 1895. The college is now within the limits of the city of Greensboro. Alt. 949.

label: Guilford County
description: was formed in 1771 from Rowan and Orange Counties. Located in the N central section of the state, it is bounded by Alamance, Randolph, Davidson, Forsyth, and Rockingham Counties. It was named for Francis North, first Earl of Guilford (1704-90), member of Parliament and intimate personal friend of George III and Queen Charlotte. Area: 652 sq. mi. County seat: Greensboro, with an elevation of 838 ft. Townships are Bruce, Center Grove, Clay, Deep River, Fentress, Friendship, Gilmer, Greene, High Point, Jamestown, Jefferson, Madison, Monroe, Morehead, Oak Ridge, Rock Creek, Sumner, and Washington. Produces tobacco, corn, wheat, oats, barley, rye, sorghum, poultry, eggs, dairy products, livestock, hogs, horses, greenhouse products, flowers, textiles, paper boxes, strawberries, soybeans, fabricated metals, aircraft parts, cigarettes, electronics, appliances, pharmaceuticals, toys, lumber, chemicals, and corrugated boxes.

label: Guilford Courthouse
description: former county seat, central Guilford County. Est. 1774; chartered as Martinville, which see, 1785; abandoned 1808. Battle there on March 15, 1781, between American Gen. Nathanael Greene and British general Lord Charles Cornwallis; site now a National Military Park.

label: Guinea Mill Run
description: a stream, rises in N Currituck County and flows SE into Tull Creek. A part of Dismal Swamp drains into Guinea Mill Run.

label: Gul Island
description: See Great Island.

label: Gulden Creek
description: rises in SE Craven County and flows NW into Clubfoot Creek.

label: Gulf
description: town in S central Chatham County. Inc. 1913, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Early nineteenth-century center of trade and coal mining. Alt. 275. The geographic center of the state, which see, is nearby.

label: Gulf Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows N into Big Laurel Branch.

label: Gulf Creek
description: rises in SE Chatham County and flows SW into Cape Fear River.

label: Gulf Prong
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows S to join Chasm Prong in forming Bradley Fork.

label: Gulf Stream
description: is a warm current in the Atlantic Ocean that flows out of the Gulf of Mexico along the E coast of the United States and E in the North Atlantic toward Europe. Along the coast of North Carolina, it approaches Cape Hatteras and gives that part of the state a milder winter than would otherwise be the case. Winter temperatures of the surface waters there are approx. 63°, while summer temperatures are about 80°. The Gulf Stream was first described by Benjamin Franklin, and it appears on a map prepared for him in 1770 by Timothy Folger.

label: Gulf Township
description: SW Chatham County.

label: Gull Island
description: a tiny island in SW Carteret County in Bogue Sound.

label: Gull Island Bay
description: on the W shore of Hatteras Island in the waters of Pamlico Sound, S Dare County opposite Gull Island.

label: Gull Rock
description: community in E Hyde County on Wyesocking Bay. A former post office there was Gulrock.

label: Gull Shoal
description: a small island in Pamlico Sound off the W shore of Hatteras Island, SE Dare County. The name appears in local records as early as 1794 as "Gull Shore."

label: Gull Shore
description: See Gull Shoal.

label: Gulledge Township
description: S central Anson County.

label: Gulley's Mill
description: community in S Wake County.

label: Gulley's Mills
description: community in SE Wake County served by post office, 1878-1903.

label: Gulrock
description: See Gull Rock.

label: Gum Branch
description: rises in W Hoke County and flows SE into Rockfish Creek.

label: Gum Branch
description: community in N Onslow County between Cowhorn Swamp and Bachelors Swamp. Mentioned in local records as early as 1748. Served by post office, 1860-1903.

label: Gum Corner
description: community in W Currituck County.

label: Gum Creek
description: rises in E Stanly County and flows SE into Cedar Creek.

label: Gum Fork
description: rises in N Lee County and flows NE into Hughes Creek.

label: Gum Forks
description: community in NW Northampton County.

label: Gum Lake
description: NE Nash County on Beaverdam Swamp.

label: Gum Log Creek
description: rises in S Union County and flows SE into Lanes Creek.

label: Gum Neck
description: community in S Tyrrell County on a canal, which flows SE into Alligator River.

label: Gum Neck Creek
description: commonly called Gum Neck Landing, rises in SE Tyrrell County and flows S into Alligator River. Appears as Landing Creek on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Gum Neck Landing
description: See Gum Neck Creek.

label: Gum Neck Township
description: S Tyrrell County.

label: Gum Pond
description: swamp in Grindle Pocosin in N Pitt County.

label: Gum Swamp
description: rises in SE Martin County and flows S into Beaufort County, where it enters Latham Creek.

label: Gum Swamp
description: rises in N Tyrrell County and flows NE into Albemarle Sound.

label: Gum Swamp Creek
description: rises in E Richmond County and NW Scotland County and flows S across Scotland County into South Carolina, where it enters Little Pee Dee River.

label: Gum Swamp Run
description: rises in SE Beaufort County in Gum Swamp and flows W into South Creek.

label: Gumberry
description: community in N central Northampton County. Settled about 1882. Alt. 134. Name probably derived from fruit of a tree described by John Lawson in 1709 as a type of black gum, the berries of which were used by the Indians in making soup and in cooking peas and beans.

label: Gumberry Swamp
description: rises in W Northampton County and flows S to join Lily Pond Creek in forming Wheeler Creek. For origin of name, see Gumberry.

label: Gumflats Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NW into Taylor Creek.

label: Gumlog Creek
description: rises in Union County, Ga., and flows NE into Clay County, where it enters Brasstown Creek.

label: Gumstand Gap
description: N Transylvania County on Seniard Ridge.

label: Gumtree
description: community in N Davidson County; named for a gum tree (cut down about 1948) at the junction of the Thomasville and Lexington roads to Winston-Salem.

label: Gun Creek
description: rises in W central Alamance County and flows SE into Great Alamance Creek.

label: Gunlock Ridge
description: W Swain County between Hickory Cove and Hazel Creek.

label: Gunna Creek
description: rises in NW Swain County and flows SW to join Tub-Mill Creek in Great Smoky Mountains National Park to form Eagle Creek.

label: Gunntown
description: community in central Rockingham County; est. 1854 by James M. Gunn and largely populated by his descendants.

label: Gunpowder Creek
description: rises in central Caldwell County and flows SE into Catawba River.

label: Gunt, Gun,
description: or from the Atlantic Ocean into Pamlico Sound through Bodie Island, opened prior to 1733 and closed in the 1770s. Appears as Gun Inlet on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Gunter Branch
description: rises in N Madison County and flows SW into Big Laurel Creek.

label: Gunter Fork
description: rises on the E slope of Luftee Knob, W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, and flows NE into Big Creek.

label: Gunter Gap
description: on the Jackson-Swain county line near the head of Connelly Creek in SE Swain County.

label: Gunter Knob
description: S Madison County at the head of Simmons Branch.

label: Guntertown
description: community in N Madison County on Barnes Creek.

label: Gupton
description: community in Franklin County. Alt. 300. Settled about 1898. Named for J. E. Gupton, local landowner.

label: Gurley Store
description: community in W Wayne County between Little River and Nahunta Swamp.

label: Gurleys Store
description: community in E central Rutherford County between Heaveners and Robinson Creeks.

label: Gusher Knob
description: mountain in SW Avery County. Site of a plant for processing fine china clay.

label: Gut, The
description: central Craven County, a channel extending between Bachelor Creek and Neuse River forming the N boundary of Hog Island. Approx. 1 mi. long.

label: Gutches Creek
description: rises in N Mitchell County and flows S into Little Rock Creek.

label: Guthrie
description: community in E Forsyth County. In 1858 Jackson Guthries and two other men from Virginia settled there and began growing tobacco.

label: Guthrie Point
description: extends from the mainland of SW Carteret County into Bogue Sound.

label: Gutter Branch
description: rises in W Mecklenburg County and flows W into Long Creek.

label: Guy Knob
description: S Macon County between Mashburn Branch and Hayes Mill Creek.

label: Guyton
description: community in W Bladen County served by post office, 1892-1922.

label: Gwaltneys Township
description: NE Alexander County.

label: Gwinns Millpond
description: SE Richmond and W Scotland Counties on Joes Creek. Covers 75 acres; max. depth 10 ft. Formed prior to 1909.

label: Gwyn
description: community in S Yadkin County served by post office, 1900-1907.

label: Gypsy
description: community in NW Henderson County served by post office, 1880-1902.

label: Haas Creek
description: rises in S Catawba County and flows S into Pott Creek.

label: Hachers Run
description: See Hatcher's Run.

label: Hack Gap Knob
description: N Madison County on Colvin Creek.

label: Hackett
description: community in W Watauga County.

label: Hacklan Branch
description: rises in N Gates County and flows s, where it is joined by Buckland Mill Branch in forming Cole Creek.

label: Hackney
description: community in SW Beaufort County.

label: Haddock
description: community in central Columbus County served by post office, 1884-1903.

label: Haddocks Crossroads
description: community in S Pitt County.

label: Hadley
description: community in E Duplin County approx. 3 mi. E of town of Beulaville.

label: Hadley Township
description: NW Chatham County.

label: Hadley's Mill Pond
description: See Contentnea Lake.

label: Hadleys Mill
description: community in central Chatham County on Landum Creek. An early nineteenth-century post office was there. Old mill still standing but not in use.

label: Hadnot Creek
description: rises in W Carteret County and flows about 5 mi. SW into White Oak River. Named for an early settler.

label: Hadnot Point
description: in central Onslow County at the junction of Wallace Creek and New River. The headquarters and hospital of Camp Lejeune Marine Corps Air Station are there. Said to have been named for Charles Hadnot, an early settler.

label: Hagaman
description: See Brushy Fork.

label: Hagan Creek
description: rises in S Surry County and flows SE into Yadkin River.

label: Hagan Fork
description: rises in central Catawba County and flows NE into McLin Creek.

label: Hagers
description: community in E Lincoln County served by post office, 1889-1903.

label: Hagers Mountain
description: N Person County between Fishing Branch and Mitchell Creek.

label: Haines Cove
description: E Haywood County between Conner Mill Branch and Anderson Mountain.

label: Haines Eyebrow
description: peak in NW McDowell County near the head of Buck Creek.

label: Hairston
description: town in SE Stokes County. Inc. 1793 as Hairstonborough, but long inactive in municipal affairs.

label: Hairy Bear Mountain
description: See Big Tom.

label: Halcher Swamp
description: rises in central Edgecombe County and flows NW into Harts Mill Run.

label: Halcombville
description: a town authorized in 1816 to be laid off on the lands of George D. Halcomb and Peter Dowel in Surry County. There is no evidence that the town was actually established.

label: Hale
description: community in N Avery County served by post office, 1911-15.

label: Hale Cove
description: N Buncombe County between Frosty Knob and Paint Fork.

label: Hale Wood
description: community in S Madison County served by post office, 1871-1908.

label: Hales Beach
description: a section of outer beach in SW Brunswick County extending from Shallotte Inlet to Tubbs Inlet.

label: Half Acre Ridge
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur extending NW from Cataloochee Divide near lat. 35°37'45" N., long. 83°04'15" W., between Den Branch and Winding Stair Branch.

label: Half Moon
description: community in N Onslow County between Bachelors Delight Swamp and Half Moon Creek.

label: Half Moon Branch
description: rises in NW Craven County and flows NE into Neuse River. Appears in local records as early as 1770. See also Cove Creek.

label: Half Moon Creek
description: rises in N Onslow County and flows W into New River. Appears as Half Moon Swamp in local records as early as 1744.

label: Half Moon Swamp
description: See Half Moon Creek.

label: Half-Moon Bay
description: W Carteret County in White Oak River between Terrapin Run and Hill's Bay. Named for the adjacent channel.

label: Half-Moon Channel
description: in White Oak River, W Carteret and E Onslow Counties. The channel has gradually filled in and is no longer the main channel of the river.

label: Halfway Point
description: the southernmost point of Mackay Island, NE Currituck County. A name given by steamboat men.

label: Halifax
description: town and county seat, N Halifax County on Roanoke River. Authorized to be laid out, 1757; inc. 1760. Named for George Montagu, second Earl of Halifax (1716-71), who was president of the Board of Trade at the time the town was est. Alt. 135. The legislature met there, 1779-81. Scene of meeting, April 12, 1775, where North Carolina representatives sanctioned American independence. See also Enfield.

label: Halifax County
description: was formed in 1758 from Edgecombe County. Located in the NE section of the state, it is bounded by Bertie, Martin, Edgecombe, Nash, Warren, and Northampton Counties. It was named for George Montagu, second Earl of Halifax (1716-71), president of the Board of Trade and Plantations and called the "Father of the Colonies" for his success in extending American commerce. Area: 724 sq. mi. County seat: Halifax, with an elevation of 135 ft. Townships are Brinkleyville, Butterwood, Conoconnara, Enfield, Faucett, Halifax, Littleton, Palmyra, Roanoke Rapids, Roseneath, Scotland Neck, and Weldon. Produces peanuts, corn, oats, soybeans, tobacco, cotton, poultry, hogs, livestock, rubber products, textiles, paper, lumber, apparel, and sand. See also Roanoke County.

label: Halifax District
description: at the time of the 1790 census, was composed of Caswell, Chatham, Granville, Orange, Randolph, and Wake Counties.

label: Halifax Township
description: E Halifax County.

label: Hall
description: community on Scotts Creek in N Jackson County.

label: Hall Creek
description: rises in SW tip of Burke County and flows N into Silver Creek.

label: Hall Knob
description: SW Burke County. Alt. approx. 1,850.

label: Hall Mountain
description: N Macon County in a bend of Little Tennessee River.

label: Hall Pocosin
description: N Gates County.

label: Hall Point
description: extends from mainland of NE Carteret County into mouth of Thorofare Bay.

label: Hall Pond
description: near the head of Little Beaverdam Creek in W Duplin County.

label: Hall Swamp
description: community in W Beaufort County.

label: Hall Top
description: central Haywood County on Chestnut Flat Ridge.

label: Hall Township
description: W Gates County. Formerly known as Scratch Hall Township; origin of name unknown.

label: Hall's Branch
description: rises in E Wake County and flows SW into Little River below Moore's Mill.

label: Hall's Creek
description: rises in E Onslow County and flows SW into Queens Creek. Named for early settlers Edward and/or Thomas Hall. Also known as Hotel Creek.

label: Hall's Gut
description: a drain in E central Hertford County that empties into Chowan River.

label: Hallback Mountain
description: S Yancey County approx. 1 mi. W of Mount Mitchell. Alt. 6,400 ft.

label: Hallison
description: See Parkwood.

label: Hallow
description: See Mount Airy.

label: Halloway
description: community in central Durham County.

label: Hallowing Point
description: extends from the mainland of central Craven County at New Bern into the Neuse-Trent River estuary opposite Union Point. Appears on the Lawson map, 1709, and the Moll map, 1729.

label: Halls
description: community in S Hertford County. Also known as Duke Hall or Dukie Hall's Crossing.

label: Halls Creek
description: rises in W Pasquotank County and flows SW into Little River. First North Carolina Assembly met on the banks of the creek in 1665.

label: Halls Crossroads
description: community in S Franklin County.

label: Halls Ferry
description: community in NE Davie County served by post office, 1878-1902. See also Siloam.

label: Halls Ferry Junction
description: community in N Stanly County. Named for the fact that railroad passengers changed trains there for the ferry over Yadkin River.

label: Halls Ford
description: S Swain County in Little Tennessee River at Horseshoe Bend.

label: Halls Harbor
description: a natural harbor in the S waters of Currituck Sound in S Currituck County.

label: Halls Knob
description: SW Cherokee County between the headwaters of Beech Creek and Nottely River.

label: Halls Marsh Branch
description: rises in N Duplin County and flows S into Goshen Swamp.

label: Halls Mill Creek
description: rises in N Wilkes County and flows SW into Mulberry Creek.

label: Halls Mills
description: community in N Wilkes County on Mulberry Creek.

label: Halls Point
description: S Onslow County, extends into New River.

label: Halls Township
description: N central Sampson County.

label: Hallsboro
description: town in central Columbus County. Settled 1888; inc. 1889, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Named for family of original settler. Produces lumber. Alt. 66.

label: Hallsborough
description: See Hallsville.

label: Hallsville
description: community on E side of Northeast Cape Fear River near the mouth of Limestone Creek, central Duplin County. Authorized to be laid out in 1818 on the lands of William Hall Sr. and sons and named Hallsborough. Post office est. as early as 1828.

label: Ham
description: community in central Bladen County served by post office, 1885-1912.

label: Hambey Bend
description: a bend in Hiwassee River, W Cherokee County, near the mouth of Anderson Creek below Hiwassee Dam.

label: Hambton Creek
description: rises in S Cherokee County and flows NW into Hiwassee River.

label: Hamburg Ditch
description: flows through Dismal Swamp in NE Gates County, connecting Corapeake Swamp with Cross Canal in NW Camden County. Both canals were known as Cross Canal in 1808 and as White Oak Spring Canal in 1833.

label: Hamburg Gap
description: on the Jackson-Macon county line N of Yellow Mountain.

label: Hamburg Mountain
description: N Buncombe County E of Weaverville. Alt. 2,910. Traditionally the site of neutral hunting grounds used by Cherokee and Catawba Indians.

label: Hamburg Township
description: SW Jackson County.

label: Hamby Branch
description: rises in E central Cabarrus County and flows S into Rocky River.

label: Hamby Mountain
description: W Wilkes County between Smithies Creek and North Prong Lewis Fork Creek. Probably named for William Hamby, an eighteenth-century settler on North Prong Lewis Fork Creek.

label: Hambys Creek
description: rises in E Davidson County and flows SW and NW into Rich Fork Creek.

label: Hamer
description: community in N central Caswell County. A post office operated there, 1882-1904.

label: Hamer Creek
description: rises in SW Montgomery County and flows SE into Richmond County, where it enters Little River.

label: Hamilton
description: town in N Martin County on Roanoke River. Known as Milton prior to 1804, when the name was changed to Hamilton and the town inc. Probably named for Alexander Hamilton (1757-1804). Also in 1804 the polling place at nearby Hogtown, which see, was combined with that at Hamilton. Produces textiles.

label: Hamilton Creek
description: See Washington Creek.

label: Hamilton Hollow
description: valley in NW Swain County between Fox Gap and Twentymile Creek.

label: Hamilton Lakes
description: former town in central Guilford County est. by Alfred M. Scales. Inc. 1925; merged with city of Greensboro in 1945.

label: Hamilton Township
description: See Catawba Township.

label: Hamiltons Crossroads
description: community in E Union County W of Gourdvine Creek.

label: Hamiltons Old Field
description: former community in central Rutherford County 3 mi. N of present Rutherfordton. In 1862 residents claimed to have been the first to nominate Zebulon B. Vance for governor.

label: Hamlet
description: town in S Richmond County. Settled about 1875. Inc. 1897. Named by John Shortridge, local citizen, for the word then descriptive of its size. An important railroad center with maintenance shops, hump classification yard, and other facilities. Produces dairy products, apparel, and furniture. Alt. 349.

label: Hamlins Shoals
description: rapids in Roanoke River, NW Halifax County, extending from the mouth of Stonehouse Creek to Tucker Island. The name appears on the MacRae map, 1833. See also Tucker Island.

label: Hammer Branch
description: rises in N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows SE into Deep Creek.

label: Hammers Millpond
description: in W Robeson and SW Scotland Counties on Little Pee Dee River.

label: Hammock, The
description: E bank of the mouth of Queens Creek in SE Onslow County. Called Starkey's Hammock in the 1790s, when it was owned by Edward Starkey. Long site of summer meetings by black teachers.

label: Hammocks Beach
description: resort on Bear Island, Onslow County. A state park.

label: Hammond Mountain
description: S Henderson County between Mill Creek and Cabin Creek. Alt. 2,978.

label: Hammonds Creek
description: rises in central Bladen County and flows NE into Cape Fear River. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Hampstead
description: community in SE Pender County. Alt. 56.

label: Hampton
description: See Ruth.

label: Hampton Bay
description: See Pettivers Bay.

label: Hampton Branch
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows NE into Mine Fork Creek.

label: Hampton Lake
description: in S Jackson County on Fowler Creek at High Hampton Estate about 1 mi. E of town of Cashiers. Named for Wade Hampton, South Carolina governor and Confederate general, founder of the estate. Was formed in 1918 and today covers 24 acres, with a max. depth of 25 ft. Used for recreation.

label: Hampton Lodge
description: community on N end of Church Island in central Currituck County.

label: Hampton Township
description: NW Davidson County.

label: Hamptonville
description: town in S Yadkin County near South Deep Creek. Settled about 1738; chartered 1818, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Named for Hampton family, early settlers who came from England.

label: Hamrick
description: community in SE Yancey County on South Toe River.

label: Hams Crossroads
description: community in E Pitt County.

label: Hancock Bay
description: E Carteret County between Tusk Creek and Middens Creek.

label: Hancock Creek
description: rises in S Craven County and flows N into Neuse River. Now within the limits of Cherry Point Marine Corps Air Station. Appears as Handcocks Creek on the Moseley map, 1733. See also Hancock Town.

label: Hancock Point
description: W Carteret County, extends into White Oak River.

label: Hancock Town
description: appears on Moseley map, 1733, as Handcocks Town in present Craven County. It was the Tuscarora Indian village of King Hancock, who participated in the 1710 attack on New Bern.

label: Hancock Village
description: part of Cherry Point housing area in SE Craven County. See also Cherry Point.

label: Handpole Branch
description: rises in central Avery County and flows N into Kentucky Creek.

label: Handy
description: community in SE Davidson County. Residents formerly received mail at Jackson Hill, 3 mi. w, and wanted a post office that would be "handy" for them. Post office est. 1889, discontinued 1931.

label: Handy Gap
description: N Wilkes County on Carters Mountain. Named for local family.

label: Hanes
description: or former community in S Forsyth County. Named for Hanes family, which est. a mill village there. Now within the corporate limits of Winston-Salem. Alt. 887.

label: Haney Creek
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows E into Elk Fork.

label: Hanging Bluff
description: See Hanging Rock State Park.

label: Hanging Dog
description: community in NW Cherokee County.

label: Hanging Dog Creek
description: rises in N Cherokee County on Hanging Dog Mountain and flows SW into Hiwassee River. It was named because an Indian's hunting dog became hung in a mass of jammed logs and vines in the flooded creek.

label: Hanging Dog Gap
description: N Cherokee County in the N end of Hanging Dog Mountain.

label: Hanging Dog Mountain
description: extends from central Cherokee County NE into the Snowbird Mountains in SW Graham County. Named peaks include Buzzard Roost, High Peak, and Rocky Knob.

label: Hanging Rock
description: E Mitchell County between Hanging Rock Branch and Gouges Creek.

label: Hanging Rock Branch
description: rises in E Mitchell County and flows SW into Beaver Creek.

label: Hanging Rock Ridge
description: extends NE from Hanging Rock on the Avery-Watauga county line between Dutch Creek and Watauga River to Townsend Gap in S Watauga County.

label: Hanging Rock State Park
description: central Stokes County in the Sauratown Mountain range. Named for a natural rock formation. Contains 3,865 acres. Est. 1935. Scenic, recreational; vacation cabins and tent and trailer camping; picnicking, swimming, boating, fishing, hiking, and nature study; lookout tower. See also Cascade Falls; Moores Knob; Tories Den. Appears as Hanging Bluff on the Kerr map, 1882.

label: Hangman Branch
description: rises in Drowned Bay, SW Brunswick County, and flows S into Calabash Creek.

label: Hangover Creek
description: rises in W Graham County in Saddle Tree Gap and flows NW into Slickrock Creek.

label: Hangover Lead
description: NW Graham County, extends NW from Saddle Tree Gap to Cold Spring Knob and NE from Cold Spring Knob to Yellow-hammer Gap.

label: Hangover Mountain
description: W Graham County near the Tennessee line. Alt. approx. 5,180.

label: Hankins
description: community in E central McDowell County.

label: Hanks Branch
description: rises in E Davidson County and flows E into Hunts Fork.

label: Hanlon Mountain
description: NW Buncombe County E of Fodderstack Mountain. Alt. 3,197.

label: Hannah Branch
description: rises in E Yancey County and flows W into South Toe River.

label: Hannah Creek
description: rises in W Johnston County and flows SE into Mill Creek.

label: Hannah Mountain
description: S Macon County between Mulberry Gap and Norton Branch.

label: Hannersville
description: community in central Davidson County served by post office, 1859-1920.

label: Hanrahan
description: community in SW Pitt County.

label: Hanted Pond, The
description: See Jumping Run.

label: Haoe (hey-yo)
description: mountain in W Graham County near the Tennessee line. Alt. 5,249. Named after John Stratton Sr., pioneer settler who climbed the mountain, straddled the line, and looked into Tennessee and shouted "Hey-yo." He then turned toward North Carolina and repeated the shout.

label: Haoe Lead
description: W Graham County between Saddle Tree Gap and Rock Creek Knob.

label: Haoe Trail
description: encircles Joyce Kilmer Memorial Forest in W Graham County and leads through the center of the forest following the main course of Little Santeetlah Creek.

label: Hap Mountain
description: SW Madison County. Alt. 4,072.

label: Happy Hill
description: S Macon County between High Holly and Pipetrack Gap.

label: Happy Home
description: See Connelly Springs; Rutherford College.

label: Happy Top
description: S Cherokee County S of Nottely River and W of Laudermilk Bend.

label: Happy Valley
description: the valley of the upper Yadkin River in N central Caldwell County between the town of Patterson and the Wilkes County line. Site of the homes of several prominent early settlers.

label: Harbinger
description: community on S tip of Currituck County. Named for a steamboat that once docked there.

label: Harbon Cove
description: E Haywood County on Bald Creek.

label: Harbor Channel
description: S Carteret County in Bogue Sound between Morehead City and Sugar Loaf Island.

label: Harbor Island
description: E New Hanover County W of Wrightsville Beach.

label: Harbour
description: community in S Surry County served by post office, 1889-1906.

label: Hard Ridge
description: S Haywood County, extends NE in an arc from the head of Gaddis Branch to Factor Branch.

label: Hard Slate Gap
description: W Graham County between Hooper Mill Creek and Snowbird Creek.

label: Hardbargain Branch
description: rises in NE Rutherford County and flows SE into First Broad River.

label: Hardee Creek
description: rises in S Pitt County and flows N into Tar River.

label: Hardin
description: town in N Gaston County on South Fork Catawba River. Inc. 1887 as Hardin and in 1897 as town of Hardin Cotton Mills. Prior to 1887, that portion of the town on the N side of the river was known as Worth, which is still the railroad name. Long inactive in municipal affairs. Alt. 679.

label: Hardin Creek
description: rises in central Watauga County and flows SE into South Fork New River.

label: Harding Swamp
description: rises in W Beaufort County and flows W to join Juniper Swamp in forming East Branch Chicod Creek. Mentioned in local records as early as 1750.

label: Hardison Mill Creek
description: rises in S Martin County and flows NW into Statons Pond on Sweetwater Creek.

label: Hardscrabble Branch
description: rises in W Yancey County and flows NE into Cane River. Named by early settlers, who found the soil there to be so unproductive that they had a "hard scrabble" to make a living.

label: Hardy
description: community in W Johnston County.

label: Hardy Creek
description: rises in S Stanly County and flows S into Rocky River.

label: Hardy Mill Branch
description: rises in W Johnston County and flows NE into Black Creek.

label: Hardy Store
description: community in E Wayne County near West Bear Creek. Named for a family living in the area before the Revolution.

label: Hare Snipe Creek
description: rises in NW Wake County and flows SE into Crabtree Creek.

label: Hare's Mill Pond
description: E Hertford County near the mouth of Deep Creek. Formed about 1736. Covers approx. 75 acres; max. depth 10 ft.

label: Hares Branch
description: rises in W Hertford County and flows NE into Worrell Mill Pond.

label: Hares Creek
description: rises in S Graham County and flows NE into Tulula Creek. Named for Jim Hare, early black resident of the area.

label: Hares Crossroads
description: community in N Johnston County.

label: Hargetts Store
description: community in W Jones County.

label: Hargrove
description: See Providence.

label: Hargrove Crossroads
description: community in NE Sampson County.

label: Hariots Island
description: See Batts Island.

label: Harkers Island
description: SE Carteret County between The Straits and Back Sound, approx. 5 mi. long and 1 mi. wide. Granted to Thomas Sparrow, March 21, 1714; later sold to Ebenezer Harker, September 15, 1730. Known as Craney Island until 1783, when three brothers who owned the island—Zachary, James, and Ebenezer Harker—divided it among themselves. In 1957 the entire island was inc. as the town of Harkers Island. Appears as Davers Island on the Smith map, 1624, and as Crane Island on the Moseley map, 1733. On the latter map, the name Harker appears to denote the owner.

label: Harkers Island Township
description: on Back Sound, The Straits, and the Atlantic Ocean in S Carteret County. Believed to have been home of Manteo, the Indian who befriended the Roanoke colonists, 1587.

label: Harley
description: community in W Wilkes County on South Prong Lewis Fork Creek. Named for Harley Thompson, nineteenth-century resident.

label: Harley Branch
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows SW into East Fork Pigeon River.

label: Harlowe
description: community in N central Carteret County on Harlowe Creek.

label: Harlowe Canal
description: See Clubfoot Canal.

label: Harlowe Creek
description: rises in central Carteret County and flows S into Newport River. A canal connects the creek with Clubfoot Creek, affording a waterway from Neuse River to Newport River.

label: Harlowe Township
description: on Newport River and Core Creek, N central Carteret County; formed from a part of Newport Township in 1917.

label: Harm Creek
description: rises in E Henderson County and flows E into Polk County, where it enters Brights Creek.

label: Harmiller Gap
description: N Yancey County near the head of Howell Branch.

label: Harmon
description: community in NW Wilkes County near the head of North Fork Reddies River.

label: Harmon Creek
description: rises in S Yadkin County and flows NE into South Deep Creek.

label: Harmon Den Mountain
description: N Haywood County between Cold Springs Creek and Tom Hall Branch.

label: Harmon Gap
description: N Avery County.

label: Harmon Knob
description: N Watauga County S and W of Norris Fork.

label: Harmon's Crossroads
description: See Aulander.

label: Harmony
description: town in NE Iredell County. Originally known as Harmony Hill because of the "protracted" or "harmony" meetings held there beginning about 1850. Inc. 1874 as Harmony Hill Camp Ground; name changed to Harmony in 1927. A late nineteenth-century academy there became the first high school in the county, 1907. Alt. 993.

label: Harmony Hill Camp Ground
description: See Harmony.

label: Harnet Cove
description: SW Buncombe County SW of Yellow Gap.

label: Harnett
description: community in S Harnett County. Gravel deposits are present.

label: Harnett County
description: was formed in 1855 from Cumberland County. Located in the E section of the state, it is bounded by Chatham, Cumberland, Hoke, Moore, Lee, Wake, and Johnston Counties. It was named for Cornelius Harnett (1723-81), Revolutionary War patriot, president of the Provincial Council and the Council of Safety, and delegate to the Continental Congress. Area: 607 sq. mi. County seat: Lillington, with an elevation of 325 ft. Townships are Anderson Creek, Averasboro, Barbecue, Black River, Buckhorn, Duke, Grove, Hectors Creek, Johnsonville, Lillington, Neills Creek, Stewarts Creek, and Upper Little River. Produces tobacco, corn, wheat, oats, soybeans, cotton, sweet potatoes, poultry, hogs, livestock, pumpkins, mobile homes, concrete products, lumber, textiles, sand, and gravel.

label: Harnett Township
description: E New Hanover County.

label: Harold
description: See South Creek.

label: Harper Branch
description: rises in central Jones County and flows E into Mill Run.

label: Harper Creek
description: rises in N Henderson County and flows SE into Clear Creek.

label: Harpers
description: community in S Johnston County served by post office, 1876-1903.

label: Harpers Crossroads
description: community in SW Chatham County E of Beck Mountain.

label: Harpertown
description: community in Wilkes County on W outskirts of Lenoir. Largely African American; founded by former slaves.

label: Harrell Swamp
description: rises in E Gates County and flows SW to join Duke Swamp and Raynor Swamp in forming Bennetts Creek.

label: Harrell Township
description: N central Mitchell County.

label: Harrells
description: town largely in SE Sampson County, although a small area of the inc. limits lies in SW Duplin County. Appears as Harrells Store on the Morse-Breese map, 1843. Inc. 1943 as Harrells Store; name changed to Harrells, 1955. Alt. 88.

label: Harrells Bay
description: swamp in SW Duplin County.

label: Harrells Quarter
description: community in SE Bertie County.

label: Harrellsville
description: town in SE Hertford County on Wiccacon River. Inc. 1883. Post office est. there in 1827 as Bethel. Name changed to Harrellsville in 1847 to honor Abner Harrell.

label: Harrellsville Township
description: SE Hertford County.

label: Harrelson Branch
description: rises in N Duplin County and flows E into Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: Harrelsonville
description: community in central Columbus County.

label: Harricane
description: community in N Wake County. For many years the area was notorious for its distillers. The name came from a hurricane that struck the section in 1805, causing extensive damage.

label: Harrington
description: community in W Harnett County. Cornwallis camped there en route to Wilmington following the Battle of Guilford Courthouse. A post office was est. there, 1855. John McLean Harrington edited and published a handwritten newspaper there, 1858-60.

label: Harris
description: community in S Moore County between Big Juniper Creek and McLendons Creek.

label: Harris
description: community in S Rutherford County. Est. about 1909 when the Carolina, Clinchfield, and Ohio Railway built a station there. Post office est. 1912 as Orenburg since there was another post office named Harris in the state. In 1914 the first Harris post office closed, and the name was then taken by the former Orenburg post office. Named for a local family.

label: Harris Branch
description: rises in W Yancey County and flows S into Lickskillet Branch.

label: Harris Burgh
description: appears on the Collet map, 1770. It was the location of the Granville County courthouse for various periods between 1746 and 1764 and was located between Hachers Run and Fishing Creek SE of the present town of Oxford. Named for Sherwood Harris, a local citizen. In 1778 it was described by James Iredell as containing "half a dozen straggling houses, and is a burlesque upon a town." It continued to exist, however, until Oxford was made the county seat in 1811.

label: Harris Creek
description: rises in N Wilkes County and flows SE into Double Creek.

label: Harris Crossroads
description: community in W Vance County on the head of Crooked Run.

label: Harris Depot
description: See Harrisburg.

label: Harris Gap
description: W Jackson County between West Fork [Barkers Creek] and Nation Creek.

label: Harris Lake
description: SE Macon County on Satulah Branch.

label: Harris Landing
description: community and landing on Chowan River, W Chowan County. Also known as Tynch Town.

label: Harris Mill Run
description: rises in W central Pitt County and flows NE into Tar River.

label: Harris Millpond
description: W Pitt County on Tyson Creek.

label: Harris Mine
description: See Harris.

label: Harris Mountain
description: See Shumont Mountain.

label: Harris Swamp Branch
description: rises in E central Brunswick County and flows E into Mills Creek.

label: Harris Top
description: SW Cherokee County on Pack Mountain between Pack Top and Signal Pole Hill. Alt. approx. 2,815.

label: Harris Township
description: N Stanly County.

label: Harris View
description: mountain peak in SE Buncombe County near the Rutherford County line.

label: Harrisburg
description: See Harris Burgh.

label: Harrison
description: former community in S Mecklenburg County, was visited by George Washington, May 28, 1791. Harrison Methodist Church there was organized about 1785 and named for Harrison Hood, donor of the site. With the development of Pineville, 3 mi. w, after 1873, Harrison began to decline.

label: Harrison Branch
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows N into Hodges Creek.

label: Harrison Creek
description: See Dawson's Landing.

label: Harrison Gap
description: S Macon County at the head of Lowery Creek.

label: Harrisons Creek
description: rises in S Cumberland County and flows S into Bladen County, where it enters Cape Fear River.

label: Harrisons Crossroads
description: community in E Rockingham County named for local landowner William Harrison.

label: Harriston
description: See Ayden.

label: Harrisville
description: community in S Montgomery County.

label: Harrold Mountain
description: See Herald Mountain.

label: Harrys Branch
description: rises in SW Duplin County near Bearford Bay and flows SW into Rockfish Creek.

label: Harshaw Bottom
description: a sandy strip along the Hiwassee River in E Cherokee County.

label: Harshaw Branch
description: rises in SE Cherokee County on Poor House Mountain and flows SE into Hambton Creek.

label: Harshaw Gap
description: central Cherokee County near a bend in West Prong Grape Creek before it flows into Grape Creek.

label: Hart Branch
description: rises in E Transylvania County and flows NE into Little River.

label: Hartford
description: See Hertford.

label: Hartland
description: community in W Caldwell County. Formerly known as Tuttles Cross Roads for Andrew Hull Tuttle, early nineteenth-century merchant there.

label: Hartleys Creek
description: rises in W Davidson County and flows NW into Yadkin River.

label: Hartman
description: community in central Stokes County.

label: Harts
description: community in W Rowan County served by post office, 1876-1903.

label: Harts Mill Run
description: rises in central Edgecombe County and flows NE into Tar River.

label: Hartsboro
description: community in central Edgecombe County.

label: Hartsease
description: See Heartsease.

label: Hartshorn
description: community in central Alamance County served by post office, 1849-1916.

label: Hartsville
description: community in NE Wake County.

label: Harvard
description: community in S Yancey County.

label: Harvel Bay
description: sand-filled bay in SE Sampson County at the head of Clear Run Swamp. See also Carolina Bays.

label: Harvey
description: See Harveys Neck.

label: Harveys Neck
description: peninsula in E Perquimans County extending into Albemarle Sound between Perquimans and Yeopim Rivers. Home of John Harvey (d. about 1679), colonial governor, and Thomas Harvey (d. 1699), governor, 1694-99. Appears simply as Harvey on the Hack map, 1684.

label: Harveytown
description: former community N of Kinston in E Lenoir County. Now within the corporate limits of Kinston. Flourished following the Civil War when Amos Harvey and his son, Lemuel, rented property there to former slaves who moved into town from surrounding plantations.

label: Harwells Island
description: silty clay island in Roanoke River in NW Northampton County, SW of the community of Vultare. Appears as Jones Island on the Price map, 1808, but as Harwells Island on the MacRae map, 1833.

label: Haslett Township
description: N central Gates County.

label: Haslin
description: community in NE Beaufort County served by post office, 1874-1907.

label: Hassell
description: town in W Martin County. Settled about 1878 and known as Dogville Crossroads until inc. in 1903. Named for Primitive Baptist elder Sylvester Hassell (1842-1928). Alt. 78.

label: Hastings Corner
description: community in E central Camden County. Named for the Hastings family, which settled there about 1700.

label: Hasty
description: town in S Scotland County. Inc. 1889, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Named for a family that owned land there when a railroad flag stop was est. Alt. 197.

label: Hatch Point
description: S Onslow County, extends into New River. Probably named for Lemuel Hatch, who owned property in the vicinity in 1760.

label: Hatchell's Point
description: See Windmill Point.

label: Hatcher's Run
description: rises in W Granville County and flows S and E into Fishing Creek. Appears on 1770 Collet map as Hatches Run.

label: Hatorask
description: See Hatteras Island.

label: Hatorask Inlet
description: from the Atlantic Ocean into Roanoke Sound through Bodie Island, opened prior to 1585 and closed prior to 1657. The site was a short distance N of present Oregon Inlet, E Dare County. At various times, Hatorask Inlet was also known as Port Fernando and under other spellings of Hatorask.

label: Hatrask
description: See Hatteras Island.

label: Hattaway Mountain
description: E Stanly County between Little Mountain Creek and Sugarloaf Mountain.

label: Hatteras
description: community near the S end of Hatteras Island, E Dare County. Inc. 1931, but never active in municipal affairs. The name apparently is an English rendition of the Algonquian Indian expression meaning "there is less vegetation." Post office est. there, 1858. Alt. 10.

label: Hatteras Bight
description: a cove in the Atlantic Ocean off the S shore of Hatteras Island at Cape Hatteras, S Dare County.

label: Hatteras Inlet
description: from the Atlantic Ocean into Pamlico Sound, lies between Hatteras Island, S Dare County, on the N and Ocracoke Island, S Hyde County, on the S. It was opened by a storm in 1846. Previously was closer to Ocracoke Inlet and closed in 1760s. From 1760s to 1846, Cape Hatteras was joined to Ocracoke Island.

label: Hatteras Island
description: one of the Outer Banks of E Dare County extending from Hatteras Inlet on the S to New Inlet and Oregon Inlet on the n. Appears as Hatrask on the White map, 1585, though at that time the name was not applied to as much of the Island as today. The name appears as Hattorask, though misplaced, on the Comberford map, 1657. Smith's map, 1624, calls it Hertfords Island, while the Moseley map, 1733, gives it its present name. See also Croatoan Island; Paquiac.

label: Hatteras Shoals
description: See Diamond Shoals.

label: Hatteras Slough
description: See Diamond Shoals.

label: Hatteras Township
description: S Hatteras Island, E Dare County on the Outer Banks.

label: Hatteras Woods
description: a heavily wooded area, 8 mi. in length N of Cape Hatteras in SE Dare County. At 2,500 acres, largest maritime forest in North Carolina. Extensive stand of mixed hardwoods and pines. Also known as Cape Hatteras Woods or Buxton Woods Coastal Reserve.

label: Hatters Branch
description: rises in NE Wake County and flows SW into Smiths Creek.

label: Hattie
description: community in W Watauga County named for Hattie Farthing.

label: Hatton Island
description: See Isle Hatton.

label: Haulover Point
description: a peninsula extending W into Albemarle Sound from the N mainland of Dare County. It is near the E tip of Durant Island.

label: Haunty Branch
description: rises in S central Transylvania County and flows NW into French Broad River.

label: Havelock
description: town in SE Craven County on Slocum Creek. Settled prior to 1857 and named in that year when the Atlantic and North Carolina Railroad from Goldsboro to Morehead City reached the area. Named for Sir Henry Havelock (1795-1857), British major general and noted Baptist layman who dramatically relieved British forces garrisoned at Lucknow, India, on September 25, 1857. Alt. 24. Cherry Point Marine Corps Air Station, which see, is adjacent.

label: Haw Branch
description: rises in N Buncombe County near Cherry Log Gap and flows N into Dillingham Creek.

label: Haw Branch
description: community in NW Onslow County on New River.

label: Haw Cove
description: SW Avery County.

label: Haw Creek
description: rises in W Orange County and flows SW into Alamance County, where it enters Haw River. Appears as Jumping Run on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Haw Fields
description: name given by traders in the early eighteenth century to the region occupied by Saxapahaw and Sissipahaw Indians between the Haw and Eno Rivers in what is now Alamance and Orange Counties. The Indians had left by the time the first white settlers arrived, and they called the region "Haw old fields," a name mentioned in 1728 by William Byrd. Haw Fields was used in 1736 in connection with a land grant there. Edward Moseley patented 10,000 acres of land in the region on November 6, 1728.

label: Haw Gap
description: NW Swain County on Jenkins Trail Ridge in Great Smoky Mountains National Park.

label: Haw Gap Branch
description: rises in NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows SE across the park boundary for a distance of 4.5 mi. into Hazel Creek.

label: Haw Knob
description: on Jess Ridge in N Buncombe County near lat. 35°44' N., long. 82°27' W. Known as Rocky Knob until 1932, when the name was changed to eliminate duplication of names in the same vicinity.

label: Haw Knob
description: on the Graham County, N.C.-Monroe County, Tenn., line. Alt. 5,472.

label: Haw Mill Creek
description: rises in W Pender County and flows S into Black River. Formerly called Hawes Mill Creek.

label: Haw Patch
description: a level area below the peak of Fork Mountain in N Mitchell County.

label: Haw Pocosin
description: NW Bertie County.

label: Haw Ridge
description: NE Mitchell County parallel to Holder Creek.

label: Haw River
description: community in E Alamance County on Haw River. Founded by descendants of Adam Trollinger, a German immigrant who settled there in 1747. His son, Jacob, built a gristmill at the site, and for many years it was known as Trollinger's Crossing or Trollinger's Ford. Alt. 539. Produces textiles.

label: Haw River State Park
description: in S Rockingham and N Guilford Counties. Est. 2003. Facilities for recreation along waters of Haw River.

label: Haw River Township
description: SE Chatham County.

label: Hawbranch
description: community in NE Moore County. Also spelled Haw Branch.

label: Hawes Mill Creek
description: See Haw Mill Creek.

label: Hawk
description: community in E Mitchell County at the junction of Right Fork [Cane Creek] and Left Fork [Cane Creek]. A post office there known as Hawk Mine operated from 1872 to 1883.

label: Hawk Branch
description: community in N Yancey County between Middle Fork Hawk Branch and South Fork Hawk Branch.

label: Hawk Creek
description: rises in E Mitchell County and flows SW into Left Fork [Cane Creek].

label: Hawk Knob
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Welch Ridge. Alt. 4,940.

label: Hawk Mine
description: See Hawk.

label: Hawk Mountain
description: E Mitchell County between Big Spring Gap and Little Yellow Mountain. Alt. approx. 5,450.

label: Hawk Mountain
description: W Transylvania County on Toxaway River.

label: Hawk Ridge
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur extending W from Welch Ridge between Huggins Branch and Elbow Branch.

label: Hawkbill Creek
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows NE into Mineral Creek.

label: Hawkbill Gap
description: NE Buncombe County between Hawkbill Rock and Snowball Mountain.

label: Hawkbill Rock
description: prominent rock mass in NE Buncombe County near lat. 35Â°42'30" N., long. 82Â°24'45" W., in Pisgah National Forest. When viewed from the valley below, the rock has the appearance of a hawk's bill.

label: Hawkins Bay
description: off the N end of Huggins Island in the mouth of White Oak River, SE Onslow County. Named for Bazel Hawkins.

label: Hawkins Branch
description: rises in N Washington County and drains W into Chappel Swamp.

label: Hawkins County
description: now in Tennessee, was created in 1787 and named in honor of Benjamin Hawkins (1754-1816). Rogersville became the county seat. The county was a part of the territory ceded by North Carolina in 1789 to the federal government.

label: Hawkins Island
description: in the E end of Brown's Sound, S Onslow County.

label: Hawkins Knob
description: E Jackson County near Caney Fork between Chastine Creek and Mull Creek.

label: Hawkins Mill Creek
description: rises in N Stokes County and flows SW into Snow Creek.

label: Hawkins Slough
description: channel among the tidalmarsh islands in White Oak River W of Swansboro, E Onslow County. Named for Bazel Hawkins. Also known as Ward's Creek.

label: Hawksbill Mountain
description: NW Burke County near the SE end of Jonas Ridge. Alt. 4,020. Known by the Cherokee Indians as Nokassa

label: Hawkside
description: community in N Onslow County.

label: Hawley's Store
description: community in Sampson County served by post office, 1848-1907.

label: Hawns
description: town chartered in 1749 to be laid out on 36 acres in Northampton County at the plantation of Samuel Jordan on the N side of Roanoke River. "Lots of half an acre each with convenient streets and squares" were authorized but apparently never laid off. The name came from the title of one of the Lords Proprietors, Baron Carteret of Hawnes and Earl Granville. See also Granville District.

label: Hawra
description: community in SW Wilson County near the head of Lee Swamp. Post office, 1898-1903.

label: Haws Run
description: rises in W Onslow County and flows E into Southwest Creek.

label: Hawshore Mountain
description: S central Avery County.

label: Hawtree Creek
description: rises in N central Warren County and flows N into Virginia, where it enters Roanoke River. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Hawtree Township
description: N Warren County.

label: Hay Meadow
description: community in N central Wilkes County on Bee Tree Branch.

label: Hay Meadow Creek
description: rises in N Wilkes County and flows S into Mulberry Creek.

label: Hay Stack
description: See Haystack.

label: Haydon Top
description: S Cherokee County S of Murphy.

label: Hayes Branch
description: rises in central Watauga County and flows S into Laurel Creek.

label: Hayes Cove
description: SW Buncombe County W of Bent Mountain.

label: Hayes Gap
description: N Cherokee County in Hanging Dog Mountain.

label: Hayes Mill Creek
description: rises in S Macon County and flows W into Little Tennessee River.

label: Hayes Mountain
description: SE Wilkes County near the Alexander County line.

label: Hayes Ridge
description: E Swain County between Williams Branch and Wesser Creek.

label: Hayes Run
description: rises in S Madison County and flows SW into French Broad River.

label: Hayes Top
description: SW Buncombe County NW of Dix Creek Gap.

label: Hayesville
description: or former township in NW Franklin County, now township no. 5.

label: Hayesville Township
description: SW Clay County.

label: Hayne
description: community in W Sampson County served by post office, 1887-1941. Alt. 153.

label: Haynes Knob
description: N Haywood County between Crawford Gap and Wesley Creek. Alt. approx, 3,500.

label: Haynes Pond
description: on Mingo Swamp on the Harnett-Sampson county line. A little more than ½ mi. in length.

label: Hays
description: community in N central Wilkes County between Hay Meadow Creek and the head of Camp Branch. A former post office est. there in the 1899 was named for the first postmaster, Paulina Hays Elledge; discontinued 1953.

label: Hays Knob
description: SW Cherokee County between Wildcat Cove and Potato Creek.

label: Hays Mill Creek
description: rises in central Cherokee County and flows SE into Valley River.

label: Hayseed
description: community in SW Catawba County served by post office, 1892-1905.

label: Haystack
description: community in W Surry County served by post office, 1831-1905. Also spelled Hay Stack.

label: Haystack Marshes
description: See Newport Marshes.

label: Haystack Point
description: point of land on the N shore of Pungo River, E Beaufort County.

label: Hayti
description: (HAY-tie), African American business district in Durham, ca. 1900-1950. Lost to urban redevelopment and highway construction in 1960s.

label: Hayward Creek
description: rises in W Craven County and flows E and SW into Trent River. Appears in early records as Haywood Creek and in the nineteenth century as both Haywood Creek and Samuel Creek.

label: Haywood
description: town in SE Chatham County on Deep River. Inc. 1796 as Lyons; name changed to Haywoodsborough in 1797 and to Haywood in 1800. Long inactive in municipal affairs. Named for John Haywood (1755-1827), state treasurer. Moncure is now immediately to the NW of the site of Haywood, which, aside from a church and a few houses, is mostly wooded.

label: Haywood County
description: was formed in 1808 from Buncombe County. Located in the W section of the state, it is bounded by the state of Tennessee and by Madison, Buncombe, Transylvania, Jackson, and Swain Counties. It was named for John Haywood (1755-1827), state treasurer from 1787 to 1827. Area: 544 sq. mi. County seat: Waynesville, with an elevation of 2,635 ft.
