Townships are Beaverdam, Cataloochee, Cecil, Clyde, Crabtree, East Fork, Fines Creek, Iron Duff, Ivy Hill, Jonathans Creeks, Pigeon, Waynesville, and White Oak. Produces apples, corn, Christmas trees, dairy products, livestock, hogs, poultry, paper, rubber goods, concrete products, chemicals, lumber, leather, textiles, tobacco, furniture, sand, and gravel.

label: Haywood Gap
description: on the Haywood-Jackson county line. Alt. 5,225.

label: Haywood Gap Stream
description: rises in S Haywood County at Sweetwater Spring and flows NE to join Buckeye Creek in forming Middle Prong [West Fork Pigeon River].

label: Hazanet Knob
description: central Graham County in the Cheoah Mountains at the head of Cochran Creek.

label: Hazel
description: community in N Surry County served by post office, 1899-1906.

label: Hazel Creek
description: rises in N Swain County on the SW slope of Silers Bald in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows SW into Fontana Lake. It was named for a patch of hazelnut bushes near its mouth.

label: Hazel Dell
description: community in E central Caldwell County. Formerly a post office.

label: Hazel Hollow
description: W Jackson County between Mince Branch and Dicks Creek.

label: Hazel Knob
description: on the Cherokee County, N.C.-Monroe County, Tenn., line in the Unicoi Mountains.

label: Hazel Top
description: peak in central Haywood County on the NW end of Teaberry Ridge.

label: Hazelnut Gap
description: on the McDowell-Yancey county line between Buck Creek Gap and Horse Gap.

label: Hazelton
description: community in N Gates County.

label: Hazelwood
description: former town in S Haywood County adjacent to Waynesville. Inc. 1905. In 1953 it became a part of Waynesville. Named for hazelnuts growing in the vicinity. Alt. 2,713. See also Waynesville.

label: Headquarters Mountain
description: SE Avery County. Alt. 4,135.

label: Headwater
description: community in SW Chatham County.

label: Heady Mountain
description: S Jackson County at S end of Chattooga Ridge. Also spelled Heddie Mountain.

label: Heady's Beach
description: See Bear Banks.

label: Healing Springs
description: community and springs in S Davidson County between Flat Swamp and Lick Creek at N end of Flat Swamp Mountain.

label: Healing Springs Township
description: S Davidson County.

label: Healthy Plain
description: community in W Wilson County.

label: Heareford
description: community in NE Stokes County served by post office, 1898-1907.

label: Heartline Creek
description: See North Fork Tar River.

label: Hearts Delight Pocosin
description: NW Bertie County.

label: Heartsease
description: community in central Edgecombe County about 8 mi. NW of Tarboro. Named by Richard Hart, who built his home there. Appears as Hartsease on U.S. Geological Survey map, 1903.

label: Heath
description: community in E Union County served by post office, 1894-1903.

label: Heath Mill Run
description: rises in N Jones County and flows S into Beaver Creek.

label: Heatherly Height
description: high ground in SE Henderson County.

label: Heathsville
description: community in W central Halifax County.

label: Heaton
description: community on Elk River, N Avery County. Alt. approx. 3,500. Named for Rev. James M. Heaton of Tennessee, who came to W North Carolina in 1882.

label: Heaveners Creek
description: rises in E Rutherford County and flows W into Robinson Creek.

label: Hebo Mountain
description: on the Haywood-Madison county line. Alt. 4,300-4,368.

label: Hebron
description: community in S Mecklenburg County.

label: Hebron Mountain
description: W Henderson County between Cantrell Mountain and North Fork. Alt. 2,966.

label: Heck Creek
description: rises in central Madison County and flows SW into Walnut Creek.

label: Hector Creek
description: rises in SW Wake County and flows SW through N Harnett County into Cape Fear River. Named for Hector McNeill, who settled along its banks, 1740.

label: Hector Creek Township
description: N Harnett County.

label: Heddie Mountain
description: See Heady Mountain.

label: Hedgecock
description: community in S Guilford County.

label: Hedricks Island
description: a narrow island of sand approx. 1 mi. long in Yadkin River, W Davidson County.

label: Heffner Gap
description: on the McDowell-Mitchell county line.

label: Heflin
description: community in N Johnston County served by post office, 1898-1903.

label: Heggie
description: community in N Rockingham County served by post office, 1898-1904.

label: Heidelburg Ferry
description: appears on the Moseley map, 1733, on New River in what is now S Onslow County, serving the Bath-New Bern-Wilmington road.

label: Heights of Gowerie
description: high bank overlooking Yadkin River, E Rowan County. Site of the home of Albert Torrence (1752-1825), from which Cornwallis cannonaded forces of Gen. Nathanael Greene, 1781.

label: Heighwaree
description: See Uwharrie Mountains.

label: Heilig
description: community in S Rowan County served by post office, 1875-1903.

label: Heilig's Mill
description: See Heilig.

label: Heintooga Bald
description: NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Overlook Ridge. Alt. 5,240.

label: Heintooga Creek
description: rises in NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows SW into Bunches Creek.

label: Heintooga Ridge
description: NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park between Heintooga Creek and Redman Creek.

label: Heldermans
description: former community in S Lincoln County on the opposite side of Leepers Creek from the community of Mariposa, but now a part of Mariposa.

label: Helena
description: See Timberlake.

label: Helens Crossroads
description: community in S Pitt County.

label: Helix
description: community in NW Davie County.

label: Hell Pocosin
description: a loam-filled pocosin in NW Onslow County between Purgatory Pocosin and the head of New River.

label: Hell Swamp
description: central Duplin County between North Prong Horse Branch and West Prong Horse Branch.

label: Hell's Half Acre
description: See Providence.

label: Helton
description: community in N Ashe County. Alt. 2,600. Site of iron forges, 1807-57.

label: Helton Creek
description: rises in N central Ashe County and flows SE into North Fork New River.

label: Helton Township
description: NE Ashe County.

label: Hembys Bridge
description: community in W Union County. Inc. 1998.

label: Hemlock
description: community in W Ashe County.

label: Hemlock Branch
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows NE into Little East Fork Pigeon River.

label: Hemlock Knob
description: peak on the Swain County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park between Mount Davis and Cold Spring Knob.

label: Hemmed Island
description: a 75-acre island covered with hardwoods in the Tar River, central Edgecombe County.

label: Hemp
description: See Robbins.

label: Hemp Patch Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows SW into Big Mooney Branch.

label: Hemphill Bald
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Cataloochee Divide near lat. 35°33'50" N., long. 83°06'11" W. Alt. 5,573.

label: Hemphill Creek
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows NE into South Toe River.

label: Hemphill Knob
description: central Buncombe County S of Lake Craig.

label: Hemphill Mountain
description: N Buncombe County between Pink Fox Cove and Pennix Cove.

label: Hemphill Spring
description: S Yancey County. Former resort on the old Mount Mitchell toll road operated by Graybeal family and used for a time during the construction of the Blue Ridge Parkway.

label: Hemphill's Store
description: community in SW Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1826-58.

label: Hen Mountain
description: central Caldwell County. Alt. 2,020. Formerly known as Turkey Hen Mountain. A nearby peak, Hibriten Mountain, was formerly known as Turkey Cock Mountain.

label: Henderson
description: city and county seat, S central Vance County. Alt. 513. Inc. 1841 and named for Leonard Henderson (1772-1833), chief justice of N.C. Supreme Court from 1829 to 1833. Originally settled in 1789 when Samuel Reavis and his sons Lewis, Samuel Jr., and Whitfield built a house there. Referred to as Lonesome Valley by a later settler, William Evans, who was homesick for Virginia. Produces textiles, hosiery, minerals, tobacco, glass products, and pickles.

label: Henderson Branch
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows NE into Burnett Creek.

label: Henderson County
description: was formed in 1838 from Buncombe County. Located in the W section of the state, it is bounded by the state of South Carolina and by Transylvania, Haywood, Buncombe, McDowell, Rutherford, and Polk Counties. It was named for Leonard Henderson (1772-1833), chief justice of the N.C. Supreme Court. Area: 382 sq. mi. County seat: Hendersonville, with an elevation of 2,146 ft. Townships are Clear Creek, Crab Creek, Edneyville, Green River, Hendersonville, Hoopers Creek, Mills River, North Blue Ridge, and South Blue Ridge. Produces apples, corn, hay, snap beans, cattle, paper products, outdoor lights, electronics, tools, limestone, granite, and clay.

label: Henderson Creek
description: rises in E Henderson County and flows NW into Clear Creek.

label: Henderson Mountain
description: S Macon County between Fork Ridge and California Ridge.

label: Henderson Shoals
description: See McAdenville.

label: Henderson Township
description: central Vance County.

label: Henderson's Ferry
description: crossed Catawba River in NW Mecklenburg into Gaston County.

label: Hendersonville
description: town and county seat, central Henderson County. Alt. 2,146. Authorized to be laid out, 1840; inc. 1847. Named for Leonard Henderson (1772-1833), chief justice of the N.C. Supreme Court, 1829-33. Produces electronic components, hosiery, textiles, and apparel.

label: Hendersonville Township
description: central Henderson County.

label: Hendricks Creek
description: rises in central Edgecombe County and flows SE through Tarboro into Tar River.

label: Hendrix
description: community in W Wilkes County on Stony Fork Creek.

label: Hennessey
description: community in S Burke County served by post office, 1896-1903.

label: Henrico
description: community in NW Northampton County.

label: Henrietta
description: community in SE Rutherford County on Second Broad River. Founded 1887 by Simpson B. Tanner Sr. with the establishment of Henrietta Mills. Named for Tanner's mother-in-law, Henrietta McRae Spencer.

label: Henry
description: community in NW Lincoln County.

label: Henry Branch
description: rises in W Nash County and flows SE into Sapony Creek. Mentioned in local records as early as 1779.

label: Henry Branch
description: rises near Black Mountain in N Transylvania County and flows SW into Avery Creek.

label: Henry Creek
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows S into Buff Creek.

label: Henry Fork
description: rises in S Burke County and flows NE and E into Catawba County, where it joins Jacob Fork in forming South Fork Catawba River. Named for the pioneer settler Heinrich Weidner (Henry Whitener).

label: Henry Knob
description: central Haywood County between Big Spring Branch and Jonathans Creek.

label: Henry Mountain
description: S Transylvania County between Paxton Creek and Cantrell Creek.

label: Henry River
description: community in E Burke County.

label: Hensley Branch
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows NE into Bald Mountain Creek.

label: Hensley Ridge
description: NW Yancey County between Bald Mountain Creek and Jim Creek.

label: Henson Branch
description: rises in SE Macon County and flows SE into Clear Creek.

label: Henson Cove
description: E Haywood County on Garden Creek.

label: Henson Creek
description: rises in S Macon County and flows NE into Shope Fork.

label: Henson Gap
description: SE Macon County between Henson Branch and Brooks Creek.

label: Henson Ridge
description: N Jackson County between Locust Creek and Cane Creek.

label: Hepco
description: former community on Waterville Lake (in Pigeon River), central Haywood County. Alt. 2,298. Was site of Haywood Electric Power Company development; the name came from the initials of the company. Now abandoned.

label: Herald Mountain
description: N Wilkes County between the head of Bee Tree Branch and Cane Creek. Named for the Harrold family, early settlers on Bee Tree Branch.

label: Herbert C. Bonner Bridge
description: See Oregon Inlet.

label: Herbert Stamp
description: peak in NE Clay County between Tipton Branch and Tate Branch.

label: Herbin's Creek
description: rises in SE Rockingham County and flows SW into Haw River. Known as High Rock Creek as early as 1754; renamed about 1800 for John and William Herbin, local landowners.

label: Herds Creek
description: rises in E Moore County and flows S into Crains Creek. Named for Charles Herd, who settled at its mouth about 1760.

label: Heriots Island
description: See Batts Island.

label: Hermitage
description: community in NW Ashe County served by post office, 1890-1904.

label: Herrells
description: community in NW Mitchell County.

label: Herren Cove
description: the valley through which the E tributary of Pole Creek flows in SW Buncombe County.

label: Herrin Knob
description: on the Haywood-Jackson county line.

label: Herring
description: or community in N central Sampson County on the head of Merkle Swamp.

label: Herring Pond
description: stream, rises in N Carteret County and flows N into Neuse River.

label: Herring Run
description: rises in central Beaufort County and flows S into Runyon Creek.

label: Herring Shoal Island
description: small island about ½ mi. in diameter off the S end of Bodie Island in Roanoke Sound, E Dare County.

label: Herring Swamp
description: rises in N Duplin County and flows SE into Marsh Branch.

label: Herring's Chapel
description: community in SW Pender County on the E side of Long Creek.

label: Herrings Township
description: N central Sampson County.

label: Herron Cove
description: N Buncombe County SW of Little Davis Mountain.

label: Hertford
description: town and county seat, central Perquimans County on Perquimans River. Est. 1758. Named for the town of Hertford in England. Appears as Hartford on the Collet map, 1770. First known as Phelps Point for Jonathan Phelps, on whose land it was est.; appears in local records as early as 1701. Produces apparel. Alt. 15.

label: Hertford County
description: was formed in 1759 from Chowan, Bertie, and Northampton Counties. Located in the NE section of the state, it is bounded by Gates, Chowan, Bertie, and Northampton Counties and the state of Virginia. It was named for Francis Seymour Conway (1719-94), Earl (later Marquis) of Hertford, a Lord of the Bed Chamber and Knight of the Garter. Area: 361 sq. mi. County seat: Winton, with an elevation of 45 ft. Townships are Ahoskie, Harrellsville, Maneys Neck, Murfreesboro, St. Johns, and Winton. Produces peanuts, tobacco, corn, soybeans, cotton, hogs, livestock, apparel, lumber, steel products, glass products, and wooden containers.

label: Hertford Township
description: W central Perquimans County.

label: Hertfords Island
description: See Hatteras Island.

label: Hester
description: community in S Granville County served by post office, 1889-1950. Named for Henry M. Hester, donor of the railroad right-of-way and station site. Alt. 384.

label: Hester's Store
description: community in SW Person County served by post office, 1854-1905.

label: Hesters Pond
description: W Bladen County on Bareford Swamp. Covers between 75 and 80 acres; max. depth 8 ft. at the dam.

label: Hestertown
description: community in SE Robeson County on Lumber River.

label: Hewins Creek
description: See Eurins Creek.

label: Hewitt
description: community in SW Swain County. Named for Frank R. Hewitt, talc-mine operator. Alt. 1,878.

label: Hewitt Gap
description: in SW Swain County on Nantahala Gorge.

label: Hewlets Creek
description: rises in central New Hanover County and flows SE into Masonboro Sound.

label: Hexlena
description: community in N central Bertie County. Inc. 1899; charter repealed 1905.

label: Hiawatha
description: See Watha.

label: Hibbard Mountain
description: W Cherokee County, extends NE from Bearpaw Creek.

label: Hibriten
description: community in central Caldwell County served by post office, 1886-1902.

label: Hibriten Mountain
description: central Caldwell County in the Brushy Mountains. Alt. 2,265. Formerly known as Turkey Cock Mountain but renamed in honor of Brighton, England, by Emma Baker, who moved there from England to teach school. See also Hen Mountain; Brushy Mountains.

label: Hickleberry Mountain
description: W Stokes County at the head of Town Fork Creek.

label: Hickman's Creek
description: rises in SE Caldwell County and flows S into Upper Little River.

label: Hickmans Crossroads
description: community in SW Brunswick County.

label: Hickory
description: community in NE Nash County between Beaverdam Swamp and Fishing Creek. Sometimes also known as Pittmans Store.

label: Hickory Basin
description: a depression in E Graham County at the head of Shell Stand Creek.

label: Hickory Bearpen Mountain
description: E Madison County between Roaring Fork and Little Creek.

label: Hickory Bottom
description: sandy valley in NW Swain County between Pinnacle Ridge and Hazel Creek.

label: Hickory Bottom Branch
description: rises in N McDowell County and flows S into Armstrong Creek near Woodlawn.

label: Hickory Branch
description: rises in W Macon County and flows SE into Dicks Creek.

label: Hickory Cove
description: W Swain County between Watia Creek and Jake Branch.

label: Hickory Cove Creek
description: rises in NW Clay County and flows SW into Rock House Creek.

label: Hickory Creek
description: rises in E Cleveland County and flows SW into First Broad River.

label: Hickory Creek
description: rises in NE Stokes County and flows E into Rockingham County, where it enters Mayo River.

label: Hickory Cross Roads
description: community in N Perquimans County.

label: Hickory Crossroads
description: community in E Johnston County.

label: Hickory East
description: unincorporated outskirts of city of Hickory, NW Catawba County.

label: Hickory Flat Branch
description: rises in W central Swain County and flows SW into Tuckasegee River.

label: Hickory Flat Cove
description: S Haywood County on a tributary of West Fork Pigeon River.

label: Hickory Flat Creek
description: rises near Mine Mountain in N Transylvania County and flows SW into East Fork French Broad River.

label: Hickory Flats
description: E Mitchell County between Beaver Creek and Gouges Creek.

label: Hickory Fork
description: rises in N Madison County and flows SE into Shelton Laurel Creek.

label: Hickory Gap
description: S Macon County between Rector Knob and Bennies Branch.

label: Hickory Grove
description: See Wilson.

label: Hickory Grove Crossroads
description: community in E Bladen County on South River. Stewarts Ferry appears on the river there on the Price map, 1808. The MacRae map, 1833, shows Cromartys Ferry there, while the soil survey map, 1914, shows Cromarties Bridge across the river and the community of Gravel Hill a short distance w. Gravelly Hill had appeared on the Colton map, 1861, and on various other maps through Kerr's in 1882. Gravelly Hill post office was there as early as 1827 and operated until 1866; it became Gravelhill in 1875. The present name occurs first on the Geological Survey map, 1954.

label: Hickory Hill
description: See Lawrence.

label: Hickory Knob
description: N Transylvania County between Presley Branch and South Prong Turkey Creek.

label: Hickory Knob Mountain
description: at junction of Alexander, Caldwell, and Wilkes Counties. Alt. 2,635.

label: Hickory Knoll Creek
description: rises in S Macon County and flows SW into Little Tennessee River.

label: Hickory Log Branch
description: rises in N Madison County and flows SE into Shelton Laurel Creek.

label: Hickory Mountain
description: on the Henderson-Transylvania county line N of Hooker Creek.

label: Hickory Mountain Township
description: W central Chatham County.

label: Hickory North
description: unincorporated outskirts of city of Hickory, NW Catawba County.

label: Hickory Nut Branch
description: rises in central Avery County and flows S into North Toe River.

label: Hickory Nut Creek
description: rises in NE Henderson County and flows SE into Broad River.

label: Hickory Nut Falls
description: on Broad River near Chimney Rock, W Rutherford County. 400 ft. tall.

label: Hickory Nut Gap
description: NW Swain County on Long Hungry Ridge in Great Smoky Mountains National Park.

label: Hickory Nut Gorge
description: W Rutherford County, through which Broad River flows. A good view of the gorge may be had from atop Chimney Rock.

label: Hickory Nut Mountain
description: in SW Burke County. Alt. 2,512.

label: Hickory Nut Mountain
description: central Jackson County, extends N from Slatten Creek to Tuckasegee River.

label: Hickory Point
description: extends from SW Carteret County into Hills Bay.

label: Hickory Ridge
description: in N Haywood County between Rube Rock Branch and Chestnut Orchard Branch.

label: Hickory Ridge Branch
description: rises in W Madison County and flows S into Roaring Fork.

label: Hickory Run
description: rises in W Onslow County and flows NE into Southwest Creek.

label: Hickory Springs
description: See Mount Vernon Springs.

label: Hickory Spur
description: peak in W Madison County between Levy Branch and French Broad River.

label: Hickory Tavern
description: See Hickory.

label: Hickory Top
description: S Buncombe County between Billy Cove Gap and Little Hickory Top.

label: Hickory Township
description: W Catawba County. Was Hickory Tavern Township prior to 1876.

label: Hickorynut Branch
description: rises in E Swain County on Yalaka Mountains near Hickorynut Knob and flows S into Una Creek.

label: Hickorynut Knob
description: E Swain County on Yalaka Mountains near the head of Hickorynut Branch.

label: Hickorynut Mountain
description: in E Swain County between Second Hurricane Branch and Hickorynut Branch.

label: Hickorynut Mountains
description: a long ridge, S McDowell County between Crooked Creek and Cove Creek.

label: Hicks Branch
description: rises in W Macon County and flows N into Nantahala Lake.

label: Hicks Creek
description: rises in S Iredell County W of Troutman and flows S into Catawba River.

label: Hicks Crossroads
description: community in NW Mecklenburg County.

label: Hicks Crossroads
description: community in NW Vance County N of Flat Creek.

label: Hicks Grove
description: community in S Rutherford County S of Broad River.

label: Hicks Pond
description: in N Warren County on Mill Creek.

label: Hickstown
description: former town in central Durham County. Inc. 1887 on property of W. H. and Ella Hicks; charter repealed 1889. Site is now within the corporate limits of Durham.

label: Hicksville
description: community in S Rutherford County served by post office, 1845-1905.

label: Hico River
description: See Hyco River.

label: Hicootomony River
description: See Hyco River.

label: Hiddenite
description: community in E central Alexander County. Named for William Earl Hidden (1853-1918), mineralogist of New York who prospected in the area about 1880. Mines nearby produced the gem hiddenite, found only in North Carolina. Inc. 1913; charter repealed 1919. Known as White Plains prior to the arrival of Hidden and so appears on a map of 1871. Alt. 1,140. Produces poultry.

label: Hide Pond
description: a muck-filled slough in SE Duplin County.

label: Hidetown
description: community in E Graham County on Stecoah Creek.

label: Higdon Branch
description: rises in E Macon County and flows NW into Ellijay Creek.

label: Higdon Mountain
description: E Macon County at the head of Higdon Branch. Alt. 4,045.

label: Higdonville
description: community in E Macon County on Battle Branch.

label: Higgens Island
description: formerly a 10-acre island in Little Tennessee River in NE Graham County. Now under the waters of Fontana Lake.

label: Higgins
description: community in N central Yancey County on Cane River. Alt. 2,390. Named for John Higgins, early settler and father of a large family.

label: Higgins Creek
description: rises in W Yancey County and flows NW into Cane River.

label: Higgins Knob
description: W Yancey County between Langford Branch and Higgins Creek.

label: Higgins Township
description: central McDowell County.

label: High Country
description: modern name applied to NW North Carolina, especially area around Boone and Blowing Rock, to promote tourism.

label: High Falls
description: in Little River in E Transylvania County S of the mouth of Grassy Creek. Height of the falls is 50 ft.

label: High Falls
description: community in N Moore County on Deep River. William England built a mill there about 1790. Originally known as The Great Falls and The Big Falls for a 15 ft. waterfall in the river. The community of Prosperity, approx. 1 mi. e, was settled about 1862, but by 1941 it had been almost completely abandoned in favor of High Falls. Prosperity was named for the fact that it was in the center of a prosperous farming section.

label: High Falls of the Tuckasegee
description: See Tuckasegee Falls.

label: High Hampton Estate
description: SE Jackson County on the W edge of Hampton Lake. Estate named for Gen. Wade Hampton, Confederate officer and governor of South Carolina, who had a home there. It is now a private recreation area and resort, High Hampton Inn. Alt. 3,524.

label: High Hickory Knob
description: SE Buncombe County between Patton Gap and Flat Top in the Swannanoa Mountains.

label: High Hickory Ridge
description: SE Buncombe County N of High Hickory Knob.

label: High Hill
description: community in N Hertford County.

label: High Hill Inlet
description: between Whalebone Island in Pamlico Sound and Portsmouth Island in E Carteret County.

label: High Hills, The
description: sand dunes on Portsmouth Island about 1 mi. NE of Drum Inlet, E Carteret County.

label: High Holly
description: mountain in S Macon County between Kinley Mountain and Middle Creek.

label: High Knob
description: E Mitchell County between Little Bald and Stagger Weed Creek.

label: High Knob
description: SW Yancey County on Wilson Ridge.

label: High Laurel Branch
description: rises in W Macon County and flows W into Nantahala Lake.

label: High Lonesome Mountain
description: SE Jackson County between Fowler Creek and Ellicott Mountain.

label: High Mountain
description: NE Rutherford County between Oakey Mountain and Silver Creek Knob.

label: High Peak
description: N Cherokee County on Hanging Dog Mountain. Also known as High Top. Alt. 4,053.

label: High Peak
description: community in SE Burke County approx. 5 mi. SE of Morganton at foot of South Mountains.

label: High Pinnacle
description: central Buncombe County NW of Elk Wallow Gap in the Elk Mountains.

label: High Point
description: city in SW Guilford County. Alt. 940. Laid out in 1853 and inc. 1859. Named for the fact that it was the highest point on the North Carolina Railroad. Produces textiles, hosiery, furniture, baked goods, apparel, corrugated boxes, fabricated metals, toys, lumber, and chemicals. Furniture market is operated there. Home of High Point University. See also Browntown.

label: High Point Lake
description: SW Guilford County, is formed at the junction of East Fork Deep River and West Fork Deep River where Deep River is formed. The lake was created by a dam constructed in 1928 and is named for and owned by the city of High Point. Max. depth 20 ft.; area 150 acres.

label: High Point Township
description: SW Guilford County. Named for the town.

label: High Ridge
description: W Madison County between Davis Branch and Murray Branch.

label: High Rock
description: former community and post office in SE Rockingham County on Haw River. Mentioned in local records as early as 1754; mill operated there from as early as 1753 until the 1920s, when the dam was broken. Gov. William Tryon camped there, 1771; Generals Cornwallis and Greene camped there during the Revolutionary War. The name survives as applied to a local farm and brick house built about 1807.

label: High Rock Creek
description: See Herbin's Creek.

label: High Rock Lake
description: on Steel Creek in S Transylvania County. Covers 15 acres and has a max. depth of 15 ft.

label: High Rock Ridge
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a spur extending W from Welch Ridge between Cold Spring Branch and Hazel Creek.

label: High Rock Wildlife Management Area
description: on High Rock Lake in SW Davidson County. Operated by state of North Carolina on privately owned land. Principal wildlife are deer, turkey, and quail.

label: High Rocks
description: peak in N Yancey County at the NE end of Chestnut Ridge.

label: High Shoals
description: See Cliffside.

label: High Shoals Branch
description: rises in S Madison County and flows E into Little Pine Creek.

label: High Shoals Township
description: SE Rutherford County. Named for a series of shoals in Second Broad River. See also Cliffside.

label: High Swan
description: peak at the N end of Swan Mountain in central Buncombe County.

label: High Top
description: SW Buncombe County NE of Stony Knob.

label: High Top
description: See High Peak.

label: High Top of Bee Tree
description: See Craggy Knob.

label: High Windy
description: peak in SE Buncombe County between Black Knob and High Top.

label: Highfall Branch
description: rises in central Cherokee County and flows SE into Morgan Creek.

label: Highland
description: See Hickory.

label: Highland Falls
description: on the headwaters of Cullasaja River in SE Macon County.

label: Highland Lake
description: central Henderson County on King Creek. Constructed about 1906. Covers 20 acres; max. depth 20 ft. Site of a summer camp. Alt. 2,117.

label: Highland Ridge
description: NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a spur extending SE from Katalsta Ridge between Enloe Creek and Raven Fork.

label: Highlands
description: town in SE Macon County. The highest town in the state, alt. 3,838. Laid out as a summer resort in 1875 by Samuel T. Kelsey and Charles Hutchinson of Kansas. They chose the location from a map when they discovered that a line drawn on it from Chicago to Savannah crossed another line at the site drawn from Baltimore to New Orleans. Inc. 1879. Named for its high elevation. Highlands has an average yearly precipitation of 79 in. Highlands Biological Station est. there 1927 as a nonprofit research and field training center for the study of plants and animals. See also Horse Cove.

label: Highlands Township
description: SE Macon County.

label: Highpeak
description: mountain on the Henderson-Transylvania county line.

label: Highs Crossroads
description: community in S Nash County near Bissett Mill Pond. It is now known also as Green Pond community.

label: Highsmith
description: community in S Pender County on Mill Creek. Named for the Highsmith family, which operated a large farm and sawmill at the site.

label: Hightop
description: N Henderson County between Baldwin Gap and Terry Gap. Alt. 3,482.

label: Hightower Gap
description: S Swain County between Licklog Creek and Wiggins Creek.

label: Hightower Township
description: SE Caswell County.

label: Hightowers
description: community in SE Caswell County. Named for Daniel Hightower, who moved there from Virginia about 1795. A post office operated there approx. 1830-1930.

label: Hightsville
description: community in W New Hanover County N of Wilmington on Smiths Creek.

label: Highview
description: community in NE Person County served by post office, 1892-1901.

label: Hilda
description: community in W Alleghany County served by post office, 1898-1907.

label: Hildebran
description: town in E Burke County. Inc. 1899. Alt. 1,149. Named for J. A. Hildebran, lumber merchant. Produces textiles and hosiery.

label: Hildebran Creek
description: rises in central Catawba County SW of Conover and flows S into Clark Creek.

label: Hildrup
description: former mining town in S McDowell County in the vicinity of Demming, which see.

label: Hill
description: community in NW Pitt County served by post office, 1892-1916.

label: Hill Forest
description: N Durham County. Contains 2,450 acres. The original tract of 275 acres was donated by George Watts Hill of Durham to North Carolina State College in 1929. He later assisted in financing additional purchases of land. Named for the original donor. The second-year class of the Department of Forestry and Environmental Resources spends 10 weeks in summer camp there doing surveying and all phases of forestry, such as timber cruising, dendrology, stand improvement, and mensuration. The camp is equipped with classrooms, dormitory, dining hall, and all necessary facilities.

label: Hill Hollow
description: N Mitchell County on a tributary of Spring Creek.

label: Hill Top
description: community in SW Guilford County.

label: Hill's Bridge
description: nineteenth-century span across Potecasi Creek, N Hertford County between Murfreesboro and Winton. Site of a Civil War skirmish, 1863. U.S. Highway 158 now crosses at or near the site.

label: Hill's Point
description: See Fort Hill.

label: Hill's Rock
description: a landing in SW Carteret County on the mainland side of Bogue Sound. Named for Edward Hill, on whose plantation it was located in the middle of the nineteenth century. Also known as White Rock.

label: Hillgirt
description: community in N Henderson County.

label: Hilliards Mill
description: See Tippetts Mill Pond.

label: Hilliardston
description: community in N Nash County on Swift Creek. Settled about 1780. Named for John Hilliard, one of the first settlers. Alt. 200.

label: Hills Bay
description: in White Oak River, W Carteret County. Named for Edward Hill, who owned the adjacent land and Cedar Point Plantation there before and during the Civil War.

label: Hills Creek
description: rises in N Scotland County and flows NE into Lumber River.

label: Hills Crossroads
description: community in E Halifax County. Settled prior to 1830.

label: Hills Mill
description: See Chiska Creek.

label: Hills Point
description: SW Beaufort County on the S side of Pamlico River.

label: Hills Pond
description: E Wayne County on the head of West Bear Creek.

label: Hills Store
description: community in E Lincoln County.

label: Hillsboro Store
description: formerly a community in E Wayne County between Hills Pond and Bear Creek.

label: Hillsborough
description: town and county seat, central Orange County on Eno River. Alt. 543. John Lawson visited the Indian town of Occaneechi there, 1701. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733. In 1754 the site came to be known as Corbinton for Francis Corbin, colonial official. Est. as Childsburgh, 1759, in honor of Thomas Childs, attorney general of the province. Name changed to Hillsborough in 1766 in honor of Wills Hill, Earl of Hillsborough (1718-93), president of the Board of Trade and Plantations, and secretary of state for the colonies. The spelling later changed unofficially to Hillsboro, but the original spelling was restored in 1965. The legislature met there in 1778 and 1782-84.

label: Hillsborough District
description: was composed of Caswell, Chatham, Granville, Orange, Randolph, and Wake Counties at the time of the 1790 census.

label: Hillsborough Lake
description: See Ben Johnson Lake.

label: Hillsborough Township
description: central Orange County.

label: Hillsdale
description: community in N Guilford County.

label: Hillside Branch
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows SE into Buffalo Branch.

label: Hilltop
description: community in S Stokes County served by post office, 1892-1903.

label: Hilma
description: See Farrar.

label: Hilton
description: community in N Brunswick County.

label: Hiltons River
description: See Brunswick River.

label: Hines Crossroads
description: community in N Halifax County. Named for Peter Hines, an early settler, a part of whose home still stands there.

label: Hinklesville
description: See Welcome.

label: Hinshaw
description: community in W Yadkin County. A post office once serving the community was named Randolph.

label: Hinson
description: community in W Washington County. Alt. 43.

label: Hinsons Crossroads
description: community in W Columbus County.

label: Hinton
description: community in central Guilford County served by post office, 1880-1903.

label: Hinton Creek
description: rises in E Rutherford County and flows E into Cleveland County, where it enters First Broad River.

label: Hinton's Branch
description: rises in E central Wake County and flows NE into Beaverdam Creek.

label: Hinton's Quarter
description: former site of Johnston County courthouse, NW Johnston County E of Clayton on the S side of Neuse River. Probably named for John Hinton, who owned much land in the area. A courthouse was est. there in 1759 or 1760 and remained until 1771, when it was moved to Smithfield, which see, after the formation of Wake County. Gov. William Tryon, on May 3, 1771, at Smith's Ferry a short distance e, reviewed troops from Wilmington and New Bern en route to suppress the Regulators.

label: Hipps Ridge
description: NW Cherokee County, extends NE parallel to Wolf Ridge.

label: Hirams Hill
description: a sand hill on Bogue Banks, SW Carteret County. Site of former community. Named for Hiram Moore.

label: Hitchcock Creek
description: rises in E Richmond County and flows SW into Pee Dee River.

label: Hives
description: community in central Sampson County served by post office, 1884-1902.

label: Hiwassee Dam
description: resort community covering 547 acres in W Cherokee County. Privately owned. Originally served as site of construction camp from 1936 to 1940 as Hiwassee Dam was being built on Hiwassee River. Alt. 1,375.

label: Hiwassee Lake
description: NW Cherokee County, was formed at the completion of Hiwassee Dam in 1940 on Hiwassee River. Approx. 20 mi. long; covers 6,120 acres, with a max. depth of 250 ft. Owned by Tennessee Valley Authority and used for flood control, power generation, and recreation.

label: Hiwassee Lake State Park
description: former state park in W Cherokee County containing 834 acres. Est. 1948; lease from Tennessee Valley Authority terminated on December 31, 1952, and it ceased to operate as a state park. Was a scenic and recreational area; provided fishing and nature study and had vacation cabins.

label: Hiwassee River
description: rises in Towns County, Ga., and flows NW into Clay County through Lake Chatuge; NW and W across the Cherokee-Clay county line; NW in Cherokee County through Hiwassee Lake and Apalachia Lake; and into Tennessee, where it enters Tennessee River approx. 30 mi. W of Athens, Tenn. Named for the Cherokee word ayuhwÃ¡-si (a meadow).

label: Hiwassee Township
description: S central Clay County.

label: Ho-Ho Village
description: a modern community on the mainland side of Bogue Sound, SW Carteret County between Bogue and Morehead City.

label: Hobart
description: See Piney.

label: Hobbsville
description: community in S Gates County. Alt. 40.

label: Hobbton
description: community in N Sampson County near Wards Swamp. A post office operated there, 1881-1904.

label: Hobby Branch
description: rises in SE Alamance County and flows S into Haw River.

label: Hobby Hole, The
description: a deep hole in Contentnea Creek approx. 3 mi. below Ruffin's (formerly Peacock's) Bridge SE of Stantonsburg on the Greene-Wilson county line. Traditionally reputed to be "bottomless." Its max. depth in 1923 was only 58 ft; by 1955 it had largely filled up.

label: Hobgood
description: town in S Halifax County. Inc. 1891. Appears as Hobgood on Gilmer map, 1863. Named for local Hobgood family. Alt. 91.

label: Hobson Branch
description: rises in N Buncombe County and flows NW into Ivy Creek.

label: Hobson Creek
description: rises in N Mitchell County and flows S into Little Rock Creek.

label: Hobton
description: community in N Sampson County served by post office, 1881-1904.

label: Hobucken
description: community on S Goose Creek Island, NE Pamlico County. Originally known as Jones Bay; renamed for Hoboken, N.J., to which large shipments of Irish potatoes were once sent. See also Secotaoc.

label: Hockiday Ridge
description: W Watauga County, extends NE from Watauga River to Rush Branch.

label: Hocut
description: community in central Bladen County served by post office, 1888-1910.

label: Hocutts Crossroads
description: community in N Johnston County.

label: Hodges Creek
description: rises in S central Watauga County and flows E into Flannery Fork [South Fork New River].

label: Hodges Gap
description: community in S central Watauga County on Hodges Creek.

label: Hodges Gap Mountain
description: S Watauga County 1 mi. SW of town of Boone. Alt. 3,376.

label: Hodges Mill Creek
description: rises in E Wake County and flows W into Neuse River.

label: Hodgetown
description: community in E Watauga County S of Camp Branch and W of Elk Creek.

label: Hodgins Pond
description: S Hoke County on Raft Swamp, was formed in 1871 and named for Henry Hodgins. Covers 100 acres; max. depth 8 ft.

label: Hoe Swamp
description: rises in N Sampson County and flows SE into Six Runs Creek.

label: Hoffman
description: town in E Richmond County. Settled in the mid-1870s with the construction of Raleigh and Augusta Air Line Railroad. Inc. 1899 and reincorporated in 1913. Named for Richard C. Hoffman (1839-1926), president of the railroad. Post office est. there 1878. During World War II, Camp Mackall was adjacent to Hoffman on the E in Richmond and Scotland Counties.

label: Hoflers Fork
description: community in E Gates County.

label: Hofmann Forest
description: Onslow and Jones Counties, contains 78,000 acres. Est. in 1934 by the North Carolina Forestry Foundation. Named for Dr. Julius V. Hofmann (1882-1965), who est. the forest program at North Carolina State College in 1929 and was director of the Division of Forestry when he retired in 1948. Used as a demonstration forest by N.C. State University.

label: Hog Back Mountain
description: NE Madison County between Bear Wallow Branch and Peter Cove Creek.

label: Hog Branch
description: See Hawk Branch.

label: Hog Camp Branch
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows SE into Rockhouse Creek.

label: Hog Cane Branch
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows N into Savannah Creek.

label: Hog Hill
description: SE Catawba County. Named for the fact that early settlers branded their hogs and let them roam there until fall, when they were taken home to be fattened.

label: Hog Island
description: See Lake Bay.

label: Hog Island Bay
description: name erroneously given to Cedar Island Bay, NE Carteret County, on the 1935 Soil Survey map.

label: Hog Island Narrows
description: NE Carteret County, connects Cedar Island Bay with Back Bay.

label: Hog Island Point
description: extends off the E mainland of Hyde County into Pamlico Sound.

label: Hog Island Swamp
description: SW Sampson County S of Little Coharie Creek.

label: Hog Point
description: a point of land in N Carteret County extending into the waters of Turnagain Bay.

label: Hog Quarter
description: See Spot.

label: Hog Swamp
description: rises in S Robeson County and flows S into Ashpole Swamp.

label: Hogan
description: community in W Rockingham County served by post office, 1885-89. Named for nearby Hogans Creek.

label: Hogan Branch
description: rises in SE Clay County between Kimsey Bald and Marbleyard Ridge and flows SW into Buck Creek.

label: Hogan Creek
description: rises in SE Orange County and flows SE through Hogan's Lake and into Bolin Creek.

label: Hogan Ridge
description: E Clay County between Hogan Branch and Black Branch.

label: Hogan's Lake
description: SE Orange County 2½ mi. NW of town of Carrboro. Alt. 488. Formed in 1930 by H. C. Hogan and named for his family. Covers 17 acres, with a max. depth of 15 ft. For private recreation.

label: Hogans Creek
description: rises in SE Rockingham County and flows NE into Caswell County and into Dan River.

label: Hogback Gap
description: W Swain County between Cabe Branch and De Hart Creek.

label: Hogback Knob
description: W Henderson County. Alt. 3,020.

label: Hogback Mountain
description: W Madison County between Spring Creek and Meadow Fork.

label: Hogback Ridge
description: S Buncombe County between Redmans Cove and Buckeye Cove.

label: Hogback Township
description: SW Transylvania County.

label: Hogback Valley
description: community in W Transylvania County near Lake Toxaway.

label: Hogeye Branch
description: rises in NW Buncombe County and flows NE into Sandymush Creek.

label: Hogg's Folly
description: name formerly applied to a tract of land in W New Hanover County adjoining Wilmington on the n. John Hogg, in the eighteenth century, by means of a ditch, enclosed a tract of land on which he intended to establish a market garden. Evidently, failure of the project produced the name.

label: Hoggard Mill Creek
description: rises in central Bertie County and flows SW into Cashie River. Appears as Wills Quarter Creek on the Collet map, 1770, a name that was in use as late as 1882.

label: Hoggard Swamp
description: S Hertford County. Wiccacon River rises there.

label: Hoggard's Mill
description: 2 mi. N of Windsor in SE Bertie County on Hoggard Mill Creek. The large pond there was the site of Lockhart Mill according to the Collet map, 1770. The surrounding community was known as Wolfington and was the county seat from 1722 until it was moved to Windsor in 1774. By 1833 the site bore its present name. See also Hoggard Mill Creek.

label: Hogjaw Gap
description: N Cherokee County.

label: Hoglot Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows NE into Bates Branch.

label: Hogpen Bay
description: in the waters of Core Sound extending into Core Banks in SE Carteret County.

label: Hogpen Branch
description: rises in SW Johnston County and flows N into Mills Creek.

label: Hogpen Creek
description: rises in SE Rutherford County and flows NE into Second Broad River.

label: Hogpen Gap
description: NE Cherokee County in the Valley River Mountains. Alt. 2,353.

label: Hogpen Mountain
description: NW Rutherford County. Alt. approx. 1,900.

label: Hogs Falls
description: rapids in Neuse River in S Wayne County in The Roundabout. Mentioned as early as 1818 in a survey of the rivers of North Carolina.

label: Hogsed Cove
description: SE Clay County, through which Eagle Creek flows.

label: Hogshead Creek
description: rises in E Transylvania County and flows NW into French Broad River.

label: Hogtown
description: former town in N Martin County on Roanoke River about 1 mi. SE of Hamilton, which see. Appears on the Collet map, 1770, and on the Price map, 1808. In 1804, however, the polling place at Hogtown was moved to Hamilton, and the former place began to decline. Probably named for the local Hogg family.

label: Hoke
description: community in SW Washington County. Alt. 41. Known as Long Ridge from about 1857 until about 1900. The post office name was changed to Hoke in 1900 in honor of R. F. Hoke (1837-1912), the Confederate general who forced the evacuation of the Federal troops from the occupied towns of Plymouth and Washington in 1864.

label: Hoke County
description: was formed in 1911 from Cumberland and Robeson Counties. Located in the SE section of the state, it is bounded by Cumberland, Robeson, Scotland, Moore, and Harnett Counties. It was named for Robert F. Hoke (1837-1912) of Lincoln County, a major general in the Confederate army. Area: 382 sq. mi. County seat: Raeford, with an elevation of 262 ft. Townships are Allendale, Antioch, Blue Springs, McLauchlin, Quewhiffle, Raeford, and Stonewall. Produces corn, wheat, oats, soybeans, cotton, turkeys, livestock, hogs, watermelons, tools, concrete products, transformers, and textiles.

label: Holberts Cove
description: community in W Polk County W of Miller Mountain.

label: Holcombe
description: community in NE Madison County.

label: Holcombe Branch
description: rises in E Madison County and flows NW into Little Ivy Creek.

label: Holcombe Cove
description: the valley through which Moore Creek flows in SW Buncombe County.

label: Holden Beach
description: a section of outer beach in S Brunswick County W of Lockwoods Folly Inlet and E of Big Beach. Approx. 3Â½ mi. long. A summer resort with cottages is there.

label: Holden Cove
description: SE Clay County between Big Kitchens and Little Kitchens Ridges.

label: Holden's Crossroads
description: community in E Wilson County N of White Oak Swamp. Named for W. T. Holden, local landowner.

label: Holder Branch
description: rises in W Duplin County and flows SW into Maxwell Creek.

label: Holder Creek
description: rises in NE Mitchell County and flows SE into Charles Creek.

label: Holiday Island
description: approx. 2 mi. long in the Chowan River, NW Chowan County. Formerly about 150 acres, but now only about 40 to 50 acres. Appears on the Collet map, 1770, as Holladay Island.

label: Holiday Lake
description: See Pages Lake.

label: Holland
description: community in S Wake County. Est. 1900. Named for J. C. Holland. Alt. 411.

label: Holland Branch
description: rises in E Onslow County and flows N into Holland Mill Creek.

label: Holland Creek
description: rises in S Rutherford County and flows NE into Second Broad River.

label: Holland Gap
description: E Haywood County on Glade Mountain.

label: Holland Mill Creek
description: rises in E Onslow County and flows into White Oak River. Also called Holland's Creek.

label: Holland Mountain
description: extends from near Canton in E Haywood County to Hooker Gap in SW Buncombe County. Its peak is known as The Pinnacle.

label: Holland's Creek
description: See Holland Mill Creek.

label: Holland's Point
description: extends from E Onslow County into Queens Creek.

label: Hollands
description: community in N Pitt County on Conetoe Creek.

label: Hollands Creek
description: rises in N central Rutherford County and flows SE into Catheys Creek. Named for James Holland, member of the first board of trustees of the University of North Carolina. Gilbert Town, former county seat, was on the creek.

label: Hollands Crossroads
description: community in NW Wayne County N of Nahunta Swamp.

label: Hollands Sein Hole
description: a shallow place in Northeast Cape Fear River in central Duplin County suitable for seining.

label: Holleman's Crossroads
description: community in SW Wake County between Whiteoak Creek and Cary Branch. Known in late 1800s as Enno (post office operated by that name, 1881-1907) and in early 1900s as Collins Crossroads.

label: Holley Branch
description: rises in SE Mitchell County and flows SE into North Toe River.

label: Holley's Mill
description: See Goshen Swamp.

label: Hollis
description: community in E Rutherford County on Hinton Creek.

label: Hollister
description: community in W Halifax County.

label: Hollow
description: See Mount Airy.

label: Hollow Ground Swamp
description: in central Tyrrell County. See also Long Island.

label: Hollow Poplar
description: See Poplar.

label: Hollow Poplar Creek
description: rises in NW Mitchell County and flows SW into Nolichucky River.

label: Hollow Rock
description: former rock cave on Deep River in SE Chatham County near Moncure. Said to have been used for shelter by Indians. Destroyed in 1957 for gravel for road construction.

label: Hollow Township
description: NW Bladen County.

label: Holloway Branch
description: rises in W Macon County and flows NW into Whiteoak Creek.

label: Holloway Mines
description: copper mines on Aarons Creek in NW Granville County. Operated from shortly prior to 1900 to about 1910 and again briefly during World War I.

label: Holloway Ridge
description: NW Yancey County between Patsy Creek and Riddle Branch.

label: Holloway Township
description: NE Person County.

label: Holly Bottom Branch
description: rises at Wildcat Spring, N Haywood County, and flows SE into Groundhog Creek.

label: Holly Branch
description: rises in SE Macon County and flows NE into Cane Creek.

label: Holly Bush
description: See Hollybush.

label: Holly Grove
description: community in N central Bertie County.

label: Holly Grove
description: community in W Richmond County.

label: Holly Grove Township
description: NE Gates County.

label: Holly Meadow Branch
description: rises in central Cabarrus County and flows S into Coddle Creek.

label: Holly Neck
description: See Beasley.

label: Holly Point
description: peninsula extending from W Goose Creek Island, NE Pamlico County, into Goose Creek at the mouth of Dixon Creek.

label: Holly Ridge
description: town in S Onslow County. Alt. 66. Est. about 1890 as a wood station on the railroad. Inc. 1941. Named for a slight elevation on which holly formerly grew; at Holly Shelter Bay about 1 mi. S was Sages Ordinary (dating from the Revolution), at which George Washington spent the night, April 23, 1791. See also Camp Davis.

label: Holly Shelter Bay
description: a pocosin in E Pender County bounded on the NE by Shaken Creek, on the W by Northeast Cape Fear River, and on the S by Trumpeter Swamp. It is about 10 mi. long and 7 mi. wide. Appears as Holly Schelter Precoson on the Collet map, 1770 (although mistakenly applied to Angola Bay), and on the Price map, 1808. Holly Shelter Wildlife Management Area, 48,470 acres, is operated by the N.C. Wildlife Resources Commission; bear and deer abound.

label: Holly Shelter Creek
description: receives the waters of Angola, Shaken, and Moores Creeks; Cane Branch; and other streams in NE Pender County and flows W approx. 30 mi. into Northeast Cape Fear River. Called Shelter River in a 1913 report by the U.S. Chief of Engineers. Appears as Holly Schelter Creek on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Holly Springs
description: community in N Yadkin County between Smithtown and Yadkin River.

label: Holly Springs Township
description: SW Wake County.

label: Holly Township
description: NE Pender County.

label: Hollybush
description: community in W Cleveland County served by post office, 1875-1905. Also spelled Holly Bush.

label: Hollyville
description: town in NE Pamlico County adjoining Vandemere. Inc. 1907, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Named for local holly trees. Known more recently as Cash Corner. See also Cash Corner No. 2.

label: Hollywood
description: community in central Carteret County served by post office, 1874-1915.

label: Hollywood Ridge
description: community in N central Caldwell County on a ridge parallel to and S of Yadkin River.

label: Holman
description: community in W Davie County near the headwaters of Bear Creek. Settled about 1786 and named for Holman family.

label: Holmans Mills
description: community in S Alamance County served by post office, 1878-1908.

label: Holmes Point
description: on the W side of New River in central Onslow County. Formerly known as Little Ragged Point.

label: Holsclaw's Creek
description: rises in E Caldwell County and flows E into Duck Creek.

label: Holt Knob
description: SE Macon County between Monger Creek and Mill Creek.

label: Holt Lake
description: central Johnston County on Black Creek. Original dam constructed prior to 1911; present dam, downstream from first, built in early 1920s. Covers approx. 400 acres; max. depth 25 ft.

label: Holt's Store
description: See Albertson.

label: Holts Mill
description: community in W Wayne County.

label: Holtsburg
description: community in SW Davidson County served by post office, 1856-66.

label: Holy Swamp
description: rises in central Robeson County and flows SE into Big Raft Swamp.

label: Homestead
description: community in NW Mecklenburg County.

label: Homing Creek
description: rises in E Wake County and flows SE into Little River.

label: Hominy
description: community in SW Buncombe County. Alt. 2,097.

label: Hominy Creek
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows generally E into central Buncombe County, where it enters French Broad River. Said to have been visited by a South Carolina hunting party before the Revolution and given the name because they ate hominy for supper the first night.

label: Hominy Gap
description: E Haywood County. Alt. 2,678. Highway between Canton and Asheville passes through the gap.

label: Hominy Heights
description: former community in central Wilson County just W of and named for Hominy Swamp, now within the limits of the city of Wilson. Known earlier as White's Store. Capt. William White operated a store there as early as 1812.

label: Hominy Swamp
description: rises in W central Wilson County and flows SE into Contentnea Creek. Appears in local records as early as 1764. Said to have been named for a hominy mill operated on its waters by that date.

label: Honey
description: community in E Union County served by post office, 1892-1903.

label: Honey Hill
description: town in central Columbus County. Inc. 1895, but long inactive in municipal affairs.

label: Honey Island Swamp
description: rises in W Brunswick and E Columbus Counties and flows SW along the Brunswick-Columbus county line through Green Swamp into Juniper Creek.

label: Honey Pond
description: community in W central Brunswick County.

label: Honey Pot Swamp
description: rises in central Gates County and flows S into Bennetts Creek.

label: Honeycut Cove
description: near the N end of the Elk Mountains, central Buncombe County E of Jump Cove.

label: Honeycutt
description: community in W Mitchell County on Big Rock Creek.

label: Honeycutt Branch
description: rises in N Mitchell County and flows S into Cane Creek.

label: Honeycutt Creek
description: rises in N central Wake County and flows NE into Neuse River. Formerly called Fall Creek and Big Fall Creek.

label: Honeycutt Mine
description: former gold mine on Little Buffalo Creek, NE Cabarrus County.

label: Honeycutts Township
description: central Sampson County.

label: Honolulu
description: community in N Craven County.

label: Hood Creek
description: rises in NE Brunswick County and flows N into Cape Fear River.

label: Hood Gap
description: E Haywood County at the NE end of Buck Cove.

label: Hood Swamp
description: community in E Wayne County near West Bear Creek. Formerly called Aaron for Aaron Parks (d. 1845), a local farmer and lay religious leader. Renamed for local Free Will Baptist church, of which Parks was a member. Name appeared in nineteenth-century records as Wood Swamp.

label: Hoods
description: or community in E Mecklenburg County. Morning Star Lutheran Church organized there in 1775.

label: Hoods Pond
description: E Wake County on Marks Creek.

label: Hoodsville
description: See Chesterfield.

label: Hoof Inn
description: an early nineteenth-century tavern in W Washington County located on what is now the Plymouth-Pinetown road approx. midway between Ausbon and Hinson.

label: Hooker
description: community in E Alleghany County. Alt. approx. 2,600.

label: Hooker Creek
description: rises in W Henderson County and flows SW into E Transylvania County and into Little River.

label: Hooker Gap
description: SW Buncombe County at the E end of Holland Mountain.

label: Hookers Knob
description: E Madison County between Jarvis Mountain and Gabriels Creek.

label: Hookerton
description: town in SE Greene County on Contentnea Creek. Alt. 75. Inc. as Hookerton, 1817, on the lands of William Hooker. Known as Caswells Landing prior to the Revolution for Benjamin Caswell, brother of Governor Richard Caswell. Several early nineteenth-century academies flourished there, and a public library was est. in 1817.

label: Hookerton Township
description: S Greene County.

label: Hooks Branch
description: rises in W Johnston County and flows S into Black Creek.

label: Hoop Pole Creek
description: a waterway between several small islands near the E end of Bogue Banks, S Carteret County in Bogue Sound.

label: Hooper Bald
description: W Graham County between McGuires community and Huckleberry Knob. Alt. 5,429. Named for Enos Hooper, who moved to Graham from Jackson County and had a farm in the valley below the mountain.

label: Hooper Branch
description: rises in N Lincoln County and flows SE into Anderson Creek.

label: Hooper County
description: was authorized to be est. from Robeson and Richmond Counties in 1851 provided the people in the territory voted for its creation. The people voted against the new county, however. It was to have been named in honor of William Hooper, one of the North Carolina signers of the Declaration of Independence.

label: Hooper Cove
description: W Graham County between Cedar Top and Rattler Ford.

label: Hooper Creek
description: rises in S Polk County and flows SE into South Carolina, where it enters Pacolet River.

label: Hooper Knob
description: central Jackson County between Moses Creek and Wayehutta Creek. Alt. 3,719.

label: Hooper Mill Creek
description: rises in W Graham County and flows SE and N into Santeetlah Lake.

label: Hoopers Creek
description: rises in N Henderson County and flows W into Cane Creek.

label: Hoopers Creek Township
description: N Henderson County.

label: Hoophole Landing
description: E Beaufort County on Pungo River. A small community adjoining the landing bears the same name.

label: Hoot Owl Cove
description: NW Jackson County on Shoal Creek.

label: Hootentown
description: See Wootentown.

label: Hootowl Hollow
description: SW Mitchell County parallel to Roaring Branch.

label: Hoots Millpond
description: E Wilkes County on Little Elkin River. Grain and sawmill operated there by the Hoots family.

label: Hoover Hill
description: community in W Randolph County. A post office operated there, 1849-1907. In the early twentieth century, a prosperous gold mine was operated there. Ancestors of President Herbert Hoover are buried in the vicinity.

label: Hoover Meadow
description: SE Yancey County between the SW end of Dovers Ridge and Sevenmile Ridge.

label: Hop Creek
description: rises in NW Catawba County and flows SE into Jacob Fork.

label: Hop Mountain
description: SW Madison County, a peak on Spring Creek Mountain. Alt. 4,072.

label: Hope
description: See Trinity.

label: Hope Mills
description: town in SW Cumberland County. Active antebellum textile center. Known as Rockfish before the Civil War. Inc. as Hope Mills, 1891, when new mills were built. Alt. 117.

label: Hope Valley Forest
description: N Chatham and S Durham Counties, contained 1,735 acres. Est. in 1941 when the U.S. government conveyed a rehabilitation camp area to North Carolina State College. Now part of Jordan Lake public lands.

label: Hopedale
description: community in central Alamance County on Stony Creek at Big Falls, which see. Produces textiles.

label: Hopewell
description: community in E Rutherford County. Named for a local church.

label: Hopewell Branch
description: rises in central Madison County and flows SW into French Broad River.

label: Hopis Branch
description: rises in W Madison County and flows S into Meadow Fork.

label: Hopkins
description: community in E Wake County.

label: Hopkins Mine
description: former gold mine in NE Cabarrus County on Beaver Creek.

label: Hopper
description: community in NE Rockingham County served by post office, 1892-1910. Named for postmaster Ida Hopper.

label: Hopper's Ford
description: See Worthville.

label: Horace
description: community in E Henderson County between Little Hungry Creek and Big Hungry River.

label: Horn Beam Swamp
description: rises in E Nash County and flows SE into Edgecombe County, where it enters Compass Creek.

label: Horn Camp Swamp
description: rises in S Robeson County and flows SW into Ashpole Swamp.

label: Horn Swamp
description: See Sandy Run.

label: Horn's Branch
description: rises in W Wilson County and flows W into Shepherd's Branch.

label: Hornblower Point
description: S Chowan County, extends from E side of Edenton Bay into Albemarle Sound. A railroad bridge across the sound extends from the site to the mouth of Kendricks Creek in N Washington County. Now a part of Edenton Naval Air Station property. Shown as Moseleys Point on the Collet map, 1770; as Hornblow's Point on the MacRae map, 1833; and as Skinner's Point on the Price map, 1808, and on the Kerr map, 1882. Named for the Horniblow family, which owned property there.

label: Hornbuckle Creek
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows NW into Soco Creek.

label: Hornbuckle Ridge
description: W Jackson County between Sassafras Branch and Grassy Knob.

label: Horne Creek
description: rises in SE Surry County and flows SE into Yadkin River.

label: Horner
description: community in E Granville County. Once a railroad siding; also site of Horner Military School.

label: Hornes Bay
description: a sand-filled bay in W Columbus County. See Carolina Bays.

label: Hornet
description: community in SE Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1880-1903. See also Alexander's Store.

label: Hornet Swamp
description: rises in W Sampson County and flows W into Little Coharie Creek.

label: Horneyhead Mountain
description: in central Jackson County on the NE end of Cedar Valley Knob. Alt. 4,060.

label: Horniblow
description: See Hornblower Point.

label: Hornpipe Creek
description: rises in S Lenoir County and flows NW into Southwest Creek. The name appears in local records dating from before the Revolution.

label: Horns Branch
description: rises in S Surry County and flows NE into King Creek.

label: Hornytown
description: community in NE Davidson County at the head of Abbotts Creek.

label: Horse Branch
description: rises in N Madison County and flows SE into Shelton Laurel Creek.

label: Horse Branch
description: rises in N Pender County and flows SW into Long Creek. Named for adjacent high ground to which wild horses retreated in time of flood in pre-Revolutionary days.

label: Horse Cove
description: N Transylvania County, extends NE from Cat Pen Gap to Davidson River.

label: Horse Cove Branch
description: rises in N Macon County and flows NE into Burningtown Creek.

label: Horse Cove Ridge
description: W Graham County, forms the SW watershed of Little Santeetlah Creek and the SW boundary of Joyce Kilmer Memorial Forest.

label: Horse Creek
description: rises in W Avery County and flows E into North Toe River.

label: Horse Creek
description: rises in S Stanly County and flows NE into Long Creek.

label: Horse Creek Gap
description: on the Haywood-Swain county line on Balsam Mountain between Chiltoes Mountain and Cataloochee Balsam. Alt. 5,575.

label: Horse Creek Ridge
description: W Avery County.

label: Horse Creek Township
description: NW Ashe County.

label: Horse Fork
description: rises in NW Catawba County and flows N into Catawba River.

label: Horse Gap
description: N Transylvania County between Laurel Brook and Cantrell Creek.

label: Horse Island
description: a long, narrow tidal-marsh island SE of Beaufort in S Carteret County.

label: Horse Knob
description: N Transylvania County at the NW end of Huckleberry Ridge near the head of South Prong Turkey Creek.

label: Horse Mountain
description: on the McDowell-Yancey county line.

label: Horse Mountain Gap
description: S Burke County. Alt. 2,018.

label: Horse Pen Bay
description: swamp in NW Brunswick County. A part of Green Swamp.

label: Horse Pen Branch
description: rises in SW Bladen County and flows W into Horse Pen Swamp.

label: Horse Pen Creek
description: rises in S central Bladen County and flows SE into Brown Marsh Swamp.

label: Horse Pen Mountain
description: at the head of Cabin Creek in S Henderson County.

label: Horse Pen Ridge
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a spur extending NW from Cataloochee Divide; its center is near lat. 35°35'40" N., long. 83°05'07" W.

label: Horse Pen Swamp
description: rises in SW Bladen County and flows W into Robeson County, where it enters Big Swamp.

label: Horse Pool
description: appears on the Moseley map, 1733, in what is now E Gates County in the W edge of the Dismal Swamp.

label: Horse Range Ridge
description: S Graham County, extends SE from Little Snowbird Creek to Old Billy Top.

label: Horse Ridge
description: N Avery County.

label: Horse Ridge
description: See Balsam Mountain.

label: Horse Run
description: rises in E Duplin County and flows SE into Cabin Creek.

label: Horse Shoe
description: community in W Henderson County. Named because it is situated in a sharp bend in French Broad River. Alt. 2,083.

label: Horse Shoe Mountain
description: W Henderson County between Johnsons Mill Creek and French Broad River. Alt. 2,775.

label: Horse Swamp
description: rises in S Robeson County and flows SW into Aaron Swamp.

label: Horse Swamp Pocosin
description: E Onslow County between Queens Creek and Little Northeast Creek.

label: Horse Trail Gap
description: on the McDowell-Yancey county line near the head of Roaring Fork.

label: Horse Trough Mountain
description: W Montgomery County near Woodrun Creek.

label: Horse's Creek
description: rises in W Moore County and flows NW into Dry Creek.

label: Horsebone Gap
description: on the Haywood-Jackson county line on the main Balsam Range. The Blue Ridge Parkway passes through or near the gap. Named for the fact that a horse, turned out to graze in the area, died, and his bones lay bleaching in the sun for a number of years.

label: Horsebranch
description: community in central Pender County on Horse Branch.

label: Horsefork Mountain
description: E Haywood County, extends NE from Fall Creek to Grassy Gap.

label: Horselot Cove
description: central Clay County, S of Evans Ridge.

label: Horsepasture River
description: rises in S Jackson County and flows SE across SW Transylvania County into South Carolina, where it enters the Toxaway River.

label: Horsepen Bay
description: a small pocosin near the head of Horse Branch, which see, N Pender County.

label: Horsepen Branch
description: rises in S Warren County and flows SE into Shocco Creek.

label: Horsepen Creek
description: rises in W Guilford County and flows NE into Reedy Fork Creek.

label: Horsepen Pocosin
description: a sandy pocosin in SW Gates County. Alt. 28.

label: Horsepen Point
description: SE Carteret County, extends from Core Banks into Core Sound.

label: Horsepen Point
description: on Ocracoke Island near the community of Ocracoke, SE Hyde County.

label: Horsepen Swamp
description: rises in W Pitt County and flows SE into Swift Creek.

label: Horseshoe
description: community on Deep River in NE Moore County. Named for bend in river.

label: Horseshoe Bend
description: See Andrews Geyser.

label: Horseshoe Mountain
description: SE Macon County at the head of Brooks Creek.

label: Horseshoe Neck
description: a sharp bend in the Yadkin River in W Davidson and E Davie Counties. The neck of land formed by the bend is in Davidson County. Appears on the Collet map, 1770, as Horse-shoe. See also Boone's Cave.

label: Horseshoe Ridge
description: S Swain County between Dark Branch and Davis Branch.

label: Horseshoe Rock
description: peak on the SW end of Wolf Mountain, E Jackson County.

label: Horseshoe, The
description: a ridge parallel to a deep bend in Hazel Creek, W Swain County.

label: Horsetrough Ridge
description: NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a spur extending SW from Overlook Ridge between Heintooga Creek and Selma Creek.

label: Horseway Swamp
description: rises in E Pitt County and flows NE into Beaufort County, where it enters Chicod Creek.

label: Horton Bay
description: N central Carteret County behind Horton Point near the mouth of South River.

label: Horton Branch
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows SE into Joe Creek.

label: Horton Creek
description: rises in W Yancey County and flows E into Indian Creek.

label: Horton Hill
description: N Yancey County between Bee Branch and Sidney Hill.

label: Horton Knob
description: N Macon County between Allen Branch and Rose Creek.

label: Horton Point
description: N central Carteret County on E shore of South River near its mouth.

label: Hoskin Fork
description: rises in NW Watauga County and flows N into SW Ashe County, where it enters North Fork New River.

label: Hoskins Point
description: See Palmetto Point.

label: Hosley Branch
description: See Hostler Branch.

label: Hostler Branch
description: rises in W Caswell County and flows E into County Line Creek. Appears as Hosley Branch on early maps of the county.

label: Hot House Branch
description: rises in central Hertford County and flows NW into Potecasi Creek.

label: Hot House Creek
description: rises in SW Cherokee County and flows SW into Fannin County, Ga., where it enters Ocoee River.

label: Hot House Township
description: SW Cherokee County.

label: Hot Springs
description: town in W Madison County on French Broad River. Named for thermal springs in the town, discovered in 1778; a health resort since 1800. Name changed from Warm Springs, 1886; inc. 1889. Alt. 1,332. An internment camp for Germans during World War I was there. Spaightville, which see, inc. 1802, may have been at the site.

label: Hot Springs Mountain
description: W Madison County parallel to Mountain Island Branch.

label: Hot Springs Township
description: former township in NW Madison County, now township no. 9.

label: Hotel
description: See Woodville.

label: Hotel Creek
description: See Hall's Creek.

label: Hothouse
description: community in SW Cherokee County on Persimmon Creek.

label: Hothouse Branch
description: rises in S Clay County and flows NW into Shooting Creek.

label: Houck
description: community in W Caldwell County served by post office, 1888-90. Name changed to Mortimer, which see.

label: House
description: community in central Pitt County, approx. 1 mi. N of Greenville.

label: House Creek
description: rises in central Wake County just W of city of Raleigh and flows NE into Crabtree Creek.

label: House Creek Township
description: central Wake County.

label: House of Passage
description: See Old Town.

label: House's Mill Pond
description: N Sampson County on Seven-mile Swamp. A mill est. there in 1812 by William House still grinds corn.

label: Houston
description: community in SW Union County. Alt. 666.

label: Houston Branch
description: rises in E Macon County and flows SW into Big Creek.

label: Houston Gap
description: E Mitchell County between Little Bear Creek and Beaver Creek.

label: Houston Knob
description: W Yancey County between Possumtrot Creek and Indian Creek.

label: Houston Ridge
description: central Avery County.

label: Houston's Shop
description: community in SE Mecklenburg County.

label: Houstonville
description: community in NE Iredell County.

label: Howard
description: community in S Bertie County served by post office, 1883-1900.

label: Howard Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows N into Dryman Fork.

label: Howard Creek
description: rises in N Watauga County and flows SE into South Fork New River.

label: Howard Gap
description: W Polk County between Warrior Mountain and Miller Mountain. Named for Capt. Thomas Howard, whose men, led by Skyuka, defeated Cherokee Indians there in 1776. See also Skyuka Mountain.

label: Howard Knob
description: mountain in central Watauga County about ½ mi. N of town of Boone. Named during Revolutionary War when a Loyalist, Benjamin Howard, fled from American patriots to a cave on the mountain. There is no record of his discovery. Alt. 4,420. See also Sampson's Chimney.

label: Howard Reef
description: SE Hyde County in Pamlico Sound approx. 1 nautical mi. N of Ocracoke Island; approx. 1¾ mi. long and over ½ mi. wide.

label: Howard Swamp
description: rises in S Robeson County and flows SW into Indian Swamp.

label: Howard's Knob Gap
description: central Watauga County. Alt. 3,679.

label: Howard's Mill
description: community in N Moore County in an area formerly known as Noise, which see. Named for John Hayworth (later Howard), who operated a tannery and gristmill there. Mill operated until 1950s.

label: Howards Bay
description: S Onslow County in New River between Cedar Point and Sulliers Bay.

label: Howards Creek
description: See Indian Creek.

label: Howards Creek Township
description: W central Lincoln County.

label: Howell Branch
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows S into Big Creek.

label: Howell Creek
description: rises in central Wayne County and flows SE into Stony Creek.

label: Howell Swamp
description: rises in N Greene County and flows SW into Beaman Run. Named for the Howell family, who were living in the vicinity as early as 1769.

label: Howells Point
description: a small neck of land on the E side of Lockwoods Folly River just N of the channel of the Intracoastal Waterway in S Brunswick County.

label: Howellsville
description: community in central Robeson County served by post office, 1894-1913.

label: Howes Point
description: E New Hanover County, extends from the mainland into the N waters of Middle Sound.

label: Howie Mine
description: former gold mine in W Union County S of East Fork Twelvemile Creek.

label: Howland Creek
description: rises in E Carteret County and flows approx. 2.2 mi. SE into Jarrett Bay.

label: Howlett Creek
description: rises in E Granville County and flows N into Little Island Creek.

label: Howsers Creek
description: rises in central Gaston County and flows E into South Fork Catawba River.

label: Hoyle
description: community in NW Randolph County served by post office, 1886-1905.

label: Hoyles Creek
description: rises in S Lincoln County and flows SW into N Gaston County, where it turns SE to flow into South Fork Catawba River.

label: Hoyles Store
description: community in S Lincoln County between Rockdam Creek and Leonard Fork. The Hoylesville post office that existed in 1822 may have been at or near the community. See also Dallas.

label: Hoylesville
description: See Dallas.

label: Hoyts Stop
description: a short channel running into the Banks Channel in W Carteret County. Named for Hoyt Tootle, a black fisherman.

label: Hub
description: See Boardman.

label: Hubbard
description: former community in W Swain County on Little Tennessee River. The site is now covered by the waters of Fontana Lake.

label: Hubert
description: community in E Onslow County on Bell Swamp.

label: Huble Creek
description: See Hubquarter Creek.

label: Hubquarter Creek
description: rises in NE Warren County and flows NE into Lake Gaston. Appears as Huble Creek on the Collet map, 1770, but with its present name on the Price map, 1808.

label: Huckleberry Branch
description: rises in SW Wilson County and flows N into Black Creek.

label: Huckleberry Creek
description: rises in NE Macon County and flows S into Beasley Creek.

label: Huckleberry Gap
description: N Madison County between White Rock Branch and Chimney Creek.

label: Huckleberry Knob
description: W Graham County between Hooper Bald and Little Huckleberry Knob. Alt. approx. 5,570.

label: Huckleberry Knob
description: N Madison County between Huckleberry Gap and White Oak Gap.

label: Huckleberry Mountain
description: NE Rutherford County between Pot Branch and North Fork. Alt. 2,108.

label: Huckleberry Patch
description: mountain in SW Watauga County at the head of Boone Fork.

label: Huckleberry Ridge
description: N Transylvania County, extends SE beside South Prong Turkey Creek.

label: Huckleberry Springs
