description: community in W Durham County a short distance NW of the city of Durham. Formerly a popular picnic site because of the excellent spring water.

label: Huckleberry Swamp
description: See Enfield.

label: Hudson
description: town in S Caldwell County. Settled in the late nineteenth century and known as Sardis for a local Baptist church. Inc. 1905 and named for David Hudson, the founder. Alt. 1,264.

label: Hudson Spring
description: community in NW Anson County on Richardson Creek.

label: Hudson Township
description: SE Caldwell County.

label: Huey Gap
description: central Haywood County on the head of Dotson Branch.

label: Huff Island
description: a sandy island approx. ½ mi. long in French Broad River, W Madison County.

label: Huffmans Creek
description: rises in N Davidson County and flows SW into Reedy Creek.

label: Huffmantown
description: community in NW Onslow County between Mill Swamp and Purgatory Pocosin.

label: Huggins Bay
description: a loam-filled bay in SW Columbus County. See also Carolina Bays.

label: Huggins Branch
description: rises in N Swain County and flows NW into Hazel Creek.

label: Huggins Creek
description: rises in N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows SW into Forney Creek.

label: Huggins Hell
description: thicket of rhododendron and laurel covering between 400 and 500 acres in N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Named for Irving Huggins, early settler, who was trapped there for several days while herding cattle.

label: Huggins Island
description: E Onslow County between Dudley's Island and Swansboro in White Oak River. Named for Luke Huggins. Appears as Stones Island on the Moseley map, 1733. A fort or battery erected there by Confederate forces was designed to protect Bogue Inlet and West Channel from the Union fleet; it was destroyed in 1862.

label: Huggins Ridge
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur extending NW from Welch Ridge between Sawbrier Ridge and Huggins Branch.

label: Hugh Day's Gap
description: NE Caldwell and W Wilkes Counties. Alt. 1,687. Named for Hugh Day, a hatter in the area in the early nineteenth century.

label: Hugh's Creek
description: See East Buies Creek.

label: Hughes
description: community in central Avery County.

label: Hughes Branch
description: rises in central Swain County and flows N into Tuckasegee River.

label: Hughes Creek
description: appears on the Collet map, 1770, apparently rising in what is now NE Yadkin County N of East Bend and flowing NE into Yadkin River.

label: Hughes Gap
description: W Mitchell County at the head of Cooper Branch.

label: Hughes Knob
description: W Jackson County between Bearpen Creek and Jim Creek.

label: Hughes Ridge
description: N Yancey County between Lottie Creek and Little Creek.

label: Hughes Ridge Branch
description: rises in E Avery County and flows E into Rockhouse Creek.

label: Hugo
description: community in N Lenoir County. The name may have been given in honor of French author Victor Hugo.

label: Huitt Bay
description: swamp in S central Brunswick County; a part of Green Swamp.

label: Hull Branch
description: rises in SE Avery County and flows E into South Harper Creek.

label: Hulls Crossroads
description: community in W Lincoln County.

label: Hulme Hill (Hull Hill)
description: a low ridge in N central Caldwell County on the N side of Yadkin River. Named for Maj. William Hulme, planter and legislator who settled there in 1807.

label: Hump Mountain
description: W Avery County. Alt. 5,587.

label: Humpback Mountain
description: on the Avery-McDowell county line at the E end of Dividing Ridge. Alt. approx. 4,200. Known by the Cherokee Indians as Koonasoga.

label: Humphrey
description: community in SE Duplin County.

label: Hungry Creek
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows NW into East Fork Pigeon River.

label: Hungry Neck
description: See Kelly.

label: Hunkadora
description: See Bahama.

label: Hunsucker
description: community in SW Scotland County. Formerly known as Brick Mill.

label: Hunsucker's Store
description: See Star.

label: Hunt's Store
description: See New Castle.

label: Huntdale
description: community in W Mitchell County on Toe River. Alt. 2,058.

label: Hunter Branch
description: rises in N central Haywood County and flows N into Stevens Creek.

label: Hunter Branch
description: rises in S Madison County and flows S into Ivy River.

label: Hunter Creek
description: rises in central Madison County between Watershed Mountain and High Rock and flows SE into Walnut Creek.

label: Hunter Jim Creek
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows SE into West Fork Tuckasegee River.

label: Hunters Bridge
description: community in central Beaufort County on Bath Creek.

label: Hunters Creek
description: rises at Great Lake in SW Craven County and flows SW along the Carteret-Jones county line into White Oak River. Named for the Hunter family, early settlers.

label: Hunters Mill Township
description: E central Gates County.

label: Hunters Millpond
description: built prior to 1720 at the junction of Raynor Swamp and Harrell Swamp at the head of Bennetts Creek, E Gates County. Was destroyed about 1922 when a new highway was built. It was about 1 mi. long. Known in later years as Cross Millpond.

label: Huntersville
description: See Murphy.

label: Huntersville Township
description: former township in NE Mecklenburg County, now township no. 15.

label: Hunting Branch
description: rises in N Northampton County and flows SE into Corduroy Swamp.

label: Hunting Creek
description: community in S Wilkes County on Hunting Creek.

label: Hunting Island
description: in Bogue Sound, SW Carteret County.

label: Hunting Island Creek
description: rises in W Carteret County and flows S into Bogue Inlet.

label: Hunting Quarter Inlet
description: appears on the Moseley map, 1733, in Core Banks of Carteret County. It was opened and closed in the 1730s.

label: Hunting Quarter Sound
description: appears on the Moseley map, 1733, as the water now forming the N end of Core Sound in NE Carteret County. Four small islands extending SE from the present Hog Island separated the sound from Pamlico Sound. Three of the four islands were named Chainshot, Harbour, and Shell.

label: Hunting Quarters Township
description: former township in E Carteret County. Cedar Island Township was formed from a part of Hunting Quarters, and the remainder is now Atlantic Township. The area was formerly a summer camp of the Core Indians.

label: Hunting Run
description: rises in N Pitt County and flows SE into Grindle Creek.

label: Huntley
description: community in central Sampson County served by post office, 1875-1922.

label: Hunts
description: community in W Nash County served by post office, 1885-1903.

label: Hunts Branch
description: rises in central Transylvania County and flows SE into Tucker Creek.

label: Hunts Fork
description: rises in E Davidson County and flows SE into Rich Fork Creek.

label: Hunts Pond
description: See Lake View.

label: Huntsboro
description: community in E Granville County. Named for John and Mourning Hunt, residents in 1760s.

label: Huntsborough
description: town authorized in 1814 to be laid off on the lands of Jonathan Hunt "on the waters of Little Ivey" in what was then Buncombe County but is now Madison County. The town apparently did not materialize.

label: Huntsville
description: town in SE Yadkin County near Yadkin River. Chartered 1792 by Charles Hunt of Salisbury, who sold lots there. Thomas L. Clingman, U.S. senator and Confederate general, was born there. Town rechartered 1822, but long inactive in municipal affairs.

label: Huntsville Mountains
description: a ridge in S McDowell County near Glenwood. Extensive gold-mining operations were carried on there from the mid-nineteenth century until 1909.

label: Huntsville Township
description: SW Rockingham County. Name derived from activity of sportsmen in area.

label: Hurdle Mills
description: community in SW Person County.

label: Hurdle Ridge
description: a strip of high ground in the Dismal Swamp, SE Gates County.

label: Hurley Lake
description: See Eury Lake.

label: Huron
description: community in NW Tyrrell County served by post office, 1900-1908.

label: Huronian Mountain
description: a peak in the Cane Creek Mountains, S Alamance County.

label: Hurrah Ridge
description: S Macon County between West Fork Overflow Creek and Abe Creek.

label: Hurricane Branch
description: rises in NW Swain County and flows S into Ekaneetlee Creek.

label: Hurricane Cove
description: E Graham County on the headwaters of Panther Creek.

label: Hurricane Creek
description: rises in N Madison County and flows SE into Big Laurel Creek.

label: Hurricane Creek
description: rises in central Wake County and flows S into Crabtree Creek.

label: Hurricane Gap
description: S Yancey County between the head of Falling Water Branch and South Fork Cattail Creek.

label: Hurricane Mountain
description: W central Swain County between Laurel Branch and Tuckasegee River.

label: Hurricane Ridge
description: See Rose Ridge.

label: Hurricane Top
description: mountain in SW Macon County between Clear Branch and Rocky Cove.

label: Hurricane Township
description: NE Ashe County.

label: Hurricane, The (HARRY-kin)
description: SE corner of Granville County and parts of Franklin and Wake Counties where a storm wreaked havoc in the nineteenth century.

label: Hurst Beach
description: See Onslow Beach.

label: Hurts Creek
description: rises in N Montgomery County and flows SW into Denson Creek.

label: Husbands Creek
description: rises in SW Caldwell County and flows S into Lower Creek. Named for Veazey Husband, locally noted Tory who lived in the vicinity.

label: Husk
description: community in NW Ashe County. Railroad name is Nella. Post office est. there, 1915.

label: Huskanaw Swamp
description: See Collie Swamp.

label: Huskey Creek
description: rises in N Swain County and flows S into Beech Flats Prong.

label: Hyatt
description: community in N Anson County served by post office, 1888-1905.

label: Hyatt Bald
description: NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Hyatt Ridge. Alt. 5,153.

label: Hyatt Branch
description: rises in W Swain County and flows SW into Goldmine Branch.

label: Hyatt Cove
description: NW Jackson County at the head of Shoal Creek.

label: Hyatt Creek
description: community in SW Haywood County on Hyatt Creek.

label: Hyatt Mill Creek
description: rises in S Clay County and flows NE into Hiwassee River.

label: Hyatt Ridge
description: NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a spur extending SE from Dashoga Ridge with its center near lat. 35°39'35" N., long. 83°13'58" W. See also McGee Spring.

label: Hyco Lake
description: See Carolina Power Lake.

label: Hyco River
description: is formed in NW Person County by the junction of North Hyco and South Hyco Creeks. It flows NE into Virginia, where it enters Dan River. In 1728 William Byrd referred to the stream as "Hicootomony, or Turkey-Buzzard River, from the great number of those unsavoury Birds that roost on the tall Trees growing near its banks." Appears on the Moseley map, 1733, as Hyco-ote. Hyco Dam, completed in 1964, now impounds its waters to form Carolina Power Lake.

label: Hyco-ote
description: See Hyco River.

label: Hycotee
description: community in E central Caswell County. A post office was operated there during the approx. period 1880-1905.

label: Hyde County
description: was formed in 1705 as Wickham Precinct, which see, of Bath County. The name was changed to Hyde about 1712. Located in the E section of the state, it is bounded by Pamlico Sound; Beaufort, Washington, Tyrrell, and Dare Counties; and (on the Outer Banks) the Atlantic Ocean and Dare and Carteret Counties. Named for Governor Edward Hyde, who died in 1712. Area: 1,364 sq. mi. (634, land; 730, water). County seat: Swan Quarter, with an elevation of 10 ft. Townships are Currituck, Fairfield, Lake Landing, Mattamuskeet, Ocracoke, and Swan Quarter. Produces soybeans, corn, wheat, cotton, snap beans, seafood, hogs, livestock, dairy products, lumber, and wooden boxes. See also Woodstock Point; Aramuskeet.

label: Hyde Islands
description: formerly two islands with a total of 10 acres in Little Tennessee River in NE Graham County. Now under the waters of Fontana Lake.

label: Hyde Mill Creek
description: rises in S Graham County and flows NE into Tulula Creek.

label: Hyde Parish
description: Church of England, Hyde County, est. 1715, coextensive with the county. By 1767 the parish was being called St. George's and in that year had 441 white taxables.

label: Hydeland
description: community in S Hyde County S of Lake Mattamuskeet near the head of Juniper Bay.

label: Hyder Mountain
description: E Haywood County between Pigeon River and Long Branch.

label: Hydro
description: community in SW Montgomery County on Pee Dee River at the dam that forms Lake Tillery. Power-generating plant is there.

label: Hymans
description: community in central Craven County.

label: Hymans Ferry
description: former ferry across Roanoke River, S Bertie County.

label: Icard
description: community in E Burke County. First known as Bowan's Crossing. Alt. 1,172.

label: Icard Township
description: E Burke County.

label: Icaria
description: community in N Chowan County. Alt. 34.

label: Icemorlee
description: See West Monroe.

label: Ichley
description: community in N Orange County.

label: Icy Knob
description: on Burke-Rutherford county line.

label: Ida
description: community in W Scotland County. Named for Ida Cotton Mills, which in turn were named for Ida Morgan, daughter of Mark Morgan.

label: Idaho
description: community in central Cumberland County served by post office, 1877-1903.

label: Idalia
description: community in SE Beaufort County.

label: Idlewild
description: community in S Ashe County. Alt. 2,700.

label: Idol
description: community in central Ashe County served by post office, 1879-1906. Also known as Idol's Mill.

label: Idol's Mill
description: See Idol.

label: Ijames Crossroads
description: community in W Davie County. A Baptist church built there in 1897 on land donated by Cas Ijames was known as Ijames Crossroads Church.

label: Ike Cove
description: S Haywood County on a tributary of Little East Fork Pigeon River.

label: Ike Mountain
description: N Buncombe County W of Dillingham.

label: Ilex
description: community in central Davidson County served by post office, 1886-1902.

label: Immer
description: community in N Montgomery County served by post office, 1888-1932.

label: Improvement Cove
description: E Swain County between Middle Ridge and Connelly Mountain on Improvement Creek.

label: Improvement Creek
description: rises in E Swain County and flows NE into Wesser Creek.

label: Inadu Knob
description: on Haywood County, N.C.-Cocke County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°43'37" N., long. 83°14'27" W. Formerly Snake Knob but, to prevent duplication within the park, the name was changed to Inadu, the Indian word for snake. Alt. 5,941.

label: Inanda
description: former town in central Buncombe County on French Broad River at the mouth of Hominy Creek. Inc. 1893; charter repealed 1901. Served by post office, 1891-1904. A church at the site still bears the name.

label: Independence Hill
description: community in N Mecklenburg County.

label: Index
description: community in SE Ashe County.

label: Indian Branch
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows SE into Bald Creek.

label: Indian Camp Bay
description: an arm of Big Colly Bay, NE Bladen County.

label: Indian Camp Branch
description: rises in E Macon County and flows N into Ellijay Creek.

label: Indian Camp Branch
description: rises in W central Transylvania County and flows SE into Kuykendall Creek.

label: Indian Camp Creek
description: rises in N Macon County and flows SE into Burningtown Creek.

label: Indian Camp Gap
description: N Jackson County near the heads of Allens Branch and Kitchin Branch.

label: Indian Camp Mountain
description: S Transylvania County in the Blue Ridge Mountains E of Estatoe Creek.

label: Indian Creek
description: rises in S Cumberland County and flows S into Bladen County, where it enters Harrisons Creek.

label: Indian Creek
description: rises in W Yancey County and flows N into Price Creek.

label: Indian Creek
description: See Dillard Creek; Town Creek.

label: Indian Ford
description: shallow rock formation in Contentnea Creek, central Wilson County, ½ mi. below Contentnea Lake. Mentioned in early records as "the falls," below which the stream is navigable by boat.

label: Indian Fork
description: rises in SW Yancey County and flows SE into Cane River.

label: Indian Gap
description: on Swain County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line near the head of Right Fork [Deep Creek]. Alt. 5,317.

label: Indian Grave Creek
description: rises in central Davidson County and flows SE into Swearing Creek.

label: Indian Grave Gap
description: S Swain County between Brush Creek and Little Tennessee River.

label: Indian Grave Gap
description: W central Swain County on the head of Laurel Branch.

label: Indian Island
description: approx. 500 acres of arable land in North River Pocosin, SE Camden County, bounded on the E by North River. Island formerly was home to a thickly settled community, but it is now abandoned. Named for the large number of Indian artifacts that have been found there.

label: Indian Knob
description: peak on Indian Ridge, W Haywood County near lat. 35°40'06" N., long. 83°07'43" W., in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Alt. 5,120.

label: Indian Landing
description: E Beaufort County on Pungo River.

label: Indian Ridge
description: W Swain County on a bend in Nantahala River; now surrounded at the SW end by the backwaters of Fontana Lake.

label: Indian Run
description: rises in E Beaufort County in Pantego Swamp and flows E into Pungo River.

label: Indian Spring Branch
description: rises in SW Buncombe County near the Haywood County line and flows W into South Hominy Creek.

label: Indian Springs
description: community in S Wayne County near a tributary of Smith Millpond. The site was settled as early as 1829 and named for local springs traditionally used by Saponi Indians.

label: Indian Springs Township
description: SE Wayne County. First listed on county tax records in 1838.

label: Indian Swamp
description: rises on the Tyrrell-Washington county line and flows N into Banton Creek.

label: Indian Top
description: central Cherokee County between West Prong Grape Creek and Rose Creek.

label: Indian Town Creek
description: See Dillard Creek.

label: Indian Trading Path
description: See Trading Path.

label: Indian Trail
description: town in W Union County. Inc. 1907. Located between heads of North Fork Crooked Creek and South Fork Crooked Creek. Alt. 697.

label: Indian Well Swamp
description: rises in S Pitt County and flows SE into Clayroot Swamp.

label: Indian Wells
description: indicated on the Price map, 1808, and the MacRae map, 1833, as four wells on Cape Fear River in SE Bladen County. Possibly these were natural artesian wells, common to the area.

label: Indian Woods
description: central Bertie County, a reservation set aside in 1717 for the Tuscarora Indians remaining in North Carolina after the war of 1711-13. The Indians later joined relatives in New York, and the state sold the tract of land in 1828.

label: Indian Woods Township
description: SW Bertie County.

label: Indiantown
description: former community in W central Currituck County approx. 5 mi. S of Shawboro. Appears in local records as early as 1764; a post office as early as 1793 and as recently as 1882. Currituck Seminary, burned during the Civil War, was there.

label: Indiantown Creek
description: a name sometimes applied to the upper course of North River, which see, in Camden County.

label: Indigo Branch
description: rises in Horry County, S.C., and flows NW into SW Brunswick County, where it enters Cawcaw Swamp.

label: Inez
description: community in S Warren County E of Shocco Creek. Post office est. there in 1890, but discontinued in 1954.

label: Ingalls
description: community in SW Avery County. Named for Senator John J. Ingalls (1833-1900) of Kansas. A nineteenth-century post office serving the area was named Keenerville.

label: Ingles Cove
description: N Buncombe County N of Ingles Gap.

label: Ingles Field Gap
description: S Buncombe County between Little Hickory Top and Stradley Mountain.

label: Ingles Gap
description: N Buncombe County between Grassy Knob and Ravens Knob.

label: Ingles Ridge
description: N Buncombe County between Sugar Cove and Sawyer Cove.

label: Ingleside
description: community in N Franklin County.

label: Ingold
description: community in S Sampson County on the E side of Great Coharie Creek. Alt. 100. Settled about 1888. Inc. 1889; charter repealed 1895.

label: Ingraham Mountain
description: NE Buncombe County near Dillingham.

label: Ingram
description: community in NW Northampton County served by post office, 1882-1907.

label: Ingram Branch
description: rises in W Macon County and flows SE into Nantahala Lake.

label: Ingrams Mountain
description: NE Anson County. Alt. approx. 525.

label: Ingrams Township
description: S central Johnston County.

label: Inipta
description: community in W Alleghany County.

label: Ink
description: See Newlife.

label: Inland Waterway
description: See Intracoastal Waterway.

label: Inman
description: community in S Robeson County served by post office, 1896-1902.

label: Inman Branch
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows SE into West Fork Pigeon River.

label: Inner Diamond Shoal
description: See Diamond Shoals.

label: Institute
description: community in NW Lenoir County. Named for the Lenoir Collegiate Institute, which operated there for a number of years after 1855. Some of the buildings of the institute were later used as residences.

label: Institute Branch
description: rises in W Hertford County and flows NE into Worrell Mill Pond.

label: Institute Township
description: NW Lenoir County.

label: Intelligence
description: community in W Rockingham County served by post office, 1901-11. Known as Bald Hill until about 1920. Between 1850 and 1900, several tobacco factories flourished there. Named because the first public school in North Carolina was there. "Danbury," plantation home of Governor Alexander Martin (1740-1807), was nearby. Sharp's Institute, operated by James Sharp, father of N.C. Supreme Court justice Susie Sharp, was there.

label: Intracoastal Waterway
description: extends from Gloucester, Mass., to Key West, Fla., a distance of 1,950 mi., of which 308 are in North Carolina. It passes through sounds, rivers, and canals. The depth of the waterway is 12 ft., minimum width is 47 ft., and minimum vertical clearance is 80 ft. The oldest segment of the waterway in North Carolina was begun in 1856 as a private enterprise. In 1873 control and maintenance of the network of coastal canals was taken over by the U.S. Corps of Engineers, and work was expanded through the 1940s. Pleasure craft, towed barges, and small freight boats use the Intracoastal Waterway.

label: Inverness
description: community in central Hoke County served by post office, 1854-1912.

label: Invershiel
description: mountain resort in E Avery County near Grandfather Mountain. A village containing shops, a church, and other buildings is modeled after an old Scottish village. Named for the village in Scotland, ancestral home of the MacRae family, developers of the resort. Est. 1966.

label: Iola
description: community in E Montgomery County served by post office, 1903-15. Named for Iola gold mine.

label: Iona
description: community in central Robeson County served by post office, 1896-1902.

label: Iotla Branch
description: rises in N Macon County and flows SE into Iotla Creek.

label: Iotla Creek
description: rises in central Macon County and flows NE into Little Tennessee River.

label: Iotla Gap
description: central Macon County near the head of Iotla Creek.

label: Iowa Hill
description: E Mitchell County between Beaver Creek and North Toe River.

label: Ira
description: community in W Wilkes County served by post office, 1899-1903.

label: Iredell
description: community in SW Brunswick County.

label: Iredell County
description: was formed in 1788 from Rowan County. Located in the central section of the state, it is bounded by Rowan, Cabarrus, Mecklenburg, Lincoln, Catawba, Alexander, Wilkes, Yadkin, and Davie Counties. It was named for James Iredell (1751-99), attorney general of North Carolina during the Revolution and delegate from Edenton to the Convention of 1788, where he advocated adoption of the Federal Constitution. Area: 594 sq. mi. County seat: Statesville, with an elevation of 925 ft. Townships are Bethany, Chambersburg, Coddle Creek, Concord, Cool Spring, Davidson, Eagle Mills, Fallstown, New Hope, Olin, Sharpesburg, Shiloh, Statesville, Turnersburg, and Union Grove. Produces wheat, oats, corn, poultry, livestock, hogs, canned milk, textiles, apparel, hay, ceramics, glass products, fabricated metal, lumber, and machinery. See also York County.

label: Iredell House
description: See James Iredell House.

label: Iredell Station
description: See Loray.

label: Irena
description: community in central Clay County on Tusquitee Creek.

label: Irene
description: community in SE Mecklenburg served by post office, 1871-80.

label: Irish Buffalo Creek
description: rises in SW Rowan County and flows S into Cabarrus County, where it enters Coldwater Creek. Called Buffalo Creek on the Collet map, 1770, but Irish Buffalo Creek on the Price map, 1808. Named for Scots-Irish settlers. See also Dutch Buffalo Creek.

label: Irish Creek
description: rises in W Burke County and flows SE to join Upper Creek in forming Warrior Fork [Catawba River].

label: Irisquoque
description: See Clubfoot Creek.

label: Iron Duff
description: community in central Haywood County on Big Branch. Named for an early settler, Aaron MacDuff. Known as Aaron Duff until 1873, when a post office was est. An error in Washington, D.C., resulted in the use of the name Iron Duff instead of Aaron Duff.

label: Iron Duff Township
description: central Haywood County.

label: Iron Mountain
description: community in S Randolph County.

label: Iron Mountain Gap
description: on the Mitchell County, N.C.-Unicoi County, Tenn., line. Alt. 3,725.

label: Iron Mountains
description: See Unaka Mountains.

label: Iron Ore Ridge
description: N Buncombe County, extends SW from Jones Knob in the Elk Mountains.

label: Iron Station
description: town in S Lincoln County. Settled about 1789. Inc. 1909. Named for the fact that many iron mines and forges were operated within a radius of 10 mi. between 1790 and 1880. Earlier known as Sharon.

label: Iron Works
description: See Troublesome Creek Iron Works.

label: Iron-Lithia Springs
description: former resort community in S Wilkes County near Old Gilreath. Buildings destroyed by fire about 1900. Alt. approx. 1,500.

label: Ironhill
description: community in S Columbus County.

label: Ironmonger Mountain
description: S central Burke County. Alt. 1,823.

label: Ironton Township
description: E central Lincoln County.

label: Irvin
description: community in E Transylvania County served by post office, 1889-1901. Later known as Blantyre, which see.

label: Irvin River
description: See Smith River.

label: Irvins Creek
description: rises in E Mecklenburg County and flows SW into McAlpine Creek.

label: Irvins Crossroads
description: community in S Lenoir County.

label: Irvinsville
description: a town authorized in 1815 to be laid out in SW Cleveland County (then Rutherford County) on Broad River opposite Quinn's Ferry. The town seems not to have developed as expected and the last mention of it occurs in local records of 1828.

label: Irwin Creek
description: rises in N Mecklenburg County and flows SW into Stewart Creek.

label: Isaac Creek
description: rises in SE Craven County and flows N into Adams Creek.

label: Isaac Hollow
description: W Watauga County, extends SE N of George Gap Branch.

label: Isaac Parlier's Creek
description: See Purlear Creek.

label: Isaac Walton Lake
description: formerly Water Works Lake, in W Person County on Storys Creek at the mouth of Satterfield Creek. Formed prior to 1928. Covers 213 acres; max. depth 25 ft. Owned by the town of Roxboro.

label: Isenhour
description: community in NE Stanly County. Grew up around Isenhour Brick Yard in early twentieth century.

label: Isenhour Mine
description: former gold mine in NE Cabarrus County on Little Buffalo Creek.

label: Isinglass Creek
description: rises in N Franklin County and flows NE into Little Shocco Creek.

label: Isinglass Ridge
description: S Graham County, extends SE from Sassafras Ridge to Little Snowbird Creek. Named for isinglass or mica mined in the area.

label: Island Borough
description: former town in E Rowan County. Inc. and authorized to be laid out in 1795 on the Yadkin River opposite the E end of Big Island, which see. Site is about 3 mi. NE of Spencer. Intended to promote navigation on the river, the town was to be built on land owned by Edward Yarborough. Little if any development took place at the site.

label: Island Branch Swamp
description: connects Resolution Branch to Musselshell Creek in NW Jones County.

label: Island Creek
description: rises in E Anson County and flows SE into Pee Dee River.

label: Island Creek
description: rises in SW Stanly County and flows S into Rocky River. Called Stillwater Creek on the Kerr map, 1882.

label: Island Creek
description: See Lillington Creek.

label: Island Creek District
description: formerly a census precinct in what is now NW Vance County approx. 2 mi. W of the town of Williamsboro. By 1790, 107 heads of families had settled in the area.

label: Island Creek Reservoir
description: in the NW corner of Vance County, is fed by Island Creek and Little Island Creek. It is separated from Kerr Lake by a dike that prevented the flooding of nearby tungsten mines. Extends about 5 mi. along the Granville-Vance county line. Formed about 1952 after the completion of Kerr Lake.

label: Island Creek Township
description: S central Duplin County.

label: Island Ford
description: across Yadkin River in W Surry County near the community of Jonesville. Mentioned in local records as early as 1778.

label: Island Fort
description: community in S Rutherford County served by post office, 1827-1907.

label: Island Swamp
description: rises in E Pitt County and flows NE into Chicod Creek.

label: Isle Hatton
description: island in Pamlico Sound that cannot now be identified; appears on the Smith map, 1624.

label: Isothermal Belt
description: See Thermal Belt.

label: Ita
description: community in N Nash County.

label: Itiner
description: community in E Harnett County.

label: Itom
description: community in central Rutherford County served by post office, 1887-1933.

label: Ivanhoe
description: community in S Sampson County on Black River. Named in the 1880s for the hero in Sir Walter Scott's novel of the same name. Alt. 29. The Colton map, 1861, shows a community at the site named Black River. Corbetts Ferry there was taken by Gen. Richard Caswell on the eve of the Battle of Moores Creek Bridge. Corbetts Ferry appears on maps at the site through 1865. Black River Presbyterian Church, est. there in 1740, occupies a building erected in 1859.

label: Ivestor Gap
description: S Haywood County on the head of Little East Fork Pigeon River.

label: Ivestor Ridge
description: S Haywood County between Grassy Cove Prong and Dark Prong.

label: Ivory Crossroads
description: community in E Franklin County.

label: Ivory Ridge
description: W Watauga County, extends NE from Hockiday Ridge S of Rush Branch.

label: Ivory Swamp
description: rises in N Wayne County and flows NE into Wilson County, where it enters Contentnea Creek.

label: Ivy
description: community in E Madison County on Little Ivy Creek. Alt. 2,150. A post office existed there from 1833. Named by early settlers because of the abundance of laurel, which they called ivy.

label: Ivy Creek
description: rises in N Northampton County and flows NE into Jordans Mill Pond on Cypress Creek.

label: Ivy Gap
description: community in W Yancey County near the Madison County line.

label: Ivy Hill Township
description: W central Haywood County.

label: Ivy Knob
description: NE Buncombe County between Little Will Branch and North Fork Ivy Creek.

label: Ivy Knob
description: E Mitchell County on Laurel Branch.

label: Ivy Ridge
description: NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur extending E from Big Grill Ridge.

label: Ivy River
description: is formed on the Buncombe-Madison county line by the junction of Ivy Creek and Little Ivy Creek. It flows W through S Madison County into French Broad River, crossing back briefly into Buncombe County at three points.

label: Ivy Swamp
description: rises in NE Wayne County and flows NE into Wilson County, where it enters Contentnea Creek. Named for the Ivey family, early settlers.

label: Ivy Top
description: S Clay County near the headwaters of Webb Creek.

label: Ivy Township
description: NW Buncombe County.

label: Jack
description: community in NE Warren County. Post office est. there in 1901, but discontinued in 1905. Due to a shift in population, the community is dwindling, and the name is not widely known.

label: Jack Bradley Branch
description: rises in N Swain County and flows S into Beech Flats Prong.

label: Jack Cabin Branch
description: rises in S Jones County and flows NW into Trent River.

label: Jack Cove
description: NW Jackson County, formerly Schuler Cove. In 1956, on a 5,000-acre tract there, R. H. Kress est. the Jack Kress School and renamed Schuler Cove in honor of his late son. Operated as a trade school, there is a model farm and nursery; classes in forestry and various trades are conducted.

label: Jack Creek
description: rises in NW Jackson County and flows SW into Tuckasegee River.

label: Jack Gap
description: central Buncombe County between Pine Knob and Bartlett Mountain.

label: Jack Island Swamp
description: W Duplin County on Nahunga Creek.

label: Jack Knob
description: E Macon County between Passmore Knob and Watauga Creek.

label: Jack Smith Creek
description: rises in central Craven County SW of New Bern and flows NE into Neuse River. It forms a part of the limits of New Bern.

label: Jack Swamp
description: flourished as a community on the stream of that name in N Northampton County from about 1775, when a Quaker meetinghouse was built there, until about 1812, by which time most of the people had moved to central North Carolina and to Ohio.

label: Jack Trail Mountain
description: W Madison County between Little Creek and Meadow Fork.

label: Jack's Branch
description: rises in E central Wake County and flows SE into Neuse River.

label: Jackdaw
description: community in S central Stanly County.

label: Jacket Swamp
description: rises in W central Halifax County and flows SE into Burnt Coat Swamp.

label: Jackeye Creek
description: rises in NE Brunswick County and flows NE approx. 5 mi. into Brunswick River.

label: Jackie Branch
description: rises in S Clay County and flows SE into Shooting Creek.

label: Jackies Mill Branch
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows SE into Cane River.

label: Jackrabbit Mountain
description: S Clay County. Now a peninsula in Chatuge Lake.

label: Jacks Bay
description: NE Carteret County on E side of Piney Island and adjacent to Long Bay.

label: Jacks Branch
description: rises in S Graham County and flows S into Tulula Creek.

label: Jacks Branch
description: rises in W Madison County and flows SW into French Broad River.

label: Jacks Creek
description: rises in W central Yancey County and flows NE into Toe River.

label: Jacks Creek Township
description: NE Yancey County.

label: Jacks Fork
description: rises in S Greene County and flows N into Tyson Marsh.

label: Jacks Knob
description: S Jackson County, is bordered on the E by Scotsman Creek. Alt. approx. 3,440.

label: Jacks Swamp
description: rises in N Northampton County and flows NE into Virginia, where it enters Fountains Creek. Appears on the map of the North Carolina-Virginia line run by William Byrd and others, 1728.

label: Jackson
description: community in SW Union County between Waxhaw Creek and Cane Creek. President Andrew Jackson was born nearby.

label: Jackson Branch
description: rises in central Cherokee County and flows SE into Colvard Creek.

label: Jackson Branch
description: rises in SE Mitchell County and flows S into Middle Ridge Branch.

label: Jackson Corner
description: community in N Pasquotank County.

label: Jackson County
description: was formed in 1851 from Haywood and Macon Counties. Located in the W section of the state, it is bounded by the states of South Carolina and Georgia and by Macon, Swain, Haywood, and Transylvania Counties. It was named for Andrew Jackson (1767-1845), president of the United States. Area 499 sq. mi. County seat: Sylva, with an elevation of 2,047 ft. Townships are Barkers Creek, Canada, Caney Fork, Cashiers, Cullowhee, Dillsboro, Greens Creek, Hamburg, Mountain, Qualla, River, Savannah, Scott Creek, Sylva, and Webster. Produces corn, dairy products, livestock, hogs, paper, fish, lumber, Christmas trees, textiles, mica, granite, olivine, and crushed stone.

label: Jackson Creek
description: community in W Randolph County.

label: Jackson Gap
description: on the McDowell-Mitchell county line.

label: Jackson Hamlet
description: a black community in S Moore County between towns of Aberdeen and Pinehurst. Est. about 1899 and named for James Jackson, an original resident.

label: Jackson Hill
description: community in S Davidson County. Said to have been named because an admirer of Andrew Jackson raised a flagstaff there to celebrate Jackson's election to the presidency, 1828. A post office as early as 1830.

label: Jackson Hill Township
description: S Davidson County.

label: Jackson Knob
description: on the McDowell-Mitchell county line. Alt. 3,223.

label: Jackson Line Mountain
description: extends SE from W central Swain County to Little Yalaka Creek in S part of the county.

label: Jackson Springs
description: town in SW Moore County on Jackson Creek. Inc. 1921; named for William Jackson, who settled nearby in 1754. The mineral spring, developed as a resort in the late nineteenth century, was patronized largely by wealthy cotton growers of North Carolina and South Carolina. The hotel there burned in 1932. Alt. 730.

label: Jackson Swamp
description: rises in E Robeson County and flows E into Big Swamp.

label: Jackson Town
description: was laid out in Rockingham County by Virginia promoters in 1818 on N side of Dan River at Eagle Falls. Failed to develop.

label: Jackson Township
description: SW Union County.

label: Jackson's Cornre
description: community in N Sampson County.

label: Jacksons Crossroads
description: community in central Duplin County.

label: Jacksons Pond
description: on Cypress Creek in E Franklin County. Formed 1885. Covers 65 acres; max. depth 20 ft.

label: Jacksons Store
description: crossroads community in central Lenoir County. Named for one Jackson, said to have been a Civil War veteran, who operated the store for many years prior to his death in the 1920s.

label: Jacksonville
description: town authorized in 1818 to be laid off on the lands of Hezekiah Naylor and Maccajah Lassiter in Randolph County "on the road from Fayetteville to Salisbury." The exact location is not known, and the town probably never developed.

label: Jacksonville Township
description: central Onslow County.

label: Jacob Branch
description: rises in W Robeson County and flows SE into Lumber River.

label: Jacob Creek
description: rises in E central Stanly County and flows SE into Pee Dee River.

label: Jacob Fork
description: rises in S Burke County and flows NE into Catawba County, where it joins Henry Fork in forming South Fork Catawba River. Named for Jacob Shuford, a pioneer settler.

label: Jacob Swamp
description: rises in central Robeson County and flows SE into Weatherspoon Cooling Pond. Approx. 7 mi. long.

label: Jacob's Gap
description: W Ashe County near the Tennessee state line. Named for an Indian youth said to have been killed by a white man.

label: Jacobs Creek
description: rises in central Rockingham County and flows NE into Dan River. "Danbury," the home of Governor Alexander Martin (1740-1807), was near its mouth. The Indian settlement Upper Saura Town was also nearby prior to 1710.

label: Jacobs Fork Township
description: SW Catawba County.

label: Jacobs Knob
description: E Macon County between Lickskillet Branch and Cullasaja River.

label: Jacobs Swamp
description: rises in S Nash County and flows SE into Tar River.

label: Jacocks
description: community in SE Perquimans County served by post office, 1894-1911.

label: Jacocks Landing
description: See Wellington.

label: Jady Branch
description: rises in W Gates County and flows SW into an unnamed swamp, which flows SE into Taylor Millpond.

label: Jake Branch
description: rises in W Swain County and flows S into Nantahala River.

label: Jake Cove Branch
description: rises in W Clay County and flows S into Fires Creek.

label: Jake Hollow
description: W Mitchell County on a tributary of Pigeonroost Creek.

label: Jake Ridge
description: SE Clay County between Jake Branch and Muskrat Branch.

label: Jalong
description: See Longhurst.

label: James Branch
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows NW into Cove Creek.

label: James Cathey's Creek
description: See Kerr Creek; Sloans Creek.

label: James City
description: community in central Craven County on Neuse River near its junction with Trent River approx. 1½ mi. S of city of New Bern. Alt. 10. Settled 1865. Named for Capt. Horace James, former Union chaplain, who supervised a freedmen's colony at the site.

label: James Creek
description: See Fiddler Creek.

label: James Iredell House
description: focal point of Historic Edenton State Historic Site, S Chowan County. Situated on approx. 2 acres. The Iredell house, built about 1759, is included in the area and open to the public as a historic house museum.

label: James Mill Creek
description: See Staffords Creek.

label: James-Town
description: See Jamesville.

label: Jameston
description: See Jamesville.

label: Jamestown
description: town in SW Guilford County. Settled 1752 and named for James Mendenhall, an early settler whose first name was chosen in Quaker fashion to avoid ostentation. Inc. 1816; rechartered 1947. Produces baked goods, corrugated boxes, and textiles. Home to Oakdale Cotton Mills, continuously operating since 1865. Alt. 779.

label: Jamestown Township
description: SW Guilford County.

label: Jamesville
description: town in E Martin County on Roanoke River. Est. 1785 as James Town; inc. 1832 as Jameston; name changed to Jamesville, 1855. Alt. 47.

label: Jamesville Township
description: NE Martin County.

label: Jane Cantrell Creek
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows NW into South Prong [Glady Fork].

label: Jane Knob
description: E Macon County between Brown Creek and Corbin Creek.

label: Jane Otter Branch
description: rises in NW Macon County and flows NW into Otter Creek.

label: Jane's Bald
description: on the Mitchell County, N.C.-Carter County, Tenn., line. Said to have been named for a woman who lost her life there in a snowstorm but who saved her young child by covering it with her own body.

label: Janeiro
description: community in S Pamlico County on Dawson Creek, which see. Known as Dawson Creek until a post office was est. (since discontinued). Named by seafaring men of the community for Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.

label: Japan
description: former community in NE Graham County on forks of Tobacco and Panther Creeks. Est. about 1908 as a supply center for surrounding lumbering camps. Named for "Japan clover" (Lespedeza striata) growing in the area. During World War II, local residents began calling it MacArthur for Gen. Douglas MacArthur, but the post office name was never changed. Inundated by waters of Fontana Lake, 1944.

label: Jarmantown
description: community in NW Onslow County between Hall Pocosin and the head of New River.

label: Jarrets Creek
description: See Jarrett Bay.

label: Jarrett Bald
description: W Macon County between Wine Spring Creek and High Laurel Branch.

label: Jarrett Bay
description: extends into the mainland of E Carteret County from Core Sound. It appears as Jarrets Creek on the Moseley map, 1733. Named for the Jarratt family.

label: Jarrett Creek
description: See Moore Creek.

label: Jarrett Hollow
description: N Mitchell County, through which an unnamed tributary of Right Fork Bean Creek flows.

label: Jarrett Knob
description: W Macon County between Moore Creek and Tyler Branch. Alt. approx. 4,500.

label: Jarrett's Gap
description: SW Macon County S of Moore Creek. Alt. 2,931.

label: Jarrett's Point
description: S Onslow County, extends into New River. Named for John Jarratt. Now within the limits of Camp Lejeune Marine Base.

label: Jarretts Creek
description: rises in SW Rutherford County and flows SW into Broad River.

label: Jarvins Mountain
description: SE Buncombe County near the Rutherford county line between Stone and Weedy Mountains.

label: Jarvis
description: community in SE Wilkes County served by post office, 1900-1914.

label: Jarvis Branch
description: rises in E Madison County and flows SE into California Creek.

label: Jarvis Channel
description: SE Currituck County in Currituck Sound.

label: Jarvis Mountain
description: E Madison County between Gabriels Creek and Sprinkle Branch.

label: Jarvisburg
description: community in SW Currituck County on North River. Settled prior to 1750. Named for the Jarvis family, of which Governor Thomas J. Jarvis was a member. Alt. 15.

label: Jason
description: town in SW Greene County. Inc. 1889, but long inactive in municipal affairs.

label: Jason Township
description: SW Greene County.

label: Jasper
description: community in central Craven County. Alt. 6. Settled about 1868. Named for local citizen James Spear.

label: Jasper's Creek
description: See Bell Bay.

label: Jasperfield Branch
description: rises in SW Madison County and flows NW into Spring Creek.

label: Jawbone Branch
description: rises in NW Burke County and flows S into Steels Creek.

label: Jaynes Cove
description: central Haywood County on a tributary of Jonathans Creek.

label: Jean Guite Creek
description: rises on the W side of the S end of the North Banks, NE Dare County, and flows N into Currituck Sound. Also known as Martins Point Creek.

label: Jefferson
description: a proposed town in what is now SW Cleveland County. A 1799 law, slightly changed in 1800, authorized the establishment of a town in S Rutherford County between the Broad River and South Carolina. A building for a warehouse and for the inspection of tobacco was to be erected there. Commissioners were authorized to purchase 50 acres of land and to lay out the town. As late as July 1803, the county court appointed a successor commissioner, but all plans for the town appear to have been abandoned when it was decided that the river could not be made navigable.

label: Jefferson Township
description: E central Guilford County.

label: Jeffersonville
description: community in Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1832-34.

label: Jeffreys
description: community in SE Granville County served by post office, 1899-1903.

label: Jenick Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NW into Graybeard Creek.

label: Jenkins Branch
description: rises in S Swain County and flows NW into Tuckasegee River.

label: Jenkins Cove
description: E Currituck County off the W side of Currituck Banks in Currituck Sound.

label: Jenkins Creek
description: is formed by junction of East Fork and West Fork in N Jackson County and flows SW into Soco Creek.

label: Jenkins Divide
description: N Jackson County between Big Witch Creek and Jenkins Creek.

label: Jenkins Swamp
description: rises in N Onslow County and flows S into Cowhorn Swamp.

label: Jenkins Trail Ridge
description: NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, extends S across the park boundary from Thunderhead Mountain to Pickens Gap.

label: Jenks Branch
description: rises in N Cherokee County at the foot of Jenks Knob and flows NE into Tipton Creek.

label: Jenks Knob
description: on the Cherokee County, N.C.-Monroe County, Tenn., line in the Unicoi Mountains.

label: Jenney Knob
description: W Jackson County between Little Savannah Creek and Savannah Creek.

label: Jennie Wolf Creek
description: See Schene Wolf Creek.

label: Jennie's Creek
description: rises in central Wake County and flows S into Neuse River.

label: Jennings
description: community in N Iredell County on Rocky Creek.

label: Jenny Branch
description: rises in W Swain County and flows SE into Tuckasegee River.

label: Jenny Lind
description: community in W Lenoir County. Named for the Swedish singer (1820-87), who, according to local legend, once sang beneath a tree there.

label: Jennys Gut
description: rises in central Perquimans County and flows N into Raccoon Creek.

label: Jepha
description: community in central Transylvania County served by post office, 1890-1901.

label: Jericho
description: former community in SE Wayne County on the N side of Neuse River from Seven Springs (then Whitehall). Destroyed by Union forces during the Battle of Whitehall on December 16, 1862. Site now included in the corporate limits of Seven Springs, which see.

label: Jericho Run
description: rises in E Lenoir County and flows NE into Stonyton Creek. The name appears in local records as early as the 1740s.

label: Jerome
description: See Micro.

label: Jerome Bog
description: a pocosin on the Bladen-Cumberland county line E of the community of Jerome. An almost perfect elliptical shape with its long axis running NW-SE, it is an ancient lake now filled with peat. See also Carolina Bays.

label: Jerry
description: See Levels.

label: Jerry Bald
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park at the NE end of Jerry Bald Ridge. Alt. 5,080.

label: Jerry Bald Ridge
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a spur extending SE from Andrews Bald on Forney Ridge between Mill Creek and Noland Creek.

label: Jerry Branch
description: rises in W Transylvania County and flows SW into West Fork French Broad River.

label: Jerry Creek
description: rises in W Avery County and flows E into Roaring River. Named for Jerry Hughes, an early settler.

label: Jerry Knob
description: central Haywood County between Jones Cove and Liner Cove.

label: Jerry Mountain
description: NE Caldwell County.

label: Jersey Settlement
description: former community on the E bank of Yadkin River near present Linwood, which see, in W Davidson County (formerly Rowan). So called because settlers in the 1750s arrived from New Jersey. A post office by the name existed as late as 1830.

label: Jerusalem
description: former community in S Davie County. In 1815 a union church was organized there, erected on land given by Nicholas Click, and named New Jerusalem. By the 1830s a community was growing up around the church; a post office est. in 1850 was called Jerusalem. Church still active (Baptist), but the community has ceased to exist as such. Alt. 787.

label: Jerusalem Township
description: S Davie County.

label: Jess Knob
description: N Buncombe County between Bald Knob and Jess Gap. Appears as Alexander Knob on state highway maps.

label: Jess Ridge
description: N Buncombe County, extends NW from Jess Gap.

label: Jessama
description: community in W central Beaufort County. More recently known as Midway.

label: Jesse
description: community in NE Person County served by post office, 1899-1904.

label: Jesse Branch
description: rises in SW Buncombe County near Rich Knob and flows NW into Beaverdam Creek.

label: Jesse Gap
description: N Buncombe County between Jess Ridge and Jess Knob.

label: Jesse Ridge
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, center near lat. 35°38'20" N., long. 83°06'50" W., between Little Davidson Creek and Mossy Branch.

label: Jesses High Top
description: peak in the Swannanoa Mountains of SE Buncombe County.

label: Jessie
description: community in S Cumberland County on Harrisons Creek.

label: Jessup
description: community in N Moore County.

label: Jester
description: community in NE Avery County.

label: Jesup
description: community in N Moore County served by post office, 1891-1934.

label: Jeter
description: community in NW Rutherford County on Cedar Creek.

label: Jewel Branch
description: rises in N central Alleghany County and flows SE into Little River.

label: Jewel Hill
description: See Marshall.

label: Jews Quarter Island
description: a peninsula approx. 2½ mi. long extending into the S waters of Currituck Sound from the mainland, SE Currituck County. Presently owned by the Chatham family and used as a hunting lodge. Appears as Deuces Quarters on early maps. Today known as Dews Island and operates as a hunting club.

label: Jim Branch
description: rises in SW Wake County and flows SW into Buckhorn Creek.

label: Jim Carroll Top
description: W Clay County, a peak of Carroll Mountain. Alt. 2,700.

label: Jim Creek
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows SE into Bald Mountain Creek.

label: Jim Ray Branch
description: rises in N central Yancey County and flows S into Little Crabtree Creek.

label: Jimes
description: community in central Davidson County served by post office, 1891-1903.

label: Jimmies Run
description: rises in NW Northampton County and flows S into Roanoke River.

label: Jimmy Branch
description: rises in N Buncombe County near Richland Mountain and flows W into Ox Creek.

label: Jimmy Gap
description: S Macon County between Bates Ridge and Hickory Knoll Creek.

label: Jims Beech Ridge
description: E Jackson County, between Bearwallow Creek and Chestnut Ridge Creek.

label: Jinnys Branch
description: community in SW Brunswick County.

label: Joanna Bald
description: on the Cherokee-Graham county line near the head of Anderson Branch. Alt. 4,708.

label: Joanna Mountain
description: E Transylvania County E of Little River between Grassy Creek and Briary Creek.

label: Joara
description: See Fort San Juan.

label: Jobs Cabin Township
description: W Wilkes County.

label: Jobs Peak
description: SE Buncombe County near the McDowell county line N of Evans Knob.

label: Jockey's Ridge
description: sand dune 80-100 ft. high a short distance N of Nags Head, Bodie Island, E Dare County. It is the highest coastal sand dune on the Atlantic or Gulf coasts. Apparently indicated by a symbol but not named on the Mouzon map, 1775; the name was in use by 1851. Designated state park 1973 and U.S. Natural Landmark 1975.

label: Joe
description: community in W Madison County on Meadow Fork. Alt. 2,649.

label: Joe Branch
description: rises in SW Beaufort County and flows NE into Chocowinity Creek.

label: Joe Cove
description: valley in central Clay County through which Perry Creek flows.

label: Joe Creek
description: rises in E Macon County and flows SW into Ellijay Creek.

label: Joe Knob
description: S Clay County on the SW end of Cherry Mountain.

label: Joe Mountain
description: N Jackson County between North Fork and Scott Creek.

label: Joe White Mountain
description: W Caldwell County. Named for Major White, Revolutionary War officer who lived on Johns River nearby.

label: Joe Young Ridge
description: S central Yancey County between Bowlens Creek and Bowlens Pyramid.

label: Joe's Fork
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows SE into N Caldwell County, where it enters Buffalo Creek.

label: Joel Branch
description: rises in N central Transylvania County and flows E into Davidson River.

label: Joel Cove
description: E Clay County between Fishprong Branch and Buck Creek.

label: Joel Jackson Pond
description: See Williams Lake.

label: Joel Ridge
description: NW Rutherford County, extends E from the head of Buffalo Creek.

label: Joes Branch
description: rises in S Vance County and flows SW into Ruin Creek.

label: Joes Creek
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows SE into Caldwell County.

label: Joes Creek
description: community in W Scotland County.

label: Joes Fork
description: rises in S Moore County and flows NE into Nicks Creek.

label: Joes Island Creek
description: rises in E Pasquotank County and flows E into Pasquotank River.

label: Joford
description: community in Duplin County served by post office, 1884-1902. A crossing point on Rockfish Creek.

label: John Anders Ridge
description: on Buncombe-Madison county line, extends SW from Moody Gap.

label: John Autrey Branch
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows N into Rock Creek.

label: John Branch
description: rises in SW Macon County and flows E into Little Indian Creek.

label: John Brown Branch
description: rises in central Jackson County and flows W into Tuckasegee River.

label: John Green Bend
description: a bend in the Hiwassee River in W Cherokee County.

label: John H. Kerr Reservoir
description: See Kerr Lake.

label: John Ish High Top
description: a peak in W Cherokee County in a bend of Hiwassee River.

label: John Mason Branch
description: rises in SE Cherokee County and flows NW into Little Brasstown Creek.

label: John Newton Branch
description: rises in central Cherokee County and flows S into Pace Branch.

label: John Reese Branch
description: rises in central Clay County and flows W and NW into Downing Creek.

label: John Rock
description: mountain in NW Transylvania County between Cat Gap and Davidson River. Alt. approx. 3,220.

label: John Rock Branch
description: rises in NW Transylvania County N of Cedar Rock Mountain and flows N on the W side of John Rock approx. 1 mi. into Cedar Rock Creek.

label: John Station
description: community in S Scotland County served by post office, 1886-1955.

label: John Taylor Branch
description: rises in W Madison County and flows E into Spring Creek.

label: John West Cove
description: in NE Cherokee County. Named for an early settler who lived in the cove.

label: Johnnies Creek
description: rises in W Transylvania County and flows SE into Tucker Creek.

label: Johns
description: community in SE Scotland County. Settled about 1875. Named for Capt. James T. John, owner of land on which the railroad station was built. Alt. 179.

label: Johns Branch
description: rises in SW Madison County and flows NW into Spring Creek.

label: Johns Camp Branch
description: rises in E Mitchell County and flows SE into Fall Creek.

label: Johns Cove
description: NW Swain County between Twentymile Creek and Twentymile Ridge.

label: Johns Creek
description: rises in central Jackson County and flows NW into Caney Fork.

label: Johns Knob
description: on the Graham County, N.C.-Monroe County, Tenn., line.

label: Johns Millpond
description: SE Scotland County on Leiths Creek. Formed 1840. Covers 150 acres; max. depth 15 ft.

label: Johns River
description: rises in N Caldwell County near the foot of Blowing Rock. Approx. 32 mi. long, it flows s, sw, and SE across W Caldwell and into N Burke County, where it enters Catawba River. Named for John Perkins, local black landowner.

label: Johns River Township
description: W Caldwell County.

label: Johns Swamp
description: rises in SE Bladen County and flows S into Colly Creek.

label: Johnson Branch
description: rises in E Wayne County and flows NE into Exum Mill Branch.

label: Johnson Cove
description: E central Yancey County between Bowlens Creek and George Fork. Said to have been named for a yodeler who walked through the region yodeling.

label: Johnson Creek
description: rises in S Vance County and flows SE into N Franklin County, where it enters Lynch Creek.

label: Johnson Drainage Ditch
description: rises S of Hendersonville in central Henderson County and flows NE into Bat Fork near its junction with Mud Creek.

label: Johnson Gap
description: near the NW end of the Henderson-Transylvania county line.

label: Johnson Knob
description: NW Henderson County on Laurel Mountain between Sassafras Gap and Rich Gap Mountain. Alt. 5,540.

label: Johnson Mill Creek
description: rises in N Clay County and flows SW into Tusquitee Creek.

label: Johnson Pond
description: See Watsons Pond.

label: Johnson Ridge
description: N Clay County between Evans and Julie Ridges. See also Matlock Bald.

label: Johnson's Branch
description: See Big Branch.

label: Johnsons Corner
description: community in NW Camden County. Named for Charlie Johnson, who operated a store there following the Civil War.

label: Johnsons Creek
description: rises in SE Lincoln County and flows S into NE Gaston County, where it enters Catawba River.

label: Johnsons Falls
description: on the Yadkin River at Donnoha, NE Forsyth County. Fall of about 4 ft. in ½ mi. A ledge of rock extends diagonally across the river, over which the water falls in a straight plunge for 2 ft.

label: Johnsons Island
description: NE Currituck County off Currituck Banks.

label: Johnsons Mill Creek
description: rises in W Henderson County and flows NW into Shaws Creek. Also known locally as Battle Creek.

label: Johnsons Mill Run
description: rises in N Pitt County in Grindle Pocosin and flows S into Tar River.

label: Johnsons Mills
description: community in S Pitt County. A post office was est. there in 1882.

label: Johnsons Pond
description: S Wake County on Terrible Creek.

label: Johnsonville
description: See Traphill.

label: Johnston
description: former county seat in S Onslow County on New River. Est. 1741; destroyed by a hurricane in September 1752 and abandoned. Named for Gabriel Johnston (1699-1752), governor of North Carolina, 1734-52.

label: Johnston County
description: was formed in 1746 from Craven County. Located in the E section of the state, it is bounded by Wilson, Wayne, Sampson, Cumberland, Harnett, Wake, and Nash Counties. It was named for Gabriel Johnston (1699-1752), governor of North Carolina, 1734-52. Area: 795 sq. mi. County seat: Smithfield, with an elevation of 155 ft. Townships are Banner, Bentonville, Beulah, Boon Hill, Clayton, Cleveland, Elevation, Ingrams, Meadow, Micro, O'Neals, Pine Level, Pleasant Grove, Selma, Smithfield, Wilders, and Wilson's Mills. Produces tobacco, corn, soybeans, wheat, oats, cotton, poultry, hogs, livestock, dairy products, sweet potatoes, turkeys, lumber, watermelons, furniture, chemicals, cottonseed oil, pharmaceuticals, wood products, heavy equipment, and crushed stone.

label: Johnston Court House
description: See Smithfield.

label: Johnston Swamp
description: rises in S Johnston County and flows NE into Stone Creek.

label: Johnstonville
description: former town est. 1788 in NE Randolph County as the county seat. Named for Governor Samuel Johnston (1733-1816), who was chief executive at the time. The town declined after 1796, when Asheboro was est. as the county seat in a more central location. The community of Brown's Crossroads is now at the site.

label: Johnstonville Township
description: SW Harnett County.

label: Johnstown
description: community in S Lincoln County on Indian Creek.

label: Jolly Branch
description: rises in SE Orange County about 2 mi. N of town of Carrboro and flows SW into Bolin Creek.

label: Jolly Gap
description: central Haywood County on the head of Dotson Branch.

label: Jolly Mountain
description: in SW Cleveland County on Broad River. Alt. approx. 925.

label: Jomeokee
description: See Pilot Mountain.

label: Jonas Creek
description: rises in N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows S into Forney Creek.

label: Jonas Ridge
description: community in NW Burke County.

label: Jonas Ridge Township
description: N Burke County.

label: Jonathan Creek
description: rises in NW Granville County and flows E into Goose Neck Creek.

label: Jonathan Crossroads
description: community in N Granville County.

label: Jonathans Creek
description: rises in W Haywood County and flows NE across the county into Pigeon River.

label: Jonathans Creek Township
description: W central Haywood County. Named for Jonathan McPeters, one of the first men of European descent to visit and settle in the area.

label: Jones
description: community in SE Beaufort County.

label: Jones Bay
description: NE Pamlico County in Pamlico Sound on the S side of Goose Creek Island. See also Hobucken.

label: Jones Branch
description: rises in SW Cleveland County and flows N into Broad River.

label: Jones Branch
description: rises in NW Watauga County and flows S into Little Beaverdam Creek.

label: Jones Chapel
description: community in S Rockingham County. Historically African American, it was founded by Samuel Jones, free black. Once known as Nubbin Ridge.

label: Jones County
description: was formed in 1778 from Craven County. Located in the E section of the state, it is bounded by Carteret, Craven, Duplin, Lenoir, and Onslow Counties. It was named for Willie Jones (1740-1801), Revolutionary leader, president of the Council of Safety, and later opponent of the adoption of the U.S. Constitution. The Lawson map, 1709, shows "Mr Jones 4000 Acres" at the location. The Moseley map, 1733, shows "Mr. Frederick Jones 7375 Acres." Area: 468 sq. mi. County seat: Trenton, with an elevation of 28 ft. Townships, now numbered 1 to 7, were formerly White Oak, Pollocksville, Trenton, Cypress Creek, Tuckahoe, Chinquapin, and Beaver Creek. Produces tobacco, corn, soybeans, hogs, livestock, peanuts, cotton, lumber, signs, marl, sand, and gravel.

label: Jones Cove
description: central Macon County at the head of Jacob Branch.

label: Jones Cove Creek
description: rises in central Buncombe County and flows SW through Jones Cove into Bull Creek.

label: Jones Creek
description: is formed in SE Anson County by the junction of North Fork Jones Creek and South Fork Jones Creek. It flows NE and S into Pee Dee River. During the Civil War, a gun factory was operated on the bank of the stream. Jones Creek was the name of a post office operated in the vicinity, 1882-1904.

label: Jones Creek
description: See Lick Fork.

label: Jones Gap
description: in the Blue Ridge Mountains on the Transylvania County, N.C.-Greenville County, S.C., line near Walker Creek.

label: Jones Island
description: See Pittmans Island.

label: Jones Knob
description: S Macon County at the head of Whiterock Branch. Alt. 4,600.

label: Jones Lake
description: central Bladen County, one of the Carolina Bays, which see. Covers 224 acres; max. depth 8.7 ft. It is part of Jones Lake State Park. Fishing, swimming, and boating. Known earlier as Woodwards Lake for Samuel Woodward, a local justice of the peace in 1734. Probably named for Isaac Jones, who later owned adjacent property.

label: Jones Lake State Park
description: central Bladen County 4 mi. N of Elizabethtown. Est. 1939 as first state park in North Carolina for blacks; integrated in 1960s. Includes 2,208 acres. A scenic and recreational area with provisions for picnicking, swimming, fishing, camping, boating, hiking, and nature study. See also Jones Lake; Salters Lake.

label: Jones Mill
description: See Page's Mill.

label: Jones Mine
description: community in E Davidson County served by post office, 1886-1905.

label: Jones Mountain
description: SW Buncombe County NE of Rockyface Mountain.

label: Jones Pond
description: SE Scotland County on Bridge Creek. Formed about 1810. Covers 75 acres; max. depth 8 ft.

label: Jones Store
description: community in S Lenoir County.

label: Jones Swamp
description: rises in W Sampson County and flows SW into South River.

label: Jones's Folly
description: See Jones Knob.

label: Jonesboro
description: former town in central Lee County a short distance SE of Sanford. The courthouse was equidistant from the two towns. Jonesboro was settled about 1869 and inc. 1873. Named for L. C. Jones, who built the railroad between Wilmington and Sanford. Merged with Sanford, 1947. The former town is now known as Jonesboro Heights in Sanford.

label: Jonesboro Township
description: former township in E central Lee County, now township no. 2.

label: Jonesborough
description: See Camden.

label: Jonesville
description: town in NW Yadkin County on the S side of Yadkin River. Est. about 1811 on the land of Richard Cunningham and Jesse Lester and named Martinsborough, probably for Governor Alexander Martin of nearby Stokes County, who died in 1807. Name changed to Jonesville for local citizen Hardy Jones in 1815. Inc. 1852. Merged with Arlington, 2001. Alt. 998.

label: Joplar
description: community in NW Mecklenburg County.

label: Joppa
description: community in N Perquimans and S Gates Counties.

label: Joppa Cemetery
description: burial ground W of Mocksville in Davie County. Graves of Squire and Sarah Boone, parents of Daniel Boone, are there.

label: Jordan Branch
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows NW into Fall Creek.

label: Jordan Creek
description: rises in central Granville County and flows SE into Coon Creek.

label: Jordan Island
description: in E Pasquotank County in Newbegun Creek near the community of Weeksville.

label: Jordan Lake
description: reservoir in Durham, Wake, and Chatham Counties. The 13,900-acre lake was created by the U.S. Corps of Engineers. Authorized 1963; construction began 1967. Name changed from New Hope Lake to B. Everett Jordan Dam and Lake in 1973 to honor former U.S. senator B. Everett Jordan. Built for recreation, water supply, and flood control.

label: Jordan River
description: See Cape Fear River.

label: Jordans
description: See Friendship.

label: Jordans Creek
description: rises in N Warren County and flows N into Sixpound Creek.

label: Jordans Landing
description: on Roanoke River, S Bertie County. The house on the Jordan plantation there is one of the oldest in the county.

label: Jordans Mill Pond
description: N Northampton County on Cypress Creek. Ivy Creek also flows into Jordans Mill Pond. Covers approx. 135 acres, with a max. depth of 12 ft. Named for an early owner.

label: Joshua Branch
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows NE into East Fork French Broad River.

label: Joshua Creek
description: rises in SE Lenoir County and flows SE into Jones County, where it enters Trent River. Probably the same tributary as Joshua Foy's Creek, which is mentioned in local records as early as 1763.

label: Joshua Foy's Creek
description: See Joshua Creek.

label: Joshua Lake
description: on Gerren Creek in S Transylvania County. Covers 60 acres and has a max. depth of 70 ft.

label: Joshua Mountain
description: S Transylvania County between the head of Joshua Branch and Middle Fork French Broad River. Alt. 3,163.

label: Jourghland
description: community in N Davidson County.

label: Joy
description: community in NW Burke County.

label: Joy Fork
description: See Joyce Creek.

label: Joyce Creek
description: rises in Dismal Swamp, N Camden County, and flows SE and SW into Pasquotank River. Though slightly misplaced, the tributary likely is the Joys Fork shown on the Moseley map, 1733, and as Joy Creek on the Price map, 1808.

label: Joyce Kilmer Memorial Forest
description: W Graham County in Nantahala National Forest, was dedicated to poet Joyce Kilmer (1886-1918), author of Trees and Other Poems, on July 30, 1936. It contains 3,840 acres of virgin forest (including poplar, hemlock, and oak) and is one of the finest stands of its type in America. Little Santeetlah Creek flows through the forest.

label: Joycetown
description: community in SE Caldwell County. An industrial center, it was named in 1947 by Regina Reid for Joyce Hogan, wife of James Hogan, owner of a manufacturing plant there.

label: Joyland
description: community in central Durham County on the outskirts of the city of Durham.

label: Joyner
description: community in W Wayne County.

label: Joyner's
description: former town in N Wilson County. Site approx. 1 mi. N of Elm City. Inc. 1870 on Wilmington and Weldon Railroad, now Seaboard Coast Line Railroad. Depot est. 1839; post office, 1846-73. Declined after establishment of Toisnot, now Elm City, which see.

label: Joynes
description: community in N Wilkes County on East Prong Roaring River.

label: Jubilee
description: community in W Davidson County.

label: Judaculla Mountain
description: N Jackson County between Balsam and Willits. Judaculla (or Jutaculla) was a giant in Indian legend.

label: Judaculla Ridge
description: E Jackson County between Beechfat Creek and Mull Creek.

label: Judaculla Rock
description: central Jackson County 3½ mi. SE of East Laport on Caney Fork. Large rock covered with well-preserved Indian picture writing of unknown origin and meaning.

label: Judd Mountain
description: W Wilkes County between Lewis Fork Creek and South Fork Reddies River. Named for the Judd family, which settled in the vicinity before 1778.

label: Judes Gap
description: on the Polk-Rutherford county line.

label: Judges Quarter
description: community in S Hyde County.

label: Judith
description: community in N central Union County.

label: Judith Island
description: peninsula on Bell Island in S Hyde County. See also Abigails Islands.

label: Judkins Township
description: E Warren County.

label: Judson
description: former community in W Swain County on Little Tennessee River. Alt. 1,563. Site now under the waters of Fontana Lake.

label: Judson Lake
description: S Transylvania County, drains N into Little River. Covers 8 acres and has a max. depth of 20 ft.

label: Judy Branch
description: rises in NW Swain County and flows S into Lake Cheoah.

label: Juford
description: community in SW Duplin County served by post office, 1884-1902. Formerly Rock Fish.

label: Jugtown
description: community in NW Moore County N of Bear Creek. Est. about 1920 by Jacques Busbee (1870-1947) and Juliana Busbee (1876-1962), artists from Raleigh. Manufactured hand-turned pottery, which has been widely distributed in the United States. Chriscoe, Cole, Craven, Luck, McNeill, Owen, and Teague families and others also worked in the vicinity.

label: Jugtown Branch
description: rises in SW Buncombe County near Jugtown and flows SE into Pole Creek.

label: Jule
description: community in N Forsyth County served by post office, 1899-1904.

label: Julian
description: community in S Guilford and N Randolph Counties. Alt. 772.

label: Julie Knob
description: N Clay County on Julie Ridge. Named for a slave formerly owned by Robert Henry, who built her a house at the foot of the mountain when she was freed.

label: Julie Ridge
description: N Clay County between Deadline and Johnson Ridges.

label: Julius Duggar's Rock House Creek
description: See Dugger Creek.

label: Julius Knob
description: N Yancey County on Cane Mountain near the head of Sampson Branch. Alt. 3,931.

label: Jumbo
description: community in E Caldwell County served by post office, 1889-1905.

label: Jump and Run Branch
description: rises in central Duplin County and flows SW into Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: Jump Cove
description: N Buncombe County E of Iron Ore Ridge.

label: Jump Off, The
description: See Mount Kephart.

label: Jump Run
description: a tidal inlet near the mouth of Middens Creek E of the community of Smyrna in E Carteret County.

label: Jump-up, The
description: peak on the Graham-Swain county line between Grassy Top and Swim Bald.

label: Jumping Branch
description: rises in N Transylvania County and flows SE into South Fork Mills River.

label: Jumping Creek
description: rises in E Jones County and flows S into Trent River.

label: Jumping Off Place
description: peak in NW Wilkes County W of Middle Fork Reddies River. It is the steepest portion of the Blue Ridge Mountains in the county.

label: Jumping Run
description: rises in NW Nash County and flows N into Tumbling Run.

label: Jumping Run
description: See Haw Creek.

label: Jumping Run Creek
description: is formed in W Harnett County by the confluence of Reedys Swamp and McLeod Creek, which see, and flows SE into N Cumberland County to enter Little River.

label: Jumping Swamp
description: rises in S Columbus County and flows NE and E into Grissett Swamp.

label: Jumpoff Gap
description: S central Yancey County between Bowlens Creek and Bowlens Pyramid.

label: Jumpoff Mountain
description: W Henderson County between the headwaters of Brightwater Branch and North Fork. Alt. approx. 3,150.

label: Jumpoff Rock
description: W Henderson County on Jumpoff Mountain. Used by Indians as a post for sentinels to observe the approach of enemies up French Broad River valley. During the 1920s a resort, the Fleetwood Hotel, was begun there but never completed.

label: Jumpup Ridge
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a spur extending SE from Bald Ridge between Bear Creek and Advalorem Branch.

label: Junaluska Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SW and NW into Valley River.

label: Junaluska Gap
description: on the Cherokee-Macon county line in the Snowbird Mountains N of Rich Knob. Alt. 3,506.

label: Junaluska Mountain
description: SW Haywood County, about 5 mi. SW of Lake Junaluska. Alt. 5,071. Named to honor Junaluska, Cherokee chief who saved Andrew Jackson's life at the Battle of Horseshoe Bend, 1812. Known for a time in the 1920s as North Eaglenest Mountain in connection with the promotion of a hotel there. See also Jones Knob.

label: Juneau
description: community in W Mecklenburg County.

label: Juney Whank Branch
description: rises in N Swain County and flows SE into Deep Creek.

label: Junietta
description: See East Fork Pigeon River.

label: Juniper
description: community in Cumberland County.

label: Juniper Bay
description: S Hyde County in Pamlico Sound E of Marsh Island. Appears as New Mattamuskeet Creek on the Moseley map, 1733. See also Cecils Harbor.

label: Juniper Branch
description: rises in S Pitt County and flows NE into Chicod Creek.

label: Juniper Branch
description: rises in S Wake County and flows S into Middle Creek.

label: Juniper Creek
description: rises in S Tyrrell County and flows NE into Northwest Fork [Alligator River].

label: Juniper Run
description: rises in SE Johnston County and flows SE into Mill Creek.

label: Juniper Swamp
description: rises in W Beaufort County and flows W to join Harding Swamp in forming East Branch Chicod Creek.

label: Juniper Swamp
description: rises in SW Onslow County and flows NW into Pender County, where it enters Shaking Creek.

label: Juno
description: community in central Buncombe County on Dix Creek.

label: Jupiter
description: town in NW Buncombe County. Inc. 1895, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Served by post office, 1885-1909.

label: Just
description: community in E Madison County on Terris Fork.

label: Justice
description: community in E Franklin County on Little Peachtree Creek. Alt. 261. Settled about 1873.

label: Justice Creek
description: rises in E Mitchell County and flows E into Avery County, where it enters North Toe River.

label: Justice Ridge
description: SW Buncombe County N of Candler Heights.

label: Jutts Creek
description: rises in SE Graham County and flows N into Tulula Creek. Named for Jutt Colvard.

label: Jutts Creek
description: community in SE Graham County.

label: Jutts Gap
