description: on the Cherokee-Graham county line in the Snowbird Mountains.

label: Kadar
description: community in S Wake County.

label: Kagle Branch
description: rises in W central Transylvania County and flows S into Catheys Creek.

label: Kagle Mountain
description: central Transylvania County between Catheys Creek and Kuykendall Creek. Alt. 3,908.

label: Kaiser Lake
description: S Transylvania County at the head of Morgan Mill Creek. Covers 2 acres and has a max. depth of 20 ft.

label: Kalamazoo
description: community in S Madison County.

label: Kalmia
description: community in SE Mitchell County. A post office operated there, 1937-54.

label: Kanady Creek
description: See Candy Creek.

label: Kanati Fork
description: rises in N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on the E slope of Nettle Creek Bald and flows NE into Beech Flats Prong.

label: Kannapolis
description: city in S Rowan and N Cabarrus Counties. Alt. 765. Until inc. in 1984, it was the seventeenth-largest unincorporated community in the United States and the largest in North Carolina. James William Cannon bought 600 acres there along the Southern Railway tracks in 1905; there he built houses and a mill, which began production in 1908. Cannon Mills, noted for manufacture of towels, was there. Since 2008 the site of North Carolina Research Campus, with focus on nutrition. The name comes from a form of the Cannon family name plus polis, the Greek word for city.

label: Kannapolis Township
description: former township in NW Cabarrus County, now township no. 4. Once named Cooks Cross Roads Township.

label: Kanuga Lake
description: central Henderson County on Little Mud Creek. Formed about 1908. Covers 12 acres; max. depth 20 ft. Summer camp owned by the Episcopal Church. Named for prehistoric Cherokee town Ka-nu-ga, on the West Fork of Pigeon River in Haywood County. The Indian name traditionally meant "Meeting Place of Many Peoples."

label: Kappa
description: community in W Davie County. In the 1870s known as Ketchie's Mill for a mill erected on Little Creek. Post office est. 1883 in the home of W. R. Ketchie, a Lutheran minister, who gave it the name Kappa, the Greek name for the letter K Davie Academy opened there about 1908, and the name Davie Academy is also sometimes still used for the community.

label: Kapps Mill
description: community in W Surry County served by post office, 1878-1929.

label: Karrs Branch
description: rises in SW Iredell County W of Troutman and flows SW into Hicks Creek.

label: Katalsta Ridge
description: NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a spur extending S from Eagle Rock. Named for a daughter of Yonaguska, noted as a pottery maker.

label: Kate Gap
description: on the Madison County, N.C.-Cocke County, Tenn., line.

label: Kate Knob
description: S Macon County between Pine Ridge and Jones Creek.

label: Katesville
description: community in central Franklin County. Settled 1888. Named for Kate Griffin, donor of the site. Alt. 300.

label: Katie Creek
description: rises in E Macon County and flows W into Walnut Creek.

label: Kawana
description: community in SE Avery County.

label: Kaylors Knob
description: SW Burke County.

label: Kayoo-lanta
description: See Chimneytop Mountain.

label: Kays Crossroads
description: community in SE Gates County.

label: Kayser Junction
description: community in W Cumberland County.

label: Kearney
description: community in N Franklin County. Alt. 300. Named in 1894 for Charlie B. Kearney.

label: Kearney Creek
description: rises in SE Craven County and flows E into Adams Creek.

label: Keasler Branch
description: rises in central Buncombe County near Craven Gap and flows SE into Bull Creek.

label: Keeauwee
description: an Indian village, appears on the Moseley map, 1733. Site was on the trading path of the Cherokee and Catawba Indians to Virginia on Deep River in present NW Randolph County. See also Caraway Creek.

label: Keel Creek
description: rises in SE Hertford County and flows S approx. 3 mi. to enter Chowan River at the NE corner of Bertie County.

label: Keelsville
description: See Congleton.

label: Keene
description: community in S Durham County about 3 mi. S of the city of Durham. Site of the yards of the Norfolk and Southern Railroad.

label: Keener
description: community in N Sampson County at the head of Beaverdam Swamp. A post office est. there in 1879 was named Bass.

label: Keener Creek
description: rises in central Cherokee County and flows SE into Marble Creek.

label: Keener Knob
description: E Macon County between the head of Crows Branch and Ledford Branch.

label: Keener Mountain
description: E Macon County between Long Branch and Brush Creek.

label: Keenerville
description: See Ingalls.

label: Keeters Store
description: community in central Halifax County.

label: Keeversville
description: See Plateau.

label: Keg Drive Branch
description: rises in N Swain County and flows SE into Left Fork [Deep Creek].

label: Keg Island
description: in the Cape Fear River, W New Hanover County SE of Campbell Island.

label: Kehukee
description: community in S Pasquotank County.

label: Kehukee Creek
description: See Kehukee Swamp.

label: Kehukee Swamp
description: rises in E Halifax County and flows SW into Roanoke River. Appears as Kehukee Creek on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Keith
description: community in W Pender County on Black River.

label: Keiths Bay
description: sand-filled bay in S Sampson County on the head of Keiths Swamp. See also Carolina Bays.

label: Keiths Swamp
description: rises in S Sampson County and flows SE into Black River.

label: Kelford
description: town in NW Bertie County. Settled 1890; inc. 1893. Built on the land of Col. S. A. Norfleet, whose home, Kelford, was named for a ford in Scotland. Alt. 88.

label: Keller Gap
description: on the Watauga County, N.C.-Johnson County, Tenn., line in the Stone Mountains.

label: Kellogs Fork
description: community in E Gates County.

label: Kellum
description: community in N Onslow County.

label: Kellumtown
description: a community of African Americans in SE Onslow County. Made up largely of people formerly living on land that became Camp Lejeune Marine Corps Air Station.

label: Kelly
description: community in central Moore County.

label: Kelly Cove
description: N Macon County on a tributary of Burningtown Creek.

label: Kelly Creek
description: rises in SE Henderson County 1½ mi. SW of Saluda and flows SE into Pacolet River. Lake Kelly, which see, is on Kelly Creek.

label: Kelly Mountain
description: S Transylvania County between Tower Creek and Cantrell Creek. Alt. approx. 2,980.

label: Kelly Ridge
description: N Macon County between Shope Cove and Kelly Cove.

label: Kellys Creek
description: rises in S Pender County and flows W into Rileys Creek.

label: Kellys Pond
description: on Southwest Creek in E Lenoir County. Formed in or prior to 1738 by a man named Marshall. Covers 312 acres; max. depth 10 ft.

label: Kellyville
description: community in SW Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1876-87.

label: Kelsey
description: community in NW Caldwell and SW Watauga Counties near Boone Fork 3 mi. W of Blowing Rock. Probably named for Samuel T. Kelsey, who operated a nursery nearby in the late nineteenth century. Also known as White's Spring.

label: Kelvin Grove
description: community in NW Wake County served by post office, 1840-1903.

label: Kelvyn Fork
description: rises in W Wake County and flows W into Brier Creek.

label: Kemps Mill
description: community in S Randolph County on Richland Creek.

label: Kems Branch
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows N into Allens Creek.

label: Kenady's Branch
description: See Candy Creek.

label: Kenan Ditch
description: a drain in S Duplin County to carry the waters of Kenan Pocosin into Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: Kenan Pocosin
description: a large swamp in S Duplin County that is drained by ditches into Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: Kenansville
description: town and county seat, central Duplin County. Authorized to be laid out 1816; inc. 1852. Alt. 127. Named for Gen. James Kenan (1740-1810), member of Provincial Congress and Revolutionary officer. Site once known as Grovemont. "Goldengrove," plantation of Congressman James Gillespie, was at or near the site of Kenansville before it was laid out. Earlier Duplin Court House was approx. 2½ mi. W of present town of Warsaw on the Duplin-Sampson county line. Site of Confederate arms factory, manufacturer of swords, sabers, and accoutrements.

label: Kenansville Township
description: central Duplin County.

label: Kendal
description: community in S Wilkes County served by post office, 1895-1914.

label: Kendall Beach
description: community on Neuse River in SW Pamlico County. Developed after World War I by a man named Kendall.

label: Kendrick Crossroad
description: community in SW Mecklenburg County.

label: Kendricks Creek
description: rises in East Dismal Swamp, central Washington County, and flows approx. 9 mi. N into Albemarle Sound. Formerly called Mackeys Creek. The part of Kendricks Creek that is S of the town of Roper is sometimes called Mill Creek locally.

label: Kenilworth
description: former town in central Buncombe County. Inc. 1891; became a part of Asheville, 1905.

label: Kenly
description: town in E Johnston County. Settled about 1875; inc. 1887. Named for J. I. Kenly, an official of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad. Alt. 220.

label: Kennebec
description: community in S Wake County. Named for a county in Maine.

label: Kennedy Creek
description: central Beaufort County. A short but rather wide stream at the W limit of Washington, N.C. It flows S into Pamlico River.

label: Kennedy Creek
description: rises in N Mecklenburg County and flows S into Sugar Creek.

label: Kennedy Crossroads
description: community in S Wayne County W of Mount Olive.

label: Kennedy Falls
description: community in NE Cherokee County.

label: Kennedy Ford
description: NE Union County in Rocky River.

label: Kennedy Top
description: NE Cherokee County near the headwaters of Kennedy Creek.

label: Kennekeet Banks
description: See Kinnakeet Banks.

label: Kenneth Branch
description: rises in S Wake County and flows SE into Neill Creek.

label: Kenneth Creek
description: rises in S Wake County and flows S into Harnett County, where it enters Neill Creek.

label: Kenricks Mounts
description: or sand dunes fixed by vegetation, are shown on the White map, 1590, somewhat S of the present community of Rodanthe on Hatteras Island, E Dare County. The dunes presumably were submerged with Cape Kenrick, which see.

label: Kent
description: community in NE Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1876-87.

label: Kenton Fork
description: See Kinton Forks.

label: Kentucky Creek
description: rises in central Avery County and flows S and W into North Toe River.

label: Keowee
description: See Cowee.

label: Kephart Prong
description: rises in N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on the E slope of Mount Kephart and flows SE to join Beech Flats Prong in forming Oconaluftee River. Named for Horace Kephart (1862-1931), author and authority on campcraft, who is buried in Bryson City.

label: Kerners Crossroads
description: See Kernersville.

label: Kerners Mill Creek
description: rises in E Forsyth County and flows W into Salem Lake.

label: Kernersville
description: town in E Forsyth County. Inc. 1871. Site first settled in 1756 by Caleb Story, an Irishman. It was purchased about 1770 by William Dobson and came to be known as Dobson's Crossroads; Washington had breakfast at Dobson's tavern on June 2, 1791. In 1871 Joseph Kerner bought the property, and the town that developed there took his name. Formerly Kerner's Crossroads. Former Southern Pilgrim College was located there. Produces hosiery, textiles, and fabricated metals.

label: Kernersville Township
description: E Forsyth County.

label: Kernersville Water Reservoir
description: on Kerners Mill Creek, E Forsyth County. Formed 1953. Covers 120 acres; max. depth 25 ft.

label: Kerr
description: community in S Sampson County. Settled about 1888. Named for John Daniel Kerr, who influenced the location of the Cape Fear & Yadkin Valley Railroad on the E side of the Cape Fear River. Alt. 91.

label: Kerr Creek
description: rises in W Rowan County and flows NE into Back Creek. Appears in early records as James Cathey's Creek, named about 1749 for an early settler. See also Millbridge.

label: Kerr Lake
description: was formed in 1952 with the completion of John H. Kerr Dam on Roanoke River in Virginia. Reservoir also fed by Dan River, Nutbush Creek, Island Creek, and many smaller tributaries, it extends into central Vance County, N Granville County, and NW Warren County. Normally it covers 48,900 acres and is 39 mi. long, with a shoreline of 800 mi. Max. depth 99 ft. Used for hydroelectric power generation, flood control, municipal water supply, irrigation, and recreation. Named for Congressman John H. Kerr (1873-1958). Initially known as Buggs Island Lake for an island in Roanoke River below the dam. The section of the reservoir extending into Vance County on Nutbush Creek is sometimes known as Townsville Lake. The official name is John H. Kerr Reservoir.

label: Kershaw
description: community in S Pamlico County between Greens and Kershaw Creeks.

label: Kershaw Creek
description: rises in SE Pamlico County and flows SE into Greens Creek.

label: Kesiah River
description: See Cashie River.

label: Ketchie's Mill
description: See Kappa.

label: Kettle Rock
description: SE Macon County between Big Dog Mountain and Chinquapin Mountain.

label: Kevin
description: community in central Mecklenburg County.

label: Key
description: community in SE Harnett County served by post office, 1888-1903.

label: Keyser
description: See Addor.

label: Kick Shin Creek
description: rises in central Surry County and flows E into Cody Creek.

label: Kidsville
description: community in E Lincoln County served by post office, 1882-1912.

label: Kies Mountain
description: S Randolph County.

label: Kiger
description: community in S Stokes County served by post office, 1890-1903.

label: Kilbart Slough
description: a short tidal creek in SW Brunswick County that joins the channel of the Intracoastal Waterway N of Hales Beach.

label: Kilby Branch
description: rises in N Wilkes County and flows S into Reddies River. Named for William Kilby, colonial settler.

label: Kilby Cove
description: S Cherokee County. An unnamed stream flowing through the cove forms the headwaters of the E fork of Cook Creek.

label: Kilby Creek
description: rises in SW Macon County and flows NE into Nantahala River.

label: Kilby Gap
description: SW Macon County on Kilby Creek.

label: Kildeer Mountain
description: W Cherokee County between Rocky Ford Creek and Shoal Creek.

label: Kilgo
description: community in NE Chatham County served by post office, 1898-1904.

label: Kilkenny
description: community in S Tyrrell County. See also Warbler.

label: Kilkenny Landing
description: S Tyrrell County on Alligator River.

label: Kill Devil Hill
description: large sand hill, E Dare County, appears first on Price map, 1808. It was from Kill Devil Hill in 1903 that the Wright Brothers made the first successful powered airplane flight. Site of 60-foot-tall monument honoring the achievement.

label: Kill Devil Hills
description: town on N Bodie Island, E Dare County. Inc. 1953. There are numerous legends concerning the origin of the name, but among the earliest was one recorded in 1728 by William Byrd of Virginia. He reported that rum consumed in that part of Carolina was shipped from New England and was of such strength that a saying arose: "That thar rum is powerful enough to kill the devil." Alt. 11.

label: Kill Devil Hills Coast Guard Station
description: on N Bodie Island in E Dare County. First est. as a life-saving station in 1878-79. Life-saving Service and Revenue Cutter Service joined to form U.S. Coast Guard in 1915.

label: Kill Quick
description: See Quick.

label: Kill Swamp
description: rises in N Sampson County and flows SW into Great Coharie Creek.

label: Kill'em Swamp
description: rises in SE Hertford County and flows NW into Chinkapin Creek.

label: Killets Creek
description: rises in central Moore County and flows N into McLendons Creek. Named for William Killet, who settled in the area about 1766.

label: Killian Branch
description: rises near Killian Knob in central Buncombe County and flows SE into Beaverdam Creek. Probably named for Daniel Killian, friend and host of Bishop Francis Asbury in his travels, 1803.

label: Killian Knob
description: W Haywood County between Mitchell Cove and Riddle Cove.

label: Killians Creek
description: rises in S Catawba County and flows S through E Lincoln County and into NE Gaston County, where it joins Leepers Creek in forming Dutchmans Creek. Appears as Killings Creek on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Killings Creek
description: See Killians Creek.

label: Killpecker Ridge
description: NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a spur extending SE from Jenkins Trail Ridge.

label: Killquick
description: See Lawrence.

label: Kilmer Memorial Forest
description: See Joyce Kilmer Memorial Forest.

label: Kimbolton
description: community in N Chatham County served by post office, 1859-1923.

label: Kimesville
description: community in W Alamance and E Guilford Counties. Settled about 1745; a mill there dates from about 1788. Named for the Keim (Kime) family, a pioneer German family in the area.

label: Kimsey Bald
description: on the Clay-Macon county line.

label: Kimsey Cove
description: W Macon County at the head of Gibby Branch.

label: Kimsey Creek
description: rises in SW Macon County and flows NE into Nantahala River.

label: Kimsey Gap
description: S Macon County between Allison Creek and Jones Creek.

label: Kimsey Ridge
description: S Clay County, extends NE in an arc from Sweetwater Gap to Sweetwater Creek.

label: Kinack
description: a name appearing on the Ogilby map, 1671, for the land now in Craven County between Upper Broad Creek and Swift Creek.

label: Kincaids Mill Creek
description: See Bristol's Mill Creek.

label: Kind
description: community in SW Madison County.

label: Kindrickers Mounts
description: See Kenricks Mounts.

label: King
description: community in SW Stokes County. Alt. 1,115. Originally known as King's Cabin for a double log cabin owned by Oscar King. The present name was adopted with the coming of the railroad.

label: King Blount's Town
description: See Ucohnerunt.

label: King Creek
description: rises in S Surry County and flows SE into Fisher River.

label: King Creek
description: rises in central Transylvania County and flows SE into French Broad River.

label: King Mountain
description: W central Transylvania County between Negro Prong and Catheys Creek.

label: King's Cabin
description: See King.

label: Kings Bluff
description: United States Lock Number 1 on Cape Fear River, SE Bladen County.

label: Kings Branch
description: rises in S Mecklenburg County and flows S into Sugar Creek. Appears as Kings River on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Kings Creek
description: rises in SE Cleveland County on Kings Mountain and flows SE into South Carolina, where it enters Broad River.

label: Kings Creek
description: community in E Caldwell County.

label: Kings Creek Township
description: NE Caldwell County.

label: Kings Crossroads
description: community in W Pitt County.

label: Kings Island
description: S Dare County in the waters of Pamlico Sound off Brooks Point, Hatteras Island.

label: Kings Mountain
description: N Jackson County between Tuckasegee River and Cope Creek.

label: Kings Mountain
description: city in SE Cleveland County. Inc. 1874. Alt. 995. Named for the mountain 7 mi. s. In 1923 East Kings Mountain, which see, became a part of Kings Mountain. Produces textiles, lumber, minerals, and hosiery.

label: Kings Mountain Township
description: former township in SE Cleveland County, now township no. 4.

label: Kings Point
description: peninsula extending from the mainland of NE Carteret County into Brett Bay.

label: Kings River
description: See Kings Branch.

label: Kingsboro
description: community in central Edgecombe County. Alt. 113.

label: Kingsdale
description: former town in SE Robeson County near the head of Mill Swamp Creek. Inc. 1907, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Site of huge sawmill operations that cleared virgin longleaf pine timber in the region; operations ceased about 1918, and the site was abandoned. Some mill foundations, machine parts, and railroad fill still visible.

label: Kingswood
description: community in SE Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1880-1903.

label: Kingville
description: former black community in N central Stanly County, now a part of the city of Albemarle. Named for Dr. O. D. King, on whose land it was founded in 1890.

label: Kingwood
description: community in SE Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1880-1903.

label: Kinley Mountain
description: S Macon County between High Holly and the North Carolina-Georgia state line.

label: Kinnakeet
description: See Avon.

label: Kinnakeet Banks
description: the name commonly given to the middle section of Hatteras Island in E Dare County extending S from Chicamacomico Banks to Hatteras Woods. Also spelled Kennekeet Banks.

label: Kinnekeet Township
description: E Dare County on the Outer Banks. Also spelled Kennekeet Township.

label: Kinnion
description: community in W Cumberland County served by post office, 1895-1907.

label: Kinsey
description: community in S Cherokee County on Nottely River. Alt. 1,609.

label: Kinston
description: city and county seat, E Lenoir County on Neuse River. Site granted to Robert Atkins in 1729 and came to be known as Atkins Bank. A chapel erected there about 1748, and a tobacco warehouse built about 1757. Est. 1762 as Kingston in honor of King George III. Renamed Kinston, 1784, after the American Revolution. Name changed to Caswell in honor of Governor Richard Caswell in 1833, but changed back to Kinston the following year. Lenoir County Community College, est. 1966, is there. Alt. 44.

label: Kinston Township
description: E central Lenoir County.

label: Kinton Forks
description: community in N Granville County.

label: Kip
description: community in central Rockingham County served by post office, 1900-1902.

label: Kipland
description: See Kipling.

label: Kipling
description: community in N central Harnett County. Known as Bradley's Store in late nineteenth century. Railroad timetable of 1907 lists it as Kipland.

label: Kirby
description: See Conway.

label: Kirby Branch
description: rises in NW Watauga County on the SE prong of Fork Ridge and flows approx. 1½ mi. SE into Cove Creek.

label: Kirby Grange
description: plantation of Christopher Gale, appointed in 1712 as the first chief justice of North Carolina; stood near Bath, central Beaufort County.

label: Kirby Knob
description: on the Jackson-Macon county line. Alt. 4,410.

label: Kirby Township
description: NE Northampton County.

label: Kirby's Gap
description: NW Caldwell County. Alt. 1,789.

label: Kirbys Creek
description: is formed by the junction of Rogers Swamp and Corduroy Swamp in N Northampton County. It flows SE and NE into Meherrin River, which forms the Northampton-Hertford county line.

label: Kirkendall Creek
description: See South Prong [Glady Fork].

label: Kirkland
description: community in NE New Hanover County.

label: Kirkland Creek
description: rises in W Swain County and flows SE into Fontana Lake.

label: Kirkland Gap
description: N Graham County between Yellow and Fax Creeks; the Appalachian Trail passes through the gap.

label: Kirklin Creek
description: rises in central Cherokee County and flows NW into Hiwassee River.

label: Kirkpatrick
description: former community in central Guilford County, now a part of the city of Greensboro.

label: Kirksey
description: community in SE McDowell County S of Marion near Rutherford county line at Cane Creek. Named for local family. Served by post office, 1895-1911.

label: Kit Creek
description: rises in W Wake County and flows NW into Chatham County, where it enters Northeast Creek.

label: Kit Swamp
description: rises in N Craven County and flows SW into Little Swift Creek.

label: Kitchen
description: community in N central Halifax County.

label: Kitchen Branch
description: rises in NE Buncombe County near Sourwood Gap and flows SW through Montreat into Flat Creek.

label: Kitchin
description: community in N Halifax County served by post office, 1893-1909.

label: Kitchin Branch
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows SE into Scott Creek.

label: Kits Knob
description: N Buncombe County NW of Jones Knob in the Elk Mountains.

label: Kitten Creek
description: rises in W Pitt County and flows NE into Otter Creek.

label: Kittrell
description: town in SW Vance County between Long Creek and Buffalo Creek. Alt. 372. Inc. 1885 and named for George Kittrell, who donated land for a railway station there. Confederate cemetery is there. Nearby Kittrell's Springs, which see, is said to have been the first summer resort in the state. Before the incorporation of the town, the community was known as Staunton. Served by post office since 1854. Kittrell College, est. 1886, was there. See also Epping Forest.

label: Kittrell Township
description: S Vance County.

label: Kittrell's Springs
description: health resort and social and recreational center in the nineteenth century. Served as Confederate hospital. Springs are ½ mi. W of the town of Kittrell, SW Vance County.

label: Kitty Fork
description: community in N central Sampson County near Great Coharie Creek.

label: Kitty Hawk
description: town and summer resort in E Dare County on the S boundary of the North Banks. Inc. 1981. Former site of the New Inlet. Settled before 1790. Name probably is a variation of an Indian place name, as it appears on maps as early as 1738 as Chickehauk. At nearby Kill Devil Hill, which see, in 1903, the Wright Brothers made the first successful powered airplane flight. Alt. 9.

label: Kitty Hawk Bay
description: NE Dare County at the E end of Albemarle Sound, which see. Bounded on the N by the S extremity of North Banks and on the S by Colington Island.

label: Klansoona
description: See Terrapin Mountain.

label: Klesee Creek
description: rises in NW Transylvania County and flows SW into Court House Creek.

label: Klondike
description: community in E Bladen County served by post office, 1898-1908.

label: Knap of Reeds
description: former community in SW Granville County dating from the nineteenth century or earlier. Served by post office, 1839-1905. The site is now within the Butner area. A Knap of Reeds District in 1790 had 77 heads of families at the time of the first census.

label: Knap of Reeds Creek
description: rises in W Granville County and flows S into Neuse River on the Granville-Durham county line.

label: Knee Branch
description: rises in S Hertford County and flows N into Ahoskie Swamp. Probably named for the cypress knees in the area.

label: Knightdale
description: town in E Wake County on the head of Poplar Creek. Chartered in 1927 and named for its founder, H. H. Knight. Alt. 318.

label: Knights Crossroads
description: community in E Wake County.

label: Knob Creek
description: rises in N Cleveland County and flows SW into First Broad River.

label: Knob Creek
description: rises in NW Rutherford County and flows SW into Broad River.

label: Knob Creek Township
description: former township in NE Cleveland County, now township no. 10.

label: Knobbs Creek
description: rises in E central Pasquotank County and flows SE into Pasquotank River at the N limits of Elizabeth City.

label: Knobcreek
description: community in N Cleveland County on Knob Creek.

label: Knobs Township
description: NW Yadkin County.

label: Knoll
description: community in SE Macon County served by post office, 1886-1905.

label: Knotts Island
description: a peninsula in N Currituck County approx. 5 by 3½ mi.; extends into North Carolina from Princess Anne County, Va. Knotts Island Channel on the E connects Currituck Sound with Back Bay (in Virginia); North Landing River on the W rises in Virginia and flows past Knott Island into Currituck Sound. Appears as Knot Isle on the Comberford map, 1657. Probably named for James Knott or a member of his family. Knott held land in S Virginia as early as 1642. See also Mackay Island.

label: Knotts Island Channel
description: a waterway between Knotts Island and Currituck Banks, NE Currituck County. The channel connects Currituck Sound in North Carolina with Back Bay in Virginia.

label: Knotts Store
description: community in W Anson County served by post office, 1877-1905.

label: Knottville
description: community in E central Wilkes County between Rock and Mulberry Creeks.

label: Knotty Pine Creek
description: See Buckland Mill Branch.

label: Knox
description: community in N Moore County served by post office, 1900-1905.

label: Kolasko
description: See Weatherman Bald.

label: Kona
description: community in W central Mitchell County near the junction of North Toe and South Toe Rivers. The name is said to have been coined by R. M. Lawson, first dispatcher for the railroad, simply because it was a short, easily spelled and understood word.

label: Konnatoga
description: See Little Pisgah Mountain.

label: Koonasoga
description: See Humpback Mountain.

label: Koonces Bay
description: on White Oak River, SW Carteret County between Wire Point and Balls Point. Named for the Koonce family.

label: Kornegay
description: community in E Duplin County.

label: Kossie
description: community in S Cleveland County served by post office, 1898-1902.

label: Kototine
description: See Little River.

label: Kross Keys
description: community in S Polk County. Settled about 1900. Named by Greenberry Sanders because of keylike intersection of roads at the site.

label: Krunkleton Knob
description: S Burke County. Alt. 2,600.

label: Ku-wa-hi
description: See Clingmans Dome.

label: Kuhns
description: community in W Carteret County. Named for William Kuhn, native of Germany and later a resident of the Stella community who engaged in lumbering along the White Oak River.

label: Kullaughee Valley
description: See Cullowhee.

label: Kure Beach
description: town in SE New Hanover County on the Atlantic Ocean. Inc. 1947. Named for the Kure family, which first settled there in 1867. Alt. 5.

label: Kurfees
description: See Jericho.

label: Kuykendall Branch
description: rises in N Buncombe County near the Madison county line and flows SW into French Broad River.

label: Kuykendall Creek
description: rises in W central Transylvania County and flows SE and SW into Catheys Creek.

label: Kyle
description: community in NW Macon County on White-oak Creek.

label: Kyles Creek
description: rises in N Henderson County and flows SE into Clear Creek.

label: Kyles Landing
description: community in NE Cumberland County served by post office, 1852-1902.

label: Laboratory
description: community in S central Lincoln County. Named for Confederate drug manufactory operated under the direction of Dr. A. S. Piggott. A part of the original laboratory still stands.

label: Lacey
description: community in E Rockingham County.

label: Lackey
description: community in E Alexander County.

label: Lackey Mountain
description: E Alexander County. Alt. 1,430.

label: Lacky Crossroads
description: community in central Cleveland County E of Lawndale.

label: Lacrosse
description: community in SE Guilford County served by post office, 1891-1904.

label: Lacys Creek
description: rises in NW Chatham County and flows NE into Rocky River.

label: Ladd Branch
description: rises in central Cherokee County and flows W into Parsons Branch.

label: Ladonia
description: community in NW Surry County on Fisher River.

label: Lagoon, The
description: S Buncombe County, is separated from the French Broad River by a narrow strip of land S of city of Asheville near the Biltmore Estate.

label: LaGrange
description: town in NW Lenoir County. Known as Rantersville and Moseley Hall prior to 1869, when it was inc. as LaGrange after Lafayette's estate near Paris. Moseley Hall had been the plantation name given by Thomas Moseley of Virginia, who settled there before the Revolution. William Dunn Moseley (1795-1863), first governor of the state of Florida, was born there. Produces trailers, tobacco trucks, and cotton gins. Alt. 113. See also Moseley County.

label: Lake Adger
description: in N central Polk County on Green River. Built by Blue Ridge Power Company in 1925 and known as Turners Lake for nearby Turners Shoals. Duke Power Company bought the hydroelectric plant and water rights in 1927 and later renamed the lake, likely for John B. Adger, who was active in power development on Broad River in South Carolina. Covers 438 acres, with a max. depth of 86 ft. Used to generate hydroelectric power.

label: Lake Ashnoca
description: central Buncombe County on Ragsdale Creek. The property of the Asheville School, it covers 27 acres.

label: Lake Bay
description: community in SE Moore County on Carrolls Branch. Formerly known as Hog Island.

label: Lake Benson
description: in S Wake County on Swift Creek. Formed in 1925 and named Rands Mill Pond for owners. Later renamed for B. B. Benson, former Raleigh city councilman. Covers 490 acres and has max. depth of 19 ft. Enlarged in 1951. Used as reservoir and for fishing.

label: Lake Brandt
description: an artificial lake in central Guilford County on Reedy Fork Creek. Max. depth 25 ft. Covers 400 acres. Formed in 1920 and named for former Greensboro mayor Leon J. Brandt (1874-1920). Municipal water supply for Greensboro and owned by the city.

label: Lake Burlington
description: central Alamance County on Stony Creek. Formed 1910; enlarged 1961. Source of water for the city of Burlington. Covers 750 acres; 7Â½ mi. long, with a 50 mi. shoreline. Fishing, boating. Known earlier as Stony Creek Lake.

label: Lake Charles
description: on Grassy Creek, SE Buncombe County.

label: Lake Cheoah
description: NW Graham and SW Swain Counties. Formed 1928 by Aluminum Company of America in damming Little Tennessee River. Covers 648 acres; max. depth 200 ft. Used for power, swimming, and boating. Alt. 1,276.

label: Lake Chub
description: See Loch Lily.

label: Lake Comfort
description: community on the S shore of Lake Mattamuskeet in central Hyde County.

label: Lake Craig
description: on Swannanoa River in central Buncombe County near the E boundary of Asheville. The Asheville Recreation Park is located near the dam. Named for Governor Locke Craig (1860-1925), whose home was nearby. The lake covers approx. 55 acres. Was a source of water for the city of Asheville prior to about 1903.

label: Lake Creek
description: flows SE from Black Lake into South River in E Bladen County.

label: Lake Creek Township
description: in E Bladen County.

label: Lake Devin
description: central Granville County on Hatcher's Run, was formed in 1954 as a source of water for the town of Oxford. Covers 100 acres; max. depth 40 ft. Named for former chief justice of the North Carolina Supreme Court, W. A. Devin, a resident of Oxford.

label: Lake Drain
description: flows E from Singletary Lake in E Bladen County into Colly Creek.

label: Lake Eden
description: on a tributary of North Fork [Swannanoa River], E Buncombe County at the former site of Black Mountain College.

label: Lake Emory
description: on Little Tennessee River in central Macon County. Covers 200 acres; max. depth 20 ft. Formed 1925. Used by Nantahala Power & Light Company to generate electricity.

label: Lake Fisher
description: NE Cabarrus County. Formed in 1946 by a dam on Cold Water Creek. Covers 277 acres; max. depth 30 ft. Named for L. A. Fisher, superintendent of Concord water and power department. Used for fishing and as a source of water for the city of Concord.

label: Lake Franklin
description: E Anson County SE of Lilesville. Covers approx. 5 acres; max. depth 25 ft. Formed in 1908 when gravel was removed from the site. Named for the owner of the property from which the gravel was dug.

label: Lake Gaston
description: was formed on Roanoke River about 8 mi. upstream from the city of Roanoke Rapids and extends along the Halifax-Northampton county line NW into NE Warren County and into Virginia. Gaston Dam, 3,600 ft. wide and 105 ft. high, was completed in 1963 by Virginia Electric and Power Company and lies on the upstream end of the Roanoke Rapids Lake. Lake Gaston is 34 mi. long, with max. width of 1.3 mi. Covers 20,300 acres, with a shoreline of 350 mi. and a max. depth of 97 ft. Used for generation of hydroelectric power and recreation.

label: Lake Gresham
description: in N central Wake County on Perry Creek. Formed in 1939. Covers 100 acres and has max. depth of 30 ft. Used for recreation.

label: Lake Hickory
description: on Catawba River, within Alexander and Caldwell Counties on the N and Burke and Catawba Counties on the s. Formed by a dam constructed in 1928 by Duke Power Co. Covers 4,110 acres. Source of hydroelectric power; fishing, boating, and swimming. Dam at the site of former Oxford Ford across the river; named for Samuel Oxford, pioneer settler who opened the ford. Alt. 829. Lake formerly known as Oxford Lake or Oxford Reservoir.

label: Lake Hunt
description: S Rockingham County. Built on N fork of Piney Creek in 1956. Covers approx. 175 acres. Named for George Hunt, mayor of Reidsville.

label: Lake James
description: on Catawba River, Burke and McDowell Counties. Formed when Bridgewater Dam was built, 1916-23, and formerly called Bridgewater Reservoir. Fed by North Fork [Catawba River], Linville River, and numerous smaller tributaries in addition to Catawba River. Owned by Duke Power Co. and named for James B. Duke (1856-1925). Covers 6,510 acres, with a shoreline of 150 mi. Used for recreation and generation of hydroelectric power.

label: Lake Johnson
description: in S central Wake County on Walnut Creek. Covers 160 acres and has max. depth of 18 ft. Owned by city of Raleigh. Used for fishing, boating, and municipal water supply.

label: Lake Juanita
description: See Lake Louise.

label: Lake Junaluska
description: community in central Haywood County on the lake. Methodist assembly grounds and resort area. The assembly was inc. in 1909 and the community site selected soon afterward. Alt. 2,584.

label: Lake Kawana
description: SE Avery County on Linville River. Two acres in area; max. depth 10 ft. Owned by Linville Resort and used for fishing, boating, swimming, and, sometimes in the winter, ice skating. Also known as Linville Lake.

label: Lake Kelly
description: water-supply reservoir in SE Henderson County for town of Saluda. Located at the head of Kelly Creek.

label: Lake Kenilworth
description: central Buncombe County in the city of Asheville. Approx. ½ mi. long.

label: Lake Landing
description: community in E Hyde County on the SE shore of Lake Mattamuskeet. The courthouse was there from about 1820 to 1836.

label: Lake Landing Township
description: E Hyde County.

label: Lake Lanier
description: in S Polk County, N.C., and NE Greenville County, S.C. Formed about 1916-18. Covers 127 acres, with a max. depth of 70 ft. Named for poet Sidney Lanier (1842-81), who spent his last years in Polk County. Water source for town of Tryon. Used for recreation and for commercial purposes.

label: Lake Lee
description: See Lake Monroe.

label: Lake Logan
description: S Haywood County on West Fork Pigeon River. Approx. 1½ mi. long and ¼ mi. wide. A water reservoir for Champion Paper and Fiber Company in Canton. Alt. 2,909.

label: Lake Louise
description: N Buncombe County in the town of Weaverville. Covers 6 acres; max. depth 50 ft. Fed by 5 underwater springs. Built before 1907 by Charles R. Moore and named Lake Juanita for Juanita Peace, a young girl who lived in the Moore home. At Moore's death, the property was given to Weaver College and later to the town of Weaverville, when the name was changed to Lake Louise in honor of Louise Moore, the donor.

label: Lake Lure
description: town in W Rutherford County on the lake of the same name. Est. 1925; inc. 1927. Alt. 1,050. The town has an immense corporate limit situating it on Buffalo Creek, Broad River, and Pool Creek.

label: Lake Mattamuskeet
description: central Hyde County, a natural lake covering approx. 30,000 acres. Alt. 3 ft. below sea level. Max. depth 5 ft. Discovered 1585 by Richard Grenville's exploring party. Appears as Paquippe on the White map, 1585, for an Indian word meaning shallow (or dry) lake; as Paquike Lake on the Comberford map, 1657; and as Mattamuskeet Lake on the Moseley map, 1733. Present name from an Indian word Mata-mackya-t-wi (it is a moving swamp; quaky bog). As early as 1789 efforts were made to drain the lake for farming purposes, and the most recent efforts at drainage came to an end in 1934. Now a federal wildlife refuge. See also Aramuskeet; Aromuskek Marshes; New Holland.

label: Lake Michael
description: W Orange County. Formed in 1953 as a municipal water supply for the town of Mebane. Covers 51 acres; max. depth 20 ft. Named for Arthur Michael, engineer for the town of Mebane at the time the lake was formed.

label: Lake Michie (mick-e)
description: reservoir for the city of Durham. About 4 mi. long on Flat River, NE Durham County.

label: Lake Mirl
description: E central Wake County on Hodges Creek. Formed in 1940. Covers 5 acres, with a max. depth of 10 ft. Open to the public for recreation.

label: Lake Monroe
description: central Union County S of Monroe. It is at the junction of Richardson and Little Richardson Creeks. Formed in 1925 and known first as Lake Lee for the owners. Later acquired by city of Monroe as a municipal water source. Covers 144 acres, with a max. depth of 35 ft.

label: Lake Norman
description: on the Catawba River in Catawba, Iredell, Mecklenburg, and Lincoln Counties. Formed by the dam at Cowan's Ford, completed 1963. Covers 32,510 acres. Shoreline approx. 520 mi. Hydroelectric plant of Duke Power Co. Named for Norman A. Cocke, retired president of the company. Alt. 760. See Duke Power Park.

label: Lake Palcoy
description: in central Haywood County near Lake Junaluska.

label: Lake Park
description: community in NW Union County. Inc. 1993.

label: Lake Phelps
description: natural freshwater lake in E Washington County and W Tyrrell County, the bed of which is thought to have been formed by the impact of a meteor. The lake surface covers 16,600 acres, with a max. depth of 12 ft.; mean alt. 10 ft. Owned by the state of North Carolina and included in Pettigrew State Park, which see. Said to have been named for Josiah Phelps, one of a group of explorers who discovered it in 1775. Known for a while as Scuppernong Lake and appears as such on the Collet map, 1770. Used for fishing, swimming, and boating.

label: Lake Point
description: point of land on the SW tip of Durant Island, central Dare County.

label: Lake Raleigh
description: in central Wake County on Walnut Creek. Formed in 1900. Covers 72 acres and has max. depth of 25 ft. Used for municipal water supply.

label: Lake Reidsville
description: in Rockingham County on Troublesome Creek. Built in 1972 to serve as part of Reidsville's water supply and for recreational activities such as fishing, waterskiing, and camping. Covers 750 acres.

label: Lake Rogers
description: See Creedmoor Lake.

label: Lake Run
description: flows S from Little Singletary Lake, NE Bladen County, into Ellis Creek.

label: Lake Santeetlah
description: See Santeetlah Lake.

label: Lake Sapphire
description: central Transylvania County on Allison Creek approx. 1½ mi. N of town of Brevard. Covers 3 acres, with a max. depth of 30 ft. Used for recreation. See also Sapphire Lake.

label: Lake Scuppernong
description: See Lake Phelps.

label: Lake Sequoyah
description: SE Macon County at the head of Cullasaja River. Formed about 1920. Covers approx. 150 acres, with a max. depth of 40 ft. Owned by the town of Highlands and used as a source of power and for swimming, fishing, boating, and skating. Named for Sequoyah (1770?-1843), Indian teacher.

label: Lake Summit
description: S Henderson County on Green River. Formed in 1920 as a source of power. Covers 350 acres, with a max. depth of 100 ft. A textile mill formerly operated there, and summer homes stand along the shores of the lake.

label: Lake Susan
description: NE Buncombe County. Formed by a dam on Flat Creek in Montreat.

label: Lake Tabor
description: S Columbus County. Formed by a dam on Grissett Swamp. Covers 8 acres, with a max. depth of 15 ft. Known as Spiveys Pond in the early twentieth century, when it was used to provide waterpower to operate a gristmill. The dam broke in 1950. The site was purchased by Tabor City, the dam was rebuilt, and the name was changed in 1955.

label: Lake Tahoma
description: W McDowell County on Buck Creek and Little Buck Creek. Formed about 1927 by J. Q. Gilkey of Marion. The name, an Indian word believed to mean "mountain lake of the gods," was suggested by Mary Hudgins of Marion. Covers approx. 500 acres; max. depth 30 to 40 ft. Owned by Lake Tahoma, Inc., a landholding corporation.

label: Lake Thorpe
description: an irregular-shaped reservoir in W Jackson County formed in 1941 by a dam on the West Fork of Tuckasegee River. Originally known as Glenville Lake for the nearby community; renamed in 1951 for J. E. S. Thorpe, former president of Nantahala Power and Light Company. Also known for a time as Thorpe Reservoir. Covers 1,462 acres, with a max. depth of 135 ft. Used to generate hydroelectric power and for recreation. Alt. 3,492.

label: Lake Tillery
description: on Pee Dee River in Montgomery and Stanly Counties. Formed in 1928. Covers 5,260 acres, with a shoreline of 104 mi. and a max. depth of 89 ft. Owned by Progress Energy and used for generating hydroelectric power, boating, swimming, and fishing. Originally named Norwood Lake for nearby town of Norwood. Renamed for former president of the company, Paul A. Tillery (1880-1933).

label: Lake Tomahawk
description: SE Buncombe County on Tomahawk Branch.

label: Lake Toxaway
description: resort community in W Transylvania County on Toxaway River. The original Toxaway Inn, built in 1901, became a popular resort for the wealthy. The lake, formed in 1903, covered 540 acres, with a shoreline of 15 mi. and a max depth of 50 ft. The dam was destroyed in the flood of 1916 but was rebuilt in 1961. The lake now covers 900 acres, the largest privately owned lake in W North Carolina, and is surrounded by homes. There is also a golf course and an airport in the community. The name is derived from the Cherokee word Tortzoo-whah (redbird).

label: Lake Trojan
description: S central Wake County on a tributary of Swift Creek. Formed about 1900 and called Yates Mill Pond for the owner of the mill. Name changed in the 1950s. Covers 20 acres, with a max. depth of 15 ft. Used as a source of power and for fishing and swimming. Mill open to the public.

label: Lake View
description: pond on Flatrock Creek in N Franklin County. Formed 1890. Known as Hunts Pond until 1931. Covers 10 acres; max. depth 12 ft.

label: Lake Waccamaw
description: town in N Columbus County on the N shore of Lake Waccamaw. Known as Flemington from as early as 1853 until about 1885, when the present name came into use. Inc. 1911. Alt. 62.

label: Lake Wheeler
description: S Wake County on Swift Creek. Formed in 1957. Covers 540 acres, with a max. depth of 30 ft. Named for Fred B. Wheeler, former mayor of Raleigh. Used as a recreation area and as a source of water for the city of Raleigh.

label: Lake William
description: on Little Rockfish Creek due W of city of Fayetteville in W Cumberland County near county line. Approx. ¾ mi. long.

label: Lake Witheranna
description: See Bull Hill Mill Pond.

label: Lake Wood
description: lake approx. 1 mi. long on Cross Creek, NW Cumberland County. Covers approx. 20 acres; max. depth 20 ft. Fishing and swimming.

label: Lake Worth
description: small community on the mainland of Dare County on the W shore of Stumpy Point Bay.

label: Lake Wylie
description: on the Catawba River in Gaston and Mecklenburg Counties, is formed by a dam constructed in South Carolina, 1924-26. Most of the lake, which covers 12,455 acres with a shoreline of 325 mi., is in South Carolina. Known as Catawba Lake until 1960, when it was renamed Lake Wylie for Dr. Walker Gill Wylie (1848-1923), friend and associate of James B. Duke. Site of Duke Power hydroelectric plant.

label: Lakefield
description: community in E Hoke County.

label: Lakers Creek
description: See Raccoon Creek.

label: Lakes Pocosin
description: a mucky slough in the SW corner of Craven County and extending into NW Carteret and E Jones Counties. Ellis Lake, Great Lake, Little Lake, and Long Lake in Craven County, and Catfish Lake in Jones and Craven Counties, are located in the pocosin.

label: Lakeview
description: community in E Moore County on Crystal Lake. Alt. 300.

label: Lakewood
description: See Tuxedo.

label: Lakey Creek
description: rises in N Macon County and flows SW into Little Tennessee River.

label: Lakey Gap
description: SE Buncombe County in Blue Ridge Mountains. Alt. 3,028.

label: Lakey Knob
description: SE Buncombe County between Lakey Gap and High Top.

label: Lamance Creek
description: rises in W central Transylvania County approx. 2 mi. S of the community of Balsam Grove and flows SE into North Fork French Broad River.

label: Lamance Creek Falls
description: on Lamance Creek in W central Transylvania County. Falls are 18 ft. high. Sometimes known as Lemon Creek Falls.

label: Lamar
description: community in E Ashe County served by post office, 1890-1912.

label: Lamb Branch
description: rises in E Cherokee County and flows SW into Peachtree Creek.

label: Lamb Creek
description: rises in central Transylvania County S of Shutin Ridge and flows E and then S into Allison Creek on W edge of community of Pisgah Forest.

label: Lamb Knob
description: W Madison County between East Fork Shut-in Creek and Stony Spur.

label: Lamb Mountain
description: S Macon County between Buck Creek and Cullasaja River. Alt. approx. 4,600.

label: Lambert
description: community in W Stanly County. Named for local family.

label: Lambert Branch
description: rises in E Swain County and flows SE into Oconaluftee River.

label: Lambert Cove
description: W Macon County on a tributary of Nantahala River.

label: Lambert Fork Creek
description: rises in NW Alexander County and flows SE into Lower Little River. Named for Alexander Lambert, early Scottish settler.

label: Lambert Point
description: peninsula extending from N Pamlico County into Bay River.

label: Lambeth
description: See Monticello.

label: Lambo Creek
description: rises in central Transylvania County and flows S into French Broad River.

label: Lambs Corner
description: community in W Camden County named for local family.

label: Lambsburg
description: community in N Surry County. Also known as Piper Gap.

label: Lamm's
description: community in N Wilson County S of Bloomery Swamp. Post office, 1895-1906. Named for Thomas Ruffin Lamm.

label: Lamm's Crossroads
description: community in W Wilson County S of Contentnea Creek. Named for Haywood Lamm.

label: Lamms Mill Pond
description: on Moccasin Creek on the Johnston-Nash county line. Approx. ½ mi. long. A mill operated there until about 1930.

label: Lamond's Old Field
description: See Candor.

label: Lamont
description: community in SE Guilford County served by post office, 1886-1907.

label: Lancaster
description: community in W Edgecombe County.

label: Lancaster Crossroads
description: community in W Nash County between Back Swamp and Peachtree Creek.

label: Lancaster Store
description: community in E Wayne County between The Slough and West Bear Creek.

label: Lance Creek
description: rises in SW Watauga County, flows S to Camp Yonahlosee, then flows in a NW arc into Watauga River. About 4 mi. long.

label: Lance Mountain
description: S Buncombe County E of Reynolds Gap.

label: Land of Eden
description: former 20,000-acre tract belonging to William Byrd (1674-1744) along the Dan River, N Rockingham County. Byrd surveyed area in 1728. Named because of its Garden of Eden qualities. An additional 6,000 acres were granted to Byrd's son in 1742. Purchased from the younger Byrd by the Farley family in 1755; by 1769 it had been divided into farms and plantations. The town of Eden, formed in 1967 by the merger of Leaksville, Spray, and Draper, took its name from Byrd's estate.

label: Landgrave Smith's Island
description: See Smith Island.

label: Landing Creek
description: See Gum Neck Creek.

label: Landing Ridge
description: a ridge of high ground in Big Pocosin, SW Gates County.

label: Landis
description: town in SW Rowan County. Inc. 1901. Named for Judge Kenesaw Mountain Landis (1866-1944), who imposed a $29 million fine on Standard Oil Company at the time the community was searching for a name. Landis Northeast is a community on the outskirts of the town.

label: Landrum Creek
description: rises in central Chatham County and flows SE into Rocky River.

label: Lands Creek
description: rises in N central Swain County and flows SW into Tuckasegee River.

label: Lane Pinnacle
description: N Buncombe County at the E end of Bull Mountain. Alt. 5,277. Named for the owner, Charles Lane, who, in the first quarter of the nineteenth century, operated an iron forge on Reems Creek. He obtained some of his ore from the mountain.

label: Lane River
description: See Alligator River.

label: Lane Swamp
description: rises in NE Nash County and flows SE into Swift Creek.

label: Lane's Creek
description: community in SE Union County.

label: Lane's Ferry
description: community in S central Pender County on Northeast Cape Fear River. The river is now bridged, but a ferry operated there for most of the nineteenth century and into the twentieth. Named for Levin Lane, landowner in the vicinity. See also Rocky Point.

label: Lanefield
description: community in W Duplin County.

label: Lanes Creek
description: rises in S Union County and flows E and NE into W Anson County and NE into Rocky River.

label: Lanes Creek Township
description: SE Union County.

label: Lanes Store
description: community in N Rutherford County on Cane Creek.

label: Lanesboro
description: community in W Anson County on Lanes Creek. A post office operated there, 1825-88. Now sometimes known as Old Lanesboro.

label: Lanesboro Township
description: W central Anson County.

label: Langdon
description: See Waddells.

label: Langford Branch
description: rises in W Yancey County and flows NW into Cane River.

label: Langs Mill Run
description: rises in E Wilson and S Edgecombe Counties and flows SE into Pitt County, where it enters Black Swamp.

label: Langston
description: community in E central Wayne County E of Stony Creek. Named for Langston family, which received land grants in the area as early as 1758.

label: Lanier
description: community in W Onslow County served by post office, 1884-1905.

label: Lanier Crossroads
description: community in SE Duplin County.

label: Lanier Swamp
description: rises in E Martin County and flows NW into Gardners Creek.

label: Laniers Creek
description: rises in W Randolph County and flows E into Uwharrie River.

label: Lankford Mountain
description: N Buncombe County W of Bill Cole Mountain.

label: Lanning Branch
description: rises near Lanning Ridge in NW Transylvania County and flows SW into Right Fork Davidson River.

label: Lanning Ridge
description: NW Transylvania County, extends S from Seniard Mountain.

label: Lansing
description: town in NW Ashe County. Inc. 1928. Produces electronics.

label: Lanvale
description: community NE Brunswick County.

label: Lapland
description: See Marshall.

label: Largo
description: former plantation in SW Warren County. The plantation house was built in 1790 by Hugh Johnson and subsequently sold to Peter R. Davis, an early Warrenton merchant (fl. 1800-1841).

label: Lark Knob
description: in NE Macon County between Beasley Creek and Mica City Creek.

label: Larler Creek
description: See Chadwick Creek.

label: Larry Brush Branch
description: rises in NW Macon County and flows SE into Cold Spring Creek.

label: Lash
description: See Walnut Cove.

label: Lashleys Island
description: See Baker Island.

label: Lasker
description: town in central Northampton County. Inc. 1895; named for Hezekiah Lasker, railroad conductor. Earlier known as Alto.

label: Lassiter
description: community in NE Wake County. Settled 1875. Named for its founder, C. J. Lassiter. Alt. 300.

label: Lassiter Branch
description: rises in W Gates County and flows NW into Somerton Creek.

label: Lassiter Mill Lake
description: artificial lake in SW Forsyth County on Blanket Creek. Formed in 1935. Built for a mill dam by Lassiter family. Covers 50 acres and has max. depth of 20 ft. Not open to the public.

label: Lassiter's Mills
description: See Lassiter.

label: Lassiters Creek
description: rises in N Nash County and flows S into Stony Creek.

label: Lassiters Crossroad
description: community in central Northampton County.

label: Lassiters Mill Pond
description: on Crabtree Creek in central Wake County within NW city limits of Raleigh. Present dam built in 1907-1908 by Mary Lassiter; pond named for her. A mill built on the site in 1778 by Isaac Hunter burned about 1823.

label: Lassiters Mills
description: community and former post office, SE Randolph County on Uwharrie River. Mill built in 1845 on the W side of the river was moved to the E side in 1925.

label: Latham
description: See Latham's.

label: Latham Creek
description: rises in NW Beaufort County and flows SE into Old Ford Swamp.

label: Latham's
description: community in NW Beaufort County served by post office, 1872-1909. Known as Latham after 1894.

label: Lattimore
description: town in W Cleveland County. Settled in 1880; a post office named Delight was est. there in 1886. Inc. 1899 as Lattimore, named for Audley M. Lattimore, Confederate veteran and first postmaster. Alt. 945.

label: Lauada
description: community in S Swain County on Pole Bridge Branch.

label: Laudermilk Bend
description: a bend in Nottely River, S Cherokee County above Cobb Bluff.

label: Laughlins Creek
description: rises in S Caswell County and flows SE into Alamance County, where it enters Buttermilk Creek.

label: Laughter Cove
description: SE Buncombe County between Spring and Garren Mountains. Named for a family of notorious moonshiners who lived in the cove in the first half of the twentieth century.

label: Laughton Point
description: extends from the mainland of central Carteret County into Newport River.

label: Launch, The
description: a narrow inlet between Tull Bay and the mouth of North Landing River in NE Currituck County. Appears on the Collet map, 1770. Site of shipbuilding operations from colonial times until the present, hence the name.

label: Laurel
description: community in N Madison County on Big Laurel Creek.

label: Laurel Bottoms
description: valley in SE Avery County along the Linville River N of the town of Linville.

label: Laurel Branch
description: rises in NE Buncombe County in the Great Craggy Mountains and flows SE into North Fork [Swannanoa River].

label: Laurel Branch
description: rises in S Haywood County E of Cold Spring Knob and flows E into West Fork Pigeon River 1½ mi. S of Lake Logan dam.

label: Laurel Branch
description: rises in W central Swain County and flows NE into Tuckasegee River.

label: Laurel Branch
description: rises in SW Yancey County and flows E into Cane River.

label: Laurel Brook
description: rises in N Transylvania County and flows SE into South Fork Mills River.

label: Laurel Creek
description: rises in NW Ashe County and flows SE into North Fork New River.

label: Laurel Creek
description: rises in SW Transylvania County and flows S into Whitewater River.

label: Laurel Creek
description: rises in W Watauga County and flows NE into Watauga River.

label: Laurel Creek Falls
description: in W Watauga County on Laurel Creek just before its confluence with Watauga River.

label: Laurel Creek Township
description: W Watauga County.

label: Laurel Fork
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows NE and SE into Elk Creek.

label: Laurel Fork Creek
description: rises in S Henderson County and flows NE into Green River.

label: Laurel Fork [Davidson River]
description: rises in W Transylvania County and flows E into Davidson River.

label: Laurel Gap
description: in N Transylvania County between Rich Mountain and Poundingstone Mountain.

label: Laurel Gap Branch
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows SW into Balsam Corner Creek.

label: Laurel Hill
description: community in W Scotland County. Named for Presbyterian church est. there, 1793, and in turn named for laurel growing on the elevated site. A post office est. there, 1807. Alt. 250.

label: Laurel Hill Township
description: W central Scotland County.

label: Laurel Hills
description: rugged terrain S of Chapel Hill, SE Orange County.

label: Laurel Knob
description: S Jackson County between Hurricane Creek and Hurricane Lake. Alt. 4,014.

label: Laurel Lake
description: SE Buncombe County near Black Mountain.

label: Laurel Mountain
description: SE Yancey County near the head of Roaring Fork.

label: Laurel Park
description: town in central Henderson County adjoining Hendersonville on the latter's SW line. Inc. 1925.

label: Laurel Patch Bald
description: on Jackson-Haywood county line. Alt. 5,560-5,580.

label: Laurel Point
description: extends from W Dare County N of Mill Tail Creek into Alligator River.

label: Laurel Point
description: extends from NE Washington County into Albemarle Sound.

label: Laurel Ridge
description: S Yancey County between Elk Fork and Cane River.

label: Laurel River
description: rises in central Carteret County and flows E into Merrimon River.

label: Laurel Springs
description: community in SW Alleghany County. Settled about 1859 and named for a spring flowing from laurel-covered rocks. Alt. 2,822.

label: Laurel Spur
description: on the Watauga-Wilkes county line E of Stony Fork Creek.

label: Laurel Top
description: peak on Swain County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near the head of Gulf Prong. Alt. 5,900-5,950.

label: Laurel Township
description: W central Ashe County.

label: Laurelton
description: community in N Madison County on Foster Creek.

label: Laurenceville
description: See Lawrenceville.

label: Laurinburg
description: city and county seat, S Scotland County. Appears on maps as early as 1865. Inc. 1877 as Laurenburg; charter amended 1883 and name spelled Laurinburg. Named for McLaurin family, early Scottish settlers. Alt. 227. St. Andrews Presbyterian College, est. 1961, is there.

label: Lawhon
description: community in central Moore County served by post office, 1892-1905.

label: Lawndale
description: town in central Cleveland County on First Broad River. Alt. 843. Settled 1870; inc. 1903. Named for spreading green lawns of Maj. H. F. Schenck, owner of local mills, est. in 1888, and local power company.

label: Lawrence
description: town in NE Edgecombe County. Known as Killquick as early as 1837, the name by which it was chartered in 1883. Laid off in an area ½ mi. square from Richard H. Gatlin's "big new store." Name changed to Hickory Hill in 1885 and to Lawrence in 1889. Original Killquick charter repealed in 1893; chartered as Lawrence in 1901, but long in active in municipal affairs.

label: Lawrence Run
description: rises in W Pitt County and flows NW into Tyson Creek.

label: Lawrenceville
description: former town in W Montgomery County on Pee Dee River. Authorized to be laid out as the county seat, 1815; named Laurenceville, 1816. Post office operated as Lawrenceville from 1818 to 1850. After Stanly County was formed from Montgomery County in 1841, Lawrenceville was no longer in the center of the county and was soon replaced as the county seat by Troy. By 1860 it was no longer being shown on maps of the state. The site is now abandoned.

label: Laws
description: community in N Orange and S Person Counties. Formerly known as Laws Store.

label: Laws Store
description: See Laws.

label: Lawson Creek
description: rises in central Craven County and flows NE into Trent River.

label: Lawson Gant Lot
description: bald spot on Swain County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line near lat. 35°32'45" N., long. 83°47'38" W.

label: Lawson Gant Lot Branch
description: rises in NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows SE into Tub-Mill Creek.

label: Lawsonville
description: community in N Stokes County. Alt. 1,179.

label: Lawyers
description: See Alexander's Store.

label: Lawyers Springs
description: W Anson County on a tributary of Brown Creek. So named because lawyers on the way to court used to stop there. Local tradition says a party of lawyers, spending the night there, froze to death on a snowy winter night.

label: Laxon
description: community in E Watauga County.

label: Laxon Creek
description: rises in E Watauga County and flows NW into South Fork New River.

label: Layn Flu
description: See Alligator River.

label: Layton
description: community in central Rockingham County served by post office, 1892-1903.

label: Laytown
description: community in NE Caldwell County. Named for Thomas Lay, eighteenth-century settler.

label: Laytown Creek
description: rises in N Caldwell County and flows SE into Yadkin River. Originally called Linville's Mill Creek.

label: Leachburg
description: community in N Johnston County served by post office, 1854-1903. Spelled Leechburg until 1876.

label: Leaches Island
description: See Hog Island.

label: Lead
description: community in S Henderson County on Green River.

label: Lead Mine Ridge
description: W Madison County between Doe Branch and Rocky Branch.

label: Leading Ridge
description: N Mitchell County between Shepherd Knob and Big Rock Creek.

label: Leaflet
description: community in W Harnett County near Upper Little River.

label: Leak Creek
description: rises in N Davidson County and flows NW into S Forsyth County, where it enters South Fork.

label: Leaksville
description: former town in N Rockingham County on Dan and Smith Rivers. Alt. 700. Inc. 1874. Named for Revolutionary War veteran John Leak, who owned a plantation there before 1797. A post office est. there in 1817. In 1793 the General Assembly directed that a town to be named Danville be laid out at the site as a tobacco inspection station; in 1797 commissioners were appointed "to build and improve the Town of Leaksville in accordance with the plan drawn up by Abraham Philips." Philips had been a member of the commission appointed in 1793 to lay out the town of Danville. In 1967 Leaksville was merged with Draper and Spray, which see, to form the town of Eden, which see.

label: Leaksville Township
description: N Rockingham County.

label: Leaman
description: community in N Moore County on Bear Creek.

label: Leander
description: community in NW Watauga County on Beaverdam Creek.

label: Leaper's Creek
description: See Leepers Creek.

label: Leasburg
description: town in E Caswell County. Est. 1788, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Named for William and James Lea, who owned part of the original site. Location of Caswell County courthouse from 1777 until 1791, when it was moved to the center of the county after Person County was formed from Caswell. Alt. 750.

label: Leasburg Township
description: E central Caswell County.

label: Leatherman
description: community on Shepherd Creek in N Macon County.

label: Leatherman Gap
description: on Macon-Swain county line between Leatherman Knob and Raven Mountain. Alt. 4,300.

label: Leatherman Knob
description: on Macon-Swain county line between Leatherman Gap and Shepherd Bald.

label: Leatherman Mountain
description: on the Macon-Swain county line.

label: Leathermans Fork
description: rises in W Mitchell County and flows SW into Right Fork [Pigeon-roost Creek].

label: Leatherwood Branch
description: rises in N Haywood County and flows E into Big Creek.

label: Leatherwood Cove
description: central Haywood County just N of Lake Junaluska.

label: Leatherwood Mountain
description: NE Cherokee County S of Andrews.

label: Leatherwood Top
description: in W Haywood County between Walker Bald and Tritt Knob. Alt. 5,000-5,020.

label: Leaventhorps View
description: See Shumont Mountain.

label: Lebanon Township
description: central Durham County.

label: Ledbetter
description: community in central Richmond County. Named for the family that est. a mill on Hitchcock Creek there about 1895.

label: Ledbetter Branch
description: rises in NE Macon County on the slope of Tellico Ridge and flows N into Swain County, where it enters Little Tennessee River.

label: Ledbetter Creek
description: rises in SW Swain County on Cheoah Bald in Nantahala National Forest and flows S into Nantahala River.

label: Ledbetter Lake
description: central Richmond County on Hitchcock Creek at the community of Ledbetter, which see. Covers 800 acres.

label: Ledford
description: See Nantahala.

label: Ledford Branch
description: rises in E Macon County and flows SE into Walnut Creek.

label: Ledford Creek
description: See Left Fork [Eagle Creek].

label: Ledford Gap
description: S Clay County near the headwaters of Hothouse Branch.

label: Ledge Bald
description: on Haywood-Swain county line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Balsam Mountain near lat. 35°38'35" N., long. 83°12'05" W. Alt. 5,175.

label: Ledge Creek
description: rises in NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows SW into Straight Fork [Raven Fork].

label: Ledge Gap
description: on Haywood-Swain county line between Beech Gap and Pin Oak Gap.

label: Ledge of Rocks Creek
description: See Ledge Creek.

label: Ledger
description: community in central Mitchell County on Snow Creek. Said to have been named by the Post Office Department because of a report submitted in a ledger by a local resident named Phillips. His record of mail sent and received in the community through another post office resulted in the establishment of a post office there. The "Good Will" Free Library, opened in Ledger in 1886 through the efforts of Charles Hallet Wing, is said to have been the first free public library in the state and the third county library in the United States. See also Wing.

label: Lee Branch
description: rises in W Macon County and flows SW into Nantahala Lake.

label: Lee County
description: was formed in 1907 from Moore and Chatham Counties. Located in the central section of the state, it is bounded by Harnett, Moore, and Chatham Counties. It was named for Gen. Robert E. Lee (1807-70). Area: 256 sq. mi. County seat: Sanford, with an elevation of 375 ft. Townships, now numbered 1 to 7, were formerly Greenwood, Jonesboro, Cape Fear, Deep River, East Sanford, West Sanford, and Pocket. Produces tobacco, corn, wheat, oats, strawberries, dairy products, hogs, bricks, lumber, textiles, heavy equipment, electronics, sheet metal, apparel, industrial machinery, furniture, sand, and gravel.

label: Lee Creek
description: rises in S Macon County and flows E into Jones Creek.

label: Lee Mountain
description: E Haywood County, extends NE between Bald Creek and Liner Creek.

label: Lee Swamp
description: rises in SW Wilson County and flows SE in an arc into Black Creek. Named for local family.

label: Leechburg
description: See Leachburg.

label: Leechville
description: town in E Beaufort County on Pungo River. Inc. 1834 and name changed from Lumberton. Reincorporated 1899, but long inactive in municipal affairs.

label: Leepers Creek
description: is formed by the junction of Sawmill and Lippard Creeks in NE Lincoln County. It flows SE into Gaston County, where it joins Killians Creek in forming Dutchmans Creek. Appears as Leapers Creek on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Lees Branch
description: rises in W Warren County and flows SE and SW into Shocco Creek.

label: Lees Creek
description: rises in SE Beaufort County and flows NW into Pamlico River. Appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Lees Creek
description: rises in NW Northampton County and flows SW into Roanoke River.

label: Lees Landing
description: on Upper Broad Creek in W Pamlico County.

label: Lees Millpond
description: E Scotland County on Big Shoeheel Creek. Covers 50 acres; max. depth 18 ft.

label: Lees Mills
description: See Roper.

label: Lees Mills Township
description: central Washington County, was formed in 1868 but was a voting precinct before that time.

label: Lees Point
description: extends from W Carteret County into White Oak River.

label: Lees Township
description: SE Columbus County.

label: Leesburg
description: See Willard.

label: Leesville
description: community in NW Wake County on head of Lower Bartons Creek. Named for John Lee, who first settled there about 1800. Alt. 300.

label: Leesville Township
description: NW Wake County.

label: Left Fork
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows SE into Beetree Reservoir.

label: Left Fork Bean Creek
description: rises in N Mitchell County and flows SE to join Right Fork Bean Creek in forming Bean Creek.

label: Left Fork Belews Creek
description: See West Belews Creek.

label: Left Fork Webb Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County near Moody Stamp and flows SE to join Right Fork Webb Creek in forming Webb Creek.

label: Left Fork [Cane Creek]
description: rises in E Mitchell County and flows SW to join Right Fork [Cane Creek] in forming Cane Creek.

label: Left Fork [Deep Creek]
description: rises in N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows SE into Deep Creek.

label: Left Fork [Eagle Creek]
description: rises in SE Clay County and flows SW to join Right Fork in forming Eagle Creek. Known also as Ledford Creek.

label: Left Fork [Indian Creek]
description: rises in N Swain County and flows SW into Right Fork [Indian Creek] to form Indian Creek.

label: Left Fork [Raven Fork]
description: rises in NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows S to join Right Fork and Middle Fork in forming Raven Fork [Oconaluftee River].

label: Left Fork [Redman Creek]
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows SW to join Right Fork [Redman Creek] in forming Redman Creek.

label: Left Fork [Swannanoa River]
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows E into North Fork [Swannanoa River]. Often known locally as Left Hand Fork.

label: Left Hand Fork
description: See Left Fork [Swannanoa River].

label: Left Prong Bent Creek
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows SE to join Right Prong Bent Creek in forming Bent Creek.

label: Left Prong South Toe River
description: has its origin at Pinnacle Spring, S Yancey County, and flows E to join Right Prong South Toe River in forming South Toe River.

label: Left Prong Three Forks Creek
description: rises in SE Yancey County and flows SW to join Right Prong in forming Three Forks Creek.

label: Left Prong [Bridge Creek]
description: rises in N central Swain County and flows NE into Bridge Creek.

label: Legal
description: community in central Harnett County served by post office, 1894-1908.

label: Legerwood
description: community in N central Caldwell County. Named for Samuel Legerwood Patterson (1850-1908), onetime state commissioner of agriculture, who donated his plantation, "Palmyra," for a farm school for boys there.

label: Leggett
description: town in N Edgecombe County inc. 1895 and reincorporated 1925 but not now active in municipal affairs. Post office name was Leggettsville, 1886-1913.

label: Leggetts Crossroads
description: community in NW Beaufort County.

label: Leggettsville
description: See Leggett.

label: Legion Beach
description: a recreation and picnic area on Albemarle Sound in N Tyrrell County 3 mi. E of Columbia. Owned by local American Legion Post. Boating, bathing, and fishing.

label: Legislature
description: See General Assembly.

label: Leicester
description: community in NW Buncombe County. Inc. 1859; charter repealed 1905. Named for or by Leicester Chapman, a settler from Leicester, England. Alt. 2,090.

label: Leicester Township
description: W Buncombe County.

label: Leiths Creek
description: rises in central Scotland County and flows SE to join Bridge Creek in forming the Little Pee Dee River.

label: Leland
description: community in NW Brunswick County.

label: Leman Gap
description: on Burke-Cleveland county line.

label: Lemay
description: community in SE Wake County served by post office, 1882-1901.

label: Lemley's Township
description: former township in NW Mecklenburg County. Now township no. 10.

label: Lemon Creek Falls
description: See Lamance Creek Falls.

label: Lemon Gap
description: on the Madison County, N.C.-Cocke County, Tenn., line.

label: Lemon Springs
description: community in S Lee County. Was designated a railroad station in 1890. Named for mineral springs, owned by a man named Lemon, which were formerly a favorite picnic spot. Alt. 369.

label: Lena
description: community in S Cumberland County.

label: Lennon Crossroads
description: community in S central Brunswick County.

label: Lennon's Marsh
description: See Warwick Bay.

label: Lennon's Mill Pond
description: See Warwick Bay.

label: Lenoir
description: city and county seat, central Caldwell County. Laid out 1841, inc. 1851. Named in honor of Gen. William Lenoir (1751-1839), a Revolutionary War leader. A nearby forerunner of Lenoir was Tucker's Barn, a small community that developed around a tavern and blacksmith shop operated by the Tucker family. Produces furniture and textiles. Alt. 1,182.

label: Lenoir Branch
description: rises in central Macon County and flows S into Cartoogechaye Creek.

label: Lenoir County (leh-NOR)
description: was formed in 1791, when Dobbs County was divided to form Glasgow and Lenoir Counties. Located in the E section of the state, it is bounded by Craven, Jones, Duplin, Wayne, Greene, and Pitt Counties. It was named for William Lenoir (1751-1839), one of the heroes of the Battle of Kings Mountain. Area: 399 sq. mi. County seat: Kinston, with an elevation of 44 ft. Townships are Contentnea Neck, Falling Creek, Institute, Kinston, Moseley Hall, Neuse, Pink Hill, Sand Hill, Southwest, Trent, Vance, and Woodington. Produces tobacco, corn, wheat, oats, soybeans, cotton, hogs, turkeys, cantaloupes, dairy products, livestock, chemicals, textiles, vacuum cleaners, ceramics, pharmaceuticals, sand, and gravel. See also St. Patrick's Parish.

label: Lenoir Creek
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows NE into East Fork Pigeon River.

label: Lenoir Township
description: S central Caldwell County.

label: Lenox Castle
description: former resort in SE Rockingham County. A tavern, baths, store, and springs made it a popular spa; probably operated prior to 1800, but flourished from 1803 until after 1844. Named for John Lenox, who advertised his tavern as "The Castle of Thundertontrenck" in 1804. A post office as late as 1882.

label: Lenox Point
description: extends from the mainland of S Carteret County into North River Thorofare E of the limits of Beaufort. Also once known as Titus Point.

label: Lenoxville
