description: a proposed town chartered in 1816 to be laid out on the lands of James McKinlay in S Carteret County E of Beaufort at present-day Lenox Point. Apparently it was never developed. A contemporary manuscript map of Lenoxville is in the North Carolina Collection, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

label: Lens Knob
description: W Surry County near Saddle Mountain Creek.

label: Lenton
description: community in S Rockingham County served by post office, 1889-90.

label: Lentz
description: community in W Rowan County served by post office, 1886-1902.

label: Lenzton
description: community in W Richmond County.

label: Leo
description: See Skinnersville.

label: Leonard
description: community in central Madison County served by post office, 1889-1901.

label: Leonard Creek
description: rises in central Davie County near the town of Mocksville and flows E for approx. 4 mi. into Dutchmans Creek.

label: Leonard Fork
description: rises in S Lincoln County and flows SE into Indian Creek.

label: Leonards Crossroads
description: community in NW Columbus County.

label: Leonards Point
description: extends from N Washington County into Albemarle Sound.

label: Leonsburg
description: former town in W Hyde County between Germantown and Sladesville. Inc. 1833, but now only a rural community.

label: Leota
description: community in N Chatham County served by post office, 1883-96.

label: Leroy Creek
description: rises in N central Avery County and flows NE into Elk River.

label: Lester
description: community in N Wilkes County between North Fork Reddies River and Mulberry Creek.

label: Letha
description: community in N Franklin County.

label: Letitia
description: community in SW Cherokee County.

label: Lettered Rock Ridge
description: NW Burke County. Alt. 3,100.

label: Level Cross
description: community and former post office, N Randolph County. Named for the level intersection of several roads there.

label: Level Cross Township
description: N central Randolph County.

label: Level Plains
description: community in NW Randolph County served by post office, 1875-1906.

label: Levelcross
description: community in SE Surry County. Named for the fact that two roads cross there in comparatively level country.

label: Levels
description: community in N central Tyrrell County at the head of Riders Creek. Alt. approx. 4. Also called Riders Creek Community. Formerly received postal service from post office named Jerry, which was located about 1 mi. SW of the community.

label: Levi
description: community in central Davidson County served by post office, 1889-1907.

label: Levingtons Creek
description: See Livingston Creek.

label: Levy Branch
description: rises in W Madison County and flows NW into Big Pine Creek.

label: Lewarae
description: town in S Richmond County. Est. 1900; inc. 1905. No longer active in municipal affairs. Name derived from parts of the names of three local families: Leak, Wall, and MacRae.

label: Lewellyn Cove
description: follows the course of a stream emptying into Little Tennessee River in N Graham County.

label: Lewis
description: See Atkinson.

label: Lewis Branch
description: rises in N Madison County and flows S into Big Laurel Creek.

label: Lewis Canal
description: central Washington County, drains NE from East Dismal Swamp into Main Canal.

label: Lewis Creek
description: rises in N Pender County and flows NE into Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: Lewis Crossroads
description: community in N Halifax County.

label: Lewis Fork
description: community in SW Wilkes County on South Prong Lewis Fork Creek. Lewis Fork Baptist Church there was organized in 1792.

label: Lewis Fork Creek
description: is formed in SW Wilkes County by the junction of North Prong Lewis Fork Creek and South Prong Lewis Fork Creek and flows SE approx. 3 mi. into W. Kerr Scott Reservoir. See also Fort Hamby.

label: Lewis Fork Township
description: SW Wilkes County.

label: Lewis Gap
description: central Buncombe County N of Patton Mountain.

label: Lewis McDaires Knob
description: N Buncombe County on Lankford Mountain. See also McDaires Cove and Ridge.

label: Lewis Mountain
description: between Henderson Creek and Lewis Creek in E Henderson County.

label: Lewis Point
description: N Tyrrell County, extends from the mainland into Albemarle Sound W of Peartree Point.

label: Lewis Swamp
description: rises in E central Brunswick County and flows E to join Rattlesnake Branch in forming Town Creek.

label: Lewis's Creek
description: See Lewis Creek.

label: Lewisburg
description: community in N Yancey County on Cane River at the mouth of Bald Mountain Creek. Alt. 2,288.

label: Lewiston
description: town in NW Bertie County. Inc. 1881. Named for the Watson Lewis family. A previous post office there, 1816-40, was known as Turner's Cross Roads. Post office known as Lewiston after 1872. Alt. 50. See also Woodville.

label: Lewisville
description: community in W Forsyth County. Named in honor of Lewis Lagenauer, around whose home it developed.

label: Lewisville Township
description: SW Forsyth County.

label: Lewters Crossroads
description: community in NE Northampton County.

label: Lexine
description: See Washburns Store.

label: Lexington
description: city and county seat, central Davidson County. Inc. 1827. Named for the Battle of Lexington, April 19, 1775, in Massachusetts. Davidson County Community College, est. 1966, is there. Alt. 810. Produces dairy products, textiles, hosiery, lumber, furniture, apparel, and batteries.

label: Lexington Township
description: central Davidson County.

label: Liberia
description: community in S central Warren County S of Reedy Creek.

label: Liberty
description: community in SE Rowan County. Named for a local church.

label: Liberty Hill
description: community in W central Montgomery County that takes its name from local Baptist church.

label: Liberty Knob
description: W Surry County near the head of Millers Creek.

label: Liberty Store
description: community in NE Guilford County served by post office, 1877-83.

label: Liberty Township
description: SE Yadkin County.

label: Lick Creek
description: rises in central Lee County and flows NE into Cape Fear River.

label: Lick Creek
description: rises in NE Orange County and flows NE into Person County, where it enters Byrds Creek.

label: Lick Fork
description: rises in N Gaston County and flows NE into S Lincoln County, where it enters Mill Creek.

label: Lick Fork Creek
description: rises in E Rockingham County and flows NE into Hogans Creek near Caswell County line.

label: Lick Log Creek
description: community in S Clay County.

label: Lick Log Gap
description: on the Madison County, N.C.-Greene County, Tenn., line.

label: Lick Meadow Branch
description: rises in E Franklin County and flows NE into Redbud Creek.

label: Lick Mountain
description: W Randolph County SW of Jackson Creek.

label: Lick Ridge
description: in E Mitchell County between Honeycutt Branch and Young Cove Creek.

label: Lick Rock
description: on the Madison County, N.C.-Unicoi County, Tenn., line.

label: Lick Run
description: rises in central Lincoln County and flows SE into Leepers Creek.

label: Lick, The
description: See Williamsboro.

label: Licking Branch
description: rises in W Gates County and flows SW into Jady Branch.

label: Licking Creek
description: See Elisha Creek.

label: Licklog Branch
description: rises in SE Buncombe County and flows S into Rocky Fork.

label: Licklog Creek
description: rises in S Jackson County on S slopes of Heady Mountain and flows S and W 1½ mi. to join Fowler Creek.

label: Licklog Gap
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park between Hickory Cove and Right Fork [Cold Spring Branch] near lat. 35°29'05" N., long. 83°39'48" W.

label: Lickskillet
description: community in S Warren County S of Shocco Creek.

label: Lickskillet Branch
description: rises in W Yancey County and flows SE into Bald Creek.

label: Lickstone Bald
description: on Lickstone Ridge in S Haywood County. Alt. 5,700. Named for the fact that salt for cattle was put on a large smooth rock.

label: Lickstone Mountain
description: on the Jackson-Haywood county line. Alt. 5,576.

label: Lickstone Ridge
description: extends NE from Soco Creek in N Jackson County to Wolfpen Mountain in S Haywood County.

label: Liddell
description: community in W Lenoir County.

label: Light
description: community in E Davidson County.

label: Light Gap
description: NE Buncombe County near Big Andy Ridge.

label: Light Ground Pocosin
description: a muck-filled area covering approx. 4 by 5 mi., W central Pamlico County.

label: Lighthouse Creek
description: See Baldhead Creek.

label: Lightwood Knot Creek
description: rises in S Richmond County and flows S into South Carolina, where it joins Beverly Creek in forming Crooked Creek.

label: Lightwood Mountain
description: E Mitchell County at the head of Laurel Branch.

label: Lilac
description: community in S Davidson County served by post office, 1895-1914.

label: Liledoun
description: community in central Alexander County on Lower Little River. Founded to produce textiles.

label: Liles Creek
description: See Lyle Creek.

label: Lilesville
description: town in E Anson County. Inc. 1874. A post office as early as 1827. Named for Nelson P. Liles, local merchant. Alt. 474.

label: Lilesville Township
description: E Anson County.

label: Lilleys Millpond
description: See Greens Millpond.

label: Lillian
description: community in N Wake County.

label: Lillie
description: See Lizzie.

label: Lillington
description: town and county seat on Cape Fear River, central Harnett County. Inc. 1859; the name was changed from Long Creek Village to Lillington in honor of the Revolutionary War patriot Alexander Lillington (1725-86). Alt. 325. Produces apparel. See also Summerville.

label: Lillington
description: See Long Creek.

label: Lillington County
description: was authorized to be est. in 1859 from a portion of New Hanover County, provided that two-thirds of the qualified voters of Rocky Point Precinct approved. The act was not approved, but Pender County, which see, was later est. in approx. the same area.

label: Lillington Creek
description: rises in E Pender County and flows SW into Northeast Cape Fear River. Named for Gen. Alexander Lillington (1725-86), whose plantation was nearby. Appears as Island Creek on the Collet map, 1770; as Maxwell Creek on the Price map, 1808; and as Lillington's Mill Creek on the MacRae map, 1833.

label: Lillington Township
description: central Harnett County.

label: Lillington's Mill Creek
description: See Lillington Creek.

label: Lilliput
description: the plantation of Eleazer Allen (1692-1750), councillor, judge, receiver general, and treasurer of North Carolina, was located on the N side of Lilliput Creek in E Brunswick County. Land was granted to Allen in 1725, and he named the plantation for the imaginary country in Jonathan Swift's satire Gulliver's Travels (1726). Part of the 300-volume library at Lilliput was inherited by a daughter of James Hasell and might have been inc. into the remarkable Hasell library. Lilliput was purchased by Gov. William Tryon as a summer residence, and he still owned the property as late as 1784. Location of Lilliput is shown on the Moseley map, 1733, under the name of "E. Allen"; on the Collet map, 1770, as "Lilliput to the G."; and on the Price map, 1808, as "Lilliput."

label: Lilliput Creek
description: E Brunswick County, flows E from McKenzie Pond into Cape Fear River. Named for Lilliput, which see, a nearby plantation. Shown as Allen's Creek on the MacRae map, 1833, and on the Colton map, 1861. Appears as Lilliput Creek on the 1865 U.S. Coast Survey map and on the Kerr map, 1882.

label: Lilly
description: community in NE Camden County.

label: Lily Branch
description: rises in central Mitchell County and flows SW into North Toe River.

label: Lily Pond Creek
description: rises in W Northampton County and flows SW to join Gumberry Swamp in forming Wheeler Creek.

label: Lima
description: community in central Craven County.

label: Lime Rock
description: community in S Surry County on Yadkin River. Took its name from local lime kiln operated by Martin family. Alt. 820.

label: Limekiln Branch
description: rises in W central Transylvania County and flows SE into French Broad River.

label: Limekiln Creek
description: rises in N McDowell County and flows E through Woodlawn into North Fork [Catawba River].

label: Limestone Creek
description: rises in E Duplin County and flows SW into Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: Limestone Township
description: SE Duplin County.

label: Linbank
description: formerly a post office and community in S Vance County approx. 4 mi. S of the town of Henderson. The building used from 1829 until 1839 as a post office is still standing, and the name survives as the name of the local road on which the building stands.

label: Linches Creek
description: See Lynch Creek.

label: Lincoln County
description: was formed in 1779, when Tryon County was divided to form Lincoln and Rutherford Counties. Located in the SW section of the state, it is bounded by Mecklenburg, Gaston, Cleveland, Catawba, and Iredell Counties. It was named for Benjamin Lincoln (1733-1810), distinguished general of the Revolution. Area: 309 sq. mi. County seat: Lincolnton, with an elevation of 860 ft. Townships are Catawba Springs, Howards Creek, Ironton, Lincolnton, and North Brook. The Schenck-Warlick Mill, the first cotton mill in the South, was built about 1812 approx. 1 mi. W of Lincolnton. Produces corn, wheat, oats, cotton, poultry, dairy products, livestock, hogs, textiles, furniture, auto parts, apples, soybeans, machinery, hosiery, crushed stone, mica, sand, and amethyst.

label: Lincoln Hollow
description: valley in W Avery County between Teagues Ridge and Powdermill Creek.

label: Lincolnton
description: town and county seat, central Lincoln County. Est. 1785. Name honors Gen. Benjamin Lincoln (1733-1810), Revolutionary War leader. The Battle of Ramsour's Mill, a Whig victory over the Tories, was fought on June 20, 1780, at a site on the N outskirts of Lincolnton. Produces textiles, furniture, machinery, and hosiery. Alt. 860.

label: Lincolnton Township
description: central Lincoln County.

label: Lindell
description: community in NW Greene County served by post office, 1898-1907. Formerly Apple-tree, which see.

label: Linden
description: town in N Cumberland County. Settled about 1800. Inc. 1913 and named for a grove of linden trees nearby. Known as Little River Academy prior to 1910. Alt. 150. See also Choffington.

label: Linden Mountain
description: W Randolph County on Jackson Creek.

label: Lindhurst
description: community in central Chatham County served by post office, 1895-1916.

label: Lindley's Mill
description: on Cane Creek in S central Alamance County, a short distance W of Sutphin. The site of a battle on September 13, 1781, in which John Butler's Whigs failed to rescue Governor Thomas Burke from David Fanning's Tories. The first gristmill there was erected in 1756 by Thomas Lindley.

label: Lindsay
description: community in SE Orange County served by post office, 1888-1905.

label: Lindsay C. Warren Bridge
description: See East Lake Landing; Sandy Point.

label: Lindscomb Branch
description: rises in NW Brunswick County and flows W into Columbus County, where it enters Livingston Creek. Sometimes known locally as Linksom Branch and believed to have been named originally Lynchum Branch.

label: Line
description: community in SW Rutherford County.

label: Line Creek
description: rises in S Buncombe County and flows NE into French Broad River. Forms the Buncombe-Henderson county boundary for approx. 1 mi.

label: Line Runner Lake
description: in S Transylvania County on Gerren Creek. Covers 11 acres and has max. depth of 28 ft. Used for recreation.

label: Line Runner Ridge
description: S Transylvania County, extends N in an arc from Blue Ridge Mountains to the head of Gerren Creek.

label: Lineberry
description: community in N Randolph County. Named for Capt. Scott Lineberry, local resident.

label: Liner Cove
description: central Haywood County near Jerry Knob.

label: Liner Creek
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows SW into Crabtree Creek.

label: Linker
description: community in S Iredell County served by post office, 1898-1903.

label: Linksom Branch
description: See Lindscomb Branch.

label: Linn Cove
description: the valley through which Linn Cove Creek flows in central Buncombe County.

label: Linn Cove Creek
description: rises in Elk Mountains in central Buncombe County and flows SW to join Webb Cove Creek in forming Beaverdam Creek.

label: Linn Cove Viaduct
description: elevated section of Blue Ridge Parkway around Grandfather Mountain. Opened in 1987.

label: Linney
description: community in central Ashe County served by post office, 1899-1915.

label: Linsters Springs
description: See Barium Springs.

label: Linviles Creek
description: See Blanket Creek.

label: Linville
description: town in E central Avery County on Linville River. Alt. 3,623. Summer resort. Post office est. 1883 as Clay; changed to Porcelain in 1885 and to Linville in 1888. Laid out by Samuel T. Kelsey of Kansas, who had earlier (with Charles Hutchinson) laid out Highlands. Inc. 1891, but not now active in municipal affairs.

label: Linville Creek
description: rises in E Davie County and flows NE into Yadkin River.

label: Linville Creek
description: See Carters Creek.

label: Linville Falls
description: community on Avery-Burke county line near the NW tip of Burke County W of Linville River. Alt. 3,325. Named for falls on nearby river.

label: Linville Gorge
description: a narrow defile through which the Linville River flows in NW Burke County. Extends from Linville Falls to Lake James. Linville Gorge "wild area" in Pisgah National Forest in Burke County, set aside on February 7, 1951, contains 7,655 acres preserved in their natural state. Foot trails make it accessible, but no other development is permitted.

label: Linville Lake
description: See Lake Kawana.

label: Linville Mountain
description: E Avery County.

label: Linville River
description: rises in E Avery County approx. 3 mi. SW of Grandfather Mountain. It flows SW in Avery County and SE and S in Burke County, where it enters Lake James. Said to have been named for two brothers who hunted along its banks between 1760 and 1766 and were killed by Indians. Known by the Cherokee as Eeseeoh (River of Cliffs). See also Linville Gorge.

label: Linville Township
description: W Burke County.

label: Linville's Mill Creek
description: See Laytown Creek.

label: Linwood
description: community in W Davidson County in the former Jersey Settlement, which see. Alt. 659. Named by Dr. William Rainey Holt (1798-1868) for his nearby plantation. Produces lumber.

label: Lipe
description: community in SW Rowan County served by post office, 1886-1902.

label: Lippard Creek
description: rises in S Catawba County and flows SW into Lincoln County, where it joins Sawmill Creek in forming Leepers Creek.

label: Lisbon
description: former community in S Sampson County at the junction of Six Runs Creek and Coharie River where Black River is formed. Authorized to be laid out on the land of Jesse Peacock in 1785 and named Lisburn, probably for the town of the same name in Northern Ireland, birthplace of Hugh Waddell (1734?-1773), colonial soldier. Authorized to be resurveyed in 1824, when it was called Lisbon. A post office est. there as early as 1833 and named Lisborne operated as Lisbon as late as 1882.

label: Lisbon Township
description: S central Sampson County.

label: Lisburn
description: See Lisbon.

label: Lisenbee Branch
description: rises in N Madison County and flows S into Spillcorn Creek.

label: Lisenbee Ridge
description: central Madison County, extends SW approx. 1½ mi. between Heck Creek and Bee Branch.

label: Lisenberry Mountain
description: NE Rutherford County between First Broad River and Duncans Creek. It is said that carpetbaggers lived in a cave there during the Reconstruction period following the Civil War.

label: Lisha
description: See Elisha Creek.

label: Lisk
description: community in SE Rowan County served by post office, 1890-1906.

label: Lissa
description: community in central Sampson County served by post office, 1894-1902.

label: Listen Knob
description: peak in central Caldwell County about 5 mi. NE of Lenoir. Named for the fact that foxhunters built fires on the top as they listened to their dogs running foxes.

label: Listers Corner
description: community in S Pasquotank County.

label: Litaker Township
description: S Rowan County.

label: Lithia Springs
description: community in central Lincoln County that was a popular nineteenth-century resort. Gen. Robert F. Hoke (1837-1912) owned the springs and marketed bottled water from them.

label: Little Abrams Gap
description: in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on the Swain County, N.C.-Blount County, Tenn., line near lat. 35°33'18" N., long. 83°46'34" W.

label: Little Alamance Creek
description: rises in W Alamance County and flows SE into Great Alamance Creek.

label: Little Alamance Creek
description: rises in central Guilford County and flows NE to join Big Alamance Creek in forming Great Alamance Creek, which see.

label: Little Andy Creek
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows W into Corner Rock Creek.

label: Little Andy Ridge
description: NE Buncombe County N of Little Andy Creek and Big Andy Ridge.

label: Little Bald
description: on the Yancey County, N.C.-Unicoi County, Tenn., line. Alt. approx. 5,240.

label: Little Bald Branch
description: rises in SW Madison County and flows NW into Spring Creek.

label: Little Bald Knob
description: on the Mitchell County, N.C.-Unicoi County, Tenn., line.

label: Little Bald Mountain
description: See Mount Squires.

label: Little Bald Rock Mountain
description: S Jackson County on E edge of Fairfield Lake and S of Bald Rock Mountain.

label: Little Balsam Gap
description: on the head of Plott Creek in W Haywood County.

label: Little Balsam Knob
description: on the head of Plott Creek in W Haywood County.

label: Little Bear Creek
description: rises in NE Cabarrus County and flows SW into Dutch Buffalo Creek.

label: Little Bear Creek
description: rises in W central Stanly County and flows S into Long Creek.

label: Little Bear Wallow Creek
description: rises in W Transylvania County and flows SW into North Fork French Broad River.

label: Little Bearpen Gap
description: on the Jackson-Haywood county line.

label: Little Bearpen Mountain
description: SE Macon County between Bearpen Mountain and Cullasaja River.

label: Little Beartrail Ridge
description: S Haywood County between Little Beartrap Branch and Big Beartrap Branch.

label: Little Beartrap Branch
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows NE into Middle Prong.

label: Little Bearwallow Mountain
description: N Henderson County between Bearwallow Mountain and Hickory Nut Creek.

label: Little Beaver Creek
description: rises in W Wake County and flows NW into E Chatham County, where it enters Beaver Creek.

label: Little Beaverdam Creek
description: rises in SW Duplin County and flows SE into Big Beaverdam Creek.

label: Little Beaverdam Creek
description: rises in NW Watauga County and flows SW into Beaverdam Creek.

label: Little Beaverdam Swamp
description: rises in W Sampson County and flows SW into South River.

label: Little Bernal Branch
description: rises in W Johnston County and flows SE into Bernal Branch.

label: Little Black Creek
description: rises in S Wake County and flows SE into W Johnston County, where it enters Black Creek.

label: Little Bottom Branch
description: rises in W Madison County and flows NE into Spring Creek.

label: Little Branch
description: rises in W Wake County and flows SW into Whiteoak Creek.

label: Little Brasstown Creek
description: rises in S Cherokee County and flows NE into Brasstown Creek.

label: Little Brier Creek
description: rises in W Wake County and flows SW into Brier Creek.

label: Little Brier Ridge
description: spur of Brier Ridge extending NE to Dark Ridge Creek in NE Jackson County.

label: Little Broad Creek
description: rises in North River Pocosin in S Camden County and flows E into North River ½ mi. below the mouth of Broad Creek.

label: Little Brown Creek
description: rises in SE Union County and flows SE into Brown Creek.

label: Little Browns Landing
description: on Cape Fear River in central Bladen County.

label: Little Brush Creek
description: rises in NE Yancey County and flows NW into Brush Creek.

label: Little Brush Mountain
description: is made up of a chain of 5 or 6 peaks in W Alexander and E Caldwell Counties.

label: Little Brushy
description: peak at the S end of Brushy Mountain, NE Buncombe County.

label: Little Brushy Mount
description: a range of mountains in E Caldwell and W Alexander Counties. Alts. from 1,850 to 1,890.

label: Little Buck Creek
description: rises in NW McDowell County on the S slopes of Woods Mountain and flows SE into Buck Creek and Lake Tahoma.

label: Little Buck Hill
description: mountain in W Avery County.

label: Little Buck Mountain
description: on Alexander-Caldwell county line. Alt. 1,890.

label: Little Buckeye Cove
description: SE Haywood County on the head of East Prong Pigeon River.

label: Little Buckle Swamp
description: rises in SE Bladen County and flows SE into Buckle Swamp.

label: Little Buffalo Creek
description: See West Buffalo Creek.

label: Little Bugaboo Creek
description: rises in N Wilkes County and flows SE into Big Bugaboo Creek.

label: Little Butt Knob
description: on the Buncombe-Yancey county line between Big Butt Knob and Point Misery. Alt. approx. 3,300.

label: Little Camp Creek
description: rises in N Rutherford County and flows SW into Camp Creek.

label: Little Cane River Gap
description: See Cane River Gap.

label: Little Caraway Creek
description: rises in NW Randolph County and flows S into Caraway Creek.

label: Little Cataloochee Creek
description: is formed in NW Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park by the junction of Woody Branch and Conrad Branch. Flows E 2 mi. and empties into Cataloochee Creek.

label: Little Catawba River
description: See South Fork Catawba River.

label: Little Cawcaw Swamp
description: rises in SW Brunswick County and flows W into Cawcaw Swamp at E limit of Thomas Bay.

label: Little Cedar Cliff
description: NE Buncombe County near Ingraham Mountain.

label: Little Cedar Mountain
description: S Buncombe County in the Swannanoa Mountains.

label: Little Celo Mountain
description: E Yancey County at the NE end of Celo Ridge.

label: Little Chestnut Bald
description: mountain peak in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on the Swain County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line near lat. 35°33'54" N., long. 83°38'30" W. Alt. 5,042.

label: Little Chestnut Mountain
description: NE Burke County and SW Caldwell Counties.

label: Little Chestnut Ridge
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur of Locust Ridge near lat. 35°32'50" N., long. 83°39'54" W.

label: Little Chimney Knob
description: S Macon County between Chimney Knob and Kimsey Gap.

label: Little Chinquapin Branch
description: rises in W Jones County and flows E about 3½ mi. into Trent River.

label: Little Choga Creek
description: rises in W Macon County and flows SE into Nantahala Lake.

label: Little Coharie Creek
description: rises in NW Sampson County and flows SE to join Great Coharie Creek in forming Coharie River.

label: Little Coharie Township
description: W Sampson County.

label: Little Cokey Swamp
description: rises in W Edgecombe County and flows SE into Cokey Swamp.

label: Little Cold Water Creek
description: rises in N Cabarrus County and flows S into Cold Water Creek.

label: Little Colington Island
description: See Colington Island.

label: Little Colly Creek
description: rises in E Bladen County and flows S into Colly Creek.

label: Little Contentnea Creek
description: rises in SE Wilson County and flows SE on the Greene-Pitt county line into Pitt County, then back to the Pitt-Greene county line, which it follows into Contentnea Creek. See also Contentnea Creek. Appears as Little Cotecktney Creek on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Little Cotecktney Creek
description: See Little Contentnea Creek.

label: Little Cove Creek
description: W Polk County flows NE and NW into Green River.

label: Little Crabtree Creek
description: rises in central Yancey County and flows E into South Toe River.

label: Little Craggy Knob
description: NE Buncombe County between Sugar Fork and Left Fork.

label: Little Crains Creek
description: See Whiteoak Creek.

label: Little Creek
description: E Beaufort County, an inlet of Pungo Creek near the junction with Pungo River.

label: Little Creek
description: rises in W Hoke County and flows SW into Lumber River.

label: Little Creek
description: rises in SE Moore County and flows S into Little River.

label: Little Creek
description: community on Little Creek S of Sams Gap, NE Madison County. Alt. 2,892.

label: Little Creek Gap
description: on the Haywood-Madison county line.

label: Little Creek Point
description: S Onslow County in New River.

label: Little Crooked Creek
description: rises in SW McDowell County and flows E into Crooked Creek.

label: Little Cross Creek
description: rises in N Cumberland County and flows SE into Cross Creek. Early settlers found that Cross Creek and Little Cross Creek crossed.

label: Little Cub Creek
description: See East Prong Cub Creek.

label: Little Currituck
description: See Farmington.

label: Little Cypress Creek
description: rises in S Jones County and flows NE into Cypress Creek.

label: Little Dam Branch
description: rises in N Cherokee County on Hanging Dog Mountain and flows NE into Hyatt Creek.

label: Little Davidson Branch
description: rises in W Haywood County and flows NW into Davidson Branch.

label: Little Davis Mountain
description: N Buncombe County in the Elk Mountains.

label: Little Deep Creek
description: rises in N central Carteret County and flows S into Deep Creek.

label: Little Deep Creek
description: rises in W Warren County and flows NE into Ellingtons Creek.

label: Little Dismal Swamp
description: NW Johnston County, drains into Dismal Branch.

label: Little Dugger Creek
description: rises in SE Watauga County and flows SE into Wilkes County, where it enters Dugger Creek.

label: Little Dugger Mountain
description: SE Watauga County near the head of Little Dugger Creek.

label: Little Ease Creek
description: a bay on the N side of Pamlico River, E Beaufort County.

label: Little East Fork Pigeon River
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows NW into West Fork Pigeon River.

label: Little Elk Creek
description: rises in SW Avery County and flows NE into Elk River.

label: Little Elk Knob
description: N Graham County between Tuskeegee Creek and Sawyer Creek.

label: Little Elk Mountain
description: central Avery County.

label: Little Elk Ridge
description: central Avery County.

label: Little Elkin River
description: rises in NE Wilkes County and flows SE into Yadkin River.

label: Little Elliby
description: See Upper Bartons Creek.

label: Little Fall Branch
description: rises in N Haywood County and flows NW into Cold Springs Creek.

label: Little Fall Creek
description: rises in N central Wake County E and flows NE into Fall Branch.

label: Little Fires Creek
description: rises in N Clay County and flows SW into Fires Creek.

label: Little Fisher River
description: rises in N Surry County and flows SE into Fisher River.

label: Little Fishhawk Mountain
description: S Macon County between Fishhawk Mountain and Whiterock Gap. Alt. 4,706.

label: Little Fishing Creek
description: is formed in E central Warren County by the junction of Walkers Creek and Big Branch. It flows SE into W Halifax County, where it enters Fishing Creek on the Halifax-Nash county line. Appears as Conway Creek on the Moseley map, 1733, and as Little Fishing Creek on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Little Fishing Creek
description: See Mill Creek.

label: Little Flat Creek
description: rises in N Buncombe County near Brittain Mountain and flows NW into Flat Creek.

label: Little Flatty Creek
description: rises in SE Pasquotank County and flows SE into Pasquotank River.

label: Little Florida
description: artificial pond in NW Tyrrell County formed in 1946 by the digging of sand from a farm to make a fill. Covers 3 acres; max. depth 30 ft. Named by C. E. Liverman, former owner, for name of the farm.

label: Little Fodderstack Mountain
description: SE Macon County at the head of Edwards Creek.

label: Little Fork
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows NW into Right Fork. These are tributaries of Swannanoa River. Sometimes known locally as Little Right Hand Fork.

label: Little Fork Ridge
description: N Mitchell County between Left Fork Bean Creek and Right Fork Bean Creek.

label: Little Foster Creek
description: rises in NE Madison County and flows S into Foster Creek.

label: Little Gap Creek
description: rises in N Watauga County and flows N into Ashe County, where it enters South Fork New River.

label: Little Glade Creek
description: rises in SE Alleghany County and flows N into Brush Creek.

label: Little Governors Creek
description: rises on the Lee-Moore county line and flows NW into Big Governors Creek. Forms part of the Lee-Moore county line for its entire course. Named for Governor Gabriel Johnston, who acquired land in the vicinity in 1748.

label: Little Grandfather Mountain
description: on the Alleghany-Wilkes county line. Alt. 3,745.

label: Little Grassy Creek
description: rises in N Granville County and flows N into Grassy Creek.

label: Little Green Creek
description: rises in SE Jackson County N of Cold Mountain and flows 1½ mi. W into Tuckasegee River.

label: Little Green Mountain
description: in SE Jackson County between Big Green Mountain and Panthertown Creek. Alt. approx. 4,100.

label: Little Green Swamp
description: NE Brunswick County. Approx. 10 mi. square.

label: Little Grill Ridge
description: W Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur from Big Grill Ridge, lat. 35°32'38" N., long. 83°47'28" W.

label: Little Gunpowder Creek
description: rises in S Caldwell County and flows E into Gunpowder Creek.

label: Little Hamer Creek
description: rises in S Montgomery County and flows S into Richmond County, where it enters Hamer Creek.

label: Little Harris Creek
description: rises in central Cleveland County and flows SE into Big Harris Creek.

label: Little Haw Creek
description: rises in E Alamance County and flows SW into Haw Creek.

label: Little Haw Knob
description: on the Graham County, N.C.-Monroe County, Tenn., line. Alt. 5,146.

label: Little Haw Mountain
description: central Avery County.

label: Little Hawk Mountain
description: E Mitchell County between Hawk Creek and Long Hollow.

label: Little Helton Creek
description: rises in N Ashe County and flows SE into Helton Creek.

label: Little Hensley Branch
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows NE into Cane River.

label: Little Hickory Creek
description: rises in S Cleveland County and flows W into Hickory Creek.

label: Little Hickory Knob

label: Little Hickory Top

label: Little Hogback Creek

label: Little Hogback Mountain

label: Little Hope Creek
description: rises in SW Mecklenburg County and flows SE into Little Sugar Creek.

label: Little Horse Creek
description: rises in W Avery County and flows SE into North Toe River.

label: Little Hoyles Creek
description: rises in N Gaston County and flows S into Hoyles Creek.

label: Little Hubquarter Creek

label: Little Huckleberry Knob
description: W Graham County between Huckleberry Knob and Doc Stewart Ridge. Alt. approx. 5,380.

label: Little Hump Mountain

label: Little Hungry Creek

label: Little Hunting Creek
description: rises in S Wilkes County and flows SE into Hunting Creek.

label: Little Hurricane Creek

label: Little Indian Creek

label: Little Inlet

label: Little Island Creek
description: rises in NW Vance County and flows N into Island Creek.

label: Little Ivy Creek
description: is formed in W Madison County by the junction of California Creek and Paint Fork and flows SW to join Ivy Creek at the Buncombe-Madison county line to form Ivy River.

label: Little Jacob Swamp
description: rises in central Robeson County and flows SE into Jacob Swamp.

label: Little Jacobs Creek
description: rises in S Stanly County and flows SE and NE into Jacobs Creek.

label: Little John Creek
description: rises in SE Craven County and flows NW into Hancock Creek.

label: Little Johnson Creek
description: See Beech Creek.

label: Little Jonas Creek
description: rises in N Swain County and flows SE into Jonas Creek.

label: Little Juniper Creek
description: rises in central Moore County and flows NW into Big Juniper Creek.

label: Little Kings Creek
description: rises in NE Caldwell County and flows NE into Kings Creek.

label: Little Kinnekeet Coast Guard Station
description: decommissioned station on Hatteras Island, SE Dare County. First est. as a lifesaving station in 1874. Life-saving Service and Revenue Cutter Service joined to form U.S. Coast Guard in 1915.

label: Little Kitchens Ridge
description: SE Clay County between Holden Cove and Tallulah River.

label: Little Knob

label: Little Knob Creek
description: rises in N Cleveland County and flows SE into Knob Creek.

label: Little Lake

label: Little Laurel Branch
description: rises in SE Mitchell County and flows S into North Toe River.

label: Little Laurel Creek
description: rises in NW Wake County and flows W into Big Lick Creek.

label: Little Ledge Creek
description: rises in S Granville County and flows S into Ledge Creek.

label: Little Lick Creek
description: rises in E Lee County and flows N into Lick Creek.

label: Little Lick Fork
description: See Lick Fork.

label: Little Limestone Creek
description: rises in E Duplin County and flows SE into Limestone Creek.

label: Little Long Creek
description: rises in central Gaston County and flows SE into Long Creek.

label: Little Long Mountain
description: SW Randolph County between King Mountain and Poison Fork.

label: Little Lost Cove Creek
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows NW into South Toe River.

label: Little Lyman Branch
description: rises in SW Macon County and flows N into Kimsey Creek.

label: Little Manor
description: Home of William Person Little, state senator from Warren County (1804-1806). The house was built in 1780 and is still standing.

label: Little Marsh Swamp
description: rises in S Hoke County and flows SE into Robeson County, where it enters Gallberry Swamp.

label: Little Matrimony Creek
description: rises in N Rockingham County and flows E in an arc into Matrimony Creek, which see.

label: Little Meadow Creek
description: rises in SE Cabarrus County and flows SW into Rocky River.

label: Little Middle Mountain
description: N Buncombe County between Brank Mountain and Brittain Cove 2½ mi. NE of town of Weaverville.

label: Little Middle Ridge
description: NE Madison County between Colvin and Amos Creeks.

label: Little Mountain
description: on Gash Creek in W Henderson County.

label: Little Mountain
description: See Anderson's Mountain.

label: Little Mountain Creek
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows SE into South Toe River.

label: Little Mud Creek
description: rises in W Henderson County and flows NE into Mud Creek.

label: Little Mulberry Creek
description: approx. 5 mi. long, rises in Pisgah National Forest, N Caldwell County, and flows first SE then SW into Mulberry Creek.

label: Little Neatman Creek

label: Little Nettle Branch

label: Little New Mountain

label: Little Nigger Head

label: Little Northeast Creek

label: Little Nutbush Creek

label: Little Panthertail Mountain

label: Little Paw Creek
description: rises in W Mecklenburg County and flows W into Catawba River.

label: Little Peachtree Creek
description: rises in E Franklin County and flows SE into Nash County, where it joins Big Peachtree Creek in forming Stony Creek.

label: Little Pee Dee River

label: Little Permetter Creek
description: rises in N central Anson County and flows S into Permetter Creek, which see.

label: Little Persimmon Creek
description: rises in E Cleveland County and flows NW into Persimmon Creek.

label: Little Peters Creek
description: rises in Virginia and flows SW into Stokes County, where it enters Peters Creek.

label: Little Pine Creek
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows SE into Pine Creek.

label: Little Pine Creek
description: rises in S Madison County and flows NE into French Broad River.

label: Little Pine Creek Township
description: former township in S central Madison County, now township no. 7.

label: Little Pine Gap
description: S Madison County on the SW end of Rocky Ridge.

label: Little Pine Mountain
description: N Avery County.

label: Little Piney Branch
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows SE into Flat Creek.

label: Little Piney Ridge

label: Little Pinnacle
description: S Macon County between Pinnacle Branch and the head of Jones Creek.

label: Little Pisgah Mountain
description: on the Buncombe-Henderson county line between the headwaters of Ashworth Creek and Blue Rock Knob. Alt. 4,412. Known as Konnatoga by the Cherokee Indians.

label: Little Pisgah Ridge
description: NW Henderson County, a part of Pisgah Ridge.

label: Little Plumtree Creek
description: rises in central Avery County and flows S and W into Plumtree Creek.

label: Little Pocket Creek
description: rises in W Lee County and flows NE into Pocket Creek.

label: Little Pole Creek
description: rises near Luther Knob in SW Buncombe County and flows S into Pole Creek.

label: Little Polecat Creek
description: rises in N Randolph County and flows SW into Polecat Creek.

label: Little Pond Branch
description: rises in W Watauga County and flows NW into Pond Branch.

label: Little Porpoise Bay
description: in Pamlico Sound on the E side of Goose Creek Island, NE Pamlico County.

label: Little Prong
description: community in NW Brunswick County.

label: Little Quankey Creek
description: rises in N Halifax County and flows SE into Quankey Creek.

label: Little Raft Swamp
description: rises in S Hoke County and flows SE into Raft Swamp in N Robeson County.

label: Little Ragged Point
description: See Holmes Point.

label: Little Rattlesnake Branch
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows S into Swannanoa River.

label: Little Rich Mountain

label: Little Richardson Creek
description: rises in S Union County and flows N into Richardson Creek.

label: Little Richmond

label: Little Ridge
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur of Big Fork Ridge extending ne; center near lat. 35°35'38" N., long. 83°08'28" W.

label: Little Ridgepole Mountain

label: Little Right Hand Fork
description: See Little Fork.

label: Little River

label: Little River

label: Little River Academy
description: See Linden.

label: Little River Township
description: NE Wake County.

label: Little Roaring Creek
description: rises in NW Avery County and flows E into Cranberry Creek.

label: Little Rock
description: community in E Rockingham County served by post office, 1850-53. Known later as Ruffin, which see.

label: Little Rock Branch
description: rises in SW Macon County and flows SW into Nantahala River.

label: Little Rock Creek
description: See Glen Ayre.

label: Little Rock Creek Township
description: NE Mitchell County.

label: Little Rock Knob
description: on the Mitchell County, N.C.-Carter County, Tenn., line. Alt. approx. 4,920.

label: Little Rockfish Creek
description: rises in S Duplin County and flows S from Boney Mill Pond into Rockfish Creek on the Duplin-Pender county Line.

label: Little Rockhouse Creek
description: rises in central Rockingham County and flows N and W into Dan River. Also known as Roach's Creek, which see.

label: Little Rocky Creek
description: See Olin Creek.

label: Little Rocky Face
description: a peak in E Haywood County between the head of Garden Creek and the head of Harley Branch.

label: Little Rocky Knob

label: Little Rocky Mountain
description: E Macon County on a tributary of Little Salt Rock Creek.

label: Little Rose Creek
description: rises in SE Mitchell County and flows NW into Rose Creek.

label: Little Ruin Creek

label: Little Salt Rock Creek

label: Little Sam Knob

label: Little Sandy Branch

label: Little Sandy Creek

label: Little Sandy Gap

label: Little Sandy Run Swamp
description: rises in W Onslow County and flows SE into Sandy Run Swamp.

label: Little Sandymush Creek

label: Little Santeetlah Creek

label: Little Sapony Creek
description: rises in W Nash County and flows SE into Sapony Creek.

label: Little Savannah Creek
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows NW into Savannah Creek.

label: Little Scaly Mountain
description: S Macon County between Abe Creek and Chinquapin Mountain. Alt. 4,200.

label: Little Shaddox Creek
description: rises in N Lee County and flows E into Cape Fear River.

label: Little Sheep Cliffs
description: S Jackson County between Horsepasture River and Sheep Cliffs.

label: Little Shell Rock
description: See North Rock.

label: Little Shepherd Mountain
description: W Randolph County between Uwharrie River and Little Caraway Creek.

label: Little Shoal Creek
description: rises in W Cherokee County and flows SE into Shoal Creek.

label: Little Shocco Creek
description: rises in SW Warren County and flows E into Shocco Creek.

label: Little Shuckstack
description: mountain in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, NW Swain County, lat. 35°29'26" N., long. 83°48'37" W. Alt. 3,821.

label: Little Silver Creek
description: rises in SW Burke County and flows NE into Silver Creek.

label: Little Singletary Lake
description: a natural lake in N Bladen County; approx. 1½ mi. long and ¾ mi. wide. Fishing. See also Carolina Bays.

label: Little Snow Creek
description: rises in N Stokes County and flows SE into Snow Creek.

label: Little Snowball Mountain
description: N Buncombe County between Cherry Log Gap and Snowball Gap. Alt. 4,824.

label: Little Snowbird Creek
description: rises in S Graham County and flows NE and NW into Snowbird Creek.

label: Little Spivey Creek
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows W into Tennessee, where it enters Spivey Creek.

label: Little Spruce Ridge
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a spur extending NE from Cataloochee Divide; center near lat. 35°33'35" N., long. 83°08'04" W., between Little Bald Branch and Bearpen Branch.

label: Little Steeltrap Creek
description: rises in N Swain County and flows SW into Forney Creek.

label: Little Stone Mountain
description: N Wilkes County on the W side of East Prong Roaring River.

label: Little Stonehouse Creek
description: rises in E Warren County and flows NE into Lake Gaston.

label: Little Sugar Creek
description: rises in central Mecklenburg County and flows SW into South Carolina, where it enters Sugar Creek. Appears as Shugan Creek on the Collet map, 1770, but with its present name on the Price map, 1808.

label: Little Sugar Loaf
description: community in central Bladen County served by post office, 1870-1901.

label: Little Swamp
description: rises in S Nash County and flows SE into Toisnot Swamp.

label: Little Swamp Branch
description: rises in SW Johnston County and flows SE into Mill Swamp Branch.

label: Little Swift Creek
description: rises in NE Craven County and flows SW into Swift Creek.

label: Little Switzerland
description: community and summer resort in NW McDowell County on the head of Threemile Creek. Alt. 3,500. Founded in 1910 as a summer resort by Heriot Clarkson (1863-1942). Named because of the supposed resemblance of the mountains of the area to those of Switzerland. See also Armstrong.

label: Little Tennessee River
description: is formed in Rabun County, Ga., by the junction of Betty and Darnell Creeks. It flows N and NW into Macon County and through Lake Emory; into Swain County and along the Graham-Swain county line through Fontana Lake and Lake Cheoah; and into Tennessee, where it enters the Tennessee River. The river was long believed to have been discovered in 1540 by Hernando De Soto and as such the first tributary of the Mississippi River discovered by Europeans.

label: Little Terrapin Mountain
description: S Jackson County approx. 1½ mi. S of Hampton Lake, is bordered on the W by Fowler Creek. Alt. 3,900.

label: Little Timber Ridge
description: N Avery County.

label: Little Tomahawk Creek
description: rises in S Sampson County and flows NW to join Big Tomahawk Creek in forming Tomahawk Creek.

label: Little Town Creek
description: rises in S Montgomery County and flows SE into Town Creek.

label: Little Troublesome Creek
description: is formed in E Rockingham County in Reidsville and flows SE into Haw River.

label: Little Trout Creek
description: rises in central Jackson County and flows N into Mill Creek.

label: Little Tuni Creek
description: rises in W Macon County and flows N into Big Choga Creek.

label: Little Turnbull Creek
description: rises in NE Bladen County and flows W into Turnbull Creek. Once known as Edward Jones Creek.

label: Little Uwharrie River
description: rises in NW Randolph County and flows SE into Uwharrie River.

label: Little Warrior Mountain
description: S Polk County W of town of Tryon. The name is a corruption of the Indian word wayah (wolf).

label: Little Webb Creek
description: rises in S Buncombe County and flows SW into Gap Creek.

label: Little Whiteoak Creek
description: rises in E Yancey County and flows NW into South Toe River.

label: Little Whitewater Creek
description: rises in S Jackson County and flows SE to join Silver Run Creek in forming Whitewater River.

label: Little Will Branch
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows SW into North Fork Ivy Creek.

label: Little Willow Creek
description: rises in W Henderson County and flows NE into French Broad River. A legendary Cherokee route, "Willow Trail," followed the course of the stream.

label: Little Yadkin River
description: is formed in SW Stokes County by the junction of East Prong Little Yadkin River and West Prong Little Yadkin River and flows S into Forsyth County, where it enters Yadkin River.

label: Little Yalaka Creek
description: rises in S Swain County and flows SW into Yalaka Creek.

label: Little Yellow Mountain
description: SE Macon County between Brooks Creek and Monger Creek.

label: Little's Mill
description: community in NW Richmond County on Little River. A post office operated there from 1850 to 1913.

label: Little's Mills
description: community in N Richmond County served by post office, 1850-1913.

label: Littledals Ferry
description: See Mount Gould.

label: Littlefield
description: community in S Pitt County. Alt. 57.

label: Littleton
description: town in E Warren County and NW Halifax County. Alt. 389. Inc. 1877 and named for Little Manor, which see. Person's Ordinary, the tavern owned by Thomas Person (1733-1800), Regulator, officer of the Continental Line, and state legislator, was located there and is shown on the Collet map, 1770. The tavern, which is still standing, was called Peterson Inn on the Price map, 1808. Littleton was mentioned by name in newspapers as early as 1823, and in 1831 a post office was est. there under the present name. The MacRae map, 1833, shows Littleton as an established community.

label: Littleton's Store
description: community in central Onslow County between Rocky Run and Mott Creek.

label: Littletown Township
description: NW Halifax County.

label: Liverman
description: See Newton.

label: Liverman Creek
description: rises in N Hertford County and flows SE into Meherrin River.

label: Livermans Mill Pond
description: W Hertford County, 1½ mi. long, drains into Potecasi Creek.

label: Liverpool
description: See Cornelius.

label: Livingston
description: See Acme.

label: Livingston Creek
description: rises in Green Swamp in N central Brunswick County and flows N across Columbus County, where it enters the Cape Fear River. Appears as Levingtons Creek on maps as early as 1844.

label: Livingswood Creek
description: See Carvers Creek.

label: Lizard Creek
description: rises in S Brunswick County, Va., and flows SE into NE Warren County, where it enters Lake Gaston.

label: Lizard Lick
description: crossroads community in E Wake County near town of Wendell. Named by a passing observer who saw many lizards sunning and "licking" themselves on a rail fence there.

label: Lizard Ridge
description: community in E central Caldwell County between Zacks Fork and Blair Fork.

label: Lizzards Creek
description: rises in Virginia and flows SE into N Halifax County, where it enters Roanoke River.

label: Lizzie
description: community in central Greene County; a post office in the late nineteenth century. Said to have been known first as Lizzie's Store for the old lady who kept a store there. Also called Lillie during the 1890s.

label: Lizzie's Store
description: See Lizzie.

label: Lizzy Mountain
description: central Jackson County between Dickson Creek and Trout Creek.

label: Lloyd Cove
description: S Macon County E of Green Cove on a tributary of Tessentee Creek.

label: Lloyd Crossroads
description: community in SE Hertford County.

label: Lloyds Meadows
description: an area of meadow land approx. 2 mi. long and 1 mi. wide in E Onslow County at the head of Horse Swamp.

label: Loafers Glory
description: community in central Mitchell County on Cane Creek. Named about 1890 by Jonathan Burleson because men delighted in whiling away their time on the porch of the local general store.

label: Loar Creek
description: See Little Creek.

label: Lobelia
description: community in SE Moore County.

label: Loch Lily
description: lake on Storys Creek, NW Person County. Formed prior to 1928 and known first as Barnetts Pond, later as Lake Chub, and finally by its present name. Covers 94 acres; max. depth 12 ft.

label: Locke Mills
description: See Forest Hill.

label: Locke Township
description: central Rowan County. Named for Gen. Matthew Locke (1730-1801), statesman and patriot, who lived there.

label: Locketts Island
description: a clay loam island approx. 1 mi. long in Roanoke River, W Northampton County.

label: Lockhart Mill
description: See Hoggard's Mill.

label: Lockport
description: community in SE Chatham County on Deep River W of Moncure. An earlier post office there was known as Lockville. Site of locks of Cape Fear and Deep River Navigation Co.; Progress Energy has a small power plant there that uses the lock canal as a mill race. At Ramsey's Mill there, following the Battle of Guilford Courthouse in 1781, the British general, Lord Cornwallis, built a bridge over Deep River.

label: Locks Creek
description: rises in E central Cumberland County and flows SW and S into Cape Fear River. See also Lords Creek.

label: Lockville
description: See Lockport.

label: Lockwoods Folly Inlet
description: between Holden Beach and Long Beach, through which Lockwoods Folly River flows into Long Bay of the Atlantic Ocean, S central Brunswick County. Appears on the Ogilby map, 1671. The name is derived from a man named Lockwood, who built a fine boat up Lockwoods Folly River but discovered that it was too large to float into the Atlantic through the inlet. He was forced to abandon his boat, and it eventually fell to pieces. Frequently in the seventeenth century, however, the word "folly" was used in the sense of the French folie (delight; favorite abode), and it formed a part of the name of English estates. Lockwoods Folly River, which see, has been described as the second-most-beautiful river in North Carolina, and it may have been the "delight" or "favorite abode" of an early settler named Lockwood. See also Longs Delight.

label: Lockwoods Folly River
description: is formed in central Brunswick County by the junction of Pinch Gut Creek and Red Run and flows W and S through Lockwoods Folly Inlet, which see, into Long Bay of the Atlantic Ocean.

label: Lockwoods Folly Township
description: S central Brunswick County.

label: Loco
description: community in N Onslow County served by post office, 1883-1903.

label: Locust
description: town in SW Stanly County. Inc. 1905, but long inactive in municipal affairs. A post office, Locust Level, opened 1869; discontinued 1919. Reestablished under present name, 1955. Named for large locust tree. Locust Level changed to Locust in 1894.

label: Locust Cove Gap
description: E Graham County on the headwaters of Stecoah Creek.

label: Locust Creek
description: rises in E Yancey County and flows SE into South Toe River.

label: Locust Gap
description: NE Buncombe County between Rough Hew Ridge and Forney Creek.

label: Locust Gap
description: on the Watauga County, N.C.-Johnson County, Tenn., line in the Stone Mountains.

label: Locust Grove
description: See Satterwhite.

label: Locust Hill
description: home of William Eaton, W Vance County. Built between 1740-43; served as an early religious center for the Episcopal Church, and the first Granville County Superior Court met there in 1746. Located approx. 3 mi. SW of Henderson.

label: Locust Hill Township
description: W central Caswell County.

label: Locust Knob
description: S central Avery County.

label: Locust Knob
description: NE Swain County on Heintooga Ridge in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, lat. 35°33'27" N., long. 83°12'08" W. Alt. 4,034.

label: Locust Level
description: See Locust.

label: Locust Licklog Gap
description: central Graham County in Cheoah Mountains between Hazanet Knob and Wauchecha Bald.

label: Locust Mountain, The
description: on Burke-McDowell county line.

label: Locust Ridge
description: W Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park extending S from Big Chestnut Bald.

label: Locust Ridge
description: E Yancey County between White-oak and Locust Creeks.

label: Locust Rough Mountain
description: N Yancey County at the SE end of Bailey Hill.

label: Locust Rough Ridge
description: W Yancey County between Simms Fork and Lickskillet Branch.

label: Locust Tree Branch
description: rises in W Macon County and flows SE into Wyah Creek.

label: Locust Tree Gap
description: W Macon County at the head of Locust Tree Branch.

label: Lodo
description: community in W Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1884-1903. Was located on the Charlotte and Atlanta Railroad at the Steele Creek station.

label: Loftins Crossroads
description: community in E Lenoir County. Named for the Loftin family, which settled there.

label: Loftis
description: See Cedar Mountain.

label: Log Hollow Branch
description: rises in N Transylvania County and flows SE into Big Bear Pen Branch.

label: Log Shoal
description: in the waters of Pamlico Sound, S Dare County, off the S part of Hatteras Island and E of Bird Islands.

label: Logan
description: community in N central Rutherford County. Named for a local storekeeper; the post office est. prior to 1882 but now discontinued was Logans Store.

label: Logan Creek
description: rises in S Jackson County and flows S into Horsepasture River.

label: Logans Store Township
description: E Rutherford County.

label: Loggerhead Inlet
description: from the Atlantic Ocean into Pamlico Sound through Hatteras Island N of the present community of Rodanthe, E Dare County. It opened prior to 1851 and closed in the late 1870s.

label: Loggy Branch
description: rises in SE Clay County and flows N into Right Fork.

label: Loggy Gap
description: mountain gap in central Avery County.

label: Loggy Knob
description: N Mitchell County between Bear-wallow Creek and Waterfall Branch.

label: Loggy Ridge
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, lat. 35°33' N., long. 83°32'08" W.

label: Lola
description: community on Cedar Island in NE Carteret County.

label: Lomax
description: community in N Wilkes County between East Prong Roaring River and Big Bugaboo Creek in rich agricultural area.

label: Lona Creek
description: rises in SE Beaufort County and flows N into South Creek.

label: London Bald
description: on the Cherokee-Macon county line.

label: Lone Bald Mountain
description: on the Haywood-Jackson county line. Originally Lone Balsam Mountain from the fact that a single large balsam tree stood on its crest. With the disappearance of the tree, the name was shortened to Lone Bald. Alt. 5,880.

label: Lone Balsam Mountain
description: See Lone Bald Mountain.

label: Lone Hickory
description: community in S Yadkin County near South Deep Creek.

label: Lone Island Ford
description: in central Rockingham County on Dan River at confluence of Dan River and Upper Hogan's Creek.

label: Lone Knob
description: N Madison County between Duckmill Branch and West Prong [Hickory Fork].

label: Lone Mountain
description: NE Rutherford County between the heads of First Broad River and Cane Creek. Alt. approx. 1,650.

label: Lone Oak Channel
description: between Beasley Bay and Currituck Sound, E Currituck County.

label: Lone Pine Ridge
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur extending SW from Thomas Ridge, lat. 35°31'15" N., long. 83°23'13" W.

label: Lonesome Mountain
description: N Madison County on Big Laurel Creek.

label: Lonesome Valley
description: See Henderson.

label: Long Acre
description: an elevated area of clay loam extending S from the head of Conaby Creek in W Washington County to Pungo Creek SE of the community of Pinetown in N central Beaufort County. The ridge is broken at the Tare-over in SW Washington County by Van Swamp. Appears on the Collet map, 1770. See also Tare-over.

label: Long Acre Township
description: N central Beaufort County. See also Acre.

label: Long Arm Mountain
description: NW Burke County. Alt. 4,350. Highest point in county.

label: Long Arm Ridge
description: S Yancey County, extends SE between Devils Den and Laurel Branch.

label: Long Bay
description: NE Carteret County between Cedar Island and Piney Island S of West Bay.

label: Long Beach
description: a section of outer beach in SE Brunswick County on the Atlantic Ocean W of Caswell Beach and E of Lockwoods Folly Inlet. Long Beach, a town there, was inc. 1955. A summer resort.

label: Long Bottoms
description: an area of approx. 50 acres of level old-field land between 2 mountains in SW Graham County on Snowbird Creek.

label: Long Branch
description: rises in N Clay County and flows SW into Tuni Creek.

label: Long Branch
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows SW into Beaverdam Creek.

label: Long Branch
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows SW into Tuckasegee River S of Hazel Hollow.

label: Long Branch
description: rises in S Madison County and flows S into Ivy River.

label: Long Branch
description: rises in SW Swain County and flows SW into Siles Branch approx. 1 mi. SE of community of Almond.

label: Long Branch
description: rises in central Wilkes County and flows SE into Mulberry Creek.

label: Long Branch
description: community in S Robeson County.

label: Long Brook
description: rises in S Catawba County and flows SW into Pinch Gut Creek.

label: Long Bunk
description: ridge in W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park extending SE from Mount Sterling Ridge, with its center near lat. 35°41'10" N., long. 83°06'40" W. Lies between Andy Branch and Dude Creek.

label: Long Cove
description: N Swain County between Bearwallow Ridge and Long Cove Ridge.

label: Long Cove Ridge
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park extending SW from Proctor Ridge, lat. 35°33'15" N., long. 83°36'25" W.

label: Long Creek
description: rises in NW Pender County and flows SE into Northeast Cape Fear River. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Long Creek
description: community in S Pender County on the stream of the same name. Alt. 50. Formerly known as Lillington, but the name was changed after the town of the same name was est. in Harnett County in 1859.

label: Long Creek Township
description: S central Pender County.

label: Long Creek Village
description: See Lillington.

label: Long Drive Ridge
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, extends SW from Thomas Ridge, lat. 35°33'25" N., long. 83°23'38" W.

label: Long Fork of Beaver Creek
description: rises in SW Wilkes County and flows E into Beaver Creek.

label: Long Gap
description: on the Buncombe-McDowell county line between Pot Cove Gap and Sourwood Gap.

label: Long Hill Township
description: NE Surry County.

label: Long Hollow
description: at the head of Left Fork [Cane Creek] in E Mitchell County.

label: Long Hope Creek
description: rises in NW Watauga County and flows N into SW Ashe County, where it enters Three Top Creek.

label: Long Hungry Ridge
description: NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park between Twentymile Creek and Moore Springs Branch, lat. 35°31'08" N., long. 83°50'57" W.

label: Long Island
description: high ground in E central Tyrrell County at the NE end of Hollow Ground Swamp.

label: Long Island
description: community in W Iredell County on Catawba River.

label: Long John Mountain
description: central Henderson County, extends from the NW limits of Hendersonville almost to French Broad River. Named for an early whiskey distiller.

label: Long Lake
description: natural lake in Croatan National Forest, S Craven County. Covers 1,100 acres; max. depth 4 to 5 ft. One of several lakes in Lakes Pocosin.

label: Long Level Mountain
description: E Mitchell County between Rube Green Top and Dellinger Hollow.

label: Long Levels
description: a rocky elevation approx. 1½ mi. long in E Haywood County between the head of Silvers Cove Creek and Long Levels Branch. Numerous other small unnamed streams rise there.

label: Long Levels Branch
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows SE into Bald Creek.

label: Long Mountain
description: W Madison County between John Taylor Branch and Turkey Cove Branch.

label: Long Mountain
description: NE Rutherford County between Molly Fork and the head of First Broad River.

label: Long Mountain Branch
description: rises in W Madison County near Long Mountain and flows E into Spring Creek.

label: Long Neck Point
description: peninsula extending from W Goose Creek Island into Goose Creek at the mouth of Upper Spring Creek, NE Pamlico County.

label: Long Pine
description: community in SW Anson County. Named for local Methodist church est. 1791-95. A post office operated there from 1869 to 1906.

label: Long Point
description: a long, narrow point of land extending off a tidal-marsh island adjacent to Piney Island in the waters of Coinjock Bay, central Currituck County. The Intracoastal Waterway separates the small island from the parent island (Piney). Gas for lighthouses was produced there.

label: Long Point
description: extends from the E mainland of Hyde County into Pamlico Sound.

label: Long Reach Sein Hole
description: a shallow place in Northeast Cape Fear River in central Duplin County suitable for seining.

label: Long Ridge
description: NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park extending SW from Hughs Ridge, lat. 35°37' N., long. 83°19' W.

label: Long Ridge
description: See Hoke.

label: Long Run
description: See Little Creek.

label: Long Shoal
description: in the waters of Pamlico Sound off the SE mainland of Dare County. The waters of Parched Corn Bay lie between it and the mainland.

label: Long Shoal Bay
description: the mouth of Long Shoal River in S Dare County.

label: Long Shoal Point
description: NE Tyrrell County, extends from the mainland into the mouth of Alligator River near the mouth of Alligator Creek.

label: Long Shoal River
description: rises in the S mainland of Dare County and flows SE along the Dare-Hyde county line into Long Shoal Bay in Pamlico Sound. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Long Shoals
description: community in S Buncombe County on French Broad River.

label: Long Shoals Mill Pond
description: S Lincoln County on South Fork Catawba River. Formed 1901 to provide power for cotton mill. Covers 125 acres; max. depth 12 ft.

label: Long Shore Branch
description: rises in E Ashe County and flows N into North Fork New River.

label: Long Town
description: See Gold Point.

label: Long's Store
description: community in N Union County.

label: Longarm Mountain
description: N Haywood County, extends NE from the head of Dogwood Flats Creek to the head of Stinking Camp Creek.

label: Longhurst
description: community in central Person County. Settled about 1890 and known first as Jalong for J. A. Long Sr., who est. a cotton mill there. Post office est. there in 1913; name changed to Longhurst in 1936.

label: Longleaf
description: community in NW Moore County served by post office, 1886-1906.

label: Longs Delight
description: appears on the Ogilby map, 1671, near the upper portion of the Cape Fear River. It was a name assigned probably for Capt. Anthony Long, member of an expedition led by Capt. William Hilton in 1663 to explore the lower Cape Fear region. See also Lockwoods Folly Inlet.

label: Longs Island
description: name applied on the Ogilby map, 1671, to the land now in NW New Hanover County between the Brunswick and Cape Fear Rivers N of Eagles Island. The peninsula was formerly an island when Fishing Creek flowed between the two rivers. See also Longs Delight.

label: Longs Store
description: community in N central Rutherford County.

label: Longshoals
description: community in S Lincoln County on South Fork Catawba River. Settled prior to 1901. Named for shoals in the river. Alt. 732.

label: Longtown
description: community in W Yadkin County on South Deep Creek.

label: Longview
description: community in SE Guilford County served by post office, 1891-1901.

label: Longwood
description: community in SW Brunswick County.

label: Longwood Park
description: community on the outskirts of Hamlet, S Richmond County. Known also as Northeast Hamlet.

label: Lonnie-Womble Creek
description: rises in N Lee County and flows SE into Cape Fear River.

label: Lookadoo Mountain
description: N Rutherford County between Carson Mountain and the head of Duncans Creek.

label: Looking Glass Creek
description: rises in N Transylvania County E of Bennett Gap on the Haywood-Transylvania county line and flows S into Davidson River. Located in Pisgah National Forest.

label: Looking Glass Falls
description: N Transylvania County on Looking Glass Creek about ½ mi. upstream from its mouth on Davidson River. The falls are 85 ft. high. Located in Pisgah National Forest.

label: Looking Glass Rock
description: N Transylvania County on the SE end of Seniard Ridge in Pisgah National Forest. Named because the huge rock face of the mountain glistens like a giant mirror.

label: Lookoff Gap
description: SE Buncombe County near Flat Top in the Swannanoa Mountains.

label: Lookout Bight
description: a bay in the waters of the Atlantic Ocean formed by the S end of Shackleford and Core Banks in SE Carteret County in connection with a stone breakwater started before World War I but never completed.

label: Lookout Bight Channel
description: See Barden Inlet.

label: Lookout Knob
description: SE Yancey County near the head of Roaring Fork.

label: Lookout Mountain
description: NE Buncombe County SE of Montreat.

label: Lookout Point
description: the S tip of Cedar Island extending into the waters of Core Sound in NE Carteret County.

label: Lookout Shoals Lake
description: on Catawba River, bounded by Iredell and Alexander Counties on the N and Catawba County on the s. Formed by a dam constructed in 1915 by Duke Power Co. Covers 1,270 acres. Source of hydroelectric power; fishing, boating, and camping. See also Island Ford.

label: Loose Mountain
description: W Caldwell County.

label: Loosen Swamp
description: See Corapeake Swamp.

label: Loosing Swamp
description: rises in N central Lenoir County and flows E for approx. 5 mi. into Stonyton Creek. The name appears in local records as early as 1744. It is believed to be derived from Lucerne, the Swiss city, and was given to the swamp by Swiss settlers who moved into the area from New Bern in the early eighteenth century. Also appears as Louson, Lousin, and Luzern.

label: Lorane
description: community in NW Rockingham County served by post office, 1898-1904.

label: Loray
description: community in W Iredell County. Grew up around Concord Church, est. 1775. Prior to 1903, when it was given its present name by Ora Sharpe, it was known as Fancy Hill post office and Iredell Station on the railroad.

label: Lords Creek
description: rises in S New Hanover County and flows W into the Cape Fear River. Named for the Lord family of Brunswick County.

label: Loretta
description: community in S Catawba County served by post office, 1893-1904.

label: Lost Bottom Creek
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, rises near lat. 35°40' N., long. 83°11'07" W., and flows SE into Palmer Creek.

label: Lost Cove
description: community in N Yancey County on Nolichucky River.

label: Lost Cove Branch
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows SE into Soco Creek.

label: Lost Cove Creek
description: in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, rises in NW Swain County and flows SE into Fontana Lake.

label: Lost Cove Ridge
description: S Yancey County, extends NE parallel to South Toe River between Little Lost Cove Creek and Big Lost Cove Creek.

label: Lost Knob
description: E Jackson County between Lynn Gap and Deep Gap.

label: Lost Ridge
description: N Watauga County, extends NE of Forest Grove Creek.

label: Lotta
description: community in N Hertford County served by post office, 1887-1909.

label: Lottie Creek
description: rises in NW Yancey County and flows SE into Bald Mountain Creek.

label: Loudermilk Ridge
description: W Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, lat. 35°28'33" N., long. 83°39'48" W.

label: Louie Camp Branch
description: rises in N Swain County and flows SE into Bradley Fork.

label: Louis Ray Knob
description: NE Buncombe County.

label: Louisburg
description: town and county seat, central Franklin County on Tar River. Alt. 280. Authorized to be laid out and named Lewisburg, 1779. Named for French king Louis XVI, to whose court Benjamin Franklin (for whom the county was named) was then American representative. Both spellings occur in early records, the present form soon becoming the only one used. Home of Louisburg College. Produces lumber and fabricated metals.

label: Louisburg Township
description: former township in central Franklin County, now township no. 10.

label: Louise
description: community in S Catawba County served by post office, 1890-1903.

label: Louse Island
description: NW Washington County in the mouth of Roanoke River. In a cluster of marshy islands, Louse Island is one of the smallest, approx. 2,000 ft. long and 200 ft. wide. It lies in the river between Rice Island and the mainland. See also Purchace Islands.

label: Lousin Swamp
description: See Loosing Swamp.

label: Louson Swamp
description: See Loosing Swamp.

label: Lousy Creek
description: rises in N central Wilkes County and flows S into Reddies River.

label: Louzanla Islands
description: area of fine sandy loam surrounded by swamp in E Washington County, SW of the community of Scuppernong.

label: Love Joy
description: community in N Montgomery County. Formerly known as Queen and had a post office by the name, 1888-1933. Often spelled Lovejoy.

label: Love Knob
description: W Watauga County at the N end of Ward Hollow.

label: Love Mountain
description: N Henderson County between Belmont Mountain and Clear Creek.

label: Love Valley
description: See Fox's Mountain.

label: Love's Level
description: community in N Union County.

label: Lovelace
description: community in SE Wilkes County between Little Hunting Creek and Hunting Creek. Named for Archibald Lovelace, prominent early-nineteenth-century resident.

label: Lovelace Creek
description: rises in S Alleghany County and flows S into Wilkes County, where it joins Basin Creek in forming Middle Prong Roaring River.

label: Lovelace Gap
description: N Buncombe County between Lovelace Knob and Jess Knob.

label: Lovelace Knob
description: N Buncombe County NW of Lovelace Gap. Alt. 4,315.

label: Lovelace Township
description: SE Wilkes County.

label: Lovelaces Creek
description: rises in E Rockingham County and flows NE into Wolf Island Creek. Named for local landowner, John Lovelace.

label: Lovelady
description: community in NW Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1894-1902.

label: Lovelady Township
description: E central Burke County.

label: Lovelady Township
description: SE Caldwell County. Named for a projected town, Lovelady, planned by Abner Summers before the Civil War. Lovelady post office, est. 1834, served a rural area, but it was moved in 1887 and the name was changed to Granite Falls, which see.

label: Loveland
description: See Willis Creek.

label: Lovers Leap
description: high point overlooking Hiwassee River in central Cherokee County.

label: Lovers Leap Ridge
description: N Madison County between Silvermine Branch and Pump Branch.

label: Loves Creek
description: rises in W Chatham County and flows E into Rocky River.

label: Loves Fish Lake
description: NE Surry County on Toms Creek. Covers 8 acres; max. depth 30 ft. Fishing. Named for J. B. Love, owner. Created 1949.

label: Loves Ford
description: N Union County in Rocky River.

label: Lovesfield
description: community in central Jackson County.

label: Lovett Island
description: a small island in SW Carteret County in Bogue Sound. Apparently named for the family whose surname appears in the old records as Lovett, Lovitt, and Lovick. Thomas Lovett or Lovick was an early landowner in the county.

label: Loviade Mountain
description: N Madison County between Wolf Branch and the head of Spillcorn Creek.

label: Lovill
description: community in central Watauga County on Brushy Fork. Named for Capt. Edward F. Lovill of Boone. Alt. 3,112.

label: Lovills Creek
description: approx. 18 mi. long, rises in Virginia and flows S into Surry County, where it enters Ararat River.

label: Low Falls
description: See Cullasaja River.

label: Low Gap
description: S Macon County between High Top and McDowell Mountain.

label: Low Gap
description: community in S central Yancey County.

label: Low Gap Branch
description: rises in NW Haywood County and flows SE into Big Creek.

label: Low Gap Hollow
description: S central Yancey County between Cane River and Bowlens Creek.

label: Low Gap Wildlife Pond
description: NW Surry County on North Fork Mitchell River. Covers 12 acres; max. depth 26 ft. Formed 1954 and owned by Low Gap Wildlife Club. Fishing.

label: Lowder
description: community in SE Stanly County served by post office, 1889-1907.

label: Lowe
description: community in central Robeson County served by post office, 1890-1949.

label: Lowe Mountain
description: W Randolph County between Taylors Creek and Caraway Creek. Named for Dan Lowe.

label: Lowell
description: town in central Gaston County. Settled about 1850 when Woodlawn Mill was built on South Fork River. First known as Wrights Station for William Wright, nearest resident.
