Inc. 1879 as Lowell because the construction of several textile mills there suggested the name of the textile center in Massachusetts. Alt. 770.

label: Lower Bartons Creek
description: rises in NW Wake County at community of Leesville and flows NE into Neuse River just E of mouth of Upper Bartons Creek, which see.

label: Lower Beaverdam Creek
description: rises in W Scotland County and flows SE into Gum Swamp Creek.

label: Lower Broad Creek
description: See Broad Creek.

label: Lower Campbellton
description: See Fayetteville.

label: Lower Coneto Township
description: former township in E central Edgecombe County, now township no. 2.

label: Lower Creek
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows SE into South Toe River.

label: Lower Creek Township
description: E central Caldwell County.

label: Lower Cullasaja Falls
description: SE Macon County NW of Highlands on Cullasaja River. Water falls a total of 310 ft. in ¼ mi. See also Cullasaja River.

label: Lower Double Branch
description: rises in W Haywood County and flows SE into Cataloochee Creek.

label: Lower Dowry Creek
description: rises in E Beaufort County and flows approx. 2 mi. SW into Pungo River.

label: Lower Falls
description: on the Graham County, N.C.-Monroe County, Tenn., line on Slickrock Creek. Water drops 1,200 ft.

label: Lower Ferry on New River
description: See Sneads Ferry.

label: Lower Fishing Creek
description: former township in NE Edgecombe County, now township no. 5.

label: Lower Fork Township
description: SE Burke County.

label: Lower Grassy Branch
description: rises in N Swain County and flows SW into Kephart Prong.

label: Lower Hominy Township
description: W central Buncombe County.

label: Lower Little River
description: See Little River.

label: Lower Norfolk County
description: See County of Norfolk.

label: Lower Pigeon
description: See Clyde.

label: Lower Sassafras Gap
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Noland Divide near the head of Bridge Creek, lat. 35°31'09" N., long. 83°27'15" W.

label: Lower Saura Town
description: former Indian village in NE Rockingham County on Dan River. Site approx. 2 mi. E of Leaksville. Probably occupied by Saura Indians by the middle of the seventeenth century and abandoned in early eighteenth century. Saura or Sara meant "a place of tall grass or weeds." See also Upper Saura Town; Town Creek.

label: Lower Second Creek
description: See South Second Creek.

label: Lower Spring Creek
description: rises in SE Beaufort County and flows E into Goose Creek.

label: Lower Town Creek Township
description: former township in S Edgecombe County, now township no. 10.

label: Lower Trail Ridge
description: SE Macon County between Devils Prong and Little Indian Creek.

label: Lowery Cove
description: N Buncombe County NW of Thurz Mountain.

label: Lowery Creek
description: rises in S Macon County between Devils Prong and Little Indian Creek.

label: Lowery Knob
description: central Macon County between Dobson Branch and Salser Branch.

label: Lowery Mill Creek
description: rises in N central Forsyth County and flows S and SW into Salem Lake.

label: Lowes Grove
description: community in S Durham County on W edge of Research Triangle Park.

label: Lowesville
description: community in SE Lincoln County. Named for Lowe family.

label: Lowgap
description: community in NW Surry County. Named for a nearby low gap in the Blue Ridge Mountains.

label: Lowing Bald
description: SW Swain County near the head of Big Creek.

label: Lowland
description: community on W Goose Creek Island, NE Pamlico County. Post office est. 1892. Processes seafood.

label: Loy
description: community in S Alamance County served by post office, 1879-1905. Known as Loy's Shop until 1895.

label: Loy's Store
description: See Loy.

label: Loyal Creek
description: See Riles Creek.

label: Loyd
description: community in SW Lincoln County served by post office, 1885-1906.

label: Luart
description: community in central Harnett County.

label: Lucama
description: town in S Wilson County. Alt. 140. Known earlier as Lucas's Crossroads. Name derived about 1883, according to tradition, by Josephus Daniels, then editor of a newspaper in Wilson, from the initial letters of the names of three friends: Lucy, Carrie, and Mary Borden. Post office est. 1884. Inc. 1889.

label: Lucas Creek
description: rises in SE Bladen County and flows SW into Cape Fear River.

label: Lucia
description: community in NE Gaston County. Oak Grove, home of James Johnston, officer in the Revolutionary War and member of the Provincial Congress, the N.C. legislature, and the Convention of 1788, is 2 mi. e. The house, built in 1782, still stands.

label: Lucile
description: community in E Wilkes County served by post office, 1887-1905.

label: Luck
description: community in SW Madison County on Spring Creek.

label: Lucknow
description: See Dunn.

label: Lucks Island
description: appears on the Comberford map, 1657, as the present Currituck Banks, E Currituck County. It was mentioned as the N limits of Carolina in the charter granted in 1663 to the 8 Lords Proprietors. See also Currituck Banks; Croatamung.

label: Lucy Branch
description: rises in S Lenoir County and flows NE into Spring Branch.

label: Luftee Gap
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains on Thomas Ridge, lat. 35°36'30" N., long. 83°26'23" W. Alt. approx. 5,200.

label: Luftee Knob
description: on Haywood-Swain county line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°41'34" N., long. 83°10'30" W., between Balsam Corner and Mount Sterling Ridge. Alt. 6,216.

label: Lukens
description: former community in N Carteret County. Abandoned following a severe storm in 1933. Church, houses, and school moved across South River to the communities of South River and Merrimon. Named for the Lukens family.

label: Lul
description: community in E Wake County.

label: Lumbee River
description: See Lumber River.

label: Lumber Bridge
description: across Cashie River in central Bertie County. Appears on the Collet map, 1770. The lumber bridge stood as late as 1833, and there is still a bridge across the river at the site.

label: Lumber Bridge
description: town in NE Robeson County. Alt. 192. Settled about 1776. Inc. 1891. Named for the wooden bridge across Little Marsh Swamp there.

label: Lumber Bridge Township
description: N Robeson County.

label: Lumber River
description: is formed on the Moore-Richmond county line where Naked Creek enters Drowning Creek. It flows SE along the Moore-Richmond and Hoke-Scotland county lines and for a short distance along the Robeson-Scotland county line. It then flows SE, E, and S across Robeson County to the Columbus-Robeson county line, which it follows into South Carolina. A short distance S of the state line, Lumber River enters Little Pee Dee River. It is approx. 125 mi. long. Sometimes known locally as Lumbee River.

label: Lumbershed Marsh
description: a tidal-marsh island in the W end of Bogue Sound, SE Onslow County, between Dudleys Island and Cedar Point. Named for a lumber shed built there during a lumber-industry boom.

label: Lumberton
description: See Leechville.

label: Lumberton Township
description: E central Robeson County.

label: Lump Mountain
description: N Rutherford County near the head of Chalk Creek.

label: Lumptown
description: community in central Madison County at the head of Revere Creek.

label: Lunday
description: community in W central Mitchell County on Toe River. Alt. 2,346.

label: Luneville
description: See Polkton.

label: Lupton
description: former community on the southernmost island in the Hog Island group, NE Carteret County. Named for Lupton family.

label: Lupton Lake
description: in S Jackson County NE of Cashiers on Horsepasture River. Formed in 1924; covers 15 acres and has max. depth of 40 ft. Named for owner. Used for fishing, swimming, and boating and as a power source. Open to the public.

label: Luster
description: community in NE Durham County served by post office, 1881-1903.

label: Luther Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County on Brushy Head Mountain and flows NE into Taylor Creek.

label: Luther Gap
description: SW Buncombe County between Luther Knob and Stony Knob.

label: Luther Knob
description: SW Buncombe County between Luther Gap and Dix Creek Gap.

label: Luthers
description: community in SW Buncombe County.

label: Luthersville
description: See China Grove.

label: Lutterloh
description: community in central Chatham County served by post office, 1894-1907.

label: Lutz Creek
description: a marsh creek in SW Currituck County, flows SW into North River.

label: Lyddies Creek
description: rises in NE Mitchell County and flows NW into Big Rock Creek.

label: Lydia
description: community in W Sampson County served by post office, 1891-1907.

label: Lydia Creek
description: rises in E Transylvania County and flows SE into French Broad River.

label: Lydie Mountain
description: N Buncombe County in the Elk Mountains.

label: Lyle Creek
description: rises in N Catawba County and flows SE into Catawba River. Appears on Collet map, 1770, as Liles Creek.

label: Lyle Knob
description: E Macon County between Mason Mountain and the head of Thompson Branch. Alt. approx. 3,600.

label: Lyman
description: community in SE Duplin County.

label: Lynch
description: community in SW Madison County.

label: Lynch Cove
description: SE Buncombe County E of Sheep Ridge.

label: Lynch Creek
description: rises in S Vance County and flows S into Franklin County, where it enters Tar River. Appears as Linches Creek on the Collet map, 1770. Said to have been named for a Major Lynch, who was sent to Bute County (now Franklin and Warren Counties) by Governor Tryon in 1768 to collect taxes but was hanged by a mob of Regulators on the bank of the stream.

label: Lynchburg
description: community in SW Lenoir County.

label: Lynches Creek
description: rises in S Union County and flows S into South Carolina, where it enters Pee Dee River. Appears on the Collet map, 1770. Also sometimes known as Lynches River.

label: Lynches River
description: See Lynches Creek.

label: Lynchs Corner
description: community in N Pasquotank County.

label: Lynchum Branch
description: See Lindscomb Branch.

label: Lyndover
description: community in NW Durham County.

label: Lynesville
description: See Townsville.

label: Lynn
description: town in S Polk County on Skyuka Creek. Inc. 1911, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Named for Lynn McAboy, son of Dr. L. R. McAboy, an early settler. Alt. 1,500.

label: Lynn Branch
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows NE into Straight Fork [Raven Fork].

label: Lynn Cove
description: SE Swain County, extends N from Shepherd Bald to Yalaka Creek.

label: Lynn Gap
description: on the McDowell-Mitchell county line.

label: Lynn Mountain
description: SW Catawba County. Alt. approx. 1,300. Believed to have been named for a pioneer settler. Sometimes also spelled Linn.

label: Lynn's Branch
description: rises in NW Wake County and flows SE into Sycamore Creek.

label: Lyon Branch
description: rises in N Clay County and flows SW into Tusquitee Creek.

label: Lyon Creek
description: See Lyon Swamp Canal.

label: Lyon Swamp
description: SE Bladen County E of Cape Fear River.

label: Lyon Swamp Canal
description: SE Bladen County, drains SE from Lyon Swamp into SW Pender County, where it is called Lyon Creek before emptying into Lyon Thorofare.

label: Lyon Thorofare
description: SW Pender County, connects Cape Fear River with Black River approx. 4 mi. above their natural junction. Approx. 3 mi. long.

label: Lyons
description: See Haywood.

label: Lyons Creek
description: rises in N Franklin County and flows NE into Devil's Cradle Creek.

label: Lyons Landing
description: community in NW Bladen County served by post office, 1850-1903.

label: Lytchs Millpond
description: S Scotland County on Gum Swamp Creek. Formed 1870. Covers 325 acres; max. depth 12 ft.

label: Lytle Cove
description: the valley through which Stepp Branch flows in SE Buncombe County.

label: Mabel
description: community in N Watauga County on Cove Creek.

label: Mabry
description: community in central Stanly County served by post office, 1889-1906.

label: MacArthur
description: See Japan.

label: Macay's Mill
description: an early Rowan County landmark. It was used as a recruiting place for soldiers during the Revolutionary War as well as a point of discharge. It was owned for many years by Judge Spruce Macay, who taught Andrew Jackson law in Salisbury. The mill, on Grants Creek in the SE section of the county, was built by Thomas Frohock and later sold to Macay. The mill was used until World War I, although the millpond was drained about 1870 because of fever epidemics. Appears on the Collet map, 1770, as Frohock Mill.

label: Macclesfield
description: town in S Edgecombe County. Inc. 1901 and named for Macclesfield, England, town of origin of the ancestors of Henry Clark Bridgers, founder of East Carolina Railroad. Alt. 100.

label: Mace Branch
description: rises in N McDowell County on the S slope of Stony Knob and flows SE about 1½ mi. into Rag Creek.

label: Macedonia
description: See Basnight.

label: Machapounga River
description: See Pungo River.

label: Machapunga Bluff
description: See Bluff Point.

label: Machapunga, Machapungo
description: See Pungo.

label: Machelhe Island
description: marsh island about ½ mi. long in the Pasquotank River, W Camden County opposite Elizabeth City. Probably named for the Macheel family, living in the area as early as 1723.

label: Machine Branch
description: rises in NW Cumberland County and flows N into Little River.

label: Machine Creek
description: rises in E central Polk County and flows SE into Whiteoak Creek.

label: Machpelah
description: community in SE Lincoln County served by post office, 1881-1908.

label: Mack
description: community in central Rutherford County served by post office, 1889-1907.

label: Mack Gap
description: W Jackson County on the head of Sutton Branch.

label: Mack Hill Gap
description: N Yancey County on McKinney Branch.

label: Mack Perry Pond
description: on Fowlers Creek, NE Wake County. Covers 38 acres; max. depth 20 ft. Used for fishing and irrigation.

label: Mack Williams Branch
description: rises in W Yancey County and flows SE into Jacks Creek.

label: Mackay Island
description: a portion of SW Knotts Island, NE Currituck County. It is separated from Knotts Island by Indian Creek and Back Creek, an inlet of North Landing River. Approx. 2 mi. long and 2 mi. wide. Appears as Notts or Mackys Island on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Mackerel Mountain
description: on the Henderson County, N.C.-Greenville County, S.C., line. Alt. 3,031.

label: Mackey Mountain
description: W McDowell County. Alt. 3,994.

label: Mackeys
description: community in N Washington County W of the mouth of Kendricks Creek on Albemarle Sound. Alt. 8. Settled about 1765 near the S terminus of Mackeys Ferry, which see, named for Col. William Mackey, local landowner. Post office est. 1856 as Mackeys Ferry; name changed to Mackeys in 1913. Mackeys Ferry appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Mackeys Creek
description: See Kendricks Creek.

label: Mackeys Ferry
description: formerly located at the present community of Mackeys in N Washington County on Kendricks Creek. Shown as T. Bells Ferry on the Moseley map, 1733; purchased from Bell by Col. William Mackey in 1735; was in continuous operation until 1938. At the time it was dismantled, the ferry operated between Edenton in S Chowan County and the S shore of Albemarle Sound immediately N of Pleasant Grove in N Washington County.

label: Macks
description: community in W Johnston County.

label: Maco
description: community in NE Brunswick County. Named Farmers Turnout in 1867, but about 1890 intended to be named Maraco for the MacRae Co., which developed land in the vicinity. The present name, easier to pronounce, came into use instead. Alt. 49. Site of the "Maco Light," an unidentified phenomenon that has been recurring frequently since a train wreck there in 1867. Traditionally, the light is said to be the lantern of Joe Baldwin, a railroad conductor who was killed while attempting to prevent the wreck. President Grover Cleveland purportedly saw the light in 1889 and asked for an explanation.

label: Macon
description: town in N central Warren County on heads of Sixpound Creek and Walkers Creek. Alt. 285. Settled in early 1800s and shown as Chestnut Crossroads on the MacRae map, 1833. Post office of Macon est. in 1839. Inc. 1889; named for Nathaniel Macon (1758-1837), speaker of the U. S. House of Representatives, member of Congress from 1815 to 1828, and president of N.C. Constitutional Convention, 1835. A Civil War training camp, Camp Macon, was located there.

label: Macon County
description: was formed in 1828 from Haywood County. Located in the W section of the state, it is bounded by the state of Georgia and by Clay, Cherokee, Swain, and Jackson Counties. It was named for Nathaniel Macon (1758-1837), speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives and U.S. senator. Area: 520 sq. mi. County seat: Franklin, with an elevation of 2,113 ft. Townships are Burningtown, Cartoogechaye, Cowee, Ellijay, Flats, Franklin, Highlands, Millshoal, Nantahala, Smiths Bridge, and Sugar Rock. Produces corn, dairy products, livestock, hogs, textiles, lumber, heavy equipment, hay, honey, plastics, and mica.

label: Mad Inlet
description: tidal waterway between Bald Beach and Bird Island in SW Brunswick County.

label: Madcap Branch
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows NW into Bunches Creek.

label: Madge
description: community in SE Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1892-1903.

label: Madison
description: town in W Rockingham County at the junction of Mayo and Dan Rivers. Alt. 577. Chartered in 1815, first sale of lots 1818; inc. 1851. Named for President James Madison (1751-1836).

label: Madison County
description: was formed in 1851 from Buncombe and Yancey Counties. Located in the W section of the state, it is bounded by Yancey, Buncombe, and Haywood Counties and the state of Tennessee. It was named for James Madison (1751-1836), fourth president of the United States. Area: 456 sq. mi. County seat: Marshall, with an elevation of 1,650 ft. Townships, now numbered 1 to 16, were formerly Marshall, Shelton Laurel, Bull Creek, Middle Fork of Ivy, West Fork of Ivy, Sandy Mush, Little Pine Creek, Spring Creek, Hot Springs, Big Laurel, Upper Laurel, Big Pine Creek, Meadow Fork of Spring Creek, Grapevine, Mars Hill, and Foster Creek. Produces tobacco, corn, dairy products, livestock, hay, nursery products, pumpkins, tomatoes, textiles, and electronics.

label: Madison Township
description: W Rockingham County.

label: Magazine Branch
description: rises in central Cherokee County and flows SW and SE into Valley River.

label: Maggie Valley
description: resort center in W Haywood County. Named when the first post office was est. in 1909 for Maggie Mae Setzer (later Mrs. Ira Pylant of Hendersonville), daughter of the postmaster. Alt. 3,019.

label: Maggot Ridge
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, extends N from Buck Knob on Cataloochee Divide, center near lat. 35°33'45" N., long. 83°08'32" W. For origin of the name, see Maggot Spring Gap.

label: Maggot Spring Gap
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°33'08" N., long. 83°07'55" W. Named for a nearby spring used by cattle rangers that had in it the larvae of an insect that resembled a maggot.

label: Magness Creek
description: rises in E Cleveland County and flows s, nw, and S into First Broad River.

label: Magnetic City
description: See Buladean.

label: Magnolia
description: old Pettigrew family plantation in W Tyrrell County on shores of Lake Phelps. Built in 1830 by Ebenezer Pettigrew. Birthplace of Confederate general J. J. Pettigrew. Now part of Pettigrew State Park. Plantation, around house named Bonarva, covered approx. 2,000 acres.

label: Magnolia Canal
description: See Bonarva Canal.

label: Magnolia Township
description: SW Duplin County.

label: Magnus
description: community in NE Person County served by post office, 1899-1904.

label: Maho Creek
description: rises in E Person County and flows N into Virginia, where it enters Hyco River. Named Mayo River in 1728 by William Byrd and his "dividing line" survey party for William Mayo, one of the surveyors.

label: Mahogany Knob
description: See White Hurricane Knob.

label: Mahogany Rock
description: summer resort in S Alleghany County.

label: Maiden
description: town in S central Catawba County. Alt. 891. Inc. 1883. Named for Maiden Creek, on which it is located. Produces furniture and textiles.

label: Maiden Cane Creek
description: rises in W Wilkes County and flows NE into Reddies River.

label: Maiden Creek
description: rises in S Catawba County and flows approx. 7 mi. SW into Clark Creek. Named for profusion of maidencane (Poaceae hemitomon) found growing in the bottomland nearby when first seen by early settlers.

label: Maiden Point
description: extends into Jones Bay, NE Pamlico County. Named because the shoreline on maps resembles a female breast.

label: Maidenhair Falls
description: S Jackson County on Trays Island Creek ½ mi. N of Fairfield Lake. Alt. 3,640.

label: Maidenhair Falls
description: SE Transylvania County on Hogshead Creek 2 mi. SE of Brevard. Water falls 50 ft.

label: Main Canal
description: extends NW from N central Washington County, where it receives the waters drained from East Dismal Swamp by a system of canals and channels them into Kendricks Creek.

label: Main Channel
description: in Bogue Sound SW Carteret County leading S into Bogue Inlet.

label: Main Creek
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows NW into Reems Creek.

label: Maine
description: See Oak Grove.

label: Maitland
description: community in central Sampson County served by post office, 1887-1904.

label: Majolica
description: community in N central Rowan County on Southern Railway. Alt. 713. It is said that while V. C. McBee, railroad superintendent, was considering a name for the termination of a siding there, his clerk, T. C. McNeely, brought in a green majolica pot filled with drinking water. McNeely suggested that the water be used for christening and that the place be named for the pot.

label: Major Hills
description: mountain in S Alamance County.

label: Makatoka
description: community in NW Brunswick County.

label: Makleyville
description: community in SW Hyde County on Pungo River near the mouth of Slade Creek.

label: Malee
description: community in W Richmond County served by post office, 1881-1906.

label: Mall Creek
description: rises in E Washington County, receives drainage from Enoch Canal, and flows NE into Scuppernong River. First shown on the MacRae map, 1833.

label: Mallard
description: community in E Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1898-1903.

label: Mallard Creek
description: See Town Creek.

label: Mallard Creek Township
description: former township in E central Mecklenburg County, now township no. 8.

label: Malloby's Branch
description: rises in central Wake County and flows SE into Beaverdam Creek.

label: Mallory Creek
description: rises in E Brunswick County and flows E into Cape Fear River.

label: Malloy
description: community in central Rockingham County served by post office, 1898-1903.

label: Malloys Pond
description: See Richmond Millpond.

label: Malmo
description: community in NE Brunswick County.

label: Malones Creek
description: rises in W Warren County and flows NW into Blue Mud Creek.

label: Maltby
description: community in central Cherokee County between the junction of Cindy Branch and Dick Branch. Alt. 1,611.

label: Mamers
description: community in W Harnett County. A short distance SE was the pre-Civil War community and post office of Fishcreek, which operated from 1914 to 1954. A muster ground for the county militia was there.

label: Mamie
description: farming community in S Currituck County on Albemarle Sound. Post office est. there in 1904 and named for Mamie Crank.

label: Manchester
description: town in NW Cumberland County on Little River. Inc. 1895, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Adjacent to Spring Lake.

label: Manchester Township
description: NW Cumberland County.

label: Maney Branch
description: rises in N Buncombe County near Paint Fork Gap and flows SW into Reems Creek.

label: Maney Gap
description: on the Madison-Yancey county line near the head of Indian Creek. Alt. 3,848.

label: Maney's Ferry
description: See Riddicksville.

label: Maneys Neck Township
description: N Hertford County.

label: Mangum
description: community in NW Richmond County.

label: Mangum Store
description: community in NE Durham County on Dry Creek about 2 mi. N of Lake Michie. Named for Willie Person Mangum, U.S. senator and area landowner.

label: Mangum Township
description: N Durham County.

label: Manly
description: community in S Moore County. Inc. 1879 as Manly Station and in 1899 as Manly; no town government was est., and the charter was repealed in 1955. Named for Charles Manly (1795-1871), governor of North Carolina, 1849-51. Alt. 444.

label: Manly Mill Creek
description: See Jones Creek.

label: Manly Station
description: See Manly.

label: Mann Point
description: on the W shore of N Bodie Island in Roanoke Sound between Kill Devil Hills and Nags Head, E Dare County.

label: Manndale
description: community in SW Orange County.

label: Manning
description: community in W Rowan County served by post office, 1887-1906.

label: Mannings Township
description: W Nash County.

label: Manns Harbor
description: community on the E shore of the mainland, central Dare County on Croatan Sound. Settled in the early nineteenth century. Known earlier as Croatan. Named for a German sea captain, Charles Mann, who harbored there during a fierce storm. He later returned, with his wife and 9 children, to live. The Indian village of Dasemunkepeuc (Algonquian word meaning "where there is an extended land surface separated by water") was located there and is shown on the White maps, 1585 and 1590, and on the Velasco map, 1611. Alt. 10.

label: Manor Branch
description: rises in NW Buncombe County near Newfound Mountain and flows NE into Sandy Mush Creek.

label: Mansfield
description: community in S Carteret County W of Morehead City.

label: Manson
description: town in W Warren County near the head of Rocky Creek. Inc. 1874, but not now active in municipal affairs. Alt. 424. First known as Cheathamville; name changed to Branchville in 1858 because the Roanoke Valley Railway branch joined the Raleigh and Gaston Railroad there. Name changed to Manson in 1859 in honor of Dr. O. F. Manson (1822-88), local physician and later a Confederate surgeon.

label: Manteo
description: town and county seat, on N Roanoke Island, E Dare County. Settled 1865. Inc. 1899. Named for the Indian chief Manteo, taken to England in 1584 by Philip Amadas and Arthur Barlowe in the service of Walter Raleigh. Alt. 12. The Lost Colony, an outdoor drama by Paul Green, has been presented nearby each summer since 1937.

label: Manus
description: community in N Richmond County.

label: Maple
description: community in N central Washington County.

label: Maple Bald Creek
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows SE into Rock Creek.

label: Maple Branch
description: rises in S Warren County and flows SE into Fishing Creek.

label: Maple Camp Bald
description: S Yancey County on the head of Maple Bald Creek. Alt. 5,275.

label: Maple Camp Ridge
description: S Yancey County between Middle Creek and Maple Creek.

label: Maple Creek
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows E in an arc into Rock Creek.

label: Maple Cypress
description: community in NW Craven County served by post office, 1873-1904. Named for maple tree growing from cypress knee in Neuse River.

label: Maple Fork Branch
description: rises in NE Northampton County and flows SE and N to join a small unnamed stream that rises in Hertford County to form Turkey Creek.

label: Maple Gap
description: S Transylvania County in Blue Ridge Mountains near the head of Abrams Branch.

label: Maple Grove
description: community in NW Caldwell County near Staircase Mountain.

label: Maple Hill
description: community in NE Pender County on Moores Creek. Alt. 50. Named by a member of the Ashe family for the trees growing at the site. A post office as early as 1879. Angola, formerly considered to be a separate community (and with a post office as early as 1882), about 1½ mi. NW, is now considered to be within the Maple Hill community.

label: Maple Run
description: rises in N Duplin County and flows NE into Goshen Swamp.

label: Maple Spring
description: See Mapleville.

label: Maple Spring Branch
description: rises in E Union County and flows SE into Beaverdam Creek.

label: Maple Spring Gap
description: on the Haywood-Madison county line. Alt. 4,050.

label: Maple Springs
description: community in W Wilkes County on South Prong Lewis Fork Creek.

label: Maple Swamp
description: rises in N Edgecombe County and flows SE into Fishing Creek.

label: Maple Swamp Creek
description: rises in E central Burke County and flows SE into Laurel Creek.

label: Mapleton
description: town in N Hertford County. Inc. 1901, but long inactive in municipal affairs.

label: Mapleville
description: community in central Franklin County. Alt. 350. Settled about 1877. Known first as Maple Spring because a maple tree grew by the spring that furnished water for a church there.

label: Maplewood
description: community in E Watauga County.

label: Maraco
description: See Maco.

label: Marasanico
description: apparently an Indian village, appears on the White map, 1585, located in what is now S Craven County on the Neuse River.

label: Marathon
description: former community in N New Hanover County near Castle Hayne. An agricultural colony of Greek farmers was est. there by Hugh MacRae of Wilmington in the early twentieth century, but it was not successful.

label: Maraton
description: village of the Moratuc Indian tribe, is shown on the Smith map, 1624, as being on the Chowan River in present E Chowan County downstream from Rockyhock Creek. The Comberford map, 1657, places the village farther upstream.

label: Marble
description: community in central Cherokee County. Inc. 1911; charter revoked June 22, 1939. Alt. 1,686. Named for deposits of marble in the vicinity.

label: Marble Creek
description: rises in central Cherokee County and flows SE into Valley River.

label: Marbleyard Ridge
description: SE Clay County between Hogan Branch and Little Buck Creek.

label: Marce
description: community in Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1894-95.

label: Marcus
description: former community in W Swain County on Tuckasegee River. Site now under the waters of Fontana Lake.

label: Mare Branch
description: rises in W central Wilson County and flows NE into Contentnea Creek.

label: Maready
description: community in SE Duplin County.

label: Marg Mountain
description: S Haywood County between Camp Branch and Browning Branch.

label: Margaret
description: community in E Franklin County. Named by C. P. Harris for his daughter. A post office prior to 1909.

label: Margaret Peak
description: on the McDowell-Rutherford county line. Alt. 2,500.

label: Margaretsville
description: town in NE Northampton County. Post office est. 1836. Chartered 1885 as Margarettsville, but charter repealed 1891. Rechartered as Margaretsville in 1895. Named for Mrs. Margaret Ridley, an early resident. Alt. 54. The railroad name is Margaret.

label: Margrace
description: community in SE Cleveland County.

label: Maria Creek
description: rises in NE Carteret County and flows SE into Core Sound.

label: Marianna Falls
description: See Dutch Creek Falls.

label: Maribel
description: community in N Pamlico County on Chapel Creek, known originally as Shoofly. At the establishment of a post office in 1883, long since discontinued, it was named by postmaster Fentress for his sweetheart in Georgia, a girl named Mary Belle.

label: Marietta
description: town in S Robeson County. Alt. 125. Settled about 1898. Inc 1911. Formerly known as Affinity until renamed by Augustus Marriel, a promoter of the Raleigh and Charleston Railroad, whose line formerly ran through the town.

label: Marietta Township
description: S Robeson County.

label: Marines
description: former community in S Onslow County on New River. A post office est. in 1885. Abandoned 1941 with the development of Camp Lejeune.

label: Marion
description: city and county seat, central McDowell County. Alt. 1,437. Inc. 1844. Named for Gen. Francis Marion (1732?-95), Revolutionary War leader. East Marion and West Marion are adjacent unincorporated communities. Produces textiles, hosiery, furniture, and paper boxes.

label: Marion Township
description: W central McDowell County.

label: Mariposa
description: community in S Lincoln County on Leepers Creek. See also Heldermans.

label: Mark Creek
description: See Morgan Creek.

label: Mark Pine Bay
description: a muck-filled bay in central Columbus County.

label: Markee's Creek
description: See Stewart's Town.

label: Marks Creek
description: rises in E Wake County and flows S into Johnston County, where it enters Neuse River.

label: Marks Creek Township
description: E Wake County.

label: Marks Knob
description: NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Dashoga Ridge. Lat. 35°40'47" N., long. 83°14'30" W. Alt. 6,140.

label: Marks Pond
description: approx. ½ mi. long, SE Harnett County on Buffalo Creek.

label: Marl Branch
description: rises in W Hertford County and flows S into Potecasi Creek.

label: Marl Pits
description: on the head of Stewarts Creek in W Duplin County. Abounds in fossils, sharks’ teeth, and fossilized whalebones.

label: Marlboro
description: town in W Pitt County immediately S of Farmville. Inc. 1875, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Alt. 82.

label: Marler
description: community in W Yadkin County.

label: Marley's Ford
description: former ford through Yadkin River W Wilkes County near the mouth of Stony Fork Creek. The site is now under the waters of W. Kerr Scott Reservoir.

label: Marleys Mill
description: community in W Chatham County.

label: Marlins Creek
description: See Sloans Creek.

label: Marlowe Creek
description: rises in central Person County in the city of Roxboro and flows N into Hyco River.

label: Marlville
description: See East Arcadia.

label: Marmaduke
description: community in S Warren County N of Fishing Creek. A post office was est. there in 1893 but was discontinued in 1930.

label: Marr Branch
description: rises in S Swain County and flows SE into Brush Creek.

label: Marr Gap
description: central Cherokee County between Bates Creek and Hiwassee River.

label: Marrow
description: community in N Randolph County.

label: Marrow Bone River
description: See Stony Creek.

label: Marrow Branch
description: rises in central Haywood County and flows NE into Pigeon River.

label: Mars Hill
description: town in E Madison County on Gabriels Creek. Inc. 1893; named for a hill in Athens, Greece. Alt. 2,300. Mars Hill College, est. 1856, is there.

label: Mars Hill Township
description: former township in SE Madison County, now township no. 15.

label: Marsden
description: See Chocowinity.

label: Marsden Creek
description: rises in central Henderson County and flows NW into Mill Pond Creek.

label: Marsh
description: community in S Davidson County served by post office, 1883-1905.

label: Marsh Bay
description: a loam-filled bay in S Columbus County.

label: Marsh Branch
description: rises in central Duplin County and flows E into Grove Creek.

label: Marsh Creek
description: rises in central Wake County and flows SE into Crabtree Creek.

label: Marsh Island
description: a peninsula extending from the S mainland of Hyde County into Pamlico Sound between Swanquarter Bay and Juniper Bay. See also Abigails Islands.

label: Marsh Point
description: extends from the S mainland of Hyde County into Rose Bay.

label: Marsh Swamp
description: rises in NW Wilson County and flows SE into Contentnea Creek.

label: Marsh Township
description: SW Surry County.

label: Marshall
description: town and county seat, S Madison County on French Broad River. Authorized to be est. 1852; site still in dispute, 1855. Inc. 1863 and named for John Marshall (1755-1835), chief justice of the U.S. Supreme Court. Alt. 1,650. Post office est. there 1857, before the establishment of the county seat, was named Lapland. For a period before Marshall was laid, Jewel Hill (or Duel Hill), at present-day Walnut, was the seat of government. County court was held at Jewel Hill as late as the fall of 1859.

label: Marshall Ridge
description: extends SE from Turkey Knob to Clear Creek in N Henderson County.

label: Marshall Tavern
description: See Ridgeway.

label: Marshall Township
description: former township in S central Madison County, now township no. 1.

label: Marshallberg
description: community on the mainland of SE Carteret County approx. 8 mi. E of town of Beaufort. Settled about 1800. Named by Matthew Marshall, a rural mail carrier, for himself. Alt. 5. Formerly known as Deep Hole Point.

label: Marshallberg Township
description: S central Carteret County.

label: Marshbourns Pond
description: in E Wake County on Buffalo Creek.

label: Marshville
description: town in E Union County. Settled in 1874. Originally known as Beaverdam for nearby Beaverdam Creek, and at the time centered around a depot on the Central Carolina Railroad. Inc. 1877 as Griffinsville; name changed to Marshville in 1897 for the Marsh family, which donated land for a school and church. Produces processed poultry, asbestos products, boxes, and staves.

label: Marshville Township
description: E Union County.

label: Marston
description: community in E Richmond County. Est. 1913. Named for Edgar L. Marston of New York, developer of local real estate. Alt. 431.

label: Martha
description: community and former post office, W Randolph County. Named for first postmaster, Martha Ingram.

label: Martin
description: community in central Yadkin County served by post office, 1887-1909.

label: Martin Bay
description: E Pitt County in Tar River.

label: Martin Branch
description: rises in N Madison County and flows SW into Little Laurel Creek.

label: Martin Branch
description: rises in N McDowell County and flows SE approx. 1½ mi. into North Fork [Catawba River] near North Cove.

label: Martin County
description: was formed in 1774 from Halifax and Tyrrell Counties. Located in the E section of the state, it is bounded by Washington, Beaufort, Pitt, Edgecombe, Halifax, and Bertie Counties. It was named for Josiah Martin (1737-86), last royal governor of North Carolina. The name very likely would have been changed, as were those of other counties named for royal governors, had it not been for the popularity of Alexander Martin, governor in 1782-85 and 1789-92. Area: 482 sq. mi. County seat: Williamston, with an elevation of 60 ft. Townships are Beargrass, Cross Roads, Goose Nest, Griffins, Hamilton, Jamesville, Poplar Point, Robersonville, Williams, and Williamston. Produces tobacco, peanuts, corn, cotton, Irish potatoes, hogs, livestock, poultry, apparel, canned goods, heavy equipment, chemicals, lumber, paper, and textiles.

label: Martin Cove
description: S Swain County on Yalaka Creek.

label: Martin Creek
description: rises in NW Yadkin County and flows NW into Yadkin River.

label: Martin Knob
description: S Watauga County between Green Mountain Branch and Cannon Branch.

label: Martin Mill Creek
description: rises in N central Forsyth County and flows S and SW to enter Lowery Mill Creek approx. 1 mi. before it flows into Salem Lake.

label: Martin Ridge
description: W Avery County.

label: Martin's Crossroads
description: See Conway.

label: Martin's Store
description: See Martins Mill.

label: Martindale
description: community in W Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1836-1902.

label: Martins Gap
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Sunkota Ridge, lat. 35°31'10" N., long. 83°24'30" W.

label: Martins Mill
description: community on West Fork Little River in NE Montgomery County. A post office, Martin's Store, existed there as early as 1828. Named for Farquhardt Martin, who had a store there, 1822-60. Dam at the mill site was washed out in 1927.

label: Martins Point
description: a projection in the S North Banks, NE Dare County, extending into Currituck Sound. Located at the mouth of Jean Guite Creek.

label: Martins Point Creek
description: See Jean Guite Creek.

label: Martinsborough
description: See Greenville.

label: Martinville
description: former town and county seat, central Guilford County. Est. 1774 as Guilford Courthouse, which see, and chartered as Martinville, 1785. Named for Governor Alexander Martin (1740-1807). Abandoned about 1808 with the establishment of Greensboro as county seat.

label: Marty's Ridge
description: NW Burke County. Alt. 3,625.

label: Marvin
description: See Point Harbor.

label: Mary Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SW into Stewart Branch.

label: Mary Gap
description: E Madison County at the head of Gabriels Creek.

label: Mary Gray Knob
description: between Rock Hollow Branch and Rogers Cove Creek in E Haywood County.

label: Mary Knob
description: on the Haywood-Madison county line.

label: Mary Sander Creek
description: a tidal creek in S Currituck County N of Poplar Branch Bay.

label: Mary Simmons Ridge
description: E Watauga County, extends S between Boone Camp Branch and East Ridge.

label: Mary's Creek
description: rises in S Alamance County in the foothills of the Cane Creek Mountains and flows E into Haw River.

label: Marys Branch
description: rises in W Avery County and flows E into Roaring Creek.

label: Marys Gap
description: E Haywood County between Rice Cove and Sassafras Knob.

label: Masa Knob
description: peak on Swain County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park about halfway between Mount Kephart and Charlies Bunion, lat. 35°38'10" N., long. 83°22'40" W. Alt. over 6,000. Named for George Masa (d. 1933), Japanese photographer whose extensive knowledge of the area, acquired through 18 years’ association with it, was recognized by his appointment as a member of the Nomenclature Committee for the first map of the park.

label: Mascomenge
description: a village of the Weapemeoc Indians; shown on the White map, 1585, as being on what is now the S tip of Chowan County on Albemarle Sound.

label: Masequetuc
description: village of the Weapemeoc tribe probably situated on what is now the SE tip of Pasquotank County. Shown on the White map, 1585. Variant spelling: Masquetuc.

label: Mashawatoc
description: See Mashoes.

label: Mashburn Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows N into Cullasaja River.

label: Mashoes
description: community on the NE shore of the mainland of Dare County on Albemarle Sound. Legend relates that it is named for Peter Michieux or Mashows who, with his family, was shipwrecked on a nearby beach in the eighteenth century. He was washed ashore with his wife and child clinging to him. When he regained consciousness, he found both were dead. The shock of the experience shattered his reason, and 20 years later he sat with his back to a cypress tree and died. His skeleton and a board on which he had rudely carved the account of his tragic experience were discovered years later. The name, in spite of the legend, may be of Indian origin; John White's map, 1585, shows an Indian village named Mashawatoc on the E Virginia shore.

label: Mason Bay
description: N Pamlico County, in Bay River.

label: Mason Branch
description: rises in SE Swain County on Una Mountain and flows SW into Yalaka Creek.

label: Mason Creek
description: rises in W central Transylvania County and flows SE into Cherryfield Creek.

label: Mason Inlet
description: NE New Hanover County between Moore Inlet on the S and Rich Inlet on the n. The waters of Topsail Sound enter the Atlantic Ocean through the inlet. Appears as Barren Inlet on the Moseley map, 1733, and on other maps as late as 1909; and as Queen Inlet during the period 1906-36.

label: Mason Knob
description: N Cherokee County.

label: Mason Mountain
description: N Macon County between Mason Branch and Cowee Creek.

label: Masonboro
description: community in E New Hanover County on Masonboro Sound. Appears on the Collet map, 1770. Named because members of the order of Masons in the late eighteenth century built houses there. A popular resort in the early and middle nineteenth century.

label: Masonboro Inlet
description: E New Hanover County opposite the mouth of Hewlets Creek between the waters of Middle and Masonboro Sounds. Shole Inlet, on the Moseley map, 1733 (Shoal on the Mouzon map, 1775), was at the site, but it closed after 1775. An inlet nearby, Deep Inlet, opened by 1808 and closed after 1833. Masonboro Inlet opened by 1833 at the old Shole or Shoal Inlet site. Took its name from the resort community of Masonboro S of the mouth of Hewlets Creek.

label: Masonboro Sound
description: E New Hanover County between Greenville Sound and Myrtle Sound.

label: Masonboro Township
description: central New Hanover County.

label: Masons Cross
description: crossroads community in S Scotland County.

label: Masontown
description: community in NE Carteret County on Nelson Bay between the mouths of Broad and Salter Creeks.

label: Masquetuc
description: See Masequetuc.

label: Massey
description: community in W central Wake County.

label: Massey Branch
description: rises in E Beaufort County and flows NE into Pungo Creek near Yeatesville.

label: Massie Gap
description: W central Swain County between Horse Cove and the head of Hickory Flat Branch.

label: Massy Creek
description: rises in W central Rockingham County and flows N into Dan River.

label: Mast
description: community in N Watauga County on Cove Creek. Alt. 2,670.

label: Mast Knob
description: SE Watauga County NW of Dugger Mountain.

label: Matakomak
description: a name appearing on the Ogilby map, 1671, to designate the territory presently in Chowan County between Yeopim River and Pembroke Creek.

label: Matchipungo
description: See Pungo.

label: Matecomack
description: See Edenton; Matakomak; Queen Anne's Creek.

label: Matherson Branch
description: rises in W Macon County and flows SE into Pine Branch.

label: Matherson Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NE into Worm Creek.

label: Mathis
description: community in SE Forsyth County. Named for a family that settled in the vicinity as early as 1757.

label: Matkin
description: community in SW Caswell County. Named in 1967 for a family long resident in the area when a plant of Burlington Industries opened there. A name was required for directing truck drivers to the rural location.

label: Matlock Bald
description: N Clay County on the N end of Johnson Ridge. Alt. 5,230.

label: Matlock Creek
description: rises in N Clay County and flows SE between Johnson and Julie Ridges into Tusquitee Creek.

label: Matney
description: community in W Watauga County on Craborchard Creek.

label: Matney Branch
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows N into East Fork [South Fork New River].

label: Matrimony
description: community in N Rockingham County served by post office, 1881-94 and 1898-1903.

label: Matrimony Creek
description: rises in NW Rockingham County at the Virginia line and flows SE into Dan River. Named prior to 1728, when William Byrd recorded that it was "call'd so by an unfortunate marry'd man, because it was exceedingly noisy and impetuous."

label: Matt Branch
description: rises in NW Swain County and flows SE into Fontana Lake.

label: Matt Mountain
description: NW Swain County between Cable Branch and Fontana Lake.

label: Mattacomack Creek
description: See Queen Anne's Creek.

label: Mattamuskeet
description: former township in central Hyde County, now reported as "Unorganized Territory." Most of the area is now owned by the federal government and is a fish and wildlife reservation. Residents vote and list taxes in Lake Landing township.

label: Mattamuskeet Lake
description: See Lake Mattamuskeet.

label: Matthews
description: town in SE Mecklenburg County. Inc. 1879. Known as Fullwood or Fullwood's Store from 1825, when a post office existed there; in 1875 it was given its present name to honor an official of the Central Carolina Railroad. Produces textiles, electrical equipment, pottery, and tools. Alt. 729.

label: Matthews Branch
description: rises in W Haywood County and flows S into Mossy Branch.

label: Matthews Creek
description: rises in W Warren County and flows NE into Fishing Creek.

label: Matthews Cross Roads
description: See Siler City.

label: Matthews Crossroads
description: community in W Nash County near the headwaters of Pig Basket Creek.

label: Matthews Township
description: W central Chatham County.

label: Mattock Creek
description: rises in N Macon County and flows SW into Cowee Creek.

label: Maua
description: community in E Yadkin County.

label: Maufin
description: town inc. in 1905 in N Pitt County on the N side of Grindle Creek. Apparently it was not developed, as the charter was repealed in 1911.

label: Mauls Point
description: small tip of land in W central Beaufort County extending into Pamlico River at the NE edge of Blounts Bay. Named for Dr. Patrick Maule (d. 1736), but earlier known as Smiths Point for a family who lived there.

label: Mauls Swamp
description: rises in N Craven County and flows SW into Swift Creek.

label: Mauney Cove
description: S Haywood County on the head of Mauney Cove Branch.

label: Mauney Cove Branch
description: rises in central Haywood County and flows NE into Factor Branch.

label: Mauney Gap
description: central Graham County between Snowbird Creek and Long Creek.

label: Maury
description: town in E Greene County. Alt. 78. Est. late nineteenth century. Inc. 1911. Named for Matthew Fontaine Maury (1806-73), naval officer and oceanographer.

label: Maw Point
description: peninsula in E Pamlico County extending into Pamlico Sound and forming the SE side of Fisherman Bay.

label: Max Patch Mountain
description: W Madison County at the SW end of Buckeye Ridge. Alt. 4,629.

label: Maxton
description: town in W Robeson County on Big Shoeheel Creek. Alt. 197. Inc. 1874 as Shoe Heel; changed to Tilden in 1877 to honor Samuel J. Tilden (1814-86), Democratic nominee for president, 1876; to Quhele in 1879, probably from a form of the Gaelic word Caoile (the narrow part of a stream); to Shoe Heel in 1881, for the imagined meaning of Quhele; and to Maxton in 1886. Local tradition says that the area was long known as Mackstown because of the many people of Scottish descent living there whose names begin with Mc or Mac; it was changed to Maxton by postal authorities when the first post office was est. in 1866. An earlier post office serving the community was Cowper's Hill, est. 1811 a mi. or so E of the present town. Carolina College operated there, 1908-26, and Presbyterian Junior College, 1929-60; Carolina Military Academy is there now.

label: Maxton Township
description: W Robeson County.

label: Maxwell
description: community in NE Henderson County at the S end of Marshall Ridge.

label: Maxwell Branch
description: rises in N Transylvania County and flows SW into Avery Creek.

label: Maxwell Creek
description: See Lillington Creek.

label: Maxwell's Store
description: community in S Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1821-49. Later known as Cluster, which see.

label: Maxwells Mill Pond
description: on Burnt Coat Creek in NE Duplin County.

label: May
description: community in N Harnett County served by post office, 1883-1904.

label: May Branch
description: rises in W Macon County and flows SE into Nantahala Lake.

label: Mayapple Gap
description: between Doubletop Mountain and Thunder Struck Mountain in N Jackson County. Named for the herb (Podophyllum peltatum).

label: Mayberry Hollow
description: valley in N central Avery County a short distance N of Cranberry.

label: Mayesworth
description: See Cramerton.

label: Mayfield
description: community in NE Rockingham County served by post office, 1853-66 and 1870-1910.

label: Mayhew
description: community in SW Iredell County.

label: Mayhew Lake
description: a small body of water formed by a dam on New Years Creek W of Blowing Rock, S Watauga County.

label: Mayne Creek
description: rises in W Cleveland County and flows SW into Sandy Run Creek.

label: Mayo
description: community in NW Rockingham County served by post office, 1821-40 and 1855-66. Named changed to Stoneville, which see.

label: Mayo Mountain
description: on W side of Mayodan, extends 2 mi. from Beaver Island Creek toward Dan River. Rises about 300 ft.

label: Mayo River
description: rises in Patrick County, Va., and flows SE into Rockingham County and into Dan River. Named for William Mayo, member of William Byrd's surveying party, 1728.

label: Mayo River State Park
description: in NW Rockingham County. Est. in 2003 with plans for hiking trails and canoe access.

label: Mayo Township
description: NW Rockingham County.

label: Mayodan
description: town in W Rockingham County on Mayo River. Built as textile mill village. Inc. 1899. Named for nearby Mayo River and Dan River. Alt. 594. See also Avalon.

label: Mayonia
description: See Whitakers.

label: Mayos Crossroads
description: community in SE Edgecombe County.

label: Mays Crossroads
description: community in W Franklin County.

label: Maysville
description: town in S Jones County on White Oak River. Inc. 1897. A post office est. there in 1827 was known as Cross Roads. It appears to be the "Young's Cross Roads" that is mentioned frequently in Civil War official records. Alt. 41.

label: Mayview Hill
description: S Watauga County on the head of China Branch.

label: Mayview Lake
description: in S Watauga County in the headwaters of Middle Fork [South Fork New River].

label: Mayview Park
description: See Blowing Rock.

label: Maywood
description: community in N Alamance County served by post office, 1886-1905.

label: Mazeppa
description: community in SE Iredell County. Alt. 901.

label: McAdams Creek
description: rises in E Alamance County and flows W into Back Creek.

label: McAdenville
description: town in E Gaston County. First Known as Henderson Shoals for Lawson Henderson, early Lincoln County official; later as Spring Shoals for a local landowner, Adam A. Springs, graduate of the University of North Carolina in 1798. Inc. 1883 as McAdenville. Named for Rufus Yancey McAden (1833-89), speaker of the N.C. House of Representatives in 1866 and local owner of mills. Alt. 600.

label: McAllister Creek
description: rises in E Cabarrus County and flows S into Adams Creek.

label: McAlpin's Grove
description: See Rennert.

label: McAlpine Creek
description: rises in E Mecklenburg County and flows SW into South Carolina, where it enters Sugar Creek.

label: McAlpine Mountain
description: S Henderson County at the head of King Creek.

label: McArthurs
description: community in S Robeson County served by post office, 1888-1907.

label: McBrides Mill
description: See Amantha.

label: McBryde's Pond
description: SW Hoke County. Located on an unnamed stream that flows into Big Raft Swamp about 2 mi. NW of Antioch. Named for Thomas F. McBryde, owner.

label: McCain
description: community in W Hoke County. Formerly named Sanatorium because a state tuberculosis sanatorium was located there. Renamed McCain in 1948 in honor of Dr. Paul P. McCain, who died in 1946. Alt. 550.

label: McCains
description: community in SE Union County served by post office, 1890-1904.

label: McCall Branch
description: rises in E Transylvania County and flows SW into Little River.

label: McCall Gap
description: S Mitchell County between South Fork [Carvers Branch] and Middle Fork Grassy Creek.

label: McCall Mountain
description: in N Transylvania County at the W end of Forge Mountain.

label: McCalls Mill Creek
description: See Staffords Creek.

label: McCampbell Knob
description: Great Smoky Mountains National Park on the Swain County, N.C.-Blount County, Tenn., line. Lat. 35°33'53" N., long. 83°45'18" W.

label: McClammy
description: community in W Wayne County served by post office, 1888-1902.

label: McClellan Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows N into Tatham Creek.

label: McClure Branch
description: rises in S Lincoln County and flows NE into Leepers Creek.

label: McClure Cove
description: E Haywood County on Pigeon River.

label: McClure Creek
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows NE into West Fork Pigeon River.

label: McClure Hicks Creek
description: rises in NW Alamance County and flows S into Ridge Creek.

label: McClure Ridge
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur extending NW from Cataloochee Divide, center near lat. 35°34'35" N., long. 83°06'52" W., between Big Bald Branch and Double Gap Branch.

label: McCollums Pond
description: at the head of Big Creek in E Montgomery County.

label: McComb Branch
description: rises in E Cherokee County and flows NW into Hiwassee River.

label: McConnell
description: community in N Moore County.

label: McCoy
description: community in NW Sampson County served by post office, 1886-1903.

label: McCoy Cove
description: E Buncombe County NE of the town of Black Mountain.

label: McCoy Creek
description: rises in E Anson County and flows SE into Pee Dee River.

label: McCoys Mill Pond
description: E Robeson County in Big Swamp. Approx. 2 mi. long.

label: McCrarey's Creek
description: See East Buies Creek.

label: McCrary Branch
description: rises in E Transylvania County and flows SE into Little River.

label: McCray
description: community in N Alamance County served by post office, 1854-1903.

label: McCronan Creek
description: rises in W Craven County and flows NE into Neuse River.

label: McCullen
description: community in N Sampson County near Hoe Swamp.

label: McCuller
description: community in S Wake County. Settled 1800. Named for John McCullers, the first settler. Alt. 300.

label: McCullers Branch
description: rises in W Johnston County and flows SE into Black Creek.

label: McCullers Pond
description: S Wake County on a tributary of Middle Creek. Covers 4 acres and has a max. depth of 20 ft. One of the oldest ponds in the county.

label: McCullough Branch
description: rises in S Mecklenburg County and flows SE into Sugar Creek.

label: McCurdy
description: community in W Iredell County served by post office, 1879-1906.

label: McDade
description: community in NW Orange County.

label: McDaires Cove
description: N Buncombe County on the NW side of McDaires Ridge. See also Lewis McDaires Knob.

label: McDaires Ridge
description: N Buncombe County, extends SW from Bald Knob to Reems Creek. See also Lewis McDaires Knob.

label: McDaniel
description: community in SW Sampson County.

label: McDaniel Bald
description: on the Cherokee-Graham county line in the Unicoi Mountains. Alt. 4,662.

label: McDaniels Township
description: SW Sampson County.

label: McDeeds Creek
description: rises in SE Moore County and flows NE to join Mill Creek in forming Shaddock's Creek. Formerly known as Shaddock's Creek.

label: McDonald Ridge
description: W Macon County between Jarrett Bald and Middle Ridge.

label: McDonald's Mill
description: See Forest Hill.

label: McDonalds
description: town in S Robeson County. Alt. 175. Inc. 1911. Named for Peter McDonald, a turpentine distiller whose business was largely responsible for the opening of a railroad station there.

label: McDowell Branch
description: rises in central Macon County and flows SE into Little Tennessee River.

label: McDowell County
description: was formed in 1842 from Rutherford and Burke Counties. Located in the W central section of the state, it is bounded by Burke, Rutherford, Henderson, Buncombe, Yancey, Mitchell, and Avery Counties. It was named for Maj. Joseph McDowell (1758-96) of Pleasant Gardens, who fought at the Battle of Kings Mountain and was a member of Congress and of the commission to settle the North Carolina-Tennessee line. Area: 447 sq. mi. County seat: Marion, with an elevation of 1,437 ft. Townships are Brackett, Crooked Creek, Dysartsville, Glenwood, Higgins, Marion, Montford Cove, Nebo, North Cove, and Old Fort. Produces corn, soybeans, dairy products, livestock, hogs, poultry, hay, honey, machinery, textiles, hosiery, furniture, paper boxes, limestone, and gravel.

label: McDowell Creek
description: rises in N Henderson County and flows E and NE into French Broad River.

label: McDowell House
description: See Quaker Meadows.

label: McDowell Mountain
description: S Macon County between Middle Creek and Little Tennessee River.

label: McDowells
description: community in N Mecklenburg County.

label: McDowells Creek
description: rises in N Mecklenburg County and flows SW into Mountain Island Lake on the Catawba River.

label: McDuffie Creek
description: rises in E Hoke County and flows SE into Puppy Creek.

label: McElroy Branch
description: rises in central Haywood County and flows SE into Factor Branch.

label: McElroy Cove
description: central Haywood County between Yates Cove and Toms Top.

label: McFarlan
description: town in SE Anson County. Inc. 1885 as McFarland, but the 1900 census used the name McFarlan. Named for Allan McFarland (1819-69), president of the Cheraw and Salisbury Railroad. Post office est. there in 1883 when the post office at nearby Sneedsboro was discontinued. Alt. 297.

label: McFarland
description: community in W Hoke County.

label: McGalliard Creek
description: rises in central Burke County and flows N into Catawba River.

label: McGee Branch
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows SE into Straight Fork [Raven Fork].

label: McGee Spring
description: NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on W slope of Hyatt Ridge near summit at lat. 35°38'20" N., long. 83°14'20" W. Drains NW into Right Fork [Raven Fork].

label: McGees Creek
description: rises in NW Franklin County and flows NE into Taylors Creek.

label: McGehees Mill
description: community in NW Person County on Hyco River. A post office there from 1874 to 1906 was known as Woodburn.

label: McGill Branch
description: rises in S Gaston County and flows SE into Crowders Creek.

label: McGinnis Crossroads
description: community in SE Polk County.

label: McGinnis Mountain
description: See McInnis Mountain.

label: McGinty Creek
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, rises on N slope of Big Cataloochee Knob near lat. 35°40'30" N., long. 83°10'12" W., and flows NE into Swallow Fork Creek.

label: McGowan Creek
description: rises in W Orange County and flows E into Eno River.

label: McGowans Crossroads
description: community in SE Pitt County.

label: McGowen
description: community in N Duplin County served by post office, 1893-96.

label: McGrady
description: community in N Wilkes County on Mulberry Creek. Alt. 1,459.

label: McHan Branch
description: rises in E Swain County and flows S into Oconaluftee River.

label: McHan Cove
description: a small valley heading SE of DeHart Bald, S Swain County, and draining NW into the valley of Wesser Creek.

label: McHan Knob
description: S Swain County between Pole Bridge Branch and Yalaka Creek.

label: McHargue Mountain
description: NW Iredell County.

label: McInnis Mountain
description: SW Wilkes County between Warrior Creek and Beaver Creek. Named for McGinnis family.

label: McIntosh Branch
description: rises in central Yancey County and flows S into Pine Swamp Branch.

label: McIntosh Creek
description: rises in W Moore County and flows N into Big Governors Creek.

label: McIntyre Branch
description: rises in N Mecklenburg County and flows NW into Long Creek.

label: McIver
description: See Williamsburg.

label: McKay Island
description: SE Chatham County in Cape Fear River. Approx. ½ mi. long and containing 65 acres, the island once was 100 acres in area.

label: McKee Branch
description: rises in central Macon County and flows NW into Cartoogechaye Creek.

label: McKees Creek
description: rises in E Mecklenburg County and flows NE into Reedy Creek in Cabarrus County.

label: McKenzie Pond
description: artificial pond in E Brunswick County. Formed approx. 1860; max. depth 10 ft.; covers 50 acres. Fed by Allen Creek and drained by Lilliput Creek, which see. Also spelled McKensie Pond.

label: McKinley
description: community in SE Tyrrell County served by post office, 1897-1901.

label: McKinney Branch
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows NW into Toe River.

label: McKinney Creek
description: rises in SE Polk County and flows SE into Rutherford County, where it enters Broad River.

label: McKinney Gap
description: on the McDowell-Mitchell county line near the SE corner of Mitchell County.

label: McKinney Gap
description: W Yancey County near the head of Elk Wallow Creek.

label: McKinney Lake
description: E Richmond County on Hitchcock Creek. Covers 65 acres.

label: McKinney Ridge
description: N central Mitchell County N of town of Bakersville and between Cub Creek and Honeycutt Branch.

label: McKoy
description: community in SW Johnston County and NE Sampson County.

label: McLamb Crossroads
description: community in N Sampson County.

label: McLamb Mill Pond
description: S Sampson County on Clear Run Swamp. Formed about 1800 and known successively as Rackley Mill Pond, as Ezzell Mill Pond, and, since about 1949, by its present name. Covers approx. 75 acres; max. depth 14 ft.

label: McLauchlin Township
description: E Hoke County.

label: McLean Creek
description: rises in S Harnett County and flows NE into Upper Little River. Named for Peter McLean, who settled along its banks about 1760.

label: McLeans Branch
description: rises in E Moore County and flows S into Thagards Pond on Little River.

label: McLeans Creek
description: rises in NW Montgomery County and flows SE into Uwharrie River.

label: McLeansville
description: community in E Guilford County. Named for the McLean family, Ulster Scots who settled in the area.

label: McLendons Creek
description: rises in W Moore County a nd flows NE into Deep River. From 1748 to 1754, known as Buck Creek. Named for Joel McLendon, who settled there about 1748.

label: McLeod
description: community in N Richmond County.

label: McLeod Creek
description: rises in W Harnett County and flows S to join Reedys Swamp in forming Jumping Run Creek. The basin of the creek was once an inland sea 30 mi. square. Its limestone bed, composed of fossilized shells, is 8 ft. thick.

label: McLeods Branch
description: rises in S Moore County and flows N into Joes Fork.

label: McLin Creek
description: rises in central Catawba County and flows NE into Lyle Creek.

label: McMilly Swamp
description: rises in S Brunswick County and flows W into Shallotte River.

label: McMullen Creek
description: rises in S Mecklenburg County and flows SW into McAlpine Creek.

label: McMurray Branch
description: rises in Forest City, S central Rutherford County, and flows N into Broad River.

label: McNairs Millpond
description: central Scotland County on Juniper Creek. Formed 1830. Covers 50 acres; max. depth 15 ft.

label: McNatt
description: community in N Robeson County served by post office, 1884-1902.

label: McNeely
description: community in N Rockingham County served by post office, 1886-1905. Named for George McNeely, local minister.

label: McNeills Township
description: SE Moore County.

label: McNeils Pond
description: SE Hoke County on Beaver Creek. Built in 1870 by J. A. McNeil. Covers 100 acres. Max. depth 8 ft.

label: McPhail Branch
description: rises in N Sampson County and flows E into Merkle Swamp.

label: McPhaul's Pond
description: located on Little Raft Swamp in SW Hoke County. Named for owner Henry McPhaul.

label: McPherson Creek
description: rises in NW Cumberland County and flows N into Little River.

label: McPhersons Creek
description: See Daniels Creek.

label: McQueen's Store
description: See Plainview.

label: McQueen's Store
description: See Queensdale.

label: McQuires
description: community in W Graham County between Queen Ridge and Hooper Bald.

label: McRae Canal
description: See Skinner Canal.

label: McWilliams Pond
description: See Monroes Millpond.

label: Meadlock Mountain
description: N Mitchell County between the head of Honeycutt Branch and Young Cove Creek. Originally spelled Medlock.

label: Meadow Branch
description: rises in S Orange County and flows SW into Chatham County, where it enters Ferrells Creek.

label: Meadow Branch
description: rises in W Wilkes County and flows S into Cole Creek.

label: Meadow Creek
description: rises in E Watauga County and flows N into S Ashe County, where it enters New River.

label: Meadow Fork
description: rises in W Madison County and flows NE into Spring Creek.

label: Meadow Fork Creek
description: rises in SW Alleghany County and flows SW into Ashe County, where it joins Laurel Fork Creek in forming Mulberry Creek.

label: Meadow Fork Gap
description: on the Haywood-Madison county line.

label: Meadow Fork Mountain
description: W Madison County parallel to Meadow Fork.

label: Meadow Fork of Spring Creek Township
description: former township in SE Madison County, now township no. 13.

label: Meadow Gap
description: NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Forrester Ridge, lat. 35°33'43" N., long. 83°42'10" W.

label: Meadow Hill
description: community in N Caldwell County served by post office, 1879-1903.

label: Meadow Mine
description: W Avery County. Mica was discovered about 1870 and the mine, still being worked, is said to have produced more mica than any other mine in history.

label: Meadow Township
description: S Johnston County.

label: Meadow, The
description: a loamy swamp in SW Johnston County.

label: Meadows
description: community in central Stokes County between Flat Shoal Creek and the head of Zilphy Creek.

label: Meadows Store
description: community in W Madison County on Spring Creek.

label: Meadows Summit
description: former station on the Danville and Western Railroad, N Rockingham County. Was the high point on the railroad from Leaksville to present Eden.

label: Meadows Township
description: S central Stokes County.

label: Meadows, The
description: area of level land in N Rockingham County along N side of Dan River. Once livestock production center. Described by surveying party of William Byrd, 1728.

label: Meads Corner
description: community in S Pasquotank County.

label: Mears Fork Creek
description: rises in NE Guilford County and flows NE into Haw River near the Rockingham County line.

label: Meat Camp
description: community in N Watauga County on Meat Camp Creek.

label: Meat Camp Creek
description: rises in NE Watauga County and flows SE into South Fork New River. Named because early hunters had a camp there, to which they took hides and salted meat.

label: Meat Camp Township
description: N central Watauga County.

label: Mebane
description: town in E Alamance and W Orange Counties. Settled about 1854 and named for a local family. Inc. 1880 as Mebanesville; name changed 1883. Mepern's [Mebane's?] Tavern in the vicinity was mentioned by Bishop A. G. Spangenberg in 1752. The Bingham School was there from 1865 to 1891. Produces bedding, furniture, textiles, and apparel. Alt. 678.

label: Mecca
description: community in SW Surry County served by post office, 1898-1913.

label: Mechanic
description: community in W Randolph County.

label: Mechanicks Hill
description: See Robbins.

label: Mechanicsville
description: See Robbins.

label: Meck Neck
description: is modern colloquial term used to describe area in NW Mecklenburg County surrounded by waters of Lake Norman on three sides and Lincoln County on the n.

label: Mecklenburg County
description: was formed in 1762 from Anson County. Located in the S central section of the state, it is bounded by the state of South Carolina and by Gaston, Lincoln, Iredell, Cabarrus, and Union Counties. It was named for Princess Charlotte Sophia of Mecklenburg-Strelitz (1744-1818), who married George III in 1761. Area: 549 sq. mi. County seat: Charlotte, with an elevation of 795 ft. Home to banks, corporate offices, and professional football and basketball teams. Townships, now numbered 1 to 15, were formerly Charlotte, Berryhill, Steele Creek, Sharon, Providence, Clear Creek, Crab Orchard, Mallard Creek, Dewees, Lemley, Long Creek, Paw Creek, Morning Star, Pineville, and Huntersville. Produces corn, wheat, oats, cotton, eggs, poultry, dairy products, processed meat, baked goods, fabricated metals, textiles, industrial machinery, canned foods, paper products, chemicals, hosiery, apparel, furniture, snack foods, software, soybeans, peaches, tires, computers, aircraft parts, electronics, and asbestos products.

label: Medford Branch
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows NW into Browning Branch.

label: Medford Cove
description: E Haywood County between Brown Cove and Chambers Branch.

label: Medlin
description: former community in NW Swain County now within the bounds of Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Settled before 1886 and named for Marion Medlin, popular Baptist minister who lived in the vicinity. After the property was acquired for the national park, houses and stores were torn down and moved. Only local family cemeteries remain to mark the site.

label: Medlock Mountain
description: See Meadlock Mountain.

label: Medoc
description: community in W Halifax County between Brinkleyville and Ringwood. Named for nearby Medoc Mountain.

label: Medoc Mountain
description: a comparatively high hill on the E bank of Little Fishing Creek, W Halifax County; center of a state park. Named for a vineyard est. there in the late nineteenth century and named for Médoc, France, which contains some of that country's most famous vineyards. "Rocky Hill," the summer home of Governor Hutchins G. Burton (1774-1832), was nearby.

label: Medora
description: community in W Edgecombe County.

label: Meege Crossroads
description: community in N Chowan County. A post office operated there, 1902-25, called Meege, which was the nickname of Mrs. Miles Elliott, wife of the postmaster.

label: Meeksville
description: community in W Wilson County served by post office, 1878-1901.

label: Meeting House Branch
description: rises in E central Wilson County and flows SW in an arc into Buck Branch. Name appears in local records as early as 1775.

label: Meeting of the Waters
description: creek in SE Orange County rising just S of the town of Chapel Hill and flowing SE into Morgan Creek.

label: Meetinghouse Branch
description: rises in N central Sampson County and flows SE into Great Coharie Creek.

label: Meetinghouse Mountain
description: extends NE from Stecoah Creek to Little Tennessee River in NE Graham County.

label: Meherrin
description: community in NE Northampton County. An earlier community by the name is now known as Severn.

label: Meherrin Creek
description: See Potecasi Creek.

label: Meherrin River
description: rises in Virginia and flows S into North Carolina, where it forms the Hertford-Northampton county line for approx. 9 mi. and then flows SE across Hertford County into Chowan River. Appears as Pochike River on the Comberford map, 1657, and as Wayanock on the Hack map, 1684. Parker's Ferry has been operated across the Meherrin River near its mouth since the early years of the twentieth century.

label: Meherrin Swamp
description: See Raynor Swamp.

label: Meiggs
description: community in SE Surry County served by post office, 1894-1901.

label: Melanchton
description: community in NE Randolph County served by a post office, 1894-1901.

label: Melrose
description: community in W Robeson County served by post office, 1855-1902.

label: Melrose Falls
description: SW Polk County on Big Fall Creek a short distance W of town of Tryon.

label: Melton Branch
description: rises in N Mitchell County and flows E into Left Fork Bean Creek.

label: Melton Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SE and SW into Valley River.

label: Melton Mountain
description: N Rutherford County between Little and Carson Mountains.

label: Melville
description: community in E Alamance County. Settled about 1845 and known at first as Burnt Shop.

label: Melville Township
description: former township in E central Alamance County, now townships nos. 10 and 13.

label: Melvin Hill
description: community in SE Polk County. Settled in late nineteenth century. Named for Thomas Melvin, first postmaster.

label: Melvin's Mill Pond
description: NE Bladen County on Little Turnbull Creek.

label: Memminger Creek
description: rises in central Henderson County and flows NE into King Creek. Named for C. G. Memminger (1803-88), Confederate secretary of the treasury, who had a summer home at Flat Rock.

label: Memory
description: community in E Cleveland County.

label: Menola
description: community in W Hertford County served by post office, 1886-1907.

label: Mentso
description: marked as the central part of Pamlico Sound, present-day Hyde County, on the White map, 1590, but apparently a place on the shore, as the name comes from an Indian word meaning "he cooks for the first time." The word could be the name given a stopping place for eating on travels, perhaps the end of a day's journey in the direction from Roanoke Island.

label: Mequopen
description: See Second Creek.

label: Mercer
description: community in S Edgecombe County. Probably the location of Mercersville post office in 1828.

label: Mercers Mill Pond
description: a stream that rises in SE Brunswick County and flows SW into tidal marshes that drain into the Atlantic Ocean through Lockwoods Folly Inlet.

label: Mercersville
description: See Mercer.

label: Merchants
description: community in NE Gates County served by post office, 1879-1913. Known as Merchants Mills after 1902.

label: Merchants Millpond
description: central Gates County on Bennetts Creek; center of a state park. Formed about 1857 by Rufus Williams and known as Williams Millpond until about 1910, when it was sold. The new owner built a store there, hence the name. Approx. 3 mi. long. Max. depth 8 ft. Sawmill and gristmill formerly operated there, but now a popular place for fishing.

label: Merchants Mills
description: See Merchants.

label: Meredith
description: community in W Orange County served by post office, 1890-1907.

label: Meredith Branch
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows S into Cane River.

label: Meredith Township
description: central Wake County.

label: Merkle Bay
description: off the NW side of Cedar Island in NE Carteret County. Merkle is local pronunciation of myrtle.

label: Merkle Swamp
description: rises in N Sampson County and flows SE into Great Coharie Creek. Appears as Myrtle Swamp on the Kerr map, 1882.

label: Merricks Creek
description: rises in S Pender County and flows NW and SW into Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: Merrill Cove
description: S Buncombe County E of Merrill Mountain.

label: Merrill Cove Creek
description: rises in S Buncombe County and flows SE into Cane Creek.

label: Merrill Creek
