description: rises near Black Knob in E Transylvania County and flows E into Cascade Lake [Little River].

label: Merrill Mountain
description: S Buncombe County between Robinson Creek and Merrill Cove.

label: Merrimon
description: community in N Carteret County.

label: Merrimon River
description: rises in central Carteret County and flows S into North River.

label: Merrimon Township
description: N central Carteret County on Neuse and South Rivers and Adams Creek. At one time a part of Straits and Smyrna Townships. Previously also known as township no. 9.

label: Merritt
description: community on Trent River in central Pamlico County. Originally known as Trent; renamed to honor Gen. Wesley Merritt (1834-1910), who captured Manila in 1898.

label: Merritt Mill Pond
description: on Bear Marsh Branch in N Duplin County.

label: Merry Hill
description: community in E central Bertie County. Named for the Webb family plantation. A post office was est. there in 1816. See also Society Parish.

label: Merry Hill Township
description: SE Bertie County.

label: Merry Oaks
description: town in SE Chatham County. Inc. 1901, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Named for grove of oaks in which Indians are said to have held tribal celebrations. Alt. 246.

label: Merrymount
description: See Paschall.

label: Mertie
description: community in N Wilkes County between North Fork Reddies River and Burke Mountain.

label: Mesic
description: community in NE Pamlico County on Bear Creek. First known as Bear Creek; renamed for S. R. Messick, the second postmaster. Alt. 4.

label: Messer Branch
description: rises in N Haywood County and flows NE into Teague Branch.

label: Messer Branch
description: rises in S central Swain County and flows SE into Bucknor Branch.

label: Messer Creek
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, rises near lat. 35°36'57" N., long. 83°36'57" W., and flows E into Rough Fork. Formerly known as Sugar Fork but changed to honor Elijah Messer, an early settler on the stream.

label: Messer Ridge
description: S Macon County, extends SE into Rabun County, Ga.

label: Metackwem
description: See Metocuuem.

label: Metakquam
description: See Metocuuem.

label: Metal
description: community in S Cleveland County served by post office, 1894-1902.

label: Method
description: community in W central Wake County near the head of House Creek.

label: Metocuuem
description: an Indian village of either the Weapemeoc or Chawanoac tribes located in what is now E Bertie County between the mouths of Chowan and Roanoke Rivers near Albemarle Sound. Appears on the De Bry map, 1590, and on the Velasco map, 1611, as Metakquam. Variant spellings are Metackwem and Mettaquen. The name may have meant "big woods" or "trees."

label: Mettaquen
description: See Metocuuem.

label: Mewborn Crossroads
description: community in N Lenoir County. Named for the Mewborn family, which settled there before the Revolution.

label: Miami
description: See Newton.

label: Miami Mountain
description: SE Buncombe County near the town of Black Mountain.

label: Mica City Creek
description: rises in NE Macon County and flows SW into Cowee Creek.

label: Mica Knob
description: S Swain County between Whiteoak Branch and Grape Cove.

label: Micaville
description: community in E Yancey County near the junction of Ayles and Little Crabtree Creeks. Alt. 2,504. Named for mica mined in the vicinity.

label: Michael
description: community in W Davidson County served by post office, 1880-1903. Michael was the surname of successive postmasters.

label: Michael Branch
description: rises in W Alamance County and flows S into Back Creek.

label: Michael's Creek
description: See Carraway Creek.

label: Michfield
description: community in S Randolph County. Said to have been named for a local resident, Mrs. Michfield Wright, or for the Michell family.

label: Micro
description: town in E Johnston County. Settled about 1890; inc. 1899 as Jerome. Named for Jerome Creech, local landowner. Named changed to Micro (small) in 1905 because of confusion with the community of Jerome in Bladen County. Alt. 192.

label: Micro Township
description: E central Johnston County.

label: Midas Spring
description: W central Mecklenburg County, 9 mi. from Charlotte. Discovered 1812 by a slave. Since 1871 commercially bottled water, high in magnesium and calcium content, has been available. Spring is located on a 40-acre tract, Midas Park.

label: Middens Creek
description: a tidal creek about 1 mi. long near Smyrna, SE Carteret County. It flows SE into Core Sound. Named for Samuel Mittams or Middams.

label: Middle Bay
description: in Pamlico Sound on SE side of Goose Creek Island, NE Pamlico County.

label: Middle Cave
description: community in E Watauga County.

label: Middle Creek
description: rises in S Transylvania County SE of Kelly Mountain and flows SW through Rainbow Lake into East Fork French Broad River.

label: Middle Creek
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows NE into South Toe River.

label: Middle Creek Falls
description: on Middle Creek S of Rattlesnake Ridge, S Macon County.

label: Middle Creek Township
description: S Wake County.

label: Middle Elk Ridge
description: central Avery County.

label: Middle Falls
description: in Snowbird Creek between Upper Falls and Big Falls in SW Graham County. Water drops approx. 50 ft.

label: Middle Fork
description: rises in E Madison County and flows SW into Little Ivy Creek.

label: Middle Fork French Broad River
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows NW into French Broad River.

label: Middle Fork Little Horse Creek
description: rises in NW Ashe County and flows E into Little Horse Creek.

label: Middle Fork Muddy Creek
description: See Salem Creek.

label: Middle Fork of Ivy Township
description: former township in E Madison County, now township no. 4.

label: Middle Fork Ridge
description: NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a spur extending SW from Dashoga Ridge, lat. 35°39'15" N., long. 83°15'30" W.

label: Middle Fork Township
description: E central Forsyth County.

label: Middle Fork [Barkers Creek]
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows NE to join West Fork in forming Barkers Creek.

label: Middle Fork [Grassy Creek]
description: rises in S Mitchell County and flows NE to join East Fork [Grassy Creek] in forming Grassy Creek.

label: Middle Fork [Hawk Branch]
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows SW to join South Fork [Hawk Branch] in forming Hawk Branch.

label: Middle Fork [Lower Creek]
description: rises in NE Caldwell County and flows SW into Zacks Fork.

label: Middle Fork [Raven Fork]
description: rises in NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows SW to join Left Fork and Right Fork in forming Raven Fork [Oconaluftee River].

label: Middle Fork [Reddies River]
description: rises in NW Wilkes County and flows SE to join North Fork [Reddies River] in forming Reddies River.

label: Middle Fork [Rock Creek]
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows E to join North Fork [Rock Creek] in forming Rock Creek.

label: Middle Fork [South Fork New River]
description: rises in S Watauga County on E limits of town of Blowing Rock and flows NE and then N to join East Fork and Flannery Fork in forming South Fork New River approx. 2 mi. SE of town of Boone.

label: Middle Fork [Upper Creek]
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows SE to join South Fork [Upper Creek] in forming Upper Creek.

label: Middle Fourth Creek
description: See Morrison Creek.

label: Middle Ground
description: a former shoal between Oak Island and Bald Head (Smith Island) in SE Brunswick County; appears on the Collet map, 1770. It is called Sea Cattle on the Price map, 1808, but the shoal had eroded and was practically gone by 1833 (MacRae map).

label: Middle Little River
description: rises in E Caldwell County and flows SE into Alexander County, where it enters Lake Hickory on Catawba River.

label: Middle Marshes
description: a group of tidal-marsh islands at the NW end of Back Sound in SE Carteret County.

label: Middle Mountain
description: NE Buncombe County between Flat Creek and North Fork [Swannanoa River].

label: Middle Mountain
description: S Transylvania County between South Prong and the head of East Fork French Broad River.

label: Middle Peachtree Creek
description: rises in central Swain County and flows S into Peachtree Creek.

label: Middle Prong
description: rises in NE Pamlico County on the N side of Goose Creek Island and flows N into Pamlico River.

label: Middle Prong of Little River
description: See Perry Creek.

label: Middle Prong [Roaring River]
description: is formed in N Wilkes County by the junction of Basin and Lovelace Creeks. It flows SE to join North Prong [Roaring River] in forming Roaring River.

label: Middle Prong [West Fork Pigeon River]
description: is formed in S Haywood County by the junction of Haywood Gap Stream and Buckeye Creek and flows N into West Fork Pigeon River.

label: Middle Ridge
description: N Madison County between Lisenbee Branch and Colvin Creek.

label: Middle Ridge
description: S Yancey County between Middle Creek and Colbert Creek.

label: Middle Ridge Branch
description: rises in SE Mitchell County and flows S into Dicks Creek.

label: Middle River
description: rises in SE Bertie County and flows NE into Cashie River. Named for the fact that along much of its course, it lies midway between Roanoke and Cashie Rivers.

label: Middle Sound
description: E New Hanover County between Topsail sound on the N and Greenville Sound on the s.

label: Middle Swamp
description: rises in N Greene County and flows SE on the Greene-Pitt county line into Little Contentnea Creek.

label: Middle Top
description: W Haywood County between Walker Bald and Germany Cove. Alt. 5,165.

label: Middle Township
description: former township in central Chowan County, now township no. 2.

label: Middle Trail Ridge
description: SW Macon County between Little Indian Creek and Nichols Branch.

label: Middle Watch Creek
description: See Salem Creek.

label: Middleburg
description: town in E Vance County between Mill Creek and Fishing Creek. Alt. 489. Inc. 1880; named for the fact that it was midway between the terminals of the Raleigh and Gaston Railroad.

label: Middleburg-Nutbush Township
description: E Vance County. Two separate townships were merged in 1965.

label: Middlesex
description: town in SW Nash County, settled about 1907. Inc. 1908. Named for the English city. Produces apparel. Alt. 255.

label: Middleton Creek
description: rises in SE Chowan County and flows NE into Yeopim River.

label: Middletown
description: town in E Hyde County between Lake Mattamuskeet and Pamlico Sound. Est. 1787, but long inactive in municipal affairs.

label: Midgett Island
description: in the waters of Pamlico Sound off the W coast of Hatteras Island, E Dare County.

label: Midland
description: community in S Cabarrus County. Name derived from the fact that it lies halfway between Charlotte and Norwood on the railroad. Inc. 2000.

label: Midstate Mill
description: community adjoining the W limits of Red Springs in N Robeson County. A textile mill est. there in the nineteenth century; now location of Amerotron textile mills. Known briefly as Dora or Dora Mills after that name ceased to be applied to what is now Red Springs, which see. Dora post office operated, 1880-84.

label: Midville
description: community in central Onslow County adjoining Jacksonville on the se.

label: Midway
description: See Jessama.

label: Midway Park
description: community in central Onslow County on the outskirts of Camp Lejeune Marine Base.

label: Midway Township
description: N central Davidson County.

label: Mike Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SE into Morris Creek.

label: Mikes Knob
description: S Madison County between Friezeland Creek and Little Pine Creek.

label: Mikes Mountain
description: N Rutherford County between the head of Catheys Creek and Second Broad River.

label: Milam
description: community in SW Ashe County.

label: Milburnie
description: pond in E central Wake County on Beaverdam Creek. Covers 50 acres and has max. depth of 20 ft. Used for recreation. Named for the former community of Milburnie there. A post office, 1891-92, served the community, and a printing establishment operated there.

label: Mildred
description: town in E Edgecombe County. Inc. 1887, but not now active in municipal affairs. Alt. 46.

label: Miles
description: community in W Orange County.

label: Miles Gap
description: N Madison County between Cutshalltown and Shelton Laurel Creek.

label: Miles Point
description: S Camden County in the mouth of Pasquotank River. Named for Miles Jones, who lived nearby approx. 1840-60.

label: Milesville
description: community in S Caswell County. A post office operated there, 1882-1907.

label: Milk House Branch
description: See Tanyard Branch.

label: Milksick Cove
description: central Swain County, extends S from Tuckasegee River.

label: Milksick Knob
description: S Macon County between Tommy Branch and Wayah Creek.

label: Milksick Ridge
description: W Jackson County between Pressley and Tilley Creeks.

label: Mill Branch
description: rises in NW Bertie County and flows N into Hertford County, where it enters Ahoskie Creek.

label: Mill Branch
description: rises in N Franklin County and flows S into Sandy Creek.

label: Mill Branch
description: rises in NW Wilson County and flows S into Contentnea Creek.

label: Mill Branch
description: community in SW Brunswick County.

label: Mill Brook
description: rises in N central Wake County and flows SE into Marsh Creek.

label: Mill Cove
description: NE Currituck County, is formed by the waters of Knotts Island Channel, which cuts into the E shore of Knotts Island.

label: Mill Creek
description: rises in S Ashe County and flows S into South Fork New River.

label: Mill Creek
description: rises in NE Henderson County and flows SE into Hickory Nut Creek.

label: Mill Creek
description: rises in W Lincoln County and flows SE into Indian Creek.

label: Mill Creek
description: rises in S Onslow County and flows S into Alligator Bay.

label: Mill Creek
description: rises in S Stokes County and flows SE into Town Fork Creek.

label: Mill Creek
description: rises in N Warren County and flows NE into Hawtree Creek.

label: Mill Creek
description: See Mill Tail Creek.

label: Mill Fork
description: rises in SW Franklin County and flows SW into Wake County, where it enters Horse Creek.

label: Mill Gap
description: N Macon County between Matlock Creek and Shepherd Creek.

label: Mill Grove
description: community about 2 mi. N of city of Durham in central Durham County.

label: Mill Hill
description: home built by Jacob Stirewalt in 1821 on Mill Creek in N Cabarrus County. Restored in 1938. Nearby creek dammed to provide power for a gristmill and tannery.

label: Mill Knob
description: S Yancey County between Sodom Branch and Indian Creek.

label: Mill Landing
description: E Bertie County on Salmon Creek. Site of a gristmill built in 1771 by George Ryan and operated for many years; ruins still exist. Ships loaded cargo from the mill at the landing.

label: Mill Mountain
description: E Stanly County on the W bank of Pee Dee River in Morrow Mountain State Park.

label: Mill Neck
description: community in N Hertford County on Buckhorn Creek.

label: Mill Point
description: N Tyrrell County, extends from River Neck into the mouth of Scuppernong River.

label: Mill Point
description: See Elon.

label: Mill Pond Branch
description: rises in N Nash County and flows NE into Flat Rock Branch.

label: Mill Pond Creek
description: rises in N Pasquotank County and flows NW into Newland Drainage Canal.

label: Mill Ridge
description: N Madison County between Little Hurricane Creek and Big Laurel Creek. Alt. 2,763.

label: Mill Run
description: rises in central Onslow County and flows NE into Southwest Creek. See also Troublesome Creek.

label: Mill Shoal Ridge
description: W Avery County.

label: Mill Spring
description: town in central Polk County. Inc. 1885 as Mills Spring, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Named for a son of William Mills, pioneer settler. Alt. 1,017.

label: Mill Station Creek
description: rises in NW Transylvania County and flows SE into Court House Creek.

label: Mill Stone Creek
description: rises in N Richmond County and flows SW into Rocky Fork Creek.

label: Mill Swamp
description: rises in W Sampson County and flows SW into Little Coharie Creek.

label: Mill Swamp Branch
description: rises in SW Johnston County and flows SE into Mill Creek.

label: Mill Swamp Creek
description: rises in E Robeson County and flows SE into Lumber River.

label: Mill Tail Creek
description: rises in W Dare County and flows N and W into Alligator River. Appears on the Collet map, 1770, as Mill Creek.

label: Mill Timber Creek
description: rises in central Avery County and flows SW into Linville River.

label: Mill Town
description: See Shiloh.

label: Millboro
description: community in N Randolph County.

label: Millbridge
description: community in W Rowan County. Named for the mill built in 1822 by Samuel Kerr and the nearby bridge over Kerr Creek.

label: Millbrook
description: community in N central Wake County approx. 3 mi. N of the city of Raleigh. Settled prior to 1860 and named for the brook on which a gristmill operated. Alt. 318.

label: Milledgeville
description: See Tuckertown.

label: Miller
description: community in E central Wayne County. Formerly known as Millers Station.

label: Miller Branch
description: rises in E central Bertie County and flows N into Cricket Swamp.

label: Miller Branch
description: rises in W Yancey County and flows S into Fox Creek.

label: Miller Cove
description: SW Swain County on the N side of Nantahala Gorge.

label: Miller Creek
description: rises in S Buncombe County and flows SE into Tweed Creek.

label: Miller Gap
description: central Haywood County on the head of Rabbitskin Branch.

label: Miller Hollow
description: W Macon County between Tom Bryan Cove and Deweese Creek.

label: Miller Mountain
description: central Buncombe County SW of Spivey Gap.

label: Miller Mountain
description: W Polk County between Howard Gap and Tryon Mountain. Alt. 2,500.

label: Miller's Point
description: a point of land extending into Pasquotank River in S Camden County. Named for Thomas Miller, who was granted land there on January 1, 1694.

label: Millers Branch
description: rises in N central Avery County and flows NW into Cranberry Creek.

label: Millers Creek
description: community in central Wilkes County near the head of Millers Creek. Alt. 1,423.

label: Millers Landing
description: N Tyrrell County on Alligator Creek.

label: Millers Station
description: See Miller.

label: Millers Township
description: S Alexander County.

label: Millersville
description: community in S central Alexander County. Named for one Miller, owner of an antebellum cotton mill there.

label: Millford
description: former community in E Vance County at Southerland Millpond. Appears on the MacRae map, 1833, but the name was out of use by 1913.

label: Milligan
description: community in S Cleveland County served by post office, 1889-1902.

label: Millingport
description: community in W Stanly County.

label: Mills Bay
description: a bay in the N end of Church Island in Currituck Sound in central Currituck County.

label: Mills Creek
description: rises in W Transylvania County and flows E into Toxaway River.

label: Mills Gap
description: on Point Lookout Mountain, E Henderson County. Named because it was used by William Mills, first-known white settler of Henderson County, when he crossed the mountains after being wounded at the Battle of Kings Mountain.

label: Mills Mountain
description: between McDowell Creek and Foster Creek in N Henderson County. Alt. 2,761.

label: Mills Pond
description: lake in SW Wake County on Basal Creek. Originally named Norris Pond. Renamed in 1925 for the owner. Covers 58 acres and has a max. depth of 20 ft.

label: Mills Ridge
description: a strip of high ground in N Tyrrell County S of Big Savanna from near the community of Levels and supporting a road on its surface. Extends E to W.

label: Mills River
description: community on Mills River in W Henderson County; inc. 2003. Alt. 2,077. A post office operated there since 1838.

label: Mills River Township
description: NW Henderson County.

label: Millsaps
description: See Santeetlah.

label: Millseat Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SW into Valley River.

label: Millshoal Township
description: NE Macon County.

label: Millstone Creek
description: See Big Governors Creek.

label: Millstone Mountain
description: N Montgomery County on Barnes Creek.

label: Milltown
description: community in central Graham County on Long Creek.

label: Millville
description: See Rockwell.

label: Millwood
description: See Gilkey.

label: Milray Knob
description: S Watauga County E of Boone Fork and NW of Cannon Branch.

label: Milton
description: See Hamilton.

label: Milton Township
description: NE Caswell County.

label: Milwaukee
description: town in E Northampton County. Inc. 1915. Settled about 1889 and known first as Bethany. Said to have been named by Hezekiah Lasker, railroad conductor, for the city in Wisconsin. Alt. 85.

label: Mimosa
description: See Melrose.

label: Mimosa Shores
description: community in W Beaufort County on Pamlico River.

label: Mince Branch
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows SW into Long Branch.

label: Mine Branch
description: rises in E Yancey County and flows SW into South Toe River.

label: Mine Creek
description: rises in N Wake County and flows S into Crabtree Creek.

label: Mine Fork
description: rises in N central Yancey County and flows NE into Jacks Creek.

label: Mine Fork Branch
description: rises in E Mitchell County and flows NW into Right Fork [Cane Creek].

label: Mine Fork Ridge
description: E Mitchell County between Bee Branch and Mine Fork Branch.

label: Mine Gap
description: S Henderson County between King Mountain and Butt Mountain.

label: Mine Hill
description: E Mitchell County between Buchanan Hollow and Cane Creek.

label: Mine Knob
description: E Yancey County near the head of Shoal Creek.

label: Mine Mountain
description: SE Henderson County on Pacolet River.

label: Mine Mountain
description: N Transylvania County, extends S beside North Prong Turkey Creek.

label: Mine Ridge
description: NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a spur extending SW from Hughes Ridge, lat. 35°36'20" N., long. 83°18'38" W.

label: Minehole Gap
description: S Buncombe County between Chestnut Mountain and Cedar Cliff. Alt. 2,555. Named because in the first quarter of the nineteenth century, very crude iron ore was mined nearby.

label: Mineola
description: community in NW Beaufort County; formerly known as Old Ford. Served by post office, 1898-1903.

label: Mineral Creek
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows NW to join Carter Creek in forming Stony Creek.

label: Mineral Gap
description: in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on the Swain County, N.C.-Blount County, Tenn., line near the head of Roaring Creek, lat. 35°34'08" N., long. 83°40'55" W. Alt. approx. 5,280.

label: Mineral Springs
description: located approx. 4 mi. E of Hookerton on Contentnea Creek in E Greene County on the Jim Smith plantation. A high ridge rises on the S side of the creek. The springs, on the slope of the hill, formerly were quite popular as a source of supposedly healthful waters. Several acres of adjacent lowlands are covered with laurel.

label: Mineral Springs
description: town in W Union County. Inc. 1905. Post office est. as Potters, 1891. Name changed to Mineral Springs in 1900. Reincorporated 1999. Site of Queen's Cup steeple-chase event. Alt. 631.

label: Mineral Springs Township
description: N Richmond County.

label: Minersville
description: mining community in SE McDowell County near Dysartsville.

label: Mines Creek
description: rises in NW Bladen County and flows E into Cape Fear River.

label: Mingo
description: community in NW Sampson County. A post office operated there, 1875-1903. Takes its name from East Mingo Branch (or Mingo Swamp). Mingo was an Indian word for a treacherous person.

label: Mingo Creek
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows NW into Raven Fork.

label: Mingo Mill
description: See Burnt Mill Creek.

label: Mingo Swamp
description: See East Mingo Branch.

label: Mingo Township
description: NW Sampson County.

label: Mingus Creek
description: in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, rises in NE Swain County and flows S and E into Oconaluftee River.

label: Mingus Ridge
description: W Haywood County, extends SE between Winchester Creek and Little Branch.

label: Mining Branch
description: rises in N central Transylvania County and flows SE into King Creek.

label: Mining Ridge
description: NW Henderson County, extends SE from Big Knob to Queen Creek.

label: Mink Neck
description: community in SE Hertford County.

label: Minneapolis
description: community in central Avery County. Post office est. 1911 and named for the city in Minnesota. Inc. 1911; charter repealed 1915. An extensive deposit of asbestos was mined there at one time.

label: Minneapolis Ridge
description: central Avery County.

label: Minnesott Beach
description: resort area in S Pamlico County on Neuse River. Developed by Hardison family, largely under the direction of Naaman Hardison, after World War I. Named for an Indian word said to mean "land of sky blue water."

label: Minnie
description: community in N Mecklenburg County served by post office for about 10 years beginning in 1898. Named for Minnie Barnhardt, first postmaster.

label: Minor
description: community in W Cabarrus County served by post office, 1898-1906.

label: Minpro
description: community in S Mitchell County on North Toe River.

label: Mint Branch
description: rises in central Macon County and flows SW into Mill Creek.

label: Mint Hill
description: town in SE Mecklenburg County. Site of Philadelphia Presbyterian Church, organized 1770. Inc. 1899, but long inactive in municipal affairs.

label: Minton
description: former community in S Wilkes County near Smithies Creek. Named for Meridy Minton, eighteenth-century settler. The Smitheys Creek Public Use Area on W. Kerr Scott Reservoir is there.

label: Mintons
description: See Mintonsville.

label: Mintons Store
description: community in SW Hertford County.

label: Mintonsville
description: community in S Gates County. Post office in 1828 was Minton's, but by 1830 known as Mintonsville.

label: Mintonsville Township
description: S Gates County.

label: Mintz
description: community in W Sampson County. Named for Wm. Ashe Mintz, whose daughter Mittie was first postmaster, 1900.

label: Miranda
description: community in W Rowan County served by post office, 1830-1903.

label: Mirey Branch
description: rises in SE Onslow County and flows NE into Turpentine Creek.

label: Mirror Lake
description: SE Macon County on Cullasaja River. Area approx. 50 acres; max. depth 40 ft.

label: Miry Branch
description: rises in W Nash County and flows E into Tar River.

label: Miry Gut
description: N central Carteret County, flows E into South River.

label: Misenheimer
description: community in NW Stanly County. Alt. 675. Former resort in the 1880s and 1890s known as Misenheimer Springs, which is still the name of the railroad station. Home of Pfeiffer University. Inc. 1903 as Gladstone, but the charter was repealed in 1909, and the name later changed to Misenheimer. Rein-corporated 2003.

label: Misenheimer Springs
description: See Misenheimer.

label: Miser Creek
description: rises in W Transylvania County and flows SE into Parker Creek.

label: Miss Creek
description: rises in SE Polk County and flows NE into Whiteoak Creek.

label: Mission
description: community in W Stanly County. Named for a local church.

label: Mission Branch
description: rises in E Cherokee County and flows SW into Hiwassee River.

label: Mission Mountain
description: E Cherokee County, extends NE from the headwaters of Suddereth Branch to the mouth of Moody Branch.

label: Mistletoe Creek
description: rises in N Cherokee County and flows SW into Tellicoe River.

label: Mitchell
description: community in S Carteret County on Bogue Sound near the mouth of Spooners Creek.

label: Mitchell Branch
description: rises in central Yancey County and flows SE into Little Crabtree Creek.

label: Mitchell County
description: was formed in 1861 from Yancey, Watauga, Caldwell, Burke, and McDowell Counties. Located in the W section of the state, it is bounded by the state of Tennessee and by Avery, McDowell, and Yancey Counties. It was named for Elisha Mitchell (1793-1857), professor at the University of North Carolina who was killed while exploring the peak that now bears his name—the highest point E of the Mississippi. Area: 220 sq. mi. County seat: Bakersville, with an elevation of 2,550 ft. Townships are Bakersville, Bradshaw, Cane Creek, Fork Mountain, Grassy Creek, Harrell, Little Rock Creek, Poplar, Red Hill, and Snow Creek. Produces tobacco, Christmas trees, apples, corn, hay, dairy products, livestock, textiles, apparel, hosiery, lumber, mica, gypsum, feldspar, kaolin, and quartz.

label: Mitchell Cove
description: W Haywood County on the head of Mitchell Cove Branch.

label: Mitchell Cove Branch
description: rises in W Haywood County and flows SE into Jonathans Creek.

label: Mitchell Creek
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows NE into Timber Creek. See also Mitchell Falls.

label: Mitchell Falls
description: S Yancey County on Mitchell Creek. It was there that Elisha Mitchell fell to his death in June 1857.

label: Mitchell Lick
description: on Cherokee-Graham county line approx. ½ mi. from the North Carolina-Tennessee state line on the headwaters of Snowbird Creek. It is a site at which early settlers salted stock and to which wild animals also came for salt.

label: Mitchell Mountain
description: NE Henderson County.

label: Mitchell Ridge
description: S Yancey County between Mitchell and Timber Creeks.

label: Mitchell River
description: rises in SE Alleghany County and flows E into Surry County, where it enters Yadkin River. Appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Mitchell Swamp
description: rises in W Robeson County and flows S into South Carolina.

label: Mitchell's Island
description: W Craven County in Trent River. Size: 361 acres, partly cultivated; the remainder is swamp.

label: Mitchells Fork
description: community in S Gates County.

label: Mitchells Township
description: N central Bertie County.

label: Mitcheners Pond
description: W Franklin County on Buffalo Creek. Formed in 1907. Covers 50 acres, with a max. depth of 12 ft.

label: Mitchenor's Station
description: See Selma.

label: Mitchiners Crossroads
description: community in NW Franklin County.

label: Mitford
description: community in SW Rowan County served by post office, 1891-1903.

label: Mix
description: community in NW Sampson County served by post office, 1886-1906.

label: Mixon Bay
description: E Beaufort County E of Bayview and opening into Pamlico River.

label: Mizell
description: community in NW Washington County.

label: Mizpah
description: community in S Stokes County served by post office, 1884-1932.

label: Moadam's Creek
description: rises in E Alamance County and flows W into Back Creek.

label: Mobley Point
description: extends from W Carteret County into White Oak River.

label: Moccasin Canal
description: E Washington County, drains from the N shore of Lake Phelps NE to Scuppernong River. Approx. 4.2 mi. long.

label: Moccasin Creek
description: rises in W Wilson County and flows S and SE into Contentnea Creek.

label: Moccasin Gap
description: W Madison County between Partridge Gap Ridge and Hopis Branch.

label: Moccasin Mountain
description: S Cherokee County, extends SE from Sheep Knob to the Clay County line.

label: Moccasin River
description: a name sometimes applied to the lower part of Contentnea Creek after it has been joined by Little Contentnea Creek. The section of the creek lies on the Lenoir-Pitt county line.

label: Moccasin Swamp
description: rises in E Johnston County and W Wayne County and flows S on the Johnston-Wayne county line into Neuse River.

label: Mocksville
description: town and county seat, central Davie County. Named for the Mock family, owners of the land on which the town was founded. Inc. 1839. Post office est. there, 1826. Produces apparel, furniture, chemicals. Alt. 866.

label: Mocksville Township
description: central Davie County.

label: Moffet Branch
description: rises in S Clay County and flows N into Shooting Creek.

label: Moffitt
description: community in SE Randolph County on Richland Creek. Named for Hugh Moffitt, who operated the first flour and feed mill there. A post office est. 1823 and discontinued 1935 was known as Moffitt's Mills.

label: Moffitt Hill
description: community in SW McDowell County.

label: Moffitt Mountain
description: E Jackson County between Chastine Creek and Coward Mountain.

label: Moffitt's Mills
description: See Moffitt.

label: Mohawk
description: community in W Harnett County served by post office, 1891-1908.

label: Mojoson
description: community in NW Guilford County.

label: Molasses Creek
description: a tidal creek in SE Brunswick County, rises in the swampy NE part of Oak Island and flows E into Elizabeth River.

label: Mollie
description: community in S Columbus County.

label: Mollie Branch
description: rises in W Avery County and flow E into Roaring Creek.

label: Mollie Ridge
description: W Avery County.

label: Molly Fork
description: rises in NE Rutherford County and flows SE and NE into First Broad River.

label: Moltonville
description: community in E Sampson County.

label: Momeyer
description: community in W central Nash County. Est. about 1910 and named for Thomas Momeyer, local resident who est. a sawmill there. Previously the community had been known as Bass's Crossroads. Alt. 190.

label: Mon Swamp
description: in SE Tyrrell County.

label: Monbo
description: community in E Catawba County on Catawba River. Named Mont Beau by the owner of a local cotton mill, but residents of the area soon corrupted the name into its present form. See also East Monbo.

label: Moncure
description: community in SE Chatham County on Deep River. A post office est. there in 1877. Inc. 1905; charter repealed1935. Named for Thomas Jefferson Moncure, civil engineer, who built the railroad station. The former town of Haywood is immediately SE of Moncure.

label: Mondine Branch
description: rises in S Jones County and flows S into White Oak River. Probably named for the Mundine family, early settlers.

label: Money
description: See Etowah.

label: Money Island
description: E New Hanover County in Greenville Sound W of Wrightsville Beach. Several acres in area, it is the traditional hiding place of pirate treasure.

label: Money Island Bay
description: in Bogue Sound, S Carteret County between Atlantic Beach and Tar Landing Bay and opposite Morehead City.

label: Money Island Swamp
description: rises in central Carteret County and flows SW into Black Creek.

label: Monger Creek
description: rises in SE Macon County and flows NE into Lake Sequoyah.

label: Monie Swamp
description: is formed in S Columbus County by Gum Swamp and Beaverdam Swamp. It flows S to join Big Cypress Swamp in forming Seven Creeks.

label: Monkey Island
description: in Currituck Sound, N Currituck County 4 mi. E of Church Island. Approx. ½ mi. square. Site of an old hunting lodge. Appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Monkey Junction
description: See Fort Fisher Junction.

label: Monks Crossroads
description: community in N Sampson County between Mill and Craddock Swamps.

label: Monroe
description: former community in NE Warren County on Roanoke River. Grew up around Robinson's Ferry after Clack Robinson laid out a town on his lands near the ferry in 1818, named it for President James Monroe, and sold lots to prospective citizens; a post office, tavern, racetrack, tobacco warehouse, and stores soon sprang up. It was shown on the MacRae map, 1833, as a well-established community. In 1840, when the Raleigh and Gaston Railroad was completed, it began a rapid decline.

label: Monroe Mountain
description: N Cherokee County between Allen Branch and Davis Creek. Alt. 3,171.

label: Monroe Township
description: central Union County.

label: Monroes Millpond
description: N Scotland County on Jordans Creek. Formed about 1825; known in the 1850s as McWilliams Pond. Covers 70 acres; max. depth 14 ft. Owned by Fayetteville Presbytery and used as a recreation area.

label: Monroeton
description: community in S Rockingham County between Troublesome Creek and Haw River. Est. prior to 1832; probably named for James Monroe (1758-1831), president of the United States. Cunningham Mill, built by James Patrick Sr. in 1818, still stands nearby. Patrick cemetery has graves dating from 1771. Cotton gin est. 1835.

label: Monroetown
description: an African American community in S Moore County approx. 4 mi. N of Pinehurst. Named for John Monroe, who est. the settlement about 1915.

label: Mont Beau
description: See Monbo; East Monbo.

label: Montague
description: community in SW Pender County. Alt. 39. Named for a local resident.

label: Monteith
description: community in E Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1880-1903.

label: Monteith Branch
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows SE into Scott Creek.

label: Montezuma
description: community in central Avery County. Known first as Bull Scrape (see Bullscrape Gap). Inc. 1891. Post office est. there in 1883 as Aaron; name changed to Montezuma in 1911. Named for Aztec chief of ancient Mexico (1479-1520). Long inactive in municipal affairs. Alt. 3,797.

label: Montford
description: former town in central Buncombe County. Inc. 1893; became a part of Asheville in 1905.

label: Montford Cove Church
description: See Whitehouse.

label: Montford Cove Township
description: S central McDowell County.

label: Montford Point
description: See Mount Pleasant Point.

label: Montgomery
description: See Graham.

label: Montgomery Corner
description: a point on the North  Carolina-Georgia state line at the SE end of Sharptop Ridge, SE Clay County due S of 30 Mile Post, which see. From the point, the state line runs W to the junction of the North Carolina-Georgia-Tennessee state lines.

label: Montgomery County
description: was formed in 1779 from Anson County. Located in the S central section of the state, it is bounded by Moore, Richmond, Stanly, Davidson, and Randolph Counties. It was named for Gen. Richard Montgomery (1736-75), Revolutionary War leader who was killed in the Battle of Quebec. Area: 499 sq. mi. County seat: Troy, with an elevation of 664 ft. Townships are Biscoe, Cheek Creek, Eldorado, Little River, Mount Gilead, Ophir, Peedee, Rocky Springs, Troy, and Uwharrie. Produces peaches, oats, wheat, corn, tobacco, cotton, poultry, hogs, livestock, cantaloupes, watermelons, textiles, furniture, packaging, carpets, mobile homes, lumber, apparel, clay, slate, pyrophyllite, and sand.

label: Montgomery Slough
description: a tidal waterway in SE Brunswick County located just inside Long Beach and extending 2½ mi. W to Eastern Channel.

label: Monticello
description: community in W Harnett County.

label: Monticello
description: former community and post office in SW Washington County approx. 1½ mi. N of the Tare-over. Settled prior to 1886; post office, 1893-96.

label: Montland
description: community in W Alleghany County served by post office, 1892-1904.

label: Montpelier
description: See Wagram.

label: Montreat
description: town in NE Buncombe County on Flat Creek. Alt. 2,500. Est. by Mountain Retreat Association, chartered 1897. Montreat is derived from the words "Mountain Retreat." Later acquired by Presbyterian Church and now operated as its Assembly Grounds (4,500 acres). Historical Foundation (library and museum) and Montreat College are there. Inc. 1967.

label: Montrose
description: community in W Hoke County. Alt. 483.

label: Montvale
description: community in SW Transylvania County.

label: Moody Branch
description: rises in E Cherokee County and flows S into Peachtree Creek.

label: Moody Branch
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows N into Bunches Creek.

label: Moody Cove
description: N Buncombe County W of Pine Mountain.

label: Moody Gap
description: on the Buncombe-Madison county line E of Moody Knob.

label: Moody Knob
description: NW Jackson County between Camp Creek and Hyatt Cove.

label: Moody Mountain
description: S Yancey County between Bowlens and Cattail Creeks.

label: Moody Stamp
description: NE Cherokee County in the Snowbird Mountains.

label: Moody Top
description: W Haywood County between Fie Top and Hemphill Creek. Alt. 5,320.

label: Moodys Mill Creek
description: rises in SW Watauga County and flows NE into Spice Bottom Creek.

label: Moon Creek
description: rises in W Caswell County and flows NE into Dan River.

label: Mooney Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows SE into Hemp Patch Branch.

label: Mooney Gap
description: at the head of Mooney Branch in S Macon County.

label: Moore
description: community in W Orange County served by post office, 1897-1905.

label: Moore Branch
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows NW into Middle Fork [South Fork New River].

label: Moore County
description: was formed in 1784 from Cumberland County. Located in the S central section of the state, it is bounded by Cumberland, Harnett, Hoke, Scotland, Richmond, Montgomery, Randolph, Chatham, and Lee Counties. It was named for Capt. Alfred Moore (1755-1810) of Brunswick County, a Revolutionary War soldier and a judge on the U.S. Supreme Court. Area: 760 sq. mi. County seat: Carthage, with an elevation of 575 ft. Townships are Carthage, Bensalem, Sheffields, Ritters, Deep River, Greenwood, McNeills, Sandhills, Mineral Springs, Little River. Produces corn, wheat, hay, oats, poultry, eggs, livestock, hogs, carpets, hosiery, textiles, canned foods, furniture, pyrophyllite, sand, clay, and gravel.

label: Moore Cove
description: between Bear Branch and Seniard Mountain in NW Henderson County.

label: Moore Creek
description: rises in SW Buncombe County near Stony Knob and flows SE into Hominy Creek.

label: Moore Creek
description: rises in SW Macon County and flows SW into Nantahala River. Also known locally as Jarrett Creek.

label: Moore Gap
description: on the Madison-Yancey county line near the head of Possumtrot Creek. Alt. approx. 3,100.

label: Moore Inlet
description: NE New Hanover County between Mason Inlet on the N and Masonboro Inlet on the s. The waters of Middle Sound enter the Atlantic Ocean through the inlet. Sometimes known as Wrightsville Inlet.

label: Moore Knob
description: E Macon County between Ellijay Creek and North Prong Ellijay Creek.

label: Moore Mountain
description: central Avery County.

label: Moore Springs Branch
description: in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, rises in NW Swain County and flows SW into Twentymile Creek.

label: Moore's Lake
description: central Anson County. Formed 1948. Fed by two springs. Covers 11 acres; max. depth 24 ft. Fishing and boating. Took its name from owner Bernard W. Moore.

label: Moores Beach
description: community in E Beaufort County on the N shore of Pamlico River, 35°23'51" N., 76°37'15" W. Formerly known also as Wade Point and Wades Point.

label: Moores Branch
description: rises in central Clay County between Church Branch and Moss Branch and flows S into Tusquitee Creek.

label: Moores Corner
description: community in S Pamlico County.

label: Moores Creek
description: rises in NW Pender County and flows S into Black River. Sometimes referred to as Widow Moores Creek in the eighteenth century; probably named for the "Widow Eliz Moore," who owned land adjacent as early as 1735. It was on the stream that the Battle of Moores Creek Bridge was fought on February 27, 1776, the first battle of the Revolutionary War in North Carolina. See also Currie.

label: Moores Crossroads
description: community in W Wilson County near the head of Lee Swamp.

label: Moores Knob
description: in the Sauratown Mountain range, W Stokes County in Hanging Rock State Park. See also Tories Den.

label: Moores Pond
description: S Franklin County on Little River. Covers 100 acres, with a max. depth of 10 ft.

label: Moores Spring
description: former community and resort in W Stokes County on Cascade Creek. Flourished from about 1870 until the early twentieth century. The hotel burned about 1935, and the site is now a popular campground. Bottled water from the spring was widely marketed.

label: Mooresboro
description: community in W Cleveland County. Alt. 970. Settled in 1780s; inc. 1885. Charter repealed 1943. Named for Lem Moore, an early settler.

label: Mooresville
description: See Warsaw.

label: Moose Cove
description: central Cherokee County.

label: Mooshaunee
description: community in N Moore County founded around railroad siding and school.

label: Moratock
description: community in W Montgomery County served by post office, 1892-1926.

label: Morattico River
description: See Roanoke River.

label: Moratuc
description: village of the Moratuc Indian tribe on the Roanoke River near the present junction of Bertie, Martin, and Washington Counties. Appears on the White map, 1585; the Velasco map, 1611; and the Smith map, 1624. See also Roanoke River.

label: Moravian Creek
description: rises in S Wilkes County and flows NE into Yadkin River. Named for the fact that Moravians had a grant from Earl Granville (see Granville District) there in the eighteenth century.

label: Moravian Falls
description: community in S Wilkes County between Moravian and Cub Creeks. Alt. 1,206. Est. in the late eighteenth century and named for the nearby waterfall.

label: Moravian Falls Township
description: S Wilkes County.

label: Morehead
description: See Rudd.

label: Morehead Bluffs
description: See Edgewater.

label: Morehead City
description: town in S central Carteret County on Bogue Sound and Newport River. Summer resort and the only deep-sea port in the state N of Wilmington; state port facilities are there. Inc. 1861 and named for John Motley Morehead (1796-1866), governor of North Carolina, who had bought land there in 1853 as the terminus of a newly inc. railroad. Ships are built there; produces asphalt and apparel. The site was formerly known as Shepherds’ Point, which see. Alt. 16.

label: Morehead Township
description: central Guilford County. Named for Governor John Motley Morehead (1796-1866) of Greensboro. Covers most of the W half of Greensboro.

label: Moretz
description: community in NE Watauga County on Meat Camp Creek. A post office operated there, 1849-1910.

label: Morgan Bay
description: in central Onslow County in New River.

label: Morgan Branch
description: rises in N Buncombe County and flows N into McKinney Branch.

label: Morgan Branch
description: rises in central Clay County and flows NW then SW into Cold Branch.

label: Morgan Cove
description: SW Buncombe County SW of Luthers.

label: Morgan Creek
description: rises in S Pender County and flows SW into Long Creek.

label: Morgan District
description: at the time of the 1790 census, was composed of Burke, Lincoln, Rutherford, and Wilkes Counties.

label: Morgan Hill
description: peak in S Transylvania County near the mouth of Cherryfield Creek.

label: Morgan Hill
description: community in N Buncombe County.

label: Morgan Mill Creek
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows SE then NE into French Broad River.

label: Morgan Mills Ford
description: N Union County on Rocky River. Site of a large gristmill dating from the middle of the nineteenth century. The building and machinery still stand, but the mill no longer operates.

label: Morgan Ridge
description: N Buncombe County, an extension of Bill Cole Mountain.

label: Morgan Township
description: NW Rutherford County.

label: Morgan's Branch
description: rises in N Wilson County and flows SE into Cattail Swamp.

label: Morgan's Mills
description: community in NE Union County.

label: Morganton
description: town and county seat, central Burke County. Est. 1784 as Morgansborough. Alt. 1,182. Named for Gen. Daniel Morgan (1736?-1802), Revolutionary War leader. Western Piedmont Community College, est. 1966, is located there. Produces furniture, electronic components, hosiery, apparel, textiles, and dairy products.

label: Morganton Township
description: S central Burke County.

label: Morgantown
description: community in E Carteret County near the NW limits of Newport.

label: Moriah
description: community in SE Person County.

label: Morlin Mountain
description: N Rutherford County between Cane Creek and the head of South Creek. Alt. approx. 2,100.

label: Morning Star
description: community in E Haywood County on the head of Allens Creek.

label: Morning Star Township
description: former township in SE Mecklenburg County, now township no. 13.

label: Morris Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SE and SW into Valley River.

label: Morris Field Air Base
description: in Charlotte, central Mecklenburg County, was dedicated April 21, 1941, and used to train combat pilots during World War II. Named for Maj. William C. Morris of Cabarrus County, distinguished World War I pilot. Property returned to city of Charlotte in 1946 for use as municipal airport.

label: Morris Knob
description: S Wilkes County at the SW end of Gill Mountain.

label: Morris Landing
description: community in SW Onslow County on Stump Sound.

label: Morris Mountain
description: N Montgomery County between Bundle Mountain and Barnes Creek.

label: Morris Pond
description: on Juniper Creek, SE Lee County. Formed about 1865. Covers 25 acres; max. depth 8 ft. Formerly a millpond, now used for fishing, swimming, and boating.

label: Morris Run
description: rises in SW Beaufort County and flows NW into Chocowinity Creek.

label: Morrison
description: community in S Richmond County.

label: Morrison Creek
description: rises in W Iredell County and flows E into Fourth Creek. Formerly known as Middle Fourth Creek.

label: Morrison's Tan Yard
description: community in SE Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1820-71.

label: Morristown
description: See Asheville.

label: Morrisville
description: town in W Wake County on Crabtree Creek. Settled 1840; chartered in 1875 and named for Jerry Morris, who owned the town site. Charter repealed in 1933. Reincorporated in 1947. Alt. 304.

label: Morrosenean
description: community in W Robeson County served by post office, 1871-1901.

label: Morrow Branch
description: rises in S Madison County and flows S into Little Sandymush Creek.

label: Morrow Creek
description: rises in S Rutherford County and flows NE into Second Broad River.

label: Morrow Gap
description: W Cherokee County between Shuler and Sular Creeks.

label: Morrow Mountain State Park
description: E Stanly County on Yadkin and Pee Dee Rivers. 4,135 acres. Est. 1935 on land given in large part by James McKnight Morrow. Former Naked Mountain, which see, renamed Morrow Mountain. Scenic, recreational area; picnicking, swimming, fishing, tent and trailer camping, boating, hiking, nature study, museum, restaurant, and recreation lodge. There are several peaks (Mill Mountain, Sugarloaf Mountain, and Tater Top Mountain) in the park, none of which is over 1,050 ft. in alt.

label: Morrow's Turnout
description: community in SW Mecklenburg County. Formerly known as Mount Moriah (post office, 1830-31, 1849-52), Mount Leer (post office, 1831-49), and since 1852 Pineville.

label: Morse Point
description: a neck of land extending from Virginia into the mouth of North Landing River in NE Currituck County.

label: Mortimer
description: town in W Caldwell County. Inc. 1907, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Alt. 1,502. Largely a ghost town. Est. in connection with a lumber mill.

label: Morton Creek
description: rises in W Transylvania County and flows SE into South Fork Flat Creek.

label: Morton Township
description: former township in NW Alamance County, now township no. 4.

label: Mortons Store
description: community in N Alamance County served by post office, 1852-1906.

label: Morven
description: town in SE Anson County. Inc. 1883. Post office est. there in 1823 and named for Morven, Scotland, home of the mother of Hugh McKenzie, first postmaster. Alt. 341.

label: Morven Township
description: SE Anson County.

label: Moscow
description: community in NW Bladen County served by post office, 1892-1907.

label: Moseley County
description: In about 1907 an unsigned petition was presented to the General Assembly proposing that a county be created from portions of Lenoir, Wayne, and Greene Counties, with the county seat at LaGrange. It was to be named for William D. Moseley (1795-1863), who was born near LaGrange and who was governor of Florida, 1845-49. The General Assembly apparently never acted on the petition.

label: Moseley Creek
description: rises in NW Lenoir County and flows SE into Falling Creek. Named for Matthew Moseley, who settled there about 1770.

label: Moseley Hall
description: See LaGrange.

label: Moseley Hall Township
description: NW Lenoir County. Named for plantation house of Moseley family.

label: Moseley's Cove
description: S Pender County on Northeast Cape Fear River. Adjacent land once was owned by Edward Moseley (1682-1749), colonial surveyor general and member of the governor's council.

label: Moseley's Creek
description: See Parrotts Creek.

label: Moseleys Point
description: See Hornblower Point.

label: Moser
description: community in S Surry County served by post office, 1889-1905.

label: Moses Branch
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows E into Jacks Creek.

label: Moses Creek
description: formed by junction of East Fork and West Fork in N Jackson County and flows SW into Caney Fork.

label: Moses H. Cone Memorial Park
description: S Watauga County on Blue Ridge Parkway NW of Blowing Rock. Est. 1950. Former estate of textile executive Moses H. Cone (1857-1908); 3,517 acres. Flat Top Manor is now a museum and craft center at which mountain handicrafts are sold. Trails for hiking and horseback riding and lakes for fishing are there. See also Bass Lake.

label: Moses Knob
description: on the Jackson-Macon county line.

label: Moss
description: community in N Cherokee County.

label: Moss
description: community in NE Stanly County.

label: Moss Branch
description: rises in E Macon County and flows S into Little Buck Creek.

label: Moss Gap
description: on the Jackson-Macon county line.

label: Moss Knob
description: on the Jackson-Macon county line. Alt. 4,500.

label: Moss Neck
description: community in W central Robeson County.

label: Mossey Islands
description: in Currituck Sound off the W shore of Currituck Banks, SE Currituck County.

label: Mossy Back Gap
description: SW Macon County on Clear Branch.

label: Mossy Branch
description: rises in W Haywood County and flows SE into Cataloochee Creek.

label: Motes Creek
description: rises in SE Alamance County and flows S into Haw River.

label: Mott Creek
description: rises in E Onslow County and flows NW into Northeast Creek.

label: Mott Swamp
description: rises in E Lenoir County and flows N into Southwest Creek.

label: Motts Creek
description: See Todds Creek.

label: Motts Falls
description: rapids in the Yadkin River, S Davidson County near the mouth of Riles and Ellis Creeks. The rapids extend approx. 8/10 of a mi. and drop 13½ ft., having 6 nearly vertical falls of from 6 in. to 2 ft. each.

label: Moulder Branch
description: rises in S Alamance County in the Cane Creek Mountains and flows SE into Cane Creek. Also known as Foust's Creek.

label: Moulton
description: community in N Franklin County.

label: Mount Airy
description: town in NE Surry County. Alt. 1,104. Settled about 1850; inc. 1869. In the early nineteenth century, the vicinity was called the Hollow or Hallow. See also Perkinsville.

label: Mount Airy Township
description: N Surry County.

label: Mount Ararat
description: See Pilot Mountain.

label: Mount Bolus
description: hill in SE Orange County near Bolin Creek ½ mi. N of Chapel Hill. An extinct volcano. Said to have been named by university students after "Old Diabolus" (devil), their nickname for Joseph Caldwell, president of the university, 1796-1835. Appears as Gander Mountain in local records as late as 1792.

label: Mount Buckley
description: the southernmost of three knobs, the central one of which is Clingmans Dome and the northernmost Mount Love, in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on the border of Swain County, N.C., and Sevier County, Tenn., lat. 35°33'15" N., long. 83°30' W. Named by Arnold H. Guyot prior to 1860 in honor of naturalist S. B. Buckley (1809-84), Guyot's friend and sometime coworker. Alt. 6,500.

label: Mount Calvert
description: See Grimesland.

label: Mount Cammerer
description: on the Haywood County, N.C.-Cocke County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Cammerer Ridge about lat. 35°45'50" N., long. 83°09'40" W. Named in honor of A. B. Cammerer, formerly of the U.S. Department of the Interior, who was active in promoting the park. Alt. approx. 4,928.

label: Mount Carmel
description: community in S Vance County on Sandy Creek. Named for a local church, which was in turn named for the biblical mountain in NW Palestine from which Elijah called down fire from Heaven.

label: Mount Chapman
description: in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Swain County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line, lat. 35°41' N., long. 83°17' W. Named for David Carpenter Chapman (1876-1938?) of Knoxville, Tenn., whose initiative and persistent activity over many years was largely responsible for the establishment of the Great Smoky Mountains National Park by the act of Congress approved on May 22, 1926. Alt. 6,425. Formerly known as Black, Old Black, and The Black.

label: Mount Collier
description: S Orange County at NE end of Grampian Hills.

label: Mount Collins
description: in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on the Swain County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line, lat. 35°35' N., long. 83°28' W. Named for Robert Collins (1806-63), one of the first settlers in the area and a guide for Arnold Guyot and other explorers. Mount Collins was renamed Mount Kephart in 1928, but that name was later given to another peak. Alt. 6,255.

label: Mount Craig
description: peak in Mount Mitchell State Park, S Yancey County near lat. 35°46'40" N., long. 82°15'40" W. Alt. 6,663. Second-highest peak in the state. One of two peaks known as Black Brothers until 1947, when renamed in honor of Governor Locke Craig (1860-1924), who was largely responsible for the establishment of Mount Mitchell State Park. Known earlier as Balsam Cone.

label: Mount Davis
description: in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on the Swain County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line. Alt. approx. 5,000. Formerly named Greenbrier Knob; renamed about 1950 for Willis P. Davis of Knoxville, Tenn., who started the movement for the establishment of the park. Located at lat. 35°34'15" N., long. 83°38'03" W.

label: Mount Energy
description: community in S Granville County served by post office, 1877-1900.

label: Mount Gallant
description: elevation in NW Northampton County. Alt. 250. Plantation there was owned by William Maule and called by the name in 1723. Governor William Tryon visited Mount Gallant in 1765 and remarked upon the fine view from its summit. Appears on the Collet map, 1770, and on the MacRae map, 1833.

label: Mount Gibbes
description: S Yancey County in Black Mountains between Clingmans Dome and Stepps Gap. Alt. 6,600. Named about 1852 for Dr. Robert Wilson Gibbes (1809-66) of Columbia, S.C., the first to measure its altitude.

label: Mount Gilead
description: town in SW Montgomery County. Settled by 1835, when a post office was est. there. Inc. 1899. Originally called Providence and was part of a 1797 land grant to William Scarborough. Named for the biblical mountain. Alt. 421. Produces shoes, hosiery, textiles, and apparel.

label: Mount Gilead Township
description: SW Montgomery County.

label: Mount Glory
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Welch Ridge near the head of White Mans Glory Creek, lat. 35°31'22" N., long. 83°36'08" W. Alt. 4,965.

label: Mount Golland
description: See Mount Gould.

label: Mount Gould
description: community in E central Bertie County served by post office, 1829-1907. Developed at the site of a plantation first known as Mount Golland and later Mount Gould after George Gould, a surveyor, came into possession of it. Littledals Ferry on the Chowan River nearby appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Mount Guyot
description: in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on the Haywood County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line near lat. 35°42'20" N., long. 83°15'30" W. Alt. 6,621. Named by Prof. S. B. Buckley prior to 1859 in honor of Arnold Guyot, geographer, who made the first comprehensive survey of the region and did much to stimulate public interest in the mountains. Known by the Cherokee Indians as Sornook

label: Mount Hardison
description: NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park at the N end of Dashoga Ridge. Alt. 6,148. Named for James Archibald Hardison (1867-1930) of Anson County, an original member of the N.C. State Park Commission.

label: Mount Hardy
description: S Haywood County near lat. 35°18'15" N., long. 82°55'38" W. Named 1957-58 for Dr. James F. E. Hardy of Asheville, who, in cooperation with Arnold Guyot, explored and named many of the mountains of W North Carolina in the 1850s. Formerly known as Black Mountain. Alt. 6,110.

label: Mount Hardy Gap
description: S Haywood County near lat. 35°17'55" N., long. 82°55'30" W. Formerly known as Black Mountain Gap.

label: Mount Heckler
description: former mountain in NE Gaston County. Following the construction of the dam on the Catawba River at the site, it was almost covered by water. Its peak now forms an island in Mountain Island Lake. Named for Mount Hecla Mill in Greensboro. In 1848 a cotton mill was transplanted near there from Greensboro by the son-in-law of the owner of Mount Hecla Mill. See also Mountain Island Lake.

label: Mount Hermon
description: community in S Caldwell County. Named for Mount Hermon Church.

label: Mount Hermon Township
description: W central Pasquotank County.

label: Mount Holly
description: town in E Gaston County. Post office est. as Huntersville in 1800, named for Rev. Humphrey Hunter, postmaster. Name changed to Woodlawn in 1846. Inc. 1879 as Mount Holly, named for the town in New Jersey where fine yarns were manufactured. Produces textiles and hosiery. Alt. 621. See also Nims.

label: Mount Holly Ferry
description: crossed the Catawba River in NW Mecklenburg into Gaston County.

label: Mount Ida
description: central McDowell County at the S limits of the town of Marion. Alt. approx. 2,000. Named for Ida Neal.

label: Mount Jefferson
description: SE of and named for town of Jefferson in central Ashe County. State park of 474 acres is maintained there for sightseeing and picnicking; created 1956. Appears in local records as Nigger Mountain as early as 1810; name changed at the creation of the park. Original name given because of the black appearance of the weathered granite of which much of the mountain is composed. A cave near the top is said to have been used by slaves fleeing to Ohio before the Civil War. Alt. 4,683.

label: Mount Junaluska
description: See Jones Knob.

label: Mount Kephart
description: in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on the Swain County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line, lat. 35°38' N., long 83°24' W. Named in 1928 for Horace Kephart (1862-1931), explorer, naturalist, and authority on campcraft who lived in the area for many years. Alt. 6,400. Mount Collins, nearby, bore the name Mount Kephart for a short while. The Jump Off, on the Tennessee side of Mount Kephart, was formerly believed to be in North Carolina. A cliff there drops vertically for almost 500 ft. and then nearly vertically for an additional 1,000 ft.

label: Mount Leer
description: See Morrow's Turnout.

label: Mount Love
description: in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on the Swain County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line, lat. 35°33'30" N., long. 83°30' W. Named by Arnold Guyot before 1860 for Dr. S. L. Love (1828-87), who accompanied T. L. Clingman and S. O. Buckley in 1858 when Clingmans Dome was first measured. Alt. approx. 6,500.

label: Mount Misery
description: appears on the Collet map, 1770, as a large sand hill N of Eagle Island in W New Hanover County. A ferry across the Cape Fear River was operated there from as early as 1754 and possibly through the Revolution.

label: Mount Mitchell
description: community in S Mitchell County on East Fork Grassy Creek.

label: Mount Mitchell State Park
description: S Yancey County. Covers 1,224 acres. Est. 1915 as the first state park in North Carolina. Scenic area, tent camping, picnicking, hiking, nature study, museum, recreation lodge, and lookout tower.

label: Mount Mourne
description: town in S Iredell County. Inc. 1875, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Settled prior to the American Revolution and took its name from the home of Rufus Reid, which Reid had named Mount Mourne for the mountain in Ireland. At Torrence's Tavern there, Lt. Col. Tarleton's British cavalry routed a force of American militia, February 2, 1781. Crowfield Academy, an early classical school about a mi. s, was est. 1760 and closed by the time of the Revolution.

label: Mount Nebo
description: See Nebo.

label: Mount Night
description: See Pores Knob.

label: Mount Noble
description: E Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, lat. 35°30'20" N., long. 83°20'15" W.

label: Mount Olive
description: town in S Wayne County. Inc. 1870. Named by Benjamin Oliver, local resident, for biblical Mount of Olives. Town limits now encompass former community of Enterprise, which see. Center for marketing produce—vegetables, strawberries, and grapes; site of a large cucumber-pickle processing plant. Mount Olive College is there.

label: Mount Pisgah
description: community in N Rutherford County on Little Camp Creek.

label: Mount Pleasant
description: See Elliott.

label: Mount Pleasant
description: See Johnsonville.

label: Mount Pleasant Creek
description: rises in E Randolph County and flows SW into Sandy Creek.

label: Mount Pleasant Point
description: extends from E Onslow County into White Oak River about 20 ft. above the water. Named for the pre-Revolutionary plantation of Emanuel Jones. Also known as Montford Point, which see, in recent years.

label: Mount Pleasant Township
description: former township in E Cabarrus County, now township no. 8.

label: Mount Prospect
description: See Waynesville.

label: Mount Regis
description: See Norlina.

label: Mount Sequoyah
description: in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on the Swain County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line, lat. 35°40' N., long. 83°18'15" W. Alt. approx. 6,000. Named for Sequoyah (1770?-1843), Indian who devised a Cherokee alphabet used in teaching thousands to read and write.

label: Mount Squires
description: in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on the Swain County, N.C.-Blount County, Tenn., line between McCampbell Knob and Rocky Top near lat. 35°33'47" N., long. 83°44'30" W. Alt. 5,042. Named for state senator Mark Squires (1878-1938), a leader in the movement to establish the park. Formerly known as Little Bald.

label: Mount Sterling
description: community in W Haywood County on Big Creek near lat. 35°45'42" N., long. 83°06'15" W.

label: Mount Sterling Creek
description: rises in W Haywood County and flows NE into Pigeon River.

label: Mount Sterling Gap
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°42' N., long. 83°05'59" W. Alt. 3,887.

label: Mount Sterling Ridge
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park from Balsam Mountain extending NE from lat. 35°40'17" N., long. 83°10'55" W., forming the watershed between Big Creek and Cataloochee Creek.

label: Mount Tirzah
description: community in S Person County. Named in 1783 by Col. Stephen Moore, Revolutionary soldier. A post office operated there, 1795-1906.

label: Mount Tirzah Township
description: SE Person County.

label: Mount Ulla
description: community in W Rowan County. Said to have been named for "a place in Ireland," probably the village of Oola. Wood Grove post office est. there in 1830; named for plantation home of Capt. Thomas Cowan, which still stands. Named changed to Mount Ulla in 1842 and to Rowan for a few months in 1900. Alt. 839.

label: Mount Ulla Township
description: W central Rowan County.

label: Mount Vernon
description: crossroads community in central Rutherford County between Catheys Creek and Second Broad River.

label: Mount Vernon Springs
description: community in W Chatham County. The springs, a popular resort area in the early and middle nineteenth century, are approx. 1 mi. w; known earlier as Hickory Springs. The present community was inc. as Ore Hill in 1907, but the charter was repealed in 1913. Named for the home of George Washington. Alt. 500. See also Wilcox Iron Works.

label: Mount Willing
description: W Orange County on the head of Toms Creek.

label: Mount Yonaguska
description: on the Haywood-Swain county line between Tricorner Knob and Luftee Knob in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°41'40" N., long. 83°14'53" W. Alt. 6,150. Named for Yonaguska, chief of the Cherokee Indians.

label: Mount Zion
description: See Chowan Beach.

label: Mountain Branch
description: rises in N Stokes County and flows E into Snow Creek.

label: Mountain Canal
description: E Washington County, extends NE from Lake Phelps to Scuppernong River.

label: Mountain Creek
description: rises in W Gaston County and flows SW into Long Creek.

label: Mountain Creek
description: community in SE Catawba County.

label: Mountain Creek Township
description: SE Catawba County.

label: Mountain Home
description: community in N Henderson County.

label: Mountain Island
description: town in NE Gaston County on Catawba River at Mountain Island Lake. Inc. 1891, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Formerly ferry site across Catawba River. See also Mountain Island Lake.

label: Mountain Island Branch
description: rises in W Madison County and flows NE into French Broad River.

label: Mountain Island Lake
description: on the Catawba River, Gaston and Mecklenburg Counties. Formed 1922-24. Covers 3,235 acres, with a shoreline of 61 mi. Owned by Duke Energy and site of hydroelectric power plant. See also Mount Heckler.

label: Mountain Park
description: community in W Surry County est. 1913 and named for its mountain location in a parklike setting.

label: Mountain Region, Mountain Section
description: or simply terms applied to the mountainous section of W North Carolina. The E limit of the region runs generally through Surry, Wilkes, Caldwell, Burke, Rutherford, and Polk Counties. The Indians referred to the area as Ottaray (Highlands). White settlers sometimes rendered the word into English as Otaré, which they translated as "Over Hills." See also Appalachian Mountains.

label: Mountain Run
description: rises in E Caldwell County and flows S into Upper Little River.

label: Mountain Run Creek
description: rises in W Rockingham Creek and flows into Mayo River. Named for Cedar Point Mountain, where creek originates.

label: Mountain Tea Branch
description: rises near Henry Mountain in S Transylvania County and flows S into East Fork French Broad River. Named for the abundance of wintergreen that grows near the branch, the herb from which "mountain tea" is made.

label: Mountain Township
description: SW Jackson County.

label: Mountain Valley
description: community in S McDowell County. Named for plantation owned by George Gradin.

label: Mountain View
description: community in S Stokes County between the head of Danbury Creek and Town Fork Creek. Mountain View Institute, an academy, operated there, 1895-1920.

label: Mountain View
description: former community in E Warren County. A post office was est. there in 1879 but was discontinued in 1929.

label: Mountainside Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows NW into Big Mooney Branch.

label: Mountainside Grove
description: community on Falls Branch in E Macon County.

label: Mouse Creek
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, rises near lat. 35°42'22" N., long. 83°07'17" W., and flows NW into Big Creek. The name is an Indian one.

label: Mouse Harbor
description: bay on the E side of Goose Creek Island, NE Pamlico County in the waters of Pamlico Sound. The shape of the bay on a map vaguely suggests the shape of a mouse.

label: Mouse Knob
description: SW Graham County on Snowbird Creek. The name is a translation of the Indian name.

label: Mouse Mountain
description: N Macon County between Rickman Creek and Bradley Creek.

label: Mowfield
description: community in W Northampton County. Sir Archie, famed thoroughbred, is buried on plantation there.

label: Moxley
description: community in N Wilkes County on Middle Prong Roaring River.

label: Moyes Run
description: rises in E Pitt County and flows SE into Broad Run.

label: Moyock
description: community in NW Currituck County. Name appears in local records as early as 1753. Alt. 5. Rev. Thomas Coke in 1785 recorded that he visited and preached at "Mowyock."

label: Moyock Creek
description: See Shingle Landing Creek.

label: Moyock Township
description: NW Currituck County.

label: Moyton
description: See Stantonsburg.

label: Mucky Branch
description: rises in N Durham County and flows NE into Little River.

label: Mud Castle
description: community in W Northampton County. Named for a pre-Revolutionary plantation there.

label: Mud Creek
description: rises in N Wake County and flows S into Horse Creek. Known previously as Mutton Creek, as shown on several nineteenth-century maps.

label: Mud Gap
description: in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Swain County, N.C.-Blount County, Tenn., line, lat. 35°31'18" N., long. 83°48'24" W.

label: Mud Lick
description: community in NW Chatham County served by post office, 1833-1904.

label: Mudcut Branch
description: rises in SW Swain County and flows SE into Nantahala River.

label: Muddy Branch
description: rises in Green Swamp in W central Brunswick County and flows NE and N into Juniper Creek.

label: Muddy Creek
description: is formed in NE McDowell County by the junction of North Muddy Creek and South Muddy Creek and flows NE into the Catawba River in W Burke County.

label: Muddy Creek
description: community in SW Forsyth County near the Davidson county line. Alt. 726.

label: Muddy Cross
description: community in S Gates County.

label: Muddy Fork
description: rises in E Cleveland County and flows SW into Buffalo Creek.

label: Muddy Fork Creek
description: rises in N central Alexander County and flows SW into Lower Little River.

label: Muddy Slue
description: a slough in the tidal-marsh islands in the Cape Fear River opposite Southport, SE Brunswick County.

label: Mudlick
description: See Mud Lick.

label: Mulatto Branch
description: rises in S Lee County and flows SE into Little Juniper Creek.

label: Mulatto Mountain
description: S Ashe County. Alt. 4,680.

label: Mulberry
description: community in N central Wilkes County at the head of Lousy Creek.

label: Mulberry Bay
description: SW Carteret County in Bogue Sound between Banks Channel and Bogue Inlet.

label: Mulberry Branch
description: rises in Green Swamp, SW Brunswick County, and flows SW into Shallotte River.

label: Mulberry Creek
description: rises in NE Onslow County and flows SE into White Oak River.

label: Mulberry Creek
description: rises in N Wilkes County and flows SE into Yadkin River. Appears as Mulberryfield on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Mulberry Fields
description: See North Wilkesboro.

label: Mulberry Gap
description: at the head of Howard Branch in S Macon County.

label: Mulberry Island
description: was former island and plantation on N side of Dan River in Rockingham County. Owned by Thomas Settle Jr., N.C. Supreme Court justice. No longer extant.

label: Mulberry Point
description: on the S shore of the Neuse River about 5 mi. upstream from its mouth between Cedar Bay and Turnagain Bay in N Carteret County.

label: Mulberry Township
description: N central Caldwell County.

label: Mulcahy
description: See Peachland.

label: Mule Gap
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Welch Ridge, lat. 35°33'02" N., long. 83°34'15" W. Alt. approx. 5,000.

label: Mull Creek
description: rises in N Catawba County and flows NE into Lyle Creek.

label: Mull Creek
description: rises in E Jackson County and flows SW into Caney Fork.

label: Mull Grove
description: community in SW Catawba County served by post office, 1842-1905. Spelled as Mullgrove after 1892.

label: Mullet Gut
description: a stream that rises in W Carteret County and flows SE into Starkey Creek.

label: Mullet Pond
description: a bay on the extreme W end of Shackleford Banks, S Carteret County.

label: Mullgrove
description: See Mull Grove.

label: Mullin Hill
description: mountain in SW Avery County.

label: Mumblehead Top
description: E Cherokee County between the headwaters of Rattler Branch and Brooks Cove.

label: Mumford
description: See Mumfords.

label: Mumford Point
description: central Onslow County about 2 mi. S of the city of Jacksonville, the point of land between the junction of New River and Northeast Branch. Now within the Camp Lejeune reservation.

label: Mumfords
description: community in N Pasquotank County served by post office, 1892-1903.

label: Munday Cove
description: central Buncombe County, extends NW from Iron Ore Ridge to Reems Creek.

label: Murchison
description: community in S Yancey County on Cane River. Alt. 2,930.

label: Murfree's Ferry or Murfree's Landing
description: or See Murfreesboro.

label: Murfreesboro
description: town in W Hertford County on Meherrin River. Settled around 1707 and known as Murfree's Landing for William Murfree, colonial and Revolutionary leader and owner of the town site. Known as Murfree's Ferry by 1770. Est. as Murfreesboro 1787. Site of Chowan University, founded there in 1848. Alt. 75. Produces wooden containers, tobacco, peanuts, cotton, corn, and pork. See also Princeton.

label: Murfreesboro Township
description: NW Hertford County.

label: Murphey
description: community in S Duplin County.

label: Murphy
description: town and county seat, central Cherokee County at the junction of Hiwassee and Valley Rivers. Alt. 1,535. Site known first as Christie Ford for an Indian named Christie who lived there. Later called Huntersville for Col. A. R. S. Hunter, who est. a trading post there with the Cherokee Indians about 1830. Inc. as Murphy, 1851, and named for Archibald Debow Murphey (1758-1832), leader for internal improvements in North Carolina. Fort Butler, site ¼ mi. sw, was one of the assembly points used by Gen.
