Winfield Scott in 1838 to gather Cherokees before moving them west. The fort served as a site for the first courts until a suitable building was erected in Murphy. Produces textiles and lumber.

label: Murphy Bay
description: a swamp in E Bladen County SE of Black Lake. See also Carolina Bays.

label: Murphy Branch
description: rises in E Yancey County and flows W into South Toe River.

label: Murphy Falls
description: on Big Crabtree Creek on the Mitchell-Yancey county line.

label: Murphy Gap
description: NE Graham County.

label: Murphy Township
description: central Cherokee County.

label: Murray Branch
description: rises in W Madison County and flows SW into French Broad River.

label: Murray Cove
description: S Haywood County on a tributary of Little East Fork Pigeon River.

label: Murray Creek
description: rises in S central Henderson County and flows N into Greer Creek.

label: Murray Gap
description: E Madison County at the head of California Creek.

label: Murraysville
description: community in N New Hanover County.

label: Murrayville
description: former community on Cane Creek in N Henderson County (then Buncombe County); named for William Murray, whose home was there. Buncombe Turnpike ran nearby. A post office operated there, 1806 to ca. 1827. The Catawba grape was discovered growing in the vicinity.

label: Mush Island
description: a sandy formation about 2¼ mi. long and 1¼ mi. wide, surrounded by silty clay, on the banks of the Roanoke River SE of Weldon, NE Halifax County. The Collet map, 1770, shows Raglins Ferry at the site; called Prides Ferry on the Price map, 1808.

label: Musketo Inlet
description: through present Currituck Banks, E Currituck County, opened prior to 1657 and closed in the 1670s. Appears on the Ogilby map, 1671. See also Denniss Island.

label: Muskrat Branch
description: rises in SE Clay County and flows NW into Shooting Creek.

label: Muskrat Creek
description: rises in central Macon County and flows E into Cartoogechaye Creek.

label: Mussel Run
description: rises in E Greene County and flows SW into Contentnea Creek.

label: Musselshell Creek
description: rises in NE Jones County and flows SW into Trent River.

label: Muttenz
description: community in W Caldwell County on Johns River.

label: Mutton Creek
description: See Mud Creek.

label: Mutual Love
description: community in NW Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1877-79.

label: Myatt's Mills
description: community in S Wake County.

label: Myatts Pond
description: S Wake County on Black Creek. Covers 44 acres and has max. depth of 12 ft. Used for recreation and as a power source.

label: Myers
description: See South Gastonia.

label: Myers Branch
description: rises in NW Swain County and flows SW into Fontana Lake.

label: Myra Lake
description: SE Wake County on Marks Creek. Formed in 1900. Covers 50 acres and has max. depth of 15 ft. Used for recreation.

label: Myrtle
description: See Elah.

label: Myrtle Grove
description: community in SE New Hanover County on Myrtle Sound.

label: Myrtle Grove Island
description: tidal-marsh island in SE Onslow County just inside Bear Inlet.

label: Myrtle Grove Sound
description: See Myrtle Sound.

label: Myrtle Island
description: in Bogue Sound, W Carteret County S of Burthen Channel.

label: Myrtle Lawn
description: a family seat in S Warren County near the community of Inez. Built by the Williams family in 1790 and still standing.

label: Myrtle Sound
description: SE New Hanover County. Also known as Myrtle Grove Sound. See also Snows Cut.

label: Myrtle Swamp
description: See Merkle Swamp.

label: Myrts
description: community in N Duplin County served by post office, 1893-96. Named for first postmaster James Grady's daughter Myrtie.

label: Nags Head
description: town on N Bodie Island facing the Atlantic Ocean, E Dare County. A popular summer resort since the 1830s. Inc. 1923; charter repealed 1949; inc. again in 1961. Numerous legends exist explaining the origin of the name. One of the most popular tells of natives who tied lanterns around the necks of ponies ("nags"), which were driven up and down the beach at night. The motion of the lanterns resembled that of a vessel at anchor and lured ships at sea into the shore, where they were wrecked and easily robbed. The name appears on maps of the area as early as 1738. Nags Head as a place name appears in various parts of England, the Channel Islands, and the West Indies.

label: Nags Head Coast Guard Station
description: central Bodie Island in E Dare County. Est. in 1874 as a lifesaving station. Lifesaving Service and Revenue Cutter Service joined to form U.S. Coast Guard in 1915. The station was declared surplus and decommissioned after World War II.

label: Nags Head Township
description: E Dare County. Includes all of Roanoke Island and the town of Nags Head.

label: Nags Head Woods
description: maritime forest, E Dare County. An ecological preserve that includes 1,400 acres. Protected by Nature Conservancy and designated a U.S. Natural Landmark, 1974.

label: Nahunga Creek
description: rises in W Duplin County and flows NE into Goshen Swamp.

label: Nahunta
description: See Fremont and Torhunta.

label: Nahunta Swamp
description: rises in E Johnston County and flows E across NE Wayne County and NE into Contentnea Creek in W Greene County. It is mentioned under various spellings as early as 1711 as Norhanty, Norrihunta, and No Honey. Appears on the Collet map, 1770, as Beaverdam Swamp in N Wayne County. It is not shown as such on subsequent maps. The name is either originally or in corrupted form a Tuscarora Indian word, perhaps from Kahunshe Wakena (Black Creek).

label: Nahunta Township
description: NE Wayne County.

label: Nain
description: community in SW Forsyth County served by post office, 1890-1904.

label: Naked Creek
description: rises in SE Montgomery County and flows SE into Richmond County. At the Moore-Richmond county line, it joins Drowning Creek in forming Lumber River.

label: Naked Creek
description: rises in SW Wilkes County and flows E into Lewis Fork Creek.

label: Naked Mountain
description: now Morrow Mountain State Park, which see, in E Stanly County. Named after a tornado stripped timber off and left it naked; renamed in 1935 to honor donor of site for a state park.

label: Naked Place Mountain
description: NE Haywood County between Bear Wallow Gap and Fines Creek.

label: Nakina
description: community in S Columbus County. Formerly known as Wattsville.

label: Nalls
description: community in W Montgomery County served by post office, 1884-1902.

label: Namonda
description: See Table Rock Mountain.

label: Nance
description: community in NE Rockingham County served by post office, 1884-1910.

label: Nancy Hawkins Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NW into Graybeard Creek. Named for an Indian woman.

label: Nancy Mountain
description: S Transylvania County between the headwaters of Toxaway Creek and Shoal Creek. Alt. 3,013.

label: Nancys Mountain
description: S Randolph County between Kies Mountain and Little River.

label: Nane Branch
description: rises in central Clay County and flows NW into Cold Branch.

label: Nanito
description: See Shingle Hollow.

label: Nanny Mountain
description: SE Buncombe County near the Rutherford County line.

label: Nansemond Indian Town
description: appears on the Moseley map, 1733, near the forks of Nottoway River and Blackwater River where they form the Chowan River. The site is now in NE Hertford County.

label: Nantahala
description: community in SW Swain County. A post office operated there, 1873-1905. After 1889 known as Ledford. Alt. 1,942.

label: Nantahala Balds
description: grassy areas in the Nantahala Mountain Range, which see, of W Macon County. Wayah Bald is the most prominent of these areas. Named for the Cherokee word Nan-toh-ee-yah-heh-lih (sun in the middle; noonday), as Indian runners between Valley River crossed it at midday on their way to Oconaluftee or Soco in Swain County.

label: Nantahala Gorge
description: ne Graham and SW Swain Counties, a canyon of the Nantahala River with such depth and such sheer sides that the Cherokee Indians named it "Land of the Middle Sun," believing that only the noonday sun could penetrate its depths. One of the several Cherokee legends is that the gorge was the haunt of the Uktena (keen-eyed), a huge horned serpent. The bright gem blazing from between its horns was called ulstitlu (it is on his head) and meant death to the family of any Indian who beheld it. However, when detached it became the ulunsuti (transparent), the great talisman that revealed the future to the possessor. When a wary hunter encased himself in leather, surprised the monster, killed it, and tore the great jewel from its head, the snake writhed from one side of the gorge to the other, shutting out the radiance of the sun and causing the perpetual twilight. The great jewel was said to be the rutile quartz, so rare that there was only one specimen among the Eastern Cherokee in 1890. In the gorge, on the left bank of the river, are caves claimed by some to have been occupied by a race that preceded the Cherokee.

label: Nantahala Lake
description: in Clay and Macon Counties on the headwaters of Nantahala River. Dam completed in 1942. Area 1,605 acres; max. depth 225 ft.; shoreline 30 mi. Owned by Nantahala Power and Light Company and used for the generation of electricity. Nantahala is an Indian word meaning "sun in the middle" and was applied to the gorge through which the river runs.

label: Nantahala Mountain Range
description: lies between the Great Smoky Mountains on the N and the Blue Ridge on the s. It extends about 50 mi. across Macon County from the junction of Nantahala and Little Tennessee Rivers in Swain County to Tallulah Falls, Ga.

label: Nantahala National Forest
description: in portions of Cherokee, Clay, Graham, Jackson, Macon, Swain, and Transylvania Counties, was est. in 1911 and includes 531,286 acres. Nature trails, mountain climbing, picnicking, and other recreational uses. See also Joyce Kilmer Memorial Forest.

label: Nantahala River
description: rises in SW Macon County and flows NW to the Clay-Macon county line, which it forms for a part of its course; it then flows into Graham County, where it enters Little Tennessee River. See also Camp Branch Falls.

label: Nantahala Township
description: S Swain County.

label: Naomi Falls
description: See Randleman.

label: Naples
description: community in N Henderson County. Alt. 2,080. A cooperative school and hospital are maintained there by Seventh-Day Adventists. Named 1901 when a post office was est. there because Mud Creek in the valley below often flooded, reminding a local resident of the Bay of Naples.

label: Narassa
description: community in NE Brunswick County. Produces lumber and fertilizers.

label: Narhantes
description: See Nahunta Swamp.

label: Narrow Ridge
description: NE Yancey County between Green Mountain and Brush Creek.

label: Narrows
description: boat channel through the narrow part of Currituck Sound near Poplar Branch. Tidal-marsh islands lie on either side of the channel in S Currituck County. Appears on the Comberford map, 1657.

label: Narrows of the Yadkin
description: formerly a portion of Yadkin River in Montgomery and Stanly Counties constricted by the Uwharrie Mountains, through which the river passes. With the construction of Badin Dam in 1917, the Narrows of the Yadkin were submerged by Badin Lake. Appears on the Price map, 1808, and the MacRae map, 1833. Sometimes referred to as Yadkin Narrows.

label: Narrows Reservoir
description: See Badin Lake.

label: Narrows, The
description: See Croatan Sound.

label: Narrowsville
description: community in NW Montgomery County near Narrows of the Yadkin. Served by post office, 1833-41.

label: Nash County
description: was formed in 1777 from Edgecombe County. Located in the NE section of the state, it is bounded by Edgecombe, Wilson, Johnston, Franklin, and Halifax Counties. It was named for Gen. Francis Nash (1742-77) of Hillsborough, mortally wounded at the Battle of Germantown while fighting under George Washington. Area: 552 sq. mi. County seat: Nashville, with an elevation of 180 ft. Townships are Bailey, Castalia, Coopers, Dry Wells, Ferrells, Griffins, Jackson, Mannings, Nashville, North Whitakers, Oak Level, Red Oak, Rocky Mount, South Whitakers, and Stony Creek. Produces tobacco, corn, wheat, oats, peanuts, cotton, poultry, hogs, livestock, machinery, computers, plastics, sweet potatoes, strawberries, cantaloupes, cucumbers, bakery products, textiles, furniture, lumber, and apparel.

label: Nash District
description: one of the districts into which Caswell County was divided at the time of the 1790 census. It contained 118 heads of families.

label: Nash Mine
description: E Cabarrus County 1½ mi. NW of Phoenix Mine Village, which see. Known as Faggart Mine in the mid-nineteenth century, when gold was mined there. Uranium was discovered there in 1954.

label: Nashville
description: town and county seat, central Nash County. Authorized to be laid out and est., 1815. Named for Gen. Francis Nash (1742-77), Revolutionary War officer killed at Germantown. Produces lumber and apparel. Alt. 180.

label: Nashville Township
description: central Nash County.

label: Nat Moore
description: community in SE Bladen County served by post office, 1875-1914.

label: Nathans Creek
description: community in E central Ashe County. Alt. approx. 2,800.

label: Nations Creek
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows NE into Tuckasegee River.

label: Nattie Branch
description: rises in S Clay County and flows N into Giesky Creek.

label: Natural Wells
description: community in SW Duplin County served by post office, 1892-1903. Name for large limestone sinkholes in the area.

label: Nausegoc
description: a name appearing on the White map, 1590, in Pamlico Sound, E Dare County approx. between the present communities of Rodanthe and Salvo on Hatteras Island. The name is believed to have been an Algonquian Indian word for "take a breathing-spell," hence a resting place for those on a long canoe journey.

label: Navassa
description: community in NE Brunswick County on Cape Fear River. Historically African American, center for Gullah Geechee culture and traditions.

label: Navy Yard Lake
description: E Anson County SE of Lilesville. Covers approx. 10 acres; max. depth 15 ft. Formed early in the twentieth century when gravel was removed from the site.

label: Naylors Knob
description: central Caldwell County. Named for James Nailor, an early settler.

label: Nazareth
description: community in central Wake County S of Raleigh. Settled 1898. Named for the biblical town by Rev. Thomas Price, who est. a Roman Catholic orphanage there. Alt. 325.

label: Neal
description: community in W Bertie County.

label: Neal Branch
description: rises in S Wake County and flows E into Swift Creek.

label: Neal Creek
description: short stream in N central Carteret County that flows NE into South River.

label: Neal Gut
description: a narrow, water-filled defile in central Franklin County that empties into Tar River.

label: Neals Creek
description: rises in SE Yancey County and flows NW into Big Lost Cove Creek.

label: Nealsville
description: See Glenwood.

label: Neatman
description: community in S central Stokes County. A post office operated there, 1857-1903.

label: Neatman Creek
description: rises in S central Stokes County and flows S into Town Fork Creek.

label: Nebo
description: community in N central Yadkin County. Once known as Mount Nebo.

label: Nebo Township
description: E McDowell County.

label: Nebraska
description: town in E Hyde County. Inc. 1855, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Probably named because of the importance of the Kansas-Nebraska Act of 1854, which repealed the Missouri Compromise.

label: Ned Branch
description: rises in central Haywood County and flows SE into Hemphill Creek.

label: Ned Gap
description: in SW Jackson County between Rich Mountain and West Fork [Dicks Creek].

label: Neddie Creek
description: rises in E Jackson County and flows SE into Tuckasegee River.

label: Neddie Knob
description: on the NE end of Neddie Mountain in E Jackson County.

label: Neddie Mountain
description: E Jackson County, extends NE between Dismal Mountain and Neddie Knob.

label: Neds Creek
description: rises in W Carteret County and flows W into Koonces Bay of White Oak River.

label: Neds Lick Gap
description: W Haywood County on the head of Hemphill Creek.

label: Neds Marsh
description: central Duplin County.

label: Nee-oh-la
description: See Pigeon River; West Fork Pigeon River.

label: Needhams Mountain
description: S Randolph County near the head of Fork Creek.

label: Needmore
description: former community in S Swain County est. about 1880 on property of Allison McHan. A thriving trading center until after about 1912, when the site was purchased by Nantahala Power Company for a right-of-way for a proposed power project. Population in 1950 was 75, but by 1960 only one house was occupied. Post office, est. 1891 and discontinued 1953, was named Needmore because of the habit of the people constantly complaining that they "needed more of this and that." Alt. 1,830.

label: Needmore Branch
description: rises in S Clay County and flows N into Shooting Creek.

label: Neely Gap
description: SW Cherokee County near the headwaters of Persimmon Creek.

label: Negro Hammocks
description: formerly two islands in S Hyde County in Pamlico Sound NE of Ocracoke Island, but now submerged. Known by the name as early as 1795. One of the islands was above water as late as 1910 and was called Negro Island.

label: Negro Island
description: See Negro Hammocks.

label: Negro Prong
description: rises in W Transylvania County and flows NE into Catheys Creek.

label: Negrohead
description: community in E Union County served by post office, 1888-1903.

label: Neil Gap
description: in N central Transylvania County on the head of Lamb Creek.

label: Neills Creek
description: rises in S Wake County and flows SW in N Harnett County into Cape Fear River. Named for Red Neill McNeill, who settled along its banks in 1740.

label: Neills Creek Township
description: central Harnett County.

label: Nella
description: See Husk.

label: Nellie
description: former community in W Haywood County on Cataloochee Creek near the mouth of Palmer Creek near lat. 35°37'40" N., long. 83°06'10" W. Settled about 1848. Named for Nellie Palmer, who in 1907, at the age of one, won first prize in a baby contest. Site now is in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park and is abandoned.

label: Nellie Ridge
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur of Big Fork Ridge near lat. 35°37'10" N., long. 83°06'50" W. Named for nearby community of Nellie.

label: Nelms
description: community in S Pamlico County.

label: Nelson
description: community in SE Durham County.

label: Nelson Bay
description: a bay formed by waters of Core Sound in NE Carteret County.

label: Nelson Branch
description: rises in E central Union County and flows NE into Rays Fork.

label: Nelson Cove
description: extends SE from Sassafras Ridge to Snowbird Creek in S Graham County.

label: Nelson Creek
description: See East Nelson Creek; West Nelson Creek.

label: Nelson Ridge
description: central Clay County between Vineyard Mountain and Tusquitee Creek.

label: Nelsons Old Ferry
description: See Graves Ferry.

label: Nelsonville
description: See Grimesland.

label: Nero
description: community in NW Wake County served by post office, 1900-1904.

label: Ness Creek
description: rises in N New Hanover County and flows SW into Cape Fear River.

label: Nestor
description: community in NW Davie County served by post office, 1886-1905.

label: Net
description: community in W Iredell County served by post office, 1894-1907.

label: Nettle Branch
description: rises in S Burke County and flows N into Jacob Fork.

label: Nettle Creek
description: rises in NW Haywood County and flows NE into Big Creek.

label: Nettle Creek
description: in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, rises in N Swain County and flows SW into Deep Creek.

label: Nettle Creek Bald
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, lat. 35°34'02" N., long. 83°22'55" W. Alt. 5,172.

label: Nettle Knob
description: community in SE Ashe County.

label: Nettle Patch
description: mountain near the Blue Ridge Parkway on the McDowell-Mitchell-Yancey county line. Alt. approx. 3,950.

label: Nettles Cove
description: N Buncombe County NE of Snowball Gap.

label: Neuse
description: See Neuse Crossroads.

label: Neuse Crossroads
description: community in N central Wake County. Named for nearby Neuse River. Formerly known as Dunnsville and as Neuse. Produces textiles. Alt. 234.

label: Neuse Forest
description: community in E Craven County.

label: Neuse River
description: is formed in W Durham County by the junction of Eno and Flat Rivers. It flows se, forming in part the Durham-Granville and Durham-Wake county lines; then through Wake, Johnston, Wayne, Lenoir, and Craven Counties, forming in part the Craven-Pamlico and Carteret-Pamlico county lines before entering Pamlico Sound. Named in 1584 by Arthur Barlowe for the Neusiok Indians. The Tuscarora Indians called the river Gow-ta-no (pine in water).

label: Neuse River Township
description: central Wake County.

label: Neuse Township
description: central Lenoir County.

label: Neuseoco Lake
description: E central Wake County on Beaverdam Creek. Covers 75 acres and has a max. depth of 20 ft. Owned by a club and used for recreation.

label: Never Mountain
description: an almost perfect cone, W Alexander County.

label: Neverson
description: community in NW Wilson County. Named for Neverson Williams. Post office, 1908-11.

label: Nevil Creek
description: rises in central Beaufort County and flows N into Pamlico River. Appears as Turners Creek on the Collet map, 1770, but the MacRae map, 1833, calls it Nevil Creek.

label: Neville Creek
description: rises in N Chatham County and flows N into Orange County, where it enters University Lake.

label: Nevin
description: community in Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1891-1902.

label: New Began Creek
description: See New Begun Creek.

label: New Begun Creek
description: rises in S Pasquotank County and flows SE into Pasquotank River. Mentioned in records of the area as early as 1660. The name Newbiggin is a common place name in the N of England, but in this case it may represent an attempt to spell in English the Indian name. Appears as New Began Creek on the Collet map, 1770, and as New Beggin Creek on the Price map, 1808, and the MacRae map, 1833. See also Weeksville.

label: New Belden
description: community in E central Pitt County.

label: New Berlin
description: See Delco.

label: New Bern
description: city and county seat, central Craven County at the junction of Neuse and Trent Rivers. Settled in 1710; inc. 1723. Took its name from Bern, Switzerland, capital of the homeland of its founder, Baron Christoph de Graffenried. Alt. 12. New Bern was the colonial and state capital from 1746 until the est. of Raleigh in 1792, although during the period the General Assembly met in various places from time to time. It met there in 1738-40, 1744-46, 1747-51, 1754-59, 1760, 1762, 1765-78, 1784-85, 1791-93, and 1794. Produces boats, lumber, apparel, dairy products, fertilizer, and processed meat. See also Tryon Palace; Drysborough.

label: New Bethel
description: community in NE Orange County. Developed around New Bethel Methodist Church, est. 1859.

label: New Bethel Crossroads
description: in W Rockingham County. Area renamed Bethany.

label: New Bethel Township
description: SW Rockingham County.

label: New Biggin Creek
description: See New Begun Creek.

label: New Branch
description: rises in N Avery County and flows NE into Buckeye Creek.

label: New Carthage
description: See Wilmington.

label: New Castle
description: community in SE Wilkes County between Osborne and Hunting Creeks. Named for the plantation of James Clemmons Hunt (1804-47), local merchant and planter. The town of Denneysville was authorized to be laid out at the site in 1817 on land then owned by George Denny, but it apparently did not develop. Known as Hunt's Store by 1847 and by its present name by the 1850s.

label: New Castle Township
description: E Wilkes County.

label: New Currituck Inlet
description: from the Atlantic Ocean into Currituck Sound through Currituck Banks, opened in the 1730s and closed in 1828. The site is now in E Currituck County.

label: New Exeter
description: See Exeter.

label: New Garden
description: See Guilford College.

label: New Hanover County
description: was formed in 1729 from Craven County. Located in the SE section of the state, it is bounded by the Atlantic Ocean, Cape Fear River, and Brunswick and Pender Counties. It was named in honor of the royal family of England, members of the House of Hanover. Area: 225 sq. mi. County seat: Wilmington, with an elevation of 38 ft. Townships are Cape Fear, Federal Point, Harnett, Masonboro, and Wilmington. Produces miscellaneous fruits and vegetables, bulbs and flowers, seafood, ceramics, optical fiber, nuclear technology, corn, soybeans, hogs, dairy products, poultry, bakery goods, fabricated metals, lumber, wooden containers, textiles, apparel, paper boxes, chemicals, refrigeration machinery, sand, and limestone.

label: New Hill
description: community in SW Wake County. Post office est. in 1832. Inc. 1907; charter repealed 1917. Alt. 356.

label: New Holland
description: community on the S shore of Lake Mattamuskeet in central Hyde County. Alt. 3. Settled 1910 and named by a development company that attempted to drain the lake for farmland but finally gave up in 1934, when the lake was allowed to refill. Their activity suggested the Netherlands’ continuous efforts to drain farmland, hence the name.

label: New Hope
description: community in SE Randolph County. Post office there, 1859-1934, was New Hope Academy, named for a local school; the building still stands but is used as a residence.

label: New Hope
description: See Durants Neck.

label: New Hope Creek
description: rises in central Orange County and flows E into W Durham County. There it turns SE and flows into Chatham County, where it becomes New Hope River, which see. Appears as New River on the Moseley map, 1733, but by 1770 (Collet map) appears as New-hope Creek.

label: New Hope Lake
description: See Jordan Lake.

label: New Hope River
description: the name applied to New Hope Creek in E Chatham County from the mouth of Whiteoak Creek to its confluence with Haw River, a distance of approx. 8 mi. See also New Hope Creek.

label: New Hope Township
description: SW Randolph County.

label: New Hope Township
description: E Wayne County. First listed in county tax records in 1838.

label: New House
description: community in W Cleveland County.

label: New Inlet
description: gave access from Onslow Bay and the Atlantic Ocean into the Basin at the S tip of New Hanover County. Used extensively by blockade runners under the guns of Fort Fisher. Closed by The Rocks, a great seawall constructed 1879-95.

label: New Institute
description: See Olin.

label: New Lake
description: See Alligator Lake.

label: New Lake Fork
description: flows SE from the S shore of Alligator Lake in N Hyde County and along the Hyde-Tyrrell county line to empty into Alligator River. N section also known as Squyars Canal.

label: New Lands
description: E Washington County, area at the NE boundary of East Dismal Swamp, which see. Name appears in county records as early as 1868.

label: New Lebanon
description: See South Mills.

label: New Light
description: community in N Wake County.

label: New Light Creek
description: rises in SE Granville County and flows SW into N Wake County, where it enters Neuse River. Shown on Collet map, 1770, as Newlight Creek.

label: New Light Township
description: N Wake County.

label: New Liverpool
description: See Wilmington.

label: New London
description: town in N Stanly County. Alt. 697. Prior to incorporation in 1891, it was known as Bilesville.

label: New Market
description: town in N Randolph County. Inc. 1813, but long inactive in municipal affairs.

label: New Market Township
description: NW Randolph County.

label: New Mattamuskeet Creek
description: See Juniper Bay.

label: New River
description: rises in NW Onslow County near the Jones County line and flows SE across the county into Onslow Bay of the Atlantic Ocean. Appears as Corani River on the Moll map, 1729, and as New River on the Moseley map, 1733. Tradition says that it was originally a long lake in a swampy area, but after an extended period of torrential rain, the lake overflowed into the Atlantic Ocean and became a new river. Camp Lejeune Marine Base is near the mouth of New River.

label: New River Inlet
description: S Onslow County between Stump Sound and Onslow Beach. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: New River Marine Base
description: See Camp Lejeune.

label: New River Township
description: central Watauga County.

label: New Salem
description: See Salem.

label: New Salem Township
description: NE Union County.

label: New Stirling
description: community in W central Iredell County.

label: New Topsail Beach
description: See Topsail Beach.

label: New Topsail Inlet
description: S Pender County between Old Topsail Inlet and the Onslow-Pender county line, through which waters of Topsail Sound flow into the Atlantic Ocean. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: New Town
description: See Wilmington.

label: New Years Creek
description: rises in S Watauga County on the W limits of the town of Blowing Rock and flows S into N Caldwell County, where it enters Thunderhole Creek.

label: Newasiwac
description: an Indian village of the Neusiok tribe located in what is now the S tip of Craven County on the Neuse River estuary. Appears on the White map, 1585. Called Neuustooc on the De Bry map, 1590, and Nustoc on the Smith map, 1624.

label: Newbern District
description: at the time of the 1790 census, was composed of Beaufort, Carteret, Craven, Dobbs, Hyde, Johnston, Jones, Pitt, and Wayne Counties.

label: Newberry Creek
description: rises in W McDowell County and flows SE into Curtis Creek.

label: Newbes Bridge
description: See Belvidere.

label: Newby's Bridge
description: See Belvidere.

label: Newdale
description: community in E Yancey County on Long Branch. Flinty, former post office serving the area, is a part of Newdale.

label: Newell
description: community in E Mecklenburg County. Settled about 1880 and named for John A. Newell, local resident, in whose home the first post office was est. in 1882. Alt. 756.

label: Newfound
description: community in W Buncombe County on Newfound Creek.

label: Newfound Creek
description: rises on the Buncombe-Haywood county line near Newfound Gap and flows NE into French Broad River.

label: Newfound Gap
description: in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Swain County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line, lat. 35°37' N., long. 83°26' W. Alt. 5,045.

label: Newfound Mountain
description: on the Buncombe-Haywood county line. The peak of the mountain is known as Big Butt Mountain.

label: Newfoundland
description: See Horseshoe.

label: Newkirk Mill Pond
description: on Ben's Creek in W Duplin County. Built by slave labor.

label: Newland
description: town and county seat, central Avery County on Linville and North Toe Rivers. Site selected by commissioners for county seat. Inc. 1913. Named for William Calhoun Newland (1860-1938), lieutenant governor, 1909-13. Site had been early muster ground in campaign against Indians and before the Battle of Kings Mountain; called Old Fields of Toe, for Toe River. Alt. 3,589. Produces textiles.

label: Newland Drainage Canal
description: in Newland Township in NW Pasquotank County, drains E into Pasquotank River.

label: Newland Township
description: n Pasquotank County.

label: Newlife
description: community in N Wilkes County near North Prong Roaring River. The former community of Ink is now a part of Newlife.

label: Newlin Township
description: former township in S central Alamance County, now township no. 8.

label: Newman
description: community in NW Warren County. A post office was located there, 1892-1906.

label: Newmarket
description: town authorized in 1801 to be est. in Orange County at or near Woody's Ferry on Haw River. It was a project of the Deep and Haw River Company designed to improve river navigation, but apparently the town was never laid out.

label: Newport
description: chartered 1789 to be county seat of Tyrrell County. On SW side of Scuppernong River at Back Landing. The town was never built.

label: Newport Marshes
description: a marshy island in Newport River about 1 mi. NE of Morehead City between the channel of the Intracoastal Waterway and Crab Point Thorofare in central Carteret County. Formerly Haystack Marshes.

label: Newport News Point
description: SE Tyrrell County, extends from the mainland into Alligator River. Appears on the Collet map, 1770, as Nupernuse Point.

label: Newport River
description: rises in W Carteret County and flows about 23 mi. E and SE into the central part of the county, where it enters Bogue Sound. Appears as Coranine River on the Lawson map, 1709, but as Newport River on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Newport Township
description: on Newport River and Broad Creek in NE Carteret County. For a time called township no. 3.

label: Newsom
description: community in S Davidson County on Yadkin River. Alt. 558. Named for the family from whom land was acquired for the railroad station.

label: Newsome
description: community in E Wayne County between Walnut Creek and West Bear Creek.

label: Newsome Store
description: community in SE Hertford County.

label: Newstump Point
description: ne Carteret County, E extension of Piney Island into West Bay.

label: Newton
description: community in E Northampton County. Known first as Miami, later as Liverman, and finally by its present name.

label: Newton
description: See Wilmington.

label: Newton Bald
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, lat. 35°32'39" N., long. 83°21'32" W. Alt. 5,142.

label: Newton Grove
description: town in N Sampson County. Alt. 185. A post office, Coxe's Store, est. in the vicinity in 1825; discontinued 1849, when Newton Grove post office est. Inc. as Newton Grove, 1879; reincorporated, 1935.

label: Newton Grove Township
description: N Sampson County.

label: Newton Township
description: central Catawba County.

label: Newtons Crossroads
description: community in SE Sampson County.

label: Niagara
description: community in SE Moore County est. about 1904 by northern interests. Alt. 402.

label: Nibb's Knob
description: See Big Cataloochee Mountain.

label: Nicanon
description: community in N Perquimans County.

label: Nichols Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows NE into Tessentee Creek.

label: Nichols Branch
description: rises in SW Macon County and flows NE into Nantahala River.

label: Nicholson
description: community in central Alamance County served by post office, 1879-1903.

label: Nicholson Creek
description: rises in central Transylvania County and flows SE into French Broad River.

label: Nicholsons Creek
description: rises in N Hoke County and flows S into Rockfish Creek.

label: Nicholsons Mills
description: community in NE Iredell County served by post office, 1876-1905.

label: Nick Bottom
description: loamy section in E Swain County on Oconaluftee River near the mouth of Goose Creek.

label: Nick Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows N into Radder Creek.

label: Nick Creek
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows SE into West Fork Pigeon River.

label: Nick Gap
description: central Haywood County on the head of Messer Branch.

label: Nickajack Creek
description: rises in E Macon County and flows NE into Cullasaja River.

label: Nickajack Gap
description: at the head of Nickajack Creek in E Macon County.

label: Nicks Creek
description: See Pheasant Creek.

label: Nicks Knob
description: S Cherokee County near the headwaters of Moccasin Creek.

label: Nigger Bay
description: between Swan Island and Currituck Banks in NE Currituck County. In 2003 state legislature directed county to rename bay.

label: Nigger Head
description: mountain on the Clay-Macon county line. Alt. approx. 4,900. In 2003 state legislature directed counties to rename mountain; now also known as Clay Knob.

label: Nigger Mountain
description: See Mount Jefferson.

label: Nigger Skull Mountain
description: W Haywood County on the head of East Fork. In 2003 state legislature directed county to rename mountain.

label: Nigger Spring
description: S Haywood County, a spring on the head of Little East Fork Pigeon River. In 2003 state legislature directed county to rename spring.

label: Niggerhead Creek
description: rises in E Union County and flows NW into Richardson Creek. In 2003 state legislature directed county to rename creek; now also known as Salem Creek.

label: Niggerskull Creek
description: See Cedar Valley Creek.

label: Niggerskull Mountain
description: See Cedar Valley Knob.

label: Nigh Inlet
description: a point of land on Ocracoke Island about 3½ mi. from the S end of the island, SE Hyde County. The inlet may be the site of Port Grenvil, which see, shown on the White map, 1590, but long closed.

label: Nikwasi
description: See Franklin.

label: Nile
description: community in N Alleghany County served by post office, 1898-1915.

label: Nimrod
description: community in SW Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1891-1902. Was on the W side of the Charlotte, Columbia, and Augusta Railroad. Site is now the Yorkmont area of Charlotte.

label: Nims
description: formerly a community in E Gaston County but now a part of the town of Mount Holly, which see.

label: Nin Ridge
description: NW Cherokee County in the Unicoi Mountains, is bounded on four sides by Bryson Lead, Groundhog Ridge, Copper Ridge, and Chestnut Orchard Ridge.

label: Nina
description: community in NE Cherokee County served by post office, 1880-1911.

label: Nine Mile Creek
description: See Ninemile Swamp.

label: Ninemile Swamp
description: rises in W Onslow County and flows SW into Duplin County, where its name becomes Nine Mile Creek and it enters Back Swamp. Named for its distance from Rich Lands Chapel, an early center of settlement.

label: Ninive
description: community in W Transylvania County.

label: Nit Top
description: on the Cherokee County, N.C.-Monroe County, Tenn., line in the Unicoi Mountains.

label: Nix Creek
description: rises in S Jackson County on N slopes of Sassafras Mountain and flows NE into Sapphire Lake.

label: Nix Mountain
description: S Jackson County between Nix Creek and Horsepasture River.

label: Nixon's
description: See Columbus.

label: Nixon's Town
description: See Nixonton.

label: Nixons Mill Creek
description: flows SE from Old Topsail Creek into Topsail Sound, S Pender County.

label: Nixonton
description: town in W Pasquotank County on Little River. The site was originally known as Windmill Point. Laid out in 1746, settled then or soon afterward, and est. 1758 as Nixon's Town. Named for Zachariah Nixon, an early settler. Appears on the Collet map, 1770; served as county seat, 1785-1800. Inc. 1818; reincorporated 1951, but not now active in municipal affairs.

label: Nixonton Township
description: S Pasquotank County.

label: No Ache Bay
description: on the W shore of Hatteras Island in the waters of Pamlico Sound, S Dare County S of the community of Salvo.

label: No Ache Island
description: a small island in No Ache Bay on the W shore of Hatteras Island in the waters of Pamlico Sound, S Dare County.

label: No Business Creek
description: rises in NW Cleveland County and flows SW into First Broad River.

label: No Business Mountain
description: NW Cleveland County near the headwaters of Cox Creek. Said to be too rough to be surveyed. Local residents claim they have "no business" on it. Alt. 1,760.

label: No Creek
description: rises in S Davie County and flows S 4 mi. into Dutchmans Creek. It is said that an early settler bought land there, and the deed called for a creek. He complained that he found no creek on his land, but later, when he discovered one, it came to be called No Creek.

label: No Grease
description: riverside site in E central Hertford County on Chowan River approx. Â¼ mi. N of Winton. A fishery there in the nineteenth century departed from custom when it kept no grease on hand, which meant that customers could not cook fish at the site.

label: No Honey Swamp
description: See Nahunta Swamp.

label: Noah Branch
description: rises in SE Buncombe County and flows SE into Rutherford County, where it enters Cedar Creek.

label: Noah's Mountain
description: in the Cane Creek Mountains, S Alamance County.

label: Nobles Crossroads
description: community in S Lenoir County.

label: Nobles Mill Pond
description: in S Lenoir County on Trent River. Formed prior to 1802 by William Williams or his son, Evan, and known as Williams Pond until 1852, when it was acquired by the Nobles family. Covers 125 acres. Max. depth 8 ft.

label: Noblin
description: community in N Granville County served by post office, 1887-1905.

label: Nobreeches Ridge
description: SE Haywood County on the head of East Fork Pigeon River.

label: Nocona
description: community in S Madison County. Alt. 1,585.

label: Nofat Mountain
description: on the Buncombe-Madison county line W of Pleasant Gap.

label: Noise
description: community in NW Moore County served by post office, 1882-1912. Ten mi. E was Quiet, which see.

label: Nokassa
description: See Hawksbill Mountain.

label: Noland
description: former community in W central Swain County on Tuckasegee River. Alt. 1,622. Named for Andrew Noland, one of the first settlers in the area. Site now under the waters of Fontana Lake.

label: Noland Creek
description: Great Smoky Mountains National Park, rises in N Swain County on Noland Divide and flows SE then SW into Tuckasegee River. Named for Andrew Noland, first settler along its banks.

label: Noland Divide
description: mountain ridge, central Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, extending from the Tennessee state line S to Bryson City. Roundtop Knob, which see, a peak on the ridge, has an elevation of 5,120 ft.

label: Noland Gap
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park between Noland Mountain and Canadian Top near lat. 35°39'10" N., long. 83°06' W.

label: Noland Mountain
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°39'35" N., long. 83°05'18" W. Alt. 3,951.

label: Nolen Creek
description: rises in W Haywood County and flows SE into Richland Creek.

label: Nolichucky River
description: is formed on the Mitchell-Yancey county line by the junction of Toe River and Cane River. It flows N and W along the county line and into Tennessee, where it enters the French Broad River.

label: Nolton Ridge
description: SE Graham County in the Snowbird Mountains.

label: Nonah
description: community in NE Macon County served by post office, 1883-1904.

label: Noratake River
description: See Roanoke River.

label: Norfleet
description: community in SE Halifax County. Norfleet Ferry appears on the Collet map, 1770, NE of the present community. The ferry across the Roanoke River was operated as late as 1886 but was discontinued in 1888, when the railroad bridge was built there.

label: Norfolk, County of
description: See County of Norfolk.

label: Norhanty Swamp
description: See Nahunta Swamp.

label: Norlina
description: town in W Warren County. Inc. 1913. Alt. 438. Originally known as Mount Regis, but the name was changed after a post office was est. there in 1900 as Norlina, a contraction of "North Carolina."

label: Norman
description: town in N Richmond County. Known first as Sprouls Old Field. Post office est. 1911 and named for Flim Norman, local lumber merchant. Inc. 1913. Long inactive in municipal affairs. Processes lumber.

label: Norrihunta Swamp
description: See Nahunta Swamp.

label: Norrington's Falls
description: in Cape Fear River in N central Harnett County. In an 1819 survey of the rivers of North Carolina, the N end, near the confluence of Hector Creek with the river, is called Norrington's Upper Falls; the S end, near the confluence of Neals Creek with the river, is called Norrington's Lower Falls.

label: Norris
description: community in E Watauga County.

label: Norris Branch
description: rises in central Watauga County and flows SE and NE into Howard Creek.

label: Norris Branch
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows N into Nolichucky River.

label: Norris Creek
description: rises in S Franklin County and flows SE and NE into Crooked Creek.

label: Norris Fork
description: rises in N Watauga County on Rich Mountain and flows SE into Meat Camp Creek.

label: Norris Pond
description: See Mills Pond.

label: North Albemarle Township
description: E central Stanly County.

label: North Asheboro
description: See Balfours.

label: North Banks
description: See Currituck Banks.

label: North Bay
description: in N Piney Island N of Rattan Bay, NE Carteret County. Approx. ½ mi. long and ½ mi. wide.

label: North Belmont
description: community in E Gaston County on the outskirts of the city of Belmont.

label: North Blue Ridge Township
description: E Henderson County.

label: North Brook
description: community in NW Lincoln County.

label: North Brook Township
description: W Lincoln County.

label: North Buffalo Creek
description: rises in central Guilford County and flows NE through the city of Greensboro to join South Buffalo Creek in forming Buffalo Creek in NE Guilford County.

label: North Cackalacky
description: See Cackalacky.

label: North Carolina
description: Please see the full entry.

label: North Catawba Township
description: S central Caldwell County.

label: North Charlotte
description: community in N Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1908-30.

label: North Clinton Township
description: central Sampson County.

label: North Cove
description: community in N McDowell County on North Fork [Catawba River]. Post office named Pitts served the community, 1915-24. Alt. 1,469.

label: North Cove Township
description: N McDowell County.

label: North Cox Creek
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows NW into Cane Creek.

label: North Creek
description: rises near Ransomville, E Beaufort County, and flows SE into Pamlico River. Appears as North Dividing Creek on the Collet map, 1770.

label: North Deep Creek
description: rises in N Yadkin County and flows SE to join South Deep Creek in forming Deep Creek.

label: North Dividing Creek
description: See North Creek.

label: North Double Creek
description: rises in W Stokes County and flows E into Dan River.

label: North Durham
description: former town in central Durham County at the N boundary of Durham. Inc. 1891. Now wholly within the limits of Durham.

label: North Eaglenest Mountain
description: See Junaluska Mountain.

label: North East
description: community in S Duplin County.

label: North Edenton
description: former town in S Chowan County adjacent to Edenton. Inc. 1911; charter repealed 1917.

label: North Fayetteville
description: community in central Cumberland County on the outskirts of the city of Fayetteville.

label: North Flat River
description: rises in central Person County and flows SW into Flat River.

label: North Fork
description: rises in NE Rutherford County and flows SW into First Broad River.

label: North Fork
description: See Creston.

label: North Fork Cattail Creek
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows SW to join South Fork Cattail Creek in forming Cattail Creek.

label: North Fork Clear Creek
description: rises in SE Mecklenburg County and flows NE into SW Cabarrus County, E through Union County, and S into Clear Creek.

label: North Fork Coweeta Creek
description: rises in S Macon County and flows SE into Coweeta Creek.

label: North Fork Crains Creek
description: See Whiteoak Creek.

label: North Fork Crooked Creek
description: rises in SE Mecklenburg County and flows E into N Union County, where it joins South Fork Crooked Creek in forming Crooked Creek.

label: North Fork Flat Creek
description: rises in W Transylvania County and flows SE into Flat Creek.

label: North Fork French Broad River
description: is formed in W Transylvania County by the junction of Indian and Shoal Creeks and flows SE to join West Fork French Broad River in forming French Broad River.

label: North Fork Hawk Branch
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows SW into Hawk Branch.

label: North Fork Ivy Creek
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows SW to join Dillingham Creek in forming Ivy Creek. Known also as Big Ivy Creek.

label: North Fork Jones Creek
description: rises in SW Anson County and flows E to join South Fork Jones Creek in forming Jones Creek.

label: North Fork Little River
description: rises in N Orange County and flows SE into NW Durham County, where it joins South Fork Little River in forming Little River.

label: North Fork Mitchell River
description: rises in NW Surry County and flows SE into Mitchell River.

label: North Fork Mountain Creek
description: rises in E Catawba County and flows SE to join South Fork in forming Mountain Creek.

label: North Fork Nahunga Creek
description: rises in W Duplin County and flows SE into Nahunga Creek.

label: North Fork New River
description: rises in N Watauga County and flows NE into Ashe County, where it joins South Fork New River on the Ashe-Alleghany county line to form New River.

label: North Fork of Rattle Snake Creek
description: rises in central Caswell County and flows NE to join South Fork of Rattle Snake Creek in forming Rattle Snake Creek.

label: North Fork Reddies River
description: rises in NW Wilkes County and flows SE to join Middle Fork Reddies River in forming Reddies River.

label: North Fork Rock Creek
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows SE to join Middle Fork Rock Creek in forming Rock Creek.

label: North Fork Sawyer Creek
description: rises in N Watauga County and flows SW into Sawyer Creek.

label: North Fork Tar River
description: rises in central Granville County and flows SW into Tar River. Appears as Heartline Creek on the Collet map, 1770.

label: North Fork Township
description: N Watauga County.

label: North Fork Tucker Creek
description: rises in W Transylvania County and flows SE into Tucker Creek.

label: North Fork [Big Pine Creek]
description: rises in S Madison County on the W side of Fork Mountain and flows NE to join South Fork in forming Big Pine Creek.

label: North Fork [Carvers Branch]
description: rises in S Mitchell County and flows SW into Carvers Branch.

label: North Fork [Catawba River]
description: rises in NE McDowell County and flows S into Lake James on Catawba River.

label: North Fork [Chambers Creek]
description: rises in W Swain County and flows SE into Chambers Creek.

label: North Fork [Cove Creek]
description: rises in N Watauga County and flows SE into Cove Creek.

label: North Fork [Duck Creek]
description: rises in NW Alexander County and flows S into Duck Creek. Known locally as White Creek.

label: North Fork [Grassy Creek]
description: rises in S Mitchell County and flows SE into Middle Fork Grassy Creek.

label: North Fork [Scott Creek]
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows SW into Scott Creek.

label: North Fork [Skeenah Creek]
description: rises in S Macon County near Blaine Knob and flows SE to join South Fork [Skeenah Creek] in forming Skeenah Creek.

label: North Fork [Swannanoa River]
description: rises in NE Buncombe County near Balsam Gap and flows S into Swannanoa River. Part of the Asheville watershed.

label: North Fork [Whitewater River]
description: rises in S Jackson County and flows SE into South Carolina, where it enters Whitewater River.

label: North Harlowe
description: community in SE Craven County.

label: North Harper Creek
description: rises in SE Avery County in Boone Wildlife Management Area and flows SE to join South Harper Creek in forming Harper Creek near the Caldwell County line.

label: North Henderson
description: community in central Vance County on the outskirts of the city of Henderson.

label: North Hominy Creek
description: rises in E Haywood County in Worley Cove and flows SW into Hominy Creek.

label: North Hunting Creek
description: See Flat Rock Creek.

label: North Hyco Creek
description: rises in S Caswell County and flows NE into Person County, where it joins South Hyco Creek in forming Hyco River.

label: North Knob
description: n Buncombe County NE of Windy Gap.

label: North Landing River
description: rises in Princess Anne County, Va., and flows S into Currituck County, where it enters Currituck Sound. The Intracoastal Waterway connects James River and North Landing River.

label: North Leopard Creek
description: rises in E Carteret County and flows NW into North River.

label: North Lumberton
description: former town in E central Robeson County. Inc. 1911. Charter repealed 1953. Now a part of Lumberton. Was a mill-owned village (Jennings Cotton Mills) until 1949-50, when houses were sold to individuals.

label: North Muddy Creek
description: rises in central McDowell County and flows NE to join South Muddy Creek in forming Muddy Creek near the Burke County line.

label: North Pacolet River
description: See Pacolet River.

label: North Point
description: See Eagleton Point.

label: North Prong
description: See Correll Branch.

label: North Prong Creek
description: rises in SE Guilford County and flows NE into Alamance County, where it enters Stinking Quarter Creek.

label: North Prong Ellijay Creek
description: rises in E Macon County and flows SW into Ellijay Creek.

label: North Prong Horse Branch
description: rises in central Duplin County and flows SE into Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: North Prong Lewis Fork Creek
description: rises in W Wilkes County and flows SE approx. 9 mi. to join South Prong Lewis Fork Creek in forming Lewis Fork Creek. Yates Mountain lies between the two prongs.

label: North Prong Roaring River
description: rises in N Wilkes County and flows SE to join Middle Prong Roaring River in forming Roaring River.

label: North Prong Turkey Creek
description: rises in N Transylvania County and flows S to join South Prong Turkey Creek in forming Turkey Creek.

label: North Prong [Clarks Creek]
description: rises in N Mecklenburg County and flows SE to join South Prong in forming Clarks Creek.

label: North River
description: about 10 mi. long, rises in central Carteret County and flows S into Back Sound and The Straits in SE Carteret County. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: North River Pocosin
description: along the W shore of North River in S Camden County.

label: North River Point
description: is the tip of S Camden Point, which extends into the mouth of North River.

label: North River Thorofare
description: between two groups of tidal-marsh islands in S Carteret County.

label: North Rock
description: island in Pamlico Sound, NE Carteret County N of Portsmouth Island. In 1795 the middle section of the island was submerged; the W end was called Great Shell Rock and the E end Little Shell Rock.

label: North Rocky Creek
description: rises in S Wilkes County and flows S into Rocky Creek.

label: North Rodanthe
description: See Rodanthe.

label: North Second Creek
description: is formed in NW Rowan County by the junction of Back and Withrow Creeks and flows NE into Yadkin River. Appears as Second Creek on the Collet map, 1770. Named because it was the second creek reached by settlers moving W from Salisbury, Grants Creek being the first. See also Withrow Creek.

label: North Shores
description: community on Pamlico River, W Beaufort County.

label: North Slope Ridge
description: N Transylvania County extends E between Joel Branch and Davidson River.

label: North Stinking Quarter Creek
description: rises in SE Guilford County and flows NE into Alamance County, where it enters Stinking Quarter Creek, which see.

label: North Toe River
description: rises in N Avery County and flows s, e, and S again across Avery into Mitchell County. It flows SW across Mitchell to the Mitchell-Yancey county line, where it joins South Toe River in forming Toe River. The last native elk shot in North Carolina is said to have been killed alongside North Toe River in 1781.

label: North Turkey Creek
description: rises in SW Buncombe County near Newfound Mountain and flows NE to join South Turkey Creek in forming Turkey Creek.

label: North Whitakers Township
description: NE Nash County.

label: North Wilkesboro
description: town in S central Wilkes County on Yadkin River. Alt. 1,016. Inc. 1891 and named for the county seat, Wilkesboro, across the Yadkin River to the s. The site was described as Mulberry Fields, a former Cherokee Indian area, in a report of Moravian surveyors in 1752. Appears as Mulberry Fields on the Collet map, 1770. Produces furniture, mirrors, textiles, apparel, hosiery, processed poultry, and dairy products.

label: North Wilkesboro Township
description: central Wilkes County.

label: Northampton County
description: was formed in 1741 from Bertie County. Located in the NE section of the state, it is bounded by the state of Virginia and by Hertford, Bertie, Halifax, and Warren Counties. It was named for James Compton, Earl of Northampton (1687-1754). Area: 544 sq. mi. County seat: Jackson, with an elevation of 131 ft. Townships are Gaston, Jackson, Kirby, Oconeechee, Pleasant Hill, Rich Square, Roanoke, Seaboard, and Wiccacanee. Produces peanuts, corn, soybeans, chemicals, sorghum, cotton, hogs, livestock, lumber, apparel, sand, and gravel.

label: Northampton Court House
description: See Jackson.

label: Northeast
description: community in N Pender County served by post office, 1900-1903.

label: Northeast Branch [New River]
description: See Northeast Creek.

label: Northeast Branch [Newport River]
description: rises in E Carteret County and flows S into Newport River E of the town of Newport.

label: Northeast Cape Fear River
description: rises in NW Duplin County about 2 mi. S of Mount Olive; flows SE to form a part of the Duplin-Wayne county line; continues S through Duplin and Pender Counties; turns slightly W to form a part of the New Hanover-Pender county line; and flows S in New Hanover County, where it enters Cape Fear River at Wilmington. Appears as Northeast Fork and North East River on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Northeast Creek
description: rises in N Onslow County and flows SW into Morgan Bay. Also known as Northeast Branch of New River. Name appears in local records as early as 1744.

label: Northeast Fork
description: See Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: Northeast Hamlet
description: See Longwood Park.

label: Northeast Prong [South Lake]
description: central Dare County.

label: Northeast River
description: See Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: Northside
description: community in SW Granville County.

label: Northview
description: community in N Lee County.

label: Northwest
description: community in NE Brunswick County.

label: Northwest Creek
description: rises in E Craven County and flows S into Neuse River.

label: Northwest Ditch
description: drains water from NW Camden County (Dismal Swamp) to the SE into Cross Canal.

label: Northwest Fork [Alligator River]
description: rises in S central Tyrrell County and flows SE into Alligator River.

label: Northwest Parish
description: Church of England, Bertie County and later Northampton County, was est. in 1727 by the division of Society Parish in the NW part of the county. In 1741 the parish became Northampton County and, except for a part of the parish in the e, was renamed St. George's Parish in 1758. The following year, the remaining part of Northwest Parish became a part of Hertford County and St. Barnabas’ Parish. Northwest Parish, therefore, ceased to exist.

label: Northwest Point
description: the NW tip of Roanoke Island, central Dare County, that extends into Croatan Sound.

label: Northwest Prong Creek
description: rises in NW Carteret County and flows S into Newport River.

label: Northwest River
description: rises in Norfolk County, Va., and flows SE into Currituck County, where it empties into Tull Bay and North Landing River. Prior to the opening of the Dismal Swamp Canal, Northwest River flowed from Lake Drummond, Va., to Currituck Sound. Appears on the Ogilby map, 1671.

label: Northwest Township
description: N Brunswick County.

label: Norton
description: community on Little Tennessee River in S Macon County. Also called Tryphosa.

label: Norton Branch
description: rises in SE Macon County and flows SW into Big Creek.

label: Norton Creek
description: rises in SW Jackson County and flows NE into Lake Thorpe.

label: Norton Fork Creek
description: rises in SW Madison County and flows NW into Spring Creek.

label: Norton Fork Gap
description: on the Buncombe-Madison county line between Chestnut Gap and Robinson Rough.

label: Norton Prong
description: rises in E Macon County and flows S into Big Creek.

label: Norval
description: community in W Harnett County served by post office, 1856-1908.

label: Norwood
description: town in SE Stanly County on Lake Tillery. Alt. 365. Post office est. there in 1826 and named for William C. Norwood, first postmaster. Inc. 1881.

label: Norwood Lake
description: See Lake Tillery.

label: Notla Township
description: S central Cherokee County.

label: Nottely River
description: rises in Georgia and flows N into Cherokee County, through which it flows n, w, and NE into Hiwassee River about 2 mi. W of Murphy.

label: Nottoway River
description: rises in Virginia and flows SE into Hertford County, where it joins Blackwater River on the Gates-Hertford county line to form Chowan River. Nottoway, meaning "adders" or "rattlesnakes," was a name applied by Algonquian neighbors to Indians in the area. The name Nataway River appears on the Ogilby map, 1671, intended for the river but mistakenly applied to the present Wiccacon River. See also Weyanoke Creek.

label: Notts Island
description: See Mackay Island.

label: Nova Scotia Branch
description: rises in SW Macon County and flows NW into Nantahala River.

label: Nubbin Ridge
description: See Jones Chapel.

label: Nubbinscuffle Creek
description: rises in W Yancey County and flows S into Bald Creek.

label: Nuna Ridge
description: NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park between Tub-Mill Creek and Gunna Creek.

label: Nunda Branch
description: in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, rises in NW Swain County and flows SE into Bone Valley Creek.

label: Nunn Mountain
description: SE Orange County on the head of Booker Creek.

label: Nuns
description: community in SE Nash County served by post office, 1898-1902.

label: Nupernuse Point
description: See Newport News Point.

label: Nutbush
description: See Williamsboro.

label: Nutbush Creek
description: rises in city of Henderson in central Vance County and flows N into Kerr Lake. Shown on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Nutbush Township
description: See Middleburg-Nutbush Township.

label: Nye
description: community in S Robeson County served by post office, 1890-1905.

label: O'Dear Creek
description: rises in NW McDowell County and flows E on the N side of Pompey Ridge into Threemile Creek.

label: O'Neals Township
description: N Johnston County.

label: Oak City
description: town in NW Martin County. Site given the name Goose Nest by a Union soldier on a raid. Inc. as Conoho, 1891. Name changed to Oak City, 1905, because of confusion with Conetoe; name selected from a calendar advertising Oak City Laundry in Raleigh.

label: Oak Forest
description: community in E Iredell County. Settled prior to 1800. Store there operated by James Gay. Thriving business community around 1900.

label: Oak Grove
description: community in W Yadkin County N of Flat Rock Creek.

label: Oak Grove Township
description: E central Durham County.

label: Oak Hill
description: community in N central Burke County about 4 mi. N of Morganton.

label: Oak Hill
description: community in central Macon County between Crawford Branch and Wallace Branch.

label: Oak Hill Mountain
description: peak in the Cane Creek Mountains, S Alamance County.

label: Oak Hill Township
description: NW Granville County.

label: Oak Island
description: a peninsula between Elizabeth River and the Atlantic Ocean at the mouth of the Cape Fear River in SE Brunswick County. Site of Fort Caswell, Long Beach, and Yaupon Beach. Appears as an island on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Oak Knob
description: E Haywood County on James Branch.

label: Oak Level Township
description: SE Nash County.

label: Oak Lodge
description: community in E Guilford County.

label: Oak Park
description: community in W Cherokee County on Shoal Creek S of Hiwassee River.

label: Oak Ridge
description: See Oak Knob.

label: Oak Ridge Creek
description: rises in E Jackson County and flows SW into Piney Mountain Creek.

label: Oak Ridge Township
description: NW Guilford County.

label: Oak Spring
description: community in central Rutherford County on Catheys Creek. A post office was there, 1855-1907.

label: Oak Summit
description: community in N Forsyth County served by post office, 1891-1903. Formerly Flat Branch.

label: Oak Swamp
description: rises in E Robeson County and flows NE into Big Swamp.

label: Oak Villa
description: community in E Hertford County. It developed on the old post road from Norfolk, Va., to Wilmington and was a point from which mail was rerouted.

label: Oakanoahs
description: See South Mountains.

label: Oakboro
description: town in SW Stanly County. Inc. 1915. Known as Furr City until about 1905. Post office est. 1914 with the coming of the railroad and when Big Lick post office was closed.

label: Oakdale
description: community in SW Wilkes County between Beaver Creek and Yadkin River.

label: Oakes Ridge
description: See Oak Knob.

label: Oakey Mountain
description: NE Rutherford County between North Fork and Collins Creek. Alt. approx. 2,200.

label: Oakgrove
description: community in NW Union County.

label: Oakland
description: community in central Nash County served by post office, 1885-1903.

label: Oakland
description: community in SW Transylvania County N of Round Mountain. Alt. 3,104.

label: Oakland Township
description: S central Chatham County.

label: Oakley
description: town in N Pitt County. Inc. 1903.

label: Oaklog Gap
description: on the Haywood-Transylvania county line.

label: Oaks
description: community in SW Orange County on Cane Creek. Site of an academy as early as 1829. The Bingham School operated there, 1844-65.

label: Oaks Knob
description: W Avery County.

label: Oakview
description: community in SW Guilford County adjacent to High Point. A portion of High Point was formerly a part of the Oakview community.

label: Oakville
description: community in N Franklin County.

label: Oakville
description: community in N Warren County between Hawtree Creek and Sixpound Creek. A post office est. there in 1872 was discontinued in 1907.

label: Oakwood Acres
description: community in S Davidson County on High Rock Lake.

label: Oakwoods
description: community in S Wilkes County between Cub Creek and East Prong Cub Creek. Settled by several Scottish families.

label: Oaky Mountain
description: NE Chatham County.

label: Obadiah Cove
description: W Graham County between Fork Ridge and Hooper Mill Creek.

label: Obadiah Gap
description: on Horse Cove Ridge in W Graham County.

label: Oberlin
description: formerly a community in central Wake County NW of Raleigh but now a part of the city of Raleigh.

label: Obids
description: community in S Ashe County. Alt. approx. 2,800.

label: Obids Creek
description: rises in SE Ashe county and flows N into South Fork New River.

label: Obids Township
description: SE Ashe County.

label: Obies Creek
description: rises in N Chatham County and flows NE into Orange County, where it enters Morgan Creek.

label: Observer
description: community in SW Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1900-1915. Named for local Observer School, which in turn was named for the Charlotte Observer

label: Ocala
description: community in S Jackson County on Fowler Creek.

label: Occacock
description: See Ocracoke.

label: Occam
description: See Croatan Sound.

label: Occaneechi Mountain
description: central Orange County S of the town of Hillsborough. Named for an Indian tribe mentioned frequently in seventeenth- and eighteenth-century records. The mountain is referred to in a letter of January 31, 1767, by Governor Tryon. Appears but is not named on the Collet map, 1770. Called Occaneeche Hills on the Kerr map, 1882. Alt. approx. 700. Now a local park.

label: Occoneechee Creek
description: rises in W Northampton County and flows S into Roanoke River. The name is probably from the Tutelo Indian word yuhkañ (man).

label: Occoneechee Neck
description: the W neck of Northampton County, is formed by a large bend in Roanoke River.

label: Occoneechee Township
description: SW Northampton County.

label: Ocean
description: community in W Carteret County served by post office, 1891-1927.

label: Ocean Isle Beach
description: town on the Atlantic Ocean, S Brunswick County. Inc. 1959.

label: Ochre Creek
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows W into Scott Creek.

label: Oconaluftee River
description: is formed in the Great Smoky Mountains in NE Swain County by the junction of Beech Flats Prong and Kephart Prong. For a part of its course, it forms the Jackson-Swain county line. It flows SE into Tuckasegee River. The name, long written as two words (Ocona Luftee), is from the Cherokee words Egwanulti or Egwani (river) and nulati or nuti (near; beside). The Cherokee town of Oconalufte, mentioned by explorer-naturalist William Bartram about 1775, was probably on the lower course of the river at present Birdtown.

label: Oconalufty Township
description: formerly in E Swain County but inc. into the limits of Charleston Township when it was enlarged between 1934 and 1940 with the establishment of Great Smoky Mountains National Park.

label: Ocracoke
description: community on Ocracoke Island, SE Hyde County. Settled in the seventeenth century. The name Ocracoke seems originally to have been Wococon, which appeared first on the White map, 1585. The Indian word apparently was waxkahikani, meaning "enclosed place," "fort," or "stockade," and it is believed that a fortified Indian village existed at the site. By 1676 the name Okok was used, and by 1709 it had developed into Occacock. See also Wococon Island.

label: Ocracoke Inlet
description: from the Atlantic Ocean into Pamlico Sound, lies between Ocracoke Island (Hyde County) on the N and Portsmouth Island (Carteret County) on the s. The pirate Blackbeard was killed in the vicinity in 1718. Once chief trade inlet for North Carolina.

label: Ocracoke Island
description: SE Hyde County, one of the Outer Banks. Approx. 17 mi. long. See also Croatoan Island; Wococon Island.

label: Ocracoke Township
description: SE Hyde County on the Outer Banks.

label: Odam Millpond
description: SW Wayne County on Thoroughfare Swamp.

label: Odamsville
description: See Faisons Old Tavern.

label: Odear Cove
description: E Swain County on the head of Wesser Creek.

label: Odell
description: community in E Warren County S of Little Fishing Creek. Post office est. there in 1892 but discontinued in 1914.

label: Odell Mill
description: See Forest Hill.

label: Odell School Township
description: former township in NW Cabarrus County, now township no. 3. Once known as Deweese Township.

label: Odessa
description: community in W Pender County served by post office, 1891-1905.

label: Off Island
description: approx. ½ mi. in diameter, lies off S Bodie Island in Roanoke Sound, E Dare County. Separated from Bodie Island by Blossie Creek.

label: Offen
description: community in N Wilkes County near Middle Prong Roaring River.

label: Ogburn
description: community in W Johnston County. Formerly spelled Aughburn.

label: Ogburn's Crossroads
description: community in NW Guilford County.

label: Ogburntown
description: community in central Forsyth County within the urban extension of the city of Winston-Salem.

label: Ogden
description: community in SW Clay County on Crawford Creek.

label: Ogle Branch
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows S into North Fork Ivy Creek. Named for a pioneer family.

label: Ogle Creek
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows SW to join Timber Creek in forming Sugar Camp Creek.

label: Ogle Gap
description: S Yancey County at the NW end of Ogle Ridge.

label: Ogle Knob
description: S central Swain County between the head of Bucknor Branch and Davis Branch.

label: Ogle Meadow Knob
description: on the Buncombe-Yancey county line. Alt. 5,384. A grassy bald known locally simply as Ogle Meadows.

label: Ogle Ridge
description: S Yancey County near the head of Ogle Creek.

label: Ogreeta
description: community in W Cherokee County on Hiwassee Lake between the mouth of Chambers Creek and Grape Creek.

label: Ohanoak
description: or an Indian village visited by Ralph Lane, 1585-86, on the W bank of Chowan River in what is now NE Bertie County S of Colerain. Appears on the De Bry map, 1590. On the Comberford map, 1657, it appears as Wohanoke. Modern Tuscarora Indians say the name means "old village."

label: Ohlanto
description: See Blowing Rock.

label: Oine
description: community in NW Warren County. Post office est. there in 1886 but discontinued in 1904.

label: Okay
description: community in NE Forsyth County served by post office, 1890-1904.

label: Okeewemee
description: community in N Montgomery County. Name derived from Indian word meaning "land between two rivers."

label: Okie Branch
description: rises in S Duplin County and flows SE into Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: Okisko
description: community in W Pasquotank County. Settled prior to 1890. Named for a king of the Yeopim Indians. Alt. 12.

label: Oklawaha
description: See Mud Creek.

label: Okok
description: See Ocracoke.

label: Ola
description: former community in W Haywood County near lat. 35°36'15" N., long. 83°08'00". The site is now within Great Smoky Mountains National Park and abandoned.

label: Old Apalachia
description: former community in NW Cherokee County below and N of Apalachia Dam near the junction of Shuler Creek with Hiwassee River.

label: Old Bald Creek
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows NE into Allen Creek.

label: Old Bald Mountain
description: on Haywood-Jackson county line. Alt. 5,800. Named for bald appearance from the Jackson County side.

label: Old Bald Ridge
description: extends from Chastine Creek in E central Jackson County N and NE to Allen Creek in SW Haywood County. Named for Old Bald Mountain, one of its peaks.

label: Old Barfields
description: See Tuscarora Beach.

label: Old Bear, The
description: point of land off E Pamlico County extending into Jones Bay.

label: Old Bethlehem
description: community in SE Warren County near the Halifax-Warren county line.

label: Old Billy Top
description: on the Cherokee-Graham county line in the Snowbird Mountains.

label: Old Black
description: See Mount Chapman.

label: Old Black Mountain
description: at the junction of the lines of Haywood County, N.C., and Cocke and Sevier Counties, Tenn., in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°42'44" N., long. 83°15'18" W. Alt. 6,430.

label: Old Catawba River
description: rises at the Catawba River Dam on Lake James and flows SE and NE into Catawba River about 1 mi. SE of Linville Dam in W Burke County.

label: Old Cove
description: N Swain County on Chambers Creek.

label: Old Dock
description: community in SE Columbus County on Waccamaw River 1 mi. SE of Schulkens Pond. Settled about 1800. Alt. 40.

label: Old Field
description: an area in what is now Beaufort County between Pungo and Pamlico Rivers; shown on the Ogilby map, 1671.

label: Old Field Bald Mountain
description: on Ashe-Watauga county line. Alt. 4,939. Named for muster ground and drill field used by Col. Benjamin Cleveland during the Revolution.

label: Old Field Branch
description: rises in NE Ashe County and flows SE into Poison Branch.

label: Old Field Creek
description: rises in E Orange County and flows NE into New Hope Creek.

label: Old Field Top Mountain
description: W Haywood County between Plott Balsams and Mingus Ridge. Alt. 5,820. Sometimes called Plott's Old Field Mountain.

label: Old Fields of Toe
description: See Newland.

label: Old Fields Township
description: W Wilson County.

label: Old Ford
description: See Mineola.

label: Old Ford Swamp
description: rises in NW Beaufort County and flows W to join Snoad Branch in forming Aggie Run.

label: Old Fort
description: town in W McDowell County on Catawba River. Alt. 1,438. Inc. 1872 as Catawba Vale by a northern land company that expected to develop a city on the Davidson plantation, which it had purchased the previous year. Name changed in 1873 to Old Fort, the name by which the community had been known since 1828 or earlier, when a post office existed there. Named for Davidson's Fort, erected in 1776 by troops under the command of Gen. Griffith Rutherford, who led expedition against the Cherokee Indians.

label: Old Fort Township
description: SW McDowell County.

label: Old Furnace
description: community in S Gaston County served by post office, 1848-1902.

label: Old Gilreath
description: community in S Wilkes County 3 mi. NW of Gilreath.

label: Old House Branch
description: rises in SE Watauga County and flows NE into Dugger Creek.

label: Old House Channel
description: a slough in the waters of Pamlico Sound immediately W of and leading to Oregon Inlet, E Dare County. Also known as Old House Slough.

label: Old House Creek
description: a short stream in N central Carteret County flowing N into South River.

label: Old Hundred
description: community in W Scotland County. Named because the 100-mile post was there when the railroad from Wilmington was built. Alt. 318.

label: Old Lanesboro
description: See Lanesboro.

label: Old Mattie Ridge
description: NE Cherokee County in the Snowbird Mountains.

label: Old Mattie Top
description: on the Cherokee-Graham county line in the Snowbird Mountains.

label: Old Mill Creek
description: rises in N central Washington County in East Dismal Swamp NE of the town of Roper and flows NW into Kendricks Creek.

label: Old Mill Swamp
description: rises in N Sampson County and flows SE into Great Coharie Creek.

label: Old Paddy Creek
description: about 7/10 mi. long, rises at Paddy Creek Dam on Lake James and flows E into Old Catawba River in W Burke County about 9 mi. W of Morganton.

label: Old Richmond Township
description: NW Forsyth County. Named for the former town of Richmond, which see, seat of Surry County from 1774 to 1789.

label: Old Road Gap
description: on the Cherokee-Macon county line.

label: Old Road Ridge
description: N Mitchell County between Spring Creek and Greasy Creek.

label: Old Rock
description: See Shell Castle.

label: Old Rocky Mountain
description: E Macon County between the head of Ellijay Creek and the head of Little Salt Rock Creek. Alt. 4,825.

label: Old Salem
