description: See Salem.

label: Old Shatter
description: See Axtell.

label: Old Sheep Knob
description: N Cleveland County. Alt. 1,497.

label: Old Skinnersville
description: See Skinnersville.

label: Old Sneedsborough
description: abandoned town in SE Anson County on Pee Dee River. Laid out in 1795 to be at the head of navigation on the Pee Dee River and named for Honora Sneyd, stepmother of Richard Lovell Edgeworth, founder of the town. Navigation was not developed sufficiently, and the town declined after about 30 years. Post office est. about 1803; closed 1883. Sneedsborough was famous for its inn. John J. McRae, governor of Mississippi (1854-58) and a member of U.S. and Confederate Congresses, was born there. See also McFarlan.

label: Old Sow, The
description: tidal-marsh island in Pamlico Sound off the SE tip of Goose Creek Island, NE Pamlico Sound.

label: Old Sparta
description: town in S Edgecombe County on Tar River. Inc. as Sparta, 1876, and reincorporated as Old Sparta, 1903. No longer active in municipal affairs. Post office est. 1829; probably came to be called Old Sparta after Sparta, county seat of Alleghany County, est. 1859, began to thrive.

label: Old Stanhope
description: See Spring Hope.

label: Old Station Gap
description: central Madison County between Brush Creek and Walnut Creek.

label: Old Topsail Creek
description: rises in S Pender County and flows S into Topsail Sound.

label: Old Topsail Inlet
description: See Beaufort Inlet.

label: Old Town
description: community in central Forsyth County. Settled 1753 by first Moravians to arrive at the Wachovia tract from Pennsylvania. First named Bethabara, or House of Passage, since it was intended to be a temporary settlement. After 1766, when Salem was begun, Bethabara declined. The post office, est. 1832, ceased to be called Bethabara in 1835 and was changed to Old Town.

label: Old Town Creek
description: See Town Creek.

label: Old Town Township
description: W central Forsyth County.

label: Old Trap
description: community in S Camden County, was probably settled as early as the 1650s. In the eighteenth century, it was the center of much maritime activity, and a grog shop there supplied the local trade with West India rum. Tradition says that men carrying grain to a local windmill tarried long at the grog shop—it "trapped" them. By the end of the Revolution, the name The Trap was being used, and after 1800 Old Trap came into use.

label: Old Tree Swamp
description: rises in W Hertford County and flows SE into Potecasi Creek.

label: Old Weeksville
description: See Weeksville.

label: Old Woman's Swamp
description: See Gilletts Creek.

label: Oldfield Creek
description: See Redbank Creek.

label: Oldfield Gap
description: on the Madison-Yancey county line near Indian Creek.

label: Oldfield Swamp
description: rises in S Robeson County and flows SE into Hog Swamp.

label: Oldfields Township
description: SW Ashe County. Named for muster ground and drill field used by Benjamin Cleveland during the Revolution.

label: Oldham
description: community in N Forsyth County served by post office, 1883-1901.

label: Olds
description: community in S Currituck County. Known locally as Olds Hill for a sand hill nearby.

label: Olds Township
description: E central Greene County. Named for the Olds family whose members moved there after 1779.

label: Oldwoman Branch
description: rises in W Pitt County and flows SE into Little Contentnea Creek.

label: Olga
description: community in W Pender County served by post office, 1900-1908.

label: Olin
description: town in N central Iredell County. Est. and inc. 1855 as New Institute when Brantley York and Baxter Clegg opened an academy there. Reincorporated 1857 as Olin in honor of Stephen Olin, Methodist educator. Inc. again in 1905, but long inactive in municipal affairs.

label: Olin Creek
description: rises in NW Iredell County and flows SE into Patterson Creek. Formerly known as Little Rocky Creek.

label: Olin Township
description: N central Iredell County.

label: Olive Branch
description: community in NE Union County E of Gourdvine Creek.

label: Olive Grove
description: community in N Cleveland County.

label: Olive Hill
description: community in W Person County.

label: Olive Hill Township
description: W central Person County.

label: Olive Hollow
description: W Watauga County, extends northward W of Laurel Creek.

label: Oliver
description: community in E Johnston County.

label: Oliver Reef
description: S Dare and E Hyde Counties in the waters of Pamlico Sound N of Hatteras Inlet. Presented by the state to the U.S. government in 1874 for use in naval target practice. Returned to the state in 1965.

label: Oliver's Crossroads
description: community in central Jones County.

label: Olivers
description: community in central Jones County.

label: Olivers Crossroads
description: community in S Catawba County.

label: Olivet
description: community in NW Caldwell County on Mulberry Creek. Named for Olivet Methodist Church, in turn named for biblical Mount Olivet or Mount of Olives.

label: Olivette
description: community in central Buncombe County.

label: Olivia
description: community in W Harnett County. Settled about 1865. Known as Rock Branch until 1913, when it was renamed to honor W. J. Olive, who in 1912 introduced cultivation of flue-cured tobacco there.

label: Ollie Branch
description: rises in central Graham County and flows SW into East Buffalo Creek.

label: Olmmetta
description: community in E Wilkes County.

label: Olne
description: community in NW Warren County served by post office, 1886-1904.

label: Olympia
description: community in W Pamlico County. In 1891 named for Mount Olympus when a post office, discontinued in 1908, was est. there.

label: Omega
description: community in N Rowan County served by post office, 1886-1904.

label: Oneida
description: community in N Alamance County served by post office, 1900-1908.

label: Onetree Point
description: shown on Moseley map, 1733, extending from the mainland of what is now SE Brunswick County into Cape Fear River between Elizabeth River and Walden Creek. Located N of and adjacent to Deep Water Point. Not shown on modern maps.

label: Onion Falls
description: in West Fork Tuckasegee River at the N end of Thorpe Reservoir in W Jackson County.

label: Onion Knob
description: Alexander-Wilkes county line.

label: Onion Mountain
description: E Macon County between the head of Cat Creek and Laurel Creek. Alt. 3,500.

label: Onitalooga Lake
description: See Ela Lake.

label: Onslow Bay
description: in the Atlantic Ocean off the SE coast from Cape Fear on the S to Cape Lookout on the n.

label: Onslow Beach
description: SE Onslow County between New River Inlet and Browns Inlet. Known earlier as Hurst Beach. Now a part of the Camp Lejeune Marine Corps Air Station and used for training for amphibious landings.

label: Onslow County
description: was formed in 1734 from New Hanover County. Located in the SE section of the state, it is bounded by the Atlantic Ocean and by Pender, Duplin, Jones, and Carteret Counties. It was named for Arthur Onslow (1691-1768), member of Parliament and speaker of the House of Commons, 1728-61. Area: 806 sq. mi (756, land; 50, water). County seat: Jacksonville, with an elevation of 23 ft. Townships are Jacksonville, Richlands, Stump Sound, Swansboro, and White Oak. Produces tobacco, turkeys, cotton, corn, soybeans, hogs, livestock, lumber, apparel, marble, crushed limestone, sand, and gravel.

label: Onslow Court House
description: See Jacksonville.

label: Onvil
description: community in central Montgomery County near the head of Thickety Creek. Served by post office, 1883-1915.

label: Onward
description: community in SW Montgomery County served by post office, 1887-96.

label: Ooneroy
description: a Tuscarora Indian village on the Roanoke River in Bertie County shown on the Moseley map, 1733. It was a chief town of the Tuscarora; the name meant "gathered together."

label: Open Branch
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows NW into Hornbuckle Creek.

label: Open Land
description: or a shrub bog area of approx. 50,000 acres in Carteret County about 12 mi. NE of Beaufort. An attempt to reclaim the area in 1926 was abandoned, but much of it is now included in a large experimental farm.

label: Open Ridge
description: S Yancey County between Rock Creek and South Toe River.

label: Opening, The
description: a clay and swamp area in E Pitt County between the head of Clayroot Swamp and Chicod Creek.

label: Ophir
description: community in N Montgomery County served by post office, 1883-1933. Settled shortly after the middle of the nineteenth century in the midst of a gold-producing area and named for the land furnishing gold for King Solomon's Temple in biblical days. Now an agricultural and timber-producing community.

label: Ophir Township
description: NW Montgomery County.

label: Oporauck
description: an otherwise unidentified designation appearing on the Comberford map, 1657, shown parallel with what is now Scuppernong River in Washington and Tyrrell Counties.

label: Opossum Swamp
description: rises in W Sampson County and flows S into Little Coharie Creek.

label: Ora
description: community in central Sampson County served by post office, 1886-1902.

label: Orange
description: community in W Sampson County between Caesar Swamp and Little Coharie Creek.

label: Orange County
description: was formed in 1752 from Johnston, Bladen, and Granville Counties. Located in the central section of the state, it is bounded by Durham, Chatham, Alamance, Caswell, and Person Counties. It has long been said that the county was named for William III (1650-1702) of the House of Orange, who ruled England from 1689 to 1702. However, in 1752, when the county was formed, the infant William V (1748-1806) of Orange was Stadtholder, and his mother, Anne, daughter of George II of England, controlled affairs of state. It seems reasonable to assume that Orange County was named in honor of William V of Orange (and perhaps also to flatter his grandfather, George II of England) instead of for William III, who had been dead for 50 years. Area: 398 sq. mi. County seat: Hillsborough, with an elevation of 543 ft. Townships are Bingham, Cedar Grove, Chapel Hill, Cheeks, Eno, Hillsborough, and Little River. Produces corn, tobacco, wheat, oats, dairy products, barley, poultry, livestock, hogs, textiles, furniture, pyrophyllite, and crushed stone.

label: Orange Factory
description: community on Little River in N Durham County formerly known as Laura Cotton Mill. Once operated by Willard Manufacturing Company.

label: Orange Grove
description: community in SW Orange County between Cane Creek and Bear Creek.

label: Orange Point
description: E Tyrrell County, extends from the mainland into Alligator River S of the mouth of The Frying Pan.

label: Orapeake
description: See Corapeake.

label: Orapeake Creek
description: See Corapeake Swamp.

label: Orapeake Swamp
description: See Corapeake Swamp.

label: Orbit
description: community in S Bladen County served by post office, 1898-1911.

label: Orchard Branch
description: rises in N central Transylvania County and flows S into King Creek.

label: Orchard Creek
description: See Craborchard Creek.

label: Orchard Ridge
description: N Madison County between Big Laurel Creek and Little Foster Creek.

label: Ore Hill
description: See Mount Vernon Springs.

label: Ore Knob
description: former town in SE Ashe County. Inc. 1875. Copper mine there once employed 250 men; closed in 1886. Little evidence of buildings remains. Alt. 3,150.

label: Oregon
description: See South Creek.

label: Oregon Hill
description: community in N Rockingham County served by post office, 1853-66 and 1868-1909. Located between the heads of Quaqua and Lovelace Creeks. It is said that a man stopped there early in the nineteenth century on his way to Oregon but never got any farther, so he called the site Oregonville and the name evolved. Nearby Guerrant Springs was a popular resort later in the century and into the early 1900s.

label: Oregon Inlet
description: E Dare County from Pamlico Sound into the Atlantic Ocean between S tip of Bodie Island and N tip of Pea Island. Formed by a hurricane on September 7, 1846. Named for the first vessel to pass through, the side-wheeler Oregon State-operated free ferry across the inlet now replaced by the Herbert C. Bonner Bridge, approx. 2½ mi. long, which opened in December 1963; named for N.C. congressman Herbert C. Bonner (1891-1965).

label: Oregon Inlet Coast Guard Station
description: E Dare County on Pea Island near Oregon Inlet. First est. as Bodie's Island Lifesaving Station in 1874; name later changed. The Life-saving Service and Revenue Cutter Service joined in 1915 to form U.S. Coast Guard.

label: Oregonville Township
description: former township in E Rockingham County. Name changed in 1887 to Ruffin.

label: Orenburg
description: See Harris.

label: Orfords Pond
description: See Sunset Lake.

label: Organ Church
description: community in S Rowan County served by post office, 1851-1906.

label: Oriental
description: town in S Pamlico County on Neuse River at the mouth of Smith Creek. First settled about 1870 by "Uncle Lou" Midgett and known as Smith's Creek. Later renamed for the Federal transport Oriental, which sank in 1862 near Bodie Island. The ship's nameplate had been found by Rebecca Midgett, wife of the town's first settler.

label: Orinoco
description: community in NE Davidson County served by post office, 1886-1904.

label: Orion
description: community in SE Ashe County.

label: Orlando
description: community in S Macon County.

label: Orleans
description: community in SW Lincoln County served by post office, 1886-1906.

label: Ormonds Township
description: SE Greene County. Named for the Ormond family, which settled in the Ormondsville community prior to 1769.

label: Ormondsville
description: community in E Greene County. Developed from a country crossroads store at the Ormond family plantation.

label: Orris's Run
description: swampy stream rises in N central Beaufort County and flows SE into Pungo Creek. Named for Orris Waters who lived nearby.

label: Orrum
description: town in S Robeson County. Settled as early as 1832 as a community around Big Branch Church. Inc. 1903. Orton was the first choice for a name in 1903 when a post office was about to be est., but as the name was already in use in Columbus County, it was rejected. Orrum was coined as a variant of Orton.

label: Orrum Township
description: SE Robeson County.

label: Orton
description: community in N Columbus County served by post office, 1883-1904.

label: Orton Branch
description: rises in S Buncombe County and flows NE into French Broad River.

label: Orton Creek
description: rises in SE Brunswick County and flows E into Cape Fear River.

label: Orton Plantation
description: E central Brunswick County overlooking Cape Fear River. House, built about 1725 by Roger Moore and later the home of Governor Benjamin Smith, is now a tourist attraction with extensive azalea gardens. The old town of Brunswick, which see, was nearby.

label: Orton Point
description: point of land S of mouth of Lilliput Creek in E Brunswick County extending into Cape Fear River.

label: Orton Pond
description: artificial pond on Orton Creek in E Brunswick County. Built about 1810. Max. depth 12 ft. Surface area 500 acres.

label: Os-quee-ha-ha
description: See Clear Creek.

label: Osage Mountain
description: S Macon County between West Fork Overflow Creek and Watkins Creek.

label: Osborn Branch
description: rises in NE Transylvania County and flows SE into Boylston Creek.

label: Osborn Mountain
description: E Watauga County between Elk Creek and Southwest Stony Fork Creek.

label: Osborne
description: community in S Richmond County.

label: Osborne Creek
description: rises in SE Wilkes County and flows S into Iredell County, where it enters Hunting Creek.

label: Osbornville
description: community in SE Wilkes County on Osborne Creek.

label: Osburn Ford
description: shallows in Pigeon River just NE of the town of Clyde in central Haywood County.

label: Osceola
description: crossroads community in NE Guilford County.

label: Osceola Lake
description: central Henderson County, is fed by Findley, Perry, and Tonys Creeks and drained by Shephard Creek. It was formed about 1914 and named for an Indian chief in the area. Covers 12 acres; max. depth 20 ft.

label: Osgood
description: community in N Lee County. Inc. 1889; charter repealed 1891. Named for local family. Early known as Shakerag, traditionally because two prominent men fought there until their clothes were torn off. Alt. 242.

label: Osmond
description: community in NE Caswell County. A post office was operated there, 1883-1916.

label: Ossipee
description: community in W Alamance County on the S side of Altamahaw. Developed after 1890 when a mill was est. there. Inc. 2002.

label: Osteen
description: community in SW Henderson County on Crab Creek.

label: Ostin Creek
description: rises in W central Polk County at the base of Chimney Top and flows NE into Lake Adger on Green River.

label: Ostin Knob
description: SE Macon County between Brown Gap and East Fork Overflow Creek.

label: Ostwalt
description: community in S Iredell County. Known as Cambridge for an Associate Reformed Presbyterian Church from the early nineteenth century until 1895, when it took its present name from J. K. Ostwalt's store when it became a post office.

label: Oswego
description: community in NE Franklin County served by post office, 1892-1903.

label: Otaré
description: See Mountain Region.

label: Oteen
description: community in central Buncombe County near the E limits of Asheville. Site of a veterans hospital, est. during World War I for tubercular soldiers. Name said to be an Indian word meaning "chief aim" and descriptive of the hospital's efforts to restore health to the disabled.

label: Othello
description: community in SE Ashe County.

label: Otis
description: community in NE Yadkin County served by post office, 1891-1903.

label: Ottanola
description: community in NE Henderson County.

label: Ottaray
description: See Mountain Region.

label: Otter Creek
description: community in N Rutherford County on Cove Creek. A post office was there, 1854-1915.

label: Otter Creek Township
description: former township in S Edgecombe County, now township no. 9. Earlier known as Autreys Creek Township.

label: Otter Gap
description: NW Macon County between Long Branch and Otter Creek.

label: Otter Mountain
description: NW Macon County between Cold Spring Creek and the head of Jane Otter Branch.

label: Otters Knob
description: See Arturs Knob.

label: Otto
description: town in S Macon County. Alt. 2,060. Inc. 1909, but long inactive in municipal affairs.

label: Otway
description: community in E Carteret County near the mouth of Ward Creek. Settled about 1800. Named for Otway Burns (1775-1848), captain of a privateer vessel in the War of 1812. Alt. 5.

label: Ouaniche
description: See Wananish.

label: Outer Banks
description: are a string of low, narrow, sandy islands extending for more than 175 mi. from the Virginia state line to below Cape Lookout. They are separated from the mainland of North Carolina by broad, shallow sounds. Narrow inlets through the Outer Banks provide access to the Atlantic Ocean from the sounds. The Outer Banks, from N to s, are Currituck Banks, Bodie Island, Pea Island, Hatteras Island, Ocracoke Island, Portsmouth Island, Core Banks, Shackleford Banks, and Bogue Banks. In 1709 John Lawson wrote of the "Sand Banks." In 1713 the term "Sea Banks" was used in describing them (see Shackleford Banks). See also Carolarns Islands; Croatoan Island.

label: Outer Diamond Shoal
description: See Diamond Shoals.

label: Outlaws Bridge
description: community in NE Duplin County.

label: Outlaws Pond
description: on Halls Marsh Branch in N Duplin County.

label: Outlook
description: community in S Madison County.

label: Outz Creek
description: rises in E Alexander County and flows E into Iredell County.

label: Oval
description: community in S Ashe County served by post office, 1898-1953.

label: Over Hills
description: See Mountain Region.

label: Overcup Creek
description: rises in NE Chatham County and flows SE into New Hope Creek.

label: Overflow Creek
description: is formed in S Macon County by the junction of East Fork Overflow Creek and West Fork Overflow Creek and flows SE into Rabun County, Ga., where it enters Chattooga River.

label: Overhills
description: community in SW Harnett County. Approx. 20,000 acres developed by the Rockefeller family as a hunting and timber-growing preserve.

label: Overlook Ridge
description: NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, lat. 35°33'37" N., long. 83°10'50" W.

label: Overshot
description: community in S Johnston County served by post office, 1893-1904.

label: Owen Creek
description: rises in central Granville County.

label: Owen Hill Landing
description: NW Bladen County on Cape Fear River at the site of Owen Hill plantation, home and birthplace of Governor John Owen (1787-1841), only N.C. governor from Bladen County. Foundation and basement of original house are still there on a bluff above the landing.

label: Owen Jones Tar Landing
description: See Tar Landing.

label: Owen's Creek
description: rises in NE Alamance County and flows SW into Jordan Creek.

label: Owenby Branch
description: rises in central Macon County and flows NE into Little Tennessee River.

label: Owenby Cove
description: central Buncombe County between Little Cedar Mountain and Gashes Creek.

label: Owens
description: community in central Cumberland County.

label: Owens Branch
description: rises in S Clay County and flows NW into Shooting Creek.

label: Owens Cove
description: S Buncombe County N of Face Rock.

label: Owens Creek
description: rises in W Warren County and flows SW into Fishing Creek. Appears on the MacRae map, 1833.

label: Owens Gap
description: on the Jackson-Transylvania county line N of the head of West Fork French Broad River. Alt. 3,590.

label: Owens Knob
description: S Wilkes County at the NE end of Gill Mountain. Alt. 1,350. The W. Kerr Scott Dam on Yadkin River is nearby. Named for one Owen, who lived there in 1752 when Moravian surveyors arrived.

label: Owens Point
description: extends from E Onslow County into White Oak River. Probably named for either Thomas Owens or Benjamin Owens, two early settlers there.

label: Owens Store
description: See Grove Hill.

label: Owensville
description: See Roseboro.

label: Owl Branch
description: rises in E Swain County near Rattlesnake Mountain and flows SW parallel to Adams Creek into Oconaluftee River.

label: Owl Creek
description: rises in N Cherokee County and flows SW into Hiwassee River.

label: Owl Creek Gap
description: N Cherokee County on Hanging Dog Mountain near the headwaters of Owl Creek.

label: Owl Knob
description: N Macon County on Matlock Creek.

label: Owltown
description: community in SW Buncombe County N of Hooker Gap.

label: Ox Creek
description: rises in central Buncombe County and flows NW into Reems Creek.

label: Ox Pen Branch
description: rises in S central Brunswick County and flows SW into Skipper Branch.

label: Oxear Cove
description: W Haywood County on the head of Hyatt Creek.

label: Oxford
description: town and county seat, central Granville County. Authorized to be laid off in 1811 and inc. 1816. The land on which the town was est. had been a part of Samuel Benton's plantation, "Oxford," hence the name. Produces tobacco and textiles. Appears on the Price map, 1808. Alt. 476. See also Harris Burgh.

label: Oxford District
description: a section of Granville County, perhaps in the central part of the county in which Samuel Benton's plantation, "Oxford," was located. In 1790 there were 65 heads of families in the district.

label: Oxford Lake
description: See Lake Hickory.

label: Oxford Township
description: central Granville County.

label: Oxfords Ford
description: community in W Catawba County served by post office, 1873-1903.

label: Oyama
description: See Few.

label: Oyster Creek
description: a channel among the tidal-marsh islands on the SW shore of Roanoke Island, E Dare County in the waters of Croatan Sound. Approx. 1 mi. W of community of Wanchese.

label: Oyster Creek
description: rises on NW Goose Creek Island, NE Pamlico County, and flows NE into Pamlico River.

label: Oyster Creek Landing
description: community in S Hyde County on Swanquarter Bay.

label: Ozark
description: community in NE Wilkes County served by post office, 1882-1908.

label: Pace Branch
description: rises in central Cherokee County and flows SW into Rogers Creek.

label: Pacific
description: See Youngsville.

label: Pack Gap
description: SW Cherokee County on Pack Mountain.

label: Pack Mountain
description: SW Cherokee County, extends SE from Pack Gap near the Polk County, Tenn., line to Signal Pole Hill. In Nantahala National Forest. Named peaks include Harris Top, Pack Top, and Signal Pole Hill.

label: Pack Top
description: SW Cherokee County in Nantahala National Forest at the NW end of Pack Mountain near the Tennessee state line. Alt. approx. 2,415.

label: Packs Creek
description: rises in S Jackson County and flows NW into Robinson Creek.

label: Pacolet Fall
description: on Pacolet River in SE Henderson County.

label: Pacolet River
description: rises in SE Henderson County near the South Carolina state line and flows NE into Polk County, where it turns SE to flow into South Carolina. There it enters Broad River. Sometimes also known as North Pacolet River.

label: Pactolus
description: town in E Pitt County. Inc. 1887. Named for the ancient river in Asia Minor. Alt. 22.

label: Pactolus Township
description: E Pitt County.

label: Paddy Creek
description: rises in W Burke County and flows SE approx. 6½ mi. into Lake James.

label: Paddy Mountain
description: central Ashe County W of West Jefferson.

label: Paddys Delight Creek
description: rises in N Northampton County and flows SE into Potecasi Creek.

label: Padgett
description: community in W Onslow County on Sandy Run Swamp.

label: Padgett Branch
description: rises in N Buncombe County and flows SE into White Branch.

label: Padgett Swamp
description: rises in W Onslow County and flows SE into Sandy Run Swamp.

label: Page
description: community in NW Pender County served by post office, 1887-1903.

label: Page's Branch
description: rises in E Wilson County and flows N into Cattail Swamp. Named for Thomas Page prior to 1786.

label: Page's Mill
description: community on East Prong Moon Creek, W Caswell County. Earlier known as Jones Mill for Richard Jones, who est. a water mill there about 1840.

label: Page's Siding
description: See Cary.

label: Page's Tavern
description: See Cary.

label: Page's Turnout
description: See Cary.

label: Pages Creek
description: rises in NE New Hanover County and flows SE into Topsail Sound.

label: Pages Lake
description: NW Bladen County, was formed about 1925 by a dam on Mines Creek. Max. depth 18 ft. Formerly known as Davis Mill Pond.

label: Paget Branch
description: rises in S Duplin County and flows S into Boney Mill Pond.

label: Pailin Creek
description: rises in E Pasquotank County and flows SE into New Begun Creek.

label: Paine Mountain
description: NW Cleveland County. Alt. approx. 1,975.

label: Pains Bay
description: S Dare County in the mouth of Long Shoal River.

label: Paint Creek
description: See Paint Fork.

label: Paint Fork
description: community in E Madison County on Paint Fork.

label: Paint Fork Gap
description: N Buncombe County near the headwaters of Paint Fork.

label: Paint Gap
description: community in W Yancey County on Indian Creek at the mouth of Horton Creek. Alt. 2,676.

label: Paint Hill
description: SE Moore County. Indians made red paint from stones found at the site, hence the name. Alt. 640.

label: Paint Mountain
description: SW Swain County between Big Creek and Right Fork [Wesser Creek].

label: Paint Rock
description: community in W Madison County on French Broad River. Inc. 1891; charter repealed 1895. Early landmark, site of a blockhouse to protect settlers from Indians, 1793. Figures on a rock cliff there appeared to early settlers to be paintings. Appears as Painted Rock on the Price map, 1808. Alt. 1,265.

label: Painted Rock
description: See Paint Rock.

label: Painter
description: See Cullowhee.

label: Painter Branch
description: rises in W Swain County and flows SE into Little Tennessee River.

label: Painter Knob
description: N Cleveland County. Alt. 2,323.

label: Painter Swamp
description: rises in W Hertford County and flows SE into Potecasi Creek.

label: Painters Gap
description: N Rutherford County on the NE side of Chalk Mountain. Perhaps originally Panthers Gap.

label: Palestine
description: community in N Stanly County. Alt. 582.

label: Palm
description: community in NE Haywood County served by post office, 1886-1905.

label: Palmer Branch
description: rises in W Haywood County and flows NW into Caldwell Fork.

label: Palmer Camp Branch
description: rises in E central Madison County and flows SE into Big Laurel Creek.

label: Palmer Creek
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, is formed by the junction of Beech Creek and Falling Rock Creek near lat. 35°38'05" N., long. 83°09'17" W. Flows E to join Caldwell Fork in forming Cataloochee Creek. Named for "Turkey" George Palmer, who lived on its banks. Sheriff of Haywood County, Palmer acquired the nickname "Turkey" because he killed so many wild turkeys.

label: Palmer Mountain
description: NE Stanly County on a peninsula in Badin Lake.

label: Palmerville
description: community in NE Stanly County.

label: Palmetto Point
description: extends from the mainland into Albemarle Sound in N Tyrrell County. Appears as Hoskins Point on the Tanner map, 1829.

label: Palmetto Swamp
description: rises in N Craven County and flows SW into Swift Creek.

label: Palmyra
description: town in SE Halifax County. Inc. 1883. A post office was est. there in 1811. Alt. 96.

label: Palmyra Township
description: SE Halifax County.

label: Palo Alto
description: community in E Onslow County served by post office, 1850-1902. Birthplace and burial site of Governor Daniel Russell (1897-1901).

label: Pamlico
description: town in E Pamlico County on Broad Creek near Neuse River. Post office est. 1878. Founded by Joshua Dean, first postmaster, who was a native of Fall River, Mass., and engaged in the lumber business there as well as in his native town. Known earlier as Broad Creek. Inc. 1913, but long inactive in municipal affairs.

label: Pamlico Beach
description: resort community in E Beaufort County on the N side of Pamlico River.

label: Pamlico County
description: was formed in 1872 from Craven and Beaufort Counties. Located in the E section of the state, it is bounded by Pamlico Sound, Neuse River, and by Craven and Beaufort Counties. It was named for Pamlico Sound. Area: 576 sq. mi. (341, land; 235, water). County seat: Bayboro, with an elevation of 8.5 ft. Townships are nos. 1-5. Produces corn, soybeans, Irish potatoes, turkeys, hogs, and processed seafood.

label: Pamlico Point
description: peninsula off Goose Creek Island, NE Pamlico County, extending into Pamlico River.

label: Pamlico River
description: is the lower course of Tar River after it enters Beaufort County. It flows SE for 33 mi. before emptying into Pamlico Sound. Explored in 1584 by Arthur Barlowe and called Cipo River, for sipowi, the local Indian word for river. Appears as Pamptico River on the Comberford map, 1657, and as Pamticough River on the Moll map, 1729. Named for the Pamlico Indians in the area. Bonds Ferry appears on the Collet map, 1770, as crossing the Pamlico River on the road from Bath to New Bern.

label: Pamlico Sound
description: NE and E North Carolina, is separated from the Atlantic Ocean by a part of the Outer Banks. Approx. 80 mi. long and 15 to 30 mi. wide. Shallow in the n; max. depth 21 ft. in the s. Sea level, freshwater, not affected by the tide. Waters from Albemarle Sound and Pamlico and Neuse Rivers enter the Sound, and it drains into the Atlantic Ocean through Hatteras and Ocracoke Inlets. Named for the Pamlico Indians who lived along its shores. Shown but not named on early maps; appears simply as The Sound on the Ogilby map, 1671, but as Pamticoe Sound on the Moseley map, 1733. The White map, 1590, labels the central part of the sound as Mentso, which see, and the N part as Nausegoc, which see. The largest sound on the E coast of the United States. See also Paquiac.

label: Pamptecough Precinct
description: was created in Bath County on December 3, 1705. It took its name from Pamptecough (Pamlico) River. The name was changed to Beaufort County, which see, about 1712. The town of Bath was the county seat from its inc. in 1705 until 1785, when Washington became the county seat.

label: Pamticoe Sound
description: See Pamlico Sound.

label: Panacea
description: community in E Warren and NW Halifax Counties on Bens Creek. Named for Panacea Springs, a popular resort there in early 1900s with a large hotel and a lake near mineral springs (supposedly curative). Water formerly bottled and sold; the hotel, lake, and cottages are gone.

label: Panacea Springs
description: See Panacea.

label: Panauuaioc
description: Indian village site shown on the De Bry map, 1590, in what is now Beaufort County near the head of Pamlico River on its S bank.

label: Pancake Branch
description: rises in W Avery County and flows NW into North Toe River.

label: Panhandle Creek
description: rises in S Madison County and flows NW into French Broad River.

label: Pant
description: community in NE Haywood County served by post office, 1884-1905.

label: Pantego
description: town in NE Beaufort County on Pantego Creek. Alt. 7. A post office since 1825. Inc. 1881.

label: Pantego Creek
description: rises in Dismal Swamp, E Beaufort County, and flows S and E into Pungo River. It is also fed by several canals draining from the swamp. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Pantego Swamp
description: E Beaufort County.

label: Pantego Township
description: NE Beaufort County.

label: Panther Branch
description: rises in S Wake County and flows S into Middle Creek.

label: Panther Branch Township
description: SE Wake County.

label: Panther Cove
description: S Graham County between Little Snowbird Creek and Old Mattie Top.

label: Panther Creek
description: rises in W Wake County and flows SW into Chatham County, where it turns NW to flow into Northeast Creek.

label: Panther Den Falls
description: on Britton Creek in NE Cherokee County. A picnic area, est. by the U.S. Forest Service, is nearby.

label: Panther Flat Top
description: mountain on Cherokee-Graham county line.

label: Panther Gap
description: S Macon County between Sheep Knob and Panther Knob.

label: Panther Knob
description: W Madison County between Hogback Mountain and Meadow Fork.

label: Panther Mountain
description: S Transylvania County between Eby Creek and Cannon Creek.

label: Panther Ridge
description: NE Macon County between Beasley Creek and Mica City Creek.

label: Panther Spring Gap
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°36'35" N., long. 83°03'50" W.

label: Panther Swamp
description: a sandy loam area approx. 1 mi. square in E Northampton County on the headwaters of Canal Swamp.

label: Panther Swamp Creek
description: rises in central Greene County and flows SW into Contentnea Creek.

label: Panther Top
description: S Cherokee County between Beech Creek and Notelly River. Alt. 2,287.

label: Panthers Gap
description: See Painters Gap.

label: Panthertail Mountain
description: W Transylvania County N of Toxaway River. Alt. 4,516.

label: Panthertown Creek
description: rises in SE Jackson County and flows NW then NE to join Greenland Creek in forming Tuckasegee River.

label: Paquiac
description: name given by John White on his maps of 1585 and 1590 to the section of Hatteras Island S of Cape Kenrick and extending almost to modern Cape Hatteras, SE Dare County. The section lay between present Chicamacomico Banks and Kinnakeet Banks. The name Paquiac is an Algonquian Indian term for "it is shallow," describing the adjacent Pamlico Sound.

label: Paquike Lake
description: See Lake Mattamuskeet.

label: Paquinouc
description: See Perquimans River.

label: Paquippe
description: See Lake Mattamuskeet.

label: Paradise
description: community in W Richmond County served by post office, 1893-95.

label: Paradise Point
description: on the E side of New River in central Onslow County. Named for a former owner of the area. Now within Camp Lejeune Marine Base. Local tradition says that the home of David Simmons was there, and that he had several daughters widely known for their charms and beauty. Lovesick beaux called the place Paradise Point.

label: Parched Corn Bay
description: in the waters of Pamlico Sound off the SE shore of the mainland of Dare County.

label: Parched Corn Point
description: land on the SE mainland of Dare County extending into Pamlico Sound.

label: Paris
description: community in SE Anson County served by post office, 1870-1901.

label: Park Creek
description: rises in SW Macon County and flows NE into Nantahala River.

label: Park Gap
description: SE Clay County between Marbleyard Ridge and Little Buck Creek.

label: Park Springs
description: lake on Moon Creek in W Caswell County. Formerly a health resort and mineral spring. Lake, covering 8 acres and owned by the Danville, Va., Kiwanis Club, long used for fishing and swimming.

label: Park Yarn
description: community in SE Cleveland County S of the town of Kings Mountain. Park Yarn mills operated there.

label: Parker
description: community in W Ashe County. Alt. 3,950.

label: Parker Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County on Brushy Head Mountain and flows NW into Valley River.

label: Parker Creek
description: rises in W Transylvania County and flows SE into West Fork French Broad River.

label: Parker Gap
description: between Neddie Knob and Cub Branch in E Jackson County. Alt. 4,038.

label: Parker Knob
description: central Jackson County between Wayehutta Creek and Moses Creek. Alt. 4,187.

label: Parker Knob
description: on the Jackson-Haywood county line. Alt. 5,420.

label: Parker Mountain
description: W Cherokee County near Bearpaw Creek.

label: Parker Ridge
description: N Cherokee County in the Snowbird Mountains.

label: Parker's Ferry
description: See Meherrin River.

label: Parkers Branch
description: rises in E Union County and flows E into Lanes Creek.

label: Parkers Creek
description: rises in N Harnett County and flows SW into Cape Fear River. Named by Peter Parker when he settled along its banks prior to 1746.

label: Parkers Fork
description: community in NE Gates County.

label: Parkersborough
description: See The Borough.

label: Parkersburg
description: town in W Sampson County. Settled about 1888; inc. 1891, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Named for William J. Parker, an early subscriber of stock in the railroad on which the town was located. Alt. 118.

label: Parks
description: community in NE Wilkes County served by post office, 1884-1906.

label: Parks Branch
description: rises in central Haywood County and flows NW into Jonathans Creek.

label: Parks Mountain
description: NW tip of Burke County. Alt. 4,066.

label: Parkstown
description: community in E Wayne County near the coincident boundaries of Greene, Lenoir, and Wayne Counties.

label: Parkton
description: town in NE Robeson County. Settled about 1884. Inc. 1901. Known first as Gillis Station for Mrs. John Gillis, who sold land for a railroad station. When the railroad was completed, the name was changed to Parkton, probably from the fact that farmers of the surrounding area "parked" teams at the station to take the train to Fayetteville.

label: Parkton Township
description: N Robeson County.

label: Parktown
description: community in S Warren County between Fishing Creek and Shocco Creek.

label: Parkville
description: community in E Perquimans County.

label: Parkville Township
description: E central Perquimans County.

label: Parkwood
description: formerly an industrial community in N Moore County. Est. before the Civil War when William Donnelly, stonemason, began making millstones there. A sawmill, brick kiln, flour mill, and other businesses developed. Bankruptcy in the 1880s forced the closing of the businesses, and the community began to decline. During World War II, the remaining buildings were dismantled and removed. In 1953 the community of Hallison, about 1¼ mi. n, changed its name to Parkwood. Hallison had been named by Maj. W. C. Petty, a railroad man, for his deceased son, Hall Jefferson. Alt. 450.

label: Parmele
description: town in W Martin County. Settled about 1885; inc. 1893. Named for a partner in the Parmele-Eccleston Lumber Company, which operated at the site. Alt. 76.

label: Parrish Creek
description: rises in central Macon County and flows NW into Burningtown Creek.

label: Parrish's Pond
description: formed about 1890 on Redbud Creek in E Franklin County. Covers 20 acres, with a max. depth of 15 ft. Known first as Babbit's Pond and then as Woods Pond.

label: Parrotts
description: community in N Lenoir County. Named for the Parrott family, which settled in the vicinity in the 1760s. Alt. 54.

label: Parrotts Creek
description: rises in E Onslow County and flows E into Queens Creek. Named for John Parrott. Generally known locally as Parrotts Swamp but also called Moseley's Creek.

label: Parrotts Swamp
description: See Parrotts Creek.

label: Parson Bald
description: in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Swain County, N.C.-Blount County, Tenn., line, lat. 35°31'25" N., long. 83°53' W. Alt. 4,730.

label: Parson Branch
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows SE into Peterson Branch.

label: Parsons Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County on Brushy Head Mountain and flows W into Valley River.

label: Parsonville
description: community in W Wilkes County on North Prong Lewis Fork Creek.

label: Partee
description: See Tuttles Store.

label: Partins Millpond
description: in S Wake County on Black Creek.

label: Partridge Creek
description: rises in N Macon County and flows SW into Whiteoak Creek.

label: Partridge Gap Ridge
description: W Madison County between Bluff Mountain and Pine Mountain.

label: Partridge's Bluff
description: See Gabourel's Bluff.

label: Paschall
description: community in N Warren County. Alt. 311. Formerly known as Merry Mount, its post office name from 1847 to 1929.

label: Paschalls
description: See Ridgeway.

label: Pasley
description: community in S Duplin County.

label: Pasley Cove
description: SE Watauga County, extends SE on the head of Dugger Creek.

label: Pasleys Ridge
description: S Watauga County, extends SE between Hog Camp Branch and Joe Creek.

label: Pasour (PAY-sewer) Mountain
description: a ridge approx. 4 mi. long extending NE from Long Creek to Sulphur Branch in N Gaston County. Alt. 1,100.

label: Pasquotank
description: community in W Pasquotank County.

label: Pasquotank County
description: was formed by 1681 as a precinct of Albemarle County. Located in the NE section of the state, it is bounded by Albemarle Sound and by Perquimans, Gates, and Camden Counties. The name of the county is from the Indian word pāsk-e'tan-ki (where the current [of the stream] divides or forks). Area: 290 sq. mi. (229, land; 61, water). County seat: Elizabeth City, with an elevation of 12 ft. Townships are Elizabeth City, Mount Hermon, Newland, Nixonton, Providence, and Salem. Produces corn, soybeans, potatoes, cabbage, miscellaneous vegetables, cotton, hogs, livestock, textiles, ships, lumber, hosiery, apparel, paper boxes, and industrial machinery.

label: Pasquotank River
description: rises in NW Camden County and flows SE to form the Camden-Pasquotank county line until it enters Albemarle Sound. An Indian village, Pasquenoke, is shown in the area on the De Bry map, 1590. Appears as Pacequenock on the Blaeu map, 1640, and as Prascantanck River on the Comberford map, 1657. The Intracoastal Waterway enters Pasquotank River through Dismal Swamp Canal. See also Shipyard.

label: Passmore Branch
description: rises in NE Clay County and flows SW into Perry Creek.

label: Passmore Knob
description: E Macon County between Jack Knob and Brown Gap.

label: Pastook
description: community in S Davidson County served by post office, 1886-1901.

label: Pasture Branch
description: rises in S Duplin County and flows SE into Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: Pasture Creek
description: stream in Nelson Bay that cuts NW into the mainland in NE Carteret County. Approx. ¼ mi. long.

label: Pat Knob
description: N Macon County between Sawmill Ridge and Shepherd Creek.

label: Pat Stable Branch
description: rises in SW Macon County and flows NE into Nantahala River.

label: Pat Stable Ridge
description: SW Macon County between Kimsey Bald and Pat Stable Branch.

label: Patchet Creek
description: rises in E Lee County and flows S into Little River.

label: Pate Creek
description: rises in NW Mitchell County and flows S into Pigeonroost Creek.

label: Pate Store
description: community in E Wayne County S of the community of Cherry and N of The Slough.

label: Pates
description: community in W Robeson County. Inc. 1883, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Named for Ed Pate, a railroad employee.

label: Patetown
description: town in E Wayne County near The Slough. Inc. 1907, but no longer active in municipal affairs. Named for the Pate family living in the area.

label: Patrick
description: community in W Cherokee County near Camp Creek.

label: Patsy Creek
description: rises in NW Yancey County and flows SE into Roaring Fork.

label: Patterson
description: town in central Caldwell County. Founded in 1851 as the site of a textile mill. Inc. 1905, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Named for Samuel Finley Patterson (1799-1874), local resident and state official. Alt. 1,253. Patterson School operated there since 1909.

label: Patterson Branch
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows SE into Jacks Creek.

label: Patterson Creek
description: rises in S central Transylvania County and flows SE into French Broad River.

label: Patterson Springs
description: community in S Cleveland County. Alt. 904. Settled in the 1880s. Named for Arthur Patterson Sr., who lived near Kings Mountain at the time of the 1780 battle.

label: Patterson Top
description: W Cherokee County N of Hiwassee Dam and E of Anderson Creek.

label: Patterson Township
description: former township in SW Durham County, now combined with Cedar Fork Township to form Triangle Township.

label: Pattersons Bridge
description: community in SW Moore County served by post office, 1876-98.

label: Pattersons Mill
description: See Roberta.

label: Patton
description: mining town in SE McDowell County near Dysartsville. Named for Patton family, local landowners.

label: Patton Cove
description: the valley through which Patton Cove Creek flows in SE Buncombe County.

label: Patton Cove Creek
description: rises near Patton Gap in SE Buncombe County and flows N through Patton Cove into Swannanoa River.

label: Patton Gap
description: SE Buncombe County between Big Flats and High Hickory Knob in the Swannanoa Mountains.

label: Patton Mountain
description: central Macon County at the head of Blaine Branch.

label: Patton Ridge
description: community in W Wilkes County near the head of South Prong Lewis Fork Creek.

label: Pattonsville
description: former community in Granville County W of the mouth of Tabb Creek on Tar River. Appears on the McRae map, 1833.

label: Paul Gamiels Hill
description: N end of Bodie Island in E Dare County. Site of lifesaving station est. in 1878-79. Lifesaving Service and Revenue Cutter Service joined to form U.S. Coast Guard in 1915. Active until after World War II.

label: Pauls Creek
description: rises in Virginia and flows S into Surry County, where it enters Stewarts Creek. Approx. 14 mi. long.

label: Pauls Gap
description: on the Haywood-Swain county line between Cataloochee Balsam and Sugar Tree Licks. Alt. approx. 5,100.

label: Paw Creek
description: community in W Mecklenburg County. Name of the railroad depot is Thrift.

label: Paw Creek Township
description: former township in W central Mecklenburg County, now township no. 12.

label: Paw Paw Ridge
description: NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, extends SW from Cherry Knob on Jenkins Trail Ridge, lat. 35°30'50" N., long. 83°44'52" W.

label: Pawpaw Creek
description: rises in NW Swain County and flows SW into Eagle Creek.

label: Paxton Creek
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows NE into French Broad River.

label: Payne Branch
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows NE into Middle Fork [South Fork New River].

label: Payne Mountain
description: SW Cherokee County, extends NE from Wolf Pen Gap to Harris Top.

label: Paynes Branch
description: rises in SW Clay County and flows NE into Brasstown Creek.

label: Paynes Knob
description: central Buncombe County NE of Rocky Knob.

label: Paynes Store
description: community in SE Alexander County.

label: Paynes Tavern
description: community in S Person County near North Flat River. Cornwallis spent a night there in 1781 during the Revolutionary War. The tavern has long since ceased to exist.

label: Pea Branch
description: rises in E Pitt County and flows E into Tranters Creek.

label: Pea Hill Creek
description: rises in S Virginia and flows S into Northampton County, where it enters Roanoke River. Appears on the map of the North Carolina-Virginia line run by William Byrd and others, 1728.

label: Pea Island
description: part of the Outer Banks in E Dare County. Once a separate island, but now part of Hatteras Island, bounded on the N by Oregon Inlet and on the S by Hatteras Island. Also known as Chicamacomico Banks, which see.

label: Pea Island National Waterfowl Refuge
description: a national wildlife refuge covering all of Pea Island and the N end of Hatteras Island to Rodanthe, E Dare County. Federally funded in 1938 as a winter preserve for migratory birds. Formerly known as Pea Island Migratory Waterfowl Refuge.

label: Pea Landing
description: See Calabash.

label: Pea Ridge
description: elevated sandy area in N Washington County on Albemarle Sound extending NE from Leonards Point.

label: Pea Ridge
description: See Ridgeville.

label: Peace
description: community in SW Wake County.

label: Peach
description: community in N Perquimans County.

label: Peach Bottom Mountains
description: a range of high, grass-covered mountains extending across most of Alleghany County from SW to N central. Among the named peaks are Cheek, Fender, and Doughton Mountains and Bald Knob.

label: Peach Knob
description: central Buncombe County SW of Craven Gap in Elk Mountains.

label: Peach Orchard
description: mountain in the Cane Creek Mountains, S Alamance County.

label: Peach Orchard Creek
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows W into Carter Creek.

label: Peachland
description: town in W Anson County. Originally known as Mulcahy; renamed in 1888 for a large peach orchard nearby. Inc. 1895. Alt. 446.

label: Peachtree
description: community in E Cherokee County.

label: Peachtree Branch
description: rises in SE Duplin County and flows W into Mill Branch.

label: Peachtree Creek
description: See White Oak Swamp.

label: Peachtree Gap
description: on Graham-Swain county line between Broke Yoke Gap and Round Top.

label: Peachtree Knob
description: on the Cherokee-Clay county line. Alt. 4,200.

label: Peacock's Bridge
description: SE Wilson County over Contentnea Creek approx. 1½ mi. SE of Stantonsburg. A bridge existed there by 1751 and is shown on the Price map, 1808, and on the MacRae map, 1833. There Lt. Col. Banastre Tarleton's British dragoons and Col. James Gorham's militia engaged in a skirmish, May 1781. Known for a time as Ruffin's Bridge.

label: Peacocks
description: community in N Columbus County. Earlier known as Peacocks Store.

label: Peacocks Crossroads
description: community in SW Johnston County.

label: Peak Creek
description: rises on the Ashe-Wilkes county line near Mulberry Gap and flows NW into South Fork New River.

label: Peak Creek Township
description: E Ashe County.

label: Peak Knob
description: E Macon County between Grindstone Knob and the head of Moses Branch.

label: Peak Mountain
description: NE Avery County.

label: Peak, The
description: SW Mitchell County between Crabtree Creek and North Toe River. Alt. 3,866.

label: Peaked Knob
description: on the Haywood County, N.C.-Cocke County, Tenn., line. Alt. 3,370.

label: Peaked Top
description: central Caldwell County near the headwaters of Abingdon Creek.

label: Peaks Bald
description: on the Macon-Swain county line between Davis Bald and Low Gap.

label: Pearce Crossroads
description: community in S Franklin County.

label: Pearce's Creek
description: rises in N Burke County and flows E into Carroll's Creek.

label: Pearces Mill Township
description: central Cumberland County.

label: Pearceville
description: community in NW Camden County. Named for Pearce family from New England, who settled there following the Revolution. Often appears on maps as Pierceville.

label: Pearsall
description: community in N Duplin County.

label: Pearson Knob
description: mountain in NW Alexander County. Alt. 1,898.

label: Pearson's Falls
description: SW Polk County between town of Saluda and city of Tryon on Colt Creek. Named for Charles William Pearson, former owner of the site. The falls tumble over 75 ft. of rugged rocks. The surrounding 308 acres contain a wildflower sanctuary and herbarium. There are more than 200 different varieties of flowers and woodland growth there.

label: Peartree Point
description: extends from the mainland into the mouth of Alligator River in NE Tyrrell County.

label: Peckerwood Creek
description: rises in central Clay County and flows NW into Tusquitee Creek. Named for an Indian, Jim Peckerwood, who lived near its head.

label: Peckerwood Ridge
description: N Cherokee County.

label: Pecks Corner
description: mountain on the Swain County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line at the head of Enloe Creek. Alt. approx. 5,700. Also known as Pecks Peak.

label: Pecks Peak
description: See Pecks Corner.

label: Pedlars Hill
description: See Pleasant Hill.

label: Pee Dee
description: community in W Montgomery County. Produces hosiery and lumber.

label: Pee Dee River
description: is formed by the junction of the Yadkin and Uwharrie Rivers in Montgomery County. It flows S along the Stanly-Montgomery and Anson-Richmond county lines into South Carolina, where it empties into Winyah Bay. Also known as Great Pee Dee River. The name may be a Catawba Indian word pi'ri (something good) or pfhere (smart; expert; capable).

label: Peebles Tavern
description: See Garysburg.

label: Peedee Township
description: W Montgomery County.

label: Peek
description: community in E Madison County.

label: Peeks Creek
description: rises in S Macon County and flows NE into Cullasaja River.

label: Peele Branch
description: rises in NE Bertie County and flows SW into Chinkapin Swamp.

label: Peeler
description: community in E Rowan County served by post office, 1894-1904.

label: Peeler Creek
description: rises in S Davie County and flows SE approx. 2 mi. into Yadkin River.

label: Peels Top
description: NW Cherokee County in the Unicoi Mountains.

label: Peewee Branch
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows S into Greens Creek.

label: Peggy Gap
description: on the head of Camp Creek in NW Jackson County.

label: Peggy Knob
description: S Macon County between Tessentee Creek and Bennies Branch.

label: Peggy Peak
description: SW Buncombe County at the E end of Smathers View Mountain.

label: Pegries
description: community in SW Richmond County served by post office, 1885-1904.

label: Pekin
description: community in S Montgomery County. A post office, Chisholm's Store, est. there 1824, was renamed Pekin in 1853.

label: Peletier
description: community in W Carteret County. Named for family of same name.

label: Peletier Creek
description: rises in S Carteret County and flows S into Bogue Sound. Probably named for Jerome Peletier, first of the family to settle in the vicinity.

label: Pelham
description: community in NW Caswell County. Est. during the Civil War as a station on the Piedmont Railroad; named for Maj. John Pelham, Alabamian killed in action during the war. Alt. 740.

label: Pelham Precinct
description: appears on the Wimble map, 1738, between the Cape Fear and the Northeast Cape Fear Rivers at approx. what is now Pender County. Wimble's map was dedicated to Thomas Hollis Pelham, Duke of Newcastle (1693-1768), secretary of state for the Southern Department. Pelham County appears at the same location on the Mouzon map, 1775. Since there appears to be no reference to such a precinct or county in the records of North Carolina, it is possible that Wimble was simply flattering his patron and that Mouzon followed Wimble's map in making his own.

label: Pelham Township
description: NW Caswell County.

label: Pell Mell Pocosin
description: N central Bertie County.

label: Pembroke
description: town in W central Robeson County. Alt. 172. Inc. 1895. Originally called Campbell's Mill on Waterhole Swamp; later, Scuffletown, after Scoville Town in England or because it was a good place to get into a fight. Today, it is center of Lumbee Indian business and social life. Named for Pembroke Jones (1825-1910), an official of the Wilmington and Weldon Railroad, which intersected the Wilmington, Charlotte, and Rutherford Railroad there. Home of the University of North Carolina at Pembroke, founded in 1887.

label: Pembroke Creek
description: rises in Pollock Swamp, E Chowan County, and flows S and SE into the W side of the head of Edenton Bay. Formerly known as the W branch of Mattacomack Creek and later Queen Anne's Creek. Took its present name from Thomas Barker's plantation, Pembroke, which was named for his birthplace, Pembroke, Mass. Barker bought his property from Edmund Gale about 1751. See also Ramushawn River.

label: Pembroke Township
description: central Robeson County.

label: Pender
description: community immediately S of the town of Halifax, E Halifax County.

label: Pender County
description: was formed in 1875 from New Hanover County. Located in the SE section of the state, it is bounded by the Atlantic Ocean and by New Hanover, Brunswick, Columbus, Bladen, Sampson, Duplin, and Onslow Counties. It was named for Gen. William D. Pender (1834-63), a Confederate officer killed at Gettysburg. Area: 869 sq. mi. (857, land; 12, water). County seat: Burgaw, with an elevation of 49 ft. Townships are Burgaw, Canetuck, Caswell, Columbia, Grady, Holly, Long Creek, Rocky Point, Topsail, and Union. Produces corn, oats, soybeans, miscellaneous fruits and vegetables, peanuts, poultry, eggs, hogs, dairy products, livestock, turkeys, seafood, metal products, and lumber. See also Pelham Precinct; Lillington County.

label: Pender's Crossroads
description: community in E Wilson County near White Swamp and Town Creek. Maj. Gen. William Dorsey Pender (1834-63), a Confederate officer killed at Gettysburg, was born nearby.

label: Pendergrass Mountain
description: central Macon County between Blaine Branch and the heads of Battle Branch and Salser Branch.

label: Penderlea
description: community in NW Pender County. Land in the area had been purchased after the Civil War by E. R. Brink, a northern investor. He subdivided it, prepared a map, and sold about 50 farms to people in New York City. His mortgage with a Wilmington bank was foreclosed, and the New Yorkers lost their farms and money. Beginning in 1934, the U.S. government purchased a total of 10,500 acres, which was subdivided into tracts of about 30 acres each. Houses and other buildings were erected, and farmers who had been removed from submarginal land taken out of cultivation by the government were moved into the area. A total of 142 farm units were est., and a school, community center, and lake were built. The farms later were sold to those who lived on them.

label: Pendleton
description: town in NE Northampton County. Est. about 1887; inc. 1893. Known as Woodward's Crossroads until renamed to honor an employee of the railroad on the first train to pass through. Alt. 84.

label: Penelo
description: community in central Edgecombe County.

label: Penelope
description: See Longview.

label: Penland
description: community in S Mitchell County on North Toe River. Alt. 2,462. Named for Milton P. Penland, pioneer settler and businessman. Penland School of Crafts grew out of a school est. there in 1910.

label: Penland Bald
description: on the Clay-Macon county line at the head of Park Creek. Alt. approx. 5,000.

label: Penland Cove
description: SE Cherokee County at the NE end of Poor House Mountain.

label: Penland Gap
description: on Middle Ridge in SW Macon County.

label: Penland Yellow
description: See Big Bald.

label: Penley
description: community in SE Watauga County.

label: Penley Branch
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows SE into Middle Fork [South Fork New River].

label: Penly Cove
description: central Buncombe County E of Bee Ridge.

label: Penn Point
description: in central Carteret County extending into Newport River.

label: Pennington
description: community in N Stanly County served by post office, 1886-1909.

label: Pennix Cove
description: N Buncombe County E of Hemphill Mountain.

label: Penny
description: community in N Johnston County served by post office, 1884-1901.

label: Penny Hill
description: town on the Edgecombe-Pitt county line on Tar River. Inc. 1875, but no longer active in municipal affairs.

label: Pennys Hill
description: a large sand hill at the present community of Seagull on Currituck Banks, E Currituck County; has been a landmark locally since the early eighteenth century.

label: Penrose
description: community in E Transylvania County between Lydia Creek and French Broad River. Alt. 2,087.

label: Pensacola
description: community in S Yancey County on Cane River. Alt. 2,858. Name derived from an Indian word probably meaning "hair people" (those who wore their hair long).

label: Pensacola Township
description: S central Yancey County.

label: Penson Knob
description: S Macon County between Dover Knob and the Georgia state line.

label: Penson Mountain
description: S Macon County between Middle Creek and Norton Branch.

label: Peoria
description: community in NW Watauga County on the head of Stone Mountain Branch.

label: Pepper Creek
description: rises in NE McDowell County and flows S into North Fork [Catawba River] near North Cove.

label: Peppers
description: community in W Mitchell County on Bee Creek.

label: Perch
description: community in SE Surry County served by post office, 1894-1904.

label: Perfection
description: community in W Craven County.

label: Perkins Branch
description: rises in central Watauga County and flows S into Hardin Creek.

label: Perkinsville
description: community in central Watauga County on Perkins Branch and Hardin Creek.

label: Permetter Creek
description: rises in N central Anson County and flows S into Brown Creek. Named for the Permenter family, early settlers.

label: Permudas Island
description: approx. 1½ mi. long, in S Onslow County in Stump Sound.

label: Pernell
description: community in N Wake County served by post office, 1885-1904.

label: Perquimans County
description: was formed by 1679 as Berkeley Precinct in Albemarle County. Located in the NE section of the state, it is bounded by Albemarle Sound and by Chowan, Gates, and Pasquotank Counties. It was named for Indians in the vicinity. The legislature met there, 1707-16. Area: 324 sq. mi. (261, land; 63, water). County seat: Hertford, with an elevation of 15 ft. Townships are Belvidere, Bethel, Hertford, New Hope, and Parkville. Produces corn, soybeans, peanuts, cotton, hogs, livestock, apparel, sorghum, truck bodies, and sand.

label: Perquimans River
description: rises in the Dismal Swamp in N Perquimans County and flows SE into Albemarle Sound. Appears as Pequaimings River on the Comberford map, 1657; as Wiquemans on the Ogilby map, 1671; and as Paquinous on the Hack map, 1684.

label: Perrishoes Creek
description: See Raccoon Creek.

label: Perry
description: community in NW Gaston County.

label: Perry Creek
description: rises in N central Wake County and flows E through Gresham's Lake and into Neuse River. Shown as Simes Creek on Bevers map, 1870.

label: Perry Gap
description: E Clay County between the headwaters of Perry and Barnett Creeks.

label: Perry Knob
description: See Perry Top.

label: Perry Ridge
description: central Avery County.

label: Perry Store
description: community in N Wake County.

label: Perry Top
description: peak in Plott Balsams in N Jackson County on the head of Monteith Branch. Also called Perry Knob. Alt. 5,080.

label: Perrys Pond
description: in NE Wake County on Buffalo Creek. Formed in 1910, covers 20 acres, with a max. depth of 10 ft. Open to the public; used for recreation.

label: Perrytown
description: community in NE Bertie County.

label: Pershing
description: See Delco.

label: Persimmon Branch
description: rises in NE Washington County and flows N and NE into Deep Creek.

label: Persimmon Creek
description: community in W Cherokee County.

label: Persimmon Ridge
description: SE Avery County.

label: Persimmon Swamp
description: rises in SW Brunswick County and flows N into Shingletree Swamp.

label: Person Branch
description: rises in N Franklin County and flows SW into Sandy Creek.

label: Person County
description: was formed in 1791 from Caswell County. Located in the N central section of the state, it is bounded by the state of Virginia and by Granville, Durham, Orange, and Caswell Counties. It was named for Gen. Thomas Person (1733-1800), Revolutionary patriot, member of the Council of Safety, and benefactor of the University of North Carolina. Area: 400 sq. mi. County seat: Roxboro, with an elevation of 671 ft. Townships are Allensville, Busby Fork, Cunningham, Flat River, Holloway, Mount Tirzah, Olive Hill, Roxboro, and Woodsdale. Produces tobacco, corn, wheat, oats, poultry, eggs, dairy products, livestock, hogs, textiles, hay, auto parts, wood products, lumber, and fabricated metals. Copper formerly was mined in the county.

label: Person Ordinary
description: See Littleton.

label: Perth
description: community in NW Bladen County.

label: Peru
description: community in S Onslow County on New River.

label: Pescud
description: See Thermal City.

label: Petche Gap
description: S central Burke County.

label: Peter Cove
description: S Haywood County on the head of Peter Cove Branch.

label: Peter Cove Branch
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows SE into Bird Creek.

label: Peter Cove Creek
description: rises in NE Madison County and flows SW into Foster Creek.

label: Peter Cove Mountain
description: E Madison County between Foster Creek and Roaring Fork.

label: Peter Dick Gap
description: central Cherokee County near the head of Cook Creek and N of Flea Mountain. Named for an early settler.

label: Peter Mashoes Creek
description: a bay off the mainland of central Dare County in the waters of Croatan Sound. The community of Mashoes is located on the creek. See Mashoes.

label: Peter Swamp
description: rises at the SE shore of Warwick Bay in E Robeson County and flows E into Big Swamp.

label: Peter Weaver Creek
description: rises in S Jackson County and flows SE then NE into Morgan Mill Creek.

label: Peters Creek
description: community in N central Stokes County on the Virginia line. Post office was there from 1850 until 1882, when name was changed to Elko, which see.

label: Peters Creek Township
description: N central Stokes County.

label: Peters Ferry
description: See Grifton.

label: Peters Point
description: point of land 1 mi. NW of Fort Fisher in S New Hanover County extending into the Cape Fear River near its mouth. See also Point Peter.

label: Petersburg
description: community in S Madison County on Bull Creek. Alt. 1,972.

label: Petersburg
description: community on Jenkins Swamp in N Onslow County.

label: Petersburg Crossing
description: a crossroads community in E Duplin County.

label: Peterson
description: community in W Mitchell County on Nolichucky River. Also known as Warrick.

label: Peterson Branch
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows S into Jacks Creek.

label: Peterson Gap
description: N Mitchell County on Fork Mountain.

label: Peterson Inn
description: See Littleton.

label: Peterson Ridge
description: N Yancey County between Cooper Gap and Bee Branch.

label: Petra Mills
description: a small farming community in SE Caldwell County. Also known as Petra.

label: Pett
description: community in E central Wake County.

label: Pettifords Creek
description: See Pettivers Creek.

label: Pettigrew State Park
description: E Washington and W Tyrrell Counties 9 mi. S of Creswell. Contains 16,828 acres, including 16,600-acre Lake Phelps. Est. 1939. Scenic, recreational, historical attraction; fishing. Somerset Place State Historic Site House, antebellum plantation, adjacent to park. See also Somerset.

label: Pettivers Bay
description: at the mouth of Pettivers Creek in White Oak River, W Carteret County. Also known as Hampton Bay.

label: Pettivers Creek
description: rises in W Carteret County and flows SW approx. 8 mi. into White Oak River. Named for John Pettiver, who owned land in the vicinity as early as 1728. Sometimes also called Pettifords Creek.

label: Petty Gulf Creek
description: rises in E Anson County and flows S into Blewett Falls Lake.

label: Petty Point
description: peninsula extending from NE Pamlico County into Bay River.

label: Pettys Shore
description: community in E Hertford County on Chowan River at the site of an earlier Indian village. A large fishery once was operated there.

label: Pfafftown
description: community in W Forsyth County. Named for Peter Pfaff, who arrived in the Wachovia settlement in 1771.

label: Pharisee Swamp
description: rises in SE Sampson County and flows NE into Bulltail Swamp.

label: Pheasant Creek
description: in the tidal-marsh islands of Bear Banks, SE Onslow County. Named for the pheasants formerly found there. Known also as Nicks Creek for Nick Moore.

label: Phelps Point
description: See Hertford.

label: Pheney
description: community in N McDowell County.

label: Phenoy
description: community in N McDowell County near present site of Little Switzerland, which see.

label: Phi
description: community in N Rowan County served by post office, 1884-1904.

label: Philadelphus
description: community in N Robeson County on Richland Swamp. Settled 1796-99; site of an early private academy.

label: Philadelphus Township
description: W central Robeson County.

label: Phillip Knob
description: S Swain County between Yalaka Creek and Little Yalaka Creek.

label: Phillips Branch
description: rises in W Watauga County and flows SE into East Fork [Cove Creek].

label: Phillips Creek
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows NW into Hogshead Creek.

label: Phillips Crossroads
description: community in N Jones County.

label: Phillips Gap
description: on the Ashe-Wilkes county line.

label: Phillips Knob
description: N central Yancey County on the head of Guilders Creek 1½ mi. N of town of Burnsville. Alt. 4,390.

label: Phillips’ Branch
description: rises in W Caldwell County and flows E into Wilson's Creek.

label: Phillipsville
description: community in E Haywood County on the W outskirts of Canton.

label: Phils Creek
description: rises in S Orange County and flows SE into University Lake.

label: Phin's Island
description: in the E end of Brown's Sound in S Onslow County. Probably named for Phineas Stephens, an early landholder on Bear Creek.

label: Phipps Branch
description: rises in E Yancey County and flows W into South Toe River. Named for Sidney Phipps, an early settler.

label: Phipps Cove
description: W Swain County between Yalaka Creek and Stevenson Branch; almost entirely submerged by the backwaters of Fontana Lake.

label: Phipps Creek
description: rises in W Yancey County and flows NW into Cane River.

label: Phipps Gap
description: W Yancey County between Indian and Price Creeks.

label: Phoebes Creek
description: rises in W Warren County and flows NE into Fishing Creek.

label: Phoenix
description: community in NE Brunswick County. A post office operated there, 1883-1938. Named for the mythical bird that, after death, rises from its ashes. Alt. 40.

label: Phoenix Creek
description: rises on the E side of Phoenix Mountain, central Ashe County, and flows N into North Fork New River.

label: Phoenix Mine Village
description: former community in E Cabarrus County at site of Phoenix Mine. Period of greatest activity was from 1870 to 1907, when the chlorination process for treatment of gold ores was perfected there by Capt. Adolph Thies. At the time, the discovery was a notable step forward in metallurgy. The mine shafts were dewatered in 1955 for further ore-deposit appraisals.

label: Phoenix Mountain
description: central Ashe County. Alt. 4, 673-4,700.

label: Pick Breeches Creek
description: rises in NE Watauga County and flows SE into Rube Creek.

label: Pick's Sliding
description: See Somerset.

label: Pickards Mountain
description: SW Orange County on the head of Morgan Creek.

label: Pickens Gap
description: NW Swain County on the S end of Jenkins Trail Ridge.

label: Pickens Nose
description: mountain in S Macon County between Betty Creek and Dryman Fork. Alt. approx. 4,900.

label: Picket Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SE and SW into Valley River.

label: Picketts Bay
description: an arm of White Oak River N of Swansboro, SE Onslow County between Muddy Creek and Mount Pleasant Point.

label: Picks
description: See Somerset.

label: Picture Creek
description: rises in SW Granville County and flows SW into Knap of Reeds Creek.

label: Piedmont
description: or extends from the Fall Line, which see, on the E to the Blue Ridge Mountains on the w. In elevation, the area ranges from approx. 500 ft. above sea level on the E to 1,500 ft. on the w. Rolling hills and stiff clay soil are characteristic of the Piedmont. The Indians knew the region as Tar-ko-ee (Catawba Land; Under Hills).

label: Piedmont
description: community in central Mecklenburg County E of Charlotte.

label: Piedmont Crescent
description: is an extended area in the Piedmont section of the state from Wake County on the E through Durham, Orange, Alamance, Guilford, Randolph, Forsyth, Davidson, Rowan, Cabarrus, Mecklenburg, Gaston, and Lincoln Counties. It follows route of Interstate 85 and includes rapidly growing urban and industrial areas, most of which had their beginning along the route of the North Carolina Railroad.

label: Piedmont Lake
description: in SE Transylvania County near Panther Mountain, drains S into Little River. Covers 5 acres, with a max. depth of 12 ft.

label: Piedmont Springs
description: community in central Stokes County on Dan River. A popular resort from about 1900 to 1930, when the hotel burned.

label: Piedmont Triad
description: a term used for the Greensboro, High Point, Winston-Salem area.

label: Pierce Creek
description: rises in SE Pamlico County and flows SE into Neuse River. Named for Edmond Pierce, who settled there in 1708.

label: Pierces Crossroads
description: community in N Halifax County. Named for the Pierce family, which settled there in 1812.

label: Pierceville
description: See Pearceville.

label: Pig Basket Creek
description: rises in NW Nash County and flows SE into Stony Creek. Legend says that an early settler, going home with a basket of newborn pigs, dropped them into the water as he tried to cross the stream while it was swollen after a storm.

label: Pig Point
description: extends into S waters of Currituck Sound in S Currituck County.

label: Pigeon Branch
description: rises in N Transylvania County near Pigeon Gap and flows SE into South Fork Mills River.

label: Pigeon Creek
description: rises in S Swain County and flows SW into Yalaka Creek.

label: Pigeon Flats Bay
description: a sand-filled bay in S Sampson County. See also Carolina Bays.

label: Pigeon Gap
description: on the Haywood-Transylvania county line on Pisgah Ridge between Green Knob and Wagon Road Ridge.

label: Pigeon House Branch
description: rises in central Wake County within the city limits of Raleigh. It rises in what is now Cameron Village and flows E into Crabtree Creek.

label: Pigeon Ledge
description: on the Haywood-Buncombe county line.

label: Pigeon River
description: is formed in SE Haywood County by the junction of East Fork Pigeon River and West Fork Pigeon River. It flows NW into Tennessee, where it enters French Broad River. Known as Nee-oh-la by the Cherokee Indians. See also Canton.

label: Pigeon Township
description: S central Haywood County.

label: Pigeonroost
description: community in W Mitchell County on Pigeonroost Creek. Named when carrier pigeons, now extinct, were common in the area.

label: Pigeonroost Creek
description: rises in W Watauga County and flows NE into Dutch Creek. See also Dutch Creek Falls.

label: Pigpen Bluff
description: NE Yancey County at the S end of Green Mountain.

label: Pigpen Cove
description: NE Buncombe County between Pinnacle Mountain and Cedar Cliff Knob.

label: Pigpen Creek
description: rises in NE Yancey County and flows NW into Toe River.

label: Pigpen Flats
description: SE Swain County on the head of Connelly Creek.

label: Pigpen Knob
description: NE Buncombe County between High Knob and Sheepwallow Knob.

label: Pigpen Knob
description: S Watauga County between Buck Ridge and Fall Ridge.

label: Pigtail
description: community in central Caldwell County near Hulme Hill.

label: Pike
description: community in N Scotland County served by post office from 1901 to 1908.

label: Pike Creek
description: rises in central Pender County and flows SE into Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: Pike Crossroads
description: community in W Wayne County between Little River and Nahunta Swamp. Named for Quaker family that settled in the area prior to 1758.

label: Pike Road
description: community in N Beaufort County.

label: Pikeville
description: town in N Wayne County in a region first settled by Quakers and on land originally granted to Samuel Pike in 1763. Land transferred in 1785 to Nathan Pike, for whom the town was named. Inc. in 1891. Alt. 142.

label: Pikeville Township
description: N central Wayne County.

label: Pilands Crossroads
description: community in SE Hertford County.

label: Pile Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows S into Valley River.

label: Pilgrim
description: community in central Davidson County served by post office, 1892-95.

label: Pilkey Creek
description: rises in W Swain County and flows SW into Fontana Lake.

label: Pilot
description: community in S Franklin County.

label: Pilot Cove
description: N Transylvania County, extends SE from Slate Rock Ridge to Bradley Creek.

label: Pilot Creek
description: rises in E Surry County and flows SW into Ararat River.

label: Pilot Gap
