description: W Swain County on Pilot Ridge.

label: Pilot Knob
description: W Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park at the SE end of Pilot Ridge, lat. 35°27'53" N., long. 83°34'22" W. Alt. 2,967.

label: Pilot Mountain
description: town in E Surry County. Alt. 1,100. Inc. 1889. Named for the nearby mountain.

label: Pilot Ridge
description: central Madison County parallel to Teat Branch. Walnut Knob is on the S end of this ridge.

label: Pilot Ridge
description: W Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a spur of Welch Ridge extending SE from Cherry Gap to Pilot Knob, lat. 35°28'18" N., long. 83°35'37" W.

label: Pilot Rock
description: N Transylvania County between Dividing Ridge and Pilot Cove.

label: Pilot Township
description: E Surry County.

label: Pilot View
description: community in central Yadkin County between North Deep and Forbush Creeks. Formerly known as Sugartown.

label: Pin Gap
description: S Macon County between Foster Knob and the head of Jones Creek.

label: Pin Hook
description: community in central Northampton County.

label: Pin Oak Gap
description: on Haywood-Swain county line on the head of Ledge Creek in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Alt. 4,428. A prominent Indian trail passed through the gap before the coming of Europeans.

label: Pinch Gut Branch
description: rises in E Surry County and flows SE into Stokes County, where it enters Big Creek. Said to have been named by Saura Indians in the vicinity who almost starved because of the scarcity of game.

label: Pinch Gut Creek
description: rises in W Anson County and flows N into Brown Creek.

label: Pinch Gut Creek
description: rises in S Catawba County and flows SW into Maiden Creek.

label: Pinchback's Tavern
description: See Clarksville.

label: Pinchgut Branch
description: rises in S Duplin County and flows S into Island Creek.

label: Pinchgut Creek
description: rises in NW Caldwell County and flows E into Johns River. See also Coldass Creek.

label: Pinckton
description: community in NW Ashe County. Alt. approx. 3,498.

label: Pine Barrens
description: See Sandhills.

label: Pine Branch
description: rises in E central Madison County and flows N into Big Laurel Creek.

label: Pine Branch
description: rises in W Surry County and flows SW into Mitchell River.

label: Pine Cabbin
description: See Weaverville.

label: Pine Camp Branch
description: rises in N Avery County and flows W into Tennessee, where it enters Elk River.

label: Pine Creek
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows NE into Lake Thorpe.

label: Pine Gap Branch
description: rises in W Swain County and flows NW into Hazel Creek.

label: Pine Grove
description: community in SE Craven County on Tucker Creek. Alt. 23.

label: Pine Hall
description: community in SE Stokes County. Named for the pine trees growing there.

label: Pine Hammock
description: a tidal-marsh island approx. 1¼ mi. long in N Pamlico County.

label: Pine Hill
description: mountain in the Cane Creek Mountains, S Alamance County.

label: Pine Knob
description: N Rutherford County between two unnamed branches that are the headwaters of Mountain Creek. Alt. approx. 1,555. Sometimes known as Piney Knob.

label: Pine Knob
description: SE Watauga County N of Bens Ridge.

label: Pine Knob Branch
description: rises in SE Watauga County and flows NE into Laurel Fork.

label: Pine Level
description: town in E Johnston County. Settled about 1868; inc. 1874. Named for pine forest and level land of the area. Alt. 155. Produces cottonseed oil.

label: Pine Level Township
description: E central Johnston County.

label: Pine Log Branch
description: rises in N Nash County and flows NE into Beaverdam Swamp.

label: Pine Log Creek
description: rises in W Anson County and flows N into Richardson Creek.

label: Pine Mountain
description: S Macon County between Jones Creek and South Fork [Skeenah Creek].

label: Pine Mountain
description: NE Transylvania County between Sitton Creek and Osborn Branch.

label: Pine Orchard Mountain
description: N Watauga County, extends NE from the head of Riddle Fork.

label: Pine Plains
description: See Cape Fear Section.

label: Pine Ridge
description: central Avery County.

label: Pine Ridge
description: SE Yancey County, extends NE between South Toe River and Pine Ridge Branch.

label: Pine Ridge
description: community in N Surry County between Little Fisher River and Stewart Creek. Alt. 1,347.

label: Pine Ridge Branch
description: rises in SE Yancey County and flows S into Three Forks Creek.

label: Pine Run
description: rises in E Watauga County and flows NE into South Fork New River.

label: Pine Stand Ridge
description: N Cherokee County, extends SE from Copper Ridge to the junction of Beaverdam and Garreck Creeks.

label: Pine Station
description: community in S Wake County.

label: Pine Swamp
description: rises in S Ashe County and flows N into South Fork New River.

label: Pine Swamp Branch
description: rises in central Yancey County and flows SW into Cane River.

label: Pine Swamp Creek
description: rises in S Alleghany County and flows N into Little River.

label: Pine Swamp Township
description: SE Ashe County.

label: Pine Top
description: peak in W Surry County near the head of South Fork.

label: Pine Tree Cove
description: W Haywood County on Pine Tree Cove Creek.

label: Pine Tree Cove Creek
description: rises in W Haywood County and flows NE into Jonathans Creek.

label: Pine Tree Gap
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°33'23" N., long. 83°06'37" W., between Little Bald Knob and Hemphill Bald. Alt. 5,270.

label: Pine Tree Mountain
description: S Buncombe County E of the Biltmore Estate.

label: Pine Tree Store
description: community in SE Hertford County.

label: Pine Tree Swamp
description: rises in NE Craven County and flows NW into Little Swift Creek.

label: Pinebluff
description: town in S Moore County. Settled approx. 1890. Inc. 1899. Named for the longleaf pine in the vicinity. Alt. 307.

label: Pinedene
description: community in S Moore County S of town of Southern Pines.

label: Pinehurst
description: town in S Moore County. Settled 1895. Inc. 1949. Named for its location in a pine forest. A popular resort founded by Tufts family and renowned for its golf courses. Alt. 536.

label: Pinelog
description: community in central Columbus County.

label: Pinelog Branch
description: rises in W Pitt County and flows SW into Little Contentnea Creek.

label: Pinelog Creek
description: rises in SW Clay County and flows NE into Brasstown Creek.

label: Pinelog Swamp
description: rises in N Columbus County and flows S into Soules Swamp.

label: Pineola
description: community in S Avery County on Linville River. Alt. 3,538. Post office est. there in 1911 as Saginaw. Name changed to Pineola in 1914 for the pine trees growing in the vicinity and for Ola Penland, daughter of a local hotel keeper.

label: Pineroot Branch
description: rises in N Mitchell County and flows W into Big Rock Creek.

label: Pinetops
description: town in S Edgecombe County. Inc. 1903. Named by Henry Clark Bridgers (1876-1951), founder of the East Carolina Railway, which was completed between Tarboro and Hookerton in 1900. On the first run of the new railroad, Bridgers noticed that he could see only the tops of pine trees from the train there. Produces furniture. Alt. 100.

label: Pinetown
description: town in N central Beaufort County. Alt. 43. Inc. 1907.

label: Pinetree Creek
description: a channel of water separated from the main body of Neuse River by two small islands in central Craven County.

label: Pineview
description: community in W Harnett County. Formerly the center of a large area devoted to dewberry culture. Alt. 320.

label: Pineville
description: town in S Mecklenburg County. Inc. 1873. James K. Polk, eleventh president of the United States, was born 1 mi. e, 1795. Formerly Morrow's Turnout, which see. Alt. 575.

label: Pineville Township
description: former township in central Mecklenburg County, now township no. 14.

label: Piney
description: community in SW Caldwell County, formerly known as Hobart. Alt. 1,309.

label: Piney Bottom Creek
description: rises on the Fort Bragg Military Reservation, NW Hoke County, and flows SW into Rockfish Creek.

label: Piney Branch
description: rises in N Mitchell County and flows S into Little Rock Creek.

label: Piney Creek
description: rises in N central Ashe County and flows SE into North Fork New River.

label: Piney Creek
description: community in NW Alleghany County.

label: Piney Creek Township
description: N central Ashe County.

label: Piney Field Top
description: E Haywood County between Pisgah Creek and Hungry Creek.

label: Piney Fork
description: community in central Rockingham County. Historically African American; named for local church.

label: Piney Fork Creek
description: rises in SW Alleghany County and flows SW into E Ashe County, where it joins Mulberry Creek in forming Cranberry Creek.

label: Piney Green
description: community in N Sampson County.

label: Piney Grove
description: See Pino.

label: Piney Grove Landing
description: on Pungo River, E Beaufort County.

label: Piney Grove Run
description: rises in E Beaufort County and flows N into Pungo River.

label: Piney Grove Township
description: NE Sampson County.

label: Piney Island
description: W portion of Church Island, which see, peninsula in central Currituck County extending into Currituck Sound. Coinjock Bay lies between the W shore and the mainland. Shown as a separate island, Pine Island, on the MacRae map, 1833.

label: Piney Island Bay
description: central Currituck County between Coinjock Bay and the SW coast of Piney Island.

label: Piney Knob
description: See Pine Knob.

label: Piney Knob Fork
description: rises in S Macon County and flows NE into Turtle Pond Creek.

label: Piney Marsh
description: N Tyrrell County, an area of swampland on Scuppernong River opposite the town of Columbia.

label: Piney Mountain
description: N Henderson County between Green Mountain and Clear Creek.

label: Piney Mountain
description: E Rutherford County between Puzzle Creek and the head of Brushy Creek.

label: Piney Mountain Creek
description: rises in E Jackson County and flows SE to join Rough Butt Creek in forming Caney Fork.

label: Piney Mountain Ridge
description: E Jackson County, extends NE from Rich Gap to Richland Balsam.

label: Piney Point
description: peninsula in E Pamlico County extending into Pamlico Sound. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Piney Prospect
description: See Point Prospect.

label: Piney Ridge
description: NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur extending W from Paw Paw Ridge, lat. 35°31'30" N., long. 83°45'22" W.

label: Piney Top
description: central Clay County at the N end of Big Pine Ridge.

label: Piney Wood Creek
description: rises in E Swain County and flows SW into Una Creek.

label: Pinhook Gap
description: on the Jackson-Transylvania county line at the head of Bee Tree Fork. Alt. 4,175.

label: Pink Beds
description: plateau area in N Transylvania County in Pisgah National Forest. Used extensively as a recreation area. Name comes from the color of rhododendron that once covered the area. Alt. 3,280.

label: Pink Fox Cove
description: N Buncombe County between Hemphill and Brank Mountains.

label: Pink Hill
description: town in SE Lenoir County. A post office est. there, 1849. Inc. 1907. Named for a nearby plantation.

label: Pink Hill Township
description: S Lenoir County.

label: Pink Ridge
description: S Avery County.

label: Pinkney
description: See South Gastonia.

label: Pinkston
description: community in central Anson County. Named about 1911, when railroad construction reached this point on the land of John Pinkston.

label: Pinnacle
description: community in SW Stokes County. Alt. 1,085. Inc. 1901; charter repealed 1903. Originally known as Culler for Emanuel W. Culler, who owned part of the land on which a railroad station was built. The railroad began operation in 1888, and the post office there, 1880-1900, was known as Culler. The present name was adopted in 1900.

label: Pinnacle Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows E into Shope Fork.

label: Pinnacle Creek
description: rises in NW Swain County on Jenkins Trail Ridge and flows SW into Eagle Creek.

label: Pinnacle Gap
description: NE Buncombe County near Craggy Pinnacle in Great Craggy Mountains.

label: Pinnacle Knob
description: at the junction of Buncombe-McDowell-Yancey county lines. Alt. 5,665.

label: Pinnacle Knob
description: on Macon-Swain county line S of Brush Creek.

label: Pinnacle Mountain
description: on the McDowell-Rutherford county line. Alt. 3,832.

label: Pinnacle Ridge
description: NW Swain County, extends NE from Eagle Creek to Pinnacle [peak].

label: Pinnacle Ridge
description: W Watauga County, extends NE between Bear Branch and Brassy Gap Branch.

label: Pinnacle Spring
description: S Yancey County, the source of Left Prong South Toe River.

label: Pinnacle, The
description: mountain in S Macon County between Hickory Knoll Creek and Gray Gap.

label: Pinner Cove
description: the valley through which Robinson Creek flows in S Buncombe County W of Merrill Mountain.

label: Pinner Creek
description: rises in S Buncombe County and flows SE into Henderson County, where it enters Cane Creek.

label: Pinnix
description: community in central Davidson County served by post office, 1894-1904.

label: Pino
description: community in NW Davie County. First known as Piney Grove, but changed to Pino in 1890 when a post office was est. (closed 1906).

label: Pinoka
description: community in S Montgomery County; named in 1922 by local teacher who looked out the front window and saw pine trees and looked out the back window and saw oak trees.

label: Pinson
description: SW Randolph County.

label: Pinson Creek
description: rises in S Caswell County and flows SE into South Country Line Creek.

label: Pioneer Mills
description: community in S Cabarrus County. Gold and copper mines operated there from the 1850s until 1931.

label: Piper Gap
description: See Lambsburg.

label: Piper Hill
description: SE Currituck County, former sand hill on S Currituck Banks. Erosion has now worn the hill down to beach level.

label: Pipes Branch
description: rises in E Cherokee County in the Valley River Mountains and flows S of Tibb Ridge into Peachtree Creek.

label: Pipetrack Gap
description: S Macon County between Thomas Knob and the North Carolina-Georgia state line.

label: Pipkins Crossroads
description: See Savages Crossroads.

label: Pireway
description: town in S Columbus County near Wacca maw River. Inc. 1883, but long in active in municipal affairs. Post office operated, 1855-1933, was known as Pireway Ferry after 1882.

label: Pisgah
description: community in S Randolph County. Named for nearby Pisgah Church. A post office est. there 1896, closed 1953.

label: Pisgah Creek
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows NW into East Fork Pigeon River.

label: Pisgah Forest
description: community in E central Transylvania County near the confluence of Davidson and French Broad Rivers. Includes the old communities of Davidson River and Ecusta. Produces lumber.

label: Pisgah Mountain
description: E Mitchell County parallel to the head of Green Cove Creek.

label: Pisgah National Forest
description: in portions of Avery, Buncombe, Burke, Caldwell, Haywood, Henderson, Madison, McDowell, Mitchell, Transylvania, Watauga, and Yancey Counties, was est. in 1911 and includes 510,113 acres. Nature trails, mountain climbing, picnicking, and other recreational uses.

label: Pisgah Ridge
description: extends the length of the Haywood-Transylvania county line. The Blue Ridge Parkway traverses its length.

label: Pit Branch
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows NE into Big Creek.

label: Pitch Landing
description: See Princeton.

label: Pitman Creek
description: rises in N Carteret County and flows N into Turnagain Bay.

label: Pitt County
description: was formed in 1760 from Beaufort County. Located in the E section of the state, it is bounded by Beaufort, Craven, Lenoir, Greene, Wilson, Edgecombe, and Martin Counties. It was named for William Pitt, Earl of Chatham (1708-78), secretary of state in England and virtual prime minister, whose vigorous war policies resulted in the defeat of the French in America by the British. Area: 656 sq. mi. County seat: Greenville, with an elevation of 64 ft. Townships are Arthur, Ayden, Belvoir, Bethel, Carolina, Chicod, Falkland, Farmville, Fountain, Greenville, Grifton, Grimesland, Pactolus, Swift Creek, and Winterville. Produces tobacco, corn, soybeans, oats, hay, apples, peanuts, cotton, poultry, hogs, livestock, lumber, textiles, batteries, baked goods, boats, canned foods, and apparel. See also Chatham County.

label: Pitt Crossroads
description: community in S Edgecombe County.

label: Pitt's Creek
description: rises in E Onslow County and flows E into White Oak River. Named for Richard Pitts.

label: Pittman Creek
description: rises in E Pamlico County and flows S into Broad Creek.

label: Pittmans Island
description: in White Oak River, SE Onslow County. Known first as Bell Island for Ross Bell, owner from 1717 until about 1746; later known as Jones Island for Emanuel Jones, who purchased it about 1746 from Bell. Present name from John A. Pittman, a later owner.

label: Pittmans Store
description: See Hickory.

label: Pitts
description: See North Cove.

label: Pitts Creek
description: rises in E Chatham County and flows SW into Whiteoak Creek.

label: Pittsboro
description: town and county seat, central Chatham County. Est. 1778 as Chatham, site of the courthouse. Pittsboro authorized to be laid out on land adjacent to the courthouse in 1785, but owners would not sell the desired land. In 1787 land on another site was acquired. Named for William Pitt, Earl of Chatham (1708-78), defender of American rights in the British Parliament. Alt. 409. Produces textiles, hosiery, poultry.

label: Pivers Island
description: S Carteret County W of the town of Beaufort. Named for the Piver family. Site of a U.S. marine biological station.

label: Pixie Mountain
description: central Avery County.

label: Plain
description: community in SE Guilford County served by post office, 1879-1903. Name derived from Quaker principles.

label: Plain View
description: community in N Richmond County.

label: Plain View Township
description: NW Sampson County.

label: Plainfield
description: community in W Alleghany County served by post office, 1898-1908.

label: Plainview
description: community in W Robeson County on the NW outskirts of Rowland, which see. McQueen's Store, a post office est. 1811 was in the vicinity. Name changed to Queensdale, which see, 1820, and operation continued until 1904.

label: Plank Bridge
description: See Camden.

label: Plank Ford
description: N Union County across Rocky River.

label: Plass Gap
description: S Macon County between Norton Branch and Middle Creek.

label: Plateau
description: town in SW Catawba County. Inc. 1885 as Keeversville. Name changed, 1893. Long inactive in municipal affairs.

label: Play Rock Hill
description: elevation in S Henderson County on Mud Creek.

label: Player
description: community in E Pender County between Shaken Creek and Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: Players Swamp
description: rises in S Pender County and flows SW into Merricks Creek.

label: Pleasant Branch
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows NW into Bunches Creek.

label: Pleasant Gap
description: on the Buncombe-Madison County line between Nofat and Carter Mountains.

label: Pleasant Garden
description: community in S Guilford County. Alt. 805. Known first as Fentress for local family; renamed Pleasant Garden about 1879.

label: Pleasant Gardens
description: community in central McDowell County. Named for the home of Joseph McDowell, Patriot leader at the Battle of Kings Mountain (1780). Post office named Garden City operated nearby, 1886-1929.

label: Pleasant Grove
description: community in E central Caswell County.

label: Pleasant Grove
description: community in N Washington County E of Kendricks Creek.

label: Pleasant Grove Township
description: SE Randolph County.

label: Pleasant Hill
description: community in W Jones County on Trent River.

label: Pleasant Hill
description: home of William Hawkins, governor, 1811-14, stands about 8 mi. N of Henderson in E Vance County.

label: Pleasant Hill Township
description: N central Northampton County.

label: Pleasant Knob
description: central Buncombe County W of Beaver Lake.

label: Pleasant Lodge
description: community in NE Randolph County.

label: Pleasant Plains
description: community in central Hertford County. A free black Baptist church said to have existed there as early as 1845.

label: Pleasant Ridge
description: See South Gastonia.

label: Pleasant View
description: crossroads community in N central Tyrrell County about 1½ mi. SW of community of Levels on S side of Riders Creek.

label: Pleasants
description: community in N Granville County served by post office, 1892-1903.

label: Pleasantville
description: community in W Rockingham County served by post office, 1818-1904.

label: Pleasure Beach
description: modern promotional term for Carolina Beach, Kure Beach, and Fort Fisher, all in S New Hanover County. Area also takes in Carolina Beach State Park.

label: Pledger Landing
description: N Tyrrell County on Albemarle Sound E of Lewis Point.

label: Plot Knob
description: SW Clay County between the headwaters of Suddawig and Rocky Branches. Alt. 2,390.

label: Plott
description: community in SW Haywood County served by post office, 1886-1926. Named for local Plott family.

label: Plott Balsam
description: a knob in W Haywood County on the NE end of Plott Balsams (ridge). Alt. 6,088. Named by Arnold Guyot for Amos Plott, pioneer settler. Nearby Enos Plotts Balsam Mountain (also known as Waterrock Knob) was named for his brother.

label: Plott Balsams
description: a ridge extending NE from Tuckasegee River in W Jackson County to Plott Balsam (knob) in W Haywood County. Known by the Cherokee Indians as Tunn Ensleas. Named for Henry Plott, father of Amos and Enoch Plott. Elder Plott introduced Plott Hound (now the State Dog) to North Carolina.

label: Plott Creek
description: rises in W Haywood County and flows SE into Richland Creek.

label: Plott's Old Field Mountain
description: See Old Field Top Mountain.

label: Plotts
description: See Eufola.

label: Pluck
description: community in N Chatham County served by post office, 1884-1903.

label: Plum Branch
description: rises in E Yancey County and flows S into Little Crabtree Creek.

label: Plum Creek
description: rises in NW Alamance County and flows SW into Ridge Creek.

label: Plummers Creek
description: rises in E Davidson County and flows NE into Randolph County, where it enters Little Uwharrie River.

label: Plumtree
description: community on North Toe River, SW Avery County. Named for Plumtree Creek, which enters North Toe River nearby. Alt. 2,830. Mica has been mined there since 1891.

label: Plumtree Creek
description: rises in central Avery County and flows S and W into North Toe River. Named for plum orchards set there by Avery and Connelly families.

label: Plyler
description: community in W Stanly County.

label: Plymouth
description: town and county seat, W Washington County on Roanoke River. Settled by 1727. Inc. 1807; named for Plymouth, Mass. Important as a shipping center and as a producer of lumber products, veneer, plywood; also the location of a paper mill and a center of grain mills. Alt. 21. Battle of Plymouth fought there, 1863.

label: Plymouth Township
description: W Washington County, was formed in 1868; was a voting precinct before that date.

label: Pocahontas
description: community in SW Swain County on Nantahala River.

label: Pochike River
description: See Meherrin River.

label: Pocket Creek
description: rises in W Lee County and flows N into Deep River.

label: Pocket Township
description: former township in W Lee County (formerly Moore County), now township no. 7. A post office named The Pocket was est. there 1828 and continued to 1905. Named for the fact that it was isolated from the remainder of the county by a bend in Deep River, hence a "pocket."

label: Pocket, The
description: See Pocket Township.

label: Pocomoke
description: community in W Franklin County.

label: Pocosin Branch
description: rises in E Pitt County and flows SE into Tranters Creek.

label: Pocosin Point
description: See Poquoson Point.

label: Poe-li-co
description: See French Broad River.

label: Poga Mountain
description: N Avery County at the N end of Beech Mountain. Alt. 3,790. Local tradition is that a man was lost on the mountain for several days, and when he returned home he explained to his friends that he had "been to Pogey." He may have been using the English-dialect word "poggy," meaning boggy or sloppy, as a field in wet weather.

label: Pogey Mountain
description: See Poga Mountain.

label: Poindexter
description: See Smithtown.

label: Poindexter Branch
description: rises in central Macon County and flows NE into Iotla Creek.

label: Point Bacon
description: appears on the Smith map, 1624, as the N portion of present Currituck Banks in E Currituck County. It was shown as extending S from Cape Henry, Va., to Currituck Inlet. Undoubtedly named for Sir Francis Bacon, whose favor Smith sought to win.

label: Point Caswell
description: community in W Pender County on Black River. Named for Richard Caswell (1729-89), governor of North Carolina. Settled prior to the Civil War. Inc. in 1883 as Caswell; charter repealed 1901. Formerly a thriving shipping point on the river; now only a church and a few houses remain.

label: Point Corbett
description: appears on the Smith map, 1624, as the area of NE North Carolina presently included in Camden and Currituck Counties.

label: Point Durant
description: See Durants Neck.

label: Point Harbor
description: community at the extreme S tip of Currituck County at Powells Point. Settled prior to 1667. Post office est. in 1906 as Marvin but changed in 1907 to Point Harbor.

label: Point Hezel
description: appears on the Collet map, 1770, as a point of land in SE New Hanover County between Hewlets and Bradley Creeks on the mainland W of modern Wrightsville Beach. Probably named for James Hasell (d. 1786), chief justice of the colony.

label: Point Lookout
description: E Haywood County on Glade Mountain. Alt. approx. 4,530.

label: Point Lookout Mountain
description: E Henderson County, extends NE from the W side of Big Hungry River. William Mills built a crude fort there soon after moving to the area, and it served as a haven for pioneer settlers in time of threat from the Indians. It was there, by tradition, that Polly Stepp, firing through a porthole, struck an Indian and exclaimed: "I've hit the Big Chief, darned if I ain't hit the Big Chief!" Remains of the old foundation logs can still be seen.

label: Point Misery
description: mountain peak on the Buncombe-Yancey county line at the E end of Big Andy Ridge. Alt. 5,715.

label: Point of Grass
description: NW point of Cedar Island in NE Carteret County between West Bay and Pamlico Sound.

label: Point of Grass Creek
description: a tidal creek on the Core Sound side of Core Banks near Drum Inlet, NE Carteret County.

label: Point of Marsh
description: a point of land extending into the mouth of Neuse River in the most N part of Carteret County.

label: Point of Woods
description: See Archie's Point.

label: Point Peter
description: point of land extending into Cape Fear River at its junction with Northeast Cape Fear River opposite Wilmington, W New Hanover County. Before the Civil War, it was a terminal for river traffic to and from Fayetteville and Averasboro. Named for Peter Mallett (b. 1744), Revolutionary leader. See also Peters Point.

label: Point Prospect
description: S Orange County in the town of Chapel Hill about ½ mi. E of the University of North Carolina campus, a very high ridge below which, as William R. Davie wrote in 1793, "the flat country spreads off… like the ocean, giving an immense hemisphere, in which the eye seems to be lost in the extent of space." The peak was owned by the university until 1894, when the U.S. Circuit Court ordered it to be sold to pay university debts. Sometimes known as Piney Prospect for the pines in the vicinity and because Point was often pronounced "pint," which evolved into Piney. Site of Gimghoul Castle.

label: Poison Branch
description: rises in N Graham County and flows NW into Fontana Lake.

label: Poison Cove
description: E Haywood County on the head of Poison Cove Branch.

label: Poison Cove Branch
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows NW into Pigeon River.

label: Poison Cove Top
description: E Haywood County near the head of Poison Cove Branch.

label: Poison Fork
description: rises in S Randolph County and flows SW into Montgomery County, where it enters Barnes Creek.

label: Poison Springs
description: See Barium Springs.

label: Pokeberry Creek
description: rises in N Chatham County and flows SW into Haw River.

label: Pole Branch
description: rises in W Johnston County and flows SE into Black Creek.

label: Pole Bridge Branch
description: rises in NW Swain County and flows S into Lake Cheoah.

label: Pole Bridge Branch
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows NE into Little River.

label: Pole Bridge Creek
description: rises in W Stanly County and flows NE into Big Bear Creek.

label: Pole Bridge Gap
description: N Wilkes County at the N end of Greenstreet Mountain.

label: Pole Creek
description: rises in SW Buncombe County from 2 branches, each rising on the S slopes of Holland Mountain. One flows SE through Milksick Cove; the other flows SE through Herren Cove. They join to flow SE into Hominy Creek.

label: Pole Mountain
description: S Wilkes County near the head of Fishing Creek.

label: Pole Road Creek
description: in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, rises in N Swain County and flows SE into Deep Creek.

label: Polecat Branch
description: rises in E Greene County and flows SW into Contentnea Creek.

label: Polecat Branch
description: rises in N Macon County and flows SW into Lakey Creek.

label: Polecat Creek
description: rises in S Union County and flows SE into South Carolina, where it enters Wildcat Creek.

label: Polecat Hollow
description: W Madison County on an unnamed tributary of French Broad River.

label: Polecat Ridge
description: N Macon County between Bradley Creek and Lakey Creek.

label: Polenta
description: community in central Johnston County served by post office, 1882-1900.

label: Poley Branch
description: rises in NE Pitt County and flows E into Tranters Creek.

label: Poley Branch
description: rises in SE Richmond County and flows S into Joes Creek.

label: Poley Swamp
description: rises in N Duplin County and flows N from Whitfields Pond into Deavers Mill Pond. Also known as Polly Run Creek.

label: Polk
description: community in N Harnett County served by post office, 1891-1904.

label: Polk County
description: was formed in 1855 from Rutherford and Henderson Counties. Located in the SW section of the state, it is bounded by the state of South Carolina and by Henderson and Rutherford Counties. It was named for Col. William Polk (1758-1834), Revolutionary War officer who was, before his death, the last surviving field officer of the North Carolina line. Area: 235 sq. mi. County seat: Columbus, with an elevation of 1,145 ft. Townships are Columbus, Cooper Gap, Greens Creek, Saluda, Tryon, and White Oak. Produces corn, wheat, oats, hay, apples, lumber, cotton, livestock, hogs, textiles, and apparel.

label: Polk Ditch
description: rises in SW Mecklenburg County and flows SE into Walker Branch.

label: Polk Mountain
description: See Gibraltar.

label: Polkton
description: town in W Anson County. With the coming of the railroad, the town was laid out on the lands of, and named for, Leonidas L. Polk (1837-92), state agricultural leader. He first proposed that it be called Luneville. Inc. 1875. Alt. 320.

label: Polkville
description: community in W Cleveland County.

label: Polkville Township
description: former township in W Cleveland County, now township no. 8.

label: Pollard Swamp
description: rises in SW Beaufort County and flows SW into Creeping Swamp.

label: Pollock Mill Creek
description: rises in W Duplin County and flows SE into Stewarts Creek.

label: Pollock Swamp
description: a marshy stream, rises in Bear Swamp, E Chowan County, and flows SW into Pembroke Creek. Pollock Swamp watershed, approx. 17 mi. long, is in the area.

label: Pollock's Ferry
description: See Bridgers Creek.

label: Pollocksville
description: town in S Jones County on Trent River. Known as Trent Bridge as early as 1779, and a post office was est. 1809. Inc. 1834 as Pollocksville, but a municipal government was not formed at that time. Reincorporated 1849. The name Pollock appears at the location on the Collet map, 1770, and others into the nineteenth century, when Trent Bridge is shown across the river and Pollocksville at the site of the town. Produces lumber. Alt. 13.

label: Pollocksville Township
description: E Jones County.

label: Polls Gap
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Balsam Mountain near lat. 35°33'48" N., long. 83°09'42" W. Alt. 5,090. Named after Aunt Polly Moody's family cow, Poll, died, and her bones were left bleaching in the sun for many years.

label: Polly Hollow
description: E Mitchell County parallel to Laurel Branch.

label: Polly Middleton Gap
description: in central Jackson County between Double Top Mountain and Horneyhead Mountain.

label: Polly Mountain
description: S Jackson County, bordered on the E by Scotsman Creek and on the S by Chattooga River. Alt. approx. 3,150.

label: Polly Run Creek
description: See Poley Swamp.

label: Polycarp
description: community in S Alexander County. Alt. approx. 1,000. Named for Rev. Polycarp Henkle, Lutheran minister in the vicinity in the nineteenth century.

label: Pomeiock
description: appears on the White-De Bry map, 1590, as an enclosed Indian village in present Hyde County between Lake Mattamuskeet and Wyesocking Bay.

label: Pomona
description: former community in central Guilford County now within Greensboro city limits. Alt. 868. Named for the Italian goddess of the fruit of trees; a nursery was once located there.

label: Pompey Ridge
description: NW McDowell County. Average alt. approx. 2,600. Locust Knob is on the ridge.

label: Pond
description: See Stokesdale.

label: Pond Branch
description: rises in W Watauga County and flows N into Beech Creek.

label: Pond Knob
description: NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Big Grill Ridge, lat. 35°32' N., long. 83°46'23" W. Alt. 4,148.

label: Pond Mountain
description: NW Ashe County. Alt. approx. 5,000. The top of the mountain is a large level plateau covered with bluegrass and containing several small ponds. Said to have been named by Peter Jefferson in 1749.

label: Pond Mountain
description: S Randolph County between Bachelor Creek and Fork Creek.

label: Pond Mountain Township
description: NW Ashe County.

label: Pond Ridge
description: in most W part of Burke County. Alt. 3,546.

label: Ponder Branch
description: rises in SE Madison County and flows N into French Broad River.

label: Ponder Creek
description: rises in E Madison County and flows SW into Middle Fork.

label: Pontop
description: community in NE Montgomery County served by post office, 1858-1873. See also Flaggtown.

label: Pony Ridge
description: S Mitchell County at the head of Brushy Creek.

label: Ponzer
description: community in NW Hyde County on Pungo River.

label: Pool
description: community in SE Rowan County served by post office, 1872-1906.

label: Pool Creek
description: rises in W Rutherford County and flows NE into Lake Lure. The Bottomless Pools, which see, are on the creek.

label: Pool Point
description: extends from E Pasquotank County into Pasquotank River at the mouth of New Begun Creek.

label: Pooletown
description: community in E Rowan County between Cedar and Panther Creeks. A post office named Pool was est. there 1872; closed 1906.

label: Poolville
description: community in SE Pasquotank County on Pasquotank River.

label: Poor House Mountain
description: S Cherokee County, extends NE from Martin Creek.

label: Poor Town
description: community in S Hertford County.

label: Poorhouse Run
description: rises in S Greene County and flows NE into Contentnea Creek. Earlier called Caswells Branch. Name derived from the fact that it runs by the former County Home.

label: Poorlith
description: community in W Union County.

label: Poors Ford
description: community in SE Polk County served by post office, 1881-1914. Named for Green River crossing.

label: Poors Knob
description: E Watauga County between Chestnut Branch and Elk Creek. Alt. approx. 2,350.

label: Poors Knots
description: community in S Wilkes County served by post office, 1888-1916.

label: Pop Castle
description: W Vance County approx. 1 mi. W of the town of Kittrell. Popecastle Inn was est. there approx. 1734, and local usage changed the name to Pop Castle. Racetrack, cockpit, and tavern were adjuncts of the inn; use of the racetrack began during the Revolution, and the main building of the inn was dismantled after the Civil War.

label: Pope
description: community in central Robeson County.

label: Pope Air Force Base
description: NW Cumberland County, was est. during World War I and named in honor of Lt. Harley Halbert Pope, who died in a postwar aircraft accident on the Cape Fear River near Fayetteville, January 7, 1919.

label: Pope Branch
description: rises in W Halifax County and flows S into Fishing Creek.

label: Popecastle Inn
description: See Pop Castle.

label: Popes Pond
description: slightly less than ½ mi. long, on Black River, SE Harnett County.

label: Poplar
description: community in W Mitchell County on Nolichucky River. Alt. 1,993. A post office there, 1872-96, was called Hollow Poplar.

label: Poplar Branch
description: rises in central Guilford County and flows NE into Reedy Fork Creek. Appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Poplar Branch
description: community on the W shore of Currituck Sound in S Currituck County. Known first as Currituck Narrows. Post office 1829. See also Narrows.

label: Poplar Branch Bay
description: S central Currituck County, is formed in Currituck Sound by the mainland, Rattle Snake Island, and Long Point.

label: Poplar Branch Township
description: S Currituck County.

label: Poplar Cove
description: S Swain County extends SW from Little Tennessee River.

label: Poplar Cove Branch
description: rises in SW Macon County and flows NE into Poplar Cove Creek.

label: Poplar Cove Creek
description: See Paxton Creek.

label: Poplar Cove Gap
description: central Macon County between the head of Mill Creek and Trimont Ridge.

label: Poplar Cove Knob
description: S Macon County between Commissioner Creek and the Georgia state line.

label: Poplar Creek
description: rises in E Wake County and flows S into Neuse River.

label: Poplar Gap
description: E Haywood County between Sheep Mountain and Glade Mountain.

label: Poplar Grove
description: community in NE Sampson County.

label: Poplar Hill
description: community in SW Anson County served by post office, 1825-1905.

label: Poplar Hollow Branch
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows S into Raven Fork.

label: Poplar Lick Gap
description: N Transylvania County on the head of Sitton Creek.

label: Poplar Point
description: a bluff on the Roanoke River, N Martin County. Appears on the Collet map, 1770. A steamboat landing was there at one time; Poplar Point Church and a rural community are nearby. Roanoke, a post office, operated at or near the point, 1851-80.

label: Poplar Point Township
description: N central Martin County.

label: Poplar Spring Top
description: on the Cherokee-Graham county line in the Snowbird Mountains.

label: Poplar Springs
description: community in S Stokes County.

label: Poplar Swamp
description: See Poplar Creek.

label: Poplar Tent Township
description: former township in W Cabarrus County, now township no. 2.

label: Poplar Township
description: NW Mitchell County.

label: Poppaw Creek
description: rises in SW Alamance County and flows N into Stinking Quarter Creek.

label: Populi
description: community in NW Bladen County served by post office, 1892-1929.

label: Poquoson Point
description: S Camden County in the mouth of Pasquotank River. Also sometimes called Camden Point. Name derived from an Algonquian word pequessen, meaning a swamp or a dismal.

label: Porcelain
description: See Linville.

label: Pores Knob
description: community in S Wilkes County near the peak of the same name. Name changed at one time to Fruitland and to East Fruitland, but the original name was soon restored.

label: Pork Creek
description: See Fork Creek.

label: Porpoise Point
description: NE Pamlico County on the E side of Goose Creek Island between Big Porpoise Bay and Little Porpoise Bay.

label: Port Fernando
description: See Hatorask Inlet.

label: Port Grenvil
description: appears on the White map, 1590, as an inlet through Ocracoke Island a short distance N of the community of Ocracoke, SE Hyde County. Named for Sir Richard Grenville. Appears as "Greenevills Rode" on the Smith map, 1624. There is some doubt that such an inlet actually existed, though it may have been at what is now known as Nigh Inlet, which see.

label: Port Landing
description: See Fort Landing.

label: Port Lane
description: an inlet from the Atlantic Ocean into Roanoke Sound through Bodie Island opposite the SE shore of Roanoke Island, E Dare County. Opened prior to 1585 and closed prior to 1657.

label: Porter
description: community in SE Stanly County. Named for an official of the railroad.

label: Porter Cove
description: on a tributary of Cullasaja River in S Macon County.

label: Porter Creek
description: rises in SE Beaufort County and flows N into Durham Creek.

label: Porter Swamp
description: rises in W Columbus County and flows NW and SW into Lumber River.

label: Porterfield Gap
description: on the Cherokee-Graham county line. Alt. 3,462.

label: Porters Gap
description: in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Swain County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line, lat. 35°38'55" N., long. 83°21'28" W. Alt. approx. 5,500.

label: Portersville
description: See Emerson.

label: Portia
description: was inc. as a town in McDowell County, 1891; charter repealed 1893. It apparently was never laid out, and the proposed site is unknown.

label: Portis Gold Mine
description: now abandoned, NE Franklin County. Shown on a map as recently as 1931.

label: Portohonk Creek
description: rises in SW Camden County and flows S into Pasquotank County. See also Jones Mill.

label: Portsmouth
description: formerly a thriving town in NE Carteret County at the tip of Core Banks. Settled in the early 1700s; est. 1753 and probably named for the city in England. Long inactive in municipal affairs. Alt. 8. See also Portsmouth Island.

label: Portsmouth Island
description: NE Carteret County, is the name applied to the NE end of Core Banks. Appears as Wococon, which see, on the White map, 1585. May have been a part of Croatoan Island. See also Portsmouth; Core Banks; Cape Lookout National Seashore Recreational Area.

label: Portsmouth Township
description: E Carteret County, is made up of Core Banks extending from Cape Lookout to Ocracoke Inlet. See also Portsmouth Island.

label: Possum Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows NW into Hickory Knoll Creek. Approx. ½ mi. long.

label: Possum Creek
description: See Possumquarter Creek.

label: Possum Hollow
description: S Haywood County on the E side of Bearpen Gap. An unnamed stream rises there and flows E into Haywood Gap Stream.

label: Possum Hollow
description: community on the N side of Yadkin River, N central Caldwell County.

label: Possum Neck Swamp
description: rises in S Craven County and flows NW into Brice Creek.

label: Possumquarter Creek
description: rises in W central Warren County and flows S into Fishing Creek. Probably named for Possum Quarter, the plantation of Governor Gabriel Johnston, mentioned in his 1751 will. Appears on the Price map, 1808, as Possum Creek.

label: Possumtown
description: See Bethany.

label: Possumtrot
description: community in W Yancey County on Possumtrot Creek. Named by an early settler who was riding down a trail on horseback when a lone opossum entered the path ahead of him and trotted along in front of the horse for some distance.

label: Possumtrot Creek
description: rises in W Yancey County and flows NE into Bald Creek.

label: Post Oak
description: See Blaine.

label: Postell
description: community in W Cherokee County on Shoal Creek. Alt. 1,900. Named for Thomas Postell, an early settler.

label: Pot Branch
description: rises in S McDowell County and flows SE into Rutherford County, where it enters Briar Creek. Erosion in rocks over which it flows has made potlike holes.

label: Pot Cove Gap
description: on the Buncombe-McDowell county line near the headwaters of Flat Creek.

label: Potaskike River
description: See North River.

label: Potato Branch
description: rises in SW Buncombe County near Potato Gap and flows NW into South Turkey Creek.

label: Potato Creek
description: rises in SW Cherokee County and flows W into Polk County, Tenn., where it turns SW and flows into Ocoee River.

label: Potato Field Gap
description: NE Buncombe County S of Snowball Mountain. The Blue Ridge Parkway passes through the gap.

label: Potato Gap
description: N Madison County at the SW end of Sugarloaf Mountain.

label: Potato Hill
description: on Jackson Line Mountain in S central Swain County between the head of Laurel Branch and the head of Davis Branch. Alt. 3,306.

label: Potato Hill
description: See Tater Hill.

label: Potato Hill Bald
description: NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Chiltoskie Ridge near the SE end of Ravens Roost Ridge, lat. 35°35'42" N., long. 83°12'33" W. Alt. 5,209.

label: Potato Hill Lake
description: artificial lake in central Watauga County on Howard Creek between Rich Mountain and Harmon Knob. Formed in 1947; max. depth 25 ft.; covers 9 acres. Open to public. Also known as Tater Hill Lake.

label: Potato Hill Mountain
description: W Randolph County on Little Caraway Creek.

label: Potato Knob
description: E Haywood County between Dutch Cove Creek and Doubletop Mountain.

label: Potato Lump Mountain
description: SW Madison County between Johns Branch and Spring Creek.

label: Potato Mountain
description: NW Buncombe County between Willow and Sandy Mush Creeks.

label: Potato Patch
description: mountain in W Haywood County on the head of a tributary of Hemphill Creek.

label: Potato Top
description: See Potato Knob.

label: Potecasi (potty-casey)
description: community in E Northampton County. Named for its location near Potecasi Creek, an Indian word meaning "parting of the waters." A post office operated there, 1839-1928.

label: Potecasi Bridge
description: See Jackson.

label: Potecasi Creek
description: rises in central Northampton County and flows E into Hertford County, where it enters Meherrin River. Appears as Weyanok Creek on the Ogilby map, 1671. The upper portion of Potecasi Creek is marked Catawhisky on the Moseley map, 1733. Appears as Meherrin Creek on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Potoskite
description: appears on the Moseley map, 1733, in S Currituck Precinct (now Currituck County), possibly representing an Indian village.

label: Potrock Bald
description: a peak in N Clay County near the headwaters of Potrock Branch and Compass Creek. Alt. 5, 200-5, 250. Named for a large rock on top of the mountain that was hollowed out by an Indian medicine man and used to steep his medicinal herbs.

label: Potrock Branch
description: rises in N Clay County and flows SW into Fires Creek.

label: Pott Creek
description: rises in S Catawba County and flows S into Lincoln County, where it enters South Fork Catawba River.

label: Potter
description: community in SW Union County served by post office, 1891-1900.

label: Potter's Hill
description: community in S central Lenoir County. So called for the Potter family, early settlers.

label: Potters
description: See Mineral Springs.

label: Potters Hill
description: community in E Duplin County.

label: Pottertown
description: See Tamarack.

label: Potts Branch
description: rises in N Macon County and flows SW into Little Tennessee River.

label: Potts Creek
description: See First Potts Creek; Second Potts Creek.

label: Pound Mill Gap
description: W Macon County between Burningtown Creek and Deweese Creek.

label: Pounding Creek
description: rises in central Clay County and flows S into Shooting Creek.

label: Pounding Mill Branch
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows NE into Elk Creek.

label: Pounding Mill Cove
description: N Yancey County on Pounding Mill Creek.

label: Pounding Mill Creek
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows NW into Cane River.

label: Poundingmill Creek
description: rises in NE Cleveland County and flows S into Knob Creek.

label: Poundingstone Mountain
description: N Transylvania County between Pounding Mill Branch and Jumping Branch. Alt. approx. 3,450.

label: Pousville
description: community in N Franklin County.

label: Poverty Branch
description: rises in N Buncombe County and flows SW into North Fork Ivy Creek.

label: Powder Burnt Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NW into Valley River.

label: Powder Springs
description: See Eupeptic Springs.

label: Powdermill Creek
description: rises in W Avery County and flows SE into North Toe River. Said to have been named because Lodawick and Dora Oakes, who lived along its banks, burned willow switches to make enough gunpowder to buy a slave.

label: Powel's Creek
description: See Greens Creek.

label: Powell Creek
description: rises in E Wake County and flows SW into Hodges Mill Creek.

label: Powell Crossroads
description: community in S Gates County.

label: Powell Knob
description: in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Swain County, N.C.-Blount County, Tenn., line between Buck Gap and Ekaneetlee Gap, lat. 35°32'24" N., long. 83°49'19" W.

label: Powells Creek
description: See Whitaker Creek.

label: Powells Pocosin
description: NW Bertie County.

label: Powells Point
description: tip of the peninsula of S Currituck County in Albemarle Sound. Appears in local records as early as 1665 and on the Ogilby map, 1671. The community (and post office, est. 1818) of Powells Point is 6½ mi. n.

label: Powellsville
description: town in N central Bertie County. Post office est. 1879; inc. 1887. Named for a local family and originally known as Powell's Crossroads. Alt. 67.

label: Powellton
description: community in NW Richmond County. A post office operated there, 1829-1918. Named for Pleasant M. Powell.

label: Powelltown
description: community in S Transylvania County near the mouth of East Fork French Broad River.

label: Powers Branch
description: rises in E Mitchell County and flows SE into Fall Creek.

label: Powhatan
description: community in N Johnston County. Alt. 294.

label: Poyner Hill
description: formerly a sand hill on S Currituck Banks, E Currituck County. Erosion has almost obliterated the hill. During World War II, a temporary Coast Guard base was located there.

label: Prather Gap
description: W Yancey County between Possumtrot and Price Creeks.

label: Prathers Creek
description: rises in SW Alleghany County and flows NW into South Fork New River.

label: Prathers Creek Township
description: W central Alleghany County.

label: Pratt
description: community in W Johnston County served by post office, 1884-1901.

label: Prattsburg
description: former community in central Durham County approx. 2 mi. E of the original railroad station for Durham. In the 1850s, William Pratt refused to give a right-of-way or land for a station at Prattsburg. The railroad avoided his property, and as a result, Durham was est.

label: Prentiss
description: community in S Macon County.

label: Prescott
description: community in S central Beaufort County.

label: Presley Branch
description: rises in N Transylvania County and flows SW into Avery Creek.

label: Presley Creek
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows NE into Tilley Creek.

label: Press Cove
description: N Jackson County on the head of East Fork [Dicks Creek].

label: Press Prong
description: rises in W Nash County and flows SE into Murrays Mill Pond on Turkey Creek.

label: Pressley Gap
description: at the head of Rose Creek in N Macon County.

label: Pressly Mountain
description: E Haywood County on the head of Conner Mill Branch and Stamey Cove Branch.

label: Prestonville
description: community in NE Stokes County.

label: Pretty Hollow Creek
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, rises near lat. 35°40'55" N., long. 83°08'17" W., on Mount Sterling Ridge and flows S into Palmer Creek.

label: Pretty Hollow Gap
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Mount Sterling Ridge near lat. 35°41'10" N., long. 83°08'26" W. Alt. 5,176 at the head of Pretty Hollow Creek.

label: Pretty Pine Branch
description: rises in NW Cherokee County and flows SE into Shuler Creek.

label: Pretty Pond
description: a natural lake in SE Brunswick County. Max. depth 8 ft. Surface area, 150 acres.

label: Price
description: community in NW Rockingham County. Est. 1868. Named for John Price, on whose plantation a store and post office were built. The post office, 1870-1956, for a time was known as Price's Store.

label: Price Creek
description: rises in SW Yancey County and flows N into Cane River.

label: Price Creek Township
description: W Yancey County.

label: Price Township
description: NW Rockingham County.

label: Price's Mill
description: community in W Union County.

label: Prices Creek
description: community in W Yancey County served by post office, 1888-1927.

label: Prickly Ash Ridge
description: W Jackson County between Tarcamp Branch and Hunter Jim Creek.

label: Prickly Pear Mountain
description: W Randolph County just W of Caraway Mountain in a close group with Black Jack, Slick Rock, and Vineyard Mountains.

label: Prides Ferry
description: See Mush Island.

label: Priest Hill
description: community in central Moore County.

label: Prince George County
description: was proposed as a name for new county by Colonial Assembly in 1762. Name, intended to honor future King George III, was rejected in favor of Bute County, which see.

label: Prince George Creek
description: rises in N New Hanover County and flows NW into Northeast Cape Fear River. Appears in local records as early as 1744, hence probably named for Prince George (1738-1820), who became George III in 1760.

label: Prince's Bridge
description: former community in NE Chatham County on New Hope Creek. A post office operated there, 1828-32. See also Cyprett's Bridge.

label: Princess Anne
description: town in SE Robeson County. Inc. 1796 "on lands of Mary Griffin and William Ashley on Drowning Creek," now Lumber River. Long inactive in municipal affairs. Site approx. 2½ mi. SE of the community of Barnesville.

label: Princeton
description: town est. 1787 on Meherrin River in NE Northampton County. Previously known as Pitch Landing. Streets were laid off and some homes built, but it soon declined as nearby Murfreesboro (inc. at the same time) grew. A plantation on the site continues to be called Princeton. Washington Ferry crossed the river there and is shown on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Princeville
description: town in central Edgecombe County just S of the Tar River from Tarboro. Settled 1865 by former slaves and called Freedom Hill. Inc. 1885 and named for Turner Prince, a resident. Alt. 58. Scene of massive flooding, 1999, owing to Hurricane Floyd.

label: Print
description: community in N Halifax County.

label: Priscilla
description: See Ranlo-Rex-Priscilla.

label: Prissy Bay
description: sand-filled bay in SE Sampson County at the head of Wildcat Swamp. See also Carolina Bays.

label: Pritchard Tavern
description: See Buena Vista.

label: Pritchett
description: community in SE Rockingham County served by post office, 1886-1903. Named for postmaster Thomas Pritchett.

label: Privett
description: community in S Franklin County.

label: Procks Point
description: extends into Jarrett Bay SE of community of Davis, SE Carteret County.

label: Proctor
description: former town in W Swain County on Hazel Creek. Alt. 1,735. Inc. 1911; the site is now in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Named for William Proctor, who was instrumental in having a post office est. there in 1886. Service discontinued, 1944.

label: Proctor Branch
description: rises in NW Swain County on Twentymile Ridge and flows SW into Twenty-mile Creek.

label: Proctor Creek
description: in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, rises in W Swain County and flows S into Hazel Creek.

label: Proctor Ridge
description: in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, N Swain County between Proctor Creek and Long Cove, lat. 35°33'18" N., long. 83°35'46" W.

label: Proctor Sang Branch
description: rises in NW Swain County and flows E into Ekaneetlee Creek. See also Seng Branch.

label: Proctorville
description: town in S Robeson County. Alt. 120. Settled about 1870. Inc. 1913. Named for Edward Knox Proctor Jr. (1862-1902), promoter of the Raleigh and Charleston Railroad.

label: Proffits Knob
description: N Watauga County SW of Laurel Branch.

label: Proffitt
description: community in SW Wilkes County served by post office, 1898-1906.

label: Progress
description: community in NW Randolph County. Formerly known as Fraziers for a local storekeeper.

label: Promontorium tremendum
description: See Cape Fear.

label: Prong
description: community in N Columbus County served by post office, 1889-1903.

label: Prophet Branch
description: rises in NW Haywood County and flows SE into Big Branch. Named for a prominent mountain family in the area.

label: Propst
description: community in SW Catawba County served by post office, 1899-1905.

label: Propst's Knob
description: SW Burke County. Alt. 3,022.

label: Prospect
description: community in NW Robeson County.

label: Prospect Hill
description: community in SE Caswell County. Named for the former Warren family plantation and its elevated view. A post office was est. there, 1823.

label: Prospect Knob
description: NW Iredell County.

label: Prospect Ridge
description: SE Burke County between Laurel Creek and Henry Fork.

label: Prosperity
description: See High Falls.

label: Protection
description: community in NE Madison County.

label: Providence
description: community in SW Chatham County served by post office, 1877-1900.

label: Providence
description: community in S Mecklenburg County, grew up around Providence Presbyterian Church, organized in 1767.

label: Providence Inlet
description: See Caffey's Inlet.

label: Providence Township
description: SE Rowan County. Named, according to tradition, because an act of God (Providence) enabled Gen. Nathanael Greene to cross Yadkin River in 1781 to escape Cornwallis. See Trading Ford.

label: Proximity
description: formerly a cotton-mill community in central Guilford County, now a part of Greensboro. Camp for Overseas Replacement Depot located there during World War II.

label: Pruitts Fork Creek
description: rises in E Rockingham County and flows E into Lower Hogan's Creek. Later known as Jones Creek, which see.

label: Public Creek
description: rises in the highlands of Indian Island, SE Camden County, and flows E into North River.

label: Puella
description: former community in central Transylvania County near confluence of Davidson and French Broad Rivers. Earlier known as Deavers and today known as Pisgah Forest.

label: Puett Cove
description: NE Cherokee County in the Valley River Mountains.

label: Puett Creek
description: rises in central Cherokee County and flows N into Vengeance Creek. See also Will Puett Cove.

label: Pug Knob
description: on Haywood-Madison county line. Alt. 4,245.

label: Pughs
description: community in N Franklin County.

label: Pughs Island
description: See Tucker Island.

label: Pulham Creek
description: rises W Polk County and flows SW into Green River.

label: Pulhams Ferry
description: See Bridgers Creek.

label: Pump
description: community in NE Madison County.

label: Pump Branch
description: rises in N Mitchell County and flows W into Big Rock Creek.

label: Pump Mountain
description: N Jackson County between Cope Creek and Scott Creek. Named for the fact that the first running water in the area was run through log pipes from the mountains to the home of Thaddeus Clingman Bryson, where the first court in Jackson County was held.

label: Pumpkin Center
description: community in N Lincoln County.

label: Pumpkin Creek
description: rises in SW Wilkes County and flows E into Warrior Creek. Maps of W. Kerr Scott Reservoir show the feature as Punkin Creek.

label: Pumpkin Patch Gap
description: N Mitchell County between Pumpkin Patch Mountain and Meadlock Mountain.

label: Pumpkin Patch Mountain
description: central Mitchell County between Cub Creek and Little Rock Creek. Alt. 4,263.

label: Pumpkintown
description: community in W Jackson County on Savannah Creek.

label: Punch Bowl
description: community in a small valley in S Macon County between Bates Mountain and the head of Bates Branch.

label: Punch Bowl Creek
description: rises in S Alexander County and flows SE into Catawba River.

label: Puncheon Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NW into Valley River. Fortified Indian villages were protected by "wooden puncheons," high stakes driven into the ground, and this may be the source of the name.

label: Puncheon Camp Branch
description: rises in W Madison County and flows NW into Spring Creek.

label: Puncheon Camp Creek
description: rises in E Henderson County and flows NE into Clear Creek.

label: Puncheon Creek
description: rises in SE Transylvania County near Standingstone Mountain and flows NW into Reasonover Creek.

label: Puncheon Fork Creek
description: rises in E Madison County and flows SW into Big Laurel Creek.

label: Pungo
description: community in NE Beaufort County on Indian Run near its junction with Pungo River. Alt. approx. 5.

label: Pungo Creek
description: rises in Great Swamp, N central Beaufort County, and flows SE into Pungo River. Appears as Machapunga Creek on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Pungo Lake
description: natural lake in S Washington and NW Hyde Counties in East Dismal Swamp. Inaccessible except through private property; not open to the public. Owned by Roper Lumber Company. Covers 2,700 acres, with a max. depth of 5 ft. Name is shortened from name for the Machapunga Indians.

label: Pungo River
description: rises in East Dismal Swamp, Washington County, and flows generally se, forming the Beaufort-Hyde county line into Pamlico River near its mouth. Appears as Machapounga River on the Comberford map, 1657, and as Machaponga on the Moseley map, 1733, and other maps until 1807, when it appears, apparently for the first time, as Pungo River on the William Tatham map. Named for the Machapunga Indians, whose name is said to have meant "bad dust" or "much dust."

label: Punkin Creek
description: See Pumpkin Creek.

label: Puppy Creek
description: rises in E Hoke County and flows S into Rockfish Creek.

label: Pups Branch
description: rises in NW McDowell County and flows SE into Armstrong Creek.

label: Pups Branch Ridge
description: See Pups Ridge.

label: Pups Ridge
description: approx. 2 mi. long, NW McDowell County in Pisgah National Forest. Formerly known as Big Ridge and as Pups Branch Ridge.

label: Purcepolis
description: community in N Scotland County served by post office, 1883-1905.

label: Purchace Islands
description: the name given on the Smith map, 1624, to the nine islands in Roanoke and Cashie Rivers at the conjunction of Bertie, Martin, and Washington Counties. Apparently one of the islands is unnamed, but the other eight are known as Louse Island, Rice Island, Goodmans Island, Wood Island, Great Island, Huff Island, Conine Island, and Tabor Island. Smith is thought to have named the islands in honor of Samuel Purchas (1575?-1626), an English compiler of travel books.

label: Purchase Knob
description: in central Haywood County between Sugar Cove and the head of Cove Creek. It overlooks a large section of the old North Carolina Land and Lumber Company tract, and prospective buyers were taken there to get a good view of the property. Alt. 5,086.

label: Purgatory
description: See Flox.

label: Purgatory Mountain
description: central Randolph County, site of North Carolina Zoological Park.

label: Purgatory Pocosin
description: a sandy loam-filled pocosin in SW Jones and NW Onslow Counties at the head of Mill Swamp.

label: Purlear
description: community in W central Wilkes County on Cole Creek. Named for Isaac Parlier, who settled on nearby Purlear Creek.

label: Purlear Creek
description: rises in W Wilkes County on the W side of Rendezvous Mountain and flows S into North Prong Lewis Fork Creek. Once known as Isaac Parlier's Creek.

label: Purley
description: community in N central Caswell County. Probably named for Purley Cobb, local resident. A post office operated there, 1855-1920. Alt. 524. Bright-leaf tobacco was discovered in 1839 on the Slade farm there.

label: Purnell
description: community in N Wake County on the head of Mud Creek; formerly known as Purnell Crossroads.

label: Purnell Crossroads
description: See Purnell.

label: Purviance Creek
description: rises in E New Hanover County and flows E into Masonboro Sound.

label: Purvis
description: community in W Robeson County.

label: Push
description: community in S Person County near Aldridge Creek.

label: Putnam
description: community in N Moore County. Called Johnson City for Harvell Johnson, local resident, until renamed for Israel Putnam (1718-90), Revolutionary War general, leader, and ancestor of local residents. Alt. 442.

label: Puzzle Creek
description: rises in E Rutherford County and flows SW into Second Broad River. Quicksand in the creek made it a "puzzle" to early settlers who wondered whether their horses could cross it.

label: Pyatt Creek
description: rises in SW Avery County and flows E into North Toe River.

label: Pyatte
description: community in central Avery County.

label: P[ort] Box
description: appears on the Smith map, 1624, in Pamlico Sound, but the feature for which this name is intended is uncertain.

label: P[ort] Vaughn
description: appears on the Smith map, 1624, in Pamlico Sound, but the feature for which this name is intended is uncertain.

label: Quail Roost
description: community in N Durham County. Named for a former hunting club there acquired in 1925 by George Watts Hill of Durham, who turned it into a dairy farm. In 1963 the farm was given to the state of North Carolina by Hill. The large house is used as a conference center by the University of North Carolina; North Carolina State University makes use of the surrounding land, designated as Hill Forest.

label: Quaker
description: community in S Stokes County served by post office, 1876-1903. Also known as Quaker Gap.

label: Quaker Creek
description: rises in NE Alamance County and flows S into Quaker Scrub Creek.

label: Quaker Gap
description: See Quaker.

label: Quaker Gap Township
description: W central Stokes County.

label: Quaker Meadows
description: a grassy region in W central Burke County 1 mi. NW of Morganton, lying between Canoe and Upper Creeks. Settled as early as 1752; appears on the Collet map, 1770. A frontier rendezvous, it was the home of Joseph and Charles McDowell, officers at the Battle of Kings Mountain (1780) and later public leaders. Zebulon B. Vance and his first wife, Harriet Espy, were married there.

label: Quaker Meadows Township
description: central Burke County.

label: Quaker Neck
description: W central Wayne County, is formed by a crook in Neuse River. Location of a Quaker settlement prior to 1758. See also Goldsboro Cooling Pond.

label: Quaker Scrub Creek
description: rises in NE Alamance County and flows S into Back Creek.

label: Qualla
description: community in NW Jackson County on Shoal Creek. The name is from the Cherokee word kwalli (old woman), because an old Cherokee woman, Polly, lived there. Also called Quallatown. Alt. 2,250.

label: Qualla Boundary
description: home of the Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians in Swain, Jackson, and Haywood Counties in Great Smoky Mountains. Est. by the United States after the Cherokee removal of 1838. Covers 63,000 acres and is the largest Indian reservation E of the Mississippi. The reservation is divided into Big Cove Town, Wolf Town, Yellow Hill Town, Paint Town, and Bird Town townships. In addition, a number of Cherokees living off the reservation in Cheoah Township, Graham County, are under tribal jurisdiction. Land is held in common and assigned on a tenant system.

label: Qualla Township
description: N Jackson County.

label: Quallatown
description: See Qualla.

label: Qualls Creek
description: rises in S Clay County and flows NE into Hiwassee River approx. ¾ mi. N of town of Hayesville. Named for an Indian woman.

label: Quankey Creek
description: rises in N Halifax County and flows SE into Roanoke River. Appears as Quountka Creek on the Moseley map, 1733; does not appear on the Collet map, 1770, or the Price map, 1808. Appears next on the MacRae map, 1833, with its present name. A Tuscarora Indian name. Indian relics have been found along its lower course.

label: Quaqua Creek
description: rises in N Rockingham County and flows E into Wolf Island Creek.

label: Quarry
description: community in S Wilkes County.

label: Quarry Branch
description: rises in N Alamance County and flows SE into Tom's Creek.

label: Quarter Swamp
description: rises in central Northampton County and flows SE into Urahaw Swamp.

label: Quebec
description: community in S Transylvania County between Blue Ridge and West Fork French Board River. Alt. 2,530.

label: Queen
description: See Love Joy.

label: Queen Anne's Creek
description: rises in S Chowan County and flows SW into the E side of Edenton Bay. Known as Mattacomack Creek prior to about 1712. The present name appears in local records as early as 1712. See also Pembroke Creek.

label: Queen Anne's Town
description: See Edenton.

label: Queen Branch
description: rises in N Macon County and flows SW into Little Tennessee River.

label: Queen Creek
description: rises in NW Henderson County and flows SE into South Fork.

label: Queen Creek Mountain
description: NW Henderson County, extends SE from Yellow Gap to Buttermilk Mountain. Alt. 3,650.

label: Queen Inlet
description: See Mason Inlet.

label: Queen Mountain
description: SE Macon County between Sassafras Gap and Big Creek.

label: Queen Ridge
description: extends NE between Snowbird and Squally Creeks in W Graham County.

label: Queens Creek
description: rises in E Onslow County and flows SE into White Oak River. Named for Queen Anne (1665-1714). Name occurs in local records as early as 1713. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733. Otway Burns (1775-1848), privateer in the War of 1812, was born on the W side of Queens Creek.

label: Queens Creek Lake
description: formed in 1948 on Queens Creek in NW Macon County. Covers 37 acres, with a max. depth of 68 ft. Owned by Nantahala Power and Light Company to generate electricity.

label: Queens Falls
description: See Queens Creek.

label: Queensdale
description: community in N Robeson County served by post office, 1820-1904. Formerly known as McQueen's Store.

label: Query's
description: community in E Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1859-1903. Named for James Query, first postmaster.

label: Quewhiffle Creek
description: rises in W Hoke County and flows S into Lumber River. The name may be derived through faulty pronunciation from the Gaelic Culmhutar (pronounced "kul-vutar"), meaning "smuggler" or "mutineer." See also Cuwhiffle.

label: Quewhiffle Township
description: W Hoke County.

label: Quhele
description: See Maxton.

label: Quick
description: community in W Caswell County originally known as Kill Quick. Post office est. there in 1898 closed 1909.

label: Quiet
description: community in N Moore County served by post office, 1883-1905. Ten mi. W was Noise, which see.

label: Quillaree Branch
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows SE into Straight Fork.

label: Quillen Mountain
description: on the Transylvania County, N.C.-Greenville County, S.C., line near the head of Pole Ridge Branch.

label: Quincy
description: community in N Onslow County served by post office, 1893-1903.

label: Quinerly
description: community in S Pitt County.

label: Quinine
description: community in S Randolph County served by post office, 1890-1921.

label: Quinine Swamp
description: rises in NW Bertie County and flows SE into Roanoke River.

label: Quinn Creek
description: rises in W Cherokee County and flows NW into Shoal Creek.

label: Quinn's Ferry
description: See Irvinsville.

label: Quioccosin Swamp
description: rises in N central Bertie County and flows NW into Stony Creek.

label: Quitsna
description: community in SW Bertie County. Name formerly spelled Quitonoi, a Tuscarora Indian word meaning "strong and mighty."

label: Quonutka Creek
description: See Quankey Creek.

label: Quoracks River
description: See Trent River.

label: Quotankney Creek
description: See Contentnea Creek.

label: Rabbit Creek
description: rises in E Macon County and flows SW into Lake Emory.

label: Rabbit Mountain
description: E Macon County between Cat Creek and Rabbit Creek.

label: Rabbit Mountain
description: W Montgomery County between Lick Mountain and Cedar Creek.

label: Rabbit Ridge
description: W Haywood County on Caldwell Fork.

label: Rabbit Shuffle
description: community in central Caswell County. Named because the land was said to be so poor that "a rabbit had to shuffle to get his rations."

label: Rabbits Crossroads
description: community in SW Chatham County approx. 3¼ mi. W of Bonlee.

label: Rabbitskin Branch
description: rises in central Haywood County and flows N into Pigeon River.

label: Raby Bend
description: in Little Tennessee River in N Macon County.

label: Raccoon Bay
description: in Currituck Sound off the W shore of Currituck Banks, E Currituck County.

label: Raccoon Branch
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows N into East Fork [South Fork New River].

label: Raccoon Creek
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows N into Richland Creek.

label: Raccoon Creek
description: rises in N Stokes County and flows SW into Snow Creek.

label: Raccoon Key
description: an island in Pamlico Sound in N end of Carteret County.

label: Raccoon Mountain
description: W Polk County. Alt. approx. 2,000.

label: Raccoon Ridge
description: W Avery County.

label: Raccoon Swamp
description: rises in SE Johnston County and flows S into Neuse River.

label: Race Prong
description: rises in NE Nash County and flows SE into Beaverdam Swamp.

label: Rachel
description: community in SW Randolph County served by post office, 1890-1926.

label: Rackley Mill Pond
description: See McLamb Mill Pond.

label: Radder Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NE into Worm Creek.

label: Radford Crossroads
description: community in E Johnston County.

label: Radical
description: community in N Wilkes County between Chestnut and Herald Mountains.

label: Radio Island
description: land mass between Morehead City and Beaufort, S Carteret County. Takes name from commercial radio station formerly operating on the island.

label: Raeford
description: town and county seat, central Hoke County. Settled 1867; inc. 1901. Took its name from the last syllables of two of the town's founders, J. A. MacRae and A. A. Williford. Produces textiles, lumber, concrete, rubber; processes poultry, and cotton. Alt. 262.

label: Raeford Township
description: central Hoke County.

label: Raft Swamp
description: rises in S Hoke County and flows SE into central Robeson County, where it enters Lumber River. Much Tory activity during the Revolution was centered there, and the name is frequently mentioned in records of the time.

label: Raft Swamp Township
description: central Robeson County.

label: Rag Creek
description: rises in N McDowell County and flows approx. 2 mi. SE into Cox Creek.

label: Ragged Point
description: central Onslow County, extends into N Morgan Bay.

label: Raglins Ferry
description: See Mush Island.

label: Ragsdale Creek
description: rises in central Buncombe County and flows SE into Hominy Creek.

label: Raider Camp Creek
description: rises in SE Avery County and flows SE into Caldwell County, where it enters Harper Creek.

label: Raider Camp Ridge
description: SE Avery County.

label: Rail Cove
description: NE Cherokee County at the head of Rail Cove Branch.

label: Rail Cove Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SW and NE into Ingram Branch.

label: Railroad Pond
description: E Anson County SE of Lilesville. Covers approx. 4 acres; max. depth 12 ft. Formed early in the twentieth century when gravel was removed from the site.

label: Rainbow Banks
description: steep bank of the Roanoke River, N Martin County between Poplar Point on the E and Hamilton on the w. Mentioned in an act of the General Assembly in 1729 and appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Rainbow Creek
description: rises in S Greene County and flows NE into Contentnea Creek. The name appears in local records as early as 1730.

label: Rainbow Falls
description: in SW Transylvania County on Horsepasture River. Height of falls is 200 ft.

label: Rainbow Gap
description: on the Buncombe-Yancey county line between Blackstock and Potato Knobs. Alt. approx. 5,860.

label: Rainbow Islands
description: areas of fine, sandy loam surrounded by swamp in E Washington County SW of the community of Scuppernong.

label: Rainbow Lake
description: in S Transylvania County on Middle Creek near its junction with East Fork French Broad River. Covers 2 acres and has a max. depth of 20 ft. Used for recreation.

label: Rainbow Springs
description: community in SW Macon County on Pat Stable Branch.

label: Raines Crossroads
description: community in E Johnston County.

label: Raines Mountain
description: Transylvania County between Carson Creek and Dunn Creek.

label: Rainey Knob
description: SW Transylvania County between Thompson River and Horsepasture River.

label: Rakahak
description: See Rockyhock Creek.

label: Raleigh
description: city, county seat, and state capital, central Wake County on Neuse River. Made county seat in 1771 and known as Wake Court House until the site was selected as the state capital in 1792 and named for Sir Walter Raleigh (1552?-1618), English statesman who sent the first English colonists to Roanoke Island. Inc. 1794. The legislature met at Wake Court House in 1781 and has met in Raleigh since 1794. Alt. 363. Now includes former communities of Oberlin and Caraleigh, which see, and West Raleigh.
