Home of North Carolina State University, Meredith College, Peace College, St. Mary's School, Shaw University, and St. Augustine's College. Produces farm machinery, bakery products, processed meat, paper products, fabricated metals, heavy equipment, textiles, dairy products, cottonseed oil, and printed products.

label: Raleigh Bay
description: in the Atlantic Ocean off the central coast of North Carolina from Cape Lookout on the S to Cape Hatteras on the N.

label: Raleigh Township
description: central Wake County.

label: Ram Branch
description: rises in central Buncombe County and flows NW into Swannanoa River.

label: Ramah Creek
description: rises in N Mecklenburg County and flows SE into Clarks Creek.

label: Ramey Creek
description: rises in NW Surry County and flows E into Roaring Fork.

label: Raminger Creek
description: rises in S Cherokee County and flows NE into Nottely River.

label: Ramoth
description: former town in central Buncombe County. Inc. 1889; name changed to Woolsey in 1903. Became a part of Asheville in 1905.

label: Ramp Branch
description: rises in N central Avery County and flows NE into Elk River.

label: Ramp Cove
description: NE Cherokee County in the Valley River Mountains. Named because ramps grow abundantly there.

label: Ramp Cove Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NW through Ramp Cove and Big Cove into Vengeance Creek.

label: Ramsaytown
description: community in N Yancey County on Cane River S of Sugarloaf Mountain. Alt. 2,141.

label: Ramseur
description: town in E Randolph County on Deep River. Known as Allen's Fall prior to 1878; named Columbia after 1878, when Deep River Mills est. Inc. 1895 as Ramseur in honor of Stephen D. Ramseur (1837-64), Confederate major general with whom William H. Watkins, one of the local mill owners, had been associated during the Civil War. Alt. 442.

label: Ramsey
description: community in S tip of Burke County on headwaters of Jacob Fork.

label: Ramsey Bend
description: in the Hiwassee River in central Cherokee County.

label: Ramsey Creek
description: rises in NW Northampton County and flows SE into Potecasi Creek.

label: Ramsey Gap
description: N Madison County at the head of Cascade Branch.

label: Ramsey Mountain
description: N Buncombe County N of Wolfpen Gap.

label: Ramsey's Mill
description: See Lockport.

label: Ramseytown Township
description: N Yancey County.

label: Ramsour's Mill
description: See Lincolnton.

label: Ramushawn River
description: appears on the Comberford map, 1657, in what is now Chowan County. Its identity is uncertain, but it lay between Yeopim River and Chowan River and may have been intended to represent the present Pembroke Creek.

label: Ranaleburg
description: community in SW Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1834-1902. Originally Randlesburg for Arthur Randolph Erwin, who opened a store and cotton gin there in 1834. Company B of 13th North Carolina Troops, known as "Ranalesburg Rifles," formed there during Civil War. Served by post office, 1851-1902.

label: Randall Gap
description: central Buncombe County near the headwaters of Ross Creek.

label: Randall Lake
description: on Big Creek in SE Macon County.

label: Randleman
description: town in N Randolph County on Deep River. First known as Dicks for Peter Dicks, who built a gristmill there approx. 1830; in 1848 a cotton mill was built there and the name changed to Union Factory. In 1866 the name was changed to Randleman for John B. Randleman, one of the owners of the mill. Inc. in 1880 as Randleman Mills; name changed to Randleman in 1889. Naomi Falls, low natural falls in Deep River, was there but now under the water behind a 25 ft. dam. Falls named for Naomi Wise, who was drowned there by Jonathan Lewis in 1808, giving rise to eponymous folk song.

label: Randleman Township
description: NW Randolph County.

label: Randolph
description: See Hinshaw.

label: Randolph County
description: was formed in 1779 from Guilford County. Located in the central section of the state, it is bounded by Chatham, Moore, Montgomery, Davidson, Guilford, and Alamance Counties. It was named for Peyton Randolph (1721?-75), president of the Continental Congress. Area: 801 sq. mi. County seat: Asheboro, with an elevation of 879 ft. Townships are Asheboro, Back Creek, Brower, Cedar Grove, Coleridge, Columbia, Concord, Franklinville, Grant, Level Cross, Liberty, New Hope, New Market, Pleasant Grove, Providence, Randleman, Seagrove, and Trinity. Produces wheat, corn, oats, poultry, dairy products, hay, barley, tobacco, nursery products, hogs, livestock, hosiery, apparel, textiles, tires, batteries, toys, furniture, shoes, and electric blankets.

label: Randolph Courthouse
description: community in W Randolph County served by post office, 1794-1810. Named changed to Asheboro, which see.

label: Randolph Mill
description: See Forest Hill.

label: Rands Mill
description: community in E Wake County near Swift Creek.

label: Rands Mill Pond
description: See Lake Benson.

label: Randys Store
description: community in N Montgomery County on Barnes Creek.

label: Ranger
description: community in S Cherokee County on Walker Mill Creek near Nottely River. Alt. approx. 1,565.

label: Rankin
description: community in S Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1888-1903.

label: Ranlo-Rex-Priscilla and Smyre Mills
description: an industrial community in E Gaston County between Lowell and East Gastonia. Textile-manufacturing plants operated there.

label: Ranns Falls
description: rapids in Cape Fear River in central Harnett County E of the town of Lillington. Mentioned as early as 1819 in a survey of the rivers of North Carolina.

label: Ransom Township
description: E Columbus County.

label: Ransom's Bridge
description: community at the junction of Nash, Franklin, Warren, and Halifax Counties; formerly thriving, but now sparsely settled. There is a bridge at the site over Fishing Creek. A post office by the name existed as early as 1822 and as recently as 1882. Was a center of gold-mining activity before the Civil War.

label: Ransomville
description: community in E Beaufort County at the head of North Creek. Named for Confederate general Matthew W. Ransom (1826-1904).

label: Rantersville
description: See LaGrange.

label: Raoul Branch
description: rises in S Buncombe County near the Biltmore Estate and flows SW into Four-mile Branch.

label: Rapid Creek Ridge
description: NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur extending S from Dashoga Ridge, lat. 35°39'10" N., long. 83°15' W.

label: Rapier Mill Creek
description: rises in SW Cherokee County and flows SE and NE into Nottely River.

label: Ratcliff Cove
description: central Haywood County, forms a semicircle on the head of a tributary of Raccoon Creek W of Ratcliff Mountain.

label: Ratcliff Mountain
description: central Haywood County between Bird Creek and Ratcliff Cove.

label: Rattan Bay
description: W Piney Island in NE Carteret County bounded by Neuse River and North, East, and South Bays. Approx. 1 mi. wide and ¾ mi. long.

label: Rattan Ridge
description: a strip of higher ground in the Dismal Swamp in SE Gates County.

label: Rattle Shoal Creek
description: rises in N Gaston County and flows NE into South Fork Catawba River.

label: Rattle Snake Creek
description: is formed in N Caswell County by the junction of North Fork of Rattle Snake Creek and South Fork of Rattle Snake Creek and flows N into Dan River.

label: Rattle Snake Island
description: a small tidal-marsh island in Currituck Sound off the SE shore of the mainland of Currituck County.

label: Rattler Branch
description: rises in E Cherokee County and flows NW into Valley River.

label: Rattler Ford
description: across Santeetlah Creek in W Graham County.

label: Rattlesnake Branch
description: rises in NW Columbus County and flows W then N into Horsepen Creek.

label: Rattlesnake Branch
description: rises in NW McDowell County on the S slope of Woods Mountain and flows SE approx. 1 mi. into Little Buck Creek.

label: Rattlesnake Cliff
description: mountain in E Swain County between Hayes Ridge and Hickorynut Knob. Alt. 4,950.

label: Rattlesnake Creek
description: rises in W Pender County and flows SE into Whiteoak Creek.

label: Rattlesnake Knob
description: NE Cherokee County in the Valley River Mountains.

label: Rattlesnake Knob
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on the SW end of Long Drive Ridge, lat. 35°33'07" N., long. 83°23'50" W. Alt. 4,311.

label: Rattlesnake Mountain
description: on Jackson-Swain county line near the head of Owl Branch.

label: Rattlesnake Pocosin
description: S Duplin County on Island Creek.

label: Rattlesnake Ridge
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur extending NW from Welch Ridge, lat. 35°30'55" N., long. 83°37' W.

label: Raven Cliff Branch
description: rises in N Haywood County and flows NW into Cold Springs Creek.

label: Raven Cliff Ridge
description: SE Haywood County between Bell Collar Cove and Little Buckeye Cove.

label: Raven Cliffs
description: on the Avery-Mitchell county line.

label: Raven Den
description: peak in N Swain County on Locust Ridge near the head of Bee Gum Branch. Alt. 4,247.

label: Raven Fork
description: rises in SW Yancey County and flows NE into Cane River.

label: Raven Fork [Oconaluftee River]
description: NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, is formed by the junction of Left Fork [Raven Fork] and Right Fork [Raven Fork] and flows SW into Oconaluftee River. See also Straight Fork.

label: Raven Hollow
description: S Haywood County between Beartrap Knob and Beartrap Ridge.

label: Raven Knob
description: See Raven Mountain.

label: Raven Knob Pond
description: NW Surry County on an unnamed tributary of Fisher River. Covers 15 acres; max. depth 20 ft. Formed in 1950. Fishing, boating, and swimming. Owned by Old Hickory Council, Boy Scouts of America.

label: Raven Mountain
description: on the Macon-Swain county line near the head of Cold Spring Branch. Alt. approx. 4,700. Sometimes also known as Raven Knob.

label: Raven Ridge
description: NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, lat. 35°40' N., long. 83°17' W.

label: Raven Rock
description: NE Swain County at the S end of Hyatt Ridge between Raven Fork and Straight Fork.

label: Raven Rock State Park
description: in Harnett County W of Lillington. Named for rock cliffs overlooking Cape Fear River. Covers 4,667 acres. Est. 1969. Recreational area with hiking, canoeing, and camping.

label: Raven Rocks
description: peak in S Watauga County on the head of China Creek approx. 2 mi. NW of town of Blowing Rock. Alt. 3,913.

label: Raven Roost Ridge
description: NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur extending NW from Chiltoskie Ridge, lat. 35°36'08" N., long. 83°12'55" W.

label: Ravencliff Mountain
description: E Haywood County between Crab Orchard Fields and Rush Fork Gap.

label: Ravenel Lake
description: SE Macon County near the head of Cullasaja River 2 mi. NW of Highlands. Approx. 2 mi. long. The body of water is probably the Stewart's Pond visited by Bradford Torrey and described in the Atlantic Monthly, September 1897.

label: Ravenrock Ridge
description: SE Clay County between Left Fork and Right Fork [Eagle Creek].

label: Ravens
description: community in NE Swain County served by post office, 1889-1915. Also spelled Ravins.

label: Ravensford
description: community in E Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Raven Fork near where it enters Oconaluftee River. Alt. 2,100.

label: Ravenswood
description: community in S Jones County.

label: Ravins
description: See Ravens.

label: Rawlingsburgh
description: community in E Rockingham County served by post office, 1821-55 and 1859-66. Named for postmaster William Rawlings.

label: Rawls
description: community in N Harnett County.

label: Ray
description: community in S Madison County served by post office, 1883-1908. Named for first postmaster.

label: Ray Branch
description: rises in W Macon County and flows NE into Deweese Branch.

label: Ray Cove
description: N Buncombe County between Ray Knob and Reems Creek.

label: Ray Knob
description: N Buncombe County between Horse Gap and Vance Knob.

label: Ray's Branch
description: rises in NE Wake County near the Franklin County line and flows S into Neuse River.

label: Ray's Mill Creek
description: rises at the town of Southern Pines in S Moore County and flows SW into Aberdeen Creek at the town of Aberdeen.

label: Raymond Island
description: off of W side of Currituck Banks in Currituck Sound S of South Channel, NE Currituck County.

label: Raymond's Creek
description: rises in S Camden County and flows SW into Pasquotank River. Named for William Raymond, who was granted land bordering the creek on February 25, 1696. Earlier called Fleming's Creek for George Fleming, who owned a small tract along the creek and died there in 1694.

label: Rayner Millpond
description: W Wayne County on a tributary of Beaverdam Creek.

label: Raynham
description: community in S Robeson County. Alt. 125. Settled about 1884. Named for the parish in Norfolk, England, from which the local Townsend family had migrated.

label: Raynor
description: community in S Franklin County.

label: Raynor Pond
description: on Mingo Swamp in SW Johnston County and E Harnett County.

label: Raynor Swamp
description: rises in S Gates County and flows NW to join Harrell Swamp and Duke Swamp in forming Bennetts Creek. Recorded as Meherrin Swamp in eighteenth-century land grants and deeds.

label: Raynors Lake
description: a crescent-shaped lake on Cypress Creek in SE Duplin County.

label: Rays Creek
description: rises in W Franklin County and flows NE into Cedar Creek.

label: Rays Fork
description: rises in E Union County and flows NW into Richardson Creek.

label: Raywood
description: community in W Union County served by post office, 1858-1903.

label: Razo Creek
description: See Resoe Creek.

label: Razor Mountain
description: N Buncombe County between Poverty Branch and Martin Creek.

label: Razorback Ridge
description: W Avery County.

label: Reading
description: See Elizabeth City.

label: Ready Branch
description: rises in S Martin County and flows SE into Statons Pond on Sweetwater Creek.

label: Readybranch
description: community in SW Wilkes County near the head of Naked Creek. A post office operated there, 1876-1935.

label: Reas Beach
description: See Albemarle Beach.

label: Reasonover Creek
description: rises in SE Transylvania County and flows NE then N into Little River.

label: Reasonover Lake
description: in SE Transylvania County in Reasonover Creek. Covers 16 acres and has a max. depth of 22 ft.

label: Reatkin River
description: See Yadkin River.

label: Reaves
description: community in N Cumberland County.

label: Reba
description: See Fountain.

label: Rebels Creek
description: rises in central Mitchell County and flows SW into North Toe River.

label: Rector Branch
description: rises in W Madison County and flows NE into Big Pine Creek.

label: Rector Butte
description: W Madison County near the head of Rector Branch.

label: Rector Knob
description: E central Burke County. Alt. 2,153.

label: Rector Knob
description: S Macon County between Cadon Branch and Cadon Gap.

label: Red Branch
description: rises in E Cabarrus County and flows E into Dutch Buffalo Creek.

label: Red Bug
description: community in SW Brunswick County.

label: Red Creek
description: See Clear Creek.

label: Red Cross
description: community in SW Stanly County. Inc. 2002.

label: Red Hill
description: community in N Sampson County between Merkle Swamp and Great Coharie Creek.

label: Red Hill Creek
description: rises in W Surry County and flows SE and NE into Fisher River.

label: Red Hill Knob
description: central Madison County. Alt. 3,180.

label: Red Hill Swamp
description: the lower course of Brown Marsh Swamp, which see. The name is applied at the Bladen-Columbus county line, and it flows S across Columbus County. At the junction with Western Prong, the name is changed to White Marsh, which see.

label: Red Hill Township
description: W central Mitchell County.

label: Red Horse Creek
description: See Worley Cove Branch.

label: Red House
description: community in NE Caswell County. Post office, 1806-49. Named for Red House Presbyterian Church, where Rev. Hugh McAden, eighteenth-century missionary, preached and is buried.

label: Red Log Gap
description: N Cherokee County at the SW end of State Ridge. Alt. 3,697.

label: Red Marble Gap
description: at the head of Rowlin Creek on the Graham-Macon county line. Alt. approx. 2,750.

label: Red Mountain
description: See Rougemont.

label: Red Oak
description: town in N Nash County. Settled about 1880 and named for a grove of red oaks at the site. Inc. 1961. Alt. 225.

label: Red Oak Cove
description: NW Haywood County on the head of Low Gap Branch in Great Smoky Mountains National Park.

label: Red Oak Knob
description: N Buncombe County near the Madison County line.

label: Red Oak Township
description: N central Nash County.

label: Red Ridge
description: NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur extending E from Twentymile Ridge, lat. 35°29'40" N., long. 83°48'10" W.

label: Red Ridge Gap
description: NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Twenty-mile Ridge between Lost Cove Creek and Coldspring Branch, lat. 35°29'52" N., long. 83°48'47" W.

label: Red Rock Ridge
description: N Avery County.

label: Red Run
description: rises in E central Brunswick County and flows SE to join Pinch Gut Creek in forming Lockwoods Folly River.

label: Red Shoals
description: community in E central Stokes County. A post office est. there in 1813 continued through 1920.

label: Red Sour
description: mountain in NW Cleveland County.

label: Red Springs
description: town in N Robeson County. Alt. 204. Inc. 1896 but settled much earlier. At the site of former Flora MacDonald College there, Vardell Hall, a school for girls, was est. in 1964 and operated for 10 years. The town was named for the color of spring and well water there, which was red because of iron oxides. Known first as Dora but changed to Red Springs in 1885. Formerly a popular health resort. Produces textiles, fertilizer, and lumber products.

label: Red Springs Township
description: NW Robeson County.

label: Red Store Crossroads
description: community in W Duplin County.

label: Red Town
description: See Deep Run.

label: Redallia
description: community in S Pitt County.

label: Redbank Branch
description: rises in W Haywood County and flows NW into Richland Creek.

label: Redbank Creek
description: rises in N Stokes County and flows S into Dan River.

label: Redbanks
description: community in W Robeson County. Alt. 179. Pembroke Farms there est. 1938 by the Farm Security Administration as a cooperative under a 99-year lease. Descendants of several members of the cooperative still operate the farms there. Redbanks is named for the relatively high clay banks of nearby Lumber River.

label: Redbud Creek
description: rises in NE Franklin County and flows E into Nash County, where it enters Sandy Creek. Formerly known as Redbud Swamp.

label: Redbud Creek
description: rises in W Vance County and flows SW into Ruin Creek. Named for the abundance of redbud trees (Cercis canadensis) in the area.

label: Redbug
description: community in central Columbus County.

label: Redcross
description: community in N Randolph County.

label: Reddick Branch
description: See Reddix Branch.

label: Reddick's Creek
description: rises in S Guilford County. Gold mine operated by John Lowder was on its banks ca. 1820.

label: Reddies River
description: community in W Wilkes County on Reddies River. The area was settled prior to the Revolutionary War.

label: Reddies River Township
description: central Wilkes County.

label: Redding
description: See Elizabeth City.

label: Redding Mountain
description: E Wilkes County N of Flat Rock Creek.

label: Reddix Branch
description: rises in S Mitchell County near Swafford Gap and flows W into East Fork Grassy Creek. Said to have been named for the Reddix family, which camped near its head. While there, two of their children died of colic and were buried at the head of the stream. Recent maps have used the form Reddick.

label: Reddy Branch
description: rises in NW Madison County and flows S into Shelton Laurel Creek.

label: Redland
description: community in N Davie County. Originally known as Bethlehem community for a Methodist church (on the site of Old Timber Ridge Meeting House, where Moravian ministers preached as early as 1773). When a post office was est. there in 1892, the name Bethlehem could not be used, as it was already in use elsewhere in the state. Redland was chosen as descriptive of the soil thereabouts. Post office closed 1906. Alt. 875.

label: Redman Creek
description: is formed in NE Swain County by the confluence of Left Fork and Right Fork and flows SW into Bunches Creek.

label: Redman Ridge
description: NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a spur extending SW from Balsam Mountain, lat. 35°34'15" N., long. 83°12' W.

label: Redmans Cove
description: S Buncombe County SW of Hogback Ridge.

label: Redmans Old Field
description: appears on the Collet map, 1770, as open ground on the N side of Cokey Swamp, which see, W central Edgecombe County S of Tarboro.

label: Redmon
description: community in SE Madison County. Inc. 1897; charter repealed 1899. Alt. 1,603.

label: Redmond Creek
description: a tidal stream on the W side of Eagles Island in the Cape Fear River, NE Brunswick County.

label: Redstone Point
description: on the mainland of N Dare County extending into Croatan Sound. The William B. Umstead Bridge, approx. 3 mi. long and opened on December 22, 1956, extends from the point to Weir Point on NW Roanoke Island; named for Governor William B. Umstead (1895-1954).

label: Redwood
description: community in E Durham County on Neuse River. Est. 1890. Named for red oaks growing in the vicinity. Flourished, 1895-1917. Following the removal of a lumber mill during World War I, the community declined.

label: Reece Mountain
description: E Lincoln County near Killian Creek.

label: Reed Branch
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows NE into Savannah Creek.

label: Reed Cove
description: E Haywood County on N side of Fork Mountain. Reed Creek flows W through the cove.

label: Reed Creek
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows W into Pisgah Creek.

label: Reed Creek
description: rises in E Stokes County and flows E into Rockingham County.

label: Reed Gold Mine
description: former gold mine in E central Cabarrus County W of community of Georgeville. Gold was found there in 1799, and the discovery of a 28-lb. nugget set off a gold rush. Mine was the site of the first authentic discovery of gold in the state. Named for John Reed, on whose farm the discovery was made. Now a State Historic Site.

label: Reed Marsh
description: rises in S Nash County and flows SW into Haw Branch.

label: Reed Misenheimers Township
description: See Earnhardt's Township.

label: Reed's Landing
description: See Great Neck Landing.

label: Reeders Creek
description: rises in S Greene County and flows E into Tyson Marsh.

label: Reeds Creek
description: rises in S Iredell County and flows S into Mecklenburg County, where it enters Davidson Creek.

label: Reeds Crossroads
description: community in W Davidson County at the head of Beaverdam Creek.

label: Reeds Hammock
description: an island in Pamlico River, SE Beaufort County; approx. ½ mi. long and 2/10 mi. wide. See also The Ditch.

label: Reeds Point
description: a point extending from the mainland of NE Dare County into Croatan Sound.

label: Reedy
description: community in NW Davidson County served by post office, 1870-1903.

label: Reedy Branch
description: rises in N Johnston County and flows SW into Little Branch.

label: Reedy Branch
description: rises in W Wake County and flows SW into Beaver Creek.

label: Reedy Creek
description: rises in SW Cabarrus County and flows NE into Rocky River.

label: Reedy Creek
description: community in NW Davidson County.

label: Reedy Creek Bay
description: an arm of Big Colly Bay in NE Bladen County.

label: Reedy Creek State Park
description: former park in NW Wake County est. in 1,234 acres in 1943 for blacks. Consolidated in 1965 with William B. Umstead State Park, which see.

label: Reedy Creek Township
description: NW Davidson County.

label: Reedy Fork
description: See Reedy Creek.

label: Reedy Fork Creek
description: rises in E Caswell County and flows NE into North Hyco Creek.

label: Reedy Glade
description: a branch, rises in E Craven County and flows E into Broad Creek.

label: Reedy Island
description: an elevated sand and loam area approx. ¼ mi. wide and ¼ mi. long in E Duplin County approx. 2 mi. SE of community of Hadley.

label: Reedy Meadow Creek
description: rises in W Bladen County and flows W into Bryants Pond on Black Swamp.

label: Reedy Patch Creek
description: rises in E Henderson County and flows NE into Broad River.

label: Reedy Patch Gap
description: E Henderson County near the head of Reedy Patch Creek. Alt. 2,242.

label: Reedy Pocosin
description: the NW section of Big Pocosin, SW Beaufort County.

label: Reedy Swamp
description: rises in E Robeson County and flows S into Ten Mile Swamp.

label: Reelsboro
description: community in W Pamlico County. Named for the local Reel family.

label: Reems Branch
description: rises in S Madison County and flows SE into Ponder Branch.

label: Reems Creek
description: See Weaverville.

label: Reems Creek Township
description: N central Buncombe County.

label: Reepsville
description: community in W central Lincoln County.

label: Reese
description: community in NW Watauga County on Little Beaverdam Creek. Est. before 1900. Alt. 3,320.

label: Reese Creek
description: rises in E Cumberland County and flows SW into Lords Creek.

label: Reeves
description: community in S Columbus County.

label: Refuge
description: community in W Robeson County served by post office, 1893-1903.

label: Regal Station
description: a stop on the Southern Railway in central Cherokee County.

label: Regans Crossroads
description: community in W Brunswick County.

label: Registers Creek
description: rises in S Guilford County and flows SE into Hickory Creek.

label: Rehoboth
description: community in S Northampton County on Quarter Swamp. Grew up around Rehoboth Methodist Church, est. 1798.

label: Reid
description: community in SW Transylvania County near the head of South Fork Flat Creek. Alt. 2,725.

label: Reid's Springs
description: See Catawba Springs.

label: Reids Mountain
description: SE Rowan County near Yadkin River at the mouth of Flat Creek.

label: Reidsville
description: city in S Rockingham County. In 1814 Reuben Reid purchased a farm and his son, future governor David Settle Reid, was appointed first postmaster in 1829. In 1864 Piedmont Railroad was completed between Greensboro and Danville, boosting Reidsville. Following the war, the town became a center of tobacco manufacturing. In time, textiles became a major factor. Post office est. in 1829. Inc. 1873. Alt. 841. Appears on the Colton map, 1861.

label: Reidsville Township
description: SE Rockingham County.

label: Reinhardt
description: community in E Lincoln County served by post office, 1888-1904.

label: Reinhardt Gap
description: on the Haywood-Jackson county line. Alt. 5,440.

label: Reinhart Knob
description: on the Haywood-Jackson county line. Alt. 6,100.

label: Relief
description: community in W Mitchell County on Toe River. Alt. 2,092. Named for the patent medicine Hart's Relief, a popular product with a high alcoholic content sold at John Peterson's store there after about 1870.

label: Rella
description: community in N Stokes County served by post office, 1894-1904.

label: Rena
description: community in W Yadkin County on South Deep Creek.

label: Rendezvous Mountain
description: W central Wilkes County between the heads of Purlear and Cole Creeks. Alt. 2,450. Named for the fact that militiamen from the area are believed to have gathered there to drill and that it is the traditional rendezvous site for troops that assembled before marching to the Battle of Kings Mountain, October 7, 1780. In 1926 Judge Thomas B. Finley and his wife gave the state 142 acres there for a state park. Now an Educational State Forest operated by the North Carolina Forest Service.

label: Renfro Knob
description: W Yancey County between Hardscrabble Branch and Nubbinscuffle Creek.

label: Rennert
description: community in N Robeson County. Inc. 1895; charter repealed 1947. Known as McAlpin's Grove until the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad was constructed; the name was then changed, probably to honor someone connected with the railroad. James McAlpin, for whom the community was first named, is said to have been a Scottish officer in the British army during the American Revolution. After the war, he remained in North Carolina, taking an oath of allegiance to the United States and becoming a schoolteacher in the community that came to bear his name.

label: Rennert Township
description: N Robeson County.

label: Rennys Creek
description: rises in S Craven County and flows NE into Neuse River.

label: Renston
description: community in SW Pitt County. Alt. 67.

label: Repose
description: community in S Lenoir County served by post office, 1887-1909.

label: Reps Martin Island
description: 14-acre sandy island in Yadkin River, NE Yadkin County.

label: Republican
description: community in W central Bertie County. Named for the Republican Baptist Church there. The name derived from the fact that the church was a public meeting place for the neighborhood.

label: Resaca
description: community in NE Duplin County served by post office, 1853-1916. Named for Mexican War Battle of Resaca de la Palma.

label: Research Triangle Park
description: a 5,000-acre tract in SE Durham and W Wake Counties. Industrial and governmental research facilities operate there in a campus-like setting. Years of planning preceded opening of first businesses in 1959. Prospects boosted by est. of IBM facility in 1964. Duke University, the University of North Carolina, and North Carolina State University loaned startup expertise and give continuing support. Success of park has made it a national and international model.

label: Reservoir Branch
description: rises in NW Madison County and flows E into Spring Creek.

label: Resoe Creek
description: rises in central Pender County and flows S into Rileys Creek. Also known as Razo and Rizzo Creek.

label: Resolution Branch
description: rises in N Jones County and flows S into Trent River.

label: Resootskeh
description: a Tuscarora Indian village in Bertie County on Indian Creek that appears on the Moseley map, 1733. Site was the base of "King Blount," the friendly Indian chief who aided the whites during the Tuscarora Indian War, 1711-13. The modern Tuscarora spelling of the word is Resootska, meaning "to our grandfather."

label: Rest
description: community in central Stanly County served by post office, 1883-1907.

label: Retreat
description: community in S Haywood County between Inman Branch and West Fork Pigeon River. Also known as Riverside, the name of the local Baptist church.

label: Reuben
description: community in NE Union County.

label: Reuben Creek
description: rises in E Mitchell County and flows SW into Little Rock Creek.

label: Reuben Mountain
description: W Stokes County at the head of East Prong Little Yadkin River.

label: Revere
description: community in central Madison County on Revere Creek.

label: Revere Creek
description: rises in central Madison County and flows NW into Big Laurel Creek.

label: Revis Branch
description: rises in N Buncombe County and flows NW into S Madison County, where it enters Ivy River.

label: Revolution
description: former community in central Guilford County. Est. 1899. Named because the textile plant est. there was expected to revolutionize the cotton-manufacturing industry. Now within Greensboro city limits.

label: Rex
description: community in NE Robeson County.

label: Rex
description: See Ranlo-Rex-Priscilla.

label: Reynolda Lake
description: seminatural lake on Silas Creek on Reynolda Estate near the Wake Forest University campus in central Forsyth County. Covers 25 acres, with a max. depth of 15 ft. Used for fishing, boating, swimming, and irrigation. Not open to the public.

label: Reynolds Cove
description: NW Buncombe County NE of Rocky Knob.

label: Reynolds Gap
description: S Macon County between the head of Ball Creek and the head of Dryman Fork.

label: Reynoldson
description: community in N Gates County. Reynoldson School operated there prior to the Civil War to prepare boys for Wake Forest College. The school was opened in 1856 and operated into the twentieth century.

label: Reynoldson Township
description: NW Gates County.

label: Rhea Branch
description: rises in N Cherokee County in Rhea Cove and flows SE and S into Valley River.

label: Rhea Cove
description: N Cherokee County at the head of Rhea Branch.

label: Rheasville
description: community in N Halifax County on Quankey Creek.

label: Rhems
description: community in W Craven County. Alt. 38. Est. prior to 1900 as Debruhls, named for a local family. Post office was est. in 1898, closed 1907.

label: Rhinehardt Creek
description: rises in N Macon County and flows NE into Little Tennessee River.

label: Rhoades Academy
description: community in S Wayne County between Thoroughfare Swamp and Beaverdam Creek.

label: Rhodarme Cove
description: E Haywood County on the head of Kems Branch.

label: Rhode Branch
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows SE into Savannah Creek.

label: Rhodes
description: community in central Duplin County.

label: Rhodes Creek
description: rises in E Orange County and flows NE into Eno River.

label: Rhodes Mill Creek
description: rises in S Catawba County and flows SE into Pott Creek.

label: Rhodes Point
description: central Onslow County in Farnell Bay in Camp Lejeune Marine Corps Air Station.

label: Rhodestown
description: community in E Onslow County.

label: Rhodhiss
description: town on Burke-Caldwell county line near the E extremity of Burke County. Settled 1875. Inc. 1903. Alt. 965. Named in 1902 for John Rhodes and George Hiss, who est. a cotton mill there. The town is divided by the Catawba River, and at one time the portion in Burke County was known as Cliffs. Produces textiles.

label: Rhodhiss Lake
description: on the Catawba River, Burke and Caldwell Counties. Formed 1924-25. Covers 3,515 acres, with a shoreline of 90 mi. Owned by Duke Power Co. and site of hydroelectric power plant.

label: Rhodo
description: community in N Cherokee County. According to local tradition, it was named for the "raw dough" biscuits once served at a local boardinghouse.

label: Rhody Franklin Mountain
description: N Madison County between Shelton Laurel Creek and the head of Martin Branch.

label: Rhyne
description: See Daniels-Rhyne.

label: Rhynes Crossroads
description: community in W central Pender County.

label: Ricahokene
description: a village of Weapemeoc Indian tribe in what is now S Perquimans County on Perquimans River. Shown on the White map, 1585; appears as Rickahock on the Comberford map, 1657. The name survives in adjoining Chowan County as Rockyhock, which see.

label: Rice Branch
description: rises in central Madison County and flows SW into Ammons Branch.

label: Rice Cove
description: E Haywood County on the head of Rice Cove Creek.

label: Rice Cove Creek
description: rises in N central Madison County and flows N into Big Laurel Creek.

label: Rice Creek
description: rises in SW Beaufort County and flows N into Chocowinity Bay of Pamlico River.

label: Rice Gap
description: N central Transylvania County between Shutin Ridge and Lamb Creek.

label: Rice Island
description: in SE Bertie County between Roanoke River and Eastmost River. A large swampy island, it measures almost 2½ mi. from tip to tip and is approx. 1 mi. wide at its greatest width. See also Purchace Islands.

label: Rice Knob
description: central Buncombe County between Craven Gap and Roaring Gap.

label: Rice Path
description: site of early settlement on E end of Bogue Banks in S Carteret County. A vessel, laden with a cargo of rice, went aground there at one time. The people on the sound side made a path across the banks to the ocean side to get the rice, and so they called it Rice Path. Storms drove out early settlers until settlement of Salter Path, which see.

label: Rice Pinnacle
description: S Buncombe County at the N end of Stradley Mountain.

label: Rices Creek
description: rises in SE Brunswick County and flows N into Town Creek.

label: Rices Pocosin
description: a swamp in central Greene County.

label: Riceville
description: community in N Buncombe County on Bull Creek, which see. Named for family of pioneer settlers. Served by a post office, 1876-1906.

label: Rich Branch
description: rises in N Mitchell County and flows E into Spring Creek.

label: Rich Cove
description: between Laurel Mountain and Big Creek in NW Henderson County.

label: Rich Fork Creek
description: rises in NE Davidson County and flows SW into Abbotts Creek.

label: Rich Gap
description: in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on the Swain County, N.C.-Blount County, Tenn., line between Gregory Bald and Forge Knob, lat. 35°31'45" N., long. 83°51'14" W.

label: Rich Gap Mountain
description: NW Henderson County on Laurel Mountain between Johnson Knob and Black Mountain.

label: Rich Hammock
description: a name applied on the Moseley map, 1733, to a neck of land (apparently especially suitable for cultivation) extending into North River, S Carteret County E of present town of Beaufort.

label: Rich Hill
description: community in E Alleghany County.

label: Rich Hill Creek
description: rises in W Ashe County and flows SE into North Fork New River.

label: Rich Inlet
description: SE Pender County, from Topsail Sound into Atlantic Ocean. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Rich Island Gut
description: N central Carteret County, flows N into South River.

label: Rich Knob
description: on the Haywood-Madison county line.

label: Rich Knob
description: S Mitchell County between South Fork [Carvers Branch] and North Fork [Grassy Creek].

label: Rich Mountain
description: in SE Macon County between Big Creek and Rich Gap.

label: Rich Mountain
description: an extended ridge beginning at town of Boone in central Watauga County and running NW to head of Sharp Creek, N Watauga County, then NE to its highest point, Rich Mountain Bald, which see, before ending at Rich Mountain Gap. Named for its unusually fertile though rugged slopes.

label: Rich Mountain
description: community on N side of mountain of same name in E Jackson County where Sugar Creek enters Caney Fork.

label: Rich Mountain Bald
description: N Watauga County on Rich Mountain. Alt. 5,372.

label: Rich Mountain Creek
description: rises in S Alleghany County and flows W into Bullhead Creek on the Alleghany-Wilkes county line.

label: Rich Mountain Gap
description: N Watauga County between Rich Mountain and Snake Mountain. Cove Creek rises on its W slope, and Meat Camp Creek rises on its E slope. Alt. 4,420.

label: Rich Neck
description: See Wilkinson Point.

label: Rich Ridge
description: W Madison County near the head of Jones Branch.

label: Rich Square
description: town in S Northampton County. Inc. 1869. Alt. 78. Settled about 1750 by Quakers from Virginia. Meeting organized in 1753 and Meeting House completed in 1760. A deed in 1761 to Thomas Hunter refers to "a tract of land called rich square," probably referring to the fertility of the soil. Appears as Richsquare on the Price map, 1808. Inc. 1883. Produces apparel.

label: Rich Square Township
description: SE Northampton County.

label: Rich Top
description: mountain in E Haywood County between Harbon Cove and Silvers Cove Creek.

label: Richards
description: See Crown Stream.

label: Richards Mill
description: on the Collet map, 1770, was located on a tributary of the Pasquotank River in what is now N Pasquotank County. The stream was located approx. 12 to 15 mi. NW of the present Knobbs Creek but has long since left its streambed to become a part of the surrounding marsh.

label: Richardson
description: community in SW Bladen County.

label: Richardson Creek
description: community in N Union County on the E side of Richardson Creek.

label: Richey Gap
description: S Macon County between Buck Knob and Richey Knob.

label: Richey Knob
description: S Macon County between Sheep Hollow and Middle Creek.

label: Richfield
description: community in N Stanly County. Alt. 661. Inc. 1899. Named for local Ritchie family.

label: Richland Balsam
description: a peak on the Haywood-Jackson county line 8 mi. S of town of Waynesville. Alt. 6,540, the highest point on Balsam Mountain, which see.

label: Richland Creek
description: rises in S Rutherford County S of Oakland and flows SE into Broad River.

label: Richland Creek
description: rises in W central Wake County near Asbury and flows N into Crabtree Creek.

label: Richland Gap
description: at the SW end of Piney Mountain Ridge in E Jackson County.

label: Richland Knob
description: N Buncombe County on Richland Mountain in Pisgah National Forest.

label: Richland Lake
description: central Guilford County formed by dam on Richland Creek. Built in 1943 by Cone Mills and used for industrial and municipal purposes.

label: Richland Mountain
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a ridge extending SE from Charlies Bunion between Kephart Prong and Bradley Fork, lat. 35°36'47" N., long. 83°20'30" W. Alt. approx. 5,600.

label: Richland Mountains
description: NE Rutherford County along Sally Queen Creek. There are several named peaks in the range.

label: Richland Swamp
description: rises in S Hoke County and flows SE into Robeson County, where it enters Big Raft Swamp.

label: Richland Township
description: S central Randolph County.

label: Richlands
description: town in NW Onslow County between New River and Mill Swamp. Alt. 64. Settled approx. 1775; inc. 1880. Named for fertile soil of the region. Former home of Richlands Academy (1848-1904); it served as the educational center of Jones and Onslow Counties. Produces lumber. Known as Upper Richlands until it was inc. in 1880.

label: Richlands Township
description: NW Onslow County.

label: Richmond
description: See Bear Creek.

label: Richmond County
description: was formed in 1779 from Anson County. Located in the S central section of the state, it is bounded by the state of South Carolina and by Anson, Stanly, Montgomery, Moore, and Scotland Counties. It was named for Charles Lennox (1735-1806), third Duke of Richmond, military officer, ambassador, and secretary of state who denounced British policy toward the American colonies. Area. 483 sq. mi. County seat: Rockingham, with an elevation of 211 ft. Townships are Beaverdam, Black Jack, Marks Creek, Mineral Springs, Rockingham, Steeles, and Wolf Pit. Produces cotton, corn, wheat, oats, peaches, poultry, hogs, livestock, textiles, paper, furniture, hosiery, and lumber.

label: Richmond Creek
description: See Richland Creek.

label: Richmond District
description: one of the districts into which Caswell County was divided at the time of the 1790 census. It contained 253 heads of families.

label: Richmond Hill
description: community on the outskirts of Burlington, central Alamance County.

label: Richmond Hill
description: community in N Yadkin County. Home of Richmond Pearson (1805-78), chief justice of North Carolina Supreme Court; he conducted a law school at his home, "Richmond Hill," which has been restored.

label: Richmond Millpond
description: NW Scotland County on Gum Swamp Creek. Formed prior to 1800 and known until 1893 as Malloys Pond for Charles Malloy, original owner. Covers 75 acres; max. depth 18 ft. Named because it was located in Richmond County when it was formed.

label: Richmond Mills
description: community in W Scotland County on Gum Swamp Creek.

label: Richneck Creek
description: rises in SW Warren County and flows E into Fishing Creek.

label: Richs Gap
description: W Avery County.

label: Rickman Creek
description: rises in N Macon County and flows SE into Matlock Creek.

label: Ricks Branch
description: rises in SE Cherokee County and flows SE into Little Brasstown Creek.

label: Ricks Creek
description: rises in NW Duplin County and flows SW into Goshen Swamp.

label: Ricky Knob
description: central Haywood County between Ned Branch and the head of Hemphill Creek.

label: Rico
description: community in N Columbus County.

label: Riddick Crossroads
description: community in W Gates County.

label: Riddicksville
description: community in NE Hertford County near Chowan River. Known as Maney's Ferry until 1825 for the Maney family, which had lived there since about 1750. The site was acquired by Adam Riddick in 1825 and the present name adopted soon afterward.

label: Riddie Cove
description: W Haywood County on Big Spring Branch.

label: Riddle
description: community in S Camden County. A post office est. there 1884 as Bray for Dempsey Bray, first postmaster, who removed to another community after two years. Renamed for Charles Riddle (1862-89), local schoolmaster, and operated until 1939.

label: Riddle Branch
description: rises in NW Yancey County and flows SE into Bald Mountain Creek.

label: Riddle Creek
description: rises in N Watauga County and flows S into Meat Camp Creek.

label: Riddles Creek
description: rises in SE Rutherford County and flows S into Broad River.

label: Ridenhour Township
description: NW Stanly County.

label: Riders Creek
description: rises in N central Tyrrell County near community of Levels and flows SW and NW into Scuppernong River.

label: Riders Creek Community
description: See Levels.

label: Ridge
description: See South Gastonia.

label: Ridge Creek
description: rises in NW Alamance County and flows SE into Haw River.

label: Ridge Spring
description: See Scuffletown.

label: Ridge's Mountain
description: W Randolph County between Uwharrie River and Caraway Creek; a long, rather low, ridge.

label: Ridgecrest
description: community in SE Buncombe County. Alt. 2,530. Southern Baptist summer assembly grounds are there.

label: Ridgepole Mountain
description: S Macon County between Little Ridgepole Mountain and Gulf Branch. Alt. 5,008.

label: Ridgeville
description: community in SE Caswell County. Known as Pea Ridge until 1875, when the present name was adopted for the ridge on which it is located. Alt. 750.

label: Ridgeway
description: community in W Warren County. Alt. 422. Inc. 1869; charter repealed 1879. Grew up around a series of inns, the first of which was Colers Ordinary, shown on the Collet map, 1770. By 1800 Charles Marshall had a tavern there; portions of the original building still exist in a local dwelling. In 1816 John Paschall operated a tavern there, and the community was known as Paschalls, the name under which it appears on the MacRae map, 1833. The present name was used when a post office was est. there in 1839; it is said to be derived from the ridge on the N edge of the community on which a railway was built. After the Civil War, a development company induced immigrants from Germany, Alsace, France, Switzerland, and England to settle there.

label: Riegelwood
description: community in NE Columbus County near the Cape Fear River. Developed around the Riegel Paper Corporation after it began production in 1951.

label: Riggsbee
description: community in NE Chatham County served by post office, 1858-1915. Known as Riggsbee's Store until 1894.

label: Riggsbee's Store
description: See Riggsbee.

label: Right Fork
description: rises in NE Cherokee County in the Valley River Mountains and flows N into Bear Branch.

label: Right Fork Bean Creek
description: rises in N Mitchell County and flows S to join Left Fork Bean Creek in forming Bean Creek.

label: Right Fork Belews Creek
description: See East Belews Creek.

label: Right Fork Cove Creek
description: rises in central Haywood County and flows SE into Cove Creek.

label: Right Fork Davidson River
description: rises in NW Transylvania County and flows SE into Davidson River.

label: Right Fork Webb Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County near Old Billy Top and flows SW and S to join Left Fork Webb Creek in forming Webb Creek.

label: Right Fork [Cane Creek]
description: is formed in E Mitchell County by the junction of Mine Fork Branch and Stagger Weed Creek and flows NW to join Left Fork [Cane Creek] in forming Cane Creek.

label: Right Fork [Cold Spring Branch]
description: rises in W Swain County and flows NW into Cold Spring Branch near its confluence with Hazel Creek.

label: Right Fork [Eagle Creek]
description: rises in SE Clay County and flows NW to join Left Fork [Eagle Creek] in forming Eagle Creek. Known also as Dave Barrett Creek.

label: Right Fork [Indian Creek]
description: rises in N Swain County and flows SW to join Left Fork [Indian Creek] in forming Indian Creek.

label: Right Fork [Pigeonroost Creek]
description: rises in W Mitchell County and flows SW into Pigeon-roost Creek.

label: Right Fork [Raven Fork]
description: rises in NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows SW to join Left Fork and Middle Fork in forming Raven Fork [Oconaluftee River]. See also McGee Spring.

label: Right Fork [Redman Creek]
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows SW to join Left Fork [Redman Creek] in forming Redman Creek.

label: Right Fork [Wesser Creek]
description: rises in N Macon County and flows NE into Swain County, where it enters Wesser Creek.

label: Right Hand Fork
description: See Right Fork.

label: Right Hand Prong [Pigeon River]
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows NE into Middle Prong.

label: Right Prong Bent Creek
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows SE to join Left Prong Bent Creek in forming Bent Creek.

label: Right Prong Martin Creek
description: rises in S Cherokee County and flows E into Martin Creek.

label: Right Prong South Toe River
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows E to join Left Prong South Toe River in forming South Toe River.

label: Right Prong Three Forks Creek
description: rises in SE Yancey County and flows W to join Left Prong Three Forks Creek in forming Three Forks Creek.

label: Right Prong [Ledge Creek]
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows NW into Ledge Creek.

label: Riles Creek
description: rises in SE Rowan County and flows SE into Stanly County, where it turns NE back into Rowan County and enters Yadkin River. The Kerr map, 1882, shows the stream as Loyal Creek.

label: Riley
description: community in S Franklin County. Post office there, 1873-1911, known as Rileys Cross Roads.

label: Riley Cove
description: E Clay County between Chunky Gal Mountain and Buck Creek.

label: Riley Knob
description: E Macon County between Higdon Mountain and Ledford Branch.

label: Rileys Creek
description: rises in central Pender County and flows SW into Long Creek.

label: Rileys Cross Roads
description: See Riley.

label: Rimer
description: community in N Cabarrus County; known also as Rimertown.

label: Ring Fire Knob
description: SE Wilkes County between Little Hunting Creek and Osborne Creek. Alt. approx. 1,300.

label: Ringstaff Mountains
description: range in the Cane Creek Mountains, S Alamance County.

label: Ringwood
description: town in SW Halifax County. Inc. 1877, but long inactive in municipal affairs. A number of homes there date from the early nineteenth century.

label: Rio
description: community in S central Transylvania County.

label: Rio Jordan
description: See Cape Fear River.

label: Rip Shin Mountain
description: N Caldwell County. Alt. 2,200.

label: Ripley
description: former town on the W outskirts of Hendersonville in central Henderson County. Inc. 1909; charter repealed 1917.

label: Rippetoe Mountain
description: S Caldwell County. Alt. 1,298. Named for William Rippetoe, who received the mountain in a land grant.

label: Rippys Township
description: former township in S Cleveland County, now township no. 3.

label: Ripshin Mountain
description: SW Buncombe County N of Mount Pisgah.

label: Ripshin Ridge
description: NW Burke County, extends from SE to NW between Steels Creek and Upper Creek. Alt. 2,875.

label: Risden
description: See Rufus.

label: Ritter
description: former community in W Swain County on Tuckasegee River. Site now under the waters of Fontana Lake.

label: Ritters Township
description: N central Moore County.

label: River Acres
description: community in central Beaufort County on the N shore of Pamlico River.

label: River Bend
description: community in NE Gaston County near Mountain Island Lake at the steam power-generating plant of the Duke Power Co.

label: River Bend Township
description: NE Gaston County.

label: River Hill
description: community in E Iredell County served by post office, 1875-1907.

label: River Neck
description: community in NW Tyrrell County near the mouth of Scuppernong River. Alt. 2. Formerly called Devenport.

label: River Neck Landing
description: NW Tyrrell County on the E side of mouth of Scuppernong River.

label: River Side
description: community on South Fork New River in SW Ashe County. Alt. approx. 2,950.

label: River Swamp
description: rises in SE Brunswick County and flows NW into Lockwoods Folly River.

label: River Township
description: NE Warren County.

label: River View Community
description: SE Columbus County; formerly known as Crusoe Island. Renamed by resolution of the General Assembly, 1961. A marshy and sandy section between the Waccamaw River and the Columbus-Brunswick county line, it lies on the edge of Green Swamp, which see. It was named Crusoe Island by outsiders because of its isolation. French political refugees, who first settled in Haiti, are said to have arrived there in 1806; their descendants still live there. Roads now penetrate the area.

label: Riverdale
description: community in E Craven County. Settled 1878 and named because of its location near Neuse River.

label: Riverside
description: community in S Macon County on Little Tennessee River.

label: Riverside
description: See Retreat.

label: Riverside Park
description: community in central Beaufort County on the N shore of Pamlico River.

label: Riverton
description: community in E Scotland County on Lumber River. A summer resort used by residents of nearby towns and their descendants. Subject of John Charles McNeill's poetry.

label: Rizzo Creek
description: See Resoe Creek.

label: Roachs Creek
description: rises in central Rockingham County and flows W into Dan River. Named for Roach family, gristmill operators.

label: Road Ridge
description: E Mitchell County at the head of Bear Creek.

label: Roan Creek
description: rises in E Ashe County and flows NW into South Fork New River.

label: Roan High Bluff
description: NE Mitchell County on Roan Mountain. Alt. 6,267.

label: Roan High Knob
description: on the Mitchell County, N.C.-Carter County, Tenn., line. Alt. 6,286.

label: Roan Island
description: a silt island in S Pender County approx. 4 mi. long and 1½ mi. wide; surrounded by Cape Fear River, Thoroughfare, and Black River.

label: Roan Mountain
description: NE Mitchell County, extends NE into Tennessee. Alt. approx. 6,200. Probably named for its roan (reddish) color when seen from a distance in the rhododendron blooming season. Site of Rhododendron Festival each June.

label: Roan Valley
description: parallel to Fall Creek in E Mitchell County.

label: Roanes Mill
description: community in S Macon County served by post office, 1878-1912.

label: Roanoac
description: an Indian village formerly near the N tip of Roanoke Island, E Dare County; the site is now submerged in the waters of Albemarle Sound. Appears on the White maps of 1585 and 1590.

label: Roanoak Town
description: See Carteret.

label: Roanoke
description: See Poplar Point.

label: Roanoke Canal
description: constructed between 1817 and 1823 and extended between 1824 and 1834 to bypass the Upper and Lower Falls of Roanoke River in N Halifax County. The canal, built by the Roanoke Navigation Company, provided a series of locks that made uninterrupted navigation of the river possible. The locks raised and lowered vessels 44 ft. from the basin to the river and could accommodate boats weighing from 30 to 50 tons. With the completion of the Raleigh and Gaston Railroad and its junction with Seaboard Railroad about 1841, the canal began a decline and was no longer used by 1865. Chockoyotte Creek Viaduct and other remnants remain.

label: Roanoke County
description: was proposed as the name for the SE portion of Halifax County in 1868, when there was a move to divide the county. A manuscript map of Roanoke County made by M. L. Venable is in the North Carolina Collection at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

label: Roanoke Inlet
description: former inlet from the Atlantic Ocean into Roanoke Sound through Bodie Island S of the present location of Nags Head, NE Dare County. Inlet was the original N boundary of Bodie Island. Opened prior to 1657 and closed in 1795, according to a note on the Kerr map, 1882. Appears on the Ogilby map, 1671.

label: Roanoke Island
description: approx. 11 mi. long and 2¼ mi. wide, E Dare County; it is separated by Roanoke Sound from Bodie Island (Outer Banks) on the E and from the mainland by Croatan Sound on the w. Site of Fort Raleigh, center of English exploration and settlement, 1584-87. Name believed to be of Algonquian Indian origin signifying "northern people" or "northerners," referring to the fact that the Indians lived on the N end of the island or that they had earlier migrated from an ancestral home in the n. The name Roanoke also came to be applied to shell beads. Site of freedman's colony, 1865. Fort Raleigh National Historic Site is on the N end of the island. See also Manteo; Carteret.

label: Roanoke Marshes
description: extensive string of low marsh islands in Croatan Sound, E central Dare County stretching from SW end of Roanoke Island to a large marshy area on the mainland. Site of a beacon est. approx. 1875; last of manually operated lights along the coast replaced by automatic beacon in 1955. The islands for the most part have washed away. Shown on the Collet map, 1770, as Daniels Marshes. Unnamed but shown prominently on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Roanoke Rapids
description: city in N Halifax County on the Roanoke River. Founded in 1893 by John Armstrong Chaloner (1862-1935) as a cottonmill site and named for the rapids in the river. Inc. 1897. Originally known as Great Falls. Produces paper and textiles. Alt. 169.

label: Roanoke Rapids Dam
description: See Lake Gaston.

label: Roanoke Rapids Lake
description: is formed by a dam near the city of Roanoke Rapids in NE Halifax County on Roanoke River. The lake extends NW along the Halifax-Northampton county line to Gaston Dam. The dam there was completed in 1955, and the lake covers 4,900 acres, with a shoreline of 47 mi. and a max. depth of 90 ft. Built by Virginia Electric and Power Company to generate hydroelectric power, the lake is also used for recreation. See also Lake Gaston.

label: Roanoke Rapids Township
description: N Halifax County.

label: Roanoke River
description: is formed in Montgomery County, Va., by the junction of North Fork and South Fork and flows SE into North Carolina in NE Warren County. It flows across a corner of Warren and along the Halifax-Northampton, Halifax-Bertie, Bertie-Martin, and Bertie-Washington county lines into Batchelor Bay of Albemarle Sound. The John H. Kerr Dam on Roanoke River in Virginia creates Kerr Lake, a part of which is in Granville, Vance, and Warren Counties. Appears as Morattico River on the Comberford map, 1657, and as Noratake River on the Ogilby map, 1671. The Moseley map, 1733, specifies Roanoke River.

label: Roanoke Sea
description: See Albemarle Sound.

label: Roanoke Sound
description: between Roanoke Island and the Outer Banks in E Dare County. Known in the eighteenth century as Sanderson's Channel for Richard Sanderson, local landowner. The name Walter Rawleigh appears there on the Collet map, 1770, though it is uncertain whether it was intended to represent the name of the sound. See also Albemarle Sound.

label: Roanoke Township
description: NE Warren County.

label: Roaring Branch
description: rises in S Mitchell County and flows NW into Crabtree Creek.

label: Roaring Creek
description: See Valley.

label: Roaring Creek Township
description: SW Avery County.

label: Roaring Fork
description: rises in W Madison County and flows NE into Meadow Fork.

label: Roaring Fork
description: rises in SE Yancey County and flows N into Three Forks Creek.

label: Roaring Fork Creek
description: rises in W Macon County and flows SW into Nantahala River.

label: Roaring Fork Mountain
description: W Madison County parallel to Roaring Fork.

label: Roaring Fork Ridge
description: SW Macon County between Roaring Fork Creek and the head of Rough Fork.

label: Roaring Gap
description: community in SE Alleghany County. Est. in 1890 as a summer resort by Alexander Chatham of Elkin, who bought land there and built the first house. Named for the fact that wind is said to rush with a roar through a gap there. Alt. 3,800. Now popular site for summer homes.

label: Roaring River
description: community in E central Wilkes County on Yadkin River at the mouth of Roaring River. Alt. 934. Settled about 1770. Inc. 1905; charter repealed 1907. A post office est. there in 1872.

label: Roaring Spout Creek
description: rises in E Yancey County and flows E into Browns Creek.

label: Roaring Spout Falls
description: on Roaring Spout Creek, E Yancey County.

label: Robbins
description: town in N Moore County on Bear Creek. Known as early as 1828 as Mechanicks Hill and Mechanicsville for David Kennedy, local mechanic and gunsmith. Later known as Elise, and inc. 1935 as Hemp. Name changed in 1943 to Robbins for Karl Robbins, owner of a local mill. Alt. 424.

label: Robbinsville
description: town and county seat, central Graham County. Alt. 2,150. Post office est. 1874. Town authorized to be laid out in 1872 as Robbinsville for local Robbins family. Inc. in 1893 as Robinsville; name changed in 1897 to Robbinsville. Produces carpets and lumber.

label: Robedo
description: community in central Montgomery County served by post office, 1903-1907.

label: Roberdel
description: town in central Richmond County on Hitchcock Creek. Settled approx. 1850; inc. 1889. Named for Robert L. Steele, textile manufacturer. Alt. 246.

label: Roberdo
description: community in S Montgomery County.

label: Roberson Ridge
description: S Haywood County between Bearpen Branch and Deep Gap Creek.

label: Roberson Store
description: community in SE Martin County on Harrison Mill Creek. Settled about 1898 and known as Amherst until after 1920. Alt. 75.

label: Robersonville
description: town in W Martin County. Settled before the Civil War. Inc. 1870 and named for Henry D. Roberson, local landowner and Confederate veteran. Alt. 78. Produces processed poultry and apparel.

label: Robersonville Township
description: SW Martin County.

label: Robert Branch
description: rises in S Madison County and flows N into French Broad River.

label: Robert Gap
description: on the Haywood-Madison county line.

label: Roberta
description: community in W Cabarrus County that grew up around Pattersons Mill, a name by which it was once known.

label: Roberts Branch
description: rises in S Cleveland County and flows E into Buffalo Creek. Named for "Squire Billy" Roberts, owner of the land through which it ran.

label: Roberts Cove
description: in E Haywood County on the head of Rush Fork.

label: Roberts Creek
description: rises in N Lee County and flows NE into Hughes Creek.

label: Roberts Crossroads
description: community in W Franklin County.

label: Robertson Creek
description: rises in S central Granville County and flows S into Beaverdam Creek near the Granville-Wake county line.

label: Robertson Mountain
description: N Jackson County between Locust Creek and Mill Creek.

label: Robertsons Pond
description: E Wake County on Buffalo Creek. Formed in 1900. Covers 65 acres, with a max. depth of 15 ft. Used for recreation and as power source.

label: Robeson County (ROB-uh-son)
description: was formed in 1787 from Bladen County. Located in the SE section of the state, it is bounded by the state of South Carolina and by Scotland, Hoke, Cumberland, Bladen, and Columbus Counties. It was named for Col. Thomas Robeson (1740-85), Revolutionary War officer. Area: 948 sq. mi. County seat: Lumberton, with an elevation of 137 ft. Triracial population with roughly equal numbers of African Americans, Native Americans (principally Lumbee), and Caucasians. Townships are Alfordsville, Black Swamp, Britts, Burnt Swamp, East Howellsville, Fairmont, Gaddy, Lumber Bridge, Lumberton, Marietta, Maxton, Orrum, Parkton, Pembroke, Philadelphus, Raft Swamp, Red Springs, Rennert, Rowland, Saddletree, St. Pauls, Shannon, Smiths, Smyrna, Sterlings, Thompson, Union, West Howellsville, and Wishart. Produces tobacco, corn, soybeans, wheat, oats, cotton, poultry, hogs, turkeys, tomatoes, cabbage, eggs, livestock, onions, tomatoes, lumber, soup, textiles, packaging, and apparel.

label: Robeson Creek
description: rises in central Chatham County and flows E into Haw River.

label: Robeson Point
description: See Robinson Point.

label: Robey's Camp Ground
description: See Rock Springs.

label: Robin Branch
description: rises in W Wilson County and flows NE and N into Black Creek.

label: Robinson Cove
description: the valley through which Robinson Creek flows in NW Buncombe County.

label: Robinson Creek
description: rises in E Rutherford County and flows SW into Second Broad River.

label: Robinson Gap
description: S central Swain County between Bucknor Branch and Cochran Branch.

label: Robinson Mountain
description: NW Buncombe County between Earlies Gap and High Knob.

label: Robinson Point
description: See Cedar Island Point.

label: Robinson Rough
description: mountain on the Buncombe-Madison county line between Norton Fork Gap and Davidson Gap.

label: Robinson's Ferry
description: See Monroe.

label: Robinwood Lake
description: SE Gaston County on Anthony Creek. Formed 1947. Covers 35 acres. Max. depth 25 ft. Swimming, fishing, boating.

label: Robson Branch
description: rises in central Avery County and flows S into Plumtree Creek.

label: Robson Station
description: community in central Orange County.

label: Roby Creek
description: rises in SE Yadkin County and flows E into Turner Creek.

label: Rochdale
description: town authorized to be laid out in Richmond County (now W Scotland County) in 1816 on the land of John Marine and others on or near Joes Creek. Apparently, the town was never laid out.

label: Rock
description: community in S Rowan County served by post office, 1883-1906.

label: Rock Branch
description: rises in N Madison County and flows SW into Shelton Laurel Creek.

label: Rock Branch
description: See Olivia.

label: Rock Camp Branch
description: rises in NW Swain County and flows E into Roaring Creek.

label: Rock Camp Run
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows NW into Straight Fork.

label: Rock Creek
description: rises in SE Caldwell County and flows E into Upper Little River.

label: Rock Creek
description: community in central Alamance County served by post office, 1849-1923.

label: Rock Creek
description: See Greens Mill Run.

label: Rock Creek Gap
description: E Mitchell County on Rock Creek Mountain.

label: Rock Creek Knob
description: W Graham County between Deep Creek and Rock Creek.

label: Rock Creek Mountain
description: E Mitchell County at the head of Little Rock Creek.

label: Rock Creek Township
description: E central Wilkes County.

label: Rock Fish
description: See Juford.

label: Rock Fork
description: rises in N Swain County and flows SE into Right Fork [Deep Creek].

label: Rock Fork Branch
description: rises in SE Person County and flows SW into Deep Creek.

label: Rock Gap
description: SW Macon County at the head of Little Rock Branch.

label: Rock Hole Creek
description: rises in SW Stanly County and flows SE into Rocky River. Called Cucumber Creek on the Kerr map, 1882.

label: Rock Hollow
description: E Haywood County between Soapstone Gap and Sheep Mountain.

label: Rock Hollow Branch
description: rises in Rock Hollow in E Haywood County and flows NW into Crabtree Creek.

label: Rock House
description: See Sweezy Mountain.

label: Rock House Creek
description: rises in S Rockingham County and flows N into Dan River. Mentioned in local records as early as 1767.

label: Rock Landing
description: formerly a landing and supply point on Roanoke River in N Halifax County constructed before 1818 for the purpose of landing stone and building supplies to be used in the construction of Roanoke Canal, which see.

label: Rock Level
description: community in N Rockingham County served by post office, 1878-1903. Also spelled Rocklevel.

label: Rock Point
description: S Carteret County, extends N from central Bogue Banks W of community of Salter Path.

label: Rock Rest
description: community in SE Union County served by post office, 1888-1900.

label: Rock Ridge
description: community in W Wilson County near Marsh Swamp. Post office named Taylor served the community, 1882-1914; named for J. M. Taylor.

label: Rock Run
description: See Telfairs Creek.

label: Rock Spring
description: community in W Orange County served by post office, 1845-1905. Spelled Rockspring after 1894.

label: Rock Springs
description: community in N Polk County.

label: Rockbrook Camp Branch
description: rises in S central Transylvania County and flows NW through Rockbrook Camp into French Broad River.

label: Rockdale
description: community in NE Cleveland County.

label: Rockdam Creek
description: rises in S Lincoln County and flows NE into Howards Creek.

label: Rockett
description: community in NE Catawba County. Est. 1886 as Roseman, but the name was changed in 1902 when a post office was est. Post office discontinued in 1903. Both names were for local families.

label: Rockfield Creek
description: rises in central Graham County and flows SW into Santeetlah Lake.

label: Rockfish
description: See Hope Mills.

label: Rockfish Creek
description: rises in SE Moore County E of town of Aberdeen and flows SE across Hoke County into Upchurch Pond on the W Cumberland County line. From the pond, it flows E across Cumberland County to enter Cape Fear River 1½ mi. E of community of Grays Creek. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Rockfish Township
description: SW Duplin County.

label: Rockford
description: town in S Surry County on Yadkin River. Est. 1790 as the county seat and so remained until 1851, when the county was divided and the county seat removed to Dobson. Alt. 838. Inc. 1819, but long inactive in municipal affairs.

label: Rockford Township
description: S central Surry County.

label: Rockhouse Branch
description: rises in SW Madison County and flows E into Sugar Camp Branch.

label: Rockhouse Creek
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows SE into Caldwell County.

label: Rockhouse Knob
description: S Macon County between Long Ridge and Wolfpen Gap. Alt. 3,100. A weather station there has recorded in various years the greatest amount of rainfall E of the Rocky Mountains.

label: Rocking Chair Branch
description: rises in S Clay County and flows S into Shooting Creek.

label: Rockingham
description: town and county seat, W Richmond County. Courthouse est. at site 1779 and known as Richmond Court House until 1784, when it was named for Charles Watson-Wentworth (1730-82), second Marquis of Rockingham, British advocate of American independence. Manufactures textiles, paper, apparel, and processes poultry. See also East Rockingham; West Rockingham. Alt. 211.

label: Rockingham County
description: was formed in 1785 from Guilford County. Located in the N central section of the state, it is bounded by the state of Virginia and by Caswell, Guilford, and Stokes Counties. It was named for Charles Watson-Wentworth (1730-82), second Marquis of Rockingham, prime minister at the time of the repeal of the Stamp Act, and supporter of proposals to grant independence to the American colonies. Area: 572 sq. mi. County seat: Wentworth, with an elevation of approx. 900 ft. Townships are Huntsville, Leaksville, Madison, Mayo, New Bethel, Price, Reidsville, Ruffin, Simpsonville, Wentworth, and Williamsburg. Produces tobacco, corn, wheat, oats, hay, strawberries, dairy products, hogs, livestock, beer, apparel, textiles, hosiery, bricks, carpets, cigarettes, and other tobacco products.

label: Rockingham Lake
description: privately owned lake built 1939 on tributary of Lower Hogans Creek, Rockingham County.

label: Rockingham Township
description: W central Richmond County.

label: Rocklevel
description: See Rock Level.

label: Rockrace Branch
description: rises in E Transylvania County and flows NE into Cascade Lake (Little River).

label: Rocks, The
description: a great seawall constructed by the U.S. government, 1879-85, to close off New Inlet between the Atlantic Ocean and the Cape Fear River in S New Hanover County.

label: Rockspring
description: See Rock Spring.

label: Rockstack
description: a mountain on the Graham County, N.C.-Monroe County, Tenn., line.

label: Rockview
description: community in N Buncombe County near the junction of Martin Creek and North Fork Ivey Creek. Alt. 2,394.

label: Rockville
description: See Rockwell.

label: Rockwell
description: town in S Rowan County. Early travelers from Salisbury to Cheraw and Camden, S.C., enjoyed good water from a rock well there, hence the name. A post office est. there 1838 as Millville, changed to Rockville in 1839 and to Rockwell in 1872. Inc. 1911. Alt. 785.

label: Rocky Bald
description: W Macon County between the head of Holloway Branch and Wine Spring Creek. Alt. 5,333.

label: Rocky Branch
description: rises in S Chatham County and flows SE into Deep River.

label: Rocky Branch
description: rises in central Macon County and flows NE into Little Tennessee River.

label: Rocky Branch
description: rises in E Watauga County and flows NW into South Fork New River.

label: Rocky Branch Ridge
description: SW Haywood County parallel to Rocky Branch.

label: Rocky Broad River
description: See Broad River.

label: Rocky Butte Mountain
description: E Jackson County near the head of Chastine Creek.

label: Rocky Cove
description: W Macon County on a tributary of Nantahala River.

label: Rocky Cove Branch
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows SW into Hominy Creek.

label: Rocky Cove Knob
description: SW Macon County at the SW end of Rocky Cove.

label: Rocky Creek
description: rises in S Iredell County between Troutman and Oswalt and flows SW into Catawba River.

label: Rocky Creek
description: See Stony Creek.

label: Rocky Face
description: N Jackson County between Rocky Face Branch and Cane Creek. Alt. approx. 3,575.

label: Rocky Face Branch
description: rises in N Jackson County on SE slopes of Rocky Face and flows S into Wayehutta Creek.

label: Rocky Face Knob
description: on the Jackson-Macon county line.

label: Rocky Face Mountain
description: S Swain County extends NE from the head of Jenkins Branch to the forks of Kirkland Creek.

label: Rocky Face Ridge
description: N Jackson County between Wayehutta Creek and Cane Creek.

label: Rocky Ford
description: community in N Franklin County.

label: Rocky Ford Branch
description: rises in NW Wilson County and flows E and NE into Town Creek.

label: Rocky Ford Creek
description: rises in SW Cherokee County and flows NW into Polk County, Tenn., where it enters Ocoee River.

label: Rocky Fork
description: rises in SE Buncombe County near Jesses High Top and flows SW into Cane Creek.

label: Rocky Fork
description: rises in S Lee County and flows W into Crane Creek.

label: Rocky Fork Creek
description: rises in N Richmond County and flows SW into Falling Creek.

label: Rocky Fork Ridge
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, lat. 35°35'20" N., long. 83°25'55" W.

label: Rocky Glen
description: See Catawba Falls.

label: Rocky Hill
description: See Medoc Mountain.

label: Rocky Hollow
description: W Watauga County between Laurel Creek and Watauga River.

label: Rocky Knob
description: SE Buncombe County between Sand Branch and Rush Branch.

label: Rocky Knob
description: S central Haywood County on the head of Peter Cove Branch.

label: Rocky Knob
description: W Watauga County between Watauga River and School House Branch.

label: Rocky Knob
description: See Haw Knob.

label: Rocky Knob Creek
description: rises in E Watauga County and flows NW into South Fork New River.

label: Rocky Knob Gap
description: between Wolf Creek and Tanasee Creek in E Jackson County.

label: Rocky Knob Ridge
description: E Macon County between Dalton Creek and Tippet Creek.

label: Rocky Knobs
description: two knobs S of Horsepasture River, SW Transylvania County.

label: Rocky Mount
description: city in E Nash and W Edgecombe Counties. Est. 1816; inc. 1867. Named for the rocky mounds and ledges on the site near the falls of the Tar River. Home of North Carolina Wesleyan College. Produces tobacco, furniture, and fabricated metals. Alt. 121.

label: Rocky Mount
description: See Bear Poplar.

label: Rocky Mount Township
description: SE Nash County.

label: Rocky Mountain
description: E central Watauga County between Rocky Branch and Rocky Knob Creek.

label: Rocky Pen Ridge
description: central Cherokee County, extends NE from Nottely River to Hiwassee River near Murphy.

label: Rocky Point
description: community in S Pender County. Alt. 39. Inc. 1905; charter repealed 1945. Name applied to the area by Barbadian explorers in 1663 for an unusual outcropping of rock near Lane's Ferry in the otherwise flat country. The community was settled in the late eighteenth century. Clayton Hall, home of Francis Clayton, native of Scotland and member of the Wilmington Safety Committee, 1774, was there. Produces lumber. See also Lillington County.

label: Rocky Point Township
description: S central Pender County.

label: Rocky Ridge
description: S Madison County parallel to Little Pine Creek.

label: Rocky River
description: rises in NE Randolph County and flows SW across Chatham County into Deep River.

label: Rocky River Springs
description: See Silver.

label: Rocky River Township
description: former township in SW Cabarrus County, now township no. 1.

label: Rocky Run
description: rises in SE Alamance County and flows SW into Hobby Branch.

label: Rocky Run
description: rises in E Onslow County and flows NW into Little Northeast Creek.

label: Rocky Shoal Branch
description: rises in S Ashe County and flows SE into South Fork New River.

label: Rocky Spring Top
description: on the Cherokee-Graham county line in the Snowbird Mountains.

label: Rocky Springs
description: community in SW Rockingham County. Name in use during Revolutionary War when soldiers mustered there. A post office est. there 1810; closed 1905.

label: Rocky Springs Township
