description: SE Montgomery County.

label: Rocky Swamp
description: rises in W Halifax County and flows SE into Fishing Creek. Appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Rocky Top
description: on the Swain County, N.C.-Blount County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park between Mount Squires and Thunderhead Mountain.

label: Rockyface Mountain
description: S Macon County between Lee Creek and Jones Creek. Alt. approx. 4,500.

label: Rockyhock
description: community in central Chowan County. Alt. 28. For a possible origin of the name, see Rockyhock Creek.

label: Rockyhock Creek
description: rises in central Chowan County and flows SW into Chowan River. Appears as Rakahak on the Ogilby map, 1671, and as Rockyhock on the Moseley map, 1733. Name may be derived from an Indian village, Ricahokene, on the E side of Perquimans River at Albemarle Sound. It may have meant "where combs [rakes?] are made."

label: Rockyknob Mountain
description: W Yancey County between Dryspring Branch and Slickrock Mountain.

label: Rocquis Creek
description: See Roquist Creek.

label: Rod
description: community in E Iredell County served by post office, 1899-1905.

label: Rodanthe
description: community in E Dare County on Hatteras Island. Formerly known as North Rodanthe. A post office there operated as Chicamacomico until 1874, when it took present name.

label: Rodanthe S Curves
description: See S Curves.

label: Rodman's Creek
description: rises in W Beaufort County and flows E into Pamlico River.

label: Rodman's Point
description: near the mouth of Rodman's Creek, W Beaufort County on the S side of Pamlico River.

label: Rodney
description: community in NE Person County served by post office, 1898-1901.

label: Roduco
description: community in W Gates County near Flat Branch in Jones Swamp. Alt. 35.

label: Roe
description: community on Cedar Island in NE Carteret County. Alt. 12.

label: Rogers
description: or community in N Northampton County.

label: Rogers Branch
description: rises in central Haywood County and flows NW into Pigeon River.

label: Rogers Cove
description: E Haywood County on the head of Rogers Cove Creek.

label: Rogers Cove Creek
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows NW into Crabtree Creek.

label: Rogers Creek
description: rises in central Cherokee County and flows NW into Valley River.

label: Rogers Creek
description: See Beech Swamp.

label: Rogers Crossroads
description: community in E Wake County N of Powell Creek.

label: Rogers Gap
description: W Cherokee County between Wehutty Mountain and Shoal Creek.

label: Rogers Mountain
description: W Yancey County between Indian and Price Creeks.

label: Rogers Ridge
description: S Avery County.

label: Rogers Store
description: community in N central Wake County. Settled prior to 1840 and named for Col. Ransome Rogers, first storekeeper. Alt. 300.

label: Rogers Swamp
description: rises in N Northampton County and flows SE to join Corduroy Swamp in forming Kirbys Creek.

label: Rogues Creek
description: rises in NW Clay County and flows SW and SE into Rock House Creek.

label: Roland Branch
description: rises in W central Yancey County and flows SE into Cane River. Believed to have been named for a black settler. See also Roland Hollow; Roland Knob.

label: Roland Creek Canal
description: rises in NW Currituck County and flows E into Guinea Mill Run.

label: Roland Hollow
description: W central Yancey County on W side of Cane Mountain. Contains a tributary of Higgins Creek.

label: Roland Knob
description: W central Yancey County between head of Roland Branch and head of Bailey Branch approx. 2 mi. W of town of Burnsville. Alt. approx. 3,620.

label: Roland Ridge
description: E Haywood County parallel to Ugly Creek.

label: Rolesville
description: town in E Wake County near the head of Cedar Fork. Settled in the early nineteenth century and named for William Roles, original settler. Inc. 1837; reincorporated 1941.

label: Rollins
description: community in S Madison County on French Broad River.

label: Rollinson Channel
description: SE Dare County, provides access through Pamlico Sound from Hatteras Inlet to the town of Hatteras. Dredged to a depth of 10 ft.; 10 ft. wide.

label: Rollover Creek
description: rises in Great Dover Swamp in W Craven County and flows SE into Bachelor Creek.

label: Rome
description: community in S Johnston County served by post office, 1882-1904.

label: Rominger
description: community in W Watauga County on Laurel Creek. Named for Rev. W. Smith Rominger, a Methodist minister in whose home the first post office was est. in 1903.

label: Ronda
description: town in E Wilkes County on Yadkin River. Alt. 934. Inc. 1907. Est. on Col. Benjamin Cleveland's estate, "Roundabout," named for a sharp bend in Yadkin River there. The town's name is a shortened form of the plantation name. Produces furniture.

label: Rooks
description: community in W Pender County.

label: Roosevelt
description: community in NE Henderson County between Whiteside Mountain and Chickasaw Knobs. Named for President Theodore Roosevelt (1858-1919).

label: Rooty Branch
description: rises in E Craven County and flows E into Broad Creek.

label: Roper
description: town in N central Washington County on Kendricks Creek. Alt. 13. Settled in 1706 by Thomas Blount, who built a dam there. Upon his death, his widow married Col. Thomas Lee, who built a mill at the site; the designations "S. Lee, Saw Mills" appear on the Moseley map, 1733. The mill, which began operation in 1709, was destroyed in an explosion in 1921. The town served as county seat from 1800 to 1823 (see also Cabin Ridge Plantation). Post office est. 1802; post office name changed to Union in 1851. In 1820 the town of Duckettsville was authorized to be laid out there but never developed. Lees Mills was renamed Roper in 1889 for John L. Roper, who est. a lumber industry there, and the town was inc. in 1907.

label: Roper Knob
description: N Macon County between the head of Rose Creek and Little Tennessee River.

label: Roper Springs
description: community in NW Halifax County. A mineral spring there was the site of an Indian camp before the arrival of white settlers. A man named Roper later operated a tavern there, hence the name.

label: Roper's Knob
description: S Burke County. Alt. 2,200.

label: Roquist Creek
description: rises in W Bertie County and flows SE into Cashie River. Many spellings (Rocquis, Rakwis, Rocquist, Roquewhist, etc.) have been used in the past, but Roquist is the accepted spelling. The word is Tuscarora for "turtle." Mentioned in local records as early as 1723.

label: Roquist Pocosin
description: SW Bertie County.

label: Roscoe
description: community in central Chatham County served by post office, 1883-1926.

label: Rose
description: See Rosewood.

label: Rose Bay
description: community in S Hyde County at the head of Rose Bay.

label: Rose Branch
description: rises in W Nash County and flows S into Sapony Creek.

label: Rose Creek
description: rises in central Cherokee County and flows SE into Dockery Creek.

label: Rose Creek
description: rises in NE Yancey County near Chestnut Mountain and flows N into North Toe River.

label: Rose Hill
description: town in SW Duplin County. Alt. 89. Settled approx. 1847; inc. 1875. Named for wild roses growing in the vicinity. Produces hogs, lumber, poultry, and wine.

label: Rose Hill Township
description: SW Duplin County.

label: Rose Mountain
description: extends along NW Burke County. Alt. 2,600.

label: Rose Ridge
description: a spur of Big Yellow Mountain in W Avery County. Named for Rose family. Also called Hurricane Ridge.

label: Roseboro
description: town in W Sampson County. Inc. 1891 and named for George McNeil Rose (1846-1924), chief counsel of the Cape Fear and Yadkin Valley Railroad. Alt. 137. Owensville (Owenville post office), est. prior to 1839 on Little Coharie Creek a short distance W of the site of Roseboro, declined with the growth of Roseboro.

label: Roseborough
description: community in SE Avery County.

label: Rosebud
description: community in N Wilson County between the head of White Swamp and Cattail Swamp.

label: Rosedale
description: community in NE Pasquotank County. Settled prior to 1890.

label: Roseland
description: community in SW Moore County. Est. around 1896 as a rival resort to Southern Pines and Pinehurst. At one time there were a number of homes there, as well as a hotel, lake, stores, and a weekly newspaper, but now it is only a rural community.

label: Roseman
description: See Rockett.

label: Rosemary
description: former community in N Halifax County, now within the limits of Roanoke Rapids. Served by post office, 1902-32.

label: Rosemead
description: community in NE Bertie County served by post office, 1891-1905.

label: Rosemont
description: See Bertie.

label: Roseneath
description: community in S Halifax County served by post office, 1823-51.

label: Roseneath Township
description: SE Halifax County.

label: Roses Branch
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows SE into Straight Fork.

label: Roses Branch
description: community in central Mitchell County on Toe River.

label: Roses Creek
description: rises in NW McDowell County and flows SE between Pompey Ridge and Pups Ridge into Armstrong Creek.

label: Roses Gap
description: NE Swain County between Thicket Branch and Roses Branch in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°39'34" N., long. 83°13'29" W.

label: Roseville
description: community in SW Person County served by post office, 1889-1906. Named for Duncan Rose, local Tory leader during the Revolutionary War.

label: Rosewood
description: community in W central Wayne County. Formerly known as Rose. Alt. 133.

label: Rosin Hill
description: community in N Sampson County on Sevenmile Swamp. Named for the fact that rosin was produced in the pine forests there.

label: Rosindale
description: community in SE Bladen County. Alt. 120. Settled in 1866 by George C. McDougald, who produced turpentine and rosin (from which the name was taken).

label: Roslin
description: community in S Cumberland County served by post office, 1869-1903. Alt. 179.

label: Rosman
description: town in S Transylvania County on French Broad River between its junction with East Fork and North Fork. Named by industrialist J. S. Silverstern, who compounded the word from the names of two associates, Rosenthal and Ormansky. Inc. 1901 as Toxaway; name changed to Estatoe in 1903 and to Rosman in 1905. A NASA satellite-tracking station was built nearby in 1962. Produces lumber. Alt. 2,188.

label: Ross Creek
description: rises in central Buncombe County near Patton Mountain and flows S into Swannanoa River. Named for an early settler. Often called Chunn Cove Creek.

label: Ross Falls
description: former waterfalls (8.1 ft. drop in a distance of 0.9 mi.) in Catawba River a short distance N of the South Carolina state line in SW Mecklenburg and SE Gaston Counties. The site is now under the waters of Lake Wylie.

label: Rosser
description: community in NE Lee County.

label: Rosy
description: community in S central Transylvania County.

label: Roten
description: community in W Ashe County. Alt. approx. 3,050.

label: Rougemont
description: community in NW Durham County. Named for nearby Red Mountain. French rouge (red) and mont (mountain). Alt. 561. Effort to incorporate in 2005 failed.

label: Rough Branch
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows NW into Hornbuckle Creek.

label: Rough Butt Bald
description: on the Jackson-Haywood county line. Alt. 6,010.

label: Rough Butt Creek
description: rises in E Jackson County and flows NW to join Piney Mountain Creek in forming Caney Fork.

label: Rough Creek
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows SE into Beaverdam Creek.

label: Rough Fork
description: rises in S Macon County and flows NE into Wayah Creek.

label: Rough Knob
description: E Macon County between Burgoin Gap and Riley Knob.

label: Rough Mountain
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park between Low Gap Branch and Big Branch; center near lat. 35°44'27" N., long. 83°10' W.

label: Rough Ridge
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur extending SE from Mount Sterling Ridge between Andy Branch and Woody Branch; center near lat. 35°40'55" N., long. 83°07'10" W.

label: Rough Run
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows SE into West Fork Tuckasegee River.

label: Rough Run Falls
description: just above the mouth of Rough Run in W Jackson County.

label: Rough-hew Ridge
description: N Swain County between Bee Gum Branch and Board Camp Creek in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°30'18" N., long. 83°32'30" W., a short spur extending W from Forney Ridge.

label: Round Bald
description: on the Mitchell County, N.C.-Carter County, Tenn., line.

label: Round Bottom Creek
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows NW into Straight Fork.

label: Round Cove
description: NE Cherokee County in the Valley River Mountains.

label: Round Hill
description: W central Swain County near the head of Greasy Branch.

label: Round Hill Branch
description: rises in NW Buncombe County and flows NE through Green Valley into Newfound Creek.

label: Round Knob
description: community in S Haywood County between Sam Branch and Inman Branch. Alt. 4,265.

label: Round Mountain
description: SW Caldwell County. Alt. approx. 1,800.

label: Round Mountain
description: See Roundtop.

label: Round Mountain Knob
description: NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park at the SE end of Round Mountain Ridge near lat. 35°29'43" N., long. 83°46'38" W. Alt. 3,033.

label: Round Peak Mountain
description: N Surry County between Camp Branch and the head of Little Fisher River. Alt. 2,094.

label: Round Top
description: on the Graham-Swain county line near the head of Ammons Branch. Alt. 3,080.

label: Round Top Mountain
description: N Madison County between Silvermine Branch and Cascade Branch.

label: Round Top Mountain
description: W Rutherford County S of Rumbling Bald Mountain.

label: Roundabout
description: See Ronda.

label: Roundabout Creek
description: rises in W Ashe County and flows SE into North Fork New River.

label: Roundabout, The
description: See Goldsboro Cooling Pond.

label: Roundtop
description: mountain in SW Transylvania County N of Horsepasture River. Also known as Round Mountain. Alt. approx. 3,500.

label: Roundtop Knob
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Noland Divide. Alt. 5,120.

label: Roundtree
description: community in SW Pitt County served by post office, 1888-1902. Named for Jesse Roundtree (1765-1831), Irish immigrant and soldier in the Revolutionary War who settled there after the war. He served as sheriff from 1818 to 1820.

label: Rouse Pond
description: on the head of Grape Branch in N Duplin County.

label: Rover
description: community in W Beaufort County served by post office, 1900-1907.

label: Row Branch
description: rises in central Avery County and flows N into North Toe River.

label: Rowan
description: See Mount Ulla.

label: Rowan Branch
description: rises in W Swain County and flows NE into Hazel Creek.

label: Rowan County (ROW-an)
description: was formed in 1753 from Anson County. Located in the central section of the state, it is bounded by Davidson, Stanly, Cabarrus, Iredell, and Davie Counties. Named for Matthew Rowan (d. 1760), acting governor at the time the county was formed. Area: 527 sq. mi. County seat: Salisbury, with an elevation of 764 ft. Townships are Atwell, China Grove, Cleveland, Franklin, Gold Hill, Litaker, Locke, Morgan, Mount Ulla, Providence, Salisbury, Scotch Irish, Steele, and Unity. Produces corn, wheat, hay, nursery products, tomatoes, oats, cotton, poultry, dairy products, livestock, hogs, refrigeration equipment, bakery products, textiles, rubber products, chemicals, furniture, apparel, industrial machinery, millstones, trucking, taxidermy supplies, concrete products, and crushed stone.

label: Rowan Creek
description: rises in SE Bladen County and flows SE into Black River.

label: Rowan Mills
description: community on the SW outskirts of city of Salisbury, E central Rowan County.

label: Rowell
description: community in N Davidson County served by post office, 1895-96.

label: Rowland
description: town in W Robeson County. Alt. 150. Inc. 1889. Named for Col. Alfred Rowland II, a Confederate officer. Ashpole Presbyterian Church there organized 1796. See also Plainview.

label: Rowland Branch
description: rises in W Macon County and flows NW into Nantahala River.

label: Rowland Township
description: SW Robeson County.

label: Rowlin Creek
description: rises in NW Macon County and flows NE into Nantahala River.

label: Rowsypock
description: area W of present town of Kill Devil Hills, E of Little Colington Island in E Dare County.

label: Roxboro
description: town and county seat, central Person County. Est. as county seat, 1793. Named for Roxburgh, Scotland. Inc. 1855. Produces lumber, fabricated metals, textiles, processed poultry, and tobacco. Alt. 671.

label: Roxboro Lake
description: See Carolina Power Lake.

label: Roxboro Township
description: central Person County.

label: Roxobel
description: town in NW Bertie County. Settled about 1800; inc. 1895. The early settlement was known as Cotten's Cross Roads; around 1808 the name was changed to Granberrys Cross Roads; and in 1816 a post office there was called Brittons Store. Roxobel appears as the post office name in 1847. The name was selected by Frances Norfleet for the popular three-volume novel Roxobel, written by Mary Martha Sherwood. The final change was necessary to avoid confusion with Britton's Neck, S.C.

label: Roxobel Township
description: NW Bertie County.

label: Royal
description: community in S Franklin County.

label: Royal Cotton Mills
description: community in NE Wake County. Named for the mills est. there. Chartered 1907; charter repealed 1943.

label: Royal Creek
description: a short stream in N central Carteret County flowing E into South River.

label: Royal Oak
description: appears on the Price map, 1808, and on the MacRae map, 1833, on the Jones-Onslow county line where a slight change in direction is made. Said to have been named after a British soldier was found hiding in the tree's top to spy on Americans; he was hanged from a limb of the tree. The decayed stump of the tree was removed about 1916 when the road from Richlands to Comfort was widened.

label: Royal Oak Swamp
description: rises in Green Swamp in central Brunswick County and flows E into Lockwoods Folly River.

label: Royal Point
description: on the Pamlico Sound side of Portsmouth Island approx. 3 mi. from Drum Inlet, E Carteret County.

label: Royal Shoal
description: in Pamlico Sound in NE Carteret and SE Hyde Counties. Extends NW in an arc from Beacon Island and obstructs the passage through Ocracoke Inlet. Appears as Ryals Shoal on the Moseley map, 1733, but by its present name on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Rozier
description: community in E Robeson County served by post office, 1888-1902.

label: Rube Creek
description: rises in N Watauga County and flows SW into Beaverdam Creek.

label: Rube Green Top
description: E Mitchell County between Middle Mountain and the Avery County line.

label: Rube Rock Branch
description: rises in N Haywood County and flows SW into Pigeon River.

label: Rubicon
description: community in central Moore County served by post office, 1890-1907.

label: Rubyatt
description: community in SW Montgomery County served by post office, 1912-14. Named for H. O. Ruby, early settler of area.

label: Rudd
description: community in N Guilford County served by post office, 1902-1907. Alt. 826. Est. 1898 as Sippanaw; later named Morehead. Because of a delay in shipment of merchandise consigned to Morehead City, railroad officials renamed the community to avoid confusion and to honor Senaca and Cicero Rudd, local residents.

label: Rudisill
description: community in S Catawba County served by post office, 1894-1903.

label: Rufe
description: former town in W Greene County near the head of Fort Run. Inc. 1887 and name changed from Shine. Shine family prominent in the vicinity as early as 1750. A public school near the site operated as Shine School.

label: Ruffin
description: community in E Rockingham County. Settled prior to 1860 and known first as Stubblefield for a local family. Name changed to honor Thomas Ruffin (1787-1870), chief justice of the N.C. Supreme Court. Inc. 1887; new charter issued 1891; charter repealed 1897. Alt. 712.

label: Ruffin Township
description: NE Rockingham County.

label: Ruffin's Bridge
description: See Peacock's Bridge.

label: Rufus
description: community in NW Caldwell County on Mulberry Creek in Pisgah National Forest. Formerly known as Risden; the present name honors W. Rufus Coffey, a nineteenth-century merchant there.

label: Rugby
description: community in N Henderson County on Mill Pond Creek served by post office, 1892-1905.

label: Ruggles
description: community in E Halifax County.

label: Ruin Creek
description: rises in W Vance County and flows S into Tabbs Creek. Appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Rumbling Bald Mountain
description: NW Rutherford County on a ridge extending SE from Shumont Mountain. Alt. approx. 3,020. There are numerous caves in the mountain, and boulders sometimes fall in them, making a rumbling noise. Known by the Cherokee Indians as Sokassa A series of earthquakes occurred there from February 10 until April 17, 1874. There were between 50 and 75 shocks. See also The Caves.

label: Rumley Bay
description: a small bay in SE Cedar Island, NE Carteret County. Named for the Rumley family.

label: Rumley Marsh
description: a tidal-marsh peninsula approx. 1¾ mi. long and ¾ mi. wide on the N shore of Pamlico River S of Jackson Swamp, E Beaufort County. Appears as Rumneys Marsh on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Rumneys Marsh
description: See Rumley Marsh.

label: Run Branch
description: rises in S Lee County and flows NE into Thoroughfare Branch.

label: Run Hill
description: sand hill in Kill Devil Hills, E Dare County.

label: Run of Swamp
description: a canal that drains the Big Pocosin in SW Gates County and empties into Chowan River.

label: Run of the Mill Pond
description: a stream that rises in SE Duplin County and flows N into Jump and Run Branch.

label: Run Swamp Canal
description: rises in W Currituck County and flows SE into Indiantown Creek. It forms a part of the boundary between Camden and Currituck Counties.

label: Runaway Knob
description: on the SE end of Runaway Ridge in SW Macon County.

label: Runaway Ridge
description: SW Macon County between the head of Allison Creek and the head of Ash Flat Branch.

label: Runion
description: community in W Madison County on French Broad River approx. 3 mi. E of Hot Springs.

label: Running Creek
description: rises in W Stanly County and flows NE into Big Bear Creek.

label: Runnymede
description: former town in central Edgecombe County. Inc. 1907 as the site of the county fair; charter repealed 1909. The site is now within the limits of Tarboro, and the name survives only as the name of a mill.

label: Runyon Creek
description: rises in N Haywood County and flows SW into Pigeon River.

label: Runyon Gap
description: N Haywood County on Snowbird Creek.

label: Runyon Ridge
description: N Haywood County parallel to Snowbird Creek.

label: Rural Hall
description: community in N Forsyth County. Earliest settler apparently was Ludwig  Bitting, former German soldier in Gen. Nathanael Greene's army who liked the area when passing through and returned after the Revolutionary War to settle. Several of his descendants still live in the county. Rural Hall, however, developed after the Cape Fear and Yadkin Valley Railroad erected a station there in 1887. Produces furniture and lumber. Alt. 1,002.

label: Rush Branch
description: rises in W Watauga County and flows SW into Watauga River.

label: Rush Creek
description: rises in NW Caldwell County and flows SW into Mulberry Creek.

label: Rush Fork
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows SW into Crabtree Creek.

label: Rush Fork Gap
description: E Haywood County on the head of James Branch.

label: Rush Mountain
description: S Lincoln County. Named for a local family.

label: Rushing
description: community in SE Union County served by post office, 1883-1903.

label: Rusk
description: community in SW Surry County served by post office, 1851-1951.

label: Ruskin
description: community in NW Bladen County served by post office, 1902-26.

label: Russell
description: community in SW Rowan County served by post office, 1886-1903.

label: Russell Branch
description: rises in Union County, Ga., and flows NE into Clay County, where it enters Pinelog Creek.

label: Russell Gap
description: W Clay County near the headwaters of Trout Cove Branch.

label: Russellborough
description: SE Brunswick County on the Cape Fear River just N of the location of the former town of Brunswick, site of the home of royal governors Arthur Dobbs and William Tryon. A house there, begun by Capt. John Russell of His Majesty's Sloop Scorpion, was purchased in 1758 by Dobbs; renamed Castle Dobbs after his marriage in 1762. At Dobbs's death in 1765, Tryon occupied the house and named it Castle Tryon. When Tryon left the house in 1770, it was purchased by William Dry and renamed Bellfont. It burned in 1776. The site was excavated in 1967 by the N.C. Department of Archives and History, and eighteenth-century artifacts were discovered, many of which are on display at Brunswick State Historic Site.

label: Russells Creek
description: rises in central Carteret County and flows S into Newport River.

label: Russellville
description: community in central Anson County served by post office for six months in 1901.

label: Russtown
description: community in SW Brunswick County.

label: Ruth
description: town in W central Rutherford County. Inc. 1893 as Hampton. Named for S. D. Hampton, first mayor. Name changed to Ruth (first part of the county name) in 1906.

label: Rutherford College
description: former town and college in E Burke County. The school was founded by R. L. Abernathy in 1853, and the 400-acre site was inc. as village of Excelsior in 1872; inc. as town of Rutherford College in 1881. Alt. 1,210. The school merged with Weaver College in 1932 and was moved to Brevard, which see, and renamed Brevard College. Town charter repealed in 1933. Now a residential community approx. 2 mi. E of town of Valdese. Named for John Rutherford, who donated the land for the school in 1853. Original post office, 1857-86, was named Happy Home; it also served Connelly Springs, which see.

label: Rutherford County
description: was formed in 1779 from Tryon County when it was divided to form Rutherford and Lincoln Counties. Located in the SW section of the state, it is bounded by the state of South Carolina and by Polk, Henderson, Buncombe, McDowell, Burke, and Cleveland Counties. It was named for Griffith Rutherford (1731-1800), leader of 1776 expedition against the Cherokee, member of the Provincial Congress, and Revolutionary War general. Area: 568 sq. mi. County seat: Rutherfordton, with an elevation of 1,096 ft. Townships are Camp Creek, Chimney Rock, Colfax, Cool Spring, Duncans Creek, Gilkey, Golden Valley, Green Hill, High Shoals, Logan Store, Morgan, Rutherfordton, Sulphur Springs, and Union. Produces corn, wheat, oats, cotton, hay, soybeans, boats, dairy products, livestock, hogs, textiles, apparel, lumber, sand, and gravel.

label: Rutherfords Mill
description: See Exeter.

label: Rutherfordton
description: town and county seat, W central Rutherford County. Served by post office since 1798. Est. 1787. Alt. 1,096. Town and county named for Gen. Griffith Rutherford (1731-1800), Revolutionary War leader. See also Gilbert Town; Mountain Creek.

label: Rutherfordton Township
description: central Rutherford County.

label: Rutherwood
description: community in E Watauga County S of South Fork New River.

label: Rutledge Creek
description: rises in NE Surry County and flows SE into Ararat River.

label: Ryan
description: community in N Robeson County served by post office, 1888-1902.

label: Ryders Pond
description: E Warren County on Little Fishing Creek. Covers approx. 10 acres, with a max. depth of 4 ft.

label: Rye Mountain
description: E Jackson County on the head of Flat Creek. Alt. 4,542.

label: Rye Patch Branch
description: rises in NW Swain County and flows SE into Twentymile Creek.

label: Rye Ridge
description: W Avery County.

label: Rye Swamp
description: rises in W Sampson County and flows SW into Little Coharie Creek.

label: Ryes
description: community in W Harnett County.

label: Ryland
description: community in N Chowan County. Site of an early Quaker settlement. Post office est. there 1888 and named for a railroad official.

label: S Curves
description: section of N.C. Highway 12 N of Rodanthe on Hatteras Island, E Dare County. Term adopted by N.C. Department of Transportation because of frequent need to repair damage due to washouts. Also called Rodanthe S Curves.

label: Sa-koh-na-gas
description: See Blue Ridge Mountains.

label: Saconon
description: community in E Henderson County on Little Hungry Creek served by post office, 1913-23.

label: Saddle Gap
description: N Transylvania County between Looking Glass Creek and Avery Creek.

label: Saddle Mountain
description: on the Alleghany-Surry county line.

label: Saddle Mountain Creek
description: rises in W Surry County and flows SE into Mitchell River.

label: Saddle Tree Gap
description: W Graham County between the headwaters of Hangover Creek and Deep Creek.

label: Saddleback
description: ridge in NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park between Roaring Creek and Desolation Branch. Its center is near lat. 35°33'26" N., long. 83°40'48" W.

label: Saddletree Swamp
description: rises in N Robeson County and flows S into Lumber River.

label: Saddletree Township
description: central Robeson County.

label: Sadler
description: community in E Rockingham County served by post office, 1898-1910.

label: Safe
description: community in SW Duplin County served by post office, 1888-1903. Name derived from the fact that the first postmaster, Jacob Carr, operated a store and therein had a large safe, the only one in the area.

label: Sag Branch
description: rises in W Haywood County and flows NW into Caldwell Fork.

label: Sage Path
description: site of early settlement on the E end of Bogue Banks, S Carteret County. Storms drove out early settlers until the settlement of Salter Path, which see.

label: Sage Rock
description: peak in W Yancey County on Sevenmile Ridge near the head of Murphy Branch.

label: Sages Ordinary
description: See Holly Ridge.

label: Saginaw
description: See Pineola.

label: Sago
description: community in central Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1891-1902.

label: Sahara of North Carolina
description: See Sandhills.

label: Sahlee Creek
description: rises in N Swain County and flows SE into Deep Creek.

label: Sains
description: community in W Lincoln County served by post office, 1886-1905.

label: Sal Patch Gap
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°38'24" N., long. 83°03'28" W.

label: Sal's Creek
description: rises in central Wake County and flows NE into Crabtree Creek.

label: Saldeer Gap
description: N Macon County between Burningtown Creek and Rose Creek.

label: Salem
description: community in N Surry County between Lovills Creek and Ararat River.

label: Salem Chapel
description: See Dennis.

label: Salem Chapel Township
description: NE Forsyth County.

label: Salem Church
description: community in SW Randolph County served by post office, 1840-1918.

label: Salem Creek
description: See Niggerhead Creek.

label: Salem Lake
description: NE Forsyth County, is fed by Lowery Mill Creek, Kerners Mill Creek, and other streams. Formed 1942. Covers 400 acres, with a max. depth of 35 ft. Source of water for Winston-Salem.

label: Salem Township
description: S Pasquotank County.

label: Salemburg
description: town in W Sampson County. Settled about 1870. Inc. 1905 and took its name from Salem Academy, est. there by Rev. Isham Royal in 1874. The academy developed into Pineland College and Edwards Military Institute, which merged in 1965 to form Southwood College; it closed in 1973.

label: Sales Branch
description: rises in central Cherokee County and flows NW into Valley River.

label: Sales Ford
description: community in central Cherokee County on Valley River.

label: Salisbury
description: city and county seat, E central Rowan County. Est. 1755. Presumably named for the town in England but possibly for the town in Maryland, the point of origin of some of the earliest settlers in Rowan County. Catawba and Livingstone Colleges are there. Produces textiles, processed food, corrugated boxes, furniture, chemicals, machinery, structural steel, and wire cloth. Alt. 764.

label: Salisbury District
description: at the time of the 1790 census, was composed of Guilford, Iredell, Mecklenburg, Montgomery, Rockingham, Rowan, Stokes, and Surry Counties.

label: Salisbury Township
description: E Rowan County.

label: Salisbury West
description: unincorporated outskirts of city of Salisbury, E central Rowan County.

label: Sally Archer Crossroads
description: community in SE Hertford County.

label: Sally Branch
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows SW into Fines Creek.

label: Sally Cove Branch
description: rises in NW Macon County and flows N into Whiteoak Creek.

label: Sally Gap
description: S Swain County between Yalaka Creek and Little Yalaka Creek.

label: Sally Haines Branch
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows N into Pigeon River.

label: Sally Mountain
description: E Madison County between Middle Fork and Ponder Creek.

label: Sally Queen Creek
description: rises in NE Rutherford County near the Burke County line and flows SW into North Fork.

label: Sally's Creek
description: rises in W Caldwell County and flows SE into Johns River.

label: Salmon Creek
description: See Southwest Creek.

label: Salola
description: See Sugarloaf Mountain.

label: Salola Branch
description: rises in N Swain County S of Clingmans Dome and flows SE into Noland Creek. Salola was the Cherokee Indian word for squirrel.

label: Sals Creek
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows NE into Glady Fork.

label: Salser Branch
description: rises in central Macon County and flows E into McDowell Branch.

label: Salt Branch
description: rises in S Onslow County and flows E into Chadwick Bay.

label: Salt Rock Gap
description: S Yancey County on Buncombe Horse Range Ridge.

label: Salter Creek
description: rises in NE Carteret County and flows SE into Nelson Bay.

label: Salter Path
description: community near the center of Bogue Banks, S Carteret County. Settlement begun about 1900 on property owned by John A. Royall of Boston, Mass. A court judgment in 1923 restricted the settlement to 84 acres and declared that only persons then resident at Salter Path and their descendants could occupy the land. See also Rice Path.

label: Salters Lake
description: a natural lake in central Bladen County on Ellis Creek 6 mi. N of Elizabethtown. Covers 315 acres, with a max. depth of 10 ft. State owned and open to the public. Fishing, swimming, and boating. Part of Jones Lake State Park, which see.

label: Salters Lumps
description: two small islands in Brett Bay off Piney Point, NE Carteret County.

label: Salton Gap
description: N Buncombe County between North Knob and Grassy Knob.

label: Saltrock Branch
description: rises in SE Macon County and flows NW into Cullasaja River.

label: Saltrock Gap
description: S Macon County on Tennessee Valley Divide.

label: Saluda
description: town in SW Polk County. Settled 1878 after the construction of the railroad. Inc. 1881. Took its name from the Indian word salutah (corn river). Alt. 2,097.

label: Saluda Mountain
description: S Henderson County along the South Carolina state line. Approx. 5 mi. long.

label: Saluda Township
description: SW Polk County.

label: Salvage Island
description: See Core Banks.

label: Salvo
description: community on Hatteras Island, E Dare County. Formerly known as Clarks or Clarksville.

label: Salyer's Bay
description: See Sulliers Bay.

label: Sam Branch
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows SE into Nick Creek.

label: Sam Cove
description: NW Graham County on Deep Creek.

label: Sam Doane Mountain
description: on Madison-Yancey County line between Moore Gap and Paint Gap. Named for an early settler.

label: Sam Gap
description: SE Buncombe County between Flint Knob and Round Mountain.

label: Sam Knob
description: S Haywood County between Sam Branch and Flat Laurel Creek. Alt. 6,030.

label: Sam Newton Branch
description: rises in central Cherokee County and flows NW into Valley River.

label: Samarcand
description: community in W Moore County. Named in 1916 by Raphael W. Pumpelly Jr. for the town in Asia Minor, which he had visited in his travels. A state home and industrial school for girls opened there in 1918. Alt. 698.

label: Samaria
description: community in SW Nash County served by post office, 1902-1907. Named for local Baptist church.

label: Sampson
description: community in N central Caldwell County on the headwaters of the Yadkin River near Blowing Rock.

label: Sampson Branch
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows SE into Jacks Creek. Named for Sampson Honeycutt, an early settler who died and was buried nearby about 1891.

label: Sampson County
description: was formed in 1784 from Duplin County. Located in the E section of the state, it is bounded by Wayne, Duplin, Pender, Bladen, Cumberland, Johnston, and Harnett Counties. It was named for Col. John Sampson (d. 1784), member of the House of Commons and the governor's council under royal governors Dobbs, Tryon, and Martin. Area: 963 sq. mi. County seat: Clinton, with an elevation of 158 ft. Townships are Belvoir, Dismal, Franklin, Hales, Herrings, Honeycutts, Lisbon, Little Coharie, McDaniels, Mingo, Newton Grove, North Clinton, Piney Grove, Plain View, South Clinton, South River, Taylors Bridge, Turkey, and Westbrook. Produces corn, soybeans, wheat, oats, hay, peanuts, tobacco, cotton, cucumbers, pepper, squash, watermelons, cantaloupe, collards, honey, nursery products, miscellaneous vegetables and fruit, poultry, hogs, livestock, turkeys, sweet potatoes, lumber, processed meat, electronics, apparel, concrete products, and textiles.

label: Sampson Creek
description: rises in S Catawba County and flows NE into Pott Creek.

label: Sampson Gap
description: W Yancey County on Sampson Mountain near the head of Simms Fork.

label: Sampson Mountain
description: SE Watauga County. Alt. 4,716.

label: Sampson Mountain
description: W Yancey County, extends SE from the head of Simms Fork to Slickrock Knob. Alt. 4,826 at Sampson Peak on the mountain.

label: Sampson Point
description: S Currituck County E of community of Point Harbor, extends into Albemarle Sound. Shown on U.S. Coast Survey map, 1865.

label: Sampson's Chimney
description: rock formation on Howard Knob, central Watauga County.

label: Sams Branch
description: rises in W Pitt County and flows NE into Tar River.

label: Sams Gap
description: on the Swain County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°34'02" N., long. 83°38'12" W.

label: Samuel
description: community in SE Surry County served by post office, 1894-1905.

label: Samuel Creek
description: See Hayward Creek.

label: Sanatorium
description: See McCain.

label: Sand Branch
description: rises in SE Buncombe County and flows S into Broad River.

label: Sand Creek
description: rises in SE Granville County and flows N into Tar River.

label: Sand Flat Mountain
description: N Henderson County between Garren Mountain and Hooper Creek.

label: Sand Hill
description: community in central Buncombe County served by post office, 1873-74.

label: Sand Hill Cove
description: E Pender County on Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: Sand Hill Creek
description: rises in E central Brunswick County and flows NE into Cape Fear River.

label: Sand Hill Township
description: E Lenoir County.

label: Sand Mountain
description: W Caldwell County. Alt. 1,500.

label: Sand Point
description: NE Carteret County, extends from W side of central Cedar Island into West Bay.

label: Sand Point
description: on NW shore of Roanoke Island, extends W into Croatan Sound, NE Dare County.

label: Sandbank Creek
description: rises in W Avery County and flows SW into Roaring Creek.

label: Sandbank Ridge
description: W Avery County.

label: Sandbluff
description: community in central Bladen County.

label: Sanders Creek
description: E Onslow County, flows from the N of Queens Creek SW into the mouth of Bear Creek. Mentioned in local records as early as 1744.

label: Sanders Island
description: E Onslow County in Brown's Sound between the mouths of Bear and Sanders Creeks.

label: Sanders Knob
description: S Macon County between Shope Fork and North Fork Coweeta Creek.

label: Sanders Point
description: W Carteret County, extends into Bogue Sound W of the mouth of Goose Creek.

label: Sanderson Fish Pond
description: on a tributary of Cabin Creek in E central Duplin County.

label: Sanderson's Channel
description: See Roanoke Sound.

label: Sandhill
description: community in N Pamlico County.

label: Sandhills
description: a series of rolling hills between the Cape Fear and Pee Dee Rivers covering portions of Richmond, Scotland, Moore, Cumberland, and Harnett Counties. Includes approx. 1,110 sq. mi. The surrounding area is approx. 600 ft. above sea level, but, within the Sandhills, there are ridges rising 300 to 400 ft. higher. Little River, Drowning Creek, and Rockfish Creek are the principal streams. Coarse sandy soil is characteristic of the area. The Basset map, 1676, marks the area "Deserta Arenosa." It has also been called Deserta Montana, Sandy Barrens, Pine Barrens, and the Sahara of North Carolina. William Hooper, in a letter of June 15, 1779, to James Iredell, used the term sandhills. The climate of the region has been classed as "Humid Subtropical," and it has an average annual temperature of approx. 61.5°. The area was settled by Scottish Highlanders beginning about 1740. They found the region covered by a stand of longleaf pines ranging in height from 100 to 120 ft. and with diameters up to 36 inches. Beneath the pines, wire grass covered the ground. Most of the pines were cut between 1875 and 1895 (for an exception, see Weymouth Woods Sandhills Nature Preserve), and the region is now covered with smaller longleaf pines, scrub oak (chiefly Turkey and Black Jack), and wire grass. Extensive peach orchards have flourished in the Sandhills since 1892. The resort towns of Pinehurst and Southern Pines, which see, have developed there.

label: Sandhills Township
description: S Moore County.

label: Sandifer
description: community in central Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1885-1909.

label: Sands
description: community in E central Watauga County between Howard Creek and Meat Camp Creek.

label: Sandy Barrens
description: See Sandhills.

label: Sandy Bay
description: in the waters of Pamlico Sound off the SE mainland of Dare County between Sandy Point on the N and Parched Corn Point on the s.

label: Sandy Bay
description: a bay in the waters of Pamlico Sound off the coast of Hatteras Island, SE Dare County. It lies between Durant Point, near the town of Hatteras, and Frisco.

label: Sandy Bottom
description: community in W Madison County on French Broad River served by post office, 1887-1911.

label: Sandy Branch
description: rises in S Stokes County and flows SE into Town Fork Creek.

label: Sandy Creek
description: rises in central Durham County and flows SW into New Hope Creek.

label: Sandy Creek
description: community in NE Randolph County served by post office, 1884-1906. Sandy Creek Baptist Church there was founded in 1755. There, in 1766, the first attempt was made to organize the Regulators.

label: Sandy Creek Township
description: SW Warren County.

label: Sandy Cross
description: community in central Rockingham County; center of productive tobacco country.

label: Sandy Foundation
description: See Sandy Bottom.

label: Sandy Gap
description: N Transylvania County near the head of Cedar Rock Creek.

label: Sandy Gap Branch
description: rises in W Swain County on Welch Ridge and flows NW into Hazel Creek.

label: Sandy Grove
description: community in SE Hoke County served by post office, 1826-96.

label: Sandy Huss Creek
description: rises in N Carteret County and flows approx. 1 mi. SW into Adams Creek on the Craven County line. Perhaps named for the fish, amiatus calva, a dogfish sometimes also known as huss.

label: Sandy Inlet
description: former inlet between Topsail Sound and Atlantic Ocean, SE Pender County. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733; closed soon after 1775.

label: Sandy John Ridge
description: N Haywood County between Big Creek and Pigeon River.

label: Sandy Landing
description: SE Beaufort County on the W side of South Creek.

label: Sandy Mush
description: community in S Rutherford County near the head of Holland Creek.

label: Sandy Mush Bald
description: on Newfound Mountain at the junction of Buncombe, Haywood, and Madison county lines. Alt. 5,152. Took its name from the nearby creek.

label: Sandy Mush Creek
description: rises near Wade Gap in NW Buncombe County and flows NE into French Broad River, forming a part of the Buncombe-Madison county line. Named by an early hunting party when sand from the creek water got into the mush they were cooking for supper.

label: Sandy Mush Township
description: former township in SW Madison County, now township no. 6.

label: Sandy Plains
description: community in S Polk County served by post office, 1887-94.

label: Sandy Point
description: appears on the Gascoyne map, 1682, as the point of land presently in SE Bertie County between Salmon Creek and Roanoke River. It also appears on the Hack map, 1684.

label: Sandy Point
description: community on Morse Point in NE Currituck County.

label: Sandy Ridge
description: See Sandy Bottom.

label: Sandy Ridge Township
description: W Union County.

label: Sandy River
description: See First Broad River.

label: Sandy Run
description: rises in S Cumberland County and flows SE into Rockfish Creek.

label: Sandy Run
description: rises in SE Northampton County and flows SE into Roanoke River. For a part of its course, it forms the boundary between Northampton and Bertie Counties. Mentioned in local records as early as 1722.

label: Sandy Run Branch
description: rises in N Duplin County and flows SW into Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: Sandy Run Creek
description: rises in E Rutherford County and flows SE into Cleveland County, where it enters Broad River.

label: Sandy Run Swamp
description: rises in W Onslow County and flows SW into Pender County, where it enters Holly Shelter Creek.

label: Sandy Run Township
description: former township in SW Cleveland County, now township no. 7.

label: Sandy Springs
description: community in SW Rutherford and SE Polk Counties. A post office operated there, 1876-1908.

label: Sandycross
description: community in SE Gates County served by post office, 1884-1906.

label: Sanford
description: city and county seat, central Lee County. Laid out about 1872. Inc. 1874. Said to have been named for Col. C. O. Sanford, engineer for the Chatham Railroad. Jonesboro, which see, merged with Sanford in 1947. Produces bricks, pottery, lumber, electrical parts, primary metals, sheet-metal working, apparel, industrial machinery, furniture, insecticides, and cosmetics. Alt. 375.

label: Sans Souci
description: community in SE Bertie County. The name of an early plantation, which in French means "without care or worry." Long site of cable-drawn ferry.

label: Santeetlah
description: community in central Graham County on Santeetlah Lake. The former post office there, 1906-30, was called Millsaps.

label: Santeetlah Creek
description: rises in W Graham County and flows E into Santeetlah Lake. Name said to have meant "blue waters" in Cherokee, but Mooney's glossary says the Indians did not recognize or understand the name, insisting it was given to the creek by white men. They called the creek Nayuhi geyuni (sandplace stream), and Little Santeetlah Creek was known by them as Tsundaniltiyi

label: Santeetlah Gap
description: W central Graham County approx. ¾ mi. W of Funnel Top.

label: Santeetlah Lake
description: central Graham County, was formed in 1928 by a dam on Cheoah River. Covers 2,580 acres, with a shoreline of 105 mi. Max. depth 240 ft. Alt. 1,940. Used for power, fishing, and boating.

label: Santeetlah Wildlife Management Area
description: in W Graham County. 37,168 acres, operated by the state of North Carolina on U.S. Forest Service lands. Principal wildlife: bear, boar, deer, raccoon, and trout.

label: Sapling Mountain
description: N Madison County between Shelton Laurel Creek and Spillcorn Creek.

label: Sapona
description: community in SW Davidson County served by post office, 1885-1903.

label: Sapona River
description: See Yadkin River.

label: Sapony Creek
description: rises in W Nash County and flows SE into Tar River. Probably named for a stopping place of the Saponi Indians as they moved from the Yadkin River area in the W soon after 1701 to join the Tuscarora in the E.

label: Sapphire
description: community in SW Transylvania County S of Horsepasture River. Named because sapphires are found in the vicinity or for the vivid blue of the sky and water.

label: Sapphire Country
description: a descriptive name applied to the area around Fairfield, Sapphire, and Toxaway Lakes in S Jackson and W Transylvania Counties. It probably came into use in commercial promotion for Mountain Lodge, Fairfield Inn, and Sapphire Inn about 1898. Name derived from the blue of the mountains as well as sapphire gems found in the area.

label: Sapphire Lake
description: S Jackson County on Horsepasture River and Nix Creek. Formed by 1916; covers 50 acres, with a max. depth of 20 ft. Part of "Sapphire Country," which see. Used for fishing, swimming, and boating; not open to the public. See also Lake Sapphire.

label: Sapsucker Branch
description: rises in central Clay County and flows NW into Peckerwood Branch.

label: Saratoga
description: town in SE Wilson County between White Oak Swamp and Goss Swamp. Settled prior to 1839; inc. 1874.

label: Saratoga Township
description: SE Wilson County.

label: Sardis
description: See Hudson.

label: Sarecta
description: area in central Duplin County on Northeast Cape Fear River. Settled about 1736 under the direction of Henry McCulloch of London. Est. 1787 as Sarecto; long inactive in municipal affairs. Alt. 67. Named for Soracte Mountain in Italy, near Rome, on which a temple to Apollo stood in ancient times. Often referred to as Soracte in colonial records. Served by post office, 1830-1903.

label: Sarem
description: community in W central Gates County; named for the ancient name for Salisbury, England. Alt. 34. A school for Indians was in operation there in 1712, and it was a preaching station for Rev. Clement Hall of Edenton in the 1750s.

label: Sarem Creek
description: rises in S Gates County and flows SE into Chowan River. Appears on the Collet map, 1770, where the modern Cole Creek is shown with the same name.

label: Sarvis Gap
description: NE Mitchell County between Wiles Creek and Lyddies Creek.

label: Sarvis Ridge
description: NE Mitchell County between Wiles Creek and Lyddies Creek.

label: Sasnett Mill Branch
description: rises in central Edgecombe County and flows SW into Cokey Swamp.

label: Sassafras Branch
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows N into Savannah Creek.

label: Sassafras Creek
description: rises in E central Avery County and flows S into Lost Cove Creek.

label: Sassafras Creek
description: rises in SW Graham County in the Snowbird Mountains and flows NE into Snowbird Creek.

label: Sassafras Falls
description: in Sassafras Creek, SW Graham County. Water drops approx. 70 ft.

label: Sassafras Fork
description: See Stovall.

label: Sassafras Fork Township
description: NE Granville County.

label: Sassafras Gap
description: SE Macon County between Clear Creek and Queen Mountain. Alt. approx. 2,860.

label: Sassafras Gap
description: on the North Carolina-South Carolina line at the junction of Transylvania County, N.C., and Greenville and Pickens Counties, S.C. Alt. 2,774.

label: Sassafras Knob
description: NW Transylvania County S of Farlow Gap.

label: Sassafras Mountain
description: on the Transylvania County, N.C.-Pickens County, S.C., line S of the head of South Prong [Glady Fork]. Alt. 3,554.

label: Sassafras Ridge
description: extends NE from Bee Gap to Willie Knob in SW Graham County.

label: Sassafras Ridge
description: elevated ground in E Washington County SW of the community of Scuppernong. The name appears in county records as early as 1868.

label: Sassarixa Swamp
description: rises in W Johnston County and flows SE into Black Creek.

label: Sasseenohla
description: See Big Bald.

label: Sassers Mill
description: community in NW Jones County on Heath Mill Run.

label: Sassers Millpond
description: N Wayne County on Great Swamp near Aycock Millpond. Fishing, boating; open to public.

label: Satterfield Creek
description: rises in W Person County and flows NE into Storys Creek.

label: Satterthwaite Creek
description: rises in E Beaufort County and flows E into Pungo River. See also Chappel Creek.

label: Satterwhite
description: community in N Granville County, formerly known as Locust Grove. Name derived from home of the Satterwhite family.

label: Satterwhite Creek
description: rises in SW Burke County and flows N into Silver Creek.

label: Satulah Branch
description: rises in SE Macon County and flows N into Mill Creek.

label: Satulah Falls
description: SE Macon County near the head of Clear Creek.

label: Satulah Mountain
description: SE Macon County between Satulah Falls and Little Fodderstack Mountain. Alt. 4,490.

label: Saucepan Creek
description: rises in SW Brunswick County and flows E into Shallotte River.

label: Sauls Creek
description: rises in N Warren County and flows NE into Hawtree Creek.

label: Sauls Crossroads
description: See Eureka.

label: Saulston
description: community in E Wayne County S of The Slough and N of the head of West Bear Creek.

label: Saulston Township
description: E Wayne County.

label: Saunder's Hill
description: See Abner.

label: Saunders
description: community in W Cabarrus County served by post office, 1891-1902. Named for North Carolina secretary of state William L. Saunders (1835-91).

label: Saunders Bay
description: in Currituck Sound off the W shore of Currituck Banks and N of Mossey Islands, SE Currituck County.

label: Saunders Point
description: peninsula extending from NE Pamlico County into Bay River.

label: Saunders’ Store
description: community in SW Caswell County.

label: Saunook
description: community in W Haywood County. Alt. 3,206. Said to have been named for a Cherokee Indian who lived in the vicinity.

label: Saura Town
description: See Lower Saura Town; Upper Saura Town.

label: Saurat
description: See Upper Saura Town.

label: Sauratown
description: former community in SE Stokes County near the mouth of Town Fork Creek on Dan River. A post office operated there, 1876-87. Earlier post office, named Saura Town, operated 1833-39.

label: Sauratown Mountain
description: a range extending from W Stokes County into the center of the county. Alt. 2,465. Appears on the Collet map, 1770. Named for the Saura Indians, who lived in the area. The Indians were mentioned by William Byrd, 1728.

label: Sauratown Township
description: SE Stokes County.

label: Savage
description: community in E Gates County served by post office, 1904-35. Alt. 33. Settled prior to Civil War and named for G. W. Savage, local landowner.

label: Savages Crossroads
description: community in N Gates County. Known first as Pipkin's Crossroads, then as Brickhouse.

label: Savannah
description: community on Savannah Creek in W Jackson County.

label: Savannah Creek
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows N into Tuckasegee River.

label: Savannah Ridge
description: in W Jackson County between Little Savannah Creek and Savannah Creek.

label: Savannah Township
description: W Jackson County.

label: Saw
description: community in SW Rowan County served by post office, 1886-1903.

label: Saw Branch
description: rises in SW Buncombe County near Saw Mountain and flows NW into South Hominy Creek.

label: Saw Mill
description: community in S Caldwell County.

label: Saw Mill Branch
description: rises in N Davie County and flows S into Dutchmans Creek.

label: Saw Mountain
description: SW Buncombe County between Saw Branch and Stony Fork.

label: Sawbrier Ridge
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur extending NW from High Rocks on Welch Ridge; center near lat. 35°31' N., long. 83°38'02" W.

label: Sawmill Branch
description: rises in central Cherokee County and flows SE into Colvard Creek.

label: Sawmill Creek
description: rises in W Transylvania County and flows SE into Cherryfield Creek.

label: Sawmill Ridge
description: N Macon County between Shepherd Creek and Matlock Creek.

label: Sawpit Branch
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows SE into East Fork [South Fork New River].

label: Sawteeth, The
description: broken, pointed summits along the Swain County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°38'30" N., long. 83°21'50" W. Alt. approx. 5,450.

label: Sawyer Cove
description: N Buncombe County E of Ingles Ridge.

label: Sawyer Creek
description: rises in N Watauga County and flows W into Cove Creek.

label: Sawyers Creek
description: rises in N Pender County and flows N into Rockfish Creek.

label: Sawyers Ferry
description: appears on the Moseley map, 1733, on Pasquotank River in what is now Camden County N of Sawyers Creek. Site was in Pasquotank Precinct of Albemarle County. Later Shipyard Ferry operated nearby. See also Shipyard.

label: Sawyers Landing
description: E Beaufort County on Pungo River.

label: Sawyersville
description: community in W Randolph County served by post office, 1849-1905.

label: Saxapahaw
description: community in SE Alamance County on Haw River. Named for the Sissipahaw Indians, who once lived in the area. A yarn mill was est. there in 1849.

label: Saxapahaw River
description: See Haw River.

label: Saxon
description: community in E Stokes County served by post office, 1891-1912.

label: Scale Creek
description: rises in NE Onslow County and flows SW into Northeast Creek.

label: Scalesville
description: community in N Guilford County. Named for the Scales family of Guilford and Rockingham Counties.

label: Scaly Mountain
description: community in S Macon County on Middle Creek.

label: Scaly Ridge
description: SE Clay County between Tallulah River and Beech Creek.

label: Scapecat Branch
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows W into Little East Fork Pigeon River.

label: Scarboro
description: community in SW Montgomery County served by post office, 1880-1901.

label: Scarlet Ridge
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park extending SE from Welch Ridge to Forney Creek. Near lat. 35°31'54" N., long. 83°34'40" W.

label: Scarlet Ridge Creek
description: rises in N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows SE into Jonas Creek.

label: Schenck Forest
description: See Carl Alwin Schenck Forest.

label: Schencks Station
description: community in S Cleveland County.

label: Schene Wolf Creek
description: rises near Organ and Lower Stone Churches approx. 5 mi. SW of Rockwell, SE Rowan County, and flows S into NE Cabarrus County, where it enters Dutch Buffalo Creek. Probably named by early German settlers, Schene being derived from schön (beautiful). Sometimes also called Jennie Wolf Creek.

label: Schley
description: community in E Orange County served by post office, 1898-1907.

label: Schlosstown
description: community in N Franklin County. Known locally as "Slosh."

label: Scholl
description: community in W Scotland County.

label: School House Branch
description: rises in W Watauga County and flows SW into Watauga River.

label: Schoolhouse Branch
description: rises in central Cherokee County and flows SE into Marble Creek.

label: Schoolhouse Branch
description: rises in central Pitt County and flows NE into Tar River.

label: Schoolhouse Flats
description: E Haywood County on Glade Mountain.

label: Schoolpath Branch
description: rises in S central Transylvania County and flows NE into West Fork French Broad River.

label: Schooner Creek
description: rises in SE Beaufort County and flows N into South Creek.

label: Schooners Bay
description: See Spooners Bay.

label: Schuler Cove
description: See Jack Cove.

label: Schulkens Pond
description: a natural lake in SE Columbus County approx. 7 mi. SW of Lake Waccamaw and 1 mi. W of Waccamaw River. Bear Branch drains Schulkens Pond into Waccamaw River.

label: Science
description: community in SW Randolph County.

label: Scippco Swamp
description: rises in Cawcaw Bay, SW Brunswick County, and flows W into Waccamaw River.

label: Scotch Grove
description: community in N central Scotland County.

label: Scotch Hall
description: See Bonarva.

label: Scotch-Irish Township
description: N Rowan County.

label: Scotia
description: community in N central Tyrrell County at the head of Second Creek.

label: Scotland County
description: was formed in 1899 from Richmond County. Located in the SE section of the state, it is bounded by the state of South Carolina and by Richmond, Moore, Hoke, and Robeson Counties. It was named for Scotland in the British Isles, from which many of the early settlers of the region emigrated. Area: 317 sq. mi. County seat: Laurinburg, with an elevation of 227 ft. Townships are Laurel Hill, Spring Hill, Stewartsville, and Williamsons. Produces cotton, corn, soybeans, peanuts, oats, watermelons, cantaloupes, hogs, livestock, processed meat, textiles, automobile parts, and lumber.

label: Scotland Neck
description: a name formerly applied to a tract of land approx. 40 sq. mi. in area in SE Halifax County. It lay E of Kehukee Swamp and W of Roanoke River and extended S through the present Buzzard Point. It was settled in 1722 by Scottish colonists. Appears on the Collet map, 1770, and the Price map, 1808.

label: Scotland Neck Township
description: SE Halifax County.

label: Scotland Village
description: See East Laurinburg.

label: Scotsman Creek
description: rises in S Jackson County and flows SW into Chattooga River.

label: Scott
description: community in NW Warren County.

label: Scott Branch
description: rises in E Macon County and flows SW into Cullasaja River.

label: Scott Creek
description: rises in E Jones County and flows E into Trent River.

label: Scott Creek Township
description: NE Jackson County. Named for John Scott, a trader among the Cherokees.

label: Scott Knob
description: S Swain County between the head of Welch Branch and Yalaka Creek.

label: Scott Mountain
description: S Buncombe County E of Enka Lake.

label: Scott Reservoir
description: See W. Kerr Scott Reservoir.

label: Scott's
description: formerly Scott's Store, community in W Wilson County S of Contentnea Creek. Named for S. H. Scott.

label: Scott's Pond
description: W Wilson County on Robin Branch. Formed 1954 and named for Exum Scott, owner. Covers 10 acres; max. depth 12 ft. Fishing, swimming, boating, irrigation.

label: Scottish Mountain
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°41'34" N., long. 83°05'08" W. Named for Scottish Mountain Lumber Co., which operated in the area in the 1920s. Alt. 4,290.

label: Scotts
description: community in W central Iredell County.

label: Scotts Creek
description: rises in NW Rutherford County and flows SE into Cove Creek.

label: Scotts Hill
description: community in SE Pender County served by post office, 1876-1943. Alt. 50.

label: Scotts Store
description: community in W Pamlico County.

label: Scottsville
description: See Belfast.

label: Scottville
description: community on Alleghany-Ashe county line. Alt. approx. 2,950. Settled about 1830 and known first as Flint Hill. Post office est. 1855 as Scottville; believed to have been named for Elizabeth Scott (1799-1856), local citizen. Post office closed, 1954.

label: Scranton
description: community in W Hyde County on Scranton Creek near Pungo River. Alt. 3. Originally known as Clark for the owner of a lumber mill there. Later renamed Scranton for another lumber mill that relocated from Scranton, Pa. Near the site of an old Indian village, Aquascogoc, which see.

label: Scranton Creek
description: rises in W Hyde County and flows W approx. 3.3 mi. into Pungo River. Formerly known as Broad Creek.

label: Scratch Hall Swamp
description: rises in W Gates County and flows W into Chowan River.

label: Scratch Hall Township
description: See Hall Township.

label: Scream Ridge
description: S Macon County parallel to Yellow Patch Creek.

label: Scrougetown
description: community in S Clay County. The site is now partially covered by the waters of Chatuge Lake.

label: Scuffleton
description: See Scuffletown.

label: Scuffletown
description: town in E Greene County on Little Contentnea Creek served by post office, 1837-42. Also spelled Scuffleton. Inc. 1885, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Settled prior to 1756; served by post office, 1837-42. Name said to be derived from disagreement among members of the local Free Will Baptist church. In recent years generally known as Ridge Spring.

label: Scuffletown
description: See Pembroke.

label: Scull Camp
description: See Skull Camp Mountain.

label: Scuppernong
description: community in E Washington County. Post office est. 1849, discontinued 1908. Location formerly known as Cool Spring.

label: Scuppernong Lake
description: See Lake Phelps.

label: Scuppernong River
description: rises in E Washington County in East Dismal Swamp and flows E into W Tyrrell County, where it turns to flow NW into Albemarle Sound. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733, as Cascoponung River. It appears as Cuscopang River on a 1788 map. Approx. 22 mi. long.

label: Scuppernong Township
description: SE Washington County, formed in 1868 and incorporates within its limits the old voting precinct of Cool Springs.

label: Sea Banks
description: See Outer Banks; Shackle ford Banks.

label: Sea Breeze
description: resort community in S New Hanover County near the S end of Myrtle Sound. Est. to serve African Americans.

label: Sea Cattle
description: See Middle Ground.

label: Sea Level Township
description: NE Carteret County on Nelson Bay and Core Sound.

label: Sea of Rawnocke
description: See Albemarle Sound.

label: Seaboard
description: town in N Northampton County. Alt. 126. Settled about 1750 and known first as Concord. Inc. 1877. Named for the Seaboard Air Line Railroad. Post office since 1853.

label: Seaboard Township
description: N central Northampton County.

label: Seaforth
description: community in E Chatham County. The site is now under the waters of Jordan Lake.

label: Seagate
description: community in E New Hanover County on the S side of Bradleys Creek. Alt. 10. Served by post office, 1910-32. Settled about 1890. Named for the fact that it is located on an inlet of Wrightsville Sound, with access thereby to the sea.

label: Seago's Lake
description: E Anson County SE of Lilesville. Covers approx. 10 acres; max. depth 20 ft. Formed early in the twentieth century when gravel was removed from the site. Named for owner.

label: Seagrove
description: town in S Randolph County. Inc. 1913. Named for a railroad official. Alt. 716. Post office since 1897. Home to North Carolina Pottery Center.

label: Seagull
description: community on Currituck Banks, E Currituck County. A lifesaving station there originally was called Old Currituck Inlet. A Coast Guard station there was decommissioned following World War II. Post office operated from 1908 to 1924.

label: Sealevel
description: community in NE Carteret County on Core Sound.

label: Sealeys Creek
description: See Celia Creek.

label: Searcy Creek
description: rises in W central Transylvania County and flows NE into Davidson River.

label: Seaside
description: community in SW Brunswick County.

label: Seay Mountain
description: central Haywood County between Jonathans Creek and Pigeon River. Alt. 3,358.

label: Secession
description: community in SW Brunswick County.

label: Seco
description: an Indian village shown on John White's map of 1585 located in what is now central Beaufort County. The name is associated with American discoveries dating from 1536, though located on different maps from the Chesapeake Bay S to Florida. De Bry's version of White's map, printed in 1590, changes Seco to Cotan. See also Secotan.

label: Second Broad River
description: rises in S McDowell County and flows SE into Rutherford County, which it crosses to the Cleveland County line and enters Broad River.

label: Second Creek
description: rises in N central Tyrrell County S of community of Pleasant View and flows W into Scuppernong River approx. 2¾ mi. S of town of Columbia. An old Indian village of uncertain tribal affiliation, Mequopen, is shown at the mouth of the creek on the De Bry map, 1590. Name means "red tribes" or "where there are red tribes."

label: Second Creek
description: See North Second Creek; South Second Creek; Back Creek.

label: Second Creek Bluff
description: at the mouth of Second Creek in E Tyrrell County.

label: Second Creek Point
description: E Tyrrell County, extends from the mainland into Alligator River near the mouth of Second Creek.

label: Second Falls
description: the middle of a series of three waterfalls on Yellowstone Prong, S Haywood County.

label: Second Hurricane Branch
description: rises in E Swain County and flows SW into Yalaka Creek.

label: Second Potts Creek
description: rises in W Davidson County and flows S into High Rock Lake on Yadkin River. Appears on the Collet map, 1770, as Potts Creek.

label: Secotan
description: an Indian village once located on the S side of Pamlico River in what is now E Beaufort County in the vicinity of Hobucken; visited by John White and other explorers based on Roanoke Island in the sixteenth century. The name meant "town at the bend of a river." Appears as Secoton on the White map, 1585; as Secota on the De Bry map, 1590; and as Secotan on the Velasco map, 1611. See also Seco.

label: Sedalia
description: community in E Guilford County. The Alice Freeman Palmer Memorial Institute, a junior college and high school for African American women est. 1901, operated there until 1960s. Campus now a State Historic Site.

label: Sedgefield
description: community in W central Guilford County. Named for the fields of sedge (grasslike plants) in the vicinity. English-style inn opened 1927. Golf course hosts national tournaments.

label: Sedges Garden
description: community in N central Forsyth County.

label: See Off Mountain
description: S central Transylvania County between Dunn Creek and Haunty Branch. Alt. 3,080.

label: See-noh-ya
description: See Black Mountains.

label: Seed Cane Creek
description: rises in E Surry County and flows SW into Ararat River.

label: Seedbed of the Colony
description: See Salmon Creek.

label: Seeoff
description: community in SE Transylvania County.

label: Seeshore
description: community in S Transylvania County on a tributary of Carson Creek.

label: Sega Lake
description: in central Transylvania County on Graham Creek. Covers ¼ acre, with a max. depth of 10 ft.

label: Seibold Branch
description: rises in E Cherokee County and flows SE into Fall Branch.

label: Seigle Creek
description: rises in NE Lincoln County and flows S into Forney Creek.

label: Selah
description: community in N Johnston County served by post office, 1892-95.

label: Selena
description: See Center.

label: Selica
description: community in W central Transylvania County between Wilson Mill Creek and Catheys Creek. Alt. 2,179.

label: Selma
description: town in central Johnston County. Known first as Mitchenor's Station for John Mitchenor. Inc. as Selma, 1873; named for the town of the same name in Alabama. Town of Selma Cotton Mills, inc. 1915 and long inactive in municipal affairs, is now within the W section of Selma. Alt. 179. Produces textiles, furniture, milled grain, and chemicals.

label: Selma Cotton Mills
description: See Selma.

label: Selma Creek
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows SW into Bunches Creek.

label: Selma Township
description: central Johnston County.

label: Selwin
description: community in S Gates County.

label: Seminole
description: community in W Harnett County.

label: Semora
description: community in NE Caswell County. Settled prior to the Revolution and known as Campbell's Crossroads. Post office, est. 1877, named Semora for the daughter of the first postmaster, James M. McAden.

label: Seng Branch
description: rises in NW Yancey County and flows NW into Cane River. Named for the herb ginseng, which was gathered in large quantities in the vicinity beginning about 1837.

label: Seng Gap
description: N Madison County at the head of Little Laurel Creek.

label: Seng Ridge
description: NW Madison County between Alum Ridge and Camp Creek Bald.

label: Senia
description: community in W Avery County. Named for a local resident, Senia Pritchard.

label: Seniard Creek
description: rises in NW Henderson County and flows S into North Fork in Pisgah National Forest.

label: Seniard Mountain
description: on the Haywood-Transylvania County line at the N end of Lanning Ridge. Alt. 5,025.

label: Seniard Ridge
description: N Transylvania County, extends SE from Seniard Mountain to Looking Glass Rock.

label: Service Ridge
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a spur extending NW from Cataloochee Divide; center near lat. 35°33'27" N., long. 83°07'15" W., between Big Bald Branch and Little Bald Branch.

label: Servis Creek
description: rises in central Alamance County and flows E into Haw River.

label: Sessoms Mill Pond
description: on Chinkapin Creek in SE Hertford County; approx. ½ mi. long.

label: Setrock Creek
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows SE into South Toe River.

label: Settle
description: community in NE Iredell County served by post office, 1873-1906. Alt. 700. A weather station from the 1880s until mid-twentieth century.

label: Setzer Mountain
description: W Haywood County parallel to Campbell Creek. Named for a prominent family of early settlers. Maggie Setzer, for whom the community of Maggie was named, was a descendant of the family. The highest peak of the ridge, which is 2½ mi. long, is 4,810 ft. in elevation.

label: Setzer's Creek
description: rises in N central Caldwell County and flows SE into Warrior Creek. Named for John Setzer, who settled nearby about 1830.

label: Setzers Depot
description: See Claremont.

label: Setzers Gap
description: central Caldwell County. Alt. 1,342.

label: Seven Bridges
description: community in W Robeson County.

label: Seven Creeks
description: is formed in S Columbus County by Big Cypress Swamp and Monie Swamp. It flows SE into Waccamaw River.

label: Seven Devils
description: commercially developed recreation area opened in 1966 in E Avery and W Watauga Counties on a 1,288-acre tract.

label: Seven Mile Creek
description: rises in E Orange County and flows SE into W Durham County, where it enters Eno River.

label: Seven Mile Ridge
description: extends from E Madison County into the S part of the county and is parallel to Bull Creek and West Fork [Bull Creek]. Named for its length.

label: Seven Paths
description: community in E Franklin County.

label: Seven Sisters
description: sand hills a short distance S of Nags Head on Bodie Island, E Dare County.

label: Seven Springs
description: town in SE Wayne County on Neuse River. Inc. 1855 as Whitehall; reincorporated as White Hall, 1881; named for the plantation home of William Whitefield, who built there about 1741. Post office est. 1881 as Jericho; name changed to Seven Springs, 1894. Named for seven mineral springs, around which a resort operated from 1881 until 1944. The hotel and springhouse still stand. The Confederate ironclad Neuse was built there. A Civil War skirmish occurred there in December 1862. Alt. 75.

label: Seven Springs Gap
description: W Graham County between Hooper Mill Creek and Wright Creek in Nantahala National Forest. Alt. approx. 3,700.

label: Sevenmile Creek
description: rises in W Orange County and flows NE into Eno River W of town of Hillsborough.

label: Sevenmile Ridge
description: E Yancey County, extends NE from Stones Knob to Crabtree Creek near Cox Knob. Alt. approx. 4,400.

label: Sevenmile Swamp
description: rises in NW Sampson County and flows SE into Great Coharie Creek.

label: Seventy-First Township
description: W Cumberland County. Named for the 71st Highland Scots Regiment.

label: Severn
description: town in NE Northampton County served by post office, 1889-1939. Alt. 59. Settled about 1833 and known first as Meherrin for an Indian tribe that had lived in the vicinity. Inc. 1919. Named for Severn Ayers, a stockholder in the Seaboard Air Line Railroad.

label: Sevier
description: community in N McDowell County on North Fork [Catawba River]. Served by post office, 1892-1903. Alt. 1,401.

label: Seward
description: community in W Forsyth County.

label: Sexton
description: community in S Madison County on Bull Creek. Served by post office, 1892-1905.

label: Sexton's Branch
description: rises in NE Wake County and flows SE into Upper Bartons Creek.

label: Seymour Johnson Air Force Base
description: central Wayne County at Goldsboro. Est. 1941 as an Army Air Forces Technical Training School and named for Lt. Seymour Johnson (1904-41), Navy test pilot from Goldsboro.

label: Shacklefoot Island
description: See Brown's Island.

label: Shackleford Banks
description: one of the Outer Banks, SE Carteret County; approx. 8½ mi. long. Named for John Shackle ford, who, with Enoch Ward, purchased the "Sea Banks" in 1713. See also Cape Lookout National Seashore.

label: Shackleford Point
description: the W tip of Shackle ford Banks, SE Carteret County, extending into Beaufort Inlet. The community of Shackleford formerly existed near the point.

label: Shacktown
description: community in SE Yadkin County between North Deep Creek and South Deep Creek. Named for B. G. "Shack" Colvard, local businessman. Previously produced tobacco baskets.

label: Shad Coye
description: central Craven County in SE end of Hog Island adjacent to Neuse River. Approx. ¼ mi. wide.

label: Shad Point
description: on the NE mainland of Hyde County extending into the mouth of Long Shoal Bay.

label: Shaddock's Creek
description: is formed in SE Moore County by the junction of McDeeds and Mill Creeks. It flows E through Crystal Lake into Little River. The name was originally applied also to present McDeeds Creek. Named for Thomas Shaddock, an eighteenth-century settler.

label: Shaddox Creek
