description: See St. Andrew's Parish; St. Paul's Parish.

label: South Skitty Branch
description: rises in E Macon County and flows SW into Cliffside Lake.

label: South Spring Top
description: on the Haywood-Transylvania county line.

label: South Stony Fork Creek
description: rises in E Watauga County and flows SE into Wilkes County and into Stony Fork Creek.

label: South Sunbury
description: community in central Gates County on Raynor Swamp.

label: South Toe River
description: is formed in S Yancey County by the junction of Left Prong South Toe River and Right Prong South Toe River. It flows N to join North Toe River on the Mitchell-Yancey county line to form Toe River.

label: South Toe Township
description: S Yancey County.

label: South Tunis
description: community in E Hertford County.

label: South Turkey Creek
description: rises on the Buncombe-Haywood county line near Turkey Creek Gap and flows NE to join North Turkey Creek in forming Turkey Creek.

label: South Virginia
description: a name frequently applied from about 1612 to about 1663 to the area that subsequently became the County of Albemarle in the colony of Carolina. William Strachey's The Historie of Travell into Virginia Britannia (1612) contains a brief description of South Virginia. After the region began to be settled (ca. 1650), it was also referred to as the Southern Plantation. In 1662 Samuel Stephens was made commander of the Southern Plantation by the Virginia Council.

label: South Wadesboro
description: town in central Anson County. Wadesboro Cotton Mill built there in 1892. Town inc. in 1893, but long inactive in municipal affairs.

label: South Washington
description: former town in N central Pender County on Washington Creek near its mouth in Northeast Cape Fear River. Laid out about 1740 by Malatiah Hamilton as the center of trade for the Welsh Tract, which see. Inc. 1791 as South Washington. About 1840 moved approx. 1½ mi. SW to a site on the newly completed railroad and came to be called Hiawatha, corrupted into Watha, which see.

label: South West Parish
description: See St. Paul's Parish; Society Parish.

label: South West Township
description: E Lenoir County.

label: South Westfield Township
description: E Surry County.

label: South Whitakers Township
description: NE Nash County.

label: South Williams Township
description: S Columbus County.

label: South Wilmington
description: unincorporated outskirts of the city of Wilmington, W New Hanover County on the Cape Fear River.

label: South Yadkin River
description: rises in NE Alexander County and flows SE across Iredell County and to the Davie-Rowan county line, which it forms to its junction with Yadkin River. Also sometimes known as South Fork Yadkin River. Appears as "Sapona or Yatkin River" on the Moseley map, 1733. See also Cedar Run Creek; Mill Fork.

label: Southeast Muddy Creek
description: rises in SE McDowell County and flows NE into South Muddy Creek.

label: Southerlands Millpond
description: in E Vance County on Sandy Creek. Area 30 acres; max. depth 10 ft. Now used by the city of Henderson as a reservoir. See also Millford.

label: Southern City
description: See East Spencer.

label: Southern Mountain
description: central Transylvania County between Brushy Creek and Burl Mountain.

label: Southern Pines
description: town in S Moore County. Inc. 1887. Known earlier as Vineland, but the Post Office Department would not accept the name because of possible confusion with the town of the same name in New Jersey. Named for its location on the edge of the longleafpine belt. A popular winter resort. West Southern Pines, inc. 1923, became a part of Southern Pines in 1931. Alt. 516. Sandhills Community College, est. 1965, is located there.

label: Southern Plantation
description: See South Virginia.

label: Southern Shores
description: town and resort community in NE Dare County on the S coast of North Banks between Kitty Hawk and Duck. Inc. 1969.

label: Southerne Virginia Sea
description: appears on the Comberford map, 1657, as the area of the Atlantic Ocean off the Outer Banks of modern North Carolina, roughly between the coast and the Gulf Stream.

label: Southmont
description: community in S Davidson County on High Rock Lake and the Winston-Salem Southbound Railway. Post office there, 1883-1906, was known as Fairmont. Reestablished as Southmont in 1910; probably named for the new Winston-Salem Southbound Railway. Alt. 669.

label: Southport
description: town, SE Brunswick County on Cape Fear River. Fort Johnston, which see, built there, 1748-64. The town began to develop by 1792 and was named Smithville for Gen. Benjamin Smith (1751-1826). Inc. in 1805 and made county seat in 1808; remained so until a new government center opened near Bolivia in 1978. Name changed to Southport in 1889 because it was the southernmost seaport in the state. Alt. 26.

label: Southside
description: community in central Lincoln County. Named for a mill built on the S side of Lincolnton in 1891. Alt. 753.

label: Southwest Creek
description: rises in W Onslow County and flows SE into New River. Appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Southwest Fork [Alligator River]
description: rises in S Tyrrell County near Alligator Lake and flows NE into Northwest Fork [Alligator River].

label: Southwest Prong Branch
description: rises in W central Carteret County and flows N into Moon Creek.

label: Southwest Stony Fork Creek
description: rises in E Watauga County and flows SE into W Wilkes County to enter Stony Fork Creek.

label: Southwood
description: community in S Bladen County in Carvers Creek Township.

label: Sowell Run
description: rises in S Greene County and flows NE into Rainbow Creek. Named for the Sowell family, which settled in the vicinity before the Revolution.

label: Sowell's Mill Creek
description: See Mill Creek.

label: Spaightville
description: a town inc. 1802 and authorized to be laid out on the "ne side of French Broad River … opposite, or a little above the upper Warm Springs" to accommodate visitors to the springs. It is not known whether the town ever existed, but it is reasonable to assume that the present Hot Springs, which see, in W Madison County is its "descendant." Spaightville was undoubtedly named for Governor Richard Dobbs Spaight (1758-1802), who died approx. 2 months before the act was passed.

label: Spain Branch
description: rises in S Buncombe County and flows SE into Avery Creek.

label: Spainhour Creek
description: rises in central Caldwell County and flows SW approx. 4 mi. into Lower Creek.

label: Spains Creek
description: rises in SE Onslow County and flows SW into Sulliers Bay.

label: Spangenberg Creek
description: See Silas Creek.

label: Spanish Oak Branch
description: rises in N Watauga County and flows S into Buffalo Branch.

label: Spanish Oak Gap
description: S Haywood County on Shining Creek.

label: Spanish Oak Hill
description: SW Alamance County.

label: Spanish Oak Mountain
description: central Avery County.

label: Spanking Back Creek
description: See Silas Creek.

label: Sparkling Catawba Springs
description: See Catawba Springs.

label: Sparkman
description: community in W Onslow County served by post office, 1888-1909.

label: Sparks Creek
description: appears on the Collet map, 1770, in NW Davidson County N of Fryes Creek. It flows W into Muddy Creek.

label: Sparks Gap
description: central Mitchell County on Pumpkin Patch Mountain.

label: Sparks Ridge
description: E Mitchell County between Bear Creek and Bailey Meadows.

label: Sparta
description: town and county seat, central Alleghany County. Post office est. there as Bower's Store, 1825; name changed to Gap Civil, 1846, and to Sparta, 1879. Inc. 1879. Named for the ancient city in Greece. Alt. 2,939. Produces apparel and textiles. See also Gap Civil Township.

label: Sparta
description: See Old Sparta.

label: Sparta Mill Pond
description: central Alleghany County on Little River. Formed in 1920. Covers 8 acres; max. depth 10 ft. Fishing and swimming.

label: Sparta Township
description: former township in SE Edgecombe County, now township no. 8.

label: Spear
description: community in W Avery County; settled 1815-30. Named for nearby Spear Tops Mountain.

label: Spear Tops Mountain
description: on Avery-Mitchell county line. Named because of its two spear-shaped peaks.

label: Speculation Land
description: massive tract in W Polk and E Henderson Counties acquired in 1790s by Speculation Land Company organized by Tench Coxe of Philadelphia. Some property remained unclaimed into the mid-twentieth century. In time, land was managed by Carolina Power Company (later Duke Power) and today is part of the Green River wildlife management area.

label: Speed
description: town in E Edgecombe County; inc. 1901. Named for E. T. Speed.

label: Speedwell
description: community in W Jackson County on Tilley Creek.

label: Speights Bridge
description: former community in N Greene County on Contentnea Creek. Settled about 1751 by Speight family, some of whom operated a toll bridge there. Civil War muster grounds a short distance n. When Fieldsboro (now Walstonburg) developed during the 1880s, Speights Bridge declined.

label: Speights Bridge Township
description: N Greene County.

label: Spence Field
description: bald spot on the Swain County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°33'48" N., long. 83°43'58" W. Alt. 4,886.

label: Spencer
description: See Spencerville.

label: Spencer Mountain
description: community immediately N of the mountain of the same name, E central Gaston County. Inc. 1895 as town of Spencer Mountain Mills. Charter repealed 1909.

label: Spencers Fork
description: rises in NE Caldwell County and flows SW into Brumleys Creek.

label: Spencerville
description: community in NW Moore County served by post office, 1888-1907. Known as Spencer until 1897.

label: Spences Corner
description: community in W Camden County; named for a pioneer family in the area and dates from about 1700.

label: Spero
description: See Balfours.

label: Spewmarrow Creek
description: rises in N Granville County and flows NW into Grassy Creek.

label: Spice Bottom Creek
description: rises in SW Watauga County and flows NE into Watauga River.

label: Spice Cove
description: the valley through which Spice Cove Branch flows in N Buncombe County.

label: Spice Cove Branch
description: rises in W Transylvania County and flows SE into North Fork French Broad River.

label: Spice Creek
description: rises in W Watauga County and flows NE into Laurel Creek.

label: Spicers Bay
description: S Onslow County in Stump Sound. Named for John Spicer.

label: Spices Cove
description: NE Buncombe County between Pinnacle Mountain and Dillingham Creek.

label: Spies (speece)
description: community in NW Moore County.

label: Spikes Creek
description: rises in SW Gates County and flows SE into Chowan River.

label: Spillcorn Creek
description: rises in N Madison County and flows SW into Big Laurel Creek. Said to have been named because an early settler spilled a load of corn in the creek.

label: Spilona
description: community in central Johnston County served by post office, 1882-1903.

label: Spindale
description: town in central Rutherford County. Est. 1916 by K. S. Tanner and named by him for its location in a valley where cotton mills were est. Inc. 1923. Isothermal Community College, est. 1966, is located there.

label: Spit Bay
description: between Davis Island and Davis Shore in Core Sound in E Carteret County.

label: Spivey Creek
description: rises in NW Yancey County and flows NW into Tennessee, where it enters Indian Creek.

label: Spivey Gap
description: central Buncombe County between Spivey and Miller Mountains.

label: Spivey Mountain
description: central Buncombe County N of Deaver View Mountain. Alt. 3,317.

label: Spiveys Corner
description: community in N Sampson County near Little Coharie Creek. Formerly known also as West Crossroads.

label: Spiveys Pond
description: See Lake Tabor.

label: Splash Dam Lake
description: E Transylvania County, drains SW into Cascade Lake. Covers 5 acres and has a max. depth of 30 ft.

label: Splashy
description: See Spray.

label: Splendor
description: community in S Henderson County served by post office, 1887-1905.

label: Split Mountain
description: E Haywood County between Fines Creek and the county line.

label: Split Whiteoak Ridge
description: W Macon County between Whiteoak Creek and Gold Pit Creek.

label: Spooks Branch
description: rises in central Buncombe County near Lewis Gap and flows NW into Beaverdam Creek.

label: Spooners Bay
description: in Brown's Sound, S Onslow County. Probably named for Jabez Spooner, landowner in the vicinity by 1743. Sometimes mistakenly called Schooners Bay.

label: Spooners Creek
description: rises in S Carteret County and flows S into Bogue Sound.

label: Spoonwater Creek
description: rises in NE Person County and flows NW into Maho Creek. Said to have received its name because it is so shallow that anyone wanting water from it would have to use a spoon to dip it up.

label: Spot
description: community on Currituck Sound, S Currituck County. Formerly Hog Quarter, but renamed when a post office was est. there about 1920 (spot is a fish that is caught locally).

label: Spot Knob
description: on Haywood-Jackson county line. Alt. 5,900-6,000.

label: Spout Branch
description: rises in W Avery County and flows E into Roaring Creek.

label: Spout Branch
description: rises in SW Madison County and flows SE into Little Creek.

label: Spout Springs
description: community in SW Harnett County. Once the center of a lumber and naval-stores industry. Alt. approx. 330.

label: Sprawls Old Field
description: See Norman.

label: Spray
description: former town in N Rockingham County on Smith River. Settled about 1813, when James Burnett est. gristmill at falls of Smith River. Site of cotton mill founded by future governor John M. Morehead; later operated by his son J. Turner Morehead. Known first as Splashy from the water thrown up by a waterwheel at a local mill; name later changed in 1890 to the more sophisticated Spray. Inc. 1951; merged with Leaksville and Draper in 1967 to form Eden, which see. Alt. 625.

label: Spread Branch
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows N into Bunches Creek.

label: Spread Eagle Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SW into Pile Creek.

label: Spring
description: community in SE Iredell County served by post office, 1898-1903.

label: Spring Bank
description: former plantation and ferry, central Wayne County on Neuse River midway between the mouths of Stoney and Sleepy Creeks. Owned by Joseph Green Sr., largest slave owner in the county in 1790 and a member of the General Assembly. In 1784 Spring Bank was designated as a location for the receipt and inspection of tobacco. The Price map, 1808, shows only Green's Ferry at the location.

label: Spring Branch
description: rises in W Franklin County and flows SE into Little River.

label: Spring Branch
description: rises in SW Wilson County and flows SE into Black Creek.

label: Spring Creek
description: rises in SW Madison County and flows NE into French Broad River.

label: Spring Creek
description: See Florence.

label: Spring Creek Gap
description: on the Haywood-Madison county line.

label: Spring Creek Mountain
description: extends NE from Frieze-land Creek in S Madison County to Rector Branch. Hop Mountain, with an alt. of 4,072 ft., is a peak on the mountain.

label: Spring Creek Township
description: former township in SW Madison County, now township no. 8.

label: Spring Garden
description: former community in N Rockingham County named for Gallaway and Scales plantation. Served by post office, 1823-40.

label: Spring Garden
description: See Castle Hayne.

label: Spring Hill
description: community in E Haywood County on Garden Creek.

label: Spring Hill Plantation
description: See East Spencer.

label: Spring Hill Township
description: NE Scotland County.

label: Spring Hope
description: town in W Nash County. Inc. 1889. Previously located approx. 4 mi. SE, but moved after a railroad was constructed in 1886-87. Said to have been named by early settlers who hoped a spring nearby would always provide water for the community. Produces lumber and apparel. Alt. 261.

label: Spring Lake
description: town in NW Cumberland County near E limits of Fort Bragg Military Reservation. Inc. 1951. See also Manchester.

label: Spring Mountain
description: SE Buncombe County between Laughter Cove and Cane Creek.

label: Spring Mountain
description: on the Madison County, N.C.-Greene County, Tenn., line.

label: Spring Mountain Branch
description: rises in SE Buncombe County and flows SW into Cane Creek.

label: Spring Point
description: central Onslow County in Farnell Bay of New River.

label: Spring Shoals
description: See McAdenville.

label: Springdale
description: community in SE Haywood County served by post office, 1876-1923.

label: Springer
description: community in W Onslow County served by post office, 1890-1917.

label: Springers Point
description: point of land from Ocracoke Island, near community of Ocracoke, extending into Pamlico Sound, SE Hyde County.

label: Springfield
description: community in N Wilkes County on North Prong Roaring River.

label: Springhill
description: community in Cumberland County near present Fayetteville; active trading center in mid-eighteenth century. Mentioned in Moravian records.

label: Springhill Township
description: SW Wilson County.

label: Springhouse Ridge
description: E Clay County between Arch and Bruce Ridges.

label: Sprinkle Branch
description: rises in central Madison County on the W slope of High Rock Ridge and flows SE 1½ mi. to empty into Walnut Creek at the community of Walnut Creek.

label: Sprinkle Cove
description: NE Buncombe County near the junction of Walker and Dillingham Creeks.

label: Sprinkle Creek
description: rises in E Madison County and flows SE into California Creek.

label: Spruce Fork
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows SW into Beetree Creek.

label: Spruce Knob
description: S Watauga County NW of White Rock Ridge.

label: Spruce Mountain
description: Haywood and Swain Counties in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Balsam Mountain near lat. 35°36'48" N., long. 83°10'34" W. Alt. 5,590.

label: Spruce Mountain Ridge
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a spur extending E from Spruce Mountain on Balsam Mountain; center near lat. 35°36'40" N., long. 83°09'05" W.

label: Spruce Pine
description: town in S Mitchell County on North Toe River. Alt. 2,620. Inc. 1907. Named for a large Carolina hemlock, locally called spruce pine, which grew near a tavern operated by Isaac English. Produces apparel, hosiery, textiles, minerals, and lumber.

label: Spruce Pine Cove
description: N Buncombe County between Wiley Mountain and Coles Cove.

label: Spruce Pine Mountain
description: SW Avery County.

label: Spruce Pine Ridge
description: NE Buncombe County between Waterfall and Carter Creeks.

label: Spruce Pinnacle
description: NE Buncombe County on Big Fork Ridge.

label: Spruce Ridge
description: S Haywood County between Cherry Cove Creek and Shiny Creek.

label: Spruills Bridge
description: E Washington County SE of Creswell. First known as Samuel Spruills Landing; designated by the General Assembly in 1740 as a point for a warehouse for receipt and shipping of crown quitrents. Called Spruills Landing as late as 1812.

label: Spur Ridge
description: E Mitchell County parallel to Green Cove Creek.

label: Spurgeon
description: community in S Wilkes County near Hunting Creek.

label: Spurgeon Creek
description: rises in NE Davidson County and flows S into Abbotts Creek.

label: Spurrier
description: community in W Mecklenburg County.

label: Squally Creek
description: rises in W Graham County and flows E into West Buffalo Creek.

label: Squhawky
description: See Williamston.

label: Squirrel Branch
description: rises in W Madison County near Squirrels Gap and flows W into Spring Creek.

label: Squirrel Creek
description: rises in W Lenoir County and flows N into Neuse River.

label: Squirrel Gap
description: N Transylvania County between Laurel Brook and South Fork Mills River.

label: Squirrels Gap
description: W Madison County on the SW end of Hot Springs Mountain.

label: Squyars Canal
description: See New Lake Fork.

label: St. Andrew's Parish
description: Church of England, Tyrrell County, est. 1729 with the formation of the county and coextensive with it. Previous to the formation of the county, the territory had been South Shore Parish (est. 1722), Chowan County. In 1767 St. Andrew's Parish had 594 white taxables. See also St. Paul's Parish.

label: St. Asaph's District
description: one of the districts into which Orange County was divided at the time of the 1790 census. It contained 199 heads of families.

label: St. Barnabas’ Parish
description: Church of England, Hertford County, est. 1759 with the formation of the county and coextensive with it. The parish in 1767 had 900 white taxables.

label: St. Bartholomew's Parish
description: Church of England, Chatham County, est. with the formation of the county in 1770 and coextensive with it. St. Bartholomew's Parish of the Episcopal Church still functions in Pittsboro.

label: St. Clair Creek
description: rises in Jackson Swamp, E Beaufort County, and flows SE into Pamlico River.

label: St. Colomb Parish
description: See Donegal County.

label: St. David's District
description: one of the districts into which Caswell County was divided at the time of the 1790 census. It contained 166 heads of families.

label: St. David's Parish
description: Church of England, Cumberland County, est. 1754 with the formation of the county and coextensive with it. In 1767 the parish had 899 white taxables, described as "mostly Scotch—Support a Presbyterian Minister."

label: St. Gabriel's Parish
description: Church of England, Duplin County, est. 1750 with the formation of the county and coextensive with it. In 1767 there were 1,071 white taxables in the parish. St. Gabriel's Parish of the Episcopal Church functions in Faison at present, though there is some question of its unbroken descent from the colonial parish.

label: St. George's Parish
description: See Hyde Parish.

label: St. Helena
description: community in central Pender County. Alt. 55. Settled 1908 by a colony of Italian farmers. Saint Helena (d. about 330) was the mother of Constantine the Great, Roman emperor. Hugh MacRae, Wilmington entrepreneur, developed the community as an agricultural colony for immigrants.

label: St. James District
description: one of the districts into which Caswell County was divided at the time of the 1790 census. It contained 111 heads of families.

label: St. James’ Parish
description: Church of England, New Hanover County, probably est. in 1729 with the creation of the county and coextensive with it. The parish is mentioned as early as 1734. In 1741 St. James's Parish was divided to form St. Philip's Parish on the S side of the Cape Fear River. With the creation of Brunswick County in 1764, St. Philip's Parish became coextensive with it and St. James's Parish with New Hanover. St. James’ Parish of the Episcopal Church still functions in Wilmington.

label: St. John's Parish
description: Church of England, Pasquotank County, est. in 1701. In 1715 the parish was divided, leaving St. John's on the SW side of the Pasquotank River and creating St. Peter's Parish on the NE side. In 1756 the two parishes were consolidated to form St. John's Parish. In 1767 the parish had 433 white taxables and was described as a "weak parish."

label: St. Johns
description: community in S Pitt County.

label: St. Johns Township
description: SW Hertford County.

label: St. Jude's Parish
description: Church of England, Surry County, est. 1771 with the formation of the county and coextensive with it.

label: St. Lawrence District
description: one of the districts into which Caswell County was divided at the time of the 1790 census. It contained 215 heads of families.

label: St. Lewis
description: town in S Edgecombe County served by post office, 1886-1904. Inc. 1895, but not now active in municipal affairs. Named for first postmaster, John I. Lewis.

label: St. Luke's Parish
description: Church of England, Rowan County, est. 1753 with the formation of the county and coextensive with it. In 1767 the parish had 3,000 white taxables. Dobbs Parish, organized by the Moravians in the Wachovia settlement, was created from St. Luke's Parish in 1755. St. Luke's Parish of the Episcopal Church still functions in Salisbury.

label: St. Lukes District
description: one of the districts into which Caswell County was divided at the time of the 1790 census. It contained 137 heads of families.

label: St. Margaret's Parish
description: Church of England, Wake County, est. with the formation of the county in 1770 and coextensive with it. (The parish probably was named for Saint Margaret because the county was named for Margaret Wake, wife of Governor William Tryon.)

label: St. Mark's District
description: one of the districts into which Orange County was divided at the time of the 1790 census. It contained 138 heads of families.

label: St. Martin
description: community in S Stanly County between Big Bear Creek and Little Bear Creek. Named for a local Lutheran church.

label: St. Martin's Parish
description: Church of England, Mecklenburg County, est. 1762 with the formation of the county and coextensive with it. The parish in 1767 had 1,600 white taxables, described as "mostly Presbyterians." St. Martin's Episcopal Church still exists in Charlotte.

label: St. Mary's District
description: one of the districts into which Orange County was divided at the time of the 1790 census. It contained 237 heads of families.

label: St. Mary's Parish
description: Church of England, Edgecombe County, est. 1756 by the division of the Parish of Edgecombe. St. Mary's Parish was in the S and the Parish of Edgecombe in the n. With the creation of Halifax County from Edgecombe County in 1758, the Parish of Edgecombe (est. 1741 with the formation of Edgecombe County) became coextensive with the new county. St. Mary's Parish then became coextensive with Edgecombe County. In 1767 St. Mary's Parish had 1,200 white taxables.

label: St. Marys Township
description: E Wake County.

label: St. Matthew's Parish
description: Church of England, Orange County, est. in 1752 with the formation of the county and coextensive with it. In 1767 the parish had 3,573 white taxables, making it the most populous parish in the colony. Reestablished in 1824, St. Matthew's Parish of the Episcopal Church continues to function in Hillsborough.

label: St. Matthews Township
description: E central Wake County.

label: St. Michael's Parish
description: Church of England, Pitt County, est. 1760 with the formation of the county and coextensive with it. In 1767 the parish had 775 white taxables and was described as a "small county—willing to make provision for a Minister."

label: St. Patrick's Parish
description: Church of England, Johnston (later Dobbs) County, est. 1746 with the formation of Johnston County. It was coextensive with the county but divided in 1756 to form St. Stephen's Parish in the W part of the county. St. Patrick's was in the e. With the creation of Dobbs County in 1758, St. Patrick's Parish became coextensive with that county. In 1767 the parish had 1,268 white taxables. The present counties of Wayne, Lenoir, and Greene are made up wholly or in part of territory that was once St. Patrick's Parish.

label: St. Paul's Parish
description: Church of England, Chowan County, est. in 1701. In 1715 the parish was divided to create South West Parish in the W part of the county. The area became Bertie County in 1722, and coextensive with it was Society Parish. In 1722 St. Paul's Parish was further divided to create South Shore Parish in the S part of the county on the S shore of Albemarle Sound. With the creation of Tyrrell County in 1729, South Shore Parish became St. Andrew's Parish, coextensive with the county. In 1767 St. Paul's Parish had 900 white taxables. St. Paul's Parish of the Episcopal Church still functions in Edenton. St. Paul's Church there was begun in 1736.

label: St. Pauls
description: town in NE Robeson County. Inc. 1909. Named for local Presbyterian church. Post office est. there in 1832 was named Tutons for first postmaster Oliver Tuton; changed to St. Pauls about 4 years later. Originally the settlement centered on a stage depot on the Fayetteville-Lumberton road about 3 mi. from present site. When the railroad came through about 1900, the settlement drifted S to center around the depot. Produces textiles.

label: St. Pauls Township
description: NE Robeson County.

label: St. Peter's Parish
description: See St. John's Parish.

label: St. Philip's Parish
description: Church of England, New Hanover, later Brunswick County, est. in 1741 when St. James’ Parish, which see, was divided. St. Philip's Parish was that part of the county S of the Cape Fear River. With the creation of Brunswick County in 1764, St. Philip's Parish became coextensive with the new county. The parish had 224 white taxable inhabitants in 1767, described as being "mostly Gentlemen." The ruins of St. Philip's Church, completed in 1765, begun a number of years earlier, still stand near Orton Plantation, Brunswick County, at the site of the old town of Brunswick.

label: St. Stephen's Parish
description: Church of England, Johnston County, est. 1756 in the W part of the county upon the division of St. Patrick's Parish. When Dobbs County was formed from Johnston County in 1758, St. Patrick's became coextensive with the new county. St. Stephen's Parish then was coextensive with Johnston County. In 1767 the parish had 1,229 white taxables, described as "able to make provision for a minister."

label: St. Thomas District
description: one of the districts into which Orange County was divided at the time of the 1790 census. It contained 139 heads of families.

label: St. Thomas Parish
description: Church of England, Tryon County, est. 1768 with the formation of the county and coextensive with it. In 1767 the parish was described as "too unsettled to make provision for a Minister."

label: St. Thomas’ Parish
description: Church of England, Beaufort County, organized 1701. St. Thomas’ Church in Bath (oldest church building in North Carolina) was constructed in 1734. The parish had 110 white taxables in 1767. St. Thomas’ Parish of the Episcopal Church still functions in Bath.

label: Stacey Creek
description: rises in SE Avery County and flows NW into Linville River.

label: Staceyville
description: See Stacy.

label: Stackhouse
description: community in N Madison County on French Broad River at the mouth of Woolsey Branch. Alt. 1,418.

label: Stacy
description: community and railroad flag stop in E Rockingham County. Named for local landowner Iverson Stacy. Appears as Staceyville on an 1860 map.

label: Stafford Hill
description: peak in the Cane Creek Mountains, S Alamance County.

label: Staffords Creek
description: rises in S Caldwell County and flows S into Catawba River on the Burke-Caldwell county line. Formerly also known as James Mill Creek and McCalls Mill Creek.

label: Staffords Mill
description: community in NW Guilford County near Oak Ridge. Called Saunders Mill during the American Revolution. Cornwallis's troops ground corn there.

label: Stag Creek
description: rises in NE Alamance County and flows S into Back Creek.

label: Stag Park
description: community and former plantation, central Pender County on the Northeast Cape Fear River. Named in 1663 by Barbadian explorers for parklike terrain on which they saw deer feeding. Appears on the Ogilby map, 1671. Governor George Burrington in about 1730 acquired 10,000 acres there and built a summer home.

label: Stagg Creek
description: rises in NW Ashe County and flows SE into North Fork New River.

label: Stagger Weed Creek
description: rises in E Mitchell County and flows NW to join Mine Fork Branch in forming Right Fork [Cane Creek].

label: Stagville
description: See Fairntosh.

label: Staircase Mountain
description: NW Caldwell County near Maple Grove.

label: Staire Branch
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows NW into Walker Branch.

label: Stairs Mountain
description: S Haywood County on the head of Crawford Creek. Alt. 5,869.

label: Stairwalk Ridge
description: SE Buncombe County E of Potato Knob.

label: Stairway Falls
description: SW Transylvania County in Horsepasture River downstream from High Falls.

label: Stalcup Top
description: S Cherokee County near the headwaters of Little Brasstown Creek.

label: Staley
description: town in E Randolph County. Post office est. there in 1883 as Staleyville. Inc. 1901 as Staley. Named for Col. John W. Staley, Confederate soldier. Alt. 725.

label: Staley Creek
description: rises in central Alamance County and flows NE into Servis Creek.

label: Staleyville
description: See Staley.

label: Stallings
description: community in NW Union County.

label: Stallings Crossroads
description: community in NW Beaufort County.

label: Stallings Station
description: See Clayton.

label: Stamey Cove
description: E Haywood County on the head of Stamey Cove Branch.

label: Stamey Cove Branch
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows SE into Pigeon River.

label: Stamey Cove Gap
description: E Haywood County on the SW end of Anderson Mountain.

label: Stamper
description: community in S Halifax County.

label: Stamy Knob
description: central Clay County between Peckerwood Creek and Cold Branch.

label: Stancell
description: See Oak Grove.

label: Standard
description: community in W Pitt County. Alt. 74.

label: Standhill Mountain
description: SW Buncombe County N of Buzzard Knob.

label: Standing Indian
description: peak on the Clay-Macon county line. The Indian name was Yunwitsulenunyi (where the man stood). Alt. 5,500. The peak has been called "the grandstand of the southern Appalachians."

label: Standing Indian Wildlife Management Area
description: SE Clay County.

label: Standingstone Mountain
description: at the junction of the lines of Henderson and Transylvania Counties, N.C., and Greenville County, S.C.

label: Stanfield
description: town in SW Stanly County. Inc. 1955.

label: Stanfield Branch
description: rises in N Buncombe County and flows W into Dick Branch.

label: Stanford
description: See Burgaw.

label: Stanhope
description: community in S Nash County. Was site of pre-Civil War Stanhope Academy. Community of Old Stanhope, about 2 mi. w, was a stop on the Raleigh-Tarboro stage line. Named for Stanhope Crenshaw who operated the stage line prior to 1896.

label: Stanley
description: town in N Gaston County. Inc. 1897 as Brevard Station and named for Robert Alexander Brevard, who gave land in 1861 for railroad station. Renamed Stanley Creek, 1893, and Stanley, 1911. Produces zippers and textiles. Alt. 852.

label: Stanley Branch
description: rises in N Buncombe County near Lankford Mountain and flows W into Dick Branch.

label: Stanley Creek
description: See Stanley.

label: Stanleyville
description: community in N central Forsyth County.

label: Stanly County
description: was formed in 1841 from Montgomery County. Located in the central section of the state, it is bounded by Montgomery, Richmond, Anson, Union, Cabarrus, and Rowan Counties. It was named for John Stanly (1774-1834), member of the General Assembly, several times speaker of the House of Commons, and member of Congress. Area: 406 sq. mi. County seat: Albemarle, with an elevation of 505 ft. Townships are Almond, Big Lick, Center, Endy, Furr, Harris, North Albemarle, Ridenhour, South Albemarle, and Tyson. Produces wheat, oats, corn, barley, lespedeza, poultry, eggs, dairy products, hogs, livestock, textiles, bakery products, mobile homes, tires, wood products, furniture, aluminum, lumber, brick, and crushed stone.

label: Stansbury
description: community in S central Brunswick County.

label: Stansfield Branch
description: rises in E Macon County and flows N into Cullasaja River.

label: Stanton
description: community in W Wilkes County served by post office, 1898-1915.

label: Stanton
description: See South Creek.

label: Stanton Township
description: W Wilkes County.

label: Stanton's Gut
description: stream, begins in SE Wilson County at the NE outskirts of Stantonsburg and runs SW into Contentnea Creek after a course of approx. 2 mi.

label: Stanton-Harrold
description: See South Creek.

label: Stantonsburg
description: town in SE Wilson County on Contentnea Creek. Alt. 92. Inc. 1817. Post office name in 1828 was Stantonburgh. Named for Willie J. Stanton, one on the first commissioners, or James Stanton, first mayor. The former community of Moyton, named for Francis M. Moye, on the E outskirts of the town, is now a part of Stantonsburg.

label: Stantonsburg Township
description: S Wilson County.

label: Star
description: town in E Montgomery County. Inc. 1897. Named by Angus Leach, local merchant, because of the high elevation of the site, visible from all directions. Known first as Hunsucker's Store. Alt. 637. Produces textiles and hosiery.

label: Star Branch
description: rises in N central Yancey County and flows NW into Jacks Creek.

label: Star Hollow
description: valley of Star Branch, W Avery County.

label: Star Peak
description: See Fox Knob.

label: Starkey Gap
description: on the Swain County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°34'12" N., long. 83°40'15" W.

label: Starkey Ridge
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°32'58" N., long. 83°37'47" W.

label: Starkey's Hammock
description: See The Hammock.

label: Starkeys Creek
description: rises in NE Onslow County and flows SE into White Oak River. Formerly called Great Swamp. Probably named for John Starkey, pioneer settler.

label: Starlight
description: community in SW Wayne County served by post office, 1894-1905.

label: Starling
description: community in SE Onslow County near the head of Queens Creek. Named for Sam Starling.

label: Starling's Bridge
description: See Falcon.

label: Starnes Branch
description: rises in central Transylvania County and flows S into Davidson River.

label: Starnes Cove
description: central Buncombe County NW of Starnes Ridge.

label: Starnes Ridge
description: central Buncombe County W of Ragsdale Creek.

label: Starretts Meadows
description: E Onslow County between the head of Wallace Creek and the head of Bear Creek.

label: Starsburg
description: community in S Cumberland County served by post office, 1885-1906.

label: Startown
description: community in central Catawba County. Named for pioneer Starr family. Earlier known as Danville.

label: State Line Gap
description: N the Watauga County, N.C.-Johnson County, Tenn., line near the head of Little Beaverdam Creek. Alt. 3,738.

label: State Line Ridge
description: on the Watauga County, N.C.-Johnson County, Tenn., line, extends SE from State Line Gap to the head of Cove Creek.

label: State Ridge
description: in the N tip of Cherokee County along the North Carolina-Tennessee state line.

label: State Road
description: community in W Surry County near the head of Camp Creek. Said to have taken its name from a "state road camp" est. there temporarily during the construction of a highway.

label: Stateline
description: See Collinstown.

label: Statesville
description: city and county seat, central Iredell County. Authorized to be laid out in 1789 and probably named in honor of the fact that North Carolina had approved the federal Constitution a few weeks previously and thus had become a state. Inc. 1847. Settlement grew up around Fourth Creek Presbyterian Church, organized there in 1753. Home of Mitchell Community College. Produces textiles, apparel, fabricated metals, furniture, flour, lumber, and machinery. Alt. 925. See also Fourth Creek.

label: Statesville Township
description: central Iredell County.

label: Staton
description: community in N Pitt County. Alt. 42.

label: Statons Pond
description: central Martin County, is fed by the waters of several streams: Hardison Mill Creek, Ready Branch, and Smithwick Creek. It is drained by Sweetwater Creek. The pond is approx. 2 mi. long.

label: Stauken's Quarter Creek
description: See Stinking Quarter Creek.

label: Staunton
description: See Kittrell.

label: Steadmans Creek
description: rises in central Stokes County and flows N into Dan River.

label: Steadmans Lake
description: is formed by a dam across Steadmans Creek, central Stokes County. Covers about 15 acres; max. depth 30 ft. Owned by Izaak Walton League of America.

label: Stearns
description: community in W central Polk County.

label: Stecoah
description: community in E Graham County on Stecoah Creek. Alt. 2,030. Name derived from Cherokee word stika'yi, the meaning of which ethnologist James Mooney believed to be lost, though it is thought by local residents to mean "lean" in the sense of "no game."

label: Stecoah Creek
description: rises in E Graham County and flows NE into Little Tennessee River.

label: Stecoah Gap
description: E Graham County between the headwaters of Sweetwater Creek and Stecoah Creek.

label: Stecoah Township
description: NE Graham County.

label: Stedman
description: town in E Cumberland County. Inc. 1913. Named for Charles M. Stedman (1841-1930), president of the North Carolina Railroad and last Confederate veteran to serve in Congress. The nineteenth-century community (with a post office) of Blocker's or Blockersville was at or near the site of Stedman.

label: Steeds
description: community in NE Montgomery County served by post office, 1897-1953. Named in 1898 for J. W. Steeds, local merchant. Alt. 662.

label: Steel Creek
description: See Steele Creek.

label: Steel Trap Ridge
description: extends from central Cherokee County NE to N Cherokee County between Bald and Hanging Dog Creeks.

label: Steele Creek
description: rises in W Mecklenburg County and flows S into South Carolina, where it enters Catawba River. The name appears on the Collet map, 1770, but is applied to the head of present Kings Branch. Named for Moses Steele, beaver hunter.

label: Steele Creek
description: community in SW Mecklenburg County. Steele Creek Presbyterian Church there was organized in 1760. A post office was est. there as early as 1828. Often spelled as Steel Creek on early maps.

label: Steele Creek Township
description: former township in SW Mecklenburg County, now township no. 3.

label: Steele Township
description: W central Rowan County. Named for Gen. John Steele (1764-1815).

label: Steeles Mill
description: See Cordova.

label: Steeles Township
description: NW Richmond County.

label: Steelman Creek
description: rises in S Yadkin County and flows SE into N Davie County, where it enters Dutchmans Creek.

label: Steels Creek
description: rises in NW Burke County and flows SE into Upper Creek. Flows between Tettered Rock Ridge and Rip Skin Ridge.

label: Steels Ridge
description: community in S Bertie County.

label: Steeltrap Creek
description: rises in N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows SW into Forney Creek.

label: Steeltrap Knob
description: in S Macon County between Bearpen Mountain and Mooney Branch.

label: Steep Hill Branch
description: rises in W Johnston County and flows SE into Middle Creek. Mentioned in local records as early as 1770.

label: Steep Point
description: extends from the mainland of NE Carteret County into Core Sound.

label: Steep Rock Mountain
description: peak in W Randolph County.

label: Steer Gap
description: E Haywood County between Hungry Creek and Pisgah Creek.

label: Steestachee Bald
description: on the Haywood-Jackson county line. Alt. 5,700. Named for the Indian word for rats or nest of rats. Indian hunters are said to have found and destroyed a nest of rats there.

label: Steestachee Branch
description: rises near Steestachee Bald in SW Haywood County and flows E into Allen Creek.

label: Stella
description: community in W Carteret County on White Oak River. Alt. 30, the highest point in the county. Originally named Barkers Bridge in honor of a local doctor, but when a post office was est. in 1866, the Post Office Department declined to accept the name.

label: Stem
description: town in S Granville County. Inc. 1911. Named for W. T. Stem, local landowner. The area was first served by the Tally Ho post office, 1 mi. ne. In 1889, however, the post office was moved there and the name changed. Alt. 470. See also Tally Ho.

label: Stephens Creek
description: rises in S Macon County and flows NE into Cullasaja River.

label: Stephens Crossroads
description: community in E Rockingham County served by Confederate post office. Named for Hiram Stephens, who migrated from New York in 1876.

label: Stephens Swamp
description: rises in E Duplin County and flows SW into Muddy Creek.

label: Stephenson
description: community in W Johnston County served by post office, 1893-1903.

label: Stephenson's Lake
description: a spring-fed lake covering 35 acres 2 mi. E of Garysburg, W Northampton County. Numerous wild ducks and geese winter there each year.

label: Stepp Branch
description: rises in SE Buncombe County and flows NW into Swannanoa River.

label: Stepp's Cove
description: on the S side of Point Lookout in NE Henderson County about 1½ mi. E of community of Edneyville. Named for Fannie Stepp, who, according to legend, was scalped there by Cherokee warriors in 1779.

label: Stepps Gap
description: S Yancey County in the Black Mountains between Mount Gibbes and Mount Mitchell. Named for Jesse Stepp, who guided the geographer Arnold Guyot through the area when Guyot mapped it in 1860.

label: Sterlings Township
description: SE Robeson County.

label: Steve Branch
description: rises in N Clay County and flows SE into Tuni Creek.

label: Steve Branch
description: rises in W Madison County and flows SE into Spring Creek.

label: Stevens
description: See Stevens Mill.

label: Stevens Branch
description: rises in NE Clay County and flows E into Clear Creek.

label: Stevens Cove
description: S Madison County at the head of Little Pine Creek.

label: Stevens Creek
description: rises in E Onslow County and flows SE into White Oak River.

label: Stevens Mill
description: community in W Wayne County on Thoroughfare Swamp.

label: Stevenson Branch
description: rises in W central Swain County on Cooper Mountain and flows SW into Greasy Branch.

label: Stevensons Point
description: community in SE Perquimans County.

label: Steward Millpond
description: in NW Union County in Goose Creek.

label: Stewards Creek
description: See Stewart Creek.

label: Stewart
description: community in S Scotland County served by post office, 1894-1905.

label: Stewart Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SW into Valley River.

label: Stewart Cove
description: E Macon County between Buck Creek and Little Buck Creek.

label: Stewart Creek
description: rises in Virginia and flows SE into Surry County, where it enters Ararat River.

label: Stewart Mountain
description: SW Cherokee County, extends SE into Fannin County, Ga.

label: Stewart Ridge
description: NE Cherokee County in the Snowbird Mountains.

label: Stewart's Pond
description: See Ravenel Lake.

label: Stewart's Town
description: town inc. in 1799 "between Peedee and Markees's Creek" in Richmond County to encourage navigation on the Pee Dee River. Apparently it was never laid out.

label: Stewarts Creek
description: rises in N central Union County and flows SE and NE into Richardson Creek.

label: Stewarts Creek Township
description: S Harnett County.

label: Stewarts Creek Township
description: N Surry County.

label: Stewarts Ferry
description: See Hickory Grove Crossroads.

label: Stewartsville
description: former community in SE Scotland County. A post office by the name existed as early as 1833. In the 1890s, Stewart was a station on what is now the Seaboard Coast Line Railroad. A cemetery called "Stewartsville" in the vicinity was "Founded 1785." See also Stewart's Town.

label: Stewartsville Township
description: SE Scotland County.

label: Stice
description: community in S Cleveland County served by post office, 1847-1902.

label: Stice Dam
description: on Broad River, S Cleveland County, provides power for mills in Shelby. Stice's Shoal community was served by post office, 1847-1902.

label: Stice's Shoal
description: See Stice Dam.

label: Stiff Knee Knob
description: SW Madison County at the head of Sugar Camp Branch.

label: Stiles
description: community in N Macon County between Bird Branch and Burningtown Creek. Served by post office, 1901-51.

label: Still Bluff
description: community in SW Pender County on a bluff overlooking Black River. Named for the fact that it is a quiet spot on a bluff.

label: Still Branch
description: rises in SE Yancey County and flows NE into Roaring Fork.

label: Still Creek
description: rises in W Carteret County and flows W into White Oak River. Named because a whiskey still was once located on the creek.

label: Stilley
description: community S Beaufort County.

label: Stillhouse Branch
description: rises in S Madison County and flows S into Ivy River.

label: Stillhouse Creek
description: rises in central McDowell County and flows S into Paxton Creek.

label: Stillwater Branch
description: rises in W central Transylvania County and flows N into Davidson River.

label: Stillwater Creek
description: See Island Creek.

label: Stillwell Creek
description: rises in NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows SW into Straight Fork of Raven Fork Creek.

label: Stinking Creek
description: rises in S Chatham County and flows SE into Haw River.

label: Stinking Quarter Creek
description: rises in S Guilford County and flows NE into Alamance County, where it enters Great Alamance Creek. Appears on the Collet map, 1770. Name said to have been derived from the fact that Indians cleaned animals there and left quarters of meat to spoil. Eli Caruthers, writing in 1856, said it was formerly known as Stauken's Quarter Creek, presumably named for a grant of land to a pioneer settler.

label: Stirewalt Creek
description: rises in central Alexander County a short distance S of Taylorsville and flows S into Lower Little River.

label: Stirrup Iron Creek
description: rises in SE Durham County and flows SE into W Wake County, where it enters Crabtree Creek.

label: Stockade Mountain
description: SW Cherokee County along the Nottely River SE of Die Bend.

label: Stocking Head Creek
description: rises in central Duplin County and flows SE into Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: Stocksville
description: community in N Buncombe County. A post office est. there 1836; closed 1958.

label: Stockton Cove
description: N Buncombe County between Morgan Ridge and Morgan Branch.

label: Stokes
description: town in N Pitt County. Settled about 1880. Inc. 1903. Named for William G. Stokes, local landowner. Alt. 56.

label: Stokes County
description: was formed in 1789 from Surry County. Located in the N central section of the state, it is bounded by the state of Virginia and by Rockingham, Forsyth, and Surry Counties. It was named for Capt. John Stokes (1756-90), Revolutionary War officer and member of the House of Commons and the Convention of 1789. Area: 458 sq. mi. County seat: Danbury, with an elevation of 825 ft. Townships are Beaver Island, Big Creek, Danbury, Meadows, Peters Creek, Quaker Gap, Sauratown, Snow Creek, and Yadkin. Produces tobacco, corn, wheat, hay, oats, poultry, eggs, dairy products, hogs, livestock, motor vehicle parts, brick, crushed stone. copper products, lumber, apples, and printed materials.

label: Stokes Mill Run
description: rises in E Sampson County and flows E into Duplin County, where it enters Stewart Creek.

label: Stokesbury
description: See Walnut Cove.

label: Stokesdale
description: town in NW Guilford County. Alt. 950. Inc. 1907. Known until 1887 as Pond; renamed probably for Governor Montford Stokes (1762-1842). Post office est. 1879.

label: Stone Creek
description: rises in SW Johnston County and flows E into Mill Creek.

label: Stone Mountain
description: at the head of Jim Creek in SW Henderson County. Alt. 3,647.

label: Stone Mountain
description: community in S McDowell County served by post office, 1848-1905.

label: Stone Mountain Bald
description: on the Watauga County, N.C.-Johnson County, Tenn., line at the N end of Stone Mountains, which see. Alt. 4,657.

label: Stone Mountain Branch
description: rises in NW Watauga County in the Stone Mountains and flows SW into Watauga River.

label: Stone Mountain Creek
description: rises in S Alleghany County and flows SW into N Wilkes County, where it enters Bullhead Creek.

label: Stone Mountain Gap
description: SE Buncombe County between Stone and Round Mountains.

label: Stone Mountains
description: a chain of mountains in W Ashe and Watauga Counties, N.C., and Johnson County, Tenn., from the Watauga River near lat. 36°17'30" N., long. 81°55' W., to the NW corner of North Carolina and thence into Virginia to Whitetop Mountain. They form the common boundary line of North Carolina and Tennessee. The name dates from as early as 1795.

label: Stonecutter Creek
description: rises in central Rutherford County and flows SW into Cleghorn Creek. Named for a stonecutter who lived along its banks and cut millstones.

label: Stonehead
description: See Pilot Mountain.

label: Stonehouse
description: home of William Person, member of the Provincial Congress, in NE Warren County on Stonehouse Creek. The house, which is still standing, dates from 1746.

label: Stonehouse Creek
description: rises in E Warren County near the town of Vaughn and flows NE into Lake Gaston. Appears on the Price map, 1808, and the MacRae map, 1833. Sometimes referred to locally as Big Stonehouse Creek.

label: Stones Bay
description: in New River in S Onslow County. Mentioned in local records as early as 1748 as Stones Creek Bay. Named for William Stone, an early surveyor in the county.

label: Stones Creek
description: rises in S Onslow County and flows NE approx. 10 mi. into Stones Bay. Mentioned in local records as early as 1744. Named for William Stone, an early surveyor in the county.

label: Stones Creek Bay
description: See Stones Bay.

label: Stones Island
description: See Huggins Island.

label: Stones Knob
description: SE Yancey County between Clear and Crabtree Creeks.

label: Stoneville
description: town in NW Rockingham County. Founded in 1858 by Rev. Frank J. Stone and Pinckney M. Stone, the latter of whom operated a general store at the site. Inc. 1877. Became a trading center for Rockingham County. Several buildings demolished by tornado, 1998. Alt. 823.

label: Stonewall
description: town in central Pamlico County on Bay River. Inc. 1857 as Jackson and apparently named for the owner of a local mill. Name changed to Stonewall, 1871, to honor Gen. T. J. "Stonewall" Jackson (1824-63). Post office est. 1877. Long inactive in municipal affairs. Alt. 10.

label: Stonewall Township
description: SE Hoke County.

label: Stoney Creek
description: rises in NE Mecklenburg County and flows SE into Mallard Creek.

label: Stoney Mountain
description: central Henderson County between Mill Pond Creek and Mud Creek. Alt. 2,843.

label: Stoney Run
description: rises in W Cleveland County and flows SE into First Broad River.

label: Stoney Town Creek
description: See Stonyton Creek.

label: Stonington Creek
description: See Stonyton Creek.

label: Stony Bald
description: on the Buncombe-Henderson county line NE of Cutthroat Gap. Alt. 4,563.

label: Stony Creek
description: rises in S Caswell County and flows S into Alamance County, where it enters Haw River. Appears as Marrow Bone River on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Stony Creek
description: See Stony Fork Creek.

label: Stony Creek Lake
description: See Lake Burlington.

label: Stony Creek Mountain
description: high grounds on the Caswell-Alamance county line.

label: Stony Creek Township
description: SW Caswell County.

label: Stony Creek Township
description: central Wayne County.

label: Stony Fork
description: community in E Watauga County near the head of Stony Fork Creek.

label: Stony Fork Branch
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows SW into North Fork [Swannanoa River].

label: Stony Fork Creek
description: rises in E Watauga County and flows SE into W Wilkes County to enter Yadkin River. Also known as Stony Creek.

label: Stony Fork Township
description: E Watauga County.

label: Stony Hill
description: community in NW Wilkes County on North Prong Lewis Fork Creek.

label: Stony Knob
description: on the McDowell-Mitchell county line between Gillespie Gap and Little Switzerland. Alt. approx. 3,330.

label: Stony Knoll
description: community in S Surry County between Fisher River and West Double Creek. Served by post office, 1893-1906. Formerly known as Butcher. Alt. 1,194.

label: Stony Mountain
description: a range about 1½ mi. long in E Stanly County on W bank of Pee Dee River.

label: Stony Mountain Ridge
description: NE Swain County, in the shape of an inverted "S" between Poplar Hollow Branch and a bend in Raven Fork.

label: Stony Point
description: community in E Cleveland County.

label: Stony Ridge
description: SE Surry County, extends NE between Yadkin River and Grassy Creek.

label: Stony Run
description: rises in W Stanly County and flows SE into Big Bear Creek.

label: Stony Spur
description: W Madison County between Little Bottom Branch and John Taylor Branch.

label: Stony Valley
description: in E Mitchell County between Bee Ridge and Middle Mountain.

label: Stonyton Creek
description: rises in N Lenoir County and flows SE into Neuse River. Now frequently appears as Stonington Creek but first called the Stoney Town Creek in the 1730s because it was near an Indian town on a hill with outcroppings of slate and sandstone.

label: Store Point
description: peninsula extending off the W side of Goose Creek Island into Goose Creek, NE Pamlico County.

label: Storey Branch
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows NW into Days Creek.

label: Story
description: community in W Gates County; formerly known as Storys Crossroads. Served by post office, 1884-85. Named for Euclid Story, postmaster.

label: Story Mountain
description: N Caldwell County. Named for the Storie family, local residents.

label: Storys Creek
description: rises in central Person County and flows NE into Marlowe Creek.

label: Storys Crossroads
description: See Story.

label: Stott Knob
description: central Surry County between Turner Mountain and Beaver Creek. Alt. 1,550.

label: Stotts Crossroads
description: community in NW Wilson County E of Marsh Swamp. Named for Godfrey Stott.

label: Stouts
description: community in W Union County 2 mi. SE of town of Indian Trail. Inc. 1907; charter repealed 1917. Alt. 658.

label: Stovall
description: town in NE Granville County. Inc. 1883 as Sassafras Fork, named for large sassafras trees at the crossroads. Post office since 1887. Name changed in 1887 to honor John W. Stovall, who gave land for the railroad station. Alt. 478. Produces lumber.

label: Stover Ridge
description: mountain in central Avery County.

label: Stowe's Hills
description: See Frisco.

label: Strabane
description: community in W Lenoir County. Named for home in Ireland of early settler. Served by post office, 1828-1905.

label: Stradley Mountain
description: S Buncombe County, extends from Little Hickory Top to Rice Pinnacle.

label: Straight Creek
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, rises near lat. 35°34'37" N., long. 83°09'36" W., and flows E into Caldwell Fork.

label: Straight Fork
description: rises in NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountain National Park and flows S and SW into Raven Fork.

label: Straits
description: community in SE Carteret County on a point of land extending into the mouth of North River.

label: Straits Township
description: on The Straits in central Carteret County. At one time, a portion of Straits was called no. 5 township. From Straits were formed Carteret and no. 9 townships (both now abolished) and Merrimon.

label: Straits, The
description: straits in the waters between North River and Core Sound in SE Carteret County between Harkers Island and the mainland.

label: Strange Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SE into Big Cove Branch.

label: Strangenbergs Creek
description: See Silas Creek.

label: Stratford
description: community in W central Alleghany County.

label: Stratton Bald
description: W Graham County at NW end of Horse Cove Ridge. Alt. approx. 5,380.

label: Stratton Branch
description: rises in NW Swain County and flows SE into Lake Cheoah.

label: Straw
description: community in S Wilkes County near East Prong Cub Creek.

label: Strawberry Branch
description: rises in E Lenoir County in the N part of Ball Pocosin and flows N into Southwest Creek.

label: Strawberry Knob
description: on the Haywood-Swain county line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°32'54" N., long. 83°09'35" W., between Whim Knob and Black Camp Gap. Alt. 5,340.

label: Street Gap
description: on the Madison County, N.C.-Unicoi County, Tenn., line.

label: Streets Ferry
description: est. over the Neuse River by Richard Graves before 1730; location was 7 mi. S of Vanceboro, central Craven County. Ceased operation, 1962.

label: Strickland Crossroads
description: community in S Johnston County.

label: Stricklandsville
description: See Magnolia.

label: Strieby
description: community in SW Randolph County. Named for a philanthropist who helped est. a church and school for blacks there in 1880. Served by post office, 1883-1940.

label: Striking Island
description: a tidal-marsh island in the Cape Fear River opposite Southport, SE Brunswick County.

label: Stringfellow Branch
description: rises in S Watauga County in Moses H. Cone Memorial Park and flows E through Bass Lake and into Chetola Lake on Middle Fork [South Fork New River].

label: Strouds Creek
description: rises in N Orange County and flows SE into Eno River.

label: Strouph Gap
description: on the SW end of Burney Mountain on the Buncombe-Henderson county line.

label: Stuards Reach
description: appears on the Smith map, 1624, in what is now the Roanoke River between Halifax and Northampton Counties.

label: Stuart Creek
description: rises in NW Henderson County in Pisgah National Forest and flows NE into North Fork.

label: Stubblefield
description: See Ruffin.

label: Stubbs
description: community in E Cleveland County on Buffalo Creek. Alt. 950. Settled about 1885. Named for Col. Seth W. Stubbs, who made the clock for the Lincoln County Courthouse, 1856.

label: Stump Inlet
description: or former inlet from the Atlantic Ocean to Stump Sound, SE Onslow County. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733, and on other maps through 1882. Apparently closed by 1912.

label: Stump Sound
description: skirts the S edge of Onslow County between the Onslow-Pender county line and Alligator Bay in S Onslow County. The sound is filled with tidal-marsh islands and is separated from the Atlantic Ocean by a barrier beach.

label: Stump Sound Township
description: SW Onslow County.

label: Stumpy Creek
description: rises in S Iredell County and flows SW into Cornelius Creek.

label: Stumpy Inlet
description: See Stump Inlet.

label: Stumpy Point
description: community on the E mainland of Dare County on Stumpy Point Bay. Alt. 3.

label: Stumpy Point Bay
description: an almost round bay on the E mainland of Dare County. It has a narrow entrance into Pamlico Sound on the SE side. Formerly a lake, it appears as Stumpy Point Lake on the Moseley map, 1733. Erosion opened the lake into Pamlico Sound.

label: Stumpy Point Lake
description: See Stumpy Point Bay.

label: Sturdivants Cross Roads
description: community in SE Union County S of Lanes Creek.

label: Sturgeon Creek
description: rises in NE Brunswick County and flows E into Mill Creek.

label: Sturgeons Point
description: on Moseley map, 1733, in what is now SE Brunswick County between Elizabeth River and Walden Creek.

label: Sturgills
description: community in N Ashe County. Named for Sheriff B. Sturgills, who helped to obtain a post office that operated 1887-1953.

label: Styron Bay
description: on the W side of Core Sound about 1.3 mi. SW of the town of Atlantic and E of Nelson Bay, NE Carteret County. Named for a local family.

label: Suburb
description: community in SE Brunswick County served by post office, 1898-1915.

label: Suck
description: community in Rutherford County served by post office, 1854-66.

label: Suddawig Branch
description: rises in SW Clay County and flows NW into Hiwassee River.

label: Suddereth Branch
description: rises in E Cherokee County on Mission Mountain and flows SE into Hiwassee River.

label: Sue
description: community in E Columbus County served by post office, 1894-1901.

label: Sugar Branch
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows SE then NE into Savannah Creek.

label: Sugar Camp Branch
description: rises in SW Madison County and flows NE into Spring Creek.

label: Sugar Camp Creek
description: is formed in S Yancey County by the junction of Ogle and Timber Creeks and flows SW and NW into Cane River.

label: Sugar Cove
description: N Buncombe County W of Ingles Ridge.

label: Sugar Cove
description: SW Macon County between Firescald Ridge and Nantahala River.

label: Sugar Cove Branch
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows NW into Sorrell Creek.

label: Sugar Cove Creek
description: rises in SE Yancey County and flows SW into Three Forks Creek.

label: Sugar Cove Gap
description: SE Yancey County near the head of Sugar Cove Creek.

label: Sugar Creek
description: rises in NW Buncombe County near Newfound Mountain and flows NE into Sandy Mush Creek.

label: Sugar Creek
description: is formed in central Mecklenburg County by the junction of Stewart and Taggart Creeks and flows SW into South Carolina, where it enters Catawba River. Appears on the Collet map, 1770. Name derived from an Indian word apparently meaning "group of huts."

label: Sugar Creek Ridge
description: E Jackson County between Sugar Creek and Rough Butt Creek.

label: Sugar Fork
description: See Messer Creek.

label: Sugar Fork Township
description: SE Macon County.

label: Sugar Gap
description: central Avery County.

label: Sugar Grove
description: community in W Watauga County on Cove Creek. Settled 1837; named for sugar maple trees in vicinity. Alt. 2,775. Post office est. 1849.

label: Sugar Hill
description: community in S McDowell County on Cove Creek. Served by post office, 1846-1917.

label: Sugar Hollow
description: E central Yancey County between Jim Ray Branch and Three Quarters Creek. Named for sugar maples growing there.

label: Sugar Loaf
description: See Carolina Beach.

label: Sugar Loaf Island
description: in Bogue Sound off Morehead City in S Carteret County.

label: Sugar Loaf Mountain
description: central Transylvania County between curves in the French Broad River.

label: Sugar Loaf Township
description: N Alexander County.

label: Sugar Mountain
description: central Avery County. Alt. 5,240.

label: Sugar Springs Cove
description: NE Buncombe County between Little Craggy Knob and North Fork [Swannanoa River].

label: Sugar Top
description: mountain in E Haywood County near the head of Garden Creek. Alt. 4,400.

label: Sugar Town
description: See Cullasaja.

label: Sugar Town Creek
description: See Cullasaja River.

label: Sugar Tree Branch
description: rises in NW Ashe County and flows S into North Fork New River.

label: Sugar Tree Creek
description: See Sugar Creek.

label: Sugarcamp Fork
description: rises in N Buncombe County and flows NW into Main Creek.

label: Sugarcamp Ridge
description: mountain in W Avery County.

label: Sugarhouse Cove
description: NE Buncombe County between Glassmine Ridge and Locust Gap.

label: Sugarloaf
description: community in N central Watauga County.

label: Sugarloaf Bluff
description: on Cape Fear River in central Bladen County. Probably named for the white, sandy beach across the river from the bluff. The river makes a 45° turn at the bluff.

label: Sugarloaf Creek
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows NW into Scott Creek.

label: Sugarloaf Knob
description: N Madison County at the NE end of Sugarloaf Mountain. Alt. 4,540.

label: Sugarloaf Mountain
description: central Watauga County, extends NW from Howard Creek. Alt. 4,705.

label: Sugarloaf Mountain
description: N Yancey County, extends SE parallel to and S of Big Creek. Alt. 3,202.

label: Sugarloaf Ridge
description: N Jackson County, extends SE from Blanton Branch to Black Mountain.

label: Sugartown
description: See Pilot View.

label: Sugartree Branch
description: rises in E Mitchell County and flows NW into Mine Fork Branch.

label: Sugartree Creek
description: See South Hyco Creek.

label: Sugartree Gap
description: on the Swain County, N.C.-Sevier County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°34'12" N., long. 83°39'28" W.

label: Sugartree Licks
description: on the Haywood-Swain county line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Balsam Mountain near lat. 35°33'23" N., long. 83°09'28" W. Alt. approx. 5,160. The name comes from the days of cattle ranging in the area and a salting place. Salt for cattle was spread on the roots of a sugar maple tree.

label: Sugartree Ridge
description: E Mitchell County between Mine Fork Branch and Dobson Branch.

label: Sugartree Ridge
description: N Watauga County, extends SE from Cove Creek to Snake Mountain.

label: Suggs Bridge
description: community in NE Montgomery County served by post office, 1831-43.

label: Suggs Creek
description: rises in NE Montgomery County and flows SE into Little River.

label: Suggs Landing
description: S Edgecombe County, on Tar River.

label: Suggs Mill Pond
description: a natural pond in N Bladen County. Named for Aligood Suggs. Has decreased in size considerably since 1914. The pond is one of the Carolina Bays, which see.

label: Suit
description: community in SW Cherokee County on the headwaters of Bearpaw Creek. Served by post office, 1886-1955.

label: Sukey Young Crossroads
description: community in N Franklin County.

label: Sular Creek
description: rises in NW Cherokee County and flows SW into Hiwassee River between Apalachia and Hiwassee Dams.

label: Suli Knob
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°33'13" N., long. 83°33'02" W. Alt. 4,920.

label: Suli Ridge
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park between Jonas and Huggins Creeks near lat. 35°32'53" N., long. 83°32'50" W.

label: Sulliers Bay
description: SE Onslow County between Howards Bay and Craigs Point. Appears in early county records as Salyer's Bay.

label: Sullins Branch
description: rises in E Mitchell County and flows SW into North Toe River.

label: Sullivan County
description: now in Tennessee, was created in 1779 and named in honor of Gen. John Sullivan (1740-95). Blountsville became the county seat. Part of the territory was ceded by North Carolina in 1789 to the federal government.

label: Sulphur Branch
description: rises in N central Gaston County just NW of Pasour Mountain and flows NE to empty into South Fork River near the community of High Shoals.

label: Sulphur Springs
description: See Davis White Sulphur Springs.

label: Sulphur Springs Township
description: S Rutherford County.

label: Sumey Creek
description: rises in NE Rutherford County and flows S into First Broad River. The name is variously spelled as Summy, Somey, and Sommey. Named for the Sumey family, early settlers.

label: Summer Haven
description: community in central Beaufort County on the N shore of Pamlico River.

label: Summerfield
description: community in N Guilford County. Inc. 1996. Alt. 881. Settled about 1769 by Charles Bruce, later a Revolutionary War patriot, and known as Bruce's Crossroads until 1812, when a post office was est. and the community was renamed in honor of evangelist John Summerfield (1798-1825). Site, according to tradition, of Revolutionary War skirmish between Lee and Tarleton; campsite of British army under Gen. Charles O'Hara of the Coldstream Guards, February 12, 1781.

label: Summerhaven
description: community in NE Buncombe County on Spruce Fork Creek.

label: Summerlins Crossroads
description: community in N Duplin County.

label: Summerville
description: community in central Harnett County served by post office, 1850-1908. The law creating Harnett County in 1855 directed that the first courts were to be held there until a county seat could be est. Continued as seat of government until 1860. First called Toomer for Judge J. D. Toomer (1784-1856).

label: Summit
description: See Elliott.

label: Summy Creek
description: See Sumey Creek.

label: Sumner
description: community in S Rowan County.

label: Sumner Township
description: S central Guilford County. Named for Gen. Jethro Sumner (1733-85).

label: Sumner's Mill
description: community in S Guilford County served by post office, 1853-59.

label: Sumpter Cabin Branch
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows S into Middle Fork [South Fork New River].

label: Sun
description: community in E Wilson County between Toisnot Swamp and Whiteoak Swamp. Served by post office, 1898-1905.

label: Sunburst
description: community in S Haywood County on Lake Logan. Named because the sun rises suddenly from behind a mountain ridge. Served by post office, 1906-28.

label: Sunbury
description: community in E central Gates County. Alt. 39. Had its origin at nearby site of Costens Mill, which appears as Constants Mill on the Collet map, 1770. Owner of the mill moved to present site of Sunbury when the road was rerouted. Probably named for the city in Pennsylvania.

label: Sunday Branch
description: rises in E central Clay County and flows NW into Tusquitee Creek.

label: Sunfish Cove
description: in N Transylvania County just S of Shooting Ridge.

label: Sunk Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SE into Dan Holland Creek.

label: Sunkoto Ridge
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a long spur extending SW from Thomas Ridge with its center near lat. 35°31'40" N., long. 83°24'28" W.

label: Sunnatee
description: See Great Craggy Mountains.

label: Sunneehaw
description: See Enos Plotts Balsam Mountain.

label: Sunny Point
description: on the W bank of Cape Fear River in SE Brunswick County. Now an ammunition loading depot.

label: Sunny Vale
description: community in NW McDowell County on Buck Creek.

label: Sunny View
description: community in N Polk County on Walnut Creek.

label: Sunnyside
description: community in SW Rowan County served by post office, 1894-1902. Formerly known as Edmiston.

label: Sunset
description: community in central Granville County served by post office, 1892-1905.

label: Sunset Beach
description: town in SW Brunswick County. Inc. in 1963.

label: Sunset Lake
description: S Wake County on Middle Creek at the junction of Basal Creek; formerly known as Orfords Pond. Covers 100 acres; max. depth 20 ft. Used for fishing and boating.

label: Sunset Mountain
description: central Buncombe County NE of Asheville.

label: Sunset Park
description: former town in central Buncombe County, now wholly within the corporate limits of Asheville. Inc. 1891; charter repealed 1897. It lay N of the town limits and W of Charlotte Street extension.

label: Sunset Rock
description: on Satulah Branch in SE Macon County.

label: Sunshine
description: community in NE Rutherford County on Robinson Creek. Served by post office, 1881-1908. Named prior to 1881 by J. W. Biggerstaff, who had a store there. The site is shaded in the early morning by Cherry Mountain, but it acquired its name because local residents could see the sunshine on the top of the mountain.

label: Sunup Knob
description: on Haywood County, N.C.-Cocke County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°44'45" N., long. 83°10'14" W. Alt. 5,050-5,100.

label: Supply
description: community in S central Brunswick County on Lockwoods Folly River. From 1805 until 1810, the county courthouse was at the site.

label: Surf City
description: town in SE Pender County on the Atlantic Ocean. Inc. 1949.

label: Surl
description: community in E Person County served by post office, 1883-1909.

label: Surry
description: See White Post.

label: Surry County
description: was formed in 1771 from Rowan County. Located in the N central section of the state, it is bounded by the state of Virginia and by Stokes, Yadkin, Wilkes, and Alleghany Counties. Named for the County of Surrey in England, birthplace of then-incumbent governor William Tryon. The fact that the name is similar to Saura, the Indian tribe that had recently inhabited the region, may have had some influence in the choice. Area: 538 sq. mi. County seat: Dobson, with an elevation of 1,265 ft. Townships are Bryan, Dobson, Eldora, Elkin, Franklin, Long Hill, Marsh, Mount Airy, Pilot, Rockford, Shoals, Siloam, South Westfield, Stewarts, and Westfield. Produces tobacco, corn, wheat, poultry, barley, grapes, honey, wine, dairy products, hogs, livestock, textiles, hosiery, apparel, furniture, granite, and crushed stone.

label: Sussex
description: community in N Ashe County.

label: Sutherland
description: community in W Ashe County. Alt. approx. 3,150.

label: Sutphin
description: community in S Alamance County served by post office, 1891-1905. See also Lindley's Mill.

label: Sutton
description: community in S Franklin County on Norris Creek.

label: Sutton Branch
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows SE into Savannah Creek.

label: Suttons Creek
description: rises in E Perquimans County and flows S into Perquimans River. Named for the Sutton family, which owned land there before 1700.

label: Suttons Mill Pond
description: approx. ½ mi. long, on Bear Creek in W Lenoir County.

label: Suttontown
description: community in NE Sampson County near Goshen Swamp.

label: Swafford Gap
description: on the McDowell-Mitchell county line. The Blue Ridge Parkway passes through the gap. Alt. 2,852. Named for Marcus Swafford (1856-1943), who lived there.

label: Swag Cove
description: NE Cherokee County on Buckhorn Ridge in the Valley River Mountains.

label: Swain
description: community in N Washington County near the head of Bakers Swamp.

label: Swain County
description: was formed in 1871 from Jackson and Macon Counties. Located in the SW section of the state, it is bounded by the state of Tennessee and by Graham, Cherokee, Macon, Jackson, and Haywood Counties. It was named for David L. Swain (1801-68), governor of the state and president of the University of North Carolina. Area: 544 sq. mi. County seat: Bryson City, with an elevation of 1,736 ft. Townships are Charleston, Forneys Creek, and Nantahala. The Qualla Boundary of the Cherokee Indians, Great Smoky Mountains National Park, Nantahala National Forest, and Fontana Lake occupy much of Swain County. Produces corn, poultry, livestock, furniture, textiles, apparel, leather goods, gaming proceeds, hay, candy, crushed stone, and feldspar.

label: Swains Mill Pond
