description: approx. 2 mi. long, on Deep Swamp Branch just before it enters the Chowan River in SE Hertford County. Formerly Taylor Pond. Est. ca. 1720.

label: Swallow Fork
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, rises near lat. 35°42'11" N., long. 83°07'47" W., and flows NW into Big Creek.

label: Swamp Creek
description: rises in SW Dare County and flows SW into Alligator River. Appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Swampy River
description: See Black River.

label: Swan Corner
description: community in N Pamlico County on Chapel Creek. Named for local Swan family.

label: Swan Creek
description: is formed in E Wilkes County by the junction of East Swan Creek and West Swan Creek and flows N into Yadkin River.

label: Swan Island
description: tidal-marsh island in the mouth of Swan Creek, E Pamlico County.

label: Swan Islands
description: three islands in Pamlico Sound in N end of Carteret County.

label: Swan Mountain
description: central Buncombe County, extends from the junction of Swope and Bull Creeks to High Swan (peak).

label: Swan Point
description: extends from Bell Island in S Hyde County into Rose Bay.

label: Swan Point
description: S Onslow County, extends into N Chadwick Bay. Appears as Swann Point in early county records.

label: Swan Pond
description: a natural pond about 1½ mi. long in the Neuse River low grounds of SE Johnston County.

label: Swan Quarter
description: former town and present county seat, S Hyde County. Alt. 10. Settled prior to 1836, when it was made the county seat. Inc. 1903; charter repealed 1929. Believed to have been named for Samuel F. Swann, an early owner of the site.

label: Swan Quarter Bay
description: in Pamlico Sound E of Bell Island in S Hyde County. See also Cecils Harbor.

label: Swan Quarter Island
description: a marsh island in Pamlico Sound, S Hyde County. Approx. 10 to 15 acres in area. See also Abigails Islands.

label: Swan Quarter Township
description: SE Hyde County.

label: Swancreek
description: community in W Yadkin County. Named for the fact that wild geese, erroneously called swans, once lived on nearby streams.

label: Swann
description: town in SE Lee County. Inc. 1875 as Swann's Station; charter repealed 1877. Re incorporated as Swann's, 1911, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Named for Frederick Jones Swann, who settled there about 1815. Alt. 278.

label: Swann Point
description: See Swan Point.

label: Swann's
description: See Swann.

label: Swann's Station
description: See Swann.

label: Swannanoa
description: community in SE Buncombe County. Named for the river on which it is located. Known first as Cooper for A. D. Cooper, owner of the land on which it developed. Produces textiles and wearing apparel. Warren Wilson College is there. Alt. 2,220.

label: Swannanoa Creek
description: rises in W McDowell County and flows E into Mill Creek.

label: Swannanoa Gap
description: on the Buncombe-Yancey county line between Potato Knob and Bald Knob.

label: Swannanoa Mountains
description: range of mountains in SE Buncombe County S of the community of Swannanoa and parallel to the Swannanoa River.

label: Swannanoa River
description: rises near Swannanoa Gap on the Buncombe-McDowell county line and flows W into French Broad River S of Asheville. Name is a corruption of Suwali-Nunna, the Cherokee word for "trail of the Suwali tribe."

label: Swannanoa Township
description: E central Buncombe County.

label: Swannanoa Tunnel
description: on the Southern Railway, SE Buncombe County near Ridgecrest. Cut in 1879 at a cost of $600,000 and 120 lives, the tunnel marked the completion of a section of the railroad. An early use of nitroglycerine in engineering occurred there.

label: Swanner
description: community in NW Alexander County.

label: Swannsborough
description: See Swansboro.

label: Swansboro
description: town in SE Onslow County on White Oak River. Earlier names had been Bogue, Weeks Point, The Wharf, and New Town. Est. as Swannsborough in 1783; named for Samuel Swann (1704-72), who represented the county in the Assembly, 1739-62. Inc. in 1877 as Swansboro.

label: Swansboro Township
description: SE Onslow County.

label: Swansee Gap
description: W Cherokee County between an arm of Hiwassee River and Sular Creek.

label: Swash, The
description: a narrow channel between Horse Island and Core Banks, NE Carteret County.

label: Swayney
description: community in NE Swain County at the junction of Straight Fork with Raven Fork in Qualla Boundary.

label: Swearing Creek
description: rises in N Davidson County and flows SW into Yadkin River. Named for Swearingen family. Appears on the Collet map, 1770, as Swaring Creek.

label: Sweet Branch
description: rises in W Yancey County and flows NW into Cane River.

label: Sweet Creek
description: rises in central Mitchell County and flows SE into Cub Creek.

label: Sweet Creek
description: See Frost Mill Creek.

label: Sweeten Creek
description: rises in S Buncombe County and flows NW into Swannanoa River. Named for the Sweiton family, early settlers. Name later changed to Foster's Mill Creek and then back to Sweeten Creek.

label: Sweetgum
description: community in S Graham County.

label: Sweetwater
description: community in W Watauga County on Beaverdam Creek.

label: Sweetwater Branch
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows SE into Sampson Branch.

label: Sweetwater Creek
description: rises in E Graham County and flows SW and nw, where it joins Tulula Creek in forming Cheoah River.

label: Sweetwater Creek
description: drains Statons Pond, which see, in central Martin County and flows N into Roanoke River. Appears as Flat Branch on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Sweetwater Gap
description: in E Graham County at the head of Sweetwater Creek.

label: Sweetwater Spring
description: in the headwaters of Haywood Gap Stream in S Haywood County.

label: Sweetwater Township
description: W Clay County.

label: Sweezy Mountain
description: a peak on Cherry Mountain, E Rutherford County. A large pile of rocks on the W side is known as the Rock House.

label: Swepsonville
description: community in central Alamance County. Named for George W. Swepson (1811-83), who built a cotton mill there in 1868. Inc. 1887; charter repealed 1901.

label: Swift Creek
description: rises in S Wake County and flows SE into Johnston County, where it enters Neuse River. Appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Swift Creek
description: See Vanceboro.

label: Swift Creek Township
description: S central Wake County.

label: Swift Fork Branch
description: rises in SE Watauga County and flows SE into Elk Creek.

label: Swift Island
description: community in SW Montgomery County served by post office, 1850-83. Site of hydroelectric plant, 1926, forming Lake Tillery.

label: Swim Bald
description: on the Graham-Swain county line between Sassafras Gap and The Jump-up.

label: Swimmer Branch
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows S into Wrights Creek.

label: Swindell
description: community in S Hyde County. A post office operated there, 1830-39.

label: Swindell Fork
description: community in central Hyde County.

label: Swinging Lick Gap
description: SW Macon County between Winding Stair Gap and Bryson Branch.

label: Swinton
description: community in N Moore County served by post office, 1888-1908.

label: Swiss
description: community in W Yancey County on Bald Creek. Alt. 2,681. Named because the surrounding countryside suggested that of Switzerland.

label: Swopes Branch
description: rises in E Cabarrus County and flows SE into Little Buffalo Creek.

label: Sycamore Creek
description: rises in NW Wake County and flows W and S along the Durham-Wake county line for a part of its course and then SE in Wake County into Turkey Creek.

label: Sylva
description: town and county seat, central Jackson County. Inc. 1889. Settled in 1861; named for William D. Sylva, a Dane employed as a carpenter by Gen. E. R. Hampton, who constructed buildings at the site. Produces paper, electronics, and textiles. Alt. 2,047. See also Webster, which was the county seat until 1913.

label: Sylva Township
description: N central Jackson County.

label: Sylvania
description: community in SW Rockingham County.

label: Sylvasla
description: community in central Wake County.

label: Sylvester
description: community in N Chatham County served by post office, 1890-96.

label: Symonds Creek
description: rises in S Pasquotank County and flows S into Little River.

label: Ta-loh-na
description: See Yellow Mountain.

label: Tabbs Creek
description: rises in E Granville County and flows SE across SW Vance County into Tar River on the Vance-Franklin county line. Appears on the Collet map, 1770, as Tans Creek, probably as an engraver's error. For a time prior to 1764, the Granville County Courthouse was located on Tabbs Creek. Tabb's Creek District had 57 heads of families at the time of the 1790 census.

label: Tabernacle
description: community in SE Guilford County served by post office, 1880-1903; the mail was sent to Climax after 1903.

label: Tabernacle Township
description: W central Randolph County.

label: Table Rock Branch
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows SW into Straight Fork.

label: Table Rock Mountain
description: NW Burke County in Pisgah National Forest. Alt. 3,918. Summit accessible by foot trail. Appears on the Collet map, 1770, as Table Mountain. Known by the Cherokee Indians as Namonda

label: Tablerock
description: community in NW Burke County.

label: Tabor Branch
description: rises in N Swain County and flows SE into Bradley Fork.

label: Tabor City
description: town in SW Columbus County. Settled 1886. Inc. 1905 as Tabor; name changed to Tabor City, 1935. Named for Mt. Tabor Presbyterian Church. Produces lumber, processed food. Alt. 50.

label: Tabor Island
description: in Roanoke River in SE Bertie County at the SW end of Bluff Island. Known by the name since the mid-nineteenth century. Approx. ¾ mi. long and 1/8 mi. wide. See also Purchace Islands.

label: Tackett Branch
description: rises in N Rockingham County and flows SE into Smith River.

label: Tadmore
description: community in the NW tip of Pasquotank County.

label: Taggart Creek
description: rises in central Mecklenburg County and flows SE to join Stewart Creek in forming Sugar Creek.

label: Tah-kee-os-tee
description: See French Broad River.

label: Talbot
description: community in W Wilson County. Post office est. there 1892 but moved a few years later to another nearby community and discontinued in 1902.

label: Talc Mountain
description: community in SW Swain County on Nantahala River.

label: Talc Mountain Branch
description: rises in SW Swain County and flows SE into Nantahala River.

label: Tali Gap
description: in NW Swain County between Pickens Gap and Haw Gap Branch.

label: Talley Mill Creek
description: rises in SE Macon County and flows SE into Rabun County, Ga., where it enters Big Creek.

label: Talleys Crossing
description: community in E Forsyth County.

label: Tallulah River
description: rises in SE Clay County and flows SE into Towns County, Ga., where it enters Tugaloo River.

label: Tally Ho
description: community in W Granville County. A post office est. there 1830 was moved to Stem in 1889, and the name was changed. Alt. 500. Named for the traditional call of fox hunters when the quarry is sighted. Fox hunting was a popular sport in the area in the eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries.

label: Tally Ho Township
description: W central Granville County.

label: Tamarack
description: community in N Watauga County on Hoskin Fork. Post Office est. 1902 and closed 1966; surrounding community generally known as Pottertown. Named for tamarisk tree.

label: Tamban Branch
description: rises in central Duplin County and flows W into Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: Tampa
description: community in S Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1888-1903.

label: Tan Yard
description: See Eldorado.

label: Tanasee Bald
description: mountain peak on the Haywood-Transylvania county line at the junction of Pisgah Ridge and Tanasee Ridge in Pisgah National Forest. Lat. 35°17'30" N., long. 82°55'03" W. Alt. 5,560. The Cherokee name for the peak was Tsul-ka-lu-tsu-na-gun-yi

label: Tanasee Creek
description: rises in E Jackson County at Mount Hardy Gap and flows approx. 9 mi. SW to enter Tuckasegee River.

label: Tanasee Gap
description: in Tanasee Ridge on the Jackson-Transylvania county line in Pisgah and Nantahala National Forests.

label: Tanasee Ridge
description: on the Jackson-Transylvania county line, forms the boundary between Nantahala and Pisgah National Forests. It is approx. 11 mi. long and extends NW from the Blue Ridge.

label: Tanawha
description: See Grandfather Mountain.

label: Tanbark Gap
description: SW Cherokee County between Pack Top and Potato Creek.

label: Tanbark Ridge
description: central Buncombe County between Jones Cove and Bull Creek.

label: Tandaquomuc
description: an Indian village of either the Weapemeoc or Chowanoac tribes located in what is now SE Bertie County between the mouths of Chowan and Roanoke Rivers. Appears on the De Bry map, 1590. The name may have meant "where the road goes by the big evergreens."

label: Tank Creek
description: rises in NW Cumberland County and flows NE into Little River.

label: Tantram Branch
description: rises in SE Buncombe County near Patton Gap in the Swannanoa Mountains and flows S into Trantham Creek.

label: Tantroft Branch
description: See Tantrough Branch.

label: Tantrough Branch
description: rises in E central Yancey County and flows N into Little Crabtree Creek. Named for the wooden trough used in tanning hides that an early settler had there. The spelling Tantroft is also used.

label: Tanyard Branch
description: rises in central Rutherford County NW of Rutherfordton and flows SE into Cleghorn Creek. At one time it was known as Milk House Branch.

label: Tanyard Creek
description: rises in N Yadkin County and flows NE into Yadkin River.

label: Tanyard Gap
description: N Madison County at the head of Silvermine Branch.

label: Tapoco
description: resort community in NW Graham County on Cheoah River. Served by post office, 1916-36. Alt. 1,110. Name coined by the Tallassee Power Company using the first two letters of the three words in the company name.

label: Tar Corner
description: community in NE Camden County. Name said to derive from a barn painted with tar that stood at intersection of two roads.

label: Tar Creek
description: rises in E Pamlico County and flows N into Broad Creek.

label: Tar Heel
description: a town in NW Bladen County. Settled 1875. Inc. 1963. Alt. 100. Named either for the appellation said to have been given, by Confederates from other states, to North Carolina troops who emerged from a river with tar adhering to their heels, or for tar produced in the vicinity taken to the Cape Fear River and then by raft to Wilmington. Along the riverfront, the ground was covered with tar, and so were the feet that passed over it.

label: Tar Kiln Creek
description: rises in S Pamlico County and flows S into Dawson Creek.

label: Tar Kiln Ridge
description: NW Clay County, extends from Short Off to the Tusquitee Mountains.

label: Tar Landing
description: community in N Onslow County between Blue Creek and New River. Early deeds refer to the landing on New River as Owen Jones's Tar Landing.

label: Tar Landing Bay
description: in the extreme E end of Bogue Banks on the sound side, S Carteret County.

label: Tar Ridge
description: S Watauga County, extends SE from the head of Days Creek.

label: Tar River
description: community in S Granville County.

label: Tar-ko-ee
description: See Piedmont.

label: Tarawa Terrace
description: residential area of Camp Lejeune Marine Base, central Onslow County. Named for the Pacific Island on which a battle was fought against the Japanese, November 21-24, 1943.

label: Tarboro
description: town and county seat, central Edge-combe County. Settled in 1732 and est. 1760. Inc. 1772. Named for Tar River, on which it is situated. Town commons, created by legislative act of 1760, is still maintained. The legislature met there in 1787. Produces textiles, lumber, machinery, toys, and paper products. In early records, the name sometimes appears as Tawboro. Alt. 58. See also Runnymeade; West Tarboro.

label: Tarboro Township
description: former township in central Edgecombe County, now township no. 1.

label: Tarcamp Branch
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows E into West Fork Tuckasegee River.

label: Tare-over
description: SW Washington County, a bridge and straight stretch of the road from Plymouth to Leachville crossing the headwaters of Flat Swamp at the NE end of Van Swamp. The name appears on the Price map, 1808, and is thought to have originated as the name for the grassy, swampy depression that cuts into Long Acre, which see.

label: Tarkiln Branch
description: rises in W Transylvania County and flows NE into Catheys Creek.

label: Tarkiln Gap
description: NE Cherokee County in the Valley River Mountains.

label: Tarkiln Mountain
description: in W Transylvania County between Tarkiln Branch and King Mountain.

label: Tarkiln Neck
description: peninsula at the junction of Pamlico and Pungo Rivers, E Beaufort County.

label: Tarkiln Ridge
description: central Macon County parallel to Poplar Cove.

label: Tarpleys Pond
description: SE Wake County on Little River. Covers 50 acres and has a max. depth of 15 ft. Used for irrigation and recreation.

label: Tarts Store
description: community in S Johnston County.

label: Tartt Path
description: pre-Civil War path still in use in E central Wilson County. It runs N from the community of Sun to the vicinity of modern N.C. Highway 42 E of Wilson. Enos Tartt operated Tartt's Mill on Bear Branch in the mid-nineteenth century.

label: Tate
description: community in N Rutherford County on Second Broad River.

label: Tate Branch
description: rises in NE Clay County and flows NE into Nantahala River.

label: Tate Gap
description: E Clay County between the headwaters of Passmore Branch and Fishprong Branch.

label: Tate's Knob
description: a small, sharp-top mountain in NE Caldwell County. Named for Andrew Tate, eighteenth-century settler.

label: Tater Hill
description: peak in N Watauga County on Rich Mountain approx. ¾ mi. S of Rich Mountain Bald. Also known in recent years as Potato Hill. Named because it resembles a large storage hill for potatoes. Alt. 5,194.

label: Tater Hill Lake
description: See Potato Hill Lake.

label: Tater Top Mountain
description: in Morrow Mountain State Park, E Stanly County.

label: Tatham Creek
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows NW into Savannah Creek.

label: Tatham Gap
description: on the Cherokee-Graham county line in the Snowbird Mountains. Alt. 3,500-3,639.

label: Tatter Knob
description: SE Buncombe County NW of Hickorynut Gap.

label: Tatums Township
description: NW Columbus County.

label: Tava Cove
description: N Cherokee County in the Snowbird Mountains.

label: Taylor
description: See Rock Ridge.

label: Taylor Bay
description: central Currituck County at S tip of Great Swamp.

label: Taylor Creek
description: a waterway separating Carrot Island from the mainland in S central Carteret County; flows from Lenox Point on the E to the mouth of Newport River on the w.

label: Taylor Creek
description: rises in N Craven County and flows SE into Neuse River.

label: Taylor Crossroads
description: community in S Nash County.

label: Taylor Millpond
description: SW Gates County, receives waters of a number of small streams and flows SE into Big Pocosin.

label: Taylor Pond
description: See Swains Mill Pond.

label: Taylor Township
description: N Wilson County.

label: Taylors Branch
description: rises in NE Columbus County and flows NE into Livingston Creek.

label: Taylors Bridge
description: community in SE Sampson County on Cuwhiffle Swamp.

label: Taylors Bridge Township
description: SE Sampson County.

label: Taylors Corner
description: community in W Jones County.

label: Taylors Creek
description: rises in S central Randolph County and flows W into Caraway Creek.

label: Taylors Ferry
description: operated across the Roanoke River between Bertie County and Martin County. Appears on the Collet map, 1770, and known to have been in operation as late as 1833.

label: Taylors Mill
description: See Tippetts Mill Pond.

label: Taylors Mill Pond
description: on the head of Corduroy Swamp in central Northampton County; approx. ¾ mi. long.

label: Taylors Pond
description: on the head of Reedy Branch in NW Duplin County.

label: Taylors Store
description: community in NW Nash County.

label: Taylorsville
description: town authorized in 1818 to be laid off on the lands of George Taylor on Black River in Sampson County. Probably never developed, and the exact site is unknown.

label: Taylorsville Township
description: central Alexander County.

label: Taywa Creek
description: rises in NE Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Hughes Ridge and flows SW into Bradley Fork. Named for a Cherokee Indian chief.

label: Tea Swamp
description: rises in central Duplin County and flows NE into Grove Creek.

label: Teaberry Ridge
description: central Haywood County between Right Fork Cove Creek and Wright Branch.

label: Teaches Hole
description: a navigable channel running NE and SW from Ocracoke Inlet, SE Hyde County. Traditionally named for Edward Teach, or Blackbeard, the notorious pirate killed nearby in 1718. Appears as Thatches Hole on the Moseley map, 1733, and shown as being closed at the NE end.

label: Teachey
description: town in SE Duplin County. Inc. 1874; charter repealed 1897; reincorporated 1903. Alt. 71.

label: Teague Branch
description: rises in central Haywood County and flows NW into Pigeon River.

label: Teague Branch
description: rises in S Macon County on the N side of Turkey Knob and flows N into Tellico Creek.

label: Teagues Ridge
description: mountain in W Avery County.

label: Teaguetown
description: community in NE Davidson County between the headwaters of Spurgeon and Abbotts Creeks. Named for a local family.

label: Tearshirt
description: See Dunn.

label: Teat Branch
description: rises in central Madison County and flows NW into Big Laurel Creek.

label: Teds Branch
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows S into Straight Fork.

label: Teer
description: community in SW Orange County on Cane Creek.

label: Teeseteska Ridge
description: S Graham County, extends N from Atoah Gap.

label: Telephone
description: community in NE Person County served by post office, 1882-1907.

label: Telfairs Creek
description: rises in S New Hanover County and flows SE into Cape Fear River. Called Rock Run on a coastal survey map made in 1851-53.

label: Tellico Bald
description: N Macon County at the head of Cold Spring Creek. Alt. 5,130.

label: Tellico Creek
description: rises in N Macon County and flows NE into Little Tennessee River.

label: Tellico River
description: rises in N Cherokee County and flows W into Monroe County, Tenn., where it turns N to flow into Tennessee River.

label: Tempa Mountain
description: S Mitchell County between Beaver Creek and North Toe River.

label: Temples Creek
description: rises in N Davidson County and flows N into Reedy Creek.

label: Tempting
description: community in N Moore County served by post office, 1886-1905.

label: Ten Mile Fork
description: community in E Jones County.

label: Ten Mile Swamp
description: rises in N Robeson County and flows SE and NE into Big Swamp.

label: Teneriffe Mountain
description: on Mud Creek in central Henderson County.

label: Tenmile Swamp
description: rises in W Onslow County and flows NW into Ninemile Swamp. Named for its distance from Rich Lands Chapel, an early center of settlement.

label: Tenmile Swamp
description: rises in E Sampson County and flows SW into Six Runs Creek.

label: Tennelina
description: community in W Madison County served by post office, 1903-34. The name is a combination of parts of the words Tennessee and Carolina.

label: Tennent Mountain
description: SE Haywood County in Pisgah National Forest near lat. 35°20'15" N., long. 82°52'10" W. Named for Gaillard Stoney Tennent (1872-1953) in recognition of his lifelong interest in studying and preserving the beauty of the W North Carolina mountains. Alt. over 6,040.

label: Tennessee
description: a state formed from W territory formerly a part of North Carolina that was ceded to the federal government in 1789. See also Watauga Settlement; District of Washington; Franklin; Davidson County; Greene County; Hawkins County; Sullivan County; Tennessee County; Washington County.

label: Tennessee Bald
description: most N peak on Tennessee Ridge on Haywood-Transylvania county line near Jackson County line. Alt. approx. 5,575.

label: Tennessee Branch
description: rises in N Swain County and flows SE into Bradley Fork.

label: Tennessee County
description: former county in what is now the state of Tennessee, was formed in 1788 and named for a Cherokee Indian word whose meaning is not now known. Clarks-ville became the county seat, but the county was divided into Montgomery and Robertson Counties in 1796, when Tennessee County gave its name to the new state. Part of the territory ceded by North Carolina in 1789 to the federal government.

label: Tennessee Ridge
description: extends from N to S along the Jackson-Transylvania county line between Haywood County line and head of West Fork French Broad River. Named peaks include Balk Knob, Bald Rock, The Pinnacle, Rockyface Mountain, Round Mountain, and Tennessee Bald.

label: Tennyson
description: community in S Davie County served by post office, 1891-1906.

label: Terebinthe
description: See Cedar Creek.

label: Teresita
description: community in S Macon County on Jones Creek.

label: Terra Ceia
description: community in N central Beaufort County. Alt. 16. Settled in the early 1920s by Dutch bulb growers; the community's name means "heavenly land."

label: Terra Cotta
description: former community in central Guilford County, now within the bounds of Greensboro. Name is Latin for "cooked earth." Named for the hard-baked clay plant there. Alt. 889.

label: Terrace Fork
description: See Terris Fork.

label: Terrapin
description: community in W Halifax County served by post office, 1893-1911.

label: Terrapin Creek
description: rises in W Warren County and flows N into Blue Mud Creek.

label: Terrapin Island
description: tidal-marsh island in Pamlico Sound, NE Pamlico County.

label: Terrapin Mountain
description: in S Jackson County between Chattooga Ridge and Chattooga River. Also called Fodderstack Mountain. Alt. 4,510. Known by the Cherokee Indians as Klansoona (terrapin).

label: Terrapin Point
description: in SE Bertie County extending into Batchelor Bay at the N side of Cashie River.

label: Terrapin Point
description: community in W Halifax County.

label: Terrapin Run
description: a bay in White Oak River, W Carteret County, that empties into Croaker Channel. Named for the fact that fishermen catch numerous terrapins there.

label: Terrazzo Switch
description: community in NE Cherokee County in Nantahala National Forest on Southern Railway. Named for terrazzo flooring made from locally mined marble chips.

label: Terrell
description: community in SE Catawba County. Named for an early Methodist minister in the vicinity.

label: Terrell Creek
description: rises in N Chatham County and flows NE into Haw River.

label: Terrell Gap
description: E Swain County on Williams Branch.

label: Terrell Mountain
description: N Chatham County 7 mi. SW of town of Chapel Hill. Alt. 849. Broadcast transmitting towers are there.

label: Terrible Creek
description: rises in SW Wake County N of town of Fuquay-Varina and flows E through Johnsons Pond and into Middle Creek.

label: Terris Fork
description: rises in E Madison County and flows W into Paint Fork. Appears as Terry Fork and Terrace Fork on various maps.

label: Terry Branch
description: rises in NW Nash County and flows E into Tumbling Run.

label: Terry Creek
description: rises in S Henderson County and flows N into Green River.

label: Terry Fork
description: See Terris Fork.

label: Terry Gap
description: in N Henderson County at the head of Kyles Creek.

label: Tessentee Creek
description: rises in S Macon County and flows W into Little Tennessee River.

label: Texana
description: community in central Cherokee County N of Murphy.

label: Teyahalee Bald
description: on the Cherokee-Graham county line in the Snowbird Mountains. Alt. 4,743.

label: Thagards Pond
description: on Little River in E Moore County. Covers approx. 100 acres. Named for William C. Thagard, who owned it from 1854 until about 1900. Was the site of Nicholas Smith's mill from as early as 1769. A residential community, Whispering Pines and a golf course were developed there about 1901.

label: Thanksgiving
description: community in N Johnston County; named for Baptist church founded there on Thanksgiving Day, 1899.

label: Tharon
description: community in E Duplin County on the head of Limestone Creek.

label: Tharp Mountain
description: NE Buncombe County between Martin and North Fork Ivy Creeks.

label: Thatches Hole
description: See Teaches Hole.

label: Thaxton
description: community in NW Ashe County. Alt. approx. 3,700.

label: Thelma
description: community in NW Halifax County near Roanoke River and S of the site of the old town of Gaston, which see. The town of South Gaston, which see, was chartered in 1895, but the charter was repealed in 1907. Alt. 224.

label: Theoff Point
description: projection from S Bodie Island into Roanoke Sound, E Dare County approx. ½ mi. N of Cedar Island.

label: Thermal Belt
description: (also called Isothermal Belt), verdant zone largely in Polk and Rutherford Counties—though to a lesser extent also in Caldwell, Mitchell, and other mountain counties—in which on certain cool nights, the temperature may be 20° or more higher on the slope of a mountain than at the base. In these areas, fruit growing is a successful undertaking, and at Tryon (Polk County) the thermal belt has contributed to resort prosperity. The thermal belt was first described by Silas McDowell in 1858.

label: Thermal City
description: community in N Rutherford County on Second Broad River. A post office est. there in 1888 was named Pescud; name changed to Thermal City for the Thermal Belt, which see, in 1891. Post office discontinued 1926.

label: Thermo Knob
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Balsam Mountain near lat. 35°41'39" N., long. 83°13'34" W. Alt. 6,120. Formerly known as Thermometer Knob.

label: Theta
description: community in NE Madison County served by post office, 1886-1900.

label: Thicket Branch
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows SW into Right Fork [Raven Fork].

label: Thickety Creek
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows S into Pigeon River.

label: Thickety Creek
description: rises in S Montgomery County and flows SW into Little River.

label: Third Creek
description: See Second Creek.

label: Third Fork Creek
description: rises in S Durham County and flows SW into New Hope Creek.

label: Thirty Foot Canal
description: E Washington County, extends NE between Lake Phelps and Scuppernong River.

label: Thomas Bay
description: S extension of Cawcaw Swamp in SW Brunswick County between its junctions with Little Cawcaw Swamp and Shingletree Swamp.

label: Thomas Branch
description: rises in central Madison County and flows SW into Hopewell Branch.

label: Thomas Creek
description: rises in W Wake County and flows SE into Little Whiteoak Creek.

label: Thomas Knob
description: S Macon County between Pipe-track Gap and Watkins Creek.

label: Thomas Landing
description: community in S Onslow County on Spicers Bay.

label: Thomas Peak
description: NW Jackson County between Camp Creek and Shoal Creek.

label: Thomas Ridge
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, extends in a semicircle from Deep Creek N following the general curve of Oconaluftee River with its center near lat. 35°32'30" N., long. 83°22'03" W. Named for Col. William Holland Thomas (1805-93), native of Haywood County and chief of the Cherokee Indians.

label: Thomasboro
description: community in SW Brunswick County. Named for Cornelius Thomas (1889-1961).

label: Thomasville
description: city in NE Davidson County. Founded 1852; inc. 1857. Named for John Warwick Thomas (1800-1871), founder. Produces furniture, textiles, hosiery, apparel, lumber, and concrete pipe.

label: Thomasville Township
description: NE Davidson County.

label: Thompkins Knob
description: at the junction of the Ashe-Watauga-Wilkes county lines in the Blue Ridge Mountains. Alt. 4,100. Also spelled Tomkins Knob.

label: Thompson
description: See Westover.

label: Thompson Branch
description: rises in W Cherokee County on Ghormley Mountain and flows NW into Shoal Creek.

label: Thompson Branch
description: rises in S Swain County and flows N into Sawmill Creek.

label: Thompson Creek
description: rises in N Transylvania County and flows S into South Fork Mills River.

label: Thompson Knob
description: N of Shuckpen Gap on the Buncombe-Haywood county line on Smathers View Mountain. Alt. 4,192.

label: Thompson River
description: rises in SW Transylvania County and flows SE into Oconee County, S.C., where it enters Whitewater River.

label: Thompson Store
description: community in NE Mecklenburg County.

label: Thompson Township
description: SW Robeson County.

label: Thompson's Branch
description: rises in N Greene County and flows E into Sandy Run. Named for a pioneer family.

label: Thompson's Bromine-Arsenic Springs
description: See Crumpler.

label: Thompsons Gap
description: E Alleghany County.

label: Thompsons Gut
description: rises in W Bertie County and flows W into Roanoke River.

label: Thompsons Millpond
description: N Wake County in Horse Creek.

label: Thompsonville
description: See Williamsburg.

label: Thorn Mountain
description: SW Macon County between Siler Bald Branch and Bryson Branch.

label: Thorntons Creek
description: rises in E Harnett County and flows SW into Cape Fear River.

label: Thorofare
description: channel in NE Carteret County connecting Thorofare Bay with West Thorofare Bay and forming the S boundary of Cedar Island.

label: Thorofare Bay
description: on the S side of Cedar Island emptying into Core Sound, NE Carteret County.

label: Thorofare Swamp
description: rises in E Pitt County and flows SE into Clayroot Swamp.

label: Thoroughfare
description: portion of Pee Dee River flowing S of Youngs Island, N Anson County.

label: Thoroughfare
description: a waterway connecting Black River and Cape Fear River, SW Pender County.

label: Thoroughfare Branch
description: rises in S Lee County and flows NE into Juniper Creek.

label: Thoroughfare Island
description: a small island in North River, W Currituck County. North of the island, the river is sometimes known as Indian-town Creek.

label: Thoroughfare Swamp
description: rises in SW Wayne County and flows NE and N into Neuse River. Formerly known as Falling Creek, and so designated on the Price map, 1808, and by Dr. Elisha Mitchell in his 1827 journal.

label: Thorpe Reservoir
description: See Lake Thorpe.

label: Thrash Branch
description: rises in central Transylvania County and flows SW into French Broad River.

label: Thrash Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County on Old Mattie Ridge and flows SE and SW into Valley River. See also Wood Lake.

label: Three Forks
description: See Busick.

label: Three Forks Creek
description: formed in SE Yancey County by the junction of Left Prong and Right Prong and flows NW into South Toe River.

label: Three Forks Mountain
description: W central Transylvania County at the NW end of Big Mountain Ridge and the W end of Soapstone Ridge. Alt. 3,774.

label: Three Hat Mountain
description: E Davidson County on the headwaters of Flat Swamp Creek.

label: Three Knobs
description: on the McDowell-Yancey county line.

label: Three Mile
description: community in S Avery County.

label: Three Mile Branch
description: rises in N Cabarrus County and flows SE into Cold Water Creek.

label: Three Mile Creek
description: rises in S Avery County and flows SW into North Toe River.

label: Three Point Gap
description: NW Cherokee County below Hazel Knob and near Bryson Lead.

label: Three Quarters Creek
description: rises in E central Yancey County and flows S into Little Crabtree Creek.

label: Three Top Creek
description: rises in S central Ashe County and flows N into North Fork New River.

label: Three Top Mountain
description: W Ashe County. Alt. 5,029.

label: Three Top Ridge
description: in S Haywood County between Nick Creek and McClure Creek.

label: Threemile Creek
description: rises in W Orange County and flows SE into Sevenmile Creek.

label: Thrift
description: railroad depot name for the Mecklenburg County community of Paw Creek, which see.

label: Thrift Cove Branch
description: rises in N Transylvania County and flows S into Davidson River.

label: Thumb Swamp
description: rises in SE Bladen County and flows E into Colly Creek approx. 5 mi. SE of Singletary Lake.

label: Thumping Branch
description: rises in SE Clay County on Little Mountain and flows SW into Eagle Creek.

label: Thunder Hill
description: S Watauga County near the head of Groundhog Branch.

label: Thunder Struck Mountain
description: E Jackson County between Snaggy Bald and Mayapple Gap.

label: Thunder Swamp
description: rises in S Wayne County and flows NW into Thoroughfare Swamp.

label: Thunderbolt Landing
description: on Cashie River, SE Bertie County.

label: Thunderhead Mountain
description: on the Swain County, N.C.-Blount County, Tenn., line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°34'08" N., long. 83°42'24" W. Alt. 5,530.

label: Thunderhole Creek
description: rises in S Watauga County approx. 2 mi. W of the town of Blowing Rock and flows S into N Caldwell County, where it enters Johns River.

label: Thunderstruck Knob
description: in NW Yancey County at the S end of Fork Ridge between Hensley Branch and Cane River.

label: Thunderstruck Ridge
description: N Jackson County between Polecat Branch and Soco Creek.

label: Thundertontrenck
description: See Lenox Castle.

label: Thurman
description: community in E Craven County on Neuse River. Alt. 26. Settled about 1850 and named for Allen G. Thurman (1813-95), member of Congress (1845-47) and later a senator from Ohio. His mother was the daughter of Nathaniel Allen, nephew and adopted son of Joseph Hewes of Edenton.

label: Thurmond
description: community in NE Wilkes County at the Surry County line.

label: Thurston
description: community in SE Alexander County served by post office, 1881-1902.

label: Thurz Mountain
description: N Buncombe County NW of Wiley Mountain.

label: Tiancok
description: an Indian village of the Chawanoac tribe; appears on the Comberford map, 1657, located in what is now N Hertford County between Potecasi Creek and Meherrin River near the Chowan River. See also Cokey Swamp.

label: Tibb Ridge
description: E Cherokee County in the Valley River Mountains.

label: Tibbs Run
description: rises in E Randolph County and flows SE into Richland Creek.

label: Ticer Branch
description: rises in W Mecklenburg County and flows SW into Paw Creek.

label: Tick Creek
description: rises in W Chatham County and flows NE into Rocky River.

label: Tickle Creek
description: rises in E Guilford County and flows SE into Alamance County, where it enters Traverse Creek.

label: Tidewater Area
description: a portion of the Coastal Plain, which see, from 30 to 80 mi. wide on the mainland side of the sounds in E North Carolina. Much of the area is swampland, known locally as "dismals" and "pocosins." There also are a number of natural lakes there, as well as many areas of savanna with a thick growth of grass and many wildflowers.

label: Tiger
description: community in NW Rutherford County on Buffalo Creek.

label: Tilden
description: See Maxton.

label: Tillery
description: town in E Halifax County. Inc. 1889, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Named for Tillery family, who settled there before 1790. Site of federal resettlement project, 1935. Alt. 64.

label: Tillery Branch
description: rises in S Madison County and flows W into French Broad River.

label: Tilley Creek
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows NE into Cullowhee Creek.

label: Tillis's Mill Creek
description: See Mill Creek.

label: Tillman
description: community in SW Chatham County served by post office, 1892-1905.

label: Tim Creek
description: rises in N Cleveland County and flows SW into Ward Creek.

label: Timber Creek
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows W to join Ogle Creek in forming Sugar Camp Creek.

label: Timber Ridge
description: S Yancey County between Timber and Ogle Creeks.

label: Timbered Ridge
description: mountain in SE Avery County.

label: Timberlake
description: community in S Person County. Settled about 1890. Named for William Timberlake Sr., first postmaster. The railroad station there is known as Helena, named for the wife of an official of the railroad. Alt. 570.

label: Timberland
description: community in W Hoke County.

label: Timothy
description: community in N Sampson County on Sevenmile Swamp.

label: Timothy Knob
description: S Watauga County on the head of Clark Creek.

label: Tims Creek
description: rises in SE Burke County near Smith Mountain and flows SE into Henry Fork.

label: Tin Cap Knob
description: W Macon County between Tyler Branch and Nantahala River.

label: Tin City
description: community in S Duplin County.

label: Tincoco
description: See Cokey Swamp.

label: Tindallsville
description: former town in E Stanly County on Pee Dee River in what is now Morrow Mountain State Park. Inc. 1795. Served as a county seat of Montgomery County for a brief time. Site long since abandoned. See also Henderson.

label: Tinoco Creek
description: See Cokey Swamp.

label: Tinsley Creek
description: rises in N central Transylvania County and flows SE into King Creek.

label: Tippecanoe
description: community in N Sampson County served by post office, 1890-1904.

label: Tippers Crossroads
description: See Six Forks.

label: Tippet Branch
description: rises in E Macon County and flows SW into Little Tennessee River.

label: Tippet Creek
description: rises in E Macon County and flows NW into Caler Fork.

label: Tippetts Mill Pond
description: on Moccasin Creek at the Johnston-Nash county line. Approx. ½ mi. long. Formed before the Civil War and known first as Taylor's Mill, later as Hilliard's Mill, and since about 1949 as Tippetts Mill. In the past a sawmill, cotton gin, and corn and wheat mills have been operated there. Wagons known as Moccasin Wagons were made there.

label: Tipton Branch
description: rises in NE Clay County and flows NE into Nantahala River.

label: Tipton Creek
description: rises in N Cherokee County in the Unicoi Mountains and flows NW through Tipton Gap into Tellico River.

label: Tipton Gap
description: N Cherokee County in the Unicoi Mountains.

label: Tipton Hill
description: community in W Mitchell County on Raccoon Creek.

label: Tipton Knob
description: N Cherokee County in the Unicoi Mountains.

label: Tiptop
description: community in S Transylvania County served by post office, 1886-1904.

label: Titepano
description: appears on White map, 1585, in what is now Currituck Sound, E Currituck County. The name may have applied to the sound and seems to have been tetep-anwi-wi (there is a swirling current; it swirls around).

label: Titus Point
description: See Lenox Point.

label: Toast
description: community in N Surry County.

label: Tobacco Branch
description: rises in N central Union County and flows SE into Chinkapin Creek.

label: Tobaccoville
description: community in N Forsyth County. Post office est. 1879 and named for a chewing-tobacco factory built there. Alt. 994.

label: Tobermory
description: community in NW Bladen County served by post office, 1917-25. Named for the village in W Scotland.

label: Tobie's Branch
description: rises in NE Wilson County and flows SE into Town Creek.

label: Todd
description: town on the Ashe-Watauga county line at the junction of Big Elk Creek with South Fork New River. Inc. 1915 in Ashe County, but that same year the county line was changed so that the town came to lie partially in Watauga County. No longer active in municipal affairs. A post office est. there as Elk Crossroads in 1837 but changed to Todd in 1894. Alt. approx. 3,000.

label: Todds Creek
description: rises in S New Hanover County and flows SW into Cape Fear River. Called Motts Creek on a coastal survey map made in 1851-53.

label: Todds Crossroads
description: community in E central Bertie County.

label: Toddy
description: community in W Pitt County. The community was known as Tugwell and the railroad name was Toddy Station in the early twentieth century. Named for the fact that a drink of whiskey could be had at a local store.

label: Toe River
description: is formed on the Mitchell-Yancey county line near Boonford by the junction of North Toe and South Toe Rivers. It flows NW along the line to join Cane River in forming Nolichucky River. Tradition says the name is derived from Estatoe, the name of an Indian princess who drowned herself in the river when her lover was killed by her kinsmen.

label: Toe River Township
description: S Avery County.

label: Toecane
description: community in central Mitchell County at the junction of Toe River and Cane Creek. Alt. 2,058.

label: Togo
description: See Genlee.

label: Toisnot
description: See Elm City and see Toisnot Swamp.

label: Toisnot Swamp
description: rises in S Nash County and flows SE into N Wilson County. It flows across the county and enters Contentnea Creek in S Wilson County. The name Toisnot is from the Iroquoian language base of the Tuscarora tosneoc, meaning "close to two rivers." The name is properly applied not to a single village but to around a dozen different sites occupied by the Tuscarora in what is now E Wilson County. Until about the 1850s, the name was spelled Tosneot and appears that way in local records dating from 1741 and on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Toisnot Township
description: N Wilson County.

label: Tokay
description: community just outside the N limits of the city of Fayetteville, central Cumberland County.

label: Tolar Landing
description: United States Lock Number 3, on Cape Fear River in NW Bladen County.

label: Tolarsville
description: community in E Robeson County served by post office, 1876-1911.

label: Toledo
description: community in NE Yancey County served by post office, 1905-54.

label: Tolers
description: community in W Orange County served by post office, 1890-1905.

label: Toliver
description: community in SW Ashe County served by post office, 1902-53.

label: Toluca
description: community in NE Cleveland County at the Lincoln County line.

label: Tom Branch
description: rises in SE Macon County and flows SW into Brooks Creek.

label: Tom Bryan Cove
description: N Macon County between Miller Hollow and Fall Branch.

label: Tom Creek
description: rises in N Mitchell County and flows S into Spring Creek.

label: Tom Creek
description: rises in E Transylvania County and flows S then abruptly NE into Little River.

label: Tom Hall Branch
description: rises in N Haywood County and flows W into Pigeon River.

label: Tom Jack Creek
description: rises in S Wake County and flows S into NE Lee County, where it joins Whiteoak Creek.

label: Tom Knob
description: W Watauga County near the head of Spice Creek. Alt. 4,293.

label: Tom Mann Creek
description: a bay on the N shore of Durant Island, central Dare County.

label: Tom Thumb Creek
description: rises on S slopes of High Peak in the Snowbird Mountains, NE Cherokee County, and flows SW and SE into Valley River approx. 3 mi. NE of Andrews.

label: Tom's Creek
description: community in central McDowell County served by post office, 1886-1905.

label: Tomahawk
description: community in S Sampson County. Settled about 1888. Alt. 99.

label: Tomahawk Branch
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows S into Lake Tomahawk then SW into Swannanoa River.

label: Tomahawk Branch
description: See Stewarts Creek.

label: Tomahawk Creek
description: is formed in S Sampson County by the junction of Little Tomahawk and Big Tomahawk Creeks and flows W into South River.

label: Tomblin Branch
description: rises in E central Brunswick County and flows NE into Lewis Swamp.

label: Tomcreek
description: See Tom's Creek.

label: Tomkins Knob
description: See Thompkins Knob.

label: Tommy Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows NE into Wayah Creek.

label: Tommy Knob
description: N Graham County between the headwaters of Yellow Creek and Cables Cove Creek.

label: Tomotla
description: community in central Cherokee County. Alt. 1,575.

label: Toms Branch
description: rises in N Haywood County and flows S into Fines Creek.

label: Toms Creek
description: See Westfield.

label: Toms Devil Knob
description: SE Alleghany County between Bullhead and Stone Mountains.

label: Toms Fork
description: stream rises in S Columbus County and flows N into Grissett Swamp.

label: Toms Mountain
description: a double-topped peak in NW Rutherford County near the headwaters of Cove Creek. Alt. approx. 1,920. Sometimes known as Chalk Mountain.

label: Toms Top
description: central Haywood County between Snakeden Top and Colman Gap.

label: Tony
description: community in S Caswell County. A post office was operated there, 1890-1908.

label: Tonys Branch
description: rises in SE Watauga County and flows SE into Joes Creek.

label: Toodies Creek
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows NE into Cane River.

label: Tooles Creek
description: rises in N Franklin County and flows SW into Lynch Creek.

label: Tooleys Creek
description: rises in SE Beaufort County and flows S into South Creek.

label: Tooleys Point
description: point of land in E Beaufort County on the N side of Pungo River at the mouth of Pantego Creek, SE limits of Belhaven.

label: Tools Ford
description: former passage across Catawba River between Gaston and Mecklenburg Counties E of the present site of Mount Holly. Named for Matthew Tool, who had a grant of land in the vicinity in 1750. The ford was used by troops crossing the Catawba River during the Revolutionary War.

label: Toomer
description: See Summerville.

label: Toot Hollow Branch
description: rises in central Swain County and flows S through Bryson City into Tuckasegee River.

label: Topnot
description: community in central Caswell County. A post office operated there, 1883-1936.

label: Topsail
description: community in S Pender County. Alt. 40.

label: Topsail Beach
description: town in SE Pender County on the Atlantic Ocean side of Topsail Island. Inc. 1963. Known prior to 1963 as New Topsail Beach.

label: Topsail Inlet
description: See Beaufort Inlet.

label: Topsail Island
description: E Pender County. Barrier beach lying between Topsail Sound and the Atlantic Ocean. Approx. 8½ mi. long.

label: Topsail Sound
description: extends NE from Mason Inlet, NE New Hanover County, across Pender County to Stump Inlet on the Onslow-Pender county line. It is separated from the Atlantic Ocean by a barrier beach. The sound, about 17 mi. in length, is filled with tidal-marsh islands. Named for the fact that local residents watched from there for the appearance of topsails of approaching vessels.

label: Topsail Township
description: SE Pender County.

label: Topsy
description: community in W Gates County served by post office, 1901-10. Alt. 33. Settled about 1870.

label: Topton
description: community in NE Cherokee County. Alt. 2,599. Named because it is at the top of a pass, Red Marble Gap. It is located very near the junction of Cherokee, Graham, and Macon Counties, and residents of all three counties consider themselves citizens of the community.

label: Torhunta
description: a village of the Tuscarora Indians, appears on the Moseley map, 1733, at the head of Contentnea Creek in what is now W Wilson County. Many variant spellings include Tarhunta, Taughoutnith, Nahunta, Narhantes. Derives from Indian term meaning "it stays overnight."

label: Tories Den
description: cave beneath Moores Knob on Sauratown Mountain in Hanging Rock State Park, W Stokes County. Entrance 12 ft. high and 10 ft. wide; cave about 25 ft. deep. Said to have been occupied by a band of Tories during the Revolutionary War.

label: Torrence Creek
description: rises in N Mecklenburg County and flows W into McDowells Creek.

label: Tory Hole
description: See Elizabethtown.

label: Tosneoc
description: See Toisnot Swamp.

label: Tosnot Depot
description: See Wilson.

label: Totero Fork
description: appears on the Moseley map, 1733, as being between Uwharrie and Caraway Creek in what is now W Randolph County. Named for Totero or Tutelo Indians, who lived in the foothills of the Blue Ridge in the seventeenth century but who subsequently migrated to E Virginia and later to Pennsylvania and elsewhere.

label: Totherrow Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SW into Valley River.

label: Tottering Bridge
description: W central Washington County over Skinner Canal near the community of Basnight. Known by the name as early as 1868.

label: Tough Ridge
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a spur extending NW from Cataloochee Divide; center near lat. 35°35'05" N., long. 83°05'54" W., between Clontz Branch and McKee Branch.

label: Tow String Creek
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows SW into Oconaluftee River. Named because an old woman who lived on the creek made tow strings for the settlers.

label: Tower Hill
description: former plantation of Governor Arthur Dobbs in what is now NE Lenoir County. He purchased 850 acres there in 1755 as a possible site for a provincial capital. By an act of the Assembly in 1758, the site was purchased for a capital to be named George City in honor of King George II. The capital was not approved by authorities in London, and the property eventually was sold by the state in 1799. Tower Hill appears on the Collet map, 1770. The name apparently originated because an "old redoubt tower" remained there from a fort constructed during the Tuscarora War, 1711-13. See also George City.

label: Tower Hill Branch
description: rises in NE Lenoir County near Georgetown and flows N into Jericho Run.

label: Town Branch
description: rises in S central Yadkin County and flows SE just S of Yadkinville into North Deep Creek.

label: Town Creek
description: rises in S Clay County and flows SE and NE into Hiwassee River.

label: Town Creek
description: See also Crane Creek.

label: Town Creek Indian Mound
description: State Historic Site, S Montgomery County. Area: 53 acres. Est. 1937. Contains excavated and restored Indian mound dating from early sixteenth century and a museum.

label: Town Creek Township
description: central Brunswick County.

label: Town Fork Creek
description: rises in W Stokes County and flows SE and then NE across the S part of the county, entering Forsyth County for a short distance and then flowing into Dan River. The headwaters are labeled Slek Creek on the Collet map, 1770, and the lower course simply Town Fork. An iron forge was operated along the banks of the creek by 1796.

label: Town Marsh
description: a tidal-marsh island SW of Beaufort in S Carteret County.

label: Town Mountain Gap
description: central Buncombe County in the Elk Mountains.

label: Town Point
description: central Onslow County at the N end of Farnell Bay and the S end of Morgan Bay. Now within the Camp Lejeune Marine Corps Air Station.

label: Town Swamp
description: SW Bertie County, a part of the larger Broadneck Swamp. Probably named for a Tuscarora Indian town in the vicinity, abandoned before 1800.

label: Townhouse Branch
description: rises in SW Swain County and flows SE into Nantahala River.

label: Townhouse Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County below Old Mattie Ridge and flows S into Welch Mill Creek.

label: Townhouse Ridge
description: NE Cherokee County between Welch Mill Creek and Townhouse Creek. Alt. 2,523.

label: Townsend
description: community in SW Watauga County.

label: Townsend Gap
description: S Watauga County near the head of Clark Creek.

label: Townsville
description: town in N Vance County between Little Island Creek and SE prong of Kerr Lake. Alt. 421. James Lyne operated a store there about 1780, and the surrounding community was named Lynesville, the name by which it appears on the MacRae map, 1833. Inc. in 1857 and named for Edmund Towne, who donated land for a railway station. Served by post office since 1855.

label: Townsville Lake
description: See Kerr Lake.

label: Townsville Township
description: N Vance County.

label: Toxaway
description: See Lake Toxaway; Rosman.

label: Toxaway Creek
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows SW into Toxaway River.

label: Toxaway Falls
description: SW Transylvania County on Tox-away River S of community of Lake Toxaway. The falls, which cascade 123 ft., are crossed by a highway bridge.

label: Toxaway Mountain
description: on the Jackson-Transylvania county line N of Horsepasture River.

label: Toxaway River
description: rises in SW Transylvania County and flows N for a short distance then SE and SW into South Carolina, where it joins Whitewater River in forming Keowee River. The name is derived from the Cherokee word Tor-tzoo-whah (redbird).

label: Tracadia
description: See Baltimore.

label: Trace Branch
description: rises in N Jones County and flows S into Beaver Creek.

label: Trace Ridge
description: extends SE from Beaverdam Gap in NW Henderson County to the junction of Wash Creek and North Fork Mills River.

label: Tracey Swamp
description: rises in N Jones County and flows N along the Craven-Lenoir county line into Neuse River. See also Gum Swamp.

label: Tracy
description: community in N Watauga County on North Fork New River.

label: Tracy Grove
description: community in E Henderson County.

label: Trading Ford
description: former ford across the Yadkin River, Rowan and Davidson Counties. The E end of Big Island was one terminus of the ford. In 1701 John Lawson visited the site, which was on a trading path maintained by Indians across central North Carolina. Gen. Nathanael Greene's American army made a crossing there, February 1, 1781, when almost caught by Cornwallis. High water prevented the British from overtaking the exhausted Americans. A Confederate fort and earth-works nearby protected the railroad and a toll bridge during the Civil War.

label: Trading Path
description: a colonial trading route dating from the seventeenth century from Petersburg, Va., to the Catawba and Waxhaw Indians. One branch entered North Carolina in Granville County and another in Warren County. They converged near the present site of Oxford and followed a SW route through Granville, Durham, Orange, Alamance, Guilford, Randolph, Davidson, Rowan, and Cabarrus Counties. At about the present site of Concord, the road split, with a W branch leading through present Charlotte to the Catawba Indians. The E branch led almost directly S through Union County to the Waxhaw Indians. The Trading Path appears on the Collet map, 1770, and the Mouzon map, 1775.

label: Trafalgar, Cabo de
description: See Cape Fear.

label: Trail Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NW into McClellan Creek.

label: Trail Ridge
description: W Haywood County, extends E from the county line to Palmer Creek.

label: Trail Ridge
description: S Macon County between Cunningham Creek and Henson Creek.

label: Trailbranch
description: community in SE Madison County. A post office operated there, 1876-1905.

label: Tramaskecooc
description: Indian village, appears on the White map, 1585, at or near the present location of Cherry Ridge Landing, which see, S Tyrrell or N Hyde County near the head of Alligator River. The tribal affiliation of the Indians is uncertain, although the Secotan Indians were active in the area. The name of the village is said to have meant either "beavers" or "people of the white-cedar swamps."

label: Tramble Gap
description: SE Henderson County near the North Carolina-South Carolina line.

label: Tramway
description: community in W Lee County. Named because it was the terminus of a tramroad from Cameron. A Civil War drill ground was approx. 1 mi. S of Tramway.

label: Tranquility
description: community in S Granville County served by post office, 1839-56.

label: Transon
description: community in E Ashe County served by post office, 1888-1926 and 1937-53. Alt. 3,300.

label: Transylvania County
description: was formed in 1861 from Henderson and Jackson Counties. Located in the W section of the state, it is bounded by the state of South Carolina and by Jackson, Haywood, and Henderson Counties. Its name is a combination of two Latin words, trans (across) and sylva (woods). Area: 379 sq. mi. County seat: Brevard, with an elevation of 2,230 ft. Townships are Boyd, Brevard, Catheys Creek, Dunns Rock, Estatoe, Gloucester, Hogback, and Little River. Produces corn, hay, Christmas trees, apples and other fruits and vegetables, poultry, dairy products, livestock, hogs, lumber, paper products, wood products, baked goods, chemicals, textiles, crushed stone, asbestos, sand, and mica.

label: Tranters Creek
description: rises in SW Martin County and flows SE on the Pitt-Martin county line and S on the Pitt-Beaufort county line into Tar River near the point at which it becomes the Pamlico River. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733. The creek was the site of a Civil War battle, June 5, 1862.

label: Trantham Creek
description: rises in SE Buncombe County near Flat Top Mountain and flows SW into Cane Creek.

label: Trantus
description: community in SW Martin County served by post office, 1901-1904.

label: Trap
description: community in NE Bertie County. Named because a local tavern about 1860 "trapped" men of the community, according to their wives.

label: Trap Branch
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows W into Straight Fork.

label: Trap Hill Township
description: NE Wilkes County.

label: Traphill
description: community in N Wilkes County E of Little Sandy Creek. Area settled by 1775. In 1833 a town to be named Johnsonville (for an invalid Revolutionary War veteran wounded at Kings Mountain, Capt. Samuel Johnson, who died the next year) was authorized to be laid out at Trap Hill but never developed. A post office to serve the community was est. there in 1837 and named Trap Hill for hunter William Blackburn's rail-pen snare, which he frequently set on a nearby hill to catch wild turkeys.

label: Traps Bay
description: S Onslow County on the E side of New River nears its mouth. Named for Capt. Cornelius Trap, who was living in the county in 1746.

label: Traps Creek
description: rises in SE Onslow County and flows SW into Traps Bay.

label: Traverse Creek
description: rises in E Guilford County and flows NE into Alamance County, where it enters Haw River.

label: Travis
description: community in NW Tyrrell County N of Scuppernong River.

label: Trays Island Creek
description: rises in S Jackson County on the N slope of Bald Rock Mountain. It flows N and W around the mountain and then S through Fairfield Lake into Horsepasture River.

label: Treeland
description: See Whitnel.

label: Treetop
description: community in central Ashe County.

label: Trenholm Mountain
description: central Henderson County on Memminger Creek. Named for the family of George H. Trenholm of Flat Rock. Tren-holm became Confederate secretary of the treasury after C. G. Memminger in 1864.

label: Trent
description: See Frisco; Merritt; Trenton.

label: Trent Branch
description: rises in N Madison County and flows SW into French Broad River.

label: Trent Bridge
description: See Pollocksville.

label: Trent River
description: rises in central Pamlico County and flows N into Bay River. Often known locally as Trent Creek.

label: Trent Township
description: SW Lenoir County.

label: Trent Woods
description: town in central Craven County on Trent River S of New Bern. Inc. 1959.

label: Trenton
description: town and county seat, central Jones County. Courthouse apparently est. at the site in or soon after 1779, when the county was formed. Apparently known as Trent until 1784, when a town to be known as Trenton was authorized to be laid off at the site of the courthouse. Inc. 1874. Took its name from the Trent River, on which it is located. Alt. 28.

label: Trenton Township
description: central Jones County.

label: Tri-Villages
description: term used by local residents of Hatteras Island, E Dare County, to refer to Rodanthe, Waves, and Salvo, three communities formerly known collectively as Chicamacomico.

label: Triad
description: See Piedmont Triad.

label: Triangle
description: term used for the Raleigh-Durham-Chapel Hill area. See also Research Triangle Park.

label: Triangle Township
description: SE Durham County. Named for Research Triangle Park, which see.

label: Trickum Creek
description: rises in N Forsyth County and flows N into Buffalo Creek.

label: Tricorner Knob
description: on the line separating Haywood and Swain Counties in North Carolina from Sevier County in Tennessee. Alt. more than 6,100. Named for its location at the coincidence of three counties.

label: Trilby
description: See Allensville.

label: Trim Cove
description: NE Cherokee County, through which an unnamed stream flows SE into Valley River.

label: Trimont Branch
description: rises in central Macon County and flows SE into Wallace Branch.

label: Trimont Mountain
description: central Macon County at the head of Jacob Branch. Alt. approx. 3,700.

label: Trimont Ridge
description: extends from White Oak Ridge in W Macon County to Jacob Branch in central Macon County.

label: Trinity
description: community in S Union County on Buffalo Creek; named for a local church. Former Hope community was located just e.

label: Trinity Harbor
description: a former inlet from the Atlantic Ocean into Albemarle Sound through North Banks S of the present community of Duck. It opened prior to 1585 and closed prior to 1657. Appears on the White map, 1590. The Smith map, 1624, labels it Worcester Inlet. Probably named because it was discovered on one of the Sundays after Trinity (either the 1st or 8th of August, 1585). The site is now in NE Dare County.

label: Trinity Township
description: NW Randolph County.

label: Trio
description: community in N Rutherford County served by post office, 1888-1906.

label: Triple Falls
description: E Transylvania County in Little River between the mouth of Hooker Creek and the mouth of Grassy Creek. Height of the falls is 50 ft.

label: Triplett
description: community in E Watauga County served by post office since 1881.

label: Triplett Creek
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows SW into Joes Creek.

label: Tritt Knob
description: central Haywood County on Jonathans Creek. Alt. 3,600.

label: Trollinger's Crossing
description: or See Haw River.

label: Trotman Creek
description: rises in S Gates County and flows W and S into Warwick Creek to form Catherine Creek.

label: Trotters Creek
description: rises in W Lenoir County and flows NW then N into Dailys Creek. Davis Mill Pond, which see, is on the creek.

label: Trotville
description: community in S Gates County. Alt. 39.

label: Troublefield Run Creek
description: rises in W Northampton County and flows S into Roanoke River.

label: Troublesome
description: community in S Rockingham County served by post office, 1834-83.

label: Troublesome Creek
description: appears on the Kerr map, 1882, and on the 1865 coastal survey map as rising in W Onslow County and flowing NE into New River or Southwest Creek. The name Troublesome Run is applied to the stream on the Price map, 1808, and on the MacRae map, 1833.

label: Troublesome Creek Iron Works
description: used during Revolutionary War. Built on Troublesome Creek, SW Rockingham County, by William Patrick, 1770. Nathanael Greene camped there, 1781; George Washington had breakfast there, June 3, 1791.

label: Troublesome Point
description: extends into the mouth of the North Landing River in NE Currituck County.

label: Trout
description: community in W central Ashe County. Alt. approx. 2,900.

label: Trout Cove Branch
description: rises in SW Clay County and flows SW into Brasstown Creek.

label: Trout Creek
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows NE into Elk Creek.

label: Trout Lake
description: artificial lake in central Watauga County on Flannery Fork. Formed in 1954, it has a max. depth of 20 ft. and an area of approx. 13 acres. Open to the public.

label: Troutman
description: town in S Iredell County. Settled about 1859 and inc. 1905. Named for Mrs. Annie Troutman and her sons, Sydney and Jacob, who settled there and operated a wagon shop. Post office est. 1872 known as Troutman's, 1889-1956. Produces apparel and furniture. Alt. 955.

label: Troutman Mine
description: former gold mine in NE Cabarrus County.

label: Troy
description: town and county seat in central Montgomery County. Laid out as the county seat in 1843 and inc. 1852. Alt. 664. Accounts vary on origin of name. May have been named for Robert Troy, member of the House of Commons in 1802 and 1806 from Anson County and trustee of the University of North Carolina, 1804-1807, who died in 1807; for John B. Troy, member of the General Assembly from Randolph County, who died before 1837; or for the ancient city of Troy. Produces furniture, carpets, textiles, mobile homes, and lumber.

label: Troy Township
description: central Montgomery County.

label: Troy's Store
description: community in NE Randolph County. A post office operated there, 1826-84. John B. Troy operated a school there in 1837.

label: Troyville
description: See Coats.

label: Truckwheel Mountain
description: S Buncombe County between Chestnut Cove and Sleepy Gap.

label: Truda
description: community in W Richmond County.

label: Truebloods Point
description: W Pasquotank County, extends into Little River just S of Nixonton.

label: Truett Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SE into Morris Creek.

label: Trull Cove
description: E Cherokee County, through which a short tributary of Slow Creek flows.

label: Trumpet Branch
description: rises in N central Iredell County and flows S into Rocky Creek just N of Olin. Before the Civil War, Joseph Weisner had an iron foundry there known as Trumpet Branch. It is believed that machinery for antebellum cotton factories in the SE was made there.

label: Trumpeters Swamp
description: rises in S Pender County and flows NW into Merricks Creek.

label: Trust
description: community in SW Madison County on Spring Creek. Alt. 2,411.

label: Truth
description: community in SE Chatham County.

label: Truvine
description: community in E Wayne County served by post office, 1891-92.

label: Tryon
description: town in SW Polk County. Inc. 1885 as Tryon City. Named for nearby Tryon Mountain, which see. Post office, est. 1855, known as Tryon City. Alt 1,075.

label: Tryon City
description: See Tryon.

label: Tryon County
description: was formed from Mecklenburg County in 1769 and named in honor of William Tryon (1729-88), governor of North Carolina, 1765-71. The county was abolished in 1779 and divided into Lincoln and Rutherford Counties, which see.

label: Tryon Mountain
description: W Polk County above the town of Tryon between Skyuka Creek and Little Cove Creek. Named for William Tryon (1729-88), governor of North Carolina, 1765-71. Named by the Cherokee for the governor in 1767 when a boundary was being est. between white and Cherokee lands. Appears on the Collet map, 1770. Alt. 3,231.

label: Tryon Palace
description: State Historic Site in New Bern, central Craven County. Est. 1952. Contains restored and reconstructed "Tryon's Palace," completed in 1770 for royal governor William Tryon. Partly burned, 1798. First capitol of state of North Carolina. Reconstruction began, 1952; palace opened to public, 1959.

label: Tryon Township
description: SW Polk County.

label: Tsiyahi
description: See Cheoah.

label: Tub-Mill Creek
description: rises in NW Swain County and flows S to join Gunna Creek in Great Smoky Mountains National Park to form Eagle Creek.

label: Tubbs Inlet
description: a tidal waterway in SW Brunswick County between Bald Beach and Hales Beach.

label: Tuck Creek
description: rises in SW Cleveland County and flows N into Broad River.

label: Tuckahoe
description: community in W Jones County served by post office, 1836-1902. Mentioned in a letter from James Iredell to his wife dated May 17, 1782. Named for a plant (Peltandra virginica or Orontium aquaticum) whose roots were cooked and eaten by the Indians.

label: Tuckahoe Creek
description: rises from Tuckahoe Swamp in W Jones County and flows E into Trent River. Appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Tuckahoe Creek
description: rises in W Pender County and flows NE into Moores Creek.

label: Tuckahoe Swamp
description: rises in S Lenoir County and flows SE into W Jones County, where it becomes less well defined and more of a true swamp. The swamp is drained to the E by Tuckahoe Creek.

label: Tuckahoe Township
description: W Jones County.

label: Tuckasege
description: community in E Gaston County on Catawba River. Tuckasege Ford over the river was nearby. It is mentioned in local records as early as 1780 and appears on the Price map, 1808. Tuckasege Ferry there was in operation in the early years of the twentieth century.

label: Tuckasegee
description: community in central Jackson County at junction of West Fork Tuckasegee River with Tuckasegee River. Named for Cherokee Indian word meaning "crawling terrapin." Alt. 2,184.

label: Tuckasegee Falls
description: W Jackson County on West Fork Tuckasegee River. The construction of Lake Thorpe stopped the flow of water, and the falls are no longer noticeable. Formerly the water plunged 60 ft. and then split into two 25 ft. cataracts. Also known as High Falls of the Tuckasegee.

label: Tuckasegee Lake
description: in central Jackson County on West Fork Tuckasegee River. Formed in 1950; covers 2 acres and has max. depth of 90 ft. Used for fishing, boating, and as a power source. Open to the public.

label: Tuckasegee River
description: is formed in SE Jackson County by the junction of Panthertown and Greenland Creeks and flows NW through central Jackson County and into Swain County, where it enters Little Tennessee River. Named for the Cherokee Indian town Tsiksitsi, which stood beside the river; the word means "crawling terrapin," referring to the sluggish movement of the water.

label: Tucker Creek
description: rises near Brevard in central Transylvania County and flows SE into Nicholson Creek.

label: Tucker Creek
description: rises in W Transylvania County and flows SE into North Fork French Broad River.

label: Tucker Gap
description: central Graham County between Mountain Creek and Sweetwater Creek.

label: Tucker Hollow
description: mountain valley in N central Avery County.

label: Tucker Island
description: a silty clay and loam island in Roanoke River, NW Northampton County. Formerly approx. 2 mi. long, but now largely covered by the waters of Roanoke Rapids Lake. Appears as Pughs Island on the Price map, 1808, and as a part of Hamlins Shoals on the MacRae map, 1833.

label: Tucker's Barn
description: See Lenoir.

label: Tuckerdale
description: community in NW Ashe County.

label: Tuckertown
description: former community in NW Montgomery County. Served by post office, 1910-30. Site now covered by waters of Tuckertown Lake, a reservoir for Carolina Aluminum Company completed in 1962. Originally named Milledgeville; renamed about 1900 for an official of a northern firm that operated a rope-manufacturing plant there. The mill was abandoned and houses were moved from the site when construction of the dam for the lake began.

label: Tuckertown Lake
description: on Yadkin River in Davidson, Montgomery, Rowan, and Stanly Counties. Covers 3,000 acres, with a shoreline of 40 mi. Max. depth 50 ft. Named for a former community in Montgomery County whose site it now covers. Completed in 1962 by Carolina Aluminum Company; used as a reservoir, to generate hydroelectric power, and for recreation.

label: Tugman Mountain
description: W Wilkes County between Stony Fork Creek and Yadkin River.

label: Tugwell
description: See Toddy.

label: Tulin
description: community in NW Cabarrus County.

label: Tulip Jewel
description: community in N Stokes County served by post office, 1888-1905.

label: Tull Bay
description: an inland bay in N Currituck County in the mouth of the Northwest River.

label: Tull Creek
description: rises in E Onslow County and flows E into Bear Creek.

label: Tull Mill Pond
description: on the head of Southwest Creek in SW Lenoir County. Formed approx. 1875. Covers 180 acres; max. depth 14 ft.

label: Tulls Creek
description: community in N Currituck County served by post office, 1826-74.

label: Tully Gap
description: NE Yancey County at the SW end of Buck Ridge.

label: Tulula
description: community in S Graham County on Tulula Creek, which see.

label: Tulula Creek
description: rises in SE Graham County and flows nw, where it joins Sweetwater Creek in forming Cheoah River. Named for the Cherokee word for the cry of the frog, talulu

label: Tumblebug Creek
description: rises in E Henderson County and flows SW into Little Hungry Creek.

label: Tumblerville
description: community in S Macon County S of Bristle Ridge.

label: Tumbling Run
description: rises in NW Nash County and flows NE into Sandy Creek.

label: Tump Island
description: NE Carteret County in West Bay off Tump Point on Cedar Island. A tump is defined as a low hill or mound or as a clump of grass, especially one forming a dry spot in a swamp.

label: Tump Point
description: NE Carteret County on W side of Cedar Island extending into West Bay.

label: Tuneigh Branch
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows SW into Bunches Creek.

label: Tungsten
description: community in NW Vance County near Little Island Creek. Named for the nearby tungsten deposits, reputedly the second largest in the world. Served by post office, 1949-59.

label: Tuni Creek
description: rises in N Clay County and flows E and SW into Tusquitee Creek.

label: Tuni Gap
description: on the Clay-Macon county line E of Bearpen Gap at the head of Little Tuni Creek. Alt. 3,526.

label: Tunis
description: community in E Hertford County served by post office, 1884-1943. Inc. 1909. Charter repealed 1935. Alt. 17.

label: Tunn Ensleas
description: See Plott Balsams.

label: Tunnel Branch
description: rises in W Swain County and flows W into Goldmine Branch.

label: Tunnel Falls
description: SE Haywood County on West Fork of Pigeon River. Water drops approx. 50 ft. Named because a small hole goes into the rock behind the falls, suggesting the entrance to a tunnel.

label: Tunnel Gap
description: SE Haywood County on the head of East Fork Pigeon River.

label: Tunnel Ridge
description: W Swain County, extends SE from Forney Ridge to Tunnel Branch.

label: Turkey
