description: town in E Sampson County served by post office since 1889. Settled about 1847; inc. 1913. Named for Turkey Creek, which flows a short distance N of the town. Alt. 153.

label: Turkey Branch
description: rises in W Scotland County and flows S into Gum Swamp Creek.

label: Turkey Cock Mountain
description: See Hibriten Mountain; Hen Mountain.

label: Turkey Cove
description: NW Swain County between Twentymile Creek and Twentymile Ridge.

label: Turkey Cove Branch
description: rises in W Madison County and flows SE into Spring Creek.

label: Turkey Cove Gap
description: NW Swain County on Twentymile Ridge in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°28'09" N., long. 83°50'07" W.

label: Turkey Creek
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows SW into Fines Creek.

label: Turkey Creek
description: rises in NW Wake County and flows S into Crabtree Creek.

label: Turkey Creek Gap
description: on the Buncombe-Haywood county line N of Big Butt Mountain near the headwaters of South Turkey Creek.

label: Turkey Gap
description: on the Haywood County, N.C.-Cocke County, Tenn., line.

label: Turkey Hen Mountain
description: See Hen Mountain.

label: Turkey Hill Creek
description: rises in W Orange County and flows SE into Cane Creek.

label: Turkey Hole, The
description: a deep slough on the E side of Contentnea Creek, E Greene County. So called from early times, probably from the abundance of wild turkeys in the vicinity.

label: Turkey Knob
description: S Macon County between Board Gap and Wolf Gap.

label: Turkey Mountain
description: SE McDowell County. Alt. approx. 1,900.

label: Turkey Pen
description: community in SW Cherokee County between Wolfe and Hot House Creeks.

label: Turkey Pen Cove
description: W Macon County between Pierce Creek and Nantahala River.

label: Turkey Pen Gap
description: on Forge Mountain in W Henderson County.

label: Turkey Pen Hollow
description: NW Cherokee County, through which an unnamed stream flows SE into Copper Creek.

label: Turkey Point
description: S Onslow County at the mouth of Turkey Creek. Appears in local records as early as 1734.

label: Turkey Quarter Creek
description: NW Craven County, a channel of water separated from the main body of Neuse River by a large swampy island.

label: Turkey Quarters
description: name applied to a portion of what is now Pender County by Barbadian explorers in 1663 because of the many turkeys killed there. Appears on the Ogilby map, 1671, but otherwise no longer used.

label: Turkey Ridge
description: SE Buncombe County between Johnson Cove and Briar Branch.

label: Turkey Swamp
description: See Turkey Creek.

label: Turkey Tail
description: See Glen Alpine.

label: Turkey Township
description: E Sampson County.

label: Turkey-Buzzard River
description: See Hyco River.

label: Turkeyfoot
description: community in W Davie County. Viewed from the air or in aerial photographs, local road intersections resemble a gobbler's appendage.

label: Turkeypen Branch
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows NE into Trout Creek.

label: Turkeypen Ridge
description: E Madison County at the head of West Fork [Bull Creek].

label: Turlington
description: community in E Harnett County. Slocomb Crossroads, formerly recognized as a separate community, is now a part of the Turlington community.

label: Turnagain Bay
description: NE Carteret County emptying into Neuse River. Known as The Bay until about 1775.

label: Turnagain Creek
description: NE Carteret County flows N to empty into Turnagain Bay. Known as The Bay Creek until around 1775. Said to have been named by Joseph Pittman, who ran an Indian out of his sweet potato patch. The Indian fled, swam the creek, and emerged on the opposite shore, where he turned to make an insulting remark to Pittman. Pittman told him to "turn again" and repeat what he had said. The Indian did, and Pittman shot him.

label: Turnage
description: community in S Edgecombe County.

label: Turnbull Creek
description: rises in White Pond Bay in S Cumberland County and flows SE into NE Bladen County, where it enters Cape Fear River in central Bladen County. Named for Thomas Turnbull, an early colonial resident.

label: Turnbull Township
description: in NE Bladen County.

label: Turner Branch
description: rises in W Haywood County and flows NW into Jonathans Creek.

label: Turner Creek
description: rises in S Yadkin County and flows SE into Yadkin River.

label: Turner Crossroads
description: community in S central Northampton County S of Bear Swamp.

label: Turner Mountain
description: central Surry County. Alt. approx. 2,100.

label: Turner Swamp
description: rises in NE Wayne County and flows N into Wilson County, where it enters Black Creek.

label: Turner Top
description: NW Cherokee County between Copper and Sular Creeks.

label: Turner's Crossroads
description: See Lewiston.

label: Turners
description: community in N Polk County between Green River and Walnut Creek.

label: Turners Creek
description: See Nevil Creek.

label: Turners Cut
description: an extension of the Dismal Swamp Canal, W Camden County, from near the canal's former mouth in the Pasquotank River to a point farther downstream, bypassing a very narrow section of the river. The Intra-coastal Waterway passes through Turners Cut.

label: Turners Lake
description: See Lake Adger.

label: Turnersburg
description: community in NE Iredell County on Rocky Creek. Settled 1849 and named for Wilford Turner, local landowner. A nineteenth-century textile mill on Rocky Creek there was the first in the county; it was burned before 1900, but it was rebuilt and is still in operation. Alt. 791.

label: Turnersburg Township
description: NE Iredell County.

label: Turnout
description: community in W Robeson County.

label: Turnpike
description: community in SW Buncombe County near the Haywood County line. Named for the fact that it was the site of the first tollgate W of Asheville on the old turnpike between Asheville and Murphy. In the early 1860s, a tavern for the accommodation of stagecoach passengers was opened there by John C. Smathers; with the coming of the railroad in 1882, Smathers enlarged his building, serving meals to railway passengers and taking in summer tourists. A post office operated there, 1858-1908.

label: Turnpike Branch
description: rises in E Hertford County and flows SE into Hoggard Swamp.

label: Turnpike Creek
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows SW into West Fork Pigeon River.

label: Turpentine Creek
description: rises in SE Onslow County and flows SE through tidal marsh into the Atlantic Ocean through Browns Inlet.

label: Turtle Pond Creek
description: rises in S Macon County and flows N into Cullasaja River.

label: Turtletown
description: community in W Cherokee County on the Tennessee line near Copperhill, Tenn. Served by post office, 1847-1912.

label: Tuscarora
description: community in W Craven County. Settled 1825. Named for the Indians who formerly lived in the area. Alt. 39.

label: Tuscarora Beach
description: summer resort in E Hertford County near the town of Winton on Chowan River. Originally a Tuscarora Indian village; settled about 1710 by John Cotton of Virginia and known as Cotton's Crossing as late as 1759, when it was authorized to be laid out as the county seat. Later known as Old Barfields and Barfields.

label: Tuscola
description: See Lake Junaluska.

label: Tusk Creek
description: a tidal creek about 1 mi. N of Marshallberg in the waters of Core Sound, E Carteret County. Formerly known also as Wolfert Creek.

label: Tuskee Gap
description: N Swain County on Thomas Ridge in Great Smoky Mountains National Park near lat. 35°33'32" N., long. 83°22'25" W.

label: Tuskeegee
description: community in N Graham County on Tuskeegee Creek.

label: Tuskeegee Creek
description: rises in N Graham County and flows NE into Little Tennessee River.

label: Tusquitee
description: community in central Clay County on Johnson Mill Creek. Served by post office, 1861-1907. Alt. 2,050.

label: Tusquitee Bald
description: N Clay County near the head-waters of Compass Creek. Alt. 5,200-5,250.

label: Tusquitee Creek
description: rises in NE Clay County and flows SW into Hiwassee River.

label: Tusquitee Gap
description: N Clay County near the headwaters of Clear Creek. Alt. approx. 3,800.

label: Tusquitee Mountains
description: NW Clay County extending NE from Leatherwood Branch to the Clay-Macon county line. Named for the Cherokee word Tusquittee or Tusquitta (rafters) because the spurs of the range suggest the rafters of a roof.

label: Tusquitee Township
description: N Clay County.

label: Tussock Bay
description: in E Bladen County.

label: Tuton
description: See St. Pauls.

label: Tuttles
description: community in SE Stokes County served by post office, 1898-1904.

label: Tuttles Cross Roads
description: See Hartland.

label: Tuttles Store
description: community in W Alexander County. Alt. approx. 1,100. A former post office, Partee, served the community, 1887-1906.

label: Tuxedo
description: community in S Henderson County on Lake Summit. Alt. 2,187. Post office est. 1908 as Lakewood, but name later changed in 1910 to avoid confusion with another Lakewood in North Carolina. Tuxedo chosen simply because it was considered euphonious.

label: Tweed Branch
description: rises in SE Cherokee County and flows SE into Little Brasstown Creek.

label: Tweed Creek
description: rises in S Buncombe County and flows S into Cane Creek.

label: Twelve O'Clock Top
description: knob on the Buncombe-Haywood county line between the head of Dutch Cove Creek and Rocky Face Mountain. Alt. approx. 4,640.

label: Twelvemile Creek
description: is formed in W Union County by the confluence of East Fork Twelvemile Creek and West Fork Twelvemile Creek and flows SW into Catawba River in South Carolina.

label: Twentymile Creek
description: rises in NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows SW into Little Tennessee River. Named because it is 20 mi. from the junction of Tuckasegee and Little Tennessee Rivers.

label: Twentymile Ridge
description: NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Its center is near lat. 35°28'50" N., long. 83°50'15" W.

label: Twin Falls
description: in S Jackson County on Long Branch mi. N of Fairfield Lake. Alt. approx. 3,420.

label: Twin Knobs
description: N Wilkes County between East Prong Roaring River and Little Sandy Creek.

label: Twin Oaks
description: community in N central Alleghany County. Alt. 2,624.

label: Twin Poplars
description: mound and trees 4 mi. N of Lenoir, central Caldwell County. According to local tradition, the Cherokee and Catawba Indians fought there for almost a week, until they became exhausted. They then made a pact declaring that thereafter, the two tribes would live in peace. As a token, they constructed a mound of rocks and tied two young poplar trees together. The trees, now giants of the forest, stand approx. 12 ft. apart at the base, and approx. 20 ft. above the ground they join to form a single tree.

label: Twin Springs
description: springs near Cedar Knob in SE Buncombe County; the source of a small unnamed stream that flows NW into Grassy Creek.

label: Twitty
description: community in W Rutherford County served by post office, 1884-1907.

label: Twomile Creek
description: rises in SW Guilford County and flows E into Deep River. Appears as Third Creek on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Twomile Swamp
description: rises in W Sampson County and flows SE into Caesar Swamp.

label: Tyancoka Creek
description: See Cokey Swamp.

label: Tyler Branch
description: rises in W Macon County and flows SW into Nantahala River.

label: Tynch Town
description: See Harris Landing.

label: Tyndall Point
description: SE Beaufort County, extends into Goose Creek.

label: Tyner
description: See Centre Hill.

label: Tyre Knob
description: on the Graham-Swain county line between Grassy Gap and Broke Yoke Gap. Named for the biblical city on the Mediterranean Sea that was famous throughout the classical world for its costly, royal purple. Called Tyre Top on some maps.

label: Tyre Top
description: See Tyre Knob.

label: Tyro Shops
description: community in W Davidson County served by post office, 1883-1903.

label: Tyro Township
description: W central Davidson County.

label: Tyrrell County (TIR-ehl)
description: was formed in 1729 from Chowan, Bertie, Currituck, and Pasquotank Counties. Located in the E section of the state, it is bounded by the Albemarle Sound and by Dare, Hyde, and Washington Counties. It was named for Sir John Tyrrell (1685-1729), one of the Lords Proprietors of North Carolina. Area: 583 sq. mi. County seat: Columbia, with an elevation of 10 ft. Townships are Alligator, Columbia, Gum Neck, Scuppernong, and South Fork. Produces soybeans, corn, peanuts, hogs, seafood, Irish potatoes, tools, wheat, livestock, and lumber.

label: Tyson Creek
description: rises in W Pitt County and flows NE into Tar River.

label: Tyson Marsh
description: stream, rises in S Greene County and flows NE into Contentnea Creek.

label: Tyson Township
description: S central Stanly County.

label: Tyson's Mill
description: See Jefferson.

label: Tysonville
description: community in central Wake County named for Tyson's Chapel and long known by that name.

label: U-Alta Lake
description: W Randolph County, is formed by a dam on Caraway Creek. Covers 20-25 acres. Named for Eula Alta Farlow, wife of Arthur Farlow, who developed the lake.

label: Ucohnerunt
description: a Tuscarora Indian town shown on the Moseley map, 1733, as situated on the mouth of Town Creek in what is now central Edgecombe County. Also called King Blount's Town for the chief under whom the Tuscarora Indians began their removal to the Roanoke River in 1732.

label: Ugly Creek
description: rises in S Stanly County and flows SE into Hardy Creek.

label: Ugly Fork
description: rises in W Haywood County near the Swain County line on the N side of Big Fork Ridge and flows E and NE into Rough Fork.

label: Ulah
description: community in S Randolph County served by post office, 1889-1953. Originally Uhla; probably named for the daughter of M. R. Moffitt, first postmaster.

label: Umbra
description: community in NE Durham County served by post office, 1891-1903.

label: Umstead Bridge
description: See Redstone Point; Weir Point.

label: Umstead State Park
description: See William B. Umstead State Park.

label: Una Creek
description: rises in SE Swain County and flows W into Yalaka Creek.

label: Una Gap
description: SE Swain County on Una Mountain near the head of Mason Branch.

label: Una Mountain
description: SE Swain County on the head of Una Creek.

label: Unahala
description: community in S Swain County on Yalaka Creek and Una Creek.

label: Unaka
description: community in NW Cherokee County near the junction of Copper and Beaverdam Creeks.

label: Unaka Mountain
description: on the Mitchell County, N.C.-Unicoi County, Tenn., line. Alt. approx. 5,190. See also Unicoi Mountains.

label: Unaka Mountains
description: in Avery and Mitchell Counties, N.C., and Unicoi and Carter Counties, Tenn., form the common boundary line between the two states from the Nolichucky River to the Doe River (in Tennessee). Of 40 miscellaneous maps dating from 1795 to 1930, 22 called the ridge, in whole or in part, Iron Mountains; others divide between Iron and Yellow Mountains; and 5 call them Unaka Mountains the entire distance. Unaka is a corruption of Unega, meaning "white"; it is used in the 1789 act passed by the General Assembly of North Carolina that ceded what is now the state of Tennessee to the U.S. government.

label: Uncas
description: community in E Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1893-1903.

label: Under Hills
description: See Piedmont.

label: Underwood Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SE into Webb Creek.

label: Underwood Mountain
description: W Henderson County, extends E in an arc between Little Willow Creek and South Fork. Alt. approx. 3,250.

label: Unicoi Gap
description: on the Cherokee County, N.C.-Monroe County, Tenn., line in the Unicoi Mountains.

label: Unicoi Mountains
description: in Cherokee and Graham Counties, N.C., and Monroe and Polk Counties, Tenn., form in part the common boundary line of the two states between the Little Tennessee River and Hiwassee River. The name is one of those in common use; it was suggested by Horace Kephart and approved by the nomenclature committees of the Great Smoky Mountains Park Commissions of North Carolina and Tennessee. The name—which, like Unaka, is a corruption of Unega, meaning "white"—was used in the 1789 act passed by the General Assembly of North Carolina that ceded what is now the state of Tennessee to the U.S. government: "where it is called Unicoy or Unaka Mountain between the Indian towns of Cowee and Old Chota."

label: Union
description: community in S Macon County on Dowdle Branch.

label: Union City
description: See Fairmont.

label: Union Copper Mine
description: former mine in NE Cabarrus County, operated extensively from the early 1900s until 1914. Further explorations made in 1960, but mine not reopened for work.

label: Union County
description: was formed in 1842 from Anson and Mecklenburg Counties. Located in the S central section of the state, it is bounded by the state of South Carolina and by Mecklenburg, Cabarrus, Stanly, and Anson Counties. At the time the county was formed, there was a dispute between local Whigs and Democrats as to whether it should be named Clay or Jackson. The name Union was suggested and adopted as a compromise and because the new county was created from parts of two others. Area: 643 sq. mi. County seat: Monroe, with an elevation of 576 ft. Townships are Buford, Goose Creek, Jackson, Lanes Creek, Marshville, Monroe, New Salem, Sandy Ridge, and Vance. Produces oats, wheat, corn, cotton, lespedeza, poultry, turkeys, hogs, dairy products, livestock, textiles, apparel, bricks, pipes, processed meat, industrial machinery, wood products, asbestos, and crushed stone.

label: Union Cross
description: community in central Yadkin County. Named for Union Cross Friends Meeting, organized in 1883.

label: Union Factory
description: See Randleman.

label: Union Grove
description: community in N Yadkin County near the head of Fall Creek.

label: Union Grove Township
description: N central Iredell County.

label: Union Hill
description: community in NE Yadkin County.

label: Union Hope
description: community in SW Nash County.

label: Union Mills
description: community in N Rutherford County. Est. 1892. Inc. 1907; charter repealed 1924. Named for the consolidation of several small sawmills in the period 1885-90.

label: Union Ridge
description: community in S Forsyth County; now within the urban extension of the city of Winston-Salem.

label: Union Township
description: W Wilkes County.

label: Unionville
description: town in N Union County at the head of Chinkapin Creek. Inc. 1911; reincorporated 1998.

label: Unity
description: community in NE Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1891-1902.

label: Unity Parish
description: Church of England, Guilford County, est. 1771 with the formation of the county and coextensive with it.

label: Unity Township
description: N Rowan County. Named for local Presbyterian church.

label: University
description: community in E Orange County on Southern Railway approx. 9 mi. N of Chapel Hill; a former rail station serving the University of North Carolina. Railroad name for the station is Glenn. Alt. 471.

label: University Lake
description: on Morgan Creek in S Orange County. Formed 1932 as a municipal water supply for Chapel Hill-Carrboro. Covers 219 acres; max. depth 30 ft.

label: Uno
description: community in central Henderson County on Clear Creek.

label: Upchurch
description: community in W Wake County. Named for William B. Upchurch, around whose farm the community grew after a railway station was built there. Upchurch is said to have built first flue-cure tobacco barn in Wake County.

label: Upchurch Pond
description: on Rockfish Creek, E Hoke and W Cumberland Counties. Approx. 5 mi. long.

label: Upland
description: community in SW Chatham County.

label: Upper Bartons Creek
description: rises in NW Wake County NW of community of Leesville and flows NE into Neuse River W of mouth of Lower Bartons Creek. Formerly called Great Elliby and Little Elliby.

label: Upper Beaverdam Creek
description: rises in W Scotland County and flows SE into Richmond Millpond (Gum Swamp Creek).

label: Upper Broad Creek
description: rises in NE Craven County on the Craven-Pamlico county line and flows SW along the line into Neuse River. Appears as Broad Creek on the Moseley map, 1733; mentioned in local records as early as 1723. Sometimes referred to in eighteenth century local records as Ashes Creek.

label: Upper Campbellton
description: See Fayetteville.

label: Upper Conetoe Township
description: former township in E Edgecombe County, now township no. 3.

label: Upper Creek
description: is formed in S Yancey County by the junction of Middle Fork Upper Creek and South Fork Upper Creek. It flows NE into South Toe River.

label: Upper Creek Township
description: N Burke County.

label: Upper Dowry Creek
description: rises in E Beaufort County and flows approx. 1½ mi. S into Pungo River.

label: Upper Falls
description: in SW Transylvania County in Laurel Creek. Height of the falls is 40 ft.

label: Upper Falls
description: SE Yancey County near the head of Crabtree Creek. Water falls approx. 75 ft.

label: Upper Fishing Creek Township
description: former township in N Edgecombe County, now township no. 6.

label: Upper Flat Creek
description: See Flat Creek.

label: Upper Flats
description: area of stony loam in NW Swain County on Greer Branch covering approx. 1.45 sq. mi.; level except the E end, which is hilly from N to S.

label: Upper Fork Township
description: SW Burke County.

label: Upper Goose Creek
description: rises in central Beaufort County and flows S into Pamlico River.

label: Upper Haw Knob
description: on the Madison-Yancey county line in the Walnut Mountains.

label: Upper Hominy Township
description: SW Buncombe County.

label: Upper Laurel Township
description: former township in NE Madison County, now township no. 11.

label: Upper Little River
description: is formed in SE Caldwell County by a number of small streams. It flows SE, forming a part of the Alexander-Caldwell county line before flowing into Catawba River. Formerly known as Clarks Little River.

label: Upper Little River
description: rises in S Lee County and flows SE into Harnett County, where it enters Cape Fear River. Scottish Highlanders settled the fertile lands along its banks during the period 1740-60. Appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Upper Little River Township
description: NW Harnett County.

label: Upper Long Creek
description: rises in SE Swain County and flows SW into Yalaka Creek.

label: Upper Pigeonroost
description: community on Right Fork [Pigeonroost Creek] in W Mitchell County.

label: Upper Poplar
description: community on Hollow Poplar Creek in NW Mitchell County.

label: Upper Richlands
description: See Richlands.

label: Upper Sassafras Gap
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Noland Divide near lat. 35°31'56" N., long. 83°27'15" W.

label: Upper Saura Town
description: former Indian village in Stokes County on Dan River. Site approx. 4 mi. E of Madison. Probably occupied by Saura Indians by the middle of the seventeenth century and abandoned in the early eighteenth century. Saura or Sara meant "a place of tall grass or weeds." The site, occupied by descendants of Europeans, was still known as Sauratown as late as 1894. Appears on the Collet map, 1770, as Upper Sawra and on the Price map, 1808, as Saurat, but it does not appear on later maps.

label: Upper Spring Creek
description: rises in NW Goose Creek Island, NW Pamlico County, and flows N to join Campbell Creek at the Beaufort-Pamlico county line to form Goose Creek.

label: Upper Town Creek Township
description: former township in W Edgecombe County, now township no. 11.

label: Upper Township
description: former township in N Chowan County, now township no. 3.

label: Upper Trail Ridge
description: SW Macon County between Nichols Branch and Big Shoal Branch.

label: Upton
description: community in NW Caldwell County. Alt. 1,420.

label: Upward
description: community in E Henderson County served by post office, 1877-1905. First called Crossroads, being at junction of Ridge Road and Howard Gap Road. Took present name from a local estate of a South Carolina summer resident.

label: Urahaw Swamp
description: rises in S Northampton County and flows NE into Potecasi Creek. The name appears in local records as early as 1719.

label: Uree
description: community in NW Rutherford County on Broad River.

label: Utah Mountain
description: central Haywood County between Snakeden Top and Fulbright Cove. Named for the fact that a band of Mormons lived there in the 1880s and 1890s. Their practice of polygamy made them unpopular with their neighbors, and the Mormons were forced to leave North Carolina. Their houses, barns, fences, and other property were abandoned, and the ruins still exist. Orchards and vineyards, as well as ornamental flowering shrubs, are now growing wild in the vicinity.

label: Utley's Creek
description: rises in S Wake County near Holly Springs and flows SW into Big White Oak Creek.

label: Uwharrie (u-whar-ee)
description: community in NW Montgomery County served by post office, 1876-1914.

label: Uwharrie Mountains
description: extend NE-SW across Montgomery, Randolph, and Stanly Counties. The Yadkin River flows through the SW end. Geologists describe the mountains as isolated, residual knobs that have resisted erosion and weathering better than the surrounding countryside. Probably formed several hundred million years ago by a number of explosive-type volcanoes. John Lawson visited the area in 1701 and used the name Heighwaree. Morrow Mountain State Park and Town Creek Indian Mound Historic Site are there. There are many named peaks, particularly in Montgomery and Randolph Counties. Alts. are not over 1,800 ft.

label: Uwharrie National Forest
description: largely in W Montgomery County but also in SW Randolph, SE Davidson, and NW Stanly Counties. Covers 204,682 acres, with headquarters in Troy. Originally laid out as a purchase unit in 1934 and made a National Forest in 1961.

label: Uwharrie River
description: rises in NW Randolph County, flows S into Montgomery County, then flows SW to join the Yadkin River in forming the Pee Dee River. The source of the Uwharrie River is approx. 840 ft. above sea level, and the elevation at the junction of the Uwharrie and Yadkin Rivers is approx. 280 ft. Appears as Uharie River on the Moseley map, 1733, but is incorrectly placed and out of proportion. The Collet map, 1770, makes the necessary corrections but calls it Voharee Creek.

label: Uwharrie Township
description: W Montgomery County.

label: Vade Mecum
description: former resort and present Episcopal Church summer camp at the junction of Vade Mecum Creek and South Double Creek in W Stokes County. Alt. 1,800. Local mineral springs accredited with curative powers by Saura Indians; about 1860 the site was acquired by Sparks family, circus operators, who built a resort hotel. It was later acquired by the Episcopal Church. Name from Latin phrase meaning "go with me," attributed to an Indian legend involving a planned elopement.

label: Vade Mecum Creek
description: rises in W Stokes County and flows NE into South Double Creek.

label: Val Dor
description: former rural post office, 1904-1905, located in a country store on the headwaters of Silver Creek in SW Burke County. Probably named for a gold mine on the Hodge plantation approx. 1 mi. away.

label: Valda
description: See Val Dor.

label: Valdese
description: town in E central Burke County. Alt. 1,203. Settled in 1893 by a group of Waldensians from N Italy. Inc. 1920. Name is Italian for "Valley of Our Lord." Produces hosiery, textiles, furniture, and bakery products.

label: Vale
description: community in NW Lincoln County. Noted for the apple orchards in the vicinity. Post office est. in 1924.

label: Valhalla
description: community in SW Polk County served by post office, 1923-50. Settled about 1885. Named for the Norse mythological Hall of Odin, where the souls of heroes slain in battle were received; the name is said to have been applied in commemoration of the battle at Round Mountain, which see, in 1776.

label: Valhalla Dome
description: peak on the NE end of Rich Mountain, W Mitchell County. Alt. over 4,060 ft.

label: Valle Crucis
description: community in central Watauga County near the junction of Dutch Creek and Watauga River. Est. in 1842 as an Episcopal mission. The name, Latin for "Valley of the Cross," was adopted because of the shape of the Watauga River valley there. The valley has an area of approx. 600 acres. Alt. 3,000.

label: Valley
description: community on Roaring Creek in W Avery County. Also called Roaring Creek.

label: Valley Creek
description: rises in SW Watauga County and flows E in an arc into Watauga River.

label: Valley River
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SW into Hiwassee River at Murphy.

label: Valley River Mountains
description: extend along the Cherokee-Clay county line to Macon County.

label: Valley Springs
description: community in S Buncombe County.

label: Valley Squirrel Gap
description: NE Cherokee County between Andrews and Rhodo.

label: Valley Town
description: community in NE Cherokee County on the outskirts of Andrews, which see. A post office operated there, 1846-91.

label: Valley Town Township
description: sNE Cherokee County.

label: Valmead
description: community in central Caldwell County. A large part of the community was annexed to the city of Lenoir prior to 1960. Named for its location in a valley meadow. Alt. 1,131.

label: Van Eeden
description: community in N Pender County. Est. on land purchased in 1909 by Frederik van Eeden (1860-1932) and Hugh MacRae for a colony of Dutch farmers. In 1939 the remaining land was purchased by a New York corporation as a refuge for Jews fleeing Germany. The last Dutch family left in 1949.

label: Van Noy Branch
description: rises in NE McDowell County and flows E into Long Branch.

label: Van Swamp
description: extends NE from N Beaufort County into SW Washington County. Area. approx. 12,000 acres.

label: Vance County
description: was formed in 1881 from Granville, Warren, and Franklin Counties. Located in the NE section of the state, it is bounded by the state of Virginia and by Warren, Franklin, and Granville Counties. It was named for Zebulon Baird Vance (1830-94), governor of North Carolina, congressman, and senator. Area. 268 sq. mi. County seat: Henderson, with an elevation of 513 ft. Townships are Dabney, Henderson, Kittrell, Middleburg, Nutbush, Sandy Creek, Townsville, Watkins, and Williamsboro. Produces tobacco, corn, wheat, oats, cotton, poultry, hogs, dairy products, livestock, cantaloupes, peanuts, soybeans, mobile homes, textiles, hosiery, glass products, pickles, tungsten, crushed stone, and sand.

label: Vance Knob
description: N Buncombe County between Ray Knob and the junction of Ox and Reems Creeks.

label: Vance Mountain
description: on the Henderson County, N.C.-Greenville County, S.C., line. Named for Governor Zebulon B. Vance (1830-94). The scene of the 1829 duel between Robert Brank Vance and Samuel Price Carson.

label: Vance Township
description: W Union County.

label: Vanceboro
description: town in N Craven County on Swift Creek. Settled about 1750 and known as Durgantown. Name changed by 1850 to Swift Creek. Inc. 1877 as Vanceboro in honor of Governor Zebulon B. Vance (1830-94) after he made a campaign speech there in 1876 while running for second term as governor. Alt. 24.

label: Vandalia
description: former community in S Guilford County; now within the Greensboro city limits.

label: Vandemere
description: town in N Pamlico County on Bay River. A Dr. Abbott, former Union army surgeon, settled there in the 1870s, and his wife gave the community its name—a Dutch word meaning "from the sea." Inc. 1874; charter repealed 1893 but renewed two years later. From the formation of Pamlico County in 1872 until 1876, Vandemere served as the county seat. Alt. 4.

label: Vandemere Creek
description: rises in N Pamlico County and flows SE into Bay River.

label: Vander
description: community in central Cumberland County. Alt. 151.

label: Vanderpool Creek
description: rises in central Watauga County and flows NW into Cove Creek.

label: Vann
description: community in W Union County served by post office, 1892-1903.

label: Vannoy
description: community in NW Wilkes County on North Fork Reddies River.

label: Vanteen
description: community in N central Wake County served by post office, 1891-1904.

label: Varina
description: former town in SW Wake County. Settled about 1890 and named for first postmaster's wife, who used the fanciful name, Varina, in her courtship correspondence. Alt. 426. Merged with Fuquay Springs to become part of Fuquay-Varina, which see, in 1963.

label: Varnals Creek
description: rises in the Cane Creek Mountains, S Alamance County, and flows NE into Haw River.

label: Varnum
description: community in S central Brunswick County on Lockwoods Folly River.

label: Vashti
description: community in NE Alexander County. Known as Cedar Run in the 1880s, when Cedar Academy operated there. Alt. approx. 1,240.

label: Vass
description: town in E Moore County. Known as Winder, for an official of the Raleigh and Augusta Air Line Railroad, prior to 1907, when it was inc. with its present name. Named for William Worrell Vass (1820-96), treasurer of the Raleigh and Gaston Railroad, 1845-90. Alt. 320.

label: Vaughan
description: town in E central Warren County. Alt. 353. Founded in 1851 as Brown's Siding or Brown's Turnout by Dr. Ridley Browne. Name changed to Vaughn in 1881 in honor of John F. Vaughn, local merchant and first postmaster. Inc. 1893.

label: Vaughan Creek
description: rises in South Carolina and flows N into Polk County, where it enters Lake Lanier.

label: Vaughan Hill
description: an elevation on the Fort Bragg Military Reservation, NW Cumberland County.

label: Vaughan's Springs
description: SE Surry County, mineral springs resort developed by the Gid Y. Vaughan family in the early twentieth century; in recent years, the site of Camp Wilson, a private summer camp for boys.

label: Vaught Gap
description: W Watauga County in Stone Mountains near the head of Beaverdam Creek.

label: Veecaune Creek
description: See Wiccacon River.

label: Vein Mountain
description: community in S McDowell County. Named for the fact that it lies in a former gold-mining area.

label: Velna
description: community in SE Randolph County served by post office, 1888-1916.

label: Venable
description: See Carrboro.

label: Vengeance Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NW into Valley River.

label: Veni
description: community in SW Halifax County served by post office, 1889-1907.

label: Venters
description: community in S Pitt County.

label: Venus
description: community in SE Ashe County served by post office, 1889-1905.

label: Vera Cruz Shoal
description: NE Carteret County, partly obstructs Ocracoke Inlet. Known during the eighteenth century as Dry Sand Shoal for the fact that it was never covered by water except during a hurricane.

label: Verd
description: community in SW Madison County.

label: Vernon
description: community in N Ashe County served by post office, 1892-1907.

label: Verona
description: community in central Onslow County. Named as a means of honoring Vera McIntyre, whose husband was one of the builders of the Wilmington and Onslow Railroad. A post office, Aman's Store, was est. in 1854. With the construction of the railroad and the establishment of Verona, the post office was moved there in 1894 and the name was changed. Alt. 49.

label: Vests
description: community in W Cherokee County SW of Hiwassee Lake. Named for first postmaster, George Vest.

label: Veto
description: community in NW Wake County served by post office, 1893-1900.

label: Viands
description: community in central Wilkes County S of the junction of Middle and North Prongs Roaring River. The name means "food" or "provisions."

label: Vicksboro
description: community in E Vance and W Warren Counties. Known prior to 1885, and until after 1913, as Coleys Crossroads.

label: Victoria
description: former town in central Buncombe County. Inc. 1887; became a part of Asheville, 1905.

label: Vienna
description: town in W Forsyth County; inc. 1794, but not now active in municipal affairs.

label: Vienna Township
description: W Forsyth County.

label: Vilas
description: community in W central Watauga County on Linville Creek. Served by post office since 1885. Alt. 2,811.

label: Village Creek
description: rises in N Craven County and flows NE into Neuse River.

label: Villanow
description: See White Hill.

label: Vincent
description: community in N Alamance County served by post office, 1889-96.

label: Vine Swamp
description: rises in E Lenoir County and flows E into Jones County, where it enters Beaver Creek. Named prior to the Revolution for the Vine family, which settled nearby.

label: Vinegar Hill
description: community in SE Beaufort County.

label: Vineland
description: See Southern Pines; Whiteville.

label: Vineyard Creek
description: rises in E Clay County and flows S into Shooting Creek.

label: Vineyard Mountain
description: W Randolph County just W of Caraway Mountain in a close group with Black Jack, Slick Rock, and Prickly Pear Mountains.

label: Vinson Store
description: former community in E Wayne County near West Bear Creek.

label: Viola
description: community in S Pender County served by post office, 1882-1901.

label: Violet
description: community in W Cherokee County on Sular Creek between Swansee and Morrow Gaps. Served by post office, 1909-33.

label: Virgil
description: community in E Watauga County.

label: Virgilina
description: town in NW Granville County on the Virginia-North Carolina border, hence its name. Inc. 1899 in North Carolina and 1900 in Virginia.

label: Virgin's Inlet
description: apparently a short-lived inlet in SE Onslow County from Brown's Sound into the Atlantic Ocean. It was described in records of 1784-85 as being near Gillets Creek.

label: Virginia
description: the name applied to the American territory granted by Queen Elizabeth to Walter Raleigh and explored in 1584 by Philip Amadas and Arthur Barlowe. The earliest evidence of the use of the name occurs before March 25, 1585, in Raleigh's seal as Lord and Governor of Virginia, which is now in the British Museum. The name honored Elizabeth, the "Virgin Queen," and was applied in the sixteenth century to the area explored from bases on Roanoke Island. In the seventeenth century, it came to be applied to the permanent settlement around Jamestown, and, after the granting of the Carolina Charter in 1663, it no longer was applied correctly to the territory that was soon to become North Carolina. See also South Virginia.

label: Virginia Creek
description: rises in SE Pender County and flows SE into Topsail Sound.

label: Vista
description: community in S Pender County on Virginia Creek. Served by post office, 1893-1913.

label: Vivian
description: community in S Gates County on Bennett Creek.

label: Vixen
description: community in central Yancey County. Served by post office, 1915-54. Alt. 2,278.

label: Voharee Creek
description: See Uwharrie River.

label: Volga
description: community in N Buncombe County on French Broad River. Served by post office, 1902-13. Alt. 1,721.

label: Voline
description: community in central Robeson County served by post office, 1893-1905.

label: Vosses Creek
description: See Mill Creek.

label: Vox
description: community in N Alleghany County served by post office, 1900-1932.

label: Vultare
description: community in NW Northampton County served by post office, 1894-1928.

label: W. Kerr Scott Reservoir
description: SW Wilkes County on Yadkin River. Formed by a dam completed in 1962. Covers 1,470 acres, with a shoreline of 55 mi. Alt. 1,030. Named for William Kerr Scott (1896-1958), governor of North Carolina and U.S. senator. Constructed for flood control and public recreation.

label: Waccamaw River
description: rises in Lake Waccamaw, NE Columbus County, and flows S and SW in part along the Brunswick-Columbus county line into South Carolina, where it enters Winyah Bay. Appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Waccamaw Township
description: W Brunswick County.

label: Waccamaw Township
description: N Columbus County.

label: Wach
description: See Wachovia; Salem Creek.

label: Wachovia
description: a tract of land laid off by the General Assembly in 1755 in NE Rowan County (now Forsyth) as an area for settlement by Moravians. The Parish of Dobbs was est. at the same time, coextensive with Wachovia. Wachovia, or Wachau-the-Aue (meadow land) along the Wach or Wack (principal stream), received its name from the fact that its water course and meadow land bore some resemblance to a valley in Austria of the same name that formerly belonged to the Zinzendorf family, prominent Moravian leaders. The parish was named Dobbs in honor of Governor Arthur Dobbs. See also Dobbs Parish.

label: Wack
description: See Wachovia; Salem Creek.

label: Waco
description: town in E Cleveland County. Alt. 916. Settled 1857. Inc. 1887. Named by George W. Hendrick for Waco, Tex.

label: Waddells
description: community in central Rockingham County served by post office, 1876-1903. Known as Langdon after 1890.

label: Wade
description: town in NE Cumberland County. Settled about 1886. Inc. 1889; reincorporated 1913, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Named for N. G. Wade, who donated the railroad right-of-way. Alt. 141.

label: Wade Creek
description: rises in E Carteret County and flows S approx. 1 mi. into Jarrett Bay. Formerly also known as Willis Creek.

label: Wade Gap
description: in Newfound Mountain on Buncombe-Haywood county line near the headwaters of Sandy Mush Creek.

label: Wade Point
description: extends from S Pasquotank County into Albemarle Sound. Appears as Wades Point on the Moseley map, 1733. It lies between Big Flatty Creek and the Pasquotank River.

label: Wade's Shore
description: a bay on the N side of Shackle ford Banks, S Carteret County. A former whaling settlement by the same name existed there.

label: Wades Point
description: point of land in E Beaufort County on the N side of Pamlico River at the W side of the mouth of Pungo River, lat. 35°23'18" N., long. 76°34'35" W. See also Moores Beach. Appears as Battis Point on the Comberford map, 1657.

label: Wadesboro
description: town and county seat, central Anson County. Authorized to be est. 1783 as county seat. Called New Town until 1787, when it was changed to Wadesboro to honor Col. Thomas Wade, Revolutionary War patriot and brother-in-law of Patrick Boggan, pioneer settler. Alt. 423. Scientists from all over the United States and Europe gathered there in 1900 to view a total eclipse of the sun. Produces hosiery, textiles, wooden boxes, bricks, hoists, medical supplies, and food products.

label: Wadesboro City Pond
description: S central Anson County on Jones Creek. Formed 1938. Covers 75 acres, with a max. depth of 25 ft. Municipal water supply, fishing, and boating.

label: Wadesboro Township
description: central Anson County.

label: Wadeville
description: community in S Montgomery County. Est. 1872 and named for Wade brothers, who operated a store there in which the first post office was est. in 1878. Post office closed 1955. Alt. 558.

label: Wading Branch Ridge
description: N Haywood County parallel to Dicks Branch.

label: Wading Place Creek
description: rises in E central Bertie County and flows S into Cashie River.

label: Wads Creek
description: rises in central Moore County and flows SE into Little River. Named for William Wadsworth, who settled on its banks in 1756.

label: Wagner Branch
description: rises in central Buncombe County near Beard Mountain and flows NW into Reems Creek.

label: Wagon Road Gap
description: in NW Transylvania County between Poplar Lick Gap and Sandy Gap N of Pine Mountain.

label: Wagon Road Ridge
description: extends SE in N Transylvania County from Pisgah Ridge on the Haywood-Transylvania county line to the confluence of the forks of Bearwallow Brook.

label: Wagon Timber Branch
description: rises in central Cherokee County and flows SE into Colvard Creek.

label: Wagoner
description: community in W Yadkin County near South Deep Creek.

label: Wagram
description: town in E Scotland County. Known first as Montpelier, then (around 1900) as Fontcal. Inc. 1911 as Wagram. Probably named for the Austrian town where a battle was fought in 1809 during the Napoleonic Wars. Alt. 250.

label: Wagstaff Store
description: community in W Person County.

label: Wahoo
description: community in NW Alexander County on Middle Little River.

label: Wahtom Pocosin
description: NW Bertie County.

label: Wahtom Swamp
description: rises in NW Bertie County and flows SE into Cashie River.

label: Wailes
description: community in SW Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1892-1902.

label: Wainwright Island
description: in Core Sound, NE Carteret County; approx. 2/3 mi. long. Probably named for James Winwright or Wainwright.

label: Wake County
description: was formed in 1771 from Johnston, Cumberland, and Orange Counties. Located in the E central section of the state, it is bounded by Johnston, Harnett, Chatham, Durham, Granville, and Franklin Counties. It was named for Margaret Wake (1733-1819), wife of Governor William Tryon. Area: 867 sq. mi. County seat: Raleigh, with an elevation of 363 ft. Raleigh is also the state capital. Townships are Barton Creek, Buckhorn, Cary, Cedar Fork, Holly Springs, House Creek, Leesville, Little River, Marks Creek, Meredith, Middle Creek, Neuse River, New Light, Panther Branch, Raleigh, St. Marys, St. Matthews, Swift Creek, Wake Forest, and White Oak. Produces tobacco, corn, wheat, oats, cotton, poultry, dairy products, hogs, livestock, farm machinery, concrete products, baked goods, textiles, cottonseed oil, apparel, furniture, pharmaceuticals, packaged foods, software, nursery products, strawberries, pumpkins, crushed stone, and fabricated metals.

label: Wake Court House
description: See Raleigh.

label: Wake Forest
description: town in NE Wake County between Hatters Branch and Richland Creek. Settled 1823. Inc. 1880 as "town of Wake Forest College," but referred to after the turn of the century as Wake Forest. Named for large wooded areas of N Wake County. Home of Wake Forest College (1834-1956) until it was moved to Winston-Salem. Home of Southeastern Baptist Theological Seminary since 1951. Produces textiles. Alt. 400.

label: Wake Forest Township
description: NE Wake County.

label: Wake Station
description: community in N Wake County.

label: Wakefield
description: community in E Wake County 1 mi. N of Zebulon. Inc. 1899; charter repealed 1913. Named for its location on a field in Wake County. The failure of local citizens to sell land for a right-of-way resulted in the location of a railroad a short distance s, where the town of Zebulon soon developed. Alt. 338.

label: Wakelon
description: community in NE Bertie County.

label: Wakulla
description: community in NW Robeson County. Alt. 208. Settled about 1860. Named by Col. Peter P. Smith for the Indian word meaning "clear water" because of numerous springs in the vicinity.

label: Walden Creek
description: rises in SE Brunswick County and flows E into Cape Fear River.

label: Waldrop Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows S into Valley River.

label: Walker
description: community in W Polk County on Harm Creek. Served by post office, 1894-1918.

label: Walker Bald
description: W Haywood County SE of Potato Patch. Alt. 5,420. Named for Felix Walker (1753-1828), land speculator and member of Congress, whose cabin dwelling was at its base on upper Jonathan Creek.

label: Walker Branch
description: rises in SW Mecklenburg County and flows SE into Steele Creek.

label: Walker Creek
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows NW into Little River.

label: Walker Creek
description: rises in SW Brunswick County, Va., and flows S into NE Warren County, N.C., where it enters Lake Gaston.

label: Walker Falls
description: waterfalls in NE Buncombe County on Walker Branch.

label: Walker Gap
description: W Swain County between the head of Mill Branch and Rowan Branch.

label: Walker Knob
description: mountain in SW Burke County. Alt. 2,919.

label: Walker Low Gap
description: E Haywood County on Glades Mountain.

label: Walker Mill Creek
description: rises in SW Cherokee County and flows SE into Nottely River.

label: Walker Mountain
description: W Montgomery County between Woodrun Creek and Dennis Mountain.

label: Walker Ridge
description: NE Buncombe County W of Walker Knob.

label: Walker Top
description: on the Buncombe-Haywood county line.

label: Walkers
description: community in E central Pender County on Burgaw Creek. Formerly known as Walkers Store.

label: Walkers Bluff
description: on Cape Fear River in E Bladen County 5 mi. above White Hall Landing.

label: Walkers Branch
description: rises in SW Yadkin County and flows E into North Hunting Creek.

label: Walkers Creek
description: rises in central Warren County and flows SE to join Big Branch in forming Little Fishing Creek.

label: Walkersburg
description: town in SE Brunswick County at Deep Water Point. Est. 1784 on lands of John Walker, for whom it was named. Courthouse and other public buildings were to be est. there but apparently never built.

label: Walkersville
description: community in S central Union County on the E side of Cane Creek. Formerly known as Wilson's Old Store community. Shown on maps as Walkersville as early as 1886.

label: Walkertown
description: community in E Forsyth County. Robert Walker was living there as early as 1771; the community was named for him. Love's Meeting House (Methodist), built there in 1797, was visited by Bishop Francis Asbury in 1799. He was greatly impressed by its glass windows. Alt. 980.

label: Walkeys
description: community in SW Union County.

label: Walks, The
description: series of immovable natural stepping stones below Flat Shoals of Watauga River near the Tennessee line in NW Watauga County. They are regularly placed across the river, and one may walk over them even when the stream is swollen, hence the name.

label: Walkup
description: community in SW Union County served by post office, 1885-1908. Also spelled Wauchope. William R. Davie's assault on Tories took place, 1780, on Wauchope plantation.

label: Walla Watta
description: community in N central Beaufort County, lat. 35°35' N., long. 76°52'15" W. Named by Surry Parker, local lumberman, for Wallace and Waters families, who lived here. Alt. 34.

label: Wallace
description: town in S Duplin County. Post office est. 1866. Alt. 51. Inc. 1873 as Duplin Roads. Name changed to Wallace in honor of Stephen D. Wallace, vice president of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad, prior to 1899, in which year the town was reincorporated. Produces textiles.

label: Wallace Branch
description: rises in SE Union County and flows NE into Little Brown Creek.

label: Wallace Channel
description: NE Carteret County, a navigable lane in Ocracoke Inlet running NW and se. Appears by the name on the Price survey of Ocracoke Inlet, 1795. Named for David Wallace Jr., whose house on Portsmouth Island was used as a sighting point by pilots using the channel entering the Atlantic Ocean. Sometimes referred to as Beacon Island Road in the eighteenth century.

label: Wallace Creek
description: rises in NE Alexander County and flows S in Greasy Creek. Probably named for Richard Wallace, pioneer Baptist minister.

label: Wallace Creek
description: rises in E Onslow County and flows SE into Morgan Bay. Named in local records as early as 1744 as Wallace's Creek.

label: Wallace Gap
description: S Transylvania County between the head of Boring Creek and the head of West Prong [Glady Fork].

label: Wallace Mountain
description: NE Buncombe County near Walkertown.

label: Wallace's Creek
description: See Wallace Creek.

label: Wallburg
description: community in NE Davidson County served by post office, 1891-1946. Named for Sam W. Wall, state senator in 1895. Inc. 2004.

label: Wallnut-Tree Creek
description: See Walnut Creek.

label: Walnut
description: community in central Madison County between Brush Creek and Hopewell Branch. Inc. 1905; charter repealed 1917. Named for walnut trees in the vicinity. See also Marshall.

label: Walnut Bottom
description: in NW Haywood County on Big Creek in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Named for the fact that numerous walnut trees formerly grew in the narrow bottomland there.

label: Walnut Branch
description: rises in W Alleghany County and flows E into Elk Creek.

label: Walnut Cove
description: town in S Stokes County. Settled 1883 and known as Lash until 1889, when it was inc. under its present name. Named for a grove of walnut trees. Alt. 634. Stokesbury, formerly a separate community just S of Walnut Cove, is now within the corporate limits.

label: Walnut Cove Branch
description: rises in W central Transylvania County and flows S into Catheys Creek.

label: Walnut Creek
description: rises in E Wayne County and flows SE then SW into Neuse River.

label: Walnut Creek
description: community in central Madison County on Walnut Creek.

label: Walnut Creek Gap
description: between Walnut Creek and the head of Moss Branch in E Macon County.

label: Walnut Creek Township
description: former township in central Edgecombe County, now township no. 11.

label: Walnut Gap
description: N Madison County at the head of Woolsey Branch.

label: Walnut Grove Township
description: N Wilkes County.

label: Walnut Hill
description: mountain in NE Ashe County. Alt. approx. 2,700.

label: Walnut Hill Township
description: NE Ashe County.

label: Walnut Hollow Gap
description: in N Graham County on Tuskeegee Creek.

label: Walnut Knob
description: N Madison County between Big Laurel Creek and Walnut Gap.

label: Walnut Mountains
description: extend E through central Madison County from French Broad River into W Yancey County. Alt. 4,335.

label: Walnut Run
description: community in N Madison County served by post office, 1872-1911.

label: Walsh
description: community in W Wilkes County on North Prong Lewis Fork Creek.

label: Walstonburg
description: town in N Greene County. Lands there acquired after 1775 by John Chester, whose plantation house, "Chesterfield," still stands. His son-in-law, Bennett Fields, after 1845 changed the name to Fieldsboro. The latter name was, and still is, used as the name of the railroad station. Fields's cousin, Seth Walston, acquired the property after the Civil War, and the name Walstonburg came to be applied. Inc. in 1908 as Walstonburg.

label: Walter
description: community in central Wayne County served by post office, 1882-1903.

label: Walter Rawleigh
description: See Roanoke Sound.

label: Walter Slough
description: in the waters of Pamlico Sound NW of Oregon Inlet, E Dare County.

label: Walters Mill
description: community in NW Caswell County named for the mill on Hogans Creek.

label: Walters Mill Pond
description: NW Lenoir County, was originally formed about 1755; rebuilt about 1900. Fed by springs and wells and drains into nearby Moseley Creek. Covers 32 acres; max. depth 12 ft.

label: Walthall
description: See Wilbon.

label: Walton County
description: was created by the state of Georgia partly in territory claimed by that state but which a subsequent survey made in 1807 revealed to be in Buncombe County, N.C. Riots and bloodshed occurred during the "Walton War" over disputed land grants made by the two states in the area.

label: Walton Crossroads
description: community in S Gates County.

label: Walton Pond
description: a swamp, rises in S Gates County and drains SE into Trotman Creek. Watton Mill appears on the stream on the Collet map, 1770, and the name is derived from the mill that existed as late as 1833 but had disappeared by 1862.

label: Wampler
description: See Elk Shoal.

label: Wananish
description: community in N Columbus County served by post office, 1899-1972. Now within the limits of the town of Lake Waccamaw. It was to have been named Ouaniche for the Indian word meaning "land-locked salmon," but the spelling Wananish was preferred for the post office name.

label: Wanchese
description: community on the S end of Roanoke Island, E Dare County. Named for one of the two Indians taken to England by Philip Amadas and Arthur Barlowe in 1584. Produces packaged seafood. Alt. 10.

label: Wantland's Ferry
description: See Jacksonville.

label: Warbler
description: former community in S Tyrrell County between Kilkenny and Kilkenny Landing. Now absorbed into the community of Kilkenny. Served by post office, 1917-32.

label: Ward Creek
description: rises in N Cleveland County and flows SW into First Broad River.

label: Ward Gap
description: W Watauga County on the head of Phillips Branch.

label: Ward Hollow
description: W Watauga County, extends SW from Love Gap to Watauga River.

label: Ward Mine
description: a gold mine in E Davidson County, was worked as early as 1842 and shown on maps as recently as 1915. Ward Gold-Mine Co., chartered 1852, purchased 400-acre tract from John Ward.

label: Ward Mountain
description: N Henderson County on Featherston Creek.

label: Ward Run
description: rises in SE Wilson County and flows SE into Pitt County, where it turns SW and enters Little Contentnea Creek.

label: Ward Swamp
description: rises in N Sampson County and flows SW into Great Coharie Creek.

label: Wards
description: community in central Columbus County.

label: Wards Corner
description: community in W Pender County at the intersection of two highways.

label: Wards Creek
description: See Hawkins Slough.

label: Wards Mill
description: community in central Onslow County served by post office, 1866-1906.

label: Wards Mountain
description: SW Orange County between Toms Creek and Cane Creek.

label: Wards Store
description: community in SE Randolph County.

label: Wardville
description: community in E Gates County. Name changed from Bosley about 1936.

label: Ware Creek
description: rises in central Carteret County and flows SW into the mouth of Newport River.

label: Wareiock
description: See Beaufort.

label: Warington
description: See Fort Landing.

label: Warlick
description: community in E Burke County served by post office, 1882-1905.

label: Warlick Township
description: former township in E Cleveland County, now township no. 5.

label: Warm Cove Branch
description: rises in W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows SE into Caldwell Fork.

label: Warm Springs
description: See Hot Springs.

label: Warne
description: community in S Clay County between Crawford and Brasstown Creeks. Alt. 1,800. Named for the Warrens, an English family who mined gold there; the name was corrupted to Warne by the Indians.

label: Warnersville
description: community settled by African Americans in what is now the SE section of Greensboro. Named for Yardley Warner, Quaker missionary.

label: Warowtani
description: appears on the White map, 1585, as a village of the Weapemeoc Indians, located in what is now S Chowan County on Albemarle Sound near Edenton.

label: Warren
description: community in N Craven County. Settled after 1910. Named for James and Ben Warren, local residents. Alt. 11.

label: Warren Bridge
description: See East Lake Landing; Sandy Point.

label: Warren County
description: was formed in 1779 from Bute County, which was divided to form Warren and Franklin Counties. Located in the NE section of the state, it is bounded by Northampton, Halifax, Franklin, and Vance Counties. It was named for Gen. Joseph Warren (1741-75), Revolutionary War patriot and physician killed at Bunker Hill. Area: 445 sq. mi. County seat: Warrenton, with an elevation of 451 ft. Townships are Fishing Creek, Fork, Hawtree, Judkins, Nutbush, River, Roanoke, Sandy Creek, Shocco, Sixpound, Smith Creek, and Warrenton. Produces tobacco, corn, wheat, oats, cotton, poultry, lumber, boxes, soybeans, dairy products, hogs, livestock, lumber products, textiles.

label: Warren Creek
description: rises in SW Buncombe County near the Haywood County line and flows NW into South Hominy Creek.

label: Warren Hollow
description: N Watauga County, extends SW from State Line Ridge to North Fork of Cove Creek.

label: Warren Plains
description: community in central Warren County. Alt. 450. The site of a post office since 1857.

label: Warren Ridge
description: SW Buncombe County between Warren and Curtis Creeks.

label: Warren's Station
description: See Conetoe.

label: Warrensville
description: town in central Ashe County. Inc. 1931, but not now active in municipal affairs. Settled about 1826 and known as Buffalo Creek until renamed for the builder of first gristmill and sawmill.

label: Warrenton
description: city and county seat, in W central Warren County. Est. 1779. Alt. 451. Named for the county, which was in turn named for Joseph Warren, killed at Bunker Hill. Produces lumber products, and textiles.

label: Warrenton Township
description: central Warren County.

label: Warrick
description: See Peterson.

label: Warrick Branch
description: rises in W Mitchell County and flows S into Toe River.

label: Warrington
description: See Fort Landing.

label: Warrior
description: African American community in central Caldwell County.

label: Warrior Creek
description: See Boomer.

label: Warrior Fork [Catawba River]
description: is formed in W central Burke County by the junction of Irish and Upper Creeks and flows SE into Catawba River.

label: Warrior Gap
description: central Caldwell County.

label: Warrior Mountain
description: central Caldwell County. Alt. approx. 2,000.

label: Warrior Mountain
description: NW Surry County. Alt. 1,805.

label: Warsaw
description: town in W Duplin County. Alt. 160. Settled about 1825. Inc. 1855. Early known as Mooresville. Renamed by the conductor of the first train to run through what was then a crossroads community because he was reading a popular novel, Thaddeus of Warsaw by Jane Porter (1776-1850).

label: Warsaw Township
description: W central Duplin County.

label: Warwick Bay
description: a natural lake in E Robeson County. One of the Carolina Bays, which see. Approx. 1¾' mi. long and 1 mi. wide. Drained from the SE by Peter Swamp. Known also as Lennon's Marsh and Lennon's Mill Pond. Now a privately owned wildfowl refuge with ducks, egrets, and cranes.

label: Warwick County
description: On December 4, 1771, in the General Assembly, a bill for establishing the N part of Orange County as Warwick County and St. Stephens Parish was read for the second time and rejected.

label: Warwick Creek
description: rises on the Chowan-Gates county line and flows SW through Welsh Pond, where it joins Trotman Creek in forming Catherine Creek. Appears on the Collet map, 1770. A brick house, still standing, built on the creek in 1746 was an early trading center.

label: Warwick Mill Pond
description: E Robeson County on Jacob Swamp. Covers 10 acres; max. depth 10 ft.

label: Wash Creek
description: rises in NW Henderson County and flows SE into North Fork.

label: Wash Hollow
description: S Haywood County on Sam Branch.

label: Wash Ridge
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur extending SE from Shanty Mountain; center near lat. 35°37'07" N., long. 83°08'15" W.

label: Wash Woods
description: community and former Life Saving Station 4 mi. S of the Virginia line on Currituck Banks, NE Currituck County. Named for hundreds of old stumps there, exposed at low tide. A post office operated there, 1907-17, named Deals.

label: Washburn
description: community in W Cleveland County. Alt. 960. Settled 1875. Named for W. W. Washburn, a county commissioner.

label: Washburn Creek
description: rises in S Rutherford County and flows SW into Cleghorn Creek.

label: Washburns Store
description: community in E Rutherford County between Puzzle and Heaveners Creeks. Formerly known as Green's Grove and, when a post office from 1889 to 1906, as Lexine, named for Lexine Pruett, daughter of General Assembly member Greenbury Pruett.

label: Washington
description: city and county seat, W Beaufort County on Pamlico River. Alt. 11. Est. 1782. Known originally as Forks of Tar River but called Washington as early as 1776. Named by Col. James Bonner, founder of the town and friend of George Washington. Produces lumber, tobacco, textiles, and apparel. Known as "the original Washington" and commonly as "Little Washington" to distinguish it from the District of Columbia. Latter nickname not favored by town citizens.

label: Washington County
description: now in Tennessee, was created from the District of Washington, which see, in 1777. North Carolina ceded its SW territory to the federal government in 1789.

label: Washington Creek
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows N into Soco Creek.

label: Washington Creek
description: rises in N Pender County and flows NE into Northeast Cape Fear River. First known as Hamilton Creek for Malatiah Hamilton, who laid out a town near its mouth about 1740; the town became South Washington, which see.

label: Washington Ferry
description: See Princeton.

label: Washington Forks
description: community in central Craven County.

label: Washington Heights
description: community in W Beaufort County adjacent to and NE of the city of Washington.

label: Washington Park
description: town in W Beaufort County. Inc. 1923. Adjoins the city of Washington on the e.

label: Washington Township
description: NE Guilford County. Named for George Washington.

label: Washington, District of
description: See District of Washington.

label: Wasp
description: community in NE Craven County served by post office, 1900-1903.

label: Wasulu Ridge
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur extending NW from Welch Ridge near lat. 35°29'22" N., long. 83°38'32" W.

label: Watauga County (wah-TAW-guh)
description: was formed in 1849 from Ashe, Wilkes, Caldwell, and Yancey Counties. Located in the NW section of the state, it is bounded by the state of Tennessee and by Ashe, Wilkes, Caldwell, and Avery Counties. It was named for Watauga River. Area: 320 sq. mi. County seat: Boone, with an elevation of 3,266 ft. Townships are Bald Mountain, Beaverdam, Blowing Rock, Blue Ridge, Boone, Brushy Fork, Cove Creek, Elk, Laurel Creek, Meat Camp, New River, North Fork, Shawneehaw, Stony Fork, and Watauga. Produces tobacco, corn, dairy products, livestock, candy, baked goods, printed items, Christmas trees, electronics, apparel, and gravel.

label: Watauga Creek
description: rises in E Macon County and flows SW into Lake Emory.

label: Watauga Falls
description: community in W Watauga County on Laurel Creek near its confluence with Watauga River.

label: Watauga Gap
description: on the Jackson-Macon county line. Alt. 3,280.

label: Watauga River
description: rises in SW Watauga County near Grandfather Mountain and flows n, forming a short section of the Avery-Watauga county line before flowing into Tennessee, where it enters Holston River. Took its name from an Indian word meaning "beautiful water."

label: Watauga Settlement
description: began to develop in 1769 in what was then W North Carolina but is now Tennessee with the arrival of settlers on the Watauga and Nolichucky Rivers. A government was formed in 1772, and in 1776 its leaders asked to be annexed to North Carolina. The District of Washington, which see, was formed to include the Watauga Settlement. See also Franklin.

label: Watauga Township
description: SW Watauga County.

label: Watch Knob
description: central Buncombe County near the junction of Beetree Creek and Swannanoa River.

label: Water Creek
description: rises in S Scotland County and flows SW into Gum Swamp Creek.

label: Water Fork
description: rises in N Wake County and flows S into Horse Creek.

label: Water Gap
description: central Graham County between Mountain Creek and Sweetwater Creek.

label: Water Oak Gap
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Welch Ridge near lat. 35°30'32" N., long. 83°36'21" W.

label: Water Tank Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SE into Valley River. Named because the Southern Railway used it as a source of water for its steam locomotives.

label: Waterfall Branch
description: rises in N Mitchell County and flows S into Right Fork Bean Creek.

label: Waterfall Creek
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows NW into Carter Creek.

label: Waterhole Mine
description: mica and feldspar mine, SW Avery County.

label: Watering Hole Swamp
description: rises in W Robeson County and flows S into Wilkinson Swamp. Also sometimes known as Waterhole Swamp.

label: Waterlily
description: community on the S end of Church Island, E Currituck County. Settled about 1750. Named for water lilies growing in ponds and ditches there.

label: Waterloo
description: community in S Union County near the present Prospect School between the head of Cane Creek and Polecat Creek.

label: Waterloo Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows SE into Little Tennessee River.

label: Watermelon Branch
description: rises in N central Madison County and flows NE into Big Laurel Creek.

label: Wateroak Creek
description: rises in SE Clay County and flows SE into Tallulah River.

label: Wateroak Gap
description: SE Clay County between Chunky Gal and Yellow Mountains.

label: Waterrock Knob
description: on the Haywood-Jackson county line. Alt. 6,292. Named Amos Plott Balsam in 1858 by Arnold Guyot for a pioneer settler at its base. Wood cutters and loggers knew it as Waterrock Knob because there was a good spring running out over a smooth rock near its top. Also spelled Water Rock Knob.

label: Waters
description: community in N Burke County.

label: Watershed Mountain
description: central Madison County between Walnut and Hunter Creeks. Alt. approx. 3,100.

label: Watershed Ridge
description: N Buncombe County between North Knob and Wildcat Mountain.

label: Waterville
description: community in N Haywood County on Big Creek. Alt. 1,440. Named for the lake and dam built there in 1929. See Waterville Lake.

label: Waterville Lake
description: on Pigeon River in N Haywood County in Pisgah National Forest. Alt. 2,258. Constructed in 1929 for hydroelectric power. Covers 340 acres; max. depth 180 ft.

label: Watery Branch
description: community in NE Wayne County. Settled as early as 1887.

label: Watery Swamp
description: rises in central Gates County and flows S into Bennetts Creek.

label: Watha
description: town in N central Pender County. Alt. 60. Inc. 1909. About 1840, with the construction of the railroad, the old town of South Washington, which see, moved to the site from a point approx. 1½ mi. NE. The railroad station originally was named Hiawatha, from which the present name was corrupted. For about two years after the formation of Pender County, Waterville served as a temporary county seat. See also Welsh Tract.

label: Watia Creek
description: rises in W Swain County and flows E into Nantahala River.

label: Watkins
description: community in W Vance County on Little Ruin Creek. Named for Samuel Watkins, Henderson merchant.

label: Watkins Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NW into Valley River.

label: Watkins Creek
description: rises in S Macon County and flows NW into Middle Creek.

label: Watkins Township
description: W Vance County.

label: Watkinsville
description: community in NE Stokes County NW of Sandy Ridge served by post office, 1878-1904.

label: Watson
description: See Watsonville.

label: Watson Creek
description: rises in N Union County and flows SE into Richardson Creek.

label: Watson Crossroads
description: community in NW Wayne County near a tributary of Great Swamp.

label: Watson Gap
description: SE Watauga County on the head of Dugger Creek.

label: Watson's Mill
description: See Worrell Mill Pond.

label: Watsons Pond
description: S Hoke County on Little Raft Swamp. Formed 1865 and known first as Edens Pond and later as Johnsons Pond. Covers 50 acres; max. depth 7 ft.

label: Watsonville
description: community in central Rowan County served by post office, 1874-1903.

label: Watts Creek
description: rises in SE Stokes County and flows SE into Town Fork Creek.

label: Watts Cross Roads
description: community in NE Cabarrus County.

label: Watts Cross Roads Township
description: former township in N Cabarrus County, now township no. 6.

label: Watts Landing
description: community in SE Pender County on Intracoastal Waterway.

label: Wattsville
description: See Nakina.

label: Wauchecha Bald
description: central Graham County in Cheoah Mountains at the head of Bee Creek. Alt. 4,400.

label: Wauchope
description: See Walkup.

label: Waughtown
description: former town in S Forsyth County; inc. 1891. First called Charlestown or Charleston for Charles Bagge, who first settled there and opened a store. When the store was sold to James Waugh, the scattered settlement surrounding it came to be called Waugh's Store or Waughtown. Post office was Waughtown by 1828. Now within the corporate limits of Winston-Salem.

label: Waumans Creek
description: rises in NE Columbus County and flows NE into Cape Fear River.

label: Waverly
description: community in E Madison County on Paint Fork.

label: Waves
description: community on Hatteras Island, E Dare County, formerly known as South Rodanthe.

label: Waxhaw
description: town in W Union County between East Fork Twelvemile Creek and Waxhaw Creek. Inc. 1889. Named for Waxhaw settlements made by Scots-Irish and Germans in 1740. The name Waxhaw comes from the Waxhaw Indians, who once claimed the region between Rocky River and Catawba River. President Andrew Jackson was born nearby. Produces textiles.

label: Waxhaw Creek
description: rises in W Union County and flows SW into Catawba River in South Carolina.

label: Waxhaws, The
description: an area generally recognized as including much of Anson, Mecklenburg, and Union Counties in North Carolina and Chester, Lancaster, and York Counties in South Carolina. Catawba River forms the W limits. Waxhaw Creek flows through the area, forming what has been called "a rich oasis in a region of pine barrens." President Andrew Jackson was born in the area in 1767. The name came from the Waxhaw Indians of the region, whose chief village, Wisacky, was visited in 1670 by John Lederer.

label: Wayah Bald
description: W Macon County at the head of Camp Branch. Alt. 5,385. Named for a Cherokee youth who, according to legend, visited the mountain with his grandfather to listen to the message of the stars. Young Wayah's name meant "wolf."

label: Wayah Branch
description: rises in SW Buncombe County and flows NE into Stony Fork.

label: Wayah Creek
description: rises in W Macon County and flows SE into Cartoogechaye Creek.

label: Wayah Gap
description: W Macon County at the head of Wayah Creek.

label: Wayanock
description: See Meherrin River.

label: Waycross
description: community in E Sampson County.

label: Wayehutta Creek
description: rises in central Jackson County and flows SW into Tuckasegee River.

label: Wayne County
description: was formed in 1779 from Dobbs County. Located in the E section of the state, it is bounded by Greene, Lenoir, Duplin, Sampson, Johnston, and Wilson Counties. It was named for Gen. Anthony Wayne (1745-96), Revolutionary War leader. Area: 555 sq. mi. County seat: Goldsboro, with an elevation of 111 ft. Townships are Brogden, Buck Swamp, Fork, Goldsboro, Grantham, Great Swamp, Indian Springs, Nahunta, New Hope, Pikeville, Saulston, and Stony Creek. Produces tobacco, corn, soybeans, wheat, oats, cotton, poultry, dairy products, baked goods, wood products, sweet potatoes, cantaloupes, pickles, hogs, livestock, and cucumbers. See also St. Patrick's Parish.

label: Waynesborough
description: first county seat of Wayne County, est. 1787. The town died after the county seat was moved to Goldsboro in 1850. Waynesborough was located on land formerly owned by Andrew Bass, delegate to the Provincial Congress of 1775, at the SW edge of the present county seat on Neuse River. After 1847 many houses were moved from the old town to the new. The old courthouse, built by Col. William McKinne, was destroyed prior to 1917.

label: Waynesville
description: town and county seat, S Haywood County. Settled about 1800 and known first as Mount Prospect. Inc. 1810. Said to have been named by Col. Robert Love (1760-1845), one of the founders and owner of part of the site, for Gen. Anthony Wayne, whom he knew during the Revolutionary War. Produces rubber, shoes, and paper products. In 1953 the adjacent town of Hazelwood, which see, was inc. into the limits of Waynesville. Alt. 2,635.

label: Waynesville Township
description: SW Haywood County.

label: Wayside
description: former community in W Swain County on Little Tennessee River. A post office, 1880-1922. Site now submerged by Fontana Lake.

label: Weapemeoc
description: the principal town of the Weapemeoc Indians visited by Ralph Lane and fellow explorers in 1585-86, was near present-day Edenton, S Chowan County. The word was also the Indian name for Albemarle Sound and may be an Algonquian word for "where shelter from the wind is sought."

label: Wease Mountain
description: NE Rutherford County between the head of South Creek and Molly Fork. Alt. approx. 2,100.

label: Weasel
description: community in NW Ashe County. Alt. 2,790.

label: Weatherman Bald
description: on the Cherokee-Clay county line in the Valley River Mountains. Alt. 4,700. Known by the Indians as Kolasko

label: Weatherspoon Cooling Pond
description: in E Robeson County at the junction of Lumber River and Jacob Swamp. Approx. 3 mi. SE of city of Lumberton. Formed in 1955 to cover 231 acres, with a max. depth of 5 ft.; shoreline is 4 mi. Named for W. Herbert Weatherspoon, longtime official of Carolina Power and Light Company. Used to cool steam condensers.

label: Weaver
description: community in central Durham County.

label: Weaver Branch
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows SE into Breedlove Branch.

label: Weaver Creek
description: rises in E Vance County and flows S into Southerlands Millpond on Sandy Creek.

label: Weaversford
description: community in NE Ashe County. Alt. approx. 2,500.

label: Weaverville
description: town in N central Buncombe County. The site was referred to as Pine Cabbin in eighteenth-century records of the county and a little later as Salem Camp Ground. A post office est. there in 1850 was named Reems Creek and changed to Weaverville in 1873. Inc. 1875. Named for Rev. Montraville Weaver, who gave land and money in 1872 to est. Weaver College (closed in 1933). From 1919 until 1921, the town was named Elkwood. Alt. 2,300. Produces textiles.

label: Weaverville Reservoir
description: N Buncombe County on Ox Creek near Bull Mountain.

label: Webb
