description: community in W Mitchell County on Brummett Creek.

label: Webb Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows NE into West Fork Overflow Creek.

label: Webb Cove
description: the valley through which Webb Cove Creek flows in central Buncombe County.

label: Webb Cove Creek
description: rises in the Elk Mountains in central Buncombe County and flows SW to join Linn Cove Creek in forming Beaverdam Creek.

label: Webb Creek
description: rises in S Clay County and flows SW into Crawford Creek.

label: Webb Creek
description: rises in E Onslow County and flows E into White Oak River. Named for Thomas Webb.

label: Webb Lake
description: S Jackson County on Cedar Creek. Formed before 1946; covers 5 acres and has max. depth of 12 ft. Used for fishing. Not open to the public.

label: Webbs
description: community in NE Lincoln County.

label: Webbs Creek
description: rises in E Rutherford County and flows S into Second Broad River.

label: Webbs Mill Branch
description: rises in SE Halifax County and flows SE into Kehukee Swamp.

label: Webster
description: town in central Jackson County just N of Tuckasegee River and 2 mi. S of town of Sylva. Inc. 1859. Named for Daniel Webster. Alt. 2,203. The town was the county seat from its establishment as such in 1852 until 1913.

label: Webster Creek
description: rises in central Jackson County and flows N into Tuckasegee River.

label: Webster Station
description: See Dillsboro.

label: Webster Township
description: central Jackson County.

label: Weddington
description: community in W Union County between Sixmile Creek and West Fork Twelvemile Creek. Inc. 1983.

label: Weecaunse Creek
description: See Wiccacon River.

label: Weed Patch Mountain
description: on the Henderson-Ruther ford county line.

label: Weedy Mountain
description: SE Buncombe County near the Rutherford County line SE of Jarvis Mountain.

label: Weeks Point
description: See Swansboro.

label: Weeksville
description: community in S Pasquotank County on New Begun Creek. Named for families of James and Charles Weeks, local landowners. Known as New Begun Creek until about 1890. Older W section of the community sometimes is known as Old Weeksville.

label: Wehutty
description: community in W Cherokee County on Rocky Ford Creek.

label: Wehutty Mountain
description: W Cherokee County between Rocky Ford and Shoal Creeks.

label: Weightman Branch
description: rises in central Davidson County and flows S into Swearing Creek.

label: Weil
description: former community in central Wayne County near the junction of Little and Neuse Rivers. Site of a brickyard and a railroad station near the site of the old county seat of Waynesboro.

label: Weir Point
description: point of land on NW end of Roanoke Island, NE Dare County. The William B. Umstead Bridge, approx. 3 mi. long and opened on December 22, 1956, extends from the point to Redstone Point on the N Dare County mainland; named for N.C. governor William B. Umstead (1895-1954).

label: Weitock River
description: See White Oak River.

label: Weitzel's Mill
description: site on Reedy Fork Creek, N central Guilford County. A skirmish occurred there on March 6, 1781, between American and British forces.

label: Welch Bald
description: N Swain County on Welch Ridge near the NE end of Big Fork Ridge. Alt. 5,087.

label: Welch Branch
description: rises in W Swain County and flows SE into Fontana Lake.

label: Welch Cove
description: N Graham County W of Fontana, follows the NE course of a stream that empties into Little Tennessee River. Formerly known as Brooks Cove. See also Fontana Village.

label: Welch Creek
description: rises in N Beaufort County and flows NE on the Martin-Washington county line into Roanoke River. Name appears as Welches Creek throughout the nineteenth century.

label: Welch Creek Township
description: N Columbus County.

label: Welch Mill Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SE into Valley River.

label: Welch Ridge
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, extends SW from Silers Bald to Little Tennessee River. Its center is near lat. 35°31'40" N., long. 83°35'30" W.

label: Welch's Bluff
description: appears on the Moseley map, 1733, on the W side of Cape Fear River in present Brunswick County between the mouth of Indian Creek and Eagle Island. Possibly named for James Welch, who owned land in the vicinity.

label: Welch's Millpond
description: formed by a dam across Warwick Creek on the Chowan-Gates county line.

label: Welches Creek
description: See Welch Creek.

label: Welcome
description: community in W Surry County served by post office, 1899-1908.

label: Weldon
description: town in N Halifax County on Roanoke River. Inc. 1843. The Collet map, 1770, shows "Weldans," perhaps referring to the family name of the owner of the land. Town site settled prior to 1830, when it was known as Weldon's Orchard or Weldon's Place for Daniel Weldon, owner. In 1834 it became the terminus of a railroad from Virginia. Lumber and apparel produced there. Alt. 81. See also Blakely.

label: Weldon Township
description: NE Halifax County.

label: Weldon's Orchard; Weldon's Place
description: See Weldon.

label: Weldons Millpond
description: on Sandy Creek in E Vance County. Covers 10 acres, with a max. depth of 6 ft. Named for Obed W. Weldon, owner. Known prior to 1913 as Amos Millpond. The mill there is still used for grinding corn; the pond is used for fishing, swimming, and boating.

label: Wellington
description: name given the former Jacocks Landing on Cashie River, SE Bertie County, for a brief time when it was the S terminus of a short railroad. Wellington is shown on the 1892 Rand McNally map, as well as on the 1897 North Carolina Railroad Commission map. The Carolina Southern Railroad was inc. as the Wellington and Powellsville Railroad in 1893.

label: Wells Bay
description: in Currituck Sound off Mossey Islands, SE Currituck County.

label: Wells Creek
description: rises in E Vance County and flows S into W Warren County, where it enters Sandy Creek.

label: Wells Knob
description: NE Wilkes County between Little Elkin River and Elkin River. Alt. 1,810.

label: Wells Mineral Spring
description: S Nash County on a tributary of Sapony Creek. A popular recreation spot in the early 1900s; water thought to have curative qualities.

label: Wells Mountain
description: on the Cherokee-Clay county line from Coleman Gap to the mouth of Little Brasstown Creek.

label: Welsh Pond
description: on Warwick Creek on the Chowan-Gates county line, covers approx. 75 acres and is from 2 to 15 ft. in depth. Named for owners, the Welch family.

label: Welsh Tract
description: an area between the Northeast Cape Fear and Cape Fear Rivers, now largely in central Pender County, on which a number of Welsh families from Pennsylvania settled in 1730 and shortly afterward. The first grant was made in 1731 to David Evans for 640 acres. Apparently no single large block of land was granted to the Welsh; instead, individuals acquired their own land. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733, as Welch Settlement. Rev. Hugh McAden mentioned the Welsh Tract during his visit to the area in 1755, and the name was still in use in 1775. Persons other than those of Welsh descent soon moved into the area, and the tract lost its identity. About 1740 the Welsh laid out a town that became South Washington, which see.

label: Wendell (win-DELL)
description: town in E Wake County. Settled 1895. Inc. 1903. Named for Oliver Wendell Holmes (1809-94), American writer and father of the U.S. Supreme Court justice of the same name. Produces tobacco, apparel, and furniture.

label: Wenona
description: community in S Washington County on the N shoulder of Dogwood Ridge on East Dismal Swamp. Est. after A. E. Rice purchased 160 acres of land there and built a house in 1912. Other settlers then purchased land from Roper Lumber Company and settled; by 1914, a school was built. A post office was est. there in 1913; closed 1955. Settlers came there from Pennsylvania, West Virginia, Illinois, and Ohio.

label: Wentworth
description: county seat, central Rockingham County. Courthouse authorized to be est. 1787; first court held there 1799. Post office operated there, 1794-1827, as Rockingham Courthouse. Named for Charles Watson-Wentworth, Duke of Rockingham and prime minister of England when the Stamp Act was repealed; on March 9 and 17, 1778, Watson-Wentworth spoke on behalf of immediate recognition of the independence of the American colonies. Rockingham Community College, est. 1966, is there. Inc. 1998. Alt. approx. 900.

label: Wentworth Township
description: central Rockingham County.

label: Wesley
description: community in SE Surry County served by post office, 1894-1905.

label: Wesley Chapel
description: community in W central Union County. Inc. 1998.

label: Wesley Creek
description: rises in NE Haywood County and flows S into Fines Creek.

label: Wesley Martin Branch
description: rises in E Cherokee County and flows NW into Valley River.

label: Wesner Bald
description: on Haywood-Jackson county line. Alt. 5,600. Named for David Wesner of Cabarrus County, who obtained a grant for 100 acres in the vicinity in 1808. Wesner froze to death while hunting deer about 1812 on the mountain that now bears his name.

label: Wesser
description: community in SW Swain County near Nantahala Gorge. Alt. 1,714. Named for the nearby Wesser Creek.

label: Wesser Bald
description: N Macon County at head of Tellico Creek. Alt. 4,800.

label: Wesser Creek
description: rises in E Swain County and flows NE into Connelly Creek.

label: Wesser Gap
description: SE Swain County on the head of Connelly Creek.

label: West Alliance
description: See Alliance.

label: West Asheville
description: former town in central Buncombe County on the W side of the French Broad River. Inc. 1889; became a part of Asheville, 1897.

label: West Bald
description: peak in the Tusquitee Mountains, N Clay County.

label: West Bay
description: S extension of Pamlico Sound between Piney Island and Cedar Island in NE Carteret County.

label: West Bear Creek
description: rises in E Wayne County and flows SE into Bear Creek.

label: West Beaver Creek
description: rises in S Ashe County and flows SE into Beaver Creek.

label: West Belews Creek
description: rises in E Forsyth County and flows NE into S Stokes County and into Belews Creek. Also known as Left Fork Belews Creek and, in Stokes County, as Little Belews Creek.

label: West Bend
description: community in W Forsyth County in a bend of Yadkin River.

label: West Bladenboro
description: town in SW Bladen County adjacent to Bladenboro, which see. Inc. 1913, but no longer active in municipal affairs.

label: West Bluff Bay
description: in Pamlico Sound W of Bluff Point in S Hyde County.

label: West Branch
description: rises in W Warren County and flows N into Malones Creek.

label: West Buffalo Creek
description: rises in SW Graham County and flows NE into Hooper Mill Creek. Also known as Little Buffalo Creek.

label: West Buies Creek
description: rises in N Harnett County and flows S and SE into Buies Creek.

label: West Canton
description: suburban area of the city of Canton in E Haywood County.

label: West Concord
description: unincorporated outskirts of city of Concord, central Cabarrus County.

label: West Cove
description: extends SW in E Haywood County between Wilson Cove and Long Branch.

label: West Crossroads
description: See Spiveys Corner.

label: West Double Creek
description: rises in S Surry County and flows SE to join East Double Creek in forming Double Creek.

label: West End
description: community in S Moore County. Named for the fact that it was the W terminus of a railroad from Aberdeen (about 1890-98) that later became a part of the Norfolk and Southern Railway. Alt. 604.

label: West Fork
description: rises in central Avery County and flows S into Linville River.

label: West Fork Campbell Creek
description: rises in W Haywood County and flows NE into Campbell Creek.

label: West Fork Deep River
description: rises in W central Guilford County and flows SE into High Point Lake, where it joins East Fork Deep River.

label: West Fork French Broad River
description: rises in W Transylvania County and flows SE to join North Fork French Broad River in forming French Broad River.

label: West Fork Little River
description: rises in S Randolph County and flows SE into Montgomery County, where it enters Little River.

label: West Fork of Ivy Township
description: former township in E Madison County, now township no. 5.

label: West Fork Overflow Creek
description: rises in S Macon County and flows SE to join East Fork Overflow Creek in forming Overflow Creek.

label: West Fork Pigeon River
description: rises in S Haywood County near the Jackson-Transylvania county line and flows NE to join East Fork Pigeon River in forming Pigeon River. Known by the Cherokee Indians as Neeoh-la, the name that they applied to the main river formed by the junction of East and West Forks Pigeon River.

label: West Fork Rocky River
description: rises in S Iredell County and flows SE into Mecklenburg County, where it enters Rocky River on the MecklenburgCabarrus county line.

label: West Fork Sandy Branch
description: rises in S Stokes County and flows S into Sandy Branch.

label: West Fork Shut-in Creek
description: rises in W Madison County and flows NE to join East Fork Shut-in Creek in forming Shut-in Creek.

label: West Fork Tuckasegee River
description: rises in W Jackson County at N end of Thorpe Lake and flows NE to enter Tuckasegee River approx. 8 mi. away at the community of Tuckasegee.

label: West Fork Twelvemile Creek
description: rises in W Union County and flows SE to join East Fork Twelvemile Creek in forming Twelvemile Creek.

label: West Fork [Barkers Creek]
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows NE to join Middle Fork [Barkers Creek] in forming Barkers Creek.

label: West Fork [Bull Creek]
description: rises in N Madison County near Bull Creek Gap and flows S to join East Fork [Bull Creek] in forming Bull Creek.

label: West Fork [Dicks Creek]
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows S to join East Fork [Dicks Creek] in forming Dicks Creek.

label: West Fork [Goose Creek]
description: rises in NW Pamlico County and flows SE into Goose Creek.

label: West Fork [Jenkins Creek]
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows S to join East Fork [Jenkins Creek] in forming Jenkins Creek.

label: West Fork [Kirkland Creek]
description: rises in S Swain County and flows N to join East Fork [Kirkland Creek] in forming Kirkland Creek.

label: West Fork [Moses Creek]
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows SW to join East Fork [Moses Creek] in forming Moses Creek.

label: West Fork [Rube Creek]
description: rises in NW Watauga County and flows SE into Rube Creek.

label: West Fork [South River]
description: a short stream at the headwaters of South River in N central Carteret County.

label: West Haven
description: community in S Buncombe County on the E limit of Pisgah National Forest.

label: West Hillsborough
description: unincorporated outskirts of town of Hillsborough, central Orange County.

label: West Howellsville Township
description: E Robeson County.

label: West Jefferson
description: town in central Ashe County. Inc. 1915. Named for its location in relation to Jefferson, the county seat. Produces hosiery and furniture.

label: West Jefferson Township
description: central Ashe County.

label: West Knob
description: on the Buncombe-Henderson county line between Double Knob and Graham Mountain.

label: West Littleton Branch
description: rises in E Warren County near the town of Littleton and flows NW into Little Stonehouse Creek.

label: West Monroe
description: former town in central Union County. Inc. 1909 as Icemorlee, a mill village named for three major stockholders: Iceman, Morrow, and Lee. Later renamed. Merged with the city of Monroe in 1949.

label: West Mountain
description: W Cherokee County between Camp and Shoal Creeks.

label: West Nelson Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SE into Valley River.

label: West Norman
description: community in Lincoln County on W shore of Lake Norman. Effort to incorporate failed in 2001.

label: West Philadelphia
description: community in NW Moore County.

label: West Point
description: former plantation, tavern, and ferry in W Wayne County at the junction of Thoroughfare Swamp and Neuse River; owned by Andrew Bass, delegate to the Provincial Congress of 1775, whose lands included site of Waynesborough, which see. Wayne County court met there during 1785. Later known as Bass Ferry. West Point was location for receipt and inspection of tobacco in 1784.

label: West Prong Grape Creek
description: rises in central Cherokee County and flows SE and SW into Grape Creek.

label: West Prong Horse Branch
description: rises in central Duplin County and flows SE into Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: West Prong Little Yadkin River
description: rises in W Stokes County and flows SE to join East Prong Little Yadkin River in forming Little Yadkin River.

label: West Prong Roaring River
description: See North Prong Roaring River.

label: West Prong [Glady Fork]
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows SE and then NE to join South Prong [Glady Fork] in forming Glady Fork. Also known as Galloway Creek.

label: West Prong [Hickory Fork]
description: rises in N Madison County and flows SE into Hickory Fork.

label: West Ridge Branch
description: rises in N Transylvania County and flows SW into South Fork Mills River.

label: West Rockingham
description: unincorporated outskirts of town of Rockingham, W Richmond County.

label: West Sanford Township
description: former township in W central Lee County, now township no. 6.

label: West Swan Creek
description: rises in E Wilkes County and flows NE to join East Swan Creek in forming Swan Creek.

label: West Tarboro
description: former town in central Edgecombe County on the NW limits of Tarboro. Inc. 1903. Charter repealed in 1909, when it became a part of Tarboro. A former West Tarboro community on the SW limits of Tarboro was inc. in 1893 and the name was changed to Hilma. See also Farrar.

label: West Thorofare Bay
description: NE Carteret County W of Cedar Island and adjacent to Long Bay. Connected with Thorofare Bay via Thorofare, a channel forming the S boundary of Cedar Island.

label: Westbrook
description: community in SE Bladen County. Named for early colonial family of Westbrook.

label: Westbrooks Township
description: N Sampson County.

label: Western Branch of Queen Anne's Creek
description: See Pembroke Creek.

label: Western Cliffs
description: E Macon County between Houston Branch and the head of Brush Creek.

label: Western Point
description: NE Carteret County; NW point of Cedar Island extending into West Bay.

label: Western Prong
description: rises in N Columbus County and flows NE and SE into Red Hill Swamp, after which it is known as White Marsh.

label: Western Prong Township
description: N Columbus County.

label: Westfield
description: community in NE Surry County. Grew up around a Quaker mission est. there in 1760 and known first as Tom's Creek. Renamed for the fact that it was a W missionary field for the New Garden [Guilford County] Quakers. Served by post office since 1834.

label: Westfield Township
description: NE Surry County.

label: Westminster
description: community in N central Rutherford County that grew up around Fort McGaughey; built approx. 1765 and used through the Revolutionary War. Sometimes known also as Brittain for Little Brittain Presbyterian Church, est. there in 1768. Present name is taken from Westminster School, founded there in 1901 by 10 Presbyterian churches in Cleveland, Polk, and Rutherford Counties; the school closed in 1923.

label: Westmouth Bay
description: between Browns and Harkers Island in The Straits, SE Carteret County.

label: Weston Knob
description: S Buncombe County S of Merrill Mountain.

label: Westover
description: community in NW Washington County. Alt. 17. A post office, White Marsh, was est. there in 1878 and continued until 1886. A 450-acre tract of land there owned by Surveyor General Edward Moseley (1682-1749) was known as White Marsh, a name that appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Westover
description: community in NE Wilson County. A post office operated there, March-December 1900.

label: Westry
description: town in E central Nash County. Settled about 1880; inc. 1909. Named for an early settler. Alt. 125.

label: Wests Branch
description: rises in N Macon County and flows S into Matlock Creek.

label: Wests Cove
description: on a tributary of Cowee Creek in N Macon County.

label: Wests Crossroads
description: community in E Lenoir County.

label: Wests Mill
description: community on Cowee Creek in N Macon County. In 1767 Thomas Griffiths, a South Carolina planter, shipped several tons of fine white clay, taken from a nearby pit, to the Wedgwood potteries in England.

label: Wet Ash Swamp
description: rises in Green Swamp in W Brunswick County and flows W into Waccamaw River.

label: Wet Creek
description: rises in W Moore County and flows N into Cabin Creek.

label: Wet Hollow
description: S Cherokee County; a mountain valley SW of Rocky Pen Ridge near the mouth of Crane Creek.

label: Wethero Mountain
description: between Cox Creek and Clear Creek in N Henderson County.

label: Weyanok Creek
description: See Potecasi Creek.

label: Weyanoke Creek
description: is mentioned in the Carolina Charter of 1665, in which the N boundary of the province is described as lying "within or about the degrees of 36 and 30 minutes northern latitude." It is shown on one version of the Comberford map, 1657, as Weyanoke River and on the other as Wepanoke River, one of several rivers flowing into Chowan River. Name soon fell out of use. Virginians thought it was intended to refer to Wiccacon River, while North Carolinians thought it was Nottoway River. Owing to the disagreement, a strip 15 mi. wide was long in dispute.

label: Weymouth Woods Sandhills Nature Preserve
description: a 403-acre tract of forest land SE of Southern Pines, SE Moore County. Vegetation varies from dense hardwood swamp forest to open stands of longleaf pine. Given to the state of North Carolina by Katharine (Mrs. James) Boyd in 1963. Alt. 350 to 500 ft.

label: Whale Camp Point
description: See Camp Point.

label: Whale Head Bay
description: in Currituck Sound off the W shore of Currituck Banks, E Currituck County a short distance S of Corolla.

label: Whalebone
description: commercial intersection on Bodie Island, E Dare County about 2½ mi. S of the town of Nags Head. Began around 1930 as intersection of then-existing sand trails and roads. Originally important commercial center. Named for whalebones in front of service station once located there. Also known as Whalebone Junction.

label: Whalebone Inlet
description: See Drum Inlet.

label: Whaley
description: community in N Avery County. Said to have been named for one Whaley, who became frightened by a screech owl and hid in a hollow log until morning.

label: Whaley Branch
description: rises in W Haywood County near the Tennessee state line and flows SW into Big Creek.

label: Wharf
description: community in N Anson County served by post office, 1889-1907.

label: Wharf, The
description: See Swansboro.

label: Wharton
description: community in NW Beaufort County. Alt. 19. Named for Lt. Col. Rufus W. Wharton, Washington resident and Confederate officer.

label: Wheat Creek
description: rises in E Polk County and flows SE into Green River.

label: Wheat Swamp
description: rises in SW Wilson County and flows SE into Wayne County, where it enters Great Swamp.

label: Wheatfield Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows SW into Tessentee Creek.

label: Wheeler Creek
description: is formed in W Northampton County by the junction of Gumberry Swamp and Lily Pond Creek and flows S into Roanoke River. The Collet map, 1770, shows Baker Mill at the mouth of the creek.

label: Wheeler's Mill
description: See Barrows Mill Pond.

label: Whetstone
description: community in N Granville County served by post office, 1889-1903.

label: Whetstone Branch
description: rises in S Davie County and flows E into Peeler Creek.

label: Whetstone Creek
description: rises in N Rockingham County and flows NE into Dan River. Tradition attributes the name to the fact that early white settlers found the Indians used stones from the stream to whet their knives.

label: Whetstone Ridge
description: S Transylvania County, extends NE from Blue Ridge to West Fork French Broad River.

label: Whichard
description: community in NE Pitt County served by post office, 1891-1926.

label: Whigg Branch
description: rises in W Graham County and flows NE into Santeetlah Creek.

label: Whim Knob
description: on the Haywood-Swain county line between Sugar Tree Lick and Strawberry Knob. Alt. approx. 5,400. Named for the fact that a whim, a horsepowered winch used to draw logs out of the valley, was operated on the peak for several years.

label: Whipping Creek
description: rises in SW Dare County and flows SW into Long Shoal River. Appears as Aquascog River on the Comberford map, 1657, and under its present name on the Collet map, 1770. Aquascogoc was an Algonquian Indian village near the head of the Pungo River estuary; the name is believed to have meant "where a place for disembarking exists."

label: Whispering Pines
description: residential community on Thagards Pond, E Moore County. Developed about 1962. See also Thagards Pond.

label: Whistling Gap
description: NW Yancey County between Chestnut Ridge and the head of Whistling Gap Branch.

label: Whistling Gap Branch
description: rises in NW Yancey County and flows SE into Little Creek.

label: Whitaker
description: See Grover.

label: Whitaker Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NW into Valley River.

label: Whitaker Creek
description: rises in SE Pamlico County between Smith Creek and Pierce Creek and flows SE into Neuse River. First named Powells Creek for William Powell, who settled there in 1703. Appears as Powells Creek on Lawson map, 1709.

label: Whitaker Crossroads
description: community in S Surry County near the head of Hagan Creek.

label: Whitaker Mountain
description: S Cleveland County.

label: Whitaker's Mills
description: See Gold Rock.

label: Whitakers
description: town on the Edgecombe-Nash county line. Settled approx. 1840; post office est. 1866. Post office name changed to Mayonia for approx. 3 months in 1886. Inc. 1872. Named for Richard and Henry Whitaker, local landowners who supplied wood to the railroad when it was being built. First known as Whitaker's Turnout. Alt. 134.

label: White Branch
description: rises in N Buncombe County and flows SW into Flat Creek.

label: White Branch
description: rises in N Franklin County and flows NE into Little Shocco Creek.

label: White Creek
description: See North Fork [Duck Creek].

label: White Creek Township
description: in S Bladen County.

label: White Cross
description: community in S Orange County. A post office there, 1880-1906, was known as Gath.

label: White Hall
description: community in central Cabarrus County.

label: White Hall Landing
description: in SE Bladen County on the Cape Fear River. An important early trading center.

label: White Hill
description: community in SW Lee County at the Moore County line. Took its name from a Presbyterian church there on a small knoll of very white sand. A former post office there, 1887-1906, was known as Villanow. The community has also been known as Caviness Crossroads.

label: White Horse Branch
description: rises in S Lee County and flows S into Little River.

label: White House
description: community in SW Randolph County served by post office, 1849-1908.

label: White Hurricane Knob
description: on the Buncombe-Yancey county line SE of Cane River Gap. Appears on recent State Highway Commission maps as Mahogany Knob.

label: White Lake
description: town in E central Bladen County. Originally chartered in 1923; repealed in 1925. Chartered again in 1951.

label: White Mans Glory Creek
description: rises in N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Welch Ridge and flows SE into Forney Creek.

label: White Marsh
description: See Westover.

label: White Oak
description: community in NW Bladen County. Alt. 46. Post office est. 1853. Named for John Whiteoak, a colonial resident. Once called Winnie for Jefferson Davis's daughter.

label: White Oak
description: community in S Wake County. Settled 1900 and named for the white oaks in the vicinity. Alt. 300.

label: White Oak Creek
description: rises in N Rockingham County and flows NE into Dan River.

label: White Oak Island
description: in W Tyrrell County, is a loamy section surrounded by swampland. Deer and bear hunting.

label: White Oak Knob
description: W Graham County in the Snowbird Mountains. Alt. 4,301.

label: White Oak Landing
description: on the Cape Fear River in NW Bladen County.

label: White Oak Mountain
description: on the Transylvania County, N.C.-Greenville County, S.C., line E of Sassafras Gap.

label: White Oak River
description: rises in N Onslow and S Jones Counties and flows SE on the Jones-Onslow county line to the Carteret-Onslow county line and into the Atlantic Ocean through Bogue Inlet. It is approx. 20 mi. long. Name derived from the Weetock Indian tribe. Appears as Weetock on the Lawson map, 1709; as Weitock River on the Moseley map, 1733; and as White Oak River on the Collet map, 1770.

label: White Oak Spring Canal
description: See Hamburg Ditch.

label: White Oak Stamp
description: a peak in SE Clay County at the SE end of Little Mountain.

label: White Oak Swamp
description: rises in S Nash County and flows NE into Toisnot Swamp.

label: White Oak Township
description: N central Haywood County.

label: White Oak Township
description: W Wake County.

label: White Owl Falls
description: SW Transylvania County in Thompson River. Height of falls is 80 ft.

label: White Plains
description: See Hiddenite.

label: White Point
description: extends from the mainland of NE Carteret County into Core Sound.

label: White Pond
description: community in S Robeson County.

label: White Pond Bay
description: a sand-filled bay in S Cumberland and N Bladen Counties.

label: White Post
description: community in central Beaufort County. Formerly known as Surry.

label: White Road
description: community in NE Forsyth County served by post office, 1850-1904.

label: White Rock
description: See Shelton Laurel.

label: White Rock Branch
description: rises in N Madison County and flows S into Hickory Fork.

label: White Rock Cliffs
description: N Madison County at the head of White Rock Branch.

label: White Rock Mountain
description: SW Buncombe County SE of Spring Mountain.

label: White Rock Ridge
description: S Watauga County, extends NW from Hillside Branch W of Buffalo Creek.

label: White Rocks
description: SW Watauga County between Bench Mountain and the head of Boone Fork.

label: White Store
description: community in SW Anson County. Est. about 1770 and named for Col. Joseph White Jr., who owned and operated a store there. A post office, 1837-1917.

label: White Store Township
description: SW Anson County.

label: White Sulphur Springs
description: See Catawba Springs.

label: White Swamp
description: rises in central Wilson County and flows NE into Cattail Swamp.

label: White Walnut Branch
description: rises in N Swain County and flows SW into Bone Valley Creek.

label: White's Spring
description: See Kelsey.

label: White's Store
description: See Hominy Heights.

label: Whiteface Mountain
description: at the junction of the Caldwell-Watauga-Wilkes county lines. Alt. 2,450.

label: Whitehall
description: See Seven Springs.

label: Whitehead
description: community in central Alleghany County. Named for D. C. Whithead, early settler. Post office est. 1883. Alt. 3,026.

label: Whitehead Creek
description: rises in N central Avery County and flows s, joining Hickory Branch before flowing into Elk River.

label: Whitehead Township
description: S central Alleghany County.

label: Whiteheads Mill
description: See Spencer.

label: Whitehouse
description: community in N Rutherford County between Cove and Otter Creeks. A stockade for the protection of settlers against Indians was erected in the vicinity of nearby Montford Cove Church in the eighteenth century.

label: Whitehurst
description: community in N Pitt County served by post office, 1900-1906. Settled about 1890 and known as Grindool (post office operated by that name, 1890-1910) until early in the twentieth century, when the name was changed to honor S. C. Whitehurst, local farmer. Alt. 68.

label: Whitehurst Creek
description: rises in central Onslow County and flows E into New River.

label: Whitelace Creek
description: rises in W Lenoir County and flows N into Neuse River.

label: Whitener
description: community in W Catawba County served by post office, 1893-1903.

label: Whitener Creek
description: rises in S Burke County and flows S into Rock Creek.

label: Whiteoak
description: community in N Onslow County.

label: Whiteoak Bald
description: NE Cherokee County in the Valley River Mountains.

label: Whiteoak Bottoms
description: SW Macon County between Kimsey Creek and Nantahala River.

label: Whiteoak Branch
description: rises in S Avery County and flows W into North Toe River.

label: Whiteoak Branch
description: rises in N Swain County and flows SW into Forney Creek.

label: Whiteoak Creek
description: rises in W Macon County and flows NW into Nantahala River.

label: Whiteoak Creek
description: rises in E Yancey County and flows E into South Toe River.

label: Whiteoak Creek
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows SE into Nolichucky River.

label: Whiteoak Creek Falls
description: more accurately a cascade, near the mouth of Whiteoak Creek at Nantahala River, NW Macon County.

label: Whiteoak Flats
description: community in N Yancey County on Whiteoak Creek.

label: Whiteoak Gap
description: N Madison County at the head of East Prong [Hickory Fork].

label: Whiteoak Knob
description: on the Cherokee-Clay county line.

label: Whiteoak Limb Ridge
description: S Graham County in the Snowbird Mountains between Rocky Spring Top and Poplar Spring Top.

label: Whiteoak Mountain
description: W central Polk County. Alt. 3,102.

label: Whiteoak Pocosin
description: W Gates County. Alt. 26 to 38.

label: Whiteoak Ridge
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur extending W from Forney Ridge and forming an arc between Bee Gum Branch and Whiteoak Branch. Its center is near lat. 35°28'38" N., long. 83°33'12" W.

label: Whiteoak Spring
description: NE Haywood County on the head of Raven Cliff Branch.

label: Whiteoak Swamp
description: rises in E Wilson County and flows SW into Toisnot Swamp. Mentioned in local records as early as 1740.

label: Whiterock Creek
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows SE into Dodgen Creek.

label: Whiterock Gap
description: S Macon County between Jones Knob and the head of Crow Creek.

label: Whiterock Mountain
description: S Macon County between Whiterock Gap and Conley Ridge.

label: Whiterock Ridge
description: W Jackson County between Wilson and Whiterock Creeks.

label: Whites Branch
description: rises in N Mecklenburg County and flows NE into Clarks Creek.

label: Whites Creek
description: rises in SW Wilkes County and flows NW into W. Kerr Scott Reservoir.

label: Whites Crossroads
description: community in NE Bertie County.

label: Whites Fork
description: community in SW Pasquotank County.

label: Whites Island
description: See Church Island.

label: Whites Knob
description: SW Burke County. Alt. approx. 1,800.

label: Whites Mill Creek
description: See Bristol's Mill Creek.

label: Whites Point
description: SE Onslow County on the W side of Queens Creek.

label: Whites Township
description: E central Bertie County.

label: Whiteside Branch
description: rises in S Yancey County and flows SE into South Toe River.

label: Whiteside Cove
description: community near Whiteside Mountain in SW Jackson County.

label: Whiteside Creek
description: rises in W Swain County on Welch Ridge and flows SW into Fontana Lake.

label: Whiteside Mountain
description: SW Jackson County 3½ mi. NE of the town of Highlands in the Blue Ridge; NE slopes are head of Chattooga River. Near the top is a sheer rock precipice 1,800 ft. high from which the mountain takes its name. Called Sanigilagi by the Cherokee Indians; the meaning is unknown. In 1950 a Spanish inscription of unknown origin was discovered there. A connected peak on the N is known as Devil's Courthouse, which see.

label: Whiteside Ridge
description: S Yancey County between Camp Creek and Whiteside Branch.

label: Whiteville
description: town and county seat, central Columbus County. Authorized to be laid out in 1810 on the lands of James B. White. Originally known as White's Crossing; inc. 1832 as Whiteville but appeared on many maps as Whitesville. Named for the man on whose land it was est. and who was a state senator, 1809-10. The former community of Vineland is now included in the S part of the town. Southeastern Community College, est. 1966, is located there. Produces lumber, apparel, tobacco, textiles. Alt. 59.

label: Whiteville Township
description: central Columbus County.

label: Whitewater Falls
description: is located on Whitewater River along the Jackson-Transylvania county line near the North Carolina-South Carolina line. The falls, among the highest in the E United States, cascade 411 ft. from an alt. of approx. 2,560. Known as Contara or Contaroga (meaning unknown) by the Cherokee Indians.

label: Whitewater River
description: is formed in S Jackson County by the junction of Silver Run and Little Whitewater Creeks and flows SE on the Jackson-Transylvania county line into South Carolina, where it is joined by Toxaway River to form Keowee River.

label: Whitfields Crossroads
description: community in E Lenoir County. Named for a prominent family that settled there before the Revolution.

label: Whitfields Pond
description: on the headwaters of Poley Swamp in N Duplin County. Alt. 118.

label: Whitford
description: community in E Jones County. Named for local Whitford family.

label: Whiting Spur
description: mountain on the McDowell-Mitchell county line.

label: Whitley
description: community in central Stanly County served by post office, 1881-1910.

label: Whitleys Crossroads
description: community in SW Nash County.

label: Whitnel
description: community in central Caldwell County. Named for J. O. White and J. L. Nelson, local mill owners. Formerly known as Treeland. Produces textiles.

label: Whitney
description: community in NE Stanly County on Badin Lake. Alt. 516.

label: Whitney Mines
description: former gold mine in NE Cabarrus County on Little Buffalo Creek.

label: Whitsett
description: community in E Guilford County. Est. 1884. Named for Whitsett Institute, successor of Fairview Academy, of which W. T. Whitsett was principal in 1888. Post office est. 1895.

label: Whitson Branch
description: rises in N Yancey County and flows SE into Jacks Creek.

label: Whitted Knob
description: N Buncombe County between Brittain Cove and Charlie Ridge.

label: Whittemore Creek
description: rises in N Buncombe County near the Madison County line and flows SW into Ivy Creek.

label: Whittier
description: town in E Swain and NW Jackson Counties on Tuckasegee River. Alt. 1,839. Est. 1885 by Dr. Clarke Whittier of California, who purchased 60,000 acres, including the town site. Chartered 1887; charter repealed 1895. Rechartered 1897, 1899, and 1907.

label: Whittier Branch
description: rises in N Buncombe County and flows NE into French Broad River.

label: Whittier Creek
description: rises in S Surry County and flows NE into Bull Run Creek.

label: Whittington
description: community in W Wilkes County on Reddies River.

label: Whittle Creek
description: rises in NW Alamance County and flows W into Buttermilk Creek.

label: Whortleberry Creek
description: rises in SE Anson County and flows SE into Pee Dee River.

label: Whortleberry Mountain
description: See Huckleberry Ridge.

label: Whortonsville
description: community in E Pamlico County on Brown Creek. Called Bethel until a post office was est. in 1904, at which time the name of the first postmaster was adopted (pronounced as if written "Hortonsville"). Post office closed 1959.

label: Whynot
description: community in S Randolph County est. late in the nineteenth century. A group of local citizens, meeting in 1860 to select a name for the post office about to be est. there, heard many suggestions phrased as "Why not name it for so-and-so?" Finally, someone in desperation said, "Why not name it Why not?" The group thought this was as good as any of the suggested names, and, since it removed any element of further controversy, the place was so named. Originally spelled as two words.

label: Wiccacanee Township
description: N central Northampton County.

label: Wiccacon River
description: is formed by the junction of several small streams in Hoggard Swamp in S Hertford County. It flows E into Chowan River. Approx. 17 mi. long. Appears as Weecaunse Creek on the Moseley map, 1733; as Veecaune Creek on the Collet map, 1770; and as Wiccacon Creek on the Richardson map, 1808. See also Weyanoke Creek.

label: Wickacon
description: community in S Hertford County.

label: Wicker
description: community in W Cumberland County served by post office, 1887-1903.

label: Wickham Precinct
description: formed on December 3, 1705, from Bath County, was named for the manor of Temple Wycombe, the home of the Archdale family in Buckinghamshire, England. John Archdale had been governor in 1694-96. In 1712 Wickham Precinct became Hyde County, which see.

label: Wide Bay
description: swamp in W central Brunswick County; a part of Green Swamp.

label: Widow Moores Creek
description: See Moores Creek.

label: Widow Mountain
description: N Wilkes County between Cane Creek and North Prong Roaring River.

label: Wiel
description: community in S Onslow County on the N side of the mouth of Duck Creek.

label: Wiggins Branch
description: rises in N Swain County and flows SE into Cooper Creek.

label: Wiggins Cove
description: E Mitchell County at the head of Beaver Creek.

label: Wiggins Creek
description: rises in W Swain County and flows NE into Little Tennessee River.

label: Wiggins Crossroads
description: community in S Edgecombe County.

label: Wiggins Crossroads
description: community in NE Gates County served by post office, 1878-1907. Alt. 30. Settled in the eighteenth century and named for a local family.

label: Wiggins Lake
description: W Edgecombe County, was formed in 1953 by a dam on Deloach Branch. Covers 52 acres, with a max. depth of 15 ft. Fishing, swimming, boating, and irrigation. Open to the public.

label: Wiggins Pond
description: See Contentnea Lake.

label: Wiggins Top
description: SW Clay County at the NE end of Chasteen Mountain.

label: Wikles Store
description: community in SE Macon County served by post office, 1869-1905.

label: Wilbanks
description: community in E Wilson County. A post office operated there, 1895-1906.

label: Wilbar
description: community in W Wilkes County on South Fork Reddies River. Alt. 2,000. Named for Henry T. Wilbar, nineteenth-century resident.

label: Wilbon
description: community in S Wake County. Also called Walthall.

label: Wilcox Iron Works
description: remains of a large stone blast furnace located at the foot of Ore Hill near Mount Vernon Springs, W central Chatham County. One of at least 3 ironworks built in the area by John Willcox (1728-93), ironmaster and landowner, during the Revolutionary era.

label: Wild Boar Creek
description: formerly rose near the E shore of the mainland of Dare County S of Stumpy Point Bay and flowed E into Pamlico Sound. Erosion that opened Stumpy Point Lake into the Sound also removed all evidence of the creek. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733, and on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Wild Branch
description: rises in N central Madison County and flows S into Big Laurel Creek.

label: Wild Cat Cove
description: on the Cherokee County, N.C.-Polk County, Tenn., line between Angelica Mountain and Hays Knob.

label: Wild Cat Mountain
description: E Davidson County between Flat Swamp Creek and Lick Creek.

label: Wild Cat Rock
description: a rugged precipice in SW Alleghany County near Doughton Park.

label: Wild Cherry Creek
description: rises in N Swain County and flows NE into Beech Flats Prong.

label: Wild Cherry Ridge
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur of Loggy Ridge near lat. 35°32'35" N., long. 83°31'25" W.

label: Wild Rock Mountain
description: SE Watauga County between Joes Creek and Old House Branch.

label: Wild Side, The
description: See Big Pocosin.

label: Wildcat Branch
description: rises in E Franklin County and flows E into Big Peachtree Creek.

label: Wildcat Branch
description: rises in central Wake County in Raleigh and flows N into Walnut Creek.

label: Wildcat Cliffs
description: on the Jackson-Macon county line SE of Whiteside Mountain.

label: Wildcat Creek
description: rises in E Macon County and flows SW into North Prong Ellijay Creek.

label: Wildcat Gap
description: on the Jackson-Macon county line.

label: Wildcat Hollow
description: N Yancey County between Seng Branch and Cane River.

label: Wildcat Knob
description: SW McDowell County. Alt. approx. 2,600.

label: Wildcat Lake
description: N Avery County on the campus of Lees-McRae College, Banner Elk, on Wildcat Creek. Covers 3 acres, with a max. depth of 12 ft. Fishing, swimming, and boating.

label: Wildcat Mountain
description: S Cherokee County E of Cane Creek. Almost right-angled in shape, it extends N and ne.

label: Wildcat Pond
description: marsh in SE Duplin County.

label: Wildcat Rock
description: W Henderson County at the head of South Fork.

label: Wildcat Spring
description: N Haywood County on the head of Holly Bottom Branch.

label: Wildcat Spur
description: peak in NW Polk County at the head of Brights Creek.

label: Wildcat Swamp
description: rises in SE Sampson County and flows NW into Black River.

label: Wildcat Top
description: peak on the Haywood County, N.C.-Cocke County, Tenn., line. Alt. 4,201. The Appalachian Trail passes there.

label: Wilder
description: See Needmore.

label: Wilders Grove
description: community in E central Wake County N of Crabtree Creek.

label: Wilders Township
description: N Johnston County.

label: Wildes Creek
description: rises in N Macon County and flows SE into Burningtown Creek.

label: Wildes Knob
description: N Macon County at the head of Wildes Creek.

label: Wildwood
description: community in W central Carteret County between Morehead Bluffs and Newport. Alt. 19 ft.

label: Wiles Creek
description: rises in N Mitchell County and flows NW into Big Rock Creek.

label: Wiley Knob
description: S Madison County at the head of Robert Branch.

label: Wiley Mountain
description: N Buncombe County between Thurz Mountain and Chestnut Knob.

label: Wilgrove
description: community in E Mecklenburg County.

label: Wilhite
description: community in W Yancey County served by post office, 1880-1915.

label: Wilkerson Creek
description: rises in W Hyde County and flows NW approx. 1½ mi. into Pungo River. Its lower course forms part of the channel of the Intracoastal Waterway.

label: Wilkerson Crossroads
description: community in W Wilson County N of Contentnea Creek.

label: Wilkes County
description: was formed in 1778 from Surry County and the District of Washington. Located in the NW section of the state, it is bounded by Yadkin, Iredell, Alexander, Caldwell, Watauga, Ashe, Alleghany, and Surry Counties. It was named for John Wilkes (1727-97), English political leader who championed American rights at the time of the Revolution. Area: 765 sq. mi. County seat: Wilkesboro, with an elevation of 1,042 ft. Townships are Antioch, Beaver Creek, Boomer, Brushy Mountains, Edwards, Elk, Jobs Cabin, Lewis Fork, Lovelace, Moravian Falls, Mulberry, New Castle, North Wilkesboro, Reddies River, Rock Creek, Somers, Stanton, Trap Hill, Union, Walnut Grove, and Wilkesboro. Produces corn, wheat, oats, tobacco, apples, peaches, glass products, hay, poultry, livestock, hogs, furniture, mirrors, textiles, apparel, hosiery, and crushed stone.

label: Wilkes Cove
description: at the head of Iotla Creek in central Macon County.

label: Wilkes Gap
description: central Macon County at the head of Iotla Creek.

label: Wilkes Mill Pond
description: in E Richmond County drains into Gum Swamp Creek.

label: Wilkesboro
description: town and county seat in S central Wilkes County on Yadkin River. North Wilkesboro, which see, lies just across the river. Laid out by 1801; inc. 1847. Took its name from the county. Wilkes Community College, est. 1967, is there. Alt. 1,042.

label: Wilkesboro Reservoir
description: See W. Kerr Scott Reservoir.

label: Wilkesboro Township
description: central Wilkes County.

label: Wilkie Gap
description: S Swain County on Licklog Creek.

label: Wilkins
description: community in SW Granville County served by post office, 1890-1905. Named for L. A. Wilkins, first postmaster and donor of right-of-way for railroad and land for the station. Alt. 360.

label: Wilkins Bluff
description: S Onslow County, extends into New River.

label: Wilkins Creek
description: rises in N Haywood County and flows SW into Pigeon River.

label: Wilkinson
description: community in E Beaufort County.

label: Wilkinson Creek
description: rises in N Chatham County and flows SW into Haw River.

label: Wilkinson Point
description: the S tip of Pamlico County extending into Neuse River. Appears on the Lawson map, 1709; called Rich Neck in local records of 1706.

label: Wilkinson Swamp
description: rises in W Robeson County and flows SW into South Carolina, where it enters Little Pee Dee River.

label: Wilkinson's Lake
description: See Bakers Lake.

label: Wilksville
description: community in W Robeson County served by post office, 1890-1902.

label: Will Branch
description: rises in N Swain County and flows SW into Oconaluftee River.

label: Will Creek
description: rises in N Cherokee County in the Snowbird Mountains and flows S into Hanging Dog Creek.

label: Will Gap
description: S Swain County between Will Knob and the head of Little Yalaka Creek.

label: Will King Gap
description: NE Cherokee County in the Valley River Mountains near the Clay County line.

label: Will Mason Branch
description: rises in SW Clay County and flows NE into Brasstown Creek. Named for a farmer who lived nearby.

label: Will Mason Gap
description: SW Clay County in Wells Mountain.

label: Will Puett Cove
description: central Cherokee County near the headwaters of Puett Creek. Named for Will Puett, who lived in the cove in the 1860s.

label: Will Quarter Creek
description: See Hoggard Mill Creek.

label: Will Scott Creek
description: rises in central Cherokee County and flows S and SW into Hiwassee River.

label: Will Scott Mountain
description: central Cherokee County, extends NE from Murphy.

label: Willard
description: community in N Pender County served by post office since 1883. Formerly known as Camera. Alt. 50. Also known as Leesburg until renamed for the Willard family, local lumber dealers.

label: Willardville
description: community in N Durham County served by post office, 1891-1904. Alt. 438.

label: Willeyton
description: community in NE Gates County served by post office, 1886-1907.

label: William B. Umstead Bridge
description: See Redstone Point; Weir Point.

label: William B. Umstead State Park
description: W Wake County 10 mi. NW of Raleigh. Est. 1943 as Crabtree Creek State Park; name changed 1955 to honor the late governor William B. Umstead (1895-1954). Contains 5,080 acres. Nature trail; camping, fishing, and boating. See also Reedy Creek State Park.

label: Williams
description: formerly an inc. town in E Yadkin County, the site now being in W Forsyth County. A whiskey distillery was operated at the site by the Williams family (who settled there about 1765) from shortly after the Revolution until 1908. On February 26, 1903, the General Assembly passed a bill prohibiting the operation of whiskey distilleries outside of inc. towns. On March 3, 1903, the town of Williams was inc. With the coming of statewide prohibition in 1908, the Williams distillery closed and the "town" ceased to exist.

label: Williams Branch
description: rises in E Swain County and flows E into Wesser Creek.

label: Williams Creek
description: rises in W Wake County and flows SE into Swift Creek.

label: Williams Crossroads
description: community in S Wake County near the head of Neal Branch.

label: Williams Lake
description: NW Sampson County on Caesar Swamp. Formed about 1855 as a millpond. Covers 30 acres; max. depth 12 ft. First owned by Joel Jackson and known as Joel Jackson Pond; acquired by his daughter, who married a Williams, hence the present name.

label: Williams Mill Creek
description: rises in E Anson County and flows SE into Jones Creek.

label: Williams Millpond
description: See Merchants Millpond.

label: Williams Mountain
description: S Polk County. Alt. approx. 1,450.

label: Williams Old Mill Branch
description: rises in central Sampson County and flows SW into Great Coharie Creek.

label: Williams Pond
description: See Nobles Mill Pond.

label: Williams Store
description: community in W Halifax County.

label: Williams Township
description: S central Columbus County.

label: Williams Township
description: NE Martin County.

label: Williamsboro
description: town in N Vance County near the head of Little Island Creek. It was authorized to be laid out in 1786 and inc. 1808. Long inactive in municipal affairs. The place was first called The Lick for a salt lick in the vicinity. It was later known as Nutbush for the creek named by William Byrd's dividing-line party in 1728 because of the profusion of hazelnuts there. Williamsboro was named in honor of Judge John Williams (1732-99). St. John's Episcopal Church there, dating from 1757, has been restored to its original condition.

label: Williamsboro Township
description: NW Vance County.

label: Williamsburg
description: community in SE Rockingham County. Known first as Thompsonville for Thomas Thompson, wagon maker. Post office by that name existed from 1848 to 1907, when the name was changed to McIver because of confusion with Thomasville. The community name remained unchanged, however, until 1960, when it became Williamsburg. In January 1840 Williamsburg School, the first public school in the state, opened here.

label: Williamsburg Township
description: SE Rockingham County.

label: Williamson Branch
description: rises in NE Wilson County and flows SE into Edgecombe County, where it enters Town Creek.

label: Williamson Creek
description: rises in E Transylvania County and flows NW into French Broad River.

label: Williamson Crossroads
description: community in NW Columbus County.

label: Williamsons Township
description: SW Scotland County.

label: Williamston
description: town and county seat, N central Martin County on the Roanoke River. Est. 1779 as Williamstown on Thomas Hunter's plantation, Skewarky (also commonly spelled Squhawky). Named in honor of William Williams, colonel in the Revolution. Produces canned foods, chemicals, tobacco, lumber, and apparel. Alt. 60.

label: Williamston Township
description: central Martin County.

label: Williamstown
description: See Williamston.

label: Willie Knob
description: S Graham County between Snowbird Creek and Little Snowbird Creek.

label: Willis Branch
description: rises in SW Cleveland County and flows N into Broad River.

label: Willis Cove
description: on a tributary of Iotla Creek in central Macon County.

label: Willis Creek
description: community in NW Bladen County served by post office, 1877-1908. Formerly Loveland.

label: Willis Creek
description: See Wade Creek.

label: Williston
description: a community in E Carteret County on Williston Creek. Named for a local family, possibly that of John Williston, who settled there in 1745.

label: Williston Creek
description: rises in E Carteret County and flows SE approx. 2½ mi. into Jarrett Bay.

label: Willits
description: community on Scott Creek in N Jackson County.

label: Willow
description: community in S Gates County on a branch of Trotman Creek. Post office est. 1878 as Willow Branch; closed 1913.

label: Willow Branch
description: See Willow.

label: Willow Creek
description: rises in W Henderson County and flows NW into French Broad River.

label: Willow Falls
description: rapids in Cape Fear River in central Harnett County NE of the town of Lillington. Mentioned as early as 1819 in a survey of the rivers.

label: Willow Green
description: community in E Greene County. Settled prior to 1890.

label: Willow Point
description: extends from the S mainland of Hyde County into Bell Bay.

label: Willow Springs
description: community in S Wake County. Settled about 1800; named for weeping willows in the vicinity. Alt. 275. Post office est. 1899.

label: Willowbies Island
description: See Bell Island.

label: Wills Creek
description: rises in S Cumberland County and flows SE into Cape Fear River.

label: Willy Knob
description: N central Alleghany County between Doughton and Black (formerly Carson) Mountains.

label: Wilmar
description: community in SW Beaufort and NW Craven Counties. Alt. 57.

label: Wilmer Branch
description: rises in SE Richmond County and flows SE into Poley Branch.

label: Wilmet
description: community in NW Jackson County. Alt. 1,866.

label: Wilmington
description: city and county seat, W New Hanover County on Cape Fear River. A port for oceangoing vessels, it is approx. 30 mi. from the Atlantic Ocean. Est. 1739-40. The town had a succession of names in its earliest years. Apparently settled and first known as New Carthage about 1733. New Liverpool seems to have been used briefly, followed by New Town or Newton, the name by which it was chartered in 1739-40, and finally Wilmington. Named for Spencer Compton (1673?-1743), Earl of Wilmington, patron of Governor Gabriel Johnston, during whose administration the town was chartered. Inc. 1760. The legislature met there, 1741, 1746, 1754, 1759-60, 1760-61, and 1764. Scene of coup d’état and racial violence, 1898. Alt. 38. Produces baked goods, fabricated metals, lumber, wooden containers, textiles, apparel, dairy products, paper boxes, chemicals, and refrigeration machinery. University of North Carolina at Wilmington is there.

label: Wilmington Beach
description: S New Hanover County on the Atlantic Ocean. Est. approx. 1913.

label: Wilmington District
description: at the time of the 1790 census, was composed of Bladen, Brunswick, Duplin, New Hanover, and Onslow Counties.

label: Wilmington Township
description: W central New Hanover County, coextensive with the city of Wilmington.

label: Wilmot
description: community in N Jackson County served by post office, 1886-1922.

label: Wilson
description: See Yadkinville.

label: Wilson Branch
description: rises in E Madison County and flows S into Big Laurel Creek.

label: Wilson County
description: was formed in 1855 from Edgecombe, Nash, Johnston, and Wayne Counties. Located in the E central section of the state, it is bounded by Pitt, Greene, Wayne, Johnston, Nash, and Edgecombe Counties. It was named for Louis D. Wilson (1789-1847), delegate to the Constitutional Convention of 1835 and an officer in the War with Mexico. Area: 373 sq. mi. County seat: Wilson, with an elevation of 147 ft. Townships are Black Creek, Cross Roads, Gardner, Old Fields, Saratoga, Springhill, Stantonsburg, Taylor, Toisnot, and Wilson. Produces tobacco, corn, wheat, oats, soybeans, cotton, poultry, tobacco products, textiles, apparel, tires, sweet potatoes, concrete pipe, motor-vehicle parts, lumber products, and processed meat.

label: Wilson Creek
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows E into Cullowhee Creek.

label: Wilson Creek Township
description: W Caldwell County.

label: Wilson Gap
description: SE Macon County between Clear Creek and Little Creek.

label: Wilson Hollow
description: NW Watauga County, extends E from Little Beaverdam Creek.

label: Wilson Knob
description: E Mitchell County at the head of Bear Creek.

label: Wilson Knob Mountain
description: See Big Butte.

label: Wilson Mill Creek
description: rises in W central Transylvania County and flows SE into Catheys Creek.

label: Wilson Mountain
description: extends NE in N Watauga County N of North Fork River.

label: Wilson Ridge
description: S Yancey County near the head of Big Poplar Creek and the head of Beech Nursery Creek.

label: Wilson Township
description: central Wilson County.

label: Wilson's Factory
description: town inc. 1883 to be laid out on the bank of the South Fork of Catawba River in Gaston County. There is no evidence that it ever existed as a town.

label: Wilson's Mills
description: town in N Johnston County. Settled about 1868; inc. 1927 and named for local family. Alt. 228.

label: Wilson's Mills Township
description: N central Johnston County.

label: Wilson's Old Store
description: See Walkersville.

label: Wilson's Pond
description: NW Wilson County on Marsh Swamp. Formed about 1900. Covers 15 acres; max. depth 12 ft. Named for Sanford Wilson, owner. Used for fishing, swimming, boating, and irrigation.

label: Wilsons Bay
description: central Onslow County in New River S of the city of Jacksonville.

label: Wilsons Creek Township
description: E Avery County.

label: Wilsons Store
description: community in NE Orange County.

label: Wilsonville
description: community in E central Chatham County. Named for Cecil Wilson, owner of a store there.

label: Wilton
description: town authorized by the General Assembly in 1818 to be est. on the lands of Sias Billings by Sr. at the mouth of Clarks Creek, SW Montgomery County. There is no evidence that the town was ever laid out.

label: Wimberly
description: See Coniott Landing.

label: Wimble Shoals
description: in the Atlantic Ocean off the community of Salvo on Hatteras Island, E Dare County. The shoals are at the approx. site of the former Cape Kenrick, which see. They were charted and given the present name by James Wimble in, or shortly prior to, 1738.

label: Winchester
description: former community in W Union County between West Fork Twelvemile Creek and East Fork Twelvemile Creek.

label: Winchester Cove
description: central Clay County near the headwaters of Greasy Creek.

label: Winchester Creek
description: rises in Towns County, Ga., and flows NW into Clay County, where it enters Brasstown Creek.

label: Winchester Creek
description: rises in W Haywood County and flows SE into Richland Creek.

label: Wind Blow
description: community in SE Montgomery County. Named about 1920 by S. R. Gaddy because it was believed that the wind would blow there if it blew anywhere in the area.

label: Wind Hill
description: community in NW Montgomery County served by post office, 1832-66.

label: Wind Mill Creek
description: See Jacks Creek.

label: Winder
description: See Vass.

label: Winders Crossroads
description: community in SW Yadkin County.

label: Windfall Creek
description: rises in N Ashe County and flows SE into Horse Creek.

label: Winding Knob
description: W Haywood County on the E end of Balsam Ridge.

label: Winding Stair Branch
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, rises near lat. 35°38'13" N., long. 83°02'55" W., and flows NW into Cataloochee Creek.

label: Winding Stair Gap
description: at the head of Poplar Cove Branch in SW Macon County.

label: Winding Stairs
description: section of road in NW Macon County between Queens Creek and the Macon-Swain county line; winds about 5 mi. down a ½ mi. drop and gives the appearance of winding stairs. Present road laid out about 1923 along a pioneer or Indian trail that, before the Civil War, was sometimes referred to as the Cat's Stairs.

label: Windingstair Knob
description: NW Burke County. Alt. 3,473.

label: Windmill Point
description: See Nixonton.

label: Windom
description: community in E central Yancey County on Little Crabtree Creek.

label: Windsor
description: town and county seat, central Bertie County. Settled 1722; est. 1768; became county seat 1774. Built on the family estate of William Gray and was known originally as Gray's Landing. Windsor was named for the royal castle near London, England. Post office est. 1794. In 1959 Windsor annexed Bertie, a small town across the Cashie River. The site is head of navigation for the Cashie River. Alt. 10. See also Hoggard's Mill.

label: Windsor Township
description: S central Bertie County.

label: Windsors
description: community in E Wilkes County named for Isaac Windsor, early settler.

label: Windy Gap
description: community in SE Wilkes County on Little Hunting Creek.

label: Windy Point
description: on the N side of Pettivers Creek at its junction with White Oak River.

label: Wine Spring Bald
description: W Macon County between Middle Ridge and Rocky Bald. Alt. 5,445.

label: Wine Spring Creek
description: rises on McDonald Ridge, W Macon County, and flows NW into Nantahala Lake.

label: Wines Top
description: peak at SW end of Glade Mountain in E Haywood County. Alt. approx. 4,375.

label: Winfall
description: town in central Perquimans County. Inc. 1887. Alt. 16.

label: Winfrey Gap
description: on the Cherokee-Clay county line. Alt. 3,493.

label: Wing
description: community in W central Mitchell County on Snow Creek. Named for Charles Hallet Wing (1836-1915), professor at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who settled nearby and in 1887 opened a lending library of about 15,000 volumes. It was the first free public library in the state and the third county library in the United States. See also Ledger.

label: Wingate
description: town in E central Union County; post office, 1896. Formerly known as Ames. Inc. 1901 as Wingate. Home of Wingate University. Produces wood products. Alt. 575.

label: Winkler Creek
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows NE into Flannery Fork [South Fork New River].

label: Winklertown
description: community in NE Caldwell County on Donahues Creek.

label: Winnabow
description: community in E central Brunswick County. Named for the plantation of Governor Daniel Russell, which, in turn, had an Indian name of unknown meaning. Called Evans Store Crossroads during the Civil War. Alt. 40.

label: Winnie
description: See White Oak.

label: Winona
description: community in N Richmond County served by post office, 1892-94.

label: Winslow
description: community in N Harnett County served by post office, 1858-1904.

label: Winstead
description: community in W central Person County served by post office, 1873-1910.

label: Winstead Crossroads
description: community in S Nash County.

label: Winsteadville
description: community in E Beaufort County served by post office, 1892-1909.

label: Winston
description: formerly an independent city in central Forsyth County. Authorized by act of 1849 creating Forsyth County and named the county seat in 1851. Since 1913 it has been consolidated with Salem as Winston-Salem, which see. Named for Maj. Joseph Winston (1746-1814), Revolutionary War leader.

label: Winston Lake
description: central Forsyth County on Brushy Fork Branch. Known earlier as City Lake. Covers 100 acres, with a max. depth of 20 ft. Used for fishing and municipal water supply. Owned by the city of Winston-Salem; open to the public.

label: Winston Township
description: central Forsyth County, coextensive with the city of Winston-Salem.

label: Winston-Salem
description: city and county seat, central Forsyth County. Formed in 1913 by the consolidation of Winston and Salem, which see, previously independent towns. Winston-Salem State University, Salem College, Wake Forest University, and the University of North Carolina School of the Arts are there. Produces tobacco, textiles, hosiery, bakery products, machinery, fabricated metals, furniture, corrugated boxes, apparel, and processed meat. Alt. 858.

label: Winter Park
description: community on the E outskirts of the city of Wilmington, W New Hanover County. Alt. 45.

label: Winter Star Ridge
description: S Yancey County between South Fork Cattail Creek and North Fork Cattail Creek.

label: Winterville
description: town in S Pitt County. Inc. 1897. Alt. 72.

label: Winterville Township
description: S central Pitt County; formerly Contentnea Township.

label: Winthrop
description: community in NE Carteret County served by post office, 1888-1908.

label: Winton
description: town and county seat, E Hertford County on Chowan River. Authorized to be laid out and est. 1768 on the land of Benjamin Wynns, for whom it was named. Appears as Wynnton in eighteenth-century records and as recently as on the Tanner map, 1827. Produces aluminum castings. Alt. 45.

label: Winton Township
description: E Hertford County.

label: Wiquemans
description: See Perquimans River.

label: Wis's Creek
description: See Long Creek.

label: Wisaoky
description: See Waxhaws, The.

label: Wise
description: community in N Warren County between Malones Creek and Sauls Creek. Alt. 392. Settled in 1890s and named for Henry Wise, local resident. A post office was est. there in 1891 but was discontinued in 1951.

label: Wise Branch
description: rises in SW Buncombe County and flows NE into Bill Moore Creek.

label: Wise Forks
description: See Wyse Forks.

label: Wise Knob
description: SW Buncombe County near the headwaters of Bill Moore Creek.

label: Wise's Crossroads
description: See Gum Swamp; Wise Forks.

label: Wiseman's View
description: an overlook for Linville Gorge in NW Burke County. Named for William Wiseman, early settler who migrated from London in the eighteenth century.

label: Wishart Township
description: SE Robeson County.

label: Wit
description: See Smyrna.

label: Withers
description: community in SE Stokes County served by post office, 1884-1905.

label: Withrow Creek
description: rises in S Iredell County and flows NE into Rowan County, where it joins Back Creek in forming North Second Creek. Appears as North Fork [Second Creek] on the Collet Map, 1770.

label: Witness Rock Ridge
description: N McDowell County on the S side of Armstrong Creek.

label: Wittenburg
description: community in S Alexander County. Named for Daniel Wittenburg, who settled in the vicinity about 1830. A post office, 1807-1909.

label: Wittenburg Township
description: SW Alexander County.

label: Wittys Crossroads
description: community in S Rockingham County. Aspen Grove was a nearby post office, 1899-1902.

label: Wococon Inlet
description: See Wococon Island.

label: Wococon Island
description: appears on the White map, 1585, as composed of parts of the present Ocracoke and Portsmouth Islands in Hyde and Carteret Counties. Port Grenvil, which see, formed its N limit and Wococon Inlet (an inlet, now closed, in Portsmouth Island) the S limit. Name probably derived from the Indian word wahkahikani (enclosed place; stockade). Appears as Gordens Island on the Smith map, 1624. See also Portsmouth Island.

label: Wohanoke
description: See Ohanoak.

label: Wolf
description: community in central Person County served by post office, 1900-1902.

label: Wolf Bald
description: on the Haywood-Jackson county line.

label: Wolf Branch
description: rises in central Buncombe County near Wolf Knob and flows SE into Shope Creek.

label: Wolf Branch
description: rises in W Yancey County and flows S into Fox Creek.

label: Wolf Cove
description: the valley through which Wolf Cove Branch flows in central Buncombe County.

label: Wolf Cove Branch
description: rises in central Buncombe County near Asheville and flows NW into Beaverdam Creek.

label: Wolf Creek
description: rises in NE Graham County and flows NE into Little Tennessee River.

label: Wolf Creek
description: community in SW Cherokee County on Wolf Creek. Served by post office, 1858-1904.

label: Wolf Creek Falls
description: on Wolf Creek in Canada Township of E Jackson County. Consists of a series of five separate falls, one being approx. 85 ft. high and the others averaging 35 ft. Located above Wolf Creek Lake.

label: Wolf Creek Gap
description: on the Cherokee-Macon county line.

label: Wolf Creek Lake
description: in central Jackson County on Wolf Creek. Formed in 1955 as a reservoir for Nantahala Power and Light Co. Covers 183 acres, with a max. depth of 170 ft. Shoreline is 6.9 mi. Used for generation of hydroelectric power. Named for Wolf Creek. See also East Fork Lake.

label: Wolf Gap
description: S Macon County between Turkey Knob and Buck Knob.

label: Wolf House Point
description: neck of land extending into waters of Currituck Sound on the W side of Church Island in E Currituck County.

label: Wolf Island Creek
description: rises in S central Rockingham County and flows NE into NW Caswell County, where it turns N to flow into Dan River.

label: Wolf Knob
description: on the Watauga-Wilkes county line E of the head of Stony Fork Creek.

label: Wolf Laurel Basin
description: depression between Fork Ridge and NW end of Horse Cove Ridge in W Graham County.

label: Wolf Laurel Branch
description: rises in W central Haywood County and flows E into Jonathan's Creek.

label: Wolf Mountain
description: S Henderson County at the head of South Fork.

label: Wolf Mountain
description: community in SE Jackson County on Tanasee Creek served by post office, 1876-1903.

label: Wolf Pen Branch
description: rises in central Franklin County and flows SE into Tar River. Now generally called Wolf Pit Branch.

label: Wolf Pen Gap
description: SW Cherokee County on the headwaters of Persimmon Creek.

label: Wolf Pen Mountain
description: E Caldwell County. Alt. 2,137.

label: Wolf Pit Branch
description: See Wolf Pen Branch.

label: Wolf Pit Creek
description: rises on the Fort Bragg Military Reservation in W Hoke County and flows NE into Rockfish Creek.

label: Wolf Pit Gap
description: E Haywood County between Millstone Mountain and Buck Cove Mountain.

label: Wolf Pit Township
description: SW Richmond County. In colonial times, it is said, the area was overrun with wolves. A trap was constructed for them, but the first animal to fall into it was a mule owned by a prominent farmer. Scottish settlers were so amused they gave the region the name of Wolf Pit.

label: Wolf Pond
description: community in S Union County.

label: Wolf Ridge
description: central Watauga County, extends NE from Rich Mountain to Howard Creek.

label: Wolf Rock
description: peak in S Macon County between Fishhawk Mountain and Tater Hill.

label: Wolf Swamp
description: rises in N Onslow County and flows SE into Northeast Creek.

label: Wolfden Branch
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows SW into Buffalo Creek.

label: Wolfden Knob
description: N Buncombe County between Rich Knob and Lane Pinnacle.

label: Wolfden Ridge
description: E Mitchell County at the head of Little Bear Creek.

label: Wolfert Creek
description: See Tusk Creek.

label: Wolfharbor Branch
description: rises in S Franklin County and flows SE into Nash County, where it enters Turkey Creek.

label: Wolfington
description: See Hoggard's Mill.

label: Wolfpen Creek
description: rises in central Henderson County and flows NW into Clear Creek. Also known locally as Bengle Creek.

label: Wolfpen Gap
description: S Haywood County in Wolfpen Mountain.

label: Wolfpen Gap
description: S Macon County between Rockhouse Knob and Dryman Fork.

label: Wolfpen Mountain
description: S Haywood County on the head of Farmer Branch and the head of Camp Branch. Alt. approx. 3,200.

label: Wolfpit Branch
description: rises in SE Buncombe County and flows NW into Swannanoa River.

label: Wolfpit Gap
description: W central Yancey County near the head of Jacks Creek.

label: Wolfscrape Township
description: NW Duplin County.

label: Wolfsville
description: community in S Union County.

label: Womacks Mill
description: community in central Caswell County; named for the mill on Country Line Creek.

label: Wood
description: community in central Rockingham County served by post office, 1891-95.

label: Wood Cove
description: swamp in central Pender County on Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: Wood Fork Branch
description: rises in N Surry County and flows SE into Beaverdam Creek.

label: Wood Grove
description: See Mount Ulla.

label: Wood Island
description: a small island in SW Carteret County in Bogue Sound.

label: Wood Lake
description: NE Cherokee County, is formed by a dam on Thrash Creek. Covers approx. 8 acres, with a max. depth of 35 ft.

label: Wood Mountain
description: between Mill Creek and Pine Creek in SW Jackson County.

label: Wood Swamp
description: See Hood Swamp.

label: Wood's Ferry
description: formerly crossed the Haw River in SE Alamance County approx. 2 mi. below Saxapahaw. Mentioned in local records prior to the Revolution.

label: Woodard
description: community in SE Bertie County served by post office, 1893-1945.

label: Woodard Mountains
description: E Madison County between California Creek and Middle Fork.

label: Woodard's Pond
description: E Wilson County, was formed in 1954 by the construction of a dam across a natural hollow between two hills. Covers 12 acres; max. depth 14 ft. Named for W. D. Woodard, owner. Used for fishing, swimming, boating, and irrigation.

label: Woodburn
description: See McGehees Mill.

label: Woodby Gap
description: N Yancey County between Hawk Branch and Byrds Branch.

label: Woodcock Knob
description: W Caldwell County. Alt. approx. 2,500.

label: Woodenton
description: See Woodington.

label: Woodfin
description: community in central Buncombe County on the E bank of French Broad River NW of Asheville.

label: Woodford
description: community in NW Ashe County.

label: Woodington
description: community in S Lenoir County. Named by Richard Caswell, who acquired a plantation there about 1767 before becoming governor. Name sometimes appears as Woodenton in nineteenth-century records.

label: Woodington Township
description: SE Lenoir County.

label: Woodland
description: town in E Northampton County. Alt. 72. Inc. 1883. Settled about 1835. Named for the Wood family, early Quaker settlers. Produces lumber. See also George.

label: Woodlawn
description: See Mount Holly.

label: Woodleaf
description: town in N Rowan County. Inc. 1909, but long inactive in municipal affairs. A post office was est. there in 1855 with Daniel Wood as first postmaster. Alt. 711. A large gravel pit is worked there.

label: Woodleigh
description: community on Knotts Island in NE Currituck County.

label: Woodley
description: community in NW Tyrrell County between Scuppernong River and the Tyrrell-Washington county line. Originated as a depot, but tracks and depot no longer in use.

label: Woodpin Creek
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows SW into Scott Creek.

label: Woodpin Falls
description: in the headwaters of Woodpin Creek in N Jackson County.

label: Woodrow
description: community in S Haywood County. Alt. 2,700. Named for President Woodrow Wilson.

label: Woodruff Branch
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows NE into West Fork French Broad River.

label: Woodrun Creek
