description: rises in W Montgomery County and flows SW into Pee Dee River.

label: Woods Branch
description: rises in central Jackson County and flows SW into Tuckasegee River.

label: Woods Gap
description: NE Rutherford County at the NE end of the Richland Mountains.

label: Woods Knob
description: S Mitchell County between Pony Ridge and South Fork [Carvers Branch]. Alt. 2,248.

label: Woods Millpond
description: E Wayne County on a tributary of West Bear Creek.

label: Woods Mountain
description: NW McDowell County, a series of small peaks. Max. alt. 3,646.

label: Woods Pond
description: See Parrish's Pond.

label: Woods Store
description: See Wood.

label: Woodsdale
description: community in N Person County. Settled about 1800. Named for the Hugh Woods family, early residents. Alt. 482.

label: Woodsdale Township
description: N central Person County.

label: Woodside
description: See Granite Quarry.

label: Woodson Branch
description: rises in W central Madison County and flows N into Big Laurel Creek.

label: Woodstock Point
description: E Beaufort County on Pungo River. In 1739 a town named Woodstock was laid out there to serve as the county seat of Hyde County. The courthouse burned in 1789, and the following year the county seat was moved. Remains of the old courthouse may still be seen at low tide off Woodstock Point. A post office at Woodstock operated until 1825.

label: Woodstock Savanna
description: E Beaufort County between Pungo Creek and Pamlico River.

label: Woodsworth
description: community in N Vance County.

label: Woodville
description: community in E Perquimans County on Little River. An early Quaker settlement. A post office operated there, 1820-1910.

label: Woodville
description: community in NE Surry County near Big Creek.

label: Woodville Township
description: W Bertie County.

label: Woodward Knob
description: NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Jenkins Trail Ridge near lat. 35°31' N., long. 83°43'02" W. Alt. 3,939.

label: Woodward's Crossroads
description: See Pendleton.

label: Woodworth
description: community in N Vance County served by post office, 1831-1914.

label: Woody Branch
description: rises in N central Henderson County and flows SE into Boylston Creek.

label: Woody Creek
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, rises near lat. 35°35' N., long. 83°10'20" W., and flows NE into Ugly Fork.

label: Woody Ridge
description: W Haywood County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur extending NE from Balsam Mountain; center near lat. 35°35'30" N., long. 83°10' W.

label: Woody's Ferry
description: See Newmarket.

label: Woolard Crossroads
description: community in NW Beaufort County.

label: Wooleyshot Branch
description: rises in SW Madison County W of Hap Mountain and flows S and W into Spring Creek.

label: Woolly Ridge
description: NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur extending SE from Blockhouse Ridge. Its center is near lat. 35°32'58" N., long. 83°41'37" W.

label: Woolsey
description: See Ramoth.

label: Woolsey Branch
description: rises in N Madison County on the S slope of Walnut Knob and flows S and W into French Broad River at Stackhouse.

label: Wooly Ridge Branch
description: rises in W Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows SE into Nunda Branch.

label: Wooten Millpond
description: E Wayne County on Walnut Creek. Named for Shadrach Wooten, Revolutionary War soldier, who moved to Columbus County in 1805. Descendants still live in the area.

label: Wooten Mountain
description: E Macon County between Cat Creek and Rabbit Creek.

label: Wootens Creek
description: rises in N Wilkes County and flows SE into Mulberry Creek.

label: Wootens Crossroads
description: community in N Lenoir County. Named for a family that long operated a store there.

label: Wootentown
description: community in central Beaufort County 1 mi. E of Washington Park. Alt. 14. Misspelled Hootentown frequently because that is the way the name is pronounced locally. An African American community on land originally owned by Harkness Wooten, a free black in the antebellum period. Many inhabitants are descended from him.

label: Wootonton
description: See Fair Bluff.

label: Worcester Inlet
description: See Trinity Harbor.

label: Worlds Edge
description: high bluff S of Chinquapin Gap, NW Polk County. Views to E extend 40 mi. to Forest City. Property, adjacent to Chimney Rock State Park tract, under conservation easement.

label: Worley
description: community in S Madison County on Big Pine Creek.

label: Worley Branch
description: rises in E Swain County and flows SE into Galbreath Creek.

label: Worley Cove
description: E Haywood County on the head of North Hominy Creek.

label: Worley Cove Branch
description: rises in S Madison County and flows SE into Sandy Mush Creek. The name Red Horse Creek is also applied to the stream.

label: Worley Knob
description: E Swain County on the head of Worley Branch.

label: Worm Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SW and NW into Valley River.

label: Worrell Mill Pond
description: NE Northampton County on Kirbys Creek. Prior to about 1916, when M. E. Worrell purchased the mill, it was known as Watson's Mill. For a time, a generator there produced electricity for the town of Murfreesboro, 3 mi. s. A marl cliff near the millrace has yielded evidence of at least ten species of marine life.

label: Worrells Mill Pond
description: W Hertford County at the junction of Hares and Institute Branches. Formed prior to 1842 and known first as Griffith's Mill Pond. Covers 75 acres, with a max. depth of 17 ft.

label: Worry
description: community in N central Burke County about 6 mi. NW of town of Morganton. Named by Jane Elizabeth Caldwell, who, according to local legend, had submitted several names that were rejected; troubled by the dilemma, she proposed Worry, which was selected.

label: Worsley Creek
description: See Chocowinity Creek.

label: Worth
description: See Hardin.

label: Worth's Mill
description: See Worthville.

label: Worthville
description: community in N Randolph County on Deep River. Settled approx. 1810 and known as Hopper's Ford for Charles Hopper, local resident. With the est. of a cotton mill by J. M. and Hal M. Worth about 1881, it came to be called Worth's Mill. Inc. 1895 as Worthville; charter repealed 1920.

label: Wrendale
description: community in N Edgecombe County served by post office, 1888-1902.

label: Wright Branch
description: rises in central Haywood County and flows SE into Jonathan Creek.

label: Wright Brothers National Memorial
description: on N Bodie Island, E Dare County. Includes the Kill Devil Hills Monument National Memorial, the reconstructed Wright hangar and workshop, and visitor center. Occupies 314 acres.

label: Wright Cove
description: the valley through which Crawford Creek flows in S Clay County.

label: Wright Creek
description: rises in W Graham County and flows NE into Santeetlah Creek.

label: Wright Knob
description: central Haywood County between Morrow Branch and Wright Branch.

label: Wright Memorial Bridge
description: See Currituck Sound; Kitty Hawk.

label: Wrights Creek
description: rises in N Jackson County and flows SW into Soco Creek.

label: Wrights Island
description: S Onslow County on the NE side of New River Inlet.

label: Wrights Station
description: See Lowell.

label: Wrightsboro
description: community in N New Hanover County. Alt. approx. 35.

label: Wrightsville
description: community on the mainland of E New Hanover County near the mouth of Bradleys Creek and Middle Sound. Settled about 1780. Known at one time as Wrightsville Sound. Named for Joshua G. Wright (1840-94) of Wilmington, organizer of a real estate agency.

label: Wrightsville Beach
description: town in E New Hanover County on Wrightsville Beach island between the Atlantic Ocean and Wrightsville Sound. Settled about 1889; inc. 1899. Alt. 5. Summer resort.

label: Wrightsville Inlet
description: See Moore Inlet.

label: Wrightsville Sound
description: E New Hanover County W of Wrightsville Beach island. See also Wrightsville.

label: Wriston
description: community in W Mecklenburg County served by post office, 1899-1902.

label: Wyanoke
description: community in NW Gates County on Chowan River.

label: Wyant Branch
description: rises in SW Macon County and flows SW into Long Branch.

label: Wyatt
description: community in N Wake County near Smiths Creek. Served by post office, 1891-1910.

label: Wycle Creek
description: rises in W central Haywood County and flows E into Jonathans Creek.

label: Wye
description: community in E Harnett County 1 mi. NE of Erwin; there, the railroad has a "Y" connection, with one line leading to Erwin and the other to Dunn.

label: Wyesocking Bay
description: in Pamlico Sound, E Hyde County, bounded by Long Point on the NE and by Hog Island Point on the sw. The Collet map, 1770, shows Yesocking Creek flowing into the bay, unnamed on the map. The creek named by Collet no longer exists since a canal has been dug at or near its course. The Indian word from which Wyesocking has developed is believed to have been wayäci, which, in combination with another word, meant "directly" or "straightaway," referring to a landing place.

label: Wykle Hill
description: N Macon County between the head of Hampton Branch and Queens Creek.

label: Wynn Creek
description: rises in SE Alamance County and flows W into Haw Creek.

label: Wynn Ferry
description: formerly in N Tyrrell County on Scuppernong River S of Columbia.

label: Wynnton
description: See Winton.

label: Wyo
description: community on the Davie-Yadkin county line. Named for local church. Served by post office, 1891-1907.

label: Wyse Forks
description: community in NW Jones County. Named for local family. Known as Wyse's Crossroads in 1863, when a Civil War engagement took place there on April 28. The battle is referred to variously as Wyse's Crossroads, Dover Crossroads, and First Gum Swamp. See also Gum Swamp.

label: Wysner Mountain
description: N Montgomery County near Barnes Creek.

label: Wythe
description: community in central Harnett County served by post office, 1890-1905.

label: X-Way
description: See Exway.

label: Xenia
description: community in central Duplin County served by post office, 1891-1903. Name derived from Greek word meaning hospitality.

label: Xuala
description: See Fort San Juan.

label: Yadkin
description: community in E Rowan County at Yadkin River. A large textile mill is there.

label: Yadkin College
description: town in W Davidson County on Yadkin River. Inc. 1875, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Named for the Methodist Protestant college opened there in 1865, closed in 1924. One college building and the ruins of another remain.

label: Yadkin College Township
description: W central Davidson County.

label: Yadkin County
description: was formed in 1850 from Surry County. Located in the N central section of the state, it is bounded by Forsyth, Davie, Iredell, Wilkes, and Surry Counties. It was named for Yadkin River, which see. Area: 335 sq. mi. County seat: Yadkinville, with an elevation of 960 ft. Townships are Boonville, Buck Shoal, Deep Creek, East Bend, Fall Creek, Forbush, Knobs, and Liberty. Produces tobacco, corn, wheat, oats, poultry, textiles, machinery, plastics, barley, crushed granite, and limestone.

label: Yadkin Creek
description: rises in S Watauga County and flows S into Caldwell County.

label: Yadkin Narrows
description: See Narrows of the Yadkin.

label: Yadkin River
description: rises in S Watauga County near Blowing Rock and flows SE into Caldwell County, where it turns NE to flow through Wilkes County and along the Surry-Yadkin, Yadkin-Forsyth, Davie-Forsyth, Davie-Davidson, Davidson-Rowan, and a part of the Montgomery-Stanly county lines. It is then joined by the Uwharrie River in forming the Pee Dee River. Called Sapona River by John Lawson in 1709. Appears as "Sapona or Yadkin River" on the Moseley map, 1733. The Sapona Indians lived in the area, but the origin or meaning of Yadkin is uncertain. It was also spelled Yatkin, Atkin, Reatkin, and other ways in the eighteenth century.

label: Yadkin Township
description: SW Stokes County.

label: Yadkin Valley
description: community in NE Davie County.

label: Yadkin Valley Township
description: NE Caldwell County.

label: Yadkinville
description: town and county seat, central Yadkin County. Commissioners in 1850 authorized to select site and lay off county seat to be named Wilson. Name changed to Yadkinville 1852; town chartered 1857. Alt. 960.

label: Yalaka Creek
description: rises in SE Swain County and flows NW into Little Tennessee River. Sometimes also called Alarka Creek.

label: Yalaka Mountains
description: extend SE from the head of East Fork [Kirkland Creek] in S Swain County to the head of Upper Long Creek in SE Swain County. Sometimes also called Alarka Mountains.

label: Yale
description: community in W Henderson County. Alt. 2,104.

label: Yamacraw
description: community in W Pender County.

label: Yancey
description: community in E Person County served by post office, 1894-1903.

label: Yancey Branch
description: rises in S Cleveland County and flows SE into First Broad River.

label: Yancey County
description: was formed in 1833 from Burke and Buncombe Counties. Located in the W section of the state, it is bounded by the state of Tennessee and by Mitchell, McDowell, Buncombe, and Madison Counties. It was named for Bartlett Yancey (1785-1828), member of the General Assembly and Congress. Area: 311 sq. mi. County seat: Burnsville, with an elevation of 2,817 ft. Townships are Brush Creek, Burnsville, Cane River, Crabtree, Egypt, Green Mountain, Jacks Creek, Pensacola, Price Creek, Ramseytown, and South Toe. Produces corn, oats, poultry, dairy products, livestock, hogs, hosiery, carpets, lumber, hay, textiles, mica, feldspar, olivine, sand, and gravel.

label: Yancey Ridge
description: E Avery County.

label: Yanceyville
description: community and county seat in central Caswell County. Est. 1791 as Caswell Court House; name changed to Yanceyville in 1833 to honor Bartlett Yancey (1785-1828), congressman and presiding officer of the state senate. Inc. 1877; charter repealed 1915. Produces textiles and lumber. Alt. 619.

label: Yanceyville Township
description: central Caswell County.

label: Yanu Ridge
description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a short spur extending SE from Welch Ridge with its center near lat. 35°32' N., long. 83°34'40" W.

label: Yarbro
description: community in NE Caswell County. Named for Capt. Joseph Yarbrough, superintendent of ammunition manufacturing in Salisbury during the Civil War. A post office operated there, 1887-1904.

label: Yarnall Knob
description: S Watauga County N of Goldmine Branch. Alt. approx. 3,900.

label: Yates Cove
description: central Haywood County between Fincher Mountain and McElroy Cove.

label: Yates Mill Pond
description: See Lake Trojan.

label: Yates Mountain
description: W Wilkes County, extends from E to W between North and South Prongs Lewis Fork Creek.

label: Yates Top
description: S Cherokee County S of Shingle Top and between Cane, Martin, and Moccasin Creeks.

label: Yaupon Beach
description: town in SE Brunswick County. Inc. 1955. Named for a species of holly that grows in the area.

label: Yaupon Creek
description: a bay in E Pamlico County in the waters of Bay River.

label: Yawpim
description: appears on the Moseley map, 1733, as a community in E Pasquotank Precinct, now Camden County, on North River. The name survives elsewhere as Yeopim, which see.

label: Yeates Knob
description: See Big Butte.

label: Yeatesville
description: town in E Beaufort County on Pungo Creek. Inc. 1881, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Named for Jesse J. Yeates (1829-92), Confederate officer and member of Congress.

label: Yellow Bald
description: S Macon County between Hurricane Creek and Bearpen Creek.

label: Yellow Branch
description: rises in NE Swain County and flows SE into Raven Fork.

label: Yellow Buck Ridge
description: N Caldwell County. Named by Bryson Coffey for a large yellow buck that he killed there. Alt. approx. 1,500.

label: Yellow Creek
description: rises in NW Haywood County and flows SE into Big Creek.

label: Yellow Creek Gap
description: N Graham County between the headwaters of Yellow Creek and Tuskeegee Creek.

label: Yellow Creek Mountains
description: extend from Cheoah River in NW Graham County E along the course of Yellow Creek to the headwaters of Mountain Creek.

label: Yellow Creek Township
description: NW Graham County.

label: Yellow Face
description: peak in N Jackson County on Plott Balsams. Alt. 6,032.

label: Yellow Gap
description: NW Henderson County on the SE end of Laurel Mountain. Alt. approx. 3,202.

label: Yellow Hill
description: mountain in W Wilkes County between Lewis Fork Creek and North Prong Lewis Fork Creek. Alt. approx. 1,300.

label: Yellow Jacket Lake
description: S Wilkes County on Moravian Creek. Covers approx. 2 acres; max. depth 15 ft. Built by R. Don Laws and named for his newspaper, the Yellow Jacket, which was est. in Moravian Falls in 1895.

label: Yellow Mountain
description: on the Jackson-Macon county line. Alt. 5,145. Known by the Indians as Taloh-na or Da-loh-no-geh (yellow).

label: Yellow Mountains
description: See Unaka Mountains.

label: Yellow Patch Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows NW into Hemp Patch Branch.

label: Yellow Spot
description: mountain in N Mitchell County. Alt. 5,112.

label: Yellow Swamp
description: rises in S Wayne County and flows W into Thoroughfare Swamp.

label: Yellowcreek
description: community in N Graham County on Yellow Creek. Served by post office, 1878-1953. Alt. 1,800.

label: Yellowhammer Branch
description: rises in NW Graham County and flows E into Cheoah River.

label: Yellowhammer Gap
description: NW Graham County between Hangover Lead and Little Tennessee River.

label: Yellowstone Falls
description: the final of a series of three waterfalls on Yellowstone Prong, S Haywood County.

label: Yellowstone Prong
description: rises in S Haywood County on the S slope of Black Balsam Knob and flows E into East Fork Pigeon River. Named because of the yellow color of mosses growing on stones in the stream. Upper Falls, Second Falls, and Yellowstone Falls are located on the stream.

label: Yeopim
description: community in SW Perquimans County served by post office, 1884-88. Named for the Yeopim Indian tribe, which inhabited the region in the seventeenth century. Alt. 15.

label: Yeopim Creek
description: rises in S Perquimans County and flows SE into the mouth of Yeopim River. Appears as Clargeons Creek on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Yeopim River
description: rises in Bear Swamp on the Chowan-Perquimans county line and flows SE along the line into Albemarle Sound. Named for the Yeopim Indian tribe. Appears on the Comberford map, 1657, at the location of present Little River on the Pasquotank-Perquimans county line, an error that was corrected on the Ogilby map, 1671. Appears as Yeopim Creek on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Yeopim Township
description: former township in SE Chowan County, now township no. 4.

label: Yerger
description: community in N central Watauga County served by post office, 1892-1905.

label: Yesocking Creek
description: See Wyesocking Bay.

label: Yoder
description: community in W Catawba County served by post office, 1894-1903.

label: Yokley
description: community in N Davidson County served by post office, 1880-1905.

label: Yonah-wayah
description: See Hanging Rock.

label: Yorick
description: community in central Bladen County served by post office, 1902-20.

label: York
description: former community in NW Warren County. A post office was est. there in 1902 but discontinued in 1905.

label: York Collegiate Institute
description: community in N Alexander County served by post office, 1855-1908.

label: York County
description: On December 7, 1771, in the General Assembly, a bill for dividing the W part of Rowan County and erecting York County and St. James Parish was read for the second time and passed. Rejected on December 10 by the Council. Iredell County, which see, was created from W Rowan County in 1788. St. James Episcopal Church, in the S part of Iredell County, was est. about 1800.

label: York Creek
description: rises in SW Carteret County and flows W into White Oak River.

label: York Institute
description: See York Collegiate Institute.

label: Yorkville
description: community in NW Bladen County served by post office, 1869-89.

label: Yost
description: community in S Rowan County served by post office, 1888-1906.

label: Younce Creek
description: rises in N Macon County and flows SE into Burningtown Creek.

label: Young Cove
description: E Macon County on a tributary of Watauga Creek.

label: Young Cove
description: at the head of Young Cove Creek in E Mitchell County.

label: Young Cove Creek
description: rises in E Mitchell County and flows SW into Cane Creek.

label: Young Gap
description: on the NE end of Burney Mountain on the Buncombe-Henderson county line.

label: Young Mountain
description: W Rowan County between Third and Withrow Creeks. Alt. 1,092.

label: Young Pisgah Mountain
description: SW Buncombe County between Hogpen Gap and Berrys Gap. Alt. 4,017.

label: Young's Store
description: See Oak Hill.

label: Youngs
description: community in central Davidson County served by post office, 1900-1903.

label: Youngs Creek
description: rises in NW Rutherford County and flows E into Cedar Creek.

label: Youngs Cross Roads
description: See Maysville.

label: Youngs Island
description: a loam island approx. 2 mi. long and ¾ mi. wide, in Pee Dee River, N Anson County.

label: Youngs Mountain
description: NW Rutherford County, extends NE parallel to Buffalo Creek. Alt. approx. 2,700.

label: Youngs Springs
description: community in SE Rockingham County; once a favorite rest area for liquid refreshment during horse-and-buggy days. Named for spring owner Robert Young.

label: Youngs Swamp
description: rises in NE Sampson County and flows NE into Goshen Swamp.

label: Youngsville
description: town in W Franklin County. Railroad name was Youngville. Alt. 449. Settled about 1839 and first known as Pacific. Inc. 1875. Named for John Young, local landowner. Produces apparel and furniture.

label: Youngsville Township
description: former township in SW Franklin County, now township no. 3. Earlier called Freemans Township.

label: Youngville
description: See Youngsville.

label: Yuma
description: See Deep Gap.

label: Zachary's
description: community in S Transylvania County near Rosman.

label: Zacho
description: community in SE Granville County served by post office, 1892-1903.

label: Zacks Fork Creek
description: rises in NE Caldwell County and flows SW approx. 10 mi. into Lower Creek.

label: Zade Knob
description: N Madison County between Bull Creek Gap and Arington Branch.

label: Zara
description: community in SE Bladen County served by post office, 1901-20.

label: Zeb
description: community in E Rowan County served by post office, 1884-1903. Named for Zebulon B. Vance, Civil War governor and later U.S. senator.

label: Zebra
description: community in N Wilkes County near East Prong Roaring River.

label: Zebulon
description: town in E Wake County. Inc. 1907. Named for Zebulon B. Vance (1830-94), governor of North Carolina and U.S. senator. Produces apparel and lumber products. Alt. 323.

label: Zeke Island
description: sandy island in the Cape Fear River opposite Snow Marsh in SE Brunswick County.

label: Zephyr
description: community in W Surry County between Mitchell River and Little Creek. Served by post office, 1900-1909.

label: Ziglar's Store
description: See Shelton's Store.
